title: Soviet Trotter Last Again Despite New Shoes
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 31 The Soviet mystery horse, Othello, wore a bright hood, a contraption to keep him from seeing shadows, and a new pair of shoes tonight. And again he finished last.

title: Alcoa Sets Up Japan Unit
description: The Aluminum Company of America said yesterday that it had formed a new subsidiary in Japan to be known as Alcoa Japan, Ltd. The company will import and market Alcoa products and administer Alcoa's Japanese investments in Japan. Wilson K. Ray, Alcoa's manager for international marketing, has been named president of the company.

title: Newsmen and Officials Targets of Wiretapping
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31Following are the names four newsmen and 13 Government officials whose telephones were tapped by the Nixon Administration various times and for varying periods between May, 1969, and February, 1971, and their affiliations at the time they were tapped:

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The cockroach, as every urban apartment dweller supposes, is an entomological terrorist. He is dirty. He makes one itch. He does not smell nice. He is not a nice bug, say, like the ladybug.

title: Business Briefs
description: ROME, Aug. 31The world's major wheat exporting nations will meet here on Sept. 20 to discuss the current world shortage of cereals, the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization announced today.

title: Spot Index of Commodities Shows a Decline for Week
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 205.1 from 209.5 last week.

title: First American in Japan's AllGirl Show
description: TAKARAZUKA, JapanHer 5 feet 8 inches may not make Margaret Akita look especially tall among her fellow American women. But in the dollland of Japan, her height is an asset in her ambition to play a coveted male role on the huge, 366by72footdeep stage of the Takarazuka Grand Theater here.

title: EXMARINE HELD FOR MENTAL TESTS
description: A former marine whose 1968 conviction on a charge of rape while on duty in Okinawa was overturned because of new evidence was held for mental observation yesterday following his arrest in Brooklyn on charges of attempting to kill a policeman.

title: The Long March
description: The end of a decade since the 1963 civil rights march on Washington is an appropriate time to assess the movement's triumphs and disappointments. How much closer have America's black citizens come to the fulfillment of Dr. Martin Luther King's dream of a nation committed to greater social justice?

title: NIXON RETURNING FROM THE COAST FOR AGNEW TALK
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif., Aug. 31President Nixon will meet with Vice President Agnew in Washington tomorrow to discuss the continuing Federal investigation into possible criminal violations involving Mr. Agnew's finances.

title: Baker Asserts Panel Will Hear Of Illegal Acts by Democrats
description: JACKSON, Tenn., Aug. 31Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., Republican of Tennessee, said today that the second phase of the Senate Watergate hearings would produce testimony on illegal, unethical, and undesirable campaign practices by Democrats in the 1972 Presidential campaign.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Aug. 31Although baseball and hockey continue to dominate the headlines, one part of the hockey season ended today in Essex County.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Aug. 31 (UPI)The New England Patriots said today they had hired additional security guards for their Sunday night National Football League preseason game with Washington because of past crowd disturbances involving a Redskin running back, Duane Thomas. Two weeks ago at Buffalo, fans hurled verbal abuses at Thomas and later threw objects at him on the bench. Thomas was restrained by teammates when he tried to climb into the stands after a fan. Chuck Fairbanks [Patriots' coach and general manager] and Peter Hadhazy [assistant general manager] want to assure that what happened in Buffalo won't happen here, said Pat Horne, the New England public relations director.

title: For 3 Days, 500 in Elmhurst Building Had No Utilities
description: More than 500 tenants of a modern, 10story apartment building in Elmhurst, Queens, spent three days without electricity and water until last night, when Consolidated Edison reported that power had been restored as of o'clock.

title: St. John's Hospital Boat Sails Off Into Sunset
description: The Lloyd I. Seaman, an engineless vessel that has served for the last 38 years as the St. John's Guild Floating Hospital, carrying poor children on harbor outings on which they and their parents are offered health and social services, made her last voyage yesterday.

title: Quarry Wins by Knockout
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 31 (AP)Jerry Quarry moved closer to another title bout with a secondround knockout of James J. Woody in a scheduled 10round heavyweight fight at the Las Vegas Convention Center tonight.

title: Foreman Stops Roman in 1st To Keep Heavyweight Crown
description: TOKYO, Saturday, Sept. 1 George Foreman, defending his world heavyweight boxMg championship for the first time, demolished Joe King Roman of Puerto Rico with a flurry of heavy blows and knocked him out with a right uppercut at 2 minutes of the first round today.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SUNDAY MORNING Chinatown of a Sunday morning before 9 o'clock is a neighborhood with far more visible charm than the raucous, tacky orientalia one sees during evening dinner excursions. It is on Sunday morning that the food markets are at their choicest, with dew still clinging to the bok choy, the snow peas and the bean sprouts fresh from the New Jersey Chinese truck farms.

title: Voluntary Overtime Puts Snag in Auto Negotiations
description: DETROIT, Aug. 31  After six weeks of talks and 14 days before a possible strike deadline, negotiations over a new contract between the United Automobile Workers and the Chrysler Corporation appeared today to have hit their first major snag  voluntary overtime.

title: Books of The Times
description: G. K. CHESTERTON. By Dudley Barker. 304 pp. Stein & Day. $8.95.Who reads G. K. Chesterton any more? Perhaps the Autobiography, the Father Brown detective stories; maybe The Man Who Was Thursday and his religious writings, notably Orthodoxy. At my neighborhood religious bookshop (which I do not visit religiously) I found exactly three titles by a man whose writing was so prodigious that even his official bibliographer had to despair of ever listing it all. Perhaps his monument is patinaed with obsolescence now, spattered with the pigeon droppings of indifference. But his critical biographiesnotably of Dickens and Robert Louis Stevenson  surely still stand. One might expect him to be buoyed back into favor on the cur gious revivalism among the young; but its preliterate aspects do not favor Chesterton, a most literate man. Glossolalia was not his bag: his best writings are aglimmer with paradox and aphorism and wit; his prose rings in the air like Chinese wind chimes. He was conservative and orthodox but certainly not a Biblethumping Fundamentalist. Indeed, in Orthodoxy he confesses that what brought him to religion was not pious writings but rather the effusions of such skeptics as Darwin, Spencer, Nietzche, Shaw et al.

title: Green's 63 Leads by 2 Strokes
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Aug. 31It was a hot day and Hubert Green's putter was blazing as he took the firstround lead of the $200,000 Sammy Davis Jr.Greater Hartford open with an eightunderpar 63.

title: Giants Seek Fifth in Row Today Against the Eagles
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 31 The New York Giants can size up a regularseason opponent for the first time tomorrow afternoon at 2 o'clock when they face the Philadelphia Eagles at Palmer Stadium.

title: Losers Get 2d Try at Swim Meet
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 31  One year after Mark Spitz and Shane Gould, worldclass swimmers will have a second chance at the first world aquatic championships.

title: Family Planning in China
description: PEKING  In China today family planning is an invisible but relentless and most efficient movement, with its own personnel, committees at every level, from the small production team and its grassroots cadres, through the Ministry of Health family planning council.

title: Dance: Fluent Frippery by Harknes
description: LEE, Mass., Aug. 30The Harkness Ballet dancers are such a nicelooking bunch that one constantly wonders how they would appear in a really substantial ballet instead of the fluent frippery they usually perrorm. These wayward thoughts were provoked by their joint program with the American Ballet Theater stars Eleanor D'Antuono and Ivan Nagy at Jacob's Pillow on Wednesday night.

title: Another in the 'Slaughter' Series:The Cast
description: "Slaughter's Big Ripoff" belongs to the class of movie that seems to offer itself for judgment in terms of body count, quarts of gore expended, variety of weaponry, number of panes of glass shattered, excellence in portrayal of death throes and destruction of automobiles.It tempts the viewer to subtract points for a flaccid thigh on a bikinied extra in the background or a bald tread on the tire of a car sinking under water after hurtling off a cliff with the hero and his girl inside.For what counts is the surface of things and by no means their substance. On the level of relationship to reality, inner logic, nuance of character and even sufficient morality to distinguish the good guys from the bad (except in the realm of drugs, which Jim Brown, as Slaughter, deftly spurns) such movies as these make no pretense toward achievement.But even within its own terms, as latter-day cinema of sheer entertainment concocted out of conspicuous violence, facile sex, with-it locales and a theme of vengeance pitting a loner against the mob and crooked cops, "Slaughter's Big Ripoff" must be adjudged third-rate.It has the conceit to virtually ignore its hero's pastsomething of an affront to those who did not see "Slaughter," the first in what promises to be a series of these filmsand the willingness to sacrifice its pacing to a long, aimless scene of Jim Brown's driving through the night while the mandatory rock tune performed by the singer James Brown takes over.As the story of how Slaughter wreaks vengeance on Duncan (Ed McMahon), the mob boss whose killer missed Slaughter while doing in some of Slaughter's friends, "Slaughter's Big Ripoff" falls short of inventiveness of plot and originality of style, but Richard Williams, as a pimp named Joe Creole, does seem to be having himself a good time."Slaughter's Big Ripoff" opened yesterday at the Cinerama and 86th Street Twin II theaters.

title: Strike Threat at Western
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) Alleging that contract negotiations are deadlocked, pilots for Western Airlines threatened today to strike Sept. 6 unless a settlement is reached. The airlines 1,308 pilots said no progress had been made on gut issues since contract talks began nearly nine months ago.

title: 4 Indicted in Shakedown of Music Stars
description: The manager of a major concert hall in Mobile, Ala., has been indicted along with a pharmacist, a nightclub operator and a disk jockey on charges of attempting to shake down some of the biggest soulmusic performers in the country, including Isaac Hayes, the Jackson Five, James Brown and Al Green.

title: Amin Tells Nixon He Doesn't Deserve Nobel
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Aug. 31 (UPI)President Idi Amin congratulated President Nixon today on his nomination for the Nobel Peace Prize, but said he believed that Mr. Nixon was nominated merely to help you recover from your worries of the Watergate affair, the Uganda radio reported.

title: Shore Hotel Operators See Heat as a Blessing
description: SPRING LAKE, Aug. 31 Heat waves traditionally bring a jolly jingle to hotel and restaurant cash registers along the Jersey shore, and the sizzling temperatures of the last few days are doubly welcome because they may help to salvage a season that up to now has been only soso.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 31 (AP)Jim Dietz of the New York Athletic Club finished third in his heat today and qualified for the semifinals in the single sculls at the European men's rowing championships. Dietz was timed in 7 minutes 41.53 seconds in a heat won by Sean Drea of Ireland in 7:26.80.

title: Horses Prance to Strains Of a ShirtSleeved Bugler
description: There was something missing just before the first race at Belmont Park yesterday, but nobody could quite figure out what it was. Then it slowly dawned that Sam Koza was not wearing his scarlet coat.

title: Books of The Times
description: G. K. CHESTERTON. By Dudley Barker. 304 pp. Stein & Day. $8.95.

title: Sky Surfing, an Ancient Dream, on Rise in U.S.
description: TORRANCE, Calif., Aug. 31Leonardo da Vinci dreamed of it. Icarus failed at it. The Wright brothers toyed with it, but cast it aside for engine power. Surely every youngster tried it.

title: Star of Zabriskie Point Jailed in Bank Robbery
description: BOSTON, Aug. 31 (AP) The young star of the movie Zabriskie Point was being held in Suffolk County Jail today on bank robbery charges.

title: A HOT CITY FACING MORE OF THE SAME
description: The unrelenting heat wave and its attendant technological discomforts  voltage reductions and slack water pressure made life difficult in the city again yesterday.

title: Waldheim Arrives in Cairo After Talks With Israelis
description: CAIRO, Aug. 31 (AP)Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations arrived in Cairo today for talks with Egyptian officials on ways to settle the Middle East conflict.

title: Senate Unit Studies Agnew Case For Possible Link to Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31Samuel Dash, the chief counsel to the Senate Watergate committee, disclosed today that committee staff members were in touch with the Justice Department to determine whether kickback allegations involving Vice President Agnew fell within the scope of the committee's investigation.

title: Excerpts From Chou's Report to 10th Congress of the Chinese Communist Party
description: Following are excerpts from Premier Chou Enlai's report to the 10th national Congress of the Chinese Communist party, delivered on Aug. 24 and adopted on Aug. 28, as distributed in English by Hsinhua, the official Chinese press agency:

title: Atlantic City's Mayor Hails New Indictments by State
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 31Mayor Joseph F. Bradway Jr. left last night to spend the Labor Day weekend in Florida, but before he left he said the indictment of 32 policemen and, city officials on corruption charges was a step in the right direction.

title: JAPANESE MOVE TO CUT INFLATION
description: TOKYO, Aug. 31 (Reuters)Japan today adopted a, series of measures to hold down total demand for goods and services and curb a sharp upturn in prices.

title: We Are Already Your Children
description: Our time has been labeled the century of the common man, the era in which America seeks to fulfill the democratic ideal by securing the rights of each individual citizen to realize his or her own potential through equality of opportunity and protection from discrimination. For many decades, newcomers to our shores sought to erase their linguistic, cultural and even religious differences, and to assimilate themselves and their children into a younger, more vital society. The dream of a melting pot in which minority groups sacrificed their heritage to become American seemed to be working until midcentury.

title: Trial of Suspect in Bombing At Wisconsin Set for Oct 15
description: MADISON, Wis., Aug. 31The trial of Karleton Armstrong on charges of murder and arson in connection with the 1970 bombing at the University of Wisconsin has been scheduled for Oct. 15 by Dane County Circuit Judge William Sachtjen.

title: Charles Chostner Marboe Weds Barbara Hewson in Bay State
description: NANTUCKET, Mass., Aug. 31In the Old North Vestry of the First Congregational Church here this afternoon, Miss Barbara Campbell Hewson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Beresford Hewson of Nantucket and Chester, N. J., became the bride of Charles Chostner Marboe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Fenton Marboe of State College, Pa.

title: Festival Time Arrives in Stonington, Which Means Her Loaves Are Ready
description: STONINGTON, Conn.Mary Gracia's home in this picturesque fishing village is often fragrant with the aroma of Portuguese sweet bread rising and baking. There is even more rising and more baking going on there than usual these days.

title: Basketball Transactions
description: AMERICAN ASSOCIATION

title: FUTURES IN CORN AND WHEAT BID UP
description: Grain traders cast off their traditional preholiday caution yesterday and bid up most wheat and corn futures prices on Midwest exchanges. But soybean prices sagged as more supplies appeared.

title: Mishaps Balk Move to Raise Sub With 2 Men Off Cork
description: CORK, Ireland, Aug. 31Attempts to rescue two men trapped in a midget submarine on the bottom of the Atlantic ran into a hitch tonight, but the submariners were described as very fit and in great spirits.

title: Bridge:
description: Opportunities are rare indeed for what might be called The Idiot Discard. If you suddenly throw away a valuable honor in a suit held in strength by the declarer, the idea is to alert your partner. The message conveyed is: I fear you are about to do the wrong thing, so please wake up and do the right thing.

title: The Opera
description: The three leading soprano roles in Les Contes d'Hoffmann are sometimes taken by one exceptionally versatile singer, Joan Sutherland and Beverly Sills being current exemplars of the tradition. The New York City Opera's production of the Offenbach work, which received its first performance of the newly spawned season on Thursday night, did not offer such triple employment to anyone, but Johanna Meier came close. She passed up the comedy coloratura part of Olympia in favor of Ruth Welting, but took on the two others.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: A Student, 17, Dies After He Collapses At a Football Drill
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 31A 17yearold student who was to have begun his junior year next week at Brentwood High School died yesterday at Southside Hospital in Bay Shore after having collapsed during a preseason football practice session.

title: 6 in Family Die in Fire
description: HANOVER, Pa. Aug. 31 (UPI) Six members of a family died today in a fire that destroyed their small, frame bungalow. The victims were identified as Joyce McWilliams, 32 years old, of nearby Penn Township, and her childrenSterling Jr., 14, (Phillip, 12, Linda, 11, Lisa, 10, land Theresa, 9.

title: Jets Game Tonight Affects Team Cuts
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 31Decisions, decisions, decisions.

title: New Way to Report Child Abuse Starts In the State Today
description: ALBANY, Aug. 31 (AP)A new roundtheclock, statewide reporting system for child abuse and neglect begins operation tomorrow.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Amendments Delay Ottawa Action on Rail Strike
description: OTTAWA, Saturday, Sept. 1 The Canadian House of Commons, sounding at times like a labor contractnegotiating team, conducted a rambling debate into the early morning tours today on legislation timed at ending the eightday strike that has halted virtually every train in the country.

title: Rockwell in Japanese Tie
description: The Rockwell International Corporation said yesterday that it had formed a jointventure company in Japan with NHK Spring Company, Ltd., of Yokohama, to market Rockwell's remote controls in the Far East. The new company was named NHKTeleflexMorse, Ltd., and will have its headquarters in the Tokyo area.

title: 8 Acquitted in Gainesville Of G.O.P. Convention Plot
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Aug 31 Seven antiwar veterans and a is supporter were acquitted today of charges that they plotted an assault with automatic weapons, slingshots and crossbows on the Republican National Convention.

title: AIRPORT XRAY BAN. IS URGED BY NADER
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) Ralph Nader urged the Government today to ban baggagescanning Xray machines at airports until officials make sure no radiation is reaching passengers or workers.

title: Catholic Schools Cutting Back As $ 19.5Million State Aid Ends
description: NEWARK. Aug. 31  Reduced enrollment, fewer schools and slimmer budgets are the outlook for the four Roman Catholic dioceses in New Jersey as they prepare to open their parochial schools next Wednesday.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The General Electric Company received $45.4million in military contracts, it was announced yesterday. These include a $30.2million addition to an Air Force award for jet aicraft engines, $14.2.million for additional ship nuclear reactor components, and $1million for Army 20 mm. automatic cannons.

title: Pakistani Flood Refugees Stunned but Plan Return
description: KARACHI, Pakistan Aug. 31 The swollen waters of the Indus River surged toward the Arabian Sea today, leaving Pakistan stunned.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the author's suhjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Stamp Dealer Who Feared Theft Is Found Slain in Midtown Shop
description: The 77yearold proprietor of a rarestamp shop, who worried for years about being held up, was shot to death yesterday in an apparent robbery attempt.

title: A Farm Union Caravan Is Spreading Boycott
description: DELANO; Calif., Aug. 31 (UPI)A caravan of 350 members of the United Farm Workers Union left today to spread a boycott campaign against table grapes and lettuce to 63 cities in the United States and Canada.

title: Miss Jill Chamberlin Is Married
description: SARASOTA, Fla., Aug. 31 Miss Jill Chamberlin and Fred A. McCormack, both of Sarasota, were married here tonight at the home of Dr. and Mrs. B. Gresham Riley, friends of the couple. Dr. Riley is provost of New College in Sarasota.

title: HUGH BEACH DEAD; TEXACO GEOLOGIST
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Aug. 31  Hugh H. Beach, retired staff geologist of Texaco, Inc., died Tuesday at the age of 64.

title: China's Tough Meat
description: In words that have reverberated down the decades, Sun Yatsen complained a halfcentury ago that the Chinese people are the poorest and weakest nation in the world. ... Other men are the carving knife and serving dish; we are the fish and the meat. Premier Chou Enlai undoubtedly had that lamentation in mind when, in his political report to the Tenth Chinese Communist Party Congress last weekend, he declared proudly: China is an attractive piece of meat coveted by all. But this piece of meat is very tough, and for years no one has been able to bite into it.

title: Seoul Reported Mollifying Tokyo Over Kidnapping
description: TOKYO, Aug. 31The Japanese Ambassador to South Korea returned home suddenly tonight amid indications of a political settlement of the Kim Dae Jung kidnapping affair.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Harlem's Mount Morris Park was renamed Marcus Garvey Memorial Park yesterday in honor of one of the first black nationalist leaders. The park, on Fifth Avenue from 120th to 124th Street, contains a swimming pool complex, an amphitheater, a recreation and cultural center and other facilities. A City Council bill approving the name change was signed by Mayor Lindsay in July.

title: Key Con Ed Engineer
description: Consolidated Edison is making lots of electricity these days. But, as they say in Jackson Heights, Queens, all that power means very little if your lights and your airconditioner are out.

title: For 3 Days, 500 in Elmhurst Building Had No Utilities
description: More than 500 tenants of a modern, 10story apartment building in Elmhurst, Queens, spent three days without electricity and water until last night, when Consolidated Edison reported that power had been restored as of 7 o'clock.

title: The Adirondack Coloring Book
description: PLATTSBURGH, N. Y.This year's visitor to the Adirondacks might think all of its inhabitants were artists, house painters, or interior decorators. For during the summer of Watergate, wherever we gather; in the bars, the general stores, the gas stations, our talk is not of corruption or dirty tricks but of colors:

description: BASEBALL

title: John Ford, 78, Film Director Who Won 4 Oscars, ls Dead
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Aug. 31  John Ford, director of The Informer, Stagecoach, How Green Was My Valley, Grapes of Wrath and other awardwinning film classics, died today at the age of 78.

title: Loan to Singapore Set
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) The United States ExportImport Bank said today it would lend $642,600 to help Singapore purchase two electric arc furnaces and services from the Lectromelt Corporation of Pittsburgh. The borrower, National Iron and Steel Mills, Ltd., of Singapore, will pay $142,800 in cash and will be aided by Bank of America financing through another loan of $642,600.

title: BRANDT POSTPONES PRAGUE TREATY TRIP
description: BONN, Aug. 31 (Reuters)Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany said tonight that he had postponed his trip to Prague to sign a treaty establishing diplomatic relations with Czechoslovakia.

title: Naples Is Grim as Cholera Death Toll Mounts to 9
description: NAPLES, Italy, Aug. 31 This city took on an uncharacteristically grim appearance today after two more patients died of cholera.

title: Notes on People
description: The New York City Police Commissioner, Donald F. Cawley, complained that some recently released movies had incorrectly portrayed New York policemen as insensitive, incompetent, coarse and corrupt. The commissioner, speaking to a group of police recruits and their families, did not name the movies he had in mind, but said they disturb me because they do not reflect the type of police officer we have...

title: Treasury Bill Yields Rise at Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities. The auction was advanced from Monday because of the Labor Day holiday.

title: Postal Rate Rise Is Approved On Newspapers and Magazines
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31The Cost of Living Council today authorized the Postal Service to put into effect a deferred in crease in rates for newspapers and magazines, junk mail and books and records. In addition, the council approved pay increases for 700,000 postal employes.

title: The Score This Point In Time
description: President Nixon likes both H. R. Haldeman and John Ehrlichman. He does not like John Dean.

title: John Ford, the Movie Director Who Won 5 Oscars, Dies at 78
description: John Ford, one of the greatest directors the American motionpicture industry has produced, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Palm Desert, Calif. He was 78 years old.

title: Cruise Ships Reported Set To Resume Visits to China
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 31 (UPI)  Visits to China by foreign cruise ships will resume next month for the first time since 1949, travel industry sources said today.

title: Local Board and Police Set Strategy on School SitIn
description: Officials from Community School Board 18 in Brooklyn and the Police Department met yesterday to plan on what to do if parents who are occupying Public School 208 in the East Flatbush section do not leave the building by the time teachers and administrators report there next week as scheduled.

title: Hue Strives for Hope Amid All the Despair
description: HUE, South Vietnam, Aug. 23Hue, which has known so much war, is at peace for the moment. But people seem anxious, waiting for some resolution of their ambiguous, precarious situation.

title: Waiting
description: This article was written by a young woman living in Brooklyn. In the last month she has received telephone and mail threats on her life from an unknown person.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Rosalyn Drexler, playwright, novelist, painter and a former professional nestler, will now enter a new field when she makes her singing debut in The Peaches, an intimate revue to be given at Judson Garden, 239 Thompson Street, on Sept. 8 as a benefit for Judson Memorial Church.

title: Foreman Stops Roman in 1st To Keep. Heavyweight Crown
description: TOKYO, Saturday, Sept. 1 George Foreman, defending his world heavyweight boxMg championship for the first time, demolished Joe King Roman of Puerto Rico with a flurry of heavy blows and knocked him out with a right uppercut at 2 minutes of the first round today.

title: Bail of $50,000 Set in Drug Case For Village Man
description: Bail of $50,000 was set in Federal court here yesterday for a Greenwich Village magazine distributor who had been arrested on a charge of conspiracy to sell phendimetrazine pills, which narcotics agents described as illegal stimulants and that the suspect called vice spice aphrodisiacs.

title: Markets Closed Monday
description: Securities and commodities exchanges as well as banks in The United States and Canada will be closed Monday in obiervance of Labor Day. Most overseas exchanges and banks utli operate as usual.

title: A Program for Allocation Of Propane Gas Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) The White House proposed today a mandatory program to allocate scarce propane fuel supplies to make sure priority consumers' needs are filled first this winter.

title: Mother of Baby Needing Operation Defies Pleas to Give Her Up
description: A drugaddicted mother who took her twomonthold daughter from Lenox Hill Hospital late Tuesday before the child was to have had a hernia operation telephoned a social worker yesterday to say she would rather have the baby die than have anybody have it.

title: Split Regulation Is Sought On Municipal Bond Trades
description: Commercial banks that deal in municipal bonds disclosed yesterday how they would like to see this part of the securities industry regulated.

title: Miss Haynie Posts 68 to Lead Golf
description: Miss Haynie's 205yard shot from the fairway into the wind on the monster eighth hole trickled in for an eagle deuce.

title: CHOU SAYS SOVIET IS BIGGER THREAT THAN U.S. TO CHINA
description: PEKING, Aug. 31  Premier Chou Enlai has intensified China's denunciation of the Soviet Union, emphasizing that Peking regards the Kremlin as a greater threat than the United States.

title: Contract for Whoelabrator

title: Small Pause at a Cambodian Front Line
description: ON ROUTE 4, in Cambodia, Aug. 31Thirtyfour miles southwest of Phnom Penh, where Communist troops have closed the most important supply road in Cambodia, icecream venders on bicycles were selling their wares to relaxed Govermnent soldiers in easy rifle range of the enemy, today, and not a shot was audible anywhere.

title: If jeans Seem on Their Last Legs,. It's Only the Beginning  As Skirts
description: As anybody who owns a beloved old pair of blue jeans will tell you, you just don't throw them away when they're frayed and tattered. In fact, connoisseurs insist that denim, like wine, improves with age. Stores are selling worn jeans for higher prices than they do new ones, and some package sandpaper with new jeans so the purchaser can antique them.

description: The Shawmut Association, a Bostonbased bank holding company, and the Forth Worth National Corporation, a Texas bank holding company, have agreed to form the American Cattle and Crop Services Corporation as a joint venture.

title: Yankee Records
Giants Seek Fifth in Row Today Against the Eagles
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 31 The New York Giants can size up a regularseason opponent for the first time tomorrow afternoon at 2 o'clock when they face the Philadelphia Eagles at Palmer Stadium.

description: Two major makers of appliances and consumer electronic goods announced yesterday that they were asking higher prices for some of their products.

title: HeatImpelled, People Stream Out of City for Holiday
description: Tens of thousands of New Yorkers streamed out of the city yesterday in search of shade or sea breezes and a Labor Day weekend away from igneous streets, power problems and a town that has been hotter than Florida all week long.

title: U.S. TRADE MISSION WILL TRY TO WIDEN SOVIET RELATIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz will head a highlevel delegation to Moscow in October to discuss further steps toward widening trade relations between the Soviet Union and the United States, Administration officials said today.

title: CHANTING CROWDS MARCH FOR PERON
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 31Vast crowds of chanting workers and youths paraded past Juan D. Pern today as the 77yearold former President opened his new bid for the presidency.

Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Attack on Rome Raises a Storm of Protest by Danes
description: COPENHAGEN, Aug. 31A storm of protest has been generated here by the denunciation of the Roman Catholic Church by Niels Matthiasen, the Minister for Cultural Relations, who has called the church reactionary and has criticized the protest of Pope Paul VI against the financial support the Danish Government is providing for a film titled The Loves of Jesus Christ.

title: S.E.C. DECREE SIGNED IN WESTGATE CASE
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 31 (AP)M. J. Coen, longtime business associate of C. Arnholt Smith, has signed a consent decree in which he agreed not to violate securities laws in connection wits Mr. Smith's WestgateCalifornia Corporation.

title: New Problems on Taps
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31the disclosure that two White House officials without access to secret foreign policy information were the targets of wiretaps that President Nixon aid that he had authorized to protect national security seems certain to raise new legal and political problems for both Mr. Nixon and Henry A. Kissinger, his nominee for Secretary of State. Mr. Nixon has defended the wireaps, 17 in all, which were placed without court orders beween May, 1969, and February, 1971, as necessary to find and stop leaks to newsmen about highly sensitive foreign policy initiatives begun in the early days of his first Adminisration.

title: U.S. Court Refuses to Block $10Million L.I. Housing
description: The Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday declined to block construction of a $10million public housing project in the. Spinney Hill section of Manhasset, L. I. A suit against the project had been brought by the Great Neck Manor Civic Association, representing homeowners in a welltodo, predominantly black residential section adjoining the building site.

title: MOSQUITO WARNING ISSUED IN BAY STATE
description: BOSTON, Aug. 31 (AP)Residents of eastern Massachusetts were advised to wear long sleeved shirts and long pants despite hot weather as a precaution against diseasecarrying mosquitos as health officials continue to battle an outbreak of eastern equine encephalitis.

title: Larry Jones Waived
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Aug. 31 (UPI)  The San Antonio Spurs waived today Larry Jones, they greatest scorer in American Basketball Association history, through the league and declared him a free agent. Jones, 30 years old, had been with the A.B.A. since its inception, playing in 456 regularseason games and scoring 9,551 points. He averaged 21.1 points a game. He played for Miami, Utah, Denver and Dallas. He also played with Philadelphia of the National Association.

title: HEALTH COMPANY BUYS 3 CONCERNS
description: The acquisition of three medicalservice companies by the American Hospital Supply Corporation for nearly $28million in stock was reported yesterday by the healthcare products company

title: Hockey Transactions
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: ExFordham Head And Writer, 26, Wed In a Civil Ceremony
description: Dr. Leo McLaughlin, the 61yearold former president and chancellor of Fordham University and a Jesuit priest for 40 years, married a 26yearold writer from New York in a civil ceremony last June.

title: Acquittal in Gainesville
description: The swift acquittal by a Florida jury of the Gainesville 8, accused of conspiring to disrupt the Republican National Convention, is another deserved rebuke for the Administration in its effort to prosecute antiwar activists by infiltrating their ranks with undercover agents and provocateurs.

title: Caribbean and Congo Role Is Laid to C.I.A.'s Airline
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31Southern Air Transport, the charter airline owned by and operated largely for the Central Intelligence Agency, appears to have performed extensive paramilitary missions in the Congo and the Carribean in addition to Indochina, aviation officials said today.

title: Greece Prepares the Way For Fair Elections in '74
description: ATHENS, Aug. 31President George Papadopoulos has asked Spyros Markezinis, a historian and widely resoected political leader, to set up a Cabinet in October and hold fair elections next year, a highly qualified source reported today.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: Los AngelesRudy Robles, 164 pounds, Carson, Calif., knocked out Indian George Davis, 164, Oakland, Calif., 9 rounds; Rodolfo Gonzalez, 140, Long Beach, Calif., knocked out Donny Sennett, 139, Boston, 3.

title: Mrs. Joanne Field Wed To Edward F. Miller
description: PETERBOROUGH, N. H., Aug. 31Mrs. Joanne Field, a greatgreatgranddaughter of Marshall Field, the Chicago merchant, was married here this afternoon to Edward F. Miller, a vice president of Smith, Barney & Co., Inc., investment bankers and stockbrokers in New York. The ceremony in Union Congregational Church was performed by the Rev. Edward C. Dahl.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Union County prosecutor's narcotics strike force has arrested 35 persons in raids against alleged drug pushers, most of them in the Elizabeth area. The suspects were among 42 persons named Wednesday in sealed indictments turned over to Superior Court Judge John L. Ard.

title: Lord Renwick, Industrialist, 68; Began British Commercial TV
description: LONDON, Aug, 31  Lord Renwick, a business leader and a powerful influence on the Conservative party, died here yesterday. His age was 68.

title: ALMA LUTZ, LEADER IN WOMAN SUFFRAGE
description: BERLIN, N. Y., Aug. 31Alma Lutz, a leader in the fight for woman suffrage and equal rights and the author of several biographies, including one of Susan B. Anthony, died today at her home here. She was 83 years old.

title: 35 FIRES BATTLED IN NORTH CAMDEN
description: CAMDEN, Aug. 31Firemen extinguished blazes in 35 buildings early today and a police car was destroyed by a fire bomb in the second consecutive night of disturbances in the north Camden area.

title: Helicopters Aiding Villagers Isolated By Mexican Quake
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 31 (UPI) Food and other aid supplies were flown by helicopter today to Indian villages in the mountains of Veracruz State isolated by the earthquake of eanly Tuesday.

title: Meany Criticizes Tools of Repression
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) George Meany said today that Americans obeyed the law when they know that those entrusted with its enforcement likewise obey.

title: Sihanouk Plans Offensive In December With Hanoi Aid
description: PEKING, Aug. 31 (UPI)Prince Norodom Sihanouk today said that his Cambodian insurgents would open a fullscale attack on Phnom Penh in December with direct military support by North Vietnam.

title: Sense in the Council
description: The City Council has wisely decided to go back to the drawing board with its abominable second try at a plan for redistricting the Council, Instead of plowing ahead with its original apparent intention to override Mayor Lindsay's veto of a plan so inequitable that it could never have survived court review, the Council leadership has obtained extra time from the courts to draw up a fairer one.

title: Rate Down in Latest Sale Of British Treasury Bills
description: LONDON, Aug. 31 (Reuters) The average rate at today's tender of British Treasury bills fell today to 10.9744 per cent from 10.9754.

title: Beame and Colorful Entourage Return to Catskills to Campaign
description: LOCH SHELDRAKE, N. Y., Aug. 31Controller Abraham D. Beame gave this Catskills vacation area a demonstration of some bigcity campaigning today as he toured its resort hotels with a colorfully decorated bus and accompanied by women campaign aides in straw hats with red, white and blue streamers.

title: A HOT CITY FACING MORE OF THE SAME
description: The unrelenting heat wave and its attendant technological discomforts  voltage reductions and slack water pressure made life difficult in the city again yesterday.

title: Barclays Unit in Singapore
description: LONDON, Aug. 31 (Reuters) Barclays Bank International said today that its Singapore branch would open for business tomorrow. This is the first branch operation established in Singapore by a British clearing bank, Barclay said.

title: Repentance of Dissidents In Soviet May Ease Terms
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 31The prosecution in the widely publicized trial of two dissidents here asked for relatively moderate sentences today on the ground that they had turned state's evidence.

title: Soviet Tells Nonaligned Lands Communists Are Natural Allies
description: ALGIERS, Aug. 31Some 75 nonaligned nations, gathering here for their biggest conference to date, were assured by the Soviet Union today that the Communist countries were their natural allies.

title: White HouseBacked Form of Immunity Is a Key Weapon in the Agnew Inquiry
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 31  A new form of immunity, put into law largely through the efforts of the Nixon Administration to strengthen the hands of prosecutors, has been a key weapon of the Republican United States Attorney here to advance the inquiry now focusing on Vice President Agnew.

title: Losers Get 2d Try at Swim Meet
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 31  One year after Mark Spitz and Shane Gould, worldclass swimmers will have a second chance at the first world aquatic championships.

title: Gas Will Cost State 5c a Gallon More If U.S. Ends Curbs
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt said yesterday that the state government would have to pay 5 cents a gallon more for gasoline during the present fiscal year if the Federal Government did not extend price controls on petroleum products.

title: NIXON FLIES BACK FROM THE COAST FOR AGNEW TALK
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif., Saturday, Sept. 1 President Nixon will meet with Vice President Agnew in Washington later today to discuss the continuing Federal investigation into possible criminal violations involving Mr. Agnew's finances.

title: Tokyo to Ask Tariff End At GATT Trade Talks
description: TOKYO, Aug. 31  Senior Japanese officials said today that Japan would aim for the total elimination of tariffs on industrial goods in the new round of trade negotiations scheduled to begin here on Sept 12.

title: Antiques
description: The death this week of Leopold Blumka, the dean of Renaissance and medieval antiques dealers, brought rare rash of comments from museum officials, eager to spell out Mr. Blumka's contributions as an art merchant.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: 1 Pagliacci character

title: STEEL PRODUCERS NEED ON PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31A Cost of Living Council hearing panel cast a critical eye today on steel industry assertions that higher prices are needed now to assure expansion of United States steelmaking capacity throughout the nineteenseventies.

title: Condemning Sky Piracy
description: The International Civil Aviation Organization (I.C.A.O.), meeting in Rome, has now followed the lead of the United Nations Security Council in condemning Israel for intercepting an Arab airliner over Lebanon last month and forcing it to land at an Israeli airport. Both rebukes were eminently warranted, but neither will make any genuine contribution to eliminating aerial piracy until both international organizations give proof that they intend to apply a single standard of censure and punishment to acts of hijacking and terrorism, no matter who the perpetrator.

title: People and Business
description: Emmett G. Solomon, chairman and chief executive of San Francisco's Crocker National Bank, wants to retire next May. His president, Leslie C. Peacock, quit several weeks ago when he got the word that he would not be stepping up to the chairman's position.

title: People in Sports: Loop Suspends Billy Martin
description: Manager Billy Martin of the Detroit Tigers was suspended yesterday for three days for instructing his pitchers to throw illegal pitches against the Cleveland Indians on Thursday night.

title: A New SingleTube Color Camera Is Devised for TV
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31Renville H. McMann Jr., president of C.B.S, Laboratories, Stamford, Conn., was granted a patent this week for a singletube color camera that he regards as an important advance in television photography. Patent 3,755,620 is assigned to the news department, and hopes that the new one will be Columbia Broadcasting Systern. Mr. McMann is working on cameras for the C.B.S. ready at least by the Presidential year 1976.

title: Zambia Seeks More Control of Copper
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Aug. 31President Kenneth Kaunda said in a surprise news conference here today that his Government was taking immediate steps to gain firmer control of the country's vital copper industry from Western interests.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: Trial of Suspect in Bombing At Wisconsin Set for Oct. 15
description: MADISON, Wis., Aug. 31The trial of Karleton Armstrong on oharges of murder and arson in connection with the 1970 bombing at the University of Wisconsin has been scheduled for Oct. 15 by Dane County Circuit Judge William Sachtjen.

title: OFFICE IS CREATED FOR TIPS ON DRUGS
description: The state will open a special office in Albany Tuesday to receive information on drug trafficking. Persons who provide such information may qualify for $1,000 rewards.

title: Campbell and Giles Gain in U.S. Amateur
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 31 (AP)Bill Cambell, Marvin (Vinny) Giles, the defending champion, and Dick Siderowf, the British Amateur champion, scored double victories today to reach the quarterfinals of the 73d United States Amateur golf championship, over the 6,816yard, par71 Inverness Club course.

title: CHOU SAYS SOVIET IS BIGGER THREAT THAN U.S. TO CHINA
description: PEKING, Aug. 31  Premier Chou Enlai has intensified China's denunciation of the Soviet Union, emphasizing that Peking regards the Kremlin as a greater threat than the United States.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 1, 1973

title: Nastase and Riessen Lose in U.S. Tennis
description: It took less than 10 minutes and only a few hundred persons were watching. But the result  the defeat of Ilie Nastase, the defending champion, by Andrew Pattison of Rhodesiaproved to be the shocker of the United States Open tennis championships yesterday at Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Government officials and media commentators have been bothered by the apparent conflict between the favorable world markets for U.S. agricultural products and the rising domestic food prices. There is a solution to this conflictexport taxation. This device provides high export returns (and Government revenue) while simultaneously preventing domestic prices from rising. It is preferable to the sudden bans on exports recently imposed by the U.S. Government. Such bans are the equivalent of infinite export taxes, are disruptive to orderly world trade and are not sustainable.

title: Alterations Alleged In Nixon Home Data
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31The chairman of a Congressional panel investigating public spending on President Nixon's private homes said today that some documents pertaining to Mr. Nixon's property at San Clemente, Calif., released earlier this week by the White House, had been altered previously.

title: OUTPUT OF CARS UP BY 40,000 IN WEEK
description: DETROIT, Aug. 31 (AP)As labor contract negotiations continued this week, auto production surged ahead by almost 40,000, according to Automotive News.

title: 12 INDIAN LEADERS SEIZED IN DAKOTA
description: WINNER, S. D., Aug. 31Two leaders of the American Indian Movement were arrested here late last night on charges stemming from a state grand jury investigation into disorders in the town of Custer last Feb. 6 in which four town buildings were burned and several Indians and whites were injured.

title: New Doggy Box a Hit With Children Here
description: Manhattan's first doggy box  an outdoor restroom equipped with a toy fire hydrantwas opened yesterday on the sidewalk of East 63d Street near York Avenue. Immediately a major problem developed: children.

title: Skylab Crew Keeps Watch On Storm in the Caribbean
description: HOUSTON, Aug 31 (UPI) The Skylab 2 astronauts kept an eye on the tropical storm known as Christine today and the crew's scientist took a turn as pilot.

title: Fannin Serves Day in Jail
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Aug. 31 (UPI)Senator Paul Fannin, Republican of Arizona, served a mandatory oneday jail sentence for drunk driving today. Sheriff's deputies said the Senator had been in a special cell reserxed for persons who must serve the oneday jail terms for drunk driving. Mr. Fannin had refused to disclose in advance when he would serve the oneday sentence. The Senator was also fined $110.

title: Shark Reports Force Bathers Out of Water
description: POINT PLEASANT BEACH, Aug. 31 (UPI)  At least 11 sharks were sighted offshore along Long Beach Island today, the state marine police said.

title: Screen: A Vampire's Progeny in Japan:' Lake of Dracula' Has Western-Style Props The Cast Directed by Yamamoto-Opens at Elgin
description: Do you want to know how vampires came to Japan?The historians of the Toho Company explain it: "Since even vampires, when not working at sucking blood, probably enjoy sexual activity, they doubtless foster offspring, albeit illegitimate ones. Dracula himself would have been no exception. It was thus during the early years of this century that one of Dracula's bastard sons made his way to Japan, liked it, settled down."He settled into a tatty old Transylvanian castle smack in the middle of modern Japan, near a lake called Fujimi, which is the Lake of Dracula, which is the title of a new movie directed by Michio Yamamoto and released by Toho. It opened yesterday at the Elgin.If the idea of a Japanese vampire movie seems intriguing, "Lake of Dracula" leaves that idea all but untouched. The actors are Japanese, but the clothes, the conventions, the architecture  especially the architecture  are all carried over from the West. I've never seen such a movie for creaking doors, footsteps on the stairs and all the other paraphernalia that have so much to do with shock and so little to do with the deeper and more delightful forms of terror.Dracula himselfactually the great-grandson of Dracula, victim of some particularly goofy sort of curse that produces vampires only every third generationis almost pure animal. He doesn't seduce; he growls. His eyes light up like bicycle reflectors  which I think they possibly are.Akiko (Midori Fujita), the girl he wants to get his teeth into, is at the same time chased by the vampire and accused of paranoia by her fianc (Choei Takahashi), a young physician who reduces every fear to Freud.Between the predator and his prey there stands nothing much except some tangled forest, a thunderstorm and the previously mentioned doors and stairways. It is as if the whole mystique of repulsive attraction were being reduced to a collection of studio props. After "Jonathan" and "Vampir," and even the "Count Yorga" movies and "Blacula," we vampire lovers are used to something better.

title: WINE TALK
description: A great deal has been written about wine tastings but still people write and ask: How do I give a wine tasting?

title: Daughter of Time Reporter Drowns Off Malaysia Coast
description: SINGAPORE, Aug. 31 Lisle Scott, 15yearold daughter of the chief Time magazine correspondent in Saigon, drowned Wednesday at an island off the east coast of Malaysia.

description: ACROSS

title: Dow Index Climbs by 5.04 As Volume Remains Light
description: The stock market said goodbye to the summer holidays yesterday with a late rally that sent profit takers to the beaches early for the long Labor Day weekend. Volume was light but increased in pace as prices advanced.

title: Colm Wins in Golf
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Aug. 31 (AP)  W. F. Colm of Pebble Beach, Calif., defeated Truman Connoll of Pompano Beach, Fla., today to win the world seniors golf championship, 3 and 2.

title: Antiques
description: The death this week of Leopold Blumka, the dean of Renaissance and medieval antiques dealers, brought a rare rash of comments from museum officials, eager to spell out Mr. Blumka's contributions as an art merchant.

title: New Attach Submarine Is Named for the City
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI)Navy Secretary John W. Warner announced today the selection of the name New York City for one of the Navy's new nuclearpowered attack submarines.

title: Leaning Contest Scheduled
description: PAYSON, Utah, Aug. 31 (UPI) Townfolk sized up trees in the city park today in preparation for what has been billed as the world's first leaning contest. Contestants will test their skill and endurance in leaning on the trees surrounding the park bandstand tomorrow morning. The winner will receive a $25 cash prize and a free visit to the chiropractor of his choice.

description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: DYNAMICS MEETING PUT OFF TILL DEC. 14
description: The Dynamics Corporation of America, operating under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act since Aug. 2, 1972, again postponed its annual stockholder meeting, this time to Dec. 14. Earlier the company postponed the normal May date to Sept. 14.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Stocks on the American Stock Exchange rose yesterday on tight trading in a technical rally before the threeday weekend. prices also rose in the overthecounter market in decreased trading.

title: Danger From Fire Rises As Water Pressure Dips
description: A water emergency was dedared in the city for the second successive day yesterday as illegally opened fire hydrants in the city and allnight lawn watering continued to drop waterpressure levels.

title: Church Council Feels Burdens of Success
description: GENEVA, Aug. 30  While the World Council of Churches was being founded in Amsterdam in August, 1948, T. B. Simatupang was in Java directing guerrillas who were soon to drive the Dutch colonial forces out of Indonesia.

description: State Controller Arthur Levitt said yesterday that the state government would have to pay 5 cents a gallon more for gasoline during the present fiscal year if the Federal Government did not extend price controls on petroleum products.

title: A Champion of Roaches Opens Exhibition Here
description: The cockroach, as every urban apartment dweller supposes, is an entomological terrorist. He is dirty. He makes one itch. He does not smell nice. He is not a nice bug, say, like a ladybug.

title: STAFF WILL TALK TO MRS. MITCHELL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Samuel Dash, the chief counsel for the Senate Watergate committee, said tonight that the committee staff planned to hold a discreet interview with Mrs. John N. Mitchell about her recent statements regarding a campaign strategy book that may have described Watergatestyle operations.

title: Joseph Durso
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 31Yogi Berra was back home today, not far from the corner lots where he learned to hit a baseball, surveying the crazy situation from the 14th floor of a circular hotel on the riverfront. On one side, the Mississippi and the vaulting arch that curves like a giant croquet wicket on its banks; on the other side, Busch Memorial Stadium. But wherever he looked, the master of the New York Mets had an exceptional view of the strange world known as the Eastern Division of the National League of Professional Baseball Clubs.

title: Consumer Notes
Roundup: Pirates, Refusing to Concede, Conquer Cubs Twice
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates, especially Willie Stargell, are not conceding the National League's Eastern Division pennant. They emphasized that last night in Three Rivers Stadium by sweeping a doubleheader from the Chicago Cubs, 70 and 52.

title: U.S. TRADE MISSION WILL TRY TO WIDEN SOVIET RELATIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz will head a highlevel delegation to Moscow in October to discuss further steps toward widening trade relations between the Soviet Union and the United States, Administration officials said today.

title: FRED WEBER DIES; A BROADCASTER, 67
description: MARGATE, N.J., Aug. 31Fred Weber, an early broadbaster and one of the principal architects of the Mutual Broadcasting System radio network, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home. He was 67 years old.

title: NIXON ASKS DELAY ON FEDERAL RAISE
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 31 (AP)  President Nixon asked Congress today to defer for 60 days a pending pay increase for Federal employes, declaring that it would needlessly fan the flames of inflation.

description: CORK, Ireland, Saturday, Sept. 1A fresh attempt to rescue two men trapped in a midget submarine on the Atlantic seabed for almost three days started early today.

description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 31 (AP)Fran Tarkenton, on the bench for almost three quarters, sparked the Minnesota Vikings to a 17point rally that led to the Miami Dolphins' first loss in a year, 2017, tonight, in a National Football League preseason game. The loss snapped Miami's unbeaten streak at 23 games.

title: WHEN HEAT RISES, CRIMES MAY NOT
description: I pray thee, good Mercutio, let's retire, Romeo's friend is advised.

title: Dollar Ends Week And Month Higher; Gold Price Slumps
description: LONDON, Aug. 31 (UPI)The United States dollar moved generally higher today, ending the week and the month on an upward trend. The price of gold again fell sharply.

title: 4 Children Die in Blaze
description: LORAIN, Ohio, Aug. 31 (AP) Four children were killed and three other persons were injured in a fire that destroyed their home early today, the authorities reported.

title: U.S. Road Safety Agency Moves to Close Loophole
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration moved today to close a regulatory loophole that exempts such vehicles as The Thing, a new Volkswagen product, from many safety standards.

title: Lions Beat Browns on Kick, 1613
description: CLEVELAND Sept. 1 (UPI) Errol Mann kicked a 21yard field goal with 15 seconds left tonight to give the Detroit Lions a 1613 victory over the Cleveland Browns in a preseason gaine.

description: TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 1 (AP)  Dave Strawn and Craig Stadler, two collegians playing for the first time in the United States Amateur Golf championship, stunned former champions Bill Campbell and Marvin (Vinny) Giles 3d in the semifinals today.

description: WASHINGTON  Memo to the University of Michigan Survey Research Center:

title: Tropical Storm Christine Reported Losing Strength
description: MIAMI, Sept. 1 (AP)Tropical storm Christine was reported losing strength today, and forecasters at the National Hurricane Center in Miami said Christine's highest sustained winds dropped from 60 to 50 miles an hour.

description: CHICAGO, Sept. 1The decline in many food prices that began this week was expected to continue until price ceilings come off beef Sept, 12.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 George Meany, in a wideranging preLabor Day commentary on the nation's problems, bitterly assailed President Nixon and his aides for seeking to pervert the nation's democratic structure and mismanaging its economy.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Recordings
description: A NEW Horowitz recording is an event, partly because Horowitz is Horowitz, one of the century's great virtuoso musicianpianists, and partly because it raises questions. Will there be any more records in the future now that his contract with Columbia is about to expire? Is this second selfimposed retirement (his last live concert appearance was in October, 1969) now to be a permanent one? We'll just have to wait and see.

title: Peregrine Falcons Gain, Thanks to Lab Breeding
description: ITHACA, N. Y.The peregrine falcon is on its way back to the Eastern United States via an apparently successful program to breed them in captivity.

title: Soviet Sentences 2
description: Two Soviet dissidents were sentenced in Moscow yesterday to three years of confinement followed by three years of enforced residence in a remote part of the country. Details appear on page 12.

title: Homes on Wheels Called Road Risk
description: KINGMAN, Ariz.On the long, lonely highways that slash across the Arizona desert, the automobile seems outnumbered much of the time these days by fleets of modem prairie schooners: pickup trucks with big, habitable superstructures, trailers bought by vacationing families to save motel bills, and huge, selfpropelled motorhomes complete with showers, color television sets and double beds.

title: Canada Acts on Strike
description: The Canadian Parliament enacted emergency legislation yesterday ordering an end to the nineday rail strike, and leaders representing most of the strikers agreed to return to work. Page 3.

title: Gerald Foster Weds Alessandra Brewer
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 1Miss Alessandra Brewer, daughter of Enzo Rangoni Lucci of New York and the late Mrs. James M. Cecil Jr., was married here this evening to Gerald Alvin John Foster, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Foster of Marshfield, Wis.

title: Americans and Thais Grow Crops for Export on the River Kwai
description: BAN KAENG, Thailand, Sept. 1 (UPI)A group of Americans and Thais have banded together to put quickfrozen specialty vegetables from the River Kwai on American tables.

title: The President, the Vice President and the Law That Ties Them
description: It is familiar ground in American history that issues of political power often become questions of law.

title: In Denville, Amateur Farmers
description: DENVILLE  This lake community has never been noted for its farms, but its farmers are becoming downright conspictkous.

title: Pamela Sue Protz Betrothed To Dr. James A. Whitaker 3d
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 1Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Protz of Garden City and Shelter Island, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Sue Protz, to Dr. James Allen Whitaker 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Whitaker 2d, of Rocky Mount, N. C. The wedding is planned for Oct. 6 at the Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation here.

title: Mailbox: Boxing Incident at the Maccabiah Games
description: To the Editor.

title: Improvements at Rome's Airport Lessen Congestion
description: ROME, Sept. 1Travelers arriving at the international airport here these days are agreeably surprised by the unexpected speed and ease with which they go through.

title: September
description: September is a month by the grace of the calendar, but almost a separate season by its own quality and disposition. It is a time of slow transition, neither altogether new nor familiarold, neither growth nor decline, neither summer nor fall. But a time of certainties, for all that.

title: Oilers Top Colts, 209, In 2d Half
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 1 (AP)Dan Pastorini, the quarterback, sparked Houston to two thirdquarter touchdowns and a running back, Bob Gresham, rushed for 153 yards to lead the Oilers to a 209 victory over the Biiltimore Colts tonight.

title: The Penny Postal Card's Centennial
description: THE centennial of the penny postal card is being observed this year, and the occasion is being marked by a new card that bears many resemblances to its forebear, but the price  6 cents  would shock its ancestor. After all, the penny card lasted from 1873 to 1952, except for a brief period in World War I.

title: Tennis at Forest Hills Has International Spice
description: Yellow tennis balls, sweltering fans, many of them shirtless, and a babel of foreign tongues mingling with Americanese  these were part of the scene last week at Forest Hills.

title: Suzanne H. Fisher Engaged to Marry
description: HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., Sept. 1Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Fisher have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Suzanne H. Fisher, to William Luntz, son of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Luntz of Canton, Ohio. An October wedding is planned.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR MARGARET CROYDEN (New Trends in Russia?, July 29) sometimes knows what she's writing about and sometimes doesn't. Rosamond Gilder may be venerable, but without her sterling efforts over the years, there wouldn't have been any I.T.I. Congress in Moscowor any I.T.I. As for our U.S. delegation (to which Miss Croyden tried like mad to be officially accredited), it may not have been worldshakingly youthful or farout but it was far from unrepresentative of either ferment or experiment. (If I were George White, I'd resent not being considered even a hint progressive.) I might add that I believe both Joe Papp and Joe Chaikin were invited but were too busy elsewhere.

title: Congress Returning
description: WASHINGTONIn the quiet of the Capitol the other day, Senate Majority Leader Mike Mansfield of Montana was sitting in his back office glancing at the newspapers and talking about future Congressional relations with the White House.

title: Bruce A. Korson Fiance Of Jeanne von Boecklin
description: GLEN COVE, L.I. Sept. 1  Mr. and Mrs. John Hall Allen of New York and Glen Cove have announced the engagement of Mrs. Allen's daughter, Miss Jeanne von Boecklin, to Bruce Andrew Korson of New York. A December wedding is planned.

title: CHAD WILL REPLACE HER FRENCH NAMES
description: FORTLAMY, Chad, Sept. 1 (Agence FrancePresse)President Francois Tombalbaye of Chad has become the first African leader to follow the directive of the new National Movement for the Cultural and Social Revolution that all French names be replaced by African ones.

title: Prime Rate Complex But Very Influential
description: One day last month Rafael Brache, an engaging 24yearold boutique owner from Mount Kisco, N. Y., walked into his friendly neighborhood banker's office and negotiated a $52,000 loan at an interest rate of 7.5 per cent. Mr. Brache used the money to buy a house in nearby Mahopac, and by the time he has repaid his loan 25 years from now it will have cost him not only the $52,000 he borrowed but also an additional $63,000 in interest for the privilege of using the bank's money for two and a half decades

title: China's Party Congress
description: WASHINGTONThe Chinese Communist party took a major stop last week to repair the political damage left by the turmoil of the Cultural Revolution and to prepare itself for the approaching succession to Chairman MaoTsetung.

title: PAUL E. LOCKWOOD, DEWEY AIDE, DEAD
description: Paul E. Lockwood, who was Secretary to the late Gov. Thomas E. Dewey and a former Public Service Commissioner, died Friday in New York Hospital after a short illness. He was 71 years old and lived at 200 East 66th Street.

title: BEAME FINDS MOST WORRY OVER CRIME
description: HAINES FALLS, N. Y., Sept. 1What are you going to do about crime? is the question Controller Abraham D. Beame has been asked most often during his quest for the votes of vacationing New Yorkers in this Catskills area.

title: Controversial Black Preacher Putting Stress on Social Issues
description: Tom Skinner threw his head back, hands outspread, and mimicked his audience. In the naaaame of Jeeeesus! he declaimed, and the largely teenage crowd giggled in recognition.

title: Now the Lineperson Comes to Football
description: Diane Thompson of Yuba City, Calif., and Toni Ihler of Portola, Calif., are swapping their pompons and cheerleader uniforms for helmets and football jerseys.

title: RALPH S. WILLIAMS
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., Sept. 1  Ralph S. Williams, for many years a tobaccoindustry executive, died yesterday in a nursing home. He was 82 years old and lived at 28 Headley Road.

title: Who Needs the Money?
description: The White House, consecrated to worship of the work ethic, ushered in the Labor Day weekend with a morale builder for the Federal Government's 3.5 million civilian and military employes: President Nixon is deferring for two months the 4.77 per cent wage increase they are supposed to get Oct. 1. Unless Congress acts this month to reverse the President's decision, the workers will not receive on schedule the raise prescribed under a law intended to keep Federal salaries in line with those for comparable jobs in private industry.

title: State Changes in the Village Law Give Increased Power to Local Communities
description: The obligation to get Albany's approval of everything from purchase of a village clock to the hiring of a fence viewer was abolished this weekend, when the state's recodified and expanded Village Law went into effect.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: On Tuesday the United Nations will open the first comprehensive international examination of the impact of multinational corporations. While the United Nations involvement in this complex issue follows aberrant behavior of one of the largest multinational corporations, there was. general recognition as early as 1947 in the nowdefunct Havana Charter of a contentious issue of major dimensions.

title: Louise Cohen Is Bride of David Trudel
description: SUMMIT, N. J., Sept. 1.Miss Louise Jane Cohen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Harry Cohen of Chatham Township, was married here this afternoon to David Joseph Trudel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Francis Trudel of Meriden, Conn. The Rev. Deane Starr performed the ceremony in the Unitarian Church.

title: Chilean Navy Units Help to Quell Student Disorders
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 1Navy units joined policemen to quell disturbances yesterday between armed groups of leftist and antiMarxist students in the Catholic University of Valparaiso, about 75 miles northwest of the capital.

title: The Journal of Long Island History Is Revived After an Absence of 8 Years
description: After an eightyear absence, the Journal of Long Island History has been revived by the Long Island Historical Society.

title: And Other Woes
description: WASHINGTONAlthough the Senate Watergate Committee has been in recess for more than three weeks now, the effect of its disclosures persist.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: ART

title: A Classic Tour of Brooklyn
description: I look upon modern architecture as esthetic vivisection, said Henry Hope Reed Jr., the arcitectural historian and preservationist, as he prepared to guide an entourage of young and old New Yorkers along Eastern Parkway from the Brooklyn Museum to the Grand Army Plaza last Sunday.

title: AROUND THE
description: VEGETABLES 1973 Many gardeners joined the grow your own vegetables movement this yearmany for the first time. They joined those who are trying to stretch their paychecks against the high cost of food and those who are growing for fun either because they have the land or take delight in fresh flavor.

title: It's NewCar Time
description: DETROIT  Optimism always has been one of the chief products of the automobile industry. As newcar time comes to Detroit once again,, the happy talk is as pervasive as  well, as the smog on a sunny day in Los Angeles.

title: POCO FIVE PLAY ROCK FOR A SUMMER NIGHT
description: Poco, the rock quintet that played in Central Park Friday and Saturday nights, is in many ways the perfect Schaefer Music Festival, summernightboogie band. The group has had an interesting genealogy, evolving as it did out of the Buffalo Springfield and its Los Angelescountry rock sound into the more overtly hardrock onslaughts it dwells on today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The article about factorybuilt dwelling units approved for erection at seven scattered sites in New York City [New Ways to Build Take Hold in City, July 29] mentioned in passing a huge housing project in Brooklyn called Starrett City. This $325million project now under construction will include 46 highrise buildings that will provide almost 6,000 dwelling units for 22,000 people. The project is a joint venture of National Kinney Corporation and Starrett Housing Corporation, the same concerns that are building the seven scattered housing projects. But at Starrett city conventional, not industrialized, construction methods are being used.

title: Unwanted by the U.S.S.R.
description: WASHINGTON  On Aug. 2, I received confirmed reservations to travel to Kiev, Moscow and Leningrad from Aug. 20 to Aug. 31. On Aug. 15, a cryptic cablegram from Intourist, Russia's tourist agency for foreigners, canceled all my reservations because of unforeseen circumstances.

title: Vijay Amritraj Upsets Layer
description: A 19yearold player from India, Vijay Amritraj, eliminated Rod Laver yesterday from the United States Open tennis championships at Forest Hills, Queens. And when he wasn't ricocheting bulletlike shots by the astonished Rocket, Amritraj spent his extra time applauding Laver's best shots.

title: A literary Who's Who
description: It's just possible that Hell will turn out to be a New York literary cocktail party. A plush conversation pit teeming with egostarved writers, their bedevilled spouses, editors, keepers and tormenterswith nothing ahead but an eternity of hollow laughter over each other's snappy oneliners.

title: MAJORITY IN POLL FAVOR HEARINGS
description: A majority of Americans hold the view that the Senate Watergate hearings are a good thing for the country and will not prevent witnesses from receiving a fair trial if they are brought to one, the latest Gallup Poll reports.

title: Pacific Air Fares Steady
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (Reuters)  The Civil Aeronautics Board this week turned down petitions to reconsider its decision last month denying 4 per cent fare increases on Pacific air routes.

title: Hawthorne Is Primping for a Birthday
description: HAWTHORNEThe bunting is draped over homes, stores and public and municipal buildings in this Passaic County borough as its 19,200 residents prepare for a huge parade tomorrow to mark Hawthorne's 75th anniversary. The excitement of anticipation can be felt up and down Lafayette Avenue, the main thoroughfare, where thousands of people from other communities will join the local celebration, beginning at 2 P.M. A lavish 224page souvenir journal, at $4 a copy, was distributed last week as part of the celebration; it includes photographs and articles that go back to the beginning of this town.

title: IRA I. SWEETWOOD
description: Ira I. Sweetwood, a stockbroker, died Friday evening at General Hospital in Passaic, N. J., after a long illness. His age was 38. He resided at 68 MacArthur Drive in Clifton, N. J.

title: Chess: Adventure Plus Precision Minus Error Is Brilliance
description: Brilliancy prizes are awarded, ideally for games containing original combinations, liberally studded with sacrifices. To qualify for the award, the combination must not be too technical in nature, that is, it must go beyond an accurately executed series of tactics in which the sacrificed material is neatly recouped.

title: PETTY APARTHEID IS UNDER REVIEW
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 1  Several South African cities, among them Johannesburg, are planning to review local ordinances and consider rewriting them to remove racial discrimination.

title: Miss Feldman Sets December Nuptials
description: NORTH WOODMERE, L. I., Sept. 1The engagement of Miss Alberta Feldman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Feldman of North Woodmere, to Lawrence Gerschel, son of Marc Gerschel and Mrs. Francine Andre Meyer, both of Paris, has been announced by the future bride's parents.

title: JAPANESE RAISING POT WITH NO KICK
description: TOKYO, Sept. 1A new kind of marijuana without a drug content, comparable to coffee without caffeine and cigarettes without nicotine, is being developed in Japan to foil thieves. They have been raiding commercial fields of hemp, plant containing the drug.

title: Home Improvement
description: ALL homes, regardless of size and style, and regardless of what materials they are built, need the protection afforded by periodic and careful application of a good quality calking compound to seal the seams, cracks and open joints around the outside.

title: SOVIET ASSAILED FROM FRANKFURT
description: BONN, Sept. 1The West German city of Frankfurt was prominently mentioned at a Moscow political trial this week as the base of an antiSoviet migr organization that gave the two defendants money, instructions and subversive publications.

title: F. H. BABCOCK DEAD HOSPITALS TRUSTEE
description: F. Huntington Babcock, former textile executive who was active in hospital work here, died Thursday at his home, 66 East 79th Street. He was 87 years old.

title: Philippines
description: MANILAOpposition Senator Benigno S. Aquino, pale and 45 pounds lighter after 11 months' detention in army camps, delivered his peroration against President Ferdinand E. Marcos before the military tribunal convened last Monday to try him for subversion. When he finished, the audience of 400 ignored military guards and cheered.

title: Miss Marvin Wed, to Dr. C. E. Blair 3d
description: GARRISON, N. Y., Sept. 1 Miss Christine Karen Marvin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul R. Marvin of Peekskill, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Charles Emmett Blair 3d, son of Mr. Blair Jr. of Hastings, Neb., and the late Mrs. Blair, the former Elinor Morrissey,

title: Going places
description: ACROSS

title: U.S. Swimmers Set 3 World Records
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 1Three world records were broken by Americans in the opening of the world aquatic championships today and the United States water polo team defeated Cuba, 43.

title: Jean C. Rushin To Be a Bride
description: SUMMIT, N. J., Sept 1Miss Jean Claire Rushin, an officer's assistant with the Wall Street Division of the Chemical Bank of New York, and Jonathan Allison Brown Jr., directormarketing support for the Western Union Telegraph Company in New York, plan to be married in December.

title: Presidential Power
description: After a momentary hint that he might simply defy the courts, President Nixon has wisely decided to keep within the judicial system his challenge of Chief Judge John J. Sirica's ruling on the disputed Watergate tapes.

title: Social Indicators
description: A longstanding sociologists' complaint is that their insights into human behavior and attitudes are seldom heeded when public policy is established. Years of governmentendorsed. boom have given everybody more televisions, automobiles and education than ever before, they say, but people do not seem much happier.

title: MARCHI GREETED IN THE CATSKILLS
