description: ELLENVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 1 State Senator John J. Marchi, Staten Island Republican, took his mayoral campaign today through what many of his staff members called Beame country, the territory of his Democratic rival, but the predominantly Jewish resort guests still gave Mr. Marchi, an ItalianAmerican, a warm to enthusiastic reception.

title: The Good Word: On Keeping Closets Closed
description: If you like to think of fictional art as a branch of magic, authors' jacket photos have to be a terrible disappointment. Andr Gide called fiction a collaboration between the Holy Ghost and the devil: yet here you have this florid mountebank in his turtleneck gazing out to sea, or this road company Blanche DuBois and no one else in sight. Is that all there is to an author? It's almost as disappointing as meeting one.

title: A CAR PREVAILS IN NORTH CAMDEN
description: CAMDEN, N. J., Sept. 1For the first time since Wednesday, North Camden was free of civil disturbances last night.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: So far this year investors have little to choose in the way of new stock issues. As a direct reflection of the sagging prices of seasoned stocks the flow of new equity offerings has slowed to a trickle.

title: On Surface, U.S. Swim Domination Has Gone Down
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 1  Fortunately, the United States swimmers have not had much time for thinking the last two weeks.

title: Mets Knock Cards From Top by .0001
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 1The September home stretch of the baseball season arrived today and the New York Metsstill in the race despite a losing summerentered it by prying the St. Louis Cardinals out of first place.

title: Wiechers Leads at 131; Three Others a Shot Back
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Sept. 1The heat made you concentrate because you felt so lackadaisical playing, suggested big Jim Wiechers today after a 66 for an 11underpar, 36hole total of 131. It gave him a onestroke lead in the $200,000 Sammy Davis Jr.Greater Hartford open golf tournament.

title: Wittgenstein's Vienna
description: Among the intellectual giants of the 20th century must surely be counted Ludwig Wittgenstein, philosopher of mind, of language and of mathematics. For this study Allan Janik and Stephen Toulmin, two American teachers of philosophy, have acted on a striking premise: an understanding of prewar World War I Vienna, Wittgenstein's native city, will make it easier to comprehend both his work and our own presentday problems.

title: Earthquakes
description: Of all natural catastrophies, none is more deeply terrifying than an earthquake. Great storms do not strike without warning. Winds and floods tear at the land, but, underneath, the earth remains steadfast.

title: Thomas Logie Miss Uzzell
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., Sept. 1Miss Laura Cowan Uzzell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Cowan Uzzell of Garden City, was married this afternoon to Thomas Davis Logic, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Logic of Wantagh.

title: A Carnival Helps a School
description: KENILWORTH  For the ninth consecutive year, this spry Union County community of 9,500 is bustling with the sights and sounds of oldtime American pageantry, a smalltown carnival.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: New and Recommended
description: FICTION

title: The Truth About Kent State
description: At 12:24 on the afternoon of Monday, May 4, 1970, a detachment of perhaps 30 National Guardsmen on the campus of Kent State University in Kent, Ohio, suddenly turned in a body and opened fire with M1 rifles and .45cal. automatic pistols on students who were hundreds of feet away. Thirteen students were Shot Four of them died.

title: MOE J. COHEN
description: CEDARHURST, L. L, Sept. 1  Moe J. Cohen, who founded the Pyramid Leather Goods Company in New York in 1923 and was its president until his retirement in 1968, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack in his home at 463 Sum mit Avenue. He was 77 years old.

title: Selling Books
description: A number of items in the news pages of The Times, as well as several articles in the Book Review itself, all appearing in the recent months since my (at least temporary) retirement from the publishing business after 38 years, have contained some rather bitter attacks on publishers. Little that is new was reported in these articles, all of which implied that publishers are, at the very least, ignorant, inefficient, stupid, grasping and altogether the kind of people who refuse to observe Mother's Day. I was moved after all these years of suffering more or less in silence to look back a bit, to see, perhaps, if matters are better or worse, or likely to go either way in the future.

title: West Point
description: WEST POINTWhat makes for a good army? One of West Point's early superintendents, Maj. Gen. John M. Schofield, had strong views nearly century ago: The discipline which makes the soldiers of a free country reliable in battle is not to be gained by harsh or tyrannical treatment. On the contrary, such treatment is far morelikely to destroy than to make an army.

title: Boston Mail Annex Delayed
description: BOSTON, Sept. 1 (AP)A $30million mail handling building, once scheduled to open in October, 1971, will not be in full operation for another year, according to Postmaster George K. Walker.

title: News of Screen
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 31Arthur Penn, the director, starts work this month on his first feature film in three years. For the Warner Brothers picture titled The Dark Tower he will team again with Gene Hackman, who rose to fame as the brother of Clyde Barrow in Mr. Penn's Bonnie and Clyde.

title: An Assemblyman at Age of 18?
description: TRENTONA court hearing later this month is expected to determine whether teenagers should he permitted to serve as State Assemblymen.

title: Special Session Could Be Fiery
description: TRENTON  Despite efforts by the Republican legislative leaders to avoid it, there were increasing signs here this weekend that the Democratic minorities in the Legislature would attempt to inject a little partisan controversy into the special oneday session on Sept. 10.

title: LETTERS
description: The idea that economists should be licensed like physicians is a dangerous concept. It may, as William C. Freund suggests in his article What Does an Economist Get Paid For? (Aug. 12), prevent people with at best, sketchy credentials from calling themselves economists, but this small benefit

title: STUDY MADE HERE ON PUERTO RICANS
description: A study of poor Puerto Rican families here has been made that draws a both brighter and bleaker profile than had been expected. The study was made by Mrs. Marta Valle, who organized the city's broadest Puerto Rican community conference for Mayor Lindsay and then served as Commissioner of Youth Services.

title: Daughter to the Daniels
description: A daughter was born Aug. 23 to Mr. and Mrs. Howard Daniel in Brasilia, Brazil, where Mr. Daniel is with the United States Information Service. Mrs. Daniel is the former Martha Wolin, daughter of Mrs. Benjamin Barolsky of Paterson, N. J. The child has been named Naomi Elizabeth.

title: TWO SUPPORTERS BREAK WITH RIZZO
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1The gubernatorial aspirations of Mayor Frank L. Rizio of Philadelphia were jolted this week with the defection of two of his close supporters  a publisher, D. Herbert Lipson, and the school board president, William Ross.

title: MEDITATION HELPS TENSE EXECUTIVES
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 1 (AP)Transcendental meditation, once the realm of the Beatles and flower children, has a new followingbusiness executives.

title: Soviet Dissidents The Regime Decides To Squeeze a Little
description: MOSCOWIn a grimy brick building in the Moscow suburb of Lyublino, a courtroom drama was played out last week against the clanking of switching engines in an adjoining railroad yard.

title: Linda DeAngelo Is Bride
description: Miss Linda Rose DeAngelo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent J. DeAngelo of Flushing, Queens, was married yesterday afternoon to Robert Leen Gaddis, son of Mr. and Mrs. M. Francis Gaddis of Port Washington, L. I. The ceremony was performed in St. Anne's Roman Catholic Church in Flushing by the Rev. Raymond N. Stafford.

title: TV News
description: TRENTONAll the television antennas in New Jersey's populous northern suburbs face New York City. Those in the southern part of the state are aimed at Philadelphia. And anyone who has tried to govern New Jersey or win an election here in recent decades has had to grapple with the fact that while a reported 75 per cent of the state's citizens get virtually all of their news and understanding of public affairs from television, the cameras in New York and Philadelphia rarely are tried to this state. Thus the New Jersey electorate generally gets to know a lot about Mayor Lindsay, Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Frank Rizzo of Philadelphia, and remains largely ignorant of what is going on in its own state.

title: WALL STREET
description: CHICAGO  Professional stock market traders like it because it affords them an opportunity to lose money profitably. Unsophisticated small traders are attracted because they know exactly how much money they can lose.

title: Garden Schedules A Preseason Sale
description: Tickets go on sale Tuesday for two New York Knicks preseason games and two New York Rangers games. They can be purchased at Madison Square Garden's main box office and at over 100 Ticketron locations.

title: LIBYA TAKES OVER ALL OIL COMPANIES OPERATING THERE
description: CAIRO, Sept. 1Libya announced tonight the nationalization of 51 per cent of the assets of all the oil companies operating in the country.

title: Bergen Plans Clinic On Ailing Greenery
description: BERGENFIELDThe Bergen County Extension Service is offering the homeowner a chance to help solve his lawn, plant, tree or insect problems. A clinic on these problems will be held at Coopers Pond Shelter House, Coopers Park, West Church Street, Bergenfield, from 11 A.M to 4 P.M. on Sept. 15.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: In the preface to this study of journalism in the life of the nation, 16901972, Robert A. Rutland raises high expectations. He warns of the possibility of U.S. newspapers being strangled by an unholy alliance of labor and capital. He talks of the nation's need for a different set of news values. He charges that American journalism has increasingly become a business with a secondary concern for the improvement of the public men and policies.

title: The Spirit of Crime
description: PARISIt may seem out of place for a foreigner to butt into the discussion of crime in America. However, my own research on crime in Paris has frequently been clarified by the fresh insights of someone familiar with American cities, even If he did not know the situation in France. Perhaps I can reciprocate.

title: How Do You Learn to Be an Artist?
description: SINCE, in a world greatly transformed, the visual arts have presumably moved far from the premises of art in the past, is there any use for a young artist, in 1973, to study the traditional disciplines?

title: South African Woman, Classified Colored on Opinion of 9 Witnesses, Fights in Court to Save Marriage
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 1 (Reuters)Mrs. Annie Koekemoer, a 25yearold housewife who was officially declared colored, or of mixed race, in spite of her white background, is the latest victim of South Africa's rigid system of race classification.

title: School Bell Is About to Ring Again
description: WEST WINDSOR  Hundreds of thousands of students across the state will be flocking back to school this week, ending the long summer recess.

title: Hunting a Deadly Cobra In the Wilds of Suburbia
description: BUFFALO GROVE, Ill., Sept. 1Roman emperors had their deadly pet lions. Cleopatra had her deadly pet asp. And David Pearson had his deadly pet cobra.

title: News Summary and Index SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 2, 1973
description: At least 35 persons, most of them foreign tourists, were killed and many were missing in a fire that turned the upper stories of a Copenhagen hotel into an inferno. More than 12 hours after the fire was put out, rescuers were still digging for bodies in the burnedout shell of the Hafnia, a 74yearold family hotel and tourist landmark near Town Hall Square. [Page 1, Columns 34.]The decline in many food prices that began last week was expected to continue until price ceilings come off beef Sept. 12. But the cheer this held for consumers was tempered by the belief among agricultural forecasters in Chicago that retail food costs would soon level off on a very high plateau and stay there the rest of this year and most of next year. Consumer reluctance to pay the highest prices in memory for pork and poultry pulled wholesale and stockyarrd prices down last week from their record levels in midAugust, [26:14.]MetropolitanMost public schools in the suburbs throughout the New York metropolitan area will reopen this week with the perennial problems of money accentuated this fall by the nation's record inflation. Particularly in the older suburbs, where enrollment has been dropping in recent years, school officials had reason to anticipate more space and more leeway for innovation. But the rapidly decreasing buying power of the funds voted for school budgets last spring has more than offset any possible savings and is again forcing educators to scramble for money. [1:1.]Narcotics detectives, armed with a search warrant and posing as Consolidated Edison workers, broke down the door of the wrong Harlem apartment in search of drugs and so frightened the apartment's lone woman occupant that she suffered severe cuts tryin gto escape through a closed window. Mrs. Ruby Baker, 56 years old, said the men never identified themselves as policemen. She thought they were burglars. [1:2.]The New York City Opera was shut down by a strike of its union musicians that forced the cancellation of the day's performances and all future ones until the contract dispute is settled. The threeyear contract between Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians and the opera company had expired at midnight. At 1 A.M. yesterday, the union notified management that it had gone on strike. [1:23.]Three teenaged youths in Queens and Nassau charged with possession of small amounts of nonnarcotic drugs were the first persons arrested in this area under the state's stringent new drug laws, which went into effect at midnight yesterday. The first arrest was made at 12:05 A.M. when Robert Tomicich, 18 years old, was taken into custody at a Jethro Tull rock concert at the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale. He was charged with possession of a controlled substance, reportedly three marijuana cigarettes. [36:35.]Index to the Other News in Section 1

title: Sandra Young, William Adams To Wed in Fall
description: DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 1Mr. and Mrs. Sanford Procter Young have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sandra Procter Young, to William Joseph Adams of Ardmore, Pa. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford William Adams of Waltham, Mass. A wedding in November is planned.

title: Making it and unmaking it
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. At Harvard, as at most major white colleges, black students have reached a crisis, one that has coincided with their rising enrollments and one that has been created in large measure by black separatism and militancy. The sharp differentiation of Negroes as a subcommunity within white Harvard, the gnawing ambivalence of loyalty experienced by Negro students forced to choose between their subcommunity and the university in general and the resulting blackwhite tension have all combined to have a nearly disastrous impact on the academic achievement and intellectual growth of Negro students. While the allblack behavioral paradigm may have its strategic value in the inner city, it is a failure on the campus.

title: Blumenthal Asks Regulating And Licensing of Repairmen
description: Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal, the Liberal party candidate for Mayor, today urged the City Council to pass legislation to require the licensing and regulation of repairmen and service dealers who repair teleVision sets, radios, audio equipment, airconditioners, washing machines and other household appliances.

title: Biaggi Urges Employment For the Vietnam Veterans
description: Representative Mario Biaggi urged yesterday that the Labor Day holiday not only celebrate the working man but that it also be a reflective time of concern for the plight of the unemployed Vietnam veterans.

title: Louise Hatch Wed to David Cluett Cass
description: BOULDER, Colo., Sept. 1In St. John's Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Louise Townsend Hatch of Boulder, daughter of the Right Rev. Robert McConnell Hatch, retired Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Western Massachusetts, and Mrs. Hatch of Randolph, N. H., became the bride of David Cluett Cass, also of Boulder. The rector, the Rev. James McKeown, performed the ceremony.

title: DRUG RAID IS MADE AT WRONG HOUSE
description: Casually dressed narcotics detectives, armed with a search warrant and posing as utility workers, broke down the door of the wrong apartment in Harlem yesterday in search of cocaine and so frightened the apartment's lone woman occupant that she suffered cuts trying to escape through a closed window.

title: Save the fruits of summer
description: Man cannot live by chutney alone. Granted. But it certainly perks up some of the inexpensive meat cuts we are getting used to. Fruit chutney is traditional with curries and ham and simply splendid with cottage cheese and freshly baked bread. This is the time for the home cook to put up her (or his) own private label chutney. Apples, tomatoes, peaches and pears, grapes and plums are at the top of their flavorand as low in price as they'll be this year.

title: Sunday Observer
description: The important thing in America is to go.

title: Arthur V. Watkins Dies at 86; Led McCarthy Censure Inquiry
description: OREM, Utah, Sept. 1 (AP)Former Senator Arthur V. Wat kins, the Republican who pre sided over the special committee that censured Senator Joseph R. McCarthy in 1954, died here to day at his daughter's home. He was 86 years old.

title: Fuchsberg Petitions Being Challenged By the State G.O.P.
description: ALBANY, Sept. 1The Republican State Committee has filed objections to nominating petitions that would give Jacob D. Fuchsberg, Democratic candidate for chief judge of the Court of Appeals, another spot on the ballot in the Nov. 6 election.

title: Candidates for U.S.E.T. Work Out on Hot Seats
description: For 10 days now, under a broiling sun for the most part, Bert de Nemethy, coach of the United States Equestrian Team's Prix des Nations (jumping) squad, has been sending 14 riders through daily drills at the group's Gladstone, N. J., headquarters.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: I Fell in Love With Montgomery Clift
description: IDID not deign to fall in with any of the boys who asked me to dance under duress and the watchful eyes of Sister Maria. Not with Richard, who was a good pitcher and who did the box step over and over again in the same spot on the brown tile floor, or with John, who was very tall and so paralyzed with fear when he approached a girl that his stomach rumbled, or with Noel, who had dimples and wavy hair and was generally proclaimed to be cute, or with Johnny, the football player.

title: New Medical Rx: R.P.A.
description: STONY BROOK, L. I. When the first class in the physician's associate program graduated from the State University's School of Allied Health Professions here last Tuesday its 14 members had their pick of a total of 70 job offers.

title: 50 Loss Stops Streak
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 1 (WI) Marty Pattin pitched a fivehitter and Carlton Fisk slammed a threerun homer today in leading the Boston Red Sox to a 50 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers. The victory broke a fourgame Brewer winning streak, three of them over the Red Sox.

title: Griffith Bout Put Back
description: PARIS, Sept, 1 (REUTERS) A 10round middleweight bout here between Australia's Tony Mundine and Emile Griffith of New York has been postponed to Oct. 22. The original date was Sept. 24.

title: New Wisconsin Publisher
description: LA CROSSE, Wis., Sept 1 (AP)Kenneth O. Blanchard, executive editor of The La Crosse Tribune since 1971, has been named publisher.,

title: Terry and McGhee Complement Bookbinder and Kaplin at Max's
description: Two pleasantly complementary acoustic duos opened Wednesday night at Max's Kansas City, Park Avenue South at 17th Street.

title: 340 Tule Elk Counted
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif. Sept. 1 (UPI)A total of 340 tule elk have been counted in the Owens Valley by state fish and game personnel, an increase of 60 over last year. Fish and Game Department biologists reported the elk, protected by state law, were counted during a threeday aerial survey.

title: Mance Appointed Trotting Director
description: Emil (Bus) Mosbacher Jr., the chairman of the New York State Racing and Wagering Board, has announced the appointment of Frederic M. Mance, 55, of Pine Bush, N.Y., as acting director of the Harness Racing Division.

title: Amtrak Improves Train Terminals
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept, 1A renovated railroad stadon to be dedicated here on Wednesday is the latest step in Amtrak's campaign to promote rail service throughout the country by modernizing some existing stations and building a few new ones.

title: The Art of Turning a Profit
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I.  At first glance, Saturday at the Benson Gallery has all the trappings of a typical Hamptons party complete with the customary odd assortment of tattered jeans and Puccis, long hair and crew cuts, bare feet and platform clogs, political chatter and recipe swapping, and a quickly disappearing supply of semidry white wine punch sipped from plastic cups.

title: TV Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: SALLY QUINN and Hughes Rudd are so good that it wouldn't surprise me, a veteran TV viewer, to see them replace Walter Cronkite in an expanded daily hourlong evening news series on CBS. With more interesting women's newstype features replacing the drab features now filling the Cronkite show.

title: Brooklyn Fireman Dies Fighting Blaze in Store
description: A fireman was killed last night in Brooklyn battling a twohour blaze in a dry goods store in the Crown Heights section.

title: Court Backs Longer Term For Ceilings on Beef Price
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) A Federal appeals court ruled today that Presidential orders keeping price limits on beef longer than on other meats were justified by the rapid rise in beef prices.

title: SHOP TALK
description: SOUTH ORANGE  When Irene Friedman opened Bazaar de la Cuisine, a gourmet cookware shop two years ago, she had had a lot of experience in home entertaining.

title: MARRIED PRIESTS SUSPECT JOB BIAS
description: Some married Roman Catholic priests are raising the question of whether to seek recourse from the Federal Government to deal with what they see as job discrimination.

title: Son to Mrs. Dennis Golub
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Dennis Golub of New York on Aug. 13 in the LyingIn Hospital. Mr. Golub is the former Miss Marla Alexander, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Harold Alexander of Long Beach, L. I.

title: Shenandoah Fish Get Ladder
description: LAKEWOOD  What is said to be the state's first Deniltype fish ladder has been installed in Lake Shenandoah Park, a new Ocean County facility that will he dedicated on Tuesday.

title: Roles Reversed in France's Bizarre Labor Drama
description: BESANCON, FranceIt is the cliffhanger of the summer in France. Can the workers of Socit Lip, the country's biggest, best  and bankrupt  watch manufacturer, keep it ticking by themselves?

title: These Little Pressure Groups Went to Market  With a Club
description: IN one episode of The Waltons last season, the large and loving family befriended an ItaloAmerican boy from New York City. Just passing through town, as all sorts of exotic outsiders conveniently happen to do on The Waltons, the youth displayed the usual hostility of an urban juvenile delinquent. In the end, though, after returning some money he stole from the Walton family, he came to trust and respect the ways of his friendly benefactors.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass.Only a whisper of a westerly breeze came across the smooth sea and it seemed an ideal day to carry out my longcontemplated plan for launching a canoe in the ocean to try for striped bass off a certain rocky point on Martha's Vineyard's South Shore.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: As much as I deplore wrongdoing by high government officials, I am little interested, indeed, whether Dean told the truth and only the truth, whether Magruder committed perjury or Ehrlichman is really what a liar. Nor whether Nixon was fully briefed on. Watergate on the 12th or 25th of March and may have been inclined to shield some of his trusted aides who served him faithfully in the past.

title: News of the Camera World
description: APHOTOGRAPHY course for beginners will be conducted at the Brooklyn Center of Long Island University on Thursday evenings from 6 to 8 P.M., starting on Sept. 23. The noncredit 10session course will cover basic 35mm techniques, including developing, printing and special effects, plus individual assignments. The tuition fee will be $69.50 and registration will begin this Thursday. For information call the Adult Education Program at (212) 8346020.

title: His only regretnot to have killed de Gaulle
description: PARIS. On the dust jacket of my edition of Frederick Forsyth's The Day of the Jackal (now a major motion picture starring Edward Fox) is the following summary:

title: Duffy's Hit Breaks Tie
description: DETROIT, Sept. 1 (UPI)Frank Duffy, who had driven in three runs with a double and a home run, drove in the winning run in the 11th inning today as the Cleveland Indians beat the Detroit Tigers, 54.

title: Deliverance
description: CORK, IrelandIt had all the elements of a movie drama: two men trapped in a submarine beneath the sea with frustrated rescuers on the surface struggling desperately against time as the sub's oxygen supply dwindled. It was all too real but it included a happy ending as the mariners trapped in the. Pisces 3 were plucked from the bottom of the Atlantic yesterday with only 90 minutes left before their air supply gave out.

title: Mailbag: Why They Flock to Hear Betty
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Literally, Sandy Hook Is Ideal for Littoral Society
description: SANDY HOOK  Four highceilinged rooms in a converted Army barracks at the tip of Sandy Hook might seem to be a strange place for the headquarters of a nationwide conservation organization, but it suits the American Littoral Society just fine.

title: Daughter to the Tarters
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 1A daughter was born Aug. 19 to Mr. and Mrs. Fred B. Tarter in the New Rochelle Hospital. Mrs. Tarter is the former Miss Barbara Smith. Her husband is president of Universal Communications, Inc..

title: Photography
description: SEVERAL weeks ago in this space A. D. Coleman confessed to a kind of despair when confronted with yet another photographic report on the life of poor blacks in the segregated South. The report in question was a book by Eugene Richards, Few Comforts or Surprises: The Arkansas Delta (The MIT Press, $9.95), and although Mr. Coleman admired the book, he felt that it would be no more successful than any other such book in changing the conditions it documented. Hence his despair.

title: INSURGENTS PRESS CAMBODIAN TOWN
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sept. 1The provincial capital of Kompong Cham, 45 miles northeast of here, remained under heavy pressure from several regiments of surrounding Communist troops today and a textile mill in the southwestern suburbs was evacuated, a Government spokesman said.

title: KEY MAN IS DROPPED IN BUFFALO INQUIRY
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 1 (AP)James C. Donahue, who headed Buffalo's temporary investigating unit looking into job abuses, has been denied a position on the permanent unit being formed next week.

title: Britons Drinking Less Tea
description: LONDON, Sept. 1 (Reuters) Britons are losing their taste for tea and turning to coffee instead, according to a Government report. The trend is disclosed in a Ministry of Agriculture survey covering the years from 1955 to 1972. In 1955 the average Briton used 9.3 pounds of tea. Last year the average had dropped to eight pounds while coffee sales increased from 1.3 pounds to 4.4 pounds in the same period.

title: 3 Youths in City Area Seized Under State's New Drug Laws
description: Three teenaged boys in Queens and Nassau County charged with possession of small amounts of nonnarcotic drugs were the first persons arrested in the metropolitan area under the state's stringent new drug laws, which went into effect yesterday.

title: Cumberland Gap Rock Festival Is Canceled Alter Court's Order
description: CUMBERLAND GAP, Tenn., Sept. 1Federal park rangers this afternoon evacuated the National Historical Park here of hundreds of young people who had come to attend a Labor Day weekend rock festival. It was canceled after being blocked by court order in both Tennessee and Kentucky.

title: They'll Leave You Happy, If Unimproved
description: DILLINGER and Bang the Drum Slowly are two new movies that could not be more unlike in style. The former is a bright and crackling celluloid comic book, a gleeful fantasia of gangster mayhem, and the latter is a chuckly and weteyed idyll about baseball players, a sort of Love Story in pinstripes. What they have in common is, first, that both are clearly products of the nostalgia craze that is still upon us (soon, one imagines, to be nostalgic for itself) and, second, that each is as perfect a piece of mindless entertainment as one could wish for in a steamy.

title: Panel Acts To Resolve Shortage Of Water
description: TRENTON  A committee composed of the 10 largest water purveyors north of New Brunswick is seeking to resolve what the state describes as a grave need for coordinated planning to satisfy the demands for drinking water.

title: Milk for Children
description: When schools open across the country this week, more than forty million children will find no milk on their lunch trays, unless local communities or their parents pick up the tab. The Federal subsidy, which amounted to $95 million last year, has for the moment been wiped outa victim of President Nixon's budgetslashing and of an unresolved conflict between the Senate and the House.

title: County College Programs: the Doorway to Fun, Skills and SelfKnowledge
description: TRENTON  Several thousand persons will be registering at New Jersey's 17 county colleges this fall, but not with the idea of eventually obtaining a degree. Instead, they are going to college to have fun, relieve the monotony of their lives, learn about themselves or perhaps pursue basic skills or learn how to speak English.

title: Art in California
description: Los ANGELES.

title: Dr. Gregory Razran, 72, Dead; Psychology Chairman at Queens
description: Dr. Gregory Razran, professor emeritus of psychology at Queens College and a leading authority on Russian psychological research was drowned Friday while swimming off St. Petersburg Beach, Fla., where he lived, His age was 72.

title: Major Evangelical Drive Appears a Failure OverAll
description: What was heralded as the biggest evangelical drive ever undertaken appears to have failed overall.

title: ... A New Form of Imperialism
description: Many countries have felt their independence threatened by political and economic imperialism, and more recently by the spread of the multinational enterprise.

title: China's Leaders Promise More Cultural Revolutions
description: PEKING, Sept. 1 (Reuters)China's leaders say they will direct the nation into a series of Cultural Revolutions as part of a continual struggle against revisionism and subversion.

title: American Yacht Sweeps Cup Match
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Aug 31 (AP)  The United States entry won the second American  Australian Cup competition yesterday by completing a sweep of the first four races of the best of seven series.

title: 2 in Submarine Rescued As It Is Raised on 3d Day
description: CORK, Ireland, Sept. 1Two Britons, trapped since Wednesday in a midget submarine 1,375 feet below the Atlantic, were hauled to the surface in their 20foot vessel today and transferred safely to their mother ship.

title: Little Vizsla Heading for 3 Big Days
description: The vizsla is an ancient Hungarian breed. Primitive stone etchings, said to be more than 1,000 years old, show the Magyar hunter with his falcon and vizsla. The rustgold dog, which measures 22 to 24 inches at the withers, is one of the smallest of the allround pointer  retriever breeds. The size has been to his advantage, for he's small enough to be a house dog. When it comes to working in the field, he can be counted on to do a big day's work.

title: Miss Jenifer L. Condit Wed to Mark Messing
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., Sept. 1 In the Manhattanville College Chapel here this afternoon, Miss Jenifer L. Condit, a 1971 graduate of the college, was married to Mark P. Messing in a Roman Catholic ceremony performed by the Rev. Edward Hart.

title: Cycling Title Won By Belgian Woman
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Sept. 1 (UPI)Nicole Van Den Broeck a 25yearold milkshop employee from Aalst, Belgium, won the women's road race today in the world cycling championships.

title: Clark Tops Mulloy For Seniors Title
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1 (AP)  Straight Clark of Haverford, Pa., won the United States Senior Grass Court Tennis Championship today by defeating Gardner Mulloy of Miami, 6.3, 64. The match lasted 53 minutes.

title: INDIANA NORTHERNU. REBUFFED BY COURT
description: GAS CITY, Ind., Sept. 1Indiana Northern University has been ordered by a state court to admit state school inspectors on Sept. 11 or face cancellation of its fall term.

title: Inscrutable Mood Of the Consumer
description: By ERNEST HOLSENDOLPHAs the business year effectively opens with the Labor Day weekend, businessmen are pondering the inscrutable consumer, and the result is far from a consensus.

title: DUBLIN TO EXTEND HEALTH CARE PLAN
description: DUBLIN, Sept. 1The Irish Republic is extending virtually free hospital service to almost the entire population under program announced this week.

title: Subsidy Helps Realize Adoption Dream
description: JERSEY CITYSometime this fall, the Rev, and Mrs. Joshua Edwards will go to court, taking with them two lively children. A while later, the four will come home a family, thanks to New Jersey's new subsidized adoption program.

title: NEED PRIESTS SUSPECT JOB BIAS
description: Some married Roman Catholic priests are raising the question of whether to seek recourse from the Federal Government to deal with what they see as job discrimination.

title: Mexico to Remain a Haven for Dissidents, Echeverria Asserts
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 1Mexico plans to continue to seek economic and political relations with nations of diverse ideologies and will continue to offer asylum to dissidents from abroad, President Luis Echeverra Alvarez said today.

title: Supervisors
description: New York City's 1.1million public school pupils will not start classes until Sept. 10, but last Wednesday, a week ahead of schedule, their principals and other school supervisors returned to work, on sudden notice, to prepare for the fall term.

title: Miss Francis Wed in Jersey
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., Sept. 1Miss Pamela Francis and John Richard Wilson were married here this morning in Christ Episcopal Church by the Rev. Tracy H. Wilder 3d.

title: TRUCE UNIT SESSIONS CANCELED BY SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 1 (UPI)South Vietnamese Government delegates boycotted five subcommission meetings of the Joint Military Commission today in what they said was a protest against Viet Cong impoliteness at a stormy meeting of the commission yesterday.

title: H.E.W. Kills Plans For Squash Court In Office Building
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has rejected plans for a squash court and sauna bath in its new $42million building.

title: Skylab's Tenants Like the Place but Wish They Could Remodel
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 1In the American Skylab program, for the first time, men have been going into space chiefly to live there. How livable is it?

title: Lightning Hits Choir's Plane
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 1 (AP)A Boeing 747 carrying 405 members and relatives of the Mormon Tabernacle Choir was struck by lightning today

title: Kenya Bans All Hunting Of Elephants Indefinitely
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 1  Kenya has banned all elephant hunting in the country and all dealings in ivory. The order will run for an indefinite period and was prompted by the nation's growing conqern over widespread poaching of elephants.

title: Future Social Events
description: By RUSSELL EDWARDS Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:The Kindness of Sports Sept. 7  When New York City's Young Women's Christian Association was founded in 1870 its stated purpose was to extend Christian kindness to that class of girls thrown on their own resources . . . In its 103 years it has accomplished that and a lot more. But when organizations specialize in spreading any kind of kindness, they need to raise the old wherewithal. This year the association's benefit activities included a Sportsorama in three acts. Enthusiasts went first to the races, next cheered the Mets at Shea Stadium and the third event will take them to the United States Tennis Championships in Forest Hills. A $50 ticket includes bus transportation, a buffet lunch in the Rose Garden and an opportunity to watch the world's tennis superstars serve each other right. Well, there's no fault in that. Tickets from BrookwoodDana, Ltd., 635 Madison Avenue. Louis F. Polk Jr. and Clarence C. pell are chairmen.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: Late one night in January, 1971, James R. Barker placed himself in front of the fire in his home to contemplate a question that almost every man broaches seriously at least once: What do I really want to do with my life?

title: The House Next Door Is a Bit of a Problem
description: Manhattan Beach is a tongue of land three blocks wide, maybe seventeen blocks long, sandwiched between the Atlantic Ocean on the south and Sheepshead Bay on the north. It is part of Brooklyn's long shoreline, which also includes Brighton Beach and Coney Island.

title: World News Briefs
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 1The United States Air Force has withdrawn a squadron of C130 transport planes from a base in central Taiwan, it was announced today, in the first reduction in the American military presence here since President Nixon's trip to China early last year.

title: Culture Loop Bus Tour Enthralls Driver, Too
description: Anthony Zerillo, who has driven Transit Authority buses for 19 years, got a chance yesterday to do what he said he seldom gets to doto say something nice about New York.

title: A BLACK ACTIVIST FREED IN CAROLINA
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Sept. 1Cleveland L. Sellers Jr., a black activist, declared upon his release from prison this week that he would seek a new investigation into what he termed the Orangeburg massacre.

title: Harry M. Addinsell Dies; First Boston Corp. Official
description: Harry M. Addinsell, who retired in 1951 as chairman of the board of the First Boston Corporation, an investment banking concern, died Thursday in Southampton, L.I., where he lived. His age was 87.

title: Plan to Extend Runway Stirs Cape Cod
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1A proposed expansion of the Provincetown, Mass., municipal airport into the Cape Cod National Seashore has touched off a dispute between conservationists and local airport officials.

title: HIGH I.R.A. LEADER IS SEIZED BY DUBLIN
description: DUBLIN, Sept. 1  Seamus Twomey, chief of staff of the Provisional wing of the illegal Irish Republican Army in BelSast, was arrested today by the Irish police in a remote farmhouse in County Monaghan, 15 miles from the border with Northern Ireland.

title: The Mideast: Wrong Place for an Optimist
description: PARIS  United Nations SecretaryGeneral Kurt Waldheim's current visit to the Middle East coincides with several significant developments in the ArabIsraeli conflict. These include the Israeli Labor party's proposal to settle conquered Arab territory, the proleered fusion of Egypt and Libya, the ascending role of Saudi Arabia's King Faisal, the complexities of oil as an Arab weapon  and, perhaps the most intriguing of all, the appointment of Henry Kissinger as American Secretary of State.

title: Funeral for John Ford Set on Coast Wednesday
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Sept. 1 (AP)  A requiem mass for John Ford will be celebrated Wednesday at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament in Hollywood, a spokesman forthe family said today.

title: R. Breck Denny to Wed Cassandra E. Hopkins
description: MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Sept. 1  Miss Cassandra Ewing Hopkins and R. Breck Denny have made plans to be married Oct 20 in Bedford.

title: Will Pyramiders Topple Into Nassau?
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I.  The slick sales companies that made the fortunes for fasttalking promoters by impoverishing thousands of innocent customers with elaborate pyramiding schemes may be forced out of business by a tough new law in Suffolk County, but for neighboring Nassau it may be only the beginning.

title: Art in London
description: LONDON EVERY year, on the anniversary of the Battle of Bosworth, a short paragraph appears among other commemorative notices in the columns of The Times of London:

title: Buchanan Knocks Out Malave in 7
description: Ken Buchanan, the former world lightweight champion, overcame a deep out over his left eye to knock out Edwin (Chu Chu) Malave at 1 minute 43 seconds of the seventh round yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum.

title: What's Opened Lately at the Movies?
description: BANG THE DRUM SLOWLY, directed by John Hancock from a screenplay by Mark Harris and starring Robert de Niro, Michael Moriarty and Vincent Gardenia, got 15 favorable reviews (Roger Greenspun, Times; Kathleen Carroll, News; Archer Winsten, Post; Rex Reed, News; Frances Taylor, Newhouse Newspapers; Bernard Drew, Gannett News Service; Leonard Harris, WCBSTV; Gene Shalit, NBC; John Simon, Esquire; Penelope Gilliatt, New Yorker; Judith Crist and Chris Chase, New York; William Wolf, Cue; Hollis Alpert, Saturday Review/World; Richard Schickel, Time), 4 mixed (Andrew Sarris, Village Voice; Jeffrey Lyons, WPIXTV; Paul D. Zimmerman, Newsweek; Stanley Kauffmann, New Republic) and 2 negative (Allan G. Mottus, Women's Wear; Joseph Gelmis, Newsday).

title: The Legacy of a Tennis Pro
description: WAYNE  Tennis  not the pattycake Sunday variety, but the real thing  is the name of the game at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Alex Mayer.

title: Garden State
description: I was stunned recently at a writers' meeting when a political journalist asked me why nobody wrote political novels any more. It's surely impossible to write a novel without taking some kind of political stance, even on hairs in the bathtub. However, this novel really is politicalon however small a scaleand I'm going to save my copy of it to show that some fine art writers do care about urban radicalism. If I wrote a planningboard novel, it would be a dull one. Garden State is not; it's skillful and deceptively easily written and quite a delight.

title: Restoration of Power Helps Foil a Robbery
description: No sooner had Mrs. Anita Troccoli reopened her clothing store in Jackson Heights, Queens, dosed for three days because of the power blackout, than she found herself staring at a holdup man with a 25caliber automatic pistol.

title: Gainesville 8
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla.  The jurors, smiling broadly, and the defendants and their lawyers, trembling with relief, half laughing, half crying were hugging each other in the courtroom. The prosecution team quickly left by a side door in hopes of avoiding reporters.

title: HUSBAND IS GUILTY IN TRIPLE SLAYING
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 1 (AP)Guillermo Aillon, a 34yearold businessman who was honored in 1971 and unemployed a year later, was convicted early today of fatally stabbing his estranged wife and her parents in August, 1972.

title: Man Is Killed by IRT Train
description: A 40yearold Brooklyn man was killed at 11:20 A.M. yesterday when he reportedly jumped in front of a train on the elevated tracks of the northbound IRT Broadway line at the West 207th Street station in the Inwood section, the police said. He was identified tentatively as Kenneth Stitt of 365 East 35th Street. The dead man had $460 in his pockets.

title: Which Card Will Labor Play?
description: If ever there were a year when organized labor might be expected to concentrate on the old Samuel Gompers goal of more, 1973 would be it. The price of almost everything the worker buys has been racing uphill, with food bills climbing fastest of all. Official Government statistics confirm what the wageearner's wife tells him every time she comes home from the supermarket: The cost of living is rising faster than the average paycheck.

title: Volunteers Race the Clock to Aid Heart Victims
description: Rona Cusick, James Persons and Rosemary Sparandera, who live on Staten Island, were unknown to each other a few years ago.

title: A Guitarist Shrugs Off Injury to Hand
description: RUMSONThe young guitarist who strolls from table to table at the Fromagerie here plays in a way that is probably unlike that of any other guitarist: He plucks the strings with the thumb, pinky and ring finger of his right hand instead, of using the first two fingers, as most guitarists do. The change was forced on him when he lost the first joint of both these fingers in an accident when he was 16.

title: Sihanouk Says His Forces Will Attack in Dry Season
description: PEKING, Sept. 1 (Reuters)Prince Norodom Sihanouk took issue tonight with reports that forces loyal to him would open a fullscale assault on Phnom Penh in December with direct military support from North Vietnam.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: HorseMeat Shop Opens in Brooklyn

title: Leisure Is Design of This Club
description: Members of the Bristol Harbor Yacht Club on Canandaigua Lake, N. Y., have found an easy way to get around the timecost factor that distresses so many boat owner on rainy weekends. None of the members owns a boat. Instead, the club owns and maintains six powerboats and a number of sailboats that are rented by the members. The vacht club is a facility of ??ol Harbor Village, a leisure community of 100 residents in the Finger Lakes region.

title: Dog Show Awards
description: AT NEWTON, N. J.

title: John Silleck Fiance of Constance Bergen
description: Mrs. Barbara Pfeil Bergen of Cutchogue, L.I., and Schuyler J. Bergen Jr., of Madison, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Constance Ann Bergen, to John Gordon Wallace Silleck. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney B. Silleck Jr. of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Kimogenor Point, New Suffolk, L.I.

title: NIXON VOW A BOON TO BOLIVIAN TWINS
description: PROVO, Utah, Sept. 1Fifteen years ago when President Nixon, then Vice President, was on a South American tour he stopped at a public health clinic in La Paz, Bolivia, held twin girls in his arms and told their mother that they would have the opportunity to attend a United States university when they grew up.

title: Karen Hoffman Bride of Student
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 1 The Princeton University Chapel was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Karen Elizabeth Hoffman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh C. Hoffman of Lawrenceville, to Peter William Engelmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Engelmann of Belle Mead. The Rev. Dana Fearon performed the Presbyterian ceremony.

title: What's Doing in MEMO CITY
description: INDEPENDENCE DAY FIESTA No more exciting fiesta can be found in this country than the celebration marking Independence Day on Sept. 16 in Mexico City. The fiesta actually gets under way the night before at 11 P.M., when the President of Mexico, Luis Echeverria, reenacts the Grito, or the call to arms, that won Mexico her independence from Spain more than 150 years ago. Standing on the balcony of the National Palace, in the Zocalo, Mexico City's main square since the days of the Aztecs, the President repeats the rallying cry sounded by Mexico's heropriest Father Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla in the town of Dolores on Sept. 15, 1810 Mexicanos, viva Mexicoand the cry echoes and reechoes across the great square as it is taken up by the thousands below. The Grito ceremonies are accompanied by fireworks, singing and dancing, topped off by a spectacular the next day.

title: Giants Recall Hurler
description: SAN FRANCISCO; Sept. 1 (UPI)The San Francisco Giants recalled righthanded pitcher, John D'Acquisto, today from Phoenix of the Pacific Coast League. The Giants said he would pitch the second game of tomorrow's doubleheader against the Atlanta Braves. D'Acquisto posted a 1612 wonlost record at Phoenix.

title: Croton Professor Missing After Storm Capsizes Boat
description: CROTONONHUDSON, N. Y., Sept. 1 (AP)Dr. Dean L. Arlton, a professor of music at Kings College in Briarcliff Manor, N. Y., was missing and presumed drowned in the Hudson River today after his sailboat capsized in a storm last night.

title: Calendar of Motor Sports Events
description: Tomorrow  East Metropolitan Racing Association points races at Lime Rock (Conn.) Park. Registration: 8 A.M.noon; tech: 8:30noon; races: 1:30 P.M.5. Information: Steve Wang, phone (516)2219414.

title: BuyandBust Operation Here Finds Drug Peddlers Wary of New Laws
description: With his distinguished gray hair and commanding presence, the wellbuilt man in the tan windbreaker and plaid pants was a conspicuous figure amid the swirling Saturday night scene in Greenwich Village.

title: Relay Record Broken
description: BERLIN, Sept. 1 (UPI)East Germany's national women's 400meter relay team posted a world record of 42.6 seconds at a national track and field meet in Potsdam today. The foursome of Petra Kandarr, Renate Stecher, Christina Heinich and Doris Selmigkeit ran twotenths of a second faster than the previous standard of 0:42.8 held jointly by the United States and West Germany.

title: Senior Citizen Fete Set in Asbury Park
description: ASBURY PARK  The selection of a queen will climax the State Senior Citizen Pageant at Convention Hall on Sept. 16.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  If, as seems likely, the Watergate affair leads to improvements in such areas as campaign finance and political tactics, so also is the stunning inflation of the first half of 1973 likely to lead to the Government's avoiding one crucial error in economic policy.

title: Witch Doctor Offers Aid To British Soccer Team
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 1 (UPI)England need worry no more about qualifying or even winning the soccer World Cup next year. A Kenyan witch doctor has written to the national team manager, Sir Alf Ramsey, to offer his services to ensure victory.

title: Mrs. Joan L. Jacobson Wed to Surgeon
description: RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Sept. 1Mrs. Joan Lochner Jacobson of Ridgefield was married here at home this afternoon to Dr. Henry Davis Minot, a practicing thoracic and cardiovascular surgeon in Norwalk and Stamford. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Edwin A. Lane, a Unitarian minister.

title: Susanna Rivinus Fiancee
description: Miss Susanna Davis Rivinus, who for the last five years has been on the staff of Newsweek in Paris, will be wed Sept. 22 to Alain Ribault, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jean Ribault of Nantes, France. The engagement has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. F. Markoe Rivinus of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia.

title: Diane Daunoras to Wed
description: NORTH TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 1Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Daunoras have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diane Marie Daunoras, to James Nathan Fry, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Herbert Fry of Philadelphia. The couple, seniors at Cornell University, will be wed next June. The future bride's father is vice president and controller of the North American Philips Corporation.

title: Calendar of Horse Shows
description: Today  Rice Farms, Middle Island Arena, Rocky Point Road, Middle island, L,1. Regular, green, amateurowner, special and junior working hunters; intermediate jumpers, ponies, adult horsemanship, equitation. 9 A.M.

title: Namath's Bombs Sink Saints, 28 to 17
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 1Joe Namath, playing almost a full game, his longest stint of the exhibition season, threw two touchdown bombs covering 73 and 85 yards and another for 58 yards to lead the Jets to a 2817 victory tonight over the New Orleans Saints before 67,434 in Tulane Stadium.

title: Best Seller List
description: This analysis is based on reports obtained from more than 250 bookstores in 110 communities of the United States, The figures in the righthand column do not necessarily represent consecutive appearances.

title: R. A. Smith Fiance of Candace Crawford
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 1Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur Cross 3d of Bronxville and Lake Sunapee, N. H., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Cross's daughter, Miss Candace Curtright Crawford, to Richard Alan Smith, son of Dr. and Mrs. Ronald Perry Smith of Plattsburgh. The wedding is planned for Oct. 20 in the Bronxville Reformed Church.

title: Crime Victims Under Study
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 1 (Reuters) An international symposium on victimologythe study on topics concerning the victims of crime  is to be held in Jerusalem from tomorrow to Thursday. The symposium is cosponsored by the International Society of Criminology and Hebrew University, Tel Aviv and BarIlan Universities ancl the Israeli Government.

title: Gardens
description: ONECOLOR flower gardens, with their subtle combinations of shades, tints and textures brings a sense of cohesiveness to the landscape. Whether done on an extensive scale or merely tucked into a few square feet to an odd corner, the plants bring interest not only to the eye but to the intellect.

title: The IllStarred History Of an Old Subway Tunnel
description: On Sept. 29th, 1907, the car roof caught fire from a short circuit [in the tunnel] ... The noise and flashes above their heads caused some passenger panic and some jumped off the car and ran for the nearest exit. From the official publication of the Electric Railroaders Association.

title: To Dealers In Antiques, Garage Sale Skirts Law
description: WYCKOFFThe 30member North Jersey Antiques Dealers Association has voiced a determination to stop what it describes as thousands of taxdodging, illegal garage sales in North Jersey.

title: Con Edison's Chief in Queens
description: Mel Schwartz moved through the partitioned corridors with grim determination. In one office, he paused to watch the group of shirtsleeved men anxiously discuss a map they had converged upon, while in another he listened intently as a staccato burst of information crackled in over a private radio line.

title: David Hilton to Wed Miss Heather Daly
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 1Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Daly have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Heather Ann Daly, to David Bradley Hilton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Hilton. Both families live in New Canaan.

title: Is Dr. Welby a Menace to Women?
description: DIAGNOSIS: Acute depression specifically among members of the female sex; communicable to millions of weekly television viewers.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES, SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 2, 1973
description: When Joe Paterno, Penn State's football coach, turned down a $1.3 million offer to coach the Boston Patriots last January, he was treated as a returning hero at Penn State. Nittany Lion folk gave a banquet in his honor, complete with gifts and words of praise. He even got the usual trophya new, big car.

title: U.S. Blacks Build New Life in Africa
description: YOFF, Senegal, Aug. 28I wake up to see the sun rising, the fishermen pushing their canoes into the surf and the waves rolling up onto the clean, clear, sandy beach and I must tell myself, Yes, this is meI'm here.

title: Dr. David Zegarelli Engaged To Dr. Elena Caryn Schmidt
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arnold W. Schmidt of Brooklyn have made known the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Elena Caryn Schmidt, to Dr. David J. Zegarelli, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward V. Zegarelli of North Tarrytown, N. Y.

title: A Disputed Punch Mars Foreman's Ring Victory
description: TOKYO, Sept. 1George Foreman, swinging his big fists as if he were chopping down trees, did just what he said he wanted to do today in successfully defending his world heavyweight boxing championship for the first time.

title: Golf Courses in Northeast Are in Worst Condition in 20 Years
description: Golf courses in the northeast area of the United States are in their worst condition in the last 20 years. Varying types of weather since Spring have caused havoc to fairways and greens.

title: Jackson F. Eno Marries Mrs. Strickland
description: SIMSBURY, Conn., Sept. 1 Mrs. Bonnie Dean Maloy Strickland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Maloy of New Hartford, was married here this afternoon to Jackson French Eno, son of Mrs. Ralph Fancher Eno and the late Mr. Eno, at Valley Farm, the home of the bridegroom's mother.

title: INDIANA NOROHERN U. REBUFFED BY COURT
description: GAS CITY, Ind., Sept. 1 Indiana Northern University has been ordered by a state court to admit state school inspectors on Sept. 11 or face cancellation of its fall term.

title: Musicians' Strike Forces City Opera Cancellations
description: The New York City Opera was shut down yesterday by a sudden strike of its union musicians that forced the cancel lation of the day's performances and all future ones until the dispute is resolved.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
Nathaniel Baker Jr. Weds Ruth Barnes
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 1Miss Ruth Natalie Barnes, daughter of Ambassador Nathan Barnes, Li. beria's chief delegate to the United Nations, and Mrs. Barnes, was married here this afternoon to Nathaniel Baker Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Baker of Monrovia, Liberia.

title: Improvements in Transit Sought at Kennedy by '80
description: Air travelers who have faced traffic jams on the way to Kennedy International Airport, as well as shortages of parking space there and difficulties in getting from one terminal to another, may be getting relief, but not right away, according to airport officials.

title: Directors Of Coop Removed By City
description: Contending that we had to do something before the situation became drastic, the city's Housing and Development Administration has removed the 12member tenant board of directors of the Luna Park cooperative apartments in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn.

title: Who Is Wallowing?
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 1Not a single current member of President Nixon's Cabinet or his senior White House stiff testified before the Senate Watergate committee. The highestranking official to appear was Assistant Attorney General Henry Petersen.

title: Music
description: POOR Julius Rudel. He goes through life with the fixed impression that the New York music critics discriminate against him in favor of the Metropolitan Opera. Poor Schuyler Chapin. He goes through life with the fixed impression that the New York music critics discriminate against him in favor of the New York City Opera.

title: Pirate Run In 9th Tops Cubs by 10
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 1 (UPI) Richie Zisk's basesloaded single over a drawnin outfield with one out in the ninth inning gave the Pittsburgh Pirates a 10 victory over the Chicago Cubs today. It put Pittsburgh over the .500 mark for the first time since June 4.

title: New Study Shows How Island Grows
description: JERICHO, L. I.Viewed as a separate entity from the New York's metropolitan area, Long Island presents some striking features.

title: Haynie's 139 Leads Golf By 2 Shots
description: FORT WORTH, Tex., Sept. (AP)Sandra Haynie reeled off a spectacular string of birdies in the closing five holes today and retained the lead after two rounds of the Ladies Professional Golf Association golf classic.

title: State Offers a Guide in Spanish to Its Parks
description: TRENTON  As a convenience for those who speak Spanish, the state's Department, of Environmental Protection has published a Spanish version of its Year 'Round Guide to New Jersey State Forests, Parks, Natural Areas and Historic Sites.

title: Artifacts Obtained From Wreck Sites Of British Frigate
description: KINGSTON, R. I., Sept. 1 (UPI)Oceanographers at the University of Rhode Island have recovered artifacts from the area where two British ships from the Revolutionary War are sunk in Narragansett Bay.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
Lido Hotel Retains Elegance In a Strictly Kosher Setting
description: LIDO BEACH, L. I.  The fabled Lido Hotel, built as Riviera resort close to home for New York socialites in the nineteentwenties, is still welcoming millionaires within its sultry pink stone arms. Originally restricted to gentiles only, it has now come full circle to strictly kosher cuisine.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Sportswear, the exciting, bestselling category of women's apparel that seemed to intrigue the customers when everything else failed, may now be coming in for its share of headaches.

title: Music
description: Alaina Reed, who was the first performer at Reno Sweeney when that supper club opened last December, has just broken the ice for still another new supper club.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: WESTERN industrial nations are experiencing their greatest economic boom in more than two decades. Not since 1951, when the growth rate reached 7.5 per cent, has there been anything like it. By comparison, the growth rate averaged only 5 per cent a year in the decade of the sixties.

title: Child Ban Survives In Housing For Aging
description: DOVER TOWNSHIP  A suit to enforce age restrictions at a housing development for the elderly, litigation that had been watched closely by virtually every growing municipality in New Jersey, has been settled in favor of the project But the outofcourt settlement failed to set a precedent, and thus left unresolved important questions that could affect the future development of many of the state's localities.

title: BOYCOTTING HERE TRIMS FOOD COSTS
description: Consumer resistance to high prices for meat and vegetables caused some of the prices to drop again last week even as metropolitanarea shoppers were stocking up for the Labor Day weekend, according to state market reporters.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Yankees are in Detroit for night games against the Tigers tomorrow and Tuesday. Then they come home for eight days at Yankee Stadium before beginning a twoweek road trip. The Milwaukee Brewers will be at the Stadium Thursday and Friday at 7:30 P.M. and Saturday at 2.

title: Numismatics
description: IN the largest outpouring of votes following one of the most strenuously (and at times bitterly) contested campaigns in its history, the American Numismatic Association elected Virginia (Mrs. John H.) Cut. ver of Thiensville, Wis., to a twoyear term as president. She is the first woman president of the 85yearold A.N.A.

title: Letters
description: The unions are coming, (by Henry P. Leifermann, Aug. 5) was terribly prejudiced and in some cases inaccurate.

title: The Subcontinent
description: KARACHI  The political impasse on the subcontinent was finally broken last week, as India and Pakistan reached an agreement under which more than 90,000 Pakistani prisoners of war and civilian internees would return home from Indian camps.

title: Threat of Teacher Strikes Seen Likely at 143 Districts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI)  Teachers in 143 school districts are threatening to strike this fall  most of them for higher wages  according to the National Education Association.

title: Audits Progressing On Flood's Losses
description: SOUTH PLAINFIELD Federal and state officials expect to complete this week a massive audit of the property losses stemming from the floods that swept this and other communities in Middlesex, Somerset, Essex and Union Counties last month.

title: Susan Claire Philbrick Is a Bride
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Sept. 1In the Greenville Community Reformed Church here this afternoon, Miss Susan Claire Philbrick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Robert Philbrick, was married to Peter Mark Wissel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Edward Wissel. The Rev. Dr. Bernard Brunsting performed the ceremony.

title: RENEWAL AGENCY DYING IN WHEELING!
description: WHEELING, W. Va., Sept. 1  The first urban renewal authority to be abolished by a referendum while still in operation is being dismantled here under the direction of a District Court judge.

title: Rurals Fighting City Slickers to Keep Hambletonian
description: DU QUOIN, Ill.Out here in the farmlands 100 miles southeast of St. Louis, where the Big Muddy River crosses the Illinois Central tracks near a town named Red Bud, rural America is fighting the city slickers for a strange prizea horse race.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE PRIME RATE ROSE to 9 per cent at several major banks.... The Federal Home Loan Bank Board raised to 10 per cent of savings and loan associations' deposits the limit on certificates of deposit over $100,000 they may offer without an interest ceiling. The intention is to check the decline in the availability of home mortgage money.... Commercial industrial loans at large New York City banks dropped $543million in the week ended Wednesday, the biggest decline in 3 years, probably because of the higher interest rates. However, business loans nationally increased $26million over the preceding week.

title: Buffer Zone Established By A.T.&T. In Jersey
description: BASKING RIDGE, N. J.Three years ago a lawyer from nearby Morristown approached several home owners in this rural community in northeast Somerset County seeking to buy their properties for an undisclosed client.

title: Stamps
description: THE incessant beat of the drum, the pounding hoofbeats of a galloping horse. the demanding ringing of church bellsthese were the sounds of the Revolutionary tocsin summoning the Colonials to take up arms against the British.

title: Atoms Soon to Be AllAmerican Team
The Suzuki Concept
description: Someday, one likes to think, archeologists searching in the ruins of Muscatine, Iowa, are likely to be puzzled by the discovery of hundreds of tiny violins. But the solution to the puzzle is likely to puzzle them even more.

title: OFFICIAL ON AGING WARNS REST HOMES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) Arthur S. Flemming, the new Commissioner on Aging, this week warned the operators of 7,000 federally subsidized nursing homes that the Administration still means business in carrying out President Nixon's 1971 pledge to improve nursing home care.

title: 2 Hurt in Car Crash That Blocks Traffic On L.I. Expressway
description: Two offduty firemen were seriously injured last evening in a fivecar crash that blocked all traffic on the Long Island Expressway in Queens for about an hour.

title: Bridge
description: In the world of brige as in other things, first one must learn the taboos and later learn when to break them. The beginner learns some simple nevers, and then unlearns them fairly quickly. When he reaches an intermediate stage, he acquires a new collection of nevers which have rather more validity.

title: BRITAIN DEBATING HER MISSILE SUBS
description: LONDON, Sept. 1  The nagging question of whether Britain should move to modernize her aging arsenal of submarinebased missiles has come alive with a parliamentary report suggesting that the country do nothing for the time being.

title: '73 Cranberry Crop Seen Topping '72's
description: TRENTONThe 1973 New Jersey cranberry crop is expected to be 10 per cent above last year's, according to Secretary of Agriculture Phillip Alampi.

title: Jarrett L. Hathaway Dies at 67; A Research Engineer for N.B.C.
description: MANHASSET, L.I., Sept. 1Jarrett Lewis Hathaway, a retired research and development engineer for the National Broadcasting Company who held 37 American and many foreign broadcasting patents, died Thursday in North Shore ?? tal. He was 67 years old and lived at 52 Stonehenge Road.

title: Orioles Chase Dobson, Beat Yanks, 106
description: Possibly embarrassed over the 5.2 loss inflicted on them by the New York Yankees in their series' opener a night earlier, the firstplace Baltimore Orioles lost little time yesterday in showing they had no intention of suffering a similar indignity.

title: 45 Une de Mai Captures $30,000 Challenge Trot
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 1In a race that chalkplayers will remember with an inward glow, Une de Mai of France went outside, inside and sideways tonight to vindicate herself and capture the $30,000 Challenge Match at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: Arthur Daley
description: I'm very proud of my young son, said. Kyle Rote of Kyle Rote Jr. Not only do I love him as a son, but I like him as a person.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: New York's diamond street, West 47th Street, has breached Fifth Avenue.

title: African Leaders Mark Zambia Railway Work
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Sept. 1The leaders of three African nations gathered at the ZambianTanzanian border this week to mark the completion of the first half of the railroad that will link landlocked Zambia with the East African port of DaresSalaam.

title: TEACHERS OF INDIANS TO GET NEW COURSE
description: LAS CRUCES, N. M., Sept. 1  Upper classmen at New Mexico State University's Colloge of Education who plan to teach Indian children will be given a new course of study on the Indian designed to prepare them to understand better the cultural and educational needs of their students.

title: Subway Accident Smoke, HeatNo Panic
description: I was in the cab, and I heard this loud noise  it sounded like a bomb. Then I heard screaming from the people, so I put the train into emergency  just releasing the handle. That's the quickest way to stop the train.

title: Chilean Official Urges Curb on Big Corporations
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 27The Chilean delegate to a United Nations panel that will study the influence of multinational corporations says action must be taken on the international, national and regional level to curb their growing and uncontrolled power.

title: 61 Chance Triumphs In Stakes
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1 (AP)  Determined King, a maiden who had finished second five times in five starts, collared the leaders with about 40 yards to go to win the $100,000 Kindergarten Stakes by a neck today at Liberty Bell Park.

title: Exhibition of Pound Letters
description: WEST LONG BRANCH A dozen highly characteristic letters by Ezra Pound to and concerning his first sweetheart will go on view Wednesday at the Murry and Leonie Guggenheim Library at Monmouth College.

title: The enemy was the present, the future was hope
description: In his Experiment in Autobiography, N G. Wells revealed that two years before he was born his mother had lost a favorite child, her daughter Frances. From this date, he thought, she had grown embittered, venting her suppressed resentment on him and opening an unhappy fissure in his character, one half of which was generous and sympathetic, the other nervously irritable.

title: Calendar of Dog Shows
description: Rockland County allbreed and obedience, Spring Valley High School, Route 59, Spring Valley, N. Y. 1,200 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: Government by Outrage
description: WASHINGTONPersonalities keep dominating the news here in the blazing heat of Washington. What's going on between President Nixon and Vice President Agnew? How are they going to deal with one another and with these independent characters like Judge Sirica, Attorney General Elliot Richardson, and Senator Sam Ervin, who keep asking awkward questions?

title: NIXON AND AGNEW MEET TWO HOURS ON KICKBACK CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1President Nixon and Vice President Agnew met alone for two hours today, discussing the Federal investigations of allegations that Mr. Agnew had received kickbacks from Maryland contractors.

title: Late Listings for Today's TV
description: Right Now: Jack M. Sable, State Commissioner of Human Rights; Mario Amaya, director of New York Cultural Center, Channel 9, 9:30 A.M.

title: Terry Finke Bride of James K. Dreyfus
description: Miss Terry Ann Finke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Finke of Sands Point, L. I., was married here last evening to James Kent Dreyfus, son of Mrs. William J. Hahn of Port Washington, L. I., and the late Charles M. Dreyfus. Rabbi Martin Rozenberg performed the ceremony in the Terrace Room at the Plaza.

title: Mazzuto to Lafayette
description: EASTON, Pa., Sept. 1Richard Mazzuto, sports information director at Trinity College, has been named to the same post at Lafayette College. He succeeds Tom Bates, who recently was appointed to a similar position at the United States Naval Academy.

title: Scheckter's Auto Crashes in Drill
description: MT. POCONO, Pa., Sept 1 (UPI)Jody Scheckter, his right hand swollen from the effects of a bee sting, lost control of his car today and crashed into a retaining wall at Pocono International Raceway, while practicing for the Labor Day L&M race that could prove the clincher in the series for the South African driving ace.

title: Foreign Investment in U.S Properties Growing
description: The Japanese are doing it. The British are doing it. The Arabs and Belgians and Germans are doing itbuying American real estate.

title: Directly to Broadway, Without a Tryout
description: A new show opened in midtown Manhattan last Monday starring 25 directors who did a little acting, a little fancy footwork and a little whistling. They received generous reviews from a tough audience: pedestrians and motorists in New York's weekday traffic.

title: 13 Die in Ethiopian Mishap
description: ASMARA, Ethiopia, Sept. 1. (Reuters)  Thirteen people were killed and 55 seriously injured when a bus crashed into a 270foot ravine near here, the Ethiopian news agency reported today.

title: A Trial Program Helps Local Projects
description: A mental health clinic for teenagers, the cleanup of more than 350 vacant lots and the illumination of a popular park are some of the key projects planned in Brooklyn and Queens under an experimental program in which local government offices can spend limited amounts of capital funds for programs of their own choosing.

title: College Football Will Begin Saturday
description: With five more schools added to the list of major colleges, 36 new head coaches among the 126 major teams and everything else pretty much the same, college football will kick off its 105th season next weekend with 23 games.

title: Part of Route 1 to Be Shut
description: The New Jersey Department of Transportation said yesterday that Route 1 in Jersey City would be, closed between 10 P.M. and a A.M. for two weeks, starting Tuesday, so that the walls of the depressed roadway leading to the Holland Tunnel could be cleaned and painted to seal the walls and aid illumination. The area extends from the Tonnelle Avenue circle to Hoboken Avenue in Jersey City.

title: 5 Doomed in Sierra Leone
description: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, Sept. 1 (Agence FrancePresse) Five men in their early 20's have been sentenced to be hanged for killing a 70yearold Freetown innkeeper on June 17 and stealing his wrist watch, a camera, a tape recorder and money.

title: Guaranteed Income
description: The debate over the idea of providing American families with a guaranteed minimum income has reached varying levels of subtlety and sophistication. But in any discussion there shortly emerges the real reason why none of the proposals has so far gained acceptance with the majority of the people who would have to pay the bill: The pervasive belief that once people are guaranteed the bare essentials, they will simply stop working; that the cost of the program would be enormous; and that the work ethic  political shorthand that the word sometimes is  would be eroded beyond redemption.

title: Nassau WorkRelease Program for Narcotics Addicts in Jail Gets New Aid
description: MINEOLA, L.I.New Federal funding has been awarded for a program in which Nassau County Jail inmates with a history of heroin addiction are allowed to go to jobs outside the jail after having been administered chemicals that block the effects of heroin. The chemicals, cyclazocine or naltrexone, make it impossible for former addicts to achieve the high given by heroin.

title: THOUSANDS FLEE HEAT WAVE HERE
description: Wilting New Yorkers flocked to parks, pools and beaches yesterday as temperatures here soared into the 90's for the fifth straight day. Showers brought unexpected relief from the heat in the late afternoon.

title: Coffee at the Treasury: Was 16c, Now a Nickel
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP)The old nickel cup of coffee returned this week to the Treasury Department cafeteria, with a little help from Phase 4.

title: SUBURBS' SCHOOLS, HIT BY INFLATION, OPEN THIS WEEK
description: Public schools in the suburbs throughout the New York metropolitan area will reopen this week with the perennial problem of money, accentuated this fall by the nation's record rate of inflation.

title: News of Stage
description: Robert Lansing has been set to star with Elizabeth Owens and James Mitchell in the Roundabout Theater Company's production of August Strindberg's The Father, which opens the company's eighth subscription season on Oct. 10.

title: Photographer Hurt
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sept. 1 (AP)Sou Vichetr, a 20yearold Cambodian photographer covering fighting for The Associated Press, was wounded today, by a bullet, for the second time in less than four months.

title: Artsthe One Stable Currency
description: ROCHESTERArt for art's sake is not a popular slogan in the twentieth century. The combination of snobs at the one extreme and philistines at the other has done its work well, and nearly persuaded us to accept almost unconsciously the idea that an assertion of importance about a particular art form or work of art is somehow elitist and undemocratic.

title: Round One
description: WASHINGTONIn the history of the Republic, disputes between Presidents and Congress and the courts have been settled by compromise, by negotiation, sometimes by bluff but more often by the process of accommodation that is the essence of political continuity and stability.

title: Shelter for Deserted Animals Is Trying to Keep the Wolf From Its Door
description: TOMS RIVERPatrick was found on Route 18 with a concussion, after having been run over by a car. Little Ginger was found blind. Danny, Baby Boy, was found abandoned and starving in a housing project in nearby Lakewood.

title: Rep Mills Convalescing
