description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 1 (AP)Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Arkansas Democrat, was in good condition today following an operation to remove a ruptured spinal disk, a Baptist Medical Center spokesman said. Dr. Thomas M. Fletcher said the patient probably would not be able to walk until Tuesday. Mr. Mills, head of the House Ways and Means Committee, will remain hospitalized at least 10 days.

title: 2 Special Waterfowl Hunting Seasons Set by State for L.I.
description: ALBANYThe State Department of Environmental Conservation announced last week that the duck and goose hunting season for Long Island will open on Nov. 19. The chick season will end 45 days later on Jan. 2 and the goose season 60 days later on Jan. 20.

title: Violent, criminal, near bankruptcy, ungovernable, yet...
description: LONDON. In one recent week a lodger in a small terraced house in Worcester, England, was charged with impaling two baby girls and one baby boy on the spikes of iron railings. A 16yearold boy was sentenced for stripping, raping and kicking to death an 80yearold woman while robbing her of 7 pence. An oldage pensioner in a middleclass London suburb was battered to death by two adolescents, infuriated because he would not part with the few shillings that he possessed. Half a million pounds of platinum and diamonds was coolly stolen from Heathrow Airport at the point of a gunfortunately unused. There was the usual weekly crop of wage snatches and bank robberies. How easy it would be to devote an issue of this magazine to the muggings, beatings, rapes and slayings that are now a weekly feature of life in B.O.A.C. England, with its leafy lanes, thatched cottages, turreted spires and that cosy, idyllic London that a few restless expatriate Americans have recently fled to, like a clutch of chattering magpies, soon doubtless to take off again. They have found in London the same barred windows, double locks and burglar alarms that they required back home.

title: Headliners
description: Racing the deadline before New York's tough new antinarcotics law went into effect yesterday, state and city authorities made simultaneous efforts to get judges into the courtrooms and keep addicts out of them. The first was accomplished Monday when Governor Rockefeller appointed 16 judges, the first of 68 special Court of Claims judges who will handle an expected increase in drug trials. The new law imposes stiff mandatory sentences, primarily for the sale and possession of hard drugs, and many more defendants are expected to demand trials. New York City, meanwhile, conducted a threeday drive to enlist addicts in the city's narcotics treatment programs before the law went into effect. The effort, utilizing mobile vans, recruited only a relative handful of addicts. There are an estimated 150,000 addicts in the city, 57,000 of them already in the city's treatment programs.

title: Health Council Picks Chief
description: Edward H. Van Ness, executive secretary of the New York State Health Planning Commission, had been named execu tive director of the National Health Council, effective Oct. 1. He will succeed Peter G. Meek, who for the last 12 years headed the voluntary agency, which is made up of members of 70 agencies and groups interested in improving health and health care.

title: THOUSANDS FLEE HEAT WAVE HERE
description: Wilting New Yorkers flocked to parks, pools and beaches yesterday as temperatures here soared into the 90's for the fifth straight day. Showers brought unexpected relief from the heat in the late afternoon.

title: Edsel Finally Succeeds: Fords Celebrate First Male to Graduate From College
description: BOSTON  Edsel Bryant Ford 2d's sister Anne Ford Uzielli was graduated from Briarcliff, and he has female cousins who received degrees from Radcliffe or some place like that and Yale.BOSTON  Edsel Bryant Ford 2d's sister Anne Ford Uzielli was graduated from Briarcliff, and he has female cousins who received degrees from Radcliffe or some place like that and Yale. But no matter. (The Board of Trustees of the college voted unanimously to confer on Ford a newly created degree  Bachelor of Cars) and detailed the particulars (black tie and sneakers). And at 9:30 P.M., the guests, mostly young college friends from the Boston area, were ?? protect the party from crashers, challenged Edsel when he arrived. But I'm the guest of honor, Edsel said jovially. No, he isn't, shouted some of his best friends.

title: Career Problems
description: A recent graduate of Barnard College, in American Studies, is working as an assistant buyer for Bamberger's department store. Another, a sociology major, is an office receptionist in Virginia, and an art history major is working as an ails in a New York City law office.

title: Price Trends
description: WASHINGTON  If the consumer as borrower faced problems from the rising interest rates, there was even worse news for the consumer as purchaser. Two significant economic indicators last week confirmed what some officials had forecastthat the cost of food and manufactured products would be heading up sharply.

title: Owen Robert Floody Marries Miss Catherine Doten Lewis
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Sept. 1 The Packer Memorial Chapel on the campus of Lehigh University was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Catherine Doten Lewis, daughter of Dr. W. Deming Lewis, president of Lehigh, and the late Mrs. Maria Chapman Lewis, to Owen Robert Floody, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert J. Floody of Wayne, N. J.

title: We Need a National Tourism Agency
description: I HAVE traveled all say life. I first went abroad in 1906 and recently completed my 58th transAtlantic trip by air. Add to that a couple of hundred trips across this continent by air and rail and I guess you'd say I'm an experienced traveler.

title: Fund Will Aid Minorities
description: NEWARK  A foundation established by students, and named in memory of a black business leader, is conducting a campaign to raise scholarship funds for minority students at the Rutgers Graduate School of Business Administration.

title: Letter Bombs
description: LONDONFor two weeks now, Londoners have found themselves on the receiving end of bombs and the threats of bombs that have become part of everyday life in Northern Ireland. It has all been happening here on a much smaller scale, but some of the sights and sounds of disruption are evident the evacuation of hotels, stores, theaters and restaurants, the scream of fire engines and ambulances, the closing of railway stations, the suspicious glance at the deserted shopping bag.

title: SOVIET DISSIDENTS GET MILD TERMS
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 1  Two Soviet dissidents who had turned state's evidence today were given the expected mild sentence of three years of confinement followed by another three years of enforced residence in a remote part of the country.

title: Kitchen conservation
description: 1. Icecream maker churns up four quarts of dessert. Bridge Co., $14.95. You do the cranking.

title: Building That U.S. Is Giving To India Will Become Hotel
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 1 (AP)A multimilliondollar apartment complex that the United States Government is turning over to India next month will be converted into a Governmentmanaged hotel, officials announced this week.

title: Nixon's Homes
description: LAGUNA BEACH  Although he has turned the phrase perfectly clear into a national clich, President Nixon continues to offer explanations that to many others seem to make clear only the need for further explanations.

title: Realization Is Captured By Amen II
description: Packing high weight of 128 pounds with no difficulty whatever, the DeeBob Stable's Frenchbred Amen II won the $57,650 Lawrence Realization at Belmont Park yesterday. A field of 10 competed in the 81st running of the stakes for 3yearolds, and Amen II was 5 lengths ahead of his nearest rival at the conclusion.

title: Leslie E. Blake Wed to Ken Kotiza
description: WEBSTER GROVES, Mo., Sept. 1In Mary Queen of Peace Roman Catholic Church here this evening, Miss Leslie Eleanor Blake, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman P. Blake of London and Greenwich, Conn., was married to Ken Edward Kotiza, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Kotiza of St. Louis. The ecumenical ceremony was performed by Msgr. Joseph M. O'Toole and the Rev. Gary Myers, a Presbyterian minister.

title: Acrostic puzzle
description: Guess the words defined below and write them over their numbered dashes. Then transfer each letter to the correspondingly numbered square in the pattern. Black squares indicate word endings. The filled pattern will contain a quotation reading from left to right. The first letters of the guessed words will form an acrostic giving author's name and title of work.

title: West Berlin Insurance
description: A team of American diplomats crossed the wall into East Berlin last week to discuss technical arrangements for a United States embassy in the socalled German Democratic Republic. Diplomatic talks will begin in Washington this month, with formal relations due to be established after the admission of both East and West Germany to United Nations membership this fall.

title: Social Announcements
description: BaerGabrilove

title: U.S. Will Sell Portion Of an Island Off Maine
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. (AP)The General Services Administration is offering for sale a portion of the Eagle Island light station in Hancock County, Me.

title: Paula L. Martin Becomes Bride
description: ROSSLYN FARMS, Pa., Sept. 1The marriage of Miss Paula Lee Martin to Frank James Coyle Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Coyle of Greenwich, Conn., took place here this afternoon at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Derek Martin, parents of the bride.

title: News Summary and Index
description: InternationalAt least 35 persons, most of them foreign tourists, wire killed and many were missing in a fire that turned the upper stories of a Copenhagen hotel into an inferno. More than 12 hours after the fire was put out, rescuers were still digging for bodies in the burnedout shell of the Hafnia, a 74yearold family hotel and tourist landmark near Town Hall Square. [Page 1, Columns 34.]

title: Details of Lin Piao's Plot to Kill Mao Given in Peking Report by Burchett
description: A detailed account of Defense Minister Lin Piao's plot to assassinate Chairman Mao Tsetung has been written by Wilfred Burchett, the leftwing Australian journalist, in a dispatch from Peking based on a report on the case prepared for presentation at the recently conchided 10th Congress of the Chinese Communist party.

title: Housing Is Short at Stony Brook; Volume of Requests Unexpected
description: STONY BROOK, L.I., Sept. 1 The State University Center here is experiencing a housing shortage for the first time in three years, as more students than expected requested a place to live on campus.

title: The golden apple
description: Lost innocence, a fairly familiar theme days, has struck most sports fans in recent years, but none so forcibly as the baseball fan, who ably had the most fully developed romantic to lose.

title: Mariano Tavares Weds Elizabeth Blaine White
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. L, Sept. 1.Miss Elizabeth Blaine White, daughter of Mrs. Frederick John Leary Jr. of Locust Valley and of Gardiner Winslow White of Atlantis, Fla., was married here this afternoon to Mariano Antonio das Neves Pita Tavares, son of Dr. and Mrs. Angelo Neves Tavares of Lisbon and Redondo, Portugal.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Milo March, the private eye in BORN TO BE HANGED by M. E. Chaber (Holt, Rinehart & Winston, $4.95), gets $300 a day, plus expenses, plus one per cent of what he saves the insurance company to which he is under contract. Michael Saxon, the private eye in William D. Blankenshiip's THE PROGRAMMED MAN (Walker, $5.95), gets 3500 a day  with a minimum guarantee of five days' work. March is more successful than most of his current counterpartswho support their miserable lives on $50 or even $25 a day. But Saxon? He is the most expensive private eye in the literature, more expensive even than Nero Wolfe.

title: Newsprint Shortage Likely to Continue for Months
description: Newspapers caught in a newsprint squeeze aggravated by rail and mill strikes in Canada face a tightened market over the long term because of a growing demand and a limited papermaking capacity, according to industry officials.

title: Six Greenwich Legislators Are Sued for Blocking Downtown Office Complex
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 1 A developer filed a $4.1million lawsuit this week against six members of the town government for opposing the construction of a threebuilding office complex in the center of downtown Greenwich.

title: Barbara Rettig And a Student Plan Wedding
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 1Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. Rettig of Bronxville and Brookfield, Conn., and of Naples, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Allene Rettig, to Joseph Vincent McKee 3d. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. McKee Jr. of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Laurie Grenley Will Be Bride Of John R. Hallen in October
description: TACOMA, Wash., Sept. 1 The engagement of Miss Laurie EnidPolk Grenley, a teacher at the NightingaleBamford School in New York, to John R. Hallen, a corporate bond trader with Weeden & Co., Inc., New York, has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Philip Grenley, parents of the future bride. Mr. Hallen Is the son of Rudolph O. Hallen of Worcester, Mass., and Boca Raton, Fla., and the late Mrs. Hallen.

title: Wendy E. Marshall Is Married On L.I. to James Duncan Whyte
description: MILL NECK, L.I., Sept. 1Miss Wendy Elizabeth Marshall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Lyon Marshall Jr. of Mill Neck, was married this evening to James Duncan Whyte, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Wood Whyte of Locust Valley. The candlelight ceremony was performed in St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church by the Rev. Howard M. Lowell, the rector. A small reception was held at Woodsong, the Marshall home.

title: Dance
description: ATHOUGH Britain's Royal Ballet clearly belongs to London, a little of it is still locked up in New York. At least New Yorkers are apt to feel quite possessive about it. After all, since the Royal first danced in New York in 1949, it has appeared there a great deal and has become something almost like a resident company.

title: N.B.C. Deadline Extended
description: A Wednesday strike deadline set by 1,350 employes of the National Broadcasting Company has been extended one week, a spokesman for the National Association of Broadcast Employes and Technicians announced yesterday.

title: '73 Tax Forms to Contain Only a Few Minor Changes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) Taxpayers will find little change in their 1973 income tax forms, Internal Revenue Service Commissioner Donald C. Alexander said this week.

title: MARY WITENBERG, 53, TEACHERTHERAPIST
description: Mrs. Mary Jane Hoffman Witenberg, a teachertherapist known for her work with emotionally disturbed children, died Thursday of a heart attack at Truro, Mass., while on vacation. She was 53 years old and lived at 119 East 71st Street.

title: Thesis: in times of crisis what people believe is true is more crucial than what is true
description: The French Revolution of 1789 was inaugurated by the Royal convocation of the Estates General and was soon propelled by the aggressiveness of the elites gathered at Versailles. It was consummated by a massive insurrection of peasants and townspeople spurred by rumors of events at Versailles and Paris. This spectacular passage of initiative from the summit of society to its base within five months, and the subsequent brushfire multiplication of the peasant revolt, spread by waves of collective panic, puzzled contemporaries and generations of subsequent historians. These are the themes of this historical masterpiece, now available in English 40 years after its publication in France. It has proven almost inexhaustible in its richness.

title: Murder most squalid
description: On a Saturday night in March, 1963 two Los Angeles policemen (Hollywood Division) were kidnapped by a pair of unlikely armed robbers and driven to a remote onion field, where one of the policemen was shot in the mouth. For a few whitehot seconds the three watched him being lifted by the fireball and slammed down on his back, eyes open, watching the stars, moaning quietly... He probably never saw the shadow in the leather jacket looming over him, and never really felt the four bullets flaming down into his chest.

title: Art
description: THE tides of life seldom cast me up on the shores of Hartford, Conn., these days when it is most often seen, if at all, as a kind of mirage on the road to Boston. If the same is true of you, you could do worse than to go out of your way to visit the city before Oct. 14but after Sept. 5. On the latter date the Wadsworth Atheneum, one of this country's most rewarding art museums, will be open again after summer closure, although a leakyroof problem might make a couple of galleries inaccessible. And until Oct. 14 you get a bonus in the form of 100 Master Drawings from New England Private Collections, a loan exhibition that I was lucky enough to see last week.

title: The State's Tidal Wetlands Act Goes Into Effect
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 1The Tidal Wetlands Act, passed by the 1973 session of the Legislature to protect and preserve the state's wetlands, became effective today.

title: A Bill to End Rail Strike Is Approved in Canada
description: OTTAWA, Sept, 1  The Canadian Parliament, in a special session that lasted most of the night, enacted emergency legislation at dawn today ordering an end to the ninedayold nationwide railroad strike.

title: Lightning Hits Choir's Plane
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. (AP)A Boeing 747 carrying 405 members and relatives of the Mormon Tabernacle Choir was struck by lightning today

title: Traviata' for Casual Operagoers
description: There was nothing about the New York City Opera's performance of Verdi's La Traviata on Friday night to suggest that the continuance of the company's fall season at the New York State Theater was in jeopardy and that it would be interrupted for an indefinite period following the death of Violetta in Alfredo's arms.

title: A Psychiatric Detective Story of Infinite Skill
description: LONDON A TRUE myth is a true bind. All the facts are in, and there is no way out. Oedipus, an honorable man, can do whatever he likes to avoid fulfilling the prophecy that he will kill his father and marry his mother, but he will kill his father and marry his mother. We give assent to the unresolvable, see that it is perfectly proportioned, perfectly just, perfectly terrifying.

title: Miss Kathryn Michele Ramage Wed to John Skelton Hutcheson
description: EGGERTSVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 1  Miss Kathryn Michele Ramage, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert William Ramage of Snyder, was married here at noon today to John Skelton Hutcheson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold H. Hutcheson of New Canaan, Conn.

title: Return to West Africa Isn't New For Blacks From the Americas
description: YOFF, Senegal, Aug. 28The return to Africa, and especially to West Africa, is not altogether new for blacks in the Western Hemisphere.

title: Herman Tries Calgary
description: CALGARY, Sept. 1 (Canadian Press ) Mark Herman, 24 years old, a tight end from the New York Giants, has come to Calgary for a fiveday trial with the Stampeders, the Western Football Conference club said today.

title: Great Falls Festival Points Up Historic Site
description: PATERSON  With nothing below but a 70foot cataract, Karl Wallenda will cross the Great Falls of the Passaic on a tightrope tonight and tomorrow at 7 and 9 o'clock.

title: Unbeaten Giants Rout Eagles, 4221, for 5th in Row
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 1 The New York Giants were almost as hot as the 95degree weather in whipping the Philadelphia Eagles, 4221, today for their fifth straight preseason victory.

title: Two Titles on the Line At Pocono
description: The championships for two roadracing series may well be settled tomorrow in a doubleheader at Pocono International Raceway in Pennsylvania. Jody Scheckter, the 23yearold South African whiz distinguished by his flamboyant, sideways driving style, is in position to clinch the L&M Championship for the drivers of Formula 5000 cars. Berth Roos of Sweden, winner of three of the first five races in the VW Gold Cup for Formula Super Vee drivers, could pick up enough points to make him just about unreachable in the three races after Pocono.

title: Summer Remedial Plan Becomes YearRound
description: A remedial reading and arithmetic program for public school children, that had to be taught on a sidewalk in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn this past summer when more than four times the anticipated number registered for the course, has turned out so well that it will be continued on yearround basis, and will be enlarged to include high school students attending early and late sessions while operating on an annual budget of $37,000.

title: Council Redistricting Hearings to Start Sept. 10
description: The City Council will hold public hearings on reapportionment on Sept. 10, 12 and 14 at City Hall as the Council tries for a third time to formulate a plan satisfactory to Mayor Lindsay.

title: Victor Rubell Fiance of Pamela Johnson
description: MILFORD, Conn., Sept. 1 Mrs. Vernon R. Johnson has announced the engagemeat of her daughter, Miss Pamela Knight Johnson of Norwalk, to Victor Joseph Rubell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Rubell of Stamford.

title: CITY NOTES GAINS IN V.D. DETECTION
description: The reported gonorrhea rate in the city continues to rise, and while that may seem like it grim fact, public health officials are actually pleased by it because it is largely the result of better reporting, brought about by new approaches to finding the victims of America's most common communicable disease other than the cold.

title: RHODESIANS HEAR THE CALL TO ARMS
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 1 (Reuters)  Middle aged Rhodesiansfrom graying company executives to carpenters, plumbers and farmers  are donning army uniforms in the fight against African guerrila insurgents.

title: The Real Thief
description: Gawain, the hero of William Steig's new book, is not the nephew of King Arthur although he is worthy of the position. Gawain is a goose. A real whitefeathered one, proud and upstanding. He is devoted to his architectural career, but summoned by the King he loves, he takes a job guarding the royal treasure. Ruby by ruby, ducat by ducat, that treasure begins to disappear. A disbelieving Gawain is tried and found guilty. I once loved you, he protests to his former friends and present judges. But now I HATE each and every living one of you. . . for seeing evil in me that is not there. And he flies out the courtroom window, across Lake Superb and away. At this point we meet the real thief. He is Derek, a mouse in a business suit. Finding a chink in the treasury wall and seduced by the bright contents, he has simply taken that which he admired to dress his poor home. At Gawain's trial Derek decides to confess but does not. The struggles of is conscience, his confession to Gawain and their triumphant return to apologies, architecture, peace and harmony are the rest of the story. No one ever learns the identity of the real thief. They must never know who did it, Gawain always wonder . . . they deserve at least that for their lack of faith.

title: Ellen Riese Betrothed to Robert Grimes
description: KINGS POINT, L. I., Sept. 1 Mr. and Mrs. Irving Riese have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Riese, to Robert S. Grimes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Grimes of New York. The couple plan to be wed on Oct. 27.

title: Point of View
description: The annual cost of housing welfare recipients in New York City is now approximately half a billion dollars, or onethird of the city's welfare budget. With a bill that size, one would expect that the city has a welldeveloped approach to the whole question of housing for publicassistance recipients. Nothing could be further from the truth.

title: A Composer Looks East
description: EARLIER this summer I studied Balinese GameIan with I Nyoman Sumandhi, a Balinese musician in residence at the American Society for Eastern Arts Summer Program at the University of Washington, in Seattle. During the summep of 1970, I studied African drumming with Gideon Alorworye, a master drummer of the Ewe tribe in residence with the Ghana Dance Ensemble at the Institute of African Studies, in Accra. I studied Balinese and African music because I love them, and also because I believe that nonWestern music is presently the single most important source of new ideas for Western composers and musicians.

title: Greenport Stakes Future on New Project
description: GREENPORT, L. I.  In one comprehensive project, this preRevolutionary War fishing village is attacking problems of substandard housing and chronic high unemployment that threaten its future.

title: The Absolute Bourgeois
description: In the period of uncertainty following the 1848 Revolution, Realism became the intellectual issue of the day in Paris. The tensions persisting throughout the century between politics and art, high and popular culture, urban fantasies and provincial realities, public and private painting all came to the fore, most notably in the confrontations over Courbet's pictures at the 1851 Salon. The social history of 19thcentury painting has up to now been bedeviled by simplistic critical theories, and has produced few studies that really matter. This book (which the publishers have unnecessarily split into two thin volumes) on the period by Timothy Clark, an English art historian at the Camberwell School of Art, London, may indicate that this situation is about to change. He is a critic committed to the left, and a very good one for a change, acute on theoretical problems and exceptionally knowledgeable. Luckily for us, he is also a delightful writer who evidently loves painting, a subtle and witty reader of texts and pictures, a critic both daring and modest.

title: Flying the Hammer and Sickle From New York to Leningrad On the Good Ship Lermontov
description: SHE's a socialist ship. The trip won't be luxurious, friends warned me. You won't like it; stick to the Italian Line, others said. Not knowing quite what to expect was, to my mind, part of the attraction of sailing aboard the Soviet Union's brand new 19,000ton Mikhail Lermontov, a vessel named for a 19thcentury Russian poet. After all, the unexpected is the rule of the sea, be it weather or chance encounters with people. There was another attraction, too. The Lermontov was inaugurating transAtlantic service between New York and Leningrad. Until she made her series of three voyages from Manhattan's Pier 40 this summer (trips she will repeat next year) there had not been a regularly scheduled passenger service between the United States and the Soviet Union for 25 years. I was determined to book passage.

title: WORLD JURISTS VOTE TO BAN WAR
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Sept. 1The sixth World Peace Through Law conference ended here yesterday, with more that 2,500 judges and lawyers from 123 countries urging that wars be outlawed, nuclear weapons be controlled and terrorism be ended.

title: Bundle up and go out
description: Primitive knitssome real, some fakewill be winter's knockout outdoor sweater fashion. Warm and sturdy, they can take the chill out of hiking in the park, schussing down the slope, roller skating, ice skatingor just messing around.

title: Italy Lays Cholera Outbreak To Sea Food, Mainly Mussels
description: NAPLES, Italy, Sept. 2 (UPI)  The Government today blamed sea food, particularly mussels, for an outbreak of cholera that has killed II persons and hospitalized hundreds more in southern Italy.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 3, 1973

title: WALDHEIM FINDS DESIRE FOR PEACE ON MIDEAST TOUR
description: CAIRO, Sept. 2  Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations left Cairo for Amman, Jordan, today after two days of talks with Egyptian officials including President Anwar elSadat.

title: ANTHONY R. LAMURA
description: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Sept. 2 (AP)Anthony R. Lamura of the Lamura Contracting Company, the Bronx, died in Mount Vernon Hospital today. He was 70 years old and lived here.

title: Vietcong Reported to Attack Post 10 Miles From Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 2 (Reuters)The South Vietnamese Army today reported an attack on a militia outpost only 10 miles from Saigon beside Route 4 leading to the Mekong Delta.

title: 4 JERSEYANS DIED IN DANISH BLAZE
description: A family of four from South Orange, N.J.a physician, his wife and their two childrenwere among the 35 persons killed in Saturday's fire at the Hafnia Hotel in Copenhagen, Denmark.

title: Congress Returns
description: Congress's return from its August recess marks the resumption of the struggle between the Nixon Administration and the Democraticcontrolled House and Senate to determine the shape of national policy. In partisan terms such a struggle is bound to be inconclusive. In terms of the national interest it can be productive. The Republicancontrolled 80th Congress and President Harry Truman, for example, had little rapport on many issues; yet together they launched the Marshall Plan and set the course of postwar foreign policy.

title: Fugitive Seized in New Orleans In Slaying of 2 Policemen Here
description: The last of five alleged members of the Black Liberation Army indicted in the 1971 murder of Police Officers Waverly Jones and Joseph Piagentini in Harlem was arrested in New Orleans yesterday morning after a police stakeout.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: NIXON SAID TO WANT DELAY IN TAPE CASE
description: President Nixon hopes to delay a Supreme Court ruling on the Watergate tapes until he has rebuilt enough public support to be able to defy anything less than a unanimous or nearunanimous decision on the case, Newsweek magazine said yesterday.

title: Public Control Growing in a Land Use Revolution
description: What authorities have called a quiet revolution in government regulation of land, America's most basic resource, is gathering momentum from coast to coast.

title: Mrs. Charlotte L. Hummel Married
description: Mrs. Charlotte Lynette Hummel, daughter of Mrs. Edward C. Hummel of New York and Irvington, N. J., and the late Mr. Hummel, was married here yesterday evening to Howard Kenneth Schwartzman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Schwartzman of Merrick, L. I. Rabbi Sanford E. Saperstein performed the ceremony at the Essex House.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: From the Police Blotter:

title: CANADIAN RAILROADS NEAR NORMAL IN EAST
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 2 (Reuters) Thousands of Canadian railroad workers went back to work today, but the largest of the eight unions involved in a nationwide strike urged its members to disregard emergency legislation passed yesterday by a special session of Parliament.

title: Murder Suspect Held
description: Herman Bell, the last of five alleged members of the Black Liberation Army indicted in the murders of Police Officers Waverly Jones and Joseph Piagentini in Harlem in 1971, was arrested in New Orleans yesterday after a police stakeout. He was held in $500,000 bail pending extradition hearings. Details on Page 21.

title: A Festive Algiers Awaits Leaders of the Nonaligned
description: ALGIERS, Sept. 2For a few days Algiers has become the center of the underdeveloped world and of all its grievances against the industrialized nations.

title: COPENHAGEN FIRE LAID TO A CONVICT
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 2The police arrested a man on leave from prison today and charged him with causing the fire at the Hafnia hotel in which 35 people, including 20 Americans, were killed yesterday.

title: Upstate Youth Slain Fleeing Policeman; Accident Blamed
description: BEACON, N.Y. Sept. 2 (AP) A parttime policeman shot and killed a teenager early today when, the police said, the policeman tripped over the youth's motorcycle during a chase and his pistol fired.

title: Chinese Envoy's Wife Killed By Letter Bomb in Zambia
description: TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 3 (AP)Chinia announced today that the wife of her charge d'affaires in the East African nation of Zambia died at the Chinese Embassy in Lusaka on Aug. 18 after a bomb despicably planted by the enemy in the mail exploded.

title: The Work Ethic
description: WASHINGTON  Aristotle, who knew his ethics, held labor in contempt: All paid employments, he wrote, absorb and degrade the mind.

title: Optimism on Credit Rates Spreading
description: Slowly, almost imperceptibly, the suspicion is spreading among creditmarket specialists that interest rates may have reached their peaks for this business cycle during the first two weeks of August.

title: Cities Step Up Efforts To Aid Runaway Children
description: While the problem of runaway children has remained constant and even eased up recently in communities across the country, local authorities are mounting increased efforts to deal with what many nnw feel has become a somewhat permanent phenomenon.

title: A SOVIET LANDING FOR PRINCE PHILIP
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 2  Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, piloting his own plane, arrived here today on a lowkey private visit that is viewed as part of an improvement of relations between Britain and the Soviet Union.

title: Personal Finance: Marital Trusts
description: A growing number of women are eager to learn to manage their own money, and are capable of doing so. At the same time many more professional estate planning services are being offered.

title: Sandra Haynie 5Stroke Victor
description: FORT WORTH, Sept. 2 (AP)  Sandra Haynie scuttled her challengers with a threeunderpar 69 today en route to a fiveshot victory in the first $30,000 Charity Golf Classic.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 2Just when they were beginning to believe in manifest destiny, the New York Mets reverted to their own dark ages today when they lost a threerun lead with three innings to go and then lost a 7.4 decision to the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Kerry Blue Named Best At Rockland
description: SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., Sept. 2A Kerry blue terrier, a native breed from Ireland, found the green setting of the Rockland County show to his liking today and led a field of 1,201 dogs on the grounds of the Spring Valley High School. He was Ch. Kerrytray! Blue Challenger, owned by Frederick and Alice Siems of Andover, N. J., and handled by Roy Holloway.

title: Fresh Winds
description: A movement in quest of a mission. That is the State of the Unions this Labor Day. Traditional conceptions of union function have been stood on their head by the low priority labor's rank and file seems to assign to the battle for the buck in major contract negotiations, despite the holes cut in workers pay envelopes by skyrocket. ing prices.

title: Dunlop Foresees Period of Trade Union Mergers
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2John T. Dunlop, a member of the Nixon Administration and one of this country's leading authorities on industrial relations, forecasts that the next two decades will be a period of mergers for trade unions, especially the smaller ones.

title: Weekly List of Mutual Funds
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Sea Scouts Rendezvous at Sandy Hook for 3 Adventurous Days
description: ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., Sept. 2More than 300 boys, and girls have been spending; the Labor Day weekend on thei beachlined peninsula of Sandy Hook, soaking in the sun plunging into the surf, making friends and learning to be better Scouts.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I was greatly disappointed at the uncritical tenor of the Aug. 22 editorial in The Times on the proposed reconstruction of the West Side Highway.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Monday, September 3, 1973

title: Fewer Encores Remain For Une de Mai to Take
description: Une de Mai is a horse in limbo. As the 9yearold French mare's earnings mount far above that of any harness horse in history, she has virtually no place to go but into retirement, and her owner is not ready for that.

title: Beach Clubs Fear Gateway Park Means End of Haven
description: This is a haven for people to get away from the rabbleit's the last frontier, said the tanned middleaged man strolling a cabana deck at the Silver Gull Beach Club on the ocean front at Breezy Point, Queens. The club, not far from the west lip of Rockaway Peninsula, has 4,200 members from more than 1,000 families.

title: LIBYA PREMIER SEES NO SHORTAGES OF OIL
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Sept, 2 (AP) Premier Abdul Salam Jalloud of Libya said today that the nationalization of all foreign oil companies by the Libyan Gpvernment should not affect oil, supplies in the United States and Europe.

title: Murder Suspect Held
description: Herman Bell, the last of five alleged members of the Black Liberation Army indicted in the murders of Police Officers Waverly Jones and Joseph Piagentini in Harlem in 1971, was arrested in New Orleans yesterday after a police stakeout. He was held in $500,000 bail pending extradition hearings. Details on Page 21.

title: Caucasus Peasant Dies at 168; Said to Be World's Oldest Man
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 2 (UPI)Shirali Mislimov, a craggyfaced bearded Caucasian peasant reputed to be the world's oldest person, died today in his mountain village of Barzavu. His age was listed at 168 by Tass, the Soviet press agency.

title: Sherrill Swan Is Wed To William B. Welch
description: SAUSALITO, Calif., Sept. 2 The marriage of Miss Sherrill Swan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Bothwell Swan of San Raphael, to William Barton Welch took place in Christ Episcopal Church here this afternoon. The Rev. J. Barton Sarjeant performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Sohier Welch Jr. of Harvard, Mass., and Mount Desert, Me.

title: Roundup: A Tough Cookie Saves Royals
description: Cookie didn't crumble yesterday and as a result the Kansas City Royals moved within 3 games of the Oakland A's in the battle for the top spot in the American League Western Division.

title: Philippines, in Rice Shortage, Is Striving to Improve Yields
description: BINAN, The Philippines, Sept. 11Farmers in the part of this town facing Laguna de Bay, the Philippines' largest lake, planted their rice this week, a month late because they waited for rain. But, barring typhoons or pests, they hoped for the best.

title: Cooking Schools: Places to Go for the Expert and NotsoExpert
description: A La Bonne Cocotte, 23 Eighth Avenue, OR 57736. Classic French cuisine taught by Mrs. Lydie Pinoy Marshall. Series of four classes, morning or evening, $60. Students prepare a complete meal. Starts Sept. 17; inquiries after Sept. 8.

title: TV Blackout Ban Seen Likely to End
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP)Pete Rozelle, commissioner of the National Football League, says he thinks it is possible that Congress will pass a law against television blackouts of home games.

title: Perth Amboy Man Knifed To Death After Argument
description: ELIZABETH, Sept. 2 (UPI)A 40yearold Perth Amboy man was stabbed to death yesterday after an argument with a friend on a sidewalk here, the police reported.

title: Red Smith
description: If a person who did not know Yancey Durham heard him talking in the next room, he would assume that the voice belonged to an actor or preacher or con man or politician, if that isn't a distinction without a difference. As a matter of fact, Yank was a little of each. He was a fight manager, He made his entrance on the national scene with the 1964 Olympic heavyweight champion, Joe Frazier, he guided Joe to the championship of the professional world, and when he died last Thursday after a stroke he left the former champion desolate, feeling that he had lost a father for the second time. Yank was only 52, had added Bob Foster, the lightheayweight champion, to his stable, and was laying plans to maneuver Frazier into a return bout with George Foreman, who knocked Joe loose from the title last January.

title: DISSIDENTS' RISKS OBVIOUS IN SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 2The continuing official press campaign against Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident physicist, forcefully demonstrates the risks, that a prominent Soviet citizen assumes in speaking out against his Government's policies.

title: LINEOFDUTY RITES SLATED FOR FIREMAN
description: A lineofduty funeral will be held Wednesday for a 33yearold fireman who died Saturday night fighting a fire in the cellar of a variety store at 756 Nostrand Avenue, in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn.

title: Jean Marie Evans Married To Arthur Stephen Lane Jr.
description: PRINCETON N. J., Sept. 2 In the Princeton University Chapel this afternoon, Miss Jean Marie Evans, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Robert Evans of Carlisle, Mass., was married to Arthur Stephen Lane Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lane of Harbourton.

title: Safety of Planned Nuclear Generator In Sea Off Atlantic City Is Still Studied
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2Twelve miles northeast of Atlantic City and 2.8 miles due east of Egg Island Harbor inlet, an orange and white tower rises 17 feet above the Atlantic, barely visible from shore.

title: 7 L.I. Police Hurt Seizing Man Who Held His Children Hostage
description: NORTH AMITYVILLE, L.I., Sept. 2Seven policemen were injured today as they rushed an armed man who had been holding them at bay for two hours, using his three children as a shield. One of the policemen was shot in the chest and shoulder.

title: Kerry Blue Named Best At Rockland
description: SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., Sept. 2A Kerry blue terrier, a native breed from Ireland, found the green setting of the Rockland County show to his liking today and led a field of 1,201 dogs on the grounds of the Spring Valley High School. He was Ch. Kerrytrayl Blue Challenger, owned by Frederick and Alice Siems of Andover, N. J., and handled by Roy Holloway.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 2Miss America Week this troubled Jersey resort has begun and as in the past, the state beauty queens will parade along the boardwalk, compete in various contests and  like most bathing beautieswon't go near the water.

title: Aussie Wins World Sail
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 2 (Reuters)David McKay won the world 16foot skiff sailing championship today. McKay, sailing Imperium, and Graham McKellar, in McKellar Sails, each ended the series with 1,070 points but McKay took the title because he finished third in today's final race while McKellar was 10th. Both are Australians.

title: White Modell to Cancel Marla Industries Leases
description: Marla Industries, Inc., operator of snack bars and coffee shops, announced Friday it was, notified by White Modell, Stores, lessor of 11 of Marla's 14 shops, that these leases were cancelling Aug. 13 for nonpayment of rent or license fees. The lease of another Marla store was also terminated for default in rent, the announcement said. Marla still operates one of the remaining shops and efforts are being made to dispose of the other one, the company said.

title: MRS. LORENZO TUCKER
description: Mrs. Julia Shaw Tucker, wife of Lorenzo Tucker, a stage and screen actor who played lead parts in early Negro films, died Friday in BeekmanDowntown Hospital. She was 67 years old land lived at 45 East 135th Street.

title: Hair Today, one ...
description: The swiftness of social change has been underscored by a decision of the United States Court of Appeals that choice of personal appearance is an ingredient of liberty. There was nothing novel in the judicial ruling itself, but only in the fact that the beneficiaries were policemen, pleading in defense of their right to wear their hair long, which was barred in Suffolk County.

title: Strike at City Opera Goes Into 2d Day; No Accord in Sight
description: The stage of the New York State Theater in Lincoln Center remained dark again yesterday as the strike of union musicians against the New York City Opera went through its second day with no settlement in sight.

title: Tennis Balls: Stronger Service Needed
description: There is a shortage of tennis balls, too.

title: A Friend of Labor
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2  The Administration's intimacy with the teamsters union illuminates the moral atmosphere that President Nixon has established.

title: South African Ban on a Play Stirs Dispute
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 2 (Reuters)  An outraged South African thought that it was unfit for any decentliving folk to witness; another berated it as indecent, suggestive and lewd; a third damned it as utterly incomprehensible, completely pointless and, to boot, filthy.

title: 4 JERSEYANS DIED IN DANISH BLAZE
description: A family of four from South Orange, N. J.a physician, his wife and their two childrenwere among the 35 persons killed in Saturday's fire at the Hafnia Hotel in Copenhagen, Denmark.

title: BLAZING SHIP FORCES EVACUATION OF 500
description: PHOENIX, La., Sept. 2 (UPI)  A ship carrying dangerous chemicals caught fire in the Mississippi River today, forcing the evacuation of 500 riverside residents and the closing of the river.

title: City to Urge Authorizing State To Build Power Plants Here
description: Only months before it leaves office, the Lindsay administration is planning to submit proposals for next year's Legislature authorizing the state to build power plants in the city.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Ved Mehta Traces Gandhi's Doctrine
description: NEW DELHIGandhi and India. The prophet and his nation seem fused, firmly locked in the pitiless struggle for dignity amid barren poverty.

title: On Highway, Folks Head Home: Summer's Over
description: EVENING SHADE, Ark., Aug. 29  It's backtoschool time time time time, the radio announcer blabbers from his echo chamber, so come on down to the Modern Sewing Center, the people who keep you in stitches stitches stitches stitches.

title: Beach Clubs Fear Gateway Park Means End of Haven
description: This is a haven for people to get away from the rabbleit's the last frontier, said the tanned middleaged man strolling a cabana deck at the Silver Gull Beach Club on the ocean front at Breezy Point, Queens. The club, not far from the west tip of Rockaway Peninsula, has 4,200 members from more than 1,003 families.

title: About the Jets:
description: Winston Hill and Emerson Boozer, who had agreed to contract terms last week and were expected to sign New Orleans over the weekend, did not. Contract wording is the problem. . . . After Joe Namath had scrambled to recover a fumbled pitchout Saturday night, taking pounding in the process, he got up thinking about the incident in Tampa in 1971 when he was hit on a fumble play. He was out 10 games aster that. WS funny how many things run through your mind at a time like that, he said. . . . Margene Adkins, a candidate for wide receiver, almost blew a big chance last night when he fumbled kickoff two yards deep in the end zone. But he picked up the ball and returned it 60 yards to the Saints' 42yardline.

title: Raben's Sloop First to Finish Vineyard Race
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 2  Norman Raben's 52foot black sloop, La Forza del Destino, was the first to finish the Stamford Yacht Club's Vineyard race today. The race turned into a drifting match for the homeward passage after a fast pace to the turning mark at the Buzzards Bay entrance light.

title: Alliance Against Dissent
description: Traditionally, the Soviet press has always emphasized the negative in the image of this country presented its readers. For the editors and writers of Pravda and Izvestia, the usual subjects of interest here have been unemployment, crime, rising prices and the like. By the customary criteria of Soviet media, therefore, the Watergate scandal should be an inexhaustible reservoir material for depicting the United States as a land virtually infinite corruption and oppression.

title: Rod Rodgers Dancers Defy the Weather
description: The Rod Rodgers Dance Company, a group at home in both proscenium theaters and outdoor community programs, brought dance into Lincoln Center's Street. Theater Festival Saturday afternoon.

title: Skylab Crew Photographs Earth and Solar Activity
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Sept. 2 (Reuters)The Skylab 2 astronauts divided their time today between scientific study of the earth and the sun.

title: Fewer Encores Remain For Une de Mai to Take
description: Une de Mai is a horse in limbo. As the 9yearold French mare's earnings mount far above that of any harness horse in history, she has virtually no place to go but into retirement, and her owner is not ready for that.

title: For Chicken Barbecue Lovers, Season Heads into Homestretch
description: PRATTSVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 2Brooks of Oneonta rolled into the parking lot in back of the United Methodist Church here at 2 P.M. yesterday with 500 chicken halves, 15 gallons of a secret barbecue sauce, 300 pounds of charcoal and a 24footlong portable grill.

title: Battle Rages in Cambodia For Vital Highway to Sea
description: ANG SNUOL, Cambodia, Sept. 2A thunderous exchange of artillery and machinegun fire continued here all day today and casualties mounted as Government forces sought unsuccessfully to break through an insurgent roadblock on Route 4.

title: Betsy Busch Has Nuptials
description: MILLBROOK, N. Y., Sept. 2Miss Betsy Busch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel S. Busch of New York and Clinton Corners, was married here this afternoon to Dr. John Joseph Szlyk, son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Szlyk Jr. of Worcester, Mass.

title: ECONOMISTS SEE A SOFT LANDING WHEN BOOM ENDS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2  Although Government economists are as aware as their fellows in business, banking and the universities of the hazards of forecasting the business outlook this summer, in general they agree with what top officials are saying publiclythat the present boom will be terminated by a soft landing and not a recession.

title: U.S. Woman Is Second In Diving
description: BELGRADE, Sept. 2 (UPI) Ulrike Knape of Sweden, an Olympic champion, recovered from a poor start in the compulsory dives in the women's threemeter springboard diving today and led intermediate standings at the world swimming championships.

title: Chalmers W. Overton Dies; Customs Broker Was 83
description: Chalmers Wolfetone Overton Sr., senior partner in the customs brokerage firm of Overton & Co. founded by his grandfather, died yesterday in Somerset Valley Nursing Home in Bound Brook, N. J. He was 83 years old and lived at 96 Willow Avenue, North Plainfield, N. J.

title: Colleges Retrench In Effort to Curb Increase in Tuition
description: A new era of retrenchment is making itself felt at colleges and universities across the country as they are trying to fight deficits and at the same time halt the relentless increase in tuitions.

title: Heath and Ulster: Gap in Attitude
description: LONDON, Sept. 2Just before he left Belfast after his twoday stay last week, Prime Minister Heath made a brief stab at meeting the people., Heavily guarded, trailed by journalists, he ventured up Anne Street.

title: Israel Curbs Hiring of Arab Farm Labor
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 2The Government today approved measures designed to prevent Israeli settlers in the occupied Arab territories from hiring local Arab farm labor.

title: Holiday Ending, but Not the Heat
description: New York City is preparing to counter its seventh straight day of above90 mugginess with a parade in Brooklyn, a concert in Central Park and the traditional start of the active politicking season by its mayoral candidates.

title: U.S. Woman Is Second In Diving
description: BELGRADE, Sept. 2 (UPI) Ulrike Knape of Sweden, an Olympic champion, recovered from a poor start in the compulsory dives in the women's threemeter springboard diving today and led intermediate standings at the world swimming championships.

title: French Unveil War Memorial
description: ANNECY, France, Sept. 2 (Reuters)France today unveiled a memorial to the wartime resistance during the Nazi occupation in World War II, The site of the huge Vshaped monument is near a battleground where 456 resistance fighters fought a German Alpine division of 12,000 men. More than a quarter of the Frenchmen were killed.

title: Seattle's Boat Watchers Drawn to Ballard Locks
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 2  This the kind of day when a big crowd gathers at the Ballard Locks, the installation that makes possible the small boat wonderland that exists here Puget Sound.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 2 (UPI)East Germany scored a fivelength victory in the Blue Ribbon eights event today at the 56th European men's rowing championship. The world champion East German crew built a 14second advantage over secondplace Czechoslovakia and won in 6 minutes 19.02 seconds. The United States was far behind in last place in 6:41.64.

title: Syosset Polo Victor On Brinkmann Goal
description: BETHPAGE, Li., Sept, 2Ted Brinkmann's goal with less than a minute left to play gave Syosset a 6.5 victory over West Hills in polo today at Bethpage State Park.

title: COPENHAGEN FIRE LAID TO A CONVICT
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 2The police arrested a man on leave from prison today and charged him with causing the fire at the Hafnia hotel in which 35 people, including 20 Americans, were killed yesterday.

title: Battle Rages in Cambodia For Vital Highway to Sea
description: ANG SNUOL, Cambodia, Sept. 2A thunderous exchange of artillery and machinegun fire continued here all day today and casualties mounted as Government forces sought unsuccessfully to break through an insurgent roadblock on Route 4.

title: Dr. Vicki Lynn Seltzer Is Wed To Richard S. Brach, Lawyer
description: Dr. Vicki Lynn Seltzer, a resident physician in obstetrics and gynecology at Bellevue Hospital, was married yesterday to Richard S. Brach, a lawyer with Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, and legislative liaison between the New York State Bar Association and the State Legislature in Albany.

title: Colleges Retrench In Effort to Curb Increase in Tuition
description: A new era of retrenchment is making itself felt at colleges and universities across the country as they are trying to fight deficits and at the same time halt the relentless increase in tuitions.

title: Sarel Kandell Bride Of Philip Kromer 3d
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2Miss Sarel Mizzi Kandell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Erwin M. Kandell of Pawling, N.Y. was married here this afternoon to Philip Frederick Kromer 3d. He is the son of Brig. Gen. Philip F. Kromer, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Kromer of Melrose, Fla.

title: DOWNTOWN BUST WRECKS BUILDING
description: An explosion yesterday destroyed the inside of a vacant building, damaged adjoining buildings and hurled shards of glass across the narrow streets of the financial district.

title: 12 DIE IN HOTEL FIRE IN BUFFALO SUBURB
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 2 (AP)Two persons were killed this morninging in a fire in a new ninestory hotel in suburban Cheektowaga.

title: To Save NATO: Reduce It
description: WASHINGTONVisiting the headquarters recently of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, I told an old friend there I thought it was high time we began to, make some plans to reduce our forces in Europe. He is living in a beautiful chateau, and he said: Well, Gene, please don't start it right now, because this is the first good overseas duty I have been able to get for Mary in all our naval service and I would like to be able to finish the tour.

title: Thousands Leave Vermont Festival After 9 Are Shot
description: HOLLAND, Vt., Sept. 2 (AP) Many of an estimated total of 35,000 young people who attended a Labor Day rock festival that was marred by gunfire streamed out of the area today, the second day of the threeday gathering. The state police said the crowd had dwindled to 10,000.

title: Blaze in Jersey Spurs Study Of TV Sets as Fire Hazards
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2A New Jersey fire in which seven persons died has touched off a special investigation by the Consumer Product Safety Commission of television sets as possible fire hazards.

title: 3 HOSTAGES SEIZED AT INDIANA PRISON
description: MICHIGAN CITY, Ind., Sept. 1 (AP)  Inmates seized control of three cellblocks at the Indiana state prison today, taking three officers hostage to press a set of 10 demands.

description: New York City is preparing to counter its seventh straight day of above90 mugginess with a parade in Brooklyn, a concert in Central Park and the traditional start of the active politicking season by its mayoral candidates.

description: IMPLEMENTATION. By Jeffrey L. Pressman and Aaron B. Wildaysky. 182 pp. University of California Press. $7.50.

title: Laos Strives to Discard French School Tie
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 1For decades French has been the language of the Laotian public schools. All subjects have been taught in French, in most cases by teachers who are French citizens. The best students from the upper social classes take the same baccalaureate examination that students in Paris take, and their hope is to study at a university in France.

title: Burke Quits Rangers
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., Sept. 2 (UPI)The Texas Rangers owner, Bob Short, said today he had reluctantly accepted the resignation of General Manager Joe Burke and had hired Daniel F. O'Brien, a minor league exeecutive, as Burke's replacement.

title: Texas Predicts More Use Of Its Own Natural Gas
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 2 Texasproduced natural gas is becoming more and more likely to be burned at a Texas destination rather than being exported into interstate commerce, new figures from the Texas Railroad Commission show. Gas which is sold interstate is subject to the Federal Power Commission's wellhead ceiling prices, but gas sold within the state is not.

title: Enrollments Fall, But Aid to Schools Climbs in Jersey
description: TRENTON, Sept. 2New Jersey's public schools will open this week with fewer pupils than last year, more money, some labor and fiscal problems and a few educational changes.

title: Laos Strives to Discard French School Tie
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 1For decades French has been the language of the Laotian public schools. All subjects shave been taught in French, in most cases by teachers who are French citizens. The best students from the upper social classes, take the same baccalaureate examination that students in Paris take, and their hope is to study at a university in France.

title: About the Mets:
description: The man who wasn't there: Bob Gibson, watching the series from the sidelines, leaning on a cane. The 37yearold pitcher, the ace of the St. Louis staff, tore the cartilage his left knee in Shea Stadium a month ago, and will not pitch again until next year. ... Red Schoendienst, manager of the Cardinals, was impressed but not surprised by George Stone's strong pitching against his team Saturday night. We tried to get him from the Mets earlier this season, he said, but they said no. Stone joined the Mets this year as a sort of throwin to the deal that brought Felix Millan from Atlanta. ... Schoendienst on Henry Aaron: I think he's swinging betterfasterthan last year. ......The Tug McGraws are naming their new daughter Cari Lynn. She was born Saturday night in North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L. I., their second child, first girl. ... Next for the Mets: Two with Philadelphia today in Shea. For the Cardinals: two in Pittsburgh, and the plot thickens.

title: STANISLAW SMIETANA
description: NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Sept. 2 (AP)  Stanislaw Smietana, past president of the National Committee of Americans of Polish Descent, died Friday after suffering a heart attack at a local beach.

title: Canada's Wheat Harvest Likely to Be Its Most Valuable
description: LIBERTY, Sask.  Canada's broad, flat prairies have juit finistied turning from green to gold. To the farmers, who have been a long time waiting for a year like this one, that signals the beginning of what is expected to be the most valuable wheat harvest here in history.

title: Philippines in Rice Shortage, Is Seeking to Improve Yields
description: BINAN, The Philippines, Sept. 1Farmers in the part of this town facing Laguna de Bay, the Philippines' largest lake, planted their rice this week, a month late because they waited for rain. But, barring typhoons or pests, they hoped for the best.

title: Canadians Plowing Profit In Tractors From Soviet
description: TORONTO, Sept. 2  One hundred tractors built in the Soviet Union are rumbling across the farmland of eastern Canada, and the two companies that import them are going to try now to get a piece of the $8.5billion United States market for farm machinery.

title: Bomb Said to Explode In Lenin Mausoleum
description: BONN, Sept. 2 (UPI)A West German newspaper reported today that a bomb exploded in the Lenin Mausoleum in Moscow yesterday, causing injuries to several persons.

title: CHINESE RETURN FROM JAPAN TALKS
description: TOKYO, Sept. 2A Chinese trade delegation has returned to Peking without concluding an expected trade agreement with Japan.

title: Hurricane Watch Issued For the Leeward Islands
description: MIAMI, Sept. 2 (AP)Gale warnings and a hurricane watch were issued today for the Leeward Islands as tropical storm Christine slowly approcahed a landfall, the National Hurricane Center in Miami said.

title: Consumers and Suppliers Differ on Scrap Supply
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 2Is costs. there a shortage of steel scrap new or isn't there?

title: 10,000 Savor Delights Of Chesapeake Crabs

title: WALDHEIM FINDS DESIRE FOR PEACE ON MIDEAST TOUR
description: CAIRO, Sept. 2  Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations left Cairo for Amman, Jordan, today after two days of talks with Egyptian officials including President Anwar elSadat.

title: The Markezinis Price
description: Some skepticism is called for in evaluating the news from Greece. It could be that President Papadopoulos is so concerned about raging inflation and restoring his country's standing with its European allies that he is ready at last to take drastic action. One report holds that he now plans to appoint a Premier who is a respected politician and who will have a free hand to pick most members of a largely civilian Cabinet and to organize fair elections for 1974. We hope the report proves to be accurate.

title: Green Gets Second 63 For 199 Tie
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Sept. 2Hubert Green, who started the tournament with a 63 but slipped to a 73 yesterday, came back with another eightunderpar round of 63 today and shared the 54hole lead in the $200,000 Sammy Davis Jr.Greater Hartford open with Bruce Devlin of Australia at 199.

title: Tokyo Rejects Seoul Offer in Kidnapping
description: TOKYO, Sept. 2The Japanese Ambassador to South Korea left for Seoul today to inform Korean officials that their proposed political settlement of the Kim Dae Jung kidnapping affair was not satisfactory.

title: Heat Plays a Part at FolkMusic Festival
description: CAPE MAY, Sept. 2Both the first Cape Island Festival of Folk Music and Crafts, held a year ago, and the second, held this weekend, featured not only music and crafts, but also bad weather.

title: 6 L. I. Policemen Plan Channel Swim
description: Six Nassau County police officers left for England yesterday hoping to become the first all American relay team to swim the English Channel. Captain Benson Huggard, who heads the team and is one of seven Americans ever to swim the Channel, said the team hopes to hit the water Sept. 12.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: LABORED DAY If you had or wanted, to stay in town this last weekend of the summer, it won't hurt at all today to sample a bit of urban greenery so that you can at least drop in a falliscorning line about the yellowing edges of the maples at tomorrow's business lunch.

title: Dallenbach Takes 500Mile Auto Race
description: ONTARIO, Calif., Sept. 2Coming off a perfectly timed pit stop with 21 laps to go in a race that put a premium on husbanding fuel, Wally Dallenbach won the California 500 today by five seconds over Mario Andretti. The winner averaged 157.664 miles an hour.

title: Redskins Trounce Patriots, 3514
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Sept. (UPI)  Sonny Jurgensen resurrected the Washington Redskins in the second half, throwing two touchdowns passes and directing two more scoring drive for a 3514 victory over the New England Patriots in a National Football League preseason game tonight.

title: Aguilar's Mexican Festival Delights Fans at the Garden
description: The muffled thunder of horses and blare of Mexican trumpets rang through Madison Squaie Garden Saturday night to the whooping delight of thousands of fans of trick riding, roping and Westernstyle crooning.

title: Christmas Stamps Picked
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 2 (UPI) A needlepoint design of an old  fashioned Christmas tree and a painting of a Madonna and child by the Italian Renaissance artist Raphael have been chosen as the 1973 Christmas stamps, the United States Postal Service said yesterday.

title: Makarios Won't Run Again
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept. 2 (AP)Archbishop Makarios declared today that he will not seek reelection when his third fiveyear presidential term expires in 1978.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The body of a man found washed up on the sand off an Atlantic City beach last week was identified as Robert. N. Nager, 74 years old, a wellknown political figure who recently pleaded guilty to tax fraud. The police said autopsy would be performed but a preliminary examination indicated that Mr. Plager apparently died of a heart attack.

description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Sept. 2Miss Flori Blumberg, a senior public health adviser in the Bronx for the New York City Health Department, and David Schwartz, a medical student at Albert Einstein College of Medicine, were married here this evening in Temple Beth El. Rabbi Emeritus Jacob Rudin, who married the bride's parents; Rabbi Jerome Davidson, spiritual leader of the temple, and Cantor Robert Bloch performed the ceremony.

title: With Nixon on the Coast: The Lighter Side
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif., Aug. 31It was like a scene from the late night mystery shows that dominate the television screens of Southern California. There in the middle of the busy southbound threelane artery of the San Diego Freeway at midafternoon was the President of the United States. For most people the only reason for even getting on that frantic thoroughfare is to get where they are going, whether it is to Mexico to buy cheap meat or to the factories and resorts strung along the coast.

title: India, in Slap at U.S., Decides to Restrict American Scholars
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 1The Indian Government, in a slap at the United States, has decided to restrict the number of American scholars admitted to the country to 20 each year.

title: Children in the Fields
description: VISALIA, Calif.It don't hurt the kids to pick a few peppers. It's against the law, I realize, but hell, they been doin' it for years. The California farmer was talking about sixty children under 12 years of age who were working alongside their parents in his nearby chili fields.

title: India, in a Slap at U. S. Decides To Restrict American Scholars
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 1The Indian Government, in a slap at the United States, has decided to restrict the number of American scholars admitted to the country to 20 each year.

title: Israelis Warned of Bombs
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 2 (UPI)Security officials cautioned Israelis today against a new type of suspected Arab guerrilla explosive devil planted inside, wickerpacked wine jugs.

title: Meany as Healer
description: George Meany has never been one to admit that he might just possibly have been wrong about anything important, so it is no surprise to find the A.F.L.C.I.O. president insisting in his annual Labor Day interview that he was dead right last year in sponsoring a Presidential neutrality policy that did much to swing normally Democratic labor votes into the Nixon column. That confidence in his own correctness is in no way diminished by Mr. Meany's current conviction that Mr. Nixon will go down in history as one of our worst Presidents, partly because of Watergate but even more because of his mishandling of the economy.

title: Barbara Ann Woolhandler a Bride
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., Sept. 2Miss Barbara Ann Woolhandler of New York, daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. George Woolhandler of Shreveport, La., was married here at noon today to Alan Charles Lowenfels, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Lowenfels of Scarsdale.

title: Adrienne Smith Bride of Lee Kuhn Fox
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., Sept. 2  Miss Adrienne Adair Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adrian Smith of Mountain Lakes, was married here this evening to Lee Kuhn Fox, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert S. Fox of Nashville. The ceremony was performed at the Governor Morris Inn by the Rev. Lyndon Schendel, a Protestant minister and director of the Planned Parenthood Association of Albany, and Rabbi Irwin H. Fishbein.

title: Preseason Football
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: 9,566 BUSINESSES FAILED IN THE YEAR
description: Last year 9,566 United States businesses failed with accumulated liabilities exceeding $2billion, Dun & Bradstreet, Inc. reported yesterday. While the number is lower than many prior yews, the average liability was a record $209,099. This was more than double the rate recorded as recently as 1968.

title: Amateur Golf Title To Stadler
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 2 (UPI)  Craig Stadler, from the University of Southern California, captured the 73d United States Amateur golf championship today with an easy 6and5 victory over David Strawn.

title: Sea Scouts Rendezvous at Sandy Hook for 3 Adventurous Days
description: ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., Sept. 2  More than 300 boys and girls have been spending the Labor Day weekend on the beachlined peninsula of Sandy Hook, soaking in the sun plunging into the surf, making friends and learning to be better Scouts.

title: Redman's Time Fastest
description: LONG POND, Pa., Sept. 2 (AP)Brian Redman of Colne. England, posted the fastest speed today in qualifying for tomorrow's L&M formula 500 Championship race at Pocono International Raceway. He bettered the course record in a SteedLola by over six miles an hour with a lap of 119.97 on the 1.8mile course.

title: Jazzmen Pick Swing Era And Age Gap Vanishes
description: This summer's music on the Mall series in Central Park, which has featured more or less classical music, finished its season with a flourish of more or less classic jazz on Thursday evening.

title: MRS. MARTHA FENNELLY
description: Mrs. Martha Davis Fennelly, a daughter of the late Norman H. Davis, chairman of the American Red Cross and AmbassadoratLarge, died Saturday in St. Luke's Hospital. She was 70 years old and lived at 200 East 66th Street.

title: 2 HalfBrothers Are Among Four Drowned Here Over the Weekend
description: Two Brooklyn halfbrothers, neither apparently able to swim, drowned in Sheepshead Bay late yesterday afternoon when they foundered at a dropoff while wading, the police reported.

title: Ocean's Temperature Reaches 82 Degrees
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 2 (UPI)  Ocean temperatures here were the second highest on record today.

title: Tigers Dismiss Martin For Policy Infractions
description: DETROIT, Sept. 2 (UPI)Billy Martin, the volatile manager of the Detroit Tigers who quit for one day in spring training, was dismissed today for his numerous runins with baseball's hierarchytwo days after he was suspended by the American League for ordering his pitchers to throw illegal greaseballs.

title: Borg Ousts Ashe in U.S. Open; Orantes and Drysdale Beaten
description: The young pretenders to the thrones of tennis made a determined assault on the game's older majesties yesterday in the United States Open championships at Forest Hills, Queens. When the smoke had cleared, the fallen included Arthur Ashe, seeded No. 3, a 67, 64, 64, 64 victim of 17yearold Bjorn Borg of Sweden, and Manuel Orantes of Spain, No. 8, gunned down by Ross Case, 21, of Australia, 61, 64, 76.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Mother and Girl Die And Father Is Hurt In a Boat Explosion
description: A woman and her infant daughter were killed yesterday and the women's husband was critically injured in a fire and ecplosion on their 41foot cabin cruiser as it was docked in Lindenhurst, L. I.

title: Public Control Growing in a Land Use Revolution
description: What authorities have called a quiet revolution in government regulation of land, America's most basic resource, is gathering momentum from coast to coast.

title: CONGRESS MEETS TOMORROW, READY TO PRESS 2 ISSUES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 Congress reconvenes at noon Wednesday after a month's vacation and will press challenges to President Nixon on two major policy issueshis, warmaking power and his right to halt the spending of funds appropriated by Congress.

title: The Conservative Leverage
description: WASHINGTON  Throughout his public career, Richard Nixon projected the impression of one who is at least viscerally conservative, a man who loves his country, and who, when it seemed important enough to him, was ready to suffer any level of unpopularity to persevere on the path which duty required.

title: Air Safety First
description: Eightyeight persons lost their lives a month ago when a Delta Air Lines jet failed to clear the Boston airport seawall while attempting an instrument landing in dense fog. A still incomplete investigation by the National Transportation Safety Board has disclosed that the death plane had a threemonth history of problems with its radio and instruments. In the six days before the crash, pilots had reported difficulties on seven occasions.

title: MALI RELIEF HURT BY FUEL SHORTAGE
description: BAMAKO, MaliWest German and American Air Force cargo planes loaded with 40 tons of food and medicine for drought and famine victims sat idle here for two days recently because of a lack of fuel.

title: The Curious Army
description: KAISERSLAUTERN, West Germany In a statement which I gave to the press on Aug. 7, 1973, I accepted responsibility for leaking some U.S. Army military intelligence reports to The New York Times and the Columbia Broadcasting System. Since I now face the possibility of courtmartial proceedings, I would like at this time to explain my motives.

title: 3 HOSTAGES FREED AT INDIANA PRISON
description: MICHIGAN CITY, Ind., Sept. 3 (AP)Three officers held hostage by dissident inmates at the Indiana state prison were relased unharmed tonight, and order was restored in the prison, officials said.

title: School Football Player, 16, Dies After Practice in 90Degree Heat
description: HONESDALE, Pa., Sept. 3A 16yearold highschool football player from Trenton collapsed and died here after a twoandonequarter hour practice session in heat reaching 90 degrees.

title: Strikes in Germany Add To Anxiety About Boom
description: BONN, Aug. 31The superheated West German economy, driven on by an export boom and beset by a high rate of inflation that has resisted the Government's attempts to treat it, has come under pressure in the last two weeks from a new irritantwildcat strikes in its biggest factories.

title: American League
description: (Tuesday, September 4, 1973

title: Cox Appoints 4 Lawyers To Investigatory Team
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UPI) Special Watergate prosecutor Archibald Cox announced today appointment of four trial lawyers to his investigation of illegal contributions in the 1972 Presidential campaign and the secret White House plumbers operation.

title: BRITISH GET TOUGH WITH SHOPLIFTERS
description: LONDON, Sept. 3A 22 yearold Polish tourist, dresser in blue denim slacks and jacket stood in the dock at Maribor ough Street Court with its domed skylight, dark paneling poor acoustics and bespectacled magistrate. As her 25yearold boyfriend glanced downward at the floor, her voice cracked and she almost wept.

title: Events Today
description: NOO JALL (New York) a play In English by Jaime Carrero, directed by Pablo Cabrera, performed by the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater, at Plaza, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 83d Street, 7:30.

title: Philip and Podgorny Hold Exceptionally Warm Talk
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 3 (UPI)Prince Philip held exceptionally warm talks with President Nikolai V. Podgorny in the Kremlin today, then over vodka and caviar discussed improving BritishSoviet relations and a possible future visit by Queen Elizabeth II, a British source said.

title: Court Bars Union Interference With Production at The Times
description: A temporary court order restraining members of Typographical Union 6 from interfering with normal production was served on the union last night by The New York Times.

title: Antique LeisureClass Horse Carriages, Anyone?
description: GLADSTONE, Sept. 3  A collection of 208 equestrian items, including sporting carriages used by the leisure class at the turn of the century and the harnesses, bits and bridles used to restrain their horses, will go on presale exhibit here tomorrow.

title: Grocery Prices Off From Peaks in MidAugust
description: Grocery prices have tumbled a bit from their midAugust, peaks, but are still about 7 per cent higher than they were six months ago, an Associated Press market basket survey; shows.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Residents of the Fire Island community of Davis Park petitioned the, Suffolk County Police Department yesterday not to construct a permanent Police Headquarters on what they described as the remote eastern edge of development on the island.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 4, 1973

title: ALBERTA UTILITIES TO JOIN GAS UNIT
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, Sept. 3 (Canadian Press)  Alberta's major natural gas utitilities are planning to Join Canadian Arctic Gas Study, Ltd., E. W. King, president of Canadian Utilities, Ltd., said today.

title: 25 Drown in Taiwan
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 3 (UPI) Twentyfive young women, on their way to work in factories drowned today when an overloaded ferry boat carrying 775 passenger sprang a leak and sank off Kaohsiung harbor southern Taiwan, harbor officials said.

title: Newlyweds Furnishing a 3Room Apartment: Will $3,000 Do It?
description: Here come the brides, not only marching down the aisle but into the stores in search of everything from living room suites to can openers.

title: HEALTH CARE PLAN WOULD TAP TAXES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3The Nixon Administration has under study a proposal that would eliminate deductions for medical bills from income tax returns, which, if enacted, would cost taxpayers an estimated $7.5billion a year.

title: Rufino Cardinal Santos Dead; First Filipino to Get Red Hat
description: MANILA, Sept. 3 (AP)Rufino Cardinal Santos, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Manila and the first Filipino to become a Cardinal, died today. He was 65 years old.

title: Stampeders Triumph
