description: CALGARY, Alberta, Sept. 3 (Canadian Press)  The Calgary Stampeders scored a 25.24 victory today over the cellardwelling Winnipeg Blue Bombers in a Western Football Conference game before21,445 ??.

title: SAMUEL ORNER DIES; INSPIRED LEFTY PLAY
description: Samuel Orner, who led the 1934 taxi strike here that was used by Clifford Odets, the playwright, as the setting for his 1933 play, Waiting for Lefty, died Sunday in Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 84 Dean Street, Tenafly, N. J.

title: Widnall Again Wins In Title Sail Series
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 3 (AP)Widnall of Marblehead, Mass., won his second straight race today in the International One  Design world championship regatta.

title: Raben Gains Vineyard Sail Trophy
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 3 Norman Raben's La Forza del Destino, which led the fleet home on the Stamford Yacht Club's 39th Vineyard race yesterday, was confirmed today as overall winner of the Vineyard Trophy on corrected time.

title: First Six Nations in E.E.C. Booming
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 3 (Reuters) Business is booming in all of the original six member nations of the European Economic Community, and company chiefs are confident that the vigorous economic expansion will continue.

title: PAKISTAN ASSURED ON U.S. FLOOD AID
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Sept, 3 (AP)A representative of President Nixon gave assurances today that the United States Government would help Pakistan recover from devastating floods.

title: Auto Talks Go On
description: DETROIT, Sept. 3 (AP)Talks between the United Automobile. Workers and Chrysler continued today despite the Labor Day holiday, but no agreements on key contract provisions were reported.

title: Tropical Storm Veers and Heads for Texas Coast
description: PORT ARTHUR, Tex., Sept. 3 (UPI)Tropical storm Delia, moving so fast it may never reach hurricane strength, turned a wide curve in the Gulf of, Mexico today and headed toward a landfall on the Texas Gulf, expected at daybreak tomorrow.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DATES It's past Labor Day and the summer showbiz doldrums presumably are over and what is left of cafe society begins perking again Tonight you can have your pick of: Eddie Haywood and his jazz piano at The Cookery, 8th Street at University Place, from 8 P.M. to 1 A.M. through Oct. 11. For reservations and information, call OR 4 4450.... Novella Nelson, taking off from her consulting chores at Joseph Papp's Public Theater and from understudying Pearl Bailey in Hello Dolly, to sing until Sept. 15 in the Paradise Room of Reno Sweeney, 126 West 13th Street. There's a $6 minimum here, but no cover. Reservations, CH 21366.... Don Cornell and Frankie Carr opening as an act at the Rainbow Grill in Rockefeller Center, through Sept. 22. Cornell began his career as a singer with Sammy Kaye in 1940, and the orchestra leader will be on hand to introduce the new team. Reservations, PL 78970.... Buddy Tate and the Jimmy McPartland Sextet and Maxine Sullivan at the Americana's Royal Box, also through Sept. 22. Information and reservations, 5811000. And tomorrow night Mel Torme opens in the Maisonette Room of the St. RegisSheraton for two shows nightly through Sept.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your Aug. 27 editorial Curb That Taxicab is surprisingly grouchy about an agency you have highly commended in the past. You claim the Taxi and Limousine Coinmission has been inexcusably sluggish in responding to environmental imperatives. I beg to differ.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: CONVOY REACHES CAMBODIAN CITY BATTLING A SIEGE
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sept. 3A convoy of 15 river boats carrying desperately needed supplies managed today to reach the encircled provincial capital of Kompong Cham, 45 miles northeast of here, a Cambodian Government spokesman said.

title: Slaying of Women Studied
description: SWANVILLE, Me., Sept. 3 (AP)Officials are investigating the slaying of two elderly Massachusetts women at their summer home in this Waldo County town. Elizabeth Jane Lemaire, 67 years old, and Jane Lemaire, 65, both of Taunton, were found shot to death late Saturday in a farmhouse where they had been vacationing for the summer. Officials said the incident was a double homicide, and the women may hate been dead for several days.

title: $12Million Pledged on TV To Fight Muscular Dystrophy
description: The Muscular Dystrophy Associations of America received pledges of more than $12million during the Jerry Lewis Labor Day Telethon, a 21hour show ending at 6:30 P.M. yesterday that was broadcast locally on WNEWTV.

title: Illegal Aliens Rounded Up
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 3 (AP)A massive roundup of illegal aliens was under way along the Mexican border today in the Labor Day weekend's final hours. A total of 990 arrests had been made since midnight Friday, a Border Patrol spokesman said. Most were promptly sent back across the border.

title: Strikes in Germany Add To Anxiety About Boom
description: BONN, Aug. 31The superheated West German economy, driven on by an export boom and beset by a high rate of inflation that has resisted the Government's attempts to treat it, has come under pressure in the last two weeks from a new irritantwildcat strikes in its biggest factories.

title: boy, 4, Slain and 2 Hurt In Harlem Traffic Dispute
description: A 4yearoldboy was shot to death and a 17yearold youth and an offduty policeman were wounded yesterday in Harlem when, the police said, a motorist fired into a group of people who had sided with another driver in a traffic dispute.

title: Books of The Times
description: DICKIE'S LIST. By Ann Birstein. 247 pages. Coward, McCann and Geoghegan. $6.95.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Dr. Peter Pillone Is Dead; Jersey Neurosurgeon, 44
description: FORT LEE, N.J., Sept 3Dr. Peter R. Pillone, a neurosurgeon in Paramus, died of a heart attack Friday while fishing off Hauppauge, L.I. He was 44 years old and lived at 56 Claremont Road.

title: DETAILS CALLED SET ON JETS FOR ISRAEL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (Reuters)Details have been completed by the United States and Israel on continued deliveries to Israel of American fighter planes, it was reported today.

title: For Some, Status Is the Cars They Lease
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 3 More and more Americans believe status is the car they drive, not the one they own. Taking their cue from corporate practice, increasing numbers of consumer are leasing automobiles instead of buying them.

title: LANDLORDS FINED TOTAL OF $39,600
description: Nathan Leventhal, the city's Rent and Housing Maintenance Commissioner, disclosed last night what he called a record package of fines, totaling $39,600, levied against seven landlords in four separate cases of alleged tenant harassment.

title: First Factoring Company Established in Singapore
description: SINGAPORE, Sept. 3 (Reuters)The Chartered Bank and Pacific International Lines have joined with Credit Factoring International, Ltd., subsidiary of the National Westminster Bank to establish the first factoring company in Singapore.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: SUMMIT, Sept. 3The question is what can Willie Wilson do for an encore? As a junior, Willie led Summit to conference titles in three sportsfootball, basketball and baseball. He was Union County's top scorer in football with 156 points, he averaged double numbers in both rebounding and scoring in basketball and he hit .444 in baseball.

title: Queens Bartender, 74, Shot to Death in Robbery
description: A 74yearold bartender in Ozone Park, Queens, was killed yesterday evening when he defied a gunman's demand for the money in his till, the police reported.

title: Soviet Berates U.S.Aided Radio For Carrying Sakharov Charge
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 3The Soviet Government charged today that an Americanfinanced radio station, beamed into the Soviet Union, was broadcasting statements by Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist who has become a target of a major, campaign of denunciation in the controlled press here.

title: Holiday Shoppers Throng Many Department Stores
description: Not everybody went to the beach yesterday.

title: COFFEE UNIT SET UP TO SUPPORT PRICES
description: LONDON, Sept. 3 (AP)Brazil, Colombia, and the Ivory Coast have jointly announced the setting up of a multinational coffeemarketing corporation capable of tapping credits up to $400million. Its aim is to support world coffee prices.

title: Ches: Five Youths (5Count 'em5) Win the U.S. Open Contest
description: This year's 778player United States Open Championship, sponsored by the Chicago Chess Club, was a triumph for the younger masters. No less than five achieved a tie for first place and not one had reached the age of 30.

title: Canadian Rail Union Yields
description: TORONTO, Sept. 3 (AP)The lone holdout union in Canada's national rail strike announced tonight that it had ordered its members back to their posts in conformance with a Government backtowork directive. The Canadian Brotherhood of Railway, Transport and General Workers, which represents 18,000 of the 56,000 nonoperating employes, originally had balked at the Governmentimposed settlement.

title: Mets Divide With Phils, Miss Chance to Advance
description: The Mets lost another chance to gain yardage in the homestretch yesterday when they split a doubleheader with the. Philadelphia Phillies while the frontrunners in the National League East were splitting two games in Pittsburgh.

title: New Chance in Cyprus
description: United Nations Secretary General Kurt Waldheim has discovered one reasonably hopeful spot in his Middle East tour. It is Cyprus, where a sharp reversal of policy by the Greek Government has spawned fresh hopes for a settlement of the senseless feuding between the Greek and Turkish communities.

title: JAPAN MAY BACK EUROPE ON TRADE
description: TOKYO, Sept. 3 (UPI)A Japanese trade official indicated today that Japan would align herself with European countries in opposing liberalization of trade terms in agriculture at international trade talks beginning next week.

title: Canon Almon Pepper, a Founder Of Church World Service, Dies
description: Canon Almon R. Pepper, director from 1936 to his retirement in 1967 of the department of Christian social relations of the Episcopal, Church, died yesterday of a heart attack in White Plains Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 23 Lewis Avenue, Hartsdale, N.Y.

title: FOREIGNBANKLAW HAILED IN CHICAGO
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 3  Illinois has just joined New York and California in permitting foreign banks to establish branches within the state.

title: Hope for Nairobi
description: A year of hard negotiations among the major financial powerscombined with the newly demonstrated ability of floating exchange rates to withstand severe shocks to confidence, massive speculation and hot money movementshas helped to dispel the crisis atmosphere in international money markets. As a result the United States, Japan and the European nations appear at last to be converging on a sensible approach to world monetary reform in time for the meeting of the International Monetary Fund in Nairobi later this month.

title: Arthur Daley
description: Billy Martin had been Casey Stengel's favorite right from the start and Ol' Case admiringly referred to him as that fresh little kid. Martin was the only Yankee who dared sass Stengel and Casey accepted it with such amused delight that his usual comment was, He's a pistol, ain't he? But Billy never presumed on his role of teacher's pet. He craftily sensed how far he could go and always shut up before he had reached the point of no return.

title: MAYORAL CONTEST BEGINS IN EARNEST
description: What politicians consider the official campaign season started yesterday with two of the four New York City mayoral candidates making traditional Labor Day visits to Coney Island and a third departing slightly from tradition to arrive, faded trunks wrapped in a towel, at a municipal pool in Manhattan, where he exchanged wet handshakes with bathers.

title: ERRORS ARE FOUND IN RELIEF CUTOFF
description: One out of six cases in which aid to families is halted or denied in New York City has been held by the state to be an error. The state checkup found the upstate rate to be more than one out of five.

title: ROBERT FOWLER JR., LANDSCAPE PLANNER
description: KATONAH, N.Y., Sept. 3Robert Ludlow Fowler Jr., landscape architect, died yesterday at his home here. His age was 86.

title: Advertising: Y.&R.'s Latest Unit
description: In January, Young & Rubicam International, Inc., established Y. & R. Enterprises, a wholly owned subsidiary to function as a smaller specialty unit. In February, it purchased Sudler & Hennessey, the largest agency in the healthcare field. Now the summer is drawing to a close and Y. & R. has struck again.

title: Holiday Comes to a Close, Hot and Sticky as It Began
description: Hordes of New Yorkers ended the Labor Day weekend and the summer's last fling at mountains and beaches yesterday and returned to their natural habitata city sweltering in its seventh straight day of 90degree temperatures. But break in the weeklong heat wave was expected today.

title: Waldheim Sees Hussein and Refugees
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 3 (Reuters)  Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations met today with King Hussein of Jordan for discussions of the Middle Eastern situation and the United Nations role in it.

title: 4 Guards Beaten in Hackensack In a HallHour Jail Disturbance
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., Sept 3  Four corrections officers were beaten by inmates at the Bergen County Jail in a brief disturbance this afternoon. Sheriff Joseph F. Job said that the uprising had been staged by five inmates of the maximumsecurity jail and that is lasted less than half an hour.

title: U.S. AND LATIN AIDES BEGIN ARMS PARLEY
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 3 (AP)High ranking United States and LatinAmerican military officers opened their 10th annual conference here today. There were indications that the Latin Americans would seek revision of the 27yearold reciprocal aid treaty.

title: Bridge:
description: The knockout event of the Labor Day tournament at the New York Hilton Hotel was won convincingly by Richard Budd, North Caldwell, N.J.; Steve Lebins, West Hartford; Chuck Lamprey, White Plains, and David Beer, Ken Lebensold and Steve Goldstein, all of New York City.

title: WorkforWelfare Rule Is Restored by the State
description: New York State's workforwelfare requirement is back in full force today, ending year's interruption because of court challenges.

title: LifeStyle for the Affluent Israelis: Heated Pools, Yachts and $23 Jeans
Texas Storm No Threat, So Skylab Control Stays
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 3 (AP)With tropical storm Delia posing no major treat to this space center, officials decided tonight not to dispatch a team of Skylab flight controllers to an alternate control center in Maryland.

title: 2 Paroled Slayers Win Early Round In Keeping Liberty
description: MANCHESTFR, N.H., Sept. 3 (AP)Freedom is assured for two paroled murderers, Frederick Martineau and Russell Nelson Jr., as long as the attempt by Gov. Meldrim Thomson Jr. to return them to the State Prison is pending in state courts.

title: Serene Shrine in Japan to Have Day in Sun
description: ISE, Japan  Inside the border of centuriesold cedars around the Ise Grand Shrine, abode of the Shinto goddess who is regarded as the spiritual mother of the Japanese nation, the most revered religious community in Japan determinedly maintains an oasis of serenity and contemplation in the midst of a highly industrialized region.

title: Malign Neglect
description: Fire Island, that splendid strip of barrier beach off the south shore of Suffolk County, appears to be in acute danger of destruction by commercial inroads and Federal indifference. Nine years ago Congress voted to incorporate more than half the island into a National Seashore so that the National Park Service could preserve and protect it as an area of great natural beauty in close proximity to large concentrations of urban population.

title: Jury to Meet on BreakIn At Ellsberg Doctor's Office
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 3 (AP) A county grand jury reconvenes tomorrow to decide whether to return indictments in connection with the breakin at the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.

title: Black Racketeers Challenging the Mafia
description: NEWARK, Sept. 3  The Mafia, entrenched in New Jersey for decades but confronted with aggressive law enforcement in recent years, is being challenged by another aggressive forceblack racketeers.

title: Highway Study Urged
description: BOSTON, Sept. 3 (AP)The Environmental Protection Agency has urged that planning for Interstate 93 through Franconia. Notch, N. H., be delayed until a study can be made on the environmental impact on the route. The new highway is to go through the area near the famed Old Man of The Mountain, and environmentalists are fighting the decision. The agency said too little was known about what effect the highway would have on the scenic area and urged delay.

title: Heat Sends Medical Staff At Open Into Extra Sets
description: The heat that felled Mrs. Billie Jean King at Forest Hills yesterday had become a formidable foe for players and spectators alike.

title: MiddleIncome College Student Finds It Difficult to Get U. S.Aid
description: While the Federal finandal aid picture for students preparing for the opening this fall of the nation's colleges and universities is even more muddled than usual, one fact seems clear: The outlook for middleincome students is indeed bleak.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: DARLINGTON, S. C., Sept. 3 (AP)Cale Yarborough bagged his first major victory in three years today and David Pearson became auto racing's fifth $1million career winner in the 24th running of the Southern 500 stock car race. Yarborough, driving a Chevrolet, beat Pearson's Mercury across the finish line by about eight seconds after a late race duel that kept the crowd of about 70,000 oil their feet for much of the final 100 miles.

title: Crime In, Sex Out, in New Film Season
description: The new movie season has no time for comedy and musicals are risky adventures, but crime continues to pay at the box office, where it joins a devilish interest in the supernatural as the year's predominant theme. A producer's ultimate achievement would be the story of a Mafioso who eliminates his victims by exorcism. Next year, perhaps.

title: Shopping Center Is Sold
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (UPI)The CNA Financial Corporetion's unit, CNA Realty Corporation, and F.M.&C. Enterprise, Inc., announced today they had sold a Chico, Calif., shopping center to First Continental Realty Fund, Ltd., for $7.1million. The North Valley Plaza regional shopping center is in a 420,000squarefoot mall, The purchaser is managed by Equity Control Corporation, a subsidiary of IDC Real Estate Corporation of Chicago.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Running for Governor
description: TRENTON, Sept. 3One of the most enduring rituals in New Jersey politics manifests itself every fourth Labor Day weekend in the opening gambits of the Democratic campaign for Governor.

title: Deauville Keeps Up With New Elite (With Style)
description: DEAUVILLE, France, Aug. 28Behind the brightly bordered hedges, behind the fantasy of gables and spires, in the boxes at the race track, on the terrace at the polo, in the highstakes room at the Casino, the people gathered for Deauville's August finale kept saying the same thing.

title: Mrs. Fairleigh Dickinson Sr., Philanthropist, Dies at 85
description: Mrs. Grace Smith Dickinson, widow of Col. Fairleigh S. Dickinson Sr., president and founder of Becton, Dickinson & Co., manufacturer of surgical instruments and medical supplies, and a founder of Fairleigh Dickinson University, died yesterday in Edgartown, Mass. She was 85 years old and lived in Rutherford, N.J.

title: Carina, Doberman, Gets Her Ninth Best in Show
description: PISCATAWAY. N. J., Sept. 3  A sleek blackandtan Doberman pinscher, Ch. Galaxy's Corry Carina who has been barking at the bestinshow door all weekend, finally was heard today and look the top award at the New Brunswick Kennel Club show at Johnson Park.

title: Damage Claims Against the City Exceed $1Billion for First Time
description: Personal and property damage claims against the city for the fiscal year that ended June 30 went over the billiondollar mark for the first time, Controller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday.

title: HiShear Seeks Shares
description: The HiShear Corporation announced over the weekend that it would make an offer to purchase up to 250,000 shares of its common stock at $12 per share net in cash. The tender offer will be made only by the formal offer of purchase, which the corporation plans to mail to its stockholders early this week.

title: British Football
description: English League Cup

title: On Labor Day, Many Living Here Find City a Nice Place to Visit
description: Labor Day is, for many New Yorkers, a day to enjoy the pleasures that sometimes seem reserved for summerholiday tourists. And so it was not surprising that at noon yesterday, most of those waiting at the new Times Square box office for halfprice tickets to Broadway shows were not outoftowners.

title: Jersey City Man Drowns
description: BYRAM TOWNSHIP, N. J., Sept. 3 (AP)Manual Mariquet, 39 years old, of 253 Eighth Street, Jersey City, drowned yesterday in Lake Tomahawk in this Sussex County community while on an outing with his wife and five children, the police said, Mr. Mariquet had eaten a large meal before going swimming. His body was recovered from four feet of water.

title: A Stitch in Haiti Saves Money, but Irks Yanks
description: DETROIT, Sept. 3Focus again was thrown today on the controversial baseball being stitched in Haiti when Sudden Sam McDowell, the New York Yankees' fireball throwing southpaw, was seen wearing small patches of tape on the index and middle fingers of his pitching hand.

title: BOOM CONTINUES IN WORLD TRADE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3World trade continued to boom In the first quarter of this year despite the international currency turmoil of the period, the International Moneary Fund reported today.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz is conducting an inquiry into complaints from individuals who purchased tickets for the recent Watkins Glen rock festival and were denied admission to the grounds because of traffic and general inaccessibility of the festival grounds.

title: JOHN F. RYAN
description: John F. Ryan, who retired, last year as president of J. C. Ryan & Sons, Inc., Yonkers, an architectural hardware concern, died Saturday in Gloversville, N. Y. He was 77 years old and lived at 1 Abbey Place, Yonkers.

title: CONGRESS MEETS TOMORROW, READY TO PRESS 2 ISSUES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 Congress reconvenes at noon Wednesday after a month's vacation and will press challenges to President Nixon on two major policy issueshis warmaking power and his right to halt the spending of funds appropriated by Congress.

title: 600,000 Get in Step With West Indian Beat of Brooklyn Parade
description: Despite a drenching rain that sent spectators scattering to storefronts and subway entrances, more than half a million people lined Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn yesterday for the annual West IndianAmerican Day Parade.

title: Yanks Win, 43, on Munson's Clout in 8th
description: DETROIT, Sept. 3  After only two days as acting manager of the Detroit Tigers, Joe Schultz knows how it feels to see his team lose a lead late in the game.

title: State Crop Output Is Up, But Heat Is Called Peril
description: TRENTON, Sept. 3New Jersey's tomatoes, known for their plump firmness and bright red color, don't like the heat wave any better than the state's wilting citizens do.

title: MSGR. JOHN J. FLANAGAN
description: Msgr. John J. Flanagan, pastor of St. Clare's Roman Catholic Church in Great Kills, S.I., since 1954, died Sunday in Staten Island Hospital.

title: Carina, Doberman, Gets Her Ninth Best in Show
description: PISCATAWAY, N. J., Sept. 3  A sleek blackandtan Doberman pinscher, Ch. Galaxy's Corry Carina who has been barking at the bestinshow door all weekend, finally was heard today and took the top award at the New Brunswick Kennel Club show at Johnson Park.

title: A Policeman Masquerades as a Cabby In a Police Car Masquerading as a Cab
description: David Goodman slapped the flag down on his taxi meter and, like any seasoned New York cabby, addressed himself affably to the rearview mirror.

title: MEANY SCORES NIXON ON ECONOMIC POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UPI) George Meany, President of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations said in a Labor Day radio address today that the Nixon Administration's economic policies had caused havoc in every area of American life except in the areas of bank and corporate profits.

title: Polaroid Focus Is on Jobs For South African Blacks
description: JOHANNESBURG  A oneyear experiment by the Polaroid Corporation of the United States to counter South Africa's discriminatory job and wage restrictions of its black majority is being successfully emulated by other Americanowned subsidiaries here.

title: Health Violations Found Here At 17 FoodHandling Concerns
description: Seventeen more foodhandling establishments here have been accused by the Health Department of violating the Health Code because their owners failed to provide valid reasons for infractions detected during two inspections.

title: Patty Cake and Parents Celebrate Her First Birthday With Banana Cake
description: Patty Cake, the Central Park Zoo's baby gorilla, was a year old yesterday. She and her parents, Lulu and Kongo, celebrated with banana layer birthday cake.

title: 10 Areas in Palisades Parks Close Because of Austerity
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Sept. 3Recreational and swimming areas of 10 large sections of the Palisades Interstate Park System closed for the season tonight because of an austerity budget. They had been open less than two and a half months this summer.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The president of the State Public Utilities Commission has asked President Nixon to grant tax relief to public utilities given rate increases under Phase 4 of the President's economic program. William E. Ozzard, in a letter to President Nixon, said that such relief would benefit consumers who pay not only for their direct utility services but also for indirect services included in the price.

title: Boy, 4, Slain and 2 Hurt In Harlem Traffic Dispute
description: A 4yearoldboy was shot to death and a 17yearold youth and an offduty policeman were wounded yesterday in Harlem when, the police said, a motorist fired into a group of people who had sided with another driver in a traffic dispute.

title: Mrs. King, Victim of Heat, Quits Match Against Miss Heldman
description: The three H'sheat, humidity and Heldmangot to Mrs. Billie Jean King yesterday, and the United States Open tennis championships lost its defending women's titleholder.

title: M'INTIRE VOWS FIGHT TO THE END
description: CAPE MAY, Sept. 3 (UPI)I am prepared to give my life for this cause, Dr. Carl McIntire, a fundamentalist preacher, said today as he dedicated an offshore radio ship and promised to provide vigorous, controversial programs.

title: New Recruiter for the Police
description: A special Police Department unit to recruit men and women from minority groups will begin work today, focused at first on producing a large turnout to take the December Civil Service examination for police officer.

title: Death of Kungfu Film Star Is Linked to Brain Edema
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 3 (AP)Bruce Lee, a star of kungfu movies, probably died of brain edema, an excess of fluid, that might have been caused by marijuana, a coroner reported today.

title: Ban on Liquor Ads Sought
description: ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 3, (AP)A resolution urging Congress to ban advertising of alcoholic beverages by radio and television stations was approved today by the Woman's Christian Temperance Union.

title: CARL DUDLEY DIES; FILM PRODUCER, 63
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Sept. 3 (UPI)Carl Ward Dudley, industrial and travel film maker who produced Cinerama South Seas Adventure, diet of a heart attack Saturday it Hong Kong. He was 63 year old.

title: ARIZONA CURTAILS SMOKING IN PUBLIC
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 3Or March 15, a Democratic State Senator, Harold Giss, puffing on a cigarette, took the Senate floor to denounce a bill to prohibit smoking in many public places, including restaurants and theaters.

title: Football Transactions
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: 22,000ACRE BLAZE CONTAINED ON COAST
description: CLEARLAKE OAKS, Calif., Sept. 3 (UPI)Firefighters succeeded tonight in enclosing a blaze that has blackened a 22,000acre region, which includes a big portion of the Mendocino National Forest.

title: French Money Growth Lags
description: PARIS, Sept. 3 (Reuters)France's gross money supply growth slowed to 1.7 per cent in June from 3.9 per cent in the same month last year, the Bank of France reported today. The central bank added that after seasonal adjustment the money supply contracted by 0.2 per cent in June following an expansion of 1.9 per cent in May this year, making a 5.6 per cent growth rate for the first half of 1973.

title: Israeli Labor Party Secretariat Approves Plan on Territories
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 3  The Secretariat of the governing Labor party today approved a controversial fouryear program for the administration of the Arab territories occupied in the 1967 war. The plan still has to he endorsed by the party's Central Committee.

title: Black Racketeers Challenging the Mafia
description: NEWARK, Sept. 3  The Mafia, entrenched in New Jersey for decades but confronted with aggressive law enforcement in recent years, is being challenged by another aggressive forceblack racketeers.

title: State Hunting Deer Poachers Who Sell the Meat
description: BREWSTER, N. Y., Sept. 3 After hours of sitting in his darkened car in the hot, huinid blackness of a newly mown alfalfa field here, Conservation Officer Paul Bernstein flipped on the vehicle's lights at about 1 AM. one day last week and drove away from his post a little disappointed.

title: Holiday Comes to a Close, Hot and Sticky as It Began
description: Hordes of New Yorkers ended the Labor Day weekend and the summer's last fling at mountains and beaches yesterday and returned to their natural habitata city sweltering in its seventh straight day of 90degree temperatures. But a break in the weeklong heat wave was expected today.

title: MAYORAL CONTEST BEGINS IN EARNEST
description: What politicians consider the official campaign season started yesterday with two of the four New York City mayoral candidates making traditional. Labor Day visits to Coney Island and a third departing slightly from tradition to arrive, faded trunks wrapped in a towel, ata municipal pool in Manhattan, where he exchanged wet handshakes with bathers.

title: Business Briefs
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 3 (Reuters)World oil production increased by 5 million barrels a day between Jan. 1 and May 31, Venezuela's Ministry of Mines and Hydrocarbons announced today. According to this estimate, world production would be about 54 million barrels a day.

title: Japanese Concern Sets Deal On South Korea Products
description: TOKYO, Sept. 3 (AP)The Victor Company of Japan, Ltd., has agreed to have the Saehan Precision Industrial Company of South Korea, manufacture color and momochrome television receivers, tape recorders and stereo sets mainly for export to the United States and Europe.

title: ARABS AND ISRAELIS ADMITTED TO PARLEY
description: GENEVA, Sept. 3 (UPI)A committee reached a compromise agreement today to permit all Mediterranean nations, including Israel, to take part in the second phase of the European security conference scheduled to begin here Sept. 18.

title: Saigon Imprisons Heads of 3 Unions
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 3Three dissident labor leaders were sentenced to 18 months in jail by a military court today on charges of participation in a Communist plot to subvert the Saigon labor movement.

title: NEW HOME SOUGHT FOR LIBERTY BELL
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3 The Liberty Bell may soon be moved from Independence Hall, where it has rested for nearly two centuries.

title: People in Sports: Aides Join Martin as Jobless
description: Firing salvos would make it sound like sour grapes, said a cairn Billy Martin, the ritually hottempered man who was dismissed Sunday as manager of the Detroit Tigers by Jim Campbell, general manager. I will take it easy and get my mind clear, he said.

title: Wounded Seal Dies As Officials Argue Over Jurisdiction
description: BOOTHBAY HARBOR, Me., Sept. 3 (AP)A wounded seal that lay unattended on a beach for 14 hours yesterday because of a jurisdictional dispute between state and Federal officials died early today.

title: JOURNALIST CALLED G.O.P. AGENT IN 1968
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) A journalist hired by the Republicans to report on the activities of 1972 Democratic Presidential candidates gathered similar information in 1968 on Hubert H. Humphrey, Jack Anderson, the columnist, reports.

title: Industry Sees Minor Price Rise in Gas Deregulation,
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3The oil industry published today a report intended to reassure the public and Congress that Federal deregulation of natural gas prices by itself would cause only minor increases in the bills of the country's 39 million residential customers.

title: Trial Federal Program On Gun Thefts Expanded
description: Because the theft of guns from interstate shipments has been found to he a possibly serious nationwide problem, a Federal reporting program tried out in only New England since July 1 is being extended throughout the country, The Associated Press reported.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: A Saturday Morning
description: It was a good session, according to Gerald Warren, the White House statement issuer. It was just the thing to do on a Saturday morning, said J. Marsh Thomson, press secretary to the Vice President. They were referring, of course, to the meeting between President Nixon and Mr. Agnew, and the notes of that meeting support these accounts of the conversation as bland pudding. Here are the official notes from the White Houseleak secretary:

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Despite a drenching rain, a huge throng lined Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn for the annual West IndianAmerican Day parade.

title: Desert Vixen Sets Record in Belmont's Gazelle
description: There will be another star racing at Belmont Park on Sept. 15, and it will not be in the $250,000 Marlboro Cup. Desert Vixen, who carried Harry Mangurian Jr.'s silks to a sixlength victory yesterday in the $56,300 Gazelle Handicap for 3yearold fillies performed so creditably that her owner plans to run her in the $100,000 Beldame Stakes that day. Desert Vixen, who has won seven straight races, six of them stakes, thrilled the 40,641 fans with a stakerecord performance. She went to the front shortly after the start and stayed there all the way under the urging of Jorge Velasquez, her jockey.

title: SHIP CARGO PERIL WAS NONEXISTENT
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 3 (Reuters)  The Coast Guard said tonight that the report of a dangerous chemical aboard a burning ship that resulted in the evacuation of an entire town of 500 persons was all mistake.

title: U.S. Withdrawing a Wing Of 3,000 Men From Taiwan
description: HONOLULU, Sept. 3 (UPI)The first major pullout of American military men from Taiwan has been announced by Adm. Noel A.M. Gayler, commander in chief of United States military forces in the Pacific.

title: Dr. Charles W. Hunt, Led Oneonta Teachers College
description: ONEONTA, N. Y., Sept. 3Dr. Charles W. Hunt, president of Oneonta State Teachers College from 1942 to 1951 and Oneonta State Normal Schooll from 1933 to 1942, died here, today at the age of 92.

title: Nixon Aides Tend to Oppose Bar on Food Exports
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3It amounts to playing God, and I don't like it, says Edgar R. Fiedler. It is as painful and difficult a decision for the Government as I can recall.

title: MiddleIncome College Student Finds It Difficult to Get U.S.Aid
description: While the Federal financial aid picture for students preparing for the opening this fall of the nation's colleges and universities is even more muddled than usual, one fact seems clear: The outlook for middleincome students is indeed bleak.

title: Football Transactions
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Arabs' Emerging Oil Strategy
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 3The emerging Arab strategy for use of oil as a political weapon against Israel is based on a potentially serious energy shortage in the Western industrial countries and Japan if Middle East producers restrict their output of oil.

title: From Europe's Viewpoint, Soybean Crisis Has Ended
description: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Sept. 3The soybean crisis, from the European point of view, appears to have ended.

title: HEALTH CARE PLAN WOULD TAP TAXES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3The Nixon Administration has under study a proposal that would eliminate deductions for medical bills from income tax returns, which, if enacted, would cost taxpayers an estimated $7.5billion a year.

title: Mr. Nixon's Plausible Fallacies
description: Some words have the sound of logic without the ring of truth. To one who was far from the August action but who had plenty of time to contemplate events, that seems to be the case with some of President Nixon's most important defensive positions. They just don't stand too much looking into.

title: Jet Crash Survivor Critical
description: BOSTON, Sept. 3 (AP)  Air Force Sgt. Leopold Chouinard, 20 years old, of Marshfield, Vt., the only survivor of a jetliner crash at Logan International Airport July 31 that took 88 lives, was reported in critical but stable condition today at Massachusetts General Hospital.

title: 30,000 Arabs in Marseilles Strike Over Racism Issue
description: MARSEILLES, France, Sept. 3 (AP)Some 30,000 Arab workers stayed off their jobs in the Marseilles area today to protest what a handbill called the racist wave directed against them.

title: Pinched for Funds, State Curbs Its Sewage Goals
description: ALBANY, Sept. 3Because of the impoundment of Federal aid funds, New York State has rated 156 proposed municipal sewagetreatment plants in order of priority and decided that only the top 29 can be built this year and next.

title: CONSUMER SPENDING IN BRITAIN FALLS
description: LONDON, Sept. 3 (Reuters)Consumer pending in Britain fell, in real terms, by three per cent in the second quarter of 1973, according to the Central Statistics Office.

title: A Stitch in Haiti Saves Money, but Irks Yanks
description: DETROIT, Sept. 3Focus again was thrown today on the controversial baseball being stitched in Haiti when Sudden Sam McDowell, the New York Yankees' fireball throwing southpaw, was seen wearing small patches of tape on the index and middle fingers of his pitching hand.

title: Chinese Troops Still Manning Road in Northern Laos
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 1Chinese troops are manning antiaircraft installations along a road they have built in northern Laos, but neither the Laotian Government nor the United States Embassy seems particularly disturbed.

title: Giants Join Pigeons in Jersey City
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 3 Last Saturday night, before the equipment or Gatorade was even unpacked, the burglar alarm sounded at the offices and new training headquarters of the New York Giants at Roosevelt Stadium.

title: Baltimore Inquiry Focusing on Agnew's Bridge Contract to the Greiner Company
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 3  In their continuing investigation of Vice President Agnew, Federal prosecutors in Baltimore have focused much of their attention on the J. E. Greiner Company, a controversial consulting engineering concern long active in Maryland politics.

title: Learning by Working?
description: The effectiveness of public education has come under fresh challenge in the recent report of the Panel on Youth of President Nixon's Science Advisory Committee. The study, directed by Dr. James S. Coleman, an authority on adolescence and on the educational problems of racial minorities, charges that too many American youths stay in school too long. It contends that large numbers could derive greater benefits from earlier chances to work and learn outside the schools.

title: PROTEST IS MADE ON LIBRARY FUNDS
description: A group of notables in the book world have protested preliminary action by the Nixon Administration that would eliminate Federal financing of local, state and institutional libraries.

title: 11 North Koreans Arrive To Set Up a U.N. Mission
description: Eleven North Koreans who will serve as their nation's first observers at the United Nations arrived at Kennedy Airport yesterday to a welcoming party that included representatives of the Chinese and other Communist missions.

title: Programs Helping College Students
description: Following are the five major programs administered through the United States Office of Education for aiding postsecondary school students and the major stateoperated programs in the metropolitan area. In addition to these programs there are other specialized forms Federal assistance, private loans and a wide variety scholarships offered by foundations, agencies and the educational institutions themselves.

title: Tappan Sells Plant
description: MANSFIELD, Ohio, Sept. 3 (UPI)The Tappan Company has announced that Jim Walter Corporation has bought its 150,000  square  foot cabinet making plant in Williamsport, Pa. for $1.8million. Tappan originally had planned to relocate the plant to a Richmond, Va. facility.

title: National League
description: (Tuesday, September 4, 1973

title: Casper's 64 For a 264 Takes Golf
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Sept. 3After a thunderstorm forced a 50minute halt in the $200,000 Sammy Davis Jr.Greater Hartford open today, Billy Casper went on to win with a closing 64 for 264. His total is the lowest on the pro tour this year.

title: ALBERT NICHOLAS, JAZZ CLARINETIST
description: GENEVA, Sept. 3Albert Nicholas, the American jazz clarinetist, died today in a hospital at Basel, after failing to recover from a recent operation. He was 73 years old.

title: Sale of Met Tickets Opens This Morning
description: Tickets for the first two weeks of the Metropolitan Opera's 197374 season will go on sale today at 10 A.M. at the company's Lincoln Center box office. The season will open Sept. 17 with Verdi's Il Trovatore.

title: Aaron Hits 707 and 708 Off Padres
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 3 (AP) Henry Aaron hit the 707th and 708th homers of his career to move within six of Babe Ruth's major league mark of 714 tonight as the Atlanta Braves handed the San Diego Padres their seventh straight loss, 73.

title: Nixon to Meet Cabinet And G.O.P. Leadership
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UPI)President Nixon will meet with his Cabinet and the Republican leadership at the White House later this week to discuss issues to lay before Congress as it returns from a recess.

title: A.F.C. Calls Meeting
description: The American Financial Corporation announced yesterday that it had called a shareholders' meeting for Thursday, Sept. 27 in Cincinnati to consider and vote on the company's offer to acquire the National General Corporation.

title: East German Wins Women's Diving Title
description: BELGRADE, Sept. 3The bounce was missing from the two American girls today and they could not come close to an East German and the other Europeans in the finals of the women's threemeter springboard diving of the world aquatic championships.

title: Tolkien's Publisher Says Silmarillion Will Be Released
description: LONDON, Sept. 37he Silmarillion, the last work of J. R. R. Tolkien, is not complete but eventually will be published, his publisher said here today.

title: Reserve Revises List For OTC Margins
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (Reuters)The Federal Reserve Board published today a revised list of 638 overthecounter stocks that are subject to its margin regulations, effective as of the opening of business tomorrow.

title: Scheckter Takes 3d, Wins Title
description: MOUNT POCONO, Pa., Sept. 3 (AP)  Brian Redman finished first in the L. & M. Formula 5000 championship race today, but a thirdplace finish gave Jody Scheckter the series title.

title: LENIN TOMB BLAST IS SAID TO KILL 3
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 3 Usually reliable Soviet sources said today that three persons were killed Saturday by the explosion of a homemade bomb in the Lenin Mausoleum on Red Square.

title: 5 Killed by Wild Auto
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 3 (AP)Five persons were killed and one critically injured yesterday when an automobile went out of control and careened into a crowd leaving an air show here. The dead were identified as Camillo J. Resch, 70 years old; his son, Phillip, 37, and grandson, Terry, 8, all of Lorain, and Gery Williams, 33, and his 6yearold son, Paul, of Eastlake. The police said the car was driven by Joseph A. Chaney Jr., 22, of Cleveland.

title: Brooklyn Residents Pray to Keep Their Homes
description: About 150 residents of the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn took part in a street mass on North Fourth, Street between Bedford and Berry Avenues yesterday to pray for 10 families living on the block who are scheduled to lose their homes Saturday when a city eviction notice takes effect.

title: Roundup: Cardinals Split With Pirates, Hold Lead
description: Baseball tradition has it that the team that leads the league on July 4 will win the pennant  and then go into the World Series.

title: CONVOY REACHES CAMBODIAN CITY BATTLING A SIEGE;Kompong Cham Resupplied by River, but Situation Is Said to Get Worse
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sept. 3A convoy of 15 river boats carrying desperately needed supplies managed today to reach the encircled provincial capital of Kompong Cham, 45 miles northeast of here, a Cambodian Government spokesman said.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Alberta Wright used to make a habit of flying to Paris to look over the latest styles, especially the interpretations of styles of bygone years, but she eventually found the price tags were placing too much of a strain on her budget.

title: Kruger Acquires Mill
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 3 (UPI)Kruger Pulp & Paper, Ltd., a privatelyowned concern, has announced it has acquired the newsprint mill operated by a Domtar, Ltd., unit, St. Lawrence Corporation, at Trois Rivieres, Quebec. Kruger said the transaction was worth about 50million. The company said it received assurance from the Quebec Provincial Government that the mill could have enou&h wood supply for longterm demand.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: A comment that should shock Americans as much as Watergate was made recently by Scott Sullivan, the Paris bureau chief of Newsweek. The truth is that when it comes to that difficulttodefine experience known as the quality of life, he wrote, millions of Europeans are living better than we do.

title: New Land Ethic: Its Spread Raises Political and Legal Issues to Be Resolved by Public
description: The nationwide movement toward landuse regulation poses an array of important and nearly inescapable policy decisions that the public is going to be called on to resolve.

title: BRENNAN CREDITS NIXON FOR GAIN
description: Secretary of Labor Peter J. Brennan yesterday praised the Nixon Administration's accomplishments for the nation's working men and women.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Some years ago, this writer became intrigued with the idea of catching the world record striped bass on a flyrod, and devoted the evenings through most of one October to that end.

title: U.S. Prepares to Vacate The 1907 Custom House
description: Shipping Row's most prominent landmarkthe Custom House on Bowling Green is about to become deserted.

title: Presence of Cholera in Rome Verified
description: ROME, Sept. 3The presence of cholera was verified in Rome today as one man died and another was found to have contracted the disease.

title: Carrier to Join Reserve Fleet
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 3 (AP)The aircraft carrier Ticonderoga goes into the Navy's reserve fleet tomorrow to join ships in mothballs. In about a year, Navy spokesmen say, her fate will be determined. After going into action for the first time in 1944, the Ticonderoga's aircraft flew strikes against Japanese forces in the Pacific. Two kamikaze suicide planes hit her on Jan. 1, 1945, taking the lives of 143 men and wounding 202.

title: At Chicago's Oak Beach, Come on inWater's Fine
description: CHICAGOThe bikiniclad young woman, dozing in the noonday sun while acquiring another layer of tan, was unaware of the stares of the fully clothed male chauvinist who sat on a nearby bench.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: NEWSMAN CONCEDES HE GOT G.O.P. PAY
description: LONDON, Sept. 4, (Reuters) An American journalist, Seymour Freidin, conceded today that he had received sums of money from the Republican party for relaying information from the Democratic camp during the 1968 and 1972 Presidential elections.

title: A SUGARMAN AIDE ACCEPTS NEW POST
description: Charles Morris, who has headed the city's reorganized program for determining welfare eligibility and grants since March, 1972, was named yesterday as Secretary of Social and Health Services for the State of Washington. He will take the new post on Nov. 1.

title: TRUSTY GIVES UP IN JERSEY MURDER
description: TRENTON, Sept. 4A convicted killer who did household chores at Morven, the Governor's mansion, under a workrelease program was arrested yesterday on suspicion of killing a man with a hatchet on Sunday during his first weekend furlough from prison.

title: Red Smith
description: When the World Journal Tribune, that bewildered relict of three New York newspapers, died in 1967, the best baseball writer in America retired. His name is Tommy Holmes, and readers deprived of his stuff these six years will pleased to know that he is alive and well in Brooklyn. Alive and well and abreast of the news, as the following letter demonstrates, far better informed than most. Tommy writes:

title: North Koreans Choose Quarters at Waldorf
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 4An 11man delegation from North Korea, here to open that Government's first diplomatic office at the United Nations, has chosen the WaldorfAstoria for its temporary quarters. A member of the party declined to discuss the hotel accommodations for the mission.

title: Smith, Kodes Reach Quarterfinals
description: His only emotion a slight twitch of the blond mustache, Stan Smith coolly wore down Tom Gorman yesterday and advanced to the quarterfinals of the $227,000 United States Open tennis championships at Forest Hills.

title: Burned Trees Are Salvaged on Coast
description: SONORA, Calif., Sept. 4 (AP)Trees that once burned in forest fires can be salvaged for use in homebuilding, and logging crews now are hauling out scorched lumber from forests throughout California and other Western States. The worst fires in 20 years in those states have ravaged almost 200,000 acres of trees and brush.

title: Court Electronics Backed
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept, 4 (AP) The Philadelphia Bar Association is supporting the installation of electronic equipment in some courtrooms to relay proceedings to newsmen outside

title: Tightening the Valve
description: Unofficial reports on the secret talks held by Arab oil ministers in Kuwait yesterday carry the welcome news that no common policy of political blackmail against the United States and other major oilconsuming nations was adopted.

title: Junior Tennis Today
description: Sixteen juniors from 11 countries begin play at the West Side Tennis Club in the first Junior International tournament today. The event, sponsored by PepsiCola, is in conjunction with the United States Open. Billy Martin of Palles Verdes, Calif., who lost to Smith in the Open, is seeded No. 1.

title: Pamela Mars Wed To Allan Malester
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4Miss, Pamela Lynn Mars, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Mars of Bethesda, Md., was married here this evening to Allan Jeffrey Malester, son of Mrs. Maurice Shugar of Baltimore and the late Frank Malester. Rabbi Joshua Haberman performed the ceremony at the Madison Hotel.

title: F.P.C. LIMITS ROLE ON GAS FROM COAL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) The Federal Power Commission ruled today that it had no jurisdiction to regulate production or transportation of synthetic gas produced from coal when unmixed with natural gas. But the commission said it did have jurisdiction over the gas produced from coal when it is mixed with natural gas and transported or sold in interstate commerce.

title: MRS. MARGARET ANGELO
description: YORK, Pa., Sept. 4 (AP)Mrs. Margaret A. Angelo, who had been decorated by two Popes, died here Sunday. She was 82 years old.

title: Boy, 12 Hurt in a Shootout During Bronx Drug Arrest
description: A 12yearold boy was wounded yesterday when he was struck by pellets from a shotgun blast that hit a suspected heroin dealer during a shootout on a Bronx thoroughfare.

title: Black Baptists Meet
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 4 (UPI) The National Baptist Convention, U.S.A., Inc., with 6.5 million members the largest black organization in the nation,, opened its 93d annual meeting today at the Los Angeles Convention Center. Convention organizers said that more than 20,000 delegates were expected to attend the sixday meeting.

title: Port Washington Teachers Union Gets a FiveYear Contract
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 4A fiveyear contract, said to be the longest teacher contract on record in the United States, was agreed to in the Port Washington School District early this morning.

title: Equity Financing
description: An offering of 750,000 common shares of the Digital Equipment Corporation at 89 per share was made yesterday by underwriters headed by Lehman Brothers. The company's stock was up  at 89 on the New York Stock Exchahge.

title: Public Interest Research Groups on 138 Campuses Set to Fight Local Problems
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4On 138 college campuses across the country this fall, social action and consumerism will joining beer parties and football as major extracurricular activities.

title: PAUL WILLIAMS
description: Paul Williams, a lawyer who was a special assistant to Assistant Attorney General Thurman Arnold in major antitrust prosecutions during the Roosevelt Administration, died Monday in a Greenwich, Conn., nursing home. He was 85 years old.

title: MUSIC HALL SEEKS CUTBACK OF SHOWS
description: The Radio City Music Hall's traditional policy of stage shows with movies faced possible curtailment as a result of its negotiation with the musicians' union, which has already shut down the New York City Opera.

title: EVERETT D. DAVIS
description: ROCHESTER, Sept. 4Everett D. Davis, vice president and traffic manager of the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad at his retirement in 1962, died yesterday at his home here. He was 81 years old.

title: Rare Sight: Public Sale of Giants' Tickets
description: The New York Giants did a thriving business yesterday in the sale of tickets on an individual game basis for their five contests at the YaleBowl in New Haven. According to a Giants' spokesman, 1,200 tickets were sold, primarily for games with the Washington Redskins, the Green Bay Packers and Dallas Cowboys. Tickets, at $8 each, were also available for games with the St. Louis Cardinals and Minnesota Vikings.

title: Lodi Moves to Bar Rebuilding Of Plant in Explosion Fatal to
description: LODI, N. J., Sept. 4The Town Council voted tonight to take every legal step to prohibit the reconstruction of the Mallinckrodt Chemical Company's plant here, which was partly destroyed three weeks ago in a fire and explosion that killed seven employes.

title: GRAND JURY ACTS IN COAST BREAKIN
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 4A Los Angeles County grand jury returned today secret indictments against unnamed defendants after the final day of testimony in the inquiry into the burglary at the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.

title: U.S. and Thai Aides Hold Talks on American Pullout
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. (UPIAmerican and Thai Government officials began a second round of talks today on the withdrawal of United States forces from six bases in Thailand.

title: Moth Warning Issued
description: URBANA, Ill., Sept. 4 (UPI) Illinois residents returning from areas with gypsy moth populations have been urged to check their vehicles for egg masses resembling a piece of sponge. A University of Illinois Extension service entomologist issued the warning yesterday after announcing that two gypsy moths had been trapped in Illinois.

title: AGNEW CASE INQUIRY RULED OUT BY DASH
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UPI) The Senate Watergate committee has not turned up evidence to warrant an Investigation of Vice President Agnew, its chief counsel, Samuel Dash, said today.

title: Times's Bid for Injunction Against Printers Is Put Off
description: A court hearing scheduled for today on an application by The New York Times for a permanent injunction to bar members of Typographical Union 6 from interfering with production of the paper by holding union meetings during working hours was postponed yesterday until tomorrow.

title: Northside Compromise
description: The inevitable clash between jobs and people in a city with limited room for business expansion often results in disruption and anguish. That makes both encouraging and important the achievement in Brooklyn's closeknit, ethnic Northside district of an acceptable compromise between the city and the community in a dispute over the conflicting claims of plant location and family relocation. Regrettably, however, the settlement may collapse in new discord unless a path is found this week through a maze of bureaucratic red tape.

title: Daughter of Sihanouk Leaves for Hong Kong
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sept. 4 Princess Norodom Bopha Devi, daughter of Cambodia's former Chief of State, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, left here with her family for Hong Kong last night. She was the first member of the Prince's immediate family to be allowed out of Cambodia by the Government since Prince Sihanouk was deposed in 1970.

title: Jim Brewer Ailing
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 4 (UPI)  The Dodgers star relief pitcher, Jim Brewer, complaining of back pains following last night's game against the San Francisco Giants, flew home today and was put in traction at Centinela Valley Hospital. The team physician, Dr. Frank Jobe, said Brewer might be laid up for the remainder of the week.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Diabetic's Parents Released
description: BARSTOW, Calif., Sept. 4 (AP)Lawrence and Alice Parker, charged with manslaughter after their 11yearold diabetic son, Wesley, died when his insulin was thrown away, were released from jail on their own recognizance today. They said they felt he had been cured by a faith healer and admitted throwing away the insulin that had kept him alive for five years. They still maintain the boy will be resurrected. A preliminary hearing is scheduled for Sept. 13.

title: MARTIN C. POWERS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) Martin Corey Powers, chief speech writer and special assistant to the Secretary of Agriculture, died Saturday in Suburban Hospital, Bethesda, Md. He was 63 years old.

title: Looking To the Future
description: WASHINGTONIn the days since he was nominated to be the 57th Secretary of State, Henry Kissinger has arranged a series of intensive discussions with the most experienced former and present leaders of the State Department and the Foreign Service.

title: Tough SeatBelt System Awaits NewCar Buyers
description: Americans are about to face the most extreme test yet of how much convenience they are willing to give up in exchange for cutting traffic deaths. After years of Madison Avenue efforts at persuasion that failed, the Government hopes to all but force newcar buyers into using safety belts.

title: People in Sports: Accursed Luck
description: It sounded like a crime of passion passion for golf that Joseph C. Dey, commissioner of the Professional Golfer's Association's Tournament Players' Division, was describing yesterday as he announced a year's suspension and $1,000 fine for Jim King of Miami.

title: Budapest Ballet Visits Edinburgh Fete
description: EDINBURGH, Sept. 4In recent years dance has played a comparatively meager role in the Edinburgh International Festival, where drama and music still reign supreme. The reason is quite simply a shortage of suitable theatersthere is hardly anywhere practicable to place largescale dance companies. Also, these few theaters are held sacred to opera and drama.

title: APPELLATE COURT ORDERS SPEEDUP IN TAPES DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4President Nixon's pending appeal of the court ruling last. week that he must surrender the Watergate tape recordings for private judicial inspection will move up to the SupremeCourt faster than the parties to the historic lawsuit thought possible.

title: DOLLAR GAINS A BIT AS TRADING DECLINES
description: LONDON, Sept. 4 (UPI)The dollar changed direction at midday today and gained in value against most European currencies in quiet trading. Gold also increased slightly.

title: School Aides, Aiming to Hold Line, May Raise Food Prices
description: Buard of Education officials said yesterday that they were making every effort to hold the line on prices that 60,000 students pay for basic meals in public and parochial schools here daily.

title: Bridge: Delicate Play Brings Victory To Hand That Seemed Beaten
description: The Swiss team event Monday that concluded the Labor Day tournament at the New York Hilton Hotel resulted in a resounding double victory for John Bookstaver, Mill Valley, Calif.; Harry Stappenbeck, Uniondale, L. I.; Richard Budd, North Caldwell, N. J., and David Beer, New York.

title: Rookie Hit Tops Yanks In 21 Game
Briefs On The Arts
description: Two film buffs who felt there were plenty of revival theaters here showing European art films but not many offering Hollywood classics have decided to open a midtown revival house devoted to forgotten American films.

title: TRUDEAU OFFERS BILL ON INFLATION
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 4  Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, under increasing pressure from the political Opposition, today presented a broad program to combat the effects of inflation.

title: DISTRICTING SUIT FILED IN MICHIGAN
description: LANSING, Mich., Sept. 4 Michigan's legislative districts, which have been redrawn to the Democrats' advantage, have come under a challenge in Federal court that may have ramifications in several other states.

title: An American TV Employe In Rome Freed From Jail
description: ROME, Sept. 4 (UPI)  The district attorney's office today released an American television employe, Jack L. Begon, from jail without bail pending further action on charges of fabricating his own kidnapping and taking company funds.

title: A Holdup Man Trades Toy Gun for Real One
description: A holdup man with a toy pistol robbed, a Manhattan grocer of more than $100 yesterday and then, in a chase and struggle, managed to take the victim's real gun before making his escape, the police reported.

title: About the Jets:
description: Steve Thompson, the defensive tackle who suffered a charley horse and a sprained ankle in last Saturday night's game gainst the New Orleans Saints, has been deactivated. He will be eligible to return for the season opener Sept. 17 against the Green Bay Packers. . . . Seven other player cuts to get the roster down to 44 players are expected be announced today. . . . Don Maynard still has not returned to camp. Maynard left the team after the game in New Orleans to return to his home in El Paso, Tex., because of illness in his wife's family. . . . The Jets will close their Hofstra training camp after tomorrow's workout and resume practice sessions at Rikers Island on Sept. 12 until they are able to gain the full use of Shea Stadium. We'll be dressing at Shea, said Coach Weeb Ewbank and going over to Rikers Island. Shea Stadium is not a good place to get a team in shape. There are too many interruptions. . . . Ewbank said he had been in telephone contact with John Riggins, his holdout fullback.

title: Black Muslim Leader Shot to Deathin Newark
description: NEWARK, Sept. 4James Shabazz, a Black Muslim leader here, was shot to death in the driveway of his home this afternoon. The police were seeking two men believed to have run up to Mr. Shabazz and fired at him as he was getting out of his car.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Roundup: Reverse Call Puts Cards 2 Games Up
description: Lou Brock is the personification of Willard Mullin's famous cartoon, the St. Louis Swifty.

title: Barnett, Chones in New Roles
description: Dick Barnett retired as a player yesterday and was named an assistant coach of the Knicks. Jim Chones, once regarded as the bright hope of the Nets, was traded to the Carolina Cougars of the American Basketball Association.

title: A SUGARMAN AIDE ACCEPTS NEW POST
description: Charles Morris, who has headed the city's reorganized program for determining welfare eligibility and grants since March, 1972, was named yesterday as Secretary of Social and Health Services for the State of Washington. He will take the new post on Nov. 1.

title: HighPressure System Is Like the One Usually Over Los Angeles
description: A lumbering, now weak, highpressure air mass that has brought the metropolitan area eight straight days of temperatures above 90 has also clamped a lid over much of the East Coast.

title: Bethlehem Adds Greek Unit
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said yesterday it had created an affiliated company in Greece to be known as the BethlehemGreek Mining Company, Ltd.

title: Nadjari Opens Inquiry on S.I. Arson Case
description: Maurice H. Nadjari, the state's special prosecutor, is investigating the handling of a yearlong investigation by the Staten Island District Attorney's office of an apparently racially motivated arson case that implicated one and possibly two police officers.

title: Cathay Pacific Airways Receives Eximbank Loan
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (Reupers)Tne United States ExportImport Bank is lending Cathay Pacific Airways, Ltd., of Hong Kong $12.397,500 to cover 45 per cent of the cost of six used Boeing 707 airliners, the bank announced today.

title: People in Sports: Accursed Luck
description: It sounded like a crime of passion  passion for golfthat Joseph C. Dey, commissioner of the Professional Golfer's Association's Tournament Players Division, was describing yesterday as he announced a year's suspension and $1,000 fine for Jim King of Miami.

title: Mrs. Josephine Lloyd Is Married in London
description: LONDON, Sept. 4 Mrs. Josephine Lloyd of New York and East Norwich, L. I., was married here today to Harold Oakley Barker.

title: The Country Store Makes a Comeback
description: TANNERSVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 4  The small parking lot off Main Street here was jammed with cars last weekend, with shoppers crowding into the A. & P. at one end of the lot and at the other, scarcely 100 yards away, into Pratt's Place, a relatively new country store.

title: Why Sweden?
description: As one of Europe's traditional neutrals, Sweden has performed many mediatory and goodwill missions in the intrnational community. More recently the Swedish Government has ventured at times to act as a moral spokesman. Thus, last December Prime Minister Olof Palme was particularly forceful in expressing the outrage and dismay which many Europeans felt at the renewed United States bombing of North Vietnam only a few weeks after the Nixon Administration had announced that peace is at hand.

title: Black Muslim Leader in Newark Shot to Death
description: NEWARK, Sept. 4 James Shabazz, a Black Muslim leader here, was shot to death in the driveway of his home this afternoon. The police were seeking two men believed to have run up to Mr. Shabazz and fired at him as he was getting out of his car.

title: The OneParty Press
description: WINDSOR, Vt.On the first anniversary of Watergate, and for several weeks now, the American public read and heard universal praise, appreciation and applause for a free press in a free country. A confirmation in 1973 of Jefferson's 1787 view that newspapers without government would be preferable to government without newspapers. American democracy again had shown the world that a press free from all outside restraint, even from selfcriticism by a council, had proved the best of all possible systems.

title: U.S. LABOR RAISING FUNDS FOR BYRNE
description: TRENTON, Sept. 4Qualified Democratic sources reported today that organized labor across the country was prepared to send a quarter of a million dollars into New Jersey in an effort to elect Brendan T. Byrne, the Democratic candidate for Governor.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: WOODWINDS Navigation may be somewhat of a problem but it's worth an early evening's sail up 42d Street from Times Square, to the Wurlitzer Building just west of the Avenue of the Americas for the first concert of the season by the New York Kammermusiker.

title: Much at Stake in Trade and Money Talks
description: In Tokyo next week some 80 pices of the General Agree nations, meeting under the ausment on Tariffs and Trade, will seek agreement on the basic objectives of a major trade negotiation in 1974the first since the Kennedy round of the nineteensixties.

title: RICHARDSON HIND AT AGNEW LEAKS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 Attorney General Elliot L Richardson said tonight that he had had indications that Jus. tice Department employes hac leaked information to newsmen about the investigation of Vice President Agnew.

title: Bryant Park Concert Disrupted by Youths; Was Last of Season
description: A gang of about 25 youths harassed the audience and musicians yesterday to the point, where the season's last free noontime concert in Bryant Park had to be cut short.

title: White House Won't Say If Ziegler Got Apology
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UPI)The White House refused today to say whether President Nixon had apologized to White House press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, for shoving hi, during an appearance in New Orleans on Aug. 20.

title: 3 in ProPalestinian Group Killed by Lebanese Officer
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 4 (UPI)A Lebanese Army officer killed three members of a proPalestinian organization and was wounded in a shooting incident early today.

title: TAPINGS OF CALLS TO NIXON UPHELD
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. (AP)The Secret Service said today that there were times when it was legally allowed to record calls to the White House without telling the caller his conversation was being recorded.

title: London Paper Barred Again By Dispute About Overtime
description: LONDON, Sept. 4 (Reuters)Britain's biggest selling evening newspaper, The Evening News of London, failed to appear for the second day today because of an industrial dispute.

title: W. L. Brody. Law Assistant In State Supreme Court
description: William L. Brody, who retired in 1968 as the senior law assistant in the State Supreme Court in Manhattan and the Bronx, died Saturday in his home at 2 Horatio Street. He was about 75 years old.

title: ARTHUR MASTER CARDIOLOGIST, 77
description: Dr. Arthur M. Master, who developed the Master TwoStep exercise tolerance test for the diagnosis of heart disease, died yesterday of cancer at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 885 Park Avenue. Until a few weeks ago, Dr. Master had maintained an active practice in cardiology at his office, 125 East 72d Street.

title: APPELLATE COURT ORDERS SPEEDUP IN TAPES DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4President Nixon's pending appeal of the court ruling last week that he must surrender the Watergate tape recordings for private judicial inspection will move up to the Supreme Court faster than the parties to the historic lawsuit thought possible.

title: Auditing of Tax Returns Sets Record This Year
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UPI)The Internal Revenue Service said today that it had reversed a nineyear decline in audit coverage by pulling for special examination a record 1.8 million suspicious returns filed during the fiscal year 1973.

title: Israel to Deport Members of Black American Sect
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 4 (AP)Israel plans to deport a community of 350 American blacks who assert they are the original heirs to the Promised Land, Israeli police officials said today.

title: How Black Doctor's Practice Differs
description: George C. Branche Jr. is a 47yearold doctor who in many ways epitomizes the stereotype of a New, York practitioner: He is tall and urbane, he has a successful practice and a home in the suburbs, a teaching appointment at a medical school and, generally, a comfortable life.

title: Advertising: Riggs to Hai Karate
description: Leave it to Bobby Riggs, The Happy Hustler of the tennis courts, to find a quick way to cash in on his newly found fame as the nation's No. 1seeded male chauvinist.

title: Electricity Again Cut Off At Elmhurst Apartments
description: About 15,000 people in Elmhurst, Queens, many of whom suffered through several days without el city last week, were without power again yesterday.

title: Tough SeatBelt System Awaits NewCar Buyers
description: Americans are about to face the most extreme test yet of how much convenience they are willing to give up in exchange for cutting traffic deaths. After years of Madison Avenue efforts at persuasion that failed, the Government hopes to all but force newcar buyers into using safety belts.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: JEFFERSON TOWNSHIP, Sept. 4Robert Leckie was stuck in a Route 46 traffic jam one morning about five years ago on his way to a Young Men's Christian Association workout in Montclair and decided, I'd be better off if I owned my own athletic club.

title: 4 Vintage Rail Coaches Auctioned Off
description: FLEMINGTON, Sept. 4 Four vintage railroad coaches that knew tile splendor of the high noon of the American passenger train were sold at auction here today for a total of $20,800 and will begin new careers of luxury on both sides of the country.

title: Tame Tropical Storm Hits Texas With Heavy Rains
description: GALVESTON, Tex., Sept. 4 (AP)  A surprisingly tame tropical storm Delia sloshed onto land today, spreading moderately heavy rains and little reported damage along the eastern Texas and western Louisiana Gulf coasts.

title: OILMEN HELD SET FOR LIBYA STAND
description: The oil industry appears ready to make a strong stand against the Libyan Government's nationalization action although the companies seem to have few weapons in their arsenal.

title: Taxes and the Sick
description: More than thirty years ago, while World War II was still on and most domestic concerns were being pushed aside, Congress first introduced into the tax code a provision permitting tax savings for families with extraordinarily high medical costs resulting from severe illness of any kind. Millions of families have since benefited from that provision for tax deduction of outofpocket doctor, hospital and related costs exceeding 3 per cent of gross income. In effect, this deduction provides a limited form of insurance against bills for major and catastrophic illness, aid sensibly geared to a recognition that families with different income levels have differing ability to pay medical costs.

title: Wealthy Women Do Menial Jobs to SaveThe Garden's Riches
description: OLD WESTBURY, L.I.Mrs. Robert A. Lovett carried her bright green basket to another section of the Italian Garden. The temperature was 95 degrees but her bright blue eyes darted along the rows of brilliant blossoms and her hands kept pacea dead leaf here, a bedraggled flower there, snip, snip.

title: LIBYAN TAKEOVER EXPECTED TO LIFT WORLD OIL PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4Government and oil industry sources expressed the common view today that Libya's takeover of 51 per cent of several major American oil companies last weekend presaged higher world oil prices generally and intensification of the already growing pressure on Washington to modify its support of Israel.

title: Cox's Office Installs Large Paper Shredder
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP)The special Watergate prosecutor, Archibald Cox, who occasionally investigates paper shredding in high places, has installed a large shredder in his own offices.

title: TransAtlantic Quibbling
description: HAMBURG, West GermanyPeering ahead into the future of transAtlantic relations, I find it impossible to detect a rationale for fundamental change. At the same time, it is hard not to predict growing friction between Europe and the United States. Separation impossible, accommodation difficult  this, I am afraid, is the outlook.

title: The Country Store Makes a Comeback
description: TANNERSVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 4  The small parking lot off Main Street here was jammed with cars last weekend, with shoppers crowding into the A. & P. at one end of the lot and at the other, scarcely 100 yards away, into Pratt's Place, a relatively new country store.

title: Dr. Abraham Goodhartz Dies; ExDean at Brooklyn College
description: Dr. Abraham S. Goodhartz, who retired in 1970 as dean of studies of Brooklyn College, with which he had been associated since 1938, died Monday in Maimonides Hospital after a coronary attack. He was 64 years old and lived at 711 Montauk Court, Brooklyn.

title: DuPontWalston to Lay Off 950 and Shut 50 Offices
description: Total layoffs of between 950 and 1,050 persons will result from the partial consolidation last July of duPont Glore Forgan, Inc., and Walston & Co., Walter E. Auch, president of duPontWalston Inc., said yesterday.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Expos May Expand Jarry Park

title: Books of The Times
description: CHICAGO, 18601919. By Stephen Longstreet. 547 pages. David McKay Company. $10.95.

title: State Prison Still Restive In Indiana After Protest
description: MICHIGAN CITY, Ind., Sept. 4 (AP)Officials said today that they had not yet established full control at the state prison here where inmates took three guards hostage on Sunday.

title: Basketball Transactions
description: AMERICAN ASSOCIATION

title: WATERGATE FIGURE FIGHTS NEW CHARGE
description: MIAMI, Sept. 4 (AP)The attorney for Frank A. Sturgis, a Watergate burglar, said today that he would subpoena records to prove that his client was engaged five years ago in undercover work against Cuba and was not involved in a stolen car ring.

title: Two Dead in Texas As 110M.P.H. Gust Destroys Trailers
