description: BIG SPRING, Tex., Sept. 10 (UPI)  A 110mile anhour wind gust from a thunderstorm smashed across the Texas plains into Big Spring today, killing two children and injuring at least two dozen persons caught in trailer houses that were rolled over and demolished.

title: Football Player Held
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Sept. 4 (AP)  Leo Hayden, running back for the St. Louis Cardinals, was ordered held for a grand jury inquiry today on a rape charge, made by a 21yearold Bloomington woman, who charged she was raped in her apartment, Aug. 21.

title: U.N. Convenes Top Economists To Testify on Multinationals
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 4 (UPI)A panel of topflight economic experts, appointed to investigate the activities of multinational corporations and devise international rules for their operations, convened for the first time today and elected L. K. Jha of India as chairman.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Penn Central Seeks Exemption Of Trackage From Safety Rule
description: The Penn Central Railroad has asked the Federal Railroad Administration to exempt more than onequarter of its track system from new national track safety standards scheduled to take effect Oct. 16.

title: Upstate Phone Rise Urged
description: ALBANY, Sept. 4 (AP)  A state examiner has recommended that the Iroquois Telephone Corporation he authorized to raise its local rates by roughly 15 per cent and obtain $300,800 in additional reverse. The company, which serves about 18,400 main telephones in several sections of central and western New York, had requested rate increases that would generate $465,000.

title: Alexandria, Va., Integrates Schools Without Incident
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Sept. 4 (AP)  The elementary school system here was desegregated without incident today, ending 10 years of racial imbalance in which some schols were 97 per cent white and others 96 per cent black.

title: Floods Subside in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 4 (AP) Flood waters were subsiding today in four Mexican states. The Water Resources Ministry predicted more heavy rains in southeastern Mexico from two tropical storms, but said they posed no immediate danger.

title: Mrs. Robert Shnayerson, Teacher of Music, Is Dead
description: AMAGANSETT, L. I., Sept 4 Mrs. Lydia Todd Shnayerson, a music teacher and the wife of Robert B. Shnayerson, editor in chief of Harper's magazine, died Sunday at their summer home here. She was 46 years old and lived at 118 Riverside Drive, New York.

title: SUSPECT IN SLAYING OF BOY ARRAIGNED
description: A suspect in the fatal shooting of a 4yearold boy and the wounding of an offduty police officer on Sunday was arraigned yesterday and ordered held without bail by Judge Hyman Solniker in Criminal Court. A hearing was set for Friday.

title: 4 Vintage Rail Coaches Auctioned Off
description: FLEMINGTON, N. J., Sept. 4Four vintage railroad coaches that knew the splendor of the high noon of the American passenger train were sold at auction here today for a total of $20,800 and will begin new careers of luxury on both sides of the country.

title: Boozer Ready for Action But Wants Signed Pact
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 4 Emerson Boozer is ready to protect Joe Namath when Joe passes, block for Jim Nance when Jim runs and do some running for the Jets, but first he wants a signed contract.

title: McCrory's 3Month Prof it Is Down
description: Three retail merchandisersthe McCrory Corporation, Tif fany & Co. and Garfinkel Brooks Brothers, Miller Rhoads, Inc.reported yesterday record sales and earning for the first fiscal halfyear.

title: Arab Laborers of Toulon Strike Over Racial Issue
description: TOULON, France, Sept. 4 (AP)  A majority of Toulon's 20,000 Arab workers stayed off their jobs today to protest what they consider racial discrimination.

title: Public Affairs Staff Reduced by H.E.W.; 275 Publications Cut
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) Attacking what he called Government puffery, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare has ordered a 77 per cent reduction in the department's public affairs staff and the elimination of 275 publications.

title: Columbia Frosh Chilled By Funny Recruiting
description: An effort to revive a 20yearold Columbia College tradition of initiating freshmen into student activities through humorous skits performed by upper classmen sputtered last night as fewer than 250 of the 735 members of the class of 1977 turned out to watch. K.C.A. (for King's Crown ActivitiesNight was designed originally to give Columbia student groups an opportunity to recruit members by demonstrating their talents as humorists. The tradition flourished until three years ago, when, in the words of one of last night's organizers, the orientation committee decided that the perversity of it was getting out of hand and people really didn't feel it was giving freshmen a good look at student activities or sexual activities at Columbia.

title: Writer Rides High on Uneasy Rider
description: Picking its way carefully across the playlists of the music radio stations is a song titled Uneasy Rider, performed by its composer Charlie Daniels. The reason for the careful progress lies in the lyric content of the song, which deals with the rider of the title, longhaired and involved in an auto breakdown in the Deep South. There is a confrontation with some denizens, including one with green teeth in a local bar, the Dew Drop Inn.

title: United Nations Day Set
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UPI) President Nixon designated Oct. 24 as United Nations Day today and said that the interests of rich and poor countries must be bridged on matters of trade and aid.

title: SPOILAGE CLAIMS POUR IN AT CON ED
description: Consolidated Edison officials in Queens said yesterday that more than 1,100 claims seeking compensation for food spoilage had been received from residents of Jackson Heights, and that none of them had been processect A power failure in the area eight days ago caused the disruption of normal lectric service to 15,000 aparttent dwellers, including the loss of refrigeration and airconditioning.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: Pathet Lao Presses Rightists on Signing of Accord
description: VIENTIANE. Laos, Sept. 4The proCommunist Pathet Lao and Premier Souvanna Phouma publicly applied heavy pressure today on the rightwing politicians and generals who have balked at signing a completed accord that would establish coalition government in Laos.

title: Teachers, Citing Inflation, Strike in Detroit and 33 Other Michigan Districts on the Eve of New School Year
description: DETROIT, Sept. 4  Teachers in Detroit and 33 other Michigan school districts went on strike today, one day before the scheduled opening of classes for the 197374 tent. About 25,000 teachers are involved in the strike, and some 645,000 students are affected.

title: News Summary and Index WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 5, 1973
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Weathermen Stay Cool As Business Warms Up
description: While New Yorkers suffered through an eighth straight day of above90 degree temperatures, operations were as cool as usual yesterday at the National Weather Service offices in Rockefeller Center.

title: British Union Head Retiring With Regret Over Workers' Image
description: LONDON, Sept. 4Victor Feather left school in the Yorkshire town of Bradford at 15, went to work filling bags of flour, joined a union, came to London for a $25aweek job and rose to become one of the most important men in the country's power structure.

title: Baseball Transaction
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended Aug. 28.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Gallup Poll commissioned by the New Jersey Education Association showed yesterday that despite a State Supreme Court ruling to the contrary, 48 per cent of those polled prefer to keep, the present system of financing the public school system, and 37 per cent favor a new uniform statewide tax. About 58 per cent cf the 459 person?? interviewed would prefer a state income tax to increases in local property taxes if taxes had to be raised.

title: Pincay Is Beaten by Heat After 2 Rides at Belmont
description: Laffit Pincay showed yesterday that jockeys are only human, too. The Panamanian, who led the moneywinning list for the last three years and is at the top of the heap this season, had to give in to the heat after riding two races at Belmont Park. The action came as a disappointment to many in the crowd of 15,962, for they had come to the park prepared to use him in their figures, in the matter of betting.

title: Europeans Hopeful on Kissinger's Role
description: PARIS, Sept. 4The nomination of Henry A. Kissinger to be Secretary of State has raised some hopes in Europe that United States embassies will regain an effective role.

title: Cambodians Gain in a Besieged Town
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sept. 4 (UPI)  The Cambodia command said today that Government troops defending the besieged provincial capital of Kompong Cham had managed to reopen the road to the airport.

title: Production of Steel Declined by 2.6% In Week to Sept. 1
description: Steel production for the week ended Sept. 1 fell by 2.6 per cent to 2.73 million tons from 2,803,000 tons in the preceding week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The production index slipped to 111.9 from 114.9 in the week ended Aug. 25.

title: Judge Tells the City It Can't Limit Hours For Street Digging
description: Dig we must, said State Supreme Court Justice Gerald P. Culkin, and yesterday he issued a preliminary injunction to prevent the city from enforcing laws that limit public utilities' streetdigging hours.

title: Detroit School Strike
description: Teachers in Detroit and 33 other Michigan school districts went on strike yesterday on the eve of the opening of classes for the 1973'74 year. About 25,000 teachers are involved in the strike and about 645,000 pupils are affected. Details on Page 25.

title: Gasoline Truck Explodes On New Upstate Bridge
description: RENSSELAER, N.Y., Sept. 4 (UPI)  A gasoline truck overturned and exploded yesterday Ion the new Dunn Memorial Bridge, shooting a ball of flame and thick smoke into the air and closing traffic on the Hudson River span for hours.

title: Rib Fracture Halts Bout
description: VIENNA, Sept. 4 (AP)Hans Orsolics of Austria stopped Italy's Massimo Consolatin in the third round of a scheduled 10round welterweight bout tonight when the Italian suffered a fractured rib. The ring physician examined Consolatin and ordered the bout stopped after the third round.

title: Pakistan Seeking Million Tons of Wheat
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 4 Describing food supplies as precariously low, the Government said today that Pakistan needed a million tons of wheat immediately as a result of the threeweek flooding of the country's river system.

title: People and Business
description: John B. Connally, who recently ended a brief tour as an unpaid special adviser to President Nixon, has resumed his directorship at Pan American World Airways, which he had previously held for almost as brief a time.

title: LONG SCHOOL PACT IS REACHED ON LI.
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 4  A fiveyear contract, said to be the longest teacher contract on record in the United States, was agreed to in the Port Washington School District early today.

title: Football Transactions
description: AMERICAN CONFERENCE

title: Convict, Out on Furlough, Surrenders in a Murder
description: TRENTON, Sept. 4A convicted killer who did household chores at Morven, the Governor's mansion, under a workrelease program was arrested yesterday on suspicion of killing a man with a hatchet on Sunday, during his first weekend furlough from prison.

title: Paine, Webber in Acquisition;
description: Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis, Inc., said yesterday that it had completed the acquisition of the retail and corporate nnance divisions and the municipal bond department of Mitchum, Jones and Templeton, Inc. Terms of the purchase were not given. Mitchum operates 20 offices, 18 in California and two in Nevada.

title: MEETING OF O.A.S. AIMS AT CHANGES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 Representatives of 23 countries of the Western Hemisphere convened in Washington today to begin drafting structural changes in the Charter of the Organization of American States, which many believe is cumbersome and obsolete.

title: Audit of All President's Finances Made in Secret by Accountants
description: The accounting firm that prepared a special audit of President Nixon's real estate transactions also prepared a completehut still secretaudit of his entire financial condition, an official of the company said yesterday.

title: Teleprompter Cuts Construction 20% In Its '73 Program
description: The Teleprompter Corporation said yesterday that it had suspended temnorarily 20 per cent of its 1973 construction program and is reviewing is entire program for adding new televions cable systems.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Sakharov Gets a Backer As Soviet Critics Increase
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 4A lonely voice was raised here today in defense of Andrei D. Sakharov as an officially inspired campaign of denunciation of the physicist, far from abating, showed signs of becoming more intense.

title: Europeans Hopeful on Kissinger's Role
description: PARIS, Sept. 4The nomination of Henry A. Kissinger to be Secretary of State has raised some hopes in Europe that United States embassies will regain an effective role.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The prominence given by the press to the political scandals of 1972 and 1973, involving first the Watergate incident and now the widely published charges against the Vice President, suggests that the news media may be as involved as the politicians.

title: 200 Plymouths Recalled
description: DETROIT, Sept. 4 (AP) The Chrysler Corporation is asking 200 owners of 1972 Plymouth Crickets to bring in their autos for inspection and repair of possible improperly installed windshields. Windshields on the vehicles in question were removed by order of the Los Angeles Port Operations to repair headliners damaged in transit.

title: Park Ave. Dental Clinic Is Opened at V.A. Hospital
description: EAST ORANGE, Sept. 4 Park Avenue dentistry came to the Veterans Administration hospital here today with the opening of a $1million clinic and research center.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Sakharov Gets a Backer As Soviet Critics Increase
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 4A lonely voice was raised here today in defense of Andrei D. Sakharov as an officially inspired campaign of denunciation of the physicist, far from abating, showed signs of becoming more intense.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Richmond College Head Named

title: BYRNE PROPOSES TOUGH DRUG LAW
description: TRENTON, Sept. 4Brendan T. Byrne, the Democratic candidate for governor, today recommended a narcotics control program that would allow maximum life prison sentences for major distributors of hard drugs in New Jersey.

title: Temperature Expected to Top 90 Today for 9th Straight Day
description: New Yorkers suffered through the worst heat wave in seven years as temperatures went into the nineties yesterday for the eighth day in a row.

title: Weicker Says Inquiry Does Not Affect Congress
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 4If the Watergate affair has paralyzed some part of Government, it has immobilized the White House and not Congress, Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. said today.

title: State Police Delay Hiring of 4 Women On Suit by a Man
description: ALBANY, Sept. 4  State Police Superintendent William E. Kirwan today delayed the swearing in of four women recruits pending the outcome of a court challenge filed by an upstate policeman who said he had scored higher on an examination than the women.

title: 2 VIETNAM SIDES NEGOTIATE AGAIN
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 4 (Reuters)Vietcong and South Vietnamese military negotiators met today for the first time in four days, averting the threat of a complete breakdown in talks to carry out the Paris peace agreement.

title: U.S. Objects to Bordello On Federal Property
description: TONOPAH, Nev., Sept. 4 (AP)Three years ago Beverly Harrell leased five acres of barren desert from the Federal Government for $100 a year. Now, says Mrs. Harrell, the Bureau of Land Management is trying to renege on the agreement because it doesn't like the kind of business she operates.

title: Prices of Futures Slump For Wide Range of Foods
description: Futures prices of many foods traded on the commodities exchanges dropped sharply yesterday. Included were grains, soybeans, live cattle and hog futures.

title: TV: Energy Crisis, Prime Subject in Prime Time
description: For three primetime hours last night, from 8 to 11, the National Broadcasting Company presented an American White Paper that might have been labeled Everything You Ever Wanted to Know About the Energy Crisis but. Were Afraid Somebody Might Actually Take Three Hours to Tell You. Energy is not, as they say in the trade, a sexy subject for television. And three hours of anything is a long haul.

title: Garven, 47, Sworn As Chief Justice; Clifford Associate
description: HACKENSACK, Sept. 4 (UPI) Pierre P. Garven was sworn in today as the youngest chief justice under the present New Jersey Constitution.

title: PRICES ADVANCE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices advanced in quiet trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market.

title: Monday's Fight
description: TokyoKuniaki Shibata, Wan, knocked out Chung Nam Chul, South Korea, 2 rounds, featherweights.

title: Hepatitis Outbreak Reported; In the U.S. Army in Bavaria!
description: NUREMBERG, West Germany, Sept. 4 (UPI)  Drug abuse has caused an outbreak of hepatitis among United; States troops in Bavaria, an Army doctor said today.

title: George Phillips Dies at 79; ExHead of Advertising Club
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 4George A. Phillips, former director of advertising for Cluett Peabody & Co., and president in 1953 and 1954 of the Advertising Club of New York, died yesterday at the Center Manor Nursing Home here. His age was 79.

title: QUEENS WIFE SLAIN; FEARED HER HUSBAND
description: A 26yearold beautician was shot to death yesterday in a beauty shop in Fresh Meadows, Queens, shortly after she told a customer that she feared her husband was going to kill her.

title: Mets Hit for Seaver at Last, Win by 71
description: Tom Seaver witnessed a strange sight in the first inning last night, but managed to keep himself from going into shock and pitched the Mets to a 71 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: GRAND JURY ACTS IN COAST BREAKIN
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 4A Los Angeles County grand jury returned today secret indict ments against unnamed defendants after the final day of testimony in the inquiry into the burglary at the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: FICTION

title: LIBYAN TAKEOVER EXPECTED TO LIFT WORLD OIL PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4Government and oil industry sources expressed the common view today that Libya's takeover of 51 per cent of several major American oil companies last weekend presaged higher world oil prices generally and intensification of the already growing pressure on Washington to modify its support of Israel.

title: HighPressure System Is Like the One Usually Over Los Angeles
description: A lumbering, now weak, highpressure air mass that has brought the metropolitan area eight straight days of temperatures above 90 has also clamped a lid over much of the East Coast.

title: CHOLERA IN ITALY KILLS 18TH VICTIM
description: ROME, Sept. 4 (Reuters) Cholera killed four more persons in Italy today, bringing the death toll to 18 as the disease struck for the first time in two northern cities despite official statements that it was waning.

title: Examination of Seal Shows Gunshot Didn't Cause Death
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Sept. 4 (AP)  An examination of a seal that died in Boothbay Harbor yesterday disclosed that it had not, died of a gunshot wound, the state Sea and Shore Fisheries Commissioner, Spencer Apollonio, said today.

title: Close Aide of Brandt Called In VoteBribe Investigation
description: BONN, Sept. 4 (Reuters)A Parliament commission investigating West Germany's votes for sale scandal decided today to summon Science Minister Horst Ehmke, a close aide of Chancellor Willy Brandt. He is the first minister to be called before the inquiry.

title: Goldfield Corp. Gives Option for Lower Settlement in Suit to Life Investors
description: The Goldfield Corporation announced yesterday it had granted an option to Life Investors International, Ltd., of Toronto to settle for $21.8million its $80million damage suit against the General Host Corporation. The option expires Nov. 1 and moves closer the plans for Life Investors International to acquire control of General Host. In litigation filed three years ago in Federal Court here Goldfield alleged, among other things; that General Host had defrauded Goldfield of 437,700 shares of General Host stock owned by Goldfield.

title: Maritime Official Renamed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) President Nixon announced today that he would nominate George H. Hearn, vice chairman of the Federal Maritime Commission, for a new fiveyear term. Mr. Hearn, a Democrat from Brooklyn, has been a commissioner since July, 1964.

title: Brooklyn Board Leaves Principal's Future Up to Him
description: District 18 school board officials said yesterday that the decision of whether Norman Desser would take his job as principal of Public School 208 in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn would be left up to him.

title: Glover on Waivers, Giants Get Claims
description: The New York Giants waved Rich Glover in front other pro football teams yesterday to test his current market value and several said they were interested enough to talk business. Glover, the Giants second choice in the 1973 college draft, was one of three players placed on waivers as cutdowns continued to the 44player limit. The other two were Otto Brown, a fifthyear defensive back, and Walter Love, a promising rookie wide receiver and defensive back.

title: Prisons and Funerals
description: During my threeyear odyssey through the world of American prisons, an elusive, halfformulated thought kept nagging at the back of my mind: Are there not disturbing similarities between the prison business and an earlier preoccupation of mine, the American funeral industry? What do prison administrators and undertakers have in common? A friend to whom I posed this question answered somewhat flippantly, That's easy, they're both in the business of shutting people up in boxes.

title: Business Briefs
description: European subsidiaries of two major American manufacturing companies announced yesterday receipt of contracts from the Soviet Union and China.

title: PRICES OF STOCKS MOVE UP AGAIN
description: Stock prices bounded ahead again yesterday, extending last week's lowkey rally, in a session that produced 1,010 advancing issues and a gain of 7.82 points for the DowJones industrial average.

title: How Black Doctor's Practice Differs
description: George C. Branche Jr. is a 47yearold doctor who in many ways epitomizes the stereotype of a New York practitioner: He is tall and urbane, he has a successful practice and a home in the suburbs, a teaching appointment at a medical school and, generally, a comfortable life.

title: Newspaper Strike Settled
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Sept. 4 (AP)Newspapdr Guild employes began producing combined editions of The Korgantown DominionPost today following settlement of a sixweek strike.

title: Adult Delinquency
description: In the roseate years when sports for youngsters and even professionals were regarded as fun and games and not simply spectaculars between commercials, Grantland Rice wrote the starryeyed but nevertheless inspiring lines: When the One Great Scorer comes to write against your name/ He marksnot that you won or lostbut how you played the game.

title: Many Academics Regret Supporting President in Newspaper Ads
description: Taken as a group, although they are more used to being taken individually, academics have not been ardent supporters of President Nixon.

title: 3 Brothers Are Sentenced For Trafficking in Heroin
description: Three brothers from the Bronx, accused of being major heroin traffickers who ever shipped giftwrapped heroin, drew heavy sentences yesterday in Federal Court.

title: Records: Jazz by Baron
description: Small jazz groups tend to fall into relatively set instrumental formatspiano trios (piano, bass, drums), quartets or quintets made up of one or two horns and a rhythm section. Benny Goodman's original trio and quartet were unusual because they did not use a bass, and the Modern Jazz Quartet is also slightly different because, instead of a horn, it includes a vibraphone.

title: Mazie Cox Will Be Wed Sunday to Brink Thorne
description: Miss Mary Ann Livingston Delafield Cox and Brinkley Stimson Thorne are planning a very small, very informal wedding Sunday in Westhampton Beach, L. I.

title: Bombs Hurt Two in Vienna
description: VIENNA, Sept. 4 (AP)Four parcel bombs exploded today in Vienna, injuring two persons, one seriously. Explosives experts defused a fifth bomb, addressed to a me ether of Parliament. The police said they did, not know the reason for the bombings.

title: Ali Ends Training
description: DEER LAKE, Pa., Sept. 4 (AP)Muhammad All ended his training here today for his fight with Ken Norton in Los Angeles next Monday. He is scheduled to leave for California tomorrow.

title: Harlem High and C.C.N.Y. Clash on Use of a Building
description: A group known as the Harlem High School Committee accused City College officials yesterday of trying to take over a school building that the committee is seeking to use for an expanded Harlem High.

title: Novel on Japan's Submersion Tops Best Sellers There
description: TOKYO, Sept. 4  In the current bestselling novel here, an American astronaut flying a spaceship over. Japan looks down and exclaims: Wow! Japan is splitting apart!

title: East German Group Arrives To Look for Embassy Site
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) A sixmember East German delegation arrived here today to search for a suitable place to open an embassy when diplomatic relations are established between East. Germany and the United States.

title: Mild Quake on Coast
description: VENTURA, Calif., Sept. 4 (UPI)The Pacific Ocean coastline north of here was rocked early today by a minor earthquake. The tremor registered 3.6 on the Richter scale.

title: Waldheim, Concluding His Tour Of Mideast, Voices Optimism
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 4 (UPI)Secretary General Waldheim completed his fivenation tour of the Middle East today with a statement reiterating that he had been encouraged by the general desire for peace he encountered in talks with government officials. He visited Syria, Lebanon, Israel, Egypt and Jordan.

title: Navy Ready to Sell Land
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) The Navy wants to dispose of more than 1,500 acres of land at its Newport, R.I. base, the Senate Armed Services Committee said today. The land, which cost about $60million, has been declared excess because of cutbacks at the Newport Naval Station and related facilities, the Navy said in a report to the committee. However, the service plans to retain some 500 acres that cost about $44million.

title: SAFETY PROMISED MORNINGSIDE HTS.
description: Mayor Lindsay promised yesterday that the city would make enormous efforts to insure the security and viability of educational and religious institutions in Morningside Heights.

title: INTEREST RATES HEAD DOWNWARD
description: The credit markets moved toward lower interest rates and higher prices for fixedincome securities yesterday as investors quietly stepped up their orders to buy from fear of missing what might turn out to be a genuine swing toward lower yields.

title: Detroit School Strike
description: Teachers in Detroit and 33 other Michigan school districts went on strike yesterday on the eve of the opening of classes for the 1973./4 year. About 25,000 teachers are involved in the strike and about 645,000 pupils are affected. Details on Page 25.

title: Beef Prices Freeze Upheld a 2d Time By Court of Appeals
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) The Temporary Emergency Court of Appeals has upheld for the second time the Government's freeze on beef prices, although it said the Government might have made errors in judgment.

title: Temperature Expected to Top 90 Today for 9th Straight Day
description: New Yorkers suffered through the worst heat wave in seven years as temperatures went into the nineties yesterday for the eighth day in a row.

title: U.S. Victor in Cricket
description: VICTORIA, British Columbia, Sept. 4 (AP)A United States team retained the 178yearold K.A. Auty trophy today in a threedav cricket match with Canada that ended in a draw.

title: Swank Doubts Early Cambodian Peace
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sept. 4The United States Ambassador, Emory C. Swank, whose tour in Cambodia ends tomorrow, today described the war here as increasingly counterproductive for both sides but sal little prospect that it would end soon.

title: Notes on People
description: In Honolulu, finishing a weekend holiday, Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin of the Soviet Union discussed the controversial sale of American wheat to his country. Probably running with the grain of Soviet public opinion, Mr. Dobrynin said of the sale, We haven't done anything, wrong. Of course we buy it as cheap as possible. Actually, you don't expect us to do otherwise.

title: Monday's Fight
description: TokyoKuniaki Shibata, Japan, knocked out Chung Nam Chul, South Korea, 2 rounds, featherweights.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Nassau County Police Department has activated a 911 telephone number to enable its 1.5 million residents to report emergency situations and obtain help more quickly for police, ambulance and fire services. The system is already in effect in New York City, Suffolk County and in some 20 to 30 major cities in the country serving about 20 million people.

title: Mall Concert Notes Jubilee Of Bandshell
description: The oppressive humidity that enveloped Central Park on Monday night made it a bit difficult to summon up the proper mood of sentiment for the occasionthe final Naumburg concert of this summer, celebrating the 50th anniversary of the present bandshell on the Mall and conducted by Joseph Silverstein.

title: DR. MILTON E. LOOMIS, FORMER N.Y.U. DEAN
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 4Dr. Milton E. Loomis, a former dean and professor of government at New York University, died here on Sunday. He was 86 years old.

title: Giant Rally Marks Allende Anniversary
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 4Scores of thousands of leftists marched today in celebration of the third anniversary of the election that brought to power President Salvador Allende Gossens and his Marxist coalition Government.

title: Exercising Some Wisdom of Their Own, They Can Eat as Well as Solomon
description: GREENWICH, Conn.Take then also unto thee wheat, and barley, and beans, and lentiles, and millet and fitches and put them in one vessel and make bread thereof, it says in Ezekiel 4:9.

title: E. German Girls World Swim Stars
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 4An American male lowered a world record twice today but his countrywomen were no match for the thickly muscled East German girls at the world swimming championships.

title: Moorer's Brother Elevated
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UPI) Rear Adm. Joe P. Moorer, younger brother of Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, was selected today for promotion to threestar admiral.

title: General Motors and Ford Deny They Fixed Prices
description: DETROIT, Sept. 4 (AP) General Motors and Ford, the nation's two largest auto makers, declared their innocence today in United States District Court as they went on trial on criminal charges of pricefixing.

title: British Trade Gap Wider With E.E.C. And Others in '72
description: LONDON, Sept. 4 (UPI)Britain's balance of trade with the Common Market deteriorated sharply last year, according to official statistics released today.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: SOVIET REIN ON JEWS IS STIFFER, REID SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5Representative Ogden R. Reid charged today that the Soviet Union had intensified its repression of Jews since President Nixon's meeting last June with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader.

title: H.U.D. ACTS TO CURB LANDSALE FRAUD
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) In an effort to block scrupulous land promoters, the Government has adopted final regulations requiring most of, the nation's land developers to disclose virtually everything about the property they offer for sale.

title: URGENCY KEYNOTE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5President Nixon, declaring that he would veto the minimum wage bill, challenged Congress today to improve upon a disappointing record by enacting his bipartisan legislative proposals.

title: Aldermanic Battle Brings Racial Politics to Waterbury
description: WATERBURY, Conn., Sept. 5A young black businessman's attempt to win a Democratic nomination for Alderman against a white lawyer accused of racism has embroiled this small industrial city in a political campaign marked by previously unfamiliar charges of racism, tokenism and boss control.

title: Radio Signal System Is Sought to Thwart Hijacking of Trucks
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) Federal officials, seeking to curb cargo hijackings, are working on a plan to send out radio signals asking trucks where they are and getting a signaled reply from the truck.

title: 10 Arrested as Group Disrupts Newark City Council Meeting
description: NEWARK, Sept. 5  Ten Imembers of a group that calls itself the National Caucus of Labor Parties, including its announced candidate for Mayor, were arrested today after a melee in the City Council chainber.

title: President's Bid to Restore Confidence
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5President Nixon said today he hoped to restore confidence in his Administration, shaken by the Watergate disclosures, by not permitting his own confidence to be destroyed and by showing the country that he was doing something. What the President says will not restore it, Mr. Nixon told his televised news conference. And what you ladies and gentlemen say certainly will not restore it. [Question 9, Page 26.]

title: MEGO
description: ESSAY

title: Dutch Fete Juliana, On Throne 25 Years
description: TILBURG, the Netherlands, Sept. 5Queen Juliana celebrated her 25th anniversary on the throne in this textile city in the southern Netherlands today amid school bands, parachute demonstrations and a popular enthusiasm that surprised even the sedate Dutch.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: For three principal reasons, Judge Sirica's decision is not a good solution to the problem of Presidential confidentiality.

title: Nixonian Initiative
description: President Nixon acted yesterday to reassure the country that it has a functioning Presidentnot, one so sunk in Watergate that he has neither time nor appetite for leadership on the urgent business of government.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Back in 1925, when the Lost Generation was whooping it up in Paris and a new, free kind of love was making the world go around, the French couturier, Jean Patou, introduced a fragrance called Amour Amour.

title: Colt Brings $68,000 At Harrisburg Sale
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 5 (AP)  A chestnut colt named Ritz Hanover brought the highest individual price $68,000today at the 35th annual standardbred horse sale at the Farm Show arena.

title: Screen: Lady KungFu
description: Aficionados of the recent wave of martialarts movies can take comfort in the knowledge that the latest arrival, Lady KungFu, displays adequate reverence for the form they first knew and loved.

title: Canadian Reserves Dip
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 5 (Reuters  Canada's foreignexchange reserves dipped $196.9millior in August to $5.589millim from $5.786million in July, the Finance Ministry said.

title: L.I. MAN DIES
description: CENTRAL ISLIP, L. I., Sept. 5 (UPI)A 43yearold man burned to death early today when fire swept through a house he was visiting here, the Suffolk County police reported.

title: SUPPLIES OF BEEF IN SUPERMARKETS ARE NEAR NORMAL
description: Meat supplies have climbed back to just about normal in supermarkets here, along with improving stocks for wholesalers who serve small retailers, butchers and restaurants, the city's Consumer Affairs Department reported yesterday.

title: Personal Finance: Easier Investing
description: Millions of people own stock today, but millions more who can afford to invest are not in the market at all. Many are on the sidelines because they were freightened off by the declining market. Others do not invest because it seems too complicated.

title: Kheel Sues for More Port Authority Mass Transit
description: Theodore W. Kheel, the labor mediator and masstransit advocate, announced yesterday a new legal move designed to force the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to spend billions on masstransit development.

title: Montana Representative Accused of Drunk Driving
description: FAIRFAX, Va., Sept, 5 (AP) Representative John Melcher was released from jain today after being arrested on a drunken driving charge. The police said the Montana Democrat had yeled obscenities at jailers and refused to take a sobriety test.

title: 2D RATE RISE IN '73 FOR LILCO OPPOSED
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Sept, 5A request by the Long Island Lighting Company for a $5,225,500 increase in electricity and gas rates for its 800,000 customers in Nassau and Suffolk Counties and part of Queens was criticized here today at a public hearing held by the Public Service Commission.

title: Damaged Soviet Submarine Is Sighted in the Caribbean
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (UM) The Pentagon reported today that a damaged Soviet submarine had been sighted in the Caribbean with a hole in its deck presumably after crashing into a Soviet surface vessel.

title: Gorman Criticizes Nastase's Pullout
description: Tom Gorman criticized Ilie Nastase of Rumania yesterday for pulling out of the doubles after his loss in the singles at Forest Hills.

title: Kerner Seeks New Trial
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (AP)Former Gov. Otto Kerner and onetime State Revenue Director Theodore J. Isaacs, convicted of bribery and other charges growing out of an Illinois racingstock controversy, are again trying to win new trials. Their awyers filed separate appeals here yesterday.

title: Sasuke Against the Wind Opens at Bijou
description: Any assessment of Sasuke Against the Wind distills itself inevitably into a balancing of the movie's magnificent black and white photography, its spectacle and its sense of period against the utter chaos of its plot.

title: Advertising: Tripling Creativity
description: Kameny Associates, one of the world's smaller agencies, believes it has come up with one of the bigger, bolder creative concepts. And everybody is entitled to his beliefs.

title: Baseball Transaction
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: Pickets Marching At Variety Office And 2 Print Shops
description: A labor dispute involving union printers and Variety has resulted in the setting up of picket lines at the office of the theatrical weekly, 156 West 46th Street, and its print shop in the Bronx and Valley Stream, L. I.

title: Bridge: Albert Dormer Reports Case Of a Tragically Naive Partner
description: One of the world's busiest bridge journalists is Albert Dormer of London. He somehow contrives to hold down a fulltime government job while carrying out the following activities: writing bridge columns and books, sometimes under other names; contributing to a wide range of magazines; writing, editing and publishing the World Bridge Federation's World Bridge News and the Bulletin of the International Bridge Press Association, and attending European and world championships as a reporter for the news agencies.

title: SOVIET DISSIDENTS RECANT IN PUBLIC
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 5Two Soviet dissidents who turned state's evidence last week at closed trial were presented here today at a major news conference to recant once more in public.

title: L.I.Officials Tell Washington of Fear Of an Oil Shortage
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 Long Island officials met today with former Gov. John A. Love of Colorado now director of the White House Energy Policy I Office, and warned of a cold winter for Long Island homeowners in the absence of mandatory allocations by the major oil companies to independent retailers.

title: Gunmen Hold 15 Hostages In Saudi Embassy in Paris
description: PARIS, Thursday, Sept. 6A small band of Palestinian gunmen took over the Saudi Arabian Embassy here yesterday morning and reportedly seized at least 15 of of its diplomats and employes as hostages. The gunmen threatened to blow up the embassy or to kill their hostages if their demands were not met.

title: Notes on People
description: A statement issued by the Supreme Court said that Chief Justice Warren E. Burger underwent surgery for a hernia condition. The operation, the Court said, was performed on the 65yearold Justice at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn. The statement said the operation was dorie while the Chief Justice was in the clinic for his annual physical examination.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: HOFFMAN IS ACCUSEL OF DRUG POSSESSION
description: Abbie Hoffman, the former antiwar activist, Yippie and defendant in the Chicago Seven trial, was indicted here yesterday by a special narcotics grand jury on charges of possession and sale of cocaine valued at $500,000.

title: MRS. JAMES W. FARRELL
description: Mrs. Mary Powers Farrell, widow of James W. Farrell, retired attorney and secretary of Bell Telephone Laboratories, died yesterday in Mary Immaculate Hospital, Jamaica, Queens. She was 84 years old and lived at 16509 85th Avenue, Jamaica.

title: Decline in Cholera Reported in Italy; Fish Sales Slump
description: ROME, Sept. 5The number of suspected cases of cholera was reported to be dwindling in Italy today, raising hopes that the outbreak was on the wane.

title: E.P.A. WOULD EASE POLLUTION RULES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5The Nixon Administration, in response to a request by industry, will propose tomorrow new regulations relaxing antipollution requirements.

title: A MIDEAST PLEDGE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5President Nixon said today that he was giving highest priority to achieving a Middle East settlement that would put an end to Arab threats to curtail future oil deliveries to Western countries.

title: POLICE ABDUCTION LAID TO 3 MUSLIMS
description: NEWARK, Sept. 5  Three Black Muslims were arrested today on charges of kidnapping a policeman as they conducted their own investigation into the slaying of their leader, James Shabazz, who was shot to death in the driveway of his home yesterday.

title: E. Germans And U.S. Set Swim Pace
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 5 For the second straight day, the East German girls, referred to by the American girls as those guys, muscled their way into what was once predominantly an American sport.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: NIXON INDICATES NO LANDGAIN TAX
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5President Nixon indicated today that he had paid no capital gains tax on a $1.24million sale of some of his property at San Clemente, Calif. He explained that the Internal Revenue Service had not ordered him to make any changes in his income tax returns.

title: Navy Suspects Ship Arson
description: NORFOLK, Sept. 5 (AP) The Navy says four fires in nine days aboard ships docked at the Little Creek Amphibious Base may be the work of an arsonist.

title: Volvo Is Planning Plant in Virginia
description: Volvo, the Swedish automobile maker, is expected to announce next week that it will build a plant to assemble passenger cars in Virginia.

title: Bread Price Rise Backed
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Sept. 5 (AP)The Puerto Rican Government has authorized an increase of 4 to 12 cents in the price of bread because of rising wheat prices. The new ceiling prices will be 32 cents a pound for the French loaf and 34 cents a pound for the sandwich loaf at all bread counters.

title: TEACHERS STRIKE AROUND COUNTRY
description: Hundreds of thousands of pupils got an extended summer vacation today as teachers struck in cities and towns around the country.

title: Icemakers Snowed Under by Orders
description: Ice dealers and manufacturers in the city are sadly watching potential profits melt away as the demand for ice during the heat wave far outstrips the capacity of plants in the area to manufacture it.

title: SOVIET SHIP CHECKED FOR DAMAGE ON REEF
description: ST. GEORGE'S, Bermuda, Sept, 5Crew members were examining their Soviet passenger ship today for possible damage incurred while the liner was lodged on an offshore reef for four days here.

title: Vatican Diplomats Meeting Under Criticism by Liberals
description: ROME, Sept. 5Apostolic nuncios and other papal diplomats started a threeday conference today to reassess their role, problems and working methods.

title: Beame Questions Subway Safety And Asks Federal Investigation
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame urged the Federal Government yesterday to begin an immediate investigation of the safety of the entire city subway system.

title: Eased Texas Marijuana Law Is Assailed as Unconstitutional
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 5A district attorney who has obtained hundreds of marijuana convictions argued today that a new Texas law that might reduce the sentences of convicted marijuana offenders was unconstitutional.

title: HIGH COURT UPHOLDS DELTEC DEBT RULING
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 5 (UPI)The Supreme Court today confirmed a lower court bankruptcy ruling on a Swift meatpacking operation here and extended some debt liability to Deltec International Ltd. and Deltec Argentina.

title: Over90 Heat Ended By Weak Cold Front
description: The above  90  degree  heat wave ended yesterday for much of the metropolitan area as a cold front moved down from New England faster than expected. But temperatures remained uncomfortably high and no real relief was forecast until tomorrow.

title: Volvo Is Planning Plant in Virginia
description: Volvo, the Swedish automobile maker, is expected to announce next week that it will build a plant to assemble passenger cars in Virginia.

title: Business Records
description: U. S. DISTRICT COURT

title: Kirksey Downed, But Is Not Out Yet
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I. Sept. 5 All things being equal, Roy Kirksey would much rather be in Philadelphia.

title: Mower Inspection Urged
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (AP) (Sears, Roebuck and Company reported today that it was asking owners of 14.000 models of two riding mowers to get in touch with Sears service units to have them inspected for safety. The mowers were identified as models No. 536.813601 and 536.813601.

title: Heat Is Proving Tough Foe for Athletes
description: Evonne Goolagong, an aborigine who learned tennis on the baked red clay of the Australian outback, shook her tight curls, soggy with the perspiration of her match at Forest Hills, and said:

title: McCord, Magruder Lectures Barred
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) Federal Judge John J. Sirica silenced two major figures in the Watergate scandal today, calling it a disgrace that criminals could profit by their wrongdoing by traveling the lecture circuit.

title: Bond Set in Air Show Deaths
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 5 (UPI)Bond was set today at $5,000 for Joseph A. Chaney Jr., 22 years old, of Cleveland, charged with five counts of vehicular homicide in the deaths of five spectators at an air show here. Mr. Chaney, who did not enter a plea at an appearance before a municipal judge, was jailed in lieu of bond. He was to enter a plea Sept. 10.

title: Theater: Desert Song
description: The Desert Song was first staged in 1926, was made info three Warner Brothers movie versions and has had a long life in summer tents and stock companiesbut it had had only one major New York revival (in 1946) until last night, when it began the new Broadway season. It seems very much like an old beginning.

title: Hockey Transaction
description: WORLD ASSOCIATION

title: Rockefeller Tells Parley in Louisiana Of Need for Candor
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 5Governor Rockefeller said today that the country's present agony underscored the people's desire for Government leadership that will place enduring moral principle over immediate political advantage.

title: PAUL KEMPF JR. DIES; EXAIDE AT TIMES, 64
description: Paul Kempf Jr., who retired last year after 29 years with The New York Times, where he was a news clerk in the Society News department, died yesterday, apparently of a heart ailment, in his apartment at 171 West 71st Street. His age was 64.

title: TEAR GAS STOPS FOES OF ALLENDE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 5The police blanketed downtown Santiago with tear gas tonight in an attempt to keep antiMarxist demonstrators from marching on the Presidential palace.

title: Gorman Criticizes Nastase's Pullout
description: Tom Gorman criticized Ilie Nastase of Rumania yesterday for pulling out of the doubles after his loss in the singles at Forest Hills.

title: Guilt Denied by Engineer In Bugging Devices Case
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 5 (UPI)  A Richmond electronics engineer, identified by a Virginia newspaper as a communications expert for President Nixon's 1968 campaign, pleaded not guilty today to charges of illegally possessing eavesdropping equipment.

title: 6 to Vie for Top Prizes In MillionDollar Lottery
description: The holders of three tickets numbered 939800 and three tickets numbered 302635 won chances at a top prize of $50,000 a year for life in the preliminary drawing yesterday for the New York State Lottery's milliondollar summer special.

title: Sudan Proclaims State of Emergency In Student Protests
description: CAIRO, Sept. 5The Sudanese Government proclaimed a state of emergency today in the wake of student demonstrations and a strike threat by six major trade unions.

title: 10 U.S. RAIDS BIT DEEP IN CAMBODIA
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (Reuters)The Defense Department has confirmed that secret bombing raids were made in Cambodia during 1970 into areas the United States said it was not bombing at that time, Senator Harold E. Hughes, Democrat of Iowa, said today.

title: Four Israeli Opposition Parties Align to Try to Defeat Laborites
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 5  Four opposition political parties agreed here today to make a joint attempt in the October parliamentary elections to unseat Golda Meir's Labor partydominated Government.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: SandHauling Official Indicted

title: Newark Police Arrest 10 In Council Chamber Fight
description: NEWARK, Sept. 5  Ten members of a group that calls itself the National Caucus of Labor Parties, including its announced candidate for Mayor, were arrested today after a melee in the City Concil chamber.

title: COTTON FUTURES CLOSE IRREGULAR
description: Heavy rains in Texas Tuesday as a rseult of strong thunderstorms sent near cotton futures deliveries soaring the daily limit in early trading yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The near October contract traded at a record of 92.60 cents a pound.

title: A Ray of Sunshine
description: NEW HAVENIt may seem odd, but I feel the shadow of the last few years is lifting. There may be no amnesty as yet for those who stepped beyond the law. There may be no physical repatriation for those who chose literal exile. But there is a new respect for skeptics; a new welcome for critics; a new tolerance of heretics. There seems to he an invitation to a repatriation of the spirit for many who had felt turned away by their own country. In at least three ways, the country is turning back to the faith of our fathers.

title: City Borrows $900Million
description: The city today sold a record $900million of shortterm notes al an average interest rate of 6.237 per cent. The interest rate was described as good in 26 present market by Controller Abraham D. Beame, who complained that the city was forced to borrow almost half of the $900million because the Federal and state goverments were slow in forwarding fiscal aid to the city. The ultimate result will be that the taxpayers will have to pay an extra $11.1 million in interest costs.

title: Grand Jury in Baltimore May Resume Next Week
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 5  The Federal grand jury investigating corruption in Maryland is expected to resume meetings next week, with indications that more indictments of local figures will be handed up before any action is taken on Vice President Agnew's case, sources close to the investigation said today.

title: ILLEGAL DUMPING IN MEADOW CITED
description: RUTHERFORD, Sept. 5 (AP) Tons of New York City garbage have been dumped in the Hackensack Meadowlands in defiance of a fiveday ban on outofstate dumping, officials charged today.

title: Paper Says President Had Brother Tapped
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5President Nixon ordered the Secret Service to tap the telephone of his brother F. Donald Nixon, The Washington Post said in its Thursday editions.

title: Brooklyn Man Charged in Death of Boy
description: A 2yearold boy who died shortly after he was taken to St. John's Hospital in Brooklyn on Tuesday night was beaten to death by his mother's boyfriend, the police charged last night.

title: President's Bid to Restore Confidence
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5President Nixon said today he hoped to restore confidence in his Administration, shaken by the Watergate disclosures, by not permitting his own confidence to be destroyed and by showing the country that he was doing something. What the President says will not restore it, Mr. Nixon told his telewised news conference. And what you ladies and gentlemen say certainly will not restore it. [Question 9, Page 26.]

title: CHINESE WILL HOLD KEY MEETING SOON
description: PEKING, Sept. 5The second of the two major political gatherings China has scheduled for this yearthe National People's Congresswill take place later this month,, according to reliable sources in the Chinese capital.

title: Police Drop Height Regivation and Draft a Unisex Test Called Free of All Prejudice
description: The height requirement will be dropped from the physical test and questions regarded by some as culturally biased will be screened out of the written test in a new Police Depart. ment qualifying examination in an effort to end bias against women and against members of racial minority groups.

title: Over90 Heat Ended By Weak Cold Front
description: The above  90  degree  heat wave ended yesterday for much of the metropolitan area as a cold front moved down from New England faster than expected. But temperatures remained uncomfortably high and no real relief was forecast until tomorrow.

title: TV: A.B.C. Teams Bennett and Lena Home at 9
description: Getting a jump on the new season, which officially begins next Monday, the Amerman Broadcasting Company is offering two whole fresh hours (excluding the commercials) of entertainment this evening.

title: EXXON PUSHES WORK ON GAS PRODUCTION
description: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that it was beginning immediately to intensify work on the first of two phases of development for coal gasification and coal liquefaction. The company estimated it would spend about $10million on the first phase.

title: Phone Pact Set in Taiwan
description: A subsidiary of General Telephone & Electronics announced yesterday an agreement to set up a joint venture company with local Taiwan interests to provide about $75million in telephone switching equipment for Taiwan's telephone system.

title: Boy Hurt as Blacks Clash With Whites At Westbury School
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 5The skull of a 15yearold white boy was fractured this morning in a melee between black and white youths at the Westbury Junior High School.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 6, 1973

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: New Hampshire's move to control its recent outbreak of Eastern equine encephalitis has canceled, for all practical purposes, birddog field trials scheduled for this fall in the state.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Sept. 5Bowlers are not the only group of sportsminded people seeking that elusive score of 300. Members of the 22 teams in the Essex County Police Revolver League shoot for that perfect score once a week from March until June.

title: 496th Golden Gate Victim
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 5 (UPI)A man plunged to his death from the Golden Gate Bridge yesterday and became the 496th known suicide from the span. He was identified as Ephram C. Oliva, 20 years old of Hamilton Air Force Base, Calif.

title: A Walkout by the Teachers in Montville Mars the Opening of Schools in the State
description: NEWARK, Sept. 5In an atmosphere of general calm, ruffled only by one facultyschool board dispute of immediate consequence, most of the hundreds of thousands of pupils and their teachers returned to classrooms today in North Jersey's school districts. The remaining school districts will reopen tomorrow or, at the latest, Monday.

title: Rosewall Beats Amritraj in Straight Sets; Newcombe, Miss Evert Also in Semifinal
description: Smiling, even applauding, as Ken Rosewall's stinging backhanders went by him, Vijay Amritraj of India was eliminated yesterday in the quarterfinals of the $227,000 United States Open tennis championships, 64, 63, 63. Thus ended the last hope for a teenager in the men's division. Amritraj had toppled Rod Laver in the third round.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The police announced yesterday the arrest of two brothers described as part of a $2.5million Volkswagen theft ring. Autosquad policemen arrested the brothers Tuesday night after they left a garage at 712 East 216th Street, the Bronx, in an unmarked commercial truck. The police said the garage contained six Volkswagens and sophisticated burglary equipment, such as punch and die sets used to alter a car's identification number. The brothers were identified as Joseph Mirenda, 35 years old, of Yonkers, and David Mirenda, 39, of Smithtown, L. The police said the ring usually stole four cars a day, taking those left by Westchester County commuters subway stations in the northern Bronx. They said the investigation was continuing.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Theater

title: Handless Woman Fights City on Relief
description: The city welfare administration was accused yesterday of refusing aid to six children and their 38yearold mother, who is without hands.

title: Jersey City Council Votes Fluoridation By an 8to1 Margin
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 5 (AP) Jersey City's Council voted 8 to 1 today to fluoridate the city's water.

title: FarmGrown Fish: A Triumph for the Ecologist and the Sensualist
description: FALMOUTH, Mass.Can a family grow a year's supply of fish in its back yard at negligible cost? Will the fish be good to eat?

title: SOUVANNA AVOIDS SPLIT WITH RIGHT
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 5Premier Souvanna Phowna and rightist members of his Cabinet today backed off from a showdown over disagreements concerning a completed protocol that would establish a coalition government with the Communistled Pathet Lao.

title: Blackedout Football
description: To hear Commissioner Pete Rozelle of the National Football League tell it, free enterprise will be permanently kicked back of its own goal line if Congress passes a bill lift ing the local television blackout on soldout home games by professional football teams.

title: People and Business
description: Moody's Investors Service, which publishes manuals, weekly stock and bond surveys and investors ratings, has named Richard D. Simmons as president. Mr. Simmons, however, is no stranger to the Dun & Bradstreet Companies, Inc., the parent of Moody'shaving previously been vice president and general counsel there and a marketing account executive at another subsidiary, the Reuben H. Donnelley Corporation.

title: TEACHERS STRIKE IN WESTCHESTER
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 5Teachers went on strike today in two Westchester County suburban areasthe wealthy, white Harrison school district and the poorer, integrated Greenburgh Central 7 District outside the city of White Plains.

title: Grim Battle for Kompong Cham Continues as Shells Fall in City
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sept. 5Grim fighting for the provincial capital of Kompong Cham, 45 miles northeast of here, continued inside the city today under a barrage of Communist shells but a Government spokesman here said the situation seemed stabilized.

title: Connecticut Allows Blue Cross a Rise On Direct Policies
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 5 (AP)Connecticut Blue Cross received state approval today to raise its rates for directpayment subscribers 5.61 per cent  less than half of the amount it had requested.

title: Nixon Won't Say How Definitive Court's Tape Ruling Must Be for Him to Obey
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5President Nixon refused today to say what sort of Supreme Court decision he would consider definitive enough to obey in the controversy over making White House tape recordings available to a Federal judge for possible transmittal to the Watergate grand jury.

title: SOVIET DISSIDENTS RECANT IN PUBLIC
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 5Two Soviet dissidents who turned state's evidence last week at a closed trial were presented here today at a major news conference to recant once more in public.

title: No Article
description: Baseball Transaction

title: Col. M. P. Good fellow, 81, Dies; Publisher of The Brooklyn Eagle
description: Col. M. Preston Goodfellow, the publisher of The Brooklyn Eagle in the nineteenthirties and a deputy director of the Office of Strategic Services in World War II, died in Washington yesterday apparently of a heart attack. He was 81 years old and was president of the Overseas Reconstruction Corporation in Washington, where he lived.

title: Raisela Beats Nancy G. In Astarita by a Nostril
description: When the field pulled up after the finish of the $29,350 Astarita at Belmont Park yesterday, Ron Turcotte on Raisela drew up beside Eddie Maple on Nancy G. and asked, Wanna settle for a dead heat? Maple's prompt reply was, 1 certainly would. The same sentiment ran through most of the crowd of 15,766, the two horses being so very close at the finish of the 61,4 furlong sprint for 2yearold fillies. Even the rival trainers, John Jacobs and Kay Jensen, had the same idea as they stood waiting for what seemed a long time before the decision was made. And it favored Raisela, by the slimmest of noses, over Nancy G.

title: Gulf Tropical Storm Threatening Crops Of Rice and Cotton
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Sept. 5 (UPI)Persistent winds and rains from tropical storm Delia flooded thousands of acres of Gulf Coast marshland today and threatened grain crops worth $100million in Texas and Louisiana, producers of half the nation's rice.

title: Miami Builder Pleads Guilty In Kickback Concealment
description: MIAMI, Sept. 5 (AP)A Miami builder, John Priestes, has pleaded guilty to falsifying a Federal Housing Authority sales agreement and rigging income tax returns to conceal more than $200,000 in kickhacks from subcontractors.

title: Yankee Records
MORE U.S. AIRCRAFT TO LEAVE THAILAND
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept, 5 (AP)United States and Thai officials have agreed on the withdrawal of 70 more American planes from Thai air bases beginning tomorrow.

title: NIXON ASKS ACTION ON 7 ENERGY BILLS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 President Nixon, acknowledging the possibility of energy shortages this winter, urged Congress today to enact seven legislative measures that he said were intended to increase the country's indigenous energy supplies.

title: Tax Fraud Appeal Planned
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5 (UPI)  Nicholas D'Andrea, Westmont, N. J., contractor, filed notice today that he would appeal a conviction for income tax fraud that resulted in a sentence of four years in prison and $20,000 in fines last week. D'Andrea was convicted last April on five of six counts of tax fraud, including evasion of $28,452 in taxes for 1966 and 1967.

title: Roundup: Red Sox Trim Orioles' Lead to 4 Games
description: Toward the end of August, the Baltimore Orioles put together a 14game winning streak and threatened to break open the fourteam battle for first place in the American League's Eastern Division.

title: A MIDEAST PLEDGE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5President Nixon said today that he was giving highest priority to achieving a Middle East settlement that would put an end to Arab threats to curtail future oil deliveries to Western countries.

title: 3,000 ATTENDMASS FOR A CITY FIREMAN
description: Three thousand city firemen marched in silent procession to a muffled drum beat in Brooklyn yesterday as a Fire Department pumper truck bore the coffin containing the body of Fireman Joseph Johnson Jr., who died at a fire last Saturday night.

title: A process that would have dismayed Darwin.
description: MIDDLESEX, EnglandAn eminent actuary has estimated that if the expectation of life in the world generally were to be increased by an average of 25 years, the population of the world at the turn of the millennium would be five billions more than is at present thought likely. This alone is enough to make one look askance at the proposalstill discussed more seriously than its merits justifyto preserve ailing or aging human beings in a state of suspended animation in the deep freeze until medicine finds a remedy for their ailments, or property values take an upward turn.

title: HIGH YIELDS MARK FANNIE MAE ISSUES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (Reuters)The Federal National Mortgage Association reported today it had issued $350.4million in fourmonth commitments to purchase home mortgages at its auction yesterday.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: UPTOWN Tonight is the next to last chance to attend one of the series of free original musical revues that have been held throughout the summer at the St. Philips Center Open Air Theater, 207 West 133d Street.

title: Zoners Pen New Ending To Anderson's High Tor
description: They [the traprock company] wanted to chew the back right off this mountain, the way they did across the cove there. Leave the old palisades sticking up here like billboards, nothing left but a false front facing the river. Not for pap, and not for me. I like this place.

title: U. S.E. E.C. Disagreement Reported at Paris Parley
description: PARIS, Sept. 5  Disagreement involving the United States and the Common Market countries were reported to have arisen again today at a highlevel monetary conference, imperiling a broad accord for a new monetary system that the major nations hope to reach in Nairobi, Kenya, later this month.

title: PLANNING AGENCY ACCEPTS PARK AID
description: The City Planning Commission set the stage yesterday for the city's acceptance of a controversial $150,000 gift from Bloomingdale's department store for alterations in the area around the Naumberg Bandshell in Central Park.

title: Ehrlichman and 3 Others Reported Indicted in West
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 5John D. Ehrlichman and three other former White House aides have been named defendants in the secret indictments for the burglary of the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist, according to sources close to the investigation.

title: For Kubelik, Staging Troyens Is a War
description: Rafael Kubelik, the first musical director in the Metropolitan Opera's history, smiled beatifically. Yes, he said, there was a simple explanation for why Hector Berlioz's monumental opera Les Troyens had never been produced in New York: Against stupidity, even the gods fight in vain. He named no names.

title: JESSE CLARKSON, 76, TAUGHT AT BROOKLYN
description: BAY SHORE, L. I., Sept. 5Jesse Dunsmore Clarkson, author and professor emeritus of history at Brooklyn College, died yesterday at the Good Samaritan Hospital, West Islip. His age was 76 and he lived here.

title: No Oil Diplomacy
description: President Nixon has made it plain that the United States will not sell Israel's independence for Arab oil, no matter how tight the energy squeeze becomes. But he has also made it plain that he faults both Israel and the Arabs for failureto do as much as they should to advance a negotiated peace in the Middle East. We feel Mr. Nixon is right on both counts. This country cannot submit diplomatic or economic blackmail by the Arabs. Neither can it relax its propeace pressure in the volatile Middle East.

title: A Winner at the Drop of an Ear
description: Occasionally at a dog show, there's an urgent call for a doctor over the public address system. At the recent Newtown fixture, the physician who responded ran from a ring, where she was showing a Skye terrier, to care for an exhibitor.

title: Consumer Credit Up Sharply in July for 4th Largest Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) Outstanding consumer credit, an indication of spending activity in the economy, increased $2.18billion in July, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: People in Sports: In Dry Dock
description: Question: What woman was chosen over Babe Ruth and Jack Dempsey to earn an Athlete of the Year title?

title: Mets Down Phils, 4 to 0, On 4Hitter
description: The Mets took another large step last night toward fulfilling their faint pennant hopes.

title: U. S. Judge Rules Holiday Inns Violates Antimonopoly Laws
description: NEWARK, Sept. 5 (AP)A Federal judge ruled today that franchising practices by Holiday Inns, Inc., the nation's largest hotelmotel operation, violate antimonopoly laws.

title: Raisela Beats Nancy G. In Astarita by a Nostril
description: When the field pulled up after the finish of the $29,350 Astarita at Belmont Park yesterday, Ron Turcotte on Raisela drew up beside Eddie Maple on Nancy G. and asked, Wanna settle for a dead heat? Maple's prompt reply was, I certainly would. The same sentiment ran through most of the crowd of 15,766, the two horses being so very close at the finish of the 6furlong sprint for 2yearold fillies. Even the rival trainers, John Jacobs and Kay Jensen, had the same idea as they stood waiting for what seemed a long time before the decision was made. And it favored Raisela, by the slimmest of over Nancy G.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was: 21936 Tickets matching the number win $1,503, Tickets, with the five numbers In reverse win $225. Tickets with the first or last four numbers In order win $225. Tickets with the first, middle or last three numbers in sequence win $25. Tickets with all five numbers scrambled win $25. Tickets matching the first and second digits, The second end third, the third and fourth or the tourth and fifth win $2.50.

title: Alien Arrests Set Mark
description: EL PASO, Tex., Sept 5 (UPI) The Border Patrol said yesterday that a record total of 11,176 Mexican aliens had been picked up in August in the El Paso area.

title: Super Is Accused Of Threatening Life Of GunRent Client
description: A 58yearold apartment house superintendent in Harlem who allegedly ran a gunrental business for worried residents of the area was arraigned yesterday in Criminal Court and held in $15,000 bail.

title: Senators Cheer Stennis After 7Month Absence
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 Seven months after he was shot during a holdup in front of his home, Senator John C. Stennis came back to the Senate today.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (Reuters)Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, sent word to House leaders today that his Ways and Means Committee would approve a new trade bill before October.

title: Camp Operator Sentenced To Probation in Bribe Case
description: Judge Morris Lasker of the Federal Court, yesterday sentenced William Mason, the operator of Camp Napanoch in Ulster County, to 30 days in prison for his part in a bribeconspiracy involving the Model Cities program in Harlem.

title: Bowmar Is Introducing PocketSized Calculator
description: The Bowmar Instrument Corporation introduced yesterday a pocketsized calculator priced at $59 and aimed specifically at housewives and students at about the junior high school level.

title: Giants' Option Keeps Glover, But Surgery May Take Davis
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 5 The New York Giants gave Rich Glover a vote of confidence today, but may lose the services of another promising rookie, Clifton Davis, for the remainder of this season.

title: ABUSE IS CHARGED AT PHOENIX HOUSE
description: Sanford D. Garelik, president of the City Council, charged yesterday that Phoenix House, a program to fight drug addiction, had been recruiting addicts from outside the state for treatment here and had been getting them on welfare.

title: Chief of U.S. Troops in Germany Visits Soviet Commander in East
description: BONN, Sept. 5The top American general in West Germany visited his Soviet counterpart in East Germany yesterday in the first such courtesy call since 1962, the United States command in Heidelberg announced today.

title: URGENCY KEYNOTE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5President Nixon, declaring that he would veto the minimum wage bill, challenged Congress today to improve upon a disappointing record by enacting his bipartisan legislative proposals.

title: SLIDE CONTINUES IN CREDIT MARKET
description: The swing of interest rates down from the peaks they reached at the beginning of August reached substantial proportions yesterday in several parts of the credit market.

title: U.S. ACCUSES HANOI ON DEAD AND MISSING
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 5 (AP)The United States today charged North Vietnam and the Vietcong with deliberately holding back information on missing Americans and delaying the return of the remains of United States prisoners of war buried in the North.

title: Adelphi Classroom on Wheels Awards a Master's
description: Adelphi University's Classroom on Wheels yesterday awarded its first master's degreeto a Penn Central commuterin a 20minute capandgown ceremony in Grand Central Terminal.

title: MUSIC HALL GIVES UNIONS A WARNING
description: The Radio City Music Hall notified seven unions representing its employes yesterday that it would suspend operations after next Wednesday if contract settlements with four of them had not been reached.

title: Levitz and Wickes Corp. Report Increased Sales
description: Two major chains of furniture warehouse showrooms, the Levitz Furniture Corporation and the Wickes Corporation. reported yesterday increased sales for August compared to the yearagomonth. However, Levitz had a much smaller gain than it has traditionally reported.

title: COLGATE ACQUIRES COSMETICS MAKER
description: Helena Rubinstein, Inc., became a wholly owned subsidiary of the ColgatePalmolive Company yesterday with approval of the $219million merger by shareholders of Helena Rubinstein.

title: C.D.C. Wins Right to Buy Stock in Its Texasgulf Bid
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 5 (Canadian Press)The Canada Development Corporation, wholly owned by the Canadian Government, won the right in United States District Court today to buy 10 million shares of Texasgulf, Inc., a major American mining and natural resources company with holdings in Canada.

title: New Planning Unit Holds First Session
description: TRENTON, Sept. 5A new agency, charged with insuring that one governmental department knows what the other is doing, held its organizational meeting today in Governor Cahill's office.

title: U.S. Open Results
description: MEN'S SINGLES

title: Kin of Accused in Police Killings Assert Authorities Harass Them
description: Relatives of alleged members of the Black Liberation Army here yesterday protested what they said was harassment by lawenforcement authorities.

title: Railroad Orders Cars
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 5 (AP) The Missouri Pacific System has announced the largest single freight car and locomotive or der in the history of the rail road. The company said ?? would buy $75million worth o?? machinery, including 60 diese locomotives, 2,519 freight car?? and 60 cabooses.

title: Sports New's Briefs
description: LONDON, Sept. 5 (AP)An American, John Fitzgerald, and two Finns, Risto Hurme and Martti Ketelae, shared the lead after the tough riding section of the world modern pentathlon championships today at London's Crystal Palace sports complex.

title: Metropolitan Briefs Teachers Strike
description: Teachers went on strike today in two Westchester County suburban areas, the wealthy white Harrison School District and the poorer integrated Greenburgh Central 7 District outside the city of White Plains.

title: Basketball Transactions
description: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION

title: Minor League Playoffs
description: Charleston 10, Rochester 5 (Charleston leads threeoffive series, 10).

title: NIXON INDICATES NOLANDGAIN TAX
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5President Nixon indicated today that he had paid no capital gains tax on a $1.24million sale of some of his property at San Clemente, Calif. He explained that the Internal Revenue Service had not ordered him to make any changes in his income tax returns.

title: Law Ending TV Blackout Is Near, Legislator Says
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 Congress is only weeks away from passing legislation that would end television blackouts of many home games in professional sports, Representative Torbert H. MacDonald said today.

title: MARCONE IS GIVEN YEAR ON TAX BRIBE
description: Natale Marcone, the president of the ItalianAmerican Civil Rights League, was sentenced yesterday to one year in prison for having paid a $4,000 bribe to an Internal Revenue Service agent investigating his personal and corporate income taxes.

title: SUPPLIES OF BEEF IN SUPERMARKETS ARE NEAR NORMAL
description: Meat supplies have climbed back to just about normal in supermarkets here, along with improving stocks for whole. salers who serve small retailers, butchers and restaurants, the city's Consumer Affairs Depart. ment reported yesterday.

title: Fire Forces Evacuation
description: MEMPHIS, Sept. 5 (AP)  A railroad tank car carrying propane gas caught fire today, forcing the evacuation of several hundrd persons in south Memphis. No injuries were reported, and firemen brought the fire under control within an hour.

title: Minor League Playoffs
description: INTERNATIONAL LEAGUE

title: 136 Picassos Brighten Red Fair
