description: PARIS, Sept. 5The most comprehensive Picasso show since the master's death last spring was officially opened tonight in the unusual setting of the French Communist party's giant annual country fair here.

title: Most of Superfecias Reportedly Fixed At 3 State Tracks, Netting $2Million
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has uncovered evidence showing that almost all of the superfecta races that were run at Roosevelt, Yonkers and Monticello Raceways from December, 1972, through March, 1973, were fixed, according to sources close to the Federal investigation.

title: Call Her Madam, Not Majesty
description: At moments of particular stress Queen Juliana of the Netherlands tells people to call her Mevrouw (Madam), not Majesteit (Majesty).

title: There's No Place Like His Home
description: The flight of 15 steps that fills the converted storefront window on East 19th Street isn't there purely for decoration.

title: Kissinger Hearings Listed On Channel 13 Tomorrow
description: Channel 13 (WHET) will provide taped coverage tomorrow of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearings on Henry A. Kissinger's nomination as Secretary of State, beginning at 10 P.M. The hearings will be taped for transmission over facilities of the Public Broadcasting Service beginning at 9 P.M.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily Iottery number yesterday was:

title: Cosmetic Hearings Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (Reuters)Public hearings on a controversial measure to regulate labeling and apply health standards for cosmetics were postponed today in the Senate for at least two more months.

title: U.S. IS CAUTIONED ON SCIENCE ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5The United States maintains a commanding position in world science, but that leadership is declining in several important indicators of scientific activity, according to a report sent to Congress today by President Nixon.

title: ABUSE IS CHARGED AT PHOENIX HOUSE
description: Sanford D. Garelik, president of the City Council, charged yesterday that Phoenix House, a program to fight drug addiction, had been recruiting addicts from outside the state for treatment here and had been getting them on welfare.

title: Shift on Comic Strips
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 5 (UPI)Yielding to subscriber pressure, Iowa's largest newspaper announced today that it would not reduce the size of comic strips. In a statement Monday, The Des Moines Register informed readers that thee, comics would be reduced in size to three columns and several regular features would be discontinued because of severe newsprint shortages. However, The Register announced this morning that reader reaction was such that the decision was made to increase the size of the comic strips.

title: 3 Black Muslims Accused Of Kidnapping Policeman
description: NEWARK, Sept. 5  Three Black Muslims were arrested today on charges of kidnapping a policeman as they conducted their own investigation into the slaying of their leader, James Shabazz, who was shot to death in the driveway of his home yesterday.

title: Manager of L I. Theater Arrested After Screening
description: CORAM, L.I., Sept. 5 (UPI)Henry K. Goldman, manager of the new Coram Theater at Routes 25 and 112, was arrested last night for the second time in a week and charged with second degree obsecenity for showing the film The Devil in Miss Jones, the Suffolk County police reported.

title: PRICES ON AMEX SHOW A DECLINE
description: Prices eased yesterday continued moderate trading on the American Stock Exchange. The overthecounter market remained firm on slightly creased volume.

title: Faded Saigon Hotel, Like the City, Is Mostly Waiting
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam Aug. 30  Andre Malraux slept there. Graham Greene's quiet American had a fateful encounter on its terrace. During the Communists' 1968 Tet offensive, American journalists took refuge in its hallways.

title: Nonaligned Nations Troubled by Discord as Parley Begins
description: ALGIERS, Sept. 5The poor nations of Asia, Africa and Latin America opened today their biggest effort to date to achieve unity against the industrial world. But they immediately confronted discord among themselves and in their home countries.

title: Marcos Finds Foe's Trial Has Debit Side
description: MANILA, Sept. 4How to handle the trial of his chief political opponent on charges of subversion, murder and illegal possession of firearms has developed into the most awkward procedural problem President Ferdinand E. Marcos has faced since he declared martial law a year ago.

title: Horse Show Results
description: AT EAST HAMPTON

title: PBW BOARD SHOWS NEW DATA SYSTEM
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5 (AP) The PBW Stock Exchange today unveiled a data dissemination system that officials said would be compatible to a new trading concept envisioned by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Prices for Stocks Climb; Dow Is Up 3.69 at 899.08
description: The stock market swung higher yesterday afternoon to post its seventh advance in the last nine sessions. Activity edged up from Tuesday's level but remained subdued at 14.58 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Refuse 3canHour Raise
description: DUNKIRK, N. Y., Sept. 5 (AP) Fire Chief John F. Palmer, paid $10,000 a year, asked the Dunkirk Common Council for a raise and got a $200 offer. In a letter to the Council yesterday he said that he worked 106 hours a week and that the raise would amount to 3 cents an hour. I wish to decline this raise, he said.

title: Seoul Diplomat Is Accused By Japanese in Kidnapping
description: TOKYO, Sept. 5Japanese police authorities reported today that they had evidence showing that South Korean Government officials took part in the kidnapping of a Korean opposition leader here last month.

title: Kissinger's Actions Challenged at Parley
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 5 The professional conduct a Henry A. Kissinger, the nation's most prominent political scientist, was called into question today by a portion of the American Political Science Association, of which he was once a member.

title: Law Ending TV Blackout Is Near, Legislator Says
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 Congress is only weeks away from passing legislation that would end television blackouts of many home games in professional sports, Representative Torbert H. MacDonald said today.

title: About the Mets:
description: Manager Yogi Berra was getting his pitching staff geared up for the stretch run. He changed his plans for the fourgame series in Montreal starting tomorrow, moving up Jerry Koosman to the opening game and Tom Seaver to Saturday night, each on three days' rest instead of the customary four. Jon Matlack will start the second game of tomorrow night's doubleheader and George. Stone will pitch Sunday.... George Theodore, who had been on the disabled list since July 8 with a dislocated right hip, was restored to the active roster.... In other personnel moves the Mets assigned Joe Nolan, catcher; Larry Fritz, first baseman, and Jim Gosger, outfielder, outright to Tidewater of the International League. The players had been on option to the farm club.... The final home game, against Montreal Sept. 26, was rescheduled from a day to a night game. A tribute to Willie Mays was scheduled the day before, and if that game was rained out, the club wanted to have a night game the following day to attract as fans as possible.

title: Bonn Aide Admits He Withdrew Funds In Bribery Inquiry
description: BONN, Sept. 5West Germany's equivalent of the Watergate hearings resumed today with an admission from a high Government official that he had withdrawn about $25,000 from a special political fund the day before a former member of Parliament claims he was bribed with the same amount.

title: William Davy, an Organizer Of First News Guild Local
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 5William M. Davy, first international organizer for what is now the Newspaper Guild and exexecutive secretary of Local No. 1 of the Cleveland Newspaper Guild for more than 30 years, died today in Lakewood Hospital. He was 78 years old.

title: FRANK ELKINS, 63, SKI WRITER, DEAD
description: Frank Elkins, a former New York Times sports writer whose coverage of skiing spurred its development in the nineteenthirties and forties, died of leukemia yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 13112 Francis Lewis Boulevard in Laurelton, Queens.

title: Himalayan Trip in Drug Case
description: MAYVILLE. N. Y. Sept. 5 (AP) A lawyer defending a ??redonia man in a drug case has left for the Himalayas, hoping to enlist the aid of a guru. The suspect, Richard A. Rowden, 21 years old, is accused of receiving a package mailed from Nepal that contained several pound of opium. The name of the ?? and his connection ?? Mr. Bowden were not disclosed.

title: CHOLERA ADVISORY ISSUED BY THE U.S.
description: United States health officials are strongly recommending that travelers to Italy receive cholera vaccinations in view of the outbreak of the disease there.

title: FREEING OF ARAB IS SOUGHT AGAIN
description: BEIRUT Lebanon, Sept. 5 The Palestinian commandos who seized the Saudi Arabian Embassy in Paris today were seeking the release of a Palestinian guerrilla leader from prison in Jordan. They demanded his freedom shortly after storming the embassy.

title: Senate Rejects 2 Curbs on Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5The Senate rejected today moves to cut the White House budget and curb, future security improvements on President Nixon's two private homes.

title: 6 to Vie for Top Prizes In MillionDollar Lottery
description: The holders of three tickets numbered 939800 and three tickets numbered 302635 won chances at a top prize of $50,000 a year for life in the preliminary drawing yesterday for the New York State Lottery's milliondollar summer special.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: Transcript of President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: Following is a transcript of President Nixon's news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Slump Is Forecast for '74  Record Set in August
description: DETROIT, Sept. 5  The chairman of the General Motors Corporation, Richard C. Gerstenberg, said today that sales of new cars in the 1974 model year would approach 11 million unitsa sharp decline from this year's record of 11.7 million.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE HONORARY CONSUL. By Graham Greene. 315 pages. Simon & Schuster. $7.95.

title: Pension Pretense
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5Next week, the Senate begins debate on two rival bills to reform the private pension industry. One is S.4 sponsored by Senators Williams (Democrat, N. J.) and Javits (Republican, N. Y.) and endorsed by the Senate Labor Committee and practically the whole liberal establishment in the Senate. The other is S.1179 sponsored by Senator Bentsen (Democrat, Tex.) and cleared by the more conservative Senate Finance Committee.

title: Avnet's Earnings and Sales Reach Record Levels
description: Avnet, Inc., a diversified industrial producer, achieved the highest sales and earnings of any quarter in its 18year his tory and set record levels for the ear ended June 30, according to results issued yesterday.

title: ExSaigon Leader Attacks Both Sides Over Prisoners
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 5 (UPI)  Retired Gen. Duong Van Minh, a former South Vietnamese leader, attacked both the Government and the Communists today for keeping political prisoners behind bars despite the Jan. 28 peace accord.

title: Federal Judge Sets Hearing on Appeal for a Delay in Trial of Mitchell and Stans
description: A hearing that could delay the trial of John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans was set yesterday by Judge Henry J. Friendly of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: Chess:
description: The knight, like the other pieces, reaches its maximum power when it is posted in the center, or when it bears directly on the center. Unlike the other pieces, the knight undergoes a dramatic difference in range when it moves to the center from the edge of the board. A bishop on one of the four center squares attacks 13 squares, but even in a corner it still attacks 7. A knight in the center attacks 8 squares; in a corner, it attacks only 2.

title: DESSER REFUSES TO LEAVE P.S. 208
description: Norman Desser, the newly appointed principal at Public School 208 in Brooklyn, said yesterday that he intended to perform his duties despite the opposition of part of the local school board and of parents holding a sitin at the school.

title: BEAN SETS RECORD FOR TIME IN SPACE
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 5 (AP) Capt. Alan L. Bean, of the Navy, the 41yearold commander of Skylab 2, became the world champion of space flight today, setting a mark for the most time in space.

title: DR. JULIUS F. MILLER
description: Dr. Julius F. Miller, clinical professor of oral surgery at New York University Bellevue Medical Center, died last night at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived in Lawrence, L. I.

title: DECEPTION LAID TO U.S. INFORMER
description: The Federal Government's star witness in the recent trial of the Gainesville Eight in Florida has shown indications of deception during a lie detector test he sought to deny an acquaintance's charges that he was a violenceprone agent provocateur last year.

title: Ehrlichman and 3 Others Reported Indicted in West
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 5John D. Ehrlichman and three other former White House aides have been named defendants in the secret indictments for the burglary of the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist, according to sources close to the investigation.

title: Most of Superfectas Reportedly Fixed At 3 State Tracks, Netting $2Million
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has uncovered evidence showing that almost all of the superfecta races that were run at Roosevelt, Yonkers and Monticello Raceways from December; 1972, through March, 1973, were fixed, according to sources close to the Federal investigation.

title: Arthur Daley
description: I'm faster than ever I'm a sight for the world. So spake Muhammad All yesterday as he abandoned his natural modesty and reticence. This pronouncement was in the nature of a farewell address as the onetime champion of the universe reluctantly left his elaborate training camp in Deer Park, Pa., and headed to California for his return match with Ken Norton on Monday.

title: An Ulster Farmer Is Killed As Tractor Strikes Mine
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 5 (AP)A tractor struck a land mine today, killing an Ulster farmer on the border with the Irish Republic.

title: Horse Show Results
description: Green Working Hunter ChampionshipChampion, Gay Wiles's Weather Watch, 13 Points; reserve, Pam Caras's Oralla, 8.

title: Blumenthal for Mayor
description: The Mayor of this largest of American cities must be capable of vigorous, imaginative, creative leadership. He must be able to attract and to hold the confidence of the people, to work with this city's diverse groups and persuade them of the mutuality of their interests. He must have more than just the stamina for an incredibly taxing assignment, although he surely has to have that as well.

title: Paper Mill Strikes Continue At 2 Canadian Companies
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 5 (AP)Strikes at Canadian paper mills continued today with 4,500 employes staying off the job.

title: Equity Financing
description: Easteln Gas & Fuel Associates announced yesterday it had purchased 110,000 shares of its own common stock at $15 a share from the S. H. Scheuer interests. The company's stock closed at 16, down.  on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: CHRYSLER PARLEY HELD IN SECRET
description: DETROIT, Sept. 5  Auto contract talks, which had been stalled for a week, showed signs of significant movement today when negotiators for the United Auto Workers announced the start of secret bargaining sessions with Chrysler Corporation on key economic issues.

title: Gunmen Hold 15 Hostages In Saudi Embassy in Paris
description: PARIS, Thursday, Sept. 6A small band of Palestinian gunmen took over the Saudi Arabian Embassy here yesterday morning and reportedly seized at least 15 of of its diplomats and employes as hostages. The gunmen threatened to blow up the embassy or to kill their hostages if their demands were not met.

title: Safety Board Asks Steps To Block Airliner Fires
description: The National Transportation Safety Board, alarmed by the July 11 airliner crash in Paris in which 124 persons died, recommended yesterday broad new governmental measures to deal with the danger of fires in flight.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Winning numbers drawn on Sept. 6 were:

title: Sen. Hughes Plans A Religious Career
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 6  Senator Harold E. Hughes, 51yearold Iowa Democrat, said today that he would leave the Senate when his first term expires next year to accept a compelling commitment to do religious work.

title: Congress Gets Plan to Protect Dollar and Oil Supply
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6Peter G. Peterson, the former Secretary of Commerce, said today that the United States could protect its future oil supplies and the value of the dollar by helping Middle Eastern countries restructure their societies.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: BIG BOARD TO RENEW COAST DISCUSSIONS
description: The board of directors of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday authorized its chairman, James J. Needham, to continue discussions with the Pacific Stock Exchange about a possible affiliation between the two groups.

title: Mrs. Huff Married in Bay State to William Everett
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Sept. 6Mrs. Brenda Huff of New York and Dr. William Henry Everett, an internist here and chief of the department of medicine at the North Adams Regional Hospital, were married this afternoon at the home of Prof. and Mrs. Dudley W. R. Bahlman. Professor Bahlman is dean of the faculty and professor of history at Williams College. The Rev. John D. Eusden, chaplain at Williams, performed the ceremony.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 8.5 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 196.6 from 205.1 last week.

title: Nixon's Mideast Pledge Fails to Kindle Hopes for Early Settlement
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6Despite President Nixon's assertion that he was giving highest priority to a Middle East settlement, Administration officials and diplomats said today that they saw little likelihood of any break soon in the ArabIsrael impasse.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Winning numbers drawn on Sept. 6 were:

title: Temperatures Here Continue to Decline; Heat Fades Slowly
description: Temperatures continued to moderate over the metropolitan area yesterday and, for the first time since the heat wave began early last week, Consolidated Edison reported virtually no heatrelated problems.

title: Roundup: Expos Beat Cubs, 53, for 6th Straight and Gain 2d Place
description: When the baseball experts were making their predictions of the 1973 pennant races, the Houston Astros, a 1962 expansion club, was mentioned prominently.

title: Notes on People
description: Government sources said that President Nixon would nominate John R. Bartels Jr. as permanent administrator of the recently created Drug Enforcement Administration. Mr. Bartels, who is 38 years old, has been acting head of the agency since July 1, when it was formed from four existing Government units involved with narcotics. Mr. Bartels, whose nomination requires Senate confirmation, was deputy director of the Office of Drug Abuse Law Enforcement, one of the units absorbed by the new agency. Before that, he had been chief of the Justice Department's organized crime strike force in Newark, and an assistant United States attorney in New York City.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Preseason Football
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: JERSEY TO CHECK SURPLUS HANDLING
description: TRENTON, Sept. 6  The State Commission of Investigation will begin public hearings Wednesday on complaints official mishandling of Federal surplus property, violations of state bidding laws and the conversion of public property and services for private use.

title: Ferguson Thanks Stars For Keeping Him at Work
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I. Sept. 6  John McKay, the University of Southern California football coach, may have done a big favor for an alumnus of San Diego State.

title: CON ED ALLOWED $164MILLION RISE
description: The State Public Service Commission announced yester day that it had granted $164.5million of the $183million increase in electricity rates requested by the Consolidated Edison Company. This is $69.2million above the temporarily increased rates now in effect.

title: Naples Destroys Its Tainted Mussel Beds
description: ROME, Sept. 6With tainted shellfish being blamed as they main source of Italy's cholera outbreak, the destruction of mussel beds was begun today in the bay of Naples.

title: GOVERNOR PLANS TO POLL WORLD
description: Governor Rockefeller intends to use publicopinion polling on an international basis and hold public hearings throughout the United States and possibly abroad as part of an ambitious study of the nation's future.

title: Clash Between President And Congress Intensifies
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 The dispute between President Nixon and Congress intensified today.

title: $273Million in Swaps
description: The Federal Reserve System intervened repeatedly in the New York foreignexchange market in July, selling the equivalent of $273million in foreign exchange acquired through swap drawings on the central banks of West Germany, France and Belgium, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday.

title: Corporate Profile
description: OTTAWA  H. Anthony Hampson, the softspoken chief executive officer of the Canada Development Corporation, talking to businessmen not too long ago, remarked that the staff of C.D.C. was small15 in all.

title: Saigon Reports Heavy Fighting At Kontum and in the Hue Area
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Sept. 7 (UPI)Government and Communist troops battled for 19 hours along the defense perimeter protecting the provincial capital of Kontum yesterday and more heavy fighting was reported 75 miles to the east on the central coast.

title: Perjury Charged by U.S.
description: Five men have been indicted. and 10 other persons have been arrested in connection with the Federal investigation of alleged fixed superfecta harness horse races at New York tracks, according to Federal court records in Broollyn.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 7:30 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 11, 7:30 P.M.) (RadioWMCA, 7:30 P.M.)

title: Jury Is Studying Campaign Gift To Nixon From Ship Executives
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 The Watergate grand jury is; investigating a secret $100,000 donation to President Nixon's political campaign made by officials of a Cleveland ship company while the concern was trying, without success, to win payment of a $5million overrun on a Government contract.

title: ARTHUR LOEWENGART
description: Arthur Loewengart, a leather manufacturer who founded Loewengart & Co. in Germany in 1925 and reestablished his business here in 1937, died (Wednesday in Palm Beach, Fla. Since his retirement, he had lived there and in Shavei Zion, Israel. He was 74 years old.

title: Senate Votes, 766, to Restrict TV Blackouts of Sports Events
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6The Senate votes today to forbid television blackouts of professional sports events that are sold out 72 hours in advance.

title: Cashings Raised Suspicion
description: A mystery woman, so beautiful she made heads turn in shops of the Offtrack Betting Corporation, helped call attention to the questionable wagering patterns that touched off a Federal investigation of the superfecta here.

title: PAPER PACT HAILED IN EASTERN CANADA
description: TORONTO, Sept. 6 (UPI)The United Paperworkers International Union said today that a major breakthrough had been achieved in the labortroubled Eastern Canadian paper industry with a tentative twoyear agreement reached yesterday between the Great Lakes Paper Company, Ltd. and 1,350 of its employes in Thunder Bay, Ont.

title: Administration Postpones Presentation of New Housing Program
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6Despite repeated announcements to Congress that a sweeping new Federal housing program would be submitted today, the Nixon Administration postponed disclosing the proposal until next week.

title: Nixon Sleeps Here
description: A surprise awaited President Nixon on his return to the White House last Saturdayhis bedroom had been completely redecorated.

title: Big Rise Expected in Capital Outlays
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 United States business plans a strong increase in investment in plant and equipment in the final two quarters of this year after only a modest growth in actual investment in the second quarter, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: 4 Named in Witness's Death
description: PUTNAM, Conn., Sept. 6 (AP) Four Rhode Island men were indicted on murder charges yesterday in the dynamiting death of a federal witness, Daniel Lapolla, last September. A Superior Court grand jury handed up the indictments against William Marrapese, 31 years old, and Nicholas Zinni, 44, both of Cranston, and David Guillette, 29, and Robert Joost, 27, both of Providence.

title: Studies Abroad Set For Joint Ventures Topping $1Billion
description: International jointventure projects that might require outlays in excess of $1billion were announced yesterday. The projects are envisioned for South Korea and Saudi Arabia.

title: TAP ON A BROTHER OF NIXON AT ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6The White House said today that if the Secret Service had wiretapped the telephone of F. Donald Nixon, the President's brother, it would have been related to the protective function of the Secret Service.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1973

title: Qaddafi Calls Nonalignment Unrealistic
description: ALGIERS, Sept. 6Col. Muammar elQaddafi, the 31yearold leader of Libya, told the elder statesmen of 75 nonaligned nations toda ythat nonalignment was virtually impossible in today's world.

title: WARREN J. MARTIN
description: Warren J. Martin, a partner in the admiralty law firm of Martin & Ryan, died of cancer Wednesday at his home, 18 Walworth Avenue, Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 54 years old.

title: U.N.'s Korean Unification Body Formally Requests That It Be Allowed to Die at 23
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 6  After 23 years, the United Nations Commission on Unification of Korea recommended its own liquidation today in a report to Secretary General Waldheim.

title: Snowfall on Mount Fuji
description: TOKYO, Sept. 6 (AP)The season's first snow fell on Mount Fuji today, two days earlier than expected.

title: 9 State U. Professors Promoted To a New Distinguished Rank
description: ALBANY, Sept. 6We have recognized research, now it is time to reward talented teaching, said Dr. Ernest L. Boyer, chancellor of the State University, today in announcing the new rank of Distinguished Teaching Professor.

title: Wednesday's Fight
description: Las Vegas, Nev.Rocky DiFazio, 153 pounds, Chicago, drew with Larry Shelton, 155, North Las Vegas, 10 rounds.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UPI)Savings Bond redemptions hit a new high in August, the Treasury Department said today, as bond holders apparently cashed in their Government securities in favor of competing investments offering higher interest rates.

title: London Study Finds That Pacts Haven't Slowed the Arms Race
description: LONDON, Sept. 6  An authoritative study reported today that despite the SovietAmerican agreement on arms limitation there is little evidence that the superpower arms race has sickened.

title: Lawyer Reports Settlement of Suits Ouer Long's Estate
description: HANNIBAL, Mo., Sept. 6 (UPI)An attorney for the widow of Senator Edward V. Long said today that a series of suits and countersuits had been settled out of court.

title: Dr. Lucile Kohn, 90, Dead; Led Labor Education Unit
description: Dr. Lucile Kohn, a retired teacher who was formerly chairman of the American Labor Education Service, died Wednesday at her home, 1138 Madison Avenue. She was 90 years old.

title: GARRET S. NAGLE
description: Garret S. Nagle, who retired in 1961 as assistant vice president of the Reynolds Metals Company, died Wednesday at his home in Jackson Heights, Queens. He was 79 years old.

title: British Petroleum Increases Its Sales and Profits to Record
description: The British Petroleum Company, Ltd., showed a sharp recovery in the three and six months ended June 30, lifting sales and profits to records for the periods, according to midyear results announced yesterday.

title: Heath Will Go to Dublin For a Talk on the North
description: LONDON, Sept. 6 Prime Minister Heath will go to Ireland on Sept. 17 for a day's talk with Liam Cosgrave, the Irish Prime Minister. It will be the first official visit of a British leader to the Republic since it was founded 51 years ago.

title: Senate Votes, 766, to Restrict TV Blackouts of Sports Events
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6The Senate voted today to forbid television blackouts of professional sports events that are sold out 72 hours in advance.

title: MARCHI CAMPAIGN LOSES DIRECTOR
description: State Senaor John J. Marchi's mayoral campaign coordinator resigned yesterday in a disagreement with Senator Marchi over strategy, finances and the influence of United States Senator James L. Buckley's aides in the campaign.

title: People in Sports: Caution Marks Morrison's Debut
description: On the eve of his debut as a college football coach, Joe Morrison displayed the cautious pessimism he picked up from his coaches during 14 years with the football Giants. His team, the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga, opens against Eastern Kentucky, but then goes on to play such schools as Vanderbilt and Auburn. For a school this size, said Morrison, we think we have the toughest schedule in the coup. try.

title: SEARLE PLANNING 215MILLION DEAL
description: G. D. Searle & Co. has reached an agreement in principle to acquire Will Ross, Inc., in an exchange of stock valued at $215.9million, the two makers of healthcare products announced yesterday.

title: Watergate as Part of the Purchase Price
description: SAN MATEO, Calif.Since most of the Watergate testimony is now in, and the President has again stated his case, perhaps it is time for an additional perspective. My own frame of reference is built on long friendship with Mr. Nixon and whatever insight and understanding of his character I have gained from my association with him.

title: Suspect in Sword Murder Seized 60 Days After Release at Attica
description: Two weeks of intensive investigation by a pair of Bronx detectives led to the arrest last night of a man who will be arraigned this morning on a charge of murdering a 23yearold psychotherapist with a sword.

title: LEGALITY SOUGHT FOR THE NUMBERS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6  A panel of prominent lawyers recommended today that the District of Columbia legalize the numbers game to serve as a model for the nation.

title: Troops Rushed to Bolster Tottering Kompong Cham
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sept. 6  With enemy troops pouring into the provincial capital of Kompong Cham, the Phnom Penh Government mounted an emergency helicopter lift of reinforcements to the embattled city today but the situation was reported, to be growing more serious by the hour.

title: Chicken Done in the Oriental Manner
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: Krogh Pleads Not Guilty In Ellsberg BreakIn Case
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 6Egil Krogh Jr., former White House aide, entered a plea of not guilty immediately after his surrender today in Los Angeles for arraignment on charges stemming from his alleged particination in a burglary scheme to obtain Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatric files.

title: LARGE RET AIL CHAINS REPORT SALES GAINS
description: Several of the country's largest retail chains reported yesterday increased sales in August over the seine 1972 month, following similar reports by other retail concerns last week.

title: TAPES ARE HEARD IN GARRISON TRIAL
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 6District Attorney Jim Garrison listened intently in Federal District Court today to tape recordings purportedly linking him to an alleged bribery scheme involving New Orleans policemen and pinball machine owners.

title: UNION AIDE SCORES CHRYSLER PROPOSAL
description: DETROIT, Sept. 6 (AP)Chrysler Corporation's proposals on working conditions look more sour, now than they did when first presented, Douglas Fraser, vice president of the United Auto Workers Union, said today.

title: Nuclear Plant to Close
description: JACKSON, Mich., Sept. (UPI)The Consumers Power Company said today it would close its Palisades nuclear power plant near South Haven, Mich., for about three month while the company conduct. tests and cleaning of the steam generating system. The measure, which will cost about $10. million, followed the closing 4 the plant Aug. 11 after ?? minute leak of radioactiv?? water was detected. Consumer Power said it would purchas?? power from other companie?? for the 90day period.

title: Earthquake in Alaska
description: PALMER, Alaska, Sept. 6 (AP)An earthquake was felt in Valdez and Anchorage early today, but no damage was mediately reported, according to the Palmer Observatory. An observatory spokesman said the quake registered 5.5 on the Richter scale and was felt very strongly in Valdez. The quake's epicenter was in Prince Dilliam Sound, 35 miles southwest of Valdez and 100 miles southeast of Anchorage.

title: Some Questions for Henry Kissinger
description: WASHINGTONIt is an appealing visionan open foreign policy, supported by a new bipartisan consensus, As he testifies at his confirmation hearings, Henry Kissinger will try to forge the new consensus he is now promoting in public and private conversations. He wants to save foreign policy from Watergate by rallying liberals as well as conservatives to the President's foreign policy banner.

title: Where Once There Was a Cast, Jacobson's Foot Sprouts Wings
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 6When the Giants' orthopedic surgeon, Dr. Anthony Pisani, gave Larry Jacobson the good news that his injured toot would be healed in time for the regularseason opener Sept. 16, the defensive tackle wasn't at all satisfied.

title: The Scenery Was Better Than the Food
description: The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: EUROPE RADIO FUND BACKED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP)  The Senate passed a bill today to authorize continued Federal financing of Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty.

title: Troops Rushed to Bolster Tottering Kompong Cham
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sept. 6  With enemy troops pouring into the provincial capital of Kompong Cham, the Phnom Penh Government mounted an emergency helicopter lift of reinforcements to the embattled city today but the situation was reported to be growing more serious by the hour.

title: !FORD NEWCAR SALES OFF 7.9% IN AUGUST
description: DETROIT, Sept. 6The Ford Motor Company reported today that it sold 194,615 new cars in August, off 7.9 per cent from 211,204 in the same month last year.

title: Boyle Accused of Murder In the Killing of Yablonski
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6W. A. Boyle, the deposed former president of the United Mine Workers of America, was arrested and charged with murder today in the 1969 killing of Joseph A. Yablonski, the leader who had sought to oust the Boyle regime in the union election that year.

title: Perjury Charged by U.S.
description: Five men have been indicted and 10 other persons have been arrested in connection with the Federal investigation of alleged fixed superfecta harness horse races at New York tracks, according to Federal court records in Brooklyn.

title: Equity Financing
description: The Boston Edison Company yesterday said it planned to sell 1 million additional shares of common stock with a $10 par value and 400,000 shares of a fourth series of cumulative preferred with a $100 par value. The offerings are planned, subject to shareholder and regulatory agency approval, for the end of next month. The company's common stocl closed yesterday at 30, up , on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Dow Penetrates 900 Level With a Rise of 1.96 Points
description: The DowJones industrial average forged back above the 900 level yesterday with a 1.96 point advance that stretched the rally from this year's Aug. 22 low to nearly 50 points.

title: WABC to Carry News Show Early on Sunday Evenings
description: Television station WABC will inaugurate an hourlong Sunday evening Eyewitness News program, beginning at 6 P.M. on Sept. 16. It will be the city's only hourlong early evening news report on Sundays.

title: House Passes Plan To Control Floods By LandUse Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) The House passed yesterday a greatly expanded flood insurance plan that gives the Federal Government more power in getting communities to conform to safe zoning laws.

title: NIXON AIDES SAY HOMES MAY FACE HEATING OIL CURB
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 Energy officials in the Nixon Administration disclosed today that the Government might have to restrict the amount of oil that could be burned by individual consumers, including that used in private homes.

title: The Pop Life
description: One song can do it. The singer Gilbert O'Sullivan, who arrives for his first American concert at Philharmonic Hall on Sept. 21, wrote Alone Again (Naturally). Recording the song, O'Sullivan had a big hit single and a big hit album.

title: The Triple To Remain At Tracks
description: The State Racing and Wagering Board will by the end of this month appoint an overall director of security for the state's race tracks, Emil (Bus) Mosbacher Jr., chairman of the twomonthold board, said yesterday.Mosbacher said he had planned to create the position before he learned this week of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's investigation into the possible fixing of superfecta races at Roosevelt, Yonkers, and Monticello Raceways.He identified the appointee only as a top guy in the security field, nut now employed in racing, who will coordinate the security functions now handled separately by the Thoroughbred Racing Protective Bureau, Inc., for the thoroughbred tracks, and by Harness Tracks Security, Inc., for the harness tracks.Mosbacher said the two organizations would continue to operate under the new structure.Mosbacher also said his board would take a careful look at all forms of multiple betting but he added there was no reason at the moment to suspend the triple, which the harness tracks introduced last April to replace the suspended superfecta.The F.B.I. had not given him any advance notice of its investigation, Mosbacher said. He said the investigation was not all bad if it proves to the public that security forces are on the alert.Track owners and security officials stressed yesterday that they had not yet seen any evidence of wrongdoing, although they conceded that speculation about fixed superfecta races would seriously damage both the image and the handle at the tracks.

title: CLOSE STUDY SET FOR EXTRA JUDGES
description: The Court of Claims judges appointed by Governor Rockefeller to handle narcotics trials under the state's stringent new drug law will undergo close scrutiny by the State Senate's Judiciary Committee before they are formally confirmed, Senator Bernard G. Gordon, chairman of the committee, said yesterday.

title: 403 Horses Bring $5Million at Sale
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 6 (UPI)  The 35th annual standardbred horse sales concluded its threeday session today with a record average price of $12,423. Reports showed 403 standardbred yearlings sold for a total of $5,010,000. In 1972, 483 yearlings grossed $5,229,900, for an average of $10,929.

title: Napanoch Prison Faces Explosive Situation, State Correction Panel Told
description: A special report to the State Commission of Correction says that the atmosphere at the state prison at Napanoch is extremely tense and an incident of almost any proportion could cause an explosive situation,

title: Louis H. Wilson, 65, Aide To Secretary of Agriculture
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6, (AP) Louis H. Wilson, an aide to Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz, died last night at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 65 years old. Mr. Wilson joined the Agriculture Department two years ago as a special assistant to the then Secretary Clifford M. Hardin. Before joining the department Mr. Wilson was for nearly 25 years an executive with the Fertilizer Institute, a trade organization.

title: Argentine Guerrillas Seize Army Post
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 6 (UPI)Leftist guerrillas captured a military supply center today and held it in the face of a police and army siege for five hours, killing one officer and wounding two men before surrendering at dawn.

title: The People's Business
description: The basic story line of President Nixon's new scenario, as revealed at his Wednesday news conference, is that he has put Watergate behind him and is turning his full attention to the business of the people. Welcome as is the President's decision to come alive again on his daytoclay responsibilities, his script contains one major flaw. It treats as either/or propositions two quite distinct issues confronting the Presidency. Mr. Nixon does not have the option of ignoring one in order to deal with the other.

title: 2d Phase of U.S. Pullout From Thai Bases Starts
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 6 (UPI)  A squadron of F105 jets whose sophisticated radar once sought out North Vietnamese missile sites left today to begin the second phase of American withdrawals from Thailand.

title: Truck Tonnage Up 5.5%
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage last week was 5.5 per cent above the corresponding week of last year. Truck tonnage last week was 1.8 per cent above the immediately preceding week. The A.T.A. also reported that based on a terminal survey of 35 metropolitan areas, increases over last year were reported at 24 localities. 23 areas reported increases over the immediately preceding week. Rail carloadings will not be report ed until Fiday because of the, Labor Day holiday this week.

title: Perilous Ulster Delay
description: Prime Minister Heath is often clumsy in dealing with the agony of Northern Ireland; but he is on target with his warning that delay in setting Ulster's new political machinery in motion can only jeopardize its effectiveness, play into the hands of both Protestant and Catholic extremists and result in more lives lost, more maimed and more wounded.

title: Clash Between President And Congress Intensifies
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6The disptite between President Nixon and Congress intensified today.

title: McIntire Loses Six Blocks in Cape May
description: CAPE MAY, Sept. 6  Cape May placed liens today on six city blocks owned by its largest property owner and taxpayer, the Rev. Carl McIntire.

title: Zumwalt's Father Dies
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 6 (AP)Col. Elmo R. Zumwalt, father of Adm. Elmo R, Zumwalt Jr., Chief of Naval Operations, died here yesterday at the age of 81. Colonel Zumwalt retired as an Army physician in 1953 and was forced by illness to retire from his position as the civilian physician at the China Lake, Calif., naval base last November.

title: WrongEnd Squeeze
description: President Nixon's decision to veto the bill for an overdue increase in the Federal minimum wage imposes on the country's working poor the grossly unfair burden of having to wait  no one knows how longfor statutory relief from the huge bite inflation is taking out of their already depressed living standards.

title: Beame Vows a StateCity Crime Drive, More Housing and Lures to Business
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame, observing with no apparent sign of real concern that overconfidence could cripple his mayoral campaign, spelled out with considerable precision yesterday the first three things he would do if he is elected as New York City's 104th Mayor.

title: Bone Spur Surgery to Sideline Knicks' Monroe
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., Sept. 6The Knicks opened their rookie training camp today with the unwelcome news that Earl Monroe had entered St. Anthony's Hospital in Oklahoma City and would undergo surgery tomorrow for the removal of bone spurs in his left foot. Dr. Donald O'Donohue, who treated Willis Reed's knee injury successfully, will perform the surgery.

title: Boyle Accused of Murder In the Killing of Yablonski
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6W. A. Boyle, the deposed former president of the United Mine Workers of America, was arrested and charged with murder today in the 1969 killing of Joseph A. Yablonski the leader who had sought to oust the Boyle regime in the union election that year.

title: Murtaugh Takes Virdon's Job
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 6 (AP) The Pittsburgh Pirates relieved Bill Virdon as manager today and brought Danny Murtaugh back from the front office to finish the season in Virdon's place.

title: Howe Glad to Quit Retirement Ranks
description: When Gordie Howe went recently for a checkup to see whether, at the age of 45, he could return to hockey, the doctor told Howe everything was fine.

title: People and Business
description: William D. Eberle, President Nixon's chief trade envoy, said yesterday in Washington that next week's ministeriallevel trade talks in Tokyo would give a political impetus to detailed negotiations in 1974.ERNEST HOLSENDOLPH

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Tokyo Ties 2d Seoul Aide to Abduction
description: TOKYO, Sept. 6The Japanese police today intensified their public allegations that South Korean officials abducted a Korean opposition leader htrs last month.

title: State Expected to Use $3Billion By '77 to Fight Water Pollution
description: NORTH BRUNSWICK, Sept. 6  Richard J. Sullivan, the state's Commissioner of Environmental Protection, today forecast that $3.3 billion, including Federal funds, would have to be spent on public waterpollutioncontrol facilities by 1977 on the basis of an anticipated 50 per cent rise in the state's population.

title: Parke Bernet Will Guarantee Authenticity for Art Buyers
description: Sotheby Parke Bernet will initiate in midSeptember an unprecedented policy of guaranteeing the authenticity of the art works it sells, a spokesman said yesterday.

title: Ellen G. Cohen Is Married Here To David Stein
description: Miss Ellen Gail Cohen was married here last evening to David F. Stein, a vice president in the international department of Kuhn, Loeb & Co. Rabbi Nathan A. Perilman performed the ceremony at the St. RegisSheraton Roof.

title: New Crop Reports Will Disclose Data Formerly Not Given
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) The Agriculture Department will soon begin disclosing information on 1974 crop prospects under a new policy aimed at giving farmers an even break with big commodity traders.

title: L.I.R.R. Shuttle Buses Due
description: The Long Island Rail Road will install continuous welded rail on its Port Jefferson branch, between Greenlawn and Northport, the next few weeks. Shuttle buses will substitute for trains during nonrush hours, from 8:45 A.M. to 4:45 P.M. The buses will operate between Huntington and Northport. The work, expected to be completed within three weeks, is intended to provide a smoother, quieter ride.

title: A TIMES INJUNCTION EXTENDED BY COURT
description: A State Supreme Court justice extended yesterday a temporary restraining order barring work stoppages by printers at The New York Times.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: CLIFTON, Sept. 6A family fun tournament, known as the Eastern States Industrial Recreation Association softball championships, opens here Saturday on 12 fields and will run, with a short break for sleep, for the next 30 hours or so.

title: An Industrial Identity Sought by Rumanians
description: BUCHAREST, Sept. 2  In Rumania, the wolf of Rome suckling Romulus and Remus is now a more relevant symbol of the country's independent spirit and nationalist ambitions than the hammer and sickle.

title: Advertising: Women vs. Men
description: Ladies, if you are heavy users of decaffeinated coffee and upsetstomach remedies you might well be drudges. If, however, you are big purchasers of paper towels you might be entitled to classify yourselves as striving suburbanites.

title: City, Hoping to Reduce Welfare Costs, Plans Medical Tests for Some Clients
description: The city is beginning a 10week crash medical screening program for welfare clients receiving aid to dependent children, hoping to be able to reclassify thousands as disabled and thus save the city and state up to $12.5million each next year.

title: Cash for Mass Transit
description: With few exceptions, cities all across this country are witnessing a familiar, but no less vicious, cycle in the fortunes of their mass transit systems: rising costs and fares, loss of passengers, reduced net income, deterioration, loss of more passengers and finally a slide into hopeless decay. Both houses of Congress are about to vote on measures to break that terrible progression by the only means that can break ita Federal operating subsidy.

title: PETERS EGLITS
description: Peters Eglits, a former president of the bar in his native Latvia and president emeritus of the Latvian Lutheran Church in this country, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived at 203 East 82nd Street.

title: Six Rescued Off Nantucket After Three Days at Sea
description: NANTUCKET, Mass., Sept. 6 (AP)Six persons were rescued yesterday after being lost at sea for three days.

title: Land Boom and Exodus to the Suburbs Underline Maryland's Current Scandal
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 6  The heart of it all is the land.

title: Progress Reported in Talks On Opera Musicians' Strike
description: Representatives of the New York City Opera and its striking musicians made some progress yesterday in their first bargaining since the walkout began seven days ago, a mediator named by Mayor Lindsay reported last night.

title: COMMANDOS LEAVE EMBASSY IN PARIS
description: PARIS, Friday, Sept. 7A band of Palestinian gunmen who had occupied the Saudi Arabian Embassy here since Wednesday morning left yesterday on a Syrian airliner, taking with them five Saudi hostages tied hand and foot.

title: JOHN M. STEINMULLER
description: VALLEY STREAM, L. I., Sept. 6John M. Steinmuller, a planning consultant for Allied Stores, Inc., who had been a mechanical engineer for the concern, died Friday at his home here. He was 79 years old.

title: Douglas G. MacAgy Dies at 60; Hirshhorn Exhibitions Curator
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 Douglas G. MacAgy, who as curator of exhibitions at the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden of the Smithsonian Institution was preparing for the opening of its collection of modern sculpture next spring, died today in Georgetown University Hospital after suffering a heart attack last month. He was 60 years old.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Superior Court Judge Gordon Brown issued an injunction yesterday against the Montville. Township Education Assocaition, ordering an immediate end to a stoppage against the township's school system. Classes for 3,600 students were curtailed for two days because of the teachers' strike. The association lawyer gave his assurance that the teachers would return to school today wtihout any preconditions. Immediately after the court session, both sides began working to revive negotiations.

title: Solzhenitsyn Links a Suicide to His Work
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 6The novelist Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn asserted today that a Leningrad woman had been driven to suicide after five days of continuous questioning by the secret police concerning the whereabouts of a major underground manuscript he wrote.

title: Miss Hofmann Rides 2 Winners At Stony Brook
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., Sept. 6Carol Hofmann, former United States Equestrian Team star, rode two jumper winners and almost captured a third class today at the opening session of the fourday North Shore Horse Show at the Oldfield Club.

title: Bettors Envious, Not Surprised
description: In OTB parlors around town yesterday, the reaction to the allegations that harnessracing, superfectas had been fixed ran the gamut from ambivalence to admiration, from anger to who the hell cares. But mostly hte frustrated bettor was simply envious.

title: Fireball Identified as Rocket
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Sept. 6 (AP)Military officials said that a rocket body from a Soviet satellite burned on reentry into the earth's atmosphere last night causing star gazers in Texas, New Mexico and Colorado to report seeing a fireball streaking across the sky. The North American Air Defense center said that the object was the body of a rocket used to launch a Soviet satellite known as Cosmos 583 into orbit on Aug. 30.

title: South Vietnamese Devalue Piaster for 5th Time in '73
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 6 (Reuters)  The Government today devalued the piaster  for the fifth time this year  to 510 to the dollar, from 500.

title: Pennsylvania Agency Raises Interest Rate
description: High interest rates apparently finally got to the Pennsylvania Industrial Development Authority, a state agency that fosters growth of industry and employment in the Commonwealth.

title: SENATE'S INQUIRY APPEARS BALKED ON HEARING TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6The Senate Watergate committee apparently lost today its last chance to gain access to President Nixon's White House tape recordings in time for its final series of hearings to reflect any secrets the tapes contain.

title: U.S. AIDES OPPOSE RHODESIA CHROME
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6The Nixon Administration joined Senate liberals today in calling for repeal of 1971 legislation exempting Rhodesia's chrome industry from a United States trade embargo.

title: Nixons Take a Cruise
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UPI) President Nixon took his family on a twohour dinner cruise aboard the Presidential yacht Sequoia this evening. He was accompanied by his wife and a daughter, Mrs. Edward F. Cox.

title: Cashings Raised Suspicion
description: A mystery woman, so beautiful she made heads turn in shops of the Offtrack Betting Corporation, helped call attention to the questionable wagering patterns that touched off a Federal investigation of the superfecta here.

title: BRITISH CONTINUE POUND GUARANTEE
description: PARIS, Sept. 6  Fresh squalls in the currency markets, touched off by heavy selling of the pound, were at least temporarily halted today as the major Western nations, declared their willingness to guarantee London deposits of sterling area countries for six more months.

title: 100 CONCERNS ASKED ABOUT POLITICAL AID
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (UPI) The Senate Watergate committee has asked about 100 corporations, selected at random, to tell whether they made illegal contributions during the 1972 Presidential campaign.

title: Horses & Equipment
description: Horses & Equipment 3985

title: COMMANDOS LEAVE EMBASSY IN PARIS
description: PARIS, Friday, Sept. 7A band of Palestinian gunmen who had occupied the Saudi Arabian Embassy here since Wednesday morning left yesterday on a Syrian airliner, taking with them five Saudi hostages tied hand and foot.

title: 3 Judges Will Hear Mitchell and Stans Appeal for a Delay
description: A panel of three judges was named yesterday to hear an appeal by defense lawyers seeking to delay the obstructionofjustice trial of former Attorney General John N. Mitchell and former Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stans.

title: Environmental Protection Agency, in Issuing Revised Air Pollution Plan, Discounts Blackout Risk
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 The Environmental Protection Agency issued its revised air pollution plans today and insisted that the proposal would not cause widespread power blackouts in the country, as had been charged by environ

title: School District Loses Aid For Stand on Pupil Tests
description: East New York School District 19 in Brooklyn has lost $965,000 in Federal aid because it refused to set up separate math and reading tests for black and Puerto Rican children.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: The American Basketball Association has picked Mike Storen as its new commissioner and will announce the action at a news conference here today. The Associated Press learned last night.

title: Level Is Wholesale  Burger Blocks Station Owners
description: The Exxon Company U.S.A. raised its wholesale gasoline prices yesterday by one cent a gallon. However, most service station owners will have to absorb the increased cost because retail gasoline prices are frozen through today and then become subject to ceiling prices already established under Phase 4.

title: Poverty and Pride Trap City's Aged
description: Many of the old people who shop at the A. & P. at First Avenue and 90th Street stand in front of the meat cases for long periods of time, like children gazing through a toy store window.

title: DR. MICHAEL M'NICHOLS
description: CEDARHURST, L. I., Sept. 6 Dr, Michael T. McNichols, a physician specializing in rheumatology who had practiced here, died Wednesday after a heart attack in the South Shore division in Rockaway of Long Island Jewish Medical Center. He was 63 years old and lived at 196 Briarwood Crossing.

title: Lillian Hellman: At 66, She's Still Restless
description: MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass.In the big, pale yellow living room, with the tall rose bushes and the ocean outside it, nothing speaks of what Lillian Hellman calls the fat, loose, wild years of her life.

title: EXREP. GARY DEAD VIRGINIAN WAS 81
description: RICHMOND, Sept. 6 (UPI)Former Representative J. Vaughan Gary, Democrat of Virginia, died today at a hospital here. He was 81 years old.

title: Kathleen Kennedy Plans Marriage to an ExTutor
description: Miss Kathleen Kennedy, daughter of Mrs. Robert F. Kennedy and the late Senator Kennedy, plans to be married in November to David Lee Townsend, a graduate student at Harvard University.

title: BOND PRICES FIRM AFTER EARLY DIP
description: The recent upturn in corporate bond prices faltered a bit in early trading yesterday but seasoned issues recovered before the end of the day and closed firm.

title: Lester Lane is Dead at 41; Oklahoma Basketball Coach
description: NORMAN, Okla., (UPI)Sept. 6Lester Lane, who became basketball coach at Oklahoma University last spring, died yesterday after playing in a faculty basketball game. He was 41 years old.

title: New District Approved For Convention Center
description: The City Planning Commission unanimously approved the creation of a special interim preservation district in the Clinton area of Manhattan where the new convention center is to be built. The special district, generally bounded by 43d and 56th Streets and Eighth and 11 th Avenues, would allow limited residential construction and rehabilitation, but would prevent the demolition of safe housing for one year.

title: American League
description: Friday, September 7, 1973

title: Cowboys Conquer Dolphins
description: IRVING, Tex., Sept. 6 (UPI)Toni Fritsch kicked a 22yard field goal with three seconds left tonight to highlight a 20point Dallas rally and give thhe Cowboys a 2623 preseason victory over Miami in their first meeting since Super Bowl VI.

title: Soviet Dissidents and Confession
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 6The public recantation by two Soviet dissidents has renewed the issue of political confessions that was dramatized by Arthur Koestler in his 1940 novel Darkness at Noon.

title: NIXON AIDES SAY HOMES.MAY FACE HEATING OIL CURB
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6Energy officials in the Nixon Administration disclosed today that the Government might have to restrict the amount of oil that could be burned by individual consumers, including that used in private homes.

title: Nude Body Found In River Identified By Jersey Police
description: Special to The New York Times

title: DeMont, 3 Others Break World Swimming Marks
description: BELGRADE, Sept. 6Rick deMont, who had to return a gold medal he won last year, won another one tonight in the world swimming championships and broke a world record in doing it. His feat was the first of four world marks bettered tonight.

title: Byrne Charges Sandman Is a Splinter Candidate
description: SEA GIRT, N. J., Sept. 6Brendan T. Byrne, the Democratic candidate for Governor, charged his Republican opponent, Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., with political extremism here tonight.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE ONION FIELD. By Joseph Wambaugh. 427 pages. Delacorte. $8.95. Perhaps there are readers cut there who will be able to race through Joseph Warnbaugh's The Onion Field completely caught up by its narrative drive and utterly vulnerable to its shocks and twists. Certainly that's the way I wanted to read this dramatic recreation of a significant crime and its complex legal aftermath, easing myself, as I was trying to do, out of the vacation frame of mind. And certainly that's the way I expected to read it, drawn, as I was, by its provocative title (The Onion Field? My Goodness, what about the onion field?); its breathless flap copy (The reader of this book will... be forced to ask if it could really be true. The answer is yes.); the author's putative expertise (Joseph Wambaugh is a detectivesergeant with the Los Angeles Police Department), and his previous record as a writer (both his earlier books, novels called The New Centurions and The Blue Knight, were highlevel entertainments).

title: 6 Share FirstDay Lead In Southern Golf Tourney
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., Sept. 6 (AP)John Schroeder and Grier Jones tied for the lead with four others, all with three  under  par 67's, after the first round today of the $100,000 Southern open golf tournament.

title: ROY S. DURSTINE
description: Roy S. Durstine Jr., formerly vice president of Roy S. Dur??rine, Inc., an advertising agency, and president and publisher of Who's Who in Advertising, Inc., died yesterday of Hodgkin's disease at his home, 226 East Sixth Street. He was 38 years old.

title: STUDY SEES HARM IN MIXED SCHOOLS
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 6A political scientist from the Pacific Northwest has told the American Political Science Association here that integrated schools may retard the political growth of blacks.

title: Dispute With an Informer Misinterpreted in Article
description: Because the transcript of a television interview was misinterpreted, The New York Times erred yesterday in describing a disagreement between an informer who testified at the Gainsville Eight trial and a woman who accused him of having been an agent provacateur.

title: Nuclear Plant to Close
description: JACKSON, Mich., Sept. 6 (UPI)The Consumers Power Company said today it would power plant near South nuclear close its Palisades Haven, Mich., for about three months while the company conducts tests and cleaning of the steam generating system. The measure, which will cost about $10million, followed the closing of the plant Aug. 11 after a minute leak of radioactive water was detected. Consumers Power said it would purchase power from other companies for the 90day period.

title: Recently Published Books
description: FICTION

title: PANHANDLE EASTERN SIGNS ALGERIAN PACT
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 6 (Reuters) The Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company said today that it signed formal contracts with Sonatrach, the Algerian national petroleum company, for Importation of 3.3 trillion cubic feet of liquefied natural gas from Algeria over a 20year period.

title: Truck Tonnage Up 5.5%
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage last week was 5.5 per cent above the corresponding week of last year. Truck tonnage last week was 1.8 per cent above the immediately preceding week. The A.T.A. also reported that based on a terminal survey of 35 metropolitan areas, increases over last year were reported at 24 localities. 23 areas reported increases over the immediately preceding week. Rail carloadings will not be reported until Fiday because of the Labor Day holiday this week.

title: Yanks Win, 86; Alous Traded
Smith and Kodes Reach Semifinals With Victories Over Parun and Pilic
description: It was a hotandcold day at the United States Open tennis championship in Forest Hills yesterday. Advancing to the semifinals of the men's singles were a hot Stan Smith over a cold Onny Parun, 63, 63, 62, and Jan Kodes over a coldandhot Nikki Pilic, 62, 46, 61, 36, 75.

title: Futures Are Mixed In Farm Products
description: After dropping the permissible daily limits for the previous two sessions, prices of agricultural commodity futures ranged widely yesterday.

title: CLERIC STABBED NEAR COLUMBIA
description: A 39yearold Canadian minister on a visit here was stabbed four times, punched, kicked, thrown to the ground and robbed of $30 as he walked yesterday through Morningside Park.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SWEETNESS AND LIGHT Next week the evenings on Christopher Street in Greenwich Village will brighten up considerably, not a moment too soon for James Caras. Mr. Caras is coowner of the LiLac Candy Store  the oldest candy store in the city, he saysjust across the street from the Theater de Lys. When the theater has a tenant, Mr. Caras and his partner, Margarett Watt, are happy; when the theater is empty they are not.

title: Recruiting Addicts
description: City Council President Sanford D. Garelik's disclosure that a New York City drug treatment program has been recruiting narcotics addicts from out of state underscores the total inadequacy of present recordkeeping and auditing procedures. This outreach practice should never have been allowed. It would not have been if the Addiction Services Agency had adequately performed its task of reviewing ongoing drug programs.

title: Milk Likely to Rise 2c a Quart Here
description: Dairy leaders estimated yesterday that a sharp, Federally ordered increase in milk prices to be paid to farmers would require a 2centaquart rise for consumers in the New YorkNorthern New Jersey area.

title: LARGE RETAIL CHAINS REPORT SALES GAINS
description: Several of the country's largest retail chains reported yesterday increased sales in August over the same 1972 month, following similar reports by other retail concerns last week.

title: Detroit Pupil Busing Case Taken to Supreme Court
description: LANSING, Mich. Sept. 6 (UPI)Attorney General Frank J. Kelley said today that he had filed a petition with the Supreme Court asking for an immediate review of the Detroit school desegregation case.

title: Department Store Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last year rose to an estimated $1.002billion, up 13 per cent from the yearearlier $889million. Total retail store sales were about $9.876billion, an increase of 12 per cent from last year's $8.799billion.

title: A SlotMachine Payoff Pat at $65,093 by Club
description: RENO, Nev., Sept. 8 (AP)A retired San Francisco accountant was said this week to have won $65,093 in what Harolds Club officials call the world's largest slot machine payoff.

title: Apartments Sought On Dobbs Ferry Site Owned by Abplanalp
description: DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., Sept. 6 Plans to build condominium apartments on a 26acre site owned by Robert H. Abplanalp, the millionaire industrialist, were presented here tonight at a meeting of the Planning Board in Village Hall.

title: SOVIET'S CRITICS VEX FRENCH REDS
description: PARIS, Sept. 6  The warnings from Soviet intellectuals against mounting internal repression amid the improvement in EastWest relations have provoked embarrassment and concern in the French Communist party.

title: Weekend Fishing Prospects in Area
description: The arrival of seasonably cool weather will, if it persists, do much to improve inshore marine angling.

title: Amnesty, Dissent And Income
description: Some new evidence on familiar questions:

title: Picketing of Beauty Pageant Site Halted
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 6A State Superior Court judge today enjoined picketing firemen against disrupting the Miss America Pageant at Convention Hall, and soon after the injunction was served the firemen packed up their placards and left the site.

title: Mrs. Sheila Krinsky Wed to Henry Ebel
description: FORT LEE, N. J., Sept 6Mrs. Sheila Krinsky, a graduate student in counseling at Columbia University, and Henry Ebel, an associate professor in the Division o?? Humanities at Richmond College of the City University of New York, were married, at the Municipal Building here this afternoon by Mayor Burt Ross.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: There is not enough gasoline in all the world to feed the appetite for power in oversized cars. There never will be enough. If your car consumes a gallon of gasoline every eight, ten, twelve, fourteen, etc., miles, it's a subversive, unpatriotic machine, dedicated to the economic overthrow of this great country.

title: Downtrend Reversed
description: Business loans at New York City banks, after declining for three weeks in a row, increased during the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday in a preliminary report.

title: Appeals Judge in Tapes Case
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 When President Nixon's lawyers, appealing Judge John J. Sirica's demand for the Presidential tapes, argue their case next week, they will appear before a court whose reputation for liberalism and innovation is unmatched by any in the country. To a great extent, the reputation of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia is a reflection of its chief judge, David Lionel Bazelon, who in his 24 years on the court has become known as almost an archetype of the activist liberal judge President Nixon has always vowed he would remove.

title: CON ED ALLOWED $164MILLION RISE
description: The New York State Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it had granted $164.5million of the $183million increase in electricity rates the Consolidated Edison Company had sought. This is $69.2million above the temporarily increased rates now in effect.

title: Airline Tax Voided
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 (UPI)  The state Supreme, Court, citing the Federal Government's constitutional authority over interstate commerce, ruled unconstitutional yesterday the city's $3 tax on departing airline passengers. The court ruled on an appeal brought by 12 major airlines that maintained the city's tax ordinance was unjustifiable and unconstitutional.

title: McIntire Loses 6 Blocks In Cape May in a Tax Sale
description: CAPE MAY, Sept. 6  Cape May placed liens today on six city blocks owned by its largest property owner and taxpay er, the Rev. Carl McIntire.

title: Sen. Hughes Plans A Religious Career
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 6  Senator Harold E. Hughes, 51yearold Iowa Democrat, said today that he would leave the Senate when his first term expires next year to accept a compelling commitment to do religious work.

title: SKYLAB FILMS END OF BIG SOLAR FLARE
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 6 (UPI)The Skylab 2 astronauts, delving into the mysteries of the sun's energy, photographed today the aftermath of a solar explosion more than 100 million times as powerful as the San Francisco earthquake of 1906.

title: BODY IS IDENTIFIED BY JERSEY POLICE
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 6The nude body of a young woman found floating in South River here yesterday with her hands bound behind her back was identified today as that of a 28yearold teacher from Lakewood.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two gunmen tried to hold up a massage parlor known as the Tender Touch at 136 East 58th Street, near Lexington Avenue, but they found it wasn't an easy touch. They fired three shots at Pio Matos, a uniformed guard, without hitting him and then fled when the guard returned the fire. He told the police he thought he had wounded one of the gunmen. . . . A taxicab company mechanic was wounded at 1:30 A.M. when a shotgun being used by two holdup men went off accidentally, the police said. The wounded man was identified as Saul Glassman, 49 years old. He was reported in good condition at Morrisania Hospital. The holdup men fled after taking $700 from the Bee & Bee Cab Company at 1481 Jerome Avenue, the Bronx. . . . The police said that Levant Brown, 22, address unknown, shot Jerry Young, 16, in the arm during a dispute in front of 620 Hopkinson Avenue, Brooklyn. Neighbors set upon the assailant, who was taken to Kings County Hospital with facial cuts and a broken arm. He was charged with attempted murder.

title: SENATE'S INQUIRY APPEARS BALKED ON HEARING TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6The Senate Watergate committee apparently lost today its last chance to gain access to President Nixon's White House tape recordings in time for its final series of hearings to reflect any secrets the tapes contain.

title: SHARES ON AMEX HIGHER AT FINISH
description: Prices rose yesterday in moderately active trading on the American Stock Exchange. The overthecounter market also was firmer on substantially higher volume.

title: U.S.Soviet Talks on Arms Set for Sept. 24 in Geneva
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 A White House official said today that the next round of SovietAmerican talks on limitation of strategic arms would begin on Sept. 24 in Geneva.

title: Edgar Winter Gits It On
description: Edgar Winter brought an immediate hyperthyroid, chairstanding, overexcited response from the sellout audience at the Schaefer Music Festival in Central Park on Wednesdayit expressed neatly the cliffhanging joy of rock n roll, good times but a short fuse.

title: RESIDENTS LOSE SUIT ON COOP CITY FRAUD
description: A Federal Court judge dismissed a suit here yesterday that had alleged fraud in the sale of apartments in the CoOp City housing development in the Bronx.

title: The Horse Race of Two Centuries
description: Because of the considerable popularity of Secretariat, the habitforming properties of television and the enduring charm of a quarter of a million dollars, the biggest horse race still on the calendar for 1973 is the invitation handicap in which Secretariat and Rive Ridge are expected to oppose other winners like Key to the Mint, Cougar II, Onion, Tentam and Annihilate 'Em at Belmont a week from tomorrow. There is, however, a little group of willful men representing no opinion but their own who will regard that event as something stale, flat and unprofitable by comparison with a race that will have been run over the same course 24 hours earlier. They call themselves the Baker Street Irregulars and the race that commands their allegiance is the 22d running of the Silver Blaze, named for the favorite in the Wessex Cup of 1890.

title: TV: Channel A Starts 13Week Art Series Sunday
description: Television went to the Museum of Modern Art last night in the form of a preview screening of a new 13week series called A for Art. The project will be seen, beginning this Sunday, not on commercial television or even public TV, but on cable television.

title: Hunter Takes Freshmen on a Shakedown Cruise Around the Hudson
description: Hunter College decided to hold freshman orientationusually a notoriously hohum affair held at the schoolaboard a Staten Island ferry boat yesterday. More than half of the 2,000 entering students turned out.

title: TAP ON A BROTHER OF NIXON AT ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6The White House said today that if the Secret Service had wiretapped the telephone of F. Donald Nixon, the President's brother, it would have been related to the protective function of the Secret Service.

title: Menotti's TamuTamu Is Cheered in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 6TamuTamu, a twoact chamber opera composed, written and directed by Gian Carlo Menotti, had its world premiere at the Studebaker Theater here last night.

title: State A.F.L.C.I.O. to Support $3.5Billion TransitBond Issue
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Sept. 6  The twomillionmember New York State A.F.L.C.I.O. gave its support today to the $3.5billion transportation bond issue that will go before the state's voters in the November election.

title: Specials to Get Extra Listings In '73 TV Menu
description: The new television season that gets under way Monday will be replete with the usual meatandpotatoes fare such as Marcus Welby, Archie Bunker, and Ironside, but it also shows promise of giving hefty servings of truly special specials.

title: Two Men: One Exhausted, One Threatened
description: The K.G.B. is celebrating a victory over an exhausted manPyotr Yakir. This man has been exhausted by almost fifteen years in Stalin's labor camps; he was first confined when he was fourteen. Yakir believed in the Communist faith of his father, a Red Army commander executed in Stalin's time; the conflict between this belief and the life he observed daily wore him out. And in recent years, when he spoke out in defense of human rights, he was further exhausted by continuous shadowing and the constant expectation of arrest.

title: Attendance Record Predicted Bridge: For Summer Nationals Here
description: The record for the biggest tournament was held by Chicago for eight years. The 1965 total of 14,511 tables stood until a month ago, when the Summer Nationals in Washington came up with a staggering figure of 16,044 tables.

title: TEN HELD HOSTAGE FREED AT JOLIET
description: JOLIET, Ill., Sept. 6Ten guards held hostage by inmates at the Stateville Penitentiary for more than nine hours today were released tonight when Illinois state policemen threatened to enter the inmates' cellblock with tear gas.

title: Mr. Nixon's ThreeFront War
description: It's the normal and prudent rule of power and politics that you never try to fight more than one battle at a time, even when you're fighting from a position of strength; but President Nixon is back in Washington, weak, breathless and defiant, fighting on three fronts at the same time.

title: Adelphi Faculty Approves 5.5% Raise in First Year
description: The faculty of Adelphi University in Garden City, L.I., has approved a threeyear contract that provides a 5.5 per cent acrosstheboard increase in the firs year. The contract, which would be retroactive to Seit. 1, is expected to be approved by the Board of Trustees next Wednesday.

title: DEVALUATION BILL PASSED BY SENATE
