description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (Reuters)The Senate approved today by 69 to 15 and sent to the White House, a bill ratifying February's 10 per cent dollar devaluation. The bill also allows the President to end the ban on private ownership of gold by Americans.

title: Japanese Yen Seen Gaining in Stability As World Currency
description: TOKYO, Sept. 7  The Finance Minister of Japan, Kiichi Aichi, suggested tonight that the yen would be used more in the future to settle international transactions.

title: Flood Loan Deadlines Set
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7 (AP) The Small Business Administration announced deadlines of Sept. 14 and 11 today for filing applications for flood disaster loans in 10 Pennsylvania counties. The 10county area was designated a disaster area by President Nixon on July 17.

title: Gas Rate Rise Asked
description: Consolidated Edison, citing increased costs, applied to the Public Service Commission yesterday for an annual increase in gas rates of $27,577,600. The bid for a 17 per cent rise came the day after the utility was granted a $164.5million Increase in its electricity rates. Page 64.

title: 2,000 LSD Pills and 12 Seized in 2 Suffolk Raids
description: The seizure of more than 2,000 tablets of LSD and the arrest of 12 persons in two raids 15 minutes apart wer announced yesterday by the police in Suffolk County.

title: LOUIS F. HANKE
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 7Louis F. Hanke executive vice president of Dreher Advertising in New York, died today, apparently of a heart attack, at his home. 9 Bradford Avenue. He was 56 years old.

title: JOHN PENNYWITT
description: BAY HEAD, N. J., Sept. 7John Pennywitt, a retired sales executive for the Gulf Oil Corporation, died today at the age of 79 at Point Pleasant Hospital. He lived here at 49 Bristol Place and formerly in South Orange.

title: Pressure on Trudeau: His Political Survival Is the Real Issue
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 7As the House of Commons was droning its way through a prolonged debate last week on the bill that was to end Canada's nationwide railroad strike, a member of the governing Liberal party rose wearily to protest that he was fed up with hearing one claim after another for what he called a monopoly of concern for working people. When we start throwing stones, we are being hypocritical, because few of us worry about the workers, declared Bryce S. Mackasey, who used to be Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's Minister of Labor.

title: HOSPITAL KITCHEN CLOSED AS DIRTY
description: TRENTON, Sept. 7 (AP)The State Health Department closed the kitchen of the Martland Medical Center in Newark today because of unsanitary conditions.

title: British Unions Vote to Resist Heath's Economic Policy
description: BLACKPOOL, England, Sept. 7  The British trade union movement, buoyed by signs that public resentment over rising prices is gaining it new support, has registered its determination to put up a hard fight against the Government's economic policies this fall.

title: CUT IN MEAT COST IS EXPECTED SOON
description: The American Meat Institute forecast yesterday that consumers throughout the country should find meat prices down considerably in a week or two, citing drops in wholesale prices of 13 to 26 per cent from mid. August highs through yesterday.

title: Workers Balk in Protest On Strange Nerve Illness
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 7 (UPI)  Workers in the print shop at the Columbus Coated Fabrics Plant refused to report to their jobs today because of a strange nerve illness leading to partial paralysis that has stricken at least 11 employes since April.

title: Wholesale Index Increase Third Biggest in 60 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7An explosion in farm prices following the end of the brief summer price freeze sent the Government's Wholesale Price Index for August up by 5.8 per cent, the Labor Department reported today.

title: GUNMEN THREATEN LIVES OF 4 SAUDIS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Saturday, Sept. 8Five Palestinian terrorists took four Saudi Arabian hostages on a flight over the Saudi capital from Kuwait yesterday and threatened to toss them out of the plane.

title: Behind the Mayorsa Civil Service Elite
description: When Mayor Lindsay name the owlish Harry I. Bronstein as the city's Personnel Director, the City Council's finance Committee took the rare step of adopting a resolution in praise of the Mayor.

title: ROCKEFELLER SEES HEROIN DRYING UP
description: Governor Rockefeller, in his first public assessment of how his new antidrug laws are working, said yesterday that heroin seems to be disappearing, drying up in the city.

title: SANDMAN, BYRNE CLASH ON TAXES
description: SMITHVILLE, N. J., Sept. Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. said tonight that New Jersey would not have an income tax for the next four years if he was elected Governor on Nov. 6.

title: Schroeder, With 65, Gains 2Shot Lead
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., Sept. 7 (AP)John Schroeder, bursting into prominence after 4 years of virtual obscurity on the pro tour, shook off a double bogey on the 15th hole, a par 4, and finished with a 65 today for a twostroke lead after two rounds of the $100,000 Southern open golf tournament.

title: 6 OIL COMPANIES PROTEST TO LIBYA
description: Six major oil companies yesterday filed a letter of protest with Libya over that nation's nationalization of 51 per cent of their assets on Libyan soil, a spokesman said here.

title: Notes on People
description: Sam Yorty, the former Mayor of Los Angeles, is expected to become a Republican. The conservative Democrat, who was defeated in June by Thomas Bradley, is expected to announce his decision by tomorrow. Both his wife and Gordon Luce, the G.O.P. state chairman, were quoted as saying Mr. Yorty would switch. At his home in Studio City, Mr. Yorty, who is considered a possible candidate for the Senate in 1976, said, It's too bad somebody couldn't keep their mouth shut. He conceded, however, that he has been talking about it and would make an announcement soon.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: High Nixon Aide Asks Unity
description: BOSTON, Aug. 28 (AP)Romana Acosta Bafluelos, the United States Treasurer, called on the nation yesterday to unite and support President Nixon. She spoke at the American Numismatic Association convention.

title: Enric Madriguera Dead; Violinist, Orchestra Leader
description: DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 7 (AP)  Enric Madriguera, onetime concert violinist and a danceorchestra leader, died today at Danbury Hospital. He was 71 years old.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: The Nobelity of Malraux
description: It is astonishing that the Nobel literary prize, designed to be the greatest tribute to a writer but too frequently awarded to nonentities over the 72 years since it was founded, has escaped one of this century's outstanding authors, Andr Malraux.

title: S.E.C. Sets Suspension Of Teleprompter Stock
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (Reuters)  The Securities and Exchange Commission tonight announced it had ordered that trading of Teleprompter securities be suspended until Sept. 16.

title: Laotians Calm, Await Ruling of Big People
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 7 In the abstract the political situation here sounds rather stark:

title: Bridge:EndPlay Frequently Hinges On Which Side Sees It First
description: On rare occasions, a declarer can begin to think about an endplay when the dummy appears. On even rarer ones, a defender can begin to think about how to forestall one at the same early stage in the proceedings.

title: Dow Average Falls 2.41, But Gains Exceed Losses
SHULTZ FINDS U. S. BURNED ON GRAIN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz became the first high Administration official today to acknowledge that the United States was burned in last year's Soviet wheat deal. He said that it would not happen again.

title: In One Small Parish, the Good Life
description: FREEPORT, Minn.  I suppose we can start with a softball game. Young men watching young ladies competing against New Munich or Freeport or Melrose. Young mothers with young husbands and two young children on the hood of the car. The cheering, the yelling, the laughterand sometimes, tearsas spectators scream for their favorite team. It is a good way of life.

title: CANADA WHEAT CROP SEEN CLIMBING 13%
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 7 (Canadian Press)Canada's 1973 wheat crop, estimated at 604.4 million bushels, will be 13 per cent larger than last year's 533.3 million bushels, Statistics Canada reported today in its first estimate of this year's principal field crops.

title: Big Brother Is Watching
description: Acting evidently on the theory that security begins at home, President Nixon seems to have had the telephone of his brother, F. Donald Nixon, systematically tapped for over a year. The President's press spokesman has explained that whatever bugging was done would have related to the protective function of the Secret Service, but that agency spoiled the explanation by noting that Mr. Nixon's brother is not included in its protective obligations to the President's immediate family.

title: Man, 63, Is Slain; 5th Murder Victim In Hotel in a Year
description: A 63yearold resident of the Endicott Hotel, on Columbus Avenue at 81st Street, which houses many welfare recipients, was found stabbed to death in his room yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: JAPANESE FORCES ARE HELD ILLEGAL
description: TOKYO, Sept. 7A Japanese district court ruled today that the nation's maintenance of military forces is unconstitutional. It was a landmark decision in the deepest and longest running controversy in postwar Japan.

title: Ehrlichman Pleads Nat Guilty in '71 Ellsberg BreakIn
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 7John D. Ehrlichman, the former Presidential adviser on domestic affairs, pleaded not guilty today to charges of burglary, conspiracy and perjury in the 1971 breakin at the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.

title: NORMAN BRUCK
description: Norman Bruck, a specialist in tax law, died Wednesday in Overbrook Hospital, Summit, N. J., after a short illness. He was 39 years old and lived at 28 Belgrade Terrace in West Orange, N. J.

title: SHULTZ FINDS U. S. BURNED ON GRAIN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7Treasury Secretary George P. Shulz became the first high Administration official today to acknowledge that the United States was burned in last year's Soviet wheat deal. He said that it would not happen again.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Geoffrey Holder, the dancer, swept down the runway wearing a black velvet cape and looking like a Spanish grandeeif the grandee happened to have the skyline of New York etched in rhinestones at his back.

title: NEW BULGE SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7The Cost of Living Council ordered today reductions ranging from 10 per cent to 30 per cent in price increases the four major automobile companies sought for their 1974 models.

title: VETO OF WAGE BILL ASSAILED BY MEANY
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 7 (UPI)George Meany, angered by soaring prices and President Nixon's veto of the minimum Ange bill, said today that the Nixon Administration had created one of the most depressing spectacles I've ever seen.

title: Castro Backs Soviet at Algiers But Sihanouk Assails Moscow
description: ALGIERS, Sept. 7The conference of nonaligned nations split sharply today between proponents and opponents of Ian active alliance with the Soviet Union.

title: Grounded Blue Angels Will Fly Again in 1974
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (UPI)The Navy's precision flying team, the Blue Angels, will return to the air next spring, the Navy announced today. Secretary John W. Warner said he decided to keep the daredevil aerobatic team flying after a panel of five senior aviation and marine generals reported they were unanimously behind the team's continuance.

title: RetailChain Sales Up 14.9% in July; 7Month Rise Cited
description: Volume in July 14.9 per cent over the corresponding 1972 month among 29 of the nation's largest retail chains selling general merchandise, apparel, food and varietystore and other merchandise, according to a compilation by The New York Times.

title: In the Mekong Delta, A War With 2 Faces
description: CAN THO, South Vietnam, Sept. 1In a muddy field beside the Bassac River here, 50 Japanese engineers are quietly erecting a large power plant that will eventually provide electricity to twothirds of the populous Mekong Delta.

title: 6 Frustrating Hours On Trail of Dealers
description: When Eddie G. Washington was arrested on narcotics charges under both the old and new state drug laws, he described himself to the police as an unemployed salesman.

title: National League
description: Saturday, September 8, 1973

title: DEADLOCK IS SEEN ON MONEY REFORM
description: PARIS, Sept. 7  Monetary reform negotiations remained deadlocked today after a conference of high financial officials of the major Western powers failed to resolve major differences.

title: Saigon Warns Newsmen On Dealings With Vietcong
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 7 (Reuters)South Vietnamese officials warned newsmen today that weekly news conferences with the Vietcong would be stopped if there was any exchange of materials with Vietcong officials.

title: Grounds For Disgust
description: The public eating places of America have become world famous, and justly so, for the extraordinarily poor quality of their coffee.

title: Firemen and a Contestant Cause Stir at Pageant Site
description: Observers who gathered in Atlantic City for the Miss America beauty pageant yesterday had their choice of two diverting disputesone involving Miss New Hampshire and her views on New Hampshire and liberation movements, the other involving local firemen and their demands for a wage increase.

title: Jets Sign Hill, Boozer (2 Down) And Have One (Riggins) to Go
description: TAMPA, Sept. 7Winston Hill and Emerson Boozer were officially back on the New York Jets' squad today after signing their contracts and Weeb Ewbank, the team's coach and general manager, was in a much better mood.

title: Patients Are Visited In Area of Cholera By Italy's President
description: ROME, Sept. 7  President Giovanni Leone flew today to the southern cities of Naples and Bari, where most of the deaths from Italy's 11dayold cholera outbreak have occurred.

title: Andrea Bess Wed in Jersey
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 7  Miss Andrea Jean Bess, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Bess of New York and South Orange, was married here today to Kevin Thomas Hughes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Francis Hughes of South Orange and Sea Girt. The ceremony was performed in the chapel of Seton Hall University by Msgr. Edward Fleming and Rabbi Samuel Silver of Stamford, Conn. The bride's father is president of Sawden & Bess, a New York advertising agency. Mr. Hughes' father is president of the Colonial Art and Decorating Company in New York.

title: Rep. Sandman and Byrne Clash On Issue of a State Income Tax
description: SMITHVILLE, N.J., Sept. 7Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. said tonight that New Jersey would not have an income tax for the next four years if he was elected governor on Nov. 6.

title: Facing a Writ, Parents Abandon P.S. 208 SitIn, but Plan Boycott
description: Confronted with a court orier, parents fighting the appointment of a new principal ended a virtually summerlong sitin at Public School 208 in Brooklyn yesterday, but vowed to keep their children home when classes start on Monday.

title: STATE FUND SAVES A DAYCARE PLAN
description: VDIELAND, Sept. 7New Jersey's Department of Community Affairs has come to the aid of a daycare program for the children of farm workers just as the last four centers in the program were preparing to close for lack of funds.

title: Workfare in New York
description: While not everyone on relief in New York City can work, many thousands can. And while not all of these can be placed in jobs, there is employment available for many who now subsist only on welfare checks. As city and state officials resume enforcing regulations requiring all ablebodied reliefers to report to state employment centers, they confront the critical task of matching employable welfare recipients to available jobs. This is a task that has not been well performed in the past.

title: Texas School Evacuated
description: RICHARDSON, Tex., Sept. 7 (UPI)An airconditioning intake duct apparently sucked carbon monoxide poison through the ventilators of a Westwood Junior High School yesterday, forcing its evacuation.

title: Convening Anthropologists Reflect Diversity of the Races They Study
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 7They tend to be genial and are very adept schmoozers in hallways and corridors.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (Reuters)The Senate Finance Committee today shelved a plan to provide up to $3billion in cheap loans to United States exporters selling to developing nations.

title: NEW DEMANDS STALL OPERA STRIKE TALKS
description: A sixhour negotiating session between the New York City Opera and the musicians' union that struck the opera a week ago brought what the city's mediator called substantial progress yesterday, but the talks broke off with no date set for their resumption and no immediate prospects for an end to the strike.

title: HOUSE BILL BARS RAIL SYSTEM CUT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) The House passed yesterday an Amtrak financial aid bill that would require all existing passenger train service to be continued on the basic Governmentbacked rail system until at least next July 1.

title: PENTHOUSE EDITOR RESIGNS ON POLICY
description: The executive editor of Penthouse, the men's magazine, and of Viva, Its forthcoming sister publication aimed at women, resigned Thursday and traded criticisms yesterday with other executives of the two sexuallyoriented monthlies.

title: Terrible Drama
description: The explosion of farm prices in August was even worse than advance notices by the Administration had indicated: Wholesale farm prices soared by an incredible 23.1 per centdouble the previous record for a single month, July 1946, after wartime price controls were lifted. And the overall wholesale price index climbed by 6.2 per centthe biggest jump since October 1946.

title: Communication System Computerized
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 Guests at the Americana Hotel in New York will soon identify themselves by card when they enter their rooms. Any unauthorized entry, or open door or window, will be reported to the central office by a new security system. The service, trademarked Gardtel, is part of a communication system patented this week by Edward M. Ulicki, executive vice president of the Telebeam Corporation, New York. Telebeam has begun installation in 1,860 rooms at the hotel, with financing by Motorola, Inc.

title: Excerpts From Kissinger's Testimony to Senators
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7Following are excerpts from henry A. Kissinger's testimony today at hearings before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on his confirmation as Secretary of State:

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Drivers Are Called In Trotting Inquiry
description: Several harnessracing drivers were among 20 persons subpoenaed by a Federal Grand Jury here yesterday in the continuing investigation of allegedly fixed superfecta races at New York tracks.

title: Man, 77, Helpless Five Days
description: SALEM, Ore., Sept. 7 (AP)An elderly man who fell at his home lay helpless for five days without food and water before being discovered by a newspaper boy. Chester B. Lindsay, 77 years old, was taken to a Salem hospital yesterday, where officials reported his condition as surprisingly good.

title: Patrolling of Morningside Park Increased After Stabbing There
description: Increased police patrols went on duty yestetday in the Morningside Park area as a result of the stabbing of a 39yearold Canadian minister there on Thursday.

title: Township Unit Is Upheld On Assigning Police Duties
description: TRENTON, Sept. 7 (AP) The State Supreme Court ruled today that the Hazlet Township Committee acted legally, when it adopted resolutions assigning two police sergeants to specific duties in the police department.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Mart Crowley's latest play, A Breeze From the Gulf, will be unveiled at the Eastside Playhouse, 334 East 74th Street, in October.

title: Tokyo Leftist Parties Demand Break With Seoul
description: TOKYO, Sept. 7Japanese leftist Opposition parties demanded in Parliament today that the Government break diplomatic relations with South Korea and cut off economic aid to that, country to retaliate for the abduction of a South Korean Opposition leader here last month.

title: Fame Comes to Eddie Futch at 62
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Sept. 7He's got three greatgrandchildren and he's 62 years old. But with his trim physique, fashionable mustache, doubleknit clothes and wide smile, Eddie Futch looks 20 years younger. When he hasn't been working with fighters, he has toiled as a waiter, a road laborer, a welder, a sheetmetal worker in an aircraft plant and only five years ago he was handling packages in the Los Angeles post office when Ken Norton entered his life. Now, after four decades on the fringe of fame, he suddenly is one of boxing's most important people. He manages Norton, who will oppose Muhammad Ali here Monday night, and he soon will succeed the late Yancey Durham as Joe Frazier's manager. He deserves his success. He has a reputation for honesty and decency, attributes not always prevalent in boxing. He also has a rare distinctionAli has lost only twice, to Norton last March 31 while incurring a broken jaw and to Frazier in 1971, and each time Eddie Futch had been working' in the other corner.

title: MARRIOTT TO SHIFT HOTEL OPERATIONS
description: The Marriott Corporation, one of the nation's major hotel operators and caterers, will operate the majority of its future hotels on a managementfee basis instead of functioning as the owner of the hotels, J. Willard Marriott Jr., president, said yesterday while in Los Angeles for the opening of the company's newest hotel.

title: 4 Horses Clear Gold Cup Jumps
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7 (AP)  Four horses jumped cleanly over all 17 fences today in the opening of the $25,000 American Gold Cup at John F. Kennedy Stadium here.

title: Leonard Cohen Muses on New Stage
description: Leonard Cohen, the Canadian poet, novelist and singersong writer, talks exactly the way he singsin a mesmerizing drone. If you listen carefully, you are sometimes rewarded with a poet's profound thoughts, sometimes with a pop star's put on.

title: The Theater: Kiley Takes a New Cervantes Role
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7The American Theater, which opened its first season last night with Richard Kiley starring in Cervantes, a new play by Norman Corwin, is, according to its producer, Ed Yoe, the 14th legitimate theater in Washington a count that obviously includes dinner theaters as well as such institutions as the Arena Stage and the Washington Theater Club.

title: Uruguayan Peso Devalued
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 7 (UPI)The Government today ordered a 1.76 per cent devaluation in the value of the Uruguayan peso in relation to the United States dollar. The Bank of the Republic now quotes the dollar at 883 pesos, buy, and 892 pesos, sell. Previous prices were 868 and 877, respectively.

title: Theater: Wood Demon
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 6In this Edinburgh Festival, the drama offerings have come in for a certain amount of general criticism. It has been generally felt that the festival pays too much attention to music and opera and too little to drama and, for that matter, dance.

title: Freight Traffic Up 7.5%
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.9 billion tonmiles, 7.5 per cent above the corresponding week last year. Carloadings during the same week totaled 555,547 cars, 2 percent above last year and 1.4 per cent above the preceding week of this year.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 7 (AP)Four Americans advanced and one was eliminated today in the freestyle competition at the world wrestling championships.

title: KISSINGER'S ROLE IN WIRETAPS SNAGS SENATE APPROVAL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 Henry A. Kissinger was threatened today with a delay in his confirmation as Secretary of State unless the Justice Department turned over to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee a report on wiretaps he approved on 17 Government officials and newsmen in 1969, 1970 and 1971.

title: College Warns Drug Users
description: PROVO, Utah, Sept. 7 (UPI) Students at Brigham Young University face immediate expulsion for use of illegal drugs, the president of the school, Dallin H. Oaks, warned yesterday.

title: Pilots at Western Airlines Reach Accord on Contract
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 7 (AP) Agreement on a new contract for Western Airlines pilots was reached last night minutes before a midnight strike deadline, the Air Line Pilots Association announced early today.

title: MRS. ERNEST ELGART
description: Mrs. Adele C. Elgart, who was executive director of Specialty Stores Association, Inc., for 30 years until her retirement in 1966, died Thursday at her home in Rome, according to word received here. She was 77 years old.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A man and woman were arrested in Queens yesterday by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and charged with stealing a 42foot yacht in Naples, Fla., sailing it on a threeweek pleasure cruise around the Yucatan peninsula and leaving it at New Orleans last month. The agents said they had found 32 pounds of marijuana when they arrested the two, Ronald James White, 35 years old, and Patricia Schirmer, 30, at the couple's home at 15734 100th Street in Howard Beach, Queens. The two were charged with interstate transportation of stolen property. No narcotics charge has been filed.

title: JAPANESE FORCES ARE HELD ILLEGAL
description: TOKYO, Sept. 7A Japanese district court ruled today that the nation's maintenance of '20;military forces is unconstitutional. It was a landmark decision in the deepest and longestrunning controversy in postwar Japan.

title: GUNMEN THREATEN LIVES OF 4 SAUDIS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Saturday, Sept. 8Five Palestinian terrorists took four Saudi Arabian hostages on a flight over the Saudi capital from Kuwait yesterday and threatened to toss them out of the plane.

title: QUARTER DEFICIT AT MATTEL WIDENS
LIBYA SAID TO LAY MORE PORT MINES
description: LONDON, Sept. 7  The Libyan Government has resumed minelaying operations in areas off Tripoli harbor, British officials said tonight.

title: Golf Results AT STANWICH CLUB
description: WOMEN'S TRICOUNTY G.A.

title: Basketball Transactions
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: People and Business
description: The Rev. Leon H. Sullivan, chairman of the Opportunities Industralization Center, said yesterday that a putback policy must govern operations of American businesses in African and Caribbean countries.

title: Wholesale Index Increase Third Biggest in 60 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7An explosion in farm prices following the end of the brief summer price freeze sent the Government's Wholesale Price Index for August up by 5.8 per cent, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Ernest Scott, Lawyer, Led Bar Group in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7Ernest Scott, a former chancellor of the Philadelphia Bar Association, who retired a year ago as senior partner of the law firm of Pepper, Hamilton & Scheetz, died today at his home in Berwyn. He was 69 years old.

title: Nixon Room Closed to Public
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) The White House said today that the public would not be able to see President Nixon's redecorated bedroom. It also ruled out any photographs of his new $5,000, early 19th century fourposter canopied bed. The Nixons are maintaining the privacy of their family quarters, said Mrs. Nixon's press secretary, Helen Smith.

title: Gil Orlovitz, Poet, Died in July; Traced to City Paupers' Grave
description: Gil Orlovitz, prolific writer of avantgarde poetry, plays and novels, died July 10 at Knickerbocker Hospital. He was 55 years old and had lived alone in a single room at 235 West 107th Street.

title: AEROSOL GLUE BAN STIRS SAFETY UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7The Consumer Product Safety Commission set up special telephone lines today to handle inquiries about aerosol spray adhesives suspected of causing genetic damage to users and deformities in their children.

title: Antiques:King of Desks Rolls Again
description: William S. Wooton's vehemently Victorian king of desks, devised and patented in 1874, is the antithesis of austere, modern office furnishings. Yet an increasing number of young people are attracted to this grandiose office on wheels, a trend that may well have been sparked by the appearance of a Wooton in the United States Pavilion at Montreal's Expo '67.

title: KISSINGER'S ROLE IN INIRETAPS SNAGS SENATE APPROVAL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 Henry A. Kissinger was threatened today with a delay in his confirmation as Secretary of State unless the Justice Department turned over to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee a report on wiretaps he approved on 17 Government officials and newsmen in 1969, 1970 and 1971.

title: ASTRONAUTS FILM BIG SUN ERUPTION
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 7 (AP) The astronauts aboard Skylab 2 photographed today a sun explosion that scientists estimated was 10 times the size of the earth. The scientists called it the brightest and biggest this year.

title: Tuned In, Turned Off, Dropped Out
description: There were plenty of seats in the rear of the bus. I paid the fare, walked down the aisle toward the empty places in back. Almost all of the passengers were huddled into the seats in front for the blare of rock music was emanating from the midst of a group of three adolescents seated on the wide, back bench.

title: Leaders at Rutgers
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 7  Andy Tighe of Woodbury, an AllEast guard last year, and John Witkowski of Fall River, Mass., the middle linebacker, were elected today by their teammates to cocaptain the 1973 Rudgers football team.

title: Nominee to Direct Foreign Aid Daniel Safford Parker
description: For Daniel Safford Parker, a man born with a silver pen in his hand, his nomination yesterday to be administrator of the Agency for International Development is a natural fusing of his interests in business and in international affairs. As the chairman of the Parker Pen Company, the world's largest maker of writing instruments, he has long been an articulate spokesman for business as well as a successful industrialist himself. And as an active participant in foreign economic and social development for many years, he has demonstrated his concern for toe ?? of the havenot nations.

title: Fed Moves to Hold Down Big Rise in Bank Lending
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7The Federal Reserve Board rolled out one of its most powerful weapons todayan increase in bank reserve requirementsas a further step in its effort, not very successful so far, to slow the rapid expansion in bank lending.

title: Marcos's Daughter Will Live Off the Princeton U. Campus
description: PRINCETON, Sept. 7Imelda Marcos, daughter of President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines, will live off campus accompanied by a Filipino security guard and a Filipino chauffeur while attending Princeton University, the dean of student affairs, Adele S. Simmons, disclosed today.

title: Boy Found Dead in Elevator Of Harlem Apartment House
description: A 15yearold boy who had been visiting his aunt was found dead yesterday in an elevator in an East Harlem housing development.

title: Giants' Streak Is in Jeopardy For Want of a Correct Shoe
description: AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 7Grass, in one form or another, was the subject of considerable concern here today as the New York Giants arrived for their final exhibition game tomorrow night, against the Cleveland Browns

title: Yanks Blanked 20th Time As Brewers Triumph, 50
description: After suffering their 20th shutout last night, 50, to Milwaukee, the Yankees had one less game to play, which should gladden their hearts because that's how it looked like they were playingjust running out the schedule.

title: Three Westchester Candidates In Executive Race Open Debate
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 7Three candidates for Westchester's top political post, County Executive, started an unusual campaign road show today with the first of a series of facetoface debates.

title: Ethel McAdie, Ad Executive; Spent 50 Years at FrankLaw
description: Mrs. Ethel G. McAdie, who in a career of nearly 50 years advanced from secretary to vice president of a large New York advertising and publicrelations agency, died yesterday in Fort Pierce (Fla.) Memorial Hospital. She was 80 years old.

title: SOUTH VIETNAMESE SHELL A REBEL UNIT
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 7South Vietnamese artillery opened fire before dawn today on a company of about 100 Vietcong soldiers assembling 12 miles west of Saigon, the Government announced.

title: '71 ATTICA SLAYING IS LAID TO INMATES
description: WARSAW, N. Y., Sept. 7 Indictments were unsealed here today charging five former inmates of Attica State. Correctional Facility with the murder of a fellow prisoner during the 1971 prison rebellion.

title: 2MonthOld Girl In Need of Surgery Is Found by Police
description: Sasheen Leathers, the 2monthold baby taken by her mother from Lenox Hill Hospital last week on the eve of an important operation, was returned safely to the hospital and in good health yesterday after an 11day search that had left authorities increasingly concerned for the child's health.

title: Marriott Is Guest (of Honor) for Once
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 7J. Willard Marriott, the Utahborn hotel man who was chairman of both of President Nixon's inaugurations, finally was given a party of his own here last night.

title: WINE TALK
description: It had to happen. There is an automobile show, a boat show, a flower show. Now there will be a wine show. It is scheduled to go on in December just where all the other big shows appear, at the Coliseum. And, if you can believe the promoters, wine people are fighting for space.

title: Long Court Vacancy Appalls Kaufman
description: Chief Judge Irving R. Kaufman declared yesterday that it was nothing less than a disgrace that the Nixon Administration had failed to fill a vacancy on the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: Police Raid Huge SmutFilm Operation
description: A pornographicfilm processing business that was said to have grossed $12.5million a year was reported devastated yesterday following raids in Queens and the seizure of expensive equipment by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and local police.

title: Grain Prices Climb Limit; Soybean Futures Mixed
EXSTATE OFFICIAL CALLED IN INQUIRY
description: TRENTON, Sept. 7 (UPI) Frederick W. Leary, a state official who was dismissed in an investigation of the state's distribution of surplus government properties, appeared today before the State Commission of Investigation.

title: Con Edison Asks for Higher Gas Rates a Day After Getting Increase in Cost of Electricity
description: The Consolidated Edison Company, citing substantial increases in costs, applied yesterday to the Public Service Commission for an annual increase in gas rates totaling $27,577,600.

title: Moral: Don't Take The Wife With You
description: To hear Frank O'Connor tell it, his wife might as well have left him at home yesterday morning when the couple drove in from Woodside, Queens, to spend a morning amid the bargains at Barney's fourth annual warehouse sale.

title: The Tombs: It's Not a Pleasant Place
description: I am writing this in cell 5 on the 7th tier of D wing in the Tombs. My cage is about 4 feet by 7 feet, painted institutional pale green, and hot as hell. The steelbarred door slides open and shut with eerie regularity, controlled by some unseen jailer.

title: Fiat Asks Workers To Increase Output To Keep Up in Race
description: ROME, Sept. 7The Fiat Motor Company is appealing to the auto workers unions to help it increase productivity and prevent it from falling back still further in the highly competitive international car market.

title: Salvatore Battaglia Dies; Headed Chicago Syndicate
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (UPI) Salvatore Battaglia a reputed former chief of the Chicago crime syndicate, died today of cancer, 11 days after he was paroled because of the terminal illness. He was 64 years old

title: President of Bolivia Bids Cabinet Resign To Strengthen Base
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 7 (AP) President Hugo Banzer Surez of Bolivia, a country that has seen 187 governments in 148 years of independence, asked his entire Cabinet to resign today.

title: Mrs. Court Beats Chris Evert in 3 Sets And Gains Final With Miss Goolagong
description: Two 31yearold married women took on a pair of youngsters yesterday in semifinal singles matches of the United States Open championships. Emerging victorious after extraordinarily tense contests were the familiar names of Mrs. Margaret Court and Evonne Goolagong, both of Australia. They'll meet today in the final.

title: Drivers Are Called In Trotting Inquiry
description: Several harnessracing drivers were among 20 persons subpoenaed by a Federal Grand Jury here yesterday in the continuing investigation of allegedly fixed superfecta races at New York tracks.

title: Anker Appoints Trustees To Supersede Two Boards
description: School Chancellor Irving Anker partly superseded the authority of two community school boards yesterday and appointed trustees to assume full legal responsibility for the controversial issues that led to the unusual action.

title: Friends Urge Nobel Prize for Sakharov
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 7Three prominent Soviet dissidents proposed today that the 1973 Nobel Peace Prize be awarded to Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and civil rights advocate, who has been the target of an intensive press campaign here.

title: Decorating? All Useless, Cutesy Objects Ought to Be Broken
description: If there's no elastic left in the budget and there's no money left to buy furniture this year and you're eating off your lap on a carpetless floor and reading the falling DowJones averages by the light of a single candle, don't despair.

title: Roundup: Bucs Win in 9th
description: Danny Murtaugh, back for his fourth term as manager of the Pittsburgh Pirates, got off to a winning start last night when the Pirates erupted for six runs in the ninth inning to beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 108.

title: LADD PETROLEUM IN MERGER PACT
description: Utah International, Inc., is planning to expand its activities into oil and gas operations through the proposed acquisition of the Ladd Petroleum Corporation for stock exceeding $61million in value.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: ORANGE, Sept. 7Tony Galento, who vowed I'll molder the bum before he fought Joe Louis for the heavyweight boxing championship in 1939, didn't quite back up his prediction. TwoTon Tony did hurt Louis with a punch above the ribs in the second round and had the Brown Bomber on the canvas in the; third round.

title: PAPER MAKER GETS ACCORD IN CANADA
description: TORONTO, Sept. 7 (AP)The Abitibi Paper Company and the United Paper Workers International Union reached agreement today to end a strike and partly ease the supply of newsprint for United States newspapers.

title: Average of Treasury Bills In Britain Up to 10.9862%
description: LONDON, Sept. 7(Reuters) The average rate at today's tender of British Treasury bills rose to 10.9862 per cent (10.9744).

title: Ehrlichman Pleads Not Guilty in '71 Ellsberg BreakIn
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 7John D. Ehrlichman, the former Presidential adviser on domestic affairs, pleaded not guilty today to charges of burglary, conspiracy and perjury in the 1971 breakin at the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 7 (AP)Four Americans advanced and one was eliminated today in the freestyle competition at the world wrestling championships.

title: Dr. Edmund Janvrin Dies; Professor of Medicine, 89
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., Sept. 17Dr. Edmund R. P. Janvrin, a former professor of medicine at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, and staff member of Bellevue Hospital, died today at Lawrence Memorial Hospital after a brief illness. He was 89 years old and lived at 38 East 85th Street in New York.

title: PRIMARY FOR JUDGES ON WEST SIDE VOIDED
description: Justice Abraham J. Gellinoff of the State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday invalidated the June 4 Democratic primary election victories of two candidates for Civil Court Judgeships in the Third Municipal Court district in Manhattan.

title: AMEX PRICES RISE AS VOLUME EASES
description: Volume eased somewhat but prices edged ahead yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market.

title: 6 Frustrating Hours in Harlem On Trail of 11 Heroin Dealers
description: When Eddie G. Washington was arrested on narcotics charges under both the old and new state drug laws, he described himself to the police as an unemployed salesman.

title: DR. Z. RITA PACKER
description: STONINGTON, Me., Sept. 7 Dr. Z. Rita Pecker, who retired in 1965 after 40 years practice in psychiatry, for the most part in New York, died yesterday at her summer home at Isle au Haut, near here. Her age was 78 and she had a winpr home in Florida.

title: Hot Putter Gives Lead To Blalock
description: DALLAS, Sept. 7 (AP)Jane Blalock, a late starter, opened defense of her $35,000 Dallas Civitan Women's open crown today, shooting a firstround, threeunderpar 69 over the waterlogged Brookhaven Country Club course.

title: Gas Rate Rise Asked
description: Consolidated Edison, citing increased costs, applied to the Public Service Commission yesterday for an annual increase in gas rates of $27,577,600. The bid for a 17 per cent rise came the day after the utility was granted a $164.5million increase in its electricity rates. Page 64.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DUCKS AND YOGA. Today in Central Park you may breatheno mean featwhile your children greet again an old friend and listen to Hans Christian Andersen's The Ugly Duckling. At 11 A.M. Diane Wolkstein, the park story teller, will depart from her intended telling of Andersen's The Swineherd, to sit down with the newly returned and polished Ugly Duckling statue off 72d Street at Fifth Avenue and talk about him.

title: Women Set Marks For Discus, Javelin
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 7 (AP)The Soviet Union's discus star, Faina Melnik, and East Germany's javelin queen, Ruth Fuchs, broke their own world records with mighty throws tonight in the finals of the women's Europa Cup track meet.

title: Herzog Out, Wilber Gets Ranger Job
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., Sept. 7 (AP)The Texas Rangers dismissed Manager Whitey Herzog tonight and named Del Wilber as interim pilot of the American League baseball team.

title: Amex Seat Price Is Up
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday announced a membership seat sale at $40,000, up $5,000 from the last sale on August 20. Seats are currently quoted at $36,000 bid and $48,000 offered.

title: Books of The Times
description: WARD 402. By Ronald J. Glasser. 232 pages. George Braziller. $6.95,

title: West Side Road Repair
description: The entranceexit ramp to the West Side Highway between 46th and 48th Streets will be closed between 7 A.M. and 6 P.M. next weekend for construction work. Transportation Administrator Constantine SidamonEristoff said the ramp's roadway would be altered on Sept. 15 and 16 to allow it to be used only for exiting southbound traffic when major rehabilitation begins on the highway's southbound lanes next month.

title: American League
description: Saturday, September 8, 1973

title: Thursday's Fight
description: Los AngelesArmando Muniz, 149 pounds, Los Angeles, knocked out Antonio Roldan, 149, Mexico, 2 rounds.

title: Suspect Seized in Plaza Bomb Threat
description: A 23yearold unemployed housepainter was arrested yesterday minutes after the president of the Plaza Hotel had delivered $11,000 in response to the man's alleged threats to blow up the hotel.

title: Onion Choice in Field of 9 for Governor
description: A cast of characters that had been juggled several times, by conjecture, during the earlier part of the week has finally been defined, and a field of nine has been named for the Governor Stakes at Belmont park today.

title: Women Set Marks For Discus, Javelin
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland. Sept. 7 (AP)The Soviet Union's discus star, Faina Melnik, and East Germany's javelin queen, Ruth Fuchs, broke their own world records with mighty throws tonight in the finals of the women's Europa Cup track meet.

title: U.S. UNIT INQUIRING INTO G.S.A.'S HIRING
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7The United States Civil Service Commission is investigating allegations that political influence may have been used to secure normally competitive Government jobs in the General Services Administration, particularly in Maryland.

title: CHAUNCEY D. STEELE
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 7 Chauncey Depew Steele, a former hotel executive who managed the Algonquin Hotel in New York in the early nine teentwenties and thirties, died yesterday at Mount Auburn Hospital. His age was 83, and he lived here.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Two persons have been arrested and another man is being sought in connection with the killings last May of two reputed Philadelphia drug dealers on a Camden street. Camden police investigators are reportedly trying to link the killings with the shooting death of a former Camden mayoral candidate, Major B. Coxson, and a possible drug war between gangs in South Jersey and Philadelphia.

title: Mets Win Twice by 10 and 42
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 7I can dream, can't I? asked Yogi Berra with his familiar big grin before tonight's doubleheader with the Expos. A double win over Montreal and we'll be knocking on second place's door.

title: 3,000 Attend Funeral for Shabazz at Mosque in Newark
description: NEWARK, Sept. 7 (AP)We loved Brother Minister James Shabazz. He is alive in the hearts of Islam.

title: WARDEN AT ATTICA GETS ALBANY POST
description: ATTICA, N.Y., Sept. 7 (AP)Ernest L. Montanye, the superintendent of Attica prison, said today that he was leaving his post to take a promotion in Albany.

title: Testing for Police
description: There can be no argument that the New York City Police Department is lowering one standard in the hiring of recruits: New male police officers will no longer have to be at least five feet, seven inches tall. It does not follow, however, that a less qualified, less efficient police force will result. In our view, just the reverse should prove true.

title: Controversy Over Legality Keeps Japanese Armed Forces Small
description: TOKYO, Sept. 7The story may be apocryphal but it is pointed ??I a discussion of Japan's SelfDefense Fores some years ago, an official of the Defense Agency suddenly stopped and blurted out: Is there any other nation in the world whose own armed forces are called illegal?

title: Chairman of A.M.A.'s Trustees Among 6 Indicted in Bank Case
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 Dr. John R. Kernodle, chairman of the American Medical Association's board of trustees, and five North Carolina businessmen were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of bank fraud involving over $1.7million.

title: Klein Backs News Parleys
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 7 (AP)  President Nixon should hold more news conferences, says Herbert G. Klein, the President's former director of communications. Mr. Klein, who said he remains a stanch supporter of the President, added that truth apparently was not the hallmark of the Administration.

title: City Begins Its Financing Of Local Anticrime Plans
description: The first contingents of what will become a citywide civilian force working with the police to fight crime became reality yesterday as the police approved their programs and Mayor Lindsay declared money available to supplement the funds the neighborhood groups had raised themselves.

title: DRUGGIST BEATEN TO DEATH IN BRONX
description: A 68yearold pharmacist was found slain behind the counter of his Bronx drugstore last night. The police said he had been beaten to death in an apparent robbery attempt. an apparent robbery attempt.

title: Cambodia Reports Town of Kompong Cham Is Now Out of Danger
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Saturday, Sept. 8After a relatively quiet night a Cambodian Government spokesman here pronounced the beleaguered provincial capital of Kampong Cham out of danger although insurgent troops still hold parts of the city.

title: Kosher Butchers In a Buying Coop Obtain Beef Here
description: A cooperative of 280 kosher butcher shops has invested more than $2.5million to buy more than 5,000 cattle since Aug. 2 to provide beef for consumers here.

title: Basketball Transactions
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: A High Jobless Rate Mars State's Economy
description: TRENTON, Sept. 7 (AP)The State Department of Labor and Industry said today that business indicators for the month of July remained favorable, with some exceptions.

title: N.A.M. Weighs Institute To Educate Businessmen
description: The National Association of Manufacturers, stung by increasing hostility toward big business by many segments of society, is studying the possibility of initiating an Institute of American Industry, which would educate business executives on broad social, political and ethical matters.

title: Pentagon May Destroy Nerve Gas Near Denver
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) The Defense Department has apparently decided to destroy, rather than move, tons of nerve gas now stored at the Rocky Mountain Arsenal near Denver, military and Congressional sources said today.

title: Watergate Comics Find the Joke Ison Them
description: CHICAGO  Watergate just isn't a laughing matter for most of the nation's standup comedians.

title: Richard V. Bonomo Dies; Led Scrap Iron Company
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 7  Richard V. Bonomo, chairman of the board of the SchiavoneBonomo Corporation of Jersey City, died today in Mountainside Hospital in Montclair. He was 78 years old and lived here at 40 Club Road.

title: Laotian Premier Insists That the Army Backs Him
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 7Prince Souvanna Phouma, the neutralist Premier, declared today that he had the support of the army and that there was a good chance that next week he might sign a completed accord that would bring about a coalition government with the Pathet Lao.

title: Art: Jules Olitski Retrospective
description: A retrospective exhibition of paintings by the American artist Jules Olitski, organized last spring by the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, has now come to the Whitney Museum of American Art, Madison Avenue at 75th Street. Consisting of approximately 50 paintings, some of them as large as 21 feet in width, the show occupies the entire fourthfloor exhibition space at the museum. It opened yesterday.

title: PRICE OF 60 F14'S CUT $10  MILLION
description: The Navy and the Grumman Aerospace Corporation have agreed on a price for the next lot of 50 F14 Tomcat fighters that is almost $10million less than the current Congress originally was asked to appropriate.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: U. S. Takes 3 Swim Crowns
description: BELGRADE, Sept. 7The expected and unexpected happened for the United States swimmers tonight and they parlayed them into three victories and one world record in the world swimming championships.

title: Perspective on Cholera
description: The outbreak in Italy of what at the moment looks like a miniepidemic of cholera, including a score of deaths, has had wide repercussions. Tourists are avoiding the affected areas; a mass campaign to vaccinate millions Italians against this disease is under way; and at all international borders, ports and airports sharp watch being kept against the entry of travelers who might be bringing cholera infection with them from Italy.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Acid Price Rise Is Set
description: Canadian Industries, Ltd., announced yesterday at Montreal that it was increasing the price of sulphuric acid by about 6 per cent, effective immediately for open market customers and on Oct. 1 for contract customers. The company sal: that price of 66degrees Baum grade sulphuric acid, which accounts for SO per cent of its sales, will go from $33 to $35 a ton. It traced the increase to higher distribution and sharply rising production costs.

title: Behind the Mayorsa Civil Service Elite
description: When Mayor Lindsay name the owlish Harry I. Bronstein as the city's Personnel Director, the City Council's finance Committee took the rare step of adopting a resolution in praise of the Mayor.

title: NEW BULGE SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7The Cost of Living Council ordered today reductions ranging from 10 per cent to 30 per cent in price increases the four major automobile companies sought for their 1974 models.

title: CUT IN MEAT COST IS EXPECTED SOON
description: The American Meat Institute forecast yesterday that consumers throughout the country should find meat prices down considerably in a week or two, citing drops in wholesale prices of 13 to 26 per cent from midAugust highs through yesterday.

title: People in Sports: Storen New A.B. A. Commissioner
description: The American Basketball Association, which changes commissioners quicker than it can say Rick Barry, selected its fourth in six years yesterday. The new man is Mike Storen, the 37yearold who resigned as general manager when the Kentucky Colonels put in an allwomen board of directors. In explaining how he will differ from his predecessors, Storen said: I don't think you will see any visible signs in change of directionbut you're going to see things done better. I'm not George Mikan saying let's start the league, or Jack Dolph saying let's look at TV, or Bob Carlson saying let's look at, merger.Just Like Any Other 7Foot Black Millionaire Who Lives Next Door), Wilt Chamberlain explains the price of success: I remember being with President Nixon a few times before he was elected and having people come up to me for autographs and not even notice him.

title: British Stars Nurse Along Their writers
description: THERE one thing British actors do that no American can actor ever thinks of doing, and that is tend carefully to the nursing of playwrights. To an American actor, a playwright's growth and reputation are matters for the playwright himself to take care of. The writer's early struggles, and experimental reaches, are no part of the star performer's business. Let the young fellow learn his trade, fight his battles, rise majesticallyand aloneto the top of his form, and then the star may very well think of favoring him by appearing in his newest piece. It had better be good, and right for the particular star, of course. If, a year later, the writer slips slightly off form, no phone call from him is likely ever to reach the performer again. His obligation, if any, has ceased. This is all rather silly, considering that without the playwright the actor really has nothing to keep his trade alive, but, in general, it's the way things are here.

title: Father Coughlin
description: Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, still alive and well at 81 though longforgotten by the public, is one of those historical figures to whom it is almost impossible to do justice. For a halfdozen years in the 1930's, his Sunday broadcasts mixing religion, politics and economic theory in a unique amalgam made him major political and cultural force. Yet his influence has disappeared without leaving a trace. He was serious in his aspirations and impact, but his career had a certain comic quality. The good and the bad effects of his popular influence were so intertwined that one is tempted either to excuse his offenses too easily or to denigrate him as a demagogue too severely and miss certain positive of his career.

title: His poetry transforms Spain into his own personal vision
description: When I was in Republican Spain in the winter and spring of 1937, Spanish poets spoke much of Garcia Lorca, their great contemporary who had been murdered in his native city of Granada the previous summer. Their feeling for him was of affection and enchantment. They gave me the impression, which I have to this day, that not to have met Lorca was to have missed some magical experience that still exists in modern life. He may not have been the greatest of modern Spanish poets, but he was beyond criticism. As a man he much him.

title: Closing Time
description: Norman O. Brown's latest book continues the meditations he begar in Life Against Death (1959) and Love's Body (1966), which ex plored the community, hidden be neath history, that exists between language, the imagination and man's body. Closing Time is no less re markable than the other two for the freedom of its text and organization, and for the pleasure of its learning and intellectual performance. Each o Brown's books is about how things can join together physically as they once did, but here his book is the place itself in which two authors the Italian philosopher Giambattista Vico and James Joyce, do actually close with each other. The form of this punning marriage, which Brown says he is performing, is uniquely his invention. Every page consists of quotations mainly from Vico and Joyce with sparse commentary by Brown, more for the sake of letting the quotations lie together than for commenting on what they mean. There is nothing of the scrapbook in this sort of transcendent sexuality, nor of a greatandsimilarideas compendium.

title: For Hange Range, A Quest for Style
description: HACKETTSTOWNA grout of talented young musicians herethey call themselves Hange Rangelive communally, work as nonunion carpenters, laborers or whatever pays a livable wage and practice two or three hours every night when they are not playing a gig.

title: Success Easily Explained For Taiwan Little League

Government officials and ordinary citizens have gloried in the teams' success and regarded them as ideal goodwill ambassadors.

title: A gift of tongues
description: I have now, on and off, lived in America long enough (by lived 1 mean dwelt in an apartment and not a hotel) both to understand and to make myself understood. Not that an Englishman needs to go to America to become acquainted with its various brands of spoken English. In 1929, as I well remember, millions of British cinemagoers saw The Singing Fool and caught those blatantly accurate and chillingly portentous words of Al Jolson (words enshrined in the Oxford Dictionary of Quotations): You ain't heard nothin yet, folks. Indeed we had not, but from that moment on we heard a great deal. All the urban and rural dialects of the Union flowed back, on Vitaphone disk or sound track, to the country which had, so long ago, given birth to them. By the time the G.I.'s shambled into England in the nineteenforties (their boots made no noise, which was a delicate gesture), Anthony Burgess, the British writer, is currently at work on a novel about Napoleon. all the pertly gumchewing shopgirls were ready to do an authentic Southern drawl or Brooklynese singsong, according to what was required. Since the war, that particular gift of tongues has been taken away from the British go and hear London's version of The Front Pagebut, by God, the Paraclete was fluttering away madly in those days of earnest fraternization. The present position seems to be that Englishmen and Americans tolerate at all. Aitchlessness is not just a mark of lowerclass British speech (vide My Fair Lady); it is to be found among the conservative aristocracy (the chairman of the board of governors of the school where I taught, Lord Saye and Sele, always said, Thought we were goin ome when he found that a governors meeting was by no means yet finished); it was general in all British speech up to the 19th century. The idea was that you pronounced an aitch when the Syllable it each other's versions of the mother tongue, but there are still large areas of ignorance both in usage and in pronunciationwhich no amount of twoway subart traffic can quite liquidate.

title: Art Notes
description: AT FIRST glance the precise geometric shapes in Ellsworth Kelly's canvases look like blownup pages from a tenthgrade geometry book. Has anyone ever told you, Mr. Kelly, that your works are boring?
