The group will visit the city of Cebu in the central Philippines and areas in Mindanao in the south to study sites of possible oil deposits, a spokesman said.

title: And what about the quota for gay militant Chicano artists?
description: Good morning/afternoon. I am Cybille, your electronic docent. You are standing in the Taki 183 Memorial Gallery, donated to the Museum by the Cultural Assimilation and Neutralization Council. Magic Markers for the 15minute scrawlin may be rented at the desk. The nominal fee will be credited to our maintenance fund for the last polychromed subway carriage known to be in running condition, donated to the museum by MarlboroughGeneral Motors Corporation. It is now on tour Japan, with our traveling exhibition, The Spraying Eye: Form and Relevance in South Bronx Calligraphy. ...

title: Mrs. Court Takes U.S. Tennis Title
description: Mrs. Margaret Court's big serve and consistency led her to her fifth United States title yesterday as she defeated Evonne Goolagong in the $227,000 Open tennis championships at Forest Hills before a record crowd of 15,137.

title: Lemmings Is No Giggle
description: JOKES about dropping acid are just about as topical as gags about hot pants this year. The counter culture moves on to new highs with the same speed that Seventh Avenue moves on to new lows and therein lies the problem with the National Lampoon's Lemmings. The offBroadway revue's second act takeoff on Woodstock is now available on disk, recorded live at the Village Gate (Banana/Blue Thumb Records BTS6006).

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Christian Science Post
description: BOSTON, Sept. 8 (AP)Zadie Hatfield of Hingham has been named executive manager of the Christian Science Publishing Society, succeeding Paul D. Sampson, who has resigned. Miss Hatfield served as advertising business manager and assistant manager of The Christian Science Monitor until her appointment as manager last February. She is the first woman named executive manager.

title: the traveler's world
description: THE anguished return from holiday revives the annual academic debate over which experience is worsethe prevacation scramble to clear the desk, tie up loose ends and turn off the working momentum, or the halting return to work, the slow picking up of those leftover loose ends, and the supreme effort to generate a new head of steam and a fresh regard for the work ethic. This time the question has a happierthanusual aspect because we still feel cheered by a recordbreaking, precedentestablishing experience achieved in the first two weeks of our vacation: We traveled more than 2,500 miles on back roads, state highways, Interstates, Expressways and the Thruway without once having to eat in a roadside restaurant!

title: Hughes's Company Wins A Round in Maheu Fight
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 8 (UPI) A Federal judge has reversed his earlier ruling and said that Howard Hughes's Summa Corporation will not have to turn over 32 confidential documents sought by Robert A. Maheu in his libel suit.

title: LordstownSearching for a Better Way of Work
description: LORDSTOWN, OhioIn some places, the lightning always seems to strike. Surely one is Lordstown, Ohio, where General Motors builds the Chevrolet Vega, its economy vehicle, now suddenly more important than ever, as anxiety persists over fuel shortages, and as autoindustry negotiations, with an un usual emphasis on work rules, speed toward an uncertain climax.

title: Prices of Small Fords Rise 7.1% Larger Models Increasing Less.
description: DETROIT, Sept. 8The Ford Motor Company said today that it was raising prices of its 1974 cars and trucks an average of $136 or 3 per cent but that it was raising prices of its small cars an average of 7.1 per cent.

title: GOVERNOR SEEKS TO AID RAILROADS
description: Governor Rockefeller is putting the spotlight on a littlepublicized feature of his proposed $3.5billion transportation bond issuethe saving of railroad lines from abandonment.

title: Rape Suspect Held As Victim Rams Car Into Police Vehicle
description: An accused rapist was arrested yesterday morning when his alleged victim ended a forced 90minute ride through Brooklyn by ramming her auto into a police car.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The financial markets moved steadily higher last week, encouraging those who believe that the period immediately following Labor Day sets the direction for late summer and early fall.

title: Saints Edge Oilers, 1610
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 8 (UPI)  A rookie, Howard Stevens, ran 22 yards for a touchdown in the final period tonight to give the New Orleans Saints a 1610 victory over the Houston Oilers.

title: Cattle Fed From Own Waste to Cut Protein Shortage
description: STERLING, Colo., Sept. 8One of the nation's large beef cattle feeding companies began yesterday to include in the normal diet of its herd substantial portions of feed derived from cattle manure.

title: Numismatics
description: A COMPREHENSIVE exhibit devoted to monies of the New World opened last Thursday at the museum of the American Numismatic Society, on Broadway between 155th and 156th Streets. The show, entitled Coinage of the Americas, Is open to the public throtigh the first half of next year.

title: Third World's Trumps
description: The socalled Third World is edging gradually into its own and it is hard to imagine that its lack of cohesion or leadership inexperience can indefinitely obscure this new political fact. Such is the main implication of the past week's meeting in Algiers of some sixty chiefs of state or government from countries in underprivileged Asia, Africa and South America.

title: BOTH SIDES DIG IN AT CAMBODIA CITY; PUSH IS EXPECTED
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sept. 8Relatively little fighting was reported in the provincial capital of Kompong Cham today, but it appeared that both sides were preparing for a maximum effort in the next few days.

title: Blume and Heartbreak Kid'What Kind of Jews Are They?
description: UNTIL quite recently it has been one of the abiding paradoxes of the American cinema that in an industry where Jews have been a major source of talent, creative and entrepreneurial, Jewish cultureparticularly in its contemporary American context  has been a very minor source of subject matter. Prior to World War II, it is difficult to find a Hollywood film that deals even marginally with this topic. Of movies that come readily to mind, what is there besides The Jazz Singer (in which the Jewish milieu, though fairly authentic, is too maudlin to be taken seriously)?

title: Grubneklaf Puts Imprint on L.I.
description: EAST HAMPTON, L.I. Art galleries in the Hamptons are usually the domains of the de Koonings, the Pollacks and the Rivers. But this summer, the territory was invaded by Grubneklaf.

title: L.I.R.R. TO SHIFT 75 UNDER NEW RULES
description: About 75 Long Island Rail Road trainmen and engineers who feel they have become pawns in a women's liberation skirmish have been notified by the line that they are to be reassigned because they do not meet new physical requirements.

title: Black Racketeers
description: Here in Newark and in other increasingly black cities in New Jersey where the Mafia has long been entrenched, black racketeers have challenged the white mobsters for control of the enormously lucrative numbers and narcotics operations in the ghetto neighborhoods.

title: LONG SCHOOL DAY FOUGHT IN POLAND
description: WARSAW, Sept. 8 (UPI)A proposal for allday school sessions for Polish children has touched off a serious dispute between the Communist Government and the Roman Catholic Church, which sees a move to cut down on afterschool time used for religious instruction.

title: THE TV SEASON GETS STARTED
description: Like a crosscountry runner delayed by a long train  in this instance, a lengthy summer strike by the men and women who write the scriptsthe new TV season has arrived out of breath and in disarray. Blame the strike for the fact that some of the new shows won't be straggling in until late next month, although the seven listed here start this week.

title: Seat Belts They'll Get the Last Word
description: Michael Kelly of Cleveland bought a new car this summer, a white Ford Maverick that had a special feature he hasn't ordered: The car wouldn't start unless he fastened his seat belt and shoulder harness.

title: William & Mary Wins, 3124
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., Sept. 8 (UPI)William and Mary recovered four Virginia Tech

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: BellmoreHelen B. Muller's batik painting, Monday through Oct. 4, Mondays to Fridays, 10 A.M. to 9 P.M., Saturday 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and Sunday 1 to 5 P.M., Bellmore Memorial Library, 2288 Bedford Avenue.

title: Arts Center Offers Two Free Concerts
description: HOLMDELNew Jersey residents are invited to apply for tickets to free concerts at the Garden State Arts Center. The concerts will be given by the United States Marine Band on Tuesday night and by the United States Army Field Band and Soldiers' Chorus on Friday night.

title: Mary Mills, On 71142, Leads Golf
description: DALLAS, Sept. 8 (UPI)Mary Mills survived a slump of three straight bogeys at the end of the front nine today and rallied to shoot her second straight 71 and take a onestroke lead going into the final round of the $35,000 Dallas Civitan open.

title: AFFLUENT SETTING FOR NONALIGNED
description: ALGIERS, Sept. 8President Idi Amin rose out of the sea and to inquiring newsmen exclaimed happily, I'm having a lovely holiday.

title: Camera world
description: A COURSE in photojournalism, designed for those with at least a basic knowledge of photography, is being offered at Queens College as part of their continuing Education Program. To meet for 12 consecutive Thursday evenings, the course will start Oct. 4, but registration will be held this week from 9 A.M. to 3:30 P.M., and from 6 to 8:30 P.M. in Academic II, Room 111 at the school. The course will include layouts, copywriting and working with editors, and the tuition will be $55. There will also be courses this fall in basic photography, as well as an intermediate workshop. For more information call (212) extension 738.

title: Metropolitan Area Found Lagging in FoodStamp Uses
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8The Federal Government spends significantly less on food stamps for povertylevel families in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, proportionately, than for their counterparts in the rest of the country.

title: In Singapore, a superpimp awaits beatification
description: In figurative use the term saint easily degenerates into a synonym for a swell guy. Saint Jack Flowers seems like a swell guy to the G.I.'s for whom he provides women in his Singapore haven called Paradise Gardens. But novelist Paul Theroux is too scrupulous with language to let the holy epithet slip quite free from its literal significance, as he is too clever to suppose that any means but comedy could salvage the crumbling definitions of holiness from solemnly enforced denigrations of religious terminology into irony and slang.

title: Nicklaus, Weiskopf Share Lead at Akron With 71's
description: AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 8It didn't seem like $50,000 golf to the spectators.

title: JOHN MONTGOMERY, HEADED PEABODY
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 8 (AP)John R. Montgomery, the first, fulltime president of the Peabody Institute, a music conservatory, died today at Union Memorial Hospital. He was 80 years old.

title: '74 SURVEY PLANNED ON HUMAN FERTILITY
description: VIENNA, Sept. 8 (Reuters)Statisticians throughout the world are preparing for a major survey on human fertility, designed to provide basic data in efforts to curb a global population explosion.

title: Colleges Keeping a Lid on Tuition
description: Beginning in 1966, Ohio State University raised its tuition annually to meet rising costs. This year there will be no tuition increase.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Almost a year ago, Joe Gores published a book called Dead Skip, about an operative in a car repossession agency. This department cheered, as did most reviewers. Now comes the second in the series, FINAL NOTICE (Random, $4.95). Again there are going to be hosannas. Tight, tense, beautifullyplotted, Final Notice maintains a high level all the way through.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
Holland, Aussie, Sets World Swim Mark in 1,500
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 8Steve Holland was afraid to stop swimming tonight and again made a joke of the world 1,500meter freestyle record.

title: Levitt Scores School Board on Its Billing
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt said yesterday that an audit by his office had found no reason to doubt that the salary bills submitted by the five members of the New York City Board of Education  amounting to $123,900 last year  were reasonably representative of the time the members gave to board business.

title: Raiders 177 Victors
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 8 (AP) Clarence Davis raced for two touchdowns tonight to spark the Oakland Raiders to a 17 7 victory over the Buffalo Bills.

title: Child Dies in 5Floor Fall
description: A 5yearold child in the Bronx fell five stories to his death yesterday after a window guard he was leaning on collapsed, the police reported. They said the boy, Francesco Perez, had been watching children play in the street from the family's apartment at 1411 Townsend Avenue.

title: Upstate Suicide's Note Is Said to Confess the Slaying of 4 Women
description: ROCHESTER, Sept. 8 (AP)A man who apparently killed himself yesterday confessed in a note that he had slain four women, a Monroe County deputy sheriff said today.

title: Housing for Aging Opens in Cape May
description: CAPE MAY  Victorian Towers, a sixstory apartment house for the elderly that was built by the Program for Housing Development of the Diocese of Camden, was dedicated last week.

title: Calendar of Motor Sports Events
description: TodayNational Hot Rod Association fall nationals at Madison Township Raceway Park, Pension Road, Englishtown, N. J., qualifying until noon; eliminations at 1 P.M.

title: West GermanIsraeli Stand At Berlin Fair Is Blown Up
description: BONN, Sept. 8 (Reuters)A GermanIsraeli stand at the international radio and television exhibition in West Berlin was blown up last night, and today the Palestinian guerrilla organization Black September was said to have taken responsibility for the act.

title: Seattle Joining Movement for Free Bus Rides
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 8 This city of 550,000 on the shores of Puget Sound will try to entice downtown motorists out of their cars by offering them a free bus ride starting Monday.

title: The Nation
description: The conventional wisdom has always been that nobody likes radicals. For the government this has meant an easy strategy: raise the specter of bombs and bullets, mix it well with beards and long hair, and a courtroom conviction on conspiracy charges was sure to follow.

title: KITCHEN REOPENED AT NEW ARK HOSPITAL
description: The kitchen at the Martland Medical Center in Newark was allowed to resume operations early yesterday about nine hours after it had been ordered closed by the New Jersey Health Department because of unsanitary conditions.

title: Mrs. Court Takes Open Title; Smith Upset, New combe Wins
description: The largest crowd in the history of Forest Hills tennis 15,137was treated yesterday to a full gamut of thrills in the United States Open championships.

title: Individual Instruction Is Praised In Suffolk
description: PATCHOGUE, L. I.Fourteen programs in Nassau and Suffolk County schools have been cited as outstanding in their achivement of individualization of instruction and will be used as training centers for teachers and administrators in the coming school year.

title: Arizona Wins, 310, From Colo. State
description: FORT COLLINS, Col., Sept. 8 (UPI)Jim Upchurch, a junior fullback, ran for two touchdowns and 102 yards today as Arizona unleashed a grueling ground game en route to a 310 victory over Colorado State In the 1973 Western Athletic Conference opener.

title: Fixed Races
description: It all started with a beautiful woman. She would come into shops of the Offtrack Betting Corporation, cash as many as five winning tickets on a superfecta race and walk out smartly as admiring eyes followed her every move. When this happened several times, O.T.B. officials stopped admiring her beauty and started pondering her luck. How could she have so many winning tickets so often?

title: Fishermen on L. I. Have the Early Morning Blues
description: FREEPORT, L. I.Flashlights and yokes cajoled motorists through the predawn darkness parking lots. A blob of yellow light was thrown on the dark street by the luncheonette that was crowded with fishermen bolting down their breakfasts and hurriedly gulping coffee. At the slip, across the street, fishermen were silhouettes aboard the Starstream, an 85footer waiting to go out for bluefish.

title: Lifting the TV Blackout: Will It Hurt or Bolster Pro Football?
description: Congress is expected to complete action soonperhaps this weekon a bill that would forbid television blackouts of sports events that are sold out. If it does, it may end for the time being one of the passionate complaints on the sporting scene: No room in the stadium, no telecast on the tube, the hometown fan shut out again.

title: Religious Disk Gave Publisher a Start
description: WACO, Tex., Sept. 8  Jar rell McCracken, a former sportscaster, has built Word, Inc., a religious publishing house that began 22 years ago with a recorded playbyplay football game between Christianity and the forces of evil, into a business empire with sales of $11.5million this year.

title: First, Human Dtente
description: WASHINGTONSince the Moscow summit of May 1972, it has become fashionable to contrast the crudity and bluntness of earlier Soviet regimes with the subtlety and sophistication of Mr. Brezhnev and his associates. But there is nothing subtle about the latest wave of show trials, staged confessions and harassment in the Soviet Union. It is evident that the supposed relaxation of tensions in international affairs is not yet accompanied by a corresponding relaxation of Soviet internal controls.

title: Legal Aid Available For All In Nassau
description: MINEOLA, L. I.,  While Legal Aid Societies elsewhere are overburdened and understaffed, Nassau's is providing poor defendants with their own lawyers, investigative services and legal appeals, without haggling over the costs.

title: Orioles Defeat Indians As Palmer Gets 19th, 61
description: CLEVELAND (UPI)  Jim Palmer tossed a fivehitter to notch his 19th victory and Al Bumbry drove in three runs tonight to pace the Baltimore Orioles to a 61 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

title: Governor To Tentam; Onion 7th
description: Tentam was the people's choice in the Governor at Belmont Park yesterday, and he came through admirably. The Cragwood Stable's 4yearold beat seven rivals in the $115,600 contest of a mile and an eighth, his nearest rival, Rule by Reason, trailing him by two lengths. Next, by a neck, came True Knight.

title: The Trees Obscure The Forest
description: The Senate's Watergate hearings are about to resume, and the Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia is about to come to grips with the issue of Mr. Nixon's tapes. So this may be a good time to assert that the real issue, like the forest in the old saying, is getting hard to see for all the trees.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONLike so much else in the era of Watergate, things were not quite what they seemed when President Nixon and the leaders of Congress held olive branches aloft last week. They used them to alternately flog and prod each other.

title: Tony Boyle
description: PHILADELPHIAFor the better part of three years, through seven successful prosecutions of the killers of Joseph A. Yablonski, the United Mine Workers reformer assassinated in 1969, Prosecutor Richard A. Sprague insisted publicly that the slayings had been ordered by none other than W. A. (Tony) Boyle, then the union President.

title: Notes: Overbooking Continues Unabated
description: ACCORDING to a report by the Civil Aeronautics Board (C.A.B.), almost 83,000 passengers were denied confirmed seatsthat is to say, bumpedon domestic flights of United States air carriers during 1972. The rate of bumping was virtually the same as the year before, slightly more than 5 passengers out of every 10,000. This represents odds of about 2,000to1, but that doesn't make the 83,000 people who were left holding their flight bags in crowded airports any happier.

title: Cambodia's No. 3 City Mirrors Colonialism
description: Kompong Cham, once the rubber capital of Cambodia, is important to both sides in the Cambodian conflict more for psychological and political reasons than for any economic or strategic considerations.

title: Heart Patient in Britain Dies
description: LONDON, Sept. 8 (UPI)surgeonsperformed Britain's first heart transplant operation in four years on a 56yearold. man at Uxbridge, near London,. today. A hospital spokesman said that the man died a short time later.

title: Chess: When Compatriots Meet Over ?? Board, All Bets Are Off
description: When countryman meets fellow countryman over the board, the outcome cannot be predicted, unless you know the antagonists. In the second Interzonal, in Petropolis, Brazil, the game between the two Yugoslav entrants, Ljuhomir Ljubojevic and Borislav Ivkov, ended in the quickest of quick draws.

title: Letters: Are Budget Motels Fire Traps?
description: To the Editor:

title: Dorothy C. Twining Is Bride Of Stephen Globus in Suburb
description: OLD LYME, Conn., Sept. 8 Miss Dorothy Crawford Twining and Stephen Edward Globus were married here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Kinsley Twining. Mr. Globus is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Globus of New York and Point pleasant, Pa.

title: Mobile Art Display Is Goin gon View
description: UNIONThe Magic Muse, a mobile art environment sponsored by the Association for the Arts of the New Jersey State Museum, will be on view at Newark State College from Thursday through Oct. 5.

title: Beware of Soviet horse traders bearing gold
description: On July 3, 1972, two and onehalf weeks after the Watergate burglary and four months after the ITT scandal had broken into print, Bernard Steinweg of the Continental Grain Company called on Carroll G. Brunthaver, the Assistant Secretary of Agriculture.

title: Before a Concert, the Hollywood Bowl Is Brimming With Food
description: LOS ANGELESThe host, smiling and wearing a camel's hair blazer, deftly transferred the long fresh asparagus from the copper skillet onto pink Spode china. Breasts of chicken Nigoise, simmering in another skillet, soon followed.

title: Indians Backed on Long Hair
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 8 (AP) The Oklahoma Human Rights Commission issued a policy statement this week defending the right of American Indians to wear their hair long while attending public schools. The commission called for the abolition of school dress codes relating to hair length.

title: Mailbox: Tennis Crowds
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: The Press and the Courts
description: The press has been severely criticized lately for publishing news that Vice President Agnew was being investigated by a Baltimore grand jury on charges of criminal action, and that John Ehrlichman had been indicted by a Los Angeles grand jury in connection with the burglarizing of Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist's office.

title: Parley of Nonaligned Nations ls Extended a Day
description: ALGIERS, Sept. 8The developing nations of the world sought today to put some teeth into three days of speechmaking in favor of their political and economic independence from the industrialized countries.

title: Mrs. Court Hailed Again As Queen of the Courts
description: She may be the greatest of all time.

title: Melissa B. Lardner Married To John R. Gordon in Boston
description: BOSTON, Sept. 8  Miss Melissa Bedford Lardner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lynford Lardner Jr. of Milwaukee, was married here this afternoon in Emmanuel Episcopal Church, to John Rousmaniere Gordon, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Hamilton Gordon of New York. The Rev. John A. Greely performed the ceremony.

title: Skylab
description: Now that things are going well with Skylab 2 and its three astronauts, the time is ripe to look at Skylab's scientific ledger. How well is America's first baby space station performing in terms of scientific achievement?

title: The Young Tennis Turks: Formulas for Success
description: They're out now, the young Turks of tennis, but they made their mark on this year's United States Open, nevertheless. Bouning headlong into a promising future, their path is strewn with the likes of Arthur Ashe, Rod Laver, Ilie Nastase, Tom Okker, Manuel Orantes, Pierre Barthes and Roger Taylor, all upset victims.

title: Adhesive Off Banned List
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) The Consumer Product Safety Commission says that one size of one brand of spray adhesive has been removed from its banned list. The product is the 15ounce size of Tri Chem Spray Mist Adhesive manufactured by the Minnesota Mining & Manufacturing Company.

title: Music
description: THE piece I wrote on instant analysis a few weeks ago evoked an unusually large amount of mail. Some of it was hate mail: You lackey of the Eastern Liberal Establishment Press, you. Some of it was honest bewilderment that politics or sociology should creep into the column of a music critic. (As if music was not a sociological or political phenomenon, from the days when cavemen rattled bones in response to a rhythmic urge, or when music was used to push warriors to greater heroic effort. See the Bible.) Some of the mail was filled with indignation, a representative example being the letter from Newcomb H. Grande of Chicago, published on this page last week.

title: Gabrielle Daniels Wed to G. L. Gibson
description: HALLOWELL, Me., Sept. 8 Miss Gabrielle Daniels, daughter of Orrin Potter Daniels of Pasadena and Dana Point, Calif., was married here this afternoon to George Langdon Gibson, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Warner Gibson of New York and Hallowell. The Rev. Charles Karsten performed the Episcopal ceremony in the garden at the home of Mrs. Langdon Marvin, grandmother of the bridegroom.

title: Clouts Help Astros Beat Giants, 97
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 8 (AP)Jim Wynn belted a tworun homer and Cesar Cedeno also connected in a fifthinning surge that carried the Houston Astros to a 97 victory over the San Francisco Giants today. The Giants' seven game winning streak was snapped.

title: That Harvest Moon
description: By the almanac, Wednesday's full moon is the Harvest Moon, the nearest one to the autumnal equinox. But that is the mathematician's logic, and a countryman calls it nonsense. The rural Harvest Moon can't occur until midmonth at earliest. So here is another item for those who would insist that the seasons are out of joint and responsible for our tempestuous and troubled weather.

title: U.S. Soccer Team Puts Its Best Feet Forward
description: Victors by 10 over Poland three weeks ago, the United States national soccer team will take on Bermuda in an exhibition match at Dillon Stadium in Hartford today at 4 P.M. Eugene Chysowych, the coach, has selected 15 players for the match, most of them from the East Coast.

title: Rutgers Eleven to Key Its Offense on Jennings; Wagner Rated Strong
description: Each of the New York metropolitan area colleges that is trying to sustain an intercollegiate football team is struggling to keep it alive because of the financial problems involved.

title: Westchester Show Today Draws 2,614
description: Lyndhurst, a historic landmark in Tarrytown, N.Y., is the site today for a historic dog showWestchester's 56th. Starting at 8 A.M., when the first of 211 Great Danes and 57 boxers are called to their rings, the judging will continue until 7 P.M., when Graham Head of Australia selects the best of the 2,614 dogs. Dogs The 67  acre estate, located on Route 9, a quartermile south of the interchange of the Thruway at the Tappan Zee Bridge, is one of 12 properties owned and maintained by the National Trust for the Historic Preservation in the

title: New and Recommended
description: FICTION

title: What's Doing In VERMONT
description: 251 CLUB  There are 251 cities and towns in Vermont and a club with a membership dedicated to visiting each one. You become a member simply by sending your name and address and the $1 annual membership fee (payable to the 251 Club) to Mrs. Liiiias M. Bailey, 1 Baldwin Street, Montpelier, Vt. 05602. You also have to state that you really want to achieve the club objectives to visit all 251 towns. Some are accessible only at this time of year, being closed by snow in winter and mud in the spring.

title: NEW MENTAL AID FOR YOUTHS DUE
description: Plans to establish at five city hospitals mental health programs for seriously disturbed children and adolescents who pass through the Family Court have been announced by Dr. June J. Christmas, Commissioner of Mental Health and Mental Retardation.

title: Miss Colorado Named Miss America
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 8Rebecca Ann King, a 23yearold Colorado farmer's daughter who wants to become a judge, was selected as the 1974 Miss America tonight, winning over nine other finalists in the annual beauty pageant here.

title: Greenhouse Tuneup Time For Winter Growing And Flowering
description: AGREENHOUSE properly prepared for winter will have minimum maintenance problems. Plant casualties from diseases and insects will be reduced.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: New Dimensions for Trade Talks
description: This week in Tokyo, Ministers from some 80 to 100 countries will meet to launch a new round of trade negotiations, one of the key objectives of the President's Aug. 15, 1971, initiatives.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: POPULAR QUESTION

title: L.I. Lectures on Rape Attracting Women's Groups
description: MINEOLA, L. I.  Two Nassau County policewomen have been popular speakers on the county's lecture circuit. Their subject is the prevention of rape and other sex crimes.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  Although there is no reason to doubt the aura of progress that surrounds the negotiations in the Committee of 20 for a reformed world monetary system, both United States and foreign officials are frank to concede that probably the toughest problem of all has not been solved.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Baseball

title: A Fantastic Talent Maturing Within a Time Pocket
description: A PAGEbypage progression through the 225 chronologically arranged plates of paintings and drawings in Rudolf Leopold's monumental new book, Egon Schiele, creates an extraordinary impression of a fantastic talent maturing within a time pocket. Schiele was born in 1890, which means within three or four years of Chagall, Mir, and Schiele's onetime colleague, Kokoschka  three vigorously productive living monuments in the history of modern art. But Schiele died 55 years ago next month, on Oct. 31, 1918, at the age of 28, and it is somehow impossible to imagine him as a grand old man. His life work, in spite of his early death, seems rounded off rather than cut short.

title: TROOPERS REGAIN UNMARKED CARS
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 8After a twoyear hiatus, Connecticut state troopers will resume patrolling the highways in unmarked cars on Monday.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: WITH the Labor Day pole passed, the nation's economy has entered the home stretch of the year in high gearstill barreling along too fast and too recklessly. Now it faces some very difficult footing in the remaining months of 1973 and probably into the early part of next year.

title: In Crops, a HighStakes Numbers Game
description: WASHINGTON  As the most closely watched crops in the gyration's peacetime history near harvest time, a commodities numbers game with incredibly high stakes is being played by governments around the world.

title: JOHN CONRAD CATTUS
description: BAY HEAD, N .J., Sept. 8John Conrad Cattus, a retired New York stockbroker, died yesterday at his home here. He was 81 years old and also lived in Montclair.

title: Holy Cross Tops UMass By 30 to 28
description: AMHERST, Mass., Sept. 8 (UPI)Pete Vaas threw two touchdown passes to Tom Rock and ran for a third score today to pace Holy Cross from a 130 deficit to a 3028 victory over Massachusetts.

title: News of the Screen
description: Richard Dreyfuss, who surprised his high school classmates in American Graffiti by going off to college at the end of the film, is now surprising himself in real life. The 25yearold actor will receive star billing in his next movie. The Apprenticeship of Duddy Kravitz.

title: A. F. Freihofer Weds Anne F. Blanchard
description: CONVENT STATION. N.J., Sept. 8  The marriage of Miss Anne Forbes Blanchard to Albert F. Freihofer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Freihofer of Troy, N. Y., took place here this afternoon. The Rev. John Miller of the Presbyterian Church in Morristown performed the garden ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Blanchard.

title: Where Wurst Is His Best
description: UNION  The homemade wursts of differing shapes and hues (about 60 varieties in all) that hang from high stainlesssteel racks the entire length of Gaiser's food store are a culinary sight to behold. But even more impressive in this Morris Avenue establishment are the sparkling walls, counters, shelves and floors, both in the shop itself and in the huge cooking and meatsmoking areas in the back.

title: Boy Spraying Graffiti Is Killed Under an IND Train in Queens
description: A 15yearold Brooklyn boy on a graffitispraying expedition with two friends was killed Friday night beneath a subway train on which he had been drawing in a Queens subway station, the police reported.

title: Clemson 1412 Victor
description: CLEMSON, S. C., Sept. 8 (UPI)Smiley Sanders and Ken Pengitore ran for firsthalf touchdowns today to send Clemson to a 1412 triumph over the Citadel.

title: Saddle River Park Opens a Bike Path
description: FAIR LAWN  The new 1mile bicycle and pedestrian path in Saddle River County Park is paved and ready for use, according to Otto C. Pehle, president of the Bergen County Park Commission.

title: A Lot Is Riding On Them
description: DETROITThe countdown has begun. At 11:59 P.M. this Friday the United Auto Workers' contract with the Chrysler Corporation will expire. And then the country will have some answers to some important questions:

title: DAVID RUMBOUGH IS MISSING OFF L.I.
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Sept. 8David P. Rumbough, the 24yearold son of Dina Merrill, the actress, and her first husband, Stanley M. Rumbough Jr., the New York industrialist, was reported missing tonight after a boating mishap in Gardiner's Bay off eastern Long Island.

title: Gallup Finds Few Favor Busing for Integration
description: A majority of Americans continue to favor public school integration, but few peopleblack or whitethink that busing is the best way to achieve that goal, the Gallup Poll reported yesterday.

title: Lani Williams Planning Marriage
description: SMALL POINT, Me., Sept. 8Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. H. Sewall Williams of Waitsfield, Vt., and Small Point of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kaiulani Cooper Williams, to Joseph Samuel Lovering Wharton 4th of Jamestown, R. I. He is a son of Mr. Wharton 3d of Bailey's Bay, Bermuda, and Mrs. Richard O. Bierregaard of Mount Kisco, N. Y.

title: Pharmacists Urge Drug Curbs
description: TRENTONThe New Jersey Board of Pharmacy has proposed a controversial regulation that would prevent supermarkets from selling such nonprescription medicstions as cold and allergy remedies and cough syrups.

title: Several of Nixon's Aides Reportedly Heard Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8President Nixon asked the White House to fly one of the Watergate tape recordings to his home in California at midnight on one of the five days that John W. Dean 3d testified before the Senate Watergate committee, Congressional investigators disclosed today.

title: Bridge
description: Perhaps the bestknown and most felicitous product of the great British school of palindromists is: A man, a plan, a canal, Panama, devised by Leigh Mercer. The great British school of bridgeplayers also uses palindromes in a way; it recognizes that at times it's best to proceed backwards instead of forwards.

title: A Quiet and Grim Ali Meets Norton at Crossroads Tomorrow
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Sept. 8  At crossroads in his career for the first Muhammad All will oppose Ken Norton The Forum here Monday night in a round heavyweight bout. Never before Ali, who suffered the ultimate irony being silenced by a broken jaw in losing 12round split decision to Norton in Diego on March 31, been confronted such a crisis. If he wins impressively, charisma will be restored, his hopes challenging George Foreman for the world title will be nurtured. If he loses, he might retire.

title: U.S. AIDES LEAVE FOR TRADE TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8  A 20member delegation headed by Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz and William D. Eberle, a White House representative, left today for a round of trade negotiations in Tokyo that President Nixon said he believed can lay the foundation for an improved world economic order.

title: Days of Sadness, Years of Triumph
description: How challenging and perceptive Geoffrey Perrett's ambitious study of America at war will seem to his; fellow countrymen, I can't tell. I can only report on it as a European who has grown up with the fact of American dominance, and with the delusion that the United States is familiar ground.

title: Miss Marjorie Alpren Married to Physician
description: The marriage of Miss Marjorie Sharon Aipren, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard E. Alpren of Lawrence, L I., to Dr. Abraham Jelin, a resident in pediatrics at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx, took place here yesterday evening at the Roof of the St. Regis Sheraton. Rabbi Joel Orenstein performed the ceremony.

title: Terror in Moscow
description: Kremlin terror tactics have almost extinguished the visible Soviet dissident movement, but not quite. That became evident last week when three Soviet citizens came publicly to the defense of Academician Andrei D. Sakharov and suggested himvery appropriatelyfor the Nobel Peace Prize.

title: The Faithful Couriers
description: Certain phenomena are associated with Labor Day in New York: residents make a pilgrimage back to the Upper East and West Sides, the tourists desert Midtown and hay fever sufferers suffer more. Another such event, the informal start of New York's mayoral campaign, began punctually last Monday, and most of its rituals were carefully observed.

title: GOVERNOR SEEKS TO AID RAILROADS
description: Governor Rockefeller is putting the spotlight on a littlepublicized feature of his proposed $3.5billion transportation bond issuethe saving of railroad lines from abandonment.

title: The Delight at the End of the Tunnel
description: IF the Eisenhower Memorial Tunnel hadn't opened earlier this year, my family and I might never have seen Georgetown, Colo.a surprisingly lovely (exorcised) ghost town a dozen miles east of the Continental Divide, 46 miles west of Denver and 8,514 feet above sea level.

title: Gardens Bring Back the Butterflies
description: MANY of us can re member a time wher we had little piece of relatively wild undeveloped land around us places where butterflies and bumblebees mingler with drifts of wildflowers in ever. changing colors, textures patterns and forms. Them places may have been along the path to school, by a roadside or a railroad rightofway. They may have been simple plots of vacant land, but they provided a steady source of wonder, especially to children who passed their way.

title: Battle Resumes On School Aid
description: TRENTONThe American Civil Liberties Union and a number of other organizations will seek a contempt citation against the Cahill administration on Tuesday, charging it with deliberately attempting to delay the full impact of a Federal Court decision striking down state aid to private and parochial schools.

title: City's First Auxiliary Mounted Policemen Will Help Patrol Parks
description: The city swore In a posse of civilians on horseback yesterday to help patrol the parks.

title: Hoosier 100 Rained Out
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 8 (UPI)The $60,000 Hoosier 100 United States Auto Club championship dirt track auto race was postponed today for one week because of rain. The annual race over the State Fairgrounds onemile oval was rescheduled for 11 A.M. next Saturday.

title: Who Makes Music and where
description: NEW YORK CITY OPERA

title: N.C. State Is 57.8 Victor
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Sept. 8 (AP)  Bruce Shaw scored one touchdown and passed for one as North Carolina State routed East Carolina, 57.8, tonight.

title: A surprisingly gentle confrontation
description: Early in 1971 Erik H. Erikson, probably the foremost psychological theorist of our time, was booked for a series of confrontations with Huey P. Newton, the Black Panther chief. First they were to meet (assisted by a few seconds and surrounded by a group of invited students) in a library at Yale University, where obviously Dr. Erikson would have the homecourt advantage. Then the scene would shift to Mr. Newton's turf for two meetings in his Oakland apartment. What the promoters of these bouts expected was, as Erikson puts it, a spectacle in which Huey was going to be aggressive and I was going to be psychoanalytic and the sparks would fly.

title: Sleeper Floats a Mile
description: NANTUCKET, Mass., Sept. 8 (UPI)  Kathy Manderson feil asleep and was awakened a mile later. Miss Manderson, 18 years old, of Groton, went to the beach yesterday and was floating peacefully in a rubber raft a few yards off shore when she dozed off. The raft, helped along by the wind, drifted out to sea. Her mother alerted the authorities and tht United States Coast Guard sent out a helicopter, which found her, still asleep, a mile out to sea.

title: Orr Is Married
description: PARRY SOUND, Ontario, Sept. 8 (AP)Bobby Orr, 25yearold star defenseman of the Boston Bruins, was married tonight to Margaret Louise Wood, 26, of Detroit.

title: How to Win a Bet by Picking Losers: Bankroll Gives Syndicates Big Edge
Gov. Sargent Seeks Rise in Food Output In Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, Sept. 8  In the spirit of World War victory gardens, Gov. Francis W. Sargent has established a commission that will study Massachusetts food production with a goal of bringing stategrown products to consumers here at lower prices.

title: City Is Eying Sheepshead Bay
description: Picturesque Sheepshead Bay, with its ramshackle atmosphere, its dirt and its smells, has vanished from the earth. In its place lies a new Sheepshead Bay, clean, tidy, practically odorless  a modern symphony of simple and orderly safety. The Brooklyn Eagle, Aug. 21, 1937.

title: Company Says It Aids Agnew Inquiry
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 8  Ai spokesman for the J. E. Greiner Engineering Company, a Maryland consulting concern, said today that is was cooperating fully with the government investigators who are checking into Vice President Agnew, and that it is confident that it will not be found culpable in the inquiry.

title: Scofield Film on N.B.C.
description: The National Broadcasting Company will repeat this afternoon, at 1:30, its presentation of Fred Zinnemann's A Man for All Seasons. Brilliantly starring Paul Scofield as Sir Thomas More, the film version of Robert Bolt's play was shown on the network last Wednesday evening, and the result was 2 hours and 15 minutes of exceptionally fine television.

title: Miss Linda Gilbert Knox Is Bride
description: EAST AURORA, N.Y., Sept. 8Miss Linda Gilbert Knox, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Northrup R. Knox, was married here today in St. Matthias Episcopal Church to Arthur Albert Schmon 2d, son of Mrs. Hugh B. Mitchell of Jordan Station, Ontario, and Robert M. Schmon of NiagaraontheLake, Ontario.

title: Northern Officials Reluctant to Alter Standards on Fuel
description: Environmental officials in New York City, New Jersey and Connecticut said yesterday that their jurisdictions would be opposed to altering existing pollution standards to allow the use of highsulphurcontent fuels, as suggested by President Nixon yesterday.

title: Will L.I. Potato Be Uprooted?
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I.  If agriculture is to survive on Long Island, the industry's future will not be rooted in potatoes.

title: CRIME MAIN ISSUE IN DETROIT'S RACE
description: DETROIT, Sept. 8The big topics in this city this week have been the dismissal of Billy Martin as manager of the Tigers, the end of the heat wave, the school teachers' strike and the auto talks.

title: Draft Turns Scouts Into Reporters
description: VALLEJO, Calif., Sept. 8 (UPI)Most of the people in the stands at a recent amateur baseball tournament here were friends and relatives, but Charlie Wallgren, with a little black book in hand, had more than a casual interest in the athletes.

title: Lime Rock Card to Be Seminar of Sorts
description: There will be a scientific gathering of sorts at Lime Rock, Conn., next Saturdaya roaring seminar on propulsion, velocity and speed. Among the participants will be physicists, electronic and automotive engineers as well as experts from various nonallied fields. The gathering will be the racing program of the International Motor Sports Association at Lime Rock Park. The seminars are properly known ea the Camel GT challenge series, which will have two sessions, and the Goodrich Radial challenge event.

description: Four open City Council committee meetings will be held this week, all by the Special Committee on Reapportionment, to consider the redistricting of the City Council. The schedule follows:

title: Bengals Beat Backers, 1310
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 8 (AP) Horst Mulhmann's 31yard field goal with three seconds remaining lifted the Cincinnati Bengals to a 1310 preseason victory over the Green Bay Packers tonight.

description: Anne SidamonEristoff has been appointed chief of the environmental protection unit of the United States Attorney's office here, Paul J. Curran, United States Attorney for the Southern District, announced yesterday.

title: ...Except To Constant Vigilance
description: WASHINGTONTo most Americans, the outbreak of cholera in Italy seems as alien as some medieval plague. The dread disease has been virtually unknown in this country for decades. But cholera is by no means a thing of the past. In fact, the world is in the midst of a pandemican epidemic of global proportionsand this is the seventh in the last Um ??.

title: Two Chileans Ask Asylum
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 8 (UPI)Two Chilean fishermen who fled their nation's Marxist regime arrived here aboard a tuna clipper this week and asked the United States Immigration Department yesterday for political asylum.

description: BOSTON, Sept. 8 (AP)Vietnam veterans could attend summer and evening classes without cost at Massachusetts comunity colleges under a bill that received initial approval Thursday in the State Senate.

description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 8 (AP)Larry Hisle drove in three runs on three hits and Dave Goltz scattered nine hits in seven innings today in Minnesota's 62 victory over the Chicago White Sox. The loss stopped Chicago's winning streak at eight games.

title: Old Rail Line Is a Lifeline for Stricken SubSahara
description: DAKAR, SenegalThe bananas, the bananas, Mrs. Fatu Traore called out from the window of a secondclass railroad car at the rural station in Kati, Mali. How much are they?

description: ALLENHURSTFishermen are casting once again from the rock jetty in front of the Allenhurst Beach Ciub and the legal skirmish that won their right to return could set the pattern for future battles aimed at providing greater public access to the ocean.

title: Hofstra Is 490 Loser To Lehigh
description: HEMPSTEAD, Sept. 8Scoring the first three times they had the ball, Lehigh University tolled up a 21to0 firstquarter lead and registered a 49to0 victory over Hofstra at the loser's field today.

description: The city's Housing and Development Administration awarded a major housing maintenance contract to a realestate company recently while allegations were pending before the agency that the company had seriously harassed tenants at two Manhattan buildings.

title: Catholic Schools Finding Ways to Survive
description: CHICAGO  About 10,000 Roman Catholic parochial schools across the country began opening their doors last week for the new school year, the first since the Supreme Court invalidated numerous forms of public financial aid to nonpublic schools. And it was quickly apparent that many of the parochial systems were significantly different from the ones that closed for the summer.

description: Burt DeBaun, who owns a farmequipment store in Osage City, Kans., about 35 miles south of Topeka, declared last week:

title: E. H. Birkenhauer Marries Miss Murray
description: SPRING LAKE, N.J., Sept. 8In St. Catherine's Roman Catholic Church here this afternoon, Miss Mary Anne Murray, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Murray, was married to Edward Harvey Birkenhauer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin C. Birkenhauer Jr. of Marysville, Ohio. The ceremony was performed by Msgr. John Grimes, assisted by the Rev. Joseph Vaskas of Chicago.

The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Borden Painter, assisted by the Rev. James F. Martin. A reception was held in the Edward S. Harkness Memorial Hall at Yale University.

title: Virginia Tops V.M.I., 160
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. Sept. 8 (UPI)  Raymond Keys ran 24 yards for one touchdown and Scott Gardner passed 8 yards for another as the University of Virginia defeated Virginia Military Institute, 160, today, in the opening football game for both teams.

description: HAMMONDSPORT, N.Y., Sept. 8  Miss Susan Martha Schroeder, daughter of C. Frederic Schroeder, managing direcor of the Pleasant Valle!. Wine Company (Great Western Wine Company), and Mrs. Schroeder of Hammondsport, was married here this afternoon to William Milford Bethke, an assistant vice president and securities analyst with the investment banking firm of Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis, Inc., in New York.

title: Mrs. Ryan Is Wed To W. G. Curtis 4th
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 8Mrs. Lynn Ryan and William G. Curtis 4th of New York, were married here this afternoon in the Round Hill Community Church by the Rev. Arthur C. Miller.

title: Douglas Leaves Hospital For Retreat in Mountains
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 8 (AP)Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas left University of Washington Hospital in Seattle today to return to his Goose Prairie, Wash., retreat in the Cascade Mountains.

title: Hypothesis: We need science also as a conscience
description: With the publication of Candle in the Wind, almost the full body of Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn's major work is now available in English translation. Only his long epic poem, The Feast of Victors, a savage diatribe composed while he was a Zek (a hardregime prisoner at the Ekibastuz labor camp in 1951 or thereabouts), has not yet seen the light of day. Nor is Feast likely soon to be published. It has been repudiated by its author as immature, biased and not meeting his literary and philosophical standards. He has bitterly protested its circulation in samizdat, or typescript, by agents of the K.G.B.contending that this has been done deliberately to slander him.

title: Best Seller List
description: This analysis is based on reports obtained from more than 250 bookstores in 110 communities of the United States. The figures in the righthand column do not necessarily represent consecutive appearances.

title: An oenophile's approach to economics
description: I descended into my wine cellar a few weeks ago and calmly selected two bottles of red Bordeaux worth $125 each for a rather special dinner party. I had bought them for $12 apiece several years earlier, knowing they would appreciate. Wine is the world's most precious consumable commodity and, unlike the stock market, it always goes up. But I was dumbfounded when I looked up the price of those two fine specimens of Chateau Latour 1953 in a trade compendium lent me by a local wine merchant. It quoted the Latour 53 at $125 retail.

title: Big Overtime Debt Of Postal Service Will Be Paid Soon
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) The Postal Service is expected this month to begin paying a multimilliondollar debt owed to more than 500,000 present and former employes on the winning side of a court battle over overtime pay.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The stock market, as many have observed, is a multitier affair. At the upper tier are a few stocks, perhaps 50 to 75, selling at 25 to 55 times their most recent 12 months' earnings.

title: German Pointer Is Best At Somerset Hills Show
description: FAR HILLS, N. J., Sept 8 Traveler, a German shorthaired pointer, defeated 2,059 other canines for the bestinshow honors at the Somerset Hills Kennel Club's 39th dog show tonight. Ch. Gretchenof Columbia River, a 4yearold, is owned by Dr. Richard P. Smith, of Hayward, Calif., an anesthesiologist, and was bred by his handler, Joyce Shellenbarger of Costa Mesa, Calif., who has had the breed for 20 years.

title: Next Saturday's College Football
description: EAST

title: John Ford 18951973
description: JOHN FORD lived for 78 years. He directed movies during six decades of American filmmaking. And he died a few days ago, full of honor and official admiration. For younger audiences, he may almost have to be saved from his admirers; how do you praise the favorite filmmaker of the Nixon Administration? For such audiences, coming to Ford at this stage may be a shock to their expectations. It is like discovering that the Poet Laureate actually wrote great poetry.

title: Montreal Mansion Falls To Wreckers' Hammers
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 8 (UPI) Van Horne mansion, former home of the late president of Canadian Pacific Railway, fell to wreckers' hammers today, after a protracted battle by citizens groups to save the landmark.

title: SEVENTH AVE.
description: American manufacturers and retailers who rushed to the Far East to scoop up apparel produced by lowwage labor are rushing back to the United States these days.

title: MORE VICTIMS FALL TO CHOLERA IN ITALY
description: ROME, Sept. 8 (Reuters)Two more people died of cholera today in Naples, where the disease first broke out in Italy, bringing the overall toll to 23.

title: Queens Family Court Aided by Protestant Clergymen Counselors
description: A distraught teenage girl appeared recently in the basement doorway entrance of the Protestant Counseling Service in the Family Court in Jamaica, Queens, and confronted the Rev. Charles Fisher.

title: Other Papers Sell in St. Louis Strike
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 8Newspaperhungry St. Louisans were planning how to get one of the limited number of outoftown Sunday papers expected to filter into this city as the local newspaper strike was in its third week.

title: City to Ask U.S. Aid for Neighborhood War on Crime
News of the Realty Trade
description: The Philippine Government is negotiating for the purchase of the sevenstory building at 556 Fifth Avenue, between 45th and 46th Streets.

title: The Honorary Consul By Graham Greene. 315 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $7.95.
description: Graham Greene is nearly 70. He was born in 1904 and is, as he says in one of these books, at the end of what should be the last decade of my life. I call attention to the fact not only because he has done soin that statement and in the majestic collected edition of his works now appearing in Englandbut because the fact is shocking in a revealing way.

title: Navigating The Rapids
description: Adolf Augustus Berle was a lifelong prodigy; a manyfaceted genius who, in Max Ascoli's words, skipped both adolescence and senility. For most of half a century until his death in 1971 he occupied a unique position on the inner fringe of American public life, powerfully influencing both the domestic and foreign policy of every Democratic Administration from Roosevelt through Lyndon Johnson. An acerbic, intense, arrogant man of small stature and immense vanity, he cultivated enemies almost as easily as friends. That was one reason, certainly, why he never quite made it to the inner sanctum of Presidential power, a fact that bothered him somewhat throughout his later years. The only rung he ever occupied on the executive ladder (from 1938 to 1944) was that of Assistant Secretary of State. But a score of statesmen, politicians and scholars here and abroad found his genius almost indispensable to their designs, and they sedulously courted his favor through four stormy decades of recent history.

title: Magazine Is Discontinued
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Sept. 8 (UPI)The Burlington Free Press, the largest newspaper in Vermont, announced today that Focus, its weekly supplemental magazine, would be temporarily discontinued until, the end of the current newsprint shortage.

title: Centennial Tribute for Max Reinhardt
description: Everyone adored Max, he was like a king.

title: It Looks Like That Old Jack Magic Is Gone
description: HAS tension mounted you? No? Why not? After all, school starts this week, which means  since our two great institutional babysitters operate in tandemthat the TV season is also about to start. Alas, up here in the woods where I live, among the eternal verities of the moon and the mosquito, we aren't lucky enough to have had an advance peek at the new fall programs. Our minds are on the past.

title: Isabella Kinney Is Wed in Maine To S. D. Keating
description: BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 8 Miss Isabella Alice Kinney, daughter of the president of General Mills, and Stephen Davis Keating, son of the president of Honeywell, Inc., both with headquarters in Minneapolis; were married here this afternoon in the Congregational Church by the Rev. William P. Booth.

title: Policer Officer Revives a Baby Feared Drowned
description: Using mouthtomouth resuscitation, a police officer in Brooklyn yesterday saved the life of a 16monthold boy whose mother had left him and alone briefly in a bathtub returned to find him submerged and apparently drowned.

title: Future Social Events
description: Sept. 12Many savants steeped in theatrical lore are of the opinion that it is time for Anne Jackson and Eli Wallach to take their place in the revered company of married theatrical greatsSothern and Marlowe, Lunt and Fontanne, et al. So, after the twain appear in the revival of Jean Anouilh's Waltz of the Toreadors, which opens the fall season of the Circle in the SquareJoseph E. Levine Theater, they will be honored at the Pub Theatrical Restaurant (they're adjacent) for their 25 years of contributing to the American theater. All the people you know and love to hear about will be there. You still might be able to squeeze in. The $50 ticket includes the play and party and also aids the nonprofit Circle in the Square.

title: Tigers Win As Coleman Posts 19th
description: BOSTON, Sept. 8 (AP) Dick Sharon and Frank Howard hit home runs and Joe Coleman gained his 19th victory today in the Detroit Tigers' 61 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

title: Lack of Evidence Is Cited by Judge In Wolf Poisoning
description: A Criminal Court Judge in Brooklyn has determined that there was insufficient evidence to hold a 70yearold woman on charges of poisoning two wolves on July 29.

title: Astronomy Course for Adults
description: CRANFORDWhat's Out There?  An Introduction to Astronomy, an eightweek course for adults, will be offered for the seventh consecutive year at the William Hiller Sperry Observatory on the Cranford campus of Union College.

title: Hoofbeats in the High Alpujarrasthe Attic of Spain
description: THE mist descended suddenly, as fine as an Aerosol spray, muffling the sound of our horses' hooves as we threaded along the lonely mountain track. A few minutes earlier we had dismounted to keep warm and now we led our horses in a ghostly file toward 10,000foot Wolf Pass, high in the Alpujarras, in southern Spain. Somewhere ahead a Spanish guide was waiting to lead us down to the valley on the other sidethat is, if we could find him.

title: Anne Hemphill Is Bride Of Matthew J. Fischer
description: RUMSON, N. J., Sept. 8Miss Anne Tripp Hemphill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julian Hemphill, was married here this afternoon to Matthew John Fischer, son of Dr. and Mrs. Walter William Fischer of Pelham Manor, N. Y. The Rev. William J. Kokoszka performed the ceremony in Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church.

title: Health Insurance
description: WASHINGTON  The philosophical position of the Nixon Administration toward health care is that Federal funds should not be used to underwrite the medical expenses of those who can afford to pay their own way, a line Of reasoning used in, the 1930's by opponents of the original Social Security Act which set up retirement benefits. Like the old tale of the grasshopper and the ant, conservatives argue that the prudent can look after themselves in illness or old age, do not need Federal help and should not be dunned for the improvidence of others.

title: Campaign Finance Law
description: BOSTON, Sept. 8 (AP)  A bill requiring candidates for local offices to file campaign finance reports with the state secretary was signed into law this week by Gov. Francis W. Sargent.

title: Cape Cod Worried By Growth RunAmuck
description: BARNSTABLE, Mass.How to control Cape Cod's runaway homebuilding boom?have reservoir capacity. We can't conceivably pipe water onto the Cape. Besides the possibility of running out, there's the risk of spoiling what's left, of having brackish water.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: Re Philip Kurland's review of Raoul Berger's Impeachment, the Constitutional Problem, may I remind you that it is unrealistic (in view of his recent television utterances) to imagirie that Richard Nixon will leave the Presidency by resignation. It is just as unrealisticas Kurland suggests  to believe that he would abide by a motion of the Joint Houses of Congress (a mere majority of those present and voting) when he can take refuge in a refusal by just over a third of the Senate to find him guilty.

title: FIGHTING INCREASES IN SOUTH VIETNAM
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 8 (UPI)Fighting flared in South Vietnam's Central Highlands today, and combat action throughout the nation was reported to have increased in the last few days.

title: Phillies Beaten, 5.3
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8 (AP)Consecutive doubles by Dave Cash, Al Oliver and Willie Stargell scored three Pittsburgh runs in the sixth inning tonight and the Pirates went on to defeat the Philadelphia Phillies, 53.

title: Somebody Up There Likes Me
description: I HAVE had a good many agents. More agents than jobs, is one way of looking at it. My first agency was the Music Corporation of America. Don't it roll off your tongue? Lee Strasberg's wife Paula (who died a few years ago) had written a kind and flattering note about me to the lady at MCA who was then handling the Strasbergs' daughter Susan, and who agreed to handle me.

title: Help for the Consumer Is Intensified
description: NEWARK  Almost 100 county and municipal consumer agencies are currently operating throughout New Jersey, partly as the result of state efforts to relieve the loacion its Division of Consumer Affairs and partly because of the public's growing awareness of its rights in the marketplace.

title: Ortega and the New Art
description: JOSE ORTEGA Y GASSET'S oncefamous essay on The Dehumanization of Art is one of those texts that ought to be reread at least once a year by everyone seriously concerned with the vicissitudes of contemporary art. It isn't a particularly happy text, yet it defines certain issuesthe issues that tend to recur every season in discussions of new artwith an almost surgical precision. It reminds us, above all, that these issues have a history that transcends whatever shortterm trends a new season is likely to bring.

title: North Korean Capital Gets Centrally Controlled Trains
description: TOKYO, Sept 8 (AP)  A subway, automated and centrally controlled, has been opened in the North Korean capital of Pyongyang, the Korean Central News Agency reported.

title: Labor Unit Reelects Abel
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 8 (UPI)I. W. Abel, president of the United Steelworkers of America, was reelected today to his fourth twoyear term as head of the Industrial Union Department of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations. The department is made up of 56 unions with a total of about six million members. Jacob Clayman, previously the administrator of the department, was elected to the newly established office of secretarytreasurer.

description: The Bridge

description: KANSAS CITY, Sept. 8 (UPI)Mickey Rivers drove in the tiebreaking run in a threerun sixth inning tonight, leading the California Angels to a 43 victory over the Kansas City Royals and a sweep of their doubleheader.

description: TODAY

title: Folk Dancers Await a Party
description: BERNARDSVILLE  Jessie MacWilliams will be up early next Saturday morning to sweep out the garage and cut the grass surrounding the swimming pool at her home on Dryden Road.

title: Jean Renoir
description: By Andr Bazin. Edited by Franois Truffaut. Translated from the French by W.W. Halsey II and William H. Simon. Illustrated. 320 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $10.

title: R. A. Westin Weds Judith A. Parker
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8Miss Judith Armistead Parker, daughter of Mrs. Jameson Parker and the late Mr. Parker, was married here at noon today to Richard Axel Westin, son of Gosta Westin, Swedish Consul in New York and Mrs. Westin of Norrkoping, Sweden.

title: U.S. Defends Its Ending of PupilTesting Grant Here
description: The United States Office of Education yesterday defended its decision to revoke nearly $1million in grants to a Brooklyn school district for refusing to administer Federal math and reading tests to pupils in two of its elementary schools.

title: Cancer Kills Baby Whale In Niagara Falls Aquarium
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Sept. 8 (AP)The Aquarium of Niagara Falls disclosed today that its baby pilot whale had died of cancer.

title: Lakes Fishermen Fear Ban on Gill Nets
description: CHARLEVOIX, Mich., Sept. 8  A proposed ban on commercial fishing with gill nets in the Michigan waters of the Great Lakes has sparked a battle between the state's commercial fishing industry and the state Department of Natural Resources Commission.

title: MRS. JOSEPH KAUFMAN
description: Mrs, Cecile Haupt Kaufman, who had been associated with Country Agency Real Estate in Westport, Conn., died there yesterday at her home, 47 Sturges Highway. She was 59 years old. Mrs. Kaufman was the wife of Joseph M. Kaufman, a New York lawyer, and the daughter of the late Ira Haupt, a member of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Mary Tayloe Harrison Is Married
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 8In St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Mary Tayloe Harrison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David A. Harrison 3d of Old Brookville and Hopewell, Va., was married to Julian Keevil, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clement Keevil of Herstmonceaux, Sussex, England. The Rev. Howard M. Lowell, the rector, performed the ceremony.

title: Mrs. Astrid Moseley Is Wed In Greenwich to John Talley
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 8.Mrs. Astrid Onstad Moseley of Greenwich and Oslo was married here this afternoon to John Joseph Talley of New York and Port Antonio, Jamaica.

title: Somerset College Gets Home
description: BRANCHBURG TOWNSHIP Somerset County College, which has been operating out of temporary facilities since its inception in 1968, is opening the first of a series of permanent buildings this fall.

title: More Jobs Asked for Inmates
description: TRENTONThe Cahill Administration has called a special conference for Tuesday, the purpose being to hopefully provide more job opportunities for prison inmates in a program designed to expedite their rehabilitation.

title: Deirdre Wagner a Bride
description: Miss Deirdre Moira Wagner, an executive recruiter for the Girl Scouts of America, and James Patrick Campbell, senior accountant with Haskins & Sells, certified public accountants, were married here yesterday afternoon in the Epiphany Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. John Moore. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Leonard B. Wagner of Bricktown, N. J., and the late Mr. Wagner. Her mother is a retired New York schoolteacher. Mr. Campbell is a son of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Campbell of Danbury, Conn., where his father is accountant.

title: Airport Funds for Vermont
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP)The Federal Aviation Administration has awarded Vermont a $337,207 grant for general airport needs. A spokesman for Senator George D. Aiken, Republican of Vermont, said the money would be for the current fiscal year and the state could decide how to spend the funds.

title: BUDDHIST TEMPLE IS BEING RESTORED
description: BOROBUDUR, Indonesia Sept. 8 (AP)The Buddhas o?? Borobudur after at least ?? centuries of patience, are being rescued from the tropical rain that were turning one of Asia' great monuments into a rock pile.

title: Ann Gach Is Married To Robert Peelle Jr.
description: MANHASSET, L. I., Sept. 8In the Congregational Church of Manhasset this afternoon, Miss Ann Christine Gch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Gch of Roslyn Heights, was married to Robert Beatty Peelle Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Peele of Roslyn. The Rev. Raymond A. Fenner performed the ceremony.

title: Group Tries to Save Woodland in Morris
description: MONTVILLE  The Valhalla Basin, 900 acres of unspoiled woodland in this Morris County community, is destined for the same fate as many other wilderness tracts unless conservationists can raise at least $2million.

title: Angus Douglass Marries Carole Baker
description: MOUNTAINVILLE, N. J., Sept, 8Miss Carole Baker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carlyle Baker of Columbus, Ohio, and Ocean Reef, Fla., was married here this afternoon to Angus Stone Douglass, a partner in Asgard Partners, New York investment bankers.

title: Rome Likes TrafficFree Area and Will Enlarge It
description: ROME, Sept. 8A month after a chunk of central Rome was closed to most private traffic, city officials and residents say that the project has been successful.

title: Fairleigh Freshman, 43, To Try the Blanda Act
description: A 43yearold freshman at Fairleigh Dickinson University, who was told to drop football 28 years ago because of a heart murmur, will play football again as a member of the Fairleigh Dickinson team that opens its season Saturday.

title: Nixon and Courts ...But Still On the Defensive
description: WASHINGTONFor weeks, President Nixon has been urging and pleading that the Watergate scandal be removed from under the Klieg lights of a Senatorial hearing room and into the practiced calm of the courtroom; that was the only way, he insisted, his crippled Presidency could be devoted to the other, pressing business of the nation.

title: New Rules Reduce Prices of Gasoline At Many Retailers
description: Motorists found gasoline 1 to 3 cents a gallon cheaper yesterday at many service stations as a result of new Government price controls that have angered retailers.

title: Volvo, U.S.A.
description: The imminent announcement by Volvo, the Swedish auto manufacturer, of plans to build an assembly plant in the United States provides fresh evidence that foreign investment is a twoway streetand one that is mutually beneficial.

title: 3 Firemen Hurt Fighting 3Alarm Brooklyn Blaze
description: Three firemen were injured yesterday fighting a threealarm blaze that engulfed three apartment buildings and left 30 persons homeless in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn.

title: Miss Malone Wed To David Tilney
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., Sept. 8  Miss Mary Teresa Malone and David Williams Tilney were married here this afternoon in St. John's Episcopal Church by the Rev. T. Carleton Lee. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Malone of Lloyds Harbor and Dr. and Mrs. Robert Wallace Tilney Jr. of Far Hills, N. J., and Northeast Harbor, Me.

title: Mrs. Meir Urges End to Red Tape for Immigrants
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 8 (AP)Premier Golda Meir has acknowledged what most Israelis have known a long time: the country is entangled in bureaucratic red tape.

title: Miss Frances E. Reid, Teacher, Married on L.I. to Peter Picoli
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 8St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Frances Elizabeth Reid, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius J. Reid Jr. of Mill Neck, to Peter Picoli, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Picoli Jr. of Upper Brookville. The Rev. Howard M. Lowell performed the ceremony.

title: Deborah Haas Becomes Bride
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Sept. 8  Miss Deborah Haas of Washington and Robert Francis Hussey were married here this morning in the Cathedral of the Incarnation, by the Right Rev. Jonathan Sherman, Episcopal Bishop of Long Island.

title: Home Improvement
description: HOME workshop enthusiasts and amateur furniture builders have three new howto books from which they can choose to improve their knowledge and get additional ideas.

title: Favorita Opens San Francisco Opera
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 8 The San Francisco Opera Company opened its 51st season last night with one of the most elaborately staged productions in its history, Donizetti's La Favorita, which had not previously been performed by Kurt Herbert Adler's company and may never have been presented hereabouts before.

title: A lowrent landmark block
description: Minutes from Manhattan, wedged in between parking lots and warehouses where no one would expect it, stands an unbroken block of handsome 19thcentury brownstones. It's 45th Avenue in Long Island City. Like several architects and an artist or two, designers Harry Schule and John McCarville discovered this tiny oasis while searching for easy commuting and lower rents. Their duplex apartment (a terrible wreck) required patching, plastering, sanding of the floors and most of the basic as well as cosmetic needs of a derelict building. By decorating with paint textured like stucco and installing a new kitchen, the designers completed the renovation for just over $5,000. That figure does not include major furniturewhich has already weathered three successive moves by its owners to new quarters. This move, they claim will be the last.

title: For the Heron Watchers, Stone Harbor Is A Treasure
description: STONE HARBORThis pretty little seashore town has all the amenities that a vacationist might expect to find in a place of its type. There are lovely, unspoiled beaches, a few good seafood restaurants, comfortable summer cottages and motels and excellent fishing.

title: Concern Tied to Agnew Inquiry Got a Major Federal Contract,
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8The General Services Administration, against the advice of another Government agency, awarded a major contract last year to a Baltimore architectural concern that is involved in the investigation of Vice President Agnew in the Federal kickback inquiry.

title: Anaya to Defend Title
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 8 (UPI)Romeo Anaya, of Mexico, the world bantamweight boxing champion, will defend his title against Arnold Taylor of South Africa here Oct. 27, Dave Levin, a promoter, said today.

title: State Plans a Survey of Job Needs for the Future
description: TRENTON  The state's Department of Labor and Industry will begin a survey of 8,000 business concerns later this month in an effort to find out just what kind of jobs will be in demand in the last half of this decade.

title: Ole Miss Sets Back Villanova
description: JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 8 (UPI)Rick Kimbrough set up two touchdowns with long punt returns and scored once on a 26yard pass reception tonight to lift sluggish Mississippi to a 246 victory over Villanova.

title: Old Water Mill on South Fork Being Restored by Women's Auxiliary
description: WATER MILL, L. I. Down by the old mill stream is where the action is this summer, as the ladies' auxiliary of this South Fork community conducts museum tours and sponsors a score of arts and crafts classes ranging from pottery to quilt making, while managing several restoration projects on the Old Water Mill Museum.

title: AMER. SOCCER LEAGUE
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Clurman Hails ParkTraffic Ban

title: Linda D. Kent, Yale Graduate, Has Nuptials
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 8Miss Linda Dingle Kent, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald Tambling Kent of Cleveland Heights, was married here this afternoon to Willard Sands Boothby 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Boothby Jr. of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Coody Wins by a Stroke in England

title: And Still the Borrowing Goes On
description: The Federal Reserve System, actively using the tools of its trade, has shoved interest rates to the highest levels on record, but banks and their customers don't seem to get the message. Business loans, except for a short while in August, have soared.

title: Marcel Retains World Ring Title
description: PANAMA CITY, Sept. 8 (AP)Ernesto Marcel of Panama successfully defended his featherweight world boxing championship with a ninthround knockout of a Japanese chalylenger, Shigemitzu Nemoto, tonight.

title: New &Novel
description: The setting is Laurencelle, a college  without  walls in Vermont, where rich, neurotic youths flirt with mononucleosis, mental breakdown, the Stanislayski method and a little learning. Everything is elective, including human relations. All in all, a tough row to hoe for Jane Potterman, a squarish freshman from Connecticut.

title: The American way of jail
description: We are all the beneficiaries of Jessica Mitford's unconventional (but extraordinarily advantageous) preparation for this book on American prisons.

title: Land Use
description: We have allowed illplanned or unwise development to destroy the beauty and productivity of our American earth.

title: Anthony D'Elia Jr., 70, Is Dead; Architect and ExArmy Officer
description: Anthony D'Elia Jr., an architect who was commandant of Fort Kilmer in New Jersey in 195657, died Thursday of a heart ailment in the West Point (N.Y.) Army Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in New Paltz, N.Y.

title: Par for the course
description: ACROSS

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Britons in the E.E.C.
description: LONDON  In the ninth month of membership in the European Economic Community, the British are, if anything, even more deeply divided than they were before Jan. 1 over whether membership is good, or on present terms, whether it is ever likely to be.

title: Steelers Conquer Falcons
