The inmates missed lunch last Friday and refused to return to their cells, They said that their breakfasts were full of bugs and that one of the prisoners had not received adequate medical treatment for asthma.

title: Woman in L.I.R.R. Bias Case Reassures Crewmen
description: Carol Wagner, the fivefoot teacher whose sexdiscrimination case against the Long Island Rail Road led to a new set of physical requirements for trainmen and engineers, rode the rails yesterday reassuring the men about their jobs.

title: Peking Church Bridal Is the First in Years
description: PEKING, Sept. 9 (Agence FrancePresse)  A French diplomat was married today in the first religious marriage ceremony here since the Cultural Revolution.

title: Norway Completing Entry Into U.S. Cruise Market
description: The arrival yesterday of the new Norwegian cruise liner, Royal Viking Sky, marked the beginning of the end of a recent and, novel chapter in international shippingthe massive incursion of new Scandinavian tonnage into the lucrative American cruise market.

title: Richard Birnbaurn Weds Miss Beckerman
description: The marriage of Miss. Martha Hart Beckerman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Beckerman, to Richard Birnbaum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Birnbaum, took place here yesterday at the Plaza. Kings County Surrogate Nathan R. Sobel performed the ceremony.

title: Bills May Put Outlay Over Nixon Goal
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9Legislation enacted or pending in Congress, together with other factors, could push total Federal Government spending as much as $10billion above President Nixon's target of $268.7billion, according to the latest calculations within the Administration.

title: U.S. Soccer Coach Pulls Switch on Foe and Wins
description: Eugene Chyzowych, coach of the United States national soccer team, made a strategy move late in the game against the national team of Bermuda yesterday, and it paid off as the Americans won 10 at Dillon Stadium in Hartford. It was the Americans' second straight exhibition victory.

title: S. N. Behrman Dies
description: S. N. Behrman, a reigning Broadway playwright for almost 40 years, died yesterday at the age of 80. Mr. Behrman, whose plays were noted for their glittering dialogue and mordant wit, was the author of two dozen comedies, including Jambowsky and the Colonel, Serena Blandish and No Time for Comedy. Page 38.

title: Irving Stirs in Victory
description: The Harlem Professidnal Basketball League title was won yesterday by the West Siders who defeated the. Courtsmen, 135124, at the Mahoney Gym of City College. Julius Irving and Billy Paultz led the winners with 27 and 24 points respectively.

title: PARIS ART DEALER FACING TAX CASE
description: PARIS, Sept. 9Daniel Wildenstein, art dealer, race horse owner and one of the richest men in the world, has been accused of tax fraud by the French Finance Ministry in a case the authorities hope will get French citizens to take their taxes more seriously.

title: Advertising: New McCann Chief
description: Eugene H. Kummel has been named president and chief executive of McCannErickson Worldwide, made up of McCannErickson, Inc., and McCannErickson International, separate entitles since 1934. It is the largest United States agency overseas.

title: No Amnesty for a Lady
description: President Papadopoulos has carried out an impressive amnesty for imprisoned opponents of his authoritarian regime in Greece, What is not yet clear is the extent to which the President's forgiveness will cover those distinguished Greeks who carried on their struggle against Mr. Papadopoulos from abroad, The first known test case is not encouraging: Lady Amelia Fleming, forcibly deported and stripped of her Greek citizenship in 1971, has been barred from feentering the country.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: Horsemeat seems to be selling well in Connecticut these days. A reader in Madison asks how I like it, and notes that he can't find a recipe for it.

title: WARREN PACK, 52, SPORTS COLUMNIST
description: Warren E. Pack, a former sportswriter and handicapper of trotting races for The New York JournalAmerican, died Saturday of leukemia in Doctors Hospital. He was 52 years old and lived at 310 East 70th Street.

title: The Opera: Diva Turns Comedienne
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 9 One sure way to catch an audience's fancy is to have a reigning prima donna turn comedienne. In the hit the San Francisco Opera had with Die Fledermaus on Saturday, Joan Sutherland was a key but prima inter pares factor.

title: Senators Plan to Shorten New Watergate Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9The Senate Watergate committee, apparently frustrated in its crosscountry search for fresh revelations about 1972 campaign sabotage, intends to abbreviate its hearings when they resume later this month.

title: 1,500 Prospective Jurors Due at MitchellStans Trial
description: A panel of 1,500 prospective jurors, the largest in the memory of officials at the United States District Court here, has been summoned for the opening tomorrow of the conspiracy trial of John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans, The Associated Press reported.

title: Health Unit Slates Another Inspection Of Martland Kitchen
description: NEWARK, Sept. 9 (UPI)The Martland Medical Center's kitchen, which was reopened on a conditional basis yesterday after being closed on Friday night because of unsanitary conditions, will undergo another inspection tomorrow, health department officials reported.

title: Superfecta
description: Coming out of the political pressure cooker that is Washington, D. C., it is a welcome relief to spend a day enjoying the serene, stately pace of New York City politics, where four candidates for Mayor, yawning and rubbing their eyes, have sauntered out of the starting gate.

title: Kuwait Sets Inquiry on Gunmen Before Decision to Hold Trial
description: KUWAIT, Sept. 9 (AP)Kuwait will investigate five Arab gunmen before deciding whether to try them for threatening to kill hostages in their fourday attempt to free an imprisoned Palestinian leader.

title: '70 SLAYING SPURS N.A.A.C.P. INQUIRY
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 9The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People in South Carolina has authorized the hiring of a special investigator to look into an unsolved 1970 slaying of a black youth in the Allendale County community of Fairfax.

title: NONALIGNED WARN MAJOR COUNTRIES
description: ALGIERS, Sept. 9A major portion of the underdeveloped world closed a fiveday conference here, today with a warning to the big powers not to make decisions without consulting it, with a condemnation of Israel, but without agreement on relations between the poor world and the two superpowers.

title: Court in Zambia Orders Leader of Sect Released
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Sept. 9A High Court here ordered the release from detention yesterday of Alice Lenshina, leader of the outlawed Lumpa sect, who has been in either detention or restriction for nine years.

title: Struggle Over the White House Tapes Goes to Appeals Court Today
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9The struggle between President Nixon and the Watergate grand jury for possession of the coveted White House tape recordings moves tomorrow onto an uncertain battleground, the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

title: With Her Boas in Tow, Regine of Paris Arrives At a New Jimmy's Here
description: France, or La Belle France as it is fondly referred to by its inhabitants, is never quite so la belle over here as when represented by a sometime redhaired, sometime brunette rounded bundle of vivacity known as Rgine. Rgine was born in Belgium and is of Polish origin but on s'en fiche.

title: Byrne, the Survivor
description: TRENTON, Sept. 9Brendan T. Byrne, the Democratic candidate for Governor, had his first direct encounter with Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., the Republican nominee, last week. The weekend news reports later were predictable.

title: Voting Begins in Norway
description: OLSO, Norway, Sept. 9 (UPI) Norwegians began a twoday election today to decide if the nonSocialist coalition will continue to rule. About 2,7 million voters have 14 parties to select from in electing 515 members of the Parliament.

title: Red Reality Wins Del Mar Handicap
description: DEL MAR, Calif., Sept. 9 (AP)Red Reality captured the $100,000 Del Mar Invitational Handicap today in blanket finish with Wing Out and the favorite Life Cycle.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Quotations from Chairman (Manager) Ralph Houk:

title: Connecticut Village's Rusticity Proves a Lure to New Yorkers
description: WESTON, Conn., Sept, 9Ken Seiden won Vest of show today for his basket of vegetables, while his mother won first prize for her zinnias.

title: Peace Agreement Reached in Tennis
description: Alan Heyman, Danish president of the International Lawn Tennis Federation, said here yesterday that an agreement had been reached with the Association of Tennis Professionals that would prevent a recurrence of this year's boycott of the Wimbledon championships.

title: PARTYGOER HELDIN BRONX SLAYING
description: A 20yearold man was arrested and charged with murder yesterday in the slaying Saturday night of William Pauneto in the East Tremont section of the Bronx.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Boy, 9, Is Star of MillerJohnson Circus
description: A circus that came to town Saturday barely got its wild animals out of their cages, its clowns into their costumes and its aerial acts off the groundthrough no fault of its own.

title: Helaine Kass Is Bride
description: JERICHO, L.I., Sept. 9In the Jericho Jewish Center today, Miss Helaine B. Kass, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jules Kass of Hicksville, was married to Warren H. Tockerman, son of Mr. and Mr. Louis Tockerman of the Bronx. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi David L. Blumenfeld.

title: Woodcock Says Chrysler Feels Pressure by Big 2
description: DETROIT, Sept. 9 (AP).Leonard Woodcock, president of the United Automobile Workers, asserted today that Ford and General Motors were putting pressure on the Chrysler Corporation in the current contract negotiations on key union demands. He said the chances of avoiding an auto industry strike were less hopeful.

title: Mandatory Fuel Allocations Are Advocated by Jackson
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UPI) Senator Henry M. Jackson calling President Nixon's energy policy a mishmash, said today that mandatory allocations of fuel were a must if the nation was to get through the winter without rationing supplies for consumers.

title: Power Outage in Brooklyn
description: Electrical service was cut off for 670 homes in the Mill Basin section of Brooklyn for 45 minutes last evening when a feeder cable was damaged just before 6:30 P.M. The Consolidated Edison Company said the affected area was a 20block stretch from Bergen Avenue to West 56th Street between Avenues T and U.

title: S. N. Behrman Dies
description: S. N. Behrman, a reigning Broadway playwright for almost 40 years, died yesterday at the age of 80. Mr. Behrman, whose plays wore noted for their glittering dialogue and mordant wit, was the author of two dozen comedies, including Jacobowsky and the Colonel, Serena Blandish and No Time for Comedy. Page 38.

title: Player Triumphs In Southern Golf
description: COLUMBUS. Ga., Sept. 9 (AP)Gary Player held off the late charge of young Forrest Fezler today to win the $100,000 Southern open golf tournament by one stroke. Player shot a 69 for a 270 total.

title: Peace Corps Aides in Africa Open Conference in Liberia
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, Sept. 10 (Agence FrancePresse) More than 50 United States Peace Coris officials and volunteers in Africa are taking part in a conference that opened today in the Liberian capital and that will last till Friday.

title: Crash Kills 31 in Africa
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Sept. 10 (AP)A bus and a timber truck collided lead on today, killing 31 person, according to reports reaching the capital. The reports sadi the bus, carrying 66 persons, was passing another truck when it collided with the oncoming vehicle.

title: Sketches of the Nine Judges Who Are Hearing Appeals on the Watergate Tapes
description: David Lionel Bazelon

title: Debt Plan Is Approved
description: The Acadia Company reports that its debt composition plan under its Chapter XI bankruptcy proceeding has been approved by Federal Court. All debts incurred since June 21, 1972, will be paid in full and prior unsecured obligations will be settled at 20 cents on the dollar. As part of the plan, the present controlling stockholders are selling their 67 per cent holdings at book value to the company.

title: Icelandic and British Ships Collide in Fishing Dispute
description: LONDON, Sept. 10 (AP)The Icelandic gunboat Thor and the British frigate Jaguar collided 30 miles off Iceland early today while the Jaguar was maneuvering to keep the Thor from cutting a British trawler's fishing gear, the British Navy reported.

title: About the Yankees:
description: The final details of the Yankees' trade for Pat Dobson, a pitcher, last June were announced yesterday. Dave Cheadle, a 21yearold southpaw who pitched for Syracuse this season, hds been assigned to Atlanta. Previously, the, Braves received Frank Tepedino, Wayne Nordhagen and Alan Closter. Cheadle had a 7.9 record in Syracuse this season. ... Two Yankees have joined the club's top 10 in career base stealing. Roy White, who has stolen 14 bases this year, is 10th, with 139 in his career, while Horace Clark, who has eight this year, is tied for seventh with Tony Lazzeri at 147, Leading the Yankees with 248 is Hal Chase, who played when the team was known as the Highlanders before World War 1... Fans planning to attend the Sept. 30 game with Detroit are invited to bring their cameras, since it will be the last game played at the present stadium. The stadium is scheduled to undergo a major face lifting this fall,

title: Books of The Times
description: H. G. WELLS, A Biography. By Norman and Jeanne MacKenzie, 487 pages. Illustrated. Simon & Schuster. $10.

title: It Was a Surprising 12 Days at Forest Hills
description: It's only two days later, but already it's hard to believe that the 12 Days of Forest Hillsthe United States Open tennis championships were real..

title: ALLOCATION BY U.S. OF FUEL OIL ASKED
description: An appeal for mandatory Federal allocation of fuel oil was made public yesterday by the Consolidated Edison Company, with a report that the Cities Service Company  representing 36 per cent of the utility's normal supply for gasturbine use  had refused any supply since June 30.

title: AGNEW REPORTED FED UP IN 1972
description: AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 10 (UPI) Vice President Agnew was so fed up with John D. Ehrlichman in 1972 that he threatened not to run for reelection, Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, said in an interview published today.

title: Alaska Oil Pact Signed
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 10 The Standard Oil Company of California announced today that it had signed an agreement to explore the oil and gas potential of 11 million acres in northern Alaska. Standard signed the agreement with the Alaskan Native Arctic. North Slope Regional Corporation. It represents Alaska natives residing north of the Brooks Range.

title: NEWSPRINT UNION SEEKS BARGAINING
description: The president of the United Paperworkers International Union, Joseph P. Tonelli, proposed yesterday an early resumption of negotiations with the Canadian International Paper Company, where workers have been on strike for six weeks.

title: Soviet Site at Upper Brookville Taken off Nassau's Tax Rolls
description: MINEOLA, L. L, Sept.10After many years of protest, letters and conferences with Federal Government officials over the question of the exemption from taxation of property owned in Nassau County by the Soviet Government, the County Board of Supervisors voted today to remove from the tax rolls the last remaining property owned by the Russians.

title: Dash Doubts That Nixon Would Alter Tapes Sought
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 10 (AP)Samuel Dash, the Senate Watergate committee's chief counsel, said yesterday he did not believe that President Nixon would alter tape recordings that have been subpoenaed in the case.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
SKYLAB FURNACE MELTS CRYSTALS
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 10 (AP)The Skylab 2 astronauts melted two crystals in space today in an experiment that scientists said might help man to use solar power, build nearly pollutionfree engines and make steel stronger.

title: COUNCIL OFFERED REMAPPINC PLAN
description: Several politicians urged a City Council committee yesterday to use community planning board boundaries as guidelines for setting up new Council districts.

title: Provisional I.R.A. Reports A Pact With Official Wing
description: DUBLIN, Sept, 10 (Reuters) The Official and Provisional wings of the Irish Republican Army, in a long struggle for the support of the Irish people, have announced plans to prevent outbreaks of hositilities.

title: A Golden Mment.
description: This space is yielded today to Mr. O. W. of Bath, Ind., who has sent us his theory of the present inflation explosion. Leading economists have dismissed Mr. O. W.'s explanation, and only, Mr. O. W. believes, because he is not an economist, but a trombone player.

title: Judge Rebuffs a Passaic School On Move to Halt S.C.!. Inquiry
description: NEWARK, Sept. 10  Federal District Judge Vincent P. Biunno today rejected a move by the. Passaic County Technical and Vocational High School to bar hearings by the State Commission of Investigation into allegations of corruption and improprieties in the operation of the institution.

title: M'CARTHY LEAVING HIS EDITORIAL JOB
description: Former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy has indicated his desire to leave his editorial post at Simon & Schuster on Jan. 1, 1974, the bookpublishing company's executive vice president, Richard E. Snyder, announced yesterday.

title: Moynihan Repairing Tie to India
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 3Six months after arriving in India Ambassador Daniel P. Moynihan is still in the midst of a delicately aggressive effort to life IndianAmerican relations.

title: 3MONTH U.S. BILLS RISE TO PEAK RATE
description: Threemonth Treasury bills sold yesterday at a rate slightly above 9 per cent, a record high, in the wake of the Federal Reserve Board's action on Friday increasing reserve requirements on large certificates of deposit. Longer term Government, corporate and taxexempt bonds were marked down  to  of a point in price in early. trading but recovered somewhat before the close. In the seasoned utilities sector, for example, New York Telephone's 8.30s of 2012 were down  to 103 and New England Power's 8s of 2003 were down  at 104.

title: EASTBLOC TRADE AT PEAK IN QUARTER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 United States trade with the Soviet Union and other countries of Eastern Europe reached a record $580.1million in the first quarter of this year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: HOUSE CITES LIDDY FOR OATH REFUSAL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10G. Gordon Liddy, a convicted Watergate conspirator, was cited for contempt today by the House for refusing to take an oath as a witness before a House subcommittee.

title: NEW CHOLERA CASES DROPPING IN NAPLES
description: ROME, Sept. 10Health officials in Naples, the area hardest hit by Italy's twoweekold cholera outbreak, reported today that the number of new cases requiring hospital treatment was continuing to drop.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Some 10,000 South Jersey bus riders were without their usual transportation because of a srike of the Amalgamated Transit Workers Union Local 1358 (A.F.L.C.I.O.), whose 165 men walked off their jobs at the Atlantic City Transportation Company.

title: Teacher Stabbed to Death
description: TOWNSEND, Mass., Sept. 10 (AP)  Judith E. Dieweg, 31 years old, a fourth grade teacher, was found stabbed to death yesterday in a wooded area at the rear of her home where she lived alone.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION ADVANCES FOR WEEK
description: Steel production for the week ended Saturday gained by 1.8 per cent to 2.78 million tons, from 2.73 million tons the week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The production index advanced to 113.9, from 111.9 in the week ended Sept. 1.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: How do moviegoers rate the ratings? The Motion Picture Association decided that the time had come once more to find out if the ratings were helping parents select films for their children. So, for the fifth year, the Opinion Research Corporation in Princeton, N.J., polled about 2,000 moviegoers and nonmoviegoers 18 years old or older.

title: Coast Guard Drops Search For Dina Merrill's Son, 23
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Sept. 10The Coast Guard this afternoon abandoned its search for David Post Rumbough, the 23yearold son of Dina Merrill, the actress, and her first husband, Stanley M. Rumbough Jr., a New York industrialist.

title: All Beats Norton on 12thRound Rally
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Sept. 10In the most dramatic fight of his career, with the Victory and his future depending on the final three minutes, Muhammad Ali dazzled Ken Norton throughout the last round for a 12round splitdecision triumph tonight at The Forum.

title: ...on Inflation, Energy
description: President Nixon gives pride of place in his message to his recommendations concerning inflation and the energy problem. This is audacious strategy because both instances he is exploiting visible problems to promote actions that will not solve the problems but will achieve objectives he has long desired on other grounds.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Norton: A Bad Decision; Ali: Nobody Hits so Hard
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Sept. 10I thought it was a very good fight, a very close fight, but I thought I got a bad decision. I thought my blows had more force. He hit harder than I thought he would, and he hurt me sometimes, but I think I won.

title: Arthur Daley
description: The overly long exhibition season has finally ended for the football mercenaries, and they will begin playing for keeps this weekend. The preliminary headknocking has lent itself to all sorts of interpretations over the years, and some of the speculation even has the ring of validity to it. For the most part, though, it's like reading tea leaves. The coachesand maybe even the fanssee them whatever they want to see.

title: Funds Sought for Nassau Expressway
description: The Nassau Expressway, still only a twomile stub leading ndwhere, was pulled out of limbo yesterday and its completion from Kennedy International Airport to Atlantic Beach, was given high priority.

title: STEEL PRICE RISE FOR 10 PRODUCERS ALLOWED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10The Government authorized the steel industry today to make a twostage, $400millionayear increase in prices of sheet and strip steel.

title: Maryland Jury Expected to Meet Late This Week.
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 10  A Federal grand jury looking into corruption in Maryland is expected to meet late this week and there were indications that further indictments might be forthcoming.

title: U.S Scientists' Message to Russians
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10Following is the text of a cablegram from Philip Handler, president of the National Academy of Sciences, to Mstislav V. Keldysh, president of the Soviet Academy of Sciences, sent Saturday:

title: Man and Girlfriend Slain In Southampton Apartment
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Sept. 10A 27yearold house painter was arrested today and charged with killing his former teen  age girl friend and the man who took his place.

title: Maynard Sent to Cards As Jets Emphasize Youth
description: Don Maynard, the scrawny castoff who wound up gaining more yardage and catching more passes than any other receiver in pro football history, was traded yesterday from the Jets to the St. Loius Cardinals for a 1974 draft choice.

title: Jerry Quarry Stops Doyle In 4th Round
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Sept. 10With a steady pounding from the opening bell, Jerry Quarry stopped Tony Doyle tonight at 1 minute 38 seconds of the fourth round in the semifinal bout on the AliNorton card at The Forum.

title: Laver to Face Czechs In Davis Cup Semifinal
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 10 (Reuters)Rod Laver has agreed to play for Australia against Czechoslovakia in the Davis Cup semifinal at Melbourne in November.

title: Calf Dies After 24 Days Of Life With Rubber Heart
description: JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 10 (UPI)A calf that lived more than 24 days with a rubber heart has died at the University Medical Center, the authorities reported today.

title: Connecticut Utility Granted $7.5Million Rate Increase
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 10 (AP)The Connecticut Public Utilities Commission approved today a $7.5million rate increase for the Connecticut Light & Power Company while denying a $4million increase for the Hartford Electric Light Company.

title: Chrysler Deadline Near, U.A.W. Extends Two Pacts
description: DETROIT Sept. 10 (AP) With a strike deadline against the Chrysler Corporation four days away, the United Auto Workers obtained today indefinite extensions of its contracts with General Motors and Ford.

title: SERGEI K. TUMANSKY, JETENGINE DESIGNER
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 10 Sergei K. Tumansky, a designer of aircraft jet engines, died here yesterday.

title: More Secret Air Attacks In Cambodia Disclosed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 The Defense Department acknowledged today that United States fighterbombers flew air strikes in support of the Cambodian Government in 1970 and 1971, with the attacks kept secret through a system of dual reports.

title: News Summary and Index TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 11, 1973
description: International

title: Small Nations' Interests Dominate U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N, Y., Sept. 10At the United Nations these days much of the debate concerns Namibia, Guinea Bissau and Zimbabwe.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: WAYNE, Sept. 10Benny Borgmann, a resident of this suburban area of Paterson, insists that, contrary to popular belief, a wouldbe professional athlete doesn't have to get an early start in baseball or basketball to become a star.

title: Nixon Renews Bus Issue; Stand Called Diversionary
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 The issue of busing to achieve school integration, which has been lying dormant in the halls of Congress during the last few months, was raised again today by President Nixon in his second state of the union message.

title: Priest Beaten and Robbed
description: LACKAWANNA, N. Y., Sept, 10 (UPI)The pastor of Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church here, was attacked and robbed last night as he was entering the rectory, the police said, The victim, the Rev. Stephen Lakovic, was listed in serious condition at Our Lady of Victory Hospital,

title: Aid to Unemployed Extended in Jersey
description: TRENTON, Sept. 10Governor Cahill and the State Legislature combined today to approve a bill providing up to 13 additional weeks of unemployment benefits.

title: Yankees Lose, 3 to 2, as Rally in, 9th Falls Short
description: In a lesson in futility, the hapless New York Yankees loaded the bases with one out in the ninth inning of last. night's game with the tailend Cleveland Indians but were unable to capitalize on the rally and lost, 32.

title: Bill to Ban Blackouts Advances
description: The determination of Congress to pass legislation this week outlawing the television blackout of the pro football teams' home games was displayed again yesterday. The most stringent of the various antiblackout billsone permanently forbidding blackouts of nationally televised sports contestswas approved by a subcommittee on communications of the House of Representatives and sent to the House Commerce Committee.

title: ALBERTA UNIT BACKS SYNCRUDE'S OIL PLAN
description: CALGARY, Alberta, Sept. 10 (Canadian Press)The Alberta Energy Resources Conservation Board announced today approval of Syncrude, Ltd.'s, revised development schedule of the Athabascan oil sands in northeastern Alberta. Also approved were certain technical changes in the development plan submitted by Syncrude, a consortium of Atlantic Richfield Canada Ltd., CanadaCities Service Ltd., Gulf Oil Canada Ltd. and Imperial Oil Ltd.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It seems a foregone conclusion that Henry Kissinger will be confirmed as Secretary of State by the Senate. But I am convinced that there are decisive reasons for refusing to confirm his nomination.

title: Stock Market Falls 7.30 In Day of Slow Trading
description: The stock market failed to penetrate again the magic 900 level yesterday on the DowJones industrial average as prices closed lower in slow trading. Last Thursday the Dow closed at 901.04, up 1.96. On Friday, the average slipped to 898.63.

title: Retail Sales Stayed Steady in August
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 Retail sales held steady in August after a sizable increase in July, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Advertising: Now GiftAmerica
description: Many of you ardent television viewers and some of you intense magazine readers are now aware that there is a way to take care of that suddenly remembered birthday of beloved but faroff Aunt Tillie.

title: Spate of Classic Disks to Continue
description: Expect the usual bumper crop of new record releases in the stores this seasonthe American classical buyer continues to be a fat, sleek, pampered animal even if he rarely seems satisfied. For all the recent classical crisis arias sung in the media, he still has a wider selection at his fingertips than collectors anywhere in the world, and at $2.98 to $6.98 a disk he is still getting a bargain for his inflated dollar (in Europe the average price for an LP is now $10 and there are no discounts).

title: Everybody's Pleased With Marlboro Cup Weights
description: Just about everybody was satisfied with the Aveights that Kenny Noe announced yesterday for the eight horses listed to run in Saturday's $250,000 Marlboro Cup. But Johnny Nerud, the trainer, who has only an objective interest in the race, asked in a mocking voice: If Secretariat [a 3yearold] is the. horse of the century, as so manry people say he is, why does he have only 124 pounds.

title: Meskill Picks Transit Chief
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 10 (AP)The executive secretary of Connecticut's Gaming Commission was named today to the post of State Transportation Commissioner. Gov. Thomas J. Meskill appointed the secretary, Joseph B. Burns, to succeed A. Earl Wood, who resigned in July. Mr. Burns, a retired president of the Fuller Brush company, headed the state's gambling operations since 1971.

title: NONALIGNED MAPECONOMIC BATTLE
description: ALGIERS, Sept. 10In the fiveday meeting of a major part of the underdeveloped world that ended here yesterday, the industrial nations were repeatedly denounced as economic imperialists and pillagers of the resources of the poor.

title: ExBanker Pleads Guilty To Misapplying of Funds
description: NEWARK, Sept. 10 (AP) Santo R. Santisi, the alleged mastermind of a $1million scheme to divert funds from the Middlesex County Bank, pleaded guilty today to three counts of a Federal indictment charging misapplication of bank money.

title: Stunt Flier Dies in Miami After Crash in Practice
description: MIAMI, Sept. 10 (AP)A stunt pilot practicing maneuvers for the National Aerobatic Championships was killed yesterday when he lost control of his singleengine plane and it smashed into a field, the authorities said.

title: Six in House Score Bill to Help Coast Avert Forest Fires
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) An emergency bill aimed at avoiding a mig fire of eucalyptus trees in the east San Francisco Bay hills is running into opposition on Capitol Hill amid a battle over Federal aid.

title: Ads for Same Products Called a Waste
description: Betty Furness, the city's Consumer Affairs Commissioner, took the advertising industry to task yesterday for having engaged in a system of heavy advertising of identical productsa system, she said, that discourages competition from cheap alternatives of identical quality.

title: Ranger Tickets On Sale Tomorrow
description: The first boxoffice sale of tickets to regularseason games of the New York Rangers start tomorrow at the Felt Forum box office at Madison Square Garden and at Ticketron locations.

title: Kelley, Rookie Linebacker, Makes Giants Even if Name Is Misspelled on His Uniform
description: Brian Kelley, a 14thround draft choice who was born in Dallas and thought he would play pro football there, made it officially with the New York Giants yesterday.

title: PARLEY DUE TODAY ON MUSIC HALL PACT
description: Contract negotiations aimed at averting a threatened shutdown Thursday of the Radio City Music Hall will be held at 2 P.M. today at the offices of the. State Mediation Board in the World Trade Center.

title: Police Begin Bicycle Patrol Working From Their Homes
description: ATHERTON, Calif., Sept. 10 (AP)Two policemen, choosing their own working hours and shedding their uniforms, will use 10speed bicyoles to patrol residential neighborhoods in two San Francisco Peninsula communities.

title: Mrs. King Is Ill, Has Blood Tests
description: Mrs. Billie Jean King was taken to a hospital in Hilton Head, S. C., for blood tests yesterday after complaining of feeling ill.

title: How the Wiretapping Program Began
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10Testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in closed session today indicated that the genesis of a program of wiretaps of 13 Government officials and four, newsmen lay in the concern of Henry A. Kissinger over repeated leaks in the press of classified information relating to his work as the President's national security adviser.

title: POSEIDON RECALLS WILL BE GRADUAL
description: The Navy announced yesterday that corrections of faults that have dogged submarinebased Poseidon missiles were expected to be made gradually rather than under a rush recall program that was allegedly recommended last spring by the man in charge of the missile's development.

title: House Unit Shelves StudentAthlete Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10) (AP)A bill to protect student athletes will not be considered by the House Education Committee this week as scheduled.

title: Class of Kindergarteners Snips Maternal Strings
description: Leigh Anne Brautigam cried quietly and Scott Finder was afraid to talk to his classmates as a sunny kindergarten room in Public School 95 filled with wistfullooking mothers and their frightened or excited children yesterday morning.

title: Vatican Envoys Said to Urge Pursuing China Ties
description: ROME, Sept. 10A group of papal diplomats concluded in threeday conference last week that Peking was emerging as an international power center much more rapidly than Vatican assessments had foreseen.

title: Equity Financing
description: The Zapata Corporation directors authorized yesterday a cash tender offer for 1,500,000 shares, about 29 per cent of outstanding shares, of the company's common stock at $25 a share. The offer will expire on Sept. 26. Stockholders accepting the offer will not be eligible to receive the company's initial quarterly dividend, declared yesterday, of 10 cents a sham payable October 31. Zapata Corporation stock closed at 21 down 3 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Feeble Bats Met Worry For Stretch
description: If today was Yogi Berra's birthday and the spunky New York Mets' manager was asked what he would like most in this closing month of the pennant race, there's no doubt that he would ask for a few .300 hitters.

title: TV Review
description: When the producers Norman Lear and Bud Yorldn adapted a British comedy series for American television and turned it into a pot of gold called All in the Family, the hunt was on for adaptable British comedies.

title: Aaron Hits 710th Homer
description: Hank Aaron hit the 710th home run of his career in Atlanta last night and moved within four of Babe Ruth's career record of 714. The tworun homer came in the third inning off San Francisco Giants' pitcher, Don Carrithers. The Atlanta Braves' slugger left the game in the fourth inning complaining of a stomach disorder. The Braves have 16 games remaining, Page 57.

title: TRAMWAY ROUTE SHIFTS TO 60TH ST.
description: An alternative route, to stein opposition, has been proposed by the State Urban Development Corporation for an aerial cablecar system to connect Manhattan with the new town being developed on Roosevelt Island, formerly Welfare Island.

title: TALMADGE URGES COTTON CONTROLS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI)  Senator Herman E. Talmadge, Democrat of Georgia, charged today that huge Japanese purchases of cotton I and wool had driven up world prices and urged the Administration to impose export controls on United States cotton.

title: Phnom Penh Reports Landing By River Inside Contested City
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sept. 10Cambodian Government troops made an amphibious landing bebind enemy lines, inside the provincial capital of Kompong Cham early today and a spokesman reported that the enemy was swept from a large area with little opposition.

title: SAUDI DISPLEASED INITH HER OIL PACT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 10 Recent action giving Iran and Libya majority control in oil companies operating there has made Saudi Arabia dissatisfied with her 25 per cent participation in American oil concerns in that nation, according to a highly placed oil source.

title: STEEL PRICE RISE FOR 10 PRODUCERS ALLOWED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 The Government authorized the steel industry today to make a twostage, $400millionayear increase in prices of sheet and strip steel.

title: African Nations Put Drought Needs at $827Million
description: OUAGADOUGOU, Upper Volta, Sept. 10  Six African naestimated today that their immediate and longrange aid requirements as a result of five years of drought and famine would cost $827million.

title: Love of Money Lures 300 to World Congress.
description: For the men and women present at the Audubon Terrace yesterday, collecting coins is more than just a passion; it is a matter of scholarship.

title: Genuine Parts Bids For Acklands, Ltd.
description: The Genuine Parts Company, an independent distributor of automotive replacement parts,. is making an offer to acquire Acklands, Ltd., Canada, for stock valued at about $75million, it was disclosed yesterday. Acklands distributes automotive parts and industrial and consumer goods. Directors of the American organization have approved a proposal to issue one share of Genuine Parts common in exchange for each $1.95 share of Acklands stock outstanding or into which other Acklands securities may be converted.

title: ADDICT ARRESTED IN FATAL BEATING
description: The police early today announced the arrest of a drug addict for the fatal bludgeoning last Friday of a 68yearold pharmacist in his drugstore at 120 East 181st Street, in the Tremont section of the Bronx.

title: Suffolk Is Seeking $3Million in Aid For Sewer Project
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Sept. 10 John V. N. Klein, the Suffolk County Executive, today proposed using $3million to $4million of Federal general revenuesharing funds to help pay for the new $588million Southwest Sewer District project, scheduled for completion by the end of the decade.

title: Spray for Encephalitis
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 10 (AP)  Low  flying planes sprayed marshes and swamplands today with an insecticide to kill mosquitoes. Three DC3 planes took part in the program, aimed at eliminating mosquitoes that carry eastern equine encephalitis. The disease has killed more than 50 horses in New England in recent weeks.

title: Belgian Factory Workers Win Pledge From Premier
description: LIEGE, Belgium, Sept. 10 Fifty employes who took over a bankrupt metalworking plant, here Friday and threatened to blow up the factory and surrounding houses won a promise today from the Belgium Premier to review their case.

title: Baker Says Nation Is Past Tile Worst of Watergate
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (UPI)Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., Republican of Tennessee, said today that he thought the nation had weathered the worse part of Watergate and the issue now had diminished importance.

title: Senate Votes for Subsidies To Mass Transit Systems
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) The Senate passed a bill today that would provide Federal operating subsidies to mass transit systems for the first time.

title: SALT INTAKE LINKED TO BLOOD PRESSURE
description: A study to determine the salt intake habits of people with hypertension showed that those with high blood pressure consumed four times as much salt as a control group with normal pressure.

title: Seven Concerts in China
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 (AP)The Philadelphia Orchestra left today on a trip to China, where it will play seven concerts. Mayor Frank Rizzo was at International Airport to see off the musicians and their director, Eugene Ormandy. Tsien Tayung, liaison officer with China's cultural mission in Washington, said the trip was the beginning of further cultural exchanges.

title: AUSSEIN VISITING CAIRO FOR TALKS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 10King Hussein of Jordan arrived in Cairo today for a formal reconciliation with Presidents Anwar elSadat of Egypt and Halez alAssad of Syria, both of whom have been openly hostile to the King for more than two years.

title: PLAN IS ADVANCED FOR OLD STONE BANK
description: The Old Stone Savings Bank, Rhode Island's largest savings bank, with assets of $653million, received permission yesterday from the state's Board of Bank Incorporation to convert into a stockhoklerowned commercial bank.

title: Conservative Jews Vote For Women in Minyan
description: In a radical break with rabbinical tradition, Conservative Judaism will allow women to be counted in the minyanthe quorum of 10 or more adult Jews required for communal worship.

title: Compound Holds Implications for Superconductivity
description: A Westinghouse scientist announced yesterday success in manufacturing a compound, that becomes superconducting loses all electrical resistance at a higher temperature than any previously developed substance.

title: Drama Theme Is Sleep
description: Where the Open Theater's The Serpent deals with the origins of life, Terminal with death, and The Mutation Show with rebirth, the company's new work, Nightwalk, offers variations on the theme of sleep. In common, all investigate with insightand precision the rituals and reflexes of civilization.

title: ExTrotting Driver CitedAs Mastermind in Fixes
description: An ??erant horsetrader from Maine, barred as a driver in the United States seven years ago, was charged yesterday. as being the mastermind of a gambling ring that made $3million this year by fixing superfecta harness races.

title: Israel Receives Confirmation Of Cuban Diplomatic Break
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 10 (Reuters)The Foreign Ministry said today that it had received official confirmation of Cuba's diplomatic break with Israel, and expressed regrets at the mote.

title: AMEX PRICES DIP IN LIGHT TRADING
description: In light trading, prices on the American Stock Exchange, after opening higher, gave ground throughout most of the rest of the session yesterday to close off slightly. Prices in the overthecounter market also were off.

title: Aid to Unemployed Extended in Jersey
description: TRENTON, Sept. 10Governor Cahill and the State Legislature combined today to approve a bill providing up to 13 additional weeks of unemployment benefits.

title: Judge Upholds Bias in Hiring Of 4 Women as State Troopers
description: ALBANY, Sept. 10A judge ruled today that state police officials practiced sex discrimination in appointing four women troopers, but he ruled that the action was justified because of a bona fide occupational qualification.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TASTES The inflationary spiral has hit many restaurants, forcing closings and, the scaling down of ambitions. None has been hit harder than the Library. Why? said Stewart Steinberg, the owner. When I first opened, used books were one cent a pound, then two years ago they went to 11 cents. Last year they were 22 cents.

title: U.S. and Canada Reach Accord on Air Routes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) The United States and Canada reached an agreement today for a new package of air routes and an expanded system to clear passengers through customs.

title: Feeble Bats Met Worry For Stretch.
description: If today was Yogi Berra's birthday and the spunky New York Mets' manager was asked what he would like most in this closing month of the pennant race, there's no doubt that he would ask for a few .300 hitters.

title: MYSTERY SHROUDS GOLD SALE REPORT
description: PARIS, Sept. 10Four hundred tons of gold, worth $1.5 billion at current market prices, may have been sold in recent months by a seller whose identity is shrouded in mystery.

title: Europe Approves a Declaration To Clear Way for Nixon Visit
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark; Sept. 10  The European allies of the United States approved a declaration tonight designed to answer Washington's appeal. for improved transAtlantic relations and to clear the way for a visit to Europe by President Nixon. But no documents were released.

title: Alligator Hunting Season Is Opened in Louisiana
description: CAMERON, La., Sept. 10 (UPI)Alligator hunting, although illegal everywhere else in the United States, will be allowed in Lousiant's south. western marshes for the next 18 days.

title: Nixon to Veto Any Defense Cut or Domestic Cost Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 President Nixon warned Congress today that he was prepared to veto any legislation that would cut defense spending 3below his budget or raise the cost of domestic programs above it.

title: KISSINGER'S ROLE IN WIRETAPS TOLD TO SENATE PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson today turned over to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee a memorandum on Henry A. Kissinger's role in the wiretapping of 17 officials and newsmen from 1969 to 1971, but failed to satisfy Senators who have threatened to delay Mr. Kissinger's confirmation as Secretary of State.

title: Nixon Election Unit Shows Aug. 31 Funds of 4Million
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) President Nixon's reelection campaign had a cash balance on Aug. 31 of $4million, the Finance Committee to ReElect the President reported today.

title: PETER BROOK PLANS RESEARCH SESSIONS
description: Peter Brook and members of his company from the International Center for Theater Research, which is based in Paris, will open a fiveweek work period today at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Domestic Air Freight Up
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI)The nation's airlines in July registered a 22 per cent increase in domestic air freight revenue ton miles compared with the same month in 1972, the Air Transport Association said today. In both domestic and international service, 22 United States airlines accounted for 471 million revenue ton miles of air cargo, a 12 per Cent increase over July, 1972.

title: BRUNO M. MOREL
description: Bruno Morpurgo Morel, president of Distillerie Stock U. S. A. of New York, distributors of brandy and vermouth, died Saturday at his summer home on Fire Island. He was 63 years old and lived at 860 Fifth Avenue.

title: Thai Army Chief Quits
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 10 (AP)  Field Marshal Praphas Charusathien the most powerful men in the Thai army, stepped down todoay from the post of Thai Army commander. His deputy, Gen. Kris Srivara, took his plcae, militray sources said. The change takes, effect Oct. 1.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Striped Bass Research
description: Officials of the various stripedbass fishing derbies held annually in the fall along the East Coast could perform a public service this year by asking participants to cooperate with a Striped Bass Fund research project now under way.

title: AWARD IN LIBEL SUIT REVERSED BY COURT
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 10 (UPI)The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in a suit that arose from the collapse of the Silver Bridge at Point Pleasant, W. Va., in May 1968, reversed today a $1million judgment for libel and invasion of privacy against The Cleveland Plain Dealer.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Trudeau Government Defeats Challenge in Commons
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 10 Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's Liberal party Government won a confidence vote in the House of Commons tonight, apparently ending for the present a political crisis that has beset it for the last several weeks.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LONDON, Sept. 10 (AP)John Conteh of Britain wore down the former World Boxing Association champion, Vicente Rondon of Venezuela, tonight and stopped him at 1:20 of the ninth round of a scheduled 10round lightheavyweight bout. Conteh, the European champion, staggered Rondon with a hard right to the jaw in the eighth round. Conteh dropped Rondon for a count of 7 with a left hook to the head in the ninth. Conteh waded in after Rondon regained his feet. Rondon's corner threw in the towel, but Referee Roland Dakin tossed it out of the ring, then halted the fight after Conteh landed four more punches. Each fighter weighed 168 pounds.

title: Lawsuit Dropped By Women Golfers
description: DALLAS, Sept 10 (UPI)Sandra Palmer and Mrs. Marlene Hagge have settled their $500,000 lawsuit, which grew out of the charges of illegal play by the Ladies Professional Golf Association against Jane Blalock. All are professional golfers.

title: Farm Units Seek To Educate Public On Price of Food
description: Representative Jerry L. Litton, Democrat of Missouri, said here yesterday that scores of farm organizations have joined to set up a program to educate the public, which he said was grossly mistaken in blaming farmers for higher food prices.

title: The EyeCatcher
description: The cardinal flowers are in blossom for those who know where to find them. They are not is common as asters, by any means, nor quite as rare as fringed gentians. But you have to look for them, despite their eyecatching color, one of the most satisfying reds in the wildflower spectrum.

title: Nixon Counterattacks ...
description: President Nixon's message to Congress is more a propaganda effort to restore the Administration's crippled prestige than a serious attempt to engage in a constructive dialogue concerning legislation. Mr. Nixon ranged across more than fifty legislative proposals from the Alaska pipeline to the restoration of the death penalty, from school busing to the problem of conversion to the metric system.

title: VITAMIN E CLAIMS HELD MISLEADING
description: A National Academy of Sciences committee has deplored the widespread public fascina tion with vitamin E, declaring that the interest was based upon misinterpretations of animal research studies.

title: IREVALUATIONS SEND SHARE PRICES DOWN
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 10 (Reuters)  Hundreds of millions of dollars were slashed off share prices in Australia and New Zealand today as stock markets reacted to yesterday's upward revaluation of the two countries' dollars.

title: PONTIAC UNIT OF G.M. PLANS SMALLER CARS
description: DETROIT, Sept. 10Pontiac's general manager, Martin J. Caserio, said today the division was ready to build a subcompact car as soon as General Motors has the extra capacity to handle it. He indicated this would be 1975.

title: KISSINGER'S ROLE IN WIRETAPS TOLD TO SENATE PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson today turned over to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee a memorandum on Henry A. Kissinger's role in the wiretapping of 17 officials and newsmen from 1969 to 1971, but failed to satisfy Senators who have threatened to delay Mr. Kissinger's confirmation as Secretary of State.

title: Blumenthal Offers Plan to Weed Out City Corruption
description: To combat corruption in city government, Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal, the Liberal party candidate for Mayor, said yesterday that if elected, he would create an investigations commission beyond mayoral control.

title: Needy Nations Increasing Dealings in Eurocurrency
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 The more creditworthy developing oountries may have raised as much as $8billion in loans on the Eurodollar and other Eurocurrency markets last year, the International Finance orporation reported today.

title: 3 Youths Are Killed in Crash Of Their Car in Connecticut
description: MILFORD, Conn. Sept. 10 (AP)Three youths were killed and two others critically injured late this morning when their car smashed into a tree here.

title: Barry Goldwater
description: WASHINGTONHow much shock, surprise and bad news can a nation absorb and still maintain its position as a world leader? Many concerned Americans are asking questions similar to this and for a very good reason.

title: Three Are Killed by Fumes While Cleaning Septic Tank
description: SULPHUR WELL, Ky., Sept. 10 (UPI)Three persons were killed yesterday and two others were overcome by poisonous fumes while cleaning a septic tank. Two more were hospitalized.

title: Nastase Is Fined $5,500. For Antics in 2 Tourneys
description: The United States Lawn Tennis Association fined Ilie Nastase of Rumania $4,500 yesterday for his actions during the Western championships last month in Cincinnati, and added a $1,000 fine for his behavior in the U.S.L.T.A. indoor chamionships at Salisbury, Md., last February.

title: SHOP TALK
description: It was an unusual scene at the Continental Baths of the Ansonia Hotel yesterday. The men were fully dressed. Usually, the Bath's clientele (all male except for Saturday nights) wears nothing but Artfullydraped turkish towels. And even those are discarded for a dip in the pool.

title: Accountant Who Defrauded Allen Funt Is an Apparent Suicide
description: On the eve of his sentencing for embezzling more than $1.2million from his client, Allen Funt, creator of Candid Camera, Seymour Goldes, an accountant, apparently committed suicide.

title: Nixon and Haig on Yacht
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI) President Nixon, accompanied by the White House, chief of staff, Alexander M. Haig, dined today aboard the Presidential yacht Sequoia.

title: SOCIALISTS LEAD IN NORWAY VOTE
description: OSLO, Norway, Tuesday Sept. 1A tightly deadlocked election threatened to perpetuate the political instability that has prevailed in Norway ever since she rejected entry into the Common Market last year.

title: Merrill Lynch Will Add Mutual Fund in October
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., the world's largest brokerage house, disclosed here yesterday that it would start a major new mutual fund next month.

title: BUILDER ACCEPTS MEADOWS DELAY
description: NEWARK, Sept. 10Frank Briscoe Company, Inc., a general contractor, has agreed to put off until Oct. 24 the signing of an agreement to build the Meadowlands race track and such auxiliary buildings as barns and dormitories, spokesmen of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority said today.

title: Wholesale Beef Prices Rise Sharply in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 10In the first day of trading after meat ceilings were removed there was no change in live cattle sales at stockyards in the Middle West today, but the wholesale price of choice beef here rose sharply.

title: Aaron Connects Again, Then Becomes Ill
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 10 (AP)Hank Aaron hit his 710th career home run tonight, moving within four of Babe Ruth's record 714, as the Atlanta Braves defeated the San Francisco Giants, 104.

title: SAKHAROV BACKED FOP PEACE AWARD
description: MOSCOW, Sept, 10The dissident novelist Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, was reported today to have proposed that the 1973 Nobel Peace Prize be awarded to Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist and civil rights advocate who has been under attack here.

title: All Outpoints Norton
description: Muhammad All rallied in the 12th and last round and gained a splitdecision victory over Ken Norton last night in Inglewood, Calif. The result reversed Norton's splitdecision upset of Ali on March 31. Details, page 57.

title: Beef Prices Remain Unchanged on the First Day Without Ceilings, but Retailers Are Unsure of Future
description: Shoppers found beef prices generally unchanged here and throughout the country yesterday on the first day Federal price ceilings were removed. However, many retailers remained uncertain on what would happen next.

title: Marcos Frees 249 Convicts And Asks Popular Support
description: MANILA, Sept. 10 (Reuters) President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines pardoned 249 convicts today, the eve of his 56th birthday, and urged Filipinos to help him build a new society.

title: Soviet Withholds Exit Visa From Panov, Kirov Dancer
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 Valery Panov, a prominent Leningrad dancer, was recently refused an exit visa that had been promised him by the Soviet authorities for emigration to Israel, a friend declared here today.

title: BILL BARS TV ADS FOR LITTLE CIGARS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 10 The House passed and sent to President Nixon today a bill to bar advertisements of little cigars from television and radio.

title: A STRIP MINE BILL GAINS IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP)  The Senate Interior Committee approved a strip mine regulation bill today, but a key environmental question remained undecided.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Conservative Jews Dote For Women in Minyan
description: In a radical break with rabbinical tradition, Conservative Judaism will allow women to be counted in the minyanthe quorum of 10 or more adult Jews required for communal worship.

title: 13 Are Injured by Bombs At 2 London Rail Stations
description: LONDON, Sept. 10  Bombs exploded this afternoon in two main railroad stations here, injuring 13 persons, three of them seriously.

title: She Found Maitre d'Job Rough, at First
description: Vincent Mastropasqua, one of the captains in the Club Sardi at Sardi's restaurant, put it succinctly.

title: Weicker Urges U.S. to Run Railroad Passenger Service
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP)Senator Lowel P. Weicker Jr., Republican of Connecticut, said today that he was drafting legislation to have the Federal Government take over the nation's passenger railroad system.

title: 800,000 Pupils Dut of School In Teachers' Strikes in Nation
description: Teachers manned picket lines instead of classrooms yesterday in strikes in the metropolitan area and around the country that have kept about 800,000 pupils from starting their fall school terms.

title: Roundup: Pirates Win, Trail by Half Game
description: While the St. Louis Cardinals were taking the day off yesterday, the Pittsburgh Pirates were pounding the Chicago Cubs, at Wrigley Field for 21 hits an 113 victory that left them .003 percentage points and a halfgame out of first place in the National League's Eastern Division.

title: Turkish Court Jails L.I. Man Man 30 Years As Drug Smuggler
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 10 (AP)  A criminal court sentenced a Long Island, N. Y., man today to 30 years in prison on charges of drug smuggling.

title: Where Once There Was Just Spock, Now There's a Crowd
description: It used to be so simple. A pediatrician would instruct a new parent to buy a baby book. And, with the confident air of someone who already knows a thing or two about children, the parent would respond, Dr. Spock, I presume.

title: CHICAGO ATTORNEYS REPORT BURGLARIES
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP)Chicago: attorneys who represent radical Weathermen, Black Panther party leaders and street gang members say their offices have been mysteriously burglarized in the last three years.

title: F.B.I. Sets Up a Division To Supervise Information
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) Clarence M. Kelley, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, announced today that he had created a new External Affairs Division to supervise the agency's dealings with the public and the news media.

title: Pan Am Orders 10 Short 747's From Boeing for $280Million
description: Pan American World Airways said yesterday that it had placed an order worth $280million for 10 models of a new, shortened version of the Boeing.

title: judges Schooled on New Narcotics Laws
description: Yesterday morning, 24 students attended special classes at Fordham University Law School and during their lunch break 16 of them were sworn in as Court of Claims judges.

title: PEKING EXPECTED TO STRESS EUROPE
description: PARIS, Sept. 9Diplomats say China has been pressing Western European countries to strengthen their ties with one another and to man their defenses against the Russians.

title: American League
description: Tuesday, September 11, 1973

title: Maj. Gen. Edward C. Rose Dead; Served Port Crime Commission
description: SEA GIRT, N. J., Sept. 10Maj. Gen. Edward C. Rose, an officer in both World Wars who was the state's first representative on the New YorkNew Jersey Waterfront Commission in 195354, died today of a heart attack at his home, 114 Brooklyn Boulevard. He was 80 years old.

title: DR. G. G. DEAVER OF N.Y.U. IS DEAD
description: PARAMUS, N. J., Sept. 10Dr. George Gilbert Deaver, a pioneer in clinical rehabilitation and a specialist in physical disabilities, died here today at the Cupola Retirement Village. His age was 83.

title: Bolivia President Swears In 4 Men in Cabinet Shuffle
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 10 (Reuters)  President Hugo Banzer Suarez today swore nil our new ministers for his 18man Cabinet and left one posiion vacant.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI)The House Ways and Means Committee, acting on President Nixon's trade bill, agreed tentatively today to give the President temporary authority to lower barriers to imports as a means of cornbating inflation.

title: 2 HELD AT AIRPORT IN DRUG SMUGGLING
description: Two Colombians were seized at Kennedy International Airport yesterday when they sought to claim seven airfreighted crates allegedly containing marijuana hidden in hollowedout slats.

title: Bridge:
description: When to cover honors with honors is a complex subject in itself. An extra dimension of complexity is introduced when the defenders have a choice of honors with which to cover.

title: Nixon Bars Polluters From Government Contracts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10President Nixon signed today an executive order denying Federal contracts, grants or loans to companies convicted of violating the Clean Air or Water Pollution Control Acts. The order requires that the administrator of the EnvironMental Protection Agency periodically provide Government agencies with lists of violators of the two environmental acts. The agencies would be required to exclude companies ein the lists from Government business.

title: LIMITS FOR BLACKS IN BUSINESS SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10A study sponsored by the Department of Labor indicates that after blacks are hired as professionals In private industry their chances of advancement are poor.

title: People and Business
description: Yesterday was a day for discouraging forecasts on the energy crisis. In an address scheduled for delivery last night to the Houston Geological Society, T. D. Barrow, senior vice president of the Exxon Corporation, warned that it would take four to ten years before there could be production from new discoveries of oil and gas. Discoveries which have not been made by the end of the year, he said, will be of little help to the U.S. in this decade.

title: DAVID PRICE IS DEAD; CRIMINAL LAWYER, 85
description: David F. Price, an attorney for the defense in several wellknown criminal cases in Brooklyn, died yesterday in North Miami Beach, Fla., where he had been living since his retirement. He was 85 years old.

title: Increases of 5% Are Indicated for Fall
description: Prices of boys's apparel are up about 5 per cent this fall, with even greater increases anticipated for next spring, retail buyers indicated yesterday.

title: Dr. Arthur S. W. Touroff Dies; ExSurgery Chief at Mt. Sinai
description: Dr. Arthur S. W. Touroff, director emeritus of surgery at Mount Sinai Hospital, died yesterday at his home, 333 East 79th Street. He was 73 years old.

title: G.O.P. Counsel Says Party Will Retain the Presidency,
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Sept. 10 (UPI)  A former White House assistant, Harry S. Dent, predicts that the Watergate scandal will not prevent the Republican party from maintaining control of the Presidency in 1976.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Rise at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's weekly monthly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Nixon to Veto Any Defense Cut or Domestic Cost Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 President Nixon warned Congress today that he was prepared to veto any, legislation that would cut defense spending below his budget or raise the cost of domestic programs above it.

title: Patrol Car Fired On In Times Sq. Chase; 3 in Gang Are Held
description: Three men allged to be members of a New Jersey motorcycle gang were arrested last night after one of them allegedly fired a shotgun blast at a police patrol car during a chase's in the Times Square area.

title: A Grand Teton Jetport?
description: One of the most devastating schemes ever advanced for a national park now looms ominously over Grand Teton, Wyo., in the form of a proposed $2.2million jetport. Last year Congress appropriated funds which may but do not have to be used to expand an existing small airport within the park.

title: For 99% of City Schools, It's a Smooth New Start
description: The new school year got off to a generally smooth start for the city's 1.1 million pupils yestesday, although protesting Brooklyn parents occupied one school to prevent its opening and kept virtually all pupils out of another.

title: Nixon Lawyers, in Appeal, Contest Release of Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10President Nixon's lawyers said today that any discussions of Watergate crimes that he might have held with White House aides were in line with his constitutional duty to see that the laws are faithfully executed and thus exempt from any rand jury scrutiny.

title: More Secret Air Attacks In Cambodia Disclosed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10The Defense Department acknowledged today that United States fighterbombers flew air strikes in support of the Cambodian Government in 1970 and 1971, with the attacks kept secret through a system of dual reports.

title: RAPIDAMERICAN SETS PROFIT MARK
description: The RapidAmerican Corporation attained record sales and earnings in the quarter and six months ended July 31, in contrast to the losses incurred in the corresponding periods a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday by the diversified retail, apparel textiles concern.

title: Nixon Tells G.O.P. Leaders He Plans To Campaign for the Party in '74 and '76
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) President Nixon told applauding members of the Republican National Committee today that he planned to campaign personally for Republican candidates in Congressional races next year and the Presidential election in 1976.

title: ExTrotting Driver Cited As Mastermind in Fixes
description: An itinerant horsetrader from Maine, barred as a driver in the United States seven years ago, was charged yesterday as being the mastermind of a gambling ring that made $3million this year by fixing superfecta harness races.

title: Dr. Lapp Warns Overuse Of XRays Could Kill 50,000
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) The current excessive use of Xrays for diagnosis will mean 30,000 American cancer deaths during the remainder of the century unless action is taken, a nuclear physicist says.

title: Credit Crunch Squeezing Home Financing Industry
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP)  The credit squeeze has caused a crisis in the home financing industry, the House Banking Committee was told today.

title: People in Sports: New Cup of Tee for Weiskopf
description: Tom Weiskopf, fresh from victory in the World Series of Golf, in Akron, Ohio, now is looking eagerly to the Ryder Cup matches in Muirfield, Scotland, Sept. 2022. Weiskopf, on Sunday, shot a 66 for a 36hole total of 137 to beat Jack Nicklaus and Johnny Miller by three strokes. Tommy Aaron was 12 strokesback.

title: Disaster Loan Bill Passed And Sent to White House
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI) The Senate passed and sent to the White House today compromise legislation to lower the interest rate on disaster loans.

title: Funds for Johnson Ranch
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI) The Air Force spent $253,400 to construct an air traffic control facility at President Johnson's Texas ranch, according to a Defense Department report released today.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Excerpts From the President's Message to Congress Giving Views on Legislation
description: Following are excerpts from President Nixon's message to Congress today:

title: Chess: Portisch Changing His Spots (Or at Least His Emphasis)
description: Can a Player change his style once it has jelled? It is not to the point to cite the case of Salo Flohr, the Czech grandmaster, who gave up the wild sacrifical orgies in which he indulged himself as a youngster for the driest of dry positional strategy in maturity. All young players make that change, though not as dramatically as did Flohr.

title: State Budget Surplus Likely to Exceed Estimate Made by Cahill by $100Million
description: TRENTON, Sept. 10The legislative Office of Fiscal Affairs reported this evening that the surplus in Governor Cahill's state budget was likely to be $300million, rather than the $200million projected last month by the outgoing Repnblican Governor.

title: Senate Democrats Compile a Must List
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10A few hours after President Nixon's latest state of the union message arrived in Congress, Senate Democratic leaders met today to begin drawing up their own list of must legislation to be passed in the next few weeks.

title: MYSTERY SHROUDS GOLD SALE REPORT
description: PARIS, Sept. 10Four hundred tons of gold, worth $1.5billion at current market prices, may have been sold in recent months by a seller whose identity is shrouded in mystery.

title: Stage: Two Plays by Storey in London
description: LONDON, Sept. 10Since the English Stage Company took over the Royal Court Theater in the midnineteen fifties, it has been the seedbed for some of the most exhilarating offerings of the British theater. Unlike the other institutional theaters in the country, the Royal Court is essentially a playwrights' theater, and it has been associated with such playwrights as John Osborne, Arnold Wesker, Christopher Hampton and David Storey.

title: Foreman Lining Up Quarry as Next Foe
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Sept. 10 (UPI)The world heavyweight champion, George Foreman, indicated tonight he would make his next title defense against Jerry Quarry in the first week of November.

title: Small Nations' Interests Dominate U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N, Y., Sept. 10At the United Nations these days much of the debate concerns Namibia, Guinea Bissau and Zimbabwe.

title: British Football Results
description: By Reuters

title: Warning to Moscow:
description: More than any other group of men and women, scientists live with the terrifying knowledge of humanity's precarious balance on the edge of selfdestruction. An awareness of awesome risks, together with their own responsibility in creating them, leads scientists at times to reach across national boundaries to appeal to the conscience of men of power. It was in such a moment of humane solidarity that the National Academy Sciences reached out to its Soviet counterpart in warning that the arrest or further harassment of Andrei D. Sakharov, the eminent Soviet physicist, might jeopardize the future of AmericanSoviet scientific cooperation.

title: MARCHI SAYS DOES IGNORE CITY CRIME
description: If they enjoy being mugged, State Senator John J. Marchi said yesterday, then New Yorkers should vote for one of his three mayoral opponents, because that is exactly what they're going to get.Mr. Marchi, the Republican candidate for Mayor and a man with a reputation for a calm Personality, made the charge during a shouting, armflailing performance in a small, reverberating room in his campaign headquarters at 355 Lexington Avenue.

title: Woman, at 100, Registers to Vote
description: NEWARK, Sept. 10 (AP)Bertha Hertz registered as new voter today at the age of 100. Mrs. Hertz, a widow, is certain she voted before, but is not certain how many years ago she cast her last vote.

title: Mystic River Bridge Closed
description: BOSTON, Sept. 10 (AP)The Mystic River Bridge connecting Boston to the north was closed today by an accident that killed the driver of a truck. The authorities said it might he months before the bridge was reopened to traffic.

title: Notes on People
description: Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany is expected to travel to the Aspen Institute for Humanistic Studies in Colorado this month to accept the Institute's StatesmanHumanist Award. Announcement of the award was made here by Robert O. Anderson, the institute's chairman, and J. E. Slater, its president. They said that Mr. Brandt would spend several days beginning Sept. 28 in Aspen and would meet informally there with leaders in various fields of learning. The award includes $10,000 in cash and a sculpture by Herbert Bayer, who is a fellow and trustee of the institute. This is the second time the award has been made. The first recipient was Jean Monnet, who was honored in 1971 for his peace efforts.

title: A Nattering Nabob of Nixonism
description: Vice President Agnew appeared to be at his alliterative apogee the other night when he told a Republican audience that we have reached the watershed of Watergate (although that could be taken to mean that everything will be downhill from here on). When he got to his main theme, however, Mr. Agnew sounded like nothing so much as a nattering nabob of Nixonism.

title: Police to Get $3.5Million in Overtime Bringing the Force to Manpower Peak
description: A plan to increase the Police Department's effectiveness with $3.5million in overtime and to expand fivefold the use of crimeprevention devices in Stores was announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.

title: Keegan Is Severed From.Trial of Kenny
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 10William A. Keegan, a former member of the Hudson County Park Commission, was severed as a defendant today in the trial of John J. Kenny and five other county officials or private citizens on charges of conspiracy to permit use of county parkland as a landfill operation for private profit.

title: 2 Children Die in Fire on W. 152d Street
description: While four policemen were rousing the residents of a burning building in which two children died in Washington Heights yesterday, fire trucks were delayed in reaching a hydrant because the street was blocked by the officers' two patrol cars.

title: U.S. and Czechoslovakia Discussing Mutual, Claims
description: PRAGUE, Sept. 10 (Reuters)  Talks between Czechoslovakia and the United States about the settlement of mutual financial claims opened in Prague today, C.T.K., the official press agency, reported.

title: COPPER FUTURES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Copper futures fell sharply yesterday with the news that President Nixon had called on Congress to take legislative action on stockpile sales. There are now some 200,000 tons of copper in the Government's stockpile that, if sold, would have an impact on the market.

title: Press Club Urges Action On Shield for Newsmen
description: The New York Press Club urged Congress yesterday to act quickly on legislation to guarantee newsmen an obsolute right to protect their confidential sources. The Associated Press reported.

title: COLUMBIA STRUCK BY 500 EMPLOYES
description: A strike of 500 employes of Columbia University for higher wages began yesterday and drew promises of support today from campus maintenance personnel and from some faculty members in the School of Social Work.

title: Merritt Knocks Out Terrell in First; 11,844 at Garden for AliNorton TV
description: As a preliminary to its closedcircuit telecast of the Muhammad AliKen Norton fight, Madison Square Garden had its own jawbreaker event last night. Jeff Merritt of Cleveland scored a firstround knockout over Ernie Terrell of Chicago, the former World Boxing Association heavyweight champion.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: 5th Suspect in Police Killing Is Here

title: Woman, 73, Is Charged With Drugs and Policy
description: Detectives posing as Consolidated Edison workmen arrested a 73yearold woman at her Harlem apartment yesterday on charges of selling narcotics and possessing numbers policy slips and two ounces of cocaine.

title: Marriage of Two Decorators Became a Merger of Styles
description: When two decorators marry, whose taste dominates?Neither one, it's a merger, insisted Barbara D'Arcy. But in her case, at least at the outset, she hastened to explain, most of the furniture was Kirk's.

title: Wholesale Beef Refund Set
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 (UPI)  The Internal Revenue Service announced today that Kansas Beef Industries of Philadelphia, Inc., would refund $101,000 as a result of violations stemming from sales above Federal price ceilings set last March. The service also said the Wichita, Kan.,based beef wholesaler, which supplies retailers in this area, would pay $20,000 in penalties.

title: Farm Unit Assails Controls
description: PARK RIDGE, Ill., Sept. 11 (AP)  The American Farm Bureau Federation urged an end today to all Federal price controls. The federation'sboard of directors said hi a statement that, if consumers are to be assured of ample meat supplies, it will be necessary to remove all price controls. The federation, with more than two million families as members, is the largest general farm organization in the country.

title: Health Violations At 29 Food Outlets Are Reported Here
description: The City Health Department has cited 29 more restaurants and other food establishments for having failed their second healthcode inspections and has warned them that violations must be corrected before a third and final inspection this month or they could be closed.

title: Rep. Sandman Joins Grandfather Ranks
description: TRENTON, Sept. 11 (AP)Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., the Republican nominee for Governor, and his wife have become grandparents for the first time.

title: DEL BAKER DEAD; MANAGED TIGERS
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Set. 11 (UPI)Delmer (Del) Baker, who ed the Detroit Tigers to an American League pennant in 1940, died at his home here today. He was 81 years old.

title: Bridge: By Trumping Partner's Ace Goren Wards Off a Disaster
