description: McGill University recently awarded the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws to Charles Goren. This was unrelated to his membership on the National Laws Commission; it was a tribute to the remarkable role he has played in the history of the game, as player, teacher, lecturer and writer.

title: REV. E. J. JOHANSON
description: BRUNSWICK, Me., Sept. 11 The Rev. E. Jerome Johanson of West Hartford, Conn., and Brunswick, a retired professor lof theology and Christian ethics at the Hartford Seminary Foundation, died yesterday in the Regional Memorial Hospital. He was 75 years old.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 12, 1973

title: United Air and Signal Call Off a Merger
description: Termination of the proposed $750million merger agreement between the United Aircraft Corporation and the Signal Companies, Inc., was announced jointly yesterday. Unexpected complications arose during the preparation of the formal merger agreement, which the two companies had been developing since the proposal announced July 9, Harry J. Gray, president of United Aircraft, and Forrest N. Shumway, president of Signal, said in a joint statement.

title: Dogs Sniff Out Hashish Aboard France
description: Customs agents yesterday removed most of a cache of about 150 pounds of hashish discovered by drugdetecting dogs in a camper vehicle that arrived here last week aboard the France.

title: AFRICAN LEADERS AT DROUGHT TALKS
description: OUAGADOUGOU, Upper Volta, Sept. 11Five African Presidents and a representative of a sixth met here today to consider recommendations for projects to alleviate the ravages of five years of drought.

title: London Bomb Scare Disrupts Train Services in Rush Hour
description: LONDON, Sept. 11 (Reuters)  A bomb scare shut down a London railway station and badly disrupted commuter services this morning in the aftermath of explosions in two stations yesterday.

title: EVANS LOSES GAME IN. CHESS TOURNEY
description: EL PASO, Sept. 11 (AP)Larry Evans has been defeated by Andrew Karklins of Chicago in the second round of the 1973 United States Chess Tournament.

title: Solzhenitsyn Assails Liberals in West
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 11  The novelist Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn has accused Western liberals of dual standards of morality in what he described as their quick readiness to denounce oppression in rightist countries but reluctance to criticize the Soviet Union.

title: Ozark Is Fined $200
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 (UPI)  Manager Danny Ozark of the Philadelphia Phillies was fined $200 last night for his antics during the Phillies' Saturday night game with the Pittsburgh Pirates. Ozark protested close play at the plate, was thrown out of the game, and, as he left, threw the club's bag of practice balls onto the field.

title: House Rejects Proposals by the Senate on Data and Military Bases
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 Siding with the Nixon Administration, the House of Representatives today rejected Senate proposals aimed at obtaining freer access to State Department information and requiring Congressional approval of militarybase agreements with foreign countries.

title: Bid in Paris Aimed at Providing for Arab Cutback
description: PARIS, Sept. 11The United States sought today to spur efforts of the major Western nations to work out oilsharing arrangements as insurance against any threatened cutback in petroleum supplies from the Arab nations.

title: S.E.C. Clears a Rate Rise In Brokerage Commissions
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a proposal of the New York Stock Exchange for an increase in brokers' commissions on securities trades. It also announced that a fixed schedule of commission rates would be abolished altogether by April 1, 1975.

title: U.S. Lines to Quit Jersey And Return to Portin City
description: Mayor Lindsay disclosed yesterday an agreement by the United States Lines to move its huge cargo container operations from Elizabethport, N. J., to Howland Hook on Staten Island. The company moved its operations out of New York four years ago.

title: S.E.C. Clears a Rate Rise In Brokerage Commissions
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a proposal of the New. York Stock Exchange for an increase in brokers' commissions on securities trades. It also announced that a fixed schedule of commission rates would be abolished altogether by April 1, 1975.

title: Blacks at G.O.P. Parley Express Discontent Over Role in Party
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 Amid grumbling from black Republicans, the party reform committee set up to attract more women, young people, minorities and ethnic group members began its work today.

title: Orthodox Rabbis Call Easing Of Minyan Rules Desperation
description: A major group of Orthodox rabbis asserted yesterday that there was no justification for the continued existence of the Conservative movement as it assailed the Conservative decision to allow women to be counted in a minyan.

title: Mediator in Opera Strike Calls Prospect for Settlement Bleak
description: The mediator in the negotiations between Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians and the New York City Opera Company said yesterday that prospects for settling the 12dayold musicians' strike were bleak.

title: People in Sports: Mrs. King Ailing
description: Mrs. Billie Jean King's $100,000, winner  take  all match with Bobby Riggs was placed in jeopardy yesterday by her husband, even though she competed in a television tournament at Hilton Head, S. C.

title: ICELAND'S CABINET CAUTIONS BRITAIN
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Sept. 11 (Reuters)Iceland declared today that she would break diplomatic ties with Britain if British ships continue ramming Icelandic ships.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:
STATE TO REVIEW MORTGAGE RATES
description: The New York State Banking Board will hold a series of three meetings next week to determine whether the interestrate ceiling on home mortgages should be lifted to 8 per cent, Harry W. Albright Jr., superintendent of banks, announced yesterday.

title: Jim Bouton Dismissed From WABC Sports Job
description: Jim Bouton, the controversial sportscaster and former New York Yankee pitcher, told local television viewers last night of his dismissal from Channel 7's Eyewitness news team.

title: Appeal on Blind Teacher
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Sept. 11 (AP)  The Poughkeepsie Board of Education voted 3 to 2 yesterday to pursue its appeal against allowing Bruce Bevan, a blind teacher, to resume teaching. Opponents of Mr. Bevan, a sixthgrade teacher, said that allowing him to teach would pose a safety problem, unless a sighted teacher were also present in his classroom.

title: BAN ON STOPPAGES EXTENDED AT TIMES
description: A preliminary injunction enjoining members of Typographical Union 6 from engaging in illegal slowdowns or work stoppages at The New York Times was granted yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Sarafite.

title: Most Auto Makers Will List Gasoline Mileages
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI)  The three biggest American auto makers and eight major foreign car manufactures together representing 90 per cent of the new cars sold in this countryhave agreed to start telling buyers how much gasoline the cars will use the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

title: WATERGATE PANEL WILL MEET TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11The Senate Watergate Committee is scheduled to meet tomorrow morning to set the scope and format of the rest of its investigation.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: AMEX PRICES OFF IN UHT TRADING
description: In continued light trading, prices on the American Stock Exchange fell shortly after the opening, recovered slightly in midafternoon but still closed sharply lower. Prices also were down in the overthecounter market.

title: Relaxation on Cuba?
description: Henry A. Kissinger says the Nixon Administration is willing at least to consult other members of the Organization of American States about the possibility of relaxing the nineyearold embargo against Cuba. Belated as it is, this slightly more flexible approach on the part of Washington is certain to get a favorable response from many O.A.S. governments long ago convinced that the attempt to isolate Fidel Castro's regime in the hemisphere was futile and counterproductive.

title: Records: Studio Jazz
description: One of the more provocative jazz events of last winter was a weeklong series of rehearsals by the Jazz Composers Orchestra of Don Cherry's Relativity Suite, conducted by the composer in December at New York University's Loeb Student Center. The rehearsals culminated in a concert performance that was such a fascinating kaleidoscope of melody, rhythm, color and exotic effects that much of it seemed to be dissolving into thin air before it could be absorbed properly. One hoped that it had been recorded.

title: JUNTA IN CHARGE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Wednesday, Sept. 12President Salvador Allende Gossens was deposed yesterday in a violent military coup, and the Santiago police said that he had committed suicide rather than surrender to the attackers.

title: Townhouse Plan Splits L. I. Blacks
description: MANHASSET, L. I.  At Herman Jackson's little grocery store on Spinney Hill, you can buy Railroad Mills Sweet Snuff or canned hogmaws or many varieties of canned greens, all favorites of the small black community here.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Federal Court in Trenton yesterday ordered New Jersey to repossess by Oct. 31 more than $3million worth of school equipment distributed to more than 700 nonpublic schools under a special aid program that was found unconstitutional last April. The twojudge panel set the deadline at the request of a coalition led by the American Civil Liberties Union, but it rejected a demand for contempt citations against Gov. William T. Cahill and other state officials for not having removed the equipment before the start of the new school year.

title: The Roots of Inflation
description: An old psychological principle says you can't get one worry out of your mind until you get a different one into it. President Nixon has seized the news that the nation is more worried about inflation than Watergate as a tremendous opportunity. Inflation is a serious problem for the President, but it cannot be fatal for him. Economic Nevertheless, to some people it does Analysis feel fatal. The nation is in a state of pain, anger and confusion over what is happening to prices and to the value of the dollar, You can feel the raw emotions, Representative Edward I. Koch, Democrat of New York, told Congressional Quarterly last (week. Especially the retirees and the elderly. They are near tears, and some are in tears.

title: 3 ARAB LEADERS CONTINUE PARLEY
description: CAIRO, Sept. 11King Hussein of Jordan and Presidents Anwar elSadat of Egypt and Hafez alAssad of Syria today continued their talks aimed at ending the isolation of Jordan within the Arab world and per, mitting the, reopening of the socalled Arab eastern front against Israel.

title: $130,000 for Filly Tops at Keeneland
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 11 (AP)Top price in today's session of the Keeneland fall sale of yearling horses was $130,000 for a gray filly by Crimson Satan out of Our Jackie.

title: Cadet Committee at West Point Does Away With The Silence
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 11  The Silence, or shunning of cadets who violate the West Point honor code, has been officially discontinued by the Cadet Honor Committee.

title: Mets Lose As Mays Is Missing
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11Most of the Mets were here tonight trying to enhance the team's chances of pulling a pennant out of this bizarre season. Willie Mays wasn't here, though, so he didn't see his team stumble and lose under a barrage of four Phillie homers, 64.

title: HANOI IS ACCUSBD BY U.S. AND SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam Sept. 11 The United States and South Vietnam have issued parallel protests over reports that North Vietnam is repairing and improving 12 formerly American airfields now in Vietcong territory.

title: Connally Meets Privately With Nixon as Speculation Mounts About '76 Prospects
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 Former Treasury Secretary John B. Connally ended a twoday visit to Washington today, more than ever an emerging national leader in the Republican party he joined last May.

title: Chrysler and Mitsubishi Set Japanese Sales Deaf
description: DETROIT, Sept. 11 (AP)Chrysler International South America, a subsidiary of Chrysler Corporation, and Mitsubishi Motor Sales today signed an agreement aimed at broadening Chrysler sales in Japan.

title: Books of The Times
description: TIDE BEST AMERICAN SHORT STORIES 1973. Edited by Martha Foley. 312 pages. Hough ton Mifflin. $8.95.

title: ExG.O.P. Aide Lands Safely
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 11 (AP)A former state Republican official, George Champion Jr., 43 years old, crashlanded his twinengine plane early today and walked away from the landing unharmed authorities

title: Convention Center
description: The questions raised by the New York City Convention Center are as big as the proposed facility and there are no easy answers. Its proponents, the Convention Center Corporation and the city, claim that it will meet a pressing need for new trade show and commercial exhibition space of a size to compete with other cities with new centers, and that it will be a generator of jobs, taxes and income for New York on a grand scale. They have an impressive set of studies and figures to prove Those who oppose the scheme have an equally impressive set of figures to disprove the Convention Center's claims. The fact is that no one has really proved anything.

title: A Nonpolitical judge
description: Before his name was picked at random out of a revolving drum last May to preside at one of the most important Wails of the year, few New Yorkers outside the sphere of the Federal Courthouse in Foley Square had ever heard of Judge Lee Parsons Gagliardi. But the 55  year  old judge, on the bench since January, 1972, is no stranger to politics and certainly no stranger to his home county of Westchester, where the Gagliardis have been producing prominent lawyers and politicians for 40 years.

title: Perry Tops Yanks, 7 to 3, To Win 16th
description: Members of the faithful in the small crowd of 5,637 at Yankee Stadium last night who watched the Indians conclude a twogame set with the Yankees hardly could have been blamed had they wondered which of the two teams was in last place.

title: U.S. Lines Will Return to City From Container Port in Jersey
description: Mayor Lindsay disclosed yesterday an agreement by the United States Lines to move its huge cargo container operations from Elizabethport, N. J., to Howland Hook on Staten Island. The company moved its operations out of New York four years ago.

title: CONNECTICUT ACTS TO BAR GAS RISE
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 11The state administration sought an order in Superior Court today to roll back price increases in gasoline and other fuels imposed by the Exxon Corporation last week in defiance of Connecticut's new Petroleum Products Control Commission.

title: Target Missile Goes Awry
description: VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Sept. 11 (UPI)A Bomarc missile to be used as a target for Navy surfacetoair missiles was destroyed shortly after launching from this base today when it malfunctioned.

title: COURT OUSTS NINE ON SCHOOL BOARD
description: The nine members of Community School Board 17 in the Crown HeightsFlatbush section of Brooklyn were ousted from office yesterday by a State Supreme Court justice, who said that there were irregularities in the local board elections last May.

title: Publisher Told to Refund Encyclopedia Sales Money
description: SAN LUIS OBISPO, Calif., Sept. 11 (UN)  After four months of study, a Superior Court judge yesterday ordered a Maryland publishing house to return the money it got from college students during a 1971 spies campaign at California State Polytechnic College here.

title: U.N.'s Bureaucracy Is Hobbled By Uncertain Skills and Loyalty
description: This is the last in a series of articles in which the chief of the United Nations bureau of The New York Times examines the status of the world organization and some of the problems that have limited its effectiveness.

title: U.S. Psychiatrists Urge Soviet Talk on Dissidents
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11The American Psychiatric Association asked today for a meeting with Soviet psychiatrists to discuss charges that political dissidents have been improperly confined in mental institutions in the Soviet Union.

title: Meminger's Target: Sharper Shooting
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 11While most of the Knicks lulled away the offseason traveling to various parts of the world, relaxing, fishing and just loafing, Dean Meminger spent his summer at the New York Police Academy on East 20th Street, a short distance from where he grew up.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Otis Elevator Company announced a $12million expansion and modernization of its original factory in Yonkers. Renewal of the century  old plant, where Elisha Otis began manufacture of the safety elevator, will represent a key element in the city's plan to convert the former Getty Square slum into a modern treelined retail center.

title: Connally's Bad Advice
description: John B. Connally, who until recently was one of President Nixon's special advisers, has volunteered an extraordinary piece of special advice. He has suggested that Mr. Nixon may well he justified in ignoring the Supreme Court if it were to order the Presidential tapes of the Watergate conversations to he turned over to the special prosecutor.

title: Business Briefs
description: Singer Signs an Accord With Soviet

title: Art Season Promises a Rich Fare
description: The close of every art season brings a warning that the age of major loan exhibitions may be drawing to a close, yet each new season somehow manages to bring us an undiminished roster of sparkling exhibitions still culled, for the most part, from collections not otherwise available to the general public.

title: NEILSEN SPEEDS RATINGS REPORT
description: Because of a major change in audiencemeasurement methods instituted by the A. C. Nielsen Company, television executives will know this morning exactly how well their new Monday night shows fared with viewers.

title: AIDE REPORTS HAITI FOILED AN INCURSION
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Diminican Republic, Sept. 11 (UPI)The Haitian Embassy in the Dominican Republic said tonight that the armed forces of Haiti had broken up a guerrilla landing earlier in the day on Haiti's northwest coast in an intense gun battle.

title: EUGENE L. MULLANEY
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 11 Eugene L. Mullaney, a retired senior director of the Gillette Safety Razor Company, who practiced law in New York for over 50 years, died yesterday at his home. His age was 83.

title: MitchellStans Trial Delayed at Appeals Court Urging
description: A dramatic lastminute postponement was granted yesterday for the scheduled trial of former Attorney General John N. Mitchell and former Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stans.

title: MARRIOTT CORP. SHOWS PROFIT RISE
Tragedy in Chile
description: Any military coup is a tragedy, representing a breakdown of civilian authority and usually the collapse of government by consent. It is especially tragic for Chile, where sturdy democratic machinery had functioned, for many years and the armed forces had a strong tradition of keeping to their barracks. The Chilean tragedy will compounded if the report of President Salvador Allende Gossens' suicide proves to be true. In a country as bitterly divided as Chile has become during President Allende's three years in office, It will require tremendous skill and tact by the military chiefs now to avert widespread civil strife.

title: JUDGES QUESTION LAWYERS ON TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11The controversy over grand jury access to secret White House tape recordings was very nearly submerged in legal confusion today as the case was argued before the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.

title: JUNTA IN CHARGE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Wednesday, Sept. 12President Salvador Allende Gossens was deposed yesterday in a violent military coup, and the Santiago police said that he had committed suicide rather than surrender to the attackers.

title: Ground Is Broken For Huge Project Serving Chinatown
description: Ground was broken in Chinatown yesterday for Confucius Plaza, a $45million, sixacre school, housing and community complex just south of the foot of the Manhattan Bridge on the Bowery.

title: Unanswered Questions on Raids
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 The Pentagon's paper yesterday on the bombing of Cambodia provided more details but  to the disappointment of some Senators  did not answer the crucial questions left over from the Senate Armed Services Committee hearings last month into the secret air war. The Senators wanted to know who authorized the falsified reporting system, who designed it and who put it into effect. Instead of being provided with names such as those of President Nixon, Henry A. Kissinger, his adviser on national security, or Melvin R. Laird, the former Secretary of Defense, the statement gave the Senate list of acronyms.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: TV: Ambitious but ClicheFilled Film
description: Comes the new season, comes another deluge of madeforTV movies, those curious arrangements of miniclimaxes signaling a commercial break. Basically, so far at least, the form is a substitute for the Grade B products that used to be palmed off as second features in movie houses. A few are more ambitious than others, and someMy Sweet Charlie, Brian's Song, That Certan Summerhave succeeded in transcending the general level of mediocrity.

title: Senators See F.B.I. Report On Kissinger and Wiretaps
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11The Justice Department moved today to facilitate the confirmation of Henry A. Kissinger as Secretary of State by bowing to Senate pressure and allowing two Senators to read a secret Federal Bureau of Investigation report on 17 wiretaps carried out from 1969 to 1971 on officials and newsmen.

title: The Dance
description: The young professionals read advanced studentsof the New Dance Group Studio presented a brief and mildly intriguing program of works Monday evening at St. Clement's ChurchTheater, 423 West 46 Street. Patrons should be warned, that the level of performance while good is a cut below that of a professional dance company.

title: Power Eluded Allende, Then Slipped From His Grasp
description: When Dr. Salvador Allende Gossens was elected President of Chile, the first freely elected Marxist President in the Western Hemisphere, senators and deputies in the joint session of the Chilean Congress serenaded his choice by raising their voices in the national anthem.

title: Cutbacks Disclosed In HomeHeating Oil
description: Cutbacks of home heating oil to 80 per cent of customers' purchases last year and turbine fuel for airlines to 70 per cent of normal were made known yesterday by the Cities Service Company.

title: A WOMAN NAMED PROVOST AT YALE
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 11Yale University announced today the appointment of Hanna Holborn Gray as provost, making her the first woman to serve at the top level of the school's administration.

title: Kodes and Borg Upset on Coast
description: APTOS, Calif., Sept. 11 (UPI)Topseeded Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia was upset tonight in the opening round of the $37,500 national hard court tennis championships at the aptos Seascape Racket Club.

title: Show Rider Improves
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 (AP)John Simpson of Canada, injured when his horse crashed into a jump during the American Gold Cup horse show, was reported in good condition in Jefferson Hospital today. Simipson, of Calgary, was injured when his horse, Texas, crashed through the 12th gate during the second round of competition Sunday.

title: Times Advertising Head Retiring
description: Max Falk advertising director of The New York Times, will retire Oct. 1, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of The Times, announced yesterday.

title: HOFFMAN IS NAMED IN NEW INDICTMENTS
description: Superseding indictments have been handed up against Abbie Hoffman, the former Ytippie leader, and three others, accusing them of selling three pounds of cocaine to police undercover agents in a midtown hotel.

title: Secretariat's Trainer Undecided on Marlboro Race
description: Air early morning workout by Secretariat and a lateafternoon scramble by a dozen 2yearolds in the 84th Futurity highlight today's scheduled activities at Belmont Park.

title: Equity Financing
description: An offering of 800,000 common shares of Utah Power & Light Company at $34.75 per share was made by underwriters headed by White, Weld; Goldman Sachs; Paine, Webber; Smith Barney and duPont Walston. The underwriters were awarded the shares in competitive bidding with a bid of $33.935 a share. The company's stock was down  at 34 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: 85 Farm Workers Protest Sale of Nonunion Produce
description: ELIZABETH, Sept. 11 (AP) A group of California farm workers, some with their families, picketed a food wholesaler for ShopRite supermarkets here today to protest marketing of nonunion grapes and lettuce.

title: Riggins Talks to Ewbank; Contract Signing Closer
description: John Riggins, the reluctant holdout, entered into third round of contract negotiations with Weeb Ewbank, wearing the cap of the Jets general manager, at Shea Stadium yesterday.

title: A Wine Dealer in Bordeaux Is Checked in New Inquiry
description: BORDEAUX, Sept. 11 (Reuters)Customs officals are checking the stocks of a Bordeaux wine house suspected of holding millions of gallons of cheap imported wine for call as quality Bordeaux red, customs sources said today, Up to 100 million bottles are said to be involved.

title: Perry Davis Marries Miss Greenbaum
description: Miss MargyRuth Greenbaum was married here last evening to Perry, Davis, an assistant to Mayor bindsay. Rabbis Bernard Rosenzweig and Steven Riskin performed the ceremony in the Lincoln Square Synagogue.

title: MAYORAL PRIMARY HEED IN DETROIT
description: DETROIT, Wednesday, Sept. 12Police Commissioner John F. Nichols, a conservative lawandorder candidate, and State Senator Coleman Young, a black liberal, appeared this morning to have qualified as the two candidates for Mayor in the general election Nov. 6.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Senate Panel Mail, By 50 to 1, Opposes Kissinger Approval
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 While Henry A. Kissinger's nomination as Secretary of State has aroused little opposition in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, mail from the public received by the committee in the last week has been overwhelmingly against Senate approval of Mr. Kissinger.

title: RECORD FORECAST FOR '73 CORN CROP
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11  The nation's corn crop, key to consumer food supplies in 1974, Will set a record of 5.77 billion bushels this year, up 4 per cent from last year and 2 per cent more than forecast in August, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Baseball Transactions AMERICAN LEAGUE
description: OaklandPurchased Rico Carty, outfielder, from Chicago Cubs.

title: Tough Call on Steel
description: The price of steel has long been accorded a special symbolic importance as an indicator of inflation; it was the basis of the famous confrontation between President Kennedy and the steel industry in 1963. However much the steel industry may regard such attention as unfair, steel prices have still not lost their symbolic importance.

title: Underworld Banker Is Tied to Trot Fixes
description: An underworld banker helped finance the betting syndicate that allegedly fixed superfecta races at New York harness tracks, a source close to the investigation disclosed yesterday.

title: Women See Boycott
description: VINELAND, Sept. 11Members of the South Jersey Board of Women's Officials, a group which has been supplying basketball referees for 18 high schools in four South Jersey counties for six years, have found themselves with no contracts for the 197374 season. And according to Mrs. Carol Pesiri, chairwoman of the board, it is because of their efforts to get equal pay.

title: 12 SLACKERS SHOT, CAMBODIANS HEAR
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sept. 11At least 12 officers in the Cambodian Army were put to death Friday for ordering their troops to retreat before a rebel attack near the besieged city of Kompong Cham, reliable sources reported today.

title: Advertising: A Market Analysis
description: One way for a manufacturer to beat price controls is to bring out a new product that had no previous price.

title: Get Off The Phones
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11The Senate Foreign Relations Committee seems determined to find out Henry Kissinger's role in wiretapping his own officials and newspaper reporters few years ago but less determined to get at the main thing, which is to get hold of this wiretapping mania in the future.

title: LARGE COMPANIES SEEK PRICE RISES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 The Cost of Living Council reported today that large corporations had notified it of their intentions to raise prices on more than a thousand products and groups of products.

title: Morrison, as a Coach, Still Reacts as a Player
description: Coach Joe Morrison, for 14 years a New York Giant, said he felt itchy Saturday as his football team, the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga, lost to Eastern Kentucky, 106., It was the first time in 21 years that he hadn't started a season in somebody's football uniform.

title: Senate Leaders to Discuss Budget Outlook With Ash
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) Senate Democratic leaders agreed today to a Nixon Administration proposal for a series of meetings with key Senators to discuss next year's budget outlook.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SHOESTRINGS For 10 years Howard Goldberg has been shepherding his increasing flock of the curious to events, people, places and things for very little money. We call it exploring the world within our reach, within our means, he says. Mr. Goldbergwho writes about science for a living, but is president of Adventure on a Shoestring otherwise  has arranged, for example, chats with a woman torero, a lie detection expert and a ghost hunter; guided tours into submarines, paper  recycling plants and vermouthblenders, and lessons in bartending, fishing and handwriting analysis.

title: 3XRAYTYPES HELD RISK IN PREGNANCY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11At least three types of drag nostic Xray procedures could expose a pregnant woman to enough radiation to be a serious danger to the fetus, two scientists reported today to an international meeting on radiation protection.

title: JOHN CHENEY GLIDDEN
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Sept. 11  John Cheney Glidden, vice president of Stone & Webster Securities Corporation, New York, died today at his home, 139 Chestnut Street. He was 55 years old.

title: Philadelphia Store Accused Of Illegal Strikebreaking
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 (UPI)A criminal warrant was issued yesterday against a Lit Brothers department store here, charging it with using illegal strikebreaking tactics.

title: Stay of Eviction at Northside Is Denied
description: A lastminute court move to stay the eviction of eight families in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn failed yesterday and the city prepared to remove them this morning.

title: 3 OIL CONCERNS TOLD TO LOWER EMISSIONS
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (UPI)The Environmental Protection Agency notified three Indiana oil refineries today that they must reduce the sulphur dioxide emissions coming from their plants in Whiting and East Chicago.

title: EDWARD A. CRONE
description: PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 11Edward A. Crone, a retired municipalbond specialist with several Wall Street firms, died yesterday at his home, 319 Franklin Place. He was 74 years old.

title: A Consent Decree Accord Is Set by Coastal States
description: The Coastal States Gas Corporation and the Securities and Exchange Commission approved yesterday a consent decree settlement of a civil complaint filed by the S.E.C. alleging that Coastal States had violated S.E.C. regulations and provisions of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

title: Gleason Signs 2Year Pact To Do N.B.C. Drama Shows
description: MIAMI, Sept. 11 (AP)Jackie Gleason, the comedian, said today he has signed a twoyear contract with the National Broadcasting Company for a minimum of three television shows a year.

title: RECORD FORECAST FOR '73 CORN CROP
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11  The nation's corn crop, a key to consumer food supplies in 1974, will set a record of 5.77 billion bushels this year, up 4 per cent from last year and 2 per cent more than forecast in August, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Ali Wants A Frazier Rematch
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Sept. 11Negotiations for a rematch between Muhammad Ali and Joe Frazier are close to being completed, according to Bob Arum, one of Ali's attorneys and the president of Top Rank, Inc., the closed circuit TV company.

title: Nixons' Potential '70 Deductions Enough to Offset Taxable Income
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 President and Mrs. Nixon may have claimed enough tax deductions in 1970, and possibly in 1971 as well, to have wiped out all of their taxable income for Federal income tax purposes, according to figures published by the White House and other official sources.

title: State Aide Says Cold Spell Would Peril Fuel Supplies
description: TRENTON, Sept. 11  A severe winter or protracted cold spell could force New Jersey utilities to curtail naturalgas deliveries to lowpriority industrial and commercial customers so as to continue service to homeowners, Arthur Schoenwald, executive director of the State Board of Public Utility, Commissioners, said today.

title: MitchellStans Trial Delayed at Appeals Court Urging
description: By ARNOLD H. LUBASCH

title: Sports Today
description: Sports Today

title: Hogan Underwent Chest Surgery Secretly
description: District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of Manhattan underwent chest surgery at St. Luke's Hospital, last Friday, Mr. Hogan's chief assistant announced yesterday.

title: People and Business
description: Melvin R. Laird, the President's chief domestic adviser, said yesterday that the nation's inflation was a good problem, not a bad problem, because it was the result of pentup dollars abroad being spent on American food.

title: Where Is The Year of Europe?
description: According to Henry Kissinger this was supposed to be The Year of Europe for U.S. policy but the chances of real success are modest. Not that it isn't high time to check the erosion of transAtlantic relationships; it is simply that too many unforeseen frustrations have occurred.

title: $275,000 in Prizes For U.S. Grand Prix
description: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Sept. 4 (AP)A prize fund of $275,000 was announced today for the United States Grand Prix auto race here Oct. 7.

title: Adhesive Spray Is Curbed
description: AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 11The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company announced today that it has voluntarily halted production and distribution of its Clear Spray Adhesive aerosol spray on Aug. 17 as a precautionary measure because of questions about the safety of such sprays.

title: Bill on TV Blackouts Near Vote
description: The House of Representatives is expected to vote tomorrow on a bill that would prohibit the National Football League from continuing its television blackouts of the teams' home games provided all tickets had been sold 72 hours in advance.

title: Grapes: About to Be Raisins Again
description: Those who are used to eating them only when they are chocolate coated or are in dark fruit cakes are probably unaware that some people have been suffering a deprivation far more poignant than a mere beef or gasoline shortage.

title: Barry Goldwater
description: WASHINGTONLike most public scandals of great magnitude, Watergate has spawned many collateral vices, not the least of which is the offense which has become known to the American public as McCarthyism.

title: Townhouse Plan Splits L.I. Blacks
description: MANHASSET, L. I.  At Herman Jackson's little grocery store on Spinney Hill, you can buy Railroad Mills Sweet Snuff or canned hogmaws or many varieties of canned greens, all favorites of the small black community here.

title: BANK OF ENGLAND PEGS INTEREST RATE
description: LONDON, Sept. 11 (Reuters)  The Bank of England said today it had asked all banks to pay an interest rate no higher than 9 per cent on deposits of less than 10,000. The measure is effective immediately.

title: P.S.C. Examiner Suggests Rejection of Phone Merger
description: ALBANY, Sept. 11 (UPI)A Public Service Commission examiner today recommended that the panel reject a proposed merger of the Sylvan Lake Telephone Company into a subsidiary of the Rochester Telephone Corporation.

title: Increase Is Vital to Western Nations, Analysts Say
description: Hisham Nazer, president of the Central Planning Organization of Saudi Arabia, said here yesterday that increased oil production would depend to a large degree on the extent of industrialization of the Saudi economy.

title: JonesMoraites Fraud Trial Under Way
description: NEWARK, Sept. 11The trial of two formerly prominent New Jersey political figures on charges of violation of Federal banking regulations and mail fraud opend in Federal District Court here this morning before Judge Lawrence A. Whipple.

title: GRACE TO SUPPLY CATALYSTS TO G.M.
description: W. R. Grace & Co. has signed an agreement with the General Motors Corporation to supply automobile emission  control catalysts, it was announced last night. The agreement calls for delivery to General Motors of 12 million to 15 million pounds of catalysts in each year of the threeyear supply contract for the model years, 1975 through 1977.

title: BERNARD E. McGUIRE
description: Bernard Edward McGuire, for three decades a newspaper telegrapher and teletypist with the North American Newspaper Alliance, died Sunday in St. Elizabeth's division of St. Clare's Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 91 Payson Avenue.

title: ISRAELIS ARE VOTING IN LABOR ELECTION
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 11The General Federation of Labor held elections throughout Israel today amid reports that the Government was hoping that the list of candidates headed by Premier Golda Meir would again win control but by a smaller margin than las time.

title: U.S. NOT SURPRISED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11United States officials were not surprised by the Chilean armed forces' revolt today, but they declined to comment for the record, to avoid even a hint of commitment to the overthrow of President Salvador Allende Gossens or involvement in it.

title: PATRICK J. CULLEN
description: Patrick J. Cullen, assistant treasurer and general service banking officer of the Times Square branch of the Chase Manhattan Bank, died in Polyclinic Hospital yesterday after being taken ill at work. He was 62 years old and lived at 14527 231st Street in the Rosedale section of Queens.

title: Jersey Is Given a Deadline On ParishSchool Material
description: NEWARK, Sept. 11A Federal court today ordered New Jersey to repossess by Oct. 31 more than $amillion in school equipment distributed to 700 nonpublic schools under the terms of a special aid program that has been declared unconstitutional.

title: About the Knicks:
description: Jerry Lucas reported to training camp with a torn muscle in his lower back. I have had back problems before, said Lucas, but it's never been this painful before. I can't bend or make any quick moves, The injury occurred two weeks ago, soon after I began working out. .. Henry Bibby and Bill Bradley also reported with minor leg ailments that, will slow their workouts for a few days. ... Red Holzman, the general manager and coach, said negotiations were continuing with Mel Davis, the No. draft choice from St. John's. According to. Lou Carnesecca, the St. John's basketball coach, Davis has registered for 12 credits. It doesn't matter whether Davis attends school. The Knicks would only lose the draft rights to him if he plays at St. John's, where he has a year of eligibility remaining. Monmouth College will give Holzman testimonial dinner next Tuesday at the Old Orchard Inn in Eatontown, N. J. The proceeds of the dinner will go to the school .... Phil Jackson, who spent the summer fishing in Montana, has a fullgrown beard .... Willis Reed, free of injuries for the first time in two years, appears to have regained much of his quickness. His weight is 242 pounds, 6 less than at the end of last season.

title: Sakharov: This, Not That
description: MOSCOWThe newspaper campaign [in the Soviet Union] with respect to my recent interviews employs as its fundamental argument the accusation that I am supposedly speaking against the relaxation of international tension, almost in favor of war. This is an unscrupulous play on the antiwar feelings of the nation which suffered the most from the Second Worad War, which lost millions of its sons and daughters. This is a deliberate distortion of position.

title: NIXON OPTIMISTIC ON DRUG ABUSES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP)President Nixon told a conference of judges, prosecutors, educators and law enforcement officers today that we've turned the corner on drug addiction in the United States.

title: FRENCH PRESIDENT ARRIVES IN PEKING
description: PEKING, Wednesday, Sept. 12 (Reuters)President Pompidou of France arrived here yesterday on the first trip to China by a West European head of state. At a dinner in his honor, he heard Premier Chou Enlai warn that the danger of war still existed and blame the nuclear superpowers for world tensions.

title: SOUVANNA SEEMS VICTOR ON ACCORD
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 11 The Premier, Prince Souvanna Phouma, appeared today to have assembled a fairly solid bloc within his Government and army in favor of signing the completed agreement for a coalition government with the Pathet Lao.

title: Woman Realizes Dream And Enters City U. at 83
description: Bertha Rosenthal Farmer was 17 years old when she received a diploma in 1907 from High School No. 147 on the Lower East Side. She vowed that Someday I'm going to go to college, even though she had to seek a job as a typist and bookkeeper to help support a widowed mother.

title: U.S. NOT SURPRISED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11United States officials were not surprised by the Chilean armed forces' revolt today, but they declined to comment for the record, to avoid even a hint of commitment to the overthrow of President Salvador Allende Gossens or involvement in it.

title: Otis Elevator Will Stay In Yonkers and Modernize
description: YONKERS, Sept. 11  The Otis Elevator Company indicated its confidence in the future of downtown Yonkers today by announcing a $12million expansion and modernization of its original factory here.

title: Socialist Says Allende Once Spoke of Suicide
description: RENNES, France, Sept. 11 (AP)The French Socialist leader, Francois Mitterrand, said tonight that President Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile told him two years ago that he would commit suicide if he were overthrown.

title: Army Enlistments Fall Short of Goal for Seventh Month in Row
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11Enlistments in the volunteen Army were 19 per cent below the goal set for August, and those in all four services were 11 per cent short of the goal. Secretary of Defense James R Schlesinger announced today.

title: Service Strike Is Ended At U. of Massachusetts
description: AMHERST, Mass., Sept. 11 (AP)An interruption of campus services was averted today at the University of Massachusetts When a strike by 1,000 nonprofessional employes ended the day it began.

title: COPPER FUTURES HIT BOTTOM AGAIN
description: The active December copper futures contract hit bottom again on traders' charts early yesterday of 74 cents a pound. Then came reports that the Government of President Allende of Chile had been ousted.

title: John P. Davis Dies at 68, Negroes Congress Officer
description: John Preston Davis, former national secretary of the National Negroes Congress, who edited the wellknown reference volume, The American Negro Reference Book, died on Monday at the BronxLebanon Hospital Center. He was 68 years old and lived at 1809 Bartow Avenue, the Bronx.

title: Senators See F.B.I. Report; On Kissinger and W iretaps
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 The Justice Department moved today to facilitate the confirmation of Henry A. Kissinger as Secretary of State by bowing to Senate pressure and allowing two Senators to read a secret Federal Bureau of Investigation report on 17 wiretaps carried out from 1969 to 1971 on officials and newsmen.

title: Lack of Funds Hampering 3 of 4 Mayoral Candidates
description: Three of the four mayoral candidates are so short of campaign funds that their campaigns may be severely handicapped. The empty campaign coffers reflect a widespread feeling among ton politicians and contributors that the three candidates are trailing far behind the Democratic mayoral contender, Controller Abraham D. Beame, and have little chance of catching up.

title: Bank Executive Is Named March of Dimes Chairman
description: The appointment of Frank G. Frederiksen, senior vice president of the Chemical Bank, as general chairman of the 1974 March of Dimes in New York City was announced yesterday by R. Jennings Mangum, chairman of the New York Chapter of the National FoundationMarch of Dimes.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Open Interest
description: Tuesday, Sept. 11, 1973 (In bushels, 000 omitted)

title: Blast in Nicosia
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept 11 (Reuters)A man, apparently a policeman, was seriously inlured when a bomb exploded beside a busy traffic circle here today. Delegates to intercommunal talks were gathering in the House of Representatives 300 yards away.

title: WAGNER SUPPORTS BEANIE FOR MAYOR
description: Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner endorsed Controller Abraham D. Beanie for Mayor yesterday and urged the biggest vote possible for his fellow Democrat to give him the kind of mandate needed to run this city.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Metropolitan Open Starts Today

title: JUDGES QUESTION LAWYERS ON TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11The controversy over grand jury access to secret White House tape recordings was very nearly submerged in legal confusion today as the case was argued before the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.

title: OPENING DELAYED AT HARLEM PREP
description: Harlem Prep, a sixyearold school serving 600 students, has apparently been overtaken by its perennial financial crisis, according to administrators who said yesterday that the school had not resumed classes this week because of a lack of funds.

title: Lowery Resigns as Fire Commissioner
description: Commissioner Robert O. Lowery, the first black to head the 14,000man Fire Department and the first cabinet member appointed by Mayor Lindsay, resigned yesterday to campaign for Controller Abraham D. Beame, the Democratic candidate for Mayor.

title: Lack of Funds Hampering 3 of 4 Mayoral Candidates
description: Three of the four mayoral candidates are so short of campaign funds that their campaigns may be severely handicapped.

title: Japan's Top Court Will Get Plea on Legality of Forces
description: TOKYO, Sept. 11 (Reuters)The Government decided today to appeal directly to the Supreme Court, rather than a high court, against a decision by a district court judge last week that the Japanese defense forces were unconstitutional.

title: Landry Selects Staubach; Morton Asks for a Trade
description: DALLAS, Sept. 11 (UPI)Coach Tom Landry of the Dallas Cowboys named Roger Staubach his No. 1 quarterback today and Craig Morton promptly asked to be traded.

title: Soviet Ships at Savannah
description: SAVANNAH, Ga., Sept. 11 (AP)Two Russian oceapographic research vessels have docked at the Port of Savannah on what the United States Coast Guard termed today a combination of goodwill visit and logistics stop.

title: New American Ambassador To Laos Begins Duty There
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 11 (Agence France  Presse) Charles S. Whitehouse arrived here today to take up his duties as the new American Ambassador to Laos.

title: Nixon Advance Men Sued Over Pekin, III., Protest
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (AP)The American Civil Liberties Union filed a, $300,000 damage suit in Federal Court today, contending that White House advance men violated the constitutional rights of five demonstrators during a speeech by President Nixon.

title: Carolina Aide, 33, Named Prison Chief By Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, Sept. 11  Gov. Francis W. Sargent named a new Commissioner of Corrections today to fill the vacancy left by the dismissal of John O. Boone.

title: Screen:' Battle of Okinawa' Has Ambiguous Viewpoint
description: With "Battle of Okinawa," which opened yesterday at the Elgin Theater, Japanese film makers continue to explore the limited dramatic possibilities of the not-quite-documentary historical feature that Darryl F. Zanuck exploited so successfully in "The Longest Day," and then virtually annihilated in the boredom of "Tora! Tora! Tora!"The film covers a period of approximately one year, beginning in the summer of 1944, when the Japanese high command decided to prepare the island for possible American invasion, and following through the invasion itself and the terrible hill-by-hill, cave-by-cave fighting that came after. Kihachi Okamoto, the director, uses some old newsreel clips (which become wildly distorted by the CinemaScope lens) and efficiently restages most key scenes, though in rather more massive detail than a nonmilitary student may be interested in.The most curious thing about the film is its difficult-to-define point of view. It seems to have reservations about the miltary men who denied adequate protection to Okinawa, and it seems to be very pro-Okinawa, one-third of whose population was slain in the fighting.Yet "Battle of Okinawa" gets so wrapped up in showing examples of the terrorthe slaughter of soldiers and the mass suicides of civiliansthat the spectacle of the carnage overwhelms any pity. The movie keeps saying in effect: "Look at what these people endured," but the images are those of conventional make-believe gore. They are not good enough.

title: PAPER COMPANY RESUMING TALKS
description: Negotiators for the United Paperworkers International Union and the strikebound Canadian International Paper Company are scheduled to resume negotiations on Friday in an attempt to end the sixweekold strike, according to the union.

title: MILITARY ASSAILED ON SUICIDE OF P.O.W.
description: BRIGHTON, Colo., Sept. 11 (AP)  A coroner's jury, ruling today that an accused former prisoner of war had committed suicide, criticized the military service for its handling of the case.

title: COPPER FUTURES HIT BOTTOM AGAIN
description: The active December copper futures contract hit bottom again on traders' charts early yesterday of 74 cents a pound Then came reports that the Government of President Allende of Chile had been ousted.

title: Benches at Grant's. Tom Getting Mosaic Touch
description: The columned dome of Grant's Tomb cuts over the trees of Riverside Park in pointed majesty. Up close, jagged smears of red, green, and blue graffiti mar the Tomb's austere granite surface.

title: Susquehanna Corp. Halts Dividends on Preferred
description: The Susquehanna Corporation announced in Los Angeles yesterday that it had suspended payment of dividends on its Class A cumulative convertible preferred stock for an indefinite period.

title: Norway Labor Party Barely Wins Vote
description: OSLO, Norway, Sept. 11Norway's Labor party and its leader, Trygve Bratteli, will form the next government in the wake of the nation's closefought general elections.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is gratifying that the concern about the nation's misuse of its limited and irreplaceable land resources, which was once shared by only a few conservationists and planners, has now proliferated to the point that the nation may be about to embrace a new land ethic rejecting the concept of land as a commodity and asserting the interests of all of the nation's citizens in the manner of its use.

title: PRICEFIXING LAID TO G.M. AND PORt
description: DETROIT, Sept. 11  The Government told a Federal Court jury today it would prove that the General Motors Corporation and the. Ford Motor Company had an unspoken agreement to fix prices illegally in autofleet sales.

title: Penn Central Rider Wins $11.80 Verdict For a NoSeat Ride
description: A man who was forced to stand on a crowded Penn Central train from Grand Central Terminal to White Plains two years ago won a jury verdict yesterday awarding him a refund of his $1.80 fare plus $10 damages for discomfort.

title: Lockheed May Get Big Hughes Loan
description: A letter of intent for a $100million loan commitment from Howard Hughes, the industrialist, has been approved by the board of directors of the Lockheed Corporation to enable financing of an extended range Lockheed L1011 Tristar jet aircraft, it was announced last night.

title: Goal Set on Basic Approach in Trade Talks
description: TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept. 12 (AP)Ministers of the nine member countries of the European Economic Community coded a prolonged negotiating session early this morning by agreeing on a basic approach to the question of trademonetary linkage in forthcom ing international deliberations on both topics, Sir Christopher Soames, the E.E.C. trade commissioner, said.

title: ARMSTRONG BARS QUEENS D.A. RACE
description: District Attorney Michael F. Armstrong of Queens, who is serving an interim term following the indictment and resignation of Thomas J. Mackell, announced yesterday that he was not a candidate for a full fouryear term.

title: The Greatest Is Now the Tiredest
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Sept. 11In other years, after other fights, Muhammad Ali liked to touch his face and preen.

title: FIRE SAFETY BYE ON PUNS SOUGHT
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday that it had asked the nation's airlines to place no smoking signs in the lavatories of all commercial airliners. It also said that it would make a special inspection of all airliner lavatories for potential fire, hazards.

title: James B. Carey Is Dead at 62; Labor Leader Founded I.U.E.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept: 11 (UPI)James B, Carey, founder and first president of the 285,000member International Union of Electrical Workers, died today, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in suburban Silver Spring, Md. He was 62 old.

title: Allende, a Man of the Privileged Class Turned Radical Politician
description: Three years ago, shortly before the end of Salvador Allende Gossens's fourth campaign for the presidency of Chile, he reflected on his three previous failures and said: If I lose this time too I'll just keep trying until the day I die. And if I don't make it then, my epitaph should read: Here lies Salvador Allende, a future president of Chile.

title: Haring on Nixon Tapes: Grave but Not Dramatic
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11Senator John C. Stennis, who has been around long enough to acquire the proper perspective, said that what went on in the United States District Courthouse here today was bound to be historic; but, for any spectators hoping that a constitutional confrontation would make courtroom drama, it was a flop.

title: City Decides to Return to Buying Its Beef From Wholesalers' Bids
description: The city went back yesterday to buying beef from wholesalers after the Purchase Commissioner, Marvin Gersten, estimated that the latest bids by wholesalers would lead to an average cost of $1.06 a pound, cut up and delivered.

title: Lakers Fine Chamberlain, West For Missing Start of Practice
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 11Neither Wilt Chamberlain nor Jerry West showed up today as the Los Angeles Lakers bgan preseason practice. Pete Newell, the general manager, promptly said they would be fined. The same appied to Keith Erickson, whose absence was less newsworthy.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Metropolitan Open Starts Today

title: 12 SLACKERS SHOT, CAMBODIANS NEAR
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sept. 11At least 12 officers in the Cambodian Army were put to death Friday for ordering their troops to retreat before a rebel attack near the besieged city of Kompong Cham, reliable sources reported today.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended Sept. 4:

title: Shortages in U.S. Schools Forcing Diverse Cutbacks
description: The country's public elementary and high schools have opened for a new school year under pressure from many of the unaccustomed shortages that have affected American households.

title: Nixon Legislative Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI)  President Nixon appointed Vernon C. Loen today as a special White House assistant for legislative affairs, succeeding James M. Sperling, who resigned. Mr. Loen, 41 years old, will assist Max L. Friedersdorf in liaison with the House of Representatives.

title: Julie Eisenhower Now an Editor
description: The White House announced that Mrs. David Eisenhower, the former Julie Nixon, had been hired at $10,000 a year as an assistant editor by the Curtis Publishing Company of Indianapolis. The President's daughter is expected to edit materials for the company's children's magazines, Jack and Jill, Child Life, Children's Playmate and Young World.

title: Firemen Get Upper Hand In Timber Blazes on Coast
description: Firefighters aided by ocean fog and dipping temperatures got the upper hand yesterday an two timber blazes that charred 20,000 acres in northern California, United Press International reported.

title: Market Place: Investment Role Of Institutions
description: United States Senators are becoming big drawing cards for luncheon meetings of the New York Society of Security Analysts, a group that usually listens to corporate executives and stockmarket observers.

title: Byrne Presses for TV Debates, Warning He May Appear Alone
description: TRENTON, Sept. 11Charging that Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., the Republican candidate for Governor, was attempting to avoil televised campaign debates, the campaign manager for Brendan T. Byrne, the Democratic nominee, warned today that Mr. Byrne would appear by himself, even if it meant debating an empty chair.

title: ANGELA DAVIS' LEADS ALLENDE RALLY HERE
description: Angela Davis blamed the United States Government last night for bringing about the military overthrow of President Salvadore Allende Gossens in Chile.

title: Stock Market Ends Lower; Dow Dips 5.57 to 885.76
description: The stock market tried hard late yesterday at least to break even but finally closed with a loss of 5.57 points in the DowJones industrial average.

title: ARTHUR GLASS,
description: Arthur Glass former assistant sports editor and copy editor with the New York Herald Tribune, The New York World Telegram and The Sun and The World Journal Tribune, died yesterday at Jewish Memorial Hospital of a heart ailment. He was 74 years old and lived at 90 Park Terrace East.

title: Rockefeller Says He Would Not Veto Death Penalty Bill
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 11 Governor Rockefeller declared today that if the Legislature passed a bill reinstating the death penalty, he would sign it.

title: Report Finds Tracks On Passenger Lines Both Good and Bad
description: NEWARK, Sept. 11 (AP)A first report today to the state Public Utilities Commission on the condition of passenger railroad tracks in New Jersey showed some good and some bad.

title: Roundup: Bucs' Blass Wins While Losing
description: The Chicago Cubs restored Steve Blass' confidence yesterday at the same time they frustrated the Pittsburgh Pirates' atempt to gain on the St. Louis Cardinals in the National League East pennant race.

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: When Gay Clement of 229 West 22d Street Stepped up to one of the boxoffice windows at the Times Square Theater Center in Duffy Square yesterday afternoon to buy a pair of tickets to last night's performance of A Little Night Music, she was informed that she was the winner of a bonanza.

title: South Africa Police Kill 10 Black Miners In a Labor Dispute
description: CARLETONVILLE, South Africa, Wednesday, Sept. 12 (Reuters)Policemen shot 10 black miners to death during disturbances at the Western Deep Levels Gold Mine here last night, the mine owners said today.

title: Cadet Committee at West Point Does Away With The Silence
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 11  The Silence, or shunning of cadets who violate the West Point honor code, has been officially discontinued by the Cadet Honor Committee.

title: CORPORATE BONDS DECLINE IN PRICE
description: Prices of seasoned corporate bonds eased again yesterday is one of the larger new financings in recent days came to market.

description: Judge Refuses to Bar S.C.I. Hearing

description: Horses & Equipment 3995

title: U.S. COMPANIES LOOKING TO CHILE
description: Some of the big United States corporations whose properties were Seized by the Chilean Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens indicated yesterday that they might consider resuming manufacturing in Chile if a new government there were receptive to investment.

title: Governor Doubts Party Loss
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 11 (AP) Governor Rockefeller of New York said today that he did not feel that Watergate would harm the Republican party. I don't think they [Watergate] are problems of the party, but are problems of indiviuals, he told a news conference.

title: ExHospital Head Indicted In Thefts of Aides' Checks
description: A former administrator of Children's Hospital in the Bronx was indicted yesterday and charged with grand larcen and forgery, according to Bronx District Attorney Mario Merola.

title: Multinational Companies Defend Role Before U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 11  Leaders of five big corporations went before a United Nations panel today to insist their concerns behave as good guests abroad, contribute to the prosperity of the countries in which they do business and do not meddle in politics.

title: Yugoslav Jet Strikes Mountain; All 42 Aboard Believed Killed
description: TITOGRAD, Yugoslavia, Sept. 11 (AP)A Yugoslav airliner crashed into a mountain peak near here today while preparing to land. All 42 persons aboard were believed killed, officials reported.

title: A NEW MAGAZINE, CHICAGOAN, IS OUT
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 12  The Chicagoan, a new monthly magazine devoted to the hap penings and affairs of the coun try's second city, published its first issue today.

title: Senate Passes a Bill Requiring Definition Of All Warranties
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) The Senate passed today a major consumer protection bill requiring that sellers state spe cifically what warranties mean.

title: EAST BLOC SEEKING TO BUY U.S. TEXTILES
description: The countries of Eastern Eu rope are in the market for textiles manufactured in this country, the American Textile Manufacturers Institute said yesterday.

title: Advertising: Black Velvet Here
description: Now that American light whisky has been around for more than a year, how would you characterize its impact on the drinking pub lic?

title: Wall Street's Future
description: Despite its newly won ap proval for higher brokerage fees  a shot in the arm, as one investment man put it yes terdayWall Street still faces a wave of mergers and consol idations.

title: Clurman Threatens To Shut Bryant Park
description: Stressing that it was neces sary to get citizens involved in maintaining the city's parks, Mr. Clurman told a meeting of trustees of the New York Public Library that parts of Bryant. Park, behind the library's main Fifth Avenue building, had become a disgrace, The park, he said, is inhabitated by gamblers, junkies, brownbaggers sucking at wine and liquor bottles, dere licts, panhandlers and men acing ripoff specialists.

title: 2 Homers Help Mets Subdue Phils, 32
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 Willie Mays continued his mystifying behavior tonight by rejoining the Mets when he wasn't expected to. But it was other Mets, including John Milner and Tug Mc Graw, who helped spark the team to a 32 victory over Philadelphia, and kept the pennant hopes alive.

title: The Oracle Sees Miami on Top
description: The Miami Dolphins will go through the season; which starts Sunday, undefeated and untied once more. Green Bay will win 13 games and tie its other game, while Washington's final wonlost tied record will be 1310. The Redskin loss will be to Pittsburgh. The Giants and Jets? Definite possibilities for the playoffs as the qualifying divisional sec andplace teams in each conference, American and National.

title: Sesame Street Screen Shows Naked Women
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 12 (AP) Children tuning in Sesame Street yesterday saw the Cookie Monster flicker off their television screens to he replaced by a parade of naked women.

title: SCHOOL LUNCHES FACING WIDE CUTS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 An estimated 800,000 children are either being dropped from or are dropping out of the fed erally subsidized school lunch program because of rising food prices, Senate investigators close today.

title: Rise in Fees Called Justified by Losses
description: Ray Garrett Jr., the new chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said yes terday that approval of higher commission rates for stock brokerage firms was justified by the dismal financial condi tion of the industry.

title: GATT Begins Talks to Liberalize World Trade
description: TOKYO, Sept. 12Members of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade began a sweeping twoyear effort here today to cut tariffs, reduce other trade barriers and gen erally liberalize world trade.

title: CAMBODIA CLAIMS A MAJOR VICTORY
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sept. 12  A Government spokesman reported today that enemy forces had been cleared from the embattled provincial capital of Kompong Cham and that the Phnom Penh Govern meet had won a clearcut vio tory.

title: Screen
description: Given the ingredients of firstrate psychological mys tery, Jealousy, a Japanese film that opened yesterday at the Bijou Theater, manages to deliver no more than soap opera  and unexceptional soap opera at that.

title: 2 MORE BOMBINGS HURT 8 IN LONDON
description: LONDON, Sept. 12 (AP) London's third and fourth bomb blasts in three days exploded today in a crowded shopping area and in the Chelsea dis trict. Eight persons were re ported injured.

title: A Slugging Marchi Accuses Wagner, Mayor and Beanie of All but Ruining City
description: State Senator John J. Marchi yesterday promised New York ers that they were going to see a slugging John Marchi from now, to election day.

title: Dance: Royal Danish Ballet at Home
description: COPENHAGEN, Sept. 11 It is always a pleasure to see the Royal Danish Ballet in its home theater here. With its long, unbroken history, and its homogenous style, the Royal Danish Ballet has a very welldefined profile that combines classicism with a considerable degree of ad yenturousness.

title: Upbeat Nostalgia Tones ScatSinging Of Pointer Sisters
description: Roseland probably hasn't been so full since big bands came back in a big waythe Pointer Sisters attracted about 3,500 rock fans, glitter people and the curious to the venerable Rose land Ballroom on West 52d Street for their official city, debut on Monday.

title: Environmental Protection Chief Says Nation Faces Test of Its Commitment to CleanUp
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 Russell E. Train, the new head of the Environmental Protec tion Agency, said today that he thought the nation was enter ing a period of testing the public commitment to environ mental progress and that he was confident that the com mitment would be fulfilled.

title: Body Found in Mine
description: FARMINGTON, W. Va., Sept. 12 (UPI)  Recovery crews yesterday found the body of a coal mine mechanic who was among 78 men killed in the 1968 Farmington No. 9 mine disaster. The victim was identi fied as Lloyd Wilson, 45 years old, of Fairmont, W. Va. His body was the 33rd recovered since the disaster.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:

title: Is Giants Defense Real? Pastorini, Coach Split
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 12 Unlike his coach, who spoke with respect that bordered on reverence, Dan Pastorini is not awed by the New York Giant defense and their fancy preseason statistics.

title: POLICEMAN SLAIN IN JERSEY CITY
description: JERSEY CITY, Thursday, Sept. 13A 26yearold police officer was shot to death here by a sniper last night after he had responded to a complaint of a doubleparked car, the po lice reported. Three men were seized and charged with mur der.

title: Britain Decides to Begin Work On a Channel Tunnel to France
description: LONDON, Sept. 13  The British Government said today that it had decided to go ahead with the construction of a tun nel under the English Channel to France.

title: Heroin Dealer Assails U.S. Judge Before Receiving a Life Sentence
description: A convicted heroin dealer was sentenced to life imprison ment and fined $300,000 in Federal District Court here yes terday after he bitterly de nounced the judge and the prosecution.

title: White House Agrees to Turn Over Some Documents in Milk Price Case
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 The White House offered today in Federal Court to permit pri vate judicial review of a series of confidential Administration memorandrums In connection with the controversial 1971 increase in Federal milk price supports.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Stories which have been filling our newspapers, magazines and television screens in recent days have fostered a dangerously distorted view of rela tions between business and govern ment in this country.

title: ALLENDE BACKERS WARNED BY JUNTA NOT TO BEAR ARMS
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 12 Chile's new military rulers announced today that a private funeral had been held for Presi dent Salvador Allende Gossens and warned that armed sup porters of the dead Marxist leader would be shot on the spot if taken prisoner.

title: U. S. FUNDS COME TO LIBRARY'S AID
description: The National Endowment for the Humanities has offered a $1million challenge grant to the research libraries of the New York Public Library.

title: Ombudsman to Be GoBetween For Utilities and Queens Users
description: Queens Borough President Donald R. Manes said yester day he would appoint an om budsman to serve as an inter mediary between borough res idents and the Public Service Commission, the Consolidated Edison Company and other util ity companies.

title: Two Jersey Aides Clash on Shutting Institution Kitchens
description: TRENTON Sept. 12  Dr. Oscar Sussman, the state's consumer health physician, who has closed kitchens in several state institutions in re cent weeks for unsanitary con ditions, ordered four more closed today and ran into a confrontation with Dr. Maurice Kott, Acting State Commis sioner of Institutions and Agencies.

title: New Pact for McMillian
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 12 (UPI)Jim McMillian, a four year pro from Columbia, signed a multiyear contract with the Los Angeles Lakers today. Terms of the pact were not disclosed. McMillian, 25 years old, averaged 18.9 points a game last season as the Lakers finished second to the New York Knicks in the National Basketball As sociation playoffs.

title: HANNAH STEIN, 53, OF JEWISH COUNCIL
description: Hannah Stein, executive di rector since 1959 of the Na tional Council of Jewish Wo men, died Tuesday in Lenox Hill Hospital, She was 53 years old.

title: Anker Report Pact With Harlem Prep For City TakeOver
description: Irving Anker, chancellor of the city school system, said last night that an agreement in principle had been reached with the directors of Harlem Prep on its entrance into the city school system perhaps by next spring.

title: MARGARET LINN DIES; STAGE, TV ACTRESS
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 12  Margaret Linn, a stage, film and television actress, died of a brain hemorrhage today in Hollywood Presbyterian Hospi tal. She was 39 years old and lived at 110 West 86th Street, New York.

title: Arthur Daley
description: The smartest move Bert Bell made during his historic reign as commissioner of the National Football League was to instigate television blackouts of home games. It was to he the salvation of pro football. League members ceased to live a daybyday existence and gained financial stability by selling tickets in advance. The demand for those tickets grew ever greater until sellouts became commonplace.

title: Bridge: The Sterns Have Reason To Praise Their System
description: The New York Double Knockout Championship for the Von Zedtwitz Trophy ended earlier this week, just in time for the start of the new season, The 197273 contest lasted 11 months and ended in a victory for a sex tet headed by Sandy Stern of New York and including her husband Roger, Barbara Tepper of Livingston, N. J., Lester Sokolower of Gutten berg, N. J., Alan Messer of Upper Montclair, N. J., and Andy Gabrilovich of Stam ford, Conn.

title: Father of an Inmate Killed in Attica Riot Sues for $1Million
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 12 (UPI) The father of a man killed dur ing the police assault on the At tica state prison during the 1971 riot is suing state officials for $1,001,000, charging that his son's civil rights were vio lated.

title: LongRun Couple Live Script Flexibly
description: Tonight Eli Wallach and Anne Jackson open in Jean Anouilh's The Waltz of the Toreadors at the Circle in the Square  Joseph E. Levine Theater, and after the premiere their friends will join them, in a gala benefit party celebrating the Wallachs' 25th anniversary. As Miss Jackson explains, it is 25 years married, together, in the theater.

title: A Vietnamese Long in Laos Is just Waiting to Go Back Home
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 1 Tran Thi Nga is waiting She is Vietnamese, and al though she has lived most of her 23 years in Laos, where her family took refuge in 1960, she yearns to go home to Vietnam.

title: Report on Taps Backs Kissinger, Senator Says
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI)Senator John Spark man, Democrat of Alabama, said today that a Federal Bureau of Investigation sum mary completely supports Henry A. Kissinger's state ments that beyond the fur nishings of names he had no involvement in wiretapping of his staff as President Nixon's national security ad viser.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)Minufacturers expect sales to decline by onetenth of 1 per cent in the fourth quarter following a 1.7 per cent increase in the third quarter, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Albania Reported Upset by China Thaw
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  The Nixon Administration's pol icy of conciliation toward China is causing serious polit ical unrest in Albania, Peking's East European ally, according to information reaching the United States.

title: National League
description: Thursday, September 13, 1973

title: Japan's Government Appeals Decision on Forces' Legality
description: TOKYO, Sept. 12 (Reuters) The Japanese Government to day appealed against a court decision last week that the country's 260,000man Self Defense Forces were unconstitu tional.

title: Nance Role As a Starter Seems Safe
description: While everybody has been trying to nail down John Rig gins, the New York Jets' fullback holdout, and find out if he really wants to play football, Jim Nance, a pro football dropout, has been trying to nail down the start ing fullback spot. And he seems to have done it so far.

title: ExP.O.W. Is Ruled Eligible To Enter Governor's Race
description: SANTA FE, N. M., Sept. 12 (AP)Attorney General David Norvell says that James Hughes, a former Vietnam pris oner of war, is eligible to run for Governor.

title: Rest of Watergate Inquiry Is Delayed and Shortened
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  The Senate Watergate commit tee decided today on a sched ule of hearings that will sharp ly curtail its public inquiry into 1972 Presidential cam paign sabotage and financing.

title: Nixon Is Scored on Latins
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) Representative Chet Holifield, Democrat of California, chair man of the House Government Operations Committee, accused the Nixon Administration today of neglecting MexicanAmeri cans, Puerto Ricans and Cu bans.

title: MRS. MARGARET DAWSON
description: Mrs. Margaret Cheney Daw son, former editor of Child Study magazine and earlier of Junior League magazine, died yesterday at her home in Salis bury, Conn. She was 71 years old, and the widow of James A. Dawson, who coordinated the construction of the United Nations headquarters.

title: Government Bonds Ease Again in Quiet Trading
description: Corporate and Government bonds eased again yesterday in quiet trading.

title: Mrs. Meir's Party Suffers a Setback In Labor Elections
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 12Premier Golda Meir's governing Labor party lost about 4 percentage points in yesterday's elections for the General Federation of Labor, but its leadership re mained unchallenged.

title: STOCKS SEESAW; DOW FALLS 4.44
description: The stock market behaved yesterday like a boat in heavy seas. It opened at its high point with the DowJones industrial average at 885.61, down only 0.15 point.

title: $4MILLION LOSS LISTED BY BACHE
description: Bache & Co., the nation's second largest brokerage firm, had a loss of $4,257,000 on revenues of $35,344,000 during the quarter ended July 31, 1973, John E. Leslie, chairman, an nounced yesterday. Earnings for the same quarter last year were $837,000 on revenues of $41,151,000.

title: Goldwater Backing Agnew; Says He Is Leading in Race
description: JACKSONVILLE, Ill., Sept. 12 (AP)Senator Barry Gold water said last night that he believed Vice President Agnew had the inside track on the 1976 Republican Presidential nomination and he said he sup ported the Vice President.

title: Nyquist Orders an Inquiry On School Elections Here
description: The State Education Com missioner announced yesterday that an inquiry would be mad into last spring's local school board elections here because of widespread reports of ?? larities and deficiencies.

title: Redefining Atlantic Tie: Difficult Hurdles Lie Ahead
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 12Euro pean officials are congratulat ing themselves at having man aged the first hurdle toward working out a new definition of relations with the United States.

title: PAROLEE IS FOUND MURDERED ON L.I.
