description: OLD BROOKVILLE, L.I., Sept. 12  The body of a 59yearold man who had been on parole on an unspecified charge in West chester County for the last four years was found in a field here early this morning. He had been shot five times with a .38cali ber weapon.

title: Nixon's Seclusion Coming to an End; Public Role Grows
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 President Nixon has emerged from seclusion in the last few days and is once again a pub lic President, meeting daily with a wide range of visitors, negotiating with Congress and making public appearances.

title: Area in Omaha Evacuated
description: OMAHA, Sept. 12, (UPI)  Hundreds of persons were evacuated from a downtown business area westerday when a construction crew ruptured a threeinch high pressure natural gas line. No injuries were re ported.

title: Miss Casals Victor In St. Louis Tennis
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 12 (AP) Rosemary Casals of San Francisco breezed to a 63, 61 victory over Barbara Downs of Alamo, Calif., in the first round of the $30, 000 St. Louis women's in ternational tennis tourna ment tonight.

title: Buses on 3 Routes Will Be Expresses During Rush Hour
description: The Transit Authority an nounced yesterday that a lim itedstop service would begin Monday during tne morning and evening rush periods on three main north  south bus routes in Manhattan.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today

title: Chronically Ill Display Their Brand of Olympics
description: The spectators didn't need a scorecard to recognize the players yesterday as the Bird S. Coler and Goldwater Me morial Hospitals held their annual miniOlympics on Roosevelt Island.

title: ExOfficial Says, He Kept State Goods in His Barn,
description: PATERSON, Sept. 12  The former head of the New Jersey Surplus Property Agency con ceded today that such state owned items as a tractor, a jeep ultimately registered in his own name, a shipment of aluminum Ibeams and at least two trailer loads of styrofoam were stored in his private barn for periods ranging up to two and a half years.

title: Met Open Lead Tied By 3 at 70
description: ORADELL, N. J., Sept. 12 Roger Ginsberg, who as a teenager traveled by bus from the Bronx to play golf in New Jersey, came back to the Garden State today and shared the firstround lead at 70 in the Metropoli tan open championship.

title: Rev. Howard O. Hough, 75, Started First Radio Parish
description: PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 12  The Rev. Howard O. Hough, founder and pastor emeritus of the First Radio Parish Church of America, died here today in the Maine Medical Center. He was 75 years old.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:

title: PROPOSED DUMPING IN SOUND PROTESTED
description: GREENPORT, L. I., Sept. 12 (AP)Several government offi cials and representatives of a number of conservation groups expressed opposition last night to a United States Navy plan to dump dredging spoil in Long Island Sound.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The State Education Comis sioner of New York announc ed that an inquiry would be made into last spring's local school board elections in New York City because of wide ADD JER CAPSULES . . . spread reports of irregulari ties and deficiencies. The Commissioner, Ewald B. Ny quist, said that the goal was to recommend changes in election procedures, but that any finding of a criminal act would be turned over to the proper prosecuting authori ties. The announcement came a day after a state judge ousted the entire school board of Brooklyn's District 17 be cause of irregularities in the recent elections.

title: GARRISON ASSUMES HIS OWN DEFENSE
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 12 District Attorney Jim Garrison, defendant in a pinball bribery case in United States District Court here, took over his own defense today because of ir reconcilable differences be tween him and his attorneys.

title: BIG NUCLEAR BLAST SET OFF BY SOVIET
description: UPPSALA, Sweden, Sept. 12 (AP)The Soviet Government set off another powerful under ground nuclear explosion on the Arctic island of Novaya Zemlya today, the Uppsala seismological institute report ed.

title: Van Dillen Beats Moore, 62, 76
description: APTOS, Calif., Sept. 12 (AP)Erik Van Dillen was the only one of eight seeded players to survive second round play in the $37,500 national hardcourt tennis championships today. The 22 yearold member of the Da vis Cup team beat Ray Moore of South Africa, 62, 76.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Burns Terms President Sympathetic to Tax Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  Dr. Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today he would not be surprised if the President proposed a tax increase to im prove the nation's budget situ ation and thus help reduce in terest rates. Dr. Burns con ferred with Mr. Nixon yester day.

title: PASSAGE IS HOPED FOR 50 KEY BIB
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 12  Democratic leaders in Cong ress, still pushing for an Octo ber adjournment, said today that they expected Congress to pass about 50 significant bills in the final weeks of the 1973 session.

title: After Nearly 12 Years of Obstacles, Waterside Housing Opens on River
description: Twelve years after it was first proposed, years in which it was nearly overwhelmed by bureaucratic, political and financial obstacles, the am bitious and dramatic Water side housing development over the East River was for mally opened yesterday by Mayor Lindsay and former Mayor Robert F. Wagner.

title: Chess Come Home, Grandmasters! U.S. Title Beckons in El Paso
description: The 1973 United States Chess Championship, which began. Sunday at the Hotel Paso del Norte in El Paso, Texas, had to struggle for its niche this year. Although the United States Chess Federa tion recognized that it was not ideal to hold the tourna ment only two weeks after the conclusion of the United States Open, Sept. 927 was the most convenient period to lure home sour grandmas ters from their prizetaking in international events.

title: G.M. ANNOUNCES '74 CAR PRICE RISE
description: DETROIT, Sept. 12The General Motors Corporation announced today that its 1974 cars arid trucks would cost an average of $97, or 2.5 per cent, more than the 1973 vehicles.

title: Packers' Dale on Waivers
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Sept. 12 (AP)Carroll Dale, the third leading active pass receiver and a member of the Green Bay Packers since the cham pionship years of the mid nineteensixties was placed an waivers today, by the Nation al Football League club. Dale, 35 years old, was offered a position as a special assistant with the team.

title: The Hearings Continue
description: The Senate Watergate committee has acted in the public interest by resisting political pressure to call off its hearings, or to close them to coverage by press and television. The panels bipartisan agreement to resume its investigations on Sept. 24 means that the Senators will adhere to their mandate to seek full disclosure of the abuse of governmental power. Senator Sam Ervin moreover has made it clear that the hearings will run their full course, if necessary beyond the committees tentative termination target of Nov. 1.

title: 2 BIG RETAILERS OPEN BRANCHES
description: Abraharn & Straus, the giant Brooklyn department store, and Ohrbach's, the Manhattan based fashionata price store, yesterday ended thier long hold. out against competing in the city's other boroughs. At 9:45 A.M., they opened their first urban branch stores in New York in the new Queens Center Mall.

title: Egypt Resumes Relations With Jordan
description: CAIRO, Sept. 12  Egypt an nounced the resumption of dip lomatic relations with Jordan today.

title: Man Found Hanged in Park
description: A 56yearold man was found hanged with his own belt from a tree in Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx yesterday, an ap parent suicide, the police re ported. They identified the man as Robert Mark of 305 East 239th Street, the Bronx. Mr. Mark, a bartender, was found hanging from a tree, near 239th Street, about 5:20 P.M., the po lice said.

title: Adjourn Prison Doctor's Case
description: OSSINING, N.Y., Sept. 12 (AP)  Dr. Daniel Zubrik, prison doctor at the state cor rectional facility here who was arrested on a charge of having a pint of scotch whisky in his possession there, was granted an adjournment and considera tion of dismissal in the case. The village judge, Malcolm D. Roy, signed the papers without comment, under the ruling, ad journment is granted for six months.

title: Britain Decides to Begin Work On a Channel Tunnel to France
description: LONDON, Sept. 13  The British Government said today that it had decided to go ahead with the construction of a tun nel under the English Channel to France.

title: 6 AFRICAN NATIONS END 14DAY TALKS
description: OUAGADOUGOU, Upper Volta, Sept. 12Six African nations today ended 14 days of meetings on ways to get help for their droughtstricken region just below the Sahara.

title: Campbell Soup's Quarterly Sales and Earnings at Peak
Judge Hears Request to Charge Five Agents of F.B.I. in Boston
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 12 A state district court judge here listened to five hours of testimony today concerning a request by citizens to have criminal charges filed against five F.B.I. agents, then recessed to allow the agents to rebut the allegations, which include as sault with a dangerous weapon, malicious destruction of prop erty and larceny.

title: 2 Blacks Here Assail Districting Plan
description: Two black elected officials expressed strong opposition yesterday to the use of com munityplanningboard bounda ries as a basis for new council manic district lines.

title: NEWARK AIRPORT GETS TERMINAL B
description: NEWARK, Sept. 12  Newark International Airport formally dedicated the second of its three glassandconcrete passenger terminals today amid predictions that the expansion would generate huge economic benefits and a reminder that it disrupted people living near by.

title: Trial of Mrs. Berrigan For Shoplifting Scheduled
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 12  The trial of Elizabeth McAlister Berrigan, former nun and wife of the prominent antiwar priest, the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan, on charges of shoplifting, is sched uled to begin Sept. 26.

title: 2d Guerrilla Group Re ported in Haiti to Oppose Duvalier
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Domini can Republic, Sept. 12 (AP)  Well informed Dominican sources reported today that a second group of guerrillas had landed in Haiti to lay the groundwork for an attempt to overthrow the government of President JeanClaude Duvalier.

title: SCHOOL LUNCHES FACING WIDE CUTS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 An estimated 800,000 children are either being dropped from or droping out of the fed erally subsidized school lunch program because of rising food prices, Senate investigators dis closed today.

title: Aspin Says Pentagon Gave Incorrect Data to Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI)Representative Les As pin, Democrat of Wisconsin, charged today that the number of active duty officers working in Government outside the mili tary services was actually twice the number the. Defense. Senate Armed Services Com mittee.

title: 20,000 Witnesses Gather
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Sept 12 (UPI)About 20,000 Jehovah's Witnesses from 22 nations gathered here today for the op ening of the international as sembly of the religious sect.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
description: Hours are given in Eastern Daylight Time.

title: POLICE DEFENDED BY SOUTH AFRICAN
description: CARLETONVILLE, South Af rica, Sept. 12  Prime Minis ter John Vorster today defend ed the police action last night in quelling a riot at the West ern Deep Levels Gold Mine here in which 11 black workers were shot to death.

title: Red Cross Criticizes Plan For States' Role on Relief
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) President Nixon's proposal to give states the major role in disaster relief could lead to 50 different levels of disaster assistance, the Red Cross told Congress today.

title: Barry Goldwater
description: WASHINGTON  The Watergate scandal and the climate it has created will have political repercussionsper haps farreaching in future elections, but I seriously doubt if they will be confined to the Republican party. Rather, the reverberations of scandal and corruption will shoot through both major parties and create real trouble for incumbents, especially those who might have been subjected to earlier charges of campaign irregularities.

title: Traffic Fines Paid in Blood Offered as Kentucky Option
description: LEXINGTON, Ky. Sept. 12 (AP)Motorists can now pay traffic fines in blood at Fay ette Quarterly Court here.

title: Export of Small Orders Of Scrap Metal Barred
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)  The Commerce Department closed the door today on ex port of small orders of scrap metal.

title: Sports Nostalgia Gets Another 3Day Shuffle
description: Loaded with athletic nostalgia, the American Sports Card Collectors Association will shuffle into town again tomorrow for its second threeday show of the season.

title: CocaCola Resets A Deal to Acquire Franzia Winery
description: The CocaCola Bottling Co. of New York, Inc., announced yesterday it has renegotiated an agreement in principle to ac quire the Franzia Brothers Win ery, for stock valued at about $49.3million.

title: Carrier Ticonderoga Bound for Scrap Heap Next April
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., Sept. 12 (UPI)The carrier they call old shake, rattle and roll, the Ticonderoga, is destined for the scrap heap and is fighting what appears to be a losing battle.

title: Irrelevant Question
description: In trying to assess the impact of Vietnam and Water gate, Henry Kissinger told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee: These traumatic events have cast lengthen ing shadows on our traditional optimism and selfesteem. ... Wherewe once ran the risk of thinking we were too good for the world, we might now swing to believing we are not good enough. Where once a soaring optimism tempted us to dare too much, a shrinking spirit could lead us to attempt too little.

title: Billy Rose Mansion to Become an Alcoholism Center
description: A 40room mansion for merly occupied by the show man Billy Rose will open later this month as the Smithers Alcoholism Center and Rehabilitation Unit of Roosevelt Hospital.

title: U.S. HAD WARNING OF COUP, AIDES SAY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 Senior United States officials said tonight that they had re ceived advance warnings of the military coup in Chile. The last warningthat the coup would take place on Tuesdaywas conveyed to the highest levels in Washington on Monday.

title: 2 Nets Singing Memphis Blues
description: KINGS POINT, L.I., Sept. 12  John Baum and Bob Lackey of the Nets don't know Charles O. Finley, the owner of the. Memphis Tams of the American Basketball Association. He doesn't know them either, but he has com plicated their lives.

title: Gallup Poll Shows G.O.P. Rating Drop To a 33Year Low
description: Voter identification with the Republican party has eroded to its lowest percentage in at Nast 33 years, according to a Gallup Poll released yesterday.

title: Kelly Bold Simplicity at the Modern Art
description: The Ellsworth Kelly exhibi tion, which opened yesterday at the Museum of Modern Art, is an event bound to baf flerand probably exasperate almost as many people as it will delight. For Mr. Kelly's art is at once extremely aus tere and utterly delectable. It abounds in bold, delicious colorbright blocks of color that fill the eye with an in tensity of concentration un like anything else in contem porary artyet it employs forms of such radical sim plicity that they will not seem like forms at all to eyes unused to fathoming the spe cial pictorial language the artist has made his own.

title: People in Sports: Ryan Strikes Out for No. 20
description: While Hank Aaron doses in on Babe Ruth's home run record, Nolan Ryan of the California Angels pursues the opposite kind of mark: most batters struck out in a season. But he insists his top, goal is to be a 20game winner.

title: BIG BOARD OPPOSES INVESTMENT PLAN
description: The New York Stock Ex change urged Federal regu lators yesterday to bar the Chase. Manhattan Bank and other banks from selling stock to small investors through monthly deductions from check ing accounts.

title: Georgia Picks Guthrie
description: ATHENS, Ga., Sept. 12 (UPI)  John Guthrie was named head basketball coach for the University of Georgia, Athletic Director Joel Eaves announced today. Guthrie suc ceeds Babe McCarthy, who resigned to coach the Ken tucky Colonels of the Ameri can Basketball Association.

title: Apparel Prices Are Emphasized At Manufacturers' Convention
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 The subject of prices was on every executive's mind and on many executives' lips at the annual convention here of the American Apparel Manufactur trs Association.

title: Cox Says Nixon's Lawyers Raise Bogus Fear to Bar Use of Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  Archibald Cox, the Justice De partment's special prosecutor, accused President Nixon's lawyers today of raising a bogus fear to block delivery of the Watergate tape record ings to a grand jury.

title: Governor Intervened in Politics, Samoan Court Told
description: PAGO PAGO, American Sa moa Sept. 12A series of sweeping charges regarding the influence of the Governor of American Samoa over the po litical life and the information media of this tiny American territory marked the opening of hearings similar to impeach ment proceedings against Gov. John M. Haydon.

title: New Pact for McMillian
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 12 (UPI)Jim McMillian, a four year pro from Columbia, signed a multiyear contract with the Los Angeles Lakers today. Terms of the pact were not disclosed. McMillian, 25 years old, averaged 18.9 points a game last season as the Lakers finished second to the New York Knicks in the National Basketball As sociation playoffs.

title: 3 WHO DEFRAUDED TIMES PLEAD GUILTY
description: An assistant accountant of The New York Times and two other men charged with second degree grand larceny in the theft of more than $25,000 from The Times through bogus expense account vouchers pleaded guil ty yesterday in State Supreme Court here.

title: Court on Judiciary: Where Judges Are Judged
description: When the Court on the Ju diciary convenes today in Al bany to hear arguments con cerning the possible removal from the bench, of State Su preme Court Justice Joseph P. Pfingst, it will be the sixth case the Court has considered in its 25year history.

title: Richardson to Base Taps on Security
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson has promised the Senate Foreign Relations Com mittee he will attempt to en sure that a genuine national security interest is involved before he orders wiretaps with out court warrants.

title: Mrs. Post Dies at 86
description: Mrs. Marjorie Merriweather Post, one of the World's rich est women, died yesterday in Washington at 86. Mrs. Post, who inherited the Postum Cereal Company and built it into the General Foods Corpo ration, was noted for her phi lanthropies, entertainment and regal way of life. Page 50.

title: Peking Opens Door to Philadelphians
description: PEKING, Sept. 12  The Philadelphia Orchestras sur mounting political, geogra phical and musical obstacles, arrived hire today at the outset of a 10day, fivecon Cert tour as the first Amen Can orchestra ever to appear in China.

title: Soapbox Derby Case Put Off
description: BOULDER, Colo., Sept. 12 (AP)The arraignment of Rob ert Lange Sr., the uncle of this year's disqualified AllAmeri can Soapbox Derby winner, was postponed today until Oct. 2 to allow a judge to consider motions filed in the case. Mr. Lange was charged with en couraging a child to violate state laws after he acknowl edged that he had instructed his nephew, James Gronen, 14 years old, in installing a mag netic device to give his gravity powered racer a faster start. Young Gronen was disqualified after racing officials discovered the device.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: 80 Site Selectors Term New BrunswickSuitable
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Sept. 12 A party of 80 represents tives of development and indus trial site selection organizations toured this city today with officials of manufacturing and transportation companies,

title: My Son the Arab Oil Man
description: You don't have to be Arab to make the cover of News week as an Arab.

title: Food Clerks' Pact Approved
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 (AP)The Cost of Living Coun cil approved today a new con tract for 6,500 retail clerks, signaling an apparent end to a strike against three major su permarket chains in the Phila delphia area.

title: Miss Stove Victor In Tennis, 76, 64
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 12 (AP) Betty Stove of the Nether lands edged Pam Austin of Rolling Hills, Calif., 76, 64, today and led, the favorites into the second round of the $30,000 St. Louis women's international tennis tourna ment.

title: Burns Terms President Sympathetic to Tax Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  Dr. Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today he would not be surprised if the President proposed a tax increase to im prove the nation's budget situ ation and thus help reduce in terest rates. Dr. Burns, con ferred with Mr. Nixon yester day.

title: Nickel Bag of Soybeans Is Sent to the President
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)President Nixon's soy bean knowledge went up a nickel's worth today.

title: Pennant Races: Pirates Take First Place
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates took over first place yesterday in the National League East with a 42 victory over the Cubs at Chicago While the St. Louis Cardinals lost to the Montreal Expos, 21, last night. Pittsburgh leads by half a game.

title: They Were Auctioning Nostalgia on Wheels
description: GLADSTONE, N. J.  The longhaired young men wear ing white gloves carefully pulled the glittering black, yellow and red British road coach to the front of the rostrum and parked it.

title: NEWS SHIELD LAW STALLS IN CAPITAL
description: There is a growing feeling in the newsgathering industry that a Federal shield law to protect journalists' confidential news sources is all but dead in Congress.

title: Colts to Start Bert Jones
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 12 (AP)  Bert Jones will start at quarterback for the Baltimore Colts against the Cleveland Browns Sunday in the Nation al Football League opener for both teams. Jones, the Colts' top draft choice, beat out Marty Mares, a fiveyear player from Columbia.

title: Pompidou and Mao Confer for 2 Hours
description: PEKING, Sept. 12 (Reuters)  President Pompidou and Chairman Mao Tsetung held a twohour meeting tonight, a French spokesman said.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Department of Environmental Protection has assigned top priority to the financing of sewer projects for the New Jersey shore, the nontidal reaches of the Passaic River watershed and the Raritan River basin.

title: B'nai B'rith Joins Move Against Soviet Olympics
description: In a meeting with the United States Olympic Com mittee executive director, F. Donald Miller, here yester day, leaders of B'nai B'rith District No. 1, headed by the district president, Lester A. Macktez of Woonsocket, R. I., strongly opposed the Soviet Union's application to have the 1980 Olympic Games staged in Moscow.

title: Mrs. Marjorie Merriweather Post Is Dead at 86
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 Majorie Merriweather Post, the businesswoman and philanthro pist whose great wealth allowed her to entertain lavishly and live regally, died today at her Hillwood estate here after a long illness. She was 86 years old.

title: NARCOTICS DEALER GETS A LIFE TERM
description: A convicted heroin dealer was sentenced to life imprison ment and fined $300,000 in Federal District Court here taterday after he bitterly de nounced the judge and the prosecution.

title: A Star Keeps the Show Warm
description: If all the customers who kicked and clawed their way into the grand ballroom of the Plaza the other day buy a fur coat, it will be a smash ing year for Ben Kahn, the furrier who sponsored the fashion show.

title: Briton Wins $1.4Million In Weekly Football Pools
description: LONDON, Sept. 12 (Reu ters)A 64yearold grand father today won almost $1.4million on the British football pools and said he hoped to live Tong enough to spend his fortune.

title: Ittleson Rites Monday
description: A memorial service for Henry Ittleson Jr., honorary chairman of the C.I.T. Financial Corpora tion who died Aug. 25 in Monte Carlo, will be held Monday at 5 P.M. in Alice Tully Hall, Lin coln Center, Broadway and 65th Street.

title: American League
description: Thursday, September 13, 1973

title: Thousands in Europe Protest the Chilean Coup
description: ROME, Sept. 12 (Reuters) Tens of thousands of demon strators marched through Euro pean cities tonight to denounce the military coup in Chile and the death of President Salvador Allende Gossens.

title: House RollCall Sustaining the President's Veto of Health Measure
Mackey to Be Player Agent
description: John Mackey, the former president of the National Football League Players As sociation and an aggressive one, has quit playing but yesterday announced a new role in sport. Mackey, whose peak playing career was with the Baltimore Colts, will serve as a player's agent for the new sports division of the William Morris Agency.

title: Protest on Food Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI)  Carrying a sixfoot card addressed to Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz and demanding his resignation, 30 members of the National Con sumers Congress demonstrated in front of the Agriculture Department today against high food prices.

title: NADER ACCUSES MULTINATIONALS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 12  Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, charged to day that the abuses committed by the giant corporations were concealed by secrecy. He urged a United Nations panel inquiring into the impact of multinational companies to try to get at the priceless infor mation now being withheld.

title: Sharp Rise in Addicts Spurs Burmese to Act Against Huge Narcotics Trade
description: RANGOON, Burma, Sept. 11 An abrupt increase in heroin addiction, among Burmese youth has spurred the military Government to take its first major steps against the huge opiumtrafficking trade.

title: JOSEPH A. BOCCIA
description: Joseph A. Boccia, who re tired in 1960 after having served 10 years as a Municipal Court justice, died Tuesday at his home, 331 East 116th Street. His age was 84.

title: Advise and Condone
description: WASHINGTONIn this week's hear ings to confirm a new Secretary of State, Senate Foreign Relations Com mittee Chairman J. William Fulbright was tempted to stretch his arm across the committee table and witness table, take the ample jowl of Henry Kissinger between thumb and forefinger and give him an affectionate pinch.

title: Hartke Asks About Bonds
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 12 (AP) Senator Vance Hartke, Dem ocrat of Indiana, asked the Treasury Department today to explain why it had not tried to locate the owners of 206, 000 unclaimed United States savings bonds in government vaults, the existence of which was disclosed in a General Accounting Office report in August.

title: Tenants Evicted in Brooklyn as Demolition Begins
description: Angry holdouts in a long fight against eviction in the Williamsburg section of Brook lyn were dragged from the stoop of a condemned build ing by sheriff's deputies yester day, and bulldozers immediately moved in to begin demolition making way for an expanded industrial plant.

title: Books of The Times
description: ROYO COUNTY. By Robert Roper. 138 pages. Morrow. $4.95.

title: TUNNEY LOSES MOVE TO REOPEN I.T.T. CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)  Senator John V. Tun ney disclosed today that attor ney General Elliot L. Richard son had rejected his demand for a reopening of the contro versial outofcourt settlement of antitrust cases against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

title: Big Board Letters Released On Bank Investment Plans
description: The New York Stock Ex change yesterday released the contents of two letters it wrote on Sept. 7 to the Controller of the Currency and the Securities and Exchange Commission com plaining about investment plans offered by some banks.

title: OIL DEALERS URGE MANDATORY RULE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 More than 700 independent heating oil dealers from the Northeast asked the Federal Government today to compel major oil companies to sell heating oil to retailers.

title: 2 Fires Contained on Coast
description: EUREKA, Calif., Sept. 12 (UPI)Nearly 1,500 firefighters began heading for home today after stopping two major fires in northern California that burned more than 21,000 acres of timber and brush. A 13,000 acre fire in Humboldt County was brought under control after destroying two summer cabins earlier in the week, and firefighters later contained an 8,200acre fire along Mendo cino County's Dog House Creek.

title: Police Wound Holdup Man Fleeing Store With $200
description: An unidentified holdup man was shot and seriously wound ed in a shootout with two po licemen last night as he fled the B & B Food Store at 366 Second Avenue? near 22d Street, in the Gramercy Park area.

title: RCA PLANS TO BETTER ITS ALASKAN SYSTEMS
description: The RCA Corporation expects to spend at least $110million in the five years ending in 1976 on expansion and moderniza tion of Alaska's communica tions system, Robert W. Sar noff, chairman, said in a speech prepared for delivery last eve ning at Andhorage.

title: French Wine Scandal Reaches Far Beyond the Vineyards
description: BORDEAUX, France, Sept. 12 A scandal is shaking France's haughty and ancient aristocracy of wine merchants over the purity of their product and is even threatening the presi dential ambitions of a former Premier.

title: 5 Industrial Groups Get F.C.C. Approval For Satellite Work
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (Reu ters)The Federal Communi cations Commission today au thorized five industrial groups to begin construction of domes tic communications satellite facilities worth $292million,

title: CLOSING AVERTED AT MUSIC HALL
description: A threatened shutdown of the Radio City Music Hall last mid night was averted when prog ress was made in negotiation for a new contract to cover the theater's orchestra musicians.

title: ALLENDE BACKERS WARNED BY JUNTA NOT TO BEAR ARMS
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 12 Chile's new military rulers announced today that a private funeral had been held for Presi dent Salvador Allende Gossens and warned that armed sup porters of the dead Marxist leader would be shot on the spot if taken prisoner.

title: Transit System a Year Old
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept, 12 (UPI)  The Bay Area Rapid Transit District, newest such transportation system in the United States, celebrated its first birthday yesterday. BART officials said that as of August, five million passengers had used the sections of the line that have been opened in the East Bay.

title: Bayh Opposes Missile
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) Senator Birch Bayh, Demo crat of Indiana, said today that he would introduce an amend ment to the military procure ment bill to stop further devel opment of the SAMD surface toair missile system.

title: S.E.C. Asks Friend Of Nixon to Admit Accusations in Suit
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 12 (AP) C. Arnholt Smith, a longtime friend and financial backer of President Nixon, was asked yesterday to admit 241 accu sations or proposed facts to be considered in a civil suit by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Bill Seeks Gun Controls
description: BOSTON, Sept. 12 (AP)A gun control measure aiimed specifically at the criminal element was filed today in the House by Representative Thom as C. Norton, Democrat of Fall River. The bill would create mandatory one to twoanda halfyear sentences for persons with previous convictions as felons who are found in posses sion of a firearm.

title: St. John's Bars Paper With AbortionBook Ad
description: St, John's University yes terday confiscated 300 copies of the University Review, a radical youthoriented month ly, which contains an adver tisement for Planned Parent hood's new book, Abortion: A Woman's Guide.

title: HOUSE SUSTAINS PRESIDENT'S VETO OF A HEALTH BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  The House gave President Nixon an important, although narrow, legislative victory to day by sustaining his veto of a bill to provide the nation with improved emergency med ical services.

title: ANDERSEN & CO. SUES S.E.C. ON AUDIT RULE
description: Arthur Andersen & Co., one of the country's eight major accounting firms, has filed a complaint against the Securi ties and Exchange Commission, charging the regulatory agency with failing to follow Federal rulemaking procedure in set ting out accounting principles.

title: Briard as Popular Here As Limburger Is in Brie
description: The province of Brie in France is famous for its cheese, Among dog fanciers, however, it is also known for a squarely built, powerful animalthe Briard. The breed still is comparatively rare in this country, Last year, only 147 were registered with the American Kennel Club, mak ing it No. 100 of the 118 listed. So when the club's recent specialty Dogs at Penn Ridge drew 56 dogs, there was great elation among the breed owners.

title: PLAN ON HOUSING MEET NEW SNAG
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  The Nixon Administration has run into a second snag over the unveiling of a new ap proach to the nation's housing problems, this time because of philosophical differences among Federal officials.

title: Futures Off Daily Limit For Grains and Soybeans
description: Prices broke sharply in the grain and soybean pits on the big Midwest exchanges yester day, with daily permissible de Clines posted in almost every wheat, corn, oats and soybean product delivery.

title: New Books
description: A Memory and Other Stories, by Mary Lavin (Houghton Mifflin, $5.95). Five short stories.

title: GOING OUT
description: HAPPY RETURNS It takes a lot of pluck to get from an ancient, but cozy bar on 10th Avenue and 51st Street to a modern monster high rise at Second Avenue and 24th Street, yet by dint of plucking diligently that's what has happened to Guitar.

title: HOUSING FOR JEWS UPHELD BY COURT
description: Reversing a lower court de cision, the United States Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that the city had not necessarily violated the constitutional rights of blacks, and Puerto Ricans by giving preference to Jews for a public housing proj ect on the Lower East Side.

title: 4 Nations Reported Cool to Oil Boycott
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 United States diplomats sound ed out West Germany, Spain, Italy and Greece during the summer about a boycott of Libyan oil, informed sources reported today.

title: Town to Add Minority Police
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept, 12 (AP) The Bridgeport Police Depart ment plans to add 43 black or Hispanic policemen under a pro posal approved in United States District Court yesterday. Judge Jon O. Newman earlier this year ordered the percentage of minority  group policemen in Bridgeport raised to 15 per cent of the entire force.

title: Notes on People
description: The Senate confirmed Pres ident Nixon's nomination of Alvin J. Arnett as director of the Office of Economic Op portunity by a vote of 88 to 3. During the hearings on his nomination, Mr. Arnett, who is 38 years old, said he supported the poverty agen cy's goals and that he ex pected O.E.O. to spend the money appropriated for it by Congress. The Nixon Ad ministration had sought to dismantle the agency and did not ask for any funds for it in the 1974 budget.

title: DEMOCRATS STARS RAISE FUNDS HERE
description: In a rare happening, the cream of the Democratic na tional, state and city crop gath ered last night at the Plaza Hotel to come to the aid of the party.

title: I THE COST OF BEEF EXPECTED TO FALL
description: Meat prices should start downward sometime between next month and the end of the year with increased shipments, of cattle to market and season al rises in pork supplies, ac cording to a Federal Agricul ture Department survey re leased yesterday.

title: Penney Freezes Phase 4 Prices; Sears Keeps Catalogue Levels
description: The J. C, Penney Company, the nation's second largest re tailer, has frozen its retail prices under Phase 4 of the Nixon Administration's eco nomic program through the end of its fiscal year, Jan. 26, 1974. During this period, it has become more promotional in pricing to keep its gross mar gins in line with Government regulations.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Frey Lone U.S. Mat Victor

title: The Algiers Alignment
description: The only thing worse than taking last week's confer ence of 76 nonaligned nations in Algiers too seriously not taking it seriously enough. The sense of community of the Third World may be more illusory than that the First (capitalist) and that of the Second (Communist) World, but it would be shortsighted to let the diver gences obscure the common interests.

title: BubbleBath Irritations Under Study by F.T.C.
description: The Federal Trade Com mission has started an inves tigation into the possibility that some bubblebath prod ucts may cause infections and other discomforts among users.

title: Samaritan Lifts Tractor
description: ROME, Me., Sept. 12 (UPI) A sixfoot, 200pound teen ager lifted a 3,000pound trac tor today to free a trapped farm worker. Kennebec County investigator, Loo Bazinet, said That Arthur Hinkley, 18 years old, had raised the vehicle enough so Lloyd Bachelder, 18, could wriggle out. Mr. Bachel der had been pinned in the seat of the tractor when it tipped over while he was trying to lift a junked car, I don't know how I did it, Mr. Hinkley told Mr. Bazinet, I ran remember anithing.

title: Nixon's Seclusion Coming to an End; Public Role Grows
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  President Nixon has emerged from seclusion in the last few days and is once again a pub lic President, meeting daily with a wide range of visitors, negotiating with Congress and making public appearances.

title: Secretariat Wedge Shot Star at Track
description: Lucien Laurin and Fred Hooper were extremely happy over developments at Bel mont Park yesterday.

title: Allard's 135. Wins At Sea Pines by Shot
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S. C., Sept. 12 (AP)  Bob Allard, a tour rookie, held off Jim Simons with a oneunder par 70 today and won the Sea Pines open golf tourna ment, a satellite event.

title: The Crime of Attica
description: The bloodiest prison uprising in all American history ended with a police charge on inmates at Attica two years ago. An inventory of changes since then reveals that some conditions at this upstate New York maximum security facility have, improved while others have not. Attica still remains a symbol of misguided correctional policies.

title: Patty's Birthday Cake Is Just Right to Stomp
description: Yesterday was a big day for gorillas here. The Bronx Zoo announced the birth of another baby gorilla and Patty, Cake, the popular baby gorilla at the Central Park Zoo, celebrated her first birthday for the second time this month.

title: TEAMSTER RIVAL CITES HOFFA TALK
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 12 Frank E. Fitzsimmons, gen eral president of the Interna tional Brotherhood of Teamsters said today that the had dis cussed union business with his predecessor, James R. Hoffa, when Hoffa was here in April, 1971, to visit his ailing wife, Josephine.

title: NEWS OF VATICAN FAKED IN 1940'S
description: ROME, Sept. 12A Jesuit historian said today that an Italian writer who specialized in fabricating Vatican informa tion between 1939 and 1948 duped American news organi zations and secret agencies, and probably Hitler and the Soviet Union as well.

title: Two School Districts Are Hit by Protest
description: Disputes over school lunches and the movement of pupils from one municipality to an other continued yesterday as schools across New Jersey be gan the second week of the new year.

title: A SixHour Battle Is Fought Over Key Vietnam Highway
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 12 (UPI)  Government troops yesterday fought Com munist forces in a sixhour bat tle for control of crucial Route 1 on the Central Coast, the South Vietnamese command said today.

title: 400 Pay Homage to Wiley Here
description: The life and work of George A. Wiley, the founder of the national Welfare Rights Or ;anization who drowned last nonth, were commemorated and celebrated yesterday in a memorial service and a march across Manhattan.

title: Two Laotian Sides Initial Accord on Coalition Rule
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Thursday, Sept. 13Negotiators for the Laotian Government in Vientiane and for the pro Communist Pathet Lao initialed an agreement yesterday bring about the first coalition government in the wake of American disengagement from Indochina.

title: AN INDIAN LEADER FREED IN SHOOTING
description: SIOUX FALLS, S. D., Sept. 12 (AP)Assault charges against an American Indian Movement leader, Carter Camp, in connec tion with the shooting of a fellow A.I.M. official have been dropped, a United States Mag istrate said today.

title: Injunctions on '72 Parley Of Democrats Are Upheld
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (UPI) The Illinois Court of Appeals refused today to overturn two injunctions issued by a circuit court judge last year against a delegation to the Democratic National Convention that suc ceeded in challenging and oust ing Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago and his elected dele gation.

title: Union Locals Ratify a Contract At Six Paper Plants in Canada
description: The United Paperworkers In ternational Union reported yes terday that six of its 17 locals at plants of the Abitibi Paper Company in Canada had rati fied a new contract providing for pay increases of 8.5 per cent in each year of a two year agreement.

title: THOMAS A O'BOYLE, LAWYER, DIES AT 56
description: Thomas A. O'Boyle, a senior partner in Shearman & Ster ling, New York law firm, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in his office at 53 Wall Street. He was 56 years old and lived in Spring Lake, N. J.

title: Georgia Picks Guthrie
Coin to Mark Bicentennial
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI)The House voted 396 to 4 today to place a special design on all silver dollars, half dollars and quarters to com memorate the nation's 200th birthday. The new design, to be determined later, will be put on the coins beginning July 4, 1975, one year before the 200th anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independ ence.

title: Doubleday Balks Family Rebel
description: The stockholders of Double day & Co., Inc., overwhelmingly defeated at their annual meet ing yesterday, a move by Mrs. Neltje Doubleday Kings, to have the huge publishing combine file a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission in order to have a public offering of the stock.

title: Illegality Laid to Auburn
description: ALBANY, Sept. 12 (AP)  A state audit of Auburn Commu nity College released today said Auburn illegally charged its half of the cost of building a new campus bookstore to a student activity fund. The audit said the city had used $58,347 in student funds to pay its share. The other half is to be paid by the state.

title: Market Place: Worries About Small Investor
description: Thomas E. O'Hara worries about whether the small in vestor who has only $500 or $600 at a time to invest is going to be permanently squeezed out of the market.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Legislator Accused of Race
description: BENNINGTON, Vt., Sept. 12 (AP)  A Vermont legislator has been named in a $110,000 damage suit alleging the statu tory rape of a 14yearold leg islative page. The suit was filed this week in County Court by Mrs. Virginia. Mc Kenna, on behalf of her daugh ter, Kimberly, the alleged vic tim. The civil suit accused Gregory Reed, 19 years old, the youngest Vermonter ever to be elected to the state House of Representatives. He de clined to comment on the suit.

title: People and Business
description: Unofficial figures yester day indicated that a consum er advocate, Mrs. Alpha Smaby, may have won a seat on the board of directors of the Northern States Power Company, the largest power utility serving Minnesota, Wisconsin, North Dakota and South Dakota.

title: Los Muchachos, A Circus of Boys, Playing at Garden
description: By definition a circus is a public entertainment composed of a variety of performances by acrobats, clowns and trained animals.

title: Liberties Group Scores Gag On McCord and Magruder
description: The American Civil Liberties Union protested yesterday a Federal district judge's order barring two Watergate defend ants, Jeb Stuart Magruder and James W. McCord Jr., from giving public lectures or grant ing press interviews, United Press International reported.

title: When Crises Were Crises
description: The last two service stations had displayed handlettered signs saying, Sorry, No Gas Today, but the one ahead apparently had a supply, since the line of cars waiting for it stretched half a block, creating a traffic situation.

title: Foreman Receives Offer of $1.5Million
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 12 (AP) George Foreman, the heavy weight boxing champion, was offered $1.5million today to defend his title against Jerry Quarry in Seattle.

title: Personal Finance: Funds' Sales Fees
description: One of the most controver sial aspects of the mutual fund industry today is the high sales charge the investor has to pay to buy mutual fund shares.

title: 2 Jersey Aides Clash on Closing Of 4 More Institutional Kitchens
description: TRENTON, Sept. I2Dr. Oscar Sussman, the state's con sumer health physician who has closed kitchens in several state institutions in recent weeks for unsanitary con ditions, ordered four more closed today and ran into a confrontation with Dr. Maurice Kott, Acting State Commis sioner of Institutions and Agen cies.

title: Colts to Start Bert Jones
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 12 (AP)  Bert Jones will start at quarterback for the Baltimore Colts against the Cleveland Browns Sunday in the Nation al Football League opener for both teams. Jones, the Colts' top draft choice, beat out Marty Mares, a fiveyear player from Columbia.

title: STOCKS DECLINE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices dropped again yester day in slightly heavier trading on the American Stock Ex change. Stocks also declined in the overthecounter market.

title: SPENDING MOUNTS FOR LASER ARE
description: The death ray, prominent in science fiction, may not be around the corner, but the Navy is considering laser de fense against guided missiles, the Air Force is researching laser defenses against antiair craft artillery and the Army is investigating the laser's capabil ities against air attack.

title: Nance Role As a Starter Seems Safe
description: While everybody has been trying to nail down John Big gins, the New York Jets' fullback holdout, and find out if he really wants to play football, Jim Nance, a pro football dropout, has been trying to nail down the start ing fullback spot. And he seems to have done it so far.

title: Vote Registration Dates To Be Oct. 3, 4 and 13
description: A State Supreme Court Justice in Brooklyn has issued an order approving a change in voter registration dates next month by the Board of Elections.

title: HOUSE SUSTAINS PRESIDENT'S VETO OF A HEALTH BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  The House gave President Nixon an important, although narrow, legislative victory to day by sustaining his veto of a bill to provide the nation with improved emergency med ical services.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Lindsay Names New Health Chief

title: Park Gazebo, Rebuilt, Still a Ladies Pavilion
description: The Ladies Pavilion in Central Park, a centuryold structure of Iacy ironwork that was knocked down by vandals two years ago, has been restored and is being re built at its old site on the Lake near Central Park West and 77th Street.

title: Exxon Challenges Connecticut Right To Control Prices
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 12  The Exxon Corporation today brought suit against the State of Connecticut in Federal Court here, contending that the state law that gave Connecticut's Petroleum Products Control Commission authority to con trol prices was unconstitutional.

title: Two Laotian Sides Initial Accord on Coalition Rule
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Thursday, Sept. 13Negotiators for the Laotian Government in Vientiane and for the pro Communist Pathet Lao initialed an agreement yesterday to bring about the first coalition government in the wake of American disengagement from Indochina.

title: Pennant Races: Pirates Take First Place
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates took over first place yesterday in the National League East with a 42 victory over the Cubs at Chicago while the St. Louis Cardinals lost to the Montreal Expos, 21, last night.

title: California Bar Delegates Supporting Inquiry on Nixon
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Sept. 12 (AP)  Delegates to the Califor nia Bar Association convention have commended an inquiry by the association into possible disciplinary action against Pres ident Nixon and other Califor nia lawyers in connection with the Watergate affair.

title: Two Seized Missiles Made by Soviet, Italian Says
description: ROME, Sept. 12  An Italian military source said today that two missiles that were appar ently to have been fired in a guerrilla attack on an Israeli airliner near here last week were believed to have been among arms supplied to an Arab country, by the Soviet Union.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: On His Own Terms
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12Henry Kis singer never yielded an inch.

title: HORSES & EQUIPMENT
description: 15.3 CHESTNUT GELDING

title: Football Transactions
description: NATIONAL CONFERENCE

title: CAMBODIA CLAIMS A MAJOR VICTORY
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sept. 12  A Government spokestnan reported today that enemy forces had been cleared from the embattled provincial capital of Kompong Cham and that the Phnom Penh Govern ment had won a clearcut vic tory.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The General Electric Com pany announced yesterday that it had received an, order for an additional 94 dieselelectric lo comotives from the National Railways of Mexico. This brings the total Mexican order to 132 locomotives and spare parts. The total value of the order is $50million, with $35million represented by yesterday's or der. Delivery of the original 38 units, which were ordered in June, has already begun, and the others are scheduled for delivery next year. All will be built by General Electric's Transport Systems division at Erie, Pa.

title: MRS. GEORGE SARGENT
description: Mrs. Mabel I. McMahon Sar gent, widow of Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent, who was rec tor of St. Bartholomew's Epis copal Church, died Tuesday at her home, 200 East 66th Street. She was 92 years old.

title: CLEAR CHOICE SET IN DETROIT RACE
description: DETROIT, Sept. 12The final retails are in, and the stage is now set for a clearcut confrontation of opposites in Detroit mayoral politics.

title: Turnpike Official Pledges Study Of Revised Driscoll Expressway
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, Sept. 12 The Mayors of four munici palities met with officials of the New Jersey Turnpike Au thority in an unusual sessibn today to press for modifica tions in the alignment of the proposed Driscoll Expressway from the turnpike in South Brunswick to Toms River.

title: Allard's 135 Wins At Sea Pines by Shot
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S. C., Sept. 12 (AP)  Bob Allard, a tour rookie, held off Jim Simons with a oneunder par 70 today and won the Sea Pines open golf tourna ment, a satellite event.

title: Martin Wolfson, Who Portrayed Captain in South Pacific, Dead
description: Martin Wolfson, a character actor best rememberd as Cap tain George (Iron Belly) Brack ett, U.S.N., in South Pacific died yesterday in Polyclinic Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 555 Ocean Ave nue, Brooklyn.

title: curious Shoppers Create Holiday Mood at Stores
description: John Furlong had his own grand opening yesterday. He opened 250 hot dog rolls at his sidewalk pushcart, feeding hungry shoppers who surged around the new Abraham & Straus and Ohrbach's stores on Queens Boulevard, looking for a place to eat.

title: Bank Robbers in Montreal Shoat 2 Guards, Killing One
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 12 (UPI) A group of bandits killed a Brinks armored car guard and wounded another today as they were picking up money at a bank. The police said as much as $100,000 might have been stolen.

title: JOHN E. HARRINGTON JR.
description: John E. Harrington Jr., a founder and retired president of Harrington, Righter & Par sons, Inc., television represen tatives, died Tuesday in New York Hospital after having, un dergone cardiovascular sur gery, He was 62 years old and lived at 120 Whitehall Boule vard in Garden City, L. I.

title: Student Aid Squeeze
description: When the Nixon Administration first decided several years ago that commercial lending institutions ought to take over the lion's share of the responsibility for student loans, the banks responded enthusiastically to this ap parent reaffirmation of free enterprise in academic lend ing. At the time money was relatively plentiful and the Governmentguaranteed loans seemed a good business opportunity.

title: Bridge Repairs in Boston
description: BOSTON, Sept. 12 (AP)  Repair work on the upper level of the Mystic River Bridge, closed after the tier collapsed Monday, should be completed within 12 weeks, according to the Massachussets Port Au thority. A gravel truck hit a support on the lower level of the bridge, causing the upper tier to cave in. The driver was killed.

title: Soviet Is Said to Stop Jamming of Voice of America
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  United States officials reported today that they had strong indications that the Soviet Union had stopped jamming broadcasts from the Voice of America, the British Broadcast ing Corporation and the West German radio.

title: $5,000 Reward Is Offered In Death of a Pet Calf
description: FRANKLIN, Me., Sept. 12 (UPI) A 38yearold man offered a $5,000 reward yesterday for in formation leading to the arrest of the person or persons who killed his children's pet calf.

title: Rest of Watergate Inquiry Is Delayed and Shortened
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  The Senate Watergate commit tee decided today on a sched ule of hearings that will sharp ly curtail its public inquiry into 1972 Presidential cam paign sabotage and financing.

title: Brooklyn Eviction Fight Ends st of Demolition
description: The long fight between resi dents of the Williamsburg sec tion of Brooklyn and the city government came to an end yesterday as two buildings were demolished and angry residents were dragged from the stoop of a condemned building where the last families had been hold ing out against eviction.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: 3 GROUPS DEFEND SOVIET DISSIDENTS
description: Sharp criticism of the Soviet Union's continuing harassment of dissident elements was voiced yesterday in the United States by a civil rights organ ization, an authors' league and a publishers' association.

title: ISRAELI AND SYRIAN PLANES IN MAJOR HOT OFF COAST; TEL AVIV CLAIMING 13 MIG'S
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 13Israeli and Syrian jets clashed over the Mediterranean today in their biggest air battle since the 1967 war, and a military spokesman here said 13 Syrian planes and one Israeli were shot down.

title: Prisoners Stage Protest At Jefferson County Jail
description: WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 13About 20 inmates of the Jefferson County Jail staged what prison officials described as a brief protest today against food preparation and the lack of recreational facili ties.

title: Market Place: Queries Raised By Unbundling
description: Bundling was a fine tradi tiona form of coping with the energy crisisback in Pilgrim times. It is defined by Webster's International Dictionary thusly: The cus tom of unmarried couples' oc cupying the same bed with out undressing, practiced chiefly in earlier days espe cially during courtship in some British and American communities.

title: LAOS AGREEMENT SIGNED BY 2 SIDES
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Friday, Sept. 14The Pathet Lao and the Vientiane Government today formally signed an agreement that will create a coalition gov ernment charged with mending wounds of 20 years of civil war.

title: BlackedOut Opera
description: Musicians at two of New York City's bestknown centers of entertainment and culture are engaged in an allornothing gamble for yearround income security that may wipe out both the institutions and their jobs.

title: Dave Anderson
description: There are men like him everywhere, executives and laborers discarded or ignored by their employers because they are considered too old for the job. Few ever get the opportunity to disprove the theory. But when the National Football League season begins Sunday, one of them will have the chance. Johnny Unitas will be at quarterback for the San Diego Chargers, and he will be symbolic to the men he represents. He's only 40 years old now, not old for most jobs, but elderly for a quarter back, even the N.F.L.'s alltime quarterback. After five games last season, he was benched by the Baltimore Colts in his 17th season with them. Then he was traded to the Chargers, as if the Metropolitan Museum of Art took down Rembrandt's paintings, as if LaScala stopped presenting Verdi's operas, as if Strat fordonAvon disowned Shakespeare. To the new hierarchy of the Colts, he had outlived his usefulness. But the Chargers appreciate him.

title: 10% PRIME IS SET BY WELLS FARGO
description: The Wells Fargo Bank yester day raised its prime interest rate on corporate loans to a record 10 per cent to make business borrowing more ex pensive than it has ever been before.

title: Met. Open, On 141, Led By Davison
description: ORADELL, N.J., Sept. 13 It's no surprise to me, said Peter Davison when he was assured his 69 for a 36hole aggregate of 141 had clinched the lead in the Metropoli tan open golf championship today. I just try to hit many good shots as pos sible, he said.

title: Shultz to Laird: Keep Hands Off In Economic Area
description: TOKYO, Sept. 13 (Reuters)  Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz said today that Mel vin R. Laird should keep his cottonpicking hands off eco nomic policy.

title: Youth's Extradition From Israel Begun In Hurok Bombing
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 13Extra dition proceedings are under way to return a 19yearold youth now serving in the Israeli Army to New York to face a murder charge in connection with the firebombing of the offices of Sol Hurok, the im presario, early last year.

title: School Election Review
description: The profusion of complaints about the way that the spring elections of the 288 members of the city's 32 community school boards were conducted forces the conclusion that unless the chaotic procedures of last May are promptly and effectively reformed, school decentralization itself will be seriously jeopardized.

title: LAOS AGREEMENT SIGNED BY 2 SIDES
description: VIENTIANE, Lads, Friday, Sept. 14The Communistled Pathet Lao and the Laotian Government in Vientiane today formally signed an agreement to create a coalition govern ment charged with mending the wounds of 20 years of in termittent civil war.

title: New East Harlem School Dispute Settled
description: A new controversy involving pupils from East Harlem was apparently resolved yesterday, but in Brooklyn, protesting parents maintained their boy cott of two schools.

title: Soviet Curbs Troubling Italian Red Leaders
description: ROME, Sept. 13The harass ment of dissident intellectuals in the Soviet Union is embar rassing the largest of all out ofpower Communist move ments in the worldItaly's just when it had seemed closer to governing than in a long time.

title: 200 Columbia Employes Stage a SitIn
description: Two hundred members of Lo cal 1199 of the Drug and Hos pital Workers Union, on strike against Columbia University since Monday, occupied the uni versity's personnel offices yes terday afternoon. The employes are seeking higher wages and faster negotiations or a con tract to replace one that ex pired last June.

title: CUT IN MEAT PRICES IS SET BY FOOD FAIR
description: Food FairPantry Pride Super markets, a leading supermarket chain, announced yesterday that it was reducing meat and poul try prices significantly below those of the last 30 days.

title: Lindsay Urges Political Activity Be Permitted for Judges in State
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 Mayor Lindsay told a House committee today that elected judges in New York State had become too insulated from the public and too lacking in ac countability.

title: Demonstrators in Argentina Charge U.S. With Chile Role
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 13 Students marched on the American Embassy here three times today, charging the Uni ted States with suporting the military takeover in Chile, but each time they were kept back by helmeted policemen carry ing machine guns.

title: Study Finds College Drug Sales Decline Under New State Laws
description: Students at eight colleges around the state report height ened fears among users of drugs, and many campus deal ers say that they have gone out of business as a result of the state's stringent new drug laws, which took effect Sept. 1.

title: Sandman Backs Measure. To Restore Death Penalty
description: TRENTON, Sept. 13  With a verbal swipe at liberal dogooders, Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., the Republican gubernatorial can didate, told a legislative com mittee today that he supported pending legislation to restore the death penalty in New Jer sey.

title: MILITARY JUNTA IN CHILE ORDERS BREAK WITH MA
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 13 Chile's new military junta named an army general as President today, formed a cabi net and broke diplomatic rela tions with Cuba in a sharp reversal of the country's foreign policy.

title: Director Bangs a Hit Loudly
description: Sports movies, goes the clich, never make a dime, so who wants to see a base ball picture about a catcher from the backwoods of Geor gia suffering from an incura ble disease? It's not exactly Love Story, where the doomed Radcliffe beauty makes Camille's final gasp seem like a spoiled pout.

title: Body of Dina Merrill's Son Found Near Gardiner's
description: The body of David Post Rum bough, the 23yearold son or Dina Merrill, the actress, was found yesterday, five days after Mr. Rumbough was reported missing in a boating acciaent in waters off eastern Long IsI and.

title: Chrysler Prices Up 2.4%; 4 Makers Raise Car Sales
description: DETROIT, Sept. 13  The Chrysler Corporation an nounced today that prices of its 1974 cars and trucks would be increased by an average of $87, or 2.4 per cent, over the base price of 1973 vehicles.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 14.5 bil lion tonmiles, 8.1 per cent above the corresponding week last year. The A.A.R. also re ported carloadings in the same week which included the Labor Way holiday totaled 474,452 cars, 2.6 per cent above the corresponding holiday week a year ago The American Truck ing Association, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 3.1 per cent above last year.

title: White House Weighs Plan for Tax Rise, With Refund When the Economy Slows
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 The Nixon Administration an nounced today that it was con sidering asking Congress to make two radical changes in the tax laws, both of which would be aimed at maintaining a prosperous economy with lessened inflation.

title: Construction of Soviet Oil Port On Black Sea Reported Started
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 13The So viet Union announced today the start of construction of a huge new port on the Black Sea as a direct outgrowth of a multi billion dollar chemical deal con cluded earlier this year with an American company.

title: Mrs. Mitcheli Says Panel Is Protecting the President
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI)  Mrs. John N. Mitchell said today that the, Senate Water gate committee was trying to protect President Nixon.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: NORTHSIDE ZONING TO ALLOW HOUSING
description: The Board of Estimate voted unanimously yesterday to re zone the Northside section of Williamsburg to permit con struction of housing for the Brooklyn families who were displaced to make way for the expansion of a factory.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP)George Meany, presi dent of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, urged the International Olympic Committee today to oppose awarding the 1980 Games to Moscow, where, he said, Olympic ideals were trampled in the dust during the recent World University games. In a signed editorial in the A.F.L.C.I.O.'s monthly magazine, he cited the hooting and jeering of the Israeli team and the rough treatment accorded Soviet Jewish citizens attending the University Games. He said totalitarian Moscow is not a fit place for the youth of the world to come together welding friendship through athletic competition.

title: Cambodian Denies Execution Of Officers at Kompong Cham
description: KOMPONG CHAM, Cam bodia, Sept. 13The Acting Governor of Kompong Cham Province today denied a re port that 12 army officers were executed here last week for ordering their men to re treat.

title: 13 Blacks Sue School For Sports Letters
description: DETROIT, Sept. 13 (AP) An attorney for 13 black members of last season's Jackson Parkside High School basketball team filed a $100, 000 suit against school offi cials today in United States District Court.

title: Sidney I. Cohen Dies at 64; TV and Film Consultant
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 13 Sidney I. Cohen, a film, theater and television service consultant, died of cancer yes terday in a hospital here. He was 64 years old.

title: Ode to a Housewife
description: CINCINNATIIt would serve this country's whining, complaining penny wise and poundfoolish housewives right if all the farmers started selling everything they produce to foreign countries.

title: Mets Top Phils, 42, On 2 Runs in 12th
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 Following their latest game of Willie or won't he, the Mets went out and kept pace with firstplace Pittsburgh tonight by trimming the Philadelphia Phillies, 42, in 12 innings.

title: Miss Suzanne B. Hooker Married to Ames Braga
description: St. Jean Baptiste's Roman Catholic Church was the set ting here yesterday for the marriage of Miss Suzanne Butler Hooker, a junior at Barnard College, to Ames Braga, who graduated with the class of '73 from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Rene Fontaine.

title: U.S. Jury Calls Top Drivers
description: A secretary's niessase that Jesse Moss was busy with a lot of clients right now helped confirm a report yes terday that 22 harnessracing drivers would begin appear ing today before a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn.

title: Addressograph Lists Loss for Quarter
South Vietnam's InflationRidden Economy Continues to Decline
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 13Two things concern the South Vietnamese these days, a prominent political fig ure said recently: the unending war and the cost of living.

title: Prince Littler Is Dead at 72; Owned London Theater Empire
description: LONDON, Sept. 13 (UPI) Prince Littler, the British im presario and theater owner, died today at his home in Sus sex. He was 72 years old. The cause of death was not dis closed.

title: Roper Hired by Plainview To Aid in School Planning
description: PLAINVIEW. L. I., Sept. 13 In an attempt to involve the entire community in the future of the public schools here, the district has hired the Roper Or ganization of New York to take a detailed look at the district.

title: JURY IN MARYLAND CLOSELY GUARDED
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 13A grand jury investigating Mary land political corruption met for about three hours today under unusual security precau tions.

title: Pompidou Sees Sights in Peking And Has a Talk With Chou
description: PEKING, Sept. 13 (Reuters) President Pompidou conferred with Premier Chou Enlai to day for three hours.

title: Eddie Palmieri Squeezed Into 3Hour Latin Show
description: Eddie Palmieri, a major force in New York's Latin music scene, was given shortshrift in the First Conquest, a commendable attempt at a Latin variety show that failed at Phil harmonic Hall on Sunday. The failure was due to flabby production, which allowed too much time between the acts on an overloaded bill, plus some inept announcing that served to reduce rather tthan increase the excitement.

title: JUDGES WEIGHING PFINGST'S OUSTER
description: ALBANY, Sept. 13  The presiding judge of the Court on the Judiciary said today that it would be a shocking situation to have a judge presiding at a trial who had been convicted of a crime and was facing a jail term.

title: Roper Hired by Plainview To Aid in School Planning
description: PLAINVIEW, L. I., Sept. 13 In an attempt to involve the entire community in the future of the public schools here, the district has hired the Roper Or ganization of New York to take a detailed look at the district.

title: News Blackout Imposed On Auto Contract Talks
description: DETROIT, Sept. 13With a strike deadline a day away, ne gotiators for the United Auto Workers and the Chrysler Cor poration intensified their efforts today to reach a contract set tlement.

title: 50 Years Later, Dempsey Looks Back
description: It seems like a long time ago, said Jack Dempsey this week as he rolled time back ward a halfcentury to the evening of Sept. 14, 1923, and his frenzied fistic battle with Luis Angel Firpo of Argentina at the Polo Grounds.

title: Pentagon Prohibits Study Where R.O.T.C. Is Ended
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13  In response to continuing pres sure from the House Armed Services Committee, the De partment of Defense has for bidden civiian employes to take courses at colleges and universities that have elimi nated Reserve Officer Training Corps programs on their campuses.

title: MET IN CRISIS CUTS PRODUCTION
description: Faced with its worst finan cial crisis since 1932, the Met ropolitan Opera has canceled the new production of Mozart's Don Giovanni planned for March 28 as well as future summer presentations of free opera concerts in the city's parks.

title: Two Saved From Raft In Hudson
description: Two 12yearold boys who had gone fishing on the banks of the Hudson River at 121st Street rather than go to school were found floating on a section of col Japsed pier in a swift current in the middle of the river.

title: In a Dodge Plant, Long Days Of Heat, Noise and Violence
description: HAMTRAMCK, Mich., Sept. 13Mickey's Dodge Bar is an industrial oasis, a cool corner of friendliness just a short dash across Joseph Campau Street from the clatter and noise and heat of the Chrysler Corpora tion's big Hamtramck assembly plant. Dodge Main, the plant is called, after the cars pro duced there.

title: Ashe, Late, Is Winner In Seattle
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 13 (AP) Arthur Ashe of Miami, top seeded but a late arrival, beat Gary Groslimond, 62, 75, today to advance to the sec ond round of the $37,500 Seattle international tennis tournament.

title: HOUSE PLANS TO ACT ON TRADE IN OCTOBER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (Reuters)House leaders an nounced today that President Nixon's trade bill would go be fore the House in the week be ginning Oct. 8.

title: CLUES ARE HUNTED IN DEATH OF GIRL
description: HOLBROOK, L. I., Sept. 13 The police questioned driv ers and visited neighbors to day in a quest for clues in the death of a 12yearold girl whose body was found yester day in a wooded lot near here.

title: ISRAELI AND SYRIAN PLANES IN MAJOR FIGHT OFF COAST; TEL AVIV CLAIMING 13 MICS
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 13Israeli and Syrian jets clashed over the Mediterranean today in their biggest air battle since the 1967 war, and a military spokesman here said 13 Syrian planes and one Israeli were shot down.

title: 37 Communists Reported Killed in Vietnam Clash
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 13 (Reuters)  The South Vietnamese command reported a battle today in the central coastal province of Binh Dinh.

title: Coral Snake Bites Handler
description: DECATUR, Ga., Sept. 13 (UPI)Otis Guillebeau, a snake handler at the Fernbank sci ence center, was listed in fair condition at a hospital today after being bitten by a coral snake. The coral snake is a member of the cobra family and is the deadliest serpent in the United States.

title: Stuffed Fish or Meatballs for Weekend
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an as terisk are followed by a recipe.

title: MILITARY JUNTA IN CHILE ORDERS BREAK WITH CUBA
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 13 Chile's new military junta named an army general as President today, formed a cabi net and broke diplomatic rela tions with Cuba in a sharp reversal of the country's foreign policy.

title: About the Giants:
description: A sevenman taxi squad was named yesterday, but it could change before Sunday's opener. On the list are Otto Brown, defensive back; Ron Lumpkin, wide receiver; Jack Rizzo, fullback; Brad Van Pelt, linebacker; John Hill, offen sive lineman; Walter Love, wide receiverdefensive back, and Dick Enderle, offensive guard. The list must be for malized by 1 P.M. tomorrow, but one more substitution to the regular 40man roster can be made as late as one hour before game time. Enderle, although listed on the taxi squad, is scheduled to start, and Love could be activated for special teams, depending on the physical status of other players. Injuries will sideline Van Pelt and Hill. . . . Only one or two players remain unsigned, according to Jim Trimble, the director of pro personnel, and contracts should be completed before Sunday's opener. No problems, Trimble said.

title: TV Hold on Football Changes
description: With the advent of tele vision following World War II, pro football was one of many sports whose games were televised live over local stations. Then dwindling at tendance, especially in Los Angeles for Rams' home games, led to the concept of foregoing television at home.

title: MO BREAK SHUTS A MIDTOWN BLOCK
description: A break in a centuryold water main under Central Park South has closed the street to traffic between the Avenue of the Americas and Fifth Avenue.

title: Car Insurance Bill Vetoed
description: BOSTON, Sept. 13 (AP) bill that would have increased minimum liability limits for state motor vericle insurance has been vetoed by Gov. Fran cis W. Sargent.

title: House Democrats Slowed On Oil Allocation Demand
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13  A Democratic drive for quick enactment of a mandatory oil supplies allocation bill bogged down unexpectedly in the House Commerce Committee today.

title: Recently Published Books
description: FICTION

title: News Summary and index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Printers Recess Newspaper Talks For Indefinite Time
description: Typographical Union 6 an nounced yesterday that it had decided to recess for an in definite period its contract negotiations with The New York Times, The Daily News and The New York Post.

title: Applause Favors Biaggi At the P.B.A. Convention
description: TANNERSVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 13Representative Mario Bi aggi, the Conservative party's candidate for Mayor and muchdecorated retired police lieutenant, won the applause sweepstakesbut by a slim marginwhen he and two other mayoral aspirants ad dressed the Patrolmen's Benev olent Association here today.

title: American BirthControl Device Being Tried by Women in China
description: A onceayear birthcontrol device developed by an Ameri can pharmacetical company is being tested on women in China. The tests are belived to be the first permitted by the au thorities in that country on a foreignmade drug since the Communists took power nearly a quarter of a century ago.

title: Joseph Mercadante Dead; Led Green Star Shipping
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 13  Joseph Mercadante, former president of the Green Star Shipping Company, died yester day at Greenwich Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived here.

title: Italian Cholera Cases Put At 239 by Health Minister
description: ROME, Sept. 13  Health Minister Luigi Gui said today that 239 cases of cholera have been verified in Italy since the disease was first identified two, and a half weeks ago, and that there have been 24 deaths from cholera.

title: Pentagon Aides Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) The Senate confirmed today nominations of Joseph T. Mc Cullen Jr. of Bethesda, Md., and David S. Potter of Elm Grove, Wis., to be Assistant Secretaries of the Navy. Also confirmed were Walter B. LaBerge of China, Lake, Calif., to be an As sistant Secretary of the Air Force, and Norman R. Augus tine of Arlington, Tex., to be an Assistant Secretary of the Army.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Dr. Paul Hoxworth Dead; Headed Blood Bank Group
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 13 (AP) Dr. Paul Hoxworth, widely known for his work with blood banks, died yesterday at the age of 66.

title: Meany Says Nixon Perpetuated Myths In Veto on Wages
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 George Meany, urgently appeal ing to Congress to override President Nixon's veto of the minimum wage bill, charged today that the President, in his veto message, had deliberate ly perpetuated many myths about the poor.

title: HOUSE BACKS A RISE IN SCHOOL LUNCH AID
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13  The House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill to in crease Federal subsidies to school lunch programs by about $100million. The vote was 389 to 4.

title: Cambodian Force in Complete Control of Kompong Cham
description: KOMPONG CRAM, Cambodia, Sept. 13For the first time since the Communist onslaught against this provincial capital began nine days ago, Govern ment troops were in complete control of the city today, al though enemy shells were still landing sporadically.

title: Volvo's Volatile Chief
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 13 The three previous speakers had succeeded only in putting the audience at the Association of Swedish Indus tries to sleep. The 35year old president of Scandina via's largest insurance com pany was the fount speaker. He stood up, surveyed the unfortunate situ ation, and start ed to sing. The now 38yearold Pehr Gustaf Gyl lenhammar de mands attention and he is sure to get it. Pehr is not exactly shy, said a friend.

title: Critical Soviet Problem: Critics
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 13What is the Kremlin's line to be? Broader contacts with the West or a crackdown on outspoken critics at home? The two mix, lat best, uneasily.

title: Jersey Official Reports Threat Of Ouster in Kitchen Inspections
