description: TRENTON, Sept. 13Dr. Oscar Sussman, the State Consumer Health Director, who has closed kitchens in a number of state institutions because of unsani tary conditions, said tonight that the State Health Commis sioner had threatened to dis miss him.

title: Senate Votes $2.8Billion For Military Construction
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI)The Senate approved to day a $2.8billion military con struction authorization bill.

title: MIRK IS DEAD; SUN YATSEN'S SON
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 13 (UPI)  Sun Fo, the only child of Dr. Sun Yatsen, founder of the Republic of China, died here today of a heart attack. He Was 81 years old.

title: Alomar's Leg Is Broken
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Sept. 13 (UPI)Sandy Alomar, Cali fornia Angels' second base man, suffered a proken leg in the AngelsWhite Sox game last night and will be out for the remainder of the season.

title: Bronx Realty Protest Snuffed Out
description: An attempt to burn a 4 foot by 5foot cardboard model of the Bronx in front of City Hall, to dramatize the deterioration of hous ing in that borough, went up in smoke yesterday as the police intervened.

title: FREDERICK H. DUTCHER
description: WILTON, Conn., Sept, 13 Frederick H. Dutcher, who re tired as associate professor of mechanical engineering at Co lumbia University in 1958, died in Norwalk Hospital on Mon day. He was 81 years old and lived here.

title: CURB IS EXTENDED ON TEXASGULF BID
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 13 ment Corporation has been prohibited from consummat ing a stock tender offer for Texasgulf, Inc., until the Fifth United States Circuit Court of Appeals can hear their case in early December.

title: INCREASE URGED IN G.I. SCHOOL AID
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 The G.I. bill, which now pro vides armed forces veterans with $220 a month to further their education, should be ex panded to pay 80 per cent of veterans' tuition and fees, a report sponsored by the Na tional League of Cities and the United States Conference of Mayors recommended today.

title: A.B.C. ACQUIRES OLYMPICS RIGHTS
description: The American Broadcasting Company announced yesterday that it had obtained exclusive United States television rights for coverage of the 1976 Win ter Olympic Games in Inns bruck, Austria.

title: New Taiwan Opera Is Off for Tour Here, Leaving Gap Behind
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 13 Taiwan's newlyorganized Na tional Chinese Opera Theater, which left today for a three month tour of the United States, may have caused the collapse of the country's only opera company giving regular public performances.

title: John Berenyi Weds Eileen M. Brettler
description: Miss Eileen Marguerite Brettler, assistant director of the neighborhood decentrali zation project in the office of Deputy Mayor Edward A. Morrison, was married here last evening to John Andrew Berenyi, banker, author and former aide to Mayor Lindsay.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Winning numbers drawn on Sept. 13 were:

title: Stock Average Falls 0.75 In 5th Consecutive Drop
description: The question of whether the Administration is planning to seek higher taxes helped keep the stock market from showing even a modest gain yesterday.

title: KROGH IS SEEKING MONEY FOR TRIAL
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 13 Egil Krogh Jr., contending that he did not commit a crime, has established a legal defense fund like that of Daniel Ells berg, the man he held a White House mandate to investigate.

title: Cambridge Court Bars Assault Case Against F.B.I. Men
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 13  A state District Court judge denied today a request by citizens here that criminal charges be filed against five agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation for assault, with a dangerous weapon, ma licious destruction of property and larceny.

title: August Price Rise In Canada Steepest Since Korean War
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 13 (AP) Canada in August recorded her largest monthly, rise in liv ing costs in more than 22 years, an increase of 1.3 per cent, which was likely to bring criticism of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's propos als to combat inflation.

title: Books of The Times
description: MARILYN: An Untold Story. By Norman Rosten. 125 pages. Illustrated. A paper back original. New American Library. $1.25.

title: RAIL RATE RISE OF 1.9% CLEARED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (Reuters)  The Interstate Commerce Commission said to day it had authorized the na tion's railroads to increase their freight rates and charges by 1.9 per cent on Oct. 1 and by an additional 0.7 per cent on Jan. 1.

title: TV: Chase Leads Off N.B.C. Season
description: Even with the new televi sion season's strategy of staggered premieres, spread over several weeks due to, script delays caused, by the writers' strike, it is impos sible to avoid roundup re views, those collections of titles strung together pre cariously with observations bordering on the cryptic. The mere quantity of TV material is numbing, in more ways than one.

title: Rites for Mrs. Post Monday
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 A funeral service for Mrs. Mar jorie Merriweather Post, who died yesterday, will be held at the National Presbyterian Church here next Monday at 11 A.M., a spokesman for the family said today.

title: It Just Ain't So
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  I am tired of being smeared. Each day I open the newspaper, look at a magazine, or watch television I read and hear of the White House in which I worked, and hardly recognize the place. Sena tor Weicker has opined that it was place where everything that was touched was corroded. Joseph Alsop has written that it was inhabited by bottomdwelling slugs. Hugh Sidey has declared that the Nixon Adminis tration turned the White House into a private instrument of revenge and fear where hatred replaced hope.

title: Hospital in Paterson Gets Federal Aid to Expand
description: PATERSON, Sept. 13A $9.1million lowinterest loan and a $900,000 Federal grant were awarded today to St. Joseph's Hospital here for ex pansion and modernization work.

title: Dockside Dining. There's Hope Yet
description: The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as ex cellent and four as superb.

title: Pianist, 30, Gets Prize, The Haskil
description: VEVEY, Switzerland, Sept. 13Richard Goode, a native New Yorker, won the fifth Clara Haskil international competition for young plan ists here last night. The vic tory carries a cash prize of 10,000 francs ($3,300).

title: Odds Favor Giants, Not Jets in Openers
description: The Giants are favored, but the Jets are not in their opening games of the pro football season. Playing for the nexttolast time in Yan kee Stadium, the Giants have an alleged easy foe in the Houston Oilers as they begin a difficult schedule. They are a 13point choice. The Jets meet one of the strongest teams in the league, Green Bay, at Milwaukee in the first Monday night game. The Packers are favored by 3 points.

title: Business Sales Top Inventory in July
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13, (Reuters)  Business sales out stripped inventory accumula tion in July for the first time in four months, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Weekend Fishing: Outlook Good
description: AREA A The supply of fish is not overabundant on the Jersey shore, but suffi cient and varied enough to keep the average fisherman trying. Blues up to 16 pounds have been taken near Sea side Park with mullet as bait. Beach fishermen near Surf City are also pulling in blues in the 8to12pound class as well as bass up to 13 pounds. Bass averaging 3 to 6 pounds are also run ning near Island Beach, re sponding to lures. In Manas quan Inlet, fishermen using diamond jigs and bucktails have reported nice catches of weakfish.

title: 3 UTILITIES CITED FOR AIR POLLUTION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13  The Environmental Protection Agency served implicit notice today that energy problems would not bring about any gen eral relaxation of air pollution standards for power plants.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A vital threeandahalf mile link of interstate Route 80 is scheduled to open at 11:30 o'clock this morning be tween ParsippanyTroy Hills and Denville in Morris County. The link will allow motorists to travel on more than 61 miles of uninterrupted freeway between the George Wash ington Bridge in Bergen County and Blairstown in Warren County. The final three miles of Route 80 in New Jersey is targeted for completion in late October or early Novem ber in Warren County.

title: Women Will Take Over B.B.C. Channel for Day
description: LONDON, Sept. 13 (UPI)  The British Broadcasting Corporation announced plans today to turn one of its radio channels over to wo men for an entire day.

title: Fillies to Race Tomorrow In a 2d Belmont Feature
description: Nobody knocks a quarter of a milion dollars, even in these days of upward spirals and inflated values. That's why the Marlboro Cup has attracted so much attention for its first running tomor row at Belmont Park. This invitation contest, in which the Meadow Stable's Secre tariat and Riva Ridge are odds on favorites against five like ly rivals, has a gross value of $250,000, with $150,000 go ing to the winner.

title: Compromised Air
description: Russell E. Train has celebrated his confirmation head of the Environmental Protection Agency in a highly appropriate way. He has taken issue with the Administra tion that appointed him on the important question relaxing the country's clean air standards in order meet the expected shortage of heating oil in the coming winter.

title: Malcolm Declares Stiffer Drug Laws Could Crowd Jails
description: Benjamin J. Malcolm, the city's Corrections Commission er, predicted yesterday that under Governor Rockefeller's stringent new drugabuse laws, which took effect Sept. 1, the city's present prison population, now 9,216, would increase by up to 3,600 in a year.

title: Met Cancels Its New Giovanni In Worst Fund Crisis Since '32
description: Faced with its worst finan cial crisis since 1932, the Met ropolitan Opera has canceled the new production of Mozart's Don Giovanni planned for March 28 as well as future summer presentations of free opera concerts in the city's parks.

title: Sandman's Drive Splits Jersey Republican Party
description: TRENTON, Sept. 13  Open warfare within a number of big Republican county organi zations and charges that Gov ernor Cahill is deliberately ploting the defeat of Represent ative Charles W. Sandman Jr. were reported today to be un dermining the conservative Republican's campaign for Gov ernor.

title: Dr. Joseph Harrisson, 77, Pharmacologist, Is Dead
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13  Dr. Joseph W. E. Harrisson, a chemist and pharmacologist who had been president and director of LaWall and Har risson Laboratories, died at the hospital of the University of Pennsylvania on Monday. He was 77 years old.

title: Bridge: Lightner, of Double Fame, Marks 80th Birthday Today
description: Theodore Lightner, one of tile world's greatest players, celebrates his 80th birthday here today. A star in the earliest days of contract bridge, he was always a first choice for Ely Culbertson when he was building a team to compete in an interna tional match abroad or a na tional championship at home.

title: People and Business
description: Hilliard W. Paige presi dent of the General Dynam ics Corporation, who has had a long career in aerospace, missile and computer devel opment, has been named chairman and chief executive of the CML Satellite Corpo ration of Washington. The appointment is effective Mon day.

title: NOSTRIKE ACCORD IN STEEL PERILED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13  A spreading rankandfile revolt is threatening the nostrike la bor contract signed earlier this year by the steel industry and the United Steelworkers of America.

title: Murderer in 1969, Counselor Today
description: WILLIMANTIC, Conn.  Warren Kimbro, the man who murdered a suspected Black Panther turncoat in Middlefield, Conn., swamp in 1969, is back doing the things he always wanted to do.

title: Text of Appeals Court Memorandum on Dispute Over Nixon Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 Following is the text of a memorandum issued today by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, addressed to President Nixon, United States District Judge John J. Sirica, and Archibald Cox, special prosecutor in the Wa tergate case:

title: American Natural Gas Unit Sets Exploration Venture
description: The American Natural Gas Company announced yesterday that its subsidiary the Michigan Wisconsin Pipe Line, has en tared into agreements Involving expenditures of about $80mil lion with the. Cities Service Corporation, the Getty Oil Com pany and the Skelly Oil Com pany to explore for and develop natural gas reserves in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Department Store Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $934million, up 9 per cent from the yearearlier $854million. Total retail store sales were about $9,047billion, up 13 per cent from last year's $8.032billion.

title: CITY TO SEIZE 25 AS BRIBE GIVERS
description: More than 25 affluent busi nessmen will be arrested with in the next three weeks when the city's Department of In vestigating completes a year long inquiry into the bribing of city officials, according to sources close to the investiga tion.

title: About the Yanks:
description: When Doc Medich walked Orlando Cepeda in the fourth inning last night, it marked the first base on balls' yielded by a Yankee since Mondaya span of 27 innings. . . . Fifty years will be condensed into 32 minutes on an original record called Yankee StadiumThe Sounds of 50 Years. All fans attending the final game on Sept. 30 will receive the album free. . . . The New Yorkers start a four game series against the Orioles in Baltimore tonight. . . Bobby Murcer was back after suffering the flu. Reggie Smith returned for Boston after missing Wednesday's game when he burst a blood vessel on his right index finger during infield practice.

title: Hess Planning New Store
description: Hess's, Inc., Allentown, Pa., a department store chain, will build its fourth suburban con venience store in Whitehall Township, north of Allentown. The 100,000 square foot store, to be known as Hess's North, is expected to open next Au gust.

title: Riggins Signs Jet Pact For $50,000 Per Year
description: For a while it seemed as if none of the Riggins clan would be playing football this year, but John will be playing for the New York Jets again.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 3 From Last Week's Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 193.6 from 196.6 last week.

title: Pawn No More
description: In Cambodia it is still civil war. In South Vietnam there is indecision. Only in Laos, third of the Indochina states, has a widely heralded ceasefire turned into formal peacesigned and sealed yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A police officer who dis appeared from his Queens home with his wife and two children about a month ago was indicted yesterday by a Queens grand jury on charges involving $29,800 in alleged badcheck transactions.

title: MARION LADY CHESHAM
description: LONDON, Sept. 13Marion Lady Chesham, the former Marion Donoghue of Philadel phia and a former member of the Tanzanian Parliament, died Sept, 6 in Guildford, Surrey.

title: People in Sports: Ilie Defends Bad Behavior
description: They want me to be a bad guy so they make me bad guy even when I am not a bad guy. That was Ilie Nastase talking yesterday about his runins with tennis linesmen, associations and writers. The runins have led to fines and possible suspen sions for the Rumanian player.

title: MRS. MEIR'S FOES GET NEW SUPPORT
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 13Some members of Premier Golda Meir's Labor party who favor annexation of the occupied Arab territories joined today in an opposition attempt to offer an alternative to the present Government in the Oct. 30 elections.

title: The Theater
description: Jean Anouilh's The Waltz of the Toreadors is a merry froth of a play, and it is de lightful to welcome it back to Broadway, where it opened last night at the Circle in the SquareJoseph E. Levine The ater.

title: Long Lines Unit at A.T.&T. Seeks Wider Data System
description: The Longs Lines department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company filed with the Federal Communications Commission yesterday for per mission to add 19 more cities to its planned digital data sys tem to create an interim 24city network for the transmission of data communications.

title: At the Whitney, 73 Works by American Impressionists
description: The exhibition, American Impressionist Painting, which opens today at the Whitney Museum of Amer ican Art, 945 Madison Ave nue, is something of a mixed blessing. Comprising 73 paint ings drawn from public and private collections through out the country, it is a re spectable survey of late 19th century American artists such figures as Mary Cassatt, John Singer Sargent, Childe Hassam, William, Merritt Chase, to name but a few who adopted the practices of the great French Impression ist masters and, in many cases, attempted to apply them to the American scene.

title: About the Mets:
description: George Stone, whose 103 wonlost record gives him the best Met winning percentage, opposes Ferguson Jenkins as a threegame series with the Chicago Cubs opens at Shea Stadium tonight... Tug McGraw, already in the jewelry business, is diversifying even further. He's getting into the leather business with his older brother, Hank, a former minor league player. With Hank providing the talent and Tug the business acumen, the brothers are forming Bullpen Leathers. Hank handcrafts all the dec orated leather items, including briefcases, purses, eye shades and buffalohunter hats.

title: Mrs. Greenfield Wed To Donald A. Petrie
description: Mrs. Elizabeth Murphy Hallstrom. Greenfield of Phil adelphia, widow of Albert Monroe Greenfield, the phil anthropist who was a realtor and board chairman of the City Stores Company, was married here Wednesday to Donald A. Petrie of Wash ington, former treasurer of the Democratic National Committee. The Rev. Felix D. Lion performed the ceremony in the Community Church.

title: Sedate Old Hotel Now Boasts a Beauty Farm
description: INTERLAKEN, Switzer land  Elfie Beck, a bar waitress who spends 10 hours a day on her feet mix ing drinks, comes in for an electric massage twice a week to help keep unsight ly cellulitis from disfiguring her sightly thighs.

title: What's Round, Wordy and Freckled All Over? A Mason Reese
description: First off, let's make couple of things perfectly clear. Mason Reese is neither a midget nor a girl. He is the precocious 7yearold boy who ate his way to fame and fortune in television commer cials for Tasty Cake, Under wood Chicken Spread and Post Raisin Bran. You know, the pudgy redhaired kid with the round face and freckles.

title: Businessmen, in Poll, See Less Inflation
description: A slowdown in the economy, without recession and with a distinct lessening of inflation was the forecast for 1974 yes terday of more than 400 busi ness economists.

title: Kennedy Asks Impeachment If Nixon Defies High Court
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (Reuters)Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massa chusetts, said today that Con gress would have no recourse except to begin impeachment proceedings if President Nixon defied any Supreme Court order to surrender White House tape recordings of Watergate conversations.

title: The Pop Life
description: Let's Go Get Stoned, sang Ray Charles back in 1965, and people in this pop life instantly knew this funky drinking song was destined to become a popmusic classic.

title: A. W. MacPherson, Broker Who. Was Tennis Champion
description: Arthur W. MacPherson, former New York investment broker who was also a tennis player, died Wedesnday at his home here. He was 78 years old and lived at 435 East 52d Street.

title: COPPER FUTURES SHOW SHARP RISE
description: Copperfutures prices on the Commodity Exchange rose sharply here yesterday, still in fluenced by the confused condi tons in Chile since the over throw of the Allende Govern ment by a military coup. The London copper market, which opens earlier in the morning, led the way with sharp price increases.

title: Advertising: La Boutique Lives
description: The folks at the agencies just don't seem to be talking about boutiques any more. Does that mean that these small creativeonly shops have disappeared from the scene? No. What it means is that like the mediabuying services they are now ac cepted as part of the scene.

title: L.I. PLAN OUTLINED FOR MASS TRANSIT
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 13 A 10year, $1.961billion trans portation program for Nassau and Suffolk Counties was out lined today by State Transpor tation Commissioner Raymond T. Schuler.

title: Mitchell Requests White House Data
description: Lawyers for John N. Mitchell have issued a subpoena for any White House tape recordings that might be related to the obstructionofJustice case in volving the former Attorney General.

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: OLE AL FRESCO Midtown will be jumping with Mexi cans at midday today, all by Way of tooling up for the southern amigos' Independ ence Day celebration over the weekend. Mexican dancers and singers and mariachi strummers will give passers by a free sampling of their specialties at three locations.

title: Study Finds College Drug Sales Decline Under New State Laws
description: Students at eight colleges around the state report height ened fears among users of drugs, and many campus deal ers say that they have gone out of business as a result of the state's stringent new drug laws, which took effect Sept. 1.

title: Kissinger's Question
description: Senatorial inquiry into Henry Kis singer's responsibility for seventeen wiretaps of dubious legality ought to be pushed to the limit. That inquiry has tended, nevertheless, to obscure Mr. Kissinger's views on the deeply troubling question of what, if any thing, the United States ought to do about the treatment of political dis sidents in the Soviet Union.

title: Congress Votes Bill To Limit TV Ban On Football Games
description: The National Football League repealed yesterday its tele vision blackout of all soldout home games in the wake of Congressional action prohibit ing continuance of the 22year old blackout policy.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Winning numbers drawn on Sept. 13 were:

title: Big Board and Lehman Plan Layoffs and BeltTightening
description: Evidence of the financial pressure on Wall Street continued to mount yesterday as the New York Stock Exchange an nounced new layoffs and Lehman Brothers, a major investment banking firm, disclosed that it was in the midst of a major belt tightening program.

title: Wednesday's Fight
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev.  David Oropeza, 147 pounds, Phoenix, Ariz., knocked out Joe Espinosa, 145, Denver, 10th round.

title: SKYLAB CREW HUNTS FOR WATER IN TEXAS
description: HOUSTON, Sept, 13 (UPI) The Skylab 2 crew hunted to day for sources of water in west Texas and helped map remote areas of the Rocky Mountains. The astronauts Capt. Alan L. Bean, Owen K, Garriott, a civilian scientist, and Maj. Jack R. Lousma photographed 12,600 miles of the earth in two long sweeps.

title: Seoul Is Reassured Of Continued Aid In Military Program
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 13 The United States, re assured South Korea today that it would continue to help mod ernize the military here and that it had no plans to reduce its own forces in Korea.

title: HARRY M'ARTHUR
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) Harry MacArthur, drama, film and nightclub critic for The Washington StarNews for nearly 30 years, died yesterday at Holy Cross Hospital after a long illness. He was 62 years old, Mr. MacArthur returned to the paper after service with the Air Transport Command in World War II, He retired as its drama critic in 1964.

title: NATHANIEL P. DAVIS, A CAREER DIPLOMAT
description: WINTER PARK, Fla., Sept. 13  Nathaniel Penistone Davis, former Ambassador to Costa Rica and former Minis ter to Hungary who retired from the Foreign Service in 1951, died yesterday at his home here. His age was 78 and he formerly lived in Glens Falls, N.Y.

title: About the Jets:
description: Six players were named to the taxi squad yesterday: Phil Wise, safety; Steve Thompson, defensive tackle, and Margene Adkins, wide receiver, all taken off the designated injured list, The others are Dennis Cambal, tight end; Rocky Turner, wide receiversafety, and Rick Harrell, rookie center.... Another player will be deactivated before Monday to fill out the squad and make room for Biggins. ... Still no progress reports on contract talks between Fred Burke, the lawyer for John Elliott, and Dick Barovick, the Jets' lawyer.... Bob Bennett, who flew in from Cali fornia to sign pacts for two of his clients two days ago, reportedly got a threeyear graduated contract for Rich Caster, the tight end. It is said to start at $40,000, going up o $60,000. Caster made an estimated $25,000 last year. ... Jerome Barkum, Bennett's other client, got a twoyear contract reported to start at $30,000 and go to $35,000 next year. He made $18,000 as a rookie last year.

title: SCHOOL SUPPLIER BALKS AT INQUIRY
description: PATERSON, Sept. 13  The head of a company that sup plied automotive parts to the Passaic County Technical and Vocational High School pleaded the Fifth Amendment today when the counsel for the State Commission of Investigation asked him to comment on the size of his profits.

title: Wednesday's Fight
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev.  David Oropeza, 147 pounds, Phoenix, Ariz., knocked out Joe Espinosa, 145, Denver, 10th round.

title: 13 Accused of Selling Drugs To Upstate Investigators
description: CORTLAND, N. Y., Sept. 13 (AP)City and county inves tigators arrested 13 persons on drugsale charges today, with two of them accused under the new state laws that could lead to life imprisonment upon conviction.

title: Agnew Reportedly Got Free Food for Years From Supermarket Executive
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 13Vice President Agnew and his family have for years received gifts of food from a friend here who is a wealthy, politically active supermarket executive, accord ing to a Maryland political fig ure with contacts in the Vice President's staff.

title: PRESIDENT SEEKS SCHOOL AID PACT
description: The Nixon Administration is making a strong effort to end its deadlock with Congress over Federal aid to education and has let it be known that if a compromise can be worked out on the way the money is dis tributed, the Administration's budget request for next year will call for more spending on schools.

title: Rockefeller And Connally
description: The pro football exhibition season is over, out the political exhibition sea son has just started. It's an appalling, almost an unbearable thought, but the practice sessions for the 1976 Presi dential election have already started.

title: Enderle Faces Up to a Monumental Problem: How to Handle Oilers' 290Pound Matuszak
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 13 Greg Larson offered Dick Enderle some friendly advice today on how to prepare for John Matuszak, Houston's 6foot8inch, 290  pound rookie.

title: Equity Financing
description: An initial public offering of 1,000,000 common shares of Pioneer HiBred International, Inc. at $27 per share was made by underwriters managed by Goldman Sachs and Blyth Eastman Dillon, The com pany, which has its headquarters in Des Moines, was founded in 1926. It produces hybrid seed Corn, hybrid layer poultry and sorghum seed. It also breeds broiler poultry and beef cattle and dis tributes alfalfa seed.

title: TERMINAL WILL GET POWERED GANGWAYS
description: The passenger ship terminal being constructed on the Hud son River between 48th and 52d Streets will offer enclosed self propelled gangways for passengers and baggage hand ling similar to those used at modern, airports, the Port Au thority announced yesterday. thority announced yesterday.

title: Pirates Top Cubs, Widen Lead
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates, who took first place in the Na tional League's Eastern Divi Ron Wednesday for the first time since May 8, increased their lead to one game yester day with a 61 victory over the Chicago Cubs. The vic tory at Wrigley Field in Chi cago gave the Pirates a 7271 wonlost record, the only team in the division over the .500 mark.

title: Chilean Economist Says Coup Illustrates Fears of Third World
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 13  A leading Chilean economist declared here today that the Chilean drama dem onstrated why poorer countries feared the industrialized powers and their influential corpo rations.

title: Samuels Suggests Republican Successor
description: Preparing to resign as presi dent of the Off Track Betting Corporation to run for'the Dem ocratic gubernatorial nomina tion Howard J. Samuels has recommended that a Suffolk County Republican replace him in the $45,000 post.

title: Supermarket Clerks Back
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 (UPI)Some 6,500 supermarket clerks returned to work today in 250 food chain outlets in the metropolitan area after ratifying a contract that ended a threeday walkout.

title: 11 in Nursing Home In Philadelphia Die In Predawn Blaze
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 (UPI)  A predawn fire raced (through a nursing home today, and 11 elderly persons were killed, in part because of what authorities called a delayed alarm and confusion among the residents.

title: Beame Says Drugs Are Being Taxed At Some Markets
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday that a survey by his office had disclosed that checkout clerks at some city supermarkets were improperly imposing the 7 per cent sales tax on drugs and medicines that by law are tax exempt.

title: APPELLATE COURT ASKS COMPROMISE IN TAPES DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 An outofcourt compromise solution to the dispute between President Nixon and the Water gate grand jury over the White House tape recordings was proposed today by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.

title: CITY TO SEIZE 25 AS BRIBE GIVERS
description: More than 25 affluent busi nessmen will be arrested with in the next three weeks when the city's Department of In vestigation completes a year long inquiry into the bribing of city officials, according to sources close to the investiga tion.

title: The Need for Tax Reform
description: The White House is formally refusing to say whether President Nixon paid any Federal income taxes in 1970 or 1971 on his $200,000 annual salary plus whatever other income he had, holding that this is a personal matteralthough an anonymous White House official says he did pay such a tax. Whether he did or not, what public records demonstrate is that he could have legally avoided any payment of taxes in 1970 and pos sibly in 1971 on the basis of legitimately claimed tax deductions.

title: APPELLATE COURT ASKS COMPROMISE IN TAPES DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 An outofcourt compromise solution to the dispute between President Nixon and the Water gate grand jury over the White House tape recordings was proposed today by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: CORPORATE BONDS FINISH DAY MIXED
description: Corporate bond prices were mixed yesterday in quiet trad ing.

title: INCUMBENTS LEAD IN CAMPAIGN GIFTS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 Incumbents raised more than twice as much money as their challengers in the Congression al election campaign last year, according to a study released today by Common Cause.

title: Yanks Beat Red Sox in 12 Innings
description: With their monuments and plaques, remembrances of an other era, in center field for the last time, the Yankees squeezed out a 21, 12inning victory last night over the Boston Red Sox.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
AMEX LIST MIXED IN LIGHT TRADING
description: Trading dipped slightly on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as prices reversed the downhill slide of three pre vious sessions and closed mixed. Similar conditions pre vailed in the overthecounter market.

title: Jersey City Patrolman's Slaying Was Not a Setup, Mayor Says
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 13 Mayor Paul T. Jordan said today that there was no planned connection between the sniper murder or a Jersey City policemen late Wednesday night and a streetcorner alter cation over a traffic violation that preceded the shooting.

title: SIGNAL LOSES ITS BID ON CEMP INJUNCTION
description: Signal Companies, Inc., was denied on Wednesday a pre liminary injunction in its suit to block a tender offer of Cemp Investments, Ltd., for up to 1.5million shares of Signal stock, it was disclosed yester day. The ruling came a day after the proposed merger of Signal with the United Aircraft Corporation had been jointly terminated.

title: Jersey Health Official Reports Dismissal Threat
description: TRENTON, Sept. 13  Dr. Oscar Sussman, the State Con sumer Health Director, who has closed kitchens in a number of state institutions because of unsanitary conditions, said to night that the State Health Commissioner had threatened to dismiss him.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (Reuters)  A system of variablerate home mortgages should be considered to allow savings and loan associations more flexibility, the chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, Thomas Bomar, told the House Banking Committee today.

title: Optimistic on Equal Rights
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 13 (UPI) Frances Farenthold, president of the National Women's Cau cus, said today the chances of the equal rights amendment's becoming law were still good because we have six years to get it ratified by the necessary 37 states. Thirty states have ratified.

title: U.S. Expected Chile Coup But Decided Not to Act
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13Administration officials said today that President Nixon had received numerous reports in the last year of an impending military coup in Chile, and had decided against taking any action that would either encourage or discourage the overthrow of the Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: SWEDISH LEFTISTS FACE A CHALLENGE
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 13The Social Democratic Party, in power for 41 years, is facing its most serious challenge in a long time in an election cam paign that has stirred the hopes of the opposition if not the imagination of the Swedes.

title: 5Under 66 By Blancas Leads Golf
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., Sept. 13 (AP)Homero Blancas's brilliant putting gave him a fiveunderpar 66 and a onestroke lead to day in the first round of the $150,000 Heritage Golf Clas sic.

title: Two Senators Urge Defense Fund Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 Two Democratic Senators, Stuart Symington of Missouri and George McGovern of South Dakota, argued today that cuts must be made in the defense budget to protect the economic strength of the nation,

title: Boston U. Posts a Surplus First Time in Three Years
description: BOSTON, Sept. 13 (AP) Boston University ended its 1973 fiscal year with its first surplus in three years, the uni versity's president, John R. Silber, said yesterday.

title: PHOENIX HOUSE CONCEDES ERROR
description: The president of Phoenix House, a drugtreatment pro gram, conceded to the Board of Estimate yesterday that his staff might have recruited a limited number of addicts from out of state into the treat ment program.

title: VOLVO CONFIRMS U.S. PLANT PLANS
description: Volvo, the Swedish auto mobile manufacturer, formally announced here yesterday that it would build a car assembly plant in the United States at a cost of more than $100million.

title: Weekend Fishing: Outlook Good
description: AREA AThe supply of fish is not overabundant on the Jersey shore, but suffi cient and varied enough to keep the average fisherman trying. Blues up to 16 pounds have been taken near Sea side Park with mullet as bait. Beach fishermen near Surf City are also pulling in blues in the 8to12pound class as well as bass up to 13 pounds. Bass averaging 3 to 6 pounds are also run ning near Island Beach, re sponding to lures. In Manas quan Inlet, fishermen using diamond jigs and bucktails have reported nice catches of weakfish.

title: NOSTRIKE ACCORD IN STEEL PERILED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13  A spreading rankandfile revolt is threatening the nostrike la bor contract signed earlier this year by the steel industry and the United Steelworkers of America.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Missing Police Officer Indicted

title: Alabama Body Acts to Make Newsmen Disclose Finances
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 13 (AP)The Alabama Legisla ture, in the closing hours of its 1973 session tonight, passed and sent to Gov. George C. Wallace a strong ethics bill that requires newsmen as well as public officials to make finan cial disclosures.

title: Congress Votes Bill To Limit TV Ban On Football Games
description: The National Football League repealed yesterday its tele vision blackout of all soldout home games in the wake of Congressional action prohibit ing continuance of the 22year old blackout policy.

title: MEMOREX AMENDS ITS REPORT TO S.E.C.
description: The Memorex Corporation, diversified manufacturer of magnetic recording and com puter equipment, has filed an amendment to its form 10Q report with the Securities & Ex change Commission on its oper ations for the six months ended June 30, it was announced last night.

title: Notes on People
description: President Nixon said yes terday that he was a member of the sneezing minority  those Americans afflicted this time of year with hay fever. Mr. Nixon disclosed his irri tation as he was having his picture taken before it meet ing with members of the House Ways and Means Committee.

title: 5% Drop in Meat Consumption Forecast
description: A 5 per cent drop in the na tion's meat consumption was forecast yesterday by Federal Agriculture Department ex perts.

title: SENATORS REVISE 2 VETOED BILLS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI)Bowing to the will of the White House, the Senate took steps today toward enact ing two major bills without provisions that had prompted their earlier vetoes.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: WESTFIELD, Sept. 13At Westfield High School, a winning football team is not just a tradition, it's a habit.

title: Dairymen Charged In Aid to Humphrey And Muskie in '68
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 13 (UPI)Two former officials of the Arkansas division of Asso ciated Milk Producers, Inc., a cooperative of dairymen, were charged today with conspiring to make illegal campaign con tributions to the 1968 Demo cratic Presidential campaign.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Recently Dr. I. D. J. Bross in a letter suggested that in association with proposed nuclear power plant at York, Pa., and other affected areas healthsurveillance system should be set up so we could at least get an early warning of any serious hazards, presumably arising from the radiation emitted by the proposed and other operational power plants.

title: U.S. Expected Chile Coup But Decided Not to Act
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13Administration officials said today that President Nixon had received numerous reports in the last year of an impending military coup in Chile, and had decided against taking any action that would either encourage or discourage the overthrow of the Government of. President Salvador Allende Gossens.

title: BY SANDMAN'S BID JERSEY G.O.P. SPLIT
description: TRENTON, Sept. 13  Open warfare within a number of big Republican county organi zations and charges that Gov ernor Cahill is deliberately plotting the defeat of Represent ative Charles W. Sandman Jr. were reported today to be un dermining the conservative Republican's campaign for Gov ernor.

title: FireDamaged Data On Millions of G.I.'s Are Being Salvaged
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 13 (AP) Spaceage technology is helping to salvage some of the millions of records damaged in a four day fire at the Military Per sonnel Records Center in sub urban Overland last July.

title: Providence Guild to Strike
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 13 (AP)Members of the Provi dence Newspaper Guild voted tonight to strike The Provi dence JournalBulletin news papers in a dispute over retro active pay. A spokesman for the Providence Journal Com pany, which publishes the newspaper, said the company would continue to publish.

title: Round to Ease Trade Barriers Approved
description: TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 14, (Reuters)Ministers from near ly 100 nations approved today a declaration paving the way for the world's most ambitious attempt to remove obstacles to international trade.

title: People in Sports: Nasty Defends Bad Behavior
description: They want me to be a bad guy so they make me a bad guy even when I am not a bad guy. That was Ilie Nastase talking yesterday about his runins with tennis linesmen, associations and writers. The runins have led to fines and possible suspen sions for the Rumanian player.

title: Insider Suit Filed; Another Is Decided
description: A brokerage firm is not au tomatically liable for the negli gent conduct of an employe, Judge Harold R. Tyler Jr. ruled here yesterday.

title: REMAPPING PANEL ENDS ITS HEARINGS
description: The City Council's special committee on reapportionment completed three days of public hearings yesterday on new councilmanic district lines. And there were indications that members were inclined to elim inate two of the four twobor Dugh districts contained in the present plan.

title: A.F.L.C.I.O. Asks More Bank Credit Go Into Housing
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) The A.F.L.C.I.O. urged Con gress today to direct the Fed eral Reserve System to allocate at least some bank credit to priority areas such as housing.

title: CONSUMER GROUPS SCORE NEW CEREAL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI) A group of nutritionists and consumer organizations criti cized today a new cereal being testmarketed by General Mills.

title: $47,244 Jackpot Reported
description: RENO, Nev., Sept. 14 (UPI) A woman hit a $47,244 jack pot on a dollar slot machine Wednesday, officials of Harold's Club casino said. She was not identified.

title: 2 Men Are Arrested By Women Officers Directing Traffic
description: Two probationary woman police officers on traffic duty made their first arrests yester day afternoon in separate inci dents just five blocks apart.

title: Betty Field, Actress, Is Dead at 55
description: Betty Field, a prominent stage and screen actress who was perhaps best known for her roles in the play Dream Girl, written by the late Elmer Rice, her former husband, and the film Of Mice and Men, died Thursday in Cape Cod Hospital, Hyannis, Mass., of a cerebral hemorrhage. She was 55 years old.

title: Marylanders Got Bargain on Surplus U.S. Land
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 14 The partners in a Maryland land development concern, including men who have been closely linked with both Vice President Agnew and Gov. Marvin Man del, were reported today to have bought more than 200 acres of surplus Federal land near Baltimore last year for less than, half its appraised value.

title: Secretariat to Race 6 Rivals at Belmont
Wall St. Firms Institute Higher Commission Fees
description: Brokerage houses yesterday began to raise their commission rates, following an announce ment by the Securities and Ex change Commission four days ago that such increases would be allowed in order to ease the financial pressure on Wall Street.

title: PRESIDENT SILENT ON PLAN ON TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept.  President Nixon and Archibald Cox, the Justice Department's special prosecutor, made no visible progress today toward the proposed outofcourt com promise of their dispute over the Watergate tape recordings.

title: Saigon Reports Fierce Battle Leaves 90 Communists Dead
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Sept, 15The South Vietnamese command today repopted a fierce battle on the main coastal highway in which it said 90 Communist soldiers had been killed.

title: Flower Show Blooming On Westchester Grounds
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 14 A new variety of that hardy perennial, the garden and flower show, has bloomed on the grounds of a 68yearold Westchester County institution, the Burke Rehabilitation Center.

title: AMEX PRICES TAKE A MIXED DIRECTION
description: Prices were mixed yesterday on the American Stock Ex change in a day of unusual developments.

title: Frankfurter Notes Are Believed Stolen By Capital Scholar
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14A number of valuable personal papers are missing from the Felix Frankfurter Collection at the Library of Congresssto len, apparently, by a scholar who had been using them.

title: ARTHUR SCHECHTER
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Sept. 14 Arthur Schechter, a regional economist with the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, died here yesterday while conduct ing a survey. His age was 55 and he lived in Valley Stream, L. I.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's subjective judgment of qual ity in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Consumer Notes
description: If you recently received an announcement in the mail from the First National City Bank telling you that the bank was changing its billing method for holders of its Master Charge cards, you may have, wondered what, it meant.

title: Notes on People
description: The West German Con sulate in New York an nounced that, on the occa sion of the admission of the Federal Republic of Germany as a member of the United Nations, Chancellor Willy Brandt and Foreign Minister Walter Scheel would visit the international organization headquarters in the next two weeks. Mr. Scheel is due in New York on Monday, and Mr. Brandt, accompanied by Federal Minister Egon Bahr, is due a week later. Mr. Brandt is scheduled to ad dress the General Assembly on Sept. 26, before visits to Chicago and Aspen, Colo. On Oct. 6 and 7 he is expected to meet in London with Prime Minister Health.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Under a row of glistening boots in a corner of the Del Mar jockey's room last week, a young jockey was studying the past performances of a horse he was about to ride. Nearby, Willie Shoemaker, putting on a beige suit to go home, glanced at him.

title: CHILE JUNTA CITES THREAT BY ALIENS
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 14 Chile's new military junta said today that the armed forces overthrew the Marxist Govern ment of Dr. Salvador Allende Gossens because more than 10,000 extremists from other countries had entered Chile.

title: BUILDING LOAN RATE OF 11% FOR BRITAIN
description: LONDON, Sept. 14 (AP) Britain's building societies an nounced today they would raise their lending rate to home buy ers 1 percentage point to a record of 11 per cent, the third increase in less than a year.

title: Tiny Laser Is Devised
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 A laser smaller than a grain of sand, which was patented this week for the Bell Sys tem, is regarded as one of the keys to future optical communications. Some day tele phone conversa tions, data and video signals may be trans mitted on pulses of laser light rather than on electrical pulses or microwaves, as they are now. Patent 3,758, 875 was granted to Izuo Hay ashi, who did the research on the Bell Laboratories staff but is now with the Nippon Electric Company in Japan.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
POLITICS FORBIDDEN FOR FEDERAL JUDGES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14(AP) The United States Judicial Conference adopted today a policy prohibiting political ac tivity by Federal judges.

title: Martha Ford Married to Peter Morse
description: GROSSE POINTE FARMS Mich., Sept. 14Miss May tha (Muffie) Parke Ford, a greatgranddaughter of Hen ry Ford, founder of the Ford Motor Company, and of Harvey S. Firestone, founder of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, was mar ried here this afternoon to Peter Christopher Morse, who is with Lehman Broth ers, investment bankers in New York.

title: Cosmos No. 586
description: MOSCOW, Sept, 14 (Reuters) The Soviet Union today launched the 586th in its series of Cosmos satellites designed for space exploration and re search. Tass, the government press agency, said all the in struments on board were func tioning normally.

title: Slip in Auto Output Spurs First Drop in Two Years
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP)  Production of the na tion's factories, mined and util ities declined in August for the first time in two years, mainly because of a sharp drop in au tomobile and truck output, the Federal Reserve Board said to day.

title: Jerusalem Defendi Pilots
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 14  Israeli officials concluded today that the battle fought by Israeli and Syrian jet fighters over the Mediterranean yesterday was an isolated incident rather than a serious attempt to renew hos tilities in the Middle East.

title: Error by Selassie Pilot Starts Hijacking Scare
description: COLOGNE, West Germany, Sept. 14 (AP)The pilot of an Ethiopian airliner flying Emperor Haile Selassie home from West Germany set off a hijacking alarm in error today while flying over Italy but then quickly reported that all was normal aboard, West German air safety offi cials said.

title: STATE PARK URGED AT RARITAN CANAL
description: TRENTON, Sept. 14 (AP) The chairman of a legislative study committee said tciday that the best way to preserve the, historic 64milelong Dela ware and Raritan Canal is by making it a state park.

title: I.R.S. Gets $967,430 Seized In a Narcotics Case Last Year
description: The Federal Drug Enforce ment Administration yesterday turned over to the Internal Rev enue Service office in Brook lyn nearly $1million in cash seized 18 months ago from two men authorities described as largescale distributors of hero in.

title: Foreign Issues in Japan Up
description: TOKYO, Sept. 14 (AP)  Trading in foreign stocks by Japanese individuals is soar ing, statistics released today by the Japan Securities Dealers Association showed. The sharp increase was attributed to rela tively calm conditions on for eignexchange markets and to expectations of foreignshare listing on Japanese stock ex changes in the near future.

title: Mr. Agnew Returns
description: Vice President Agnew appears to be the latest recruit in President Nixon's campaign to portray the investiga tion of the Watergate scandals as an obstruction of the business of the people. This tactic depicts as villains those who want to get to the bottom of the White House horrors instead of those who committed them.

title: FoodArid Famine
description: The worldwide inflation in the cost of food and the developing shortages as demand outruns supply pose a threat to the life and health of millions of people The urgency of that threat has been pointed up by DirectorGeneral Boersma of the Food and Agriculture Organization.

title: Dryden Quits Hockey for Law Clerk Job
description: In what he described as an irrevocable decision for this year, Ken Dryden said yes terday he was leaving his job as a hockey goalie, reported ly at a salary of $80,000 a year, to become a $7,000a year law clerk.

title: Cornelia Lynde Meigs, Author Of Children's Books, Dies at 88
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 14Cor nelia Lynde Meigs, a well known author of books for chil dren, died on Monday at her home in Harford County. She was 88 years old.

title: Laos Pact: Reunion or Paralysis
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 14 The 6,000word protocol signed today by the Pathet Lao and the Vientiane Government is a perfect recipe for national re conciliationor for govern mental paralysis.

title: Some Obstacles Remain, Pompidou Says in Peking
description: PEKING, Sept. 14 (Reuters)  President. Pompidou of France said today that there were still stumbling blocks to Chinese  French relations, though there were many areas in which both countries were in harmony, including the need to build independent nuclear ar senals.

title: Thieu's NonCommunist Opponents Say They Feel Powerless
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 12  Fragmented and gloomy, the nonCommunist political opposition to President Nguyen Van Thieu now feels itself virtually helpless.

title: REVIEW HEED AIM
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 14  Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson has decided to let evidence against Vice President Agnew go to the Federal grand jury that is investigating charges of Maryland political corruption, Government sources in Washington said today.

title: 8 CHASE AND CATCH A MUGGING SUSPECT
description: Alerted by a young woman's screams, a group of outraged citizens pursued and caught a purse snatcher after a four block chase on the East Side yesterday.

title: Mrs. Fletcher Wed To Ray Pendleton
description: Mrs. Eleanor Langley Fletcher of New York, wid ow of Walter D. Fletcher, was married here yesterday afternoon to Ray Pendleton. The ceremony in the Unitar ian Church of All Souls was performed by the Rev. Wal ter Donald Kring.

title: Fire Prevention Week
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP)  President Nixon announced the signing of annual proclama tions on Fire Prevention Week And National Hunting and Fish ing Day. Fire Prevention Week will begin Oct. 7. The day to honor hunters and fishermen is Sept. 22.

title: Prime Rise Widens
description: After several major banks had increased their prime rate to 10 per cent from 9 per cent, the Committee on Interest and Dividends made requests for justification of the rate rise. Page 37.

title: Protestant Cleric in Ulster Begins 24Hour Peace Vigil
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 14 (UPI)A Church of Ireland clergyman began peace vigil here today.

title: Hauge Asks U.S. to Hire Disadvantaged Workers
description: Gabriel Hauge, chairman of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, proposed yes terday that the Government, acting as employer of last re sort, hire some 500,000 un skilled or disadvantaged work ers as a better means of re ducing unemployment than con stantly pumping up the econo my with inflationary results.

title: F.C.C. Head Proposes Curbs on Relicensing Powers
description: Dean Burch, chairman of the Federal Communications Com mission, proposed yesterday to strip his agency of its un bridled administrative discre tion in programing and to sub stitute known guidelines equi tablyenforced in the licensing of television stations.

title: Market Place: Experts View The Favorites
description: If your favorite stock picks for 1973 have turned into clinkers, you have a lot of company among money managers at the big banks, insurance companies, mutu al funds and college endow ment funds.

title: FRANK B. ALLEN
description: KINNELON, N. J., Sept, 14 Frank B. Allen, who retired last year as executive vice president of the Industrial Timer Company in Parsippany, of which he was a founder, died of cancer at his home here at Smoke Rise yesterday. His age was 62.

title: Sussman Is Forbidden To Shut More Kitchens
description: TRENTON, Sept. 14Dr. Oscar Sussman, who has or dered kitchens or bakeries, in nine state institutions closed in, the last three weeks because of unsanitary conditions, was told today that he did not have the power to order further closings. was told today that he did not have the power to order further closings.

title: GEORG EWALD
description: BERLIN, Sept. 14 (UPI) Georg Ewald, East German Ag ricultural Minister, was killed today in an automobile acci dent, the East German news service A.D.N. reported. He was 46 years old.

title: Sharp Battles Reported on 3 Sides of Phnom Perth
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sept, 14 (UPI)With the reb els' attack on Kompong Cham apparently blunted, sharp fight ing was reported today on three sides of Phnom Penh.

title: Governor's Career Is at Stake, But Life Goes On in Pagopago
description: PAGOPAGO, American Sa moa, Sept. 14They stood on the broad front porch of the old white wooden high court building of American Samoa each morning and each afternoon this week  High Talking Chief S. Aoeula and Mayor Charlie, as Chief T. Saleaumoa likes to call himself for the sake of the pa lagi, or white man. They and scores of others, palagis and Sa moans, were waiting for a glimpse of their Governor of four years, John M. Haydon, to come flashing up to the courthouse porch in his black limousine with the flags on the fenders They were also waiting for a seat in the courtroom where he is on trial for his very political existence.

title: Gulf Coast Alerted to Lost Cyanide
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 14 (AP)Coastal residents from Texas to Florida were warned today to watch the Gulf of Mexico for blue barrels con taining potentially lethal so dium cyanide and potassium cyanide.

title: An OilTruck Wreck Causes Series of Mishaps on L.I.E.
description: An oil truck jackknifed and overturned last night on the Long Island Expressway near Douglaston, Queens, slightly in juring the driver, closing west bound lanes and causing a series of minor traffic accidents.

title: Murder Charge Dismissed Against One of Harlem Six
description: A State Supreme Court jus tice in Manhattan yesterday dismissed a murder indictment against Robert Rice, one of the socalled Harlem Six, in a dif ferent slaying because the case had not been prosecuted in the nine years that elapsed since the killing.

title: CHRYSLER STRUCK BY U.A.W. AS TALKS FAIL AT DEADLINE
description: DETROIT, Saturday, Sept. 15  The United Auto Workers struck the Chrysler Corporation at midnight after the parties failed to agree on a new con tract last night.

title: ZENITH CAUTIONS ON COLOR TV FIRE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 The Zenith Radio Corporation and the Consumer Product Safety Commission issued warnings today of a possible fire hazard in 12,000 Zenith dolor television sets.

title: Fire at a Subway Station Halts Runs to Rockaways
description: A fire damaged the elevated IND subway station at the Broad Channel stop in Jamaica Bay last night, halting train service between Howard Beach in Brooklyn and the Rocka ways.

title: Tito Hints That U.S Is to Blame in Chile
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 14  President Tito charged in an angry speech today that imperialist reaction an apparent allusion to the United Stateshad instigated hireling generals to over throw and murder President Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile.

title: LawyertoBe Passes His Own Legal Exam
description: Robert H. Harris won his first legal case yesterday, al though he has not yet passed the bar examinations.

title: Vital Stretch of Route 80 Opens In Jersey, Ending Big Bottleneck
description: Drivers who have been wait ing for years to get onto a vital, unfinished stretch of In terstate 80 in North Jersey were literally unchained yes terday and sent speeding on their way on the sixlane ex pressway.

title: City Aid for Park Concerts
description: Free summer concerts by the Metropolitan Opera in city parks could continue next year under city sponsorship, Richard Lewisohn, city Finance Admin istrator, said yesterday. Schuy ler G. Chapin, Met general manager, said Thursday that the opera had canceled plans for future free concerts Ainm an economy move. Mr. Lewisohn said he thought the Bureau of the Budget could find the $200,000 needed to keep the concerts going.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:

title: JAMES B. NEWMAN
description: LYME, Conn., Sept. 14James B. Newman, who retired in 1967 as a partner in Kahn & Jacobs, New York architectural firm, died Monday at Middlesex Memorial Hospital, Middletown., He was 80 years old and lived here.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Indianapolis Gets W.H.A. Team

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Briton Gets Retrospective of His Choice
description: In his search for what is epic in everyday objects and everyday attitudes, the Bit ish artist Richard Hamilton has become one of the more highly publicized stars of the contemporary scene. The retrospective showing of his work, which has just opened at the Solomon R. Guggen heim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, has been selected by Mr. Hamilton himself and thus gives the artist's eye view of what his work is about.

title: Stocks Reverse as Average Gains 5.79
description: The stock market yesterday shook off a morning decline and closed at its best levels of the day.

title: People and Business
description: In what could be taken as a gesture toward reducing antiAmerican feelings in the Arab world, G. A. Costanzo, executive vice president of First National City Corpora tion, said in Beirut, Lebanon, yesterday that his bank was prepared to invest $1billion to assist economic develop ment in Middle Eastern Arab countries.

title: Varied Groups Urge Senate Panel to Reject Kissinger
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee was urged by a variety of political groups to day to reject Henry A. Kis singer's nomination as Secre tary of State for reasons rang ing from his Vietnam policy to his Jewish background.

title: Pirates Drop Cards to Third, Move 1 Games in Front
description: The battle for first place in the National League's Eastern. Division was settled quickly last night in St. Louis as the Pittsburgh Pi rates scored a 31 triumph in a game in which all the runs were scored in the first in ning.

title: Shipping/Mails
SOVIET INDUSTRY RESISTS REFORMS
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 14The So viet Union disclosed this week that an ambitious industrial re organization plan providing for a system of Government com panies and aiming at a more efficient economy had en countered resistance and was running behind schedule.

title: Jets' Puetz Upsets Odds, Closes In on Herman's Job
description: About the only time Valparaiso ever gets in the news, is when it's in relation to Chile, said Gary Puetz, the New York Jets' 6foot3 inch, 255pound rookie guard from Valparaiso.

title: BERNIE BOLAND
description: DETROIT, Sept. 14, (AP) Bernie Boland, who pitched for the Detroit Tigers from 1915 to 1920, died Wednesday in Mount Carmel Hospital after a three week illness. He was 81 years old.

title: Lifting the Blackout Reveals a Split Screen
description: New York pro football fans, their loyalties already split remained divided yes terday on the impact that lift ing the television blackout on local games would have on the Giants and Jets.

title: Agnew Associates Linked To Fund Collection in 60's
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 14Per sons who have been cooperat ing with an inquiry by the United States Attorney's of fice here in return for preferen tial treatment have told in vestigators that three close associates of Vice President Agnew collected money from consulting engineers and others on his behalf while he was Governor of Maryland.

title: COURT FOR ELECTION IS NAMED BY ATHENS
description: ATHENS, Sept. 14 (Reuters) The Greek Government ap pointed an 11man civilian Con stitutional Court today as a first step in its promise to re store democracy.

title: 286 Takes Met. Golf For Davison
description: ORADELL, N. J., Sept. 15  As officials mopped water from the greens with huge bath towels so the contest ants could finish in the heavy downpour, Peter Davison, an assistant professional at the Woodmere, L.I., club, won the Metropolitan open cham pionship today by one stroke.

title: Antiques: Indian Ideas
description: No one needed a crystal ball to foresee what would happen to vintage American Indian wares once the general public began to understand what had, decades earlier, made such avid collectors of George G. Heye and William Randolph Hearst.

title: Haitian Denies Knowledge Of a Reported Invasion
description: PORTAUPRINCE, Haiti, Sept. 14 (AP)The Haitian In formation Minister said today that there was nothing to reports of a guerrilla invasion of Haiti's north coast.

title: MUSIC HALL, UNION BEGIN TALKS AGAIN
description: Efforts were resumed yes terday to prevent the shut down of the Radio City Music Hall over terms of a new con tract covering the theater's or chestra musicians.

title: Prime Rise Widens
description: After several major banks had increased their prime rate to 10 per cent from 9 per cent, the Committee on Interest and Dividends made requests for justification of the rate rise. Page 37.

title: Strike of Security Men Is Averted at Belmont
description: A possible strike by Pinker ton security guards that threatened to close Belmont Park today was averted last night when the guards agreed to report to work while nego tiations continued on a new labor contract.

title: TRIAL DELAY ASKED BY TURNER LAWYERS
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 14 (AP)Attorneys for Glenn W. Turner, the Florida busi nessman, filed a petition today to delay Mr. Turner's mail fraud trial here.

title: TEACHERS IN CLIFTON VOTE TO GO ON STRIKE
description: CLIFTON, Sept. 14 (UPI) The Clifton Teachers Associa tion voted overwhelmingly Fri day to strike the city's 16 pub lic schools on. Monday because of a contract dispute with the board of education.

title: TV Bill Presents A Riddle
description: Like it or not, officials of the networks televising Knickerbocker and Ranger games said yesterday they were prepared to obey legis lation banning TV blackouts of games sold out at least 72 hours in advance. Presi dent Nixon signed the bill into law yesterday.

title: ALBERT SKIRA, 69, PUBLISHER OF ART
description: GENEVA, Sept. 14  Albert Skira, the Swiss publisher noted for books on works of art and the history of art, died today at his home in Dully, near here. He was 69 years old.

title: STATE G.O.P. VOWS TO HELP MARCH
description: Richard M. Rosenbaum, the Republican state chairman, promised State Senator John J. Marchi yesterday that the state committee would give him substantial help in his con test for Mayor.

title: Equity Funds Shifted
description: Shareholders of three mutual funds managed by the Equity Funding Corporation of Ameri ca, the company now in bank ruptcy proceedings after an in surance scandal, voted yester day to turn over the mutual fund management to the Chan ning Management Corporation. The three funds are Equity Growth, Equity Progress and Fund of America.

title: Train Takes Oath
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) Russell E. Train was sworn in today as director of the En vironmental Protection Agency.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Chile's new military junta said it had over thrown the country's Marxist Government because more than 10,000 extremists from other countries had entered Chile, seriously threatening the destiny of the country. As thousands of civilians milled about down town Santiago, the junta announced that its policies would be those of national unity not geared to the ineffectual patterns of the right or the left. The communique blamed the former Government for going beyond the limits of the law, in accumulating politi cal and economic power and of endangering the rights and liberties of the country's inhabitants. [Page 1, Column 2.]

title: Art: Early Photos of Mideast
description: The early development of photography, in the 19th cen tury, coincided with the ro mantic cult of exoticism. As the smoke and fumes of a primitive industrialism rose over the cities of Western Europe for the first time, poets and paintersand pho tographers, too  immersed themselves in dreams of the Orient, which in that period could mean just about any thing east or south of Rome. The European mind, already recoiling from the first as saults of machine civilization (of which the camera was, of course, a part), looked for solace, refreshment and in spiration in alien climates and cultures.

title: School Supplier Testifies Middleman Staked Him
description: PATERSON, Sept. 14The brother of, an alleged middle man through whom Passaic County Technical and Voca tional High School bought most of its supplies told a Com mission of Investigation hear ing today how he was set up in a business whose big gest customer by far was the school.

title: Tradition No Longer Walks Princeton's Hallowed Halls
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 14 The sculptured lions re main sprawled on the stoop of ancient, ivycovered Nas sau Hall, which quartered troops during the Revolution ary War. On Witherspoon Green, near the dormitory in which young Woodrow Wil son lived as an undergradu ate, students pitch gaily col ored Frisbees while others lie on the soft, green grass read ing or talking.

title: Unified Patents System Explored by Europeans
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 14  Rep resentatives of 21 Western European nations opened monthlong conferen'ce in Munich this week to adopt a new, unified European patent system.

title: SENATORS SWITCH ON PENSION PUNS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 The Senate Finance Committee, bowing to an intense lobbying campaign, backtracked today on legislation that would have greatly reduced the size of the tax  free contributions that many lawyers, doctors and other professionals have been making to their own pension plans.

title: For Cleaner Elections
description: In the glare cast by the financial outrages of the 1972 political campaignwith its bartering of Government favors for bundles of laundered cashthe Senate last July passed a wellmeant but much too hasty reform bill, now soon to be considered by the House.

title: Farm Export Data Meeting
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP)The Agriculture Depart ment will hold a public meeting on Sept. 19 to discuss putting into effect a new repqrting sys tem for farm exports to for eign nations. The department said, that the new system, or dered by Congress in the Agri culture and Consumer Protec tion Act of 1973, will include weekly reports on farm com modity sales and contracts by exporters.

title: L.I. Boy Is Charged in Slaying of Girl, 12
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Sept. 14 A 15yearold boy was ar rested today and charged in connection with the murder of Jennifer Sturek, 12, in nearby Holbrook on Tuesday.

title: BARBARA ANN TYLER
description: BOSTON, Sept. 14 (AP) Barbara Ann Taylor, executive secretary for the Boston Red Sox from 1936 until her retire ment last month, died tonight at the Massachusetts General Hospital.

title: 4 Watergate Burglar's Ask To Shift Plea to Not Guilty
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14Four of the original seven Watergate defendants contended before a Federal judge today that they had been deceived into pleading guilty, and asked to change their pleas to not guilty.

title: Okker, Richey in Seattle Net Semifinals
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 14 (AP) Tom Okker of the Nether lands and Cliff Richey ad vanced today to the semi finals of the $37,500 Seattle international tennis tourna ment.

title: SAKIIAROV BACKER DENOUNCED AT JOB
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 14  One of the few scientists who spoke up on behalf of the phy sicist Andrei D. Sakharov dur ing the recent campaign by the Soviet press was reported to day to have been denounced himself at a meeting of his re search institute.

title: Dance: Flindt Appraised
description: The director of a ballet Company, unlike the conduc tor of a symphony orchestra, tends to be judged on two levels. First there is the Tines tion of how well he is main taining or improving the com pany's standards, and this is the rough equivalent of as sessing a permanent conduc tor's success on the uphold ing of an orchestra's form and tradition.

title: GIRL, 17, MAY REGAIN USE OF SEVERED ARM
description: Surgeons at the Hospital Center at Elmhtirst, Queens, said yesterday that they were cautiously optimistic that a 17yearold girl would regain the use of an arm that was severed Wednesday and sewn back on in a sevenhour opera tion that night.

title: STEEL UNION CITES SUPPORT FOR PACT
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 14 (UPI)  The United Steelworkers of America said today that most of its 400,000 members in the steel industry were very strongly in favor of the his toric no  strike agreement reached with major producers regardless of reports of rank andfile discontent.

title: City Ends Its Saturday Marriage Rites
description: The city's civil marriage ceremony is no longer per formed on Saturdays in the small chapel in the Municipal Building.

title: Newspaper Guild Strike Halts Providence Bulletin
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 14 (AP)A strike by members of the Providence Newspaper Guild halted publication today of The Evening Bulletin, one of two newspapers published by the Providence Journal Co.

title: ALBERT N. VINKE
description: Albert N. Vinke, who had spent some four decades in the steamship industry in this port, died Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack, on his return by plane from a vacation in Bermuda. He was in his 70's and lived at 38 Searing Street, Hempstead, L. I.

title: PRESIDENT SILENT ON PLAN ON TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14  President Nixon and Archibald Cox, the Justice Department's special prosecutor, made no visible progress today toward the proposed outofcourt com promise of their dispute over the Watergate tape recordings.

title: Arabs Cite Cairo Talks
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 14 Jordanian and other Arab diplo mats here charged today that Israel provoked a major air battle with Syria yesterday in an attempt to discourage the restoration of a unified Arab military front made up of Syria, Jordan and Egypt.

title: AIDE DENIES BIAS IN SCHOOL DISPUTE
description: MORRIS TOWNSHIP, Sept. 14The School Superintendent of Harding Township denied today that the township wanted to withdraw its pupils from Morristown High School be cause of racial reasons.

title: Irwin Shoots 66 and Leads by 3
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S. C., Sept. 14 (AP)Hale Irwin, playing in intermittent showers, shot a fiveunder par 66 and established a threestroke lead today in the second round of the $150,000 Heritage golf tour nament. His tworound total is 135. Grier Jones was sec ond at 138.

title: CUMMINS ENGINE SETS ACQUISITION
description: The Cummins Engine Com pany plans to expand its in terests in England through a proposed acquisition of the Holset Engineering Company, Ltd., for $27million in cash, it was announced yesterday by the Columbus, Ind., manufactur er of diesel engines for trucks and other applications. Holset, a producer of tur bochargers, vibra tion dampers vis cous fan drives and flexible couples for the diesel and auto motive industry, is based at Huddersfield. Sales for this year are projected at more than $25 million, Henry B. Schact, presi dent of Cummins, said in the announcement.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:

title: MORE BANKS RAISE PRIME RATE TO 10%
description: The First National City Bank and several other big banks raised their prime rate yester day to 10 per cent from 9 per cent, following the Wells Fargo Bank's move announced last Thursday afternoon.

title: Tregaskis Had Heart Attack
description: HONOLULU, Sept. 14 (UPI)  The death of Richard Tre gaskis has been listed officially as caused by a heart attack. The author was found dead in waters off Ala Moana Park here Aug. 15. The results of an autopsy were released Wednesday. Mr. Tregaskis was best known for his World War II book, Guadalcanal Diary.

title: PERJURY CHARGED IN RACING INQUIRY
description: The parade of harness driv ers before a Federal grand jury started yesterday and when their first few hours of testi mony ended, a minor figure in the sport was charged with perjury.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: H.I.P. Wins 22.1% Rate Rise

title: GELLER WINS A GAME IN CHESS TOURNEY
description: PORTOROZ, Yugoslavia, Sept. 14, (Reuters)  Grandmaster Efin Geller of the Soviet Union mastered a brilliant victory over Lev Polugayevski, a compatriot, at the beginning of the second half of the threeman tourna ment here last night and sud denly improved his chances in the run for the vital first two places.

title: French Lift Ban in Nuclear Zone, Signaling End of Current Tests
description: PARIS, Sept. 14 (Reuters) The French gave notice today that they had ended the 1973 nuclear test series in the South Pacific that had raised a storm of protest around the world. A decree lifted, a ban on shipping in the nuclear testing zone around the atoll of Mururoa.

title: E.P.A. CONSIDERS BAN ON ENDRIN PESTICIDE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) The Government is consider ing a ban on endrin, a common ly used pesticide in the same family as DDT, an Environ mental Protection Agency offi cial confirmed today.

title: VERONICA M. FLYNN
description: Veronica M. Flynn, who retired from the public school system in 1971 after 43 years of service, died yesterday at St. Barnabas Hospital. She was 69 years old and lived at 510 East 23d Street.

title: No. 3 Man in China, Youngest in the Top Echelon, Has Had a Meteoric Rise
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 14  When President Pompidou !called this week at Chairman Mao Tsetung's secluded resi derice in Peking's Forbidden City, he was greeted at the door by a solidly built, young ish man whose presence at the threshold of ultimate power in China seemed a carefully cal culated piece of political sym bolism.

title: CHILE JUNTA CITES THREAT BY ALIENS
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 14 Chile's new military junta said today that the armed forces overthrew the Marxist Govern ment of Dr. Salvador Allende Gossens because more than 10,000 extremists from other countries had entered Chile.

title: A.M.C. Recalls Taxicabs
description: DETROIT, Sept. 14 (UPI) The American Motors Corpora tion announced today a recall of 995 Matador and Ambassa dor taxicabs and other heavy duty service vehicles to replace a potentially defective steering part.

title: Coffee Exchange Seeking Protection in Weis Case
description: The New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, Inc., and its clearing association announced yesterday, that it had taken court action to protect the cof fee and sugar futures traders of Weis Securities, Inc., a bro kerage house now in liquida tion. The action was taken by intervening in the bankruptcy hearings now underway here.

title: Life In a Great Capital
description: Reports that the President had been wiretapping his brother seemed in bad taste, coming as they did so soon after the President's plea to leave this. Sort of thing to the courts where he could withhold the evidence.

title: FRANKLIN C. PALM
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 14 (UPI)Franklin C. Palm, his torian and educator at the Uni versity of California, died Wednesday at the age of 83.

title: 4 Watergate Burglars Ask To Shift Plea to Not Guilty
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14Four of the original seven Watergate defendants contended before a Federal judge today that they had been deceived into pleading guilty, and asked to change their pleas to not guilty. asked to change their pleas to not guilty.

title: NEW DRUG LAWS USED IN 2 CASES
