description: By Betsy Haynes. 139 pp. New York: Thomas Nelson. $4.95. (Ages 11 to 15)

title: Firewood Demand Rising, and So Is Price
description: CHATHAMThe price of firewood is on the rise, as many New Jersey home owners apparently plan to use their fireplaces to help lower the cost of centrally heating their residences.

title: REPORT ON MEN'S WEAR
description: The prices are, not unexpectedly, higher; the pleasant surprise is that the clothes are nicely lowkeyed. The showoff fashions have, for the most part, been shelved and the look this fall is more agreeable than aggressive. The most conspicuous colors, in everything from suits and jackets to sweaters and sportswear, will be camel and bottle green  freshlooking and sophisticated and anything but boisterous. Fabrics, too, are gentle as well as gentlemanly: revivified flannels, updated with chalky stripes and plaids; soft and comfortable shetlands; colorfully dotted Donegal tweeds, often in blends which render them considerably less coarse than those from the past. (Because of the soaring cost of wool, tailored clothing, in fact, is being increasingly blended.) Even the stillimportant checks and plaids, no matter how im pressively sized, have a relaxed elegance. Witness, at left, the blockplaided jacket with a stitchedlook overpane. By Larry Kane for Raffles Wear, it sports two buttons, center vent and is blended of wool and polyester. Ws $135 at B. Altman & Co. Under it, a longsleeved, Vnecked pullover provides the vested look slated to be very much in evi dence this winter. Some others: waistlength warmups, called baseball jackets last spring and now, in heftier fabrics, hailed as football jackets; mackinawplaided snow coats; sausagequilted ski wear; bulkyknit shawlcollared cardigans (many in what has now been dubbed winter while); and enough bow ties to enable any man to be a Bow Blummell. The report continues.

title: Clamming Up at the Beach
description: CUTCHOGUE, L. I.  For most people, the Labor Day weekend marked the end of summer activities. Many were eating the leftovers in their refrigerators before leaving their summer homes until next year. Crafts shops had reduced their prices by 50 per cent.

title: Suburban Schools Problems Pile Up
description: Some lastminute hard bargaining between teachers and local school boards, spurred by a few well aimed court orders, got most of the metropolitan area's public schools open on schedule this month. But rising costs and inflation, plus stag nant tax bases and some shifts in public attitudes toward education, promise to make suburbanschool operations more complex and con tentious than in the past.

title: B. D. Parker Jr., Miss Toni Trent Wed in Suburb
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Sept. 15Miss Toni Trent, a member of the staff of the PhelpsStokes Fund in New York, and Barrington Daniels Parker Jr., an associate in the New York law firm of Sulli van & Cromwell, were mar ried here this afternoon in St. Catherine African Method ist Episcopal Church.

title: CHRYSLER IMAGE DETROIT PARADOX
description: DETROIT, Sept. 15If corpo rations were families of people, then the Big Three auto com panies could be viewed as hav ing only cars in common. Their corporate personalities are as different as those in All in the Family are from those in The Forsyte Saga.

title: DENVER APPROVES TRANSIT PROPOSAL
description: DENVER, Sept 15Voters in the metropolitan area have de cided to embark on a $1.56 billion venture in public trans portation that depends heavily on an unproved personal model of urban travel.

title: Old Role for Women in China Resisting Change
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 15  When a young Hong Kong bus inessman from a family in Chiu Chow decided to marry re cently, his, family insisted that his bride should come from their ancestral home in the Swatow area of China's Kwang tung Province. Although Peking officially discourages such old customs as arranged marriages, a relative living in China had no difficulty in finding a bride, and the Chinese authorities pro vided a permit for her to go to Hong Kong.

title: A Year After Charges, Morris Jail Conditions Are Improved
description: MORRISTOWN  It is by no means perfect. Some problems still exist, and some incidents still occur But in the year that has passed since a grand jury be gan investigating the Morris County Jail, jail personnel, inmates and county officials have seen significant im provements.

title: Saturday's Stepchild, Club Football, Labors for Its Disciples
description: A stone building on a beau tiful hilltop in Riverdale, the Bronx, where alcoholics once received $100aday treat ment, is now the home of one of the nation's new breed football teams  the Manhattan College club team.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., Sept. 15Dean Me minger, starting in the backcourt in place of Earl Monroe, who is recuperating from surgery, scored 24 points today as the Knick veterans defeated the rookies, 135104, at Monmouth College. Meminger played three quarters, then stubbed a toe and left the game. Harthorne Wingo had 21 points and 10 rebounds and Wilis Reed 17 points and 14 rebounds. The rookies were led by Tom Riker, who scored 24 points and grabbed 10 rebounds. Al McGuire scored 15 points and had six assists.

title: Shortening the Rations
description: WASHINGTONFor thousands of ghetto children, the lunches they eat at school are their only hot, nutritious meals of the day. Now many may lose them. A Senate study made public last week said high food prices are jeopardizing the Federally financed school lunch program, and estimated that 800,000 chil drenin urban and suburban schools alikewill be dropped from the program. Again, the question was raised: How can children learn with empty stomachs? At least 13 schools in New York State have already stopped serving the lunches, and more are expected to do so. Figures for New Jersey and Con necticut were unavailable, but officials said many districts were expected to cut back. In the three states, the cost of a school lunch has risen from 10 to 15 cents in recent months.

title: Fumbles Sink Coast Guard
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept, 15 (AP)Mike Mahoney, a de Pensive tackle, recovered two fumbles deep in Coast Guard territory to set up scores that gave Southern Connecti cut a 90 victory today. It was the season, opener for both teams.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: Best Seller List
description: This cobased uities of th United Stateess. The fithaner the right. hand column do not necessarily represent consecutive appearances.

title: Friday Bad For Driving In the State
description: ALBANY, Sept. 15  Most motor vehicle acidents in the state take place on Fri days, especially between 4 and 5 P.M. But the worst time for fatal accidents is in the early hours of a Sun day morning. The safest day to drive is Tuesday, especial ly between 5 and 6 A.M.

title: Paterson Loses to Ithaca
description: Garry Bucci and GaryGiroux ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 15 (AP) each returned pass intercep tions for touchdowns today as Ithaca scored a 48.2 col lege football triumph over William Paterson.

title: State Office Plan Stirs Concern
description: TRENTONA proposal that the state buy or construct, rather than lease, office space has stirred concern among some urban officials. They foresee a possible loss of tax ratables if the plan is adopted.

title: Bridge
description: At the start of an evening of rubber bridge you break open two decks of shiny new cards and discard the jokers. Chances are, there will re main at least one joker at the tablethe player who puts his faith in offbeat bidding and play.

title: Gianelli Is Putting More Weight Into Knicks' Lineup
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 15  When the Knicks open their preseason schedule Saturday night against the Phoenix Suns at Madison Square Garden, the only recognizable feature about John Gianelli will be his number. It's 40.

title: Son to. Mrs. Solomon
description: BEDFORD HILLS, N. Y., Sept. 15A son was born Sept. 5 to Mr. and Mrs. Burt Solomon in the Klingenstein Pavilion of Mount Sinai Hos pital in New York. Mrs. Solo mon is the former Miss Susan Crane. Her husband is pub licity manager for the Para mount Pictures Corporation. The child has been named Robert James.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I read with interest the Aug. 26 article on Good year's woes as to what to do about its aging. Akron blimp hangar.

title: REV. WILFRED HURLEY
description: OLD TOWN, Me., Sept. 15  The Rev. Wilfred G. Hurley, a Paulist priest and author of more than a score of books on religion, died here Sept. 1. He was 77 years old.

title: Welfare Apartments Fought
description: The largest tenants' coun cil in Brooklyn has charged that the city has been refer ring large numbers of wel fare clients to poorly main tained Flatbush apartments.

title: AROUND THE
description: This is the time of year when nature begins winding down. A time of relaxation, a time to finish summer grow ing and put the polish on fruits and flowers.

title: The Crystal Nights
description: The loud shattering of glass win dows, as thousands of Jewishowned storefronts are smashed on the in famous Crystal Night in prewar Nazi Germany, seems little more than a distant tinkle by the time it riches the ears of 15yearold Elly Josephs. Elly, who lives on a farm in Con necticut with her devout Russian Orthodox Mama, her grandmother Baba, her beloved Pop and older brother Phil, is much less concerned with these faroff events than with her own daydreams of be coming an actress, her worries about being too fat and her dearest project  getting her parents to move off their farm.

title: Great Year Is Predicted For 1973 Beaujolais
description: PARIS, Sept 15 (Reuters) The 1973 Beaujolais vint age may become the finest of this century, French wine experts predicted today after tasting the first samples.

title: THE VEST: BACK IN FRONT
description: Veats, some thing of a fashion underdog in recent years, are now back at the top. The threepiece look, whether it be matchingg, contrasting or merely a har monizing pullover, is very much alive.

title: Price Rises
description: It was hard to find anyone last week who was happy about prices or the economy. The steelmakers were unhappy that they got price increases they asked for in two stages, rather than one; the automakers got only part of what they were seeking; Repre sentative Bertram Podell, the Brook lyn Democrat, complained about the high cost of bagels (on top of an astronomical cost of lox), and the prices of boys' fall clothing were up about 5 per cent.

title: The Chilean Tragedy
description: Two theories were bound to surface in the aftermath of the military takeover in Chile and the suspicionladen death of President Allende. One was that the United States was responsible for the coup; the other was that the tragic fall of Dr. Allende proves it is impossible any where to build a socialist system by democratic means and machinery. To accept either theory is to overlook the principal cause of Chile's disaster and its meaning for the future.

title: There is no such thing as a typical bill
description: As he tries to disencumber himself of the Watergate crimes and con spiracies, President Nixon repeatedly cries out The time has come for the rest of us to get on with the urgent business of our nation. One of the several merits of this enter taining book is that it provides re vealing insights, into how Mr. Nixon, gets on with the nation's business when he is molt engulfed by scandal. One can only conclude that the busi nessmen who support Mr. Nixon po litically would never choose him to be general manager of any of their enterprises.

title: Swedes Vote Today, With Jobs an Issue
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 15 In three months, Jan Sjogren, a 29yearold construction en gineer; has applied for 40 jobs. He remains unemployed, dis appointed and a small symbol Of the discontent and concern that has put in jeopardy the continued rule of the Social Democrats, in power here for 41 years.

title: Students Advised by Students
description: One of the subjects was loneliness at Archbishop Mol loy High School last week end.

title: CASE DISMISSED FOR AGNEW DONOR
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 15Fed eral criminal charges against the supermarket executive who has provided Vice President Agnew with gifts of food were dropped here earlier this year under circumstances that an other accused food chain exec utive calls discriminatory.

title: Denise Hanrahan Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. James F. Hanrahan of Kings Park, L.I., have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Denise Eileen Hanrahan, to Frank Ciafone, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frank Ciafone of Hunt ington, L. I. His father is dentist.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: BaldwinExhibition of works by Mar guerite A. Snider, through Sept., Mondays to Fridays, 9 A.M. to P.M. and Saturdays, 9 A.M. to P.M., public library, 2385 Grand Avenue.

title: The Americanization of the Met, and Two Who Further
description: THE 197374 season may or may not go down in history as the one that marked the Americani zation of the Metropolitan Opera, but it will certainly stand as one in which Amer ican singers got more atten tion there than they had had previously. During the com ing months, a dozen of them are going to be marching in to work in the august estab lishment, and a goodly num ber will be taking over a variety of major roles.

title: Marcia Clare Is Wed Upstate
description: TANNERSVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 15Miss Marcia Helen Clare, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. N. Holmes Clare of New York and the Onteora Club, here, was married this after noon to Henry Buckland Sawyer 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sawyer Jr. of Wellesley, Mass.

title: What's So Super About This Superdirector?
description: TEN years ago the idea of building a promotion campaign for a movie around the personality of the direc tor would have been virtually un thinkable. Since then the auteur theory, and the media's restless search for new celebrities, have turned the director into a superstar. The publicity for two recent moviesDillinger and Electra Glide in Bluehas focused almost exclu sively on their young directors.

title: Biggest publicworks project since the pyramids
description: Gonna be one sumbitchin' airport. An electrician working on the Dallas/ Fort Worth Regional Airport.

title: 20 Dead in Brazilian Crash
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 15 (UPI)At least 20 people were killed last night in a flaming collision involving three cars and a bus on a highway about 10 miles north of Rio de Ja neiro, the police said. Initial reports said that the bus went off the highway and plum meted into a river.

title: ACCENT MARKS
description: Piping hot fashion note: contrasting trim on suits and sport coats.

title: Miss Goolagong Reaches Charlotte Tennis Final
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Sept. 15Evonne Goolagong of Australia and Eugenia Bir yukova of the Soviet Union advanced to the final of the $40,000 women's tennis tour nament today with straight set victories.

title: Rochester Tech Picks
description: ROCHESTER, Sept, 15 (AP) A defensive back, Rick Knaack of Albany, and a tight end, Joe Moffet of Ber nardsville, N.J., have been chosen cocaptains of the Rochester Tech football team.

title: Longer Terms in Drug Cases Unlikely
description: TRENTON  The chances are dim that, despite demands to the contrary, the post election session of the Legis lature will approve measures calling for stiffer prison terms for those convicted of narcotics offenses.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
Calendar of Horse Shows
description: TODAY

title: New &Novel
description: Last Night At the Brain Thieves Ball

title: Winn Kadick to Be Bride of Winthrop Redmond
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 The engagement of Miss Elizabeth Winn Kadick to Winthrop William Redmond has been announced by Col. and Mrs. Misha Nicholas Kadick, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Woodward Redmond of Washington and a grandson of Winthrop W. Aldrich, former president and board chairman of the Chase National Bank in New York and Ambassador to the Court of St. James's under President Eisenhower.

title: PUBLIC LAW FIRMS SEEK I.R.S. RULING
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 15 Five public interest law firms have petitions pending before the Internal Revenue Service in Washington on whether they can accept courtawarded, fees and still maintain their tax exempt status.

title: PORTISCH, GELLER DRAW CHESS GAME
description: PORTOROZ, Yugoslavia, Sept. 15 (AP)  Lajas Portisch of Hungary and Efim Geller of the Soviet Union drew their game today in the eighth round of the Three Grandmasters Chess Tournament.

title: Heavy, Traffic and American GraffitiTwo of the Best
description: RALPH BAKSHI'S most ly animated feature, Heavy Traffic, is American graffiti of a very high and unusual order, a tale of a young New York City pilgrim named Michael, halfItalian, halfJewish, ever innocent, and his progress through a metaphor that is nowhere near as dreary as it sounds: the pinball machine called Life. It is a liberating, arrogant sort of movie, crude, tough, vulgar, full of insult and wit and an aware ness of the impermanence of all things.

title: The Genesis of Pollution
description: LONDON  For about two hundred years the advance of the Industrial Revolution has been accelerating. At the same time, it has been increasing in potency. In the nineteenth century, its triumphs were applauded by its beneficiaries  though not by its more numerous victims. Within the last quarter of a century, however, every one, including the beneficiaries, has rather suddenly become aware of large and sinister entries on the debit side of the account.

title: The New Play
description: THE DESERT SONG, the re vival of the Sigmund Rom berg operetta with book and lyrics by Otto Haibach, Oscar Hammerstein 2d and Frank Mandel, got three favorable reviews (Emory Lewis, Bergen Record; Wil liam Glover, AP; Jack Gaver, UPI), five mixed (Richard Watts, Post; Wil liam Raidy, Newhouse Newspapers; Leonard Har ris, CBSTV; Kevin Sanders, ABCTV; Lawrence Wun derlich, Cue) and nine negative reviews (Mel Gus sow, Times; Douglas Watt, News; Martin Gottfried, Women's Wear, Allan Wal lach, Newsday; Stewart Klein, WNEWTV; Leonard Probst, NBC Radio; John Simon, New York; Jack Kroll, Newsweek; Michael Feingold, Village Voice).

title: College Gets New Planetarium
description: RANDOLPH TOWNSHIP There will be more than a fourstar attraction here next month, when the County Col lege of Morris opens its new planetarium as an addition to its Academic/Science Build ing.

title: Indian Charity Drive Ends
description: TIFF CITY, Mo., Sept. 15 (AP)Rising food costs and the sponsor's advancing years have rung the curtain on Box 14A, Tiff City, a charity that has supplied food at Christmas for Indian families in north eastern Oklahoma and south western Missouri for 20 years.

title: MoneyOrder Curb Asked
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) A bill requiring licensing of companies that deal in money orders has been introduced by Senator Bill Brock, Republican of Tennessee, The legislation I am proposing would insure the protection of the users of money orders from flybynight operators, i nsufficiently capi talized companies and outright fraud, he said Thursday.

title: BABY JOINS MOTHER IN AN UPSTATE JAIL
description: OSWEGO, N.Y., Sept. 15 (UPI)  A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that Mrs. Katherine Apgar, 21 years old, may keep her 2 mouthold baby girl with her while she waits in jail for her murder trial to begin.

title: College Names Trustees
description: LANCASTER, Pa., Sept. 15 (AP)Franklin and Marshall College announced this week the election of six new trus tees to fiveyear terms. They are: J. Robert Fisher, New York; Sigmund Hyman, Bal, timore; Dr. Aaron Martin, Ox ford, Pa.; Mrs. John L. Polcyn, Lancaster; Thomas S. Quinn Jr., Cornwall, Pa., and. Arthur J. ??hadek, Alpine, N. J.

title: DROP IN JOB FORCE IS ANALYZED HERE
description: The labor force in the city has been shrinking, and econ omists of the First National City Bank has suggested the reason may be at least in part the existence of attractive al ternatives to working.

title: For Wine, whistles or Muffins
description: SWEET ELDER or elder berry (Sambucus cana densis) a native species of northeastern United States, ranks high among berrybearing bushes or small trees. It is a handsome shrub, to 10 feet high and luxuri antly tropical in foliage. Its panoply of bloom  a broad, flat creamywhite flower cluster marks the beginning of summer; the ripe inky colored fruits, hanging in beaded umbels, mark the be ginning of summer's end.

title: News Summary and Index SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 16, 1973
description: Senate liberals, accusing the Ninon Admin istration of covering up the full extent of United States aid to South Vietnam's police force and prison system, are planning a major floor fight to delete all, police sup port froth the pending foreign aid bill. The legislation, which now, provides for $376 million in economic aid for Southeast Asia about half of the funds sought by the Ad ministrationis scheduled for a Senate vote next week. Many Senators reportedly ex pressed willingness to delete police and prison support from the bill. At issue is growing public, evidence that political op ponents of the Government of President Nguyen Van Thieu are still being jailed and tortured. [Page 1, Column. 8.].

title: An Alleged Commuting Bandit Is Seized After 3 Bank Holdups
description: A man known to the police as the commuting bandit be cause he was said to have flown to New York from Miami only for the purpose of robbing banks was arrested Friday as he was allegedly preparing to commit his fourth bank robbery in less than a month.

title: New Canaan, Greenwich, Westhill Win
description: New Canaan, which usual ly passes the opposition dizzy in the Fairfield County (Conn.) Interscholastic Ath letic Conference, surprised Ripawam with a furious ground attack yesterday en route to a 270 victory at Stamford's Boyle Stadium.

title: Mongolian Paper Says China's Troops Trespass
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 15 (AP)  Mongolia has charged that Chi nese troops repeatedly trespass on its territory to carry out photo reconnnaissance and kill cattle.

title: Klecatsky Defeats Dietz in Sculling
description: Dr. Larry Klecatsky of the New York A.C. was just 2.5 seconds off the course record yesterday as he defeated his teammate, Jim Dietz, by three lengths in the 73d an nual Metropolitan rowing regatta. Klecatsky's time was 7 minutes 18.1 seconds for the 2,000meter singles event.

title: SOFT SIDE OF LEATHER
description: Soft suede: rugged rival and gentle side kick of leather.

title: Who Says women Never Win?
description: RECENTLY I watched a television program on which some ladies from the National Organiza tion of Women (NOW) were complaining about the terrible Way their sisters are being portrayed in television commercials. These ladies were not at all happy about commercials that show women doing things like washing dishes, changing babies and cooking dinner. They were especially unhappy with commercials that show a woman doing things for a man, like washing his clothes, serving his break fast, making his bed, etc. Their point was that commercials in which women are shown working at domestic chores tend to perpetuate the masterservant relationship between men and women.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: WASHINGTON  When Emerson Schmidt became the United States Chamber of Commerce's first econo mist nearly 30 years ago, only eight economists were employed by all of the cor porations in the country, and they spent their time poring over the dreary figures that then constituted the sum and substance of the gloomy science of economics.

title: The Bounty
description: This is a time of ripeness, of maturing fruit and seed and nut. We think of it as a time of harvest, when the farmer and the gardener have gathered their year's produce and can tally up the summer's accounts. The barn, the granary, the bin and the silo will soon be full, and the root cellar, the cold pantry and the freezer. We speak of it as the autumn bounty.

title: CAPPING IT OFF
description: Heading for the peak of renewed popu larity: the dashing cap.

title: Television
description: ONE of the more significant con frontations currently taking place in the television arena involves the case of Accuracy in Media, Inc., a nonprofit, selfappointed watth dog of the electronic and print press, versus the National Broadcasting Com pany. At issue is the content, or over all thrust, of an hourlong documentary entitled Pensions: The Broken Promise, presented on the network a year ago last Wednesday.

title: DAVID RAUCH
description: MIAMI BEACH, Sept 15  David Rauch, vice president of the Van Brode Milling Com pany in Clinton, Mass., until his retirement this month, died today in Golden Isles Hospital

title: Laos Agreement
description: VIENTIANEIt had often been said that if Laos were left alone, the tiny nation would find peace by itself. The parties to its 20year civil war, the argument went, were more proxies for the North Vietnamese and the French (and then the Americans) than genuine enemies in their own right.

title: Headliners
description: It was called the biggest air battle between Israel and Syria since the sixday war in 1967 and, as usual, there were two conflicting versions. The Israeli version went like this: Syria, in an attempt to score a propaganda victory for the Arab cause, last Thursday sent 16 fighters to attack a fourplane Israeli patrol taking a routine look at what's going on in the Mediterranean off the Syrian coast the ensuing dogfight, which Israel considered an isolated incident, 13 Syrian MIG21's and one Israeli Mirage were shot down. The Syrian version went like this: Sixtyfour Israeli planes pounced on a far smaller number of Syrian planes in Syrian air space, with the resultant loss of eight MIG's and five Israeli planes. Arab officials contended that Israel had provoked the battle in an effort to discourage restoration of a unified Arab military front made up of Syria, Jordan and Egyptthe subject of toplevel talks in Cairo last week.

title: ENERGY AIDE MAPS AN ECONOMY DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15A householder who turns down his thermostat by 3 degrees can have up to 9 per cent on his homeheating bill this winter, according to John H. Gibbons, who has just been appointed as the Government's first Director of Energy Conservation.

title: OPENSPACE LAW CALLED FAILURE
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Sept. 15 Connecticut's openspace law has proved an ineffective and expensive way to keep open land from being developed, the Connecticut Citizen Action Group has charged in a study.

title: U. of Chicago Science Hall Damaged by Explosions
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (UPI) A series of explosions ripped through a chemical storage room in historic Jones Hall on the University of Chicago campus today.

title: West German Soccer
description: Bayun Munich 2, Werder Bremen 2.

title: PRIVATE PENSIONS TO BE SCRUTINIZED
description: Two state legislators from Brooklyn representing a Demo cratic task force on pension legislation have scheduled a public hearing in Manhattan on Thursday concerning legislative action to safeguard the pension rights of workers in private business.

title: Nixon and Congress
description: WASHINGTONLast week's chap ter in the struggle between the Nixon White House and the Congress was in many ways like a comic opera: There was a great deal of posturing that failed to obscure reality. Beneath all the sham and show there emerged a picture of a weakened President ad n]onishing the legislative branch on priorities and policies almost as if he were still enjoying a position of strength, and a Congress strong enough to defy the President in number of areas but uncertainly led and lacking any strong sense of di rection or confidence on where it is going.

title: A.K.C. Official Opens the Door a. Trifle for Women
description: After 89 years, women fi nally may achieve equality with men at the American Kennel Club.

title: ON DONEGAL GROUND
description: donegal tweed, that hefty wool (or woolblended) fabric dotted with colorful nubs, returns to brighten  and warm the cold days ahead.

title: Batsto Village Becomes A Haven for Craftsmen
description: BATSTO  When visitors walked into the Blacksmith Shop at historic Batsto Vil lags recently, they saw more than just a lifeless reproduc tion of what life was like 150 years ago.

title: ABPLANALP LOAN RETAINED BY G.O.P.
description: Robert H. Abplanalp, one of President Nixon's closest friends, has been trying for nearly a year to get the Com mittee for the Reelection of the President to reimburse him for a $25,000 loan.

title: Chess: In Sight of the Vino, Pfleger Finds the Veritas Is Painful
description: An international tourna ment in a wine cellar? That would appear outlandish in any other setting but Spain, which is currently undergo ing a remarkable chess boom. What began as a vast train ing and recruiting program for school children has caught the interest of the vintners Montulia and Alvear, who staged their Torneo del Vino in Montilla in August.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: I've seen my share of stacked decks, as we all have, but few will ever compare to J. H. Plumb's onesided view of London (An Englishman's love letter to New York, Sept. 2).

title: SUPPORTER OF NIXON UNDAUNTED BY HOAX
description: URBANA, Ill., Sept. 15 (AP) An Urbana businessman, Dwight Dobbs, says while the call he purportedly received from the White House was probably a hoax, it has not changed his feelings about the President.

title: New Magazine Says Right Things About Women
description: In the male  dominated World of sports, most articles on women athletes are writ ten in a geewhizwouldya believeit tone. Except superstars like Billie Jean King, Olga Korbut, Kathy Whitworth and Robyn Smith, few words, Marlene Jensen says, are wasted on women. Such lack of coverage, stereotyping bias and stereotyping of women athletes as curiosities and unfeminine muscle  bound Amazons, prompted Mrs. Jensen to start The Sports woman, a magazine devoted to women in sports. Original ly planned as a quarterly, the first issue, published March, drew such a favor able response that it will now appear six times a year.

title: Scout Leaders Sought
description: The Girl Scouts of the U.S.A. are recruiting men and women to serve as troop leaders and assistant leaders. People interested in becom ing leaders should write for a free booklet, Girl Scout. Leaders, which provides de tails. The address is: Jane Underwood, Girl Scouts of the U.S.A., 830 Third Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10022.

title: Madeleine Cresap Bride Of Philip K. Bartow Jr.
description: WAYNE, Pa., Sept. 15  Mrs. Madeleine Reed Cresap and Philip Key Bartow Jr. were married here this after noon in the chapel of Old St. David's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Richard Hess per formed the ceremony, as sisted by the Rev. Frederick Hill.

title: Galbraith's General Theory of Reform
description: In The Afflu ent Society (1958) John Ken neth Galbraith's dominant theme was that produc tion for private affluence brought public squalor. His The New Industrial State (1967) explained why our sys tem produced such an overabundance of dog food and male deodorants and such a shortage of decent housing, medical care and breathable air. Galbraith's answer, as he rephrases it in his latest book, Economics and the ,Public Purpose, was that the growth of power in both public and private bureaucracies was now the decisive force in economic and politi cal life. The technostructure, i.e., the lawyers, accountants, advertising men, engineers, and salesmen who manage the great corporations, ran those organizations neither in obe dience to the market nor in response

title: City Politicians Defer to Beame As MayorElect, Not Candidate
description: Continued From First Page of Second Section ing to him as the next Mayor of New York.

title: Holy Cross Wins
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 15 (AP)  John Provost re turned a punt 58 yards for a touchdown, blocked another punt that set up a touchdown and intercepted a pass that led to a field goal today as Holy Cross defeated North eastern, 3814.

title: The United Nations Opens
description: The scene, as always, will be im pressive when the United Nations General Assembly convenes this Tues day afternoon for its 28th regular session. That great domed hall aswirl with delegates from all over the world, men and women, black and white, brown and yellow, some, main ly Africans and Asians, in their color ful national dress. For a moment every year it appears that this is in deed the Parliament of Man, that after the solemn, always moving mo ment of silent prayer, or meditation, these men and women will turn their individual and national energies to the urgent catalogue of man's needs.

title: DASH FOR. RAIN
description: Seven water proofs that know enough to go out into the rain.

title: Reginald Murphy 3d Weds kathleen A. McKinnell
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., Sept. 15  Miss Kath leen Ayres McKinnell, daugh ter of Mrs. Wayne E. Wetzel of Rockville, Md., and the late William H. McKinnell; was married here this after noon to Reginald Lambert Murphey 3d.

title: I'm Not Scared Any More
description: LEONTYNE PRICE still smarts from the beating she took battling her way to reach the twinpeaked summit where she was crowned both prima donna assoluta and opera's first black international super star. The scars she carries are invisible to the eye. But they become instantly evident as the voluptuous and voluble diva explosively relives the stormier portions her life, those dulcet, mellifluous tones of hers taking on a shrill, shrewish quality. This is the Price of today talk ing, not the careful and polite, often cardboard figure of the past.

title: POLICE AIDE HERE GETS MIDWEST JOB
description: A 38yearold deputy inspec tor in the city's Police Depart ment, believed to be the only policeman in the country to hold a doctoral degree from Harvard University, has been chosen to become Chief of Police in Kansas City, Mo.

title: Miss Whitworth Leads With a 70
description: LEAWOOD, Kan., Sept. 15 (UPI)Kathy Whitworth, the defender, took the lead in the second round of the $25,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association Southgate open today with a two underpar 70 as Mrs. Gerda Boykin suffered a double bogey on the 18th hole.

title: The Fuel Supply
description: With the metropolitan area's hot weather energy crises so fresh in memory, it is perhaps not the time for speculations about the severity of the upcoming winter or about the measures people will have to take to keep themselves warm. Perhaps not, but there are quite a few people doing just that, and with some alarm, be cause there is a general consensus that there will be a critical fuel short age in the colder months ahead.

title: Music
description: NOT long ago I heard an old recording of Mahler's Fourth Symphony conducted by Willem Mengelberg. Two things to keep in mind: Mengelberg was considered one of the supreme conductors of his time; and he was held in the greatest respect by Mahler himself, who seldom had a good word to say about any conductor. O.K. Mengelberg starts the Mahler Fourth simply and briskly enough; but at the third measure, where Mahler has marked un poco ritard, and grazi oso, Mengelberg takes a very leviathan of a ritard. Grazioso? By modern taste it sounds elephantine.

title: Legion Conventioneers Again Earn a Salute From Wildwood
description: WILDWOODThey carne back here again for the 25th time, and somehow it seemed more like traditional Fourth of July celebration or family reunion than any thing else.

title: Chrysler Talks With Apologies, An Auto Strike
description: DETROITIt began as a strange sort of strike, almost as if the parties were apologizing to each other and to the public. Speaking in moderate tones, with no trace of bitterness or defiance, chief spokesmen for the United Auto Workers and the Chrysler Corporation announced late Friday night that strike against Chrysler would begin at midnight.

title: Should I Do It Myself? Well Now, It Depends...
description: Asking how much it will cost to main tain a house is like asking how much will cost to drive to work. There are many variables in either case. Driving costs will depend upon such things as the type and age of the car, the distance driven and whether toll roads and bridges are used.

title: PARITY STRUCTURE IS TARGET OF P.B.A.
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, representing nearly 30,000 police officers in the city, has decided to exert a major effort in contract nego tiations with the city to break the current parity structure.

title: King Gustaf of Sweden Is Dead; Heir Becomes Carl XVI Gustaf
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 15  King Gustaf VI Adolf of Swe den died at 8:35 P.M. (3:35, New York time) today in the hospital in Halsingborg. He was 90 years old and had reigned for nearly 23 years.

title: The Babe was always a boy
description: Grantland Rice, the prince of sportswriters, used to do a weekly radio interview with some sporting figure. Frequently, in the interest of spon taneity, he would type out questions and answers in advance. One night his guest was Babe Ruth.

title: Georgia Tech Upset By South Carolina
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Sept. 15 (AP)  Jeff Grantz, a sopho more quarterback, ran and passed for four touchdowns and Mel Baxley returned, an intercepted pass 100 yards for a score to lead underdog South Carolina to a 4128 victory over Georgia Tech tonight.

title: Daniel Borge Jr. Weds Lucy Van Itallie
description: FENWICK, Conn., Sept. 15 Miss Lucy Maria Van Itallie and Paul Daniel Borge Jr., students at the University of Washington's Graduate School of Business, were married here this afternoon in the Fenwick Chapel of St. Mary's bytheSea by the Rev. Calvin Gengras, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: TWO CHARGES FILED: TRAFFIC AND MURDER
description: Two police officers gave a 39yearold man a summons for driving through a red light in Brooklyn early yesterday, then 20 minutes later arrested him in a tavern on a murder charge, the police said.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE GOVERNMENT'S COMMITTEE ON INTEREST AND DIVIDENDS ordered large banks to justify their in crease in the prime rate to a record 10 per cent. The Wells Fargo Bank led the jump from 9 per cent and was joined by the First National City Bank.... The National Association of Business Economists reported that a con sensus of 415 business economists indicated a slowdown in the economy next year, without a recession. They see Inflation receding somewhat and a slight decline in business profits.... Melvin R. Laird, the President's chief domestic adviser, said Mr. Nixon was considering asking Congress for a temporary tax increase of up to 10 per cent to fight inflation. Extra taxes would be refunded after the economy had cooled.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: Mrs. King Is Choice In Tourney
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 15 (AP) A fourtime Wimbledon singles champion, Mrs. Billie Jean King, has the favorite's role in the $30,000 women's professional tennis tourna ment which opens Monday.

title: SOVIET DENOUNCES WESTERN SUPPORT OF ITS DISSIDENTS
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 15The So viet Union today denounced Western expressions of support for a tiny bunch of intel lectuals and warned that no one is allowed to violate the principles of our democracy.

title: Dun & Bradstreet Plea Lost In Credit Report Libel Case
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 15 (AP) Credit reports do not qualify for First Amendment privileges, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled yesterday.

title: Shorter Reviews No Neutxal Ground
description: By Joel Carlson. 382 pp. Thomas Y. Crowell. $8.95.

title: Roosevelt Joins Tax Fight
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 15 (AP)James Roosevelt has been appointed to a committee that will, lead the campaign on behalf of Gov. Ronald Reagan's plan to cut taxes. Mr. Roose velt, 66 years old, a former Democratic Representative, heads a financial consulting firm in Los Angeles. The Rea gan plan to put stringent tax controls into the state Consti tution will be decided at a special election Nov. 6.

title: Passaic's Hill Area Fights New Units
description: PASSAIC  Home owners in this city's best residential area are fighting to block the construction of highrise apartment houses already ap proved by municipal officials.

title: Grambling Triumphs
description: LORMAN, Miss., Sept. 15 (AP)  Grambling pushed across touchdowns in the sec ond and third periods today in beating Alcorn A. and M., 226.

title: News Summary and Index
Calendar of Dog Show Events
description: TODAY

title: U. of Florida Gets $115,296 In First Gatorade Royalties
description: GAINESVILLE Fla., Sept. 15Every time the New York Jets or the Miami Dolphins empty a case of Gatorade, they enhance medical re search at the University of Florida.

title: OVER AND OUT
description: Overcoats: seven not to be overlooked.

title: A searcher for truth in Santa Barbara
description: To Die in California re turns to the scene of many crimes, to locations out of Louis B. Mayer and characters from Central Psychiatric Cast ing. Yet, though the flora and fauna are familiar, Newton Thornburg saves his novel from numbing predictability by oc casionally cutting a new path through the terrain.

title: Machinemade man; Tools for Conviviality By Ivan Illich. World Perspectives. Vol. 47, planned and edited by Ruth Nanda Anshen. 110 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $5.95.
description: Dangerous? Ivan Illich has been so designated several times (and in these very pages, if memory serves). Yet he is a rigorous and serious and baroquely original thinker, a mad searcher for truth, a brilliant polemicist, a strangely pragmatic visionary, a devoted teacher, even Socratic. He carries a stack of index cards in a worn leather case he wears on his belt like a holster. Semper paratus: he is a Marine on the shores of the contemporary mind. Tools for Conviviality, which follows his cantankerous Deschooling Society by some two years, is the most powerful articulation to date of the dream which obsesses him, possesses him, allows him no rest: the realization of a pure international communism which works.

title: Cornell Replaces Dartmouth as the Team to Beat for Iv League Football Title
description: For the first time in more than five years a team other than Dartmouth enters the football season favored to win the Ivy League cham pionship. Cornell is the choice of the majority of coaches in the league and by most persons who make the mistake of forecasting any thing in sports.

title: Disputed Bypass Put in State Bond Issue
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I.  Funds for the extension of Sunrise Highway from Shin necock Hills to Amagansett will be included In Novem ber's $3.5billion New York State Transportation Bond issue despite the Federal Government's delay in ap proving the 23milelong by pass.

title: 3 Catholic Laymen Starting a College For Liberal Arts
description: CONCORD, N. H. Sept. 15 (AP)  Three Roman Catholic laymen who say American uni versities have lost their intel lectual and moral vigor have announced plans to open their own college.

title: Kathleen Campbell Wed
description: Miss Kathleen Terese Campbell was married yester day morning in to William Ed ward Lees n St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. Charles Mahoney. The bride, daughter of Mrs. Patrick Campbell of the Bronx and the late Mr. Campbell, is an alumna of Hunter College. Her husband, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Lees of Plandome, L.I., is a graduate of C. W. Post Col lege.

title: The big look for fall
description: Don't worry. Daytime clothes are still casual. But they're bigger. The year's most prophetic shapes are roomier and bulkierwideshouldered coats, bubbletopped suits, nowaist dresses. And widergreat sweeping capes. And longer skirts are dropping, some to below the knee.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Talk about a delayed build up! The title of William Hag gard's latest novel is THE NOTCH ON THE KNIFE (Wal ker, $4.95), but not until the last few pages does the action have much relevance to the title. Then everyone comes on like gangbusters.

title: Guidelines for U.S. And Press Offered By Research Group
description: Freedom House, which does research about American.insti tutions, says that relations between the Federal Govern ment and the news media are deplorable and has offered guidelines for journalists and government officials.

title: The New Movies
description: THE TALL BLOND MAN WITH ONE BLACK SHOE, directed by Yves Robert from a screenplay by Fran ois Veber and Robert and starring Pierre Richard and Mireille Darc, got nine fa vorable reviews (Ann Guar ino, News; Howard Kissel, Women's Wear; Frances Taylor, Newhouse News papers; Leonard Harriso WCBSTV; Gene Shalit, NBC; Jeffrey Lyons, WPIX TV; Penelope Gilliatt, New Yorker; Chris Chase, New York; Hollis Alpert, Satur day Review/World), six mixed (Roger Greenspun, Times; Archer Winsten, Post; Martin Levine, News day; Molly Haskell, Village Voice; William Wolf, Cue; Paul D. Zimmerman, News week) and two negative; (Stanley Kauffmann, New Republic; Rex Reed, News).

title: From to JBCT
description: The writer, formerly Deputy Mayor in John Lindsay's Administration and now a publicrelations consultant, pretended he is the manager of the 1973 mayoral campaigns of Abraham Beame, John Mar chi, Albert Blumenthal and Mario Biaggi and pre pared these eyes only memos to each of them.

title: Tennessee Slips Past Duke, 2117
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 15 (AP)  Condredge Hollo way, the quarterback, brought ninthranked Tennes see from the brink of defeat tonight by diving to the Duke 1yard line on a fourthdown play, which set up the Vol unteers' gamewinning touch down. Tennessee scored with 2 minutes 5 seconds remain ing to win, 2117.

title: College Football This Week
description: Friday

title: WABAT SHORTAGE LOOMING IN INDIA
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 15 A severe wheat shortage is loom ing over India even as ex ceptionally good rains assure bumper crops throughout the country.

title: Mrs. Sarno Has Son
description: A daughter was born on Aug. 23 at the New York University Medical Center to Dr. and Mrs. John E Sarno Jr. The child has Veen named Christina Lamarque. Mrs. Sarno, known professionally as Martha Taylor Sarno, is assistant professor and her husband is professor of clin ical rehabilitation medicine at the New York University School of Medicine. Mrs. Sarno also is director of speechpathology services at the Institute of Rehabilita tion Medicine, where Dr. Sarno is director of outpa tient services.

title: News of the Stage
description: For the first time in his ca reer, Arthur Laurents, whose output includes the books for West Side Story and Gypsy, will have one of his plays mak ing its debut off Broadway.

title: NATO Reported to Decide on TroopCut Offer to Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13  Authoritative sources report that the United States and its Atlantic allies have agreed to propose to the Soviet Union and its Warsaw Pact partners that both sides initially cut their forces in Central Europe to about 700,000 men.

title: Sarah GarciaMata Wed to R. J. Ripley
description: SIASCONSET, Mass., Sept. 15Miss Sarah Anne Apple ton GarciaMata, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carlos Garcia Mata of New Canaan, Conn., and Siasconset, was married here this afternoon to Rich ard J. Ripley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack C. Ripley of Seattle.

title: Nixon's favorite coach says:
description: On a frozen afternoon in late November, 1971, President Nixon surprised his favorite pro football team, the Washington Redskins, with an unsched uled visit to their Virginia practice camp. Dwarfed by the jostling players, his bare head wreathed in clouds of steamy breath, the President asked after their bruises, recalled their college heroics and alluded sympathetically to recent losses that had dropped them out of first place. Then, he said:

title: Priest Aids Alcohaplics And Addicts In Paterson
description: PATERSON  A former policeman who became a priest runs a rehabilitation center here for drug addicts and alcoholics.

title: DRUGRAID HOUSE IS STILL A WRECK
description: MASSAPEQUA, L. I., Sept. 15  It is 15 months since Treasury Department agents swooped down on the split level ranchstyle house of John Conforti and wrecked the house and property in a vain search for $4million in profits from smuggled heroin believed to have been hidden there. The eightroom house is still unin habitable.

title: Hofstra Triumphs Over Wagner, 2413
description: Hofstra University stopped secondhalf threats with two interceptions and a fumble recovery yesterday and de feated Wagner College, 2413, in the Metropolitan Football Conference opener at Fischer Field in Staten Island.

title: Graffiti Goes LegitBut the ShowOff Ebullience Remains
description: THE first time I saw the new graffitithe stylishly calligraphed and ornamented signa tures of spraycan and mark ingpen vandalswas three years ago in Philadelphia. I was dismayed by the near total saturation of urban sur faces; it made the whole city look as if it were slated for demolition. But I was also impressed by its artfulness and odd chasteness: there wasn't a dirty word or even a John loves Mary in sight. It was all pure primitive es theticism and selfadvertise ment.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: EVIDENCE is accumulating that the nation's eco nomic ailments are increasing, rather than abating, in the final months of a most hectic year. And, unfortunately, there is no clear exit in view from the maze of problems confronting the public and the business community.

title: 6 Are Attendants Of Miss Garrity At Her Wedding
description: RYE, N.Y., Sept, 15  Miss Sheila Tucker Garrity, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Devin Adair Garrity, was married this afternoon to Leroy Frantz Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Frantz of New Rochelle. The cere mony was performed in the Rye Presbyterian Church by th Rev. Joseph P. Bishop.

title: Dallenbach Seeks Victory At His Home in Trenton
description: Usually when a race driver refers to a track as his home track it is because he did most of his early driving there. When Wally Dallen bach speaks of the Trenton Speedway, though, the ref erence has many other con notations.

title: Knappwins U. S. Title in Shields Sail
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 5Arthur Knapp Jr. of the host Larchmont Yacht Club won the Shields Class na tional championship today when the final event, of the scheduled fiverace series could not be completed be cause of fading wind.

title: Harrison and Greenburgh Teachers Still on Strike
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 15 Striking teachers in the Har rison and Greenburgh school districts have ended their sec ond week on the picket lines.

title: Ten Indoor City Pools Open Season Tomorrow
description: The Parks Administration's 10 indoor swimming pools in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx will begin their new season tomorrow.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Women, according to pro moters for the professional football business, are now just as sappy about football as men, and even if this is only half true, it is a sad state of affairs. Just how sad has been easy to observe over the past few years.

title: 14 Youths Bolster Renewal in Elizabeth
description: ELIZABETH  Fourteen teenagers recently completed a 10week project in which they helped to plug holes in what an American Friends Service Committee worker called the oldest incomplete urbanrenewal program in the world.

title: ANTIPOVERTY UNIT TO FIGHT OUSTER
description: The community antipoverty corporation for the often em battled Ocean HillBrownsville area in Brooklyn was planning yesterday to contest the city administration's effort to de pose it in a State Supreme Court hearing this week.

title: AGENCIES' MEMOS LINKED TO G.O.P.
description: Watergate investigators have discovered internal memoran dums from a number of the Nixon Administration's regula tory agencies in the files of the Committee for the Reelection of the President, according to sources close to the investi gation.

title: A Babylon Man Reported Missing During Boat Ride
description: BAY SHORE, L. I., Sept. 15 (UPI)A member of the Bab ylon Village, L. I., Fire Depart ment band was reported miss ing last night during a band outing on a boat in the Great South Bay, the Suffolk Counts police reported.

title: King Will Win In Four Sets
description: Forget that she sprained her knee in New Jersey. Forget that she was knocked out by the heat at Forest Hills. Forget the bloodsugar scare, Bobby's taunts, Margaret's loss. Mrs. Billie Jean King is the finest clutch hitter in tennis. There is no reason to think she won't beat Bobby Riggs in the Astrodome Thursday night.

title: Penalty for Builder Who Exceeded Limit On Height Is Urged
description: Community Board 6, in the east midtown area, has recom mended that the builder of a luxury apartment house who exceeded the 33 stories speci fied in his permit be allowed to complete the structure pro vided that he sets aside equiva lent space in the building for middle  income apartments for the elderly.

title: ON WITH THE SNOW
description: Waiting for winter: an avalanche of lustilyplaided mackinaws and very bright, solidshaded out er jackets.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Notes: The Gas Drought Wasn't All That Dry
description: NOW that the big drain on gaso line pumps caused by the sum mer motorist is over, it's time to take stock of the socalled gas crisis and what the future holds. Gen erally, drivers didn't get stranded with dry tanks, as some Cassandras had pre dicted, partly because American motor ists both heeded warnings to conserve gas by reducing speed and refilled their tanks before fuel gauges fell too low. Moreover, the shortage of supplies and there was, and still is, a shortage just wasn't as bad as some suppliers had indicated it would be. However, the oil companies and the American Automo bile Association, which kept tabs on gasstation stocks across the country throughout the summer, say that we can expect a pinch again next summer when vacationers once more take to the road.

title: A Correction
description: In a recipe for Sailor's Chicken, which was published in this section last Sunday, the second step in the direc tions should have read: Ar range chicken in a single layer, skin side up in a roast ing pan. Pour lime juice over the chicken, sprinkle with tarragon, salt, and pepper and dot with butter before baking.

title: Met Games This Week
description: TodayChicago at Shea Stadium, 2:05 P.M.

title: Who Is Saying What
description: Muhammad Ali sums it up after his victory over Ken Norton: I was angry with myself for getting so out of shape for my last fight, and I had to prove I could still fight like I know I can. From now on I'm going to try to be a wellconditioned old man, like Archie Moore was.

title: Miss Foster Has Nuptials
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 15  Miss Caroline Nichols Foster, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William James Foster 3d of Birmingham, Mich., formerly of Pleasant ville, was married here this afternoon to Jan Dwight Chester Slee, son of William T. F. Slee of Brussels and Mrs. Hendrik A. H. Sijthoff of Greenwich, Conn., and The Hague, the Netherlands.

description: RED BANKCan a 114 pound woman cope with a 250pound man who must be carried by stretcher to a waiting ambulance?

title: Cortland State Loses
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 15 (AP)John Levy tossed two touchdown passes, one a 51yarder in the third quarter today, as Springfield rolled In a 3420 victory over Cort land State. II was the first loss in 15 games for Cortland.

description: Three the Hard Way, de scribed as a big black action picture with four black stars, will follow Papillon, sched uled for December release, as the next project for Allied Ar tists.

title: RetiredBut. Not Too Old
description: The golden years often lose their gild. Many old people, are relegated to innocuous duties that do little to bos ster their morale. But for the last year, a Nassau County program has been giving these people something to live for and society has been the beneficiary.

title: STATE EDUCATORS CITE FUND NEEDS
description: ALBANY, Sept. 15Public avid private education systems in the state, from kindergarter through university graduate schools, need more money, the Board of Regents has been told.

title: JAMES TOCCO WINS MUNICH PIANO PRIZE
description: James Tocco, a 30yearold American pianist, was selected Friday as winner of the piano division of the Munich Interna tional Competition. He will re ceive a cash award of 6,000 marks (approximately $3,000) and a concert contract with the Bavarian Radio.

title: $1Million Roofed Mall Opens in Bergen
description: PARAMUS  The Bergen Mall literally raised the roof last weck, when it officially opened a $1.2million enclo sure of most of its 78 storms, 11 of them new.

title: ANTIWAR ACTIVIST WILL BE DEPORTED
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 15  A Milwaukee man who has been called a saint, who has been denounced by many Milwau keeans and who has been la beled an undesirable by the Government will be deported to his native Ireland next week.

title: John Winthrop Aldrich Weds Mrs. Middleton
description: RED HOOK, N. Y., Sept. 15 Mrs. Katharine Delano Ryan Middleton was married in Christ Episcopal Church here this afternoon to John Winthrop Aldrich. The Right Rev. Albert A. Chambers, re tired Bishop of Springfield, Ill., performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Orion W. Davis, rector of the church.

title: Mrs. Bierce Has Nuptials
description: ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 15  The marriage of Mrs. Joycelyn Blaikie Bierce, wid ow of Thurber H. Bierce, to Augustine Hicks Lawrence Jr. of Wilmington, Del., took place here this afternoon.

title: What's Doing in ATHENS
description: ARTThe Thera frescoes exhibition seems to be one of the bestkept secrets in the National Archeologi cal Museum here. Thousands of foreign visitors get museum feet exploring this treasurepacked modern lacyrinth, but few know that the magnificent 3,500yearold frescoes are on display on the up per floor. The wallpaintings were retrieved from a thick layer of ash and pumice that shrouded the Ae gean island of Thera after the eruption of its volcano about 1500 B.C. Keep an eye peeled for the unretouched and beautiful Red Eared Priestess. The museum, at 44 Patission Street, mercifully has new visiting hours stretching non stop from 8 A.M. to 6 P.M. Tues day through Sunday (closed Mon day). The entrance fee is $1 (free Thursday and Sunday) and there is an extra charge for the Thera Rooms (33 cents) which one is welladvised to visit first.

title: Where Top Riders Train
description: GLADSTONETechnically any amateur horseback rider who is at least 18 years old old and a citizen is eligible to compete for a place on the United States Olympic Eques trian Team, As a practical matter, however, it takes about as much skill and prac tice as a violinist needs to get to Carnegie Hall.

title: Bowling Green Is Victor
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 15 Bowling Green State of Ohio trounced Syracuse, 4114, in a football upset today be fore 18,254 shocked and silent fans in Archbold Sta dium.

title: Heavy Traffic and American Graffiti
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:

title: Cards Trail By 3 After Pirates Win
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 15 (AP) Manny Sanguillen's tworun single and Dave Parker's threerun homer paced the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 74 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals today that pre served the Pirates' lead in the National League East. The Cards, who have lost seven straight, dropped to three games off the pace.

title: Friday Bad For Driving In the State
description: ALBANY, Sept. 15  Most motor vehicle acidents in the state take place on Fri days, especially between 4 and 5 P.M. But the worst time for fatal accidents is in the early hours of a Sun day morning. The safest day to drive is Tuesday, especial ly between 5 and 6 A.M.

title: HOTDOG QUILTED
description: The colors are electric, the featherweight fabrics are racingstriped and sausagequilted.

title: Hampton Bridge for Sale
description: Stone bridge, used. Suitable for railroad, vehicles or strolling. Terms. Apply Mayor Hugh Far ley, Hampton Borough, N. J.

title: Answer to the conundrum of self
description: Peter Davison at 45, successful poet and director of the Atlantic Monthly Press, has written a personal history indeed. The stern candor of it makes one wonder at first if he is to be linked with the confessional writersthe Robert Lowells, Sylvia Plathswho have walked naked be fore us these years in bitter anger and resentment, accusing and hating their fathers, finding life worth re vealing only in its guilts and humili ations, its appalling failures. But of Peter Davison this is far from true. If his search is, like theirs; a search for identity, unlike them he has escaped selfpity; he has made the impossibly difficult journey from re sentment to compassion. And he has found himself.

title: Packers Come Running to Test Jets
description: The big rap against the New York Jets last season was that they did not beat a team with a winning rec ord in a 7won, 7Iost season.

title: In Gravesend, The Past Bends To a New Day Slowly, Slowly
description: It was a great day for Women's Lib when Deborah Moody gathered up her skirts and 40 followers and marched out of Lynn, Mass. She had had a fall ing out with New England Puritans and had been invited to take herself elsewhere. The year was 1643, and she made straight for Nieuw Amsterdam, with its promise of religious freedom.

title: University Is Hot to Patent Unit
description: FLORHAM PARK  Lead ing authorities on modern law and procedure will be the guest speakers at the annual Patent Institute to be held at Fairleigh Dickinson University on Oct. 13.

title: Cathedral Recitals to Resume in Newark
description: NEWARK The fifth sea son of weekly free concerts at the Cathedral of the Sacred Heart will begin Sept. 25 with a performance by the cathedral organist. John Rose. It will start at 8:30 P.M.

title: Boston College Tops Temple Eleven, 450
description: NEWTON, Mass., Sept. 15 (AP)Mike Esposito, Boston College's fine back, wrecked Temple with his explosive bursts tonight and the Eagles posted a 45.0 victory.

title: ChinaUpper Volta Ties Set
description: TOKYO, Sept, 15 (AP) China and Upper Volta have established diplomatic rela tions, Peking's official news agency Hsinhua, said today.

title: Second Sunday For Monticello
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., Sept. 15  The second of eight cards of Sunday harness racing will be held tomor row afternoon at Monticello Raceway where a crowd of 9,144 showed up a week ago to attend the opener. The time for the first post is 2:30 P.M. and the price of general admission is $2.50.

title: SHOP TALK
description: CRESSKILLHamrah's is a store of impressive size and attractive ambiance that sells the latest fashions for women and children. This year, Mary Hamrah and her three daugh ters are marking 16 years in business.

description: New York football fans, all of them, will have an op portunity today to see if the Giants, those preseason hot hots, are for real in the reg ular season.

title: 5% Revaluation Tomorrow For Netherlands Guilder
description: THE HAGUE, Sept. 15 (AP) A 5 per cent revaluation of the Dutch guilder was announced today by the Finance Ministry, which said that the measure was taken to fight inflation and unemployment.
