description: Besancon

title: Riggs an 85 Favorite
description: RENO, Nev., Sept. 15 (AP) Oddsmakers have estab lished Bobby Riggs as an 85 favorite to beat Mrs. Billie Jean King in their tennis match Thursday in Houston. A better must put up $8 to win $5 on Riggs and $5 to win $8 on Mrs. King.

title: 600,000 Pontiacs Recalled Over FuelLine Fire Hazard
description: PONTIAC, Mich., Sept. 15 (UPI)  A Pontiac spokesman said yesterday that the com pany was recalling 600,000 cars, about twothirds of its 1973, model production in the United States, to correct a potential fire hazard in a fuel line.

title: Amherst Student Drowns
description: AMHERST, Mass., Sept. 13 (AP)  Gerald G. Penny, 18 years old of New Orleans, freshman at Amherst College, drowned yesterday while taking a swimming test at the school, the police said.

title: Monmouth to Put 4 Houses on View
description: FREEHOLDFour histori cally significant houses and a Museum will be opened to the public on Oct. 27 and 28 to help commemorate the 75th anniversary of the Mon mouth County Historical As sociation.

title: Missouri Is Winner By 17 to 0
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., Sept. 15 (AP)Tommy Reamon came off the bench and scored two touchdowns, one on a daz zling 70yard burst through a wave of defenders, and lifted the Missouri Tigers to a 170 victory today over Mississippi.

title: Pitt Surprises Georgia With a 77 Tie
description: ATHENS, Ga., Sept. 15 (AP)Georgia was held to a surprising 77 tie by Pitts burgh today in Johnny Majors's first game as Pitt's football coach.

title: State Plan Marks Gains For Aspiring Physicians
description: TRENTONDespite the growing need for medical services and physi cans in New Jersey's major cities, substantial numbers of American graduates of foreign medical schools have been unable to continue their medical training in the state or gain residencies in its hospitals.

title: Democrats Seek $6.2Million in 8Hour Telethon
description: BURBANK, Calif., Sept. 15 (AP)  Politicians and Holly wood stars teamed up tonight in a nationwide telethon to raise $6.2million for the debt ridden Democratic party. More than $4million was pledged in the first six hours.

title: Mets Divide With Cubs, Lose Ground to Pirates
description: The New York Mets re sumed their dwindling ver sion of a pennant race in Shea Stadium yesterday, but lost half a step when they divided a doubleheader with the Chicago Cubs.

title: Growing Disenchantment With Controls
description: WASHINGTON  With the transition from the Nix on Administration's Freeze 2 to Phase 4 complete, what ever enchantment there was with price controls a year ago seems to have gone the way of most illusions.

title: Dolphins Must Establish Superiority All Over Again
description: MIAMI, Sept. 15  Frank Gifford, in a moment of con templation 16 years ago while playing for a winning New York Giant team, said, The trouble with this sport is they don't let you stand still and taste it for very long. No matter what you've done you have to go right back out there and do it over again; do it even better. Gif ford the year be fore had been voted the best player in the National Foot ball League.

title: Flirth Tops Knightly Way By Nose in Colonial Trot
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 (AP)Flirth, with Ralph Baldwin in the sulky, went in front in the final stride tonight to beat Knightly Way by a nose in the $103,495 Colonial Trot at Liberty Bell Park.

title: Elephant Shopping Ambition Fills a Vacuum
description: Like chickadees, politicians prefer to cavort in cool weather. So the pre autumn breezes that swept across the country last week were followed by some potential candidates for the Presidency in 1976. Most of them were Republicans and the most active of those were John Connally and Nelson Rockefeller.

title: Route 35: Neon Nights for Singles
description: SOUTH AMBOY  Night falls, the neon lights go on, the band tunes up and the drinks start to flow.

title: Cambodian Planes Attack Rebel Force
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sept. 15 (AP)Propellerdriven fighter planes, each carrying four bombs, today struck insur gent positions from which a town 13 miles from Phnom Penh was being shelled.

title: Jules Olitski: A Sectarian Scenario
description: IN the Jules Olitski retro spective that has now come to the Whitney Mu seum of American Art, the earliest paintings date from the late fifties. Olitski, who was then in his late 30's, was working in a style based on certain Parisian painters of the periodmostly Fau trier. Until I consulted the chronology of Olitski's career in the catalogue of the cur rent show, I assumed he was still working in Paris at the time, for these paintings, with their thick, colorless surfaces of encrusted spackle, embody all the cliches of art infor mel  then considered the Most advanced pictorial style in Europe, and Paris's answer to the New York School.

title: Movies
description: ELLIOTT GOULD and Donald Sutherland make a lugubrious pair of comics. They're like roommates in some college dorm where everyone else is a freshman and they're seniors. They've seen it all, brother, and they've seen it together.

title: Tapes Case
description: WASHINGTONIt was almost as if the referee had let Joe Frazier and Muhammad All box ten spirited rounds and then, without a decision, sent them back to the dressing room to make up.

title: MOVIES ARE BIG BOX OFFICEON TV
description: Movies are bigger than everon television, that is. If anything characterizes the first weeks of the new TV season, other than the delayed pre mieres of many new shows owing to the writers' strike earlier this year, it is the abundance of bigboxoffice movies. Frontloading, or stuff ing the premiere weeks with shiny special fea tures, isn't new, but the trend seems to be toward bigger film blockbusters. A network pays millions for movies like the ones shown here, all scheduled for this week, in the fond hope that viewers will 1) keep tuning in, same time and channel, for the rest of the season and therefore 2) remain forever innocent of what the competition is offering.

title: Susan Kanter To Be a Bride
description: The engagement of Miss Susan Elizabeth Kanter to J. Stewart Thomas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hywel D. Thomas of Downend, Bristol, England, has been announced by the future bride's, parents, Mr. and Mrs. Marvin W. Kanter of Roslyn, L.I.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The financial markets wound up on a lower level last week despite indications that the Nixon Administration was considering new ways to slow inflation.

title: The Idea That Chinese Art Is Difficult to Understand Vanishes'
description: THE Freer Gallery in Washington has the right idea about birthdays. For its fiftieth it is giving a se ries of presents to everybody. The first, an exhibition of Ukiyoe paint ing, which opened May 2, has closed and was succeeded last Wednesday by an exhibition of Chinese figure painting. The day before it ends on Jan. 15 it will be replaced by a show of Islamic ceramics, which will wind up the anni versary year.

title: MAN PLEADS GUILTY TO SEX ABUSE OF BOY
description: RNERHEAD, L. I., Sept. 15 (AP)A New York man named in an indictment alleging con spiracy, sodomy and sexual abuse of boys, pleaded guilty yesterday to having sexual re lations with a boy under 14 years of age.

title: Nuptials for Page Ellen Holmyard
Milbrey T. Rennie Is Bride of David H. Taylor. Jr.
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 15  In Immanuel Presbyterian Church here this afternoon, Miss Milbrey Tower Rennie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Roxburgh Rennie of Milwaukee and Palm Beach, Fla., was married to David Hendrickson Taylor Jr., son of Mr. Taylor of Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., and Mrs. Con stance Matless Taylor of Wenham, Mass. The Rev. William H. Johnstone per formed the ceremony.

title: POLICY ON SOVIET FACES FIRST TEST
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 The Nixon Administration's policy of building improved relations with the Soviet Union faces its first important Con gressional test on Wednesday and officials expressed concern today about the longterm ef fect on SovietAmerican rela tions in case of defeat.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONThe glory days of the Senate Watergate Committee may have come to an end. Meeting last Wednesday for the first time in five weeks, the committee decided to limit the scope of its inquiry severely and to ease the frenetic pace at which it operated in the late spring and early summer. Furthermore, there were in dications that the one prominent mem ter of the Nixon team who has not yet testified, Charles W. Colson, may never be called before the committee.

title: Ishmael updated, a thwarted marriage, assorted sex, roaring Catholics, a sweet sweet man
description: Thirtyone doesn't seem like quite the optimum age for the American boy to hit the road, to light out for the Territory, but Larry Ban croft doesn't let that fact slow him down: The important thing was to move, to keep the windows open and the scenery fresh. Walking out in the middle of his father's funeral service, Larry, like Ishmael, drives off his spleen by rushing from all havens asternhis Pequod a Porsche; his Qtteequeg a Benton Harbor pick up named Mary Lou; his white whale the stoned Leviathan of the Ameri can West. in 1972. Ishmael started out with a couple of shirts in his carpetbag and some loose change. Bancroft digs equipment: an Ameri can Express card, several assorted charge plates, $5,000 in cash, flare bottom Levis, enough other clothes for an Arctic expedition, a pair of mirrorfinish Polaroid sunglasses, and some Janis Joplin tapes.

title: Lucia Castro Is Bride Of Paul L. Hosefros
description: Miss Lucia Castro and Paul Leslie Hosefros of New York were married here yes terday afternoon in the Church Center for the United Nations by the Rev. Melvin Hawthorne. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carlos Julio Castro Gonzales of Bogota, Colombia, where her father, an educator, owns and directs the Gymnasia Cundinamarca. The bride groom is a son of Mrs. Tibor Sands, president of Welsh Crafter, importers.

title: Finns Change Diet to Fight Heart Attacks
description: JOENSUU, Finland, Sept. 15Tens of thousands of Finns have begun to change their diets and lifestyles in a communitywide experi ment to soften the deadly impact of arteriosclerosis in the area with the world's highest incidence of heart attacks.

title: Menotti's Hard Blow to the Gut
description: CHICAGO. COMPOSING operas these days is a chancy business, as no one must know better than Gian Carlo Menottihe has, after all, been at it with unrelenting vigor for 52 years (his unofficial opus one was something called The Death of Pierrot, writ ten at age 10). Considering the mortality rate of most contemporary operas, Menot ti has garnered amazing six cess with the public (if not always with the Critics) and The Medium,. The Tele phone, The Consul, Amahl and The Saint of Bleecker Street show every signs of achieving solid rep status.

title: The first step in museumization
description: The great massaudience picture maga zines, of Which Life was, by common con sent, the very greatest, have now fol lowed Holly wood movies and the old radio enter tainments into the museum of Amen ican culture, yet another casualty of the television age. For many of its readers (viewers?), Life was retired from its primary (visual) function long before its actual demise in 1972. The ascendancy of the video screen had the (often unjust) effect of induc ing a feeling of dj vu about the magazine's photographic layouts. If one turned to the magazine at all in those last years, it was, more often than not, to read it rather than to look at it. Indeed, it was a little eerie at times to find oneself turning those large, slippery pages in order to scan the narrow columns of type devoted to reviews of books and movies and television, but these review columns constituted for many of us the best of Life in the last years of the maga zine's existence.

title: PALESTINE GROUP CONDEMNS ACCORD
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 15 The Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, the leading Marxist group within the Palestinian resistance movement, strongly condemned today the reconciliation of Egypt and Syria with King Hussein of Jordan.

title: Hot Line Is Fighting Pollution
description: TRENTON  For almost three years now, New Jersey ans with a pollution problem have been able to dial (609) 2927172 and get a direct connection into the office of Commissioner Richard J. Sul livan of the Department of Environmental Protection.

title: Lab Workers' Hobby Pays Off
description: PRINCETONIt's harvest time in the gardens behind the RCA Corporation labora tories here, gardens where laboratory employes have been growing vegetables  including more tomatoes than they can give awayon land ploughed and watered by management.

title: Pop
description: CECIL TAYLOR, the mercurial composer pianist whose con structivist methods have been a pervasive influ ence in contemporary jazz, has ended a fiveyear hiatus in his recording career with the release of a solo piano LP on his own Unit Core label. Since the appearance of Conquistador, his last commercial recording, Tay lor has concentrated on hon ing his compositional and improvisational skills. He has also attracted attention as an educator through his innovative performance workshops and classes in AfroAmerican music at Antioch College in Yellow Springs, Ohio, Indent, his new LP, was recorded at Antioch earlier this year.

title: Bridgeport Tops Allred For 22d Straight, 14.8
description: ALFRED, N. Y., Sept. 15 Carmine Bove caught a 63 yard pass from Mitchell Sanders as the clock ran out to give Bridgeport a 148 vic tory over Alfred today.

title: MICHIGAN TUITION STIRS STRIKE MOVE
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 15The recent sizable tuition increase at the University of Michigan promises to revive the spirit of student activism last evidenced here during the antiwar, antidraft and black liberation protests of the late nineteensixties.

title: Marcy Butler Is Bride
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Sept., 15  Miss Marcy Ann Butler, a model for the Mannequin Agency in New York, was married here this afternoon to Arthur Forrest, director of the Dick Cavett television show. The outdoor ceremony was performed on the beach by Judge Henry Kendrick of the Civil Court. The bride is a daughter of Maj. John Butler, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Butler of Portsmouth, N. H. The bride groom's parents are the late Mr. and Mrs. Jonas Feinberg of New York.

title: WhitesOnly Rule Rejected
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept, 15 (AP)Two lodges of the Be nevolent and Protective Order of Elks in the San Francisco Bay Area have voted to drop the order's whiteonly member ship rule, San Rafael Lodge 1108 voted 3 to 1 to reject the 105yearold restriction, an of ficer said. San Mateo Lodge 1112 also reportedly voted to drop the ban.

title: The Last Days of a Bhicoilar Resort
description: MONEY ISLAND, N.J.Soon the littlestrip of coarse beach will be deserted, Popsicle season will be over and the white enamel chairs at Laura's Candy Store will be turned over the tables. Anoth er summer will become a memory for the folks and kids for whom Money Island, a foursquareblock area of cot tages on the Toms River in Ocean County, N. J., is paradise.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: Reviewing The Young Men cken, Hilton Kramer states that history has proved him an unreliable guide to the subject of comparative politi cal pathologies, and that his newspaper columns now have only an antiquarian inter est. It is a common dictum of today's literati.

title: More Adults Will Go to School
description: TRENTON  New Jersey education officials expect the state's adultschool enroll ment to rise this year.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: President Nixon's proposed trade legislationand what happens to it in Congress in the next few monthswill very likely determine world trade relations for many years to come for two fun damental reasons.

title: BIAGGI ASKS DEATH FOR SOME CRIMES
description: Representative Mario Biaggi, the Conservative party candi date for Mayor, called on the State Legislature yesterday to adopt a law providing a man datory death penalty for cer tain crimes.

title: Ten Indoor City Pools Open Season Tomorrow
description: The Parks Administration's 10 indoor swimming pools in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx will begin their new season tomorrow.

title: 6 Interceptions Help Navy to Roll, 378
description: LEXINGTON, Va., Sept. 15 (AP)Cleveland Cooper ran for 172 yards and two touch downs and Navy intercepted six passes today as the Mid dies opened with a 378 romp over Virginia Military Institute.

title: Valley Forge Park Fee Is Set
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 15 (AP)The Pennsylvania Histor ical and Museum Commission has voted to levy a 50cent ad mission charge for four historic buildings at Valley Forge State Park, effective Monday.

title: SHETLAND COUNTRY
description: In an era which is becoming increas ingly blendconscious, the label stating All Shetland Wool is, more than ever, something special.

title: COASTAL DRILLING SPURS NEW CLASH
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15  The growing conflict between environmentalists and industrial interests over whether to Grill for oil and natural gas along the East Coast and in the Gulf of Alaska was rekindled this week at hearings of the Presi dent's Council on Environ mental Quality.

title: '74 AUTOS MATCH '73'S ON MILEAGE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 Tests by the Environmental, Pro tection Agency indicated that 1974model automobiles, now coming on the market, will get about the same gasoline mile age as their 1973 counterparts.

title: Biblebased conversation, rich with insight
description: If educators came out with a body of knowledgeknowledge of events, of persons, of sayings, of great lines or paragraphs of verse or prose, of mathematical figures or formulae, and certainly, knowledge of the Bibleif they came out with this body of knowledge and said, All children in our culture should.

title: Jocelyn Grace Is Bride Of Edward R. Howe Jr.
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept 15 St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Chestnut Hill was the set ting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Jocelyn Grace, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Gifford Grace Jr. of Chestnut Hill and Fishers Island, N.Y., to Edward Red field Howe Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Howe of West Hartford, Conn. and Fishers Island. The Rev. Tom Turney Ed wards performed the cere mony.

title: George Gershwin's Music? 'S Wonderful Still
description: COMPOSERS, by tradi tion, are not a gen erous lot. Essentially, we are a breed of men and women concerned with the arrangement of the same seven notes. So with raw material in such short supply, we tend to be some what taciturn when it comes to assaying each other's work. We are closet wor shipers of our colleagues' talentsand will often go to extremes to avoid having to pay them public compliment. I suspect there are even those among us who are tempted to give credence to the apocryphal anecdote about Beethoven getting the idea for his Fifth Symphony from the whistling of a street sweeper. We belong to a tightly knit but mutually ex clusive brotherhood that could have given sibling ri valry its name.

title: The Making of a Professor of Jazz
description: EDISON  When Ralph Berton talks about jazz, he draws on a personal experi ence that began at the age of 6 and a 34year career of writing and lecturing on the subject. On Tuesday evening, as he opened a weekly course on jazz at Middlesex County College's Division of Continu ing Education, Mr. Berton got right to the heart of the mat ter.

title: Bhutto's Visit A Friendly Hand But No Arms
description: RAWALPINDIPrime Minister Zul fikar All Bhutto was in a reflective mood. Believe me, he said, sitting in his garden at dusk sipping a scotch and soda, this much we have learned in our twentyfive years of existence. You can't lead a great power by the nose.

title: Art Show on Tap In Paterson Today
description: PATERSON  Art in the Park, an annual professional art show, will be held today in Eastside park. Sponsored by the Paterson Parks De partment, with the coopera tion of other city agencies and William Paterson Col lege, the show is expected to attract more than 5,000 visi tors and 300 artists.

title: Teaneck Sees Project as a Threat
description: TEANECKOpposition has developed here to the in clusion, in this township's ambitious urbandevelopment plan, of a highrise luxury apartment complex. The op position reflects in part a growing concern in many New Jersey communities that such apartments pose a threat to their residential character.

title: Ohio State's Runners Rip Minnesota, 56 to 7
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 15 (AP)Archie Griffin returned a kickoff 93 yards and Neal Colzie ran back a punt 78 yards for touchdowns and Harold (Champ) Henson scored three times today in powering thirdranked Ohio State to a 567 triumph over Minnesota in a Big Ten foot ball opener before 86,005.

title: COMMON MARKET FUR CAMPUSES SET
description: ST. PAUL, Sept 15 (AP) Minnesota and Wisconsin are operating a common market for college education.

title: Mrs. Perkins Is Remarried
description: Mrs. Kathryn Bowling Perkins, a teacher at the Dalton School Jere, and Jus tus Allan Hovey Jr., a vice president of Radio. Free Eu rope, were married here yes terday afternoon in a Presby terian ceremony at St. Cor nelius Chapel on Governors Island by Comdr. Samuel Baez of the Chaplain Corps, U. S. N.

title: Yanks Beat Orioles, 30, On Stottlemyre's 4Hitter
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 15 Looking like the Yankees whose fans thought they were going to win the pen nant back in July, the New York team defeated the Orioles tonight, 3.0, for the second straight night.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: IHAVEN'T strictly fol lowed Walter Kerr's ca reer, being too busy trying to create my own. But a year ago, I over heard, or overread, an ex cerpt from his book, God on the Gymnasium Floor, that was filled with such sudden rightness, such punctilious urgency, was so succinctly ebullient, that began to think here might be the Critic's Critic moving be yond rhetoric and the tauto logies of taste into the firm est imaginative ground of symbol or that dance of the body called poetry.

title: Gold: A Tragedy in African Mines ...
description: JOHANNESBURG  The deaths of 12 African mineworkers11 from po lice gunfire, one hacked to death by mobat South Africa's richest and deepest gold mine has led to a sor rowful public postmortem. Two main questions are being asked by both blacks and whites: Why did the riot occur? Why did the police shoot to kill?

title: Oil Nations, at Vienna Meeting, Seeking More Price Increases
description: VIENNA, Sept. 15Ministers from the biggest petroleumex torting nations were seeking more price increases today and amendments of existing accords with Western companies in moves that could bring new disturbances to the international oil market.

title: Law Curbs Cemetery Fraud
description: TRENTON State officials expressed confidence last week that New Jersey ceme teries would cooperate in the enforcement of a new law that is designed to protect the public against unfair charges for grave markers.

title: Fuel Oil Shortage Is Protested on Island
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I.  An gered by what he termed the callous disregard of the major petroleum companies toward the plight of Long Island homeowners, Hemp stead Town Supervisor Al fonse D'Amato last week de manded that the Federal and state governments investi gate the companies' practices that have precipitated a loss of more than 300 million gallons of fuel oil to Long Island this winter.

title: Byrne and Sandman Discuss the Issues At Jaycee Meeting
description: NORTH BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept, 15 (AP)The Democratic and Republican candidates for Governor of New Jersey ap peared to be better prepared today as they met again in the campaign.

title: Memorial for Dr. Papanek
description: A memorial service for Dr. Ernst Papanek, former execu tive director of the Wiltwyck School for Boys in Esopus, N. Y., and later a professor of educational psychology at Queens College, will be held at 3 P.M. today in the Community Church, 40 East 35th Street. 113r. Papanek died in Vienna on Aug. 5 at the age of 73.

title: Riggs Will Win In Three Sets
description: Don't sweat it guys, Bobby Riggs will beat Mrs. Billie Jean King Thursday night at The Astrodome in Houston, Easily.

title: Arthur Daley
description: Danny Murtaugh is beginning to re semble a man caught in a revolving door. Whenever Joe Brown, the frontoffice boss of the Pittsburgh Pirates, needs a manager, he gives that door a push and out pops Dauntless Danny to rescue him. A little over a week ago Brown pushed once again and Murtaugh emerged for a fourth term in office, thereby equaling the record of Franklin Delano Roose velt.

title: Translation of the Bible Coming Out
description: Another modern English version of the Biblethis one called The New Interna tional Bibleis about to be made available to the public in its New Testament sec tion. Its sponsor is the vene rable New York Bible Society International, which has put over $500,000 into the proj ect since 1967.

title: Mary Erb's Bridal
description: OCEAN CITY, N. J., Sept. 15Miss Mary Frances Erb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Erb of Ocean City and Fleetwood, Pa., was mar ried here this morning to Jack William Bennett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Bennett of Ocean City and Greenwich, Conn. The ceremony was per formed in Our Lady of Good Counsel Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Joseph McCauley

title: Leading Performers Scheduled At College
description: Brooklyn College's con cert series, considered one of the most successful in the country, will enter its 20th season by presenting such major artists as Franco Co relli, Luciano Pavarotti, Re nate Tebaldi, Marilyn Horne, Joan Sutherland, Richard Tucker. Robert Merrill and Yehudi Menuhin.

title: Dressage Test Taken By Winnett
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Sept, 15Jack Winnett of Tuxedo Park, N. Y., a member of the United States Equestrian Team's 1972 Olympic squad, rode Mario to victory in the intermediate class today at the WestchesterFairfield Dressage Association horse show.

title: The Corporate Political Squeeze
description: During the last two months, seven blue  chip companies with household names such as American Airlines, Gulf Oil and Goodyear Tire and Rub ber have admitted in rapid sequence that they illegally contributed almost half a million dollars to President Nixon's 1972 reelection cam paign.

title: QUESTIONS
description: If you have a question, or know the answer to a question. asked in these columns, please serrd it to Garden News, The New York Times, Times Square, N.Y. 10036. We will publish questions of general interest and the practical solutions. Please enclose a stamped, selfaddressed envelope.

title: Van Breda Kolff Hired
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (UPI) Charles O. Finley said to night he had hired. Butch van Breda KoIff to coach his Memphis Tams in the Amer ican Basketball Association, Van Breda Kolff, who signed a twoyear contract, has coached the Los Angeles Lakers, the Detroit Pistons and the Phoenix Suns.

title: Llana ArrottWatt Will Marry
description: Miss Llana ArrottWatt, a graphic designer here, and Thomas M. Wyman of New York, a financial analyst at Texasgulf, Inc., plan to be wed on Oct. 20.

title: The Nation
description: To the innocent eye, nothing much happened in Tokyo last week when 102 nations assembled to launch What has been called the Nixon round of trade negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The Stone & Webster Engi neering Corporation, which occupies the 29th and 30th floors at One Penn Plaza, has signed a lease for the 31st floor with an option to rent the 32d floor in the office building.

title: CITY POLITICIANS DEFER TO BERME
description: During the special session of the State Legislature in July, the city's legislative liaison representative in Albany, Rich ard A. Brown, was making al most as many calls to Con troller Abraham D. Beame as to Mayor Lindsay.

title: Reds Beat Braves, 3 to 2, On Perez Homer in 10th
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 15 (UPI)  Tony Perez, who begged his way into the start ing lineup, slammed a two out, 10thinning homer to night off Wenty Ford, a rookie, to give the Cincinnati Reds a 32 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

title: Deborah Joy Garber Betrothed To Douglas W. MacKelcan Jr.
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 15Mr. and Mrs. Harry Douglas Garber have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Joy Garber, to Douglas Walker MacKelcan Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. MacKelcan of Wilmington, Del.

title: ROBERT D. CHATFIELD
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 15  Robert D. Chatfield, a res taurateur who operated several wellknown establishments in Fairfield County, died today at his home, 218 Cedar Heights. He was 54 years old.

title: Soviet Dissidents
description: Prof, Harrison S. Brown of the Cali fornia Institute of Technology is for eign secretary of the National Acad emy of Sciences, which, with about 1,000 American members and 120 for eign associates, is the foremost body of American scientists.

title: Year of Europe
description: BRUSSELSThe promised Year of Europe finally began last week in Copenhagen. It was not only late in arriving: it turned out to have a ra ther different meaning from the one President Nixon had in mind when he launched the concept last winter.

title: Battle of the Tapes
description: The Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Colum bia has provided President Nixon with an opportunity back away froth the constitutional confrontation toward which he appears headed in the battle of the White House tapes. If Mr. Nixon's overriding concern is protect the separation of powers rather than defend the concept of executive confidentiality as such, then the court's ingenious proposal could lead to a compromise satisfactory to both sides.

title: Gale A. Gwiazdowski Has Nuptials
description: NORWICH, Conn., Sept. 15 Miss Gale Ann Gwiazdow ski, a June graduate of Bos ton University Law School, and John Warren Moscow, an assistant district attorney for New York County, were married here this morning in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Lewis Blecharzyk.

title: Christopher du Pont Marries Marcie C. Lazar in New Paltz
description: NEW PALTZ, N. Y., Sept. 15Miss Darcie Caryn Laz ar, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Louis Allen Lazar of New York and Goshen, was mar ried here this afternoon, to Christopher Truesdale du Pont, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexis Felix du Pont of Wil mington, Del.

title: In Cold Print: Launching and ReEntry of a Satellite
description: It has been nine months now since I started writing this column and so far publishers have found only two things seriously wrong: (1) style and (2) content. For reasons best known to themselves, publishers seem to feel that this space could more use fully be devoted to praising their books than to questioning how and why they publish some of them.

title: Miss Sparks Bride Of Dr. Peter Kent
description: SUDBURY, Mass., Sept 15  Miss Shirley Lillian Sparks, a registered nurse at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston, was married here this evening to Dr. Peter Denes Kent, a resi dent in orthopedic surgery at the Children's Medical Center in Boston.

title: An Evening of Splendor
description: Though the moment is brief, a fascinating evening is in store for those who grow night blooming cereus. In just an hour, plus, the curious leaftype cactus opens a lovely flower to release a heady fragrance. By morning, the display ends. Plants must be watched closely when a ripe flower bud appears as the exciting occasion is not to be missed. Epiphyllurn adapt readily to pot culture and are kept cool and dry in winter to rest. Blossom time is during the summer months. The species shown here, E. oxypetalum, is called Queen of the Night.

title: Education Aid for Veterans
description: BOSTON, Sept. 15 (AP)The state would pay the tuition for Vietnam veterans to attend evening and summer classes at community colleges under a measure that received final ap proval Thursday in the Massa chusetts Senate.

title: CHARLES KENNARD, LED SMITH, BARNEY
description: Charles W. Kennard, former chairman of the board of Smith, Barney & Co., investment bank ers, died yesterday at the Neu rological Institute of Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center after a long illness. He was 65 years old and lived at 19 Circle Crest, Manhasset, L. I.

title: PLAN IS PROPOSED TO CHANGE ZONING
description: A proposal of top city plan ners to change the zoning rules for multifamily housing by set. ting 37 criteria for quality drew both criticism and praise at a citysponsored workshop of architects and planners last week.

title: Strike at Chrysler
description: The strike of 117,000 Chrysler workers punctures a yearlong national record of industrial peace, but there seems basis for hope that it will not settle into a costly test of strength of the kind that marked the Ford strike of 1967 or the even more dismaying General Motors shutdown of 1970.

title: Letters: A Stewardess Who Fears Turbulence
description: To the Editor: I would like to take exception to the opinion of Edward McKittrick in Diane; Ouding's article on flying (Some of the Best People Are Afraid of Flying, Travel, Section, Aug. 12) that turbulence ..... won't hurt you. As a stewardess for eight years, I know that turbulence certainly can hurt you if you are not wearing your seat belt, and your chances of that happening are far greater than your ever being in a plane crash.

title: Carteret Is a Divided. Borough, but United It Stands
description: CARTERET  Thirtyfour major industries are situated along the borders of this Middlesex County borough, which is divided by the New Jersey. Turnpike. While these companies contribute a great deal financially to this com munity of 24,000 people, they also have created the problems that confront the pop ulation: heavy trucking on the streets, little land to develop for residential use, pollution and other environmental difficul ties and lackluster cultural development.

title: Child to Mrs. Fischer
description: POTOMAC, Md., Sept. 15 A daughter was born Sept. 3 to Dr. and Mrs. David J. Fischer at the Washington Hospital Center in Washing ton. Mrs. Fischer, whose hus band is a psychiatrist, is the former Miss Lorraine Kwas nick of Brooklyn, New York. The child has been named Nicole Erica.

title: Deborah Blakemore Wed in Palm Beach
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Sept. 15Miss Deborah Vaughan Blakemore, daughter of Mrs. Anita Christian of Atlanta and Thomas George Blake more of Palm Beach and New York, was married here this evening to Harvey Melville Hall 2d, son of Mrs. Irma de Leon Hall of Marion, Mass., and Mr. Hall of Palm Beach. The ceremony was performed in the BethesdabytheSea Episcopal Church by the Rev. Dr. Hudson Cary, the rector.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  Mem bers of the Nixon Adminis tration were taken somewhat aback by the bitter outpour ing of rage by the leaders of organized labor after the President vetoed the new minimumwage bill.

title: Nat'l Pastime? Gimme a Beer, Hon, and Fix the Contrast
description: As pro football strides briskly on stage and baseball limps to the final curtain, the question again emerges: Which of the two sports is the na tional pastime? In an effort to find the answer, The Times turned to Fred Saidy, coauthor of Finian's Rain how, an observer of the passing [and batting] scene and former base ball writer for the Manitou Springs I now Pikes Peak] Journal [circ. 866]. In destroying the myth and the lan guage in a single Ring Lardnerish swoop, Saidy answers the question of whether baseball or football is the na tional pastime. His answer: Neither.

title: French Truckers' Guide: The Poor Man's Michelin
description: ACK in my younger days, when I began most of my longdistance trips by standing at the side of the road displaying a shirt card board on which I had lettered my destination, one of many generous truck drivers I encountered gave me a piece of folkoftheroad wisdom: When you see several trucks or an abundance of grease and oil stains in the parking lot of a roadside restaurant, you have come upon a good, inexpensive place to eat. Truck drivers, he said, like their food and they know the roads.

description: Bold and brawny outdoorsized plaids are set to have a field day this fall. On these pages, eight at ease.

title: W. Virginia Rally Tops Maryland, 2013

title: MARKET TO SPEAK WITH SINGLE VOICE
description: PARIS, Sept. 15The Com on Market countries have agreed on a procedure to en able a European spokesman to speak for them as a group in coming negotiations with Com munist nations.

title: U.S BUSINESS ROUNDUP
the traveler's worId
description: RARE today, indeed, is the travel er who gallops up to a roadside inn in a cloud of dust, tosses his horse's reins to a rotund, aproned hosteler and strides into the tavern calling loudly for food, much drink, com fort and shelter for himself and horse. Yet most of the laws of innkeeping and their interpretation, laws involving mod ern motels and highrise downtown lux ury hovels, are predicated on the prob lems that arose between host and guest in medieval days when inns and taverns were first developing as houses of public accommodation and entertainment, and the fine questions of liability to man and horse and the subtleties of the hostguest relationship were first estab lished in English common law.

title: Social Calendar
description: A full page calendar of social and charity events in the New York area for the 197374 season is on Page 68.

title: LEGISLATURE ENDS SESSION ON COAST
description: SACRAMENTO, Sept. 15 The California Legislature ended the first year of its new Congressional  type twoyear sessions last night with the Democratic leadership of both the Senate and Assembly prais ing the Legislature's accom plishments as the best in re cent years.

title: Secretariat Wins, Setting a World Record
description: Thoroughbred racing at its very best was presented to a crowd of 48,023 at Bel mont Park yesterday. Sec retariat, the splendid 3year old owned by the Meadow Stable, contributed a thrill ing performance in tak ing the $250,000 Marlboro Cup in the worldrecord time of 1:45 2/5 for the 1 miles.

title: Wood Tops Twins, 114; Gains 24th
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (UPI)  Wilbur Wood, with the help of an 11run cushion in the first four innings tonight, coasted to his 24th triumph of the season as the Chicago White Sox defeated the Min nesota Twins 114.

title: Betsey E. Bruckner Married to Robert W. Pease
description: MANHASSET, L.I., Sept. 15.  Miss Betsey, Emerson Bruckner and Robert Wallace Pease, June graduates of Bucknell University, were married here today in Christ Episcopal Church. The Rev.

title: Nov. 6 Trial for Rap Brown
description: ELLICOTT CITY, Md., Sept. 15 (AP)The trial of H. Rap Brownon charges of failing to show up at his scheduled 1970 court appearance here on arson and riotrelated counts has been set for Nov, 6.

title: The Frogmen
description: Imagine swimming half a mile or so beneath the sea before you begin, disarming a prickly mine  then knowing that a slip of your hand will blow you to pieces. Navy frog men lived with this terror dur ing the war in the Pacific, and Robb White pays them tribute in this adventure story. Amos Wainwright, hero of The Frogmen, is a stubborn young ensign who winds up with three other frogmen on an extremely dangerous mis sion. The flimsy little task force must sail several hundred miles in a tiny wooden ship, slip past Japanese patrols into a strange harbor, and disarm mines they've never seen be fore. They must do this before the invasion starts, radio back to Pearl Harbor, and then run for their lives  even though they suspect their skipper is a spy for the enemy. An un likely story, farfetched? You don't believe it can be pulled off? You don't know Capt. Robb White who takes his charac ters to the limits of their en duranceand then tightens the screw onehalf turn. They squirm and so will you. An underwater knife fight, an ex ploding mine, a lastminute res cuedeath, danger and sus pense  the author cooks an oldfashioned chowder, and makes it delectable.

title: A Devastating End for a Unique, Troubled Venture
description: Political eruptions, like volcanic ones, occur suddenly after building slowly, and seem almost as inevitable. The end of the Allende regime in Chile came with, a rush of events that began in the country's history and the customs of decades.

title: The Guest Word
description: in the northwestern corner of Sicily it is not necessary to invent stories or new journalism about the Mafia. Because it's there. The American jongleurs of Mafia chic who have glorified the gang ster families are only threatened by fly ing cocktail glasses at Manhattan water ingholes or the indignity of being shot down from the best seller list by a cook book author.. But for a novelist or jour nalist in Sicily, writing about the honor able friends presents fundamental moral and artistic problems, not to mention the possibility of incurring their displeasure.

title: U. of Virginia Names Physicist as President
description: CHARLOTTEVILLE, Va., Sept. 15Frank L. Hereford Jr., a physicist, has been elected to succeed Dr. Edgar F. Shannon as president of the Univesity of Virginia.

description: Baseball jackets scored so resoundingly this past spring, the warmup jacket was a shooin for fall.

description: OXFORD, Ohio, Sept, 15 (AP)Bob Hitchens ran for 71 yards and two touchdowns today and Dave Draudt kicked two field goals as Miami of Ohio scored a 320 college football victory over Dayton.

title: Dance
description: AMERICAN dance is no longer unique. 04 rather it is almost no longer unique  and those linguistic purists who object to any comparative use of the word unique must here suffer with good grace.

title: 5 Blacks Hanged in Pretoria
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 15 (Reuters)Five black men were hanged in Pretoria's central prison yesterday, bring ing the total number executed in South Africa this year to 28, it was announced today. The men had been sentenced to death on murder charges.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: A few days ago a passer by sweltering in the more than 94degree heat paused before the Fifth Avenue win dow of Arnold Constable's store to allow his adrenalin to catch up with his falter ing pulse. He found himself staring into a display fea turing leather and suede coats for men and it seemed incongruous to him that Con stable's, much like stores everywhere, was pushing coldweat her clothes when all anyone could possibly want was to immerse oneself in to tub of ice cubes.

title: AIDES ON WATERGATE CONFER WITH NIXON
description: CAMP DAVID, Md., Sept. 15 (AP)President Nixon con ferred here today with two top aides, apparently on an appel late court suggestion that he compromise on his refusal to turn over Watergaterelated tapes to Archibald Cox, the special prosecutor.

title: Radical redesign
description: This duplex apartment has the free wheeling sense of space and the archi tectural drama that may be expected in a modern house, but is seldom seen in an apartment. Curves, light and greenery, exemplified by the sky lighted stairwell (shown at left and in center) that curves through two levels, spilling sunshine into the wideopen interior, set the theme. Architect Nor man Jaffe redesigned the coop apart ment for a family with two young children. It takes a very together family to be able to live this way, he says, because all the rooms open onto each other. There are no corridors, no separation of adult and child areas, no offlimit rooms. The lion's share of space went to areas that are usually shortchanged in apartments. There is a huge, eatin kitchen, for instance, and a master bedroom that incorpo rates most of the features of a bath room (the toilet is separate) and opens onto the foyer, which also.

title: PORTISCH, GELLER DRAW CHESS GAME
description: PORTOROZ, Yugoslavia, Sept. 15 (AP)  Lajos Portisch of Hungary and Efim Geller of the Soviet Union drew their game today in the eighth round of the Three Grandmasters Chess Tournament.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Pakistan's Leader Heads for U.S. With His Priorities Changed by Devastating Floods
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Sept. 14  Prime Minister Zul fikar All Bhutto of Pakistan, struggling to give shape to fragmented nation, begins an official visit to the United States on Monday in a mood darkened by recent floods be trip will be Mr. Bhutto's first to the United States since he assumed the leadership of Pakistan in December, 1971, after the nation's humiliating loss of her eastern wing, now Bangladesh. At that point Paki stan had reached the lowest ebb in her 25year history: the nation was shattered, the In dians had crushed Pakistani forces in three weeks and the defeated army was the object of international scorn because of its violence against civilians in Bangladesh.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 According to intelligence ports recently received her Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Sovi Communist party leader, hi emphasized to Eastern Eur pean leaders that the mov ment toward improving rely tions with the West is a tactic, policy change to permit the Soviet bloc to establish its st periority in the next 12 to years.

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 16 (AP)Communist sol diers killed two soldiers, wounded eight more and in jured 10 civilians today when they fired two mortar rounds into a military position near Tam Quan, the military com mand reported.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 The Democratic party's fund raising telethon appears to have wiped out about half the debt owed by the national party, in addition to raising a sizable sum to be used by state Demo cratic organizations.

description: BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 17 (AP)An earthquake rattled windows in the San Francisco Bay area tonight. The police said the earthquake slightly damaged telephone lines in the Mission District of San Fran cisco, but no damage was re ported in other areas.

title: AL SHERMAN DIES; WROTE HIT SONGS
description: LOS ANGELES Sept. 16 (AP) Al Sherman, the songwriter who helped raise the spirtis of a Depressionera generation with his hit song Potatoes Are Cheaper, died yesterday at the age of 76.

title: Nixon Returns Home
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 16 (AP) President Nixon returned to the White House by helicopter from Camp David, Md., tonight. He had spent part of the after noon watching the Washington RedskinsSan Diego Chargers football game on television with his family.

title: Mrs. Allende Arrives in Mexico And Is Given a Warm Welcome
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 16 (UPI) Mrs. Salvador Allende, widow of the deposed President of 2hile, received a warm welcome it the airport here today from lundreds of Mexican officials, admirers and leftwing political refugees.

title: P.B.S. to Carry Watergate With Live or Taped Option
description: The Public Broadcasting Service will provide live and taped television coverage of the hearings of the Senate Se lect Watergate Committee, starting Sept. 24. A spokesman for the network, whose local outlet is Channel 13 reported yesterday that the 239 public stations would be offered the options of carrying the live, gaveltogavel proceedings dur ing the day from Washington, or taped on prime evening time, or both.

title: Agee Clout Helps Sink Pirates, 73
description: Tommie Agee, the disap pointing former Met who was traded to the Houston Astros and acquired by the St. Louis Cardinals on Aug. 18, tight ened the National League Eastern Division race yester day. Agee not only helped the Cards snap a sevengame los ing streak, but also enabled the Montreal Expos and the Mets, both winners, gain ground on the pacesetting Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: COUNT D'ORMESSON OF FRENCH ACADEMY
description: PARIS, Sept. 16Vladimir d'Ormesson, member of the Acadmie Franaise, writer and diplomat, died yesterday at his residence in the Chateau d'Ormesson outside Paris. He was 85 years old.

title: AUTO TALKS GO ON, MOOD OPTIMISTIC
description: DETROIT, Monday, Sept. 17  Negotiators for the United Auto Workers and the Chrysler Corporation, meeting in a gen erally optimistic climate, pressed early today for an end to the U.A.W. strike that shut down some 50 Chrysler plants at midnight last Friday.

title: Simpson's 250 Yards Set N.F.L. Rush Mark
description: O. J. Simpson, a Heisman Trophy winner as a running back at Southern California, started his fifth season in the National Football League with explosive power yester day, gaining 250 yards as the Buffalo Bills whipped the New England Patriots, 3113, at Foxboro, Mass.

title: Frenchmen Square Off At Their Kind of Boccie
description: Two teams of expatriate Frenchmen from Manhattan and North Jersey squared off in Central Park yesterday afternoon to determine the metropolitan champions of la ptanque, a French bowling game similar to boccie.

title: College Ground Hogs Have Their Day
description: College football's first big day and night of action be longed to the ground attacks with Alabama displaying the most impressive one in rec ord fashion. The Crimson Tide used 73 of 77 available players in trouncing Califor nia, 660, Saturday night.

title: ARTISTS EXHIBIT IN PATERSON PARK
description: PATERSON, Sept. 16Recog nized artists, aspirants to artis tic achievement and a band of happy young daubers gathered in Eastside Park here today to participate in Paterson's sixth annual Art in the Park pro gram.

title: STRIKE IS VOTED BY LAY TEACHERS
description: Lay teachers voted yesterday to strike today at Roman Cath olic high schools in Brooklyn and Queens. About 14,000 pu pils attend the eight high schools in the two counties, which constitute the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn.The 550 members of the Lay Faculty Association planned to put picket lines around the school this morning.

title: PORTISCH QUALIFIES IN CANDIDATES CHESS
description: PORTOROZ, Yugoslavia, Sept. 16Lajos Portisch, a Hun garian grandmaster, last night assured himself of participation in the chess matches from which will emerge the challeng er to Bobby Fischer of the United States, the world cham pion. He did so by drawing a 27move game here with Lev Polugayevski, a Soviet grand master.

title: Ludwig to Head Wolf Trap
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) John M. Ludwig, who devel oped and managed the Min nesota Opera Company, has been appointed general direc tor of the Wolf Trap Founda tion for the Performing Arts. The announcement was made today by Melvin R. Laird, board chairman of the foundation, and an aide to the President.

title: Showmanship New Tactic To Fight Library Declines
description: New Orleans has been put ting on puppet shows, Pitts burgh has offered investment advice, and there's a place in Oakland, Calif., that has been giving out Mexican food. Attle boro, Mass., has featured folk singers and Baltimore county has produced motorcycle repair lessons, while Rockville, Md., has found a deft fellow who demonstrates how to tune up a Corvette.

title: Board of Estimate Is an Enigma of Democracy in the City
description: In the circus of city gov ernment, if the Mayor is the ringmaster and the City Coun cil the clown, then surely the Board of Estimate is the back room manager poring over the proceeds of the Big Top.

title: Changed Chicago Board Seeking a Chief
description: Lawrence F. O'Brien, former Democratic National Commit tee chairman, refused the job after he looked beyond the $110,000 salary.

title: Sweden's New King Carl XVI Gustaf
description: The 27yearold heir to the Swedish crown, prepared for his position since early child hood, has mounted the throne in the waning of its power and glory and with his life's work still to be done.

title: Berks' Best Is Awarded To Spaniel
description: KUTZTOWN, Pa., Sept. 16 A Brittany Spaniel, with a Welsh name, made history today when he was chosen best of 1,901 dogs at the 44th annual show of the Berks County Kennel Club at the fair grounds. He was Ch. Efynant's Revelation, co owned by Mrs. Joan Coluccio of Rhinebeck, N.Y., and John Mattinson of Whippany, N.J. His name means by the brook.

title: Franco Over Ailment
description: SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Sept. 16 (UPI)Generalissimo Francisco Franco, who is 80 years old, has recovered from a slight gastrointestinal disor der, the national news agency, Cifra, said today.

title: Dance: Indian Program
description: The Westerner approaching oriental art must tread war ilynot least In the matter of Indian dance. In the United States and in Western Europe we have seen a great deal of Indian dance, and in many ways the experience can have been misleading.

title: Mrs.Mitchell Says That Her Husband Has Left Her
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UPI)Mrs. John N. Mitchell said tonight that her husband, President Nixon's former At torney General and campaign director, had left her.

title: PRESIDENCY STUDY ASKED BY MONDALE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 Senator Walter F. Mondale urged Congress today to create a national study commission to recommend methods to reduce the Presidency to life size and Insure that the White House would be open and accountable to the American people and the Congress.

title: RULING DUE TODAY TELEXI.B.M. SUIT
description: TULSA, Okla., Sept, 15 (UPI) United States District Judge A. Sherman Christensen will rule tomorrow in the billion dollar damage suit brought by the Telex Corporation against the International Business Ma chines Corporation charging monopoly in business tactics by the computer giant.

title: TALKS GO ON TO STOP MUSIC HALL CLOSING
description: Vincent D. McDonnell, chair man of the State Mediation Board, will meet today with leaders of the stagehands and the musicians unions in an ef fort to avert the closing of Radio City Music Hall.

title: Cuba Says Envoys Halted Attack on Embassy in Chile
description: HAVANA, Sept. 16 (Reuters) Cuba's Ambassador to Chile, ousted as a result of the mili tary coup d'tat last week, said yesterday that foreign diplo mats in Santiago intervened to halt armed attacks on the Cu ban mission during the upris ing.

title: Oil Nations Will Ask Rise In Prices at Oct. 8 Parley
description: VIENNA, Sept. 16In a new campaign to increase their revenues the major oilexport ing nations announced their in tention today to meet with oil company representatives in Vienna on Oct. 8 to revise the industry's basic pricing accords.

title: ASH CALLS TAX RISE NOT NOW IN ORDER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 Roy L. Ash, director of the Office of Management and Budget, said today that the Administration's present posi tion was that no tax increase is in order, despite the fact that President Nixon is study ing some proposals to raise taxes.

description: Despite the money nation ally televised Monday night football has provided for the National Football League, some coaches still look on it as an inconvenience.

description: After a brief inquiry, the New York City Council found that the charges were true that one drug center has been recruiting addicts for its treatment program from out of state. More stringent contract provisions will prevent this kind of activity in the future.

title: Dr. Leonard Carmichael Dies; Headed Smithsonian Institution
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 Dr. Leonard Carmichael, a vice president of the National Geo. graphic Society and former head of the Smithsonian Insti tution, died today of cancer at the Washington Hospital Center. He was 74 years old.

title: JUDICIAL PANEL ASKS A GRAND JURY CURB
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) A Federal criminal justice commission says that a grand jury indictment should no longer be required for any criminal prosecution.

title: Secretariat To Run in Turf Races
description: Secretariat, not only a Triple Crown winner but a millionaire and worldrecord holder, too, after a smash ing triumph Saturday in the $250,000 Marlboro Cup, will be switched over to turf racing, his trainer, Lucien Laurin said yesterday.

title: ExArmy Balloonists to Meet

A spokesman, Starnes H. Wellborn, 78 years old, of Houston said the 15,000man corps was disbanded in 1932. About I50 veterans remain in the organization, he said.

title: Bridge: Old Experts Never Die They Just Shuffle Along

But in fact Amer ica's great players have proved to be a highly dur able group. Of the 65 players who have represented this continent in world team championships since 1950, 61 are still living.

title: Pope Paul Expresses Concern for Chileans
description: CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Sept. 16Pope Paul VI ex pressed the hope today that Chile would be spared a civil war, and called for concord among all citizens of a people that is so worthy of esteem.

title: Archibald Rutledge Dies; Poet Laureate in Carolina
description: McCLELLANVILLE, S.C., Sept. 16 (UPI)Archibald Rutledge, poet laureate of South Carolina, died today at Hampton Planta tion near here. He was 90 years old.

title: Mark Set in Loans To Poor Nations
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16  The World Bank reported today record lending of $3.56billion to the lessdeveloped countries in the year ended last June 30, with a shift emphasis toward projects of direct relevance to the bulk of the population.

title: Turkey Races Attract Thousands in Montgomery, Ind.

title: Oil Nations Will Ask Rise In Prices at Oct. 8 Parley
description: VIENNA, Sept. 16In a new campaign to increase their revenues the major oilexport ing nations announced their in tention today to meet with oil company representatives in Vienna on Oct. 8 to revise the industry's basic pricing accords.

title: Film: 'Retour d'Afrique':Tanner Work Explores Boredom in Geneva The Cast
description: Movies about people in the dead-center of boredom are usually difficult to sit through. Boredom is contagious. It is the Asian flu of the arts. Given half a chance, it leaps off the screen to ravage the audience. At $3 to $5 a ticket, it is cheaper to stay home to search for flyspecks on the ceiling of a room that has not seen a fly in years.Alain Tanner, the Swiss director of "CharlesDead or Alive" and, most notably, "La Salamandre," makes films about people who come perilously close to that numbing, anesthetizing dead-center, but escape it, not always for their own good. This is the source of Tanner's comedy, which, in his new film, "Le Retour d'Afrique," is intelligent, humane and just a tiny bit irrelevant, at least to someone who does not share the feeling that he is being overwhelmed by the boredom of life in Switzerland today.Vincent (Franois Marthouret) and his wife Franoise, (Josee Destoop) are young, in love with each other, and thoroughly fed up with their roles as witnesses to great endeavors in other parts of the world, more specifically, the Third World. They live quite comfortably in Geneva, where he works as a gardener and she as an attendant in an art gallery. At night they go to movies with their friends and afterward have ponderous discussions about film, its meaning and its mission. But Vincent and Franois don't want to watch. They want to do.At last Vincent comes to a decision: They must either have a baby or immigrate to Algeria, which is the nearest Third World country they can reach (and the only one where they have a friend to help them get settled). Since Franoise flatly refuses to have a baby, they make preparations for Algeria. They give up their jobs, sell their car and their furniture, and say good-by to their friends, only to have their contact in Algeria cable them at the last minute not to come, that things are not working out there."La Retour d'Afrique" (Return from Africa) is about the emotional return of Vincent and Franoise to Geneva after spending two weeks holed up in their empty apartment as ersatz exiles, hiding from their friends to whom Vincent had grandly explained their emigration by saying: "I don't want to suffocate in my own fat."Much more, perhaps, than Tanner realizes, "Le Retour d'Afrique" is a very Swiss sort of movie. It has no great highs or lows. It is efficient, and it keeps wanting to be funnier than Tanner can quite allow it to be, as if the natural high spirits of Vincent and Franoise would somehow diminish their importance.Far from diminishing their importance, the few scenes in which we see Vincent and Franoise behaving with something on the order of exuberance give them and the film a striking identity. Otherwise, "Le Retour d'Afrique" is too muted, too gray, like the photography that was apparently designed to make Geneva look like the world's dullest suburb that Tanner thinks it is.The performances are attractive, especially those of Miss Destoop, who has a lot of the quality of Cher Buono, when Cher plays it straight, and of Juliet Berto, as a moody and funny Spanish exile in Switzerland.I suspect that the principal problem with "Le Retour d'Afrique" is its screenplay, which Tanner wrote himself. It is never strong enough to prevent the boredom and futility experienced by Vincent and Franoise from seeping into the experience of watching the film. It opened yesterday at the 8th Street Playhouse.

Rivers Stadium, the Pirates, in the final two weeks of their bid for a fourth con secutive division baseball title, the Pittsburgh Steelers staged a successful start to day toward a second straight football title after 39 years of failure.

title: Kings, Queens, Pawns

One backroom deal has followed another in his incongruously jovial and ruthless regime, and the public has been largely excluded  from the decision making process.

title: Pop Music: Getz, Evans and Thornton
description: Carnegie Hall was filled with jazz on Saturday evening. The Stan Getz quartet and Gil Evans's 12piece orchestra were in the main auditorium, while upstairs, in Carnegie Recital Hall, the Clifford Thorn ton quartet was playing. A commuter between the two halls was somewhat startled to find that Mr. Thornton's four men (trumpet, piano or vibes, bass and drums) were achieving much the same color fully kaleidoscopic ensemble effects as Mr. Evans's 12 musi cians. The parallel went farther because the ensemble passages were the meat and essence of both groups, while the solo ists tended to ramble on with dwindling effectiveness.

title: Austin Captures U.S. Tennis Title
description: APTOS, Calif., Sept. 16 (AP)Jeff Austin won the United States hardcourt ten nis championship today by upsetting Onny Parun of New Zealand, 76, 64, in the final. It was his first national men's title.

description: FINNISH LINE Here's your chance, possibly a onceinalifetime chance, to catch up with the movie situation in Finland all at one swoop in New York, from today through Sept. 29. The Finnish Film Festival is running at the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center, 63d Street and Broad way (7992200, ext. 248). It consists of 13 films, only one of which has been seen here previously. A few, date from the nineteenfifties, but most are from the late sixties and the seventies. One has not even been seen in Finland, a new film, One Man's War, directed by Risto Jarva, having its world premiere at 6:30 Friday at the festival.

title: Report Scores Nursing Homes on Medicaid Claims
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt reported yesterday that Medi caid claims by nursing homes in New York City had more than trebled in four years to reach $262.3million last year. He called for greater state cosk control efforts.

Corbett, president of the state's twomillionmem ber branch of the American Federation of Labor and Con gress of Industrial Organiza tions, said tonight that Con gress should override President Nixon's veto of a bill to in crease the minimum wage to $2.20 a hour as a means of re ducing welfare payments.

title: Peace in the Schools . . .
description: The opening of the nation's schools, often marred recent years by conflict and even violence, has been accomplished this month in a generally encouraging atmosphere of peace. There have been the customary teachers' strikes; but even such disruptions appear less numerous and less acrimonious than during the previous decade.

description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 16 Thousands of Argentine youths marched through this capital tonight in protest against the military coup d'dtat in Chile and Yankee Imperialism.

description: A test of the recordshatter ing 10 per cent prime rate begun last week by the Wells Fargo Bank and since adopted by five others  may come this week even before other banks have an opportunity to act. And the outcome is being awaited in the credit markets.

title: HASSAN IS KEEPING OPPOSITION AT BAY
description: RABAT, Morocco, Sept. 15 After two summers of near disaster, King Hassan II ap pears to have made a strong comeback, displaying his popu larity with Morocco's masses, dealing harshly with his op ponents and working harder than ever before.

title: Milk Up 8c a Gallon
description: TRENTON, Sept. 16 (AP) The minimum price of a gallon of milk in New Jersey in creased by 8 cents today, bring ing the total increase to 22 cents in the past year. The raise brought minimum milk prices to $1.18 a gallon, 62 cents a half gallon and 33.5 cents a quart.

title: OSPITAL RENAMED AMID PROTESTERS

title: ARMY IN GERMANY DROPS DRUG DRIVE
description: BAST, Sept. 16An Army Special training platoon pro gram, designed to instill in sus pected drug users fear of being caught and punished for illegal acts, was canceled last week after a television news team tried to make a film about it, an Army spokesman in Bad Kreuznach said today.

title: PANEL ON FETUSES PASSED IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 The Senate has passed a bill that would establish a national commission for the protection of human subjects of medical experiments and charged it with special responsibilites to weigh the ethics of psycho surgery and research involving the live aborted human fetus. In the case of fetal research, an amendment to the bill called for a temporary ban on use of Federal funds or facilities for studies involving any fetus re moved from the mother's body in the course of therapeutic abortion. The ban would be effective until the proposed commission established its own guidelines on this subject.

title: Yanks Lose To Orioles, Then Win

title: POOR READER SUES COAST EDUCATORS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 16 (AP)Peter W. Doe is an 18 yearold boy from a middle class family. Throughout his school years he attended class regularly, caused no disciplin ary problems and got his high school diploma on schedule.

Beyond a cer tain threshold, the per capita energy consumption of one class imposes ex ploitative social relations, no matter how much energy the poor consume.

title: Government Unit in China Promotes Family Planning
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 16 China, whose mammoth popu lation is swelling at a rate of a least 15 million people a year has disclosed the existence a a highlevel state organizatior specifically devoted to the pro motion of birth control.

title: Richard Ross Weds Patricia E. Holstein
description: Miss Patricia Ellen Holstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Holstein of New York and Roslyn Heights, L.I., was married here yester day to Richard David Ross, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Ross of Miami Beach.

title: Finn Equals World Mark
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 16 (AP)  MonaLisa Pur siainen of Finland equaled the women's 400meter world record today with a time of 51.0 seconds in an interna tional track and field meet.

title: Look Ahead to Theater Hits of '50's
description: Remember the theater in the nineteenfifties? A Raisin in the Sun, Look Home ward, Angel, Picnic, Pa jama Game, The Visit, The Waltz of the Toreadors. And Gigi, the big movie musical of 1958. Watch for them again on Broadway this seasonmost of them in dif ferent guise. There will also be a new version of the musi cal Candide in Brooklyn.For those with slightly longer memories, there will be several reruns of hits of the forties. Carol Channing will star in still another mu sical version of Gentlemen Prefer Blondesnow called Lorelei, The Lincoln Center production of A Streetcar Named Desire will move to Broadway. And for true nos talgia, two Andrews Sisters, Patti and Maxene, will star in Over Here, a musical sa lute to the U.S.O. canteens of World War II.

title: Your Next President
description: Political prophecy has become un reliable; nevertheless, we can predict that the next Presidentwhether he is Republican or Democrat, and takes office by election or successionwill have an operating style sharply con trasting with Richard Nixon's.

title: SOCIALISTS SEEM NARROW VICTORS IN SWEDISH VOTE
description: STOCKHOLM, Monday, Sept. 17  The Social Democratic party, in power here for 41 years, apparently won, a narrow victory early this morning over a nonSocialist coalition in the tightest election in modern Swedish history.

title: SOCIALISTS SEEM NARROW VICTORS IN SWEDISH VOTE
description: STOCKHOLM, Monday, Sept. 17The Social Democratic party, in power here for 41 years, apparently won a narrow. victory early this morning over a nonSocialist coalition in the tightest election in modern Swedish history.

title: Dave Anderson
description: On the roofs of the old, worn brick apartment houses behind the Yankee Stadium bleachers, the TV antennas resembled scarecrows against the sky. In other years, dozens of people were up on those roofs, peering down for free on what they could see of the New York Giants' game. But yesterday, only three men were observed up there, two together to the left of the scoreboard, one to the right. Their TV sets weren't working or they don't own any, because yesterday, by Federal law, the Giants were playing a Yankee Stadium game that was on TV here. You could turn on your TV set and watch them disassemble the Houston Oilers, 3414, for free unless you were among the 3,850 people with purchased tickets who didn't bother to use them. The attend ance, a voice announced in the press box in the fourth quarter, 57,979 came through the turnstiles, 3,850 bought tickets but did not come.

title: Gorilla and Leopard Stolen
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (AP)A baby gorrilla and a rare baby, snow leopard, said to be val ued at $10,000, were stolen to day from the Lincoln Park Zoo.

title: Two Union Officials Deny Embezzlement of $170,000
description: Two union officials accused of embezzling $170,000 from union funds pleaded not guilty yesterday.

title: Wood, Field and Stream:
description: The time may come when hatcheryreared Atlantic sal mon stocked in certain small rivers, which are riot now ma jor salmonproducing streams, will provide substantial har vests of the species, says Lee Wulff, director of the Inter national Atlantic Salmon Foundation.

title: Cuba, in U.N., Says Nixon Instigated Chilean Coup
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept, 17  Cuba today accused President Nixon of having in stigated the coup in Chile last week in which the Marxist Government of President Sal vador Allende Gossens was overthrown.

title: CHRYSLER REACHES TENTATIVE ACCORD WITH AUTO UNION
description: DETROIT, Sept 17  The striking United Automobile Workers reached a tentative settlement today with the Chrysler Corporation that was described as precedentset ting and a breakthrough in giving the industrial worker more say over how long he will work and under what condi tions.

title: Dr. Oskar Halecki Dies at 82; Polish Historian, Teacher Here
description: Dr. Oskar Halecki, a leading historian in Poland until the onset of World War II, died yesterday in White Plains Hos pital. He was 82 years old and lived at 35 Barker Avenue, White Plains.

title: Capt. Al Cohol, Heroic Superdrunk, Fights Booze in Canadian North
description: MONTREAL Sept. 16The Government of the Northwest Territories has published a se ries of comic, books attacking alcoholism, which is one of the main social problems of Can ada's bleak frozen North.

title: LifeSize Presidents
description: Senator Walter Mondale of Minne sota is proposing the appointment of a national commission to recommend ways and means of making the Presi dency open and accountable to the American people and to Congress. The need for a lifesize Presidency is clear, but who needs another na tional commission?

title: Prices of Stocks Climb Despite Plunge by I.B.M.
description: The stock market weathered 126point plunge in Internation 11 Business Machines  the afl ame favorite among glamour is mesto forge ahead yesterday pri higher volume. The Dow tones industrial average, which foes not include I.B.M. rose 3.63 points to 892.99.

title: Yorktown Heights, Newburgh Schools Struck by Teachers
description: School strikes in the state spread yesterday. Teachers in Newburgh and Yorktown Heights, walked out, joining those in Harrison and Green burgh who have been picketing since the first day of school, Sept. 5. A union official said that the schools of Crotonon Hudson might be the next to be struck.

title: Insurance Held Valid for BlownUp 747
description: Federal District Judge Mar vin E. Frankel ruled, yesterday that 30 American and British insurance companies must pay Pair American World Airways $24,3million for a Boeing 747 jetliner destroyed by members of an Arab terrorist group in Cairo three years ago.

title: Stripping the Land
description: Every week in the year, some 4,650 acres of the sur face of the United States are stripped away for the coal that is to be found a few feet beneath. For years the streams of such Eastern states as West Virginia and Ken tucky have been choked with silt and poisoned by acids. Hills have been eroded, trees uprooted and the landscape left desolate with spoil banks. Now these badlands are moving westward at a sickening rate as strippable coal deposits are exploited from New Mexico to Montana.

title: Chile's Junta Said to Plan Military Trials for 5,200
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 17 A senior official said here today that 5,200 civilians de tained during the military takeover of Chile would be tried by courtmartial.

title: U.S. ATTORNEY NAMES CIVIL DIVISION CHIEF
description: John W. Nields Jr. was named yesterday to succeed Michael D. Hess as chief of the civil division in the United States Attorney's office here.

title: Pyromaniac Is Hunted
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 17 (AP)City Fire Chief Charles McRedmond has asked for po lice assistance in finding the insane person responsible for setting 10 fires in Stamford this month. The most recent fire of suspicious origin destroyed a vacant twoandahalfstory wooden building on West Avenue, officials said.

title: New Top Enlisted Man In Air Force Is a Black
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP)The Air Force today selected Chief M. Sgt. Thomas N. Barnes, a black, to be its top enlisted man.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:

title: Amex Stocks Irregular
description: Activity on the American Stock Exchange continued Fri day's erratic behavior. Prices were mixed, but the number of advances led declines and the Amex market value index was off, although only 3 of its 16 components showed a de crease.

title: POMPIDOU ENDS VISIT TO CHINA IN LOW KEY
description: SHANGHAI, Sept. 17 (Reu ters)President Pompidou of France left China today after a weeklong visit marked by great cordiality, but no major new initiative in Chinese French relations.

title: Congress's Female Alter Egos
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  They come from the worlds of politics, journalism and academia, often by way of stenographic pools, and some wield rare power in the maledominated landscape of Washington politics.

title: COOP CITY STRIKE ENTERS A 4TH DAY
description: Garbage spilled from its con tainers at Coop City in the Bronx yesterday as a threeday strike by maintenance men, porters and security guards stopped the area's 55,000 resi dents from using their incinera tors and compactors.

title: SCHOOL LUNCH AID URGED IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  School lunch officials, appear ing before the Senate Select Committee on Nutrition and Human Needs, urged Congress today to approve an escalator clause to increase the Federal Government's contribution to the school lunch program..

title: Philadelphians Play Committee Music
description: PEKING, Sept. 17About the worst condemnation in China is to be called an in dividualist. Almost every thing is done by committee. Musicians of the Philadelphia Orchestra have been finding this out. Music here is com posed by committee. At the end of the performance of the Yellow River Concerto tonight, four composers came on stage to share the bows. The score is a communal effort,

title: Basketball Transactions
description: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION

title: Percy Now Would Support A 10 Pct. Tax Surcharge
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (UPI)  Senator Charles H. Percy re yersed today a previous stand and said he would support a proposal for a 10 per cent sur charge on the Federal income tax.

title: Heath Encounters Irish Snag on Timing
description: DUBLIN, Sept. 17  Prime Ministers Edward Heath and Liam Cosgrave failed to agree today on a timetable for es tablishing the proposed Coun cil of Ireland, a body that would provide a link between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic and keep alive the hopes for eventual unification.

title: Expos Win, 54, Then Lose, 53 in 12th
description: MONTREAL Sept. 17 (UPI) As five St. Louis players let Ron Wood's pop fly to the mound with two out in the ninth inning drop for a single, Felipe Alou scored the winning run from second base tonight and the Montreal Expos downed the Cardinals, 54, in the first game of a doubleheader.

title: Ousted Brooklyn Tenants Promised CoOps by City
description: Tenants from the Northside community in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, who are being relocated to permit ex pansion of a factory, will be in new, permanent homes by next summer, city officials said yesterday.

title: Ervin Rejects Demand To End Panel Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP)Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., Democrat of North Caro lina, rejected today a demand from the Republican Gover nor of New Hampshire that the Senate Watergate com mittee halt its hearings.

title: NORMAN WILSON, EDUCATOR, DEAD
description: PUTNEY, Vt., Sept. 17Nor man H. Wilson, former direc tor of the Asian Center in Tok yo of the American Friends Service Committee, and until recently director of the An tiochPutney Graduate School of Education, died here Satur day of cancer. He was 47 years old and had recently been named director of school serv ices for the School for Interna tional Training in Brattleboro.

title: Rockefeller Cites Lesson In the Shock of Watergate
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., Sept. 17Governor Rockefeller de clared here tonight that the Watergate scandal ultimately could become a very signifi cant turning point for America by reversing a sense of moral decay that he said had tragical ly permeated all phases of this nation's economic and so cial life.

title: Priest Who Quit to Marry Will Be Rep. Waldie's Aide
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 17 (UPI)A former priest who resigned to marry a divorced mother of three will work as a poitical aide to Representa tive Jerome Waldie, Democrat of California who is a guberna torial hopeful.

title: Giants' Thompson Sidelined
