description: Rocky Thompson, who felt good enough to go dancing after the New York Giants' openinggame victory last Sunday, learned yesterday that he would be sidelined for at least four weeks with a neck injury.

title: People and Business
description: Harvey Berkey, 30year old son of Benjamin Berkey, 62, the founder of Berkey Photo, Inc., a leading com pany in photo processing and the manufacture and importa tion of cameras and photo graphic equipment, has been elected president of the com pany.

title: I.B.M. Is Found Guilty in Antitrust Suit And Told to Pay Telex $352.5Million
description: TULSA, Okla., Sept. 17  The International Business Ma chines Corporation was found guilty today of violations of the Sherman Antitrust Act and ordered to pay triple damages of $352.5million to the Telex Corporation, a manufacturer of peripheral equipment for com puters.

title: Il Trovatore Opens New Met Season
description: At 8:25 last night, anyone who had bought a ticket for the Metropolitan Opera's 89th opening night, or anyone who had been invited, was inside the opera house watching the curtain come up on Verdi's Il Trovatore. But not every one who wanted to be inside was.

title: British Soccer
description: FIRST DIVISION

title: Varehouse Damaged By Fire
description: DETROIT, Sept. 17 (AP) The top three floors of a furniture warehouse collapsed yesterday during a fire that burned out of control for more than four hours, filling the downtown area with smoke.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The West Side Highway Project will probably not be able to meet its Dec. 15 date for public hearings on the various alternative proposals for reconstructing the obso lete highway, Lowell K. Bridwell, executive director of the project, said yesterday. I doubt it can be done, he said at a monthly meeting of the project's steering com mittee in its offices at 19 Rector Street.

title: ABITIBI RESUMES PAPER PRODUTION
description: Newsprint production re sumed yesterday at the largest plant of the Abitibi Paper Corn pany at Iroquois Falls, Ont., but contract disputes remained unsettled at three other paper makers.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
New Tropical Storm Born
description: MIAMI, Sept. 17 (AP)Trop ical Storm Ellen was spawned today in the Atlantic, 2,700 miles eastsoutheast of Miami. The storm holds winds of up to 60 miles an hour, the Na tional Hurricane Center in Miami reported.

title: Loan Reforms Asked By SelfHelp Groups
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  Zepresentatives of organiza tions that are trying to finance selfhelp activities in poor communities said today new Federal legislation was needed they are ever to get the nec essary funds.

title: MORE BANKS RAISE PRIME RATE TO 107,
description: The move to a 10 per cent prime rate broadened a bit yes terday as several more major banks followed the lead of the Wells Fargo Bank, which moved up from the 9 per cent level last Thursday.

title: U.S. Analysis Links Big Oil Imports Gain To Eased. Air Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  The Nixon Administration, put ting new pressure on states and cities to relax cleanair stand ards for the winter heating sea son, said today that such action could increase imports of heat ing oil by up to 400;000 barrels a day.

title: Hogan Has Had a Stroke And LungTumor Surgery
description: District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of Manhattan suffered a minor stroke on Aug. 10 and was taken to St. Luke's Hos pital, where he underwent sur gery for a lung tumor on Sept. 7, Joseph C. Hogan, his brother, said late yesterday.

title: News Summary and Index
description: A senior official in Santiago, Chile, said that 5,200 civilians detained during the mili tary takeover of the country would be tried by courtmartial under wartime military laws. The ruling military junta has said that 4,000 supporters of President Salvador Al lende Gossens, who died in the coup d'tat, were being held. [Page 1, Columns 23.]

title: Dollar Weakens Here In Moderate Trading
description: The dollar weakened in re lation to key European cur rencies yesterday in moderate trading on foreignexchange markets here. Dealers said that the easing was the re sult of dollar liquidation, in reaction to the 5 per cent up ward revaluation of the Dutch guilder during the weekend.

title: Fall Lawn Reseeding Will Cost More
description: ALBANY, Sept. 17With the beginning of the fall planting season  the best time to put in a new lawn or repair an old onehome owners are facing a shortage of grass seed and a sky rocketing increase in its price. Since, spring, the cost has more than doubled.

title: Pastore Says Scalpers Caused NoShows
description: Facing an obvious wetold youso situation by the Na tional Football League own ers and commissioner Pete Rozelle, Senator John O. Pas tore, Democrat of Rhode Island, suggested yesterday that the reason behind 49,551 absentees at nine pro foot ball games on Sunday was scalpers.

title: TV Review
description: For Sundays at 7:30 P.M., the Columbia Broadcasting System has taxed its imag ination and come forth with a series called The New Perry Mason, starring Monte Markham. Not surprisingly, and not without justification, reruns of the old Perry Mason, starring Raymond Burr, are now being billed in some markets as The Real Perry Mason.

title: Rangers Start Huffing and Puffing Under New Coach
description: KITCHENER, Ontario, Sept. 17Changes have been so rapid in this burgeoning coln mlinity that the barber shop down the road now adver tises, Two barbersno wait ing.

title: Cassidy Outpoints Dupree at Forum
description: Irish Bobby Cassidy, a lightheavyweight from Levit town, L. I., scored a unani mous decision over Jimmy Dupree of Jersey City last nigth in a 10round bout at the Felt Forum.

title: Westinghouse Is Awarded
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation was awarded a $30million contract yesterday as prime contractor for a 132, 000  kilowatt steam  electric generating plant for the Corpo racion Electrica de la Costa At lantica of Barranquilla, Colom bia.

title: Fall Lawn Reseeding Will Cost More
description: ALBANY, Sept. 17With the beginning of the fall planting season  the best time to put in a new lawn or repair an old onehome owners are facing a shortage of grass seed and a sky rocketing increase in its price. Since spring, the cost has more than doubled.

title: Steel Industry Gain In Output for Week Largest This Year
description: The steel industry rebounded in the week ended Sept. 15 to score the largest percentage gain in production for any single week to date this year.

title: Pirates Chase Seaver, Beat Mets, 103
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 17 Repeatedly repressed by Torn Seaver the past five years, the Pittsburgh Piratse explo sively rebelled against their master tonight.

title: KICKBACKS CITED AT PASSAIC SCHOOL
description: PATERSON, Sept. 17The head of a supply company that did almost $279,000 worth of business with the Passaic County Technical and Voca tional High School, testified to day that he paid about 5 per cent of that amount in com missions to Alex Smollok, the school's business manager.

title: CITY TO TIGHTEN RELOCATION RULES
description: The Lindsay administration announced yesterday a series of administrative changes and a legislative proposal designed to tighten control over hous ing relocation companies, some of which have been accused by the city or state of having ha rassed tenants to force them to move from private buildings scheduled for demolition. Most of the buildings involved are rent controlled.

title: RICHFIELD JOINING IN GAS PRICE RISE
description: The Atlantic Richfield Com pany announced yesterday that it would go along with the in dustry trend, increasing the wholesale price of gasoline and distillat s by 1 cent a gallon under Cost of Living Council regulations.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Cambodia Reports New Attack At Beleagured Provincial City
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sept. 17 (AP)The Cambodian command said today that insur gent forces renewed attacks on paratrooper positions around the airport at the provincial capital of Kompong Cham, end ing a lull of several days.

title: Advertising: Airline Split Seen
description: One of the most frequently heard rumors of doom in ad vertising  that American Airlines and Doyle Dane Bern bach are splittingappears now close to being true, ac cording to an authoritative source.

title: The Importance of Hatchery Salmon
description: Wulff noted that Iceland, whose Atlantic salmon man agement has been good enough to make her fishing, once very ordinary in com parison with other areas of the North Atlantic, now the best in the world. . . . [and] Iceland's rivers are harvest ed primarily by angling. It seems ridiculous to pay peo ple to do a service a host of anglers are anxious to pay to perform.

title: 2 BLOCS ARE TIED IN SWEDISH VOTING
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 17  Sweden faced a period of political uncertainty today after nearfinal election results showed the governing Social Democrats and their nonSocial ist challengers in an absolute deadlock in the fight for Parliament.

title: Connally Hailed at Start of 60Day Tour
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 17  The band played The Eyes of Texas Are Upon You and huge slide was projected be fore the audience of 2,600 farmers that said: Honorable John B. Connally, A Distin guished American.

title: 2 BLOCS ARE TIED IN SWEDISH VOTING
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 17  Sweden faced a period of political uncertainty today after nearfinal election results showed the governing, Social Democrats and their nonSocial ist challengers in an absolute deadlock in the fight for Parliament.

title: Wiretaps Termed No Bar To Approval of Kissinger
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17A special Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee reported today that Henry A. Kissinger's role in the wiretapping of 17 offi cials and newsmen from 1969 to 1971 was not such as to bar him from confirmation as Secretary of State.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Fell at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 Yields on United States Treas ury bills fell in the Govern ment's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Ogden Unit Gets Ship Order
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 17 (UPI)  The Ogden Corpora tion's Avondale shipyards sub sidiary has signed contracts totalling $322.5million to build three more large liquified natural gas carriers for the El Paso Natural Gas Company, bringing its total to six. The latest order is subject to approval of subsidies by the Federal Maritime Commission and the financing of El Paso's second Algerian gas project be fore April 1.

title: Plebe Puts Genuine Kick Into Navy's Maneuvers
description: Navy had little trouble beating Virginia Military, 378, in the Middies' opener Saturday as Cleveland Cooper ran for 172 yards in 25 car ries. Also, Navy and its new coach, George Welsh, came up with a bonus in Steve Dykes, a plebe (freshman) placekicker. Dykes equaled the Navy single game record with three field goals. He does it with out a shoe on his kicking foot al though he keeps his sock on. . . . Another freshman place kicker, Bruce Crystal of Le high, gave the Engineers a 2220 victory over Connecti cut, Saturday, when he booted a 33yard field goal with a minute and nine seconds re maining. The freshman from Scarsdale, N. Y., keeps his shoe on. . . . Tennessee's placekicker, Ricky Town send, is the best of the no shoe booters. The junior in creased his career conversion string to 34 in a row as the Vols beat Duke, 2117, Sat urday. Townsend said, The reason I kick better without a shoe is that in being a soccerstyle kicker the bot tom of my shoe would hit the ground as I swing through to meet the ball. . . Ten nessee plays at Army this week in the Cadets' opener. Army has its own fine place kicker in Jim Barclay, who has won six games for us in the last two seasons, ac cording to Coach Tom Cahill. barclay wears shoes.

title: Chauffeured Limousines at Issue in Senate Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 Every weekday morning, James T. Lynn, Secretary of Housing and Urban Develop ment, climbs into a chauf feurdriven limousine in sub urban Maryland and is whisked to his office.

title: Hugo Winterhalter Dead at 64; '50's Popular Music Arranger
description: Hugo Winterhalter, whose lush arrangements of popular tunes in the nineteenfifties helped 11 records sell more than 1 million copies, died of cancer yesterday in Greenwich (Conn) Hospital. He was 64 years old.

title: Engagements
description: PACKARDBIRD. The engagement Is an nounced between Richard Bruce Selig, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. J. Packard of 13 Acacia Gardens, St. John's Wood, London, N.W. 8, and Veronica Susan, elder daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. M. G. Bird of Abingdon Villas, London, W. 8. England.

title: Union Beach Puts Ecology Second to a Power Plant
description: UNION BEACH, Sept. 17 An aroused public in this Rari tan Bay town of 7,000 packed an environmental impact hear ing this morning to oppose con servationists and to demand that the way be cleared for the building of a $200million pow er plant in a portion of the Raritan Bay's wetlands within the borough.

title: Policeman Charged In Drug Case Loses A Reinstatement Bid
description: A police officer who has been suspended for allegedly selling $35 worth of marijuana was denied yesterday a request that he be restored to duty and be given rehabilitation in the same way that the Police Depart ment tries to help alcoholics.

title: Nets Defeat 76ers In Preseason Debut
description: BINGHAMPTON, N.Y., Sept. 17Kevin Loughery's preseason coaching debut was a success tonight as his New York Nets of the Amer ican Basketball Association defeated the Philadelphia 76eres, 9488, at Veterans Memorial Arena. Loughery coached the 76ers last season when they compiled the worst record in National Bas ketball Association history.

title: CHRYSLER REACHES TENTATIVE ACCORD WITH AUTO UNION
description: DETROIT, Sept 17  The striking United Automobile Workers reached a tentative settlement today with the Chrysler Corporation that was. described by Leonard Wood cock, the union president, as, a breakthrough in giving the industrial worker more say over how long he will work and un der what conditions.

title: Unity Effort by 3 Arab Nations Puts Guerrillas on the Defensive
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 17 The coordination by Egypt, Jordan and Syria of a unified position toward Israel, ap parently in preparation for po litical negotiations, has placed the Palestinian guerrilla move ment on the defensive.

title: Policeman Charged In Drug Case Loses A Reinstatement Bid
description: A police officer who has been suspended for allegedly selling $35 worth of marijuana was denied yesterday a request that he be restored to duty and be given rehabilitation in the same way that the Police Depart ment tries to help alcoholics.

title: Tests Criticized, France Quits. Pacific Parley
description: TUMON BAY, Guam, Sept. 17 France today walked out of the annual meeting of the South Pacific Conference, a regional aid body, when repre sentatives of island territories strongly condemned the recent French nuclear tests over Mururoa.

title: JOHN BEFFEL DEAD; AIDED SACCO DEFENSE
description: John Nicholas Beffel, a news paperman who turned to pub licity and fundraising for so cialist and anarchist defend ants, including the Mooney Billings and SaccoVanzetti cases, died Sunday in Polyclinic Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived at the De Witt Nurs ing Home, 21 East 79th Street.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Colonel Qaddafi in nationalizing the oil interests in Libya may have done us a historic favor. It has impelled Western statesmen, including Presi dent Nixon, to consider a new long range approach to the solution of the oil crisis. The irony of recent history is that the power of the monopolies (of the West) has had to give way to the monopoly of power of the Middle East. It signifies nothing less than that the age of oil imperialism is coming to an end. We have no choice but to face up to it.

title: U.S. Neither Denies Nor Confirms Taps On Nixon's Brother
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  The Treasury Department, in voking executive privilege, re fused today to tell Senator Joseph M. Montoya whether, President Nixon had instructed the Secret Service to wiretap the telephone of his brother F. Donald Nixon.

title: COMPETITORS HAIL DECISION ON I.B.M.
description: The Computer Industry As sociation, which includes about two dozen companies in the field but not the International Business Machines Corpora tion, yesterday cheered a court decision ordering I.B.M. to pay $352million to the Telex Cor poration in an antitrust suit. The computer group asserted that the court has now estab lished what everyone has long knownthat I.B.M. is in viola tion of antitrust laws.

title: Denver Woman Gives Birth to Sextuplets
description: DENVER, Sept. 17  A 34 yearold woman who had re ceived injections of a fertility hormone gave birth to sex tuplets here late last night.

title: Wiretaps Termed No Bar To Approval of Kissinger
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17A special Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee reported today that Henry A. Kissinger's role in the wiretapping of 17 offi cials and newsmen from 1969 to 1971 was not such as to bar him from confirmation as Secretary of State.

title: SOYBEAN AND CORN RISE DAILY LIMIT
description: Rainy weather in some Mid west growing areas and cold weather in the upper Midwest prompted scare buying and short covering into the Chicago Board of Trade's markets yes terday. Prices of many soy bean and corn contracts jumped the daily permissible limits yes terday, and closed strong. Wheat prices also rose sharply.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Bridge:
description: Skill in card play is to some extent measurable. Most players firmly believe that they are above average in this department, but how much above? Are you in the best 10 per cent? Or the best 1 per cent?

title: Goolagong Signs With Net League
description: World Team Tennis served another ace in its bid for rec ognition yesterday when the Pittsburgh Triangles an nounced the signing of Evonne Goolagong to a gen erous multiyear contract.

title: SCHOOL DISSIDENTS LOSE COURT ROUND
description: East Flatbush parents lost an attempt yesterday to have court overturn the recent ap pointment of Norman Desser as principal of Public School 208 in Brooklyn.

title: Weather or Not in Television Land
description: One of the most vivid recollections of my boyhood, said Wellington Mara, president of the Giants, was the sight of my father on Saturday nights during the foot ball season. Pop kept walking to the front window, peer ing out into the darkness to see if there were any rain clouds obscuring the stars. Weather meant everything us in the old days. It was the difference between losing money, breaking even or maybe even making a little.

title: New Appointments Announced By The Metropolitan Museum
description: The director of Houston's Museum of Fine Arts and the former director of the Min neapolis Institute of Arts will join the staff of the Metro politan Museum of Art, the museum's president, Douglas Dillon, has announced.

title: FRUEHAUF LISTS MERGER DETAILS
description: The merger proposal of the Fruehauf Corporation and the KelseyHayes Company involv ing an exchange of stock valued at about $92million, an nounced a month ago, will in clude a tender offer for Kelsey Hayes stockholders.

title: Steuben Accepts OTB
description: BATH, N.Y., Sept. 17 (UPI) The Steuben County board of Supervisors voted, 244. today to join 18 other mu nicipalities, including Buffalo and Rochester, in the West ern Regional Offtrack Betting Corporation. The board said it expected to get about 3 per cent of the system's total revenue through its partici pation.

title: Shift of Morristown High Pupils Opposed Because of Racial Mix
description: MORRIS TOWNSHIP, Sept. 17  Dr. Harry W. Wenner, Morris School District super intendent, said today that the racial balance at Morristown High School would be negatively affected if Harding Township's pupils were allowed to withdraw.

title: Now in Pittsburgh, It's Beef at 1945 Prices
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 17 Thousands of persons, at tracted by a sale of beef at prices as much as $1 a pound below regular prices, con verged today on a downtown market.

title: S.E.C. SUES CONCERN BASED IN BAHAMAS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (Reuters)The Securities and Exchange Commission said to day that it had filed suit against a Bahamas company, three Ca nadians and two Britons, charg ing them with selling unregi stered stock in the United States.

title: Moscow Patriarch, in Geneva, Defends Church's Role in East
description: GENEVA, Sept. 17  Patri arch Pimen of Moscow, head of the Russian Orthodox Church, today rejected West ern charges that the churches in Eastern Europe fail to de nounce injustices in their own countries.

title: Equity Financing
description: A secondary offering of 400,000 common shares of Citizens & Southern National Bank of Georgia at 22 per share was made by Salomon Brothers. The company's stock, traded overthecounter, closed 22 bid, 22 asked, down .

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LONDON, Sept. 17 (UPI)Danny McAlinden, the British and Commonwealth heavyweight champion, pulled out of a fight tonight against Tim Wood, former British Amateur Boxing Association champion, when the Board of Control refused to guarantee that McAlinden's titles would not be at stake.

title: American Airlines Calling Smith, 74, Back to Run It
description: C. R. Smith, the 74yearold Texan who left American Air lines five years ago after build ing it into a colossus, is ex pected to be called back to morrow as chairman of the financially sagging company.

title: Sir Christopher Steel, 70, Occupation Aide in Germany
description: LONDON, Sept. 17  Sir Christopher Steel, deputy high commissioner of the Allied oc cupation forces in Germany in 1949 and later ambassador in West Germany, died today in a hospital at Swindon, Wiltshire. His age was 70.

title: Funds to Train Counselors For Handicapped Are Ending
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) The Nixon Administration is quetly eliminating its pro grams to train counselors and other professionals who work with deaf, blind and Crippled persons.

title: Study Finds Women Academicians' Salaries Lag
description: More women graduate from American high schools than men, they receive better grades in college, and they apply them selves as diligently to their work, but they do not achieve anything near parity with men in academic rank and salary, according to the latest report by the Carnegie Commission on Higher Education.

title: JOB BIAS CHARGED TO 4 COMPANIES AND MAJOR UNIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  The Federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, in the most extensive concerted action of its eightyear history, has notified four of America's big gest corporations and several major unions that charges of job discrimination have been filed against them.

title: Congress's Female Alter Egos
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  They come from the worlds of politics, journalism and academia, often by way of stenographic pools, and some wield rare power in the maledominated landscape of Washington politics.

title: Corruption in South Vietnam Seems Worse
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 17Lam is an epileptic and mentally retarded, but he was drafted into the South Vietnamese Army anyway be cause his family could not afford the bribe demanded by Government officials to certify him as unfit. Now, a year later, Lam has finally been discharged after his father went into debt to raise the million piasters ($2,000) the of ficials wanted.

title: Noe, Racing Secretary, Is Hard Man to Satisfy
description: On the basis of what went on at Belmont Park on Sat urday, when Secretariat broke a world record in win ning the $250,000 Marlboro Cup, and Desert Vixen was equally impressive in winning the $109,800 Beldame Stakes it would seem that Kenny Noe would have been completely satis fied with those momentous devel opments. Not so, said Noe, in a brief resting period at his busy office yesterday. The 45 yearold racing secretary of the New York Racing Associ ation, cited several instances that he called unsatisfactory.

title: DANNY BELCASTRO
description: WESTBURY, L.I. Sept. 17 Danny Belcastro, former com missioner of the American Softball Association for the metropolitan area, died today in North Shore Hospital after having suffered a heart attack at his home, 581 Lowell Street. He was 58 years old and was associated with the patron services department of Roose velt Raceway.

title: Industry Group Tries to End Confusion Over Meat Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 A standardized identification system for labeling various cuts of beef, pork, veal, and lamb, was unveiled today by the National Live Stock and Meat Board for the meat in dustry.

title: American Airlines Calling Smith, 74, Back to Run It
description: C. R. Smith, the 74yearold Texan who left American Air lines five years, ago after build ing it into a colossus, is ex pected to be called back to morrow as chairman of the financially sagging company.

title: F.D.A. RECALL NEWS TO BE RESTRICTED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  The Food and Drug Adminis tration plans to end soon its present policy of issuing a news release every time it recalls a drug or other product that is found to present a threat to the safety of consumers.

title: Miss Frances Poublon Wed to Jack B. Harris
description: Miss Frances Poublon, daughter of Col. and Mrs. Eugene Poublon of Buren, the Netherlands, was mar ried yesterday to Jack Brown Harris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sam Harris of New York. The civil ceremony took place in the Chateau at Zeist, the Netherlands.

title: Trade and Freedom
description: In calling on President Nixon yesterday to give voice to American concern over Moscow's latest assaults on individual liberties, the Senate emphasized that progress toward dtente with the Soviet Union need not and should not involve sacrifice of this country's right to speak out in behalf of human freedom.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NORMAL OPERATION The New York Philharmonic, ending a summer of playing in the parks, in the neighbor hoods and to people sitting on rugs, starts a new regu lar season tonight, playing to an audience that comes in and sits on seats in Phil harmonic Hall, 63d Street and Broadway (8742424). Tonight's concert has Pierre Boulez conducting the or chestra's traditional pension fund benefit opener, and there are still some seats left at $15. However, tickets generally cost $3.50 to $9 for each concert in the 32 week subscription series that starts Thursday at 8:30 and will have run through 117 performances before wrap ping it up on May 18.

title: Nationalist Guerrillas Seize Black Children in Rhodesia
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 17A number of black child ren in a remote tribal area of northeastern Rhodesia were kidnapped by marauding na tionalist guerrillas in an ex cursion across the border from Mozambique Wednesday night, the Rhodesian Government dis closed today.

title: MRS. JACK R. GOLDBERG
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., Sept. 17 Mrs. Sally Sandler Goldberg, wife of Dr. Jack R. Goldberg, dean of the Graduate School of Social Work of New York Uni versity and former, Commis sioner of Social Services, died yesterday at her home, 15 Black Birch Lane. She was 51 years old.

title: SEGRETTI AGREES TO PLEAD GUILTY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 Donald H. Segretti, who was hired to play tricks on the Dem ocrats in the 1972 Presidential campaign, has agreed to plead guilty to an expanded four count indictment charging cam paign law violations and to co operate with the Watergate special prosecutor.

title: Oct., 23 Trial Is Set For Mitchell and Stans
description: A new starting date of Oct. 23 was set yesterday for the trial of former Attorney Gen eral John N. Mitchell and former Secretary of Com merce Maurice H. Stans in Federal District Court here.

title: Agnew Said to Hold Long Discussions About Resigning
description: WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Sept. 18 (UPI)Vice President Agnew, under investigation for alleged bribery, extortion and tax law violations, has held lengthy discussions about re signing, The Washington Post reported today.

title: Standoffs in Scandinavia
description: The pattern of recent elections in three of the four Scandinavian countries is astonishingly consistent: Voters in great numbers are dissatisfied with the forces of social democracy but have not yet decided on a clearcut, viable alternative.

title: PanAmerican Road Put Off Indefinitely
description: PANAMA, Sept. 17  The United States and Panama have abandoned their original inten tion to build the final link of the PanAmerican Highway by 1976, and it remains unclear how much longer the $150mil lion project will take.

title: Agony of the Americas
description: How hollow the rhetoric that ush ered in the Alliance for Progress in 1961 sounds in the wake of Chile's tragedy.

title: Denver Woman Gives Birth to Sextuplets
description: DENVER, Sept. 17  A 34 yearold woman who had re ceived injections of a fertility hormone gave birth to sex tuplets here late last night.

title: Lakers Trade McMillian For Braves' 71 Smith
description: The Log Angeles Lak ers planned yesterday for the time when Wilt Cham berlain would no longer be with them. They obtained Elmore Smith, a young, proven 7foot1inch center, from the Buffalo Braves for highscoring Jim McMillian.

title: Judges Drop Case Against Costantino
description: A panel of Federal appeals judges decided yesterday to take no action against Judge Mark A. Costantino, who sits in Federal Court in Brooklyn and who had been the subject of complaints by Government lawyers and others.

title: 2,500 Policemen at Rites For Jersey City Officer
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 17  About 2,500 policemen from this city and from as far away as Ohio, attended the funeral today of Casper Buonocore Jr., a Jersey City motorcycle pa trolman who was fatally shot by a sniper Wednesday night.

title: Now in Pittsburgh, It's Beef at 1945 Prices
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 17 Thousands of persons, at tracted by a sale of beef at prices as much as $1 a pound below regular prices, con verged today on a downtown market.

title: Homosexual Films Ruffle Businessmen on 44th St.
description: Movies appealing to homo sexuals are now being shown in a theater directly across 44th Street from Shubert Alley.

title: Two More Bombs in Britain; Explosives Expert Wounded
description: LONDON, Sept. 17 (UPI) Two more bombs exploded in Britain today, one of them wounding an explosives expert as he was on his way to defuse the device, planted outside an office building in Birmingham.

title: To Pedal a Theory
description: CUERNAVACA, MexicoThe exist ence of socially disruptive energy quanta can be illustrated by focusing on trafficall journeys of people out side their homes. This traffic is the sum total of two modes of production. The first is selfpowered locomotion by pedestrians and cyclists whichI shall call transit, and the second, mo torized conveyance or transport. In the United States, the transport of people now utilizes most of that 4 per cent of all energy which is burned to produce and operate vehicles. For the sole purpose of this transport, 250 million Americans use more than 1.3 billion Indians and Chinese use for all purposes combined. As a result of this dependence on transport, the typical American spends about three times more hours in trafficrelated activities than does a Chinese.

title: Gas Regulations Appealed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP)  A bipartisan group of 33 Senators and Western gasoline station owners appealed sepa rately to the Cost of Living Council today to revise Phase 4 oil industry regulations. Under the regulations, retailers have been required to roll hack prices while other sectors of the oil industry have been allowed to raise prices. The Senators said the squeeze was likely to force many small businessmen to close down in a matter of weeks.

title: Hogan Had Stroke
description: District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of Manhattan suffered a minor stroke on Aug. 10 and was taken to St. Luke's Hosi tal, where he underwent sur gery for a lung tmor on Sept. 7, Joseph C. }Joan, his brother, said late yesterday.

title: BERME PROPOSES POLICE OUTPOSTS
description: Posing in the brisk breeze and bright sunshine on Colum bus Avenue, in front of a shut tered restaurant, Controller Abraham D. Beame suggested yesterday that such vacant stores could be used as police outpostssmall subunits that could give reassurance to neighborhoods far from regu lar station houses.

title: Wrecker's Ball Begins to Write Finis to Lewisohn Stadium's Career
description: The demolition of Lewisohn Stadium began yesterday morning when the wreckers' ball struck one of the con crete walls of what used to be a cultural center on the City College campus, and is now an unused and decaying arena.

title: Estimate of Pollution Control Costs Pared
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  A representative American fam ily will he paying about $250 a year1.8 per cent of $13,500 incomefor pollution controls by 1976, the Council on En vironmental Quality said to day.

title: An East Side Shop Where You Can Buy Chocolate or Make It
description: Liza Minnelli is patrial to his homemade handdipped chocolate wafers, Richard Avedon keeps his ground al mond log by his bedside and Elizabeth Taylor survived her separation from Richard Burton with a supply of his chocolatecovered strawber ries.

title: Chess:
description: SICILIAN DEFENSE

title: SANTIAGO'S POOR TALK OF REVENGE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 17 Santiago is still in a state of shock from the abrupt political surgery of last Tuesday.

title: President's Jetliner Is Being Renvoated At Cost of $285,000
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17, (UPI)  President Nixon's jet liner is undergoing alterations at a price of $285,000, largely to conform to his wife's wishes that guest quarters be next to the President's lounge.

title: Branch Office in Singapore Opened by Marine Midland
description: SINGAPORE, Sept. 17 (UPI) John S. Lawson, board chair man and president of the Marine Midland Bank of New York, today opened the insti tution's first branch office in Asia.

title: Skull and Sneakers Found In House of Missing Youth
description: A human skull and remains of a pair of sneakers were found yesterday in a furnace in a Bronx tenement from which a 13yearold boy has been reported missing since last March, the police said.

title: Rangers Start Huffing and Puffing Under New Coach
description: KITCHENER, Ontario, Sept. 17Changes have been so rapid in this burgeoning com munity that the barber shop down the road now adver tises, Two barbersno wait ing.

title: The Theater: I Love Thee Freely
description: The love affairs of poets tend to be more fervent than those of other mortals, more fervent and occasionally more confused. The love affair of the impetuous but unworldly Robert Browning for the sweetly determined but in valided Elizabeth Barrett has become one of the most fa mous of poetic history. Its faine depends in part on the stature of the poets con cerned but more, one fears, on the legendary tyranny of Miss Barrett's father and the eventual elopement of the lovers from her home in Wimpole Street.

title: Music Hall Orchestra Accepts Cut in Annual Work Guarantee
description: Radio City Music Hall's or chestra musicians ratified a threeyear contract settlement with the theater's management at midnight last night, avert ing a shutdown threatened for this morning.

title: SKYLAB 2 CREWMEN PRPARE TO RETURN
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 17 (AP) With just eight days left in the mission of Skylab 2, pre parations have started on the ground and in space for the return of the astronauts, who have broken the record for time in space.

title: A Drug Success
description: Back in 1969, when drug abuse was an almost wholly unanswered problem in New York City, those addicted to heroin had to wait as long as six months to be inter viewed for acceptance into a methadone treatment pro gram, After the interview, those accepted often had to wait another six months or more before actually gaining entrance into such a programone that detoxified addicts and stabilized them on a maintenance dose of methadone. The goal was to kill the overpowering craving for heroin and thus enable addicts to resume employment and normal social life.

title: Corporate Profile
description: In the computer industry, there is the International Business Machines Corpora tion and there are the others all of which lag far behind the giant. Many of these other companies are also giant corporations.

title: Aaron Hits No. 711
description: Hank Aaron hit the 711th home run of his career last night in Atlanta Stadium and moved within three of Babe Ruth's record of 714. The homer by the Braves' slug ger was hit against Gary Ross of the San Diego Padres, A crowd of only 1,362 pay ing fans watched. The Braves have 10 games remaining. Details on Page 49.

title: Business Briefs
description: The nation's foodretailing industry as a whole was described as in a very poor financial position by the National Association of Food Chains yesterday. But it still foresaw food prices stabilizing and even some declines by the first of the year.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Musicians of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra re portedly voted last night to accept a reduction in the guar anteed work year from 36 to 23 weeks, following a cut in the ochestra's budget from $1.8million to $1.1million. The acceptance clears the way for rehearsals to begin to morrow for the fall season.

title: Wood, Field and Stream:
description: The time may come when hatcheryreared Atlantic sal mon stocked in certain small rivers, which are not now ma jor salmonproducing streams, will provide substantial har vests of the species, says Lee Wulff, director of the Inter national Atlantic Salmon Foundation.

title: TEACHERS' STRIKES END IN 2 BIG CITIES
description: Teachers in Lansing, Mich., and Providence, R. I., voted yesterday to accept new con tracts and end their walkouts, United Press International re ported. Other teachers' strikes continued around the country, leaving hundreds of thousands of pupils on extended summer vacations.

title: Strike Closes 4 Catholic High Schools
description: A strike by lay teachers at Roman Catholic high schools in Brooklyn and Queens yesterday forced the closing of four schools as 356 of the 517 lay teachers did not show up for work.

title: Alleged Mass Slayer's Death Ruled Justifiable Homicide
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 17 (UPI) An assistant district attorney said today that the death of an alleged mass slayer, Dan A. Corll, was justifiable homicide and that no charges would be filed against Elmer Wayne Hen ley, 17 years old, already under indictment for six of 27 known murders of teenaged boys.

title: SOME BROKERS PLAN NO EARLY FEE RISE
description: Several large brokerage firms said yesterday that they would not raise commission rates on orders in excess of $5,000 until the New York Stock Exchange membership approved increases on smaller orders as well. That action is expected Sept. 24.

title: Striking Teacher Finds He Needs More Money
description: Like most of the 550 other members of the Lay Faculty Association, who face the pros pect of having no income, Dennis Rogan had to talk the strike situation over with the family.

title: Mrs. King Victor Twice in Tourney
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 17 (AP) Mrs: Billie Jean King swept two matches tonight in the $30,000 Virginia Slims tennis tournament.

title: New Watergate Climate
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  The Senate Watergate commit tee's decision to abbreviate public hearings on 1972 Presi dential campaign sabotage and spending and to terminate the inquiry as soon as possible is the most significant reflection of a change in the legal and political climate of Washington. The hearings were to have resumed this week. In stead, they have been delayed un til next week and the panel will meet behind closed doors tomorrow to sort out uncertainties about its wit ness list and its life expec tancy. What seems certain is that the committee members are no longer eager to serve as the focus of the Government's examination of the roots and aftermath of the Watergate breakin 15 months ago.

title: Teamster Sweethearts
description: Few episodes in recent labor history have been more repulsive than the undisguised partnership between the scandalridden Teamsters Union and largescale agricul tural interests in California to smash the tiny United Farm Workers, headed by Cesar Chavez.

title: M'DONNELL SCORES U.S. LABOR POLICY
description: Vincent D. McDonnell, chair man of the State Mediation Board, charged yesterday that a national labor policy of flex ible rigidity was responsible for many of the problems ne gotiators and mediators were having in arriving at new con tract agreements.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: MATAWAN, Sept. 17If a women's version of the Harlem Globetrotters is ever established, Dottie McCrea of Matawan will qualify for the team with her ability and experience. Miss McCrea has played basketball in many cities in the United States, in Peru and now is starting a 10month stay in Monaco.

title: Only 1,362 Fans See Aaron Clout
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 17 (AP) Hank Aaron moved a step closer to Babe Ruth's record of 714 home runs tonight, hitting his 711th career homer.

title: A. J. BEDELL, REFINED EYEINTERIOR PHOTOS
description: ALBANY, Sept. 17Dr. Ar thur J. Bedell, an ophthamolo gist who more than 40 years ago perfected photography of the interior of the eye as an aid to treatment, died today in Child's Hospital. He Was 93 years old and lived in Alta mont, N.Y.

title: JOB BIAS CHARGED TO 4 COMPANIES AND MAJOR UNIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  The Federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, in the most extensive concerted action of its eightyear history, has notified four of America's big gest corporations and several major unions that charges of job discrimination have been filed against them.

title: Aaron Hits No. 711
description: Hank Aaron hit the 711th home run of his career last night in Atlanta Stadium and moved within three of Babe Ruth's record of 714. The homer by the Braves' slug ger was hit against Gary Ross of the San Diego Padres. A crowd of only 1,362 pay ing fans watched. The Braves have 10 games remaining. Details on Page 49.

title: 3 Policemen Shot in Arresting 3 Believed Black Army Chiefs
description: Three policemen were wounded in a shootout last night when a large force of policemen and Federal Bureau of Investigation agents raided a Bronx apartment and arrested three men alleged to be mem bers of the Black Liberation Army, a group of radicals ac cused of the killing of police men and other murders and robberies.

title: Opera: Seasoned Cast, New Leader
Policemen Are Shot in Arresting 3 Believed Part of Black Army
description: Three policemen were wounded and an unidentified man was reported shot to death last night when a large force of policeman raided a Bronx apartment and, after a shootout, arrested three men alleged to be members of the Black Liberation Army, a group of radicals accused of killing policemen and other murders and robberies.

title: Child Health Day Set Oct.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) President Nixon today pro claimed Oct. 1 as Child Health Day and said that one of our most important national respon sibilities is the assurance of full and healthy development for the children of America.

title: Valley Forge Fees Held Up
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 17 (UPI)A proposed 50cent ad mission charge to four histori cal buildings at the Valley Forge State Park did not go into effect today as scheduled. The charge was help up yester day by Gov. Milton J. Schapp, who said he had received numerous complaints about the proposed fee.

title: Books of The Times
description: ECONOMICS AND THE PUBLIC PURPOSE. By John Kenneth Gailbrath. 334 pages. Hough ton Mifflin. $10.

title: S.E.C. SEEKS ORDER TO RESTRAIN GEOTEK
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17 The Securities and Exchange Commission filed an application today for a temporary restrain ing order to prevent Geotek Resources Fund, Inc., and asso ciated companies from engag ing in certain activities that would further endanger the as sets of its shareholders.

title: MGM to Cut Activities In Films and Stress TV
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17  MetroGoldwynMayer, Inc., an nounced today that it would withdraw from motion picture distribution and dramatically cut back the production of films.

title: O. J. Is Not the Only Back Who Ran Wild in Openers
description: Apart from O. J. Simpson, an old hero, the National Football League had some new heroes emerge from its opening set of games Sunday. One was a rookie named Terry Metcalf, who runs like a jackrabbit.

title: HandCranked Airplane Shows It Has Some Life
description: TEWKSBURY, Mass., Sept. 17 (UPI)John Pateman re fueled a plane at TewMao Airport last night and then tried to start up the engine. It wouldn't work.

title: Another Fraternity Is Closed at Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 17One of Yale University's two remaining Greekletter fraternities closed its doors last week at the beginning of the fall semester. The oth er plans to close sometime this year, bringing to an end the slow and steady decline of fraternity life here.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: SEGRETTI AGREES TO PLEAD GUILTY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 Donald H. Segretti, who was hired to play tricks on the Dem bcrats in the 1972 Presidential Campaign, has agreed to plead guilty to an expanded four count indictment charging cam paign law violations and to co operate with the Watergate special prosecutor.

title: 2 Years' Probation Given In a Stock Bribing Here
description: After pleading guilty to vio lating credit regulations of the Federal Reserve System in stock dealings, Pericles Con stantinou, 39 years old of 351 E. 84th St., received a sus pended sentence yesterday and was fined $1,000 in Manhattan Federal Court.

title: The Easy Way
description: When the President talks about get ting on with the great tasks confront ing America, it seems to be only foreign policy and warmaking readi ness that he has in mind.

title: Science Fiction Getting Serious Study on Campuses
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Sept. 17  A strange, mutant species of literary man has been romping here among the cool green hills of central Pennsylvania for four days crow.

title: DR. FRANK KRIISE OF MAYO CLINIC, 75
description: Dr. Frank H. Krusen, an in ternational authority on physi cal medicine and rehabilitation, died Sunday night at his home in Orleans, Mass. He was 75 years old.

title: Sex Discrimination in Britain Barred Under Government Plan
description: LONDON, Sept. 17The British Government announced a plan today to outlaw unfair discrimination against women in employment and to promote equal opportunities in all fields of life.

title: Packers Hold Jets Scoreless For 59:33 and Triumph, 237
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 17 Unprepared and uninspired, the New York Jets were the epitome of inefficiency to night in a 237 loss to the Green Bay Packers in the opener of the Monday night TV series in the National Football League season.

title: Multinational Companies Called Agents of Change
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17 The chief reason multination al companies are disturbing to many governments and their citizens is that they represent today's visible agents of change, Walter B. Wriston, chairman of the First National City Corporation, told the an nual session of the Internation al Industrial Conference here today.

title: W.H.O. Reports Dread Diseases Are Soaring in the Region of India
description: NEW DELHI, Sept 17The World Health Organization re ported today that some dread diseases thought to be under control were on the rise again in India and other nations of this region.

title: Music: Cathy Berberian Sings and Acts
description: Cathy Berberian, looking more than a little like Mae West in her best days, came to Town Hall on Friday night to present a recital that, ac cording to Miss Berberian, might have taken place in the salon of Mme. Verdurin, a character in Marcel Proust's Remembrance of Things Past.

title: Mother Drops Fight to Regain Daughter Yielded for Adoption
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 17 A 20yearold mother who fought in the courts to regain the daughter she gave up at birth, dropped the fight today because the baby was getting too old to be moved around like a pawn.

title: MANPOWER NEEDS AT BORDER CITED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 Bureau of Customs personnel are performing the bulk of the work assigned to the United States Immigration and Na turalization Service at one of the country's busiest ports of entry because of the latter agency's lack of manpower, Congress was told today.

title: Rangers Hire Lucchesi
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., Sept 17 (AP)Frank Lucchesi, former manager of the Philadelphia Phillies, has been hired as a third base coach by the Texas Rangers.

title: Philip Berrign and Elizabeth McAlister: Resisting Together
description: BALTIMOREIt is a pleasant three story house in an integrated, but pri marily black, neighborhood. The second hand furniture, a $325 mlange of fin ishes and styles, is softened and per sonalized with pictures, banners, me mentos and books. When the weather is warm, the door is open to the roar of lumbering city buses.

title: RESERVE APPROVED FLEXIBILITY IN JULY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (Reuters)The Federal Reserve Open Market Committee voted in June to temporarily grant the New York Federal Reserve Bank great flexibility in carry ing out monetary policy in July.

title: Notes on People
description: After he became the second man to walk on the moon, said the former astronaut Edwin E. (Buzz) Aidrin, life became a veritable hell for him.

title: Businessmen Fight A.T.&T.P. lan to End WATS Lines
description: A group representing about 100 large and small compa nies agreed here yesterday to fight efforts of the American Telephone and Telegraph Com pany to eliminate by the end of 1974 its wide area telephone service (WATS).

title: Mexican Industrialist Slain In Attempted Kidnapping
description: MONTERREY, Mexico, Sept. 17 (AP)A band of six to nine rnent, apparently leftist guer rillas tried to kidnap one of Mexico's wealthiest industrial ists today and he and four other persons were killed in a gun battle, the police said.

title: American League
description: Tuesday, September 18, 1973

title: Rockefeller Cites Lesson In the Shockof Watergate
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., Sept. 17Governor Rockefeller de cared here tonight that the Watergate scandal ultimately could become a very signifi cant turning point for America by reversing a sense of moral decay that he said had tragical ly permeated all phases of this nation's economic and socal life.

title: U.N. OPENS TODAY AMID UNCERTAINTY
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 17 The 28th annual General Assembly begins here tomorrow in an atmosphere of uncertainity and doubt.

title: Old Coach on Riggs: Boring
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., Sept. 17 Mrs. Eleanor (Teach) Ten nant, who taught a bandy legged kid named Bobby Riggs to play tennis over 40 years ago, thinks he is not only the greatest and cockiest player in the world, but also one of the dullest to watch.

title: Home Run By Orioles Tops Yanks
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 17It took only one batter to make the Yankees' Wayne Grang er, purchased from the St. Louis Cardinals last month, a losing pitcher tonight.

title: Consumers Union, F.D.A.. Dispute Milk Lead Levels
description: Consumers Union, the inde pendent product testing service, and the Federal Food and Drug Administration clashed yester day over a Consumers Union report charging that tests showed six major brands of evaporated milk to be contam inated with impermissably high concentrations of lead. The milk is widely rused in infants' for mulas.

title: DR. EUGENE FARLEY, LED WILKES COLLEGE
description: WILKES BARRE, Pa., Sept. 17Dr. Eugene Shedden Far ley, president of Wilkes College from its establishment in 1947 to 1970 and a past president of the American Association of Junior Colleges, died today at his home in nearby Beaumont, apparently of a heart attack. He was 74 years old.

title: Pope Is Silent on Annulments For Marriages Without Love
description: ROME, Sept. 17  Pope Paul VI today gave a long address to participants in an interna tional congress on canon law, but passed over in silence a recommendation for a signifi cant change in the Roman Catholic Church's rules on mat rimony.

title: A Naturalist's Eye View of the National Zoo
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 To tour a zoo with Ger aid Durrell, the naturalist, is to appreciate what it might have been to inspect a kitchen with Escoffier.

title: Rucker in Norwegian Deal
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 17 (UPI)  The Rucker Company has obtained a $10million or der from the Odfjell Drilling and Consulting Company in Norway, for equipment to be used aboard seven new sub mersible drilling rigs in the North Sea.

title: Judges Drop Case Against Costantino
description: A panel of Federal appeals judges decided yesterday to take no action against Judge Mark A. Costantino, who sits in Federal Court in Brooklyn and who had been the subject of complaints by Government lawyers and others.

title: COMPETITOR IS SUED IN HIRING OF OFFICER
description: Cushman & Wakefield, the real estate and insurance com pany, filed a $2million suit yesterday against a competitor who allegedly lured away a Cushman vice president and his confidential information.

title: Salt Miners End Walkout
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 17 (AP) A 140day salt miners' strike here ended today when Federal mediators announced that a mail ballot by workers favored acceptance of a contract with the International Salt Company and returning to work. The striking miners voted 87 68 to return to work, the union reported. The company's three year contract offer included an 85cent hourly wage increase and improved fringe benefits.

title: 400 Clifton Teachers Strike, Disrupting 16 Public Schools
description: CLIFTON, N. J., Sept. 17 More than 400 teachers struck this city's 16 public schools to day, disrupting the normal class activities for the system's 11, 600 students.

title: KingRiggs Match Point Is Money
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 18Some call it the tennis battle of the sexes or the $100,000 hustle or the Woodstock of the Bob by Riggs generation. But one thing is certain: When Billie Jean King and Bobby Riggs step out on an improvised court in the infield of the As trodrome Thursday night, the game they play will have more in common with Ringling Brothers circus or Cecil B. DeMille spectacle than with Wimbledon or Forest Hills.

title: JOHN J. McCARRICK
description: John J. McCarrick, associate professor at the. College of Business Administration of St. John's University in Jamaica, Queens, died yesterday at Doc tors Hospital in Freeport, L. I. He was 58 years old and lived in Merrick, L. I.

title: Maryland Rivals Keep Eye on Mandel
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 18  Sometimes politics seems to be as much a staple in Maryland as crab cakes.

title: New Litton Ovens
description: Litton Industries introduced yesterday a new line of micro wave ovens aimed at the low cost market. The new compact units are priced under $300 with the lowest price model to sell at $259.

title: CATHOLIC SCHOOLS OPEN IN WALKOUT
description: Lay teachers on strike against eight Roman Catholic high schools in Brooklyn and Queens said that more of their colleagues had joined in the walkout yesterday  a claim disputed by spokesman for the Diocese of Brooklyn.

title: Honda Civic Tops Lists In '74 Auto Mileage Test
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) The Environmental Protection Agency released figures today on mileage performance of 1974 automobiles, placing the 2,000 pound Honda Civic at the top of the list and the 4,000pound Ferrari365 GTB4 at the bot torn.

title: Rehabilitation Bill Cleared
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UPI) The House gave final Con gressional approval today to a scaleddown version of a twice vetoed vocational rehabilitation bill that the Administration said it would accept. The bill would authorize $1.54billion over two years to state and local govern ments and private agencies to operate programs of rehabil tating the handicapped for jobs.

title: Twins Found Slain Behind the Offices Of U.A.W.inEdison
description: EDISON, N.J., Sept. 18Two brothers who worked at the Ford Motor Company's as sembly plant here were found shot to death today in the front seat of a car parked behind the office of Local 980 of the United Auto Workers.

title: 35 Countries Resume Security Parley
description: GENEVA, Sept. 18  Dele gates of 35 countries opened the second, downtobusiness phase of the European security conference here today amid de bate in both Western Europe and the United States on just how fast and how far the move toward warmer relations with the Soviet bloc should proceed.

title: Notes on People
description: Japan's Premier Rakuel Tanaka will fly next week to France, West Germany and Great Britain, bearing gifts. The Kyodo news agency in Tokyo reported that Mr. Tanaka would offer $1mil lion in each of the three countries to assist univer sities with Japanese studies programs. Mr. Tanaka, who will make a similar offer later when he visits the So viet Union, seems to be get ting into a habit of passing out doles of $1million. He presented 10 such gifts to American universities when he visited the United States month.

title: Israeli Druses Entering Modern Era
description: JOULIS, Israel, Sept. 8 When Salame Elmaza enrolled in the nurses' training program at Naharlya Hospital last month, seven religious elders from this village visited her father to request her withdraw al.

title: JUDGE UIIDER FIRE ASSAILB U.S. AIDE
description: Federal Judge Mark A. Cos tantino has accused one of the chief Federal prosecutors in the Eastern District of New York, where Judge Costantino has served on the bench since 1971, of holding a personal animus toward him and of engaging in a baseless, per sonal attack on the court.

title: P.B.I. AGENT SUSS OVER SUSPENSION
description: A Federal Bureau of Investi gation agent who is under sus pension for alleged insubordi nation yesterday filed a suit against the agency's director, Clarence M. Kelley, and against the bureau, asserting that his suspension was the final act in a campaign of persecution and harassment visited upon him by his superiors and col leagues in the bureau.

title: A.T.&T. DENIES PLAN TO END WATS LINES
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company denied yes terday that it had any plans for eliminating its wide area tele phone service (WATS). C. Thom as Koenig, marketing manager for A.T. & T.'s Long Lines de partment said:

title: U.S. MOVES TO ?? FRAUD BY ALIENS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 The acting commissioner of teh United States Immigration and Naturalization Service said today that his agency had start ed a program designed eventu ally to replace millions of alier identification documents with ones far more difficult to coun terfeit.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: PLAY TIME If you play piano or a stringed instru ment and are wondering what more you can do about it you might look in tonight at Chamber Music Associates at the 92d Street Y.M. Y.W.H.A., at Lexington Ave nue (4276000). This is audi tion night  you can look them over and they can look you over at no charge.

title: 2 GERMANYS JOIN U.N. AS ASSEMBLY OPENS 28TH YEAR
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 18  East and West Ger many were admitted as mem bers of the United Nations to day at the, opening of the 28th annual General Assembly.

title: Hearne Backers' Tact Deflates Protest
description: A group of demonstrators who won widespread public at tendon when they were thrown out of a meeting of the City Council in Newark two weeks ago invaded a BeameforMay or campaign  meeting yester day and encountered the po lite indifference of a roomful of demonstrationwise New York City politicians.

title: Mrs. Elizabeth Blakemore Wed To Stanton Griffis, ExEnvoy
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Sept. 18Stanton Griffis, the fi nancier and former Ambas sador to Poland, Egypt, Ar gentina and Spain, wed Mrs. Elizabeth Blakemore last Thursday in Palm Beach. Circuit Judge Paul T. Douglas performed the ceremony in his chambers.

title: A Partisan Union Beach Splits With Conservationists on Plant
description: UNION BEACH, Sept. 18 We have heard here what is good for the fish, what is good for the birds, what is good for the clams, but nobody has told us what is good for the people, declared Albert Oster vich, a retired resident who favors the building of a power plant on the Raritan Bay here in spite of objections from con servationists.

title: Amati Four Bow in U.S. In Bartok
description: The Amati Quartet, found ed in Amsterdam seven years ago, is being intro duced to American audiences this week and next with series of three concerts at Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: Stage: CSC Repertory in Moby Dick
description: Ever since its foundation in 1967, the CSC Repertory has given a great deal of simple theatrical pleasure to New York. Its fiveperform ance weekend schedule, from Thursday through Sunday, embraces a regular rotating repertory. The plays them selves are usually classic but frequently adventurous, and when you think you can get six different plays for a sub scription of a mere $15, this has got to be one of the few bargains left in New York.

title: Girt, 10, Electrocuted
description: FORT WALTON BEACH, Fla., Sept. 18 (AP)A 10yearold girl getting ready to go horse back riding was killed yester day after coming into contact with a lowvoltage electric fence around a pasture. Laurie Kimbrall of Fort Walton Beach was barefoot and standing on wet grass when she touched the wire, the police said.

title: Apollo Is Host to First FirstRun Film
description: The haze of a rainy after noon replaced the kleig lights, and the audience came in buses instead of limousines. There were no ermines or pearls, except for Earl (the Pearl) Monroe, who hobbled in on crutches with one foot solemnly dressed in a large white cast.

title: Stars 'Save the Children'
description: "Save the Children," the movie spinoff (and theme) of last year's Black Exposition conducted by Operation PUSH (People to Save Humanity) in Chicago's Amphitheater, has the virtues of being forthright, unabashedly emotional and entertaining. And, if two hours of more than 30 black artists doing their musical things occasionally seem repetitive, the heart and craft of the performers (and speakers, including the Rev. Jesse Jackson, head of PUSH) project enough soul and meaning to captivate viewers.The name "acts," who contributed their services to "Save the Children," now at the Criterion, Beekman and Apollo Theaters, constitute enough talent to fill a month of Sundays on the stage of Harlem's Apollo Theater. And they neatly complement the intercut arts, crafts and commerce displayed at the Exposition as well as the footage of Chicago's blacks, their churches, schools, slums and playgrounds.Credit Stan Lathan, the director; Matt Robinson, the producer, and George Bowers and Paul Evans, the film's editors, with making "Save the Children" move briskly and with considerable impact in promoting the hope for the future of its "Children." But it is really the performers in this teeming "cast" who make this bulging package of jazz, blues, rock, gospel, ballads and honest proseletyzing a gratifyingly varied and persuasive entertainment.

title: Drab Dress, Florid Talk At the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 18Many of the dele gates attending the opening of the 28th General Assembly today seemed to have aban doned the native costumes they once wore here.

title: SOME NIXON AIDES HINT THAT AGNEW OUGHT TO RESIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 Some high White House officials have been saying in private con versations in the last few days that it might be best for Vice President Agnew to resign and allow President Nixon to choose a new Vice President.

title: Senate Opens Way For Early. Passage Of Pension Reform
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 The Senate cleared the way today for early passage, pos sibly tomorrow, of a bill to es tablish Federal standards for the improvement of private pension systems.

title: Memorial for Mrs. Post Held at Church in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18, (AP)  Mrs. Dwight D. Eisen hower was among the friends, diplomats, officials and mem bers of Congress who attended a memorial service yesterday for Mrs. Marjorie Merriweather Post at the National Presby terian Church.

title: HomeStake Asks Chapter X
description: The HomeStake Production, Company, Tulsa, Okla., an nounced yesterday that it would file for bankruptcy under Chapter X of the Federal Bank ruptcy Act. The filing is pur suant to an agreement with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a suit by the S.E.C. filed Sept. 11, 1973, in the Federal District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma.

title: WILLIAM A. WILSON
description: William A. Wilson, an admir laity lawyer and senior partner of Wilson & Hopkins, 116 John Street, died on Sunday at St. Vincent's Medical Center, Staten Island. He was 53 years old and lived at 67 Forest Avenue, Silver Lake, S. 1.

title: Whitney Museum Opens Downtown Branch
description: Th Whitney Museum of American Art, launching a satellite from Madison Ave nue and 75th Street, will make a landing in lower Manhattan today when it opens a branch at 55 Water Street.

title: Chevrolet to Drop Engine Types To Meet Exhaust Standards
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., Sept. 18(UPI)Chevrolet an nounced yesterday that it would drop two engine types and limit sales of three others in 1975 to meet interim Federal exhaust emission standards.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: TOMS RIVER, Sept. 18Curt Blefary has two memen tos of the eight years he played major league baseball. One is a World Series ring he earned as a member of the 1966 Baltimore Orioles and the other is a lifetime pass, engraved with his name, to major league games.

title: Mutual Buying Syndicate Elects a New President
description: Sam Ruderman has been elected president and treasurer of Mutual Buying Syndicate, Inc., one of New York's largest buying offices and merchandis ing service concerns. He suc ceeds Walter Awe, who died earlier this week.

title: CHRYSLER TO PAY FOR HEALTH PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 The tentative pact agreed to yesterday between the United Automobile Workers and the Chrysler Corporation contains a provision that is expected to spur demands by labor for en actment of national health in surance, which has been stalled in Congress for three years.

title: 2 of 3 Black Army Suspects Are Held Without Bail
description: Six persons were arraigned yesterday on charges of at tempted murder and possession of weapons as a result of a raid and shootout with the police Monday night in a Bronx apart ment believed by the police to be the headquarters of the Black Liberation Army.

title: 17 States of South Pacific Move To Reform Region's Aid System
description: TUMON BAY, Guam, Sept. 18 Seventeen island states and territories in the South Pacific took a step today toward end ing what many in the area re gard as the insulting way in which regional aid programs are administered.

title: Football Transactions
description: AMERICAN CONFERENCE

title: Senate Unit Recommends Kissinger's Confirmation
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18, The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted 16 to 1 today to recommend the confirmation of Henry A. Kissinger as Secre tary of State. The full Senate will probably approve the nom ination on Thursday or Friday.

title: Iceland Rules Out Any Talks OnWithdrawal of U.S. Force
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Sept. 18 (Reuters)An Icelandic offi cial declared today that United States troops must leave the Atlantic alliance's air base at Keflavik and ruled out any possibility of negotiation on the subject.

title: Geotek Resources Denies S.E.C. Charge It Is Insolvent
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 18  Geotek Resources, at the opening of hearings on whether a temporary receiver should be appointed to supervise the af fairs of the Geotek complex of companies, denied today an assertion by the Securities and Exchange. Commission that the companies are insolvent.

title: 2 GERMANYS JOIN U.N. AS ASSEMBLY OPENS 28TH YEAR
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 18  East and West Ger many were admitted as mem bers of the United Nations to day at the opening of the 28th annual General Assembly.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I do not endorse every point in the accusations directed against Western liberals by Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, but he is surely right in his charge That they have been guilty of a double standard of moral judgment in evalu ating the behavior of Communist and nonCommunist regimes.The prospective abandonment by the Department of Defense of the 607bed, 117acre Naval Hospital at St. Albans in Queens has evoked a controversy about the future use of this property, ultimately to be decided by the Gen eral Senices Administration [news story Aug. 26].

title: Wide Gap Reported As Talks Resume In Strike at Opera
description: Both sides were reported far apart last night in efforts to end the 18day strike by Local 802 of the American Federa tion of Musicians that has forced the New York City Opera Company to cancel all performances since Sept. 1.

title: Boston Changes Teams, From Channel 7 to 2
description: Jim Bouton, the controver sial former New York Yankee pitcher, has joined WCBSTV as sportscaster, it was an nounced yesterday by Ed Joyce, director of news for Channel 2.

title: STOCK DEAL IS SET BY BRONFMAN UNIT
description: Cemp Investments, Ltd., owned by the Bronfman family of Distillers CorpotationSea grams, Ltd., in Canada. and other investors in the group announced yesterday the acqui sition of 1.5million shares of Signal Companies, Inc.; stock, pursuant to a tender offer of Aug. 9, Since more than that number was tendered, the group said it would purchase the stock on a pro rata basis at about 93.5 per cent. Signal is in the oil and gas field and makes turbine engines.

title: Rangers' Camp. Bed Checks, Clean Shaves and Hope
description: KITCHENER, Ontario, Sept. 18Lou Passador, the Ran gers' chief, scout, banged on the hotel door and a young minor leaguer opened up. All right, said Passador with a scowl, who has the beer? The player shrugged. You should know better than to jeopardize your ca reer for another nut, he lec tured. You've been around a long time now.

title: Senate Unit Recommends Kissipger's Confirmation
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted 16 to 1 today to recommend the confirmation of Henry A. Kissinger as Secre tary of State. The full Senate will probably approve the nom ination on Thursday or Friday.

title: Big Banks Continue Move To 10% Prime Loan Rate
description: A number of major banks here and over the nation have joined in the upward movement to a 10 per cent prime lending rate yesterday, making the in creased level virtually industry wide. The Bank of America, the nation's largest bank, and the Chase Manhattan Bank, the na tion's third largest, were among those joining the Wells Fargo Bank, which initiated the increase to 10 per cent from 9 per cent last Thursday. In New York, the Chemical Bank, the Morgan Guaranty Trust, the Irving Trust, the Bank of New York and the Marine Midland Bank all an nounced increases to 10 per cent, They were joined by, among others: the Mellon Bank, of Pittsburgh, the Philadelphia National Bank and the Girard Rank of Philadelphia, the Con tinental Illinois National Bank & Trust of Chicago, the Sector ity Pacific National Bank of Los Angeles, the Bank of Cali fornia and the Crocker National Bank, both of San Francisco.

title: Elliott Roosevelt Linked to Plot Against Pindling
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 A convicted dealer in stolen securities told a Senate com mittee today that he was hired in 1968 by Elliott Roosevelt, a son of the late President and a former Mayor of Miami Beach, Fla.. to assassinate Lynden O. Pindling, the Governor of the Bahamas.

title: SCHOOL SOCCER
Watergate Panel to Hear
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18The Senate Watergate com mittee decided today to call Patrick J. Buchanan, a White House speech writer and political strategist, as one of first witnesses when public hearings begin next week.

title: CHARGES DISMISSED FOR 7 IN PROTESTS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) The Government has dropped charges against seven antiwar prayer protesters and a judge has suspended fines imposed on three other protesters.

title: Rangers' Camp: Bed Checks, Clean Shaves and Hope
description: KITCHENER, Ontario, Sept. 18Lou Passador, the Ran gers' chief scout, banged on the hotel door and a young minor leaguer opened up. All right, said Passador with a scowl, who has the beer? The player shrugged. You should know better than to jeopardize your ca reer for another nut, he lec tured. You've been around a long time now.

title: Baroness, 84, Benefactor Of St. Vincent's Hospital
description: BURLINGAME, Calif., Sept. 18Baroness Charles P. Wran gellRokassowsky of Phoenix, Ariz., and formerly of New York, died here Monday at the Peninsula Hospital. Her age was 84.

title: Jordan Declares Amnesty For Political Prisoners
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 18 King Hussein of Jordan de dared an amnesty today for political prisoners, including Palestinian guerrillas jailed since 1970, in a move toward Arab reconciliation.

title: Burch License Renewal Formula Praised in House
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 Dean Burch, chairman of the Federal Communications Com mission, received a generally favorable reception from a key Congressional subcommittee to day for his proposed new sys tem for measuring the perform ance of television stations.

title: Inquiry Told of Albany Police Thefts
description: ALBANY, Sept. 18The State Commission of Investigation, opening hearings today into al leged corruption in the Albany Police Department, heard wit nesses testify that policemen had carried out burglaries, had covered up the crimes with of ficial sanction and then had sought to intimidate citizens who complained.

title: GARRISON TAPE VOICE HELD FABRICATION
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 18 A tape of a voice previously identified as that of District Attorney Jim Garrisona key part of his trial for bribery and conspiracy  is a fraudulent fabrication, Dr. Louis J. Gerst man, professor of speech and communications sciences at City University of New York, testified today in Federal Dis trict Court.

title: British Football
description: By Reuters TEXACO CUP

title: PRESS IS ADVISED TO NAME SOUROES
description: Senator Barry Goldwater lec tured the press yesterday on its need to give sources for its articles, particularly concerning its reporting on the Watergate scandal, and on the investiga tion into Vice President Agnew's affairs.

title: PROBLEM YOUTHS TO BE SEPARATED
description: Beginning today, the State Division for Youth will provide separate facilities for children who need supervision for be havior problems and for chil dren convicted of serious crimes such as murder and robbery.

title: CAPITAL EXPECTS MARLAND TO QUIT
description: Sidney P. Marland Jr., the Federal Government's chief edu cation official, has submitted his resignation, authoritative sources said yesterday. They Said an announcement would be made by the White House to day.

title: Pentagon Says PopUp Missilp Gives Soviet Heavier Warhead
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18  The Soviet Union, according to Defense Department officials, has developed a popup tech nique for launching missiles that could significantly Increase the warhead payload of its inter continental missile force.

title: Security and. Freedom
description: Irony mounts upon irony as the easilyoverlooked Con ference on Security and Cooperation in Europe resumes deliberations in Geneva.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: At 10:30 A.M. yesterday, Joseph Papp initiated one of the most impressive produc ing schedules, perhaps, in the history of the American thea ter. He placed in rehearsal at the Vivian Beaumont Theater David Rabe's In the Boom Boom Boom, which is to be the New York Shake speare Festival's initial pres entation at its newly acquired Lincoln Center theater com plex.

title: SEXTUPLET DEAD OF LUNG AILMENT
description: DENVER, Sept. 18 (AP)One of the Stanek sextuplets died tonight, but the five other babies remained in fair to satisfactory condition.

title: Export Future Weighed
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 18 Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Minister of Petroleum and Min eral Resources of Saudi Arabia, said here today that failure to reach a peaceful solution to the IsraeliArabian conflict and to solve his nation's economic problems could result in a re duction of Saudi petroleum pro duction. He also said Saudi Arabia had not changed her oil export policies in the face of the energy crisis in the United States.

title: One Sextuplet Dies
description: Julia Stanek, the weakest of the sextuplets born Sun day to Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J. Stanek in. Denver, died last night of a respiratory ailment. Details on Page 29.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Ave. nue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8 P.M. (RadioWHN, 8 P.M.)

title: FREDERIC E. MEYER
description: PORT DEPOSIT, Md., Sept. 18Frederick E. Meyer, actor, stage manager and director of the Timbers Playhouse in Mount Gretna, Pa., died Sunday in an automobile accident here. His age was 63, and he lived at 333 West 18th Street in New York.

title: CHRYSLER TO PAY FOR REATH PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 The tentative pact agreed tc yesterday between the United Automobile Workers and the Chrysler Corporation contains a provision that is expected tc spur demands by labor for en actment of national health in surance, which has been stalled in Congress for three years.

title: Rockefeller in Jersey
description: TRENTON, Sept. 18  De spite his familiar smile and the warm reception he received last night, Governor Rockefel ler saw that something was wrong the moment he arrived in Cherry Hill to deliver the principal speech at the dinner starting Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr.'s Republican campaign for Governor.

title: Slayer of 10 Gets Life Terms
description: SANTA CRUZ, Calif., Sept. 18 (UPI)Herbert W. Mullin, 26 years old, who was convicted of slaying 10 persons early this year, was sentenced today to life imprisonment of each of two counts of firstdegree mur der, and five years to life on eight counts of seconddegree murder.
