Mullin, whose high school class chose hint most likely to succeed, was present for the sentencing in an orange jump suit issued him at the Vacaville medical figility where he has been confined since his convictions Aug. 19. He made no comment.

title: Sanitationmen Open Talks, Firemen Quit Them in Huff
description: The city's contract negotia tions with its uniformed serv ices began to warm up yester day as sanitationmen walked into bargaining talks and fire men walked out of them in huff.

title: The Preservation of Muteness
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 17Following are excerpts from an article written by Lidiya K. Chukovskaya, Soviet essay ist, addressed to the ordinary citizen in defense of Andrei D. Sakharov, the embattled physicist:

title: More Ivy Leaguers Kept in Pro Ranks
description: With the Giants bound for the Yale. Bowl in New Haven for their final five games, someone asked if they were going to play in buttondown shirts. It was a satirical ques tion, but more to the point is that the Ivy League has be come considerably less for eign to pro football and 11 of its alumni made the final 40man squads last week. That is the most in history. Dick Jauron, Yale's all America running back, stuck with the Detroit Lions as a reserve safety. Carl Bari sich, the Princetonian drafted on the 11th round by Cleve land, commendably made the Browns' team as the third defensive tackle behind Wal ter Johnson and Jerry Sherk. That is about the best pair in the league.

title: Theo Lefevre Is Dead at 59; Premier of Belgium, 196165
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 18Theo Lefevre, a forceful SocialChris tian politican who was Premier from 1961 to 1965, died of can cer here this morning. His age was 59.

title: Decentralized Art: Great
description: Everyone has talked about museum decentralization, but the Whitney Mu seummiracle of miracles!has ac tually done something about it. It has now established a branch museum in an area of the city that, despite its celebrated concentration of corporate wealth and power, may justly be de scribed as culturally deprived. The Whitney has, moreover, allocated for its initial event in this new exhibition facility a selection of pictures from its own permanent col lection that is both wide ranging and of high qual ity. The exhibition call Beginnings: Di rections in TwentiethCentury Ameri can Painting, which opens today, is no token representation culled from the museum's rejects. It includes some of the most respected names in the history of modern American artMarsden Hartley, Willem de Kooning, Ben Shahn, George O'Keefe and Mark Rothko, among othersand, more often than not, these artists are represented by firstrate ex aples of their work.

title: Black in Brownsville Raid, Exonerated in April, Dies
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18 (AP) Edward Warfield, who was in a company of black soldiers accused of carrying out the Brownsville Raid at the turn of the century, died today of an apparent heart attack at the age of 89.

title: Bengalis and Pakistanis Begin Exchange Today
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 18 The first group of 1,680 Pak istani prisoners of war will be set free within 10 days, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said here today.

title: School Figure Suspended As Passaic Inquiry Ends
description: PATERSON, Sept. 18The State Commission of Investiga tion ended today its hearings on charges of waste, laxity and corruption in the management of state surplus property and said that findings of improprie ties or criminal activities would be red over to the propel law enforcement authorities.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 18 (AP)A Seattle group, headed by Dave Cohn, a restaurateur, has made an offer to buy the San Diego Padres, and the matter will be considered at a meeting of National League baseball owners in Chicago tomorrow, Cohn said.

title: Bridge: Proper Defensive Strategy Is Not Always Successful
description: When a defender has the ace of dummy's long, strong suit, his aim is usually straightforward: He at tempts to put his ace on the declarer's last card in the suit, It is therefore somewhat disconcerting to find a hand on which the contract succeeds if this principle is followed and fails if the principle is ignored.

title: N.Y.R.A. Trackman Offers Clues to Record Times
description: The spate of recordbreak ing performances at New York Racing Association tracks has caused more than a little wonder and curiosity. There are some dedicated students of the thoroughbred sport who keep records of their own, charting the way standards are whittling down over the years. One of these enthusiasts, a former publish ing executive, has come up with the observation that the general level of time per formances since 1958 has improved by two full sec ond.

title: New Lights May Harm City Trees
description: The highintensity sodium street lights that have been installed here to help re duce crime may be killing trees, according to research by the United States Depart ment of Agriculture.

title: 12 Criminal Counts Against Governor of Samoa Quickly Dropped
description: PAGO PAGO, American Sa moa, Sept. 18Gov. John. M. Hayden of American Samoa was charged last night with two criminal counts of inter ference with civil rights, but this morning the charges were dismissed and the Assistant At torney General who brought them was ousted.

title: Company Urges Review
description: Maurice F. Granville, chair man and chief executive offi cer of Texaco, Inc., yesterday called upon the American pub lic to pause and examine the nation's policy in the Middle East.

title: Whitney Museum Opens Downtown Branch
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art, launching a satellite from Madison Ave nue and 75th Street, will make a landing in lower Manhattan today when it opens a branch at 55 Water Street.

title: Oilers, to Ron Johnson, A Shocking Experience
description: Ron Johsnon received sev eral shocks in Sunday's New York Giant 3414 victory over the Houston Oilers.

title: Music Philharmonic's Grand Success
description: The New York Philhar monic, living dangerously, opened its season last night with a gala Pension Fund Benefit Concert, and with an unresolved musicians' contract dispute hanging over Philharmonic Hall like a sword. The contract, sched uled to expire at midnight to morrow, added a note of anxiety to the proceedings, but nothing got in the way of the program's success, which turned out to be im mense.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was: 64507
description: Tickets matching the number win $2,500. Tickets, with the five numbers in reverse win $225. Tickets with the first or last four numbers in order win $225. Tickets with the first, middle or last three numbers in sequence win $25. Tickets with all five numbers scrambled win $25. Tickets matching the first and second digits, the second and third, the third and fourth or the fourth and fifth win $2.50.

title: Bhutto, in Washington, Receives a Warm Welcome From Nixon and Pledge of Assistance for Pakistan
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan today re ceived a warm welcome from President Nixon and promises of generosity toward Pakis tan's aid and credit needs.

title: News Summary and Index
description: King Hussein of Jordan declared an am nesty for political prisoners, including Pal estinian guerrillas jailed since 1970, to further Arab reconciliation. One of the bene ficiaries of the amnesty will be Mohammed Daoud Odeh, better known as Abu Daoud, a leader of the Palestinian guerrilla group Al Fatah, whose imprisonment has been followed by two spectacular, but unsuccess ful, attempts by extremists to force his re lease. [Page 1, Columns 12.]

title: Public Financing of Campaigns Backed at Senate Panel Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18  The Democratic national chair man and a bipartisan group of Senators endorsed today the idea of using public funds to finance election campaigns for Federal office.

title: Weeb's Jets in Chaos, Not Concert
description: Quietly, with a quick little nod, Weeb Ewbank shook his head and shrugged.

title: F.B.I. AGENT SUES OVER SUSPENSION
description: A Federal Bureau of Investi gation agent who is under sus pension for alleged insubordi nation yesterday filed a suit against the agency's director, Clarence M. Kelley, and against the bureau, asserting that his suspension was the final act in a campaign of persecution and harassment visited upon him by his superiors and col leagues in the bureau.

title: Graffiti Reflects Its Director's Youth
description: The guileless innocence of the early nineteensixties when teenagers still guzzled beer and necked at drivein restaurants, and hair styles were ducktails or ponytails, and music rocked to the Twist  is unsettling even the most sophisticated film goers at American Graffiti.

title: Watergate Panel to Hear Buchanan, a Nixon Writer
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18The Senate Watergate com mittee decided today to call Patrick J. Buchanan, a White House speech writer and political strategist, as one of its first witnesses when public hearings begin next week.

title: Remodeling of Nixon's Jet Confirmed by White House
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 Gerald L. Warren, the deputy White House press secretary, acknowledged today the ac curacy of reports that $285,000 was being spent to rearrange the compartments of the new Presidential jet, The Spirit of '76.

title: Tape of Nixon Talk on Milk Prices Acknowledged
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 The White House acknowledged today the probable existence of a tape recording of a 1971 meeting between President Nixon and leaders of the dairy industry that occurred just be fore the Administration an nounced a major milk price support increase.

title: Red China Is Voted In
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 18 (UPI)The Asian Games Federation executive com mittee, led by Japan and Iran, today voted to oust Nationalist China and admit the People's Republic of China.

title: Nadjari After One Year: The Reviews Are Mixed
description: During Maurice H. Nadjari's first year as the special state prosecutor in charge of inves tigating corruption here, he has obtained indictments against 35 personsincluding a District Attorney, a judge, the presi dent of the City Tax Commis sion, eight police sergeants, two detectives and eight police officers.

title: Normal Activity Returns To Columbia After Strike
description: Columbia University returned to normal activity yesterday after members of Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Union completed their first full day on the job.

title: PAPER CONCERN SETS $1.25BILLION OUTLAY
description: T. F. Willers, chairman and chief executive of the Cham pion International Corporation, announced yesterday that the company had committed $1.25 billion in capital expenditures over the next five years to strengthen its three major busi nesses.

title: NATIONAL LEAGUE Reds 1, Astros 0 American League National League Cards Beat Expos, 74, Stay Close AMERICAN LEAGUE A's 5, Angels 4 Orioles 6, Tigers 2
Business Briefs
description: The General Motors Corporation said here yesterday that it had made a proposal to the Government of Saudi Arabia to build a plant in that nation for assembling cars and trucks. A spokesman said that arrangements had not been completed and declined to estimate the size of the undertaking.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Negotiations between New York City and its uniformed services began to warm up with John J. DeLury, sanita tionmen's leader, meeting Mayor Lindsay and proposing a ninemonth agreement with no wage rise other than a retroactive cost of living increase. Meanwhile, a ne gotiating committee for fire men walked out of a meeting with Herbert L. Haber, Direc tor of Labor Relations for the city.

title: People in Sports: GOP Is Told to Emulate Okla.
description: The University of Okla homa scandal that involved the rigging of scholastic rec ords of football prospects has not hurt the Sooners on the gridiron. After Oklahoma routed Baylor, 4214, Grant Teaff, the losing coach, said, If the Republican party comes out of their investiga tion in Washington as good as Oklahoma did out of theirs, they'll be in the White House forever.

title: Hashish Is Seized
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 18 (AP)  Federal agents seized 110 pounds of hashish, valued at more than $500,000, from an Israeli motor vessel at Mo bile, Ala., last night and said several arrests were expected.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Sussman Bids Cahill Investigate Kitchens
description: TRENTON, N. J., Sept. 18 pr. Oscar Sussman, the state consumer, health services di rector who was stripped of his power to close kitchens at state institutions because of unsani tary conditions, urged Gover nor Cahill today to investigate the administration of the insti tutions.

title: Auto Industry Views Chrysler Pact As Liberal andBig, Fat Settlement
description: DETROIT, Sept. 18  The new threeyear contract agreed to yesterday by th striking United Automobile Workers and the Chrysler Corporation was described in the auto in dustry today as a liberal agreement and a big, fat set tlement.

title: Satellite Contract Let By Comsat to Hughes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP)The Communications Satellite Corporation awarded a $65.9million contract to day to the Hughes Aircraft Company to build four high capacity domestic satellites.

title: Glass Container Prices Raised by OwensIllinois
description: OwensIllinois, Inc., announced yesterday that it had increased prices of its glass containers by somewhat less than 5 per cent, effective immediately.

title: Thousands Line Route as Gustaf's Body Is Taken to Stockholm Palace
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 18 (UPI)Tens of thousands of Swedes, many weeping, bade farewell to King Gustaf VI Adolf today as a motorcade bearing his coffin journeyed from southern Sweden to the royal palace here. Their heads bowed, Swedes lined a 342 mile route to watch the cof fin, draped in the royal flag, move by. Children placed flowers in front of the pro cession, home guard units pa raded with lowered flags and school classes sang hymns by the roadside as the body of the 90yearold monarch passed slowly before them on a crisp, sunny day.

title: Jordan Declares Amnesty For Political Prisoners
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 18 King Hussein of Jordan de clared an amnesty today for political prisoners, including Palestinian guerrillas jailed since 1970, in a move toward Arab reconciliation.

title: YEAR IN JAIL GIVEN FOR STOCK FRAUD
description: A Federal judge imposed a oneyear prison sentence yes terday on a millionaire busi nessman described by the Gov ernment as the principal figure in the biggest stock fraud in history.

title: Decentralized Art: Great
description: Everyone has talked about museum decentralization, but the Whitney Mu seummiracle of miracles!has ac tually done something about it. It has now established a branch museum in an area of the city that, despite its celebrated concentration of corporate wealth and power, may justly be de scribed as culturally deprived. The Whitney has, moreover, allocated for its initial event in this new exhibition facility a selection of pictures from its own permanent col lection that is both wide ranging and of high qual ity. The exhibition call Beginnings: Di rections in TwentiethCentury Ameri can Painting, which opens today, is no token representation culled from the museum's rejects. It includes some of the most respected names in the history of modern American artMarsden Hartley, Willem de Kooning, Ben Shahn, George O'Keefe and Mark Rothko, among othersand, more often than not, these artists are repreiented by firstrate ex amples of their work.

title: Moscow Plans U.S.Built Trade Center
description: The Soviet Chamber of Corn merce and Industry and th?? Occidental Petroleum Corpora tion announced plans here yes terday to build a $110million International Trade Center in the center of Moscow.

title: Rockefeller in Jersey
description: TRENTON, Sept. 18Despite his familiar smile and the warm reception he received last night, Governor Rockefeller saw that something was wrong the mo ment he arrived in Cherry Hill to deliver the principal speech at the dinner starting Repre sentative Charles W. Sandman Jr.'s Republican campaign for Governor.

title: Advertising: Magazine Pitch
description: It was one of those mo mentsa stirring, memorable, hearttugging moment that will be long remembered by all those lucky enough to have been there.

title: A Sextuplet Dies
description: Julia Stanek, the weakest of the sextuplets born Sun day to Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J. Stanek in Denver, died last night of a respiratory ailment. Details on Page 29.

title: MALE FILMS ENDED AT LITTLE THEATER
description: The owner of the Little Thea ter on West 44th Street, fol lowing strong pressures from the theatrical community, ordered exhibtors of male pornographic movies yesterday to stop the show.

title: New York's NonCouncil
description: The local lawmaking body of New York Citythe City Councilis too largely a nonrepresentative, non functioning, noninvestigative, nonlegislating, nonmeet ing collection of anonymous people who spend too little time at City Hall and respond too of ten to private political pressures. We suspect that any poll of New Yorkers would turn up pathetically few who could even name their City Councilman.

title: 1 IN 3 WOMEN FAIL ON CONTRACEPTION
description: Despite advances in birth control techniques that have sharply lowered the nation's birth rate, more than a third of the women in a national study of couples practicing birth control over a fiveyear period became pregnant any way, according to a report made public yesterday.

title: Six Nassau Policemen Swim The Channel, but Miss Record
description: LONDON, Sept. 18Six Nassau County patrolmen, bat tling sixfoot waves and 35 mileanhour winds, tonight completed a twoway relay swim of the English Channel but failed to set a record.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: The winning Ntwv Jersey daily lottery number yester day was

title: People and Business
description: The president of the Cham ber of Commerce of the United States, Edward B. Rust, said yesterday that the consumeradvocate Ralph Nader was miscast as an enemy of the American business system. Instead, Mr. Rust declared, he is, con trary to much business opin ion, committed to making the system work.

title: Rap Studios Need License From City, Judge Here Decides
description: The city yesterday won its first favorable court decision against studios that have opened in the Times Square area after police crackdowns closed most massage parlors.

title: Yanks Lose 13th Time To Red Sox
description: BOSTON, Sept. 18Homers proved the life of the party tonight but singles spiked the punch as the Boston Red Sox feasted on their Yankee cousins for the 13th time this season and seven of eight at Fenway Park by a score of 42. Boston leads the year's series, 1341.

title: Mondale Begins To Stir
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18For sev eral years, Senator Walter F. (Fritz) Mondale of Minnesota has been recog nized as one of the most promising of the rising generation of Democratic politicians, but something has held him back.

description: BASEBALL

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18A Civil Service appeals exam iner reinstated today A. Ernest Fitzgerald, the Air Force cost analyst who disclosed a $2billion cost overrun on the C5A aircraft project and then was dismissed, and ordered back pay totaling more than $100,000 for him.

title: VANDALISM WAVE HITS COOP CITY
description: Coop City in the Bronx was hit last night by a series of in cidents of vandalism including flooding in seven highrise buildings when fire hoses on top floors were turned on by unknown persons.

title: Latin President of U.N. Assembly
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 18At the end of an acrimonious debate a dis appointed Asian diplomat strolled over to Leopoldo Benites of Ecuador.

title: 30 of 93 Seized in Rhodesia Are Still Held by Guerrillas
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 18About 30 black children and young men and women, cap tured in their villages by bands of nationalist guerrillas Sept. 7 in the northeastern area of Rho desia, are still in the hands of the raiders.

title: Chilean Junta Puts Toll in Week at 95
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept 18 (AP)A spokesman for the Chil can junta, giving official figures for the first time, said today that 95 people had been killed and 300 wounded since last Tues day when the threeyearold Government of President Salva dor Allende Gossens was over thrown in a military coup.

title: Objets d'Art From Orient Auctioned at J.F.K. Airport
description: A collection of more than 400 antique ivories and 600 from the Orient, as well as 1,000 other items including jades, bronze sculptures, snuff bottles and Art Deco ivories is being auctioned off at Kennedy Air port's International Hotel.

title: King Riggs Match Point Is Money
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 18Some call it the tennis battle of the sexes or the $100,000 hustle or the Woodstock of the Bob by Riggs generation. But one thing is certain: When Billie Jean King and Bobby Riggs step out on an improvised court in the infield of the As trodrome Thursdaynight, the game they play will have more in common with a Ringling Brothers circus or a Cecil B.DeMille spectacle than with Wimbledon or Forest Hills.

title: DONALD HUTCHINSON, GYNECOLOGIST, DIES
description: PITTSBURGH; Sept. 18Dr. Donald L. Hutchinson, chair man of the department of ob stetrics and gynecology at the University of Pittsburgh, died of cancer yesterday in his home in suburban Fox Chapel. He was 47 years old.

title: GlamourIssue Decline Paces StockMarket Dip
description: Some of Wall Street's favor ite glamour stocksunsettled by the adverse Federalcourt decision affecting the Interna tional Business Machines Corpo ration  showed substantial losses yesterday.

title: Richfield Elects Officers
description: William F. Kieschnick Jr., has been elected an executive vice president and a member of the board of directors of the Atlantic Richfield Company. Richard M. Bressler and Fran cis X. McCormack have been elected senior vice presidents and Howard A. Slack a vice president.

title: $1.75Million for Right Arm
description: DETROIT, Sept. 18 (UPI)A 69yearold Detroit man who lost his right arm in a factory accident was awarded $1,750, 000 yesterday by a unanimous Wayne County Circuit Court Jury. Joseph Pippen, the victim, lost the arm Oct. 25, 1970, as he was removing scrap from a punch press at the Atlantic Die Casting Company of Detroit.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Federal judge in Newark yesterday upheld an Air Force decision to switch a potential $75million jetengine repair contract from the CurtissWright Company of Wood Ridge to a concern in Texas.

title: Mathews Rehired As Atlanta Pilot
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 18 (AP) The Atlanta Braves renewed the contract of Manager Eddie Mathews for next season, but dropped the pitching coach, Lew Burdette.

title: MITSUBISHI PLANS KOREAN VENTURE
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 18  The Mitsubishi group of Japan has proposed to invest in, the construction of a huge petrochemical complex on Ko rea's south coast in a joint venture with South Korean companies.

title: Books of The Times
description: KIND AND USUAL PUNISHMENT. The Prison Business. By Jessica Mit Jord, 340 pages. Illustrated with Charts and Tables. Knopf. $7.95.

title: BOMB CASE FIGURE FOUND GUILTY HERE
description: A State Supreme Court jury today convicted Carlos Felici ano, a Puerto Rican national ist, on four of six charges that stemmed from the discovery of a bomb that failed to go off at the General Electric Building at 51st Street and Lexington Avenue.

title: Era of Routine Violence Against Blacks by Whites in the South's Black Belt Appears Ended
description: LOWNDES COUNTY, Ala., Sept. 16There was a time in the South's Black Belt when blacks were routinely the vic tims of extreme abuse by whites.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
CHILE ATTACKING IDEOLOGY OF LEFT
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 18 The shooting has now largely ended in most of Chile, and a new kind of battle is beginning: an ideological struggle to try to wipe out the effects of three years of leftwing Government on the consciousness of the working class and the very poor, and to incorporate the middle class firmly into the support structure for the new regime.

title: Scarsdale Fights Bronx River Parkway Change
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 18 Sixty years ago a Scarsdale resident, Emily Butler, donated most of the 39 acres she owned along the Bronx River to encourage construction of a landscaped parkway.

title: Screen:Furie's 'Hit' Is a Caper Film Without Style. The Cast
description: Sidney J. Furie, the Canadian-born director who made a couple of good, concise films early in his career ("The Leather Boys," "The Ipcress File"), now seems to be turning out movies as if they were yard goods. His "Lady Sings the Blues," which had the good fortune to star Diana Ross, ran almost two and a half hours and still never got around to telling the real story of Billie Holiday.His new film, "Hit!", is a caper movies that was apparently designed as escapist entertainment, though by the time it enters its third hour you may well think you've been trapped. It isn't easy to leave a movie after you've invested that much time and money in it, no matter how foolish it is. You have a right to know how it turns out."Hit!" has a screenplay credited to Alan R. Trustman ("The Thomas Crown Affair") and David M. Wolf, but it looks very much like the sort of movie that was made up as it went along to match its landscapes (Los Angeles, Seattle, Marseilles).The story, for what it's worth, is about a black Federal agent (Billy Dee Williams) who, after his teenage daughter is killed by drugs, takes it upon himself to recruit, finance, train and transport to France a small band of private American citizens willing to assassinate the nine leaders of a Marseilles drug syndicate.Although the movie is about order outside law, it lacks even the offensive political purpose of something like Don Siegel's "Dirty Harry." It's a movie out for kicks, but the kicks are so implausible, so humorless, so without redeeming style and wit, that to sit through it is to give oneself a false low. In addition to Williams, the cast includes Richard Pryor, Gwen Welles, Paul Hampton, Warren Kemmerling, Janet Brandt and Sid Melton, who are the members of Williams's very unlikely gang. Miss Brandt and Melton, for example, play a nice little old Jewish couple who go along on the assassination trip as a way of thanking Uncle Sam for giving them a second chance. Miss Brandt slices the throat of her victim. Melton shoots his two targets in the chest and face."Hit!" opened yesterday at the Loews State 2 and Orpheum Theaters.

title: AMEX TOCKS GAIN AS TRADING RISES
ULSTER WARNING ISSUED BY HEATH
description: LONDON, Sept. 18  Prime Minister Heath issued a warn ing last nightwhich he ap parently retracted tonight that Northern Ireland might have to be fully integrated into Britain if the current efforts for a political solution failed.

title: Soviet Said to Seek World Red Meeting
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 18The So viet ??eadership is reportedly preparing the way for a world Communist meeting in Moscow next year after the European security conference, which opened in Geneva today.

title: Behind Swedish Vote Discontent
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 18The clich about Sweden is that she has the world's highest stand ard of living, income levels al most as high as the United States, an unparalleled system of socialwelfare benefits and pretty girls. The unanswered question is whether the Swedes are happy.

title: Meet Milton Milton
description: Milton Milton is unique in the an nals of education. If he bears resem blance to the black educator in Ralph Ellison's Invisible Man, he has taken the trouble, at least, to disguise his Uncle Tomism in a profusion of Afri can garb. If, in his dashikis and Yo ruba necklaces we faintly recognize the chairman of the SEEK department on the plush upper East Side, we can not completely credit that impression either, for, despite his very real physi cal existence, Milton Milton is a sym bol of the failure of the City University of New York to take remedial educa tion seriously.

title: RCA DEMONSTRATES LARGE IMAGE SENSOR
description: The RCA Corporation demon strated yesterday what it de scribed as the largest solid state image sensor in the in dustry.

description: CAMBODIA REPORTS OPENING OF RTE. 4

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A public relations and ad vertising concern in Wood mere, LI., agreed not to use the Nassau County seal on its stationery after two po litical opponents of Ralph G. Caso, the Republican County Executive, charged that such use created the impression of official endorsement.

title: I.M.F. Meeting: A Monetary Safari
description: The great monetary safari is about to begin. By the end of this week, the top financial of ficials of more than 120 nations will be assembling in Nairobi, Kenya, to continue their hunt for a new world monetary system.

title: Symphony Chief Thanks Musicians on Taking Cut
description: NEWARK, Sept. 18Alan V. Lowenstein, president of the New Jersey Symphony Orches tra, said today that he was grateful (or the decision of the orchestra's musicians to ac cept a reduced season.

Ernest Fitzgerald, the Air Force cost analyst who disclosed a $2billion cost overrun on the C5A aircraft project and then was dismissed, and ordered back pay totaling more than $100,000 for him. title: 3 SUPECTS SEIZED IN A COCAINE RING
description: A suspected major importer of cocaine and two alleged accomplices were arrested by a team of undercover policemen last night and charged with selling two and a quarter pounds of cocaine to one of the officers in a bar and grill in Brooklyn, the police reported.

title: Penn Central's Silver Went Once, Twice And Was Gone
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Penn Central Railroad, larg est and once the richest rail road in the land, has auc tioned off the family silver, 1,527 tarnished pieces long retired from its dining cars.

title: TORNADO STRIKES 2 AREAS ON L.I.
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 18 A tornado touched down in the South Bellmore area of Nassau County and the Calverton area of Suffolk County this mornng and uprooted trees, damaged automobiles, capsized small boats, broke windows and blew shingles off roofs.

title: Beanie Backers' Tact Deflates Protest
description: A group of demonstrators who won widespread public at tentkin when they were thrown out of a meeting of the City Council in Newark two weeks ago invaded a BeameforMay or campaign meeting yester day and encountered the po lite indifference of a roomful of demonstrationwise New York City politicians.

description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: New Model at Chrysler ...
description: The settlement of the brief strike of Chrysler workers may mark as much of a turning point in labor history as the memorable General Motors contract of 1948. That agreement represented a long step toward bringing an element of science into the determination of what con stituted a fair wage increase.

title: New Lights May Harm City Trees
description: The highintensity sodium streetlights that have been installed here to help re duce crime may be killing trees, according to research by the United States Depart ment of Agriculture.

title: The Assembly Convenes
description: Only a hardened cynic could fail to be moved by the bustling scene in the great hall beside the East River at the opening of the United Nations General Assembly. At such a time, in the climate of goodwill that prevails, it is difficult to believe that this organization, launched with great hopes by 51 member states in the after math of war 28 years ago, and now embracing 135 countries in every part of the world, cannot make useful contribution to global peace and security.

title: Food Riots Resume in India
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 18 (AP) Policemen opened fire on a mo?? and kited one man in Mysore state in southern India today as food riots broke out again after three days of peace. At least five persons were killed in riots last weekend that be gan as demonstrations for more and lowerpriced food.

title: Monies Won't Be Revalued
description: THE HAGUE, the Nether lands, Sept. 18 (Reuters)The Surinam And, Netherlands An tines  (Dutch West Indies) currencies will not be revalued to conform with last Saturday's 5 per cent tevaluation of the Dutch guider, according to messages reaching here today from the Dutch, West Indies.

title: SUN WITS PRICES OF GRAIN FUTURES
description: Sunshine in Chicago after days of rain in the Midwest was enough to depress prices yesterday for soybeans, wheat and corn on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Sex Equality in Coast Guard
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UPI)The House voted today to give women equal rights in the Coast Guard Reserve, in cluding the right to serve on combat vessels and to give or ders to men of lower rank.

title: TV Review
description: It's not as if there aren't enough problems hounding the primetime access rule, which took a half hour away from network programing each evening and gave it to the local stations. One major goal was to increase the di versity, and just posaibly the quality, of TV fare.

title: Chamberlain Is Playing A Guessing Game Again
description: Wilt Chamberlain is play ing his favorite guessing game again, a normal prac tice during most of his Na tional Basketball Association seasons. Chamberlain's fail ure to report to the Los An geles training camp, coupled with the Lakers' acquisition of Elmore Smith, a 7foot1 inch center, from the Buffalo Braves for Jim McMillian, stirred reports even more yesterday.

title: 2 Catholic Schools New Bomb Targets In Northern Ireland
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 18 (UPI)Two more Roman Catholic schools here were hit by bombs during the night, the third and fourth tar gets this week of what the British Army said may be part of a campaign by Protestant extremists to cripple parochial school facilities.

title: Ne Win, in Power 11 Years in Burma, Still an Enigmatic Figure
description: RANGOON, Burma, Sept. 12  Eleven years after Ne Win seized power in Burma, he re mains one of the most remote and enigmatic leaders in Asia.

title: Santa Fe Railway Planning $90Million '74 Expenditure
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 18 (AP) The Santa Fe Railway said to day it planned to spend about $90million for locomotives and freight cars as, part of Its 1974 capital expenditures.

title: Smith, Ashe Win In Pacific Tennis
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18 (AP)Stan Smith opened the defense of his Pacific South west tennis championship to day with a 64, 64 victory over Mike Machette, a young player he helped to develop.

title: Antiwar Groups to Oppose U.S. Aid to Saigon Prisons
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17 A coalition of antiwar and church groups opened the In ternational Days of Concern for South Vietnamese Political Prisoners here today.

title: State P.G.A. Golf Put Off
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Sept. 18 (AP)Rain forced postponement of to day's opening round of the $30,000 New York State Professional Golfers' As soclation Tourney.

title: Kissinger and Callieres
description: WASHINGTONHenry. Kissinger is probably better qualifredlthan any oth er man to become American Secretary of State and, despite the lamentable political atmosphere in this country, one is justified in hoping this promise will be borne out by success.

title: U.S. Loses Bid to Dismiss Suit to Close Tax Loophole
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18  Federal District Court Judge June Green has denied a Gov ernment motion to dismiss a suit that seeks to close a tax loophole for making political campaign contributions.

title: COMMODITY ME SEEKS REGULATION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 18 (AP)  An executive from one of the giants of the grain business told a House subcommittee to day that the Commodities Ex change Authority should be enlarged, strengthened, and made an independent, agency similar to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Nancy H. Wadelton Jersey Bride
description: RUMSON, N. J., Sept. 18 Miss Nancy. Harris Wadelton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis B. Wadelton, of Fair Haven, was married here to day to Charles Peters Seger. The ceremony was performed at St. George'sbytheRiver Episcopal Church by the Rev. G. P. Mellick Belshaw.

title: Goldin Proposes to Add Creativity To Workings of Controller's Office
description: Volunteering lavish praise of Abraham D. Beame, his mayor al running mate, State Senator Harrison J. Goldin spoke ex pansively yesterday of his plans to infuse new creativi ty into the City Controller's office as Mr. Beame's heir.

title: SOME NIXON AIDES HINT THAT AGNEW OUGHT TO RESIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 Some high White House officials have been saying in private con versations in the last few days that it might be best for Vice President Agnew to resign and allow President Nixon to choose a new Vice President.

title: N.Y.U. Says It Has Recovered From Brink of Bankruptcy
description: New York University has pulled itself back from the brink of bankruptcy and turned a corner with grow ing enrollments, a vanishing deficit and the opening of im portant new physical facilities, according to to its president, James M. Hester.

title: Pentagon Says PopUp Missile Gives Soviet Heavier Warhead
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 The Soviet Union, according to Defense Department officials, has developed a popup tech nique for launching missiles that could significantly increase the warhead payload of its inter continental missile force.

title: Seoul Says It Has No Clues In Tokyo Kidnapping Inquiry
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 18  A senior official of the Seoul district prosecutor's of fice announced today that South Korean investigators had been unable to find any clues as to who kidnapped Kim Dae Jung, a Korean opposition lead er, in Tokyo and brought him to Seoul early last month.

description: Wilt Chamberlain is play ing his favorite guessing game again, a normal prac tice during most of his Na tional Basketball Association seasons. Chamberlain's fail ure to report to the Los An geles training camp, coupled with the Lakers' acquisition of Elmore Smith, a 7foot1 inch center, from the Buffalo Braves for Jim McMillian, stirred reports even more yesterday.

title: Ship Free Off Gulfport, Miss.
description: GULFPORT, Miss., Sept. 18 (UPI)A Danish ship carrying 4,000 tons of frozen meat to the United States was freed today after running aground in the Mississippi Sound. The Bel gian Reefer, which had been stuck since Sunday night, was pulled free by two tugs during high tide.

title: Panel Told of Thefts By Police in Albany
description: ALBANY, Sept. 18The State Commission of Investigation, opening hearings today into al leged corruption in the Albany Police Department, heard wit nesses testify that policemen had carried out burglaries, had covered up the crimes with of ficial sanction and then had sought to intimidate citizens who complained.

title: Records: Solti, Ashkenazy in Beethoven Concertos
description: The smartest way to col lect the complete Beethoven piano concertos is to buy them individually, and ideally to get more than one per formance of at least some of them: These are such rich pieces that no one pair of pianists and conductors can hope to say all there is to say on even one of them, let alone on all five.

title: O'Connor's Record 61 Marks Ryder Cup Practice
description: GULLANE; Scotland, Sept. 18While the United States Ryder Cup team participated in its first formal practice session today, Christy O'Con nor of Dublin buoyed the hopes of Britain and Ireland's squad with a round of 61.

title: Lewisohn Offers FivePoint Plan To Strengthen City Controller
description: Richard Lewisohn, the Re publican party candidate for City Controller, yesterday is sued a fivepoint program to improve the operation of the office and to establish a sys tem of continuous monitoring of municipal agencies.

title: Lake ErieOntario Canal Called Unjustified in Rep
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 18 (AP) The Army Corps of Engine has announced that an a American canal Connect Lakes Erie and Ontario is ?? economically justified.

title: O'Connor's Record 61 Marks Ryder Cup Practice
description: GULLANE, Scotland, Sept. 18While the United States Ryder Cup team participated in its first formal practice session today, Christy O'Con nor of Dublin buoyed the hopes of Britain and Ireland's squad with a round of 61.

title: I.B.M. CRITICIZES AWARD TO TELEX
description: Frank T. Cary, chairman of the International Business Ma chines Corporation said yester day that Federal Judge A. Sher man Christensen's ruling against I.B.M. in its antitrust case with the Telex Corpora tion goes beyond that of any judicial precedent and contains serious errors of fact and law.

title: Beatrice Foods Raises Earnings 25%
F.D.A. Says Tests Show Canned Milk to Be Safe
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UPI)The Food and Drug Administration said today it had tested more than 36,000 cans of evaporated milk and concluded there was no dan ger of high lead content.

title: Senate Unit Acts on Chrome
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved a bill to day to halt the importation of Rhodesian chrome ore. The bill, by Senator Hubert Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, would repeal a 1971 action by Con gress allowing imports of the ore despite sanctions imposed by the United Nations Security Council.

title: Working Women: The Job Ahead
description: It became evident in the course of an allday confer ence on women and work held Monday that, as feminist Ronnie, Eldridge put it, wo men are now bringing their values into a changing world.

title: WOMAN, 74, SHOT IN QUEENS HOME
description: A 74yearold woman was re ported in fair condition yester day after being shot in the hallway of her Queens home by a young man who stole her purse containing $14, her wrist watch and a bag of groceries she was carrying.

title: Widow, Citing Possible lncrirnination, Balks at Queries on Husband's Murder
description: PATERSON, Sept. 19  The widow of a wealthy paving con tractor has refused on the ground of possible selfincrimi nation to answer 103 of 104 questions asked her in a civil suit that charges she inten tionally, willfully and wrong fully caused his death.

title: TV Networks to Rotate Watergate Coverage
description: The three commercial tele vision networks will continue their rotating live coverage of the Senate Watergate hearings for the next week's sessions, spokesmen an nounced yesterday.

title: Inquiry in St. Louis Strike
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 19 (UPI) The National Labor Relations Board investigated today charges against teamsters of unfair labor practices as a strike against the St. Louis PostDispatch, entered its fifth week.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: New Jersey's schoolboy football season opens this weekend with North and Central Jersey offering 10 games tomorrow, 116 Saturday and 10 Sunday. The early con sensus is that Westfield, Montclair, North Bergen, Clifton, Summit, Hackensack and Seton Hall will be the dominant teams.

title: Opera
description: Seeing Bizet's Carmen at the Metropolitan Opera on Tuesday night was particular ly interesting in that a pro duction experienced a year ago as new and arresting was now being put on view as a standard repertory item.

title: Islanders' Future Orr: Denis Potvin
description: PETERBOROUGH, Ontario, Sept. 19The difference is immediately felt in the Is landers' camp, where they are preparing for Year Two of their National Hockey League careers.

title: Leonardo's Mirror  Writing: Just $10,000, for the Set
description: A homemade scrapbook full of hardtoread mirror handwriting is slated to go into publication this winter at a price of $10,000, which makes it perhaps the world's most expensive new set of books.

title: Screen: Ferreri's La Grande Bouffe
description: Marco Ferreri, the Italian director whose La Grande Bouffe (The Big Feast) opened at the Little Carnegie yesterday, is best known here for three films: The Con jugal Bed (1963), in which an eager 40yearold bride groom becomes a fatality, the victim of his lusty young wife's sexual appetites; The Ape Woman (1964), about a wretched lady covered with hair like a sheepdog's fur, and The Man With the Bal loons, about a fellow who is so obsessed with finding out how much air a balloon con tains that he goes crazy and commits suicide.

title: Advertising: Gainer and Loser
description: Kenyon & Eckhardt has become a victim of the energy crisis and Ogilvy & Mather a beneficiary.

title: Colson, Citing Fifth, Balks at Questions
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 Charles W. Colson refused to day to answer questions put tc him by the Senate Watergate committee, claiming his con stitutional right against selfin crimination.

title: Net Rises at Distillers Corp.Seagrams
Equity Financing
description: McDonald's Corporation has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a secondary offering of 952,312 common shares, 100,000 of which are being sold by chair man, Ray A. Kroc. After the sale, Mr. Kroc will own 7,016,402 shares. The company's stock was up  at 68 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Personal Finance
description: One of the biggest gripes of the small investor is that he is unable to get in on the big money because he has only a few thousand dollars to invest.

title: Seton Hall Coed Found Slain Beside Her Car in Roselle Lot
description: A 19yearold coed at Seton Hall University in South Or ange, N. J., was found slain early yesterday by a 19year old boy walking his dog in a wooded lot in Roselle, N. J.

title: Rebel Reports Hijacking Bid Against Selassieby Prince
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 19 (AP)  The Eritrean Liberation Front said today that Haile Selassie's grandson held the Ethiopian Emperor at gunpoint aboard an airborne jetliner last week and tried to force him to abdicate 4.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: The Bleeding Stops
description: In ordering the Air Force to reinstate A. Ernest Fitz gerald to his post as Deputy for Management Systems, the Civil Service Commission has exonerated a public servant who placed the taxpayers' interests above bureaucratic team spirit.

title: Ryan Shatters League Record For StrikeOuts
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., Sept. 19 (AP)Nolan Ryan broke the American League one season strikeout record and pitched a fivehitter in lead ing the California Angels to a 62 victory over the Texas Rangers tonight in the first game of a doubleheader.

title: Housing or Facade?
description: The need for new approaches to public housing is in contestable. The deterioration and abandonment of costly highrise developments in some bigcity slums have brought even wellrun projects into disreputeoften un fairly.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Sept. 20, 1973 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Prices Rising on Just Plain Spaghetti
description: Prices of such simple foods as spaghetti for the family and frankfurters and hamburgers in fastfood outlets have started an upward climb in the city.

title: SECURITY PARLEY TO HEAR 6 STATES
description: GENEVA, Sept. 19The 35 nation European security con ference decided today to allow delegates of Israel and five Arab countries to appear be fore it and present their views on the continent's security.

title: Judge Calls Show Ring No Place for Two Hats
description: When Mrs. Mary Stephen son moved from the East to Phoenix, Ariz., several months ago, she chose a house last a 15minute drive to the airport. And with good reason. She now is doing so much judging, she's in a plane almost weekend.

title: Canadian Javelin Reports British Kynoch Venture
description: Canadian Javelin, Ltd., an nounced yesterday at Montreal that British Kynoch Metals, Ltd., has signed a letter of intent to purchase the entire initial production of blister cop per from Canadian Javelin's proposed Cerro Colorado Cop per project in Panama. It is expected that the project's out put, estimated at around 88,000 tons of copper ore a day in the initial stage, would he extended as output is increased.

title: Mary Wigman, Dance Innovator, Dies
description: BERLIN, Sept. 19 (UPI)  Mary Wigman, the German dancer and choreographer who Was a leader of the pioneer moderndance movement, died last night. Her age was 86 Miss Wigman broke her thigh three years ago and never re covered from the accident.

title: Charlotte Curtis Will Succeed Salisbury as the OpEd Editor
description: Charlotte Curtis, Family/Style editor of The New York Times, has been appointed editor of the OpEd page as successor to Harrison E. Salisbury, effective upon his retirement, it was an nounced yesterday by John B. Oakes, editor of the editorial page of The Times.

title: Consumer Groups Briefed On Thrift Unit Proposals
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (Reuters)The Nixon Admin istration moved today to enlist the support of consumer groups for its proposals to restructure the nation's financial system. One of the main proposals would allow saving institutions to offer interestbearing check ing accounts.

title: Reuss Seeks to Extend Reserve Requirements
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (Reuters)A bill to make all Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation member banks subject to the reserve re quirement regulations of the Federal Reserve Board was introduced by Congressman Henry S. Reuss, Democrat of Wisconsin, a member of the House Banking Committee.

title: Philadelphia Electric Set To Give Minority Back Pay
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 (AP)The Philadelphia Electric Company consented today to give $250,000 in back pay to minority employes and agreed to improve their employment opportunities.

title: Convict Cited for Contempt
description: ROCHESTER, Sept. 19 (AP)  A convict who refused to answer a prosecutor's questions in a murder trial yesterday got a sevenmonth jail sentence for contempt of court. The man, Leonard Felder, 21 years old, was given the penalty in State Supreme Court in the trial of Richard S. Anderson, 22, who is accused of murdering William Alexander last year.

title: L.I.U. Gets Vice Chancellor
description: Malcolm MacKay has re signed as First Deputy Super intendent of Insurance for New York State to become vice chancellor of Long Island Uni versity.

title: ExPatrolman Testifies He Committed 16 BreakIns With Other Albany Police
description: ALBANY, Sept. 19  A for mer policeman told the State Commission of Investigation to day that he had committed 16 burglaries with 11 fellow po licemen, including a lieutenant and two sergeants still on the force.

title: Pirate Ship Begins Broadcast Off Jersey
description: ABOAD THE M.V. OCEAN IC, Sept. 19Defying the Fed eral Government, the Rev. Carl McIntire put an unlicensed ra dio station on the air today from this pirate ship 12 miles off Cape May, N. J.

title: PAYMENTS DEFICIT REDUCED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 The deficit in the nation's basic balance of interna tional payments  generally considered the most meaning ful of the four definitions used declined further in the sec ond quarter to the lowest level in almost three years, the Com merce Department reported to day.

title: Feisty, LowCost Godot
description: The Jean Cocteau Theater, one of a number of offOff Broadway houses clustered around the Bowery, is em barked, in its third year, on its first season of repertory. Under the direction of Eve Adamson, the Jean Cocteau is rotating Waiting for Godot, Jean Anouilh's Me dea, No Fit Place for a Child to Play (a compilation from the words of Edna St. Vincent Millay, adapted and performed by Jere Jacob) and, beginning this Saturday, Ionesco's The Lesson. All the plays are cast with actors from the Jean Cocteau's small resident company.

title: EARL W. BENNETT OF DOW CHEMIAL
description: MIDLAND, Mich., Sept. 19 (AP)  Earl W. Bennett, former Board chairman of the Dow Chemicl Company, died today. He was 94 years old.

title: 2 EXPOLICEMEN GUILTY OF ASSAULT
description: Two former plainclothes po licemen pleaded guilty yester day to charges stemming from their having illegally abducted, shot and arrested a man so that one of the policemen would have to go to court the next day and thus not have to go on patrol that night.

title: ARAB ROLE DENIED IN OIL SHORTAGE
description: The energy difficulties of the United States are not the result of any Arab oil squeeze, at least up to now, John Lichtblau, head of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, said yes terday.

title: Brezhnev Excerpts
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 19  Fol lowing is an unofficial trans lation of excerpts from a speech by Leonid 1. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, delivered today in Sofia, Bulgaria, and transmitted to Moscow by Tass, the Soviet press agency:

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:

title: F.B.I. Reportedly Trailed Columnist on Visit to Paris
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 The Nixon Administration or dered a highranking F.B.I. of ficial to follow Joseph Kraft, the syndicated columnist, to Paris in 1969 and to arrange with the French government to keep him under electronic and physical surveillance during the visit, according to sources familiar with the operation.

title: Warmup for Columbia
description: Columbia will face Wil liams in a preseason football game at Baker Field Satur day at 2 P.M. Tickets will cost $2 for adults and $1 for youngsters under 18, with children under 6 admitted free. Columbia opens its regular home season Sept. 29 against Bucknell.

title: PRESIDENT URGES U.S ALLOWANCES TO SPUR HOUSING
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 President Nixon, in a message to Congress, proposed today that the Government provide housing allowances for poor and moderateincome families rather than continue what he described as a wasteful, in equitable system of subsidizing buildings for the needy.

title: U.S. Propane Allocation Seen As Threat to Local Gas Supply
description: The chairman of the state Public Service Commission warned yesterday that a pro posed Federal priority plan for allocating propane gas supplies could cut off gas heat for 1.5 million families in Brooklyn, parts of Queens and Staten Island, all Long Island and sev eral upstate areas on the cold est days this winter.

title: World Poll Finds Many Leaders Take Less Positive View of U.N.
description: A survey released yesterday by Gallup International reports that 45 per cent of leading fig ures in 70 nonCommunist na tions say their attitude toward the United Nations has become less favorable. No change in view was reported by 37 per cent.

title: Schedules In Playoffs Established
description: There will be no days off for travel in the American and National League play offs unless the Los Angeles Dodgers beat the Cincinnati Reds for first place in the National League's Western Division, the baseball com missioner's office said yes terday.

title: SAIGON CHARGES HANOI WAR MOVES
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Sept. 20 (AP)The South Vietnamese Government today charged Hanoi with making intensive warlike prep arations to reopen hostilities' in South Vietnam.

title: NIXON'S LAWYERS SEEM TO RULE OUT ACCORD ON TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19  President's Nixon's lawyers, strongly hinting that they would reject any outofcourt compro mise on Presidential tape re cordings, declared today that their client would not delegate his constitutional duties and prerogatives to Archibald Cox, the Watergate special prosecu tor.

title: Links With Soviet: Criticism Stings Administration
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 The Nixon Administration has been stung by the growing criticism in the United States and in Soviet dissident circles of its effort to move from con frontation to cooperation with the Soviet Union.

title: Mrs. Allende Now Feels Husband Was Murdered
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 19The widow of President Sal vador Allende Gossens of Chile said today that on the basis of new information she had received since her husband's death, she now believed that he did not commit suicide, but was murdered by the mili tary forces that overthrew his Government eight days ago.

title: Minimum Wage Fiasco
description: The failure of the House of Representatives to override President Nixon's veto of the minimum wage bill con demns millions of workers at the bottom of the income scale to intolerable exploitation in a period of skyrocket ing living costs.

title: MRS. ERIK L. JENSEN
description: LONDONDERRY, Vt., Sept. 19  Mrs. Johanna Stephan Jensen, widow of the Rev. Erik L. Jensen, pastor emeritus of Immanuel Lutheran Church in New Rochelle, N. Y., died Sun day in Grace Cottage Hospital in Townshend. She was 84 years old.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: New York Panel Studies Belgrade City Services
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 19Members of the Tem porary State Charter Revision Commission for New York City are engaged in wideranging discussions with officials here to find out whether the capital city of a Marxist country has something to teach them about ways to improve municipal services and give citizens a sense of involvement.

title: For Chilean Conciliation
description: Chile's new military Government has wisely ended censorship of outgoing news dispatches and allowed a planeload of foreign reporters to fly in from Argentina. The outside world will thus have its first chance to judge the junta's claim that the situation in Chile has largely returned to normal after the violent overthrow of the Popular Unity Government and the tragic death of Presi dent Salvador Allende.

title: REHNQUIST CAUTIONS ON DISQUALIFICATION
description: Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist of the Supreme Court suggested last night that too many judges may be disqualify ing themselves from sitting on cases on the grounds of per sonal interest and bias.

title: Look Down, Those Weeds Could Be the Makings of a Salad
description: One thing that struck me this season, said Sally Ann Lederman, was to hear people say how expensive lettuce was  that tasteless stuff  when just by stoop ing down they could gather a week's supply of salad.

title: SENATE APPROVES PENSION REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19  The Senate passed tonight a bill for Federal standards to protect the rights of workers covered by private pension plans. The vote was unanimous, 93 to 0.

title: U.S. Court Refuses to Bar Fire Island Development
description: A Federal judge yesterday refused a request by Fire Is land property owners to order a halt to all commercial devel opment on the island.

title: A Cannery Connection
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  The pungent smell of peaches and pears being canned and the constant droning of cans clanking and machinery buzzing are enough to make any newcomer sick.

title: Blood Ritual Cheers CholeraAnxious Naples
description: NAPLES, Italy, Sept. 19 (Reuters)  Thousands of Neapolitans, anxious about the cholera outbreak that has killed 26 people, rejoiced today when Corrado Cardi nal Ursi reported that the miracle they had hoped for had happenedthe blood of St. Januarius, or San Gen naro, had liquefied.

title: GULF OIL RAISES GASOLINE PRICES
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation an nounced yesterday that it had increased its gasoline prices to dealers and jobbers by 0.9 cent, effective immediately. Gulf, which followed a similar action earlier in the week by the At lantic Richfield Company, said that it regrets that Phase 4 regulations do not now permit the dealer to pass the increase through to the customer. A com pany spokesman said Gulf realized the action imposed an increased burden on dealers whose pumps already carry the legal ceiling price and has urged that the Cost of Living Council reg ulations be revised so as not to penalize the dealer.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Federal Government has approved the controver sial alignment of Interstate Route 895 across Burlington County to link Route 295 in New Jersey with Route 95 in Pennsylvania, the State Transportation Department announced today. The announcement came nearly four years after Democratic charges during the 1969 guberna torial campaign that Governor Cahill, then the Republican nominee, could enrich himself and his associates by influencing the alignment of I895 so that it would pass near a planned development in which they had an interest.

title: Hungarian Official Dies
description: BUDAPEST. Hungary, Sept. 19 (UPI)  Deputy Premier Peter Valyi died yesterday of in juries suffered when he fell into a cauldron of molten metal at the Lenin metalworks in Miskolc, northern Hungary, on Saturday, the Hungarian press agency said. He was 54 years old. Witnesses said a crane ran out of control and pushed Mr. Valyi into the pit.

title: Rainbow Room Reverts to Style By Adding Performers to Menu
description: After a hiatus of more than 30 years, entertainment has returned to the Rainbow Room on a regular, fivenightsaweek basis. On Jan. 1, 1948, the room, which had been one of the city's most elegant night clubs since it opened in Octo ber, 1934, lighting up the New York skyline on the 65th floor of the R.C.A. Building, closed during the World War II black out. Since it is reopening after the war, the emphasis has been on food and drink, with enter tainment only on special occa sions.

title: WIDOW IS SILENT IN MURDER QUIZ
description: PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 19 The widow of a wealthy pay ing contractor has refused on the ground of possible selfin crimination to answer 103 on 104 questions asked her in a civil suit that charges she in tentionally, willfully and wrongfully caused his death.

title: Notes on People
description: The country's highestrank ing education official, Sidney P. Marland Jr., resigned yes terday, for reasons of time, age and economics.

title: Tuesday's Fight
description: Miami  Vinnie Curto, 172 pounds, Miami, knocked out Tommy Hicks, 175, Ithaca, N. Y., 8 rounds.

title: Smith Struggles To Win in 3 Sets
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 (AP) Stan Smith struggled to beat 20  year  old Dick Bohrnstedt of Redlands, 57, 62, 63, in the second round of the $75,000 Pacific South west open tennis tournament today.

title: Mr. Hogan's Candidacy
description: Manhattan District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's name will appear on the ballot this November as the nominee of all four major political parties in New York City. The outpouring of support for him in the June Democratic primary, where he easily repelled the only challenge to his candidacy for a ninth term, indicates the distress that will be widely felt over the disclosure that he suf fered a minor stroke last month and underwent major lung surgery two weeks ago.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Ave nue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8 P.M. (RadioWHN, 8 P.M.)

title: CoOp City Agreement Reached After Bronx Board Settlement
description: A tentative agreement to end a fiveday strike by 400 build ing service workers at Coop City in the Bronx was an nounced early today by the State Mediatioh Board.

title: Giants Lose Thompson and Get Roland
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 19 The New York Giants lost one of their running backs, Rocky Thompson, for the sea son today, but gained another in Johnny Roland, a free agent reject from the St. Louis Cardinals who could turn out to be a real bargain.

title: LEON KEMPNER
description: Leon Kempner, a retired advertising and public relations man who had worked on the Work's Progress Administra tion's New York Guidebook in the nineteenthirties, died Tues day, apparently of a heart attack, at St. Vincent's Hospi tal. He was 71 years old and lived at 417 West 19th Street.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TRIBUTES George Gersh win would have been 75 years old next Wednesday had he not died, with all that prolific musical genius, in 1937. The anniversary is not going unmarked, with the publication of several books about Gershwin, a film ret rospective here and an exhibition now running at the downstairs Hallmark Gallery, Fifth Avenue and 56th Street (5829130).

title: Profit Gains Reported By T.W.A. and National
description: Trans World Airlines, Inc., and National Airlines both reported yesterday increased earnings for August.

title: The Agnew Resignation Question
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19  Should Vice President Agnew resign? Will he resign?

title: ExNight Club Dancer Loses Her Bid to Avoid Extradition
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 (AP) Lillian Reis, onetime night club owner and dancer, has lost in a legal bid to avoid extradition to Florida to serve a twoyear jail sentence on a drug conviction.

title: Newcombe Gains At Columbia Net
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Sept. 19 (AP)Topseeded John New combe of Australia disposed of Britain's Graham Stillwell, 64, 64, in today's opening round of the first Palmetto tennis classic.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Federal Government has approved the contro versial alignment of Interstate Route 895 across Burling ton County to link Route 295 in New Jersey with Route 95 in Pennsylvania, the State Transportation Department announced today. The announcement came nearly four years after Democratic charges during the 1969 guberna torial campaign that Governor Cahill, then the Republican nominee, could enrich himself and his associates by influ encing the alignment of I895 so that it would pass near a planned development in which they had an interest.

title: Pilot Unit's Chief Threatens Drastic Action on Terrorism
description: ROME, Sept. 19 (Reuters) The leader of the 50,000 inter national airline pilots warned today that pilots would take drastic action to halt air terror ism if nations and airlines evaded their responsibility.

title: D. Johnson Sets Mark; Aaron Idle
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 A crowd of 40,000 (including 31,012 paying at Dodger Stadium tonight, disappointed at Hank Aaron's decision not to play or even pinch hit, had to settle for seeing an other sort of homerun his tory being made by Davey Johnson, who hit his 43rd homer of the season as the Atlanta Braves lost to Los Angeles, 41.

title: RICHARD S. ROBIE, 70, CARRENTAL LEADER
description: BOSTON, Sept. 19 (AP) Richard S. Robie, a financier and leader in the automobile and truckrental industry, died yesterday in Peter Ben Brig ham Hospital, He was 70 years old and had homes in Marble head and in Mirror Lake, N. H.

title: GOVERNOR'S TRIAL IS ENDED IN SAMOA
description: PAGO PAGO, American Sa moa, Sept. 19Testimony in the trial of Gov. John M. Hay don on charges of violating the Hatch Act ended late yester day while political controversy and intrigue continued to swirl around the proceedings and the Government of this tiny Amer ican territory in the South Pa cific.

title: MAURICE M. FRIEDMAN
description: Maurice M. Friedman, a law yer who had also been executive director of the New York Fur niture Merchants Association, died yesterday at his home, 10 East 70th Street. He was 65 years old.

title: Miss Casals Scores Uphill Net Victory
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 19 (AP) Rosemary Casals of San Francisco fought back to de feat 16yearold Kathy Kuy kendall of Miami, 46, 62, 63, and move into the quar terfinals of the $30,000 wo men's tennis tournament to night.

title: PAYMENTS DEFICIT REDUCED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 The deficit in the nation's basic balance of interna tional payments  generally considered the most meaning ful of the four definitions used declined further in the sec ond quarter to the lowest level in almost three years, the Com merce Department reported to day.

title: I.B.M.'s 11Point Gain Paces A Broad Rally on Stock Market
description: A strong recovery in Inter national Business Machines, the leading glamour Issue of Wall Street, sparked a broad rally yesterday in the stock market.

title: Phils Down Cards, 32
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 (UPI)Denny Doyle doubled to highlight a tworun fifth inning tonight and give Steve Carlton and the Philadelphia Phillies a 32 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Marijuana Seized on Yacht
description: MIAMI, Sept. 19 (UPI)The Coast Guard seized $5million worth of marijuana today aboard, a 43foot yacht in the Bahamas. Two Miami men, identified as Nelson Lopez Paz and Dagoberto Norquez, sur rendered themselves and their boat the authorities said.

title: Riggins, Not Nance, Seems Set To Start Sunday Against Colts
description: Snuffed out of the Jets' starting offensive unit so quickly after having worked so diligently to rekindle his pro football career this year, Jim Nance might be expected to be bitter or at least won der out loud what a guy has to do to merit a legitimate shot at keeping a starting job.

title: REBELS IN BURK SPREADING SOUTH
description: RANGOON, Burma, Sept 14 Thousands of Chinesesup ported insurgents, long in control of dense jungles in northeast Burma, are slowly moving. Southward.

title: Cubs Beat Expos, 86, on 3 Clouts
description: CHICAGO, Sept 19 (AP)  Tworun homers by Rick Monday, Ron Santo and Billy Williams enabled the Chicago Cubs to overcome Montreal's early fiverun lead and de feat the Expos today, 86.

title: Nixon to Concentrate On Domestic Problems
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)President Nixon plans to concentrate on domestic problems until Congress re cesses. Aides say the date of any European trip is now uncertain.

title: FOUR G.O.P. SENATORS HAD HEAVY SUPPORT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) Four incumbent Republican Senators who were reelected last year raised, more than a third of the funds received by all 33 Republican Senate candi dates, according to Common Cause, which describes itself as a citizens lobby.

title: Agnew's Aides Studying 100YearOld Case
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19  Aides to Vice President Agnew, researching possible courses of action by nun, have been study ing a 100yearold precedent that indicates he might do well to sit tight in his present office.

title: BUSING BECOMES A CAMPAIGN ISSUE
description: TRENTON, Sept. 19  The Democratic and Republican candidates for Governor of New Jersey clashed sharply to day over making a campaign controversy of the racially di visive and politically explosive issue of regional school con solidation and the forced bus ing that it involves.

title: Leonardo's MirrorWriting: Just $10,000 for the Set
description: A homemade scrapbook full of hardtoread mirror handwriting is slated to go into publication this winter at a price of $10,000, which makes it perhaps the world's most expensive new set of books.

title: RETURN OF REFUGEES BEGUN BY PAKISTAN
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 19 The repatriation of Bengali war refugees from Pakistan and nonBengalis from Bangladesh started today, in the wake of the agreement in New Delhi last month between India and Pakistan for the normalization of relations on the subcon tinent.

title: Knight Chain Picks Hills as Chairman And Chief Officer
description: In major changes in the top management of the Knight Newspapers, Inc., of Miami, the directors yesterday elected Lee Hills as the chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Goldwater Thinks Agnew Might Resign if Indicted
description: Senator Barry Goldwater said yesterday that he believed Vice President Agnew would con sider resigning if he were in dicted, rather than put the country and himself through long impeachment proceeding.

title: NEW KING BEGINS REIGN IN SWEDEN
description: STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 19Sweden's new King, Carl XVI Gustaf, was formally in stalled today but not crowned. His reign began a few hours before final unofficial returns confirmed that the governing Social Democrats would have the backing of only half the members of Parliament elected last Sunday.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Show Drop at Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 Yields on oneyear Treasury bills dropped to the lowest level since June in the Gov ernment's sale today of $1.8 billion of these shortterm securities.

title: Decisive in Decisions
description: There was an inexhaustible output of letters, often on small note paper, both to close associates and slight acquaintances. They were short, perhaps two or three paragraphs, and, as the typ ing errors indicated, he often pecked them out himself, typ ically late at night, when all others but the cleaning crew had left. In the more than three dec ades when C. R. Smith presided over the development of American Airlines into one of the giants of a rough and dynamic business, he spent long hours at his work though carefully scheduling time for relaxation and con templation.

title: NixonBhutto Talks End Without Pledge of Arms
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 Prime Minister Zulfikar All Bhutto of Pakistan wound up two days of talks with Presi dent Nixon and Administration officials today without succeed ing in his stated aim of loosen ing the United States embargo on arms sales.

title: Police Surprise Holdup Men
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 19 (AP)  The police in suburban Amherst surprised two holdup men emerging from a supermarket yesterday and killed one and captured the other after a running gun battle. The police said they had received a tip that the robbery was going to take place and were waiting in the store's parking lot when the robbers emerged.

title: PAUL RASKIN
description: CEDARHURST, L. I., Sept. 19Paul Raskin, who retired in 1969 as vice president of the Lightolier Corporation, manufacturer of lighting fix tures, died today, apparently of a cerebral hemorrhage, in Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre. He was 74 years old and lived at 288 Cedarhurst Avenue.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: The Bear Fact
description: MATANE, QuebecThere was a time when Raoul Roux, the ebullient proprietor of Hotel Belle Plage on the northwest corner of the Gasp Peninsula, had to have help from a black bear to attract business, but that no longer applies.

title: POLICE CHECK LINK IN TWINS' SLAYING
description: EDISON, Sept. 19The po lice said today they were check ing, among other leads, the pos sibility of a connection between the slaying of twin brothers here yesterday and the killing in Newark 15 days ago of James Shabazz, a Black Mus lim leader.

title: Business Briefs
description: Chrysler Signs Pact With Honda

title: People and Business
description: The quest for a kind of monetary golden fleece agreement on the value of Special Drawing Rights, or paper goldhas still a long way to go, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Anthony Barber, said yester day at a conference of Com monwealth finance ministers in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania.

title: Six Named to Find a Home For Schomburg Collection
description: ALBANY, Sept. 19  Gov ernor Rockefeller, today ap pointed six persons to a com mittee that will try to find a permanent home for the Schom burg Collection of AfroAmerican history.

title: 200 Said to Be Out $50,000 Over a Defunct Day Camp
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 19 (AP) At least 200 Connecticut resi dents paid close to $50,000 to enroll their children in a de funct day camp this summer, a lawyer for the state's Con sumer Protection Department testified today.

title: SMITH RETURNED AT AMERICAN AIR
description: Directors of American Air lines returned C. R. Smithat 74, almost 10 years older than any other major airline chief in the nationas chairman and chief executive officer yester day in the hope that he can pull the troubled airline out of its financial dilemma.

title: LAX CONTROL SEEN ON DRUG TESTING
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19A Congressional report made pub lic today charged that because of lax enforcement of drug laws the public is being inade quately protected from poten tial hazards posed by experi mental medicines.

title: Yachtman Rents Plane and Spots Stolen Ketch Bound for Europe
description: Two Long Island teenagers with dreams of sailing to Eu rope in a $110,000 ketch they allegedly stole were seized on Long Island Sound yesterday after an airandsea search di rected partly by the boat's owner from a rented airplane.

title: Miss Kanarek Upset
description: Carol Weymuller won the Brooklyn women's tennis tournament, a new event, by upsetting top  seeded Mimi Kanarek in the final yester day, 75, 41, retired. Miss Kanarek, the East's fourth ranking player, became in disposed and could not finish the match at the Hiway Club.

title: Canadian International Paper Co. Rejects New Union Proposals
description: The United Paperworkers In ternational Union said in Mon treal yesterday that labor contract negotiations had been broken off with the Canadian International Paper Company after the newsprint manufac turer rejected the union's latest proposals.

title: Stocks Rally Broadly
description: The stock market staged a broad and spirited rally yes terday as the DowJones in dustrials rose 19.11 points to 910.37. A recovery in I.B.M. shares, climbing 11 to 270 after recent sharp weakness, sparked the rally. New York Stock Exchange volume, at 24.57, million shares, was the heaviest in seven months. Page 71.

title: Brazil Devalues Cruzeiro
description: BRASILIA, Sept. 19 (Reuters)  The Central Bank today de valued the cruzeiro to 6.12/6.16 a United States dollar from the previous parity of 6.09/6.13. The devaluation announcement was issued by the Central Bank tonight.

title: Howard P. Jones Is Dead at 74; Envoy to Indonesia, 195865
description: STANFORD, Calif., Sept. 19 Howard P. Jones, who served as Ambassador to Indonesia from 1958 to 1965, one of the longest such terms of continu ous service in recent times, died yesterday at his home. He was 74 years old.

title: NIXON'S LAWYERS SEEM TO RULE OUT ACCORD ON TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19  President's Nixon's lawyers, strongly hinting that they would reject any outofcourt compro mise on Presidential tape re cordings, declared today that their client would not delegate his constitutional duties and prerogatives to Archibald Cox, the Watergate special prosecu tor.

title: Tourney Set for E.C.A.C. Fives in '75
description: The Eastern College Ath letic Conference voted yes terday to conduct a 16team postseason basketball tour nament starting in 1975 to help raise more operating revenue for the conference. The league is hopeful that the tournament will be sanc tioned to determine the four major independent Eastern teams that will compete in the annual National Colle giate Athletic Association championship tourney.

title: EUROPEAN REPLY ON TIES IS VAGUE
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 19 Re sponding to an American call for a new Atlantic charter, the European Economic Com munity proposed to the United States today that they join in pledge to intensify cooperation on the basis of equality.

title: SKYLAB ASTRONAUTS TAKE ALPS PHOTOS
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 19 (UPI) The Skylab 2 astronauts photo graphed the Swiss Alps today searching for, clues to ava lanches. Over Israel they col lected data on geology, water resources and crops.

title: U.S. to Cancel $2Billion Owed by India
