description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19  The United States and India have reached a tentative agree ment to write off twothirds of India's estimated debt of $3, billion in rupees to this coun try, Administration officials said today.

title: W. W. WURSTER, ARCHITECT, DIES
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 19 William Wilson Wurster, na tionally prominent architect and founding dean of the uni versity of California's College of Environmental Design at Berkeley, died of complications from Parkinson's disease early today at his home here. He was 77 years old.

title: News Summary and Index THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 20, 1973
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Algeria Bars Immigration To France in a Dispute
description: ALGIERS, Sept. 19 (AP) Algeria said today that she was suspending all emigration to France until France guarantees the safety and dignity of 100,000 Algerians there.

title: Mets Win to Trail by 1 Games
description: The New York Mets called forth all sorts of fantasies again last night as they de feated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 73, and drew within 1 game of the top of the four team race in the National League's East.

title: 2 Britons Freed in Chile Report Brutal Conditions
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept 19 Reports are spreading here of the arrest, ill treatment or dis appearance of foreigners, main ly those who came here as political exiles from other Latin American countries. Some re ports have been confirmed, others not.

title: HOUSE SUSTAINS WAGE BILL VETO
4Level Garage Collapses, Burying Dozens of Autos
description: A fourlevel garage on West 28th Street collapsed early yes terday afternoons burying dozens of automobiles, heavily damaging scores more and leav ing several dangling precarious ly in the remains of the build ing. There was no one in the building at the time.

title: EUROPEAN REPLY ON TIES IS VAGUE
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 19  Re sponding to an American call for a new Atlantic charter, the European Economic Com munity proposed to the United States today that they join in a pledge to intensify cooperation on the basis of equality.

title: Roosevelt Asks Apology on Iriquiry
description: LISBON, Sept. 19 (AP)El liott Roosevelt demanded public apology today from Sen ator Henry M. Jackson for testimony given to a Senate subcommittee by a witness who accused Mr. Roosevelt of participating in an assassina tion plot.

title: Cabbies Taught Defense Beats Offensive Driving
description: Like football players, they sit bunched together in a darkened room watching films of the way their peers perform. After the show, everyone talks about why things went wrong and how to do better.

title: Trend Is Stronger For Dollar Abroad As Gold Price Dips
description: LONDON, Sept. 19 (UPI) The United States dollar re gained a bit of lost ground to day on European money mar kets. The price of gold dropped $1.60 an ounce to $101.40.

title: F.B.I. Reportedly Trailed Columnist on Visit to Paris
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19  The Nixon Administration or dered a highranking. F.B.I. of ficial to follow Joseph Kraft, the syndicated columnist, to Paris in 1969 and to arrange with the French government to keep him under electronic and physical surveillance during the visit, according to sources familiar with the operation.

title: A Bongo to Be Bred
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 18 (AP) The Cincinnati zoo says it will send one of its two rare female bongos to the Mil waukee zoo next week for breeding. The animal has been called the most beautiful and rare of antelopes.

title: Gas Dealors Bar Shutdown
description: ALBANY, Sept 19 (AP)  A group of 40 gasoline retailers in this area decided against a proposed threeday shutdown to protest government profit con trols. Two dealers had proposed a shutdown for this weekend to 75 dealers but they formed a dealer's association instead.

title: CHINESEAMERICAN AHEAD IN SEATTLE
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 19  Liem Tuai, 37 years old, is rated as having a better than average chance to become Seattle's first ChineseAmerican Mayor, and the first of his race to head a major American city.

title: Heart Fund Chief Named
description: John F. Hennessy Jr., presi dent and chairman of the en gineering firm of Syska & Hen nessy, has been appointed gen eral chairman of the 1974 Heart Fund campaign in the city. The drive will seek to raise $3million to further hte Heart Association's reseach, education and community pro grams.

title: SAIGON MAY FREE ONE OF ITS CRITICS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 19Wellinformed Amer ican sources said today that the Government was planning to release one of its leading critics in a move apparently designed to counter recent un favorable publicity about Sai gon's treatment of political prisoners.

title: Goldwater Thinks Agnew Might Resign It Indicted
description: Senator Barry Goldwater said yesterday that he believed Vice President. Agnew would con sider resigning if he were in dicted, rather than put the country and himself through long impeachment proceeding.

title: The Two Germanys Tell U.N. They Renounce Use of Force
description: UNITED NATIONS, N, Y., Sept. 19The Foreign Minis ters of the two Germanys, in their first speeches as members of the United Nations, today renounced the use of force.

title: Europe Weighs New Roles for Labor After Lip Case
description: PARIS, Sept. 19The efforts of 1,300 workers at a watch company in France to keep on making watches after manage ment decided to close, down the factory has caused some funda mental questioning here about the relation of labor and capi tal and the rights of workers to participate in the decisions of management.

title: Boy Flees Spofford as 12 Beat Counselors
description: Five counselors were injured Tuesday night in a disturbance involving 12 youths in deten tion at the Spofford Juvenile Center in the Bronx, the police said. One of the youths, a 15 yearold boy who was believed to have been the leader of the disruption, escaped and was being sought by the police yes terday.

title: SOME DOUBT HERE ON HOUSING PLAN
description: State and local housing offi cials here expressed hope yes terday that the housing policies announced by President Nixon yesterday would permit con struction of certain projects whose fate had been in doubt since last January.

title: Sheriff Pleads Not Guilty Of Thefts and Misconduct
description: SCHOHARIE, N. Y., Sept. 19 (AP)Schoharie County Sheriff John Goldswer has pleaded not guilty to charges of grand lar ceny, petty larceny and official misconduct.

title: Basketball Transactions
description: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION

title: G. B. Stern, British Novelist, Is Dead at 83
description: LONDON, Sept. 19G. B. Stern, the novelist, died today in a hospital at Wallingford, Berkshire. She was 83 years old.

title: Another Samurai Slice of Life
description: Out of the enmities loosed in 19thcentury Japan by Western insistence on an end to its isolation, the director Masahiro Shinoda has fash ioned another of his vexing samurai dramas.

title: Pirate Ship Off Jersey Begins Broadcasts Challenging F.C.C.
description: ABOARD THE M.V. OCEAN IC, Sept. 19Defying the Fed eral Government, the Rev. Carl McIntire put an unlicensed ra dio station on the air today from this pirate ship 12 miles off Cape May, N. J.

title: Willie Mays Retiring
description: Willie Mays has decided to retire from baseball, ending a 22year career, The retire ment of the 42yearold star will be announced by the Mets today. Details, Page 57.

title: Hiller Ties Save Mark
description: DETROIT Sept. 19 (UPI) John Hiller tied the major league record with his 37th save this season and possibly his easiest, preserving a 10 1 victory for the Detroit Tigers tonight against the Baltimore Orioles. Hiller re lieved Joe Coleman at the start of the ninth and tied the mark set by Clay Car roll of Cincinnati last season.

title: Pennant Race
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE EAST

title: International Group Reports Wheat Shortage Has Eased
description: LONDON, Sept. 19 (AP) The International Wheat Coun cil said today that the world wheat shortage had apparently been reduced.

title: Books of The Times
description: HEARTLAND. By Saul Maloff. 279 pages. Scribner's. $6.95.

title: MARCHI DECLARES CRIME TOP ISSUE
description: Five of every 100 New Yorkers are fulltime muggers, rapists and murderers, State Senator John J. Marchi de clared yesterday, anddefend ing that mathematical division of the city against some ques tioning by reportershe said that all other New Yorkers should get combat pay.

title: YABLONSKI KILLER SENTENCED TO DIE
description: WASHINGTON, Pa., Sept. 19 (AP)  Aubran W. Martin, one of three gunmen convicted in the 1969 Yablonski family mur ders, was sentenced today to die in the electric chair.

title: High School Sports
description: The high school football season opens this weekend with some new coaches, some old winning streaks and a prepared excuse or two.

title: Black Parents in Carolina To End Boycott of Schools
description: BOWMAN, S. C., Sept. 19 (UPI)  Parents of about 1,000 black children agreed last night to end a school boycott protest ing the alleged indifference of two white school board mem bers whose children attend segregated private academy.

title: PREGNANCY IS LINKED TO LOWER IMMUNITY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI)  A Georgetown Uni versity research team reported today that pregnancy appears to partly disable a woman's defense mechanism against se vere viral infections.

title: Governor Thomson Urges Cooperation on Watergate
description: CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 19 (AP) Gov. Meldrim Thomson, Jr., who accused Senate Watergate investigators of Gestapolike tactics in the state, says he will continue to urge New Hampshire citizens to cooper ate fully with committee mem bers.

title: Colson, Citing Fifth, Balks at Questions
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19  Charles W. Colson refused to day to answer questions put, to him by the Senate Watergate committee, claiming his con Istitutional right against selfin crimination.

title: U.S.I.A. HEAD PRESSES SOVIET ON NEWSMEN
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 19James Keogh, Director of the United States Information Agency, met today with high Soviet officials to urge, among other things, that Moscow ease restrictions on American correspondents based in the Soviet Union.

title: On Charity
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19  Arthur Goldberg, the former everything, used to tell the story of the rescue party that approached some trapped moun taineers in a snowy ravine, yelling to them, It's the Red Cross! To which the desperate men yelled back, We gave at the office!

title: Hearings on Taylor Law Will Weigh the Exemption of Teachers
description: The Assembly Committee on Governmental Employes will hold public hearings next month to determine whether teachers and other public em ployes in nonessential services should be excluded from the no strike provisions of the Taylor Law.

title: Discussed and Dissected, Billie Jean, Bobby Ready
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 19Bob by Riggs, after having rustled her husband for $150 a set without losing a game, will play Mrs. Billie Jean King for $100,000, winner take all, here tomorrow night.

title: CLIFTON TEACHERS OBEY COURT ORDER
description: CLIFTON, N.J., Sept. 19 Teachers here voted to return to work today rather than defy in order from Superior Court Judge Peter Ciolino in Pater son yesterday to end a twoday strike.

title: People in Sports: DeJardin Out
description: The Philadelphia 76ers, who won only nine of 82 games last season to qualify as the worst team in the his tory of pro basketball, dis missed Don DeJardin, the general manager, yesterday. The dismissal was a surprise. Iry Kosloff, the club owner, had indicated on several pre vious occasions that he planned to rehire DeJardin.

title: Reading Scores for City Pupils Are Improving, Reports Indicate
description: City and state education offi cials reported yesterday that city pupils had scored gains on recent reading tests.

title: Wafter Schirra Sr., Flyer Was Astronaut's Father
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 19 (UPI) Walter Schirra Sr., father of Walter Schirra Jr., retired Navy captain and astronaut, died in Veterans Hospital yesterday. He was 79 years old.

title: Dance Returns to Hemispheric Beat
description: There will be a New World accent to the 197374 dance season and much of it will have a southoftheborder beat.

title: Consumer Units Support Sussman on Health Code
description: NEWARK, Sept. 19Con sumer groups rallied to the support of Dr. Oscar Sussman, the state's embattled consumers, health director who has been stripped of his powers to close kitchens at state institutions because of unsanitary con ditions.

title: CONNALLY MEETS FAT CATS HERE
description: John B. Connally, a leading rival of Governor Rockefeller for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1976, went fish ing for support in the Govern or's own pond yesterday.

title: FITZGERALD RULING SUPPORTED BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)  President Nixon expressed the hope today that the case of the Air Force cost analyst, A. Ernest Fitzgerald, would be completed now without the necessity of an appeal of a Civil Service Commission order that Mr. Fitzgerald be rehired.

title: Housing Starts Decline As Credit Flow Slows
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19  Housing starts, beginning to re fleet the tightening of mortgage credit, declined last month to the lowest level since October, 1971, the Commerce Depart ment reported today.

title: PRESIDENT URGES U.S. ALLOWANCES TO SPUR HOUSING
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19  President Nixon, in a message to Congress, proposed today that the Government provide housing allowances for poor and moderateincome families rather than continue what he described as a wasteful, in equitable system of subsidizing buildings for the needy.

title: Chess:
description: There are no fans as fickle as those who follow chess. Although they know full well that no one wins all the time, they seem to expect just that from their heroes.

title: Ellis Sued for Divorce
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 19 (AP)Dock Ellis of the Pittsburgh Pirates was sued for divorce today in Allegheny County Common Pleas Court by his wife, Eliz abeth. The couple was mar ried in 1965 and they have one daughter.

title: Amy Vanderbilt's Lecture Tips Cabbies on Etiquette
description: Amy Vanderbilt, arbiter of etiquette, yesterday lectured those who delight in being arbiters of just about every thing else

title: Butterflies Sweep South Along Connecticut Coast
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Sept. 19 (AP)Swarms of migrat ing monarch butterflies are sweeping along the Connec ticut coast in their race to reach the South before the first frost.

title: Deliverers' Union In Tentative Accord With 3 Papers Here
description: The Newspaper Deliverers Union has reached a tentative agreement on a new twoyear contract with The Daily News, The New York Post and The New York Times, it was an nounced yesterday by Carl Levy, president of the inde pendent union.

title: MRS. SAMUEL B. DARLING
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 19  Mrs. Edith Van Ingen Darling, a suffragist before World War I and later a leader in the Briarcliff and Mount Pleasant branches of the League of Women Voters, died yester day at. Somers Manor in Somers. She was the widow of Samuel B. Darling, a lawyer and an author and editor of law pub lications, Her age was 92.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party leader, told the West in a speech in Bulgaria not to try to bargain for Soviet concessions be cause of Moscow's interest in improving relations. His speech was evidently in reac tion to Western criticism of the handling of dissidents and of restrictions on a free move ment of people and ideas. A harsher, parallel message was transmitted in English over Moscow radio, accusing the United States Senate of gross interference in Soviet in ternal affairs with the approval of an amend ment urging the Kremlin to permit free expression and free emigration. [Page 1, Column 1; Text, P. 11.]

title: MORATORIUM ENDS ON PH.D. PROGRAMS
description: The state has rifted the two year moratorium on the estab lishment of new doctoral pro grams by public and private universities in the state but has, at the same time, adopted tougher standards for both ex isting and new programs.

title: Nixon's Energy Aide Hints That U.S. Is Likely to Control Fuel Oil Supply
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19  A White House meeting of Ad ministration officials and state Governors today appeared to move the Government closer to management of heating oil sup plies.

title: Pupils' Reading Scores Are Improving
description: City and state education offi cials reported yesterday that city pupils had scored gains on recent reading tests.

title: HONOR RETRACTED TO HEAD OF PEPSICO
description: The American Jewish Com mittee has withdrawn its 1973 award for civic leadership, which was to have gone to Donald M. Kendall, chairman of pepsico, Inc., and one of the most active promoters of trade with the Soviet Union.

title: PEAKS IN QUARTER POSTED BY A.T. & T.
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company had its best quarter ever In the three months ended Aug. 31, accord ing to figures released here yesterday. Both revenues and earnings reached new highs for the quarter and for the 12 months ended Aug. 31.

title: Democrats Expect to Collect 92% of Telethon Pledges
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 19 (UPI) The Democratic National Committee expects to collect 92 per cent or better of the $5.4million pledged at this month's national telethon.

title: The Stage: Happy Ibsen
description: New York is acquiring a number of theaters that are primarily devoted to classic repertory, and, as long as their standards are high, this seems a very welcome devel opment. The N.R.C.  New Repertory CompanyThea ter is a company that opened its fourth season Tuesday night with a most striking production of Ibsen's The Lady From the Sea.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:

title: Mrs. Allende Now Feels Husband Was Murdered
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 19The widow of President Sal vador Allende Gossens of Chile said today that on the basis of new information she had received since her husband's death, she now believed that he did not commit suicide but was murdeted by the mili tary forces that overthrew his Government eight days ago.

title: CATTLE FUTURES DECLINE IN PRICE
CHRYSLER DENIED A PRICE INCREASE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 Moving with unusual speed, the Cost of Living Council rejected today a price increase pro posed yesterday, by the Chrys ler Corporation.

title: Senate Passes Medical Bill Replacing One Nixon Vetoed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) The Senate, passed a substi tute today for a $185million medicalservices bill vetoed by President Nixon.

title: The Search for Peace of Mind Through Lies
description: WEST CORNWALL, Conn.  The Pentagon's most recent lies about bombing Cambodia bring back a question that often occurred to me when I was press attach at the American Embassy in Vientiane, Laos.

title: BEND WARNS WEST ON PUTTING STRINGS ON PACTS
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 19Leonid I. Brezhnev told the West to day not to try to barter for Soviet concessions because of Moscow's interest, in improved relations.

title: Willie Mays Retiring
description: Willie Mays has decided to retire from baseball, ending a 22year career. The retire ment of the 42yearold star will be announced by the Mets today. Details, Page 57.

title: Auto Union Council At Chrysler Backs New 3Year Pact
description: DETROIT, Sept. 19 (UPI)  The Chrysler council of the United Auto Workers approved new threeyear contract to day that, if ratified by the workers this weekend, would end a strike against the No. 3 auto maker.

title: Talking Picture Wins Matron by Head for 4th in Row
description: Talking Picture almost was upset in the $111,250 Matron at Belmont Park yesterday, but the star of the Elmen dorf stable rallied at the right time under Ron Tur cotte to register the triumph by a head. In second place the longpriced Dancealot, who preceded Raisela among the nine in the sevenfur long test for 2yearold fillies.

title: Data on Security Parley
description: Following is some basic information about the second phase of the European security conference, which opened in Geneva Tuesday.

title: Stocks Rally Broadly
description: The stock market staged a broad and spirited rally yes terday as the DowJones in dustrials rose 19.11 points to 910.37. A recovery in I.B.M. shares, climbing 11 to 270 after recent sharp weakness, sparked the rally. New York Stock Exchange volume, at 24.57 million shares, was the heaviest in seven months. Page 71.

title: Arthur Daley
description: The Giants will play their last football game in the Yankee Stadium on Sunday. Or will it really be the last? It certainly is supposed to be, because the construction crews are about to begin the facelifting and moderniza tion of the ancient ball park, shunting the Giants off the Yale Bowl for the remainder of this season and all of next.

title: ALFRED UDELL
description: Aldred Udell, former head of Udell Travel Service, died yes terday in Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 51 years old and lived at 415 East 52d Street and in East Hampton, L.I.

title: Seton Hall Coed Found Slain Beside Her Car in Roselle Lot
description: A 19yearold coed at Seton Hall University in South Orange, N. J., was found slain early yesterday by a 19year old boy walking his dog in wooded lot in Roselle, N. J.

title: Carman R. Runyon Jr., 80, Dies; Beamed First Public FM Signal
description: Carman R. Runyon Jr., a pi oneer in the development of FM radio, died yesterday. He was 80 years old and lived at 130 East End Avenue.

title: 3 More Sextuplets Are Stricken With Lung Illness
description: DENVER, Sept. 19 (UPI) On the third day of their life, three of the five remaining Sta nek sextuplets were stricken today with the lung disease that killed their sister the day be fore. Doctors completely re placed the blood in the re maining girl to try to save her life.

title: C.I.A. Will Abolish Estimates System, Form a New Board
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 The Central Intelligence Agency is planning to abolish the 15 yearold system of turning out what it calls national intelli gence estimates, sometimes as many as 50 a year.

title: BREZHNEV WARNS WEST ON PUTTING STRINGS ON PACTS
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 19Leonid I. Brezhnev told the West to day not to try to barter for Soviet concessions because of Moscow's interest in improved relations.

title: Man Cleared in Danish Fire
description: COPENHAGEN, Sept. 19 (Reuters)A 33yearold con vict was officially cleared to day of a charge that he deliber ately started a hotel fire that killed 35 people, including 20 American tourists on Sept. 1, a spokesman for the state attorney's office said.

title: Johnson Papers Released
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 19 (UPI) President Lyndon B. John son's papers on urban affairs, kept in his Presidential library since his retirement, will be opened to the public in con junction with a symposium on American cities Oct. 89, the library's director, Harry Mid dleton, announced today.

title: 17 Food Concerns Cited as Violators For Second Time
description: The Health Department has named 17 more restaurants and food establishments as second offenders against the health code. If a third inspec tion later this month finds the violations still uncorrected, closing orders could result.

title: Judge Dismisses Suit Over Democrats' Debt
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 (AP)A lawsuit filed last year to shut off telephone service to the Democratic National Committee because it had not paid a large bill was dismissed today in Unit ed States District Court.

title: Contract Awarded
description: The Interstate United Corpo ration has been awarded the food service contract for the Bankers Trust Company, it was announced yesterday by Peter A. Tullio, executive vice presi dent of Interstate United. The contract, which is effective Sept. 28, covers seven of the bank's New York City loca tions.

title: The Katzenbach Paper
description: BOSTON, Sept. 19The United States should abandon all covert operations in foreign countries except the gather ing of intelligence. That proposal is made by Nicholas deB. Katzenbach, the former Attorney General and Under Secretary of State, in an article just published in Foreign Affairs.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The New York and American Stock Exchanges yesterday re leased their latest reports of trading in listed shares by major stockholders, directors and of ficers. The lists include the fol lowing:

title: Parole Aide Asserts Coppolino's Request Will Be Rejected
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sept. 19 (AP)Dr. Carl Coppolino, convicted of murdering his wife six years ago, has been turned down twice for parole and prob ably will be rejected a third time in November, according to a state official.

title: A.C.L.U. Unit in Ohio Sues To End School Punishment
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 19 (UPI) The Ohio American Civil Liberties Union foundation charged in Federal court yester day infliction of physical pun ishment on students by school teachers, including spanking in the lower grades, was un constitutional except in self defense.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19  The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot pri mary prices for the week ended Sept. 11.

title: Butterflies Sweep South Along Connecticut Coast
Ellen Becomes Hurricane 820 Miles from Bermuda
description: MIAMI, Sept. 19 (UPI)The tropical storm Ellen became a full hurricane with 85 milean hour winds today as it moved across the open Atalntic far from land.

title: COMPANY CLEARED IN KICKBACK CHARGE
description: A graphicarts company and its president have been ac quitted of charges that they paid kickbacks to an executive of American Airlines to obtain business contracts with the air line.

title: Brooklyn's Regal Egyptian Display
description: The Brooklyn Museum, which is the proud possessor of a renowned collection of ancient Egyptian art, has mounted an extraordinary loan show of objects from the Amarna period (1378 1362 B.C.) which has rarely before served as the subject of a special exhibition. En titled Akhenaten and Y Nefer titi: Art from the Age Of the Sun King, the exhibition brings together more than 170 examples, mostly small stone carvings, drawn from the short, dazzling reign of this young Pharaoh and his legendary queen.

title: Cabbies Taught Defense Beats Offensive Driving
description: Like football players, they sit bunched together in a darkened room watching films of the way their peers perform. After the show, everyone talks about why things went wrong and how to do better.

title: Witness Testifies He Paid Garrison Bribes for 8 Years
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 19 A Government informant, Pershing O. Gervais, testified in Federal District Court today that he had over a period of about eight years delivered bribe money to District Attor ney Jim Garrison, who is on trial on charges of bribery and conspiracy.

title: Same Old Fenway Story: Yankees Lose
description: BOSTON, Sept. 19  The final 2 hours 10 minutes the Yankees spent in Fenway Park tonight were no dif ferent than most of their other 25orso hours here as the Boston Red Sox defeated the New Yorkers, 3 to 1. It was Boston's eighth triumph in the nine home games against the Yankees.

title: Ulster Warehouse Blown Up
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 19 (UPI)Terrorists blew up a fourstory customs ware house filled with wine and, whisky in Londonderry tonight.

title: DIVESTING SOUGHT BY OWENSILLINOIS
description: OwensIllinois, Inc., a leading producer of glass products and paper containers, is seeking to divest itself of about 18 per cent of the 21 per cent it holds of the common stock of the OwensCorning Fiberglas Cor poration, valued at about $112 million. Edwin D. Dodd, presi dent of Owens Illinois, said the company had asked for a modi fication of a 1949 Department of Jus tice consent decree relating to the holdings. Under the pro posed modification, Owens Illinois would divest itself of the holdings of OwensCorning within five years by any method or methods OwensIllinois might choose.

title: Doctor in the House Changes Character
description: The box office still adver tised a movie called Dr. Sex, but yesterday the Ritz Theatet, which had featured pornographic movies, became the permanent home of a children's theater group.

title: AMEX REGISTERS SHARP ADVANCE
description: Prices and trading volume spurted sharply upward yester day, on the American Stock Ex change as the number of large blocks traded climbed to 18 from 12 in each of the previous two sessions. The overthe counter market went through a similar experience.

title: THOMAS L. C. VAIL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP)Thomas L. C. Vail, chief counsel of the Senate Finance Committee for the last seven years, died yesterday of cancer at Northern Virginia Doctors Hospital in Arlington, He was 45 years old.

title: Consumer Notes
Trevino and Casper Lead Off Today; Nicklaus, Palmer in CleanUp Spot
description: MUIRFIELD, Scotland, Sept. 19They weren't chosen arbitrarily, said Jack Burke, the nonplaying captain, as he announced the United States Squad beginning defense of the Ryder Cup tomorrow against the professional golf ers of Britain.

title: Cambodian War Tableau: A Company Decimated, a Widow Stoic, a Proper Respect for the Ashes
description: WAT KRUOS, Cambodia, Sept. 19The first truck con voy of supplies to reach Phnom Penh in nearly three weeks rumbled along Route 4 today, but Mrs. Chan Navi paid no attention. She was removing the bones of her soldier husband from the embers in which his com rades had just cremated him.

title: Alligator Shuts Runway
description: TAMPA, Fla., Sept. 19 (UPI) A runway at Tampa Interna tional Airport was closed for about half an hour last night after an arriving commercial jet touched down on a sixfoot allgator trying to cross the pavement.

title: Overdue Aid Bills
description: The United States, which in the past has been known to lecture other nations unmercifully about their failure to meet their financial obligations and commitments, is in heavy arrears to the international aid agencies it is pledged to support.

title: Betty Field Rites Tomorrow
description: There will be a memorial service tomorrow for Betty Field, the actress, who died last Thursday in Hyannis, Mass., at 11:30 A.M. in the Community Church, Park Ave nue at 35th Street.

title: An ExYouth Corps Head Accused of Murder Attempt
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 19 (UPI) A former Syracuse Neighbor hood Youth Corps director and past administratorcounselor for a Syracuse University con tinuingeducation program was arrested on a charge of at tempted murder last night, the police reported.

title: Las Vegas Changing Its Image With Help of Baby Sitters
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev.  Giant neon signs touting allnew, allnude revues. Gambling dens that never close. Chorus girls in seethrough feathers. Gaming tables where run away dads drop family sav ings. Prostitutes. Discothque dancers who move body parts most people never knew existed. Loud bands. And baby sitters.

title: Schedules In Playoffs Established
description: There will be no days off for travel in the American and National League play offs unless the Los Angeles Dodgers beat the Cincinnati Reds for first place in the National League's Western Division, the baseball com missioner's office said yes terday.

title: Bridge:
description: The oldest established per manent floating bridge game in New York begins today at the Pines Hotel in South Fallsburg. It is the New York New Jersey regional cham pionships, which began in the thirties as the Summer Nationals in Asbury Park, N. J., and has changed its location repeatedly in the last four years.

title: Amy Vanderbit's Lecture Tips Cabbies on Etiquette
description: Amy Vanderbilt, arbiter of etiquette, yesterday lectured those who delight in being arbiters of just about every thing else.

title: Writing Your Own Variation on I Do
description: Now that selfexpression is almost as requisite to the wedding ritual as the I do and till death us do part components, the betrothed couple may find they must worry about ceremonial words along with seating arrangements.

title: Deadlock Continues In City Opera Talks After Night Session
description: An allnight bargaining ses sion failed yesterday to bring a contract settlement that could end the 19dayold strike of Local 802 of the American Fed eration of Musicians against the New York City Opera Company.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: TELEVISION MINISTER SELLS GIRDLE PLANT
description: AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 19 Rex Humbard, the television minister, has sold his Brooklyn girdle factory, once the corner stone of his nowdissipated financial empire.

title: HUSSEIN WATCHES PRISONER RELEASE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 19 King Hussein of Jordan per sonally supervised the release from prison today of Pales tinian guerrilla leaders who benefited by a royal amnesty covering about 1,500 prisoners.

title: Mays, at 42, Decides He'll Retire
description: Willie Mays has finally de cided to end his 22year ca reer in baseball, and his retirement will be announced today by the New York Mets.

title: SENATE APPROVES PENSION REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19  The Senate passed tonight a bill for Federal standards to protect the rights of workers covered by private pension plans. The vote was unanimous, 93 to 0.

title: Court Gives City Council Until Oct. 15 to Draw Redistricting Plan
description: The State Court of Appeals yesterday gave the City Coun cil until Oct. 15 to come up with a third redistricting plan. The court issued the deadline in an order that did not include an opinion.

title: Credit Markets: Prices Advance in Active Trading
description: Prices moved higher in the corporatebond market yester day in active trading.

title: Weekend Prospects for Fishermen in Area
description: AREA A  Smalltomedi umsized striped bass are be ing caught from the bent, at Surf City, N.J., with reg ularity. An occasional large blue or fluke is also being taken. Fluke are in Barnegat Bay at Beach Haven and Barnegat Inlets. Large blue fish are once again being taken by boats chumming off Barnegat Ridge and surf fishermen are catching 15 to18pound stripers along the shore. School tuna and albacore are still present at the Ridge. A few blues are reported in the surf at Sea side Park, N.J., and stripers are being caught there in in creasing numbers, including a 42pounder landed this week, All along the Jersey coast, the water has cleared and settled after Friday's storm, and angling should improve steadily.

title: Nixon Nominates James Quello to F.C.C. Vacancy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 James H. Quello, a retired broadcasting executive from Detroit, will be nominated for membership on the Federal Communications Commission, the White House announced today. Mr. Quello, 69 years old, is a former vice president of the Capital Cities Broadcast ing Corporation.

title: Wednesday's Fight
description: Las Vegas, Nev.Angel Gar cia, 146 pounds, Madrid, Spain, outpointed Jose Miranda, 147, Los Angeles, 10 rounds.

title: A Shaking Rookie Who Became a Wonder
description: I was a 2yearrold kid from Birmingham. Willie Mays remembered, and frightenedkids from any where will know how I felt. I was so scared, out there in the ondeck circle when Bobby Thomson went up to hit, scared I'd have to go up there with the game depend ing on me, that I was shaking.

title: Endowment Points Up Fiscal Crises At All Components of Lincoln Center
description: The Avery Fisher endown ment, while it will alleviate the financial burden of one constituent of Lincoln Cen ter, serves to throw into sharp relief the extraordinary dimensions of the fiscal crises of all the Center's cultural components.

title: Pressure Only Spurs Soviet Dissidents
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 20Far from suppressing dissident sen timent in the Soviet Union, the recent intensive Soviet press campaign against Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and civil rights advocate, seems to have provided domestic critics of the regime with a new rally jing point.

title: 5 in Watergate Asked To Back Up Plea Shift
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UPI)  The special Water gate prosecutor, Archibald Cox, today challenged five of the original bugging con spirators to substantiate their charges that they were lured into crime by high government officials.

title: The State Is Drafting Plan To Soften Pollution Curbs
description: TRENTON, Sept. 20Richard 3. Sullivan, State Commissioner of Environmental Protection, said today he would have a plan to relax New Jersey's tough airquality standards in two to three weeks.

title: COED'S MURDERER MAY BEAR SCARS
description: ROSELLE, N.J., Sept, 20  The slayer of a 19yearold Seton Hall coed being sought by the police may bear the marks of a brutal struggle with his karatetrained victim in a secluded treefringed lot of a quiet residential section here.

title: Mrs. King Defeats Riggs, 64, 63, 63, Amid a Circus Atmosphere
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 20Mrs. Billie Jean King struck a proud blow for herself and women around the world with a crushing 64, 6.3, 6.3 rout of Bobby Riggs tonight in their $100,000 winner takeall tennis match at the Astrodome.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Sept. 20The battle between Gary Smolyn and John Piccirillo for No. 1 quarterback at Rutgers has been decided in favor of neither. Steve Havran, a south paw alleverything at Bridgewater East High School, will start at Lehigh Saturday in the opening game.

title: Mrs. King Defeats Riggs, 64, 63, 63, Amid a Circus Atmosphere
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 20Mrs. Billie Jeat. King struck a proud blow for herself and women around the world with a crushing 64, 63, 63 rout of Bobby Riggs tonight in their $100,000 winner takeall tennis match at the Astrodome.

title: Immigrant Laborers in Belgium Find That Prejudice Is on a Sliding Scale
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 14The signs on the publicnotice boards in Belgian shop win dows offering apartments for rent and specifying pas d' trangers. (no foreigners) are not addressed to the French secretaries or West German economists working at the headquarters of the European Economic Community.

title: TIE TO EAST STUDIED BY COMMON MARKET
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 20  The Council of Ministers of the European Economic Commun ity called today for a study of the possibility of establishing contacts with the Soviet bloc's trading organization.

title: Philharmonic Hall Gets $8Million Gift
description: Philharmonic Hall, which opened 11 years ago this month, yesterday was renamed Avery Fisher Hall in apprecia tion of a major gift of undis closed size by a pioneer manu facturer of highfidelity phono graph and radio equipment. In formed sources in musical and financial circles here immedi ately estimated the overall gift at $8million to $10mil lion.

title: GRAM PARSONS DIES; ROCK STAR WAS 27
description: Gram Parsons, the rock mu sician and former member of the Byrds, died Wednesday in Joshua Tree, Calif. He was 27 years old. The cause of his death was not immediately de termined. The San Bernardino coroner is awaiting results of autopsy tests.

title: INTERVIEWS CLOSE 1 IN 5 RELIEF CASES
description: One of every five welfare cases investigated in the state has been closed in the first two months of facetoface in terviews with welfare families, the State Department of Social Services announced yesterday.

title: Shops Flout Price Law In Midtown
description: A new city consumer pro tection ordinance is being violated by many Times Square merchants catering primarily to tourists. They continue to charge more than list prices without conspic uously posting or labeling items with the manufactur er's suggested selling price.

title: Business Records
description: Thursday, Sept. 20, 1973

title: More Veterans' Aid Asked
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) A recommendation for in creases in veterans benefits to cover college costs has been sent to Congress by a consult ing organization. The 339page report from Educational Testing Service of Princeton, N. J., said th real value of benefits to veerans after World War II was greater than the current allowances.

title: Socrate Barozzi Is Bead; Violinist at Philharmonic
description: Socrate Barozzi, a New York Philharmonic violinist from 1934 to 1959 who had often been soloist at stadium, park and promenade concerts here, died Saturday in San Antonio, Tex., at the age of 79.

title: A Supersonic Concorde Lands in Texas
description: GRAPEVINE, Tex., Sept. 20 In the first visit of a super sonic airliner to the United States, a FrenchBritish Con corde flew here today from Caracas, Venezuela, to provide an extra dimension to Satur day's dedication of the world's largest jetport.

title: PAUL DICKOPF DEAD; EXHEAD OF INTERPOL
description: WIESBADEN, West Germany, Sept. 20 (AP)Paul Dickopf, former president of Interpol, died yesterday at the age of 63.

title: NIXON AIDES AND COX FAIL TO GET ACCORD ON TAPES; TEST IN HIGH COURT SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  President Nixon's lawyers and Archibald Cox, the special prosecutor in the Watergate case, informed the United States Court of Appeals here today that they had failed to reach a compromise on access to Presidential tape recordings bearing on the Watergate crimes.

title: Earnings of U.S. Corporations Rise 34% in the Second Quarter
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP)Profits of United States corporations during the second quarter of the year were 34 per cent above a year earlier, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Air Ducts Are Ordered Installed Near Site of Fatal IRT Accident
description: Dr. William J. Ronan, chair man of the Metropolitan Trans portation Authority, yesterday ordered the city's Transit Au thority to install new air ducts and power lines in the IRT Flushing line's East River sub way tunnel, near the scene of a fatal accident Aug. 28.

title: New Post for Mulzoff
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., Sept. 20 (AP)Frank Mulzoff, for mer basketball coach at St. John's University, was named today as coach of the new Cherry Hill Rookies of the Eastern Basketball Association. Rich Iannarella, Cherry Hill's general man ager, said Mulzoff, who coached St. John's from 1970 to this year, signed a one year contract.

title: Notes on People
description: A woman and four men were presented Harmon In ternational Aviation Awards yesterday in the Oval Office of President Nixon.

title: Indian Head to Sell Stock to a Dutch Company
description: Indian Head, Inc., which has become a diversified industrial company through acquisition and internal development, yes terday reached an agreement in principle to sell about 15 per cent of its common shares to a privately held Netherlandsbased industrial company. Under the agreement, Indian Head will sell 750,000 shares of its stock at $27 a share. The latter amount would come to an additional $29.7 million.

title: Sampling Goulash Circuit Now That Fall's Arrived
description: The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judg ment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable estab lishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Last of the Jailed Guerrillas Are Set Free by Jordan
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 20 (UPI)Jordan today released the last of the 747 Palestinian guerrillas pardoned by King Hussein as part of a gesture of reconciliation toward the Palestinians as well as toward Egypt and Syria.

title: SAIGON WILL FREE FOUR DISSIDENTS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 20The Government announced today that it had decided to release from pris on Mrs. Ngo Ba Thanh, a leading critic of the war and the Government, and three dis sident labor leaders.

title: The Agnew Case
description: For several weeks, speculation and rumors concerning possible criminal charges have swirled around Vice President Agnew. He has held one fullscale press con ference, and also issued a brief supplementary state ment, denying these charges. The Justice Department now seems to be moving toward decisive action in the investigation.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Four teenage boys died when their car crashed into a brick pillar in Little Falls in Passaic County.

title: Texts of Letters on Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP)  Following are the texts of letters from Presi dent Nixon's lawyer, Charles Alan Wright, and the special prosecutor in the Watergate case, Archibald Cox, advising the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia that its suggested compromise on the White House tapes issue had failed.

title: ConventionCenter Plan Meets With an Obstacle
description: At the prompting of Repre sentative Bella S. Abzug, the House Public Works Committee placed an obstacle yesterday in the path toward Federal ap proval of the city's plan to build a $200million convention center over the Hudson River.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
People and Business
description: Edward W. Duffy, 47, pres ident of the Marine Midland Banks, Inc., of Buffalo, will become chief executive of ficer of the $12billion bank holding company on Oct. 1. He will succeed Charles A. Wilding, 65, who continues as chairman.

title: DR. ERIC BAKER, 74, METHODIST LEADER
description: The Rev. Dr. Eric Wilfred Baker, honorary president of the World Methodist Council and for 19 years secretary of the British Methodist Confer ence, died in London on Wednesday. He was 74 years old and lived in Eastbourne, Sussex, England.

title: European Voice
description: A chronic complaint of the present Administration that it wants to converse with Europe but cannot find any common European interlocutormay be moving toward at least temporary relief, in preparation for an oftdiscussed European tour by President Nixon late this year.

title: It's Up, Up and Away for Forbes
description: Malcolm S. Forbes, the 54 yearold magazine publisher who collects art and real estate, had his first balloon ride 15 months ago. Yester day he announced plans to start a crosscountry flight on Oct. 3 from the Oregon coast to the New Jersey shore, add ing wryly that a landing any place between Maine and Florida would be considered satisfactory.

title: REGULATIONS SET ON STERILIZATION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 Safeguards to protect human rights in the sterilization of persons under 21 years of age, or who are legally incapable of consenting to the operation, will be issued tomorrow by the Department of Health, Educa tion and Welfare.

title: Colavito Quits as Coach
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 20 (AP)Rocky Colavito has resigned as first base coach fbr the Cleveland Indians, effective at the end of the current season, a spokes

title: FULL PRODUCTION SET FOR TEXAS OIL RATE
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 20 Wideopen production for the 19th consecutive month has been ordered by the Texas Railroad Commission, as de mand for Texas oil continues to increase.

title: Wave of Killings Spurs Algeria To Curb Migration to France
description: PARIS, Sept. 20Algeria has suspended immigration of her workers to France until the current wave of antiAlgerian acts is brought under control.per cent of the local popula tion, tensions will mount. The recent events bear them out.

title: French Discount Rate Rises From 9.5 to 11%
description: PARIS, Sept. 20 (UPI)The Bank of France today raised its basic lending rate from 9.5 per cent to 11 per cent a postwar high and the sec ond increase in two months.

title: 500 Jam Nassau Court In Harness Race Inquiry
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 20 About 500 persons connected with harness racing at Roose velt Raceway crowded into three courtrooms in the County Court Building here today in response to sub poenas issued by Nassau County District Attorney Wil liam Cahn in his investiga tion of irregularities in races at the Westbury track.

title: Gamblers Anonymous Signs In at OTB
description: Gamblers Anonymous, selfhelp group with no pro motion department, appears to be making quiet progress in the widely promoted shops of the Offtrack Betting Cor poration.

title: Two Voices of the U.S. Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTONIn [judicial] matters relating to procedures, methods and practices, it is better to risk some false starts rather than make no starts at all, I am reminded of an ad in an English newspaper for Guinness Beer. The ad has the face of a man with a skeptical if not truculent, scowling look, and the caption was: I don't like Guinness Beer because I have never tried it.

title: Football Transactions
description: AMERICAN CONFERENCE

title: Gasoline Stations to Be Allowed To Increase Their Prices Soon
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) Gasoline retailers will be al lowed to raise prices soon, probably by Oct. 2, John Dun lop, director of the Cost of Living Council, said today.

title: Equity Financing
description: A special offering of 129,300 common shares of the Zale Corporation at 20 was completed yester day by Shields and Company. The company's stock was up  at 20 on the New York Stock Ex change.

title: Deficit Widened to $18.1Million at Pennsy in August
CatholicSchool Crisis
description: In 10 years, the proportion of laymen and women teaching in the Roman Catholic high schools operated by the Dio cese of Brooklyn has shot up from 20 to 65 per cent. This statistic helps explain the is sues behind the strike directed against eight parochial schools in Brooklyn and Queens, the two boroughs that make up the dio cese. Such labor strife, virtually un known when nuns, brothers and priests predominated on the faculties of Catholic schools, has been increasing as fewer young people have entered religious vocations and Cath olics have grown ever more dependent on lay teachers to staff their shools.

title: Bank Loans Still Rising As Money Growth Slows
description: Bank loans increased, credit conditions tightened, money supply growth slowed and the Federal funds rate inched up to a record height in the most recent reporting periods, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday.

title: Rangers Send Down 22
description: KITCHENER, Ont., Sept. 20 (AP)The New York Rangers assigned today 22 players, including goalie Peter McDuffe and forwards Rick Middletown and Al Blanchard, to their Provi dence club of the American Hockey League.

title: SENATE UNIT FINDS VERY LITTLE BASIS FOR 17 WIRETAPS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee said today that very little, if any, justifica tion, was presented in most instances for the White Housesanctioned wiretapping of the phones of 13 officials and four newsmen from 1969 to 1971.

title: Books of The Times
description: A TREASURY OF ROMANESQUE ART: Metal work, Illumination and Sculpture From the Valley of the Meuse. By Suzanne Collon Gevaert, Jean Lejeune and Jacques Stien non. 320 pages. Praeger. $50.

title: U.S. Says Its Supply Of Wheat Can Meet International Needs
description: ROME, Sept. 20  The United States gave assurances today that its stockpiles of wheat, though shrinking, were sufficient to meet de mands from all over the world.

title: 5 Injured in London As Bomb Goes Off In Army Barracks
description: LONDON, Sept. 20 (AP)  Terrorists exploded a large bomb inside an army barracks in London's Chelsea section early today. Two soldiers and three civilians were injured.

title: Short Interest Off 1,115,359 Shares During the Month
description: Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange dropped by 1,115,359 shares to 16,844, 252 shares in the month ended Sept. 14. It was the lowest short position on the Big Board since January, 1972, the ex change said.

title: CHILE PET NETS A LEFTWING HERO
description: SANTIAGO, Chile Sept. 20 A hero of the Chilean left known as Comandante Pepe has been captured with 17 of his men while attempting to Organize resistance In the south Against the military junta, it was officially announced here today.

title: EDWARD SHARP DIES; ACTIVE IN ZIONISM
description: Edward Sharf, Zionist and civic leader and a former na tional president of B'nai Zion, American fraternal Zionist or ganization, died Wednesday evening at the age of 58. He lived at 13718 75th Road, Flushing, Queens.

title: FOOTBALL TONIGHT
description: Home teams listed first. HoustonSouth Carolina.

title: Any Agnew Replacement May Face Bar on '76 Bid
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 Democratic leaders of the House of Representatives have reportedly made plans to insist, if Vice President Agnew leaves office before his term expires, that his successor pledge not to seek election as President in 1976.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Price Is Right Buses Jammed

title: INQUIRY REQUESTS ROOSEVELT REPLY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 Elliot Roosevelt has been in vited to appear before the Sen ate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations next week or as soon as possible thereafter to answer charges that he was involved in a plot to kill the Governor of The Bahamas at the time.

title: Rockefeller Names Panel To Promote Bond Issue
description: Governor Rockefeller an nounced yesterday the forma tion of what was described as a nonpartisan and broadly rep resentative citizens panel to support passage of the $3.15 billion state bond issue, which will be in the ballot on Elec tion Day as a referendum.

title: Arabs Shaping New Unity
description: CAIRO, Sept. 20The prag matic moderate and conserva tive Arab leaders who control most of the area between the Nile and the Persian Gulf are fashioning a new solidarity.

title: HEROIN ADDICTION IS REPORTED DOWN
description: Using new statistical evi dence, Mayor Lindsay reiterated yesterday that heroin addiction in the city was declining markedly.

title: SAMUEL ARONOWITZ
description: ALBANY, Sept. 20 (AP)  Samuel Aronowitz, a lawyer and a founder of radio station WTRY in Troy, died today of injuries following an auto ac cident. He was 83 years old.

title: ZENITH TO INCREASE 8 COLOR TV PRICES
description: The Zenith Radio Corporation announced yesterday that it would increase prices on eight of its 48 models in its current E color television line, effec tive Oct. 1.

title: 14 Firemen Hurt in blaze
description: A twoalarm fire on the 15th floor of an 18story apartment house in Rego Park, Queens, caused injuries to 14 firemen yesterday, fire officials re ported. Officials said the blaze, which broke out shortly before 2 P.M. at 9707 Horace Hard ing Expressway, was brought under control at 2:55 P.M. The injured firemen were treated at St. John's Hospital. No cause for the blaze has been determined, but the spokesman said the fire was not suspi cious.

title: CLOTHING MAKER SLAIN IN ELEVATOR
description: A 78yearold clothing manu facturer was stabbed to death just before 1 P.M. yesterday in the elevator of his office build ing in the garment district.

title: State Is T old How Retired Are Cheated on Pensions
description: Dozens of elderly people yes terday described to state of ficials how, after a lifetime of work, they had applied for their pensions in private industry only to find that they were not eligible, that the funds had been dissipated or that their benefits were lower than they had been led to believe.

title: Jersey Coed's Killer May Bear Scars Of Battle With KarateTrained Victim
description: ROSELLE, N.J., Sept. 20  The slayer of a 19yearold Seton Hall coed being sought by the police may bear the marks of a brutal struggle with his karatetrained victim in a secluded treefringed lot of a quiet residential section here.

title: Any Agnew Replacement May Face Bar on '76 Bid
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 Deimocratic leaders of the House of Representatives have reportedly made plans to insist, if Vice President Agnew leaves office before his term expires, that his successor pledge not to seek election as President in 1976.

title: BIAGGI RIDICULES MARCHI ON CRIME
description: Representative Mario Biaggi ridiculed yesterday the tough lawandorder stance of State Senator John J. Marchi, his main competitor for the right ofcenter vote in the mayoral race.

title: Guard at the Watergate Says He Can't Get Job
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP)The security guard who discovered the Water gate breakin said today that he was out of work and un able to persuade potential employers to hire him.

title: News Summary and Index FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 21, 1973
description: International

title: A Supersonic Concorde Lands in Texas
description: GRAPEVINE, Tex., Sept. 20 In the first visit of a super sonic airliner to the United States, a FrenchBritish Con corde flew here today from Caracas, Venezuela, to provide an extra dimension to Satur day's dedication of the world's largest jetport.

title: Most Aides to Rockefeller Urge Drive for Presidency
description: A majority of Governor Rockefeller's, closest advisers are recommending tha he net seek a fifth term and instead concentrate all his efforts on bid for the Republican Presi dential nomination in 1976.

title: Olen Is Adviser to Eastern Dry Goods
description: Maurice E. Olen, once con sidered a retailing boy won der who headed the H. L. Green variety store chain and was indicted and fined in 1961 for allegedly violating laws of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has emerged as a financial adviser and spokes man for the Eastern Dry Goods Company in possible bankruptcy discussions involv ing stores that Eastern recent ly bought.

title: Poem Attributed to Neruda Attacks the Coup and Nixon
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 20 (Reuters)President Nixon and the head of Chile's military junta, Gen Augusto Pinochet Ugarte, were attacked in a poem published here today and re portedly written by Pablo Ne ruda, the Chilean poet who won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1971.

title: Philadelphians Score 2 Hits in Shanghai
description: SHANGHAI, Sept. 20The Philadelphia Orchestra to night played the last concert but one on its trip to China. The program was familiarBeethoven's Pastoral Sym phony, Respighi's; Pines of Rome, Barber's Adagio for Strings and the Yellow Riv er concerto with Yin Cheng chung as soloist.

title: AMEX PRICES UP ON GOOD VOLUME
description: Prices rose, again in continued good volume on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market yesterday.

title: Nixon And Connally
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20Two lead ing Democrats are now on record as saying that if Vice President Agnew resigns or is shoved, President Nixon should have no trouble in choosing Mr. Agnew's successor and getting the Democraticcontrolled Congress to ap prove the President's personal choice.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (Reuters)The Securities and Exchange Commission said it had censured Walston & Co., Inc., and suspended overthecounter trading at Waiston's Chicago office for two weeks beginning Oct. 1 1973.

title: Officer in Albany Says fellow Police Joined in Thievery

title: Ethiopia Denies an Attempt To Hijack Selassie's Plane
description: PARIS, Sept. 20 (AP)The Ethiopian Embassy in Paris to day denounced as imaginary reports from Beirut, Lebanon, that a member of the royal family tried to hijack the plane carrying Emperor Haile Selas sie from West Germany to Ad dis Ababa last Friday.

title: L.I. MAN IS PROPOSED FOR U.S. JUDGESHIP
description: The two United States Sen ators from New York have agreed to recommend a Suffolk County lawyer for a Federal judgeship in the Eastern Dis trict.

title: PRESIDENT'S COPTERS REGARDED AS SAFE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) A new $31million fleet of 11 Presidential helicopters may get extra emergency exits and interior lighting as a result of a nighttime crash in the Ba hamas last May. But otherwise, the Pentagon says, there will be little change in safety proce dures involving President Nix on's helicopters on their 150 mile flights from Florida to the Bahamas.

title: Eastern Airlines Is Eliminating Officers in Effort to Reorganize
description: Three vice presidents of East ern Airlines have left the com pany, and three others have been demoted in an executive shakeup that seems at least partly intended as a response to recent criticism that its man agement was topheavy.

title: McIntire Silences Radio at Sea On Complaint of Nearby Station
description: COLLINGWOOD, N.J., Sept. 20After a oneday stand, the Rev. Carl McIntire took his seaborne pirate radio station off the air today.

description: Winning numbers drawn on Sept. 20 were:

description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Sept. 20 (AP)The de fending champion, Jim Wright of Inwood, L. I., took a three stroke lead after the second round today in the New York State Professional Golfers' Association open.

title: Scheel Sees Gainful NixonMarket Talks
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 20Foreign Minister Wal ter Scheel of West Germany today defended the European Economic Community's re sponse to the United States' call for a new Atlantic char ter.

description: The Giants are big favor ites, the Jets little ones to win on Sunday. The Jets will be in Baltimore against the Colts (Channel 4, 2 P.M.) while the Giants are the hosts to the Eagles in their finale at Yankee Stadium (Channel 2, 1 P.M.). The big game, Miami at Oakland, will not be televised here. The Monday night match is unusually unin teresting, New Orleans at Dallas. title: People in Sports: Aaron Airs Johnson's Secret
description: Hank Aaron of the Atlanta Braves says he knows the secret of Dave Johnson's homerun success and it has nothing to do with playing in Atlanta Stadium. I've seen him hit 'em a long way anywhere, said Aaron. He always hits the ball in the air and that's the secret of hitting home runs. John son, Aaron's teammate, on Wednesday night walloped his 43d, to break the record for most homers in a season by a second baseman, set in 1922 by Rogers Hornsby of the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: COPPER CONCERNS WATCHING CHILE
description: Major copper companies said yesterday they had not com municated with the new Chilean military Government about the possible reopening of mines there.

title: Maybe I'll Cry Tomorrow, Says Mays
description: Willie Mays  conceding that maybe I'll cry tomor rowannounced yesterday that he would end his base ball career at the close of this season, his 22d as one of the superstars of the ma jor leagues.

title: Rangers Send Down 22
description: KITCHENER, Ont., Sept. 20 (AP)The New York Rangers assigned today 22 players, including goalie Peter McDuffe and forwards Rick Middletown and Al Blanchard, to their Provi dence club of the American Hockey League.

title: TV Review
description: The World at War, pro duced by Jeremy Isaacs for Britain's Thames Television, is an unusually ambitious project devoting 26 hourlong episodes to a factual docu mentation and analysis of World War II. It is also un usual in other ways.

title: Legality of G.O.P. Aid for FoesUpheld
description: The chairman of the State Assembly Committee on the Election Law yesterday said that even if Republican cam paign officials did aid Liberal candidates in 1972 in order to deny victory to Democrats, he could see nothing illegal in that.

title: Albert Backs Public Funding Of Federal Election Campaigns
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 House Speaker Carl Albert in dicated today his support for some form of public financing of Federal election campaigns.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on U. S. railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 17.2 billion ton miles, 8.7 per cent above the corresponding week last year. Carloadings in the same week totaled 564,387 cars, 2.7 per cent above last year. The Amer ican Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 3.1 per cent above last year.

title: EARL CLIFTON RENO, ACTIVE IN UNIONISM
description: SHARON, Conn., Sept. 20 Earl Clifton Reno, a leader in major labor demonstrations in the Depression years, died Sun day at his home here of a heart ailment complicated by emphy sema. He was 68 years old.

title: Food Concern Indicted
description: A 10count Federal indict ment ment has charged a frozen food processing concern with discharging organic wastes and leaking residues into the Plattekill River at Highland, N. Y. The indictment named Teddy's Frosted Foods Inc., whose TVdinner processing operation two months ago was moved elsewhere from a plant on the Plattekill, a Hudson River tributary.

title: A 2c Postage Rise Asked For 1st Class and Airmail
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., Sept. 20Postmaster Gen eral E. T. Klassen said to night that he would seek au thority next week to raise firstclass and airmail post age rates by 2 cents each to pay for recent wage increases and capital improvements.

title: Film: Anarchic Comedy:Belated Bow for 'Get to Know Your Rabbit' The Cast
description: Brian De Palma's "Get to Know Your Rabbit" was made three years ago; yet it did not arrive in New York until Wednesday, and then with less advance word than usually accompanies the opening of a Broadway shoe store. This casual treatment is unfortunate since De Palma ("Greetings," "Hi, Mom") is a very funny filmmaker. He's most funny, so far, anyway, when he's most anarchic, and "Get to Know Your Rabbit," though somewhat inhibited by conventional form, has enough hilarrious loose ends and sidetracks to liberate the film from its form.In outline, it's the story of a nice, clean-cut market analyst named Donald Beeman (Tom Smothers), who one day walks out of his office in the Los Angeles headquarters of Servo-Temp, Inc., to be a tap-dancing magician. It's Donald's aim to become perfectly seedy, which doesn't amuse his girl very much, especially when he comes home with the rabbit that's been issued to him at class. "It doesn't suit you," she says crossly, and then remembers how nice he looked with his attach case colored burnt umber.Donald's path to Perfect Seediness is littered with lunatics, some more desperate than others, like the airline, pilot who, before each flight, climbs to the top of a tree and refuses to come down. "It's just butterflies," says a stewardess to a kindly fireman who wants to help. "If you can get him down now, he can still make the 10:52 flight to Detroit."There's a depressed brassiere manufacturer (Allan Garfield), who dreams of finding a girl, someplace, somewhere, who appreciates a good, medium-priced bra. There also are old Mr. Delasandro (Orson Welles), who teaches Donald how to become a seedy, tap-dancing magician; Katharine Ross, a small-town girl who comes to worship Donald's lack of talent, and John Astin, a former executive at Servo-Temp whom Donald finds on Skid Row, clutching a wine bottle and a knapsack containing his dearest possessions (a matching pen-and-pencil desk set). Tom Smothers makes a very cheerful, optimistic novice, though his Donald is never a pushover for the con artists he meets. When Mr. Delasandro, after graduating Donald magna cum laude, asks the young man if he would like to consider himself Mr. Delasandro's spiritual son, Donald thinks a minute, then says no.Movies that promote the importance of non-conformity are almost always fraudulent or, what's worse, they're sentimental. "A Thousand Clowns" is a case in point. "Get to Know Your Rabbit" largely avoids those pitfalls, and with a great deal of comic exuberance. It also reinforces my expectation that De Palma will one day make a really fine American comedy.

title: Bob Smith Gets 65 to Lead Golf By One Stroke
description: ENDICOTT, N. Y., Sept. 20 (UPI)Without golf's leading players to contend with, and shooting a blistering 29 on the back nine, Bob E. Smith led the first round today of the $100,000 Broome County open with a sixunderpar 65. Eight of the top golfers are competing in the Ryder Cup in Scotland and most of the rest are taking the week off.

title: Cubs Hand Expos 4th Loss In Row
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (UPI)  Rick Monday collected three hits and scored three runs today to lead the Chi cago Cubs to a 54 victory over Montreal. The defeat ex tended the Expos' losing streak to four games and left them with two more losses than Pittsburgh, the leader, with 10 games to play in the National League's eastern di vision race.

title: Lavine Says Interviews Cut Welfare Rolls 20%
description: One of every five welfare cases investigated in the state has been closed in the first two months of facetoface in terviews with welfare families, the State Department of Social Services announced yesterday.

title: Pretrial Assistance Held Helpful in Cutting Crime
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 20The process of pretrial intervention, in which screened defendants are placed under the supervi sion of a community's re sources instead of going to trial and possibly to prison, is rapid ly gaining recognition as an important new component of the American judicial system.

title: Talks in Capital Stall Baltimore Jury
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 20Cru cial negotiations in Washington between the Federal prosecu tor here and Vice President Agnew's lawyers brought the Federal grand jury investiga tion of bribery and kickback allegations against Mr. Agnew to a halt today.

title: Thomas Fitzpatrick Is Dead; Fitz of Artist and Writers
description: Thomas F. Fitzpatrick, the Fitz of Fitz and Hitz, who have operated the Artist, and Writers Restaurant, formerly Jack Bleeck's, at 213 West 40th Street, for the last 20 years, died Wednesday. He was 73 years old and lived at 173 Cen tral Ave., Madison, N.J.

title: Officer in Albany Says Fellow Police Joined in Thievery
description: ALBANY, Sept. 20An Al bany policeman told the State Commission of Investigation to day that he had carried out many burglaries and larcen ies with fellow policemen and said that to remain in good Standing with his colleagues he had felt compelled to pre tend that he was stealing even more than he was.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Sept. 20 (AP)The Memphis Tams have selected forwards John Baum and Jim Ard, from the New York Nets as compensation for signing a rookie, Larry Kenon, the Nets announced today.

title: Screen:Story of Dope Pusher Employs Technology
description: A motion picture called "The Story of Dope" opened yesterday at the First Avenue Screening Room. It is a concise and well-observed pastiche of self-congratulatory industrial films in general and an impudent take-off on that coffee commercial in which El Exigente determines the future of growers by bestowing his favor on their crop. Only in this case the crop is marijuana.Unfortunately, "The Story of Dope" is a film within a film, and to see it one must endure "Arnold's Wrecking Co.," a sophomoric celebration of marijuana and youthful smarts at the expense of an assortment of cartoon characters who might as well be wearing labels identifying them as Typical Jewish Mother and Stupid Corrupt Pig Cop.The Arnold of the title is a preposterously straight and inept youth who comes to Philadelphia for a summer visit to his cousin Kenny, is forced to smoke marijuana, becomes an instant convert to its pleasures and proceeds to turn pusher. But he is a pusher on a mammoth scale, using the techniques and technology of big business in a concern he calls Arnold's Wrecking Co.The idea reads better than it plays, and one need not look far for the culprit. The movie is directed by Steve De Souza from a screenplay by Mr. De Souza. The part of Kenny is played by Steve De Souza. The rewards of self-indulgence are to be found in "The Story of Dope"; the excesses are all too visible in "Arnold's Wrecking Co."

title: FORDYCE ST. JOHN, SURGEON, 89, DIES
description: Dr. Fordyce Barker St. John, an eminent surgeon, teacher and clinical investigator, died Wednesday at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, which he helped plan and to which he devoted his profes sional life and energies. He was 89 years old and lived at 520 East 86th Street.

title: Don Use Ms. With Miss Stafford, Unless You Mean ms.
description: Whenever there comes in the mail a piece of firstclass matter addressed to me as Ms., I slit the envelope open and if there is a check within, abstract it. Then I reseal the envelope with Scotch tape (I like to do this when I have just finished changing a type writer ribbon or have been out in the garden messing with beets or scallions or other vegetables that grow under groundand you know what Scotch tape looks like when it is applied with grimy fingers) and, circling the Ms. in red, I write, also in red: NOT AC CEPTABLE TO ADDRESSEE. RETURN TO SENDER, and put it back in my letter box.

title: Sloan House Y Is Getting 60 Inmates of City Prisons
description: The Sloan House Y.M.C.A. on 34th Street just east of Ninth Avenue will become the resi dence next month for 40 male and 20 female inmates serv ing the last three months of their city prison sentences, Cor rection Commissioner Benjamin J. Malcolm said yesterday.

description: Hank Aaron of the Atlanta Braves says he knows the secret of Dave Johnson's homerun success and it has nothing to do with playing in Atlanta Stadium. I've seen him hit 'em a long way anywhere, said Aaron. He always hits the ball in the air and that's the secret of hitting home runs. John son, Aaron's teammate, on Wednesday night walloped his 43d, to break the record for most homers in a season by a, second baseman, set in 1922 by Rogers Hornsby of the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Philip R. Mather, Headed Social Health Association
description: BOSTON, Sept. 20  Philip R. Mather, board chairman the American Social Health Association, died, apparently of a heart attack, last evening. He was 79 years old and lived in Chestnut Hill.

title: Eleven Miners
description: South Africa's police ignited both an internal crisis and an international incident when they killed eleven black miners and wounded more than twenty others during a riot at the country's largest gold mine last week. The shootings inevitably rekindled painful mem ories for South Africansblack, white and coloredof the slaying of 69 Africans at Sharpeville in 1960 for pro testing the Nationalist Government's harsh racial laws.

title: Breakthroughs in the Chrysler Agreement
description: DETROIT, Sept. 20When Douglas Fraser, a vice presi dent of the United Autoinobile Workers union, made visits to the plants recently some work ers came to him and said: Doug, you've got to do some thing. Things have got to change.

title: Goldstein of The Times Honored By Lindsay for Service to City
description: Nathan W. Goldstein, circula tion director of The New York Times for 25 years, was cited by Mayor Lindsay last night for distinguished and exceptional service to New York City.

title: Quilici Is Rehired By Twins for 1974
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 20 (AP)The Minneso ta Twins signed Manager Fnank Quilici today to man age again in 1974 with an increase in salary despite a losing session.

title: Kissinger Drive Seen
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 20  Is rael expects a renewed Ameri can effort to get the Middle East stalemate off dead center later this year.

title: Brown Jug To Melvin In Raceoff
description: DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 20 (UPI)  Melvin's Woe, driven by Joe O'Brien, won the onemile Little Brown Jug pace for 3yearolds today.

title: Advertising: Mercurial Airlines
description: Los Angelesbased Con tinental Air Lines, with a total advertising and promotion budget of some $10million, announced yesterday that Benton & Bowles and Ogilvy & Mather had been selected as finalists for its account, but did not rule out the pos sibility that it might stay with Needham, Harper & Steers.

title: Pork With Apples
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an aster isk are followed by a recipe.

title: Securities Industry Assails Bank Investment Services
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  Spokesmen for the securities in dustry gave Congress today what one legislator called scary presentation of the dangers they see in permitting banks to sell common stocks to their depositors without the kind of regulation to which stockbrokers are subject.

title: SEC IN A SHIFT ON VARIABLE LIFE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  The Securities and Exchange Commission, backtracking to significant degree on a decision it made last January, proposed new rules today to tighten the regulations under which insur ance companies would be per mitted to sell variablelifein surance policies.

title: 564MILLION ASKED FOR SCHOOLS HERE
description: A $564million school construction program for 197475, which would provide 52,700 more seats for pupils and make possible improve ments to many sxisting schools, was proposed yesterday by School Chancellor Irving Anker.

title: The Pop Life
description: On stage the Moody Blues rock group, takes, it calcu lates, one hour and 45 min utes to go through its act. The British group arrives in New York next month on a 10 country tour.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20 Inflation is a prime topic among delegates to the International Industrial Conference here this week.
