description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 20  Is rael expects a renewed Ameri can effort to get the Middle East stalemate off dead center later this year.

title: Philharmonic Hall Gets Gift of $8Million
description: Philharmonic Hall, which opened 11 years ago this month, yesterday was renamed Avery Fisher Hall in apprecia tion of a major gift of undis closed size by a pioneer manu facturer of highfidelity phono graph and radio equipment. In formed sources in musical and financial circles here immedi ately estimated the overall gift at $8million to $10mil lion.

title: Bhutto Warns U.N. of Peril in BigPower Talks
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 20  Prime Minister Zul fikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan told the General Assembly to day that the greatest impedi ment to peace in the world was the injustice imposed on the weak by the strong.

title: Tinney Cavenaugh Figgatt Headed Cotton Exchange
description: PHOENIXVILLE, Pa., Sept. 20 Tinney Cavenaugh Figgatt, a former independent floor cotton broker, who was elected presi dent of the New York Cotton Exchange in 1960, died here yesterday at the age of 90. He lived in Pawling, N. Y.

title: Dedication of Roosevelt Island Will Recall the New Deal Era
description: The turbulence and hope in which the New Deal was born in the early nineteenthirties will be recalled Monday when Welfare Island is officially re named Franklin D. Roosevelt Is land.

title: Musicians Remain At Philharmonic; Reject Opera Bid
description: Negotiators representing man agement and musicians of the New York Philharmonic orches tra were reported quite far apart early today. A strike deadline passed at midnight, but the musicians union said it would continue to perform at concerts until further notice.

title: Stock Prices Move Ahead On Heaviest '73 Trading
Passaic Tech Unit Head Vows Full Investigation
description: PATERSON, Sept. 20When the Board of Freeholders voted last night to set up a three man subcommittee to investi gate management practices and possible academic shortcomings at the Passaic County Techni cal and Vocational School Mrs. Louise Friedman was pleased, but not elated.

title: LowKey, HighFidelity Donor Avery Robert Fisher
description: Someday it will be Avery Fisher Hall. They'll say, Who the hell was Avery Fisher? It doesn't bother me. In case anyone is won dering today who Avery Fisher isaside from being the source of the quotation abovethe brief answer is: a modest, 67yearold multi millionaire who has made what he calls a major gift to Lincoln Center. As Lincoln re sult, Philharmon ic Hall is undergoing a change of name, an altera tion that prompts the brown eyed, whitehaired highfidel ityequipment pioneer to as sert what is readily apparent to anyone who talks to him for only a few minutes. You won't believe this, he said, but I'm really a modest guy. It doesn't mean so much to me as I expect it to mean to my family, particularly my son. I want him to have something to chin on in his career.

title: Acupuncture Is a Hit With the Philadelphia Musicians in China
description: PEKING, Sept. 19  The rest of the Philadelphia Or chestra's concerts in China will be played by a slightly punctured group.

title: Colavito Quits as Coach
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 20 (AP)Rocky Colavito has resigned as first base coach for the Cleveland Indians, effective at the end of the current season, a spokes man for the American League baseball club said today. Colavito, a favorite with the fans while an out fielder with the Indians, said he was resigning after one year as coach for financial reasons.

title: Hawkins Left No Estate
description: LONDON, Sept. 20 (Reuters) Jack Hawkins, whose movies included The Bridge on the River Kwai, left nothing after payment of liabilities and death duties, his will disclosed today. His wife, Dorreen, said: I sup pose everyone expected Jack to leave half a million, but people don't realize that English actors are never rich because they pay such enormous taxes. Mr. Hawkins died last July of throat cancer.

title: Senate Begins Debate on Weapons Procurement and Research
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The Senate began today what is expected to be a protracted debate on the Nixon Adminis tration's defense policies, with the issues of military spending enmeshed in a confrontation between two senior and proud SenatorsStuart Symington of Missouri and Henry M. Jackson of Washington.

title: JERSEY TO PROVIDE MORTGAGE FUNDS
description: TRENTON, Sept. 20 Gov ernor Cahill announced today that the state would move quiekly to provide up to $100 million in emergency home mortgage funds to ease New Jersey's growing housing cri sis.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Coop City Strike Is Ended

title: Nassau Candidate Says G.O.P. Demanded $100 for Promotion
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 20  Norman Blankman, Independent party candidate for Nassau County Executive, said today that a Republican committee man had been denied a promo tion In a county job after re fusing to give the Republican party $100.

title: U. S. ISSUES GAIN IN ACTIVE TRADING
description: Government issues rose yes terday in active trading as corporate bonds remained firm.

title: SENATE UNIT FINDS VERY LITTLE BASIS FOR 17 WIRETAPS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee said today that very little, if any, justifica tion, was presented in most instances for the White Housesanctioned wiretapping of the phones of 13 officials and four newsmen from 1969 to 1971.

title: Ms. Magazine, a Success After 16 Issues
description: The women at Ms. mag azine are very happy in deed these days, for they are managing, with a bold ness not always seen in their male counterparts, what has become a miniconglomerate.

title: Making Pensions Secure
description: The unanimous vote in the Senate for comprehensive reform of private pension plans is not only a significant contribution to improved oldage protection for American workers but also a reassuring sign of vitality in the legislative process.

title: Taylor Purchases Colt for $2Million
description: TORONTO, Sept. 20 (AP) Tentam, a 4yearold colt who holds the record for. 1 miles on the grass, was purchased for $2million by E. P. Taylor, a spokesman for, the Canadian owner and breeder said today.

title: Franc Devaluation Rumor Depresses Money Market
description: LONDON, Sept. 20 (AP)  Rumors of a possible de valuation of the French franc set off a wave of speculation on world money markets to day, dragging down the dollar and, putting pressure on the French currency.

title: For Forbes, It Will Be Up, Up and Away
description: Malcolm F. Forbes, the 54 yearold magazine publisher who collects art and real estate, had his first balloon ride 15 months ago. Yester day he announced plans to start a crosscountry flight on Oct. 3 from the Oregon coast to the New Jersey shore, add ing wryly that a landing any place between Maine and Florida would be considered satisfactory.

title: The Chicago Loop's Decline Is Magnificent Mile's Gain
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 20Put the city up; tear the city down; put it up again; let us find a city, wrote Carl Sand burg, the poet laureate of Chicago, in his poem The Windy City?

title: F.D.A.Will Require A Warning on Pill For Morning After
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UPI)  The Food and Drug Administration said today that it would require doctors to warn patients that the morn ing after birth control pill may not be safe and may trig ger side effects such as blood clotting.

title: No Change Expected In Callas Tour Here
description: Maria Callas' American recital tour this season will proceed as scheduled de spite the announcement that she had to cancel her ap pearance in London's Royal Festival Hall tomorrow night. Sander A. Gorlinsky, her European concert man ager, called the cancellation a postponement, caused by doctor's orders that the fa mous soprano rest. She has an eye ailment that under nervous tension can lead to glaucoma, he said.

title: Arabs Shaping New Unity
description: CAIRO, Sept. 20The prag matic moderate and conserva tive Arab leaders who control most of the area between the Nile and the Persian Gulf are fashioning a new solidarity.

title: PLANS FOR HIGHWAY SCORED IN VILLAGE
description: A study presented last night at a meeting of Community Board 2 in Greenwich Village said that the proposed recon struction of the West Side Highway would do little to solve the problem of traffic congestion along Manhattan's West Side, and could possibly even become an alternate route for trucks that now use New Jersey highways.

title: Robyn Smith Is Ready for Riggs
description: Robyn Smith would like to ride against Bobby Riggs in a horse race, but she doubts the male chauvinist of the sports world would accept the challenge.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: BAIT AND HARRY BREW LAST BATCH
description: Another New York brewery has ceased production, leaving only two operating here. As late as 1953, there were five and after Repeal, more than a dozen breweries in New York.

title: SETBACK TO TALKS ON ULSTER IS SEEN
description: LONDON, Sept. 20  Prime Minister Heath's suggestion, later qualified, that Northern Ireland might have to be inte grated into Britain continued to send off political sparks today, but there were signs that the threeday controversy was beginning to fade.

title: CLOTHING MAKER SLAIN IN ELEVATOR
description: A 78yearold clothing manu facturer was stabbed to death just before 1 P.M. yesterday in the elevator of his office build ing in the garment district.

title: Ulster Protestant Is Cleared Of Murder in a Dublin Court
description: DUBLIN, Sept. 20  An 18 yearold Protestant from Northern Ireland was cleared here today of a double murder charge.

title: Nixon Nominates James Quello to F.C.C. Vacancy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 James H. Quello, a retired broadcasting executive from Detroit, will be nominated for membership on the Federal Communications Commission, the White House announced today. Mr. Quello, 69 years old, is a former vice president of the Capital Cities Broadcast ing Corporation.

title: Mrs. King Calls Victory Culmination of Career
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 20She flung her racquet high to ward the girded roof of the Astrodome and then col lapsed, tears in her eyes, in her husband's arms. Mrs. Billie Jean King had just beaten the ladykiller of wo men's tennis and all of a sud den, she was a champion, a woman and a little girl at the same time.As Larry, her husband, lifted her onto a table at courtside, Mrs. King held the $100,000 winner's trophy high in the air, blowing kisses to the crowd. She stuck her tongue at Dennis van de Meer, her coach. She held up a fist to some friends.For Billie Jean, it was in her own words, the culmin ation of 19 years of tennis. But as she walked into the Houston Astros' dressing room for the postmatch press conference, she was still so keyed up she insisted on taking her blue suede sneak ers off and walking around barefooted on the raised platform for a moment to calm herself.

title: Chile Poor Are Visited By General
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 20The frail wooden shacks of the Ho Chi Minh shanty town were adorned with miniature Chilean flags commemorating Armed Forc es Day.

title: Hopeful Reading Trend
description: News of the improvement of the reading scores in the city's schools is of psychological as well as educa tional significance. The extent of the gains, reported by the State Education Department, is still modest; but the indication of a threeyear trend and the fact that the same tests show a continued downward slide in the state's other large cities justify cautious hope that a turning point in New York's public education system may have been reached.

title: TV Blackout Is Lifted For Six Sunday Games
description: The National Football League announced last night that six football games this Sunday were sold out 72 hours in advance and will be telecast in their respective host cities.

title: Soviet Forms World. Copyright Agency
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 20  The Soviet Union today announced the longgawaited formation of state copyright agency to act as a clearing house for publishing Soviet works abroad or foregin works in the Soviet Union.

title: Destination Leads Race On Sound
description: NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 20Russell L. Hoyt's Desti nation, a Cuthbertson and Cassian 43foot sloop that flies the New York Yacht Club burgee, was first to fin ish and also the winner on corrected time in the Inter national Offshore Rule Divi sion I today. It was the opening leg of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's annual cruise on Island Sound.

title: VIOLATIONS CHARGED IN GARAGE COLLAPSE
description: City Buildings Commissioner Theodore Karagheuzoff said yesterday that cars were parked without legal authoriza tion on the roof of the Travel ers Garage on West 28th Street when the building collapsed Wednesday.

title: 5caRide Day Lures Connecticut Bus Riders
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 20 You could ride a bus almost anywhere in and around New Haven, Hartford or Stamford today for a 5cent fare. And if, you didn't have nickel well, they were being given away free on the street cor ners.

title: Informant Says Garrison Allies Tried Bribery on His Testitnony
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 20A Government informant, Per shing O. Gervais, testified in United States District Court here today that an attorney allegedly supplied to him by District At torney Jim Garrison, a de fendant in a bribery case here, had talked with Mr. Garrison's lawyers about letting them write, the script for the trial in exchange for $50,000.

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: ARIOSO The Amato Op era Theater, 319 Bowery, at Second Street (2288300), is off to another season in its 103seat house, where it will be doing six produc tions starting tonight wtih a new one of Giordano's Andrea Chenier, in Italian.

title: U.S HELD LAGGING IN USE OF SCIENCE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The United States leads the world in advanced communica Lion's research but lags, in some important respects, in apply ing that technology for the na tion's benefit, according to a report released today by the Na tional Academy of Engineering.

title: JERSEY PROVIDING MORTGAGE FUNDS
description: TRENTON, Sept. 20 Gov ernor Cahill announced today that the state would move quickly to provide up to $100 million in emergency home mortgage funds to ease New Jersey's growing housing cri sis.

title: East German's Great Moment at U.N.
description: Otto Winzer, an old Com munist with a reputation for tough orthodoxy, is in a mel low mood these days, happier than any of his aides can ever remember, because of fresh recognition accorded him as Foreign Minister of East Ger many.

title: British Gain 3Point Edge Over U.S. In Ryder Golf
description: MUIRFIELD, Scotland, Sept. 20  The United States Ryder Cup team received a jolting setback today as the squad of players from Britain and Ireland took the lead, 52 on the first day of the professional golf series.

title: Bridge: Preempting the Preemptor Is an Exercise in Futility
description: It a partnership has a strong sixcard suit in one major opposite a singleton, and a similar holding in the other, the other way round, it might seem a matter of indifference which suit be came trumps. But if one suit split threethree and the other fourtwo, the former would no doubt seem more desirable.

title: HeatingOil Supply Called 30% Short In State for Winter
description: A 30 per cent gap between needs and present likely supplies of heating oil through out New York State for next winter has been forecast by oil distributors and retailers in a report to the Temporary State Commission on Living Costs and the Economy.

title: C.I.A. Will Seek to Excise Parts of Book by ExAide
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  The Central Intelligence Agency has told the American Civil Liberties Union that it will op pose the publication of about 100 pages of allegedly classified material contained in an ac count by a former C.I.A. of ficial of the agency's internal workings.

title: Nuclear Power Plant Safety Questioned by Senator Byrd
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UPI) The Senate Democratic whip, Robert C. Byrd, said to day that he was sufficiently impressed by the doubts of some scientists to question whether nuclear power plants were a major risk to the safety of the United States.

title: Music: Salome Unveiled
description: Salome, for all its secure foothold in the operatic repertory, presents a continu ing dilemma: any soprano possessed of a voice hefty enough to sing the part is likely to be too hefty of figure to manage the Dance of the Seven Veils without strain ing the imagination as well as the stage boards. And vice versa, of course.

title: 4 to Plead Ellsberg BreakIn's Legality
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20  Four former Nixon Administra tion aides, indicted for the breakin at the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist, will argue that their activities were lawful and within the scope of authority of the President, their lawyers said here tcday.

title: McIntire Silences Pirate Radio at Sea
description: COLLINGWOOD, N.J., Sept. 20After a oneday stand, the Rev. Carl McIntire took his Seaborne pirate radio station off the air today.

title: PARTY COMPROMISE URGED BY STRAUSS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP)Robert S. Strauss, the Democratic National Chairman, appealed today for compromise between factions within the party as a party reform com mission prepared to map plans for rewriting controversial 1972 delegate selection guidelines.

title: Dr. William Granger Jr. Brooklyn Physician, 82

title: COTTON FUTURES ARE UP THE LIMIT
description: Desperate buyers bid all but the most distant cotton deliv eries up the daily permissible limit of 2 cents a pound yes terday on the New York Cot ton Exchange.

description: KOMPONG CHAM, Cambo dia, Sept. 20Enemy shelling of this provincial capital has subsided to the point at which one person was killed and 14 were virunded today  rela tively inconsequential casual ties in a town that has seen 8,000 killed or wounded in the last three weeks.

title: Dave Anderson
description: For two decades, Willie Mays played baseball as if he were 22 years old. Then suddenly he was 42 and his body wouldn't let him do what his mind wanted to do, which was to play baseball forever. With three sore ribs that won't let him swing a bat, with a sore arm that won't let him make the long throw from center field, Willie. Mays has surrendered to his body. He announced yesterday that he wouldn't play baseball next season. He stood behind a long table in the Diamond Club at Shea Stadium with the New York Mets' hierarchy around him, a significant setting. His ab sence from New York, when the Giants moved to San Francisco in 1958, contributed to the creation of the Mets' franchise. But that didn't make his surrender any easier.For him, baseball has been a refuge from the reai world. In his mind, he'd still like to play forever. Perhaps sub consciously, a few phrases betrayed that feeling.

title: BUILDING COLLAPSES, INJURING WORKMAN
description: A section of a building under renovation on the Lower East Side fell to the sidewalk yes terday about noontime, injur ing a workman.

title: U.S. DENIES AIDING SIRIKERS IN CHILE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 The State Department de scribed as absurd today any suggestion that the United States had financed the truck drivers' strike in Chile that pre ceded the military overthrow of President Salvador Allende Gossens last week.

title: Agnew at Bay
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20The Nixon Administration, as a derisive saying goes, is all heart. It was willing to let Ernest Fitzgerald bleed for a while. It was willing to let the pa thetically loyal Pat Gray twist slow ly, slowly in the wind. Its list of political hulks, scrapped when neces sary, runs from John Sears and Bob Ellsworth, who were among the earli est Nixon comeback workers, to John Mitchell, once something of a father figure to Mr. Nixon himself.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The surtax plan revealed by Melvin Laird merits support. The fast rise of inflation can no longer be stated in exact figures. How far the tremendous rise of international commodity prices and the devaluation and shaky posi tion of the dollar will carry our price level, no one can predict.

title: Ben Webster Saxophonist With Jazz Bands, Is Dead
description: AMSTERDAM, The Nether lands, Sept. 20 (UPI)  Ben Webster, the American jazz tenor saxophonist who played in the Fletcher Henderson, Duke Ellington, and Count Basie or chestras, died today of cerebral thrombosis. He was 64 years old.

description: CHICAGO, Sept. 20Mrs. Jacqueline Jackson smiled at the hordes of schoolchildren moving through the exhibit she had conceived and said: What's so beautiful about it is they're bringing pencils and papers along.

title: Light Penalty for WhiteCollar Crime
description: When Jack L. Clark, the for mer chairman of the scandal ridden Four Seasons Nursing Centers of America, Inc., was sentenced earlier this week to one year in prison, with parole possible after only four months, the Federal prosecu tors who had hoped to prove that there was no special privi lege for people of wealth and pres tige made it clear that they were chagrined. By their estimate, the Four Seasons scandal had cost un wary shareholders $200million, and they had urged substantial punishment for Clark, a mil lionaire who could have re ceived a maximum sentence of five years in prison and a fine of $10,000.

title: Screen: Using the C.I.A.:Ex-Agent Is Spook Who Sat by the Door
description: In "The Spook Who Sat by the Door," Dan Freeman (Lawrence Cook), a mildmannered, bespectacled, black social worker who seems to know his place, allows himself to become the token by which the Central Intelligence Agency becomes integrated.There is, of course, no thought of ever sending Dan into the field. Black men, otherwise invisible, have a tendency to be conspicuous as spies. They stand out. Dan is kept around the home office where he says "yes, sir" and "no, sir," and escorts sightseeing parties through the nonclassified sections. That, however, is just one side of Dan. The other side is Dan Freeman as the superblack nationalist. After Dan has learned everything that the C.I.A. has to teach him about guerilla warfare and weaponry, he returns to Chicago to orgnize a black revolution that, at the end of the film, is about to bring white America to its knees.Like Dan Greenlee's novel, on which it is based, "The Spook Who Sat by the Door" is a difficult work to judge coherently. It is such a mixture of passion, humor, hindsight, prophecy, prejudice and reaction that the fact that it's not a very well-made movie, and is seldom convincing as melodrama, is almost beside the point.The rage it projects is real, even though the means by which that rage is projected are stereotypes. Black as well as white.Mr. Greenlee, who adapted his novel for the screen with Melvin Clay, and co-produced the film with Ivan Dixon, the director, couldn't care less about convincing white audiences of anything except black anger. The white characters are even more idiotic than can easily be explained by their roles as C.I.A. officials and United States Senators. The blacks are either poetic proles or members of the corrupted black middle class. "This is not about hating white folks," Freeman says as the black revolution is about to begin. "This is about loving freedom enough to fight and die for it."In spite of what Dan Freeman says, the film equates the two. "The Spook Who Sat by the Door" stacks its cards, and in doing so, it raises black consciousness by trivializing several hundred years of black neglect.

title: Say Hey, Mr. Mays...
description: Willie Mays may have been born in Alabama, but he was a New Yorker from the time he made his debut with the old New York Giants in 1951. His fourteen years in San Francisco when the Giants moved there were full of brilliant accomplishment, but his love stayed here and the city loved him. There was joy all around when he came back as a member of the Mets last year. Now, retiring at age 42, he is saluted not because he helped break down baseball's race barriers or because he was in the front rank of the game's alltime greats, but because he was the epitome of what all great athletes ought to bea man of grace and dignity. His list of vices began and ended with the bedevilment of opposing pitchers.

title: Hockey Transactions
description: ST. LOUISAssigned Keith Hall, goalie; Gary Davidson end George Tower, defense men to Columbus of the international League.

title: Museum Head Named At Victoria and Albert
description: LONDON, Sept. 21  Dr. Roy Strong, 38yearold di rector of the National Por trait Gallery, has been ap pointed the new director of the Victoria and Albert Mu seum.

title: MILITARY JUNTA IN CHILE OUTLAWS MARXIST PARTIES
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 21 The new military junta said to day that it had banned Marxist political parties and would soon announce a new constitution giving the armed forces a role in future legislative bodies.

title: Russians Start Truck Talks With G.M.
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 21 (AP) The Soviet Union has started preliminary talks with General Motors in hopes of convincing the United States automaker to build a billiondollar truck factory in Siberia, United States sources said today.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: FICTION

title: Ceiling Unlimited
description: Weeks of unctuous Administration preconditioning do not lessen the shock of yesterday's official announce ment that consumer prices in August took their biggest onemonth jump since the inflationary explosion that followed the removal of World War II economic controls a quartercentury ago.

title: Britain's Liberals Flexing New Muscle
description: SOUTHPORT, England, Sept. 21All the Liberal party mem bers in Parliament could sit comfortably around one table in the popular Chinese restau rant at this seaside resort. But judging from the mood of the annual Liberal assembly now under way, the delegates are confident they'll soon have enough to fill up the whole place.

title: Interest Unit Asks 4% Increase Limit For 1974 Dividends
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UN) The Committee on Interest and Dividends proposed today that corporations pay 1974 dividends not more than 4 per cent higher than dividends paid in 1973.

title: DOCK UNION HEAD IN JERSEY MISSING
description: Fifty undercover agents of the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor ar search ing here and in New Jersey dock areas for clues to the mysterious disappearance of the head of a Jersey City long shoremen's union.

title: Teleprompter, in Trouble, Lets 600 Go
description: The Teleprompter Corpora tion, the country's largest operator of cabletelevision systems, announced yesterday that it had recently discharged some 600 of the 3,000 employes in its cable division as one of several major steps taken to cut costs and tighten its business operations.

title: Solzhenitsyn Asking Author's Rights
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 21 Refer ring to the announcement yes terday that a Soviet copyright agency had been established, Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the dissident novelist, today chal lenged the Government to pro tect his work from unauthor ized publication in the West.

title: A Pollock Sold for $2Million, Record for American Painting
description: A Jackson Pollock painting, Blue Poles, has been sold to the Australian National Gellery in Canberra for $2millionthe highest price ever for in Ameri can painting.

title: Open Interest
description: Friday, Sept. 21, 1973 (in bushels, 000 omitted)

title: Strike Threatens to Close City Opera
description: Beverly Sills, leading soprano with the New York City Opera, warned yesterday that if a mu sicians' strike was not settled within 48 hours, there Would be no more performances this fall or next spring.

title: Recital: Susan Wyner
description: Susan Davenny Wyner, a soprano who needs no intro duction to alert followers of the vocal scene in New York, appeared at Tully Hall on Wednesday evening as win ner of the 1973 Joy in Sing ing Award Recital.

title: Equity Financing
description: The Detroit Edison Company has filed with the Michigan Public Service Commission for authority to issue and sell up to 4,000,000 shares of common stock. The company's common closed at 19, up  on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Polugayevsky Fills 8th Spot In Chess Qualifying Event
description: PORTOROZ, Yugoslavia, Sept. 21 (AP)Lev Polugayevsky of the Soviet Union defeated Efim Geller by half a point today in a special threeman chess tour nament, becoming the eighth and final competitor for the right to challenge Bobby Fischer, the world champion.

title: Miami Tops A Fumbling Texas, 2015
description: MIAMI, Sept. 21 (AP) The University of Miami scored a stunning 2015 upset tonight over Texas. Woody Thompson, the Miami fullback, scored three touch downs.

title: Retrospective Honors Marcel Duchamp
description: The largest retrospective exhibition yet held of the works of the late. Marcel Duchaffip  patron saint of Dada, surrealism and sev eral fhinor contemporary artistic cultsopened yester day at the Philadelphia Mu seum of Art, Fairmount Park, with all the reverence that attends a religious spectacle.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Ave nue and 126th Street, Flush ing, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 2:15 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 9, 2:10 P.M.)) (Radio  WHN, 2:10 P.M.

title: Building Systems Lenders Declare Its Credit in Default
description: Building Systems, Inc., of Cleveland said yesterday that its lender banks had declared the credit agreement between the company and the banks to be in default and all funds on deposit with them had been applied to reduce the loans.

title: MRS. EDWARD SHERMAN
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 21 (AP)  Hazel Poole Sherman, presi dent of the company that pub lishes The Newport Daily News, died today at the age of 89.

title: 27 Holdups of Subway Clerks Laid to Eight Brooklyn Youths
description: Eight Brooklyn youths, in cluding a 14yearold boy, were arrested yesterday by Transit Authority detectives and charged with committing 27 armed robberies of subway change booths in which $21,894 in cash and tokens was taken.

title: MILITARY JUNTA IN CHILE OUTLAWS MARXIST PARTIES
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 21 The new military junta said to day that it had banned Marxist political parties and would soon announce a new constitution giving the armed forces a role in future legislative bodies.

title: NORTH BRUNSWICK BOYCOTTS SCHOOLS
description: NORTH BRUNSWICK TOWN SHIP, Sept. 21About 90 per cent of this municipality's 3,800 publicschool children were kept home today by their parents to support a demand that the State Education Department permit its 223 10thgrade students to be transferred from New Bruns wick High School to attend a new $10million high school here.

title: NIXON WILL ALLOT PROPANE SUPPLIES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI) President Nixon has decided to order mandatory allocation of propane fuel to users facing possible shortages in coming months, White House officials said today. The details are to be announced within a few days.

title: 200 TO LOSE JOBS ATJERSEY AIRPORT
description: NEWARK, Sept. 21  Some 200 restaurant employes, many of them waitresses with 20 years' service, will lose their jobs at Newark International Airport beginning Sunday be cause of what they contend is age discrimination and their inability to fit into miniskirts.

title: Agnew, The Fall Guy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21You come into Washington from the United States, and it's crazy. The big thing is Agnew. A Vice President. You've heard of him? Right. Of the United States. Mildly interesting man, a lot of people went very big for him when he used to give it to the press. All right, the media. Really laid it on with a dictionary. Same guy. Interesting man, big spokesman for good old days, good old ways. Really like to go back there myself, and who wouldn't? Any how, Agnew could warm you up about the chances of getting back there, al though he didn't have any real sug gestions how to make the trip, and for that matter would you really want to go if he did? I mean, it was great back there in the good old days, but you had to know how to use the clutch, and the TV was only seven inches big, and they still hadn't invented the frozen french fry.

title: 200 Will Lose Restaurant Jobs In PhaseOut at Newark Airport
description: NEWARK, Sept. 21Some 200 restaurant employes, many of them waitresses with 20 years service, will lose their jobs at Newark International Airport beginning Sunday be cause of what they contend is age discrimination and their inability to fit into miniskirts.

title: Meditation Urged as DrugAbuse Cure in Schools
description: A Board of Education official who heads the drug informa tion program in the city's high schools said yesterday that he would recommend trying tran scendental meditation at sever al schools to help curtail drug abuse.

title: WOMAN IN SUBWAY DIES IN ACCIDENT
description: A 63yearold woman died last night after she was tram pled by a crowd of rushhour subway riders who were carried onto her when she fell at the bottom of a narrow escalator at the IND subway station at 34th Street and the Avenue of the Americas.

title: NASA Begins Studies To Learn Suitability Of Women in Space
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has started studies aimed at even tually putting women into space.

title: Black General in Army To Head D.C. Command
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)  The Army's senior black general will become commander of the Military District of Washington in November, it was announced today.

title: Escaped Crane Is Caught
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21 (UPI)  A wattled crane valued at $180,000 that escaped, from the Los Angeles Zoo Monday night was captured nearby in Griffith Park by an 8man crew with a net last night.

title: Weekend Strike Called By N.B.C. Technicians
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)Negotiators represent ing technical employes of the National Broadcasting Com pany voted today to strike the network at 12:01 A.M. Saturday unless agreement is reached on a new contract.

title: Oakland's Lewis Eligible
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 21, (UPI)Allan Lewis, who set a World Series record for most appearances, sixas a pinchrunner last year, was declared eligible today for the American League play offs.

title: Dr. Jean Wilde, 78, Dies; Hunter German Professor
description: Dr. Jean T. Wilde, emeritus professor of German at Hunter, College and an author and translator, died Wednesday at her home, 600 West 161st Street. Her age was 78.

title: U.N. Assembly Quickly Adopts Agenda
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 21The General Assem bly, in a rare display of har mony, adopted an agenda for its 28th annual session in less than an hour today.

title: NIXON AND AGNEW HOLD SECRET TALK AS RUMORS MOUNT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  President Nixon and Vice Presi dent Agnew met alone for an hour yesterday, and a new round of rumors and reports circulated today that negotia tions were under way for Mr. Agnew to resign in return for a guilty plea to a minor of fense.

title: DOCK UNION HEAD IN JERSEY MISSING
description: Fifty undercover agents of the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor, are search ing here and in New Jersey dock areas for clues tothe mysterious disappearance of the head of a Jersey City long shoremen's union.

title: TIMES LABOR SUIT WEIGHED BY COURT
description: State Supreme Court Justice Vincent A. Massi reserved de cision yesterday on whether The New York Times still has a labor contract with Typo graphical Union No. 6 forbid ding strikes or interference with operations through chapel, or shop, meetings.

title: Soviet Backs Multinational Companies
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21 Multinational companiesin creasingly controversial in many Western nations concerned about the sanctity of their econ omies  will find an enthu siastic host in the Soviet Union, Jermen M. Gvishiani, deputy chairman of the Soviet Union's Council of Ministers for Science and Technology, indicated to day.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:

title: Murdered Coed Mourned In Simple Funeral Service
description: ELIZABETH, Sept, 21  A simple funeral service was held this morning for Ann Logan, the 19yearold Seton Hall coed murdered in a sexual assault earlier this week.

title: Saigon Frees One of Its Sharp Critics
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 21Mrs. Ngo Ba Thanh, one of the sharpest critics of the Government of President Nguyen Van Thieu, and three independentminded labor lead ers returned today from prison to their homes and families.

title: Watergate Defendants Told To Support Pleas to Court
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP)Five of the Watergate defendants were ordered today by the chief United States District Court judge, John J. Sirica, to file affidavits to support their request to with draw their guilty pleas.

title: Chileans at U.N. Seek Normality
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 21Ten days after the Government of President Sal vador Allende Gossens was toppled, members of the Chile an delegation here seem intent on trying to restore the sem blance of a normal routine.

title: Miss Whitworth 71 Leads Oregon Golf
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 21 (AP)Kathy Whitworth, the defending champion, stroked five birdies today to take a onestroke lead after the first round of the second annual Portland golf tournament.

title: Louisianian Accused
description: BATON ROUGE, Sept. 21 (UPI)Cleveland Gallen 3d, of Houma, La., was charged with murder and attempted murder yesterday as a result of a shoot ing in the Student Union at Southern University. Albert Carter, 27, of Baton Rouge was killed and Charlie Polk, New Iberia, La., was wounded in the incident.

title: Houston Victor, 2719
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 21 (AP) The passing of D. C. Nobles and the running of Leonard Parker carried 16thranked Houston to a 2719 victory over South Carolina tonight in the Astrodome.

title: WINE TALK
description: Three years ago, the influ ential Bank of America pre dicted that by 1980 the Amer ican wine market would reach some 400million gallons. A year earlier, in a survey, wine industry leaders in this country foretold of a 335 million gallon market by 1979.

title: King Treats a TeenAger Like Riggs, Wins, 61, 61
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 21 (UN) Jean King, fresh from her victory last night over lobby Riggs, knocked off an opponent 40 years younger than Riggs here to day and advanced to the semifinals in the $30,000 Houstoh women's tennis tournament.

title: Libyan Jets Attack An Italian Warship Off African Coast
description: ROME, Sept. 21 (AP) Liby an Air Force jets attacked and Italian warship in the Mediter ranean's international waters off the Libyan coast, the Ital ian Defense Ministry said.

title: DISPUTE ON PERMIT OF FALLEN GARAGE
description: The license issued by the Department of Consumer Af fairs to the garage that col lapsed last Wednesday per mitted parking on the roof, but the city's Buildings Department said yesterday that the license it had issued did not.

title: SENATE CONFIRMS KISSINGER, 78 TO 7
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  Henry A. Kissinger, who emi grated with his family to the United States 35 years ago to escape Nazi persecution, was confirmed by the Senate today as the next Secretary of State. The vote was 78 to 7.

title: L.I. HOME IS ROBBED OF $50,000 IN GEMS
description: SANDS POINT, Sept. 21  Two men posing as telephone repairmen talked their way into the home of William P. Tavoul areas, the president of Mobil Oil Company, this afternoon, and stole $50,000 worth of Mrs. Tavoulareas's jewelry, Nassau County detectives reported.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Garbage Is Considered for Generators

title: Mets Attain .500 Mark and First Place in East As Seaver Defeats Pirates, 102, Before 51,381
description: Tom Seaver pitched the New York Mets past the prostrate Pittsburgh Pirates into first place last night be fore a cheering, chanting crowd of 51,381, the largest of the season in Shea Sta dium.

title: Airman Admits Perjury
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., Sept. 21 (UPI)  An airman who was a key witness against a Kitty Hawk crewman convicted of rioting aboard the aircraft car rier pleaded guilty to three counts of perjury yesterday. Michael Angelo Laurie, 19 years old, of Selden, N.Y., made the plea during arraign ment before his scheduled trial. He was charged with making false statements in the trial of Seaman Cleveland Mallory, whose conviction last Jan. 4 was later reversed by the Navy.,

title: Lottery Numbers
description: (A Correction)

title: Hunt Continues for LessPolluting Car Engines
description: DETROIT, Sept. 21Since 1963 the General Motors Cor poration has investigated well over 300 proposals for alternate types of auto mobile engines, according to Edward N. Cole, president of the giant auto maker. G.M. spent $36milion last year and this year we expect to spend about $46million ex ploring the alternate types of engines, he said.

title: TERRY LEAMGPOST AT JACOB'S PILLOW
description: Walter Terxy, who has served since February as director of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festi val in Lee, Mass., has submitted his resignation to the board of directors of the 40yearold in stitution founded by the late Ted Shawn.

title: H. H. PRIDE, SERVED AS N.Y.U. MARSHAL
description: Dr. Herbert Hammond Pride, who retired as professor of mathematics at New York Uni versity in 1956, after 42 years on the faculty, died Thursday of cancer in Hendersonville, N.C., where he lived. His age was 82.

title: Texas Bias Dispute Heated by Remark On Accuser's Race
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 21  Robert S. Calvert, the state's 81yearold Comtroller of Pub lic Accounts, has turned allega tions of racism and sexism in his office into an overnight cause clbre by referring to his accuser as a nigger wo man.

title: Glenn Strange, Actor, Dies; Was Gunsmoke Bartender
description: LOS ANGELES. Sent. 21 (AP) Glenn Strange, who portrayed Dr. Frankenstein's monster in films and Sam Noonan, the big, leathery bartender in the tele vision series Gunsmoke for 11 years, died last night of cancer at a hospital here, He was 74 years old.

title: Art: Worthy Variety of Local Debuts
description: It is often said that so Called new talenttalent new to the New York exhibi tion scenesuffers formida ble, if not insurmountable, barriers when it comes to ex hibiting in the established uptown galleries, and the claim, is undoubtedly true in a great many cases. Yet this week's roster of exhibitions is remarkable for artists who are making their New York debuts.

title: Hope for Dodgers ...
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 21The last chance to revive, a pennant race in National League West was afforded the Los Angeles Dodgers as they opened a threegame series with the Cincinnati Reds tonight. The Dodgers had to win all three to make the challenge believable, and their chances were improved by the fact that Johnny Bench of the Reds would be suspended for the first two games.

title: A SOVIET DISSIDENT SAID TO BE MOVED
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 21 (AP)  Friends of Pyotr G. Grigoren ko, a dissident and a former general, say he has been re leased from a psychiatric pri son, but officials at the hos pital where he was reported to be transferred said they had no patient of that name.

title: Basketball Transactions NATIONAL ASSOCIATION
description: PHILADELPHIAObtained Bill Hewitt, for ward, from Buffalo on waivers.

title: Conformity Backfires for a Commune
description: GREERS FERRY, Ark., Sept. 20 There is a commune here that went straight and, thereby went wrong.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CONTINENTAL The con tinent is the big one, Asia, and the Asian Moon Festival, which started out to become a tradition last year, returns late today, 5:45 to 11 P.M., to Central Park's. Wollman Memorial Rink, near 64th Street and the Zoo. (If it rains, try tomorrow.)

title: WORLD RESERVE OF GRAIN IS URGED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  An international conference of economists proposed today creation of a world grain re serve to guard against periodic shortages and help stabilize prices.

title: News Summary and Index SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 22, 1973
description: International

title: Phils Lose to Cards, 123; Ozark Kept as Manager
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21 (UPI) Joe Torre belted threerun homer and Rick Wise posted his first victory since Aug. 5 tonight as the St. Louis Cardinals defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 123.

title: Volvo Forms Unit in U.S. To Market Marine Products
description: Volvo, the Swedish car man ufacturer, announced yesterday that it had formed a company in the United States to market and service marine products of Volvo Penta, one of the world's leading marine engine manu facturers.

title: U.S. the Text for Student With a Major in Racing
description: After a fourmonth observa tion of thoroughbred racing in this country, 23yearold Dean Latimer will return to his native city of Bulawayo in Rhodesia most impressed with just about everything he has seen, he said yester day while watching the races from the steward' stand at Belmont Park. What I find most interesting about your rac ing is your high purse structure, said Latimer, a university graduate who has studied the industry at Newmarket, England, and finished a course yesterday at the Jockey Club School here.

title: Tennessee Meets Army Today
description: When Tom Cahill was the plebe (freshman) football coach at West Point, the Army assigned young lieutenants to assist him. They were either former foot ball players just out of college with an R.O.T.C. commission or newly commis sioned West Point graduates.

title: Basketball's Back, Knicks Meet Suns
description: Only four months since thp Knicks won the National. Basketball Association cham Piohship from the Los An geles Lakers in a fivegame series, professional basket ball returns to New York to night with a preseason doubleheader at Madison Square Garden.

title: Nyquist Accused by Clark, Of Capitulating to Racism
description: ALBANY, Sept. 21Dr. Ken neth B. Clark, shattering the usual calm of a State Board of Regents meeting, today publicly attacked the State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyqu quist, for what he charged was capitulating to racism by failing to compel New York City to desegregate schools in Canarsie and elsewhere.

title: U.S. Ties British in Golf, 88
description: MUIRFIELD, Scotland, Sept. 21Although a substi tute played a dramatic role a0 scored a holeinone to day for the Ryder Cup team Of Britain, the United States squad drew even in the series. The twoday standing in the competition for professional golfers was 88.

title: JIM CROCE, SINGER, AND 5 ARE KILLED
description: NATCHITOCHES, La., Sept. 21 (AP) Jim Croce, the rock singer whose recent record Bad, Bad Leroy Brown sold a million copies, was killed last night with five other people when their chartered airplane crashed on takeoff from the airport here.

title: Market Place: Dacade Eventful For Texasgulf
description: It happened nearly a dec ade ago. A prosaic sulphur company, which had been ex ploring for ore near Timmins, Ontario, suddenly tapped one of the most extensive copper fields to be discovered in modern times.

title: Mary Gordon Thompson, Women's Labor Leader
description: STAFFORD SPRINGS, Conn., Sept. 21 (AP)Mary Gordon Thompson, a former president of the Boston Women's Trade League, died in a hospital here Wednesday. She was 88 years old.

title: Strike Could Close City Opera In 2 Days, Beverly Sills Warns
description: Beverly Sills, leading soprano with the New York City Opera, warned yesterday that if a mu sicians' strike was not settled within 48 hours, there would he no more performances this fall or next spring.

title: Woman's Fiance Held in Death Of Her 2YearOld Son Here
description: A 25yearold man accused of causing the death of the 2 yearold son of his financee was held without bail yester day in Criminal Court pending a hearing Oct. 25.

title: AUGUST INCREASE IN PRICE OF FOOD BIGGEST SINCE '46
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 Food prices recorded their big gest increase for a single month in 27 years in August and con sumer prices as a whole made their biggest onemonth rise in 26 years, the Government re ported today.

title: The Enormous Unknown
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y.It is startling paradox that the United States, which has traditionally favored free trade, business competition and opposed monopolies or cartels, should now be the administrative seat for most of the world's largest corpora tions including those multinational monsters which dominate the eco nomic scene.

title: Brain Pacemaker Is Helping Some With Handicaps
description: Driven by a devotion to treating presumably hopeless patients, a New York brain surgeon has developed an other in a series of tech niques to reverse the inca pacitating symptoms of se vere neurological disorders.

title: Rauscher Pierce Plans First of Texas Merger
description: The Rauscher Pierce Secu rities Corporation and First of Texas, Inc., both member firms of the New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday they have, agreed in, principle to merge. The merger is ex pected to be completed in early October with Rauscher Pierce as the surviving firm,

title: Gimbel Brothers in Red Again As Sales Rise Only Nominally
description: Gimbel Brothers, Inc., which operates a nationwide chain of department stores, continued to operate in the red in the second fiscal quarter ended July 31, according to the semiannual report issued yes terday. Sales were up for both periods but only nominally.

title: U.S. Leaves Thai Base As Withdrawal Goes On
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 21 (Reuters)  The Ameri can flag was lowered at the Nam Phong Airbase in north eastern Thailand today in a ceremony to mark its official closing to United States forces.

title: A Town Where Bringing Lunch to School Is a Punishable Offense
description: CEDAR GROVE, N. J.If a young child eats a brownbag lunch in school instead of walking home for one of mother's meals, is there something slight ly immoral about that?

title: PRICES ROSE HERE 1.9% IN ONE MONTH
description: The largest single monthly increase in consumer prices in the metropolitan area in 25 years1.9 per centwas re ported for August by the re gional office of the Federal Bu reau of Labor Statistics yester day.

title: Auction: 600 Folk Pieces in Catskills
description: ELLENVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 21Folk art collectors and dealers from many states converged this week on this Catskill Mountain communi ty. They came to judge for themselves just how impor tant the welladvertised wares auctioned yesterday and those up for sale today really are.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: Licavoli, Gangster, Dies at 69; Ordered Capone Out of Detroit
description: DETROIT, Sept. 21 (UPI) Thomas (Yonnie) Licavoli, the ganster who once ordered Al Capone to keep out of Detroit, died Sunday in Columbus, Ohio, at the age of 69.

title: Leaders in Senate Acclaim Mrs. King
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI)Senator Hugh Scott, Republican of Pennsylvania, said today that through her defeat of Bobby Riggs, in tennis, Mrs. Billie Jean King ratified the 26th Amend ment.

title: Cambodian Convoy of 16 Boats Reaches a LongIsolated Town
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sept. 21 (AP)  Government marines, taking advantage of the Mekong River's high water, moved a 16boat convoy today to the longisolated provincial capital of Prey Veng, the mili tary command said.

title: Mrs. Cushing Wins MatchPlay Title
description: JERICHO, L.I., Sept. 21 Mrs. Justine Cushing, after establishing an early lead, coasted to a 5and4 victory over Mrs. Vincent Larkin of Nassau today in the Wom en's Long Island matchplay championship final at Mea dow Brook Club.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Democrats' Dilemma ...
description: Whatever substance there may be in the speculation that Vice President Agnew may soon resign, Democratic leaders in Congress and out are preparing positions for that contingency. On the face of it, the 25th Amend ment seems plain as to the mechanics: President Nixon would appoint a new Vioe President, subject to approval by a majority in each house of Congress. But the usual gap between simple theory and complex reality is widen ing by the day.

title: Reporter Allowed To Reveal Sources Of Data on Chotiner
description: PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 21  Federal District Judge Ed ward T. Gignoux ruled here today that a New Hampshire newspaper reporter might dis close to Watergate investiga tors his sources for an article linking a former Presidential aide, Murray Chotiner, to acts of political espionage, includ ing the Watergate breakin.

title: OLIN IS SET TO SELL ALUMINUM UNIT
description: The Olin Corporation signed an agreement yesterday for the sale of its domestic aluminum business to the Consolidated Aluminum Corporation (Con alto) for $126million in cash. The price is subject to certain yearend balance sheet adjust ments and to other conditions. Otherwise, the transaction is expected to be closed on Jan. 3. Conalco, which is 60 per centowned by Swiss Alumin ium, Ltd., of Zur ich, Switzerland, and 40 per cent by the Phelps Dodge Cor poration here is incorporated in the United States and is based in St. Louis.

title: PRINCETON IS FINE, MISS MARCOS SAYS
description: PRINCETON, Sept. 21Like many freshmen at Princeton University, Maria Imelda Mar cos is distrustful of the univer sity food, unsure of the campus geography and slightly baffled by the variety of possible aca demic, and extracurricular pur suits.

title: Lottery Number
description: (A Correction)

title: Cassia Shoots a 69, Wins State P.G.A.
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 21 (AP)Jimmy Cassia fired a threeunderpar 69 to defeat the defending cham pion, Jimmy Wright of In wood, L. I., by one stroke and win the New York State Professional Golfers Associa tion championship.

title: L.I.'s 1950's Flea Market Is the Selling of Nostalgia
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Sept. 21 David Dorfman, who is 16 years old, was nostalgic.

title: Landslide Victory Predicted for Peron Tomorrow
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 21 Political aides of former dic tator Juan D. Pern predicted, today, as Argentina's presi dential campaign ended, that he would win the election on Sunday with more than 60 per cent of the votes.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: High School Notes
description: With the opening of the new school year has come an expansion of the idea that young people can learn in places besides classrooms.

title: PRICES ROSE HERE 1.9% IN ONE MONTH
description: The largest single monthly increase in consumer prices in the metropolitan area in 25 years1.9 per centwas re ported for August by the re gional office of the Federal Bu reau of Labor Statistics yester day.

title: Brain Pacemaker Is Helping Some With Handicaps
description: Driven by a devotion to treating, presumably hopeless patients, a New York brain surgeon has developed an other in a series of tech niques to reverse the inca pacitating symptoms of se vere neurological disorders.

title: Mets Take First Place
description: The Mets, who were in last place Aug. 30, climbed to the top of the National League's Eastern Division last night as Tom Seaver de feated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 102. Details on Page 21.

title: Governor Counters Statements By Levitt on State Bond Status
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Sept. 21  Governor Rockefeller moved today to protect his bond flank, as one of his aides put it, from possible attacks by State Controller Arthur Levitt.

title: 20 Hurt at Yellowstone
description: YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK, Wyo., Sept. 21 (UPI) A doubledecked tour bus over turned here yesterday, result ing in injuries to 20 of the 35 elderly persons aboard.

title: Wallet Containing $935 Is Lost, Then Returned
description: A waiter aboard the Leon ardo da Vinci lost $935 while on shore leave here yester day, but he got it back as the liner was preparing to re turn to Naples.

title: COTTON FUTURES RISE LIMIT AGAIN
description: Nearby delivery cottonthe October contractjumped to 95 cents a pound yesterday, up the 2centapound daily limit and the highest price in the 103year history of the New York Cotton, Exchange. Thus, cotton has not been so high priced since the Civil War era.

title: NIXON AND AGNEW HOLD SECRET TALK FOR SECOND TIME
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21  President Nixon and Vice Presi dent Agnew met alone for more than an hour yesterday, height ening rumors and reports that an Agnew resignation was un der consideration.

title: Expos Drop Fifth in Row As Cubs Triumph, 3 to 1
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 21 (UPI) Bob Locker retired three Montreal batters in order with the tying run on third base in the eighth inning to day to save a 31 triumph for the Chicago Cubs, who handed the Expos their fifth straight defeat.

title: KNIGHT CHAIN BUYS 3 PAPERS IN SOUTH
description: MIAMI, Sept. 21 (AP)  Knight Newspapers, Inc., an nounced today it had reached agreement to purchase The Co lumbus (Ga.) Ledger, The Co lumbus Enquirer and The Bra denton (Fla.) Herald.

title: FASHION TALK
description: No doubt some women will be unsettled by the new lais sezfaire direction of fash ion. No hassling over hem lines. No insistence on slim skirts over the wide ones, high waistlines over low ones or, in fact, the necessity of marking the waistline at all. Pants or dresses? You take your choice.

title: Bridge: In Which a Defender Leads Ace Not of Partner's Suit
description: SOUTH FALLSBURG, N.Y., Sept. 21  A player who selects the ace of his part ner's suit as the opening lead has usually made a sensible move. But other considerations may come into play when the deal is freakish. On the diagramed example, both North and West had to lead the less obvious ace for best results.

title: Hiller Sets Save Mark
description: DETROIT, Sept. 21 (UPI) John Hiller, a lefthander who wasn't sure if he'd ever pitch again after suffering a heart attack two years ago, set a major league reoord for saves in a season tonight when he posted his 38th for the De troit Tigers in a 51 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

title: Some Readers Take Mr. Goldwater to Task, and...
description: Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, wrote three articles for the OpEd Page of The Times in which he as sessed the effects of Watergate on the na tion and on his party. Senator Goldwater called for a complete clearing of the air, and said that a new sense of conservatism was needed in the highest councils of government. He also speculated on who might lead the country out of its malaise. Readers responded strongly to the article.

title: Debt Payments Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21, (AP)  Representative Jim Wright, Democrat of Texas, said today he would offer an amendment requiring that an nual payments be made on the $460billion national debt. A similiar measure offered by Mrs. Wright in 1959 was de feated.

title: Cahill, Citing Uselessness, Cancels Sussman Meeting
description: TRENTON, Sept. 21 The heat in state institutional kitchens caused by Dr. Oscar Sussman's sanitation inspec tions apparently became too much for Governor Cahill today. The Governor canceled the meeting at which he was ex pected to reprimand Dr.. Sussman, the state's consumer health director.

title: Business Briefs
description: Seat on Big Board Is Sold by Jefferies

title: POLICEMAN DENIES LEADING BREAKINS
description: ALBANY, Sept. 21A police lieutenant identified by three other police witnesses as the man who led them in breaking into stores and looting parking meters testified today that he had absolutely not beeti pres ent during any such crimes.

title: National League
description: Saturday, September 22, 1973

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:

title: TERRY LEAVING POST AT JACOB'S PILLOW
description: Walter Terry, who has served since February as director of the Jacob's Pillow Dance. Festi val in Lee, Mass., has submitted his resignation to the board of directors of the 40yearold in stitution founded by the late Ted Shawn.

title: Notes on People
description: For Senator John V, Tun ney, yesterday was the be ginning of two weeks of lean days.

title: Biaggi Calls for Rebuilding of Police Force
description: A Police Department that has suffered a ruthless purge must be rebuilt, Repreientative Mario, Biaggi said yesterday, as part of an overall effort to rescue the city from dispirited state of limbo.

title: Shifting Cost of Pollution Control
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21I wouldn't want to seem casual or cavalier about $13billion, John Busterud of the Council on Environmental Quality re marked the other day, but it really doesn't represent a sig nificant difference.

title: Nixon Estate Is Called Underassessed
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., Sept. 21 (UPI)The assessment on) President Nixon's Western Nhite House in San Clemente ??s nearly $1million under what ??t should be, according to an grange County supervisor.

title: Turkish Accident Kills 23
description: ISPARTA, Turkey, Sept. 21 (AP)  Twentythree personsi were killed and four seriously injured today when an open truck careened off the highway an doverturned near this south central Turkish town.

title: Bonnto Seek National Policy on Radical in Office
description: BONN, Sept. 21The West German Government will pro pose a law codifying one of the most touchy subjects in current West German politics a 1972 ruling by the ten state governors that radicals should not ordinarily be al lowed to hold official posi tions.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on conference report on bill extending the Council on International Economic Policy for two years, which passed, 49 to 43, Sept. 20.

title: S.M.U. Conquers Ore. State, 3546
description: CORVALLIS, Ore. Sept. 22 (UPI)Keith Bobo, the quar terback, and a freshman, Ricky Wesson, led Southern Methodist to a 3516 victory over Oregon State today. An dy Duvall, a defensive back, and a defensive end, Clarence Dennard, ran back intercep tions of 49 and 11 yards for touchdowns.

title: Orioles Win And Clinch Title in East
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept, 22 (AP) Al Bumbry tied a major league record with three tri ples today in pacing the Bal timore Orioles to a 71 vic tory over the Milwaukee Brewers that clinched the American League East Divi sion championship.

title: URGENT AID ASKED FOR CORAL REEFS
description: KEY LARGO, Fla., Sept. 22 The state's coral reef forma tions are in danger of extinc tion, according to marine biol ogists. Citing damage inflicted by water pollution, boat an chors, souvenir hunters and de velopers, scientists stress that urgent measures must be taken if the coral reefs are to survive.

title: Crime Not Only Pays, But It's Funny, Too.
description: WHILE television thrives on un importance, some of it less trivial than the rest, movie goers have become increas ingly stern about the unimportant film, not the bad film but the good, entertain ing for aslongasittakestowatch movie that, afterwards, disappears from the memory with the completeness of rain sinking into a desert. I'm not talk ing about unimportant schlocky movies, some of which, like Cleopatra Jones, achieve financial rewards by meeting some contemporary needs or by being a part of some particular fashion.

title: He is the American Optimist
description: Ordinary people brood over their failings and try to correct them; talent puts its failings to work. John Cage is not a power ful logician or rigorous thinker in the linear sense, but that has not kept him from being widely regarded, at age 60, as the most disturbingly original musical mind (if not the best com poser) that America has pro duced since Charles Ives. Rec ognizing his, limitations, per haps, he long ago rejected the rationalist tradition of art and the artist out of which Bach and Beethoven arose, putting his faith instead in the great god Chancedice, I Ching, Ti betan prayer wheels, anything that allows his philosophically elusive mind to go its own free way. Significantly, however, he also believes in the efficacy of the perfect machine, which is the opposite side of the coin to chance. Computers are the new prayer wheels of Cage's and our own touching faith in prac tical science.

title: U.S. Scholar Calls Soviet an Unreliable Partner
description: A leading political scientist and historian says that the So viet Union is bound to be an unreliable partner in East West accommodation and co operation.

title: Summers Dancers Joined by Audience In Museum Garden
description: It was so quiet and still in the Sculpture Garden of the Museum of Modern Art that it was difficult to believe that the Friday night dance concert had begun. Bue Energy Changes by the Elaine Sum mers Company started slowly and worked up to a clangorous frenzy.

title: WALL STREET
description: Paul E. Erdman, an expert on world currency markets, a former hanker in Switzer land and now a bestselling novelist, has investment ideas for Americans that run some what counter to the prevail ing wisdom on Wall Street.

title: Bridge
description: Any time a suit bid is given an artificial meaning the deal may be played up sidedown, with the trump length in the dummy. This is seldom material if the artifi cial bid is in a minor suit, as most of them are, since most contracts are played in major suits or notrump. But players who extend their artificialities to the major suits not in frequently find themselves playing upside down, some times with profit, sometimes with loss.

title: Season Opens in Essex for EarlyFilm Buffs
description: NUTLEYFrom now un til June, about 40 movie buffs will be sampling their favorite silent and early talkie fare in a little back yard theater that once served as a fruitjelly fac tory.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  Tens of thousands of stockholders all over the nation have been receiving, along with their dividend checks, a little pink and white leaflet with a frightening message.

title: SmallTown Weeklies of All Kinds Thriving
description: NEW BRUNSWICK Most people these days, particular ly city dwellers, probably think smalltown weekly newspapers are a ghost of the past and about as out moded as the buggywhip industry.

title: Bible Society Starts Program To Increase Literacy Overseas
description: A 12year, $63million fund raising project to help the world's newly literate people read better was announced yesterday by the American Bible Society.

title: Why Congress won't fight
description: WASHINGTON.

title: GLENN CRITICIZES OHIO DEMOCRATS
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 22 John H. Glenn, the former astronaut, shattered the har mony of Ohio Democrats this week by accusing party leaders of bossism and blackmail in attempting to arrange a United States Senate endorse ment for his archrival, Howard M. Metzenbaum, a Cleveland millionaire.

title: ROBERT S. HART MAN, TAUGHT PHILOSOPHY
description: Dr. Robert S. Hartman, re search professor of philosophy at the National University of Mexico and the University of Tennessee, died Friday in Mex ico City. He was 63 years old and lived in Cuernavaca, Mexico.

title: COMMON MARRET SEES MORE UNITY
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 22Euro pean Common Market officials are voicing cautious optimism that the market can move into a new stage of development in the next three months, going beyond its original achieve ments of a unified farm policy and elimination of tariff bar riers.

title: Diugrandess, 19 by 19
description: ACROSS

title: Arthur Daley
description: Not long ago Joe Pignatano, the Met coach, conversed briefly with someone behind the dugout and then spoke to Willie Mays.

title: Taking over from Lenin
description: We have had Trotsky's Stalin his portrait of the rude, ruthless, conspiratorial Georgian who won the struggle for Lenin's succession. We have had Stalin's Stalinthe homog enized selfportrait of the famous Short Course in the History of the Communist Party. We have Khrush chev's Stalin of the Secret Speech the boldstroke revelation of a para nold bullying tyrant. We have Svet lana Alliuyeva's horror over a father who winds up devouring his country, his family, all that is near and dear to him. We have Isaac Deutscher's classic studythe sage, ironic re construction of the Revolution be trayed and its betrayer.

title: WILLIAM E. M'GINNITY
description: William E. McGinnity, who retired several years age, as vice president in charge of op erations and maintenance for the Brown Harris Stevens Inc., real estate company, died yes terday in Meadowbrook (L.I.) Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Baldwin, L.I.

title: StrikeOut Fever Hits Mrs. Nolan Ryan
description: I've been watching Nolan pitch ever since I was 10 and he was playing for the Little League in Alvin, Tex., said Mrs. Ruth Ryan. But until now I didn't know what ex citement really was.

title: A Lot Preceded the Ms.Match
description: It was far, and a far cry, from Wim bledon. There was a marching band and costumed entertainers, banners and Tshirts and buttons and celebri ties in evening clothes sipping cham pagne in $100 courtside seats. Billie Jean King was carried in on a royal litter borne by five young men in togas. Bobby Riggs arrived in a rick shaw with golden wheels, propelled by five models straight out of a male chauvinist's erotic fantasy. The tele vision production suggested an unholy marriage between Miss America and the Rose Bowl Parade, and a tuxedoed Howard Cosell described the proceed ings as if it were a prizefight. The camera angle? It could have been worse: The camera might have been aimed at the ceiling.

title: Miss Kelly Bride of Dr. Dennis Huskins
description: Miss Elizabeth Jane Kelly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward G. Kelly of Tenafly, N. J., was married here yes terday afternoon to Dr. Den nis George Huskins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Huskins of Hempstead, L. I. The cere mony was performed by the Rev. David B. Maxwell in the Pauline Hartford Memorial Chapel at the ColumbiaPres byterian Medical Center.

title: Carrier Saratoga Damaged By Blaze at Norfolk Dock
description: NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 22 (AP)A fire broke out on the aircraft carrier Saratoga to night, possibly resulting in major damage to a section of the ship, Navy officials said.

title: Nolde: Redeemed by His Art
description: FRENCH Impressionism, so the German Expres sionist Emil Nolde claimed, did not ap peal to his harsher Northern senses. The disavowal was appropriate. Although Nolde resorted to Impressionist techniques in his early land scapes and figure paintings, the relaxed sunny art of the French Impressionistswith its predominantly pleasure loving, bourgeois lifeview did not particularly coincide with the highly expressive purposes of his own art.

title: Miss Lorraine Besch Is Wed To Ens. Paul B. Sanwick Jr.
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., Sept. 22  In Christ Episcopal Church here this afternoon, kiss Lorraine Wrightson Besch and Ens. Paul Bain bridge Sanwick Jr., U.S.N.R:, graduates of the University b! Colorado, were married by the Rev. George W. R. Mac Cray.

title: Elliott Roosevelt Planning To Come Back Next Month
description: LISBON, Sept. 22 (UPI) Elliott Roosevelt, son of Presi dent Franklin D. Roosevelt, said today that he would probably return to the United States the first week in October to face a Senate rackets investigation.

title: Waltz Me Around Again, Anouilh
description: IF you have never seen Jean. Anouilh's The Waltz of the Toreadors, I am quite sure you will be delighted with the half of it a fine company is performing at Circle in the Square. I don't mean that they've clipped the text; all three acts are there, accounted for with brisk and beguiling energy. It's just that actor's and director have given Most of their talented attention to the surface slyness and spryness of the farce, leaving very little over for the canker that keeps eating its heart out.

title: A Job Without Pay, And Many Want It
description: Whenever a vacancy occurs on the board of trustees of the Brooklyn or the Queens library systems, there are at least 20 applicants for the job. Yet the position pays nothing, brings little pub licity and is of very little use in advancing professional careers. In fact, most trus tees dip into their own pock ets periodically to do their jobs properly.

title: HIGHLIGHTS: OF THE WEEK
description: I.B.M. WAS FOUND GUILTY of having violated the Sherman Antitrust Act and was ordered to pay Telex, a computer equipment manufacturer, triple damages amount ing to $352.5million. I.B.M. says it will appeal.... The nation's deficit in the balance of international payments was $782million in the second quarter, narrowed from $947million in the first quarter and sharply less than the average quarterly deficit of $2.5 billion during 1972.

title: Oyster Bay To Control Oil Storage Facilities
description: OYSTER BAY, L.I.  The Oyster Bay Town Board recently adopted an ordiance giving the Division of En vironmental Control regula tory powers over oil storage facilities in the town in an effort to prevent oil spills from damaging land and waterways.

title: Mother Gets Children Out of Hungary
description: A 39yearold New Jersey woman returned to the United States with her two children last night after spiriting the youngsters out of Hungary where they had been taken by her former husband.

title: Chess: A Giant Upset Is Brewing As Grefe Is Good in El Paso
description: One of the biggest upsets in American chess is in the making. John Grefe, a young California master, is showing his heels to a 12man field, including five grandmasters, in the United States Chess Championship going on in El Paso.

title: Headliners
description: Sweet Music

title: Divide and Conquer the Overgrown Perennials
description: FALL is the best time to lift, separate, and re plant overgrown hardy perennials. By Septem ber, most kinds, even August bloomers, like phlox and day lilies, have finished flowering,

title: It Takes a Snob to Know One
description: PARIS  What does snob bishness mean to you? How are you (or are you not) a snob? Give the best example of snobbishness you know. Who else should answer these questions? Who should definitely not answer them?

title: Pumpkins Ripen Too Early
description: NEW SHREWSBURYThe pumpkins have lost their leaves and the children may lose their pumpkins for Hal loween.

title: AGNEW SETTING UP FUND FOR DEFENSE IF HE IS INDICTED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 Vice President Agnew is estab lishing a legal defense fund in his own behalf for use in the event that he is indicted in con ection with kickbacks he al legedly received from Maryland businessmen, an Agnew aide said today.

title: Mailbox: TV Football Blackout, Boxing and Bingo
description: TO THE EDITOR: Arthur Daley was right on target when he pointed out in his column about the lift ing of the TV football black outs being a violation of the rights of the club owners never thought I would see the day that I personally would shed a tear of sym pathy for the lords of profes sional football or basebal.

title: 27 PRIMARIES SET FOR CONNECTICUT
description: HARTFORD, Sept 22Demo crats in 27 towns in Connecti cut are holding primary elec tions on Tuesday with scarcely a thought about mending the splits in the state organization or filling the yawning vacuum at the top of it.

title: Sloan Sets Mark As Temple Wins
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 (UPI)Tom Sloan set a Tem ple singlegame rushing rec ord tonight and the Owls amassed their highest game yardage total ever in defeat ing Akron, 4733.

title: My Dog's Trip to Europe Has Been a Howling Success
description: MY dog Canardhalf collie, half shepherd, female, 7 years old is having a great time in Eu rope. And her reception, you could say, has been a glittering one. As people pass her on the street, faces light up, hands reach out and there are jovial calls from the mouths of TVwatching Europeans of Lassie! Las sie! One day in Vienna, I counted no fewer than 30 men, women and chil dren who petted my dog, talked to her, fed her and/or gave me advice about her upbringing.

title: Catholic Schools Getting Judaica
description: A collection of 20 books on Jewish religion and cul ture will be presented to a Brooklyn Roman Catholic school by an Orthodox rabbi on behalf of a CatholicJew ish ecumenical group in a formal assembly at the school this week.

title: Brick Township Kick Wins
description: Brick Township, regarded as New Jersey's best school football team in 1972, barely managed to increase its un beaten streak to 22 yester day with a 76 victory over Matawan in Matawan.

title: Haughton Pays $45,000 for Colt
description: YONKERS, Sept. 22Wil liam Haughton, noted train o erdriver, purchased the two highest priced youngsters at the Old Glory select yearling sale today at Yonkers Race way.

title: New & Novel
description: The short story is alive and well in Canada, where most of these 15 tales originate like fresh winds from the North. Alice Munro (Lives of Girls and Women) creates a solid habitat for her fiction south western Ontario, a generation or more in the pastand is in sympathetic vibration with the farmers and townspeople who live there.

title: Football Transactions
description: NATIONAL CONFERENCE

title: Getting the clues
description: ACROSS

title: Skylab Descending
description: HOUSTONAfter a recordbreaking 59 days in orbit, logging more than 24 million miles, the Skylab 2 astro nauts are to leave their space station this Tuesday and return to earth. It will be an anxious moment at the end of a mission of quiet accomplishment, for there are two key questions con cerning the return of this crew: How reliable is the Apollo spacecraft, the somewhat disabled ferry vehicle? How will the astronauts readjust to earth's gravity after being in weightlessness twice as long as any man before?

title: Peter Lincoln Folsom Marries Joan Morgan
description: NORTHPORT, L. I., Sept. 22  The marriage of Miss Joan Morgan to Peter Lincoln Folsom took place here this afternoon at the Eaton's Neck home of Mr. and Mrs. Henry S. Morgan, grandpar ents of the bride. The Rev. Howard M. Lowell of St. John's of Lattingtown Epis copal Church performed the ceremony.

title: How Mets Did It: Healthy Arms
description: They stood last on July 8, a dozen games out for first place in the mad world known as the National League's Eastern Division last in the pack and last in the hearts of their country men, who were still feverish over the revival of the Yankees.

title: The Nation
description: DETROIT  Last week's strike by the United Automobile Workers against the Chrysler Corporation was remarkable enough just because was apparently the shortest produc tion workers walkout in U.A.W. his tory. But the settlement produced by the strike may be more remarkable still. The terms of the agreement reached last Monday, less than three days after the strike began, were described as precedentsetting, a breakthrough and a milestone.

title: Passaic Weighs Rent Control
