description: PASSAIC  Landlords and tenants took turns last week assailing a rentcontrol meas ure proposed by the City Council that would exempt twofamily houses.

title: Susan Handy, Designer, Wed
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Sept. 22 Miss Susan Parker Handy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Parker Douglas Handy, was married here this after noon to James Campbell Stover, son of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Stover of Princeton, N. J., by the Rev. Stanley Lyon Houston in the Green field Hill Congregational Church.

title: Lincoln Stops Mason and Brooklyn Tech, 128
description: Lincoln, with a young squad, stopped George Mas on, the heralded senior yesterday and upset Brook lyn Tech, 128, in a Public Schools Athletic League Brooklyn Division I game at Lincoln Field. John Harris, a Lincoln sophomore, scored both touchdowns.

title: Composer With Patience
description: When Ted Harris, a com poser, received a letter from the New York Bicentennial Corporation last month stat ing it was interested in the opera that he had col laborated on with the late American poet William Car los Williams, he was not overly excited. At 60 years of age, he is an energetic man with sparkling eyes and long gray hair, who has received many letters of encourage ment but few commitments.

title: What's Doing in THE SMOKIES
description: By WARNER OGDENBEARWATCHING  The eumber one attraction in the 800square mile Great Smoky Mountains Na tional Park (half in Tennessee, half in North Carolina) is its 300 or so waddling black bearsthough they will, of course, have a strong rival next month when the fall colors blaze. In summer, the bears cause bearjams on park roads; in fall, they panhandle less but can still be seen, particularly from the transmountain road (U.S. 441), which winds across the park, and Clingmans Dome Road. Be warned, though, that while the bears have lost their fear of man because of their protected status, they're still dangerous. Visitors, are advised not to feed them and to close car windows when bears approach. You can be fined $25 for handing them food. Recently, an Ohio boy was slashed by a bear when his father held up some candy to en courage a bear to stand. And not long ago a bear sniffing around for food roughed up the kitchen of a park ranger's homeeven leaving a faucet turned on.

title: New and Recommended
description: THE HONORARY CONSUL, by Graham Greene. (Simon & Schuster, $7.95.) A comedy, in Greene's later mode, that deals with death, revo lution, God's darker side and a drunken British consul in Argentina.

title: Raytheon Gets Contract
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP)The Raytheon Company of Bedford, Mass., has received a $21.9million contract from the Army for development of a portion of a ballistic missile system, Representative Paul Cronin, Republican of Massa chusetts, said this week.

title: Walter Squires Have Son
description: A son was born Sept. 10 to Mr. and Mrs. Walter C. Squire at the Columbia Pres byterian Medical Center. The child has been named Harri son Daniel. Mrs. Squire, the former Miss Gail Wilder of New Haven, is a fourthyear student at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University. Her husband is a lawyer with Carter, Ledyard & Milburn.

title: the traveler's world
description: THIS is the second installment of our inquiry begun last week into the hotel guestinnkeeper re lationship based on the recently published textbook The Laws of Inn keepers by Prof. John H. Sherry (Cor nell University Press), and we come now to the question of who is a guest and must he sign the hotel register. While the hotelier may refuse known criminals, persons of ill repute and known bad morals, and those whose dress, uncleanliness and comportment indicate they might bring a bad repu tation to his establishment and discom fort to his guests, the law compels him to accept all others he has rooms for, and to care for them properly.

title: Country Music: A Basic Discography
Susan Schmid, an Economist, Is Bride of Robert J. Mullaney
description: The marriage of Miss Susan R. Schmid, daughter of Mrs. Frances Schmid of Flushing, Queens, to Robert J. Mullaney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Mullaney of Flushing and Sag Harbor, L. I., took place in Brooklyn yesterday morning.

title: Piscataway Says Thanks to Elmer
description: PISCATAWAY  Edward Elmer Trotman retired re cently after 21 years as an employe of the Piscataway Board of Education. He was feted at a testimonial dinner by members of the board, teachers, administrators, sec retaries and janitors.

title: Cubs Score In 10th, 52, Stay 2 Out
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 (UPI)Jose Cardenal tripled home two runs in the 10th inning and scored on a throwing error as the Chi cago Cubs took a 52 decision from the Philadelphia Phil lies tonight.

title: Keelyn Mulvey, Peter Brown Jr. Married in Rye
description: RYE, N. Y., Sept. 22 Miss Keelyn McKeever Mul vey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen W. Mulvey of Harrison, was married here this morning to Peter Camp bell Brown Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Brown of Pelham Manor.

title: PACIFIC ISLANDERS GAINING NEW ROLE
description: TUMON BAY, Guam, Sept. 20  From the 18thcentury writings of James Cook, the British navigator, to the works of the American novelist James A. Michener, enraptured ac counts of the islands have identified the term South Pa cific with visions of the easy life on golden beaches shaded by swaying palm trees.

title: Banker Weds Nanette Char
description: WILTON, Conn., Sept. 22 In St. Matthew's Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Nanette Therese Char, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Char of Honolulu, was married to Butler Mac Lean Gander, son of Mr. and Mrs Lindley H. Gander of Wilton. The Rev. Kenneth Robinson performed the cer emony.

title: The Ranchers' and Housewives' Tug of War
description: The Federal ceilings on wholesale and retail beef prices have been lifted. Pack ing houses closed during the summer beef shortage have reopened and retailers are once again promoting wide choices of cuts over the counter.

title: Post 2816 Victor; Powers Stand Out
description: Ed Powers passed and ran C. W. Post to a 2816 victory over Wagner yesterday as the Pioneers opened defense of their Metropolitan Con ference crown on Staten Is land. Post has a 20 won lost record and Wagner has a 0.2 mark.

title: The Discreet Alarm of the Off Off Broadway Playwright
description: borrowing a hit from Luis Bunuel's The Discreet Charm of the Bour geoisie

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 22 (AP)A judge has or dered, a greyhound racetrack concessionaire to refund about $53,000 to the public because of overcharging. One result will be 5cent beer.

title: McKechnie to Quit P. C. L. Presidency
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 22 (AP)William McKechnie Jr. will leave his post as presi dent of the Pacific Coast Baseball League at the end of the year.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: THE Russians aren't coming. They are already here. Armand Hammer signed yet another contract with one of them at the WaldorfAstoria last week, while out in San Francisco, Aleksei N. Kosygin's soninlaw was signing with the Stanford Re search Institute.

title: Meadowlands Seeking Ways to Dispose of Garbage
description: RUTHERFORD  Hacken sack Meadowlands Develop ment Commission was study ing methods last week of coping with the flood of gar bage that continues to gobble up land that could be used for something better than a dump.

title: Monetary Fund Aide Is Con Victim in Kenya
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 22 (AP)William B. Dale, the International Monetary Fund's director from the United States, was bilked of $150 and his wallet today by two sidewalk con men here.

title: Margaret Vose Westport Bride
description: WESTPORT Conn., Sept. 22 Miss Margaret Vance Voss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Baldwin Vose, was married here this evening to Robert Francis Armao, son of Mrs. Michael Charles Armao of New York and the late Dr. Armao.

title: Suburbia Marches on the Poconos
description: LORDS VALLEY, Pa.The hills hereabouts are alive with the sounds of subdivisionhammers pounding, environmentalists gasping, bulldozers clanking, city folks writing out checks.

title: Recordings
description: THOMAS EDISON never intended it at all: The talking machine wasn't really meant to sing. Reproduction of music was only fourth on Edison's list of potential uses for his new device. (Tenth, incidentally, was connection with the tel ephone so as to make that instrument an auxiliary in the transmission of permanent and invaluable records, in stead of being the recipient of momentary and fleeting communications.)

title: Personalities without gossip
description: If the incomplete Memoirs of Waldo Frank were to be read only by those interested in the author's selfportrait, this book would probably suf fer the same fate that most of his other volumes have. For, as Lewis Mumford says in his excellent introduction, Today the name of Waldo Frank is almost unknown in his own country. The writer who half a century ago seemed to many of his contemporaries one of the most vital literary figures of his generation is now for gotten by all except students of our cultural past. Most Amer icans have eyes for the latest thing only.

title: A LandBound Voyage on the CarGoRail Across Canada
description: ROBERT YOUNG, the onetime chairman of a onetime railroad called the New York Central, once observed that it is possible for a pig to cross the U.S. without changing trains but not possible for human being. True. There wasn't then and there still isn't a through passenger train across, this country; the switch in Chicago remains part of the dis commodious lore of American railroad ing. Yet, as a growing number of Americans seem to be discoveringmy self very recently among themnot just one but two trains regularly span the continent north of the border in Can ada (now that a monthandahalflong series of rail stripes has ended), One runs on the Canadian National line, the other on the Canadian Pacific line, and both travel through some of the most dramatic and least trampled country in North America. Moreover, they provide some of the rare remain ing amenities to be found on long distance trainsand one of the lines, the Canadian National, offers an attrac tive contemporary amenitya package deal whereby it will carry your auto mobile from coast to coast for about $180 extra.

title: Sports Betting Advocates Regrouping in Legislatures
description: BOSTON  Unshaken by what they concede was a substantial opening set back, proponents of legalized sports betting are regrouping here for another try.

title: N. H. L. Set To Open on October 10
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 22 (Canadian Press)The Na tional Hockey League season will begin in seven cities Oct. 10, the latest start since the 196970.

title: U.S. Defeats Britain in Golf
description: MUIRFIELD, Scotland, Sept. 22  On this bleak afternoon under overcast skies, the United States professional golfers retained the Ryder Cup by defeating the squad from Britain. 19 to 13. The teams had started the day deadlocked 8 to 8.

title: Macmillan Tells of Kennedy Calls in '61 Cuba Crisis
description: LONDON, Sept. 22The unusually close relationship be tween President John F. Ken nedy and former Prime Minister Harold Macmillan emerges vividly in exerpts from tele phone conversations between the two leaders, as set down in the final volume of Mr. Macmillan's memoirs, published this week.

title: Citizens Budget Unit Names Clarence Michalis Trustee
description: The election of Clarence F. Michalis, administrative vice president of BristolMyers Com pany, as a trustee of the Citi zens Budget Commission, has been announced by William S. Renchard, chairman of the non partisan civic research organ ization.

title: MIGRANT DIVISION HELD INEFFECTIVE
description: Puerto Rico's Migration Di vision, set up in 1948 to aid adjustment of Puerto Ricans on the mainland, has deteriorated and become ineffectual in the last four or five years, ac cording to key leaders who have submitted their views to Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon.

title: LEON WASSERMAN
description: Leon Wasserman, a real estate broker who had taken part in many major sales in this city, died Wednesday, ap parently of a heart, attack, at his home, 15419 21st Avenue, Whitestone, Queens.

title: Parkway Repairs Set for This Week
description: WOODBRIDGE  Garden State Parkway expansion work in the vicinity of the Cheesequake service area will necessitate a onemile north bound traffic restriction for approximately 20 hours Tuesday and Wednesday. The northbound entrance to and exit from the Cheesequake service area will also be closed.

title: Nixon: No
description: WASHINGTONThe Court of Ap peals, with nothing to lose and a great deal to gain, had tried a long shot: To avoid a drastic collision between the judicial and executive branches of government, it had urged President Nixon and Special Prosecutor Archi bald Cox to find a way to resolve the Watergate tapes issue out of court.

title: N.B.C. and Technicians Reach Accord on Pact, Averting Strike
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP)The National Broadcast ing Company and its technical employes agreed on a new threeyear contract tonight, averting a strike.

title: Columbia Is Beaten In Football TuneUp
description: Williams downed Colum bia, 147, in a preseason foto ball game yesterday at Baker Field.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:

title: Miss Nancy Helen Goodrich Bride of Harold McGraw 3d
description: PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 22 Miss Nancy Helen Good rich and Harold W. McGraw 3d were married here this afternoon by the Rev. Ste phan Foote in St. Mary's Episcopal Church.

title: An Italian art
description: The Italians have a number of hearty vegetable stews in their cooking herit age that are good main dishes especially when meat and poultry prices are out of sight as they were this summer when a threepound chicken cost more than $4 in our local market at Cortona in southern Tus cany. These stews are easy to cook since they are all moreorless dishes, meaning it doesn't really matter if the cook uses a little less of this or more of that vegetable. For a complete meal, add bread and cheese, a salad, some wine. Dessert if you must.

title: At Nairobi, The I.M.F.'s Dutch Uncle
description: WASHINGTON  The In ternational Monetary Fund has gone through three phases in its existence of little more than a quarter of a century. H. (for Hendrikus) Johannes Witteveen, a slim, baldish, softspoken Dutch man, took over this month as managing director at what is clearly a major turning point for the Fund.

title: Diane Cooperman Fiancee of John Blank
description: Miss Diane Sue Cooperman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Cooperman of New York and Harrison, plans to be married next summer to John Bennett Blank, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Blank of Bridgeport.

title: In the Varieties of Trees, L. I. Is the Garden Spot of the State
description: The glacial afterthought known as Long Island har bors a greater number and greater variety of tree cham pions than all the rest of New York State.

title: Finelli Outstanding As Blair Triumphs
description: BLAIRSTOWN, N.J., Sept. 22Blair Academy used a nearperfect offense and a stiff defense to crush Admiral Farragut today, 410.

title: CITY WILL HONOR YESHIVA U. HEAD
description: Dr. Samuel Belkin, the Hel lenist, scholar and educator be ginning his 30th year as presi dent, of Yeshiva University, will be honored by the city next Tuesday. Mayor, Lindsay and 1,200 leaders in education, med icine, science and philanthropy will gather at Gracie Mansion in tribute to the 62yearold University head.

title: Getting Seesaw an DiskA Stormy Saga
description: THE saga of Seesaw did not end when the musical survived the turmoil of a tumultu ous preBroadway breakin, during which it was re written, restaged, rechoreo graphed and recast. It opened with so little money to spare that, for safety's sake, a closing notice was posted backstage as soon as the curtain rang down on its opening night, March 19. However, it survived its first week and the closing notice came down. By the end of the second week, the gross was actually $800 over the breakeven figure and things were looking up. But there was still one loose end to be taken care of: The cast re cording.

title: Schooner Is Queen for Day at Mystic
description: MYSTIC, Conn., Sept. 22 The schooner was queen here today.

title: Brezhnev Goes to Tashkent For Meetings on Agriculture
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 22 (UPI) Leonid I. Brezhnev, General Secretary of the Soviet Com munist party, met today in Tashkent with party leaders of the nation's cotton  growing republics, Tass, the official press agency, said.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time
description: Tomorrow, Sept. 24

title: LONG TRIALS SEEN ON WOUNDED KNEE
description: SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Sept. 22 (AP)  Litigation stemming from the occupation of Wounded Knee promises to last longer than that 71day siege. And, in the view of one defense attorney, the trials will constitute a major civil rights case for American Indians.

title: 2 SKYLAB CREWMEN TAKE BRIEF WALK
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 22Two of the Skylab astronauts, getting ready for their return to earth Tuesday, went out side their orbiting space sta tion today to retrieve film from a set of telescopes that have been observing the sun's turbulent atmosphere.

title: World News Briefs
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept 22  A South Korean Cabinet Minister and a proGovernment legislator assailed the Japanese press today for the way it re ported on the abduction of a Korean opposition politician from Tokyo to Seoul.

title: STRAUSS DISPUTES RIFT OVER REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 Robert S. Strauss, chairman of the Democratic National Com mittee, made a surprise appear ance today before his party's convention reform commission to lament the impression that divisive infighting might sink an agreement on new rules.

title: State is Acting on Mortgages
description: TRENTONThe Assembly Banking Committee has scheduled an open meeting on Nov. 8 to consider three proposals designed to ease the home mortgage market in New Jersey.

title: Beanie and Blumenthal Gain Backers
description: Assemblyman Albert H. Blu menthal picked up the support of two organizations, and Con troller Abraham D. Beame gained the endorsement of newspaper yesterday as all of the four mayoral candidates campaigned actively.

title: Brownsville Trailers Now Look Permanent
description: Two blocks south of Eastern Park way in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, an unusual and once con troversial city housing project that was designed to be temporary has be come an apparently permanent fixture amid rows of burnedout buildings.

title: Loomis Defeats Hopkins
description: WINDSOR, Conn., Sept. 22 Loomis scored two first half touchdowns today and then used a strong defense to defeat Hopkins Grammar, 1412. Bill Majewicz led the Loomis defense with three interceptions at his defensive halfback spot.

title: Erving Scores 32 as Nets Beat Squires, 116111
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 22 (AP)Julius Erving scored 32 points tonight, 14 in the final period, leading the New York Nets to a 116111 vic tory over the Virginia Squires in an American Basketball Association exhibition game.

title: Purchasing Power Drops For Workers in Factories
description: The purchasing power of an average factory production worker's salary in the New YorkNortheastern New Jersey area continued to decline dur ing July, as sharp increases in prices cut into earnings, the United Slates Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: British Chrysler Workers End Strike, Resume Talks
description: LONDON, Sept. 22 (AP) Striking workers at a Chrysler Motors plant in Britain agreed today to return to work for a week and to allow talks to re sume.

title: The Stones In the Soup
description: GOATS HEAD SOUP (Rolling Stones Rec ords COC 59101) is not the recipe for an Inexpensive cut of meat but the title of the Rolling Stones's latest album. After g summer of lean pickings in rock, Soup gets the au tumn off to a zesty start. This collection of Mick Jag gerKeith Richard tunes re minds me once again that the Stones are the best rock n roll band inthe business. Even after ten years of ex istence, every element essen t%al to rock works for them music, energy, charisma, showmanship. A few bands May surpass the Stones in one category or another but who else covers the field like Mick nagger (vocals), Keith Rich rd (guitar), Mick Taylor (gui tar), Charlie Watts (drums) and Bill Wyman (bass)?

title: Barringer Streak Ended at 21
description: The start of a new season signaled the end of some old routines for two Newark schools yesterday as Bar ringer lost its first game in 22 and Newark Central won its first in 13.

title: Mrs. John N. Mitchell
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Sept. 22 The American Independent party, winding up a threeday convention here, has elected William K. Shearer of Lemon Grove, Calif., as its national chairman.

title: Where Are We Going?
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22The six yearold children who went into the first grade in America the other day will be 33 at the end of the 20th cen tury, and the assumption is that they will then be ready to meet the prob lems of a new century in a new world.

title: DRUG JUDGES OFF TO SMOOTH START
description: Last Monday morning, Acting State Supreme Court Justice Mary Johnson Lowe opened the door to her regular chambers on the seventh floor of the Civil Court Building in Manhattan and found, much to her sur prise, a man.

title: Captain Bligh And Mr. Christian
description: I am a Bligh man unashamed, utterly unimpressed by the at tacks on the record of that great seaman and early Gov ernor of Australia. If this lengthy effort by Richard Hough had never been written there would be no loss. The story lurches about the Pacific like the maligned little Bounty trying to weather the Horn while the writer libels the un fortunate Bligh and tries his best to scatter nautical lingo through his text.

title: EastWest Detente
description: MOSCOW  The controversy over the fate of Andrei Sakharov, the dissident Soviet physicist, has calmed down for now. But on both sides of the controversy there is the awareness that this was a crucial test case for defining that inviting but ambitious concept  detente. And each camp knows the question is not settled.

title: After The Coup
description: SANTIAGO  During the day, the city's streets are bustling with traffic heavier than at any time in recent weeks. Shops are open again, and workers are drifting back to the bullet pocked factories, Youngsters licking icecream cones walk past policemen cradling submachineguns. People of all ages congregate in front of the fire and rocketgutted ruins of the squat, gray Presidential Palace.

title: Student Weds Susan Lesch
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Sept. 22In the Immaculate Heart Of Mary Roman Catholic Church here this afternoon, Miss Susan Marie Lesch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Lesch of Scarsdale and Highland Lakes, N. J., was married to James Peter Carr Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Carr of Bloomfield, N. J., and High land Lakes.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Billie Jean King performs the postmortem on Bobby Riggs after defeating him in their tennis Battle of the Sexes: I felt sorry for him. He had tried hard and given his best. I know how that feels. I know what it means to lose. He's been a great loser. He said well done and many other kind things.

title: Elizabeth R. Elkinton Is Fiancee of Charles C. Barr
description: LAWRENCE, L .I., Sept. 22 Mr. and Mrs. Chalmers Handy have announced the engagement of Mrs. Handy's daughter, Miss Elizabeth Roberts Elkinton, to Charles Carrington Barr, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Watson Barr 3d of Louisville, Ky. A wed ding in December is planned.

title: Mighty I.B.M. Takes Its Lumps
description: The big grin that broke out on the face of Floyd L. Walker last Monday morning in the Court Clerk's office in the Federal Building in Tulsa told the whole story.

title: German Newsman Reports Allende Was Shot in Back
description: OFFENBURG, West Germany, Sept. 22 (UPI)A West Ger man reporter said in a report published today that he saw the body of Salvador Allende Gossens the day the Chilean President died and that Dr. Al lende had been shot in the back, shoulders and head.

title: Mr. Clean of State Kitchens
description: TRENTONOscar has the politicians squirming a col league of Dr. Oscar Sussman said last week, alluding to the public disclosures of filthy conditions in the kitchens of state institutions.

title: Air Force Academy Wins on Late Pass
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Sept. 22 (AP)The Air Force Academy converted an Oregon fumble into a touchdown in the fourth quarter, with Rich Haynie hitting Bob Farr on a 6yard pass for the score, as the Fal cons pulled out a 2417 vic tory today.

title: Greenwich Vanquishes Stamford Catholic, 407
description: The Greenwich Cardinals took a giant step toward defense of their Fairfield County Conference Western Division title with a 407 trouncing of Stamford Cath olic yesterday.

title: GUERRILLAS BACK NEW JORDAN TIES
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 22 The high command of the Pales tinian guerrilla movement gave grudging approval today to the reconciliation of Egypt and Syria with Jordan, but con tinued to denounce King Hus sein of Jordan as an enemy.

title: Vote on County Charters
description: TRENTONVoters in nine counties containing more than twothirds of the state's population will decide Nov. 6 whether they want to over haul their county govern ments.

title: Numismatics
description: THE increasing interest in the collecting of offi cial Presidential inau gural medals shows no sign of slackening. Prices, which had been rising stead ily but slowly since the early '70's, began to really take off last January with the un precedented, highintensity nationwide promotion and distribution of the Nixon Agnew second inaugural medals. The preliminary re port on the sale of the two kinds of silver and two kinds of bronze medals indicates that just under 130,000 pieces were sold, for a gross return of slightly more than $3.5 million.

title: Farmingdale Survives Scare in 368 Victory
description: Herricks, unheralded among the teams that comprise the Nassau County North Shore Division I, threw a mild scare into Farmingdale before los ing yesterday, 368.

title: Delay in Currency Accord Seen at World Fund Talks
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 22 The new managing director of the International Monetary Fund said today in his first news conference that an agreement on a reformed world monetary system could be expected at the earliest a year from now.

title: Grambling 3114 Victor Before 64,243
description: Louisana Negro Normal and Industrial Institute de feated Centenary Biblical In stitute in football yesterday, and 64,243 persons came to Yankee Stadium to watch. It would be more credible, using the colleges' newer names to say that Grambling beat Morgan State, 3114.

title: For Every Marriage In Egypt, 2 Divorces
description: CAIRO, Sept. 22 (Reuters) Divorces in Egypt are now double the number of mar riages, according to Govern ment figures. In 1970 there were 700,000 cases of divorce throughout the country, com pared with 325,000 marriages, and the divorcetomarriage ratio is believed to have con siderably increased since then.

title: CAMBODIAN FORCE TAKES REBEL SITE
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sept. 22 (AP)  Government forces routed insurgents from a pagoda on the northern fringes at Kompong Cham to day after 17 hours of fighting, the military command reported.

title: Education
description: Ever since the 1880's when Dean Christopher Columbus Langdell of Harvard Law School invented the case method of instruction, al most all law school courses have been taught the same way: For the three years of their legal training, students have read and discussed hundreds of judicial opinions, most of them from appeals courts. They were rarely urged to inquire wheth er the rules handed down by the Supreme Court were followed or undermined by lower tribunals, whether the protection of the law filtered down to the majority of people who could not afford law yers, or what it felt like to play the roles  and assume the re sponsibilities  of prosecutor, de fense counsel, government bureau crat, labor negotiator or, for that matter, ambulance chaser.

title: The Environment
description: At some time in the distant fu ture, said the Council on Environ mental Quality, it may be possible to aggregate all aspects of environ mental quality, and issue a definitive pronouncement that, for example, the quality of the environment improved 3.68 per cent during the past year.

title: Late Listings for Today's TV
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONThe bizarre has be come commonplace here since those bumbling burglars broke into Demo cratic headquarters more than a year ago, but not commonplace enough to forestall a mild uproar over the latest episode in the life and difficult times of Vice President Spiro T. Agnew.

title: Caron Weingrow Bride
description: OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Sept, 22Miss Caron Wein grow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard L. Weingrow, was married here this after noon, to Marc Alan Haim, son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Haim of Valley Stream. Judge Stanley 1. Rosenthal of the Nassau District Court peiformed the ceremony in the gardens of the Old West bury Country Club. The bride's father served as treasurer of the Democratic National Committee during the 1972 Presidential elec tion.

title: Far Rockaway Conquers Springfield Gardens, 340
description: Far Rockaway, the defend ing Public Schools Athletic League champion, led by a junior quarterback, Eric Lieb erman, defeated visiting Springfield Gardens, 340, yesterday. It was the losers' first varsity start in the P.S.A.L.

title: ExMayor Is Found Guilty of Extortion In Little Ferry Case
description: LITTLE FERRY, N.J., Sept. 22Ferdinand A. Heinige, the Republican Mayor here, from 1961 to 1969, was convicted yesterday of misconduct and extortion.

title: Taking over from Hoover
description: Here is a book that brings an initial joy to the reviewer by merely arriv ing in the mail. In 1952 an assistant professor of history at the University of Illinois, Frank Freidel, published the first of a projected series of bio graphical volumes on Franklin D. Roosevelt. By 1956 the third volume had appeared, and the story was brought to the election of 1932. The author's scholarship and skill estab lished this as the definitive biog raphy, comprehensive in detail and scope, measured in judgment. But volume four did not soon appear. The years of Roosevelt's Presidency were crowded with complex issues; massive manuscript collections began to open in the 1950's, and soon there after the New Deal era was churning with controversy between liberal and New Left historians. Freidel was de layed. This month Freidel, now at Harvard, publishes the fourth volume, a major event for those interested in recent American history.

title: All you can do is breed the best with the best
description: LEXINGTON, Ky. The Darley Arabian, believed to have been foaled in 1700 in Syria and brought to England four years later by James Darley, begat in 1716 Bartlet's Childers, who begat Squirt, who begat Marske, who begat Eclipse, from whom 90 per cent of the world's thoroughbreds are descended.

title: ExCity Aide to Be Sworn As Criminal Court Judge
description: Richard A. Brown, formerly the city's chief legislative rep resentative in Albany, will be sworn in tomorrow by Mayor Lindsay as a Criminal Court judge. Mr. Brown, who is 40 years old, was appointed to the $36,451ayear post by the Mayor for a term to expire at the end of 1982.

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Time to Plant Lilies In a Sunny Site Where Soil Drains Easily
description: IN recent years, the hardi est and most beautiful lily species have been painstakingly crossed and recrossed until, today, hybrid lilies are truly easy to grow. Few flowers have such a spread of bloom seasons. A succession of types and colors will flower all summer. Here in the Northeast lilies bloom from late May to early Sep tember, in full sun or at the woods' edge.

title: Delaware Romps
description: NEWARK, Del., Sept. 22 (AP)Delaware, scoring 27 points in the second quarter, trounced Gettysburg, 6018, today. The Blue Hens tallied five touchdowns rushing and posted four scores on passes.

title: Indians Win, 51, on Old Yank Weapon
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 22  The home run, which has be come a big thing in the local scene because of the short ened fences at Municipal Stadium, erupted tonight as the Cleveland Indians pro duced four of them to tri umph over the New York Yankees, 51.

title: Plan to Buy Air Force Housing Dropped
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I.  After three years of trying to acquire 172 units of surplus Air Force housing in West hampton for moderate and middle  income cooperative development, Southampton has pulled out of the project.

title: White Township Fights to Remove Students From Morris High
description: MORRISTOWN  Will an almost exclusively white Morris County school district be allowed to withdraw its students from a high school with a significant black pop ulation or will it be forced to keep them there to main tain racial balance?

title: Aid for Liberal Senators
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UPI)A fundraising letter is being circulaed for liberal Sen ators, more than a year before the 1974 election, saying that the White House plans to give highest priority to defeating them. Senators Lee Metcalf of Montana and William Proxmire of Wisconsin, both Democrats, sent out the letters, seeking early and generous financial assistance for their liberal colleagues.

title: L. I. Farmland Still Threatened
description: CUTCHOGUE, L. I.  Suf folk County's onceabundant farmland is rapidly giving way to developers and the county's efforts to save what remains of this land for pos terity is endangered by the attractive profits offered to the farmers and by local dis putes.

title: Levittown Memorial Rally Pays Off, 2220
description: Levittown Memorial, last year's champion in Division III and among the favorites in Division II this season, was only minutes away from watching its season go down the drain yesterday when it rallied for 22 points in the final period to defeat Mep ham, 2220.

title: Private Schools Relaxing Uniform Rules
description: MONTCLAIR  The drab, shapeless uniform, the starched white shirt, the beanie hat and the saddle shoes have all but disap peared from private girls' schools in New Jersey.

title: Rangers Win, 103 In First Exhibition
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22  The New York Rangers opened their exhibition sea son with a 103 victory to night over the Philadelphia Flyers before 16,381 fans at the Spectrum.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday that its lawyers would request oneweek delay in the Interstate Commerce Commission's hearings scheduled to open tomorrow on a proposal to raise the PATH commuter line's fare to 50 cents from 30 cents.

title: Tenants Enter Political Arena
description: TRENTONThe New Jersey Tenants Organization an nounced last week that it would endorse the guberna torial candidate who made a commitment to the needs of the 3.5million tenants of this state.

title: William Mosier Weds Miss Patricia Taylor
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., Sept. 22Miss Patricia Ann Tay lor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Bradley Taylor Jr. of Scarsdale, and William Hin nant Mosier, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Willis Mosier of Greenville, N. C., were mar ried here at noon today. The ceremony was performayed in the Manhattanville College Chapel by the Rev. Francis Xavier Murphy of Rome, the bride's uncle, assisted by the Rev. Mills R. Omaly and the Rev. John J. Boland.

title: Green's 199 Leads by 5 After 2d 65
description: ENDICOTT, N.Y., Sept. 22 (AP)Hubert Green shot his second straight course rec ordequaling 65 today for a 199 total after 54 holes and a fivestroke lead in the $100,000 Broome County open golf tournament.

title: Hackensack Area Is Being Upgraded
description: HACKENSACKMayor Mi chael J. D'Arminio of Hack ensack has announced that a $2.5million industrial and office building will be erected on South River Street and Hudson Street.

title: KISSINGER SWORN, PRAISED BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 Henry A. Kissinger took the Constitutional oath as the 56th United States Secretary of State today and was acclaimed by President Nixon as the first naturalized citizen to gain the office.

title: Child to Mrs. Manocherian
description: A daughter was born Sept. 12 to Mr. and Mrs. Fraydun Manocherian of Scarsdale, N.Y., at the New York Uni versity Hospital. The child, the couple's fifth, has been named Caroline Elena. Mrs. Manocherian is the former Miss Jennifer Robbins of New York.

title: Palisades Park Post Filled
description: ALBANY, Sept. 22 (UPI) George W. Perkins Jr. of Mill brook, a farm owner and man ager, has been appointed to the Palisades Interstate Park Com mission, Governor Rockefeller's office announced today. Mr. Perkins, 48 years old, will fill the vacancy caused by the res ignation of Mrs. Linn Perkins. He will serve throgh Feb. 12, 1976, in the unsalaried post.

title: Control of Secret Fund Linked to 3 Near Nixon
description: During President Nixon's first Administration, while he was making heavy investments in homes in Florida and Cali fornia, three persons close to him are said to have had con trol of a secret political fund of $1,098,000 in cashmostly $100 billsand $570,000 in checking accounts.

title: Miss Martinez Wed To Robert J. Malito
description: Miss Margaret Ann Mar tinez, who is protocol aide to Mayor Lindsay, was married here yesterday after noon to Robert J. Malito, first deputy commissioner of the Department of Public Events and Mayoral Deputy Chief of Protocol. The Rev. Rich ard Rodney Kirk performed the Episcopal ceremony in the chapel for the United Nations.

title: Birth Control
description: For the past five years American demographers have, been congratulat ing themselves on the success of con traceptive practices in this country. They point out that the population growth rate for the nation has de clined rapidlyfrom 1.5 per cent a year in 1962 to 0.8 per cent last year. Most of that decline has been at tributed to the mass acceptance of birth control pills, intrauterine devices (IUD) and voluntary sterilization.

title: Mrs. Mitchell Says She Wants Her Husband to Return to Her
description: Mrs. John N. Mitchell has told an interviewer that she wants to be reunited with her husband and that the sugges tion of divorce has only been through the media.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: The knitting industry has hit a snag with consumers buying fewer doubleknit garments because of the ris ing price of apparel, a sur plus of the fabric and com plaints about its quality.

title: U.S. GIVES THE CITY $104MILLION MORE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 In the aftermath of the Water gate scandal, the Federal purse strings have been loosened to provide New York City with a windfall of $104million in Federal funds.

title: Skylab and the Sun
description: The Skylab 2 astronauts now hold every possible record for length of time spent outside of earth's atmosphere, and they are in good health and spirits.

title: Syracuse Loses in Last 35 Seconds, 148
description: SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 22 (AP)Tyrone Wilson bowled over from 2 yards out with 35 seconds left, leading Michigan State to a 148 victory over Syracuse in a regionally televised football game today.

title: Talks Will Resume In the Opera Strike At City Hall Today
description: A meeting is scheduled for 2 P.M. today at City Hall be tween both sides in the mu sicians strike against the New York City Opera, a special me diator announced yesterday. No talks were held yesterday.

title: Elks Sue ExChapter
description: MADISON, Wis., Sept. 22 (UPI)The Benevolent and Pa ternal Order of Elks filed a Federal court action this week against the Madison chapter, which lost its charter after dropping its whitesonly mem bership clause. The suit alleged that the Madison Elks group was infringing on the National Elks trademark by continuing to use the name and insignia even though it has no charter.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: As a lecturer in the Harvard AfroAmerican Studies De partment from 1969 to 1971, I had the honor of meeting Dr. Martin Kilson, who was introduced to me as an emi nent scholar. His article The black experience at Harvard (Sept. 2) belies his reputa tion. It is a conglomeration of halftruths and guesses that does an injustice to a scholar of his stature.

title: URGENT AID ASKED FOR CORAL REEFS
description: KEY LARGO, Fla., Sept. 22 The state's coral reef forma tions are in danger of extinc tion, according to marine biol ogists. Citing damage inflicted by water pollution, boat an chors, souvenir hunters and de velopers, scientists stress that urgent measures must be taken if the coral reefs are to survive.

title: Shaking the man loose from vanished time
description: The referent for Shake speare's greatness is rather ob viously not his biography but his 37 plays, his narrative poems, and his Sonnets. Still, our curiosity about the man himself has never been satis fied. We would be somewhat happier, more comfortable in contemplating the size of his achievement, we think, if the once living creature, whom Ben Jonson tells us he loved on this/side idolatry, had more of a shape and substance for us. We do have E. K. Cham bers's definitive twovolume William Shakespeare: A Study of Facts and Problems (1930) which puts together all the raw factual data for a life. But Chambers does not try to pro duce that illusive thing: what Shakespeare was like as a per son.

title: Pamela A. Giles Wed to Lawyer
description: READING, Pa., Sept. 22 Miss Pamela Ann Giles, daughter of Mr, and Mrs. John Stanley Giles Jr. of Wyomissing, was married here this afternoon to Mi chael Joseph Needham, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. Needham of Riverdale, the Bronx. Msgr. Henry J. Hues man performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church.

title: 48 Rookies Win Starting Berths in N.F.L. LineUps
description: Last winter's draft of the college talent was advertised by the pro scouts as a rich one and apparently they were right. Not only did 238 rookies win jobs but 48 be came starters. The latter figure, 17 higher than last season, Is more significant than the other because the squaas were ex panded this year from 40 to 47 players on offi cial rosters.

title: Margo Sloan Is Bride Of William Pearson 3d
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 22Miss Margo Forbes Sloan and William Osgood Pearson 3d were married here this afternoon at St. Joseph's Ro man Catholic Church by Msgr. Joseph P. Moore.

title: Fictions sweet, ripe and rotten
description: At one point Cornelius Christian, J. P. Donleavy's tough, sardonic, tender hero says, I'll take the whole imagination of the world with me. It's a credible threat. Christian is to A Fairy Tale of New York what Falstaff is to Henry IV's more private parts: not only. witty in my self, but the cause that wit is in other men.

title: Shows at Stamford, Newport This Week
description: Boatshow fever, once a pleasant malady associated only with winter, can now be caught just as easily in early autumn. Striking evidence of this development will be pro vided this week at Stamford, Conn., where the second an nual North Atlantic Boat Show opens a threeday run on Fri day and at New port, R.I., where the Newport In ternational Sail boat Show gets its four  day stand under way on Thursday. Both events are inthewa ter shows, a new marketing concept that appears to have caught the fancy of major boating manufacturers and distributors.

title: Twicetold tale
description: Richard B. Wright's first novel, The Weekend Man, was published in 1970. Set in and around Toronto, it is about a salesman of educational equipment who himself lacks the equipment to be a salesman and who stumbles to such small success as he has. His marriage is in tentative condition; he gets along uncomfort ably with his brother, who lives a hundred miles away; his son is Mon goloid. At the end of the novel, he and his wife are moving toward reconciliation. Love will have to do.

title: Three Britons Try Injecting Insulin Into Muscles
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 22 Three British doctors have de veloped a new emergency therapeutic regimen for pa tients suffering from diabetic coma, a complication of one of man's most common diseases.

title: Diagrandess, 21 by 21
description: ACROSS

title: Wendy Smith Is Bride Here Of C. T. Born
description: Miss Wendy Smith, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Smith of New York, was mar ried here yesterday afternoon to Christopher Thomas Born, son of Dr. and Mrs. John H. Born of New York and Car mel. The Rev. Terence Finlay performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. Bartholo mew's Episcopal Church.

title: An Egyptian Treasure in Brooklyn
description: The magnificence of Egyp tian art has never been fully comprehended. The works of art that have come down to us have been appreciated more for their historical grandeur than for their esthe tic impact. Now an Egyptian art show, Akhenaten and Nefertiti, which opened this week at the Brooklyn Mu seum, brings to us a splendid array of Egyptian art, splen did not only in its historical importance but also in its superb esthetic force.

title: Clouds Speckle the Condominium Horizon
description: The mushrooming popularity of condominiums and the benefits they providemore extensive home owner ship, enlightened land use, greater recreational opportunities  have all been widely heralded.

title: Vols Triumph, 3718
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 22  The corps of Cadets sang On Brave Old Army Team today for the first time this season and indeed an outclassed Army team played bravely against 10th ranked Tennessee. But the Cadets, the ones in black shirts and gold football pants, couldn't play well enough to stifle slippery Condredge Holloway and his tearaway orange jersey and the Vols marched away with a 3718 victory.

title: Consumer Is Not Convinced Enough Is Being Done About Prices
description: Tempers are flaring in the aisles of the nation's super markets. Despite pledges of lower prices by cattlemen's trade groups, Agriculture De partment statisticians and store managers after Federal price ceilings on rood were removed, the American consumer is not convinced that enough is be ing done to hold food prices down.

title: Abrams to Hold Hearings On Community Proposals
description: The Bronx Borough Presi dent, Robert Abrams, announced yesterday that he would con duct a series of neighborhood hearings to receive community proposals for local improve ments to be included in the 197475 capital and expense budgets.

title: Mrs. King Bows To Miss Casals
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 22 (AP) Mrs. Billie Jean King, the toast of women's tennis after heating Bobby Riggs, ended a magical week today by los ing to Rosemary Casals, 76, 61, in the semifinals of $30,000 tournament here.

title: News of Screen
description: Frank D. Gilroy, the Pulitzer Prizewinning playwright from the Bronx, has finally made it to the Old West that he loves. Mike Frankovich, the producer, has acquired rights to Mr. Gil roy's western novel From Noon Till Three, which Dou bleday will publish on Oct. 19. The author is set to write the script and to direct the film for release by Columbia Pic tures. It is slated to be shot on location in the Southwest early next year.

title: Mrs. Chester Has Child
description: A daughter was born Sept. 17 at the LyingIn Hospital here to Mr. and Mrs. Jeffrey Victor Chester of New York. The child has been named Jessica Rachel. Mrs. Chester is the former Miss Lynne Terry Friedman. The child's father is the wine manager of Park & Tilford Co. a division of Schenley Industries, Inc.

title: A Poll Finds 30% Have No Religious Preference
description: BERNARDS TOWNSHIP Almost onethird of the households surveyed in a re cent religious census have no church preference, a typical ratio for a predominantly Christian community in New Jersey.

title: Pies of Delicious Orchards
description: COLTS NECKIt all began 13 years ago with a trial 10 apple pies a dayfrom a small farmhouse oven. To day, Delicious Orchards, a 250acre fruit farm backing up a spacious and modern country store, sells about 900 pies on weekends and thousands at Thanksgiving time.

title: The songwriter who was a composer
description: George Gershwin would have been 75 this week. Three biographies, a postage stamp, a spate of new re cordings to be released this fall, all invite us to reexamine, or bask nostalgically in, one of the great American legends. When he died of a brain tumor in 1937, at what should have been midcareer, Gersh win already occupied a special posi tionthe only songwriter I know who became a composer, as Irving Berlin said. That position did not deterioratethe tradition of all Gershwin concerts at Lewisohn Sta dium and the Hollywood Bowl con tinued for decadesand reached some sort of apotheosis with the tours to Europe and Russia of Porgy and Bess in, the 1950's. His credentials have been challenged, but in the popular imagination at least, here and even more so abroad, he hasn't been supplanted as the American songwriter composer.

title: Writing Wild
description: Among the booming items in the book business lately have been volumes on the problems and the rise of women, about black life and liberation, on Indians, and about what is called ecology, usu ally erroneously, by which is meant en vironmental issues, alarums and wist fulness. With all but the first of these categories, a publisher's main difficulty has not been to find willing readers, but enough writers.

title: Lillian Hellman Walking, Cooking, Writing, Talking
description: Lillian Hellman is 67 years old now, and as I ar rive at her house on Martha's Vine yard, the new house she built on the beach just below the one she shared with Dashieli Hammett, she is standing at the door saying she hasn't been feeling well  she has a bronchial infection that worried the doctors because of her emphysema, and the emphysema has weakened her heart, and she has been on antibiotics for the last two weeks and they make her sleepy.

title: Photography
description: IN an effort to make the showing of home movies as easy as pulling out the family album, Bell & Howell has introduced a new double purpose motion picture projector that takes pre loaded 50foot cassettes of Super 8 or regular 8mm film. Specifically styled to be at tractive enough to be left out on top of a table or bookcase, much like a record player, this new projector is called the Model 1641 Double Fea ture and it enables the owner to show movies quickly in one of two waysby projecting on a conventional screen in the usual manner, or by viewing on a builtin rear projection screen on the front of the unit without need for setting up a separate screen the line.

title: Stan Mikita to Get Honorary Degree
description: ST. CATHARINES, Ontario, Sept. 22 (Canadian Press) Stan Mikita, the hockey all star who grew up here but never finished high school, will receive an honorary doc tor of laws degree at Brock University Oct. 15.

title: Jackson On the Offense
description: WASHINGTONAt a Cook County political dinner last spring, Mayor Daley of Chicago, in fine oratorical fettle himself, introduced the evening's speaker, Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington. Closing with a Daley esque flourish, the Mayor declared:

title: Nassau Unit Aids LowIncome Persons
description: ROOSEVELT, L. I. While home improvements con tinue to lead the list of complaints among Nassau consumers, new consumer centers in the county's low incomeareas are dealing with the harsher realities of loan sharks, repossessions and usedcar swindles.

title: Legislators Discuss Future Of Parks
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I.  Be sieged by offers to do ev erything from riding to the hounds along North Shore Estates to taking a guided tour through a 3,500acre hunting preserve used by millionaire sportsmen, a group of state legislators began lis tening to public suggestions last week on how best to utilize 7,500 acres of mostly undeveloped parklands now owned by the state.

title: Italian Masons End Split and Church Enmity Wanes
description: ROME, Sept. 21  Italy's oncepowerful Freernasons have ended a 65year split amid signs that the enmity of the Roman Catholic Church is waning.

title: Denis Potvin, the Rookie, Pacing Pro Hockey Entry
description: PETERSBOROUGH, On tario, Sept. 20Denis Pot vin, the New York Island ers' prize rookie hasn't been himself on the ice this week and he doesn't expect to be himself until some time in November.

title: Kissinger at State
description: WASHINGTONTo the relief, de light and doubts of Washington and the world diplomatic community, ap pearance and reality are finally joined in holy patrimony: Henry Kissinger the new Secretary of State as well as Assistant to the President.

title: Wedding Planned By Jane F. Gilman
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Sept. 22Dr. and Mrs. Manuel Alar. Gilman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Fenwick Gilman, to Henry Reed Hoke 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hoke Jr.

title: What to do about stagflation
description: There is no doubt that, of all economists alive today, Gunnar Myrdal has made the most impor tant contributions to the subject but, because of the entrenched re sistance of the profession to ideas that challenge received orthodoxy, it cannot be said that they have been the most influential. In this volume of collected essays and ad dresses he records and reflects upon the various phases of a long life's work.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: At the beginning of the football season, the Raiders of the Indianapolis Dads Club League are normally smartly suited up in new uni forms. But this year they have had to play their first two games in faded practice jerseys and the remnants of last year's game shirts. Their new cotton uniforms, ordered more than two months ago, have not yet arrived.

title: Few PrescriptionDrug Prices Posted Here, Despite New Law
description: A new city regulation requir ing druggists to post their prices for the 150 most com monly prescribed drugs went into effect yesterday with few signs of compliance by pharma cists or of enforcement efforts by the city.

title: Berkeley Honors Bhutto, Class of '50, For Achievement
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22  Prime Minister Zulfikar All Bhutto of Pakistan, who is on a six  day visit to the United States, was awarded the. Berke ley Citation, the highest award of his alma mater, the Univer sity of California at Berkeley, this afternoon.

title: Meet Mark Broken by 3 Harriers
description: KINGS PARK, L. I., Sept. 22Three runners broke the meet record and a 120pound former football guard was a victor in his first crosscoun try race today in the fourth annual Nassau County Coaches invitation meet at Sunken Meadow State Park.

title: Surviving Sextuplets Gain
description: DENVER, Sept. 22 (AP) After nearly a week of battling for life, the five surviving Stanek sextuplets are becoming stronger by the hour, doctors said today.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market staged a dynamic advance on tre mendous trading volume last week as a wave of bullish ness swept through the gray canyons of Wall Street.

title: Cattle and Hog Shipments Rise; Wholesale Meat Prices Decline
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 22  Fat tend beef cattle and hogs were brought to Middle Western markets in large numbers this week, sending wholesale prices down and offering the hope that the reductions will be passed on to supermarket counters within a few days.

title: Life, to be lived not feared
description: This book, says editor Bert Kaplan, is concerned with the experience of mental illness. It is presented in the conviction that there is no better starting point for those seeking to un derstand this strange and baf fling phenomenon than ac counts of its experience. An unusual approach, and it achieves the minimum of what one patient calls words, tech nical phraseswhose syllables clatter together and make noise like scientific analysis. It does allow experience to speak for itself. Either through excerpts from books describing breakdowns. Or documents written at the request of doc tors. Or as bootstrapsurvival techniques. There are 30 or so contributors.

title: Aid for Jersey Central Riders
description: NEWARK  Jersey Cen tral commuters living west of Plainfield, who are fear ful of losing service when PATH trains replace the Cen tral between Newark and Plainfield, may wind up with an improved express train schedule.

title: Companies to Get Credit
description: BOSTON, Sept. 22 (AP)A bill giving tax credit to com panies who hire persons re ceiving unemployment compen sation, welfare or manpower training, was signed into law Thursday by Gov. Francis W. Sargent.

title: PRESS OMBUDSMAN DESCRIBES WORE
description: Of course, in Sweden the polls show that most people don't believe all they read In the papers, particularly the afternoon papers, said Lennert Groll, the Swedish press om budsman, who is visiting in this country for a month or so, hold ing seminars on press freedom problems.

title: Eagles Try To Cool Off The Giants
description: The Philadelphia Eagles, who lost to the New York Giants in 95degree weather earlier this month, will chal lenge the New Yorkers' hot eightgame winning streak today at Yankee Stadium.

title: Flushing Is Beaten By Holy Cross, 136
description: The running and pass re ceiving of Steve Sokolich a sophomore halfback, led Holy Cross to a l36 victory over Flushing Friday night before 3,500. Sokolich ran 52 yards and combined on a 6yard scoring pass play with Tim Lisante for the winning points.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
description: (CAPT.) MOSS BUNKER: DAMN THE GARBAGE, (FULL SPEED AHEAD)  At sea, blowing horns and whis tles works... fine, like tooting a horn in traffic or at the cross road; that is, in daylight. But while whistling in the dark is a common practice on land, its efficacy notwithstanding, it is often useless at sea.

title: Waiting for Bobby
description: It was just about a year ago that Boris Spassky and Bobby Fischer had their showdown in Reykjavik. Poor Boris, psychologically pistolwhipped, outmaneuvered, andyesoutplayed, picked himself up off the ground, un derstandably discouraged. He was as drained of blood as any human being since Dracula started noshing the necks of Transylvanian virgins. He re turned to Russia and the bleak, un forgiving, pitiless eyes of the chess commissars. Bobby came back to the United States and the greatest chess ovation since Paul Morphy returned from Europe in 1859.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: In almost all American oc cupations, the Fourth Com mandment requirement to rest on the seventh day has been expanded to rest also on the sixth. In several occupations  particularly teaching and the ministry the Commandment has been further extended to a sab batical year off.

title: Pitt Eleven Is Defeated By Baylor
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 22 (UPI)Baylor unleashed a devastating ground attack bolstered by Gary Lacy's 167 yards rushing on 39 carries and survived a fourthperiod Pittsburgh rally to defeat the Panthers 20 to 14 today.

title: V.A. SEEKS TO LIFT MEDICAL SERVICES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (UPI)The Veterans Adminis tration has announced a new program to improve its medical services.

title: Ervin: Yes
description: WASHINGTONNo one seems cer tain whether or how it will work, but the Senate Watergate committee will try to define the defects in the American political system and aim the nation toward possible reforms when the seven Watergate Senators resume their televised inquiry here tomorrow.

title: How to Go to Harvard without Passing the Boards
description: CLASSES at Harvard open tomor row morning, And if you find yourself fascinated by the na tion's oldest college  Harvard, founded in 1636, is 140 years older than the United Statesyou can go to Cambridge, Mass., and get an education of sorts without being enrolled as student.

title: JazzFolk Series Is Opening in Essex
description: WEST ORANGEThere is rock music aplenty in North Jersey, according to three young folk singers who moved into a house on Maple Street last spring. But, they have found, there is almost no opportunity to hear folk music and not much chance to hear jazz. So they decided to start a concert series that would fill this gap.

title: Julius, Adolph, Leonard and sometimes Herbert
description: Time: 1930. Scene: A Marx Brothers sto ry conference. First to enter, only 45 minutes late, is direc tor and certified genius Her man Mankiewicz. At irregular intervals thereafter, enter Zep po Marx with wife and Afghan hounds; Harpo and two blondes; Chico with wife and wirehair terrier; Groucho and wife; three gagwriters. One of the script's authors begins to read his 126page effort. Sev eral of the dogs fall asleep. Harpo does likewise. Aside from the choked voice of the author, there is a profound silence. Not a giggle, chuckle comment. Author finishes.

title: Soviet Reveals Goals Of Its Mars Flight; Skylab 2 Nears End
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 22A So viet space scientist, in an un usual break with traditional se crecy, disclosed today some of the scientific goals and experi ments of the caravan of four Soviet spaceships on their way to Mars.

title: Cavaliers Trim Roster
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 22 (AP)The Cleveland Cavaliers cut Floyd Lewis and James Lister, rookies, from the squad today, reducing the roster to 16.

title: Yale Improves Fiscal Condition; Balanced Budget Held Possible
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 32Yale University lost less money dur ing the last school year than it has in the last four years, and could conceivablyfor the first time since 1966end the current fiscal year with a bal anced budget.

title: A's Wrap Up Tie For West Crown
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP) Sal Bando's tworun homer in a five  run first inning backed Jim Hunter's 21st tri umph as the Oakland A's downed the Chicago White Sox, 93, tonight and clinched at least a tie for their third straight American League West title.

title: What Will Become of Anna, Juliet and Ariadne?
description: GETTING its fall season off to the earliest start in its history, the New York City Opera opened with a flourish on August 29and was closed after three performances by a strike of union musicians. The musicians' contract with the company was up, and negotiations for a new con tract had reached an impasse. As the tragic situation at the State Theater continued, it increasingly jeopardized the very life of the company, ac cording to Julius Rudel, the director. I'm distraught, was all he could say, and Beverly Sills, brightest of the company's sopranos, said that she felt as if she were help lessly watching Rome burn.

title: Yorkville Gets Grassy Ball Field On Site of Proposed HighRises
description: Yorkville residents and city politicians yesterday celebrated the opening of the first grass covered football field in their area, one month before the Board of Estimate is scheduled to consider a proposal to build two highrise apartment build ings and a school on the site.

title: Armenians ReVel in Ethnicity And Invite You to Do the Same
description: The city's 40,000 residents of Armenian descent invited New Yorkers of other ethnic heritages to a party this week end to say, May you have a gracefilled 75th anniversary, or, in Armenian Shnorhavor yotanasoon hinkerort dare tartz.

title: Audubon Society Selling Fifth Ave. Landmark
description: The National Audubon Society has agreed to sell the Georgianstyle man sion at 1130 Fifth Avenue, on the north corner of 94th Street, Its former headquarters. The buyers are inves tors who plan to convert the building to professional offices and apart ments.

title: Connors, Okker Gain Coast Final
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept, 22 (AP)Jimmy Connors de feated Raul Ramirez and Tom Okker upset hie Nastase in today's semifinals of the $75,000 Pacific Southwest open tennis tournament.

title: CONFERENCE HELD ON CURRICULUMS
description: Questions of what should be taught and whythe extent to which relevance, values and career training should perme ate the higher educational cur riculum were the subjects of extensive discussion here dur ing a twoday conference yes terday and Friday at the Rockefeller University.

title: Doctor of Animals Busy in Brooklyn
description: Dogs, bats and pigeons, plus occasional wild skunks and snakes, have kept Dr. Samuel Hutt on his medical toes for 34 years.

title: HongKong: Fishermen In 2 Worlds
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 22 Mr. and Mrs. Wong Shuifat have never had to leave home to go to work, for the Wongs are fishermen and home is their junk.

title: East Asia: Tradition and Transformation
description: Americans do not like to think of themselves as extre mists, but we are, not a patient people. The demand for instant answers to instantly (and usual ly belatedly) recognized prob lems is part of the American way. China has been little more than a name, or an emotionally loaded stereotype, to most peo ple in this country until a year or two ago. Now there is a mad rush to find out all about it. The reasons for both past neglect and current attention are clear enough, but even so the abrupt flipflop in attitudes in amazing.

title: Morality and Power
description: Americans entered the postwar world true to their tradition as a people concerned with the preservation of peace through international law and morality. President Roosevelt founded his postwar policy on a strong United Nations and warned that the second World War had again demonstrated the bankruptcy of balanceofpower diplomacy.

title: THEATER OPENINGS
description: NELLIE TOOLE & CO.  Tomorrow, Theater Four, 7. A play by Peter Keveson. Starring Sylvia Miles and Stefan Gierasch.

title: JET CRASH INQUIRY SIFTING EVIDENCE
description: PEABODY, Mass., Sept. 22 National Transportation and Safety Board hearings into the July 31 crash of a Delta Airlines DC9 at Boston's Lo gan Airport, which took the lives of 88 persons aboard, have been marked thus far by intensive questioning.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Quilller is a veteran of the British Secret Service. Philis is a comparative newcomer. Both are neoBond types, cleared to kill, lethal, impervious to pain, selected for highlevel mis sions. But Ritchie Perry's Philis is, a Bond epigone. Adam Hall's Quiller, a much more though ful type, belongs to the Le Cant ambience.

title: D. E. Franz Jr. to Wed Miss Jones
description: CHESTERTOWN, Md., Sept. 22Dr. and Mrs. Hen ry Alvan Jones have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Caro line Jones, to Donald E. Franz Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Franz of Garden City, L. I. A December wedding is planned.

title: Heide Hynes Plans Bridal
description: WILTON, Conn., Sept. 22 The engagement of Miss Heide Hynes to Peter M. Moran has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Edward G. Hynes, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Moran of New Canaan.

title: Report Sees Sex Bias Rampant In Schools
description: NEW BRUNSWICKNew Jersey is doing a poor job in eliminating sex discrim ination in its public schools, according to a report issued by the New Jersey chapter of the Women's Equity Ac tion League.

title: Gibson Raps With Yale Group
description: NEW HAVEN  Sitting hunched over a cup of after dinner tea last week, New ark's Mayor, Kenneth Gib son, glanced coolly at the in quisitive, scrubbed faces of the dozen Yale students seated around him.

title: DR. CHARLES DODD, BIBLICAL SCHOLAR
description: LONDON, Sept. 22The Rev. Dr. Charles Harold Dodd, con sidered one of the world's lead ing experts on the New Testa ment, died today in a hospital at Goring, about 50 miles west of here. He was 89 years old.

title: Prices
description: Yet another indicator of inflation, the consumer price index, went up 1.9 per cent in August, and largely as a result, the average worker's pur chasing power went down.

title: Summit Takes 10th in Row, Westfield 43d
description: Wane Wilson missed half the game because of a minor injury, but still provided Summit with the punch it needed yesterday for a 2416 victory over Piscataway, its 10th in a row, in Summit.

title: Vanderbilt Cup Restored For Bridgehampton Races
description: The Vanderbilt Cup, one of auto racing's first major trophies, is back in the com petition. A replica of the cup will be awarded to the team that registers the most points in two days of sports car rac ing at the Bridgehampton (L. I.) Race Circuit next Sat urday and Sunday. The rac ing will be under the supervision of the East Metro politan Racing Association with the New York Region of the Sports Car Club of America serving as a guest host. The two clubs have invited other regions of the S.C.C.A. to join them in the for the cup.

title: A Future Right To a Pension
description: Every member of Congress has a file full of heartbreak  the horror stories of elderly workers who found that the company pensions they had counted on to beef up their Social Security just weren't there when they retired after decades on the job. Sometimes they lost out because they switched from one employer to an other. Or their employment was in terrupted for a year Or two by lay offs when business was bad. Or their employer went bankrupt or was ab sorbed in a merger.

title: Madrid Bans Death Notices of Allende
description: MADRID, Sept. 22The Gov ernment has cracked down on efforts by some Spanish groups to use the fall of Salvador Al lende Gossens in Chile to pro test the political regime here.

title: Soviet Shows Uneasiness on Pompidou's Visit to China
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 22  The Soviet Union has publicly taken comfort in differences that ap peared during the first visit to China by President Pompidou of France, but publication this weekend of an attack on some common elements in French and Chinese policies suggested private uneasiness about French dealings with Peking.

title: Is Superstar About ChrisvOr About Us?
description: SEVERAL years ago, when protest against Ameri can involvement in Vi etnam was hottest, sev eral protesters, myself in cluded, stood on the balcony that overlooks the floor of the New York Stock Ex change and tore dollar hills into pieces. As the tiny green slivers dropped to the floor, we shouted our indignation at those who made money off the war. And we prayed. We prayed for the souls of those brokers and the bodies and souls of those being bombed in Vietnam. We be lieved all right,

title: FRANCES HEILPRIN
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Sept. 22  Frances Heilprin, who had operated her own in terior decorating shop on Mad ison Avenue in New York for half a century until her retire ment about 10 years ago, died today in a nursing home here. She was 91 years old.

title: U Conns Pin 2614 Defeat On Vermont
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Sept. 22A secondhalf drive led by Eric Torkelson gave Con necticut a 2614 victory over Vermont today. Torkelson carried the ball 33 times for 150 yards and scored two touchdowns.

title: Horse Show Results
description: AT SOMERS, N.Y.

title: City Reading Scores
description: In recent years New York City school officials have had little to be happy aboutparticularly when the results of the annual city and state pupil reading tests have been made known. Last week they got some un expeded good news, even though they were not quite sure how to explain it or what to make of it.

title: Update the Home Landscape
description: EVEN the best gardens eventually require ren ovation. Whether to repair, replace or dis continue a mess of overgrown planting or to discard and begin again are decisions most of us have to face sooner or later.

title: Volunteer Army
description: WASHINGTONThe figures pouring from the Pentagon on enlistment for the volunteer forces point to an in escapable conclusion: Not enough men are being recruited to fill out even the attenuated Army and Marine Corps of the postVietnam military establish ment.

title: Libya
description: Under the fouryear reign of the flamboyant Col. Muammar elQad dafi, Libya, once a quiet proWestern monarchy, has become one of the most militant of the Arab nations. The Libyan Government has led the way in setting higher prices for Middle Eastern oil, and has recently nation alized Western companies operating in Libya in a move to bring pressure on the West, primarily the United States, to stop giving aid to Israel.

title: Mary Tyler Moore's irascible Boss Is a Pussycat
description: FANS of The Mary Tyler Moore Show are a mixed bag. They include video holies who cannot start or finish the day without the tube's reassuring purr; shame less liars who insist that be fore Watergate they never watched television except for Masterpiece Theater; mys terious Nielsen families to whom we are all in thrall; nil legendary comedy writer Goodman Ace, who finds the show's players so believable and hilarious that between Saturday nights (9 P.M. on CBS) he mopes around fight ing a desire to phone their (fictional) TV studio in Min neapolis to ask ... how things are going.

title: Mideast oil, American demand, Israeli security
description: We do not wish to place any restrictions on our oil exports to the United States but, as I men tioned, America's complete support of Zionism against the Arabs makes it extremely difficult for us to continue to supply the United States' petroleum needs and to even maintain our friendly relations.

title: Film Study of Riggs Aided Billie Jean
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 21What did Mrs. Billie Jean King do the eve before her $100,000 match last Thursday with Bobby Riggs in the Astro dome? Well, she went to the movies, sort of. She revealed today that in her hotel suite she and her coach, Dennis van der Meer, had twice run through the films of Bobby's match against Mrs. Margaret Court last May. Declaring firmly that she wanted no rematch with Riggs, Mrs. King said of possible future intersex tennis battles, Mar garet went and opened the door and I hope I shut it.

title: Art
description: IN the art of Ellsworth Kelly, which is currently the subject of a large retrospective exhibition at the Mu seum of Modern Art, we confront a body of work that is both extremely individual and extremely traditional. What is most individual is this art is the concrete visual experience of the artist himselfthe precious donne that, no matter how radically transformed, serves as the fulcrum of all his en deavors. What is most traditional is the means by which this individual ex perience is given objective form.

title: Montclair Is Shutout Victor
description: Montclair bidding for a re turn to New Jersey leader ship, opened its season yes terday with a 200 victory over Morris Hills in an im portant intersectional con test at Rockaway.

title: An apartment that evolved
description: The happiest rooms don't happen overnight; they evolve. This high ceilinged apartment in a midnine teenthcentury, Greenwich Village brownstone was seven years in the making, despite the fact that both the occupants work in the fields of design and art. Buzz Miller of Melvin Dwork Associates and Alan Groh were not concerned with the latest fashion in design. They wanted a sense of spa ciousness and an ambiance of warmth, art and contemporary elegance. The mix of French, English and American furnishings and the vibrant contem porary art came about slowly as they found pieces that appealed to them. There are no formal room separations so the spaces flow together and share a common color scheme. The walls are a rich gray, a color that required many trialanderror coats of paint un til they achieved the right shade of gray that was as warm and inviting in the evenings as in daylight. The 150yearold wooden shutters were discovered in an old house in Galves ton, Tex., and shipped by barge to New York. Their own mix (cont.)

title: The World and Watergate
description: The repercussions of Watergate on U.S. policy cannot yet be assessed but they are clearly negative. It will take a long time for even the most brilliant and consistent diplomacy to improve this dismal picture.

title: Progressive Trade Bill
description: The trade bill now before the House Ways and Means Committee is a better bill than the President's proposed Trade Reform Act of 1973. Mr. Nixon's bill was con ceived in a markedly different politicaleconomic envi ronment earlier this year: the United States was running deep deficits in its balances of trade and payments; there were strong pressures for the highly protectionist BurkeHartke bill; and Mr. Nixon, fresh from his elec tion victory, was demanding and seemed likely to get virtually a free hand from Congress to deal with trade policy.

title: Viscount Paul Van Zeeland, 76, Prewar Belgian Premier, Is Dead
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 22 (AP) Viscount Paul Van Zeeland, who was Premier in the critical years just before World War II, when the nation narrowly averted a Fascist takeover, died today at the age of 76.

title: High Cost of Living
description: WASHINGTONEarly this year, the Air Force put into service for President Nixon's personal use a new fourengine jet, The Spirit '76, to supplement a fleet of fourengine jets that are maintained for the use of the White House. The plane cost $7.4million and the Gov ernment spent $1.7million more equipping it with a plush interior.

title: Movies
description: BOTH Gordon's War and Cleopatra Jones are important films. They are remarkably accur ate in reflecting the mood, the ambience, the sensibility of the seventies in black communities across the nation. Such an accurate reflection is startling, for movies are many months in prepara tion and by the time the moviegoer puts his money down, he gets to see what was the going thingtwo or three years ago.

title: Colts Name Is Familiar; Jets Don't Know Faces

title: Heath in Ireland
description: LONDONIreland has always been known as the graveyard of English politicians. Prime Minister Edward Heath came back alive from Dublin last week, but not before he tripped over a bone. It was his jawbone, in fact.

title: Bad to Better to Best
description: REVIEWING TV series premieres is a mug's game. Sometimes the producers of a show will tailor an opening episode to try to appeal to every body from Lionel Milling to the Mafia: an ethnic heehaw here, a sexual innuendo there, the pratfall and the tearjerk and the Nixon joke. This is like eating 10 years of leftovers at a single sitting; such shows will take a couple of months to find out whatever is dis tinctive about them. By that time the public will have already made up its mind, and the reviewers will be writing about nothing but specials on Afghanistani nomad culture.
