title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: Jimmy Breslin's recent Guest Word (which predicted an un favorable reaction, by Manhat tanbased reviewers, to his new novel World Without End, Amen) gives the impression that he is a spokesman for the workingclass semiliterates who heavily populate the bor ough of Queens. He may have a point in saying that the liter ary Establishment, the steadies at Elaine's, and even the re viewing staff of The Times, do not properly appreciate us. However, his posture as our defender bears some scrutiny.

title: Notes: Leaf Peepers Get Their Turn Again
description: AS days cool and the leaves begin to turn, many travelers are plan ning a fall foliage trip. The leaf peeping season, as it is somewhat mockingly called in New England, has just started in Maine and is expected to extend there at least through the third week in October. Elsewhere along the Eastern Seaboard, the leaves are likely to turn a little later, depending on the weather, but peak peeping time in many regions usually coincides, with the Columbus Day weekend, which this year is, Oct. 68. Should the season be a little late, the Veterans Day weekend, Oct. 2022, will give travelers another threeday period for a foliage trip.For those who enjoy participating in fairs and festivals along with color watching, a number of communities have planned events for the season. One of the biggest will take place Oct. 6 to 14 in North Adams, Mass., during the Northern Berkshire Fall Foliage Festival (more about this event in the next item).

title: PHILADELPHIANS END CHINA VISIl
description: SHANGHAI, Sept. 22  The Philadelphia Orchestra con ducted by Eugene Ormandy last night ended its visit tc China with a concert in the Auditorium of the Revolution ary Committee. Afterward there was a banquet attended by Chinese dignitaries. Innumer able toasts to friendship anc continued cultural interchange between China and the Unitec States were proposed.

title: Art Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: WHEN I read John Canaday's article about kids in mu seums (Hey, Look! And Other Principles of Es thetics, June 24) I was re minded of the Metropolitan Museum's knotty problems over the last half century; more than half a century. It was in 1912 that the museum first organized lectures in its galleries for high schools for the teachers and for stu dents. Discussions of the mu seum's responsibility to fur nish popular instruction transpired behind the scenes, with the secretary of the mu seum, Henry W. Kent, con stantly pressing new ideas in behalf of children, while the rest of the administration gave attention to expansion through acquisition and growth. In spite of the uneven emphases, the educational undertakings of the Metro politan were formally or ganized into a department.

title: Not a Bing, or a Gentele, but a Chapin
description: Everybody, except for a few cynics who knew him when, likes Schuyler Chapin. Just read his press notices: he is Mr. Popularity Plus, New York's newest outoftheblue celebrity. It was surely nothing personal, therefore, when a crisis arose at the Metropolitan Opera involving confidence in Chapin's leadership capabilities. That is why it took the board of directors, which had named him acting general manager following the death of Goeran Gentele, nearly 10 months of shillyshallying before finally deciding last May to award him the post outright for three years.

title: Selling schooling like groceries
description: A fable may dramatize the, true source of the nation's present discontent with our public schools: Suppose that, 50 or 75 years ago, the U.S. had adopted the same institutional arrange ments for the distribution of food as it did adopt for elementary and secondary schools. Suppose, that is, that the retail provision of groceries had been nationalized, that food was paid for by taxes and distributed by Governmentrun stores. Each family would be assigned to a store, as it is now assigned to a school, on the basis of its location. It would be entitled to receive, without direct pay ment, a collection of foods, as its children are entitled to receive a collection of classes. It would be able to choose among foods, as its children choose among subjects. Presumably this would be done by giving each family some number of ration points and assigning point prices to various foods. Private grocery stores would be permitted (just as private schools are), but persons shopping in them would be taxed for the support of the public stores just the same.

title: Tremor Hits Sicilian Area
description: AGRIGENTO, Sicily, Sept 22 (UPI)An earth tremor early today sent thousands of Sicil ians fleeing villages that suf fered heavy damage during the disastrous quakes of 1968, re gional officials said. title: If... ?
description: Science fiction seldom offers the opportunity to review two new novels by two genuine gi ants, all at once. Faced with TIME ENOUGH FOR LOVE by Robert Heinlein (Putnam, $6.95) and Arthur C. Clarke's REN DEZVOUS WITH RAMA (Har $6.35), one flounders in lein once published a future history that placed all the stories he had written (and all the stories he intended to write) in a chronology cover ing some thousands of years. One arresting feature was the lifeline marked Lazarus Long. Born in the late nineteenth cen tury, he was clearly a mutant, a member of a family, or group, or tribe known as the Howards.

title: Nothing but the Factsof Life
description: There has always been a dispiriting quality for me in books of sexual instruction. Descriptions of sexual activity taken out of the context of the drama of courtship and life in general seem to me dull, seldom erotic and very often misleading. I have always thought that good fic tion, even if it is as far removed from sexual explicitness as the novels of Henry James, teaches us more about the problems and joys of cou pling than the most detailed and clinically accurate sex manual ever will.

It had been revoked when Hodge was convicted in 1956. He was paroled from prison in 1963.

title: TWO MEN RESCUED ON CAPSIZED BOAT
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22 (AP)Two men who said they clung to their capsized trimaran in the Pacific Ocean for more than two months were rescued yesterday by a British steam ship, the Coast Guard reported.

title: Dance Mailbag
description: Writing recently in these pages on the New York City Ballet's summer season at Saratoga, Harry F. Gaugh, critic and teacher, comment ed that It was an exercise in predictability, and ques tioned whether the company performs as well in Saratoga as in New York. Following are responses to his article.

title: A.K.C. Sets Meeting to Educate Public
description: The first of a series of educational symposiums will be held by the American Kennel Club on Dec. 1, at Haddon Hall in Atlantic City, the day before the Board walk show. The theme is A Day with the A.K.C., and the program promises to be lively, varied and informa tive.

title: Katharine Rohrer Wed To Thomas G. Haight.
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 22  Miss Katharine Ani Rohrer and Thomas Griffith Haight were married here this afternoon in the Re formed Church by the Rev. Martin Punt.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:

title: This Week in Sports
description: In the final week of the regular schedule, the Mets will be aiming to triumphor at least be a factorin the National League's bizarre Eastern Division race. The Yankees will be anxious to close out a disappointing season.

title: Hans J. Wolflisberg Dies; ExPresident of Nestle
description: SOUTHBURY, Conn., Sept. 22  Hans Joseph Wolflisberg, former president and board Ichairman of the Nestle Cor poration, died Tuesday in Waterbury Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived here.

title: From the Vast Sahara, an Oasis Erupts...
description: In southern Tunisia, near the Algerian border, the vast empty reaches of the Saharawith its infinity of sensuous sculptured forms, glaring light and baking heatcreate a transcendent esthetic experience. Then suddenly, dramatically, the experience is height ened. An oasis erupts in splendid ex uberance, the simple forms replaced by a baroque tracery of palm trees, the alit softened and filterect, the heat tempered by shade and moisture. Gar dens, buildings, animals, people. Tour ist groups come from Tunis or Ham mamet or Djerba to experience an oasis and meet its residents: a boy swimming in an irrigation canal, fed from a timeless well; an old woman, her eyes seared by the sun; an inn keeper who says, There are three things I love above all elsesolitude, flowers and womem...in that order.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: I WISH to correct some factual errors in Eleanor Perry's statements rela tive to The Man Who Loved Cat Dancing, as quot ed by Judy Klemesrud in The Times (July 29).

title: The World
description: STOCKHOLM For some time now there have been suggestions of an un ease in Swedish society, of Trouble in Paradise, of a growing weariness with the costs of the prosperity and progress that have provided this country with one of world's highest standards of living.

title: Maryland Eleven Upsets North Carolina, 23 to 3
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Sept. 22 (AP)Al Neville, Mary land quarterback, passed for two touchdowns and set up a third one with a long pass, leading the Terrapins to a 233 upset victory over North Carolina today.

title: Survival or Extinction
description: By an encouragingly onesided vote, the House of Representatives has approved the strongest move yet made in Congress to save the scarce animal species of this planet from extinction. The bilk pushed chiefly by Representative John Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, would implement the historic convention for the protec tion of endarigered species, agreed to by eighty nations last spring. It would, moreover, replace the feeble law now on the Federal books.

title: London Company First; Pincay Wins 4 Straight
description: London Company displayed excellent turf credentials at Belmont Park yesterday in winning the 1mile Man hattan Handicap. The 3year old representative of the Chance Hill Farm flashed a formidable closing rally to beat Elmendorf's Big Spruce, with Triangular of the Ho beau Farm next in the field of 13.

title: 55% in Gallup Poll Disapprove Nixon's Performance in Office
description: A majority of the Americar people, 55 per cent, disap prove of President Nixon's performance in office, a Gallup Poll reports today.

title: Powell and Gross Spark Riverdale Victory, 248
description: Frank Bertino began his 30th year as head coach at Riverdale yesterday as he has begun most of the previ ous 29with a victory. Two scoring runs by Damon Powell and an outstanding day passing by Jonathon Gross gave Riverdale a 248 victory over Ardsley.

title: OffDuty Policeman And Friend Injured In Brooklyn Fight
description: An offduty 34yearold po liceman was shot and critically wounded and a friend was stabbed early yesterday in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn during an altercation with a dozen youths, the police said.

title: Plane Museum Is Planned in New Nassau Center
description: MINEOLA, L.I.  Long Is land's reputation as having been the cradle of aviation will be permanently memo rialized in a building in a new $44million Nassau County park at Mitchel Field, the former Air Force base.

title: Every act molds the public's perception
description: Having previously portrayed the character of one President, Emmet John Hughes now con templates how personal style can infuse the most original creation of the Founding Fath ers with life and leadership. What results is a discussion that is both perceptive and timely. Not only is that topic under much current agitation, but 1976 will markin addi tion to our bicentennialthe 100th anniversary of a signifi cant challenge to the durabili ty of the American Presidency. Hardly more than one decade after Appomattox, it suddenly seemed difficult to select a chief executive without further bloodshed.

title: Tribe Challenging Federal Authority On Its Gambling
description: MISSOULA, Mont., Sept. 22  Attorneys for, the Black Feet Indian tribal council, go ing into United States District Court, have challenged the right of agents of the Federal Bu reau of Investigation to confis cate slot machines and remove them from the reservation.

title: Bucknell Is Victor Over Boston U.
description: LEWISBURG, Pa., Sept. 22 Bob Langan, a halfback, scored three touchdowns to lead Bucknell to a 24.16 vic tory over Boston University today.

title: Dance
description: LONDON'S Festival Ballet is, in size at least, Brit ain's second company. It is a large and capa ble troupe, about the size of American Ballet Theater. The comparison, incidentally, stops right there. Now more titan 20 years old it is a strange company that seems to have had more downs than ups.

title: Reds Score By 119, Gain Title Draw
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 (AP)  Pete Rose hit a two run homer in the fifth inning as Cincinnati defeated Los Angeles, 119, today. The victory clinched at least a tie for the National League's Western division champion ship for the Reds.

title: A Business Summit by San Francisco Bay
description: SAN FRANCISCOA sizable chunk of the world's corporate wealth was represented last week in San Francisco. While the public meeting was laced with discussions of the epochal responsibili ties of the multinational corporation, champagne flowed freely from fountains at private parties and rented Cadillac limousines filled the streets around Nob Hill.

title: J. MURRAY MITCHELL, EXOFFICIAL OF NATO
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 J. Murray Mitchell, a retired hanker and a former assistant secretary general of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, died yesterday at his summer home in County Waterford, Ireland. He was 75 years old.

title: Moscow Jews Demonstrate To Protest Emigration Curb
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 22 (UPI)A group of Soviet Jews demon strated outside the central syn agogue here today with yellow Stars of David pinned to their lapels to protest the Govern ment's refusal to let them emigrate to Israel.

title: Executives' Pay Uproar
description: The proposed Phase 4 con trols on executive compen sation have, predictably, thrown big business into a state of irate confusion.

title: Poly PreP 1210 Victor
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 22 Eric Kipperman was the difference last night as Poly Prep of Brooklyn beat Pingry, 1210. Kipperinan, a fullback and defensive back, blocked a thirdquarter punt and ran 40 yards for the deciding score. He also intercepted a pass late in the game as Poly thwarted a Pingry rally.

title: AROUND THE
description: Unless rainfall is plentiful, watering will be essential for all newly planted shrubs, perennials, lawns and evergreens; continue until hard frosts. These plants must have moist root areas to establish themselves well for winter. Withhold all fertilizer at this time ... Start bulb planting and continue into November.

title: Politics as Unusual
description: WASHINGTONAs the revelations of Watergate continue to unfold, have noted a growing tendency to claim that such activity was an aber ration involving a few misguided zeal ots acting in an irresponsible manner and that the attention directed to Watergate represents a massive effort to discredit the President.

title: Diana Sands, 39, Dies of Cancer; Acclaimed for Raisin in the Sun
description: Diana Sands, the actress who won overnight critical acclaim for her stage portrayal in 1959 of Sidney Poitier's young sister in A Raisin in the Sun, died Friday night at SloanKettering Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases. She was 39 years old.

title: TWO MEN RESCUED ON CAPSIZED BOAT
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 22 (AP)Two men who said they clung to their capsized trimaran in the Pacific Ocean for more than two months were rescued yesterday by a British steam ship, the Coast Guard reported.

title: Calendar of Dog Shows
description: TODAY

title: Founder Leaving Brookdale
description: LINCROFTIn his five years at Brookdale Commu nity College, the college's founding president, Ervin L. Harlacher, said it was his in tention to accomplish 10 years of work.

title: Special Ambulances Aid Heart Victims
description: Two specially equipped am bulances that, in effect, bring the resources of a hospital emergency room to a heart attack victim, are being oper ated by New York Hospital and the Empire State Ambulance Service.

title: Christopher Stackpole Marries Miss Emory
description: Miss Margaret Woodnutt Emory, daughter of Mrs. John Martin Groome Emery of Westbury, L.I., and the late Mr. Emory, and Dr. Chris topher Wayne Stackpole, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Stackpole of Williamstown, Mass., were married here yes terday afternoon at the Wil Jiams Club by the Rev. Jo seph O'Rourke, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: READY FOR INSPECTION
description: 8BOB & CAROL & TED & ALICE  Twentyish married couple and thirtyish married couple explore their particu lar generation gap. With Anita Gillette, David Spielberg, Robert Urich and Ann Archer (ABC).

title: Shinn Art Shown in Trenton
description: TRENTON  An exhibi tion of works by Everett Shinn, a New Jersey mem ber of the controversial turn ofthecentury group, The Eight, is on view at the New Jersey State Museum until Nov. 25.

title: Hackensack Stops Wayne Valley, 250
description: Hackensack stamped itself as a favorite in Bergen Coun ty yesterday when it opened its season with a 250 vic tory over Wayne Valley in Hackensack.

title: PANAMA PRAISED FOR DRUG CURBS
description: PANAMA CITY, Sept 22  A year or so ago, Panama was being criticized both inside and outside the United States Gov ernment as having failed to stop the narcotics trade here. Now, it is receiving nothing but praise.

title: Amtrak Urges the Preservation Of Periled New London Station
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., Sept. 22Amtrak, the national rail passenger service, has proposed saving historic Union Station here from demolition by the city's Redevelopment Agency.

title: Maraziti: A Man in Constant Motion
description: BOONTON  Representa tive Joseph J. Maraziti of New Jersey's 13th Congres sional District is a perpetual motion machine come to life. Palms upturned, arms out stretched, hands on hips, pointing, standing, sitting, pacing  he never seems to run down.

title: Best Seller List
description: This analysis is based on reports obtained from more than 250 book stores in 110 communities of the United States. The figures in the right band column do not necessarily represent consecutive appearances.

title: Chile's Military Holding 30 Allende Aides on Isle
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 22 Thirty top aides of former President Salvador Allende Gos sens are being held prisoner on an island in the Strait of Ma gellan and about 7,000 people are imprisoned in the National Stadium in Santiago, a member of the ruling military junta an nounced today.

title: DENVER TO VOTE ON REGIONAL PLAT
description: DENVER, Sept. 22  In the second of three related fall elec tions, voters of the Denver area will decide on Tuesday whether to take another step toward metropolitan govern ment.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: ART

title: TACTIC PARLEY SET IN ALBANY BY G.O.P.
description: State Senate Majority Lead er. Warren M. Anderson has de cided to call his fellow Repub licans to Albany next month to take the unusual step of formulating a preliminary leg islative program before the reg ular session, where the Gov ernor traditionally takes, the lead in setting the agenda.

title: U.S. SCHOOL AID ROLE SEEN AS OVERRATED
description: A majority of Americans ser iously overestimates the Fed eral share of the financing of public schools, according to a survey made public last week.

title: U.S. to Help in 6Year International Effort to Learn Why Continents Move
description: A program of observations from pole to pole and from midcontinent to the greatest ocean depths has been outlined as the American contribution to a 52nation effort to under stand the process that is driv ing the continents hither and yon.

title: New U. S. Envoy in Sudan
description: KHARTOUM, The Sudan, Sept. 22 (UPI)The new United States Ambassador to the Su dan, William D. Brewer, pre sented his credentials to Presi dent Gaafar alNimeiry today. Mr. Brewer succeeds Cleo A. Noel Jr., who was assassinated by Palestinian guerrillas in Khartoum last March with his deputy, George C. Moore, and a Belgian diplomat.

title: Tunisians Report Moves To Expel 2 Soviet Envoys
description: TUNIS, Sept. 22 (Reuters) Tunisia has declared two So viet diplomats unwelcome, the official Tunisian news agency said today.

title: Cantor Renewing Liturgical Music
description: LAWRENCE, L. I.  The Book of Psalms exhorts Sing a new song unto the Lord and David Benedict coach and accompanist to top operatic stars, assistant professor of music, some time movie actor, White House visitor and cantor for Temple Israel hereis heeding the call.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Salmon Fry
description: MUSQUARO LAKE, Que bec  Less than 15 min utes after our bush pilot, Lionel Deraps, landed our Norseman float, plane on the placid waters of an unnamed lake high in the Musquaro River watershed in north eastern Quebec, Gordon Blair was fast to a good sized landlocked salmon that broke free on its first leap.

title: RUBY NEWMAN DEAD; BAND LEADER WAS 70
description: PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 23 (AP)  Ruby Newman, high society band leader, died Thurs day at the age of 70 in Pitts field General Hospital.

title: Pop Music: Gilbert O'Sullivan, WorkingClass Man
description: The setting of the perform ance was Las Vegas flash: a comedian, Marty Baris, as au dience softener; the girl singer following; the big orchestra, strings and all, and finally the star of our show bounding on stage to a fanfare. But Gilbert O'Sullivan stopped that partic ular image right there. His songs are quirkily personal and rooted firmly in the British working class, a long way from Broadway where O'Sullivan made his New York debut, Fri day, at the Avery Fisher Hall, formerly Philharmonic Hall.

title: Photography
description: SINCE I have made it a practiceindeed, a pol icyto nag periodically at the Metropolitan Mu seum of Art when it fails to pay due attention to photog raphy, it is only fair to com mend that institution for its record over the past year. During this period, the Met has presented exhibits by George Tice, Imogen Cun ningham, Paul Strand and Man Ray, along v ith the Painterly Photograph show and its current one, Early Photographers in Egypt and the Holy Land: 18481870. That's an impressive list, and a wellbalanced one.

title: STEUBEN PARADE LURES THOUSANDS
description: The last day of summer was brightened in the city yester day as the marchers in the 16th annual Steuben Day parade strode up Fifth Avenue, draw ing waves of applause from watchers and squeals of delight from childrenand causing a few minor traffic jams.

title: TEXTBOOKS ANGER HONG KONG REDS
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 22The Comsnanist press in Hong Kong has called on the government's Education Department to revise outdated history and geography textbooks that say nothing about the People's Republic of China.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONFor Henry A. Kis singer, the process of obtaining the advice and consent of the Senate to his nomination was carefully re corded by television cameras and newspaper headlines; for thousands of others, the process merits only a oneline listing in the Congressional Record.

title: Medical Programs
description: WASHINGTONOutrageous, was the brand that Senators Edward M. Kennedy and Alan Cranston stamped last week on a bill, shuttling around Congress since last spring, that is a perfect example of the Mexican stand off between the White House and Capitol Hill. The central issuethe Administration's direction of and sup port for Federal medical programs has long since been obscured by Con gressional log rolling and White House prestige.

title: Housing Policy
description: A little more than five years ago, in one of the last gasps of the Great Society, President Lyndon B. Johnson ceremoniously signed into law a bill that he declared could be the Magna Carta to liberate our cities. The Housing and Urban Development Act of 1968 authorized the Federal Gov ernment to subsidize the construction and rehabilitation, over the following 10 years, of some six million apart ments and singlefamily homes for poor families and those of moderate income, enough housing, as Washing ton saw it, to break the back of the nation's slumhousing problem.

title: Ratilekha, Govinda Offer Indian Dance In 12Solo Concert
description: Ratilekha and Govinda, two young American dancers of Indian parentage and great appeal, are attempting some thing worthwhile and interest ing in their presentation, The Sacred Dances of India.

title: The secret ingredient seems to be love
description: Jay Haley's new book asks us to rethink the question of how psychotherapy can make people change. Haley comes out of one of the highest energy groups of our time the Palo Alto research group that, in the midfifties, under anthropologist Gregory Bate son, formulated the double bind theory of schizophrenia. (A double bind is a set of mutually contradictory mes sages from which there is no exit: With a mother who com plains, Don't you love me? and then pulls uneasily away from the child's embrace, a child is always in the wrong.) As clinicians became aware that schizophrenics were the victims of disturbed patterns of communication in their fam ilies, the symptoms of schizo phrenia were looked at as the only possible escape route from intolerable situations, and finally deciphered as oblique countercommunications.

title: Polanski: Rosemary's Baby and After
description: IT is Polanski weather: gray, threat ening, with patches of fog, the weather of Knife in the Water and CuideSac, of Repulsion and Macbeth. The director is staying in a distinctly Raymond Chandlerish rented house in the hills above the Sunset Strip: a pretentious and run down Spanish folly, crowded with garish plantings and boasting a garden waterfall. It seems only appropriate that the house's owner is George Mont gomery, who played Philip Marlowe in a version of The High Window (The Brasher Doubloon, 1947), and that here Polantki has been completing with the writer Robert Towne the script for his new movie, a Chandlerish detective story of the thirties, China town, to start shooting at Paramount on Oct. 8.

title: Tickets, Tickets, Who's Got the Film Festival. Tickets?
description: I'M trying to buy as many tickets as I can. It's a surprise for my boy friend,, says the petite, curlyhaired girl in blue jeans and flannel shirt. Her name is Brenda Baum, she is a sophomore at NYU, and she's on the verge of tears. I won't be going to any of the movies myself. I've only got $14, and all the one and two dollar tickets are already sold.

title: Boy, 16, Given 30 Years In Strangulation of Girl
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Sept 20 (UPI)A 16yearold Columbia boy was sentenced yesterday to 30 years in prison for volun tary manslaughter in the strang ulation of a 7yearold girl.

title: Wendy L. Cudd Married Here To Robert Pile
description: Miss Wendy Lee Cudd, an interior decorator and painter in oils, was married here yesterday afternoon to Rob ert Edward Pile of New York and San Juan, Puerto Rico, a stockbroker with Harris Upham & Co. The Rev. Dennis W. K. Wagner per formed the ceremony in Christ Church Methodist.

title: Poet Confronts Problems of Exile in Work and Life
description: Last year, after a decade of controversy and conflict, Joseph Brodsky slipped into exile from his native Russia under circumstances that left it uncertain whether the final decision had been his own or his Government's.

title: China's Gift to the Island Providing Ducky Feasts
description: One hundred years ago, the Pekin duck was imported to this country from China. Its destination was Stonington, Conn., but 17 years later this white duck crossed the Long Island Sound and eventually became known here as the Long Island duck.

title: Watergate Panel to Focus On Excesses in Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 Samuel Dash, the chief counsel of the Senate Watergate com mittee, says that the panel, in its second round of public hear ings, will focus on determining how pervasive and systematic the attempts were last year by supporters of President Nixon's reelection campaign to under mine the Democratic opposition.

title: Music
description: INEVER would have imag ined long ago, when I was starting out as a jazz pianist, that so much of my time would be devoted not to playing in clubs, but in high schools, colleges, elementary schools and even kindergarten.

title: It's Like Looking At The Mind Of Andr Malraux
description: SAINTPAULDEVENCE.

title: Notre Dame Triumphs Over Northwestern, 440
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 22 (UPI)Tom Clements hit on nine of 12 passes for 152 yards and a touchdown and ran for two touchdowns him self in the first half today before retiring to the bench while Notre Dame defeated Northwestern, 440.

title: Autumn
description: The autumnal equinox passed through last night, but it didn't turn the color of one leaf, alter the tempo of one cricket's rasping, deepen or diminish the smell of autumn out where there are clouds of asters at the roadside.

title: Met Fans Shy Away From Predictions
description: Another Impossible Dream or just a premature night mare? Met fans who recalled the Cinderella events of 1969, when their team won the World Series, were wary yesterday of predicting that history would repeat.

title: Court Ruling On School Financing Is Awaited
description: TRENTONThe New Jer sey Supreme Court's land mark decision striking down the state's system of financ ing public schools will face its final legal test when the United States Supreme Court begins its fall term next week.

title: 35 Drown in the Ganges
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 22 (UPI) Some 35 women and children drowned when a boat capsized in the Ganges River yesterday, the Press Trust of India re ported today.

title: BERLIN ESCAPES BECOME RISKIER
description: BERLIN, Sept. 22An East German physician hid with his wife and daughter this week in a westbound truck, adding to the growing number of people who have fled to the West in the last few months.

title: U.S. Gives Arms to Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 22 (AP)The United States Military Assistance Command in Thailand has given the Thai Government 13 LVT7 tanks and six 105mm. howitzers to modernize its Marine Corps, The equipment was valued at $2.5million. An LVT is an am phibious tracked vehicle for beach landings.

title: For the Aged, a Daily Struggle
description: Anthony Roeters bought his flatroofed brick house in Woodside, Queens, 17 years ago so he wouldn't have to pay rent in my old age. But now at 86 years of age, his Social Security and pen sion are not enough to meet the basic needs of himself and his wife, Mary, 78.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Administration's attitude, pro fessedly for raisons d'tat, toward the Russian dissidents' cause should come as no surprise. It is totally in accord with its domestic behavior.

title: David Rockefeller Joins Unit For Urban League Dinner
description: David Rockefeller, chairman of the board of the Chase Man hattan Bank, has joined a group of business, labor and civic leaders as a committee member for the National Urban League's annual Equal Opportunity Day Dinner, scheduled for Nov. 14 in the Grand Ballroom of the New York Hilton Hotel.

title: It's Easy to Getto Allamuchy
description: ALLAMUCHYThis part of Warren County used to be a long way from the city, whether it was a major urban area of New Jersey or New York City. Now, a motorist can drive here in less than an hour from George Wash ington Bridge. That is be cause Interstate Route 80, designed to run across the coun try, is opened going west to a point about 10 miles beyond this rural community. Before last week, when the 3.5mile stretch from Parsippany Troy Hills to Denville was completed, only the motorist going east had the luxury of a noninterrupted 65mile run, except for a brief span from Denville to Route 202.

title: N.A.A.C.P. TO FIGHT U.S. HIRING ORDER
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 22The Na tional Association for the Ad vincement of Colored People is planing court action against a Department of Labor directive on minority group hiring.

title: American International Ends Bridgeport Skein
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 22 (AP)  Greg Davis and Jerry Stellmach combined for 259 yards rushing and four touchdowns today as Ameri can International upset Bridgeport, 3825, ending the nation's longest winning streak at 22 games.

title: Germany's Unsuccessful Tax Experiment
description: BONN  West Germany's experience with repayable tax surcharges has shown that they are fine in theory but hard to operate in prac tice.

title: Lap Fund of $34,000 Breaks Auto Record
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Sept, 22 (AP)A lap prize fund of $34,000 has been added to the purse for the Oct. 7 Na tional 500 stock car race at Charlotte Motor Speedway.

title: NIXON VETOES BILL ON DISASTER AID
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) President Nixon today vetoed amendments to the Small Busi ness Act, arguing that their dis aster relief sections were likely to cost the Federal Government $800million more a year and create an administrative night mare.

title: Sally A. Hamlin To Be a Bride
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 22Mr. and Mrs. Fran cis B. Hamlin Jr. have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sally Anne Hamlin, to Cullen Wal ter Coates Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Coates of Atherton, Calif.

title: Miss Brosnahan Wed to John Tassie Jr.
description: DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 22  Miss Penelope Rogers Brosnahan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent J. Brosna han, was married here, this afternoon to John Milton Tassie Jr. in a ceremony per formed by the Rev. Robert N. Back of St. Luke's Epis copal Church and the Rev. Pierre Batton of St. John's Roman Catholic Church. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. Tassie of New York and Mrs. Brogan Tassie of Princeton, N.J.

title: TIME RUNNING OUT IN PISA'S CONTEST
description: NSA, Italy, Sept. 16  Two months are left of a year's search for a way to prop up the endangered Leaning Tower and officials here say: The serious proposals should come in now. Not many have, so far.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Here is an alarming little news story. It is about eight men who went to Florida in 1972 with a mind to stage some sort of protest against the Vietnam war.

title: American Legion Unit Elects
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 23 (AP) Carle Wells of Atlanta was named national commander of the American Legion 40 & 8 yesterday. He succeeded Ralph Stovall of Memphis. The con vention drew 1,759 delegates from 50 states, Japan, Panama, Germany, France and the Dis trict of Columbia.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I take issue with your assessment [editorial Sept. 9] of Controller Beame's career in public life and his potential to be an outstanding Mayor of New York.

title: SAIGON AIDE SAYS GRAFT IS LIMITED
description: Foreign Minister Nguyen Phu Duc of South Vietnam defended his Government yesterday against reports that it was cor rupt and repressive.

title: On Cohabitation
description: WASHINGTON  Eight times as many couples are living together today without being married as cohabited ten years ago.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 24, 1973

title: Cardinal Grants Authority
description: BOSTON, Sept. 23 (UPI) Humberto Cardinal Medeiros, the Archbishop of Boston, con veyed special authority today on 800 Catholic nuns and lay parishioners to give Holy Com munion.

title: Bridge: When Everything Looks Good The Opening Lead Is Hardest
description: Bridge is a difficult game of chance, as one might con clude from a study of the most freakish deal in Satur day's play at the New York New Jersey Regional Champ ionships here.

title: August Shipments And Orders Grew For Machine Tools
description: Machine tool orders and shipments, in August showed gains over July and over August, 1972, the National Machine Tool Builders' As sociation reported over the weekend.

title: Coleman Wins 22d On 1Hitter
description: DETROIT, Sept. 23 (AP) Joe Coleman pitched a one hitter and Jim Northrup drove in two runs with his 11th and 12th homers, lead ing the Detroit Tigers to a 30 victory over the Boston Red Sox today.

title: StampsbyMail Program Starts
description: A dozen post offices in the northern half of New Jersey have distributed to 50,000 residents franked envelopes with instructions printed on them so that patrons can order stamps by mail. It is the first test in the metropol itan area of a new national postal service program.

title: Suit Charges False Data In a Deal Involving Scott
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23  Evidence gathered in a civil suit against the General Serv ices Administration suggests to persons close to the case a pat tern of irregularities in the award of a multimilliondollar Federal contract to a Philadellvant phia developer.

title: New Approaches Slated For Medical School Here
description: Dr. Thomas C. Chalmers, the director of the Bethesda, Md., Clinical Center of the National Institutes of Health, hopes to put some new approaches to medical education into prac tice when he becomes dean of the Mount Sinai School of Med cine of the City University of New York next week.

title: Nation's Planners Look Past Phase
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 After phase 4, what? Even as they prepare for the expected flood of autumn price increases. Administration policy planners have been thinking about how to deal with inflation in 1974 and beyond.

title: Boy Clawed in Maine
description: NEW GLOUCESTER, Me., Sept. 23 (AP)Aaron Moser, 11 years old, was reportedly attacked today by a bobcat near his home. He was badly scratched and was taken to Central Maine General Hospital in Lewiston where a series of rabies shots was started.

title: Chile's Junta Acting to Restore a Free Economy
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 23 Chile's ruling military junta has, begun to dismantle some of the institutions that drew attention to this country as a laboratory for the establishment of social ism through democratic con sent.

title: Charges of Political Favoritism Enter Maryland Building Fight
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 23  Charges of political favoritism have heightened a controversy over expanding efforts by Maryland state health officials to curb sewage flow through limitations on construction.

title: White Sox Beaten, 105
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (AP) The Oakland A's clinched their third straight American League Western Division championship today by de feating the Chicago White Sox, 105, for Vida Blue's 20th victory.

title: AGNEW'S COUNSEL MOVING TO BLOCK U.S. JURY INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23  Vice President Agnew has re portedly made a decision to confront headon, as a friend has put it, the possibility, that he may be indicted by a Federal grand jury in Baltimore for alleged bribery and extor tion.

title: AUSTRALIANS HAIL POLLOCK PURCHASE
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 23 Art authorities here wel comed as a coup for Australia the purchase of Jackson Pol lock's Blue Poles for $2mil lion ($1.49million Australian).

title: Perot: Supersalesman In Relief Controversy
description: A few years ago, when H. Ross Perot, the Texas computer millionaire, first sought entree to the huge, potentially lucrative world of New York welfare administration, his sales staff members reported they had no good contacts in state gov ernment to pursue.

title: WATERGATE PANEL MAY CONSIDER F.B.I
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., Sept. 23One of the subjects the Senate Watergate committee might take into consideration would be the future of the F.B.I., according to Fred Thompson, the chief minority counsel to the committee. His remarks were made in a news conference prior to a speech to students at the State Uni versity Center here.

title: N.B.C. Technicians Union Head Optimistic on Vote for Contract
description: Edward Lynch, president of the National Association of Broadcast Employes and Tech nicians, said yesterday that un ion leaders were not worried about rankandfile acceptance of the tentative agreement reached with the National Broadcasting Company Satur day night.

title: In a Chilean Farm Area, the Coup And the Reprisals Came Swiftly
description: TALCA, Chile, Sept. 23In this agrarian center, the mili tary coup d'tat of 12 days ago started early in the morning, when local army troops took control of the radio stations and ordered all leftist leaders to turn themselves in to the police.

title: Phils Blunt Cubs' Hopes, Rallying for 97 Victory
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 (AP)Ken Brett's tworun single capped a fiverun eighthinning counter rally today that carried the Phil adelphia Phillies to a 97 vic tory over the Chicago Cubs. The loss dropped the Cubs 3 games back of the divi sionleading New York Mets.

title: Mets' Records
description: BATTING

title: Canadian Grand Prix To Revson
description: MOSPORT, Ontario, Sept. 23 (AP)Peter Revson, an American driver for the British McLaren racing team, won the Grand Prix of Canada today after a rain delayed and confusing 200 mile Formula I race. His victory was good for at least $25,000 prize money.

title: School Football
description: LOCAL

title: I'd Like to Play Riggs, Says Miss Goolagong
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 23 (Reuters)Evonne Goola gong would like to play Bob by Riggs in Australia.

description: FIRST GAME

title: Measure for Measure
description: AUSTIN, Tex.The American farm er's parity ratio (prices received rela tive to prices paid) fell from 107 in 1951 to 70 in 1971. It was 78 by De cember 1972, and 102 by August 1973.

title: Maryland G.O.P. Election Prompts a Walkout by 80
description: BALTIMORE, Sept., 23 (UPI) The former head of the Mary land Committee for the Reelec tion of the President has been elected chairman of the divided Republican State Central Com mittee.

title: N.F.L. LineUps
description: AT DALLAS

title: Buddhism Retaining Its Hold in Burma
description: PAGAN, Burma, Sept. 12 This city of ruins is where the Burmese empire flou ished, where an 11thcentury King brought Buddhist monks to the arid plain to convert the spirit worshipers and ani mists. It is the city where craftsmen, buoyed by reli gious fervor, built brick and stucco temples and pagodas and monasteries covering 16 square miles.

title: The Times Names Picture Editor
description: Dane N. Bath, graphics edi tor of The Chicago Tribune, has been named picture edi tor of The New York Times, A. M. Rosenthal, managing editor of The Times, an nounced yesterday.

title: INCREASE IN FORCES APPROVED IN JAPAN
description: TOKYO, Sept. 23 (AP) Despite a lower court ruling that Japan's military forces are unconstitutional, Parlia ment approved two bills today increasing the size and scope of those forces.

title: 65% of Welfare Mothers Proving Disabled in Tests
description: Sixtyfive per cent of the mothers on welfare screened in a new city medical testing pro gram were found to have severe disabilities, according to city officials and represent atives of the medical labora tories administering the tests.

title: New Wing of Boston's Public Library Quietly Embodies Architecture's Best
description: BOSTONThis city has sleeping giant. The new wins of the Boston Public Library on Copley Square by Philip Johnson and John Burgee has opened without fanfare, watched only by architects and librarians who have rightly guessed that it would be one of the country's more important new buildings. In the curious mess that is this part of Boston's Back Baya series of striking new construction projects connected, to use the word loosely, by sloppy disorder that cannot even qualify as messy vitality  the library is outstanding. But it would be outstanding any where. It poses, and solves, a number of functional, struc tural, environmental and es thetic problems with mastery, and represents the kind of unity of program and solu tion that is what the best architecture has always been about.

title: Advertising: A Defensive Duo
description: It was with some embar rassment that Victor G. Bloede, toward the end of last week, gave a speech that was amazingly similar in thrust to one given three days earlier by David B. Mc Call.

title: British Rugby
description: RUGBY LEAGUE

title: Skylab 2 Flight Ends Tomorrow
TV: The Sorry State of Children's Programing
description: Once or twice a year, the duty to deal with children's programing on commercial television becomes inescap able. As the bulk of that programing is confined to Saturday mornings, dominat ed by cartoons and commer cials, the prospect is inevita bly dreary. This year, despite the pressures from various professional groups and de spite numerous dogood network seminars on the problem, the schedule is not just dominated but monop olized by cartoons and com mercials.

title: Certified Service Offered For Postal Mailgrams
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) The United States Postal Service announced today the inauguration of certified deliv ery service for large volume users of Mailgram, the postal letter that goes by wire.

title: CowboyStyle Wedding Reception in an Old Bank
description: Rosemary's wedding didn't take place in the safe deposit vault after all. This some what disappointed a few hundred friends and ac quaintances who trooped to the old hank at 110 Hudson Street in the nighttime wasteland between Green wich Village and Wall Street Saturday expecting to wit ness the ceremony.

title: PIANO WORKS PLAYED BY PINA ANTONELLI
description: Pina Antonelli, the pianist who gave a recital Saturday night at Tully Hall, has the kind of keyboard facility that enables her to skitter through Dohnanyi's Rhapsody in C, Khachaturian's Toccata and Liszt's Mephisto Waltz at high speed, and she did pre cisely that with a certain charm. She also gave a sturdier account of the BachLiszt Pre lude and Fugue in A minor, and a lighthearted one of a Haydn Sonata in D. Brahms's Paganini Variations had also been an nounced for the program, but they were replaced with two of Chopin's Etudes.

title: Six Drown in Florida
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 23 (AP)  Six persons fishing from a jetty at the mouth of the St. Johns River were swept off by a wave and drowned, the authorities said today. One victim was identified as Arthur Hagans of Jacksonville. Offi cials refused to release the names of the others but said all the victims were believed to be related.

title: Groups Criticize State's Mandatory Minimum Terms for NonDrug Offenses
description: Civilliberties groups and criminaldefense organizations are preparing a fullscale legal attack on new state mandatory minimum sentences for a vari ety of crimes, including rape, armed robbery and burglary.

description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 23 Juan D. Pern was elec ted president of Argentina again today, 18 years after he was ousted from power by a military coup d'tat.

title: World Unit Formed To Combat Disease Lethal to Coconuts
description: MIAMI, Sept. 23An Inter national Council to Combat Lethal Yellowing, a disease that is deadly to the coconut palm tree, has been formed by a group of scientists from around the world who met here last week.

title: Laird Insists There Will Be No Tax Increase This Y ear
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 Melvin R. Laird, President Nix on's chief adviser on domestic affairs, insisted today that there will be no tax increase this year.

title: INSTRUCTIONAL TV EXPANDS IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Sept. 23  New Jersey's Public Broadcasting Authority will begin its in structional television schedule tomorrow, broadcasting to an expanded student audience, of fering a larger variety of courses and, for the first time, producing one of its own shows.

title: GROUP CRITICIZES PATHFARE DELAY
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 23 (AP) A merchants group here is sued a protest today against any delay in hearings on a pro Iposed fare increase on the Port Authority TransHudson rail line.

title: Pop Music: 3 Approaches to the Guitar
description: Three guitarists who don't appear very often in New York combined Friday evening in Carnegie Hall to present a pan oply of possibilities for their instrument. John Fahey led off the bill and made the strongest, most individualistic impression. Fahey's style looks deceptively easy to imitate: digital dexter ity is hardly the point here. What he does is assemble sty listic and melodic fragments from all over America and then improvisatorily weave them in to medleys that suggest Indian ragas. Fahey's music is obses sive, with its strumming drones anti compulsive reiteration of short fragments and the effect is mystically hypnotic.

title: Angels' Ace Gains 20th
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Se?? 23 (AP)Nolan Ryan, su?? ported by Frank Robinso?? five runs batted in, became 20game winner for the fil?? time and moved closer to ?? major league season strip?? out record today as the Ca?? fornia Angels routed the Mi?? nesota Twins, 157.

title: Green, With 266, Takes Tour Golf by 6 Strokes
description: ENDICOTT, N. Y., Sept. 23 (AP)Hubert Green carded a 67 on the final round today for a total of 266, and won the $100,000 Broome County open golf tournament and pocketed $20,000. His score for 72 holes was 18 under par.

title: Sue Burgess, Interior Designer, Married to Paul K. Goldsmith
description: PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Sept. 23 The marriage of Miss Sue Gardner Burgess to Paul Kenneth Goldsmith, son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Gold smith of Rockville, Md., took place here this afternoon. State Supreme Court Justice Charles Tierney performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Carter L. Bur gess, parents of the bride.

description: AT RIVERSIDE Y.C. CORINTHIANS RENDEZVOUS

title: Alyce Gluer Bride Of Dr. Roger Rose
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Sept. 23 Miss Alyce JoAnne Gluer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eloy Gluer of Lakehurst, N. J., was married here this afternoon to Dr. Roger Miles Rose, a New York otolaryn gologist and the son of Mrs. BenHenry Rose of New York and the late Dr. Rose.

title: 65% of Welfare Mothers Proving Disabled in Tests
description: Sixtyfive per cent of the mothers screened in a new city medical testing program were found to have severe disabili ties, according to city officials and representatives of the med ical laboratories administering the tests.

title: English Terrorist Bombings Result in the First Fatality
description: LONDON, Sept. 23  The first death in the present out break of terror bombings in England occurred tonight when an army officer died who had tried to defuse a bomb in Bir mingham last Monday.

title: Watergate Panel Meets Today; Status of Other Inquiries Listed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 The Senate's Watergate hear ings, which resume tomorrow, are only one of many investi gations and legal proceedings now under way concerning( potential scandals that directly or tangentially involve Presi dent Nixon or his associates.

title: High Tide for Waters Adjacem to New York
Electric Ads Ordered Off
description: GLEN EDEN BEACH, Ore., Sept. 23 (UPI)Gov. Tom Mc Call ordered today that electric advertising signs be turned off throughout Oregon to conserve energy. He said he had received conflicting opinions about the legality of his order and said a court test may be inevita ble.

title: MRS. ALEXANDER CAVEN
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Sept. 23Mrs. Louise Place Caven, widow of former Mayor Alex ander Caven and a former member of the national board of the Young Women's Chris tian Association, died yesterday in Vassar Hospital. She was 80 years old.

title: Braniff and Air Pilots Agree, Ending FiveMinute Strike
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) Braniff International Airways and the Air Line Pilots Associ ation reached a contract agree ment early today, ending a strike by flight attendants five minutes after it began.

title: Chilean Refugees Denied Passes to Leave Country
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 23 The military junta here has notified foreign embassies that Chilean citizens will no longer be given safeconduct passes for political asylum abroad, foreign diplomatic sources here disclosed today.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: CABBY SHOT IN HEAD IN BROOKLYN HOLDUP
description: A 25yearold Brooklyn taxi cab driver who got his chauf feur's license only last month was shot and seriously wounded last night by a holdup man in he BedfordStuyvesant section.

title: Mrs. Joan Windell Rewed
description: TEANECK, N. J., Sept. 23 Mrs. Joan Ruth Abrams Windell of Teaneck was mar ried here this noon to Mort Rubenstein, a widower and creative consultant to Via corn International, the tele vision and cable company. Rabbi Louis J. Sigel per formed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Nor man Landau, brotherinlaw and sister of the bride, whose former marriage ended in divorce. Mrs. Rubenstein is a graduate of Brooklyn College and her husband of Cooper Union.

title: Brazilian Opposition Elects
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 23 The opposition Brazilian Demo cratic Movement last night nominated its chairman, Elisses Guinaraes, 56 years old, to op pose the Government's candi date, Gen., Ernesto Geisel, in the presidential election cam paign. General Geisel's victory is assured by an overwhelming Government majority in the Electoral College, which will meet to choose a President next Jan. 15.

description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23 (AP)  Lefthander Jimmy Connors defeated Tom Ok ker, 75, 76, to capture the Pacific Southwest tennis championship today.

title: Top U.S. Drug Aide Says City Will Get More Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 The country's top narcotics treatment official predicted to day that New York City would receive a greater share of new Federal narcotics  treatment funds, and promised to cut red tape.

description: The Mets are not the only team to have stirred pennant fever. Following are tempera ture readings, high and oth erwise, from other contend ers' cities:

title: A REBEL ON CYPRUS FEARS PLOT ON LIFE
description: ATHENS, Sept, 23  Gen. George Grivas, the Cyprus underground leader, has de nounced what he said was a plot to catch or kill him to elim inate his opposition to a Greek Turkish settlement in Cyprus.

title: The Committee's Task
description: As the Ervin committee resumes its hearings today with its focus now on abuses in the 1972 election cam paign, no oneand least of all the committee members themselvesshould view its business as a mere tidying up of leftovers. The public interest demands that the hearings continue with all the thoroughness necessary to unfold the entire pattern of corrupt and unlawful practices for which Watergate has become the label.

title: Both Sides in Cambodia Seem Exhausted By Fierce Combat, but No End Is in Sight
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sept. 23After three months of extreme ferocity, the war in Cambodia seems to have bled both sides to the point of exhaustion, and although the fighting is far from over, major crises in the next few months seem unlikely.

title: Blanda Kicks End Dolphin String, 127
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 23 The Oakland Raiders, who had not contributed to it while it lasted, ended the 18 game winning streak of the Miami Dolphins today with a deceptively decisive 127 vic tory fashioned by George Blanda's four field goals and a stifling defense.

title: 20NATION GROUP PUTS OFF CHANGE IN MONEY SYSTEM
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 23 Finance ministers from 20 na tions who have been made re sponsible for developing an im proved world monetary system decided today not to negotiate any further here but instead to set themselves a deadline of next July 31 for agreement on all the main issues involved.

title: State Mental Health Association Joins In Defense of Embattled Dr. Sussman
description: NEWARK, Sept. 23  The New Jersey Association for Mental Health has joined consumer groups in the state that are backing Dr. Oscar Sussman, the controversial consumerhealth director, who has been stripped of his powers to close kitchens at state institutions where un sanitary condi tions are found. In a letter to Governor Cahill, Richard C. Har denbergh, the as sociation president, said his group supports the desig nated and responsible staff of the State Department of Health in its efforts to bring the New Jersey psychiatric hospitals up to acceptable sanitary standards.

title: Save the City Opera
description: Under strong prodding from Mayor Lindsay, repre sentatives of the New York City Opera and its unionized musicians have begun a lastditch effort to save that deficitridden institution, now threatened with extinction by a threeweekold strike. The chief point at issue is the opera's desire to scale down its present guarantee of 11 weeks of extra pay for work outside the regular season. That guarantee began when the poor man's opera conducted a summer festival of light opera; now much of the pay goes for no work.

title: Dr. Marland Steps Down
description: When Sidney P. Marland Jr. became United States Commissioner of Education in 1970, his qualifications an administrator of proved talents seemed appropriate to deal with the serious internal problems in the sprawling Office of Education. Before long, however, it became evident that the Nixon Administration viewed the job of the chief education official  Dr. Marland was later elevated to Assistant Secretary for Education in the Department of Health, Education and Welfareas primarily one of image  building. The desired image was one of progress, when the realities were those retrenchment.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: New York Typographical Union 6 voted to end its 17month strike against the defunct Morning Telegraph and to remove its picket lines from The Daily Racing Form, a sister newspaper published by Triangle Publications in Hightstown.

title: 4 Youths Charged With Defrauding Telephone Company
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Sept. 23 (UPI)Suffolk. County po lice said yesterday that four Long Island youths had been charged with tampering with [telephone equipment to make calls worth an estimated total or $100,000 to such places as Shanghai, the United States Embassy in Moscow and a guard shack at Buckingham Palace.

description: HOUSTON, Sept. 23On the flight director's console at Mis sion Control here is a glass tank containing a small female spi der named Arachne, for the woman in Greek mythology who tried to outweave Minerva and was turned into a spider.

title: The Atlantic Gap
description: PARIS, Sept. 23Even be fore they start negotiating on a declaration about their spe cial relations, Western Europe and the United States have found themselves in apparent disagreement on the purpose of the exercise.

description: MOSCOW, Sept. 23Soviet authorities arrested a Latvian Jew today for demonstrating outside the Communist party's Central Committee building and detained an American correspondent covering the event, seizing his film forcibly.

title: SPASSKY AND BYRNE PAIRED IN TOURNEY
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 23 (AP) Boris Spassky, who lost the world chess championship to Bobby Fischer in the summer of 1972, will face Robert Byrne of the United States in the first round of the Candidates Matches next year.

description: Sept. 27 Lottery Drawing Advanced

title: CABINET SEARCH BEGINS IN GREECE
description: ATHENS, Sept. 23  Greece today entered a week of gov eriimentmaking that will test the militarybacked regime's avowed plans to restore parlia mentary democracy.

title: Yanks Top Cleveland, 91 and 21
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 23  Having won only four of their last 13 games, the hap less New York Yankees stirred themselves suffi ciently today to take a dou bleheader from the last place. Cleveland Indians, 91 and 21.
