description: GERMANAMERICAN LEAGUE

title: BLACK HOLE TIED TO FOREST DAMAGE
description: Two physicists have proposed that the event that leveled forests in a wide region of Siberia on June 30, 1908, was the passage of a black hole that plunged completely through the earth.

title: Kennedy Visit to Yacht Race Cost Government $600,000
description: BOSTON, Sept. 23 (UPI)A visit by President Kennedy and his family to the America's Cup yacht races in Newport, R. L, in 1962 cost the Government $600,000, a General Services Administration official said today.

title: Many Home Buyers Are Disappointed By the Shortage of Mortgage Money
description: For many middleclass work ing Americans, buying a house js rapidly becoming beyond reach. They cannot get a mort gage, or if they qualify for one, they cannot afford it.

title: Case Dropped for 3 in Alleged MunicipalLoan Fraud
description: A criminal case against three men accused of defrauding the city's Municipal Loan Program has been dropped for lack of proof that city officials tried hard enough to avoid being duped.

title: Reds Stalled by Dodgers
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23 (AP)Steve Garvey and Tom Paciorek slugged tworun homers and the Los Angeles Dodgers whipped Cincinnati, 64, today and prevented the Reds from clinching the Na tional League's Western Di vision title.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Opponents of a massive recreational property devel opment in the Catskills say they will keep fighting the project even though the two towns involved and the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation have given the necessary approval for its completion.

title: Degrees Awarded To a Prison Class
description: WEST WINDSOR, Sept. 23 Twentyeight men, traditionally capped and gowned, if untradi tionally attentive and disci plined, received degrees in arts and sciences this afternoon from Dr. Richard K. Green field, president of Mercer County Community College, at an unusual commencement ex ercise in the college auditor ium.

title: GOING OUT Guider
description: JAZZ The Downbeat, on the southwest corner of Lex ington Avenue and 42d Street (9721082), was once a Long champs restaurant, and it still looks pretty much like one, sleek and a bit formal. For five years it has been the Downbeat, with live jazz on the menu.

title: Dave Anderson
description: In the confusion, at least the New York Giants showed a sense of history. On their last play at Yankee Stadium, a 14yard field goal by Pete Gogolak salvaged a 2323 tie with the Philadelphia Eagles yesterday. The tie was like kissing your nearest season ticketholder goodbya re minder of the glory years when the chant in the upper deck was Deefense, Deefense and a reminder of the disaster years when the chant was Goodby, Allie. Now the Giants are somewhere in between. Artistically as well as geographically. In complaining that the field goal shouldn't have been permitted, Mike McCormack, the Eagles' coach, growled, I don't think the Giants were set, they were still moving. He meant at the line of scrimmage. He could have meant moving to New Haven and eventually to New Jersey, if the proposed stadium there ever replaces the swamp rats. But while the Eagles griped, Alex Webster smiled.

title: HalfCompleted Project Still Fought in Catskills
description: ROCK HILL, N. Y., Sept. 23 Opponents of a massive recreational property develop ment in the Catskills say they will keep fighting the project even though both the towns and the State Department of Environmental Conservation have given the necessary ap proval for its completion.

title: The Pennant Race
Vatican Says It Takes No Position on Chile
description: ROME, Sept. 23A spokes man said today that the Vatican had not taken any formal position on the military Government in Chile.

title: Body of Pilot Is Located
description: BECKET, Mass., Sept. 23 (AP)The body of a West Hart ford, Conn., pilot was found today in the wreckage of his singleengine private plane in dense woods off U.S. 20 near Sherwood Forest, the state po lice reported. The victim, Jaro slow Luckan, 37 years old, was pronounced dead at the scene. The plane had left Brainard Airport in Hartford yesterday morning, en route to Rochester, and investigators said they be lieved the crash occurred some time yesterday.

title: U.S.Company ls Granted 117Million Iraq Contract
description: BEIRUT, Sept. 23Iraq has awarded a $117million con tract for construction of crude oil exporting facilities in the Persian Gulf to Brown & Root, Inc., an American company, the Iraq news agency announced today.

title: Suit Charges False Data In a Deal Involving Scott
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23  Evidence gathered in a civil suit against the General Serv ices Administration suggests to persons close to the case a pat tern of irregularities in the award of a multimilliondollar Federal contract to a Philadel phia developer.

title: David Roaman, Built Chain Of Women's Apparel Shops
description: David Roaman, chairman since 1966 of Roaman's, Inc., a chain of women's apparel shops, died Saturday at his home, 25 Cen tral Park West. He was 67 years old.

title: PERON AND WIFE WIN IN ARGENTINA
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 23 Juan Z. Perlin tonight won his third term as President of Argentina after his chief rival, Ricardo Balbin of the Radical party, conceded victory with nearly 90 per cent of the votes counted.

title: Realism In Dtente
description: BOSTON, Sept. 23  In granting trade advantages to the Soviet Union, Should the United States require con cessions to human rights? As Con gress grapples with that profound question, it is important to remember the human realities involved. Hence a story.

title: Nixon Signs a Bill Making Dollar Devaluation Formal
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (Reuters)  President Nixon, signed a bill this weekend for mally devaluing the dollar by 10 per cent. The devaluation has been effective since the Ad ministration announced it last February.

title: The Screen: 'Harry in Your Pocket':James Coburn Is Star of Pickpocket Film
description: The peripatetic world of pickpockets has provided the producer-director Bruce Geller, who gave television audiences "Mission: Impossible" and "Mannix" with the material for a promisin??? debut in feature films."Harry in Your Pocket??? playing at the Forum and Riviera theaters, is a film of many pleasures, not the leas??? of which is the thoroughgoing professionalism that sets ???its goals  good perfor???ances, eye-catching settings, absorbing storyand achieves every one of them with clean precision.Below the glossy surface of things, this is also a film with something to say about crime and morality, jealousy and loyalty, youth and age and the pleasures of craftsmanship in a world where everyone wants to start at the top and no one wants to serve an apprenticeship.For those who know nothing of the art of picking pockets, the movie is a kind of a vocational school and a type of Berlitz school. The vocational school offers an education in the techniques of picking pocketsthe work of cannons (master pickpockets), steerers (victim spotters) and stalls (who distract victims). From the Berlitz comes a language of kicks (pockets) and holding (retaining possession of a poke, or wallet.).The teachers are James Coburn as Harry, the cannon whose first law is ???Harry Never Holds"; Wal??? Pidgeon as the steerer, ???d Michael Sarrazin and his girl friend, Trish Van De???re, who hire on with the two old pros as stalls.Mr. Coburn covets not only cash and credit cards but Miss Van Devere. Mr. Sarrazin covets Mr. Coburn's skills and success; Mr. Pidgeon covets cocaine and immortality of a sort, and Miss Van Deverewell, without her, things would be a lot less interesting.For all its polish, there is a bittersweetness to "Harry in Your Pocket" and moments reminiscent of "The Hustler" and "The Cincinnati Kid." You'll come away from it checking your pockets, but not because it has taken your money without giving good entertainment in return.

title: Text of the European Economic Community's Proposal on Relations With U.S.
description: Following is the text of a proposal by the European Economic Community for a joint declaration on relations between the Common Market and the United States:

title: Some Answers to NotSoEsoteric Monetary Questions
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) The world's top financial ex perts have gathered in Nairobi, Kenya, to try to speed up the slow pace of international monetary reform. Even with a push, the job will not be a quick one. The debate may ap pear esoteric to most Ameri cans, but the new monetary rules that are eventually writ ten could have enormous impli cations for world trade, jobs, prices and the ease and cost of travel. Here are some of the issues involved in the nego tiations:

title: Guerrilla Office in Berlin Angers Jews
description: BERLIN, Sept. 23The open ing of a Palestinian guerrilla mission in East Berlin and other undercover Arab activi ties have stirred a furor in West Berlin, particularly among the Jewish population.

title: LoveaFair Shows Power of Urban Togetherness
description: Yoga devotees stood on their heads on stage in the Central Park Sheep Meadow yesterday. Nearby, Althea Gibson gave beginners a first tennis lesson. Members of the Hare Krisna sect distrib uted sticky fruitandnut luglus, and bare feet pre dominated as hundreds of people held hands to dance in a human energy chain.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today; Sept. 24, 1973
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Listed to speak in general debateBrazil, Unit ed States, Peru, Ecuador, Singapore, Cameroon (tenta tive), Norway, Nicaragua, Ire land and Paraguay.

title: Recently Published Books
description: A Dream Play, by August Strind berg, adapted by Ingmar Berg man, interoduced and translated by Michael Meyer (Dial Press, $6).

title: She Is Woman
description: BALTIMORE The American woman is the most cherished, the luckiest, the best loved, the richest woman in the world. She has the most things, the best men, the happiest children, the biggest houses. Why then are Ameri can women worrying about the prob lems of American women? If we are so damned lucky, what is all the fuss and fury about?

title: Costa Concreto
description: The Mediterranean coast of Spain is still dotted with the rough stone ruins of Roman watchtowers and Moorish castles but they do not stand alone. Crowding the play grounds of the Costa Brava, the Costa Blanca and the Costa del Sol are the modern highrise hotels and apart ment houses that have turned Spain's once placid shores into a concrete desert.

title: Benita Valente and Rita Shane Make Met Debuts
description: If the Metropolitan Opera has as good luck with all the American singers it takes into the company this year as it did with those who made their debuts in the Saturday matinee performance of Mo zart's Die Zauberflte, it will have much to rejoice in.

title: Green, With 266, Takes Tour Golf by 6 Strokes
description: ENDICOTT, N. Y., Sept. 23 (AP)Hubert Green carded a 67 on the final round today for a total of 266, and won the $100,000 Broome County open golf tournament and pocketed $20,000. His score for 72 holes was 18 under par.

title: CONGRESS FUNDING UNDER CHALLENGE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 Around the halls of Congress it's known as playing the money gameauthorizing vast amounts of money for various programs, but appropriating much smaller sums.

title: Nixon Back in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP)  President Nixon returned to Washington tonight from his retreat at Camp David, Md., where he combined work and relaxation over the weekend.

title: Chavez's Battered Farm Union Embarks on a Rebuilding Effort
description: FRESNO, Calif., Sept. 23 The United Farm Workers Uni on is in trouble, but the dele gates to the union's first con stitutional convention are busy building their labor organiza tion, not burying it.

title: I Always Vote, the Mayor Says, but the Question Is: For Whom Nov. 6??
description: Now that it is certain that Mayor Lindsay will not run for reelection, the new guessing game at City Hall is: Will he endorse any of the candidates seeking his joband if so, when?

title: Books of The Times
description: THE MARRIED LOVERS. By Julius Horwitz. 202 pages. Dial. $6.95.

title: Alouettes Upset Argos
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 23 (UPI) The Montreal Alouettes, paced by an outstanding de fensive effort, scored an up set 1910 victory today over the Toronto Argonauts.

title: Chicagoan Buying McCall's Magazine
description: McCall's, the centuryold women's magazine with a cir culation of 7.5 million a month, will be sold by Norton Simon, Inc., to Chicago interests for an undisclosed amount of cash and notes next week.

title: FIXEDTERM LAWS DRAW OPPOSITION
description: Civilliberties groups and criminaldefense organizations are preparing a fullscale legal attack on new state mandatory minimum sentences for a vari ety of crimes, including rape, armed robbery and burglary.

title: Party Unanimously Picks Mrs. Meir to Head Slate
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 23 (AP) Israel's dominant Labor party chose Premier Golda Meir una nimously today to lead its list of candidates in the general elections Oct. 30, virtually as suring her of another four years in office.

title: Mansfield Hoping for a Cut Of $6Billion in Arms Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI) The Senate Democratic lead er, Mike Mansfield of Montana, said today he hoped that close to $6billion could be cut out of the $21.9billion military pro curement bill now on the Sen ate floor.

title: Concorde Lands in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (Reuters)The Concorde, the BritishFrench supersonic air liner, landed here today on its first Washington visit, The craft arrived at Dulles Interna tional Airport after a flight from the DallasFort Worth air port for a fourday visit.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: RIDGEWOOD, Sept. 23  This busy Bergen County community seems destined to have a transplanted Okla homan by way of Texas move into town next year. He's Lindy McDaniel, the New York Yankee pitcher, who is about to purchase a twostory colonial home on the east end of the township.

title: Civic Group Asks Rise in Workload For City U. Staff
description: The Citizens Budget Commis sion, a nonpartisan civic group, said yesterday that the City University of New York could save from $26million to $34 million a year by increasing the faculty workload without di minishing the quality of educa tion.

title: LIBYAN OIL CHIEF WARNS CONCERNS
description: VIENNA, Sept. 23Any at tempts by Western oil com panies to boycott Libyan oil during the current nationaliza tion dispute will be met by a general shutdown in the fields of the major exporting nations, Libya's Oil Minister, Ezzedin A. Mabruk, has said in an inter view.

title: Sydney: Opera House to Open, at Last
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 23After prolonged contro versy, frustrating delays and evermounting expense, the spectacular architectural cre ation known as the Sydney Opera House is at last about to open its first season on Friday. Some critics say the big white edifice on the wa terfront, designed to look like a ship under full sail, should be called anything but an opera house. For one thing, limited space in the performing area prevents the presentation of a full range of grand opera. We can't put on Aida, a spokesman for the project said recently. But how often do you want to go to Aida, anyway?

title: PESSIMISTIC VIEW OF FUTURE ISSUED
description: MENLO PARK, Calif., Sept. 23The Institute for the Fu ture has issued a sweeping and somewhat pessimistic, forecast on the next decade.

title: Fire on Saratoga Put Out; Inquiry Into Cause Begun
description: PORTSMOUTH, Va., Sept. 23 (UPI)A fire on the third deck of the giant aircraft carrier Saratoga was extinguished early today after burning for nine hours.

title: YUGOSLAV PURGES OF PARTY STEP UP
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 23  A new wave of purges is under way in Yugo slavia's League of Communists to make the party ideological ly pure before its crucial 10th Congress early next year.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Angela and Philip Bloom have arranged Wood n Straw East, their shop at 1727 Sec ond Avenue between 89th and 90th Streets, to look as much like a Haitian market as pos sible. The walls are covered with carved wooden masks and plaques as well as rather lurid paintings, which Mrs. Bloom characterizes as prim itive art. She says they ap peal to a customer immedi ately, or not at all.

title: Personal Finance
description: If you have purchased a new house, registered a new car, subscribed to a maga zine, ordered a catalogue or in any way given your name and address to a profitmak ing organization, chances are very strong that your mail box will be filled shortly thereafter with a wide variety of junk mail.

title: Kissinger Speaks at U.N. Today, Marking Entry Into the Club
description: Henry A. Kissinger flew to New York yesterday for three days of intensive diplomatic discussions that will mark his entry into what Dean Rusk, one of his predecessors as Secretary of State used to call the club of foreign ministers.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 23Tak ing advantage of Montreal errors committed under the pressure of the tightest of pennant races, the Pittsburgh Pirates today captured a dou bleheader and moved to within a halfgame of the New York Mets.

title: AllWoman Bill at the Film Forum
description: Under the collective title Inside Women or Por trait of the Artist as a Young Woman, a program of six short films ranging from the surreal to the documentary ushered in the fourth season of the Film Forum last week end. The program will be re peated next weekend.

title: Donizetti Maria Stuarda Opens 19th Chicago Lyric Opera Season
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 23  The 19th season of Chicago's Lyric Opera has opened at the Civic Opera House here with a pro duction of Gaetano Donizetti's 139yearold, threeact bel can to work, Maria Stuarda.

title: Joe Suffers A Shoulder Separation
description: Joe Namath went to Lenox Hill Hospital yesterday on the return of the Jets from Balti more. The injured quarter back will remain there until Dr. James Nicholas, the team's orthopedist, decides whether an operation is nec essary on his right shoulder.

title: A New Presidency
description: Long before the Watergate crimes brought Mr. Nixon's White House into disrepute, there had been widespread concern that the office of the Presidency had somehow become bloated, unresponsive, unduly secretive, out of touch with the people and perhaps even with reality.

title: Plane Crash Hurts 2 Thais
description: BANGKOK, Sept. 23 (Reu ter)Two women were slight ly injured by flying wreckage when an American Phantom jet crashed near the Ubon Ratch athani air base in northeastern Thailand, a United States mil itary spokesman said today.

title: MAYOR ENTERS MUSICIANs' TALKS
description: Mayor Lindsay intervened personally yesterday in an ef fort to avert a threatened can cellation today of the New York City Opera season be cause of a strike by union mu sicians.

title: WILLIAM COWGILL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 William Warwick Cowgill, vice president in charge of the war products division of the United States Rubber Company (now Uniroyal) in World War II, died yesterday at the Washington Hospital Center. He was 80 years old and lived in Fairfield, Conn.

title: Susanne Lyons Is Wed to F. H. Kass 3d
description: WEST ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 23Miss Susanne Joan Lyons, a student at Trinity College in Washington, and Frederic Henry Kass 3d, who is in his fourth year at the George Washington University School of Medicine, were married here this evening at Mayfair Farms. The ceremony was performed by Judge Julius A. Feinberg of the Essex County Court.

title: At Garden Tonight
description: FIRST GAME

title: $60Million in Help To New Immigrants Is Planned in Israel
description: Histradrut, Israel's labor federation, will undertake a fouryear, $60million program of vocational training, health services and cultural work among new immigrants, includ ing the heavy influx of Russian Jews.

title: Intruder Attacks Olivier In Actor's Brighton Home
description: LONDON, Sept. 23  Lord Olivier was attacked by an in truder yesterday in his home in Brighton, 50 miles south of London. He was hit on the face and his glasses were broken but he was not seriously hurt, the National Theater reported today.

title: 2 Quints Oft Respirators
description: DENVER, Sept. 23 (UPI) The five surviving Stanek sex tuplets completed their first week of life today with two of them well enough to be taken off respirators, an apparent victory over a lung disorder that claimed the life of their sister.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The team that Casey Sten gel used to call my amazing Mets amazed 54,701 fans in Shea Stadium yesterday by defeating the St. Louis Cardinals, 52, and storming to their sixth straight vic tory.

title: 600 Bengalis, Pakistanis Freed and Flown Home
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 23 (AP)More than 600 Ben galis and Pakistanis were repat riated today by United Nations chartered aircraft in two flights between Lahore and Dacca and Karachi and Chittagong, offi cial sources said.

title: Whitworth Wins Golf At Portland
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 23 (AP)Kathy Whitworth shot a par 73 in a steady drizzle today to win the $30,000 Portland golf tournament, her third straight pro victory.

title: The Pierrepont: A Brooklyn Horror House
description: Hotels often provide a bro chure that lists their serv ices, but according to some Brooklyn residents, the best place to read about the Pier repont Hotel in Brooklyn Heights may be the police blotter of the 84th Precinct.

title: Pablo Neruda, Nobel Poet, Dies in a Chilean Hospital
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 23 Pablo Neruda, a Nobel Prize winner who was regarded as one of Latin America's great est poets, died tonight in the Santa Maria Clinic. He was 69 years old.

title: PARADE IN HARLEM DRAWS THOUSANDS
description: Gregory Brown, 2 years old sat spellbound atop a police barricade on Seventh Avenue in Harlem yesterday, and when he spotted a colorful float of musicians  complete with a towering man in scarlet robes and headdresshe almost fell off his perch.

title: Gold Wire Worth $55,000 Stolen at Kennedy Airport
description: A $55,000 cargo of gold wire, destined for shipment to Singa pore, was stolen from an air freight terminal near Kennedy International Airport.

title: MRS. CLARENCE PICKETT
description: MEDFORD, N.J., Sept. 23 Mrs. Lilly Peckham Pickett, widow of Clarence E. Pickett, who was executive secretary of the American Friends Service Committee from 1929 to 1950, died yesterday in the Medford Leas Retirement Community. She was 91 years old.

title: His Dream House Resembles An Ark in a Couple of Ways
description: SOUTH SALEM, N.Y.It's no Mount Ararat, that wood ed swell of land cleared this summer by the Rev. Jack S. Miller and his team of ama teur construction workers.

title: CHARLES PREVIN, 86; MUSICAL DIRECTOR
description: HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 23 (UPI) Charles Previn, an Academy Awardwinning musical direc tor, who led George Gershwin's first Broadway show, La La Lucille, died here yesterday. He was 86 years old. Mr. Previn won an Oscar in 1937 for the musical scoring of 100 Men and a Girl.

title: British Rugby
description: RUGBY LEAGUE

title: Cliburn Is Challenged To Battle of the Sexes
description: MANILA, Sept. 23 (UPI) Susan Starr, an American pianist, has challenged Van Cliburn to a musical battle of the sexes.

title: Fuller Warren of Florida Dies; Served Two Terms as Governor
description: MIAMI, Sept. 23 (AP)  Former Gov. Fuller Warren died today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 67 years old.

title: Hart's Passing Leads Cards To 3427 Upset of Redskins
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 23.  In a stirring game marked by consecutive 97yard kickoff returns in a 34point fourth quarter, the St. Louis Cardi nals upset the Washington Redskins, 3427, today. The Cardinals, who have an attack minded new coach in Don Coryell, went right at the Redskins' strength, pass de fense, and shattered it.

title: Canadian Grand Prix To Revson
description: MOSPORT, Ontario, Sept. 23 (UPI)Peter Revson of New York, driving a McLar en, came from behind today and won the Canadian Grand Prix, which was marked by confusion and controversy over the actual winner.

title: STRANGLER SOUGHT IN WOMAN'S DEATH
description: WRIGHTSTOWN, Sept. 23 (AP)The police are searching for the strangler of a woman whose body was found in the back seat of her car 200 feet from a Methodist church here this afternoon.

title: TONIGHT'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: Pittsburgh at Montreal (2) Moose (1111) and Briles (1313) vs. Renko (1411) and McAnally (77).

title: Professor Weds Cynthia M. Pyle
description: Miss Cynthia Munro Pyle, a doctoral candidate in Ital ian Renaissance literature at Columbia University, and Dr. Richard Stanley Kayne, pro fessor of linguistics at the University of Paris in Vin cennes, were married here yesterday afternoon in St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University.

title: I.M.F. OVERFLOWS NAIROBI'S HOTELS
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 23 More than 3,000 people from outside Kenya have descended upon this first African capital to be host to the annual meet ing of the World Bank and In ternational Monetary Fund, and so far matters have gone smoothly.

title: Dance: Talented Soloists
description: The Cubiculo has in the last few years taken a very special place in American modern dance. With its simple, spartan stagemore of a place than a stageit has proved hospitable to any number of dancers, some es tablished, some virtually un known.

title: MARCHI ASSAILED ON CRIME STAND
description: In the first joint appearance of the four major candidates during the mayoral campaign, Assemblyman Albert H. Blu menthal sought to counter State Senator John J. Marchi's safety inthestreets campaign by link ing his Republican rival with the Watergate scandal and the investigation of Vice President. Agnew.

title: Steelers Triumph, 336, Over Browns, Take Lead
description: A solid defense, timely passing, better ball control and fewer mistakes are the ingredients that Terry Brad shaw, the Pittsburgh Steeler quarterback, said it took to win championships.

title: Newcombe Victor
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Sept. 23 (AP)  John Newcombe stormed past Dick Stockton today to win the singles fi nal, then teamed with Owen Davidson to take the doubles in the $20,000 Palmetto, ten nis tournament.

title: Chrysler Workers Ratify Pact; Production Is to Resume Today
description: DETROIT, Sept. 23 (AP)  Chrysler workers have ratified the contract negotiated last week between the No. 3 United States auto maker and the United Automobile Workers, clearing the way for produc tion to resume tomorrow.

title: Perot: Supersalesman In Relief Controversy
description: A few years ago, when H. Ross Perot, the Texas computer millionaire, first sought entree to the Jiuge, potentially lucrative world of New York welfare administration, his sales staff members reported they had no good contacts in state gov ernment to pursue.

title: Increase in Tolls on Turnpike, First Since '51 Being Weighed
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Sept. 23 (AP)The executive director of the New Jersey Turnpike Au thority said today that tolls on the turnpike might have to be raised to meet increased main tenance and building costs.

title: Shea Jammed as Cardinals Lose, 52
description: Pennant fever soared in the city yesterday as shriek ing Met fans stampeded down the elevated ramp to Shea Stadium, used ladders to scale fences, perched in trees and stood in mammoth lines outside ticket windows.

title: Chilean Refugees Denied Passes to Leave Country
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 23 The military junta here has notified foreign embassies that Chilean citizens will no longer be given safeconduct passes for political asylum abroad, foreign diplomatic sources here disclosed today.

title: Notre Dame, Using Offense Borrowed from Delaware, Starts New Season Impressively
description: Notre Dame borrowed the University of Delaware of fense last year, using it about half of the time. The Irish have apparently de cided to move from that wingT with motion exclu sively this year. It was the pattern of attack all game long as Notre Dame opened its season Saturday by trouncing Northwestern, 44 0.

title: Woman in a Mental Institution In Ohio 97 of Her 102 Years
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 24 (UPI)  On June 25, 1876, Gen. George Custer made his last stand at the battle of the Little Big Horn. Also on that day, Martha Nelson com pleted her first year in a mental institution. She is still there.

title: HUNT LINKS COLSON TO PLAN THAT LED TO 1972 BREAKIN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24E. Howard Hunt Jr. told the Senate Watergate committee as it resumed public hearings today that Charles W. Colson, the former White House special counsel, had been aware early last year of the largescale intelligence scheme that led to the Watergate breakin.

title: City Opera and Musicians Reach Accord to End 24Day Strike
description: The New York City Opera and Local 802 of the Amer ican Federation of Musicians reached agreement early yes terday on a new contract, erasing the threat that the opera might shut down for the fall and spring seasons and paving the way for a resump tion of performances Saturday night.

title: DR. MARGARET STAHR
description: Dr. Margaret Stahr, a lawyer, who retired as professor of political science at Hunter Col lege in 1959, died Sunday at nursing home in Lewiston, Me. Her age was 80. She for merly lived here and in Northampton, Mass.

title: STRIKE CONTINUED BY LAY TEACHERS
description: A strike by lay teachers against eight Roman Catholic high schools in Brooklyn and Queens started its second week yesterday with representatives of both sides saying that there were no signs of a break in the dispute over salaries.

title: Bridge: Young Group Gains Victory In Swiss Team Championship
description: SOUTH FALLSBURG, N. Y., Sept. 24One of the young est teams in the event cap tured the Swiss Team Cham pionship Sunday. The event concluded the New York New Jersey Regional Cham pionships here. Dave Berk owitz, Bob Sartorius and Harold Lilie, all of New York, and Mike Gurwitz of Hillside, N. J., all in their twenties, topped a field of 190 teams by winning 7 matches of a possible 8.

title: NIXON BACKS RISE IN GASOLINE PRICE AT RETAIL LEVEL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24  In an apparent effort to avert further protest shutdowns of filling stations, the White House said today that Presi dent Nixon had told the Cost of Living Cbuncil to act this week to allow an increase in retail gasoline prices.

title: Duryea Due to Be Called In VoteDraining Inquiry
description: A Manhattan grand jury is scheduled to begin hearing testimony next Tuesday on an alleged Republican party scheme to drain votes from Democratic candidates in the state by promotion of Liberal party candidates.

title: U.S. AGENCY SHIFTS ON BEACH EROSION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 The National Park Service has decided that surrender is the most honorable conclusion of its fight to prevent beach ero sion at the Cape Hatteras Na tional Seashore, officials of the agency said today.

title: The U.N.Selecting a Role
description: Almost everyone is inclined to take a parochial view of the United Nations, equating its success or effective ness with whether or not it seems to serve their own national interests, charging it with failure or impo tence when it pays more attention to other people's interests. The United States is not exempt from this human weakness. The U.N. has often in recent years been an undeserving target of the pique of both Congress and the executive.

title: Text of Secretary of State Kissinger's Address Before U.N. General Assembly
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept 24Following is the text of the speech delivered here today by Secretary State Kissinger:

title: 30 Families Are Evacuated in South Bronx Fire
description: Five persons were rescued on aerial ladders and 30 fami lies had to be evacuated yes terday in a threealarm fire that burned through six frame dwellings in the South Bronx.

title: Quintuplets Die Within an Hour; Four of Stanek Sextuplets Gain
description: TEMPLE, Tex., Sept. 24 (UPI)  Quintuplets, three girls and two boys, were born to a Cam eron, Tex., housewife tonight, but all five died within an hour.

title: U.S. Signs Accord To Help Europeans Launch Space Lab
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 The United States Government signed an agreement today with nine West European coun tries enabling the Europeans to participate in international space research by constructing a large space laboratory by 1980.

title: I.M.F. Chief Terms Float No Panacea
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 24 The new managing director of the International Monetary Fund said today that the ex perience of the last six months had shown that floating cur rencyexchange rates offer no panacea for the problems con fronting us.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The president of the Pa trolmen's Benevolent Associ ation in New York City, Rob ert M. McKiernan, gave new contract proposals to Mayor Lindsay, including a bid for a substantial pay increase to compensate for the rise in the cost of living and a goal of breaking parity with fire men and winning 20 per cent more than sanitationmen.

title: STATE CITES FLAWS AT WILLOWBROOK
description: Despite major advances in the relief of overcrowding and the improvement of living con ditions at the Willowbrook State School, a report issued yesterday by State Controller Arthur Levitt criticized 22 op erational and fiscal manage ment areas and made 96 recom mendations for improvements.

title: GEOTEK IS ENJOINED FROM MAKING SHIFTS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 24 United States District Judge William G. Sweigert today is sued a temporary restraining order that would halt the Geo tek complex of companies from making any fundamental struc tural changes or engaging in any new business, pending a ruling by the Judge on wheth er a temporary receiver should be appointed to supervise the affairs of the companies, as requested by the Securities and Exchange Commission here last week.

title: Amendment for School Prayer Supported at a Senate Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UPI)  A proposed constitu tional amendment to allow vol untary prayer in public schools won strong support from reli gious and patriotic leaders who testified today before the Sen ate Constitutional Amendments subcommittee.

title: KOSYGIN HOLDING BELGRADE TALKS
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 24Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union arrived to day for a week's visit to strengthen longrange economic cooperation, to sort out some problems and to discuss inter national issues in the context of improved EastWest rela tions.

title: Theater: Nellie Toole
description: It all begins with a classi fied advertisement in The New York Times. A manso experienced that he has held down 17 jobs in 10 years goes to a Second Avenue bar. He has to meet the boss, for an unspecified job. He is ner vous. The bar is closed. A pianist plays Chopin. The bartender serves him an orange blossom. The plot is about to murken.

title: Jets Hope Namath Can Avoid Surgery
description: While a meditative, real istic Joe Namath rested painfully in a $170 private room at Lenox Hill Hospital yesterday, the Jets pondered the optimistic possibility that their quarterback could avoid an operation and return for the final five games of the season.

title: Three Bodies Recovered
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Sept. 24 (AP)The bodies of three of the six Coast Guardsmen missing in the crash of an am phibious rescue plane have been recovered, the Coast Guard said today. The bodies were identified as those of Harold Brown, Stonington, Conn.; Ben jamin Gaskins, Buxton, N. C., and John Pletger, Salt Lake City.

title: Marchi Lays Much of the Blame for Crime on Courts in the City
description: If elected Mayor, John J. Marchi said yesterday, he would be a LaGuardia type who would ride herd on judges and, if they did not measure up, demand their impeachment.

title: LOCKHEED MAY SEEK EXTENSION OF LOAN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (Reuters) The Lockheed Air craft Corporation may have to seek an extension of the ma turity date or an alteration in the payment schedule on its $250million Government guar anteed loan, Edward Schmults, treasury general counsel, said today.

title: 3 Buffalo TeenAgers Held In Shooting and a Robbery
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 24 (AP) The Buffalo police have charged two teenaged youths in con nection with fatal shootings and accused a third of robbing a bank.

title: GALLUP FINDS MOOD OF DISILLUSIONMENT
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 24 (UPI)  Politics and politicians now stand at the lowest point in public respect during this century, George Gallup, the pollster, said today.

title: TAKEOVER CLEARED BY FIRST HARTFORD
description: Full control of Forbes & Wal lace, a Springfield, Mass., de partmentstore chain, will be acquired for an undisclosed sum by the First Hartford Corpora tion, a Manchester, Conn., hold ing company, following an agreement yesterday by minor ity stockholders to sell their 38 per cent of voting stock.

title: Cook Is Accused in Strangling Of Woman Air Force Employe
description: WRIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Sept. 24  A hamburger cook was charged last night with the murder of Elizabeth Ann Ander son, a McGuire Air Force Base civilian employe who was found strangled yesterday morning in the back seat of her car.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Terminal B Opens at Newark Airport

title: White House Service Set
description: WASHIINGTON, Sept. 24 (UPI)President Nixon plans to hold a worship service in the White House in October after nearly a sixmonth hiatus, a spokesman said today. The dep uty press secretary, Gerald L. Warren, said in response to questions, that Mr. Nixon had not suspended the worship services, the last of which took place April 4 in the East Room.

title: People in Sports: Big Wilt Plays It Coy, Sells Books
description: Wilt Chamberlain, still playing the guessing game, said yesterday negotiations for him to jump to San Diego involved more than just the Conquistadors. It has to be obvious the entire American Basketball Association is in volved, said Chamberlain, who is in New York City to promote his book, Wilt, Macmillian ($6.95). You would be surprised at the money they have offered me.

title: 4 in Florida Family Drown
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 24 (AP)Four members of a Jacksonville family have drowned and two more are feared drowned, the possible victims of a large wave that Swept them from a jetty, the authorities say. The four were, identified yesterday as Louise Pitts, 71 years old: her brother, the Rev. Arthur B. Hagans; her sister. Althea H. Jernigan, 37, and Mrs. Pitts's daughter, Helen Ranks, 50.

title: Rising Wind $4.80 Victor At Westbury
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 24  A 2yearold bargain trotter named Rising Wind took a positive step toward the 1974 Hambletonian to night at Roosevelt Raceway by winning the $82,695 West bury Futurity.

title: CREW FAILURE LINKED TO BOSTON AIR CRASH
description: BOSTON, Sept. 24 (AP) The Massachusetts Aeronautics Commission has attributed the crash of a Delta DC9 airliner last July 31 at Boston's Logan Airport to failure of the crew to utilize all navigational in formation available to them.

title: 2 Hospitals With a Bold Plan Find It Their Financial Ruin
description: French and Polyclinic hos pitals, two health institutions that have served the city's West Side for more than 90 years, are in bankruptcy and in danger of being shut down by a courtappointed referee if they can't show by the end of October that they can turn the financial corner.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BLOCK BUSTER In New York, when a building or so begins to go, so does the rest of the block. That means going good and going bad. Take the north side of the 400 block on West 43d Street, between Ninth and Tenth Avenues, a rather shabby neighborhood that by and large now appears to be turning into a smallscale cul tural center.

title: U.S. Offers to Sell Lebanon 18 Skyhawk Attack Planes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24  The United States has offered to sell Lebanon a squadron of 18 A4 Skyhawks, a light at tack bomber, Administration officials reported today.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International Secretary of State Kissinger, addressing the United Nations General Assembly, said that the United States would never be satis fied with a world of uneasy truces, of offsetting blocs, of accommodations of con venience. In a broad statement of principles in his first speech as Secretary of State, Mr. Kissinger said at a packed session of the General Assembly that the United States looked beyond the bilateral diplomacy, the pragmatic agreements and the dramatic steps of recent years. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Seoul Urged to Set Deadline for Arrest Of Kim Kidnappers
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 24A prominent South Korean opposition legislator demanded today that the Cabinet resign if the Government fails to ar rest the kidnappers of Kim Dae Jung within a set time.

title: Citizens Coalition Formed To Help Elect Fuchsberg
description: A citizens coalition of regu lar and reform Democrats, la bor leaders, lawyers and rep resentatives of civic groups has been formed to support Jacob D. Fuchsberg, the Democratic nominee for chief judge of the Court of Appeals.

title: Crime Issue in Mayoral Debate Is Second to Who Raised It First
description: State Senator John J. Marchi and Representative Mario Biaggi debated yesterday who was first to emphasize the crime issue, while their two rivals for the mayoralty let their mimeograph machines do their talking.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: Reagan Signs Death Bill, Restoring Penalty on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 (AP) A bill restoring the death penalty in California on a lim ited basis was signed today by Gov. Ronald Reagan, who said he regretted the step, but be lieved the measure would save lives.

title: Wallace Vetoes Pension Bill To Aid Disabled Governors
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 24 (AP)Gov. George C. Wal lace has vetoed a bill passed during the recent session of the Alabama Legislature that would have provided a pension for Governors s disabled in of fice.

title: Radio: C.B.S. on Drama Bandwagon
description: As television dives into adult, i.e., primarily sexu al, themes in an attempt to attract audiences of young marrieds, i.e., more conspicu ous consumers, it may be facing some surprising com petition from an older and relatively neglected brother. His name is radio.

title: World Bank Moves to Lend $22Billion to Poor Lands
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 24 Robert S. McNamara, president of the World Bank, announced a $22billion lending program for poor countries today, par ticularly stressing help for nearly 800 million rural people who have been bypassed by economic growth.

title: Air Merger Study Backed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UPI)The Senate approved to day legislation calling for study of a possible merger by the Air Force Reserve and the Air Na tional Guard.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: Mrs. Frances McCullough of Harper & Row demurs about the remark here that hot foods come from poor countries:

title: THRIFT OUTFLOWS 3D HIGHEST EVER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 The Federal Home Loan Banks board announced today that the outflow of deposits in sav ings and loan associations in August had been the third largest in historya net of $1.2billion more in withdraw als than in deposits.

title: The Living Spirit
description: In the 1930's, the lights of free scholarship were being extinguished in the great universities of Germany and Italy, and within a decade the darkness enveloped most of the European continent. It was in response to this intellectual blackout that the late Alvin Johnson, president of The New School, mobilized a rescue opera tion of Europe's persecuted scholars. The goal was not merely to provide a refuge but to perpetuate in American education and culture the best of the Old World's intel lectual, heritage.

title: BHUTTO SUGGESTS TALKS WITH INDIA
description: Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan said yester day that his country would like to discuss a mutual reduction of arms with India in the near future.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Years ago, dowagers had their chauffeurs drive them down to 14th Street, where Ohrbach's was then located, so they could save a dollar on a pair of gloves or a hand bag.

title: Cowboys Trounce Saints, 403
description: DALLAS, Sept. 24 (AP) Dallas methodically trounced the New Orleans Saints, 403, on the power running of Cal vin Hill and Robert Newhouse tonight to hand Cowboy Coach Torn Landry his 100th National Football League vic tory.

title: State's TransitBand Plan Is Denounced by City Club
description: Trustees of the City Club of New York, an organization of 400 prominent business and professional men, denounced Governor Rockefeller's proposed $3.5billion transportation bond issue yesterday. Mean while, the State Chamber of Commerce and Industry an nounced its support of the bond issue.

title: A.S. NEIL, 89,DIES; LED SUMMERHILL
description: LONDON, Sept. 24,A. S. Neill, founder of the revolu tionary and controversial Sum merhill School, in which chil dren were allowed to develop in their own way, died today at Aldeburgh, Suffolk. He was 89 years old.

title: Black Women Form Panel To Study Creative Talent
description: An organization of black women announced yesterday the formation of a national commission on the arts and letters that will research, identify and secure the crea tive talents of black people, with particular emphasis on black women.

title: Sad Feet in the Sky
description: Superman is middle aged. He has every right to be, after all those dec ades of chasing bullets and flying crosscountry without even a wind shield to keep his face from chapping.

title: Thalia Theater Adopts 2dRun Movie Policy
description: The Thalia will end its 31year reign as the Upper West Side's oldest repertory movie theater Friday when a new manager takes over and begins showing second run films.

title: Pacific Phone Net Rises
description: The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph company reported yesterday records for its third fiscal quarter ended Aug. 31. Net income amounted to $72.5 million, equal to 44 cents a share, compared with $61.1 million, or 40 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues climbed to $685.4million from $611.8 million.

title: Welfare Fraud Is Reported After Onondaga Case Study
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 24 (AP)A number of Onodago County resident have been illegally re ceiving both welfare and unem ployment compensation at the same time, it was reported to day.

title: CERRO CANCELING PERU SALE OFFER
description: The Cerro Corporation an nounced yesterday that it had withdrawn its offer to sell to the Peruvian Government its mining and smelting business in Peru.

title: Elton John Subdues Side Issue Tactics; Fans Provide Extras
description: The annual New York Elton John concert had the artist ap pear onstage dressed in white feathered trousers and vest, in laid with silver lam, alter nately resembling a gay cabel lero and a rock'n' roll rooster. John pays meticulous attention to the appearance of his act, al though this year's show was toned down somewhatno tap dancers and midgets material ized as they did last year.

title: Superdoses of Vitamins To Be Limited Monday
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 24 (UPI)  Barring lastminute court intervention, this is the last week that Americans will be able to buy highconcen tration doses of vitamin A or vitamin D without a pre scription.

title: SUSPECT LOSES PLEA ON STENNIS ASSAULT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP)A United States District Court judge refused today to dismiss Federal charges against a teenager accused of attempt ing to kill Senator John C. Stennis, Democrat of Missis sippi.

title: Moslem Revolt in Philippines Reported on the Wane
description: MANILA, Sept. 24The Mos lem rebellion on Mindanao Is land in the Philippines has been blunted, two Moslem leaders and two defense officials said today.

title: SOVIET JEW IS SENT HOME AFTER ARREST
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 24 (AP)A Latvian Jew who staged a demonstration in Moscow yes terday has been sent by train to his hometown of Riga with an armed escort, Jewish sources reported today.

title: JOHN KITCHEN DIES; FEDERAL JUDGE, 61
description: WOODBURY, N. J., Sept. 24 (AP)Judge John J. Kitchen of the United States District Court in Camden died Friday, ap parently of a heart attack, in Underwood Memorial Hospital. His age was 61. He lived in Bridgeport.

title: Agnew, Nixon and The Future
description: Spiro T. Agnew's legal strategists now are said to be planning an attack in Federal court on the right of the Government to bring ordinary criminal charges against him. Their contention will be that under the Constitution Vice President must be Impeached, convicted and removed from office before he can be made to stand trial like any other citizen.

title: Chese: Kavalek Really Pouring It On In Effort to Overtake Grefe
description: With but three rounds to go in the United States Chess Championship, the unher alded California master John Grefe continued to set the pace. His 82 score put him a point ahead of Grandmaster Lubomir Kavalek of Wash ington and far ahead of the rest of the 13man field in the tournament being played in El Paso.

title: Dr. Richard Cummings Dies Taught History at Brooklyn
description: Dr. Richard O. Cummings professor of history at Brook lyn College, who wrote on the development of food process ing and refrigeration, died Fri day at his home in the Tower Hotel, Brooklyn. His age wa?? 64.

title: U.S. Steel Gains Approval For a 2.4% Price Increase
description: The United States Steel Cor poration announced yesterday that it had received formal ap proval from the Cost of Living Council to raise prices by 2.4 per cent for flat rolled sheet and strip products, beginning Monday.

title: Brandt Turning to Domestic Reforms
description: BONN, Sept. 24Chancellor Willy Brandt, who, in the phrase used here, may do fine on for eign policy but knows a good deal less about domestic policy, is making a priority effort this fall to mark his second term with domestic reform.

title: AGNEW WILL KEEP 2 SPEAKING DATES; Richardson Abruptly Drops Flight to Texas Because of Most Pressing Business
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 As Vice President Agnew's at torneys prepared to go into court by Wednesday to try to head off an investigation and possible indictment of their cli ent, Mr. Agnew's office an nounced today that he still planned to make a speaking trip to California this week.

title: Michigan School Strike Spurs Parent Blockade
description: Angry parents in Lincoln Park, Mich., a suburb of Detroit, surrounded the of Education building yester day and pledged to blockade negotiators until an agreement was worked out to end a teachers' strike.

title: Saigon Base in Highlands Taken; Troops Believed Trekking Out
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 24 (Reuters)Communist troops overran a Government base camp in the Central High lands during the weekend and the retreating Government rangers have been out of con tact for nearly two days, mili tary sources said today.

title: New Orders for Durables Fell 1.6% During August
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP)New orders for durable goods from the nation's manu facturers declined in August for the second straight month, the Commerce Department le ported today.The pace of orders for dur able goods is one of the kcy business indicators relied on by the Government in fore casting future performance of the economy.The decline in new orders in August could indicate a slowdown in the economy, & though the Commerce Depal ment also reported that un filled orders increased at even et faster rate during the month.An increase in unfilled or ders may indicate that busi ness is producing at capacity and unable to keep up with demand.The report showed that new orders for durable goods de creased $680million, or 16 per cent, to $42billion after sea sonal adjustments.Shipments fell $1.7billion, or 4.2 per cent, to $39elion.Since new orders continued to exceed shipments, unfilled orders increased $2.95billion, or 3 per cent, to $102.5billion at the end of August.The Commerce Department said the August decreases in new orders included declines in the machinery industries, down $480million, fabricated met als, down $235million, and transportation equipment, down $145million.These decreases were partial ly offset by a $485million in crease in orders for the pri marymetals industry.The increase in unfilled orders was led by increases in primarymetals orders totaling $1billion.

title: CURBS ARE ASKED IN BANK INVESTING
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UPI)Senator Lloyd M. Bent sen Jr., Democrat of Texas, and two witnesses before his Senate Finance Subcommittee said to day reforms are necessary to prevent banks and other major institutions from dominating, the United States economy.

title: Judge Again Orders Seizure of a Jet in Drug Case
description: For the second time in two months, Federal Judge Jack B. Weinstein yesterday directed the United States Attorney in Brooklyn to seize a Colombian jetliner in which narcotics had been smuggled from South America.

title: Bid to Halt Public Hearing Is Denied by Appeals Court
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 24 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the DiStrict of Columbia denied today a pri vate group's request that it prohibit the Senate Watergate committee from continuing public hearings.

title: SOVIET SAYS CHINA SPURNED A TREATY
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 24Leonid I. Brezhnev said today that the Soviet Union offered China a nonaggression pact in mid June but that the Chinese lead ers in their frenzied antiSo vietism did not reply.

description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 24Secretary of State Kissinger said today that the United States would never be satisfied with a world of un easy truces, of offsetting blocs, of accommodations of conveni ence.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24  The American family: Is it bet ter off today than it was a century ago?

description: To the Editor: A recent British independent study provides substantial evidence that the arms race is not slowing down but continuing to escalate.

description: Dean Witter & Co., Inc., said yesterday income for the fourth quarter ended Aug. 31 dropped sharply from yearearlier levels.

title: BOLIVIA UNION CHIEFS SEIZED AS PLOTTERS
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 24 (AP)Eightynine labor leaders were arrested last night, ac cused of plotting to overthrow the military regime of President Hugo Banzer Surez.

description: Jorge Ahumada of Argen tina scored a unanimous, 10 round decision over Jose Gonzales of Puerto Rico last night in a lightheavyweight boxing bout at the Felt Forum of Madison Square Garden.

title: Hearings an Bias Charges Against Times Ads Curbed
description: A State Supreme Court jus tice in Manhattan issued a temporary restraining order yesterday barring the City Commission for Human Rights from holding public hearings on charges that The New York Times accepted discriminatory advertisements for jobs in South Africa.

title: The Pennant Race
An American Spy by Profession Everette Howard Hunt Jr.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Everette Howard Hunt Jr., today's leadoff witness at the Senate Watergate hear ings, left the Central Intelli gence Agency in 1970 after 21 years of clandestine op erations. But after the con victed Watergate conspirator left to take a more mundane public relations job, he couldn't get over the fact, according to a friend, that he'd been a C.I.A. agent. You couldn't have a conversation with him for 10 minutes without him bringing it up some way or other. This was a romanti cist who couldn't get over the fact that he had been a spy.

description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:

title: Denial by Teleprompter On Dismissals Confirmed
description: Despite reports on Friday that 50 persons had been let go by Teleprompter Manhattan Cable TV, employes confirmed yesterday denials by its presi dent, Joseph C. Groth Jr., that anyone had been discharged from the New York outlet, which serves subscribers in the upper half of Manhattan.

title: AUDIENCE SEIZES KISSINGER TEXTS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 24A few minutes after Secretary of State Kissinger began to speak in the General assembly, the last of 500 copies of his text was grabbed up by delegate, prompting an Amer can official to say, That's unnylast year I couldn't get did of three.

title: Jersey Schoolboy Critical
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J., Sept. 24 (UPI)A high school football player remained in a coma in the intensive care unit of a Morristown Hospital tonight. A blood vessel in his head ruptured following a game last Saturday. A spokesman at Morristown Memorial Hospital said Robert Fernandez, 17 years old, was in critical condition after a threehour operation to remove a blood clot that had formed in his brain. Fernandez, of Morris Hills High School, played until the last three minutes of a game against Montclair High School, had complained of dizziness and headaches shortly after leaving the field.

title: High School Sports
description: Chris Legree could be an allAmerican. He is the starting quarterback for the South Shore football team, he plays varsity baseball at the Brooklyn school and is a member of the basketball team. But Chris doesn't come from an allAmerican house or even an allcity apartment. He is from Osborne Street in Brownsville. The ghetto.

title: Cambodia Asks Million a Day More Aid
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sept. 24A Cambodian Gov ernment official, saying we are short of many things, ap pealed to the United States to day to increase its military aid by the amount Washington used to spend on the bombing here, which the Cambodians esti mated at $1million a day.

title: Conference Opens to Sounds of Africa
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 24  When the more than 5,000 delegates, advisers, wives, guests and assorted hangerson arrived for the opening of the International Monetary Fund conference this morning, they were greeted by great waves of rhythmthumping of tribal drums, chanting of singers, stamping of feet, jangling of bells, but all jumbled to gether.

title: Mr. Kissinger's Debut
description: It was an auspicious coincidence of timing that led Henry Kissinger to the United Nations General Assembly yesterday for his first official act as Secretary of State. The opening words of his formal address only heightened the sense of anticipation for what this respected scholar diplomat could present before the world forum.

title: F.D.R. Island
description: Government, said Franklin Delano Roosevelt 37 years ago during the dedication ceremonies of the Triborough Bridge, cannot close its eyes to the pollution of waters, to the erosion of soil, to the slashing of forests, any more than it can close its eyes to the need for slum clearance and schools and bridges. His words were recalled yes terday by Arthur Schlesinger Jr., the late President's foremost chronicler, during another dedication ceremony the renaming of Welfare Island to perpetuate F.D.R.'s memory.

description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 24 (AP) Tony Perez and Andy Kos ko hit home runs tonight as the Cincinnati Reds clinched the National League Western Division championship by de feating the San Diego Padres, 21.

description: The New York City Opera and and Local 802 of the Amer ican Federation of Musicians reached agreement early yes terday on a new contract, erasing the threat that the opera might shut down for the fall and spring seasons and paving the way for a resump tion of performances Saturday night.

title: Remember John Dean?
description: WASHINGTON  Only in America could President Nixon cling to power as his Administration is rocked by scandal. In any other selfgoverning nation, the parliament would months ago have called the head of govern ment to account.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UPI) President Nixon took an earlyevening cruise on the Potomac River today along with Alexander M. Haig, his chief of staff. They were out for about two hours on the Presidential yacht Sequoia. The White House said they had dinner aboard.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP)The Treasury Depart ment announced today it has started an investigation into whether imported hand tools from Japan are being sold in the United States at less than fair value in violation United States antidumping laws.

description: PARIS, Sept. 24  Dr. Josu de Castro, a Brazilian diplo mat and scholar who was known for his work in favor of thirdworld countries, died here today at the age of 65.

title: 8 PRISON OFFICERS TO SUE OVER PLEAS
description: Eight correction officers and their union announced yester day that they would sue the city and the Legal Aid Society for $1million because, they said, both had conspired to in duce guilty pleas from the of ficers in departmental hearings.

title: Police Officer Arraigned
description: A 34yearold New York City police officer who disappeared with his family from his Queens home more than a month ago was arraigned in Queens Su preme Court yesterday on carges of having passed $29,800 worth of bad checks. He was apprehended last week in a trailer camp in Ohio. The of ficer, Robert Cameric of 11959 27th Avenue, was held in $1,000 bail on three counts of grand larceny and four of issuing bad checks.

title: Plan to Cut More Timber In National Forests Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24A Presidential panel urged today that the lumber industry be allowed to cut down substan tial portions of the national forests, and President Nixon immediately endorsed the rec ommendation.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24A Presidential panel urged today that the lumber industry be allowed to cut down substan tial portions of the national forests, and President Nixon immediately endorsed the rec ommendation.

title: Ousted Bosses Back at Chile's Plants
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 24 The military junta has placed the vast majority of statecon trolled factories and businesses back in the hands of the exec utives who ran them before the Government of President Sal vador Allende Gossens was voted into power.

title: People and Business
description: Dr. William J. Fellner, who was Sterling Professor of Economics at Yale until July, was nominated by President. Nixon yesterday to be a member of the Council of Economic Advisers.

title: Skylab 2 Heads for Splashdown Today
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 24  The Skylab 2 astronauts were set tonight to bring their record 59day mission to an end with a splashdown in the Pacific Ocean at 6:20 P.M., Eastern daylight time tomorrow.

title: Soviet Car Ownership Rises, but the Drivers Are Unprepared
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 24As the dreaded Sunday drivers put newly acquired cars through their paces on these chilly au tumn weekends, a Soviet traf fic safety group is warning that only onethird of them have received proper driver training.

title: Senate Votes to Require Notice on Closing of Bases
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP)The Senate voted today to require the Defense Depart ment to give a minimum of six months' notice of military base closings in the United States.

title: Weekend Boxing
description: Toronto  Jose Napobs, 147 pounds, Mexico, outpointed Clyde Gray, 145, Toronto, 15 rounds; Napoles retains world welterweight title.

title: Brothel Boss Tells Of Albany Bribes
description: ALBANY, Sept. 24A for mer narcotics and prostitu tion chief and two of his former prostitutes testified here today that for years they systematically paid sev eral hundred dollars a week in bribes to Albany police men to stay in business.

title: Indonesian Aide Doomed
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 24 (Reuters)An Indonesian police official was sentenced to death by a military tribunal today for helping mastermind the abortive Communist coup d'tat in 1965. The official, Brig. Gen. Sugeng Sutarto, 54 years old, was chief of staff of the now defunct State Intelli gence Agency under the regime of the late President Sukarno.

title: PACIFIC ISLANDS PONDER TOURISM
description: AGANA, Guam, Sept. 21 Ornate airconditioned hotels dominate the once entirely green landscape curving aroun?? sapphirehued Tumon Bay, the lively center of the booming tourist industry on this tiny American island in the western Pacific.

title: Weizmann Unit Names Aide
description: Morris L. Levinson, head of a foodproducts concern, has been elected president of the American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science. Mr. Levinson, president of As sociated Products, Inc. succeeds Abraham Feinberg, now board chairman of the Weizmann In stitute, which is in Rehovot, Israel.

title: Miss Durr Wins Title At Houston
description: HOUSTON. Sept. 24 (UPI) Francoise Durr, displaying stunning accuracy, upset Rosemary Casais, 64, 16, 64, today to capture the $30, 000 Virginia Slims singles championship.

title: Dance: Fused Artistry
description: Until recently, the profes sional relationship between dancers and sculptors has been a conventional one. The dancer was merely a model, interchangeable with any other subject. Certainly this was true in the case of those sculptors most attracted to dancers in the past: Degas, Rodin and Bourdelle.

title: The Screen: Double Bill:' The Man Called Noon' and 'Triple Irons' The Casts
description: Perhaps it's chauvinistic but the West wins over the East in the double dish of ersatz adventures, "The Man Called Noon" and "Triple Irons," that are playing in local theaters. But it's a minor triumph since the manufactured action in both is aimed largely at producing gore rather than persuasive logic or artistic excitement.There are no karate chops in "Triple Irons," the Oriental martial-arts exhibition turned out in Hong Kong and dubbed into English. Its small distinction is David Chiang, as a one-armed, handsome hero, who is the handiest man around with two swords. And, to the accompaniment of comic-book dialogue, grunts, grimaces and scores of corpses, he finally dispatches Ku Feng, the bandit-villain and master of those destructive triple iron bars that cost him his arm in the first place. Even with a pretty heroine, Li Ching, around, a visit to this familiar, bloody kung-fu country isn't necessary."The Man Called Noon," filmed on rugged, Spanish mountain locations, is fairly successful in maintaining some mystery, as Richard Crenna, its amnesiac, gun-fighter seeks to find his true identity and a hidden fortune.Under Peter Collinson's brisk direction, the chases, fights and shootouts are serious and practically continuous. But the equally serious characterizations cry for fuller explanations. Farley Granger, as a bearded, scheming judge, who, like Patty Shepard, is out to grab that fortune, and Rosanna Schiaffino, as the well-endowed heroine who aids and loves Mr. Crenna, may be occasionally effective but they are rarely as large as life.Mr. Crenna is fairly convincing in an underplayed performance that makes him as much an intellectual as a gunslinger. "I get the feeling," he muses at one point in his search, "that I've been here before." That wise observation generally could apply to both "The Man Called Noon" and "Triple Irons."

title: COMMUNIST ATTACKS IN LAOS REPORTED
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 24 (UPI)  North Vietnamese and Pathet Lao troops attacked at least three Government posi tions in the first reported Com munist violation of the Laotian peace accords signed on Sept. 14, the Defense Ministry said today.

title: U.A.W. SETS SIGHTS ON FORD CONTRACT
description: DETROIT, Sept. 24 (UPI) The United Auto Workers Union, having ended its dispute with the Chrysler Corporation, turned its full attention today to the Ford Motor Company, the union's second negotiation target.

title: 50Cent PATH Fare Proposal, Stalled by I.C.C., Is Called Dead
description: Hearings on a proposal to raise fares on the PATH com muter line to 50 cents from 30 cents were abruptly ended yes terday amid growing reports that the proposal was dead.

title: Inexco Selling to Gulf Oil 6 Million Barrels of Crude
description: The Inexco Oil Company said yesterday that the Gulf Oil Company had agreed to prepay $30million for six million bar rels of crude oil from the Hi light field in Wyoming. The oil covered by the agreement is expected to be delivered by Inexco over the next five years.

title: SCHOOL LUNCHES PUSHED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UPI)  The Senate approved today a $300million increase in Federal aid to the school lunch program with a provi son for even more money if food costs keep rising.

title: ERNEST J. ARIES
description: Ernest J. Aries, a partner in Aries Associates, a real estate concern with offices in Yonkers, Hartsdale and Bed ford, N. Y., died Sunday in Memorial Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Yonkers.

title: Another Battle of Sexes
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 24 (UPI)Georgia had its own ten nis battle of the sexes and generations yesterday as 19 yearold Betsy Butler beat 62yearold Bitsy Grant in a $500 winnertakeall match, 61, 57, 63. Miss Butler, the state's secondranking player, capitalized on her strong serve to defeat the onetime star in 90degree heat.

title: Notes on People
description: Accusations that his trans fer from Key Biscayne, Fla., to Pittsburgh had been ar ranged by President Nixon because of an Easter sermon interpreted as critical of the President are completely false, the Rev. John A. Huff man said yesterday.

title: N.Y.U. Historian Gets Post With Smithsonian
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Brooke Hindle, a New York University faculty member since 1950, has been ap pointed director of the Smith sonian Institution's National Museum of History and Tech nology here, the institution announced today.

title: Cook Held in Jersey Strangling Of Woman Air Force Employe
description: WRIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Sept., 24A hamburger cook was charged last night with the murder of Elizabeth Ann And erson, a McGuire Air Force Base civilian employe who was found strangled yesterday morning in the back seat of her car.

description: BASEBALL

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Dr. James R. Cowan, the State Health Commissioner, and Dr. Maurice Kott, Acting State Commissioner of Insti tutions and Agencies, met with Attorney General George F. Kugler Jr. yesterday to plan inspection procedures for kitchens in state institutions. The meeting followed the controversial closings of kitchens and bakeries in nine state institutions or daycare centers by Dr. Oscar Suss man, State Director of Comumnity Health Services.

title: WILLIAM J. MURPHY 3D
description: William J. Murphy 3d, sales manager for South and Central America of the Lummus Com pany, an engineering and con struction concern, and a for mer vice president of the Chemical Construction Cor poration, died yesterday of a stroke at North Hudson Hos pital in Weehawken, N. J. He was 48 years old and lived in East Meadow, L. I.

title: World Bank Moves to Lend $22Billion to Poor Lands
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 24 Robert S. McNamara, president of the World Bank, announced a $22billion lending program for poor countries today, par ticularly stressing help for nearly 800 million rural people who have been bypassed by economic growth.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:

title: Pirates Split Pair and Trail by HalfGame
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 24In an atmosphere of hail and farewell, the miracle du Parc Jarry apparently ended tonight, but not before the Expos inadvertently helped the New York Mets in the National League East race.

title: 60 Die in Japanese Rains
description: TOKYO, Sept. 24 (UPI)A severe storm dropped nearly a foot of rain in northern Japan today, causing scores of land slides and bringing death, floods and destruction to a wide area. The police reported at least 60 persons dead or missing in the southern part of Japan's northern island, of Hok kaido, and the northern and western parts of Honshu, the main island.

title: Chile Seizes a U.S. Professor in Hunt for Leftists
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 24 The military authorities made dozens of new arrests in down town Santiago today as the housetohouse search for sup porters of the late President Salvador Allende Gossens con tinued.

title: 50Cent PATH Fare Proposal, Stalled by I.C.C., Is Called Dead
description: Hearings on a proposal to raise fares on the PATH com muter line to 50 cents from 30 cents were abruptly ended yes terday amid growing reports that the proposal was dead.

title: HardDriving Blues Stoke Lively Session At Coast Jazz Fete
description: MONTEREY, Calif., Sept. 23  Since 1964, the Saturday afternoon programs at the Mon terey Jazz Festival have tradi tionally been devoted to the blues, and they have almost always filled the 7,000seat arena of the Monterey County Fairgrounds. Yesterday after noon, at the 16th annual festi val, it was evident why these blues events have been so suc, cessful: They are as much a social event and an opportunity for audience participation as they are a musical presentation.

title: Cahill to Ask Tighter Controls to Halt Surge in Cable TV License Requests
description: TRENTON, Sept. 24Gover nor Cahill said today he would ask the Legislature to strength en state control over the bur geoning cable television indus try.

title: Paper to Change Name
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 24 (UPI) The newspaper of the Roman Catholic diocese of Buffalo will change its name to the Catholic News of Western New York, effective Oct. 25. The 100year old weekly, called the Magni ficat since 1964. will also change its format and publish more vital Catholic news with a positive direction.

title: ShortTerm Rates Plunge For 2d Session in a Row
description: Shortterm interest rates plummeted again yesterday in continued professional response to clues left by the Federal Re serve late last week that its increasingly tight monetary pol icy might have come to an end.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: ROSELLE, N. J.Although a tragic midsummer acci dent caused the loss of part of his right arm, Peter Ilich, a Fairleigh Dickinson University sophomore, refused to let the misfortune prevent him from continuing his col legiate soccer career. Ilich, a 20yearold Elizabeth resident who was to have been a starting forward on the Knights' team this fall, suffered a severed right arm just below the elbow in a meatgrinding plant where he had worked for over a year.

title: Dodge $85Million Is Left to Foundation
description: MORRISTOWN, Sept. 24  Geraldine Rockefeller Dodge, a niece of John D. Rockefeller, left the bulk of an $85million estate to a foundation in her name devoted to charitable, scientific, literary or other edu cational purposes, or for the prevention of cruelty to ani mals, or for the encouragement of art.

title: Agnew's Close Friends Central to jury Inquiry
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 24The case against Vice President Agnew, if there is one, win depend on the testimony of men he has considered to be among his closest friends.

title: Books of The Times
description: Under most circumstances, the story behind this volume of letters would seem ordinary enough. On an August evening in 1912, in the AustroHungarian city of Prague, a dreamy young middleclass Jew who earned his living at the time as minor official in an insurance firm, paid a call to the home of a friend with whom the shared a passionate interest in litera time. There, on that evening, he met Another visitor, an attractive if conven tional young woman from Berlin named Felice Bauer. Before the evening was over, the young man had fallen deeply in love with Felice. Almost at once, he began to write to her, once, twice, three times day, long letters full of confessions of love, demands for photographs and per sonal details, and hopes for a future together. And the young woman wrote back, reciprocating the young man's feelings.

title: Conspirator Quietly Buries Myth of the Superspy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 The Watergate hearings, once the hottest ticket in town, reopened today to less than capacity crowds.

title: MRS. ENGELHARD
description: BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., Sept. 24Mrs. Emelia Maria Canthal Engelhard, widow of Charles Engelhard who founded Engel hard Industries and mother of the late Charles W. Engelhard who expanded it to form Engel hard Minerals and Chemicals Corporation, died yesterday at Craigmore, her home here. She was 96 years old.

title: Greenburgh Teachers End Walkout, but Strikes in Harrison and Yorktown Are Continuing
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 24 School teachers in Greenhurgh's Central 7 District voted over whelmingly today to end a twoweekold strike and return to classes tomorrow.

title: Quintuplets Die Within an Hour; Four of Stanek Sextuplets Gain
description: TEMPLE, Tex., Sept. 24 (UPI)  Quintuplets, three girls and two boys, were born to a Cam eron, Tex., housewife tonight, but all five died within an hour.

title: PLAN FOR FACULTY ASSAILED AT CITY U.
description: The City University of New York yesterday attacked as flawed both in method and in substance a report by the Citizens Budget Commission that recommended a heavier workload for the City Univer sity faculty as a way of reduc ing expenses.

title: U.S. Recognizes Chile Under Military Junta
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 24 (AP)The United States of ficially recognized Chile under her new military junta today, the Chilean Foreign Ministry reported.

title: Gallagher Request For Parole Denied; Must Serve Term
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) The United States Parole Board today denied parole to former Representative Cornelius E. Gallagher of New Jersey and ruled that he should serve his full sentence for attempting to evade income taxes.

title: SOVIET SAYS CHINA SPURNED A TREATY
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 24Leonid I. Brezhnev said today that the Soviet Union offered China a nonaggression pact in mid June but that the Chinese lead ers in their frenzied antiSo vietism did not reply.

title: Black Muslim Plane Falls; 5 Aboard Not Seriously Hurt
description: GARY, Ind. Sept. 24 (AP) A Garybased Black Muslim Constellation plane, used for air freight operations between Chicago and California crashed on landing and burned early today at the Gary Municipal Airport.

title: NIXON BACKS RISE IN GASOLINE PRICE AT RETAIL LEVEL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24  In an apparent effort to avert further protest shutdowns of filling stations, the White Houge said today that Presi dent Nixon had told the Cost of Living Council to act this week to allow an increase in retail gasoline prices.

title: Postal Service Seeks Rise In Rate on FirstClass Mail
