description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UPI) Postmaster General Elmer T. Klassen said today that the United States Postal Service would seek an acrosstheboard increase in postal rates to take effect next January, including raising first class mail from eight to 10 cents.

title: Plans for Memorial at Roosevelt Island Announced During Dedication Ceremony at Site
description: A new deal for an old island was formalized yesterday as Welfare Island was renamed and dedicated in honor of President Franklin D. Roose velt in the presence of four of his five children and scores of Rooseveltera Democratic celeb rities.

title: Secretary Dent in Budapest
description: BUDAPEST, Sept. 24 (UPI) Secretary of Commerce Freder ick B. Dent opened talks today with Hungarian Government leaders on mutual trade rela tions and international eco nomic questions. Mr. Dent is touring Eastern Europe and will also visit Poland, the Soviet Union and Yugoslavia.

title: State Aide Challenges City On Welfare Medical Tests
description: The State Welfare Inspector General's office yesterday chal lenged figures released by the city that showed that nearly 65 per cent of the mothers on welfare screened in a new medi cal testing program were suf fering from severe disabilities.

title: The Cheers for Peron Echo the 1950's
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 24  Argentines by the hundreds of, thousands paraded shouting through the streets of Buenos Aires early today, acclaiming the overwhelming victory won by Juan D. Pern in the Presi dential elections yesterday.

title: Widow of Allende Leaves Mexico for Visit in Cuba
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 24 (Reuters)The widow of the former Chilean President, Sal vador Allende Gossens, flew to Cuba today for a visit. She was accompanied by the Cuban Ambassador to Mexico, Fer nando Lpez Muino.

title: IRA F. WARNER
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 24Ira F. Warner, a New York insurance broker and for 40 yeas a director of what is now Warnaco, Inc., a diversified apparel company of which his father was a founder, died to day in Bridgeport Hospital, He was 71 years old and lived in Fairfield, and in Palm Beach.

title: Seagull Author Crashes
description: MIDLAND, Tex., Sept. 24 (UPI)  Richard Bach, whose book Jonathan Livingston Sea gull told of a seagull master ing flying techniques, overshot a runway and crashed today in a World War II fighter at Mid land Airport. He was not in jured.

title: Goldsand, Pianist, Mines Riches of Rachmaninoff
description: This year marks the 100th anniversary of Rachmani noff's birth, but commemora tive concerts have been neither abundant nor par ticularly enterprising, con sidering the respectable quantity of music the Rus sian composer left. However, Robert Goldsand, in his re cital Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall, offered a repre sentative sampling of the works for solo piano.

title: REPORT WARNS U.S. OF POLYDRUG ABUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UPI)  The Federal Government is concentrating too much on sup pressing theheroin traffic and paying too little attention to the spread of other illicit nar cotics into the suburbs and schools, a Congressional report said today.

title: Mets Take a Breather, With Eyes on Pursuers
description: While the Pittsburgh Pirates were playing their critical doubleheader in Montreal, the Mets rested their sixgame winning streak yesterday and braced for the six games that could settle the championship of the Na tional League's chaotic East em Division.

title: ALLEN FISHER SINGS IN SENSITIVE STYLE
description: Allen Fisher might have taken an easy path Sunday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall by choosing a less strenuous pro gram of songs and by interpret ing them with less variety of nuance and communicational fervor. That he did not is very much to his credit, although the overall impression he left was that of an unusually sen sitive and musicianly young tenor with a limited command of a basically attractive instru ment.

title: Pincay Goal $4Million
description: While Hank Aaron and Nolan Ryan struggle for well publicized baseball records, New York's hottest jockey gallops quiety toward the first $4million season in the history of horseback riding.

title: Marchi Says Lindsay Did Some Good Things
description: Mayor Lindsay went into City Hall with some strength and some gump tion and he did some ex citing good things initially, particularly with respect to rearrangement of the city's tax structure.

title: POLICE GIVE MAYOR PAYRISE PROPOSAL
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association presented contract proposals to Mayor Lindsay yesterday, including a hid for a substantial pay increase and higher salaries than firemen.

title: HUNT LINKS COLSON TO PLAN THAT LED TO 1972 BREAKIN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24E. Howard Hunt Jr. told the Senate Watergate committee as it resumed public hearings today that Charles W. Colson, the former White House special counsel, had been aware early last year of the largescale intelligence scheme that led to the Watergate breakin.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Washington Copy In Art Auction

title: A Prison Plot to Kill Speck, Mass Murderer, Reported
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (AP)  Prison officials say they have learned of an alleged plot to kill Richard F. Speck, the con victed mass murderer, in prison.

title: NYQUIST ATTACKS SCHOOLAID PLANS.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Ewald B. Nyquist, New York State Commissioner of Educa tion, today attacked a Congres sional formula that he said de prived New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and other urban states of adequate Federal funds to provide educational as sistance to disadvantaged youths.

title: Giants Still Say Grim Scored
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 24 Did the New York Giants lose a certain touchdown because an official couldn't see Bob Grim catch the ball in the end zone?

title: RELEASE SOUGHT ON HEALTH FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24A suit intended to force the Nixon Administration to release $126 million in impounded funds for mental health and alcoholism programs was filed today by 21 organizations. 10 persons and two states.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said yesterday that it had negotiat ed a $67million contract with the McDonnell Douglas Cor poration for procurement of 20 Delta launch vehicles.

title: Argentina's Choice
description: Juan Domingo Pern has now completed an astonish ing political comeback by winning the Presidency of Argentina with more than 60 per cent of the vote in a free election. Mr. Pern overcame major handicaps: eighteen years of exile, his age (he will be 78 four days before taking office Oct. 12), and the insistence that his wife, Isabel, be nominated Vice President despite strong opposition from some leftwing supporters.

title: Dow Up 8.81 to 936.71
description: The stock market's strong rally, appearing to catch its second wind over the weekend, extended recent gains yester day as activity continued brisk.

title: 3 Major Blood Banking Groups Fail To Agree on a Reorganization Plan
description: BETHESDA, Md., Sept. 24 Two of the nation's most im portant bloodbanking organi nations announced today plans to form an American Blood Institute to help reorganize the country's entire blood dis tributing enterprise.

title: Guards at Belmont Agree to Contract
description: A labor dispute that threatened to halt thorough bred racing at Belmont Park was ended last night when Pinkerton guards at the track ratified a new two year contract with the security company.

title: Nixon Fights Committee Bid for Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24  President Nixon's lawyers asked the United States District Court here today to reject the request for a summary judg ment that would force Mr. Nixon to turn over to the Sen ate Watergate committee tape recordings made in his office.In a 71page motion filed with Chief Judge John J. Sirica, Mr. Nixon's lawyers argued that the court had no jurisdic tion in the matter, that the committee, was exceeding con stitutional limits and its own mandate in requesting the tapes and that the President had an unquestioned power to give in formation to the Congress or to withhold it.

title: PRICES ARE HIGHER ON AMEX ANDOTC
description: The American Stock Ex change marketvalue index rose sharply yesterday, with its re tail, hightechnology and part of its naturalresources com ponents showing considerable strength. Prices also rose in the overthecounter market.

title: Pop, Rock Thrive on Concert Format
description: Some faces, new places that's the outlook for rock in the coming months in New York. The rock industry (and it is an industry) is forever poised and ready, awaiting the arrival of the New Elvis or the New Beatles to take us all into a new era of ex citement and affluence.

title: AGNEW WILL KEEP 2 SPEAKING DATES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 As Vice President Agnew's at torneys prepared to go into court by Wednesday to try to head off an investigation and possible indictment of their cli ent, Mr. Agnew's office an nounced today that he still planned to make a speaking trip to California this week.

title: Equity Financing
description: The Cordura Corporation announced its direct ors had authorized purchase of up to one million Cordura common shares outstanding from time to time for use in possible future acquisitions, employe benefit programs and stock option plans. The com pany's stock was up  at 4 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: A New Kissinger: Stress on LongRange Problems
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 24  Henry A. Kissinger raised more questions than he offered to solve today, but that was apparently his intention in his first speech as Secretary of State.

title: CITIZENS UNIT SCANS WESTCHESTER RACE
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 24 Common Cause, a nonpartisan citizens group, began today to monitor the campaign finances of the County Executive race in Westchester County.

title: TV NoShows Back at Parks
description: For six games on Sunday, there were 15,326 noshows, meaning those who had tick ets to the local pro game, but decided not to bother at tending, possibly because the game could be seen at home on television. That was quite a drop from 50,072 the week before who stayed away from 10 games tele vised locally.

title: Eximbank Sets Taiwan Loan
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UPI) The United States ExportIm port Bank today approved a $5.6million loan for Taiwan's Telecommunications Director ate and promised to support, if required, two private loans for another $5.6million, Taitel will use the funds for the purchase of United Statesmade commu nications equipment, valued at $14million. The United States suppliers have not yet been selected.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
RESTRAINT ASKED ON PERSICO TRIAL
description: Carmine Persico went on trial yesterday on a charge of plotting to harbor a fugitive murder suspect, with a judge again trying to black out his underworld record. A similar attempt in another case was ruled out of order on appeal.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Fell at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 Yields on United States Treasury bills fell sharply in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: At 6:50 A.M., an Entire Family Sits Down to Dinner Together
description: SOUTH SALEM, N. Y.By 6:27 A.M., which was when the sun rose on the first day of school here, the meat loaf in Betty Treyz's brick and beamed kit chen looked brown and juicy through the oven window. It was baking away in there with nine potatoes.

title: The Chunnel Wins
description: In 1867, upon being informed that Thome de Gamond had devised a plan to build a tunnel across the English Channel, Queen Victoria is said to have remarked: You can tell the French engineer that, if he succeeds, I will give him my blessings in my personal name and in the name of all the ladies of England. But a decade or so later, Lieut. Gen. Sir Garnet Wolseley thundered: Surely, John Bull will not endanger all that man can hold most dear, simply in order that men and women may cross to and fro between England and France without running the risk of seasickness. By that time, the Queen herself had withdrawn her blessing and called the tunnel very objectionable.

title: COTTON FUTURES RISE, THEN FALL
description: October delivery cotton jumped the 4 cents a pound daily limit yesterday reaching 99 cents a pound, the highest level in the 103yearhistory of the New York Cotton Exchange. Cotton prices have been rising steadily yesterday amid talk of heavy export buying and a growing shortage.

title: PROSECUTORS FINISH! IN GARRISON CASE
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 24! (UPI)The prosecution closed1 its case against District Attord ney Jim Garrison today, saying that he had betrayed the pub lic trust by accepting bribes from pinball machine operators for nine years.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: It Was Quite a Confusing Race

title: Advertising: The McCall's Plan
description: There was no surprise in the publishing community over the announcement of the impending sale of Mc Call's magazine. Everyone in the field knew that David J. Mahoney, chairman and pres ident of Norton Simon, Inc., wanted to sell it.

title: MUSICUS SAYS OIL IS IN SHORT SUPPLY
description: Fuel oil dealers in the city now have only about onefourth of the home heating oil they can store instead of the 70 per cent supply they should have as of Oct. 1, the city's energy coordinator said yesterday.

title: Boyle of Miners Union Is Admitted to Hospital
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP)W. A. Boyle, 71year old former president of the United Mine Workers, was admitted to George Washing ton University Hospital to night after suffering a pos sible stroke, hospital officials said.

title: Duryea Due to Be Called In VoteDraining Inquiry
description: A Manhattan grand jury is scheduled to begin hearing testimony next Tuesday on an alleged Republican party scheme to drain votes from Democratic candidates in the state by promotion of Liberal party candidates.

title: MRS. CHARLES E. BACON
description: BOSTON, Sept. 24  Mrs. Pauline Conant Bacon, widow of Charles E. Bacon, a former chairman of Allyn & Bacon Inc., textbook publishers, died yesterday at her home here.

title: Celtics Top Knicks, 10898
description: Smarting from a 140100 defeat here on Saturday night at the hands of the Buffalo Braves, the Boston Celtics played their National Basketball Association pre season exhibition last night against the New York Knicks at Madison Square Garden as if it were a vital playoff game.

title: U.S. Court Calls Hearing To Set Plans for Pennsy
description: Judge John P. Fullam of the Federal District Court in Phila delphia yesterday set Oct. 12 for a hearing to which he has asked all interested parties in the Penn Central Railroad's bankruptcy to advise the court under what conditions the rail road can continue train service.

title: An AboveAverage Brooklyn CatholicSchool Student Is Frustrated by Strike
description: For 16yearold Francis Folan, yesterday, the sixth day of the strike by teachers in eight Roman Catholic schools in Brooklyn and Queens, was the first day he voluntarily stayed home.

title: Arthur Daley
description: When it was originally decided to honor Willie Mays at Shea Stadium tonight, the planners thought it would not only be a nice send off for Willie but would also be a welcome interlude at the tag end of a disappointing season. Little did they suspect that they'd find themselves engulfed by Metsomania, a form of lunacy caused by pennant fever.

title: City Opera Saved
description: Thanks to the peace efforts of Mayor Lindsay's special mediator, Harold Israelson, the New York City Opera and its unionized musicians have settled the strike that threat ened to kill that invaluable cultural institution.

title: MRS. GEORGE F. ELIOT
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn., Sept. 24 Mrs. June Cowley Eliot, wid ow of George Fielding Eliot, the military writer and broad caster, died Friday in a Tor rington hospital. She was 71 years old.

title: Splashdown Coverage Set by 3 TV Networks
description: Skylab's expected splash down at 6:20 P.M. today will be covered live by the three major television networks.

title: Chilean Junta Hails Neruda But Bars a State Funeral
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 24 The military junta paid homage today to the Nobel Prizewin ning poet Pablo Neruda, who died here last night of cancer, as a figure of national pride. But it said there would not be a state funeral because the country was under a state of siege.

title: Cultural Revolution's Values Stressed
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 24A campaign of denunciation of the fallen Lin Piao is being made an occasion for reaffirming the values of the Cultural Revolu tion that he was once supposed to personify.

title: Associated Dry Goods Elects
description: William P. Arnold, president of J. W. Robinson Company, Los Angeles, has been elected to the board of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation. Robinson's is an Associated store division.

title: John Meehan, Correspondent For U.P.I. and FoxMovietone
description: LONDON, Sept. 24 (UPI) John J. Meehan, a correspon dent for United Press Interna tional and FoxMovietone News for 26 years died at his home today. He was 52 years old.

title: Steel Job Safety Stressed
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (UPI) New occupational health and safety standards are greatly needed to protect steel workers at their jobs, I. W. Abel, presi dent of the United Steelworkers, told the union's National Safety and Health Conference today.

title: Dodge $85Million Left to Foundation
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., Sept. 24 Geraldine Rockefeller Dodge, a niece of John D. Rockefeller, left the bulk of an $85million estate to a foundation in her name devoted to charitable, scientific, literary or other ed ucational purposes, or for the prevention of cruelty to ani mals, or for the encouragement of art.

title: ExEngineer at I.B.M. Brings Suit Against Concern, A.T.&T.
description: An 80yearold inventor and former research engineer for the International Business Ma chines Corporation has filed suit in Federal Court in Wash ington, charging both I.B.M. and the American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation with restraint of trade in viola tion of the Sherman Antitrust Act.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION OFF 1.3% IN WEEK
description: Production or steel in the week ended Saturday totaled 2,848,000 tons, a decline of 1.3 per cent from the 2,886,000 tons poured in the preceding week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yester day.

title: Terminal B Opens at Newark Airport, More Smoothly Than Counterpart Did
description: NEWARK, Sept. 24  At 5:35 this morning, Eastern Air Lines Flight 653 took off for Wilmington, Del. The unevent ful, ontime departure was the first from the stillincomplete Terminal B at Newark's new and expanding airport.

title: Hunt Says He Fabricated Cables on Diem to Link Kennedy to Killing of a Catholic
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24E. Howard Hunt Jr. said today that he had fabricated State Depart ment cables to show a link be tween President Kennedy and the assassination of the Presi dent of South Vietnam, Ngo Dinh Diem, a Roman Coholic, to estrange Catholic voters tram the Democratic party.

title: Connecticut School Assailed for Cutting Pledgeof Allegiance
description: MONROE, Conn., Sept. 24 (AP)A decision to cut back recitation of the Pledge of Al legiance at a high school here was aimed at trying to get the students to be a little more pa triotic. In the process it has stirred criticism from a school board member and others.

title: Campaign Money Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) Hearings on legislation to regulate political campaign con tributing and spending prac tices, long dormant in the }pause Administration Commit tee, will begin next week, the committee chairman, Wayne L. Hays, Democrat of Ohio, said today.

title: Football Transactions
description: NATIONAL CONFERENCE

title: MRS. CHARLES H. JONES
description: Mrs. Anna Livingston Short Jones, widow of Charles H. Jones, a member of the Long Island family for which Jones Beach is named, died yesterday at her home in Palm Beach, Fla. She was 85 years old and lived also at 1 East 66th Street and Cold Spring Harbor, L. I.

title: Chile's Military Chiefs Abolish Nation's Largest Labor Group
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 25 The military junta today abol ished the largest labor organi zation in Chile.

title: Nevele Bret 21 Favorite In Futurity
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 25 (AP)Nevele Bret drew post position No. 4 and was in stalled as the 21 favorite today for Friday night's 14th edition of the $81,695 Roose velt Futuritythe richest and most prestigious of all 2 yearold pacing events.

title: INSPECTOR FIGHTS TO STAY ON FORCE
description: Deputy Inspector James Mc Evoy is 58 years old, has been a New York City police officer for 33 years and is not ready to quit. He has petitioned the State Supreme Court to pre vent his forced retirement or reduction in rank.

title: AID TO CAMBODIA HELD INADEQUATE
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia Sept. 25Sources in the Unit ed States Embassy, citing higher level of fighting thi: year as a result of a Commu nist offensive, asserted today that more aid was needed foi the Lon Nol Government and said that a way will have to be found to provide it.

title: Garden State Ethnic Festivals a Dual Hit
description: HOLMDEL, Sept. 25Last Sunday the kilt was the dress of the day at the Garden State Arts Center while bag pipes and the songs of Bobbie Burns provided the ambience.

title: Nixon Urges Nation To Display Fairness
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 President Nixon appealed to the American people tonight to give Vice President Agnew the basic, decent consideration and presumption of innocence that are both his right and his due.

title: Tariff Curbs on Soviet Assailed
description: Donald M. Kendall, the chair man and chief executive offi cer of Pepsico, Inc., urged yes terday that the United States lift what he called its discrim inatory tariff restrictions against the Soviet Union.

title: Antifreeze Shortage Seen; Emergency Allocation Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI)Add antifreeze for au tomobiles to the items that may be scarce this winter.

title: Nixon Urges Nation To Display Fairness
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 President Nixon appealed to the American people tonight to give Vice President Agnew the basic, decent consideration and presumption of innocence that are both his right and his due.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., Sept.  Bob Seddon's problem, some of his friends put it, is that he is soccersick. Seddon says he has had the disease for 15 years now, but it has just started to infect others.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE RIVERSIDE VILLAS MURDER. By Kings ley Amis. 224 pages. Harcourt Brace Jova novich. $6.95.

title: Cornfeld to Reimburse Swiss I.O.S. Employes
description: GENEVA, Sept. 25 Bernard Cornfeld has agreed to wholly reimburse Swiss employes for losses they suffered through investing in his Investors Over seas Services mutual fund em pire. He also undertook to aid nonSwiss employes and to make available $1,335,000 for the reimbursements and to help sort things out in the wake of the crash of I.O.S.

title: Letter to the House
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25Following is the text Vice President Agnew's letter to the House tonight:

title: MRS. POST'S WILL FILED IN CAPITAL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 Marjorie Merriweather Post, the breakfastfood heiress whose fortune and style of liv ing outshone that of most queens, and whose philanthropy was legend, displayed a royally imperious touch in her last will and testament, a 50page docu ment filed yesterday in District of Columbia Superior Court.

title: Improved Security In the City Schools Pledged by Anker
description: In an effort to curb crime and violence, public schools will use more security devices, including pensize personal alarms for teachers and closed circuit television sentries, School Chancellor Irving Anker said yesterday.

title: Pension Reform Drive Gains as House Panel Supports a Bill to Protect Rights of Workers
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 A Congressional drive for pen sion reform gained momentum today as the House Education and Labor Committee unani mously reported out a bill to protect the rights of workers covered by private retirement plans.

title: Rosh haShanah, the Year 5734 For Jews, to Begin at Sundown
description: Rosh haShanah, the Jewish New Year, will begin at sun down today with solemn syna gogue services.

title: L.S.U. Ticket Sale Stirs Student Fight
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 25 (UPI)Fighting broke out today among Louisiana State University students standing in a long line to buy tickets to the L.S.U.Mississipi foot ball game on Nov. 3.

title: MIDDLE EAST UNIT SEES FUND CRISIS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 25 The United Nations agency that provides food, medical care and education for 1.5 million Palestinian refugees is in finan cial difficulties that could bring a curtailment of services.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: The longawaited rematch between the former world heavyweight champions, Muhammad Ali and Joe Frazier, is very close to being made, according to United Press International. We are satisfied with the terms, said Bob Arum, Ali's attorney. Now it's up to them to agree.

title: BID TO HOUSE ENDS LONG SPECULATION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 Vice President Agnew's sudden and dramatic lateafternoon ap pearance at the House of Rep resentatives today ended weeks of speculation about how he would fight allegations that have emerged against him from a Federal investigation into corruption in Maryland.

title: REA Director Resigns
description: Selig Altschul, president of Aviation Advisory Service, inc., resigned yesterday as a director of the REA Holding Corpora tion, parent of the express company. Mr. Altschul, who joined REA three years ago, said he was retiring now for personal reasons.

title: Excerpts From Gromyko's Speech to U.N. Assembly
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 25  Following are excerpts from an address delivered in the General As sembly today by Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, as supplied in English trans lation by the Soviet mission:

title: Mrs. Huxtable on Editorial Board
description: Ada Louise Huxtable, archi tecture critic of The New York Times, has been named a member of the editorial board of The Times, it was announced yesterday by John B. Oakes, editor of the edi torial page. Mrs. Huxtable will divide her time between the editorial board and ex panded duties as architecture columnist for the Sunday paper.

title: APLANT HAZARDS HELD OVERSTATED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  Members of Congress reviewing the safety of nuclear power plants were told today that worst case analysis had over stated the real risks of serious accidents to these plants ten fold or more.

title: Scott Defends Role in Award of Contract
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 Senator Hugh Scott asserted today that his involvement in the selection of a site for a Federal building in Philadelphia was a legitimate advocacy springing from the desires of my constituents that did not benefit him financially in any way.

title: Westinghouse Elects
description: Dr. Marina v. N, Whitman, the first woman to serve on the Council of Economic Ad visers, was elected yesterday to the board of the Westing house Electric Corporation. Dr. Whitman recently returned to the University of Pittsburgh after serving on the council. She had been in governmental service since 1970.

title: Brewers Top Yanks In 13th, 32
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 25 The Brewers defeated the Yankees tonight, 3.2, in 13 innings. Lindy McDaniel, the losing pitcher became the first Yankee pitcher to bat this season.

title: Fisher in Display Of the Improbable On 5String Bass
description: String bass recitals are rare enough, but an unaccompanied, pizzicato string bass recital ending with The Flight of the Bumble Bee, the first half of the Second Hungarian Rhap sody by Liszt, the National Em blem March and Chopin's Revolutionary Etude? Against all probability, that is precisely what took place at Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night as Al Fisher made his New York concert debut.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:

title: Records
description: If you put on the Concord String Quartet's superb new recording of George Roch berg's String Quartet No. 3 (Nonesuch H71283, $2.98) somewhere in the middle, you might swear for minutes on end that you were listen ing to some unfamiliar piece by Beethoven or Mahler. For what Mr. Rochberg, long identified as a leading Amer ican serialist, has written is piece that carries the prin ciple of collage to new ex tremes. Instead of weaving together actual short quota tions, or fragments into an antique styleas Charles Ives and innumerable others since have doneMr. Roch berg pulls apart the time span and juxtaposes whole, long blocks of his own ma terial in different styles. That means the quartet lasts 47 minutes, and that changes, when they do come, are all the more dramatic for their infrequency.

title: Probation in Fraud Case
description: ROCHESTER, Sept. 25 (AP)I Five Elmira residents whol admitted filing fraudulent apI plications for Federal disaster loans followig the June, 1972 floods, have been placd on probation. One of the de fendants was ordered to repay the Government $1,000 he had received.

title: Howe Displays Old Style In W .H.A. RoundRobin
description: It was billed as the world's first hocky spectacular. But a small crowd of 7,092 at Madison Square Garden last night was unexcited by the World Hockey Association's four team roundrobin con test which marked the first home appearance of the New York Golden Blades.

title: Outrider's Quarter Horse Is Surest Bet at Belmont
description: Prince was the fastest horse on the track at Bel mont Park yesterday. The program never shows Prince's name, because he is a 7year old gelded quarter horse owned by an outrider, Jimmy Dailey.

title: CAT BURGLAR GETS 30 WORKS OF ART
description: A cat burglar squirmed 25 feet up a drainpipe on a hand some town house on East 68th Street and, the police believe, was helped by accomplices to steal 30 pieces of art valued at almost $150,000.

title: Failures Mark Russian Space Program
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  Although the Russians have spent almost twice as much on manned space programs as the United States, the Soviet effort his been beset by failure lately and its record stands in stark contrast to the successes of Skylab and Apollo, according to intelligence sources.

title: U.S. IN DISARRAY, DR. MEAD CHARGES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  Dr. Margaret Mead, the anthro pologist, told a Senate subcom mittee today that the American dream had turned into a night mare for millions of the na tion's citizens.

title: Ivy Group Athletics Gets Chief
description: The eight Ivy League uni versity presidents, deter mined to better coordinate athletic policies, named the leagues first executive direc for yesterday. He is RicardA. Mestres, a 63yearold Prince ton graduate, who served his alma mater as vice president of financial affairs and treas urer for 20 years before re last year.

title: Providence Guild Votes To End 12Day Strike
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I. (AP) Local 41 of The Newspaper Guild voted to end a 12day strike against the Journal Com pany tonight following the is suance of a Superior Court in junction that would have lim ited the guild's ability to picket the newspaper's main offices.

title: The Satraps
description: On September 17 Asia News Service of Berkeley, Calif., received a broadcast from Prensa Latina, the Cuban press agency, saying that this poem by Pablo Neruda, Chilean poet and 1971 Nobel laureate, had been written shortly before the military coup in his country and published in Argentina. Mr. Neruda died last Sunday. The poem is translated by John Felstiner of Stanford.

title: C. B. S. Head to Speak Out on TV's Rights'
description: Arthur R. Taylor, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System said yesterday he planned to speak out this fall on television's rights under the First Amendment, on TV's re sponsibility to the public and on what dangers we see in Government regulation.

title: ExHusband Kills Former Wife And Himself in Jersey Home
description: CALDWELL, N. J., Sept. 25 (UPI)  After holding his divorced wife hostage while 25 policemen surrounded his home and filled it with tear gas to day, a Caldwell man apparently shot her in the head and then committed suicide, the police reported.

title: First Class Mail Costing 10 Cents Planned for Jan. 5
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 Postmaster General Elmer Klassen, contending that there is no better bargain in the country than mail service, submitted a request today to the Postal Rate Commission for an across the board rise in postal rates. The proposal in eludes 2cent increases in air mail postage from 11 cents to 13 cents, and in first class post age from 8 cents to 10 cents.

title: RATES DROP AGAIN FOR SHORT TERM
description: Shortterm interest rates tumbled again along a broad front yesterday in continued re sponse to a belief that the Fed eral Reserve credit policy is be coming somewhat less tight.

title: NIXON AIDE SEES RISE IN FOOD PRICE LATER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 Gary L. Seevers, the agricul tural expert on the President's Council of Economic Advisers, (predicted today that food prices would be relatively stable through October but would (probably start rising again to ward the end of the year.

title: Chamber Backs Transit Bonds; Kheel Disputes City Club Stand
description: The New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry yes terday announced its endorse ment of Governor Rockefeller's proposed $3.5billion transpor tation bond issue.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Berrigans Expect Baby
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 25 (UPI)  The Rev. Philip F Berrigan and his wife, Elizabeth McAlis ter, said today that they were expecting a baby in April. Father Berrigan, who was ex communicated from the Roman Catholic Church for breaking his priest's vows by marrying, said that he and his wife, a former nun, planned to raise the child in the church.

title: Sugarman Offers Plan to Find Absent Fathers in Relief Cases
description: The city, in whole or in part, was offered, yesterday as a pilot area for a Federal project that would try to find absent fathers in welfare cases.

title: HUNT THEORIZES ON DOUBLE AGENT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 E. Howard Hunt Jr., who has written more than 40 spy novels, added a new twist to the Watergate plot today, pro posing a theory that the bur glars were exposed by a double agent.

title: Inquiry on I.T.T. Sought; Antitrust Cases at Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  The Department of Justice asked a Federal court today to order an inquiry into the pos sibility that the International Telephone and Telegraph Cor poration was attempting to thwart the terms of the already controversial settlement of three antitrust cases against it.

title: LowCost Loans to Poor Lands Backed
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 25 The United States and 24 other nations agreed in principle to day to contribute $4.5billion to the World Bank over the next three years for lowcost loans to the poorest countries, but the shadow of the United States Congress hung over the agree ment.

title: Coryell, Cardinals' Rookie Head Coach, Evokes Memories of Vince Lombardi
description: The temperature was a muggy 86 in Busch Stadium last Sunday but the St. Louis Cardinals were blowing clean fresh air through the Na tional Football League. In scoring 34 points on one of the league's best defensive teams, Washington, the Car dinals displayed an offense based on the pass that was a pleas ure to watch in contrast to the stodgy predict able ground at tacks that infest the N.F.L.

title: BROKERS INDICTED ON FRAUD CHARGE
description: Nine stockbrokers were in dicted here yesterday on charges that they participated in scheme that allegedly manipu lated an overthecounter stock from $1 to $5.50 a share in a twomonth period in 1971.

title: U.S. and Soviet Resume Talks on Strategic Arms
description: GENEVA, Sept. 25  The United States and the Soviet Union resumed their talks or limitation of strategic arms to day, with negotiators working against a new deadline for comprehensive agreement.

title: Kitchen Closings Are Curbed in Jersey
description: TRENTON, Sept. 25  The dramatic closings of dirty kit chens in restaurants, hospitals and state institutions by Dr. Oscar Sussman ended today.

title: DrugPayola Defendant Seeks Delay
description: Charging that he has been the target of adverse news paper and magazine publicity, Pasquale Falcone, an alleged chief figure in Federal investi gations of both drug smuggling and record company payola, basked yesterday that his trial on drug charges he postponed.

title: Kissinger's New Vision
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 25 If the United Nations does nothing else for the statesmen of the world, it manages somehow to make them pay attention to their hopes and ideals. They don't really believe in the U.N. as an effective instrument for keeping the peace, but they defend its prin ciples in theory even when they defy them in practice.

title: Santas, One 106, Begin Training for Christmas
description: Santa Clause went into training here yesterdaya re minder to anyone who didn't happen to be thinking about it that Christmas was exact ly three months away.

title: 41 Neighborhood Groups Cited for Beautification
description: Fouryearold Gerald Wil liams planted a white flower that, to the best of his recol lection, was a yesanthenan.

title: Agnew's Lawyers And Justice Dept. Reach an Impasse
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25Vice President Agnew moved today to head off any Federal grand jury action against him by asking the House of Representatives to begin an inquiry into charges that he took kickbacks from contractors when he was a state and local official in Maryland.

title: Doctor at C.I.A. Links Kissinger To Request for Ellsberg Profile
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25The Senate Watergate committee made public today an affidavit in which an official of the Cen tral Intelligence Agency linked Henry A. Kissinger, the new Secretary of State, to a 1971 request for a psychiatric profile, of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg.

title: CREW OF SKYLAB 2 ENDS RECORD TRIP, 59 DAYS IN SPACE
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 25Man's longest journey in space, the marathon 59day, 24million mile flight of the Skylab 2 crew, ended today with a safe and accurate splashdown in the Pacific Ocean.

title: Esty Memorial Tomorrow
description: There will be a memorial service at 4 P.M. tomorrow in Judson Memorial Church for William C. Esty 4th, a founder and treasurer of the Village Community School, who died of cancer in August at his sum mer home in Shoreham, L. I. He was 48 years old, a graduate of the Deerfield Academy and Amherst College, and a free lance writer. He left his wife, the former Susan Colby New man, and four children, Abigail, Annie, Miles and Thomas.

title: Permanent Currency Floating Is Denounced at Parley
description: NAIROBI, Kenya Sept. 25 The leading economic powers displayed today some of their disagreements on specific points of international mone tary reform, but all expressed a will to reach agreement by the new deadline of next July 31.

title: INDIA BARS VISAS TO U.S. SCHOLARS
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 25 Nearly half the American scholars seeking to work in India this year are unable to receive visas, according to In dian and American officials.

title: West Side Highway Work Expected to Causetie Ups
description: Mayor Lindsay, concerned that much of the public is un aware of the impending effects of closing part of the West Side Highway for 90 days, has or dered the distribution of maps and detour instructions.

title: 22 Slates of Candidates: To Vie in Israeli Election
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 25The deadline passed tonight for en tering candidates in the parlia mentary elections to be held Oct. 30, with 22 slates entered.

title: Richey, Okker, Nastase Advance in $50,000 Tennis
description: NILES, Ill., AP  Cliff Richey of Sarasota, Fla., and Tom Okker of the Nether lands breezed through first round matches today in the $50,000 Tam international tennis tournament.

title: CREW OF SKYLAB 2 ENDS RECORD TRIP, 59 DAYS IN SPACE
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 25Man's longest journey in space, the marathon 59day, 24million mile flight of the Skylab 2 crew, ended today with a safe and accurate splashdown in the Pacific Ocean.

title: SENATE UPHOLDS VETO ON LOAN PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP)The Senate sustained to day President Nixon's veto of a bill that would have mark edly liberalized the disaster loan program.

title: Namath Gets on His Feet, And XRays Look Good
description: It looks good, Dr. James Nicholas said yesterday. The latest Xrays show a perfect reduction. Unless something unexpected hap pens, we've decided against surgery.

title: Royalty Attends King Gustaf's Funeral
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 25 (AP) All but one of Europe's reigning Kings and Queens fol lowed the body of King Gustaf VI Adolf to its grave today.

title: LAWS ON BUILDING EASED BY COUNCIL
description: The City Council passed four bills yesterday that would change construction standards to conform with Federal regu lations so as to obtain $77.5 million in Federal urbanre newal aid.

title: BOYLE NEAR DEATH IN SUICIDE EFFORT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 W. A. Boyle, the 71yearold ailing former president of the United Mine Workers Union, attempted suicide last night on the eve of a court appearance he this morning on a murder charge, his doctor disclosed to day.

title: Nets Win, 115111; Erving Scores 20
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Sept. 25  A jump shot by Bill Paultz with 1 minute 27 sec onds remaining and a pair of free throws by John Roche enabled the New York Nets to defeat the Virginia Squires, 115111, tonight in an American Basketball As sociation preseason game at Fairfield University.

title: Other Major News
description: The Senate sustained Presi dent Nixon's veto of a bill that would have markedly liberalized the disaster loan program. The vote was 59 to 36, or five short of the re quired twothirds to over ride a veto. Page 16.

title: Agnew's Lawyers And Justice Dept. Reach an Impasse
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25Vice President Agnew moved today to head off any Federal grand jury action against him by asking the House of Representatives to begin an inquiry into charges that he took kickbacks from contractors when he was a state and local official in Maryland.

title: AILEEN POE
description: Aileen Poe, an actress who appeared in many Broadway shows, from Berlin in 1931 to Fade Out, Fade In with Carol Burnett in 1964, died Saturday in Deerfield Beach, Fla., where she had been liv ing in retirement. She was 79 years old.

title: Inquiry on I.T.T. Sought; Antitrust Cases at Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 The Department of Justice asked a Federal court today to order an inquiry into the pos sibility that the International Telephone and Telegraph Cor poration was attempting to thwart the terms of the already controversial settlement of three antitrust cases against it.

title: Text of Nixon Statement
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP)Following is the text of a statement by President Nixon regarding the allegations against Vice President Agnew:

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: After a New York State As semblyman was mugged and complained about inadequate police protection, Albany detec tives were sent out to interview prostitutes and barowners in an apparent attempt to dis credit the legislator's story, a former detective testified.

title: MOZAMBIQUE KILLING TERMED CONFIRMED
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Sept. 25 (Reuters)The Johannesburg Star said today that it had obtained confirma tion that there was a massacre in Mozambique last year.

title: Newlywed Dies in Jump From Husband's Auto
description: LOPATCONG, Sept. 25 (AP)A wife of eight days was killed last night when she jumped from her hus band's moving car on River Road here during an argu ment, the state police said.

title: Saigon Says Reds Used Tanks in Attack on Camp
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Sept. 26 (Reuters)  The Saigon military Com mand said today that the North Vietnamese Army had used tanks to overrun a ranger base camp in the Central Highlands the first direct tank assault reported since the ceasefire in January.

title: Guerrillas Kill Argentina's Labor Leader
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 25 Argentina's principal labor leader, a strong supporter of Presidentelect Juan D. Pern, was assassinated by urban guer rillas today less than 24 hours after a Marxist guerrilla organ ization was outlawed by the Government.

title: Computer Discussions End
description: The Control Data Corpora tion announced yesterday that it had discontinued discussions with the Bank of America and the Memorex Corporation con cerning a possible agreement to manage and maintain com puter peripheral equipment built and leased by Memorex.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FLICK FLECKING What with the Lincoln Center Film Festival coming up, it seems as if the whole town is get ting moviehappy. A new Wednesday 8 P.M. series, The Biograph, starts resur recting oldies in an examina tion of film's origins tonight at Central Arts, the church associated center at 108 East 64th Street (TE 80808).

title: Text of C.I.A. Ellsberg Affidavit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 Following is the text of an affidavit submitted to the Senate Watergate committee by a Central Intelligence Agency staff psychiatrist concerning the psychological profile of Daniel Ellsberg:

title: U.S.I.A. Chief Fails to Ease Soviet Curbs on Newsmen
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 25 (UPI)  James Keogh, director of the United States Information Agen cy, said today that he had com plained to Soviet officials about unfair restrictions on Ameri can newsmen, but had made no progress in getting them lifted.

title: Other Major News
description: The Senate sustained Presi dent Nixon's veto of a bill that would have markedly liberalized the disaster loan program. The vote was 59 to 36, or five short of the re quired twothirds to over ride a veto. Page 16.

title: Prominent Brokers Fail to Gain Accord On Negotiated Rates
description: Leaders of the securities in clustry, meeting yesterday in Boston, failed to agree on unified stance regarding a con troversial order by the Securi ties and Exchange Commission that all brokerage house corn mission rates must be fully negotiated by April 30, 1975.

title: Baseball Says Farewell To Willie Mays and Era
description: Baseball said goodby to another era last night at Shea Stadium. For 55 min utes a crowd of more than 50,000, young and old, cheered Willie Mays, who is leaving the game after 22 years.

title: People in Sports: ShakeUp at Ole Miss
description: I don't see how in the world we can improve the situation in terms of wins, but we'll certainly be trying, said John Vaught, who was brought out of retirement yesterday to replace Billy Kinard as football coach and Frank (Bruiser) Kinard as athletic director at the Uni versity of Mississippi.

title: Gubernatorial Candidates Divided on Education
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Sept. 25 The Republican and Demo cratic nominees for Governor appeared today before a forum arranged at Rutgers University by the American Association of University Professors and disagreed on the state's Ad ministratory of Education.

title: FRIEND OF NIXON WINS COURT POINT
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 25C. Arnholt Smith won a prelimi pary skirmish today with the internal Revenue Service over he service's move to press criminal proceedings against the 74yearold financier, a longtime friend of President Nixon.

title: Hawks Set Back Knicks by 9786
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 25  The New York Knicker bockers dropped their third straight exhibition game to night to the Atlanta Hawks, 9786. The game was played for the benefit of the United FundRed Cross Societies be fore a capacity crowd of 7, 550 in Jadwin Gym.

title: BID TO HOUSE ENDS LONG SPECULATION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  Vice President Agnew's sudden and dramatic lateafternoon ap pearance at the House of Rep resentatives today ended weeks of speculation about how he would fight allegations that have emerged against him from a Federal investigation into corruption in Maryland.

title: Soviet Bids 5 Big Powers Cut Arms Budget by 10%
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 25The Soviet Union pro posed today that the five great powers that are permanent members of the Security Coun cil cut their military budgers by 10 per cent.

title: Astronauts' Return
description: That was a triumphant return of the Skylab 2 astro nauts yesterday. The word triumphant is entirely appropriate because even at this early point it is evident that their 59day stay in orbit was not only the longest manned space flight in history but also the most pro ductive.

title: NewCar Sales Up 33.5% In MidSeptember Period
description: DETROIT, Sept. 25  New car sales in the Sept. 1120 period rose 33.5 per cent to 201,447 units from the 150,910 sold in the comparable days of 1972.

title: Fire Levels Summer Home
description: CHAUTAUQUA, N. Y., Sept. 25 (AP)  Fire in this resort community destroyed one sum mer home yesterday and dam aged three others. There were no injuries. The loss was esti mated in excess of $150,000.

title: RESPECT HISTORY, BRANDY ASSERTS
description: Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany, speaking here yesterday at an occasion filled with memories of Nazi persecu tion, warned against a tendency all over the Western world to treat the knowledge of history rather lightly and somewhat arbitrarily.

title: 13 More Judges Are Named Under New Antidrug Laws
description: ALBANY, Sept. 25 (AP)  Three more appointments to new State Supreme Court judge ships, created to enforce the new antidrug laws, were an nounced by Governor Rockefel ler's office today.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP)A House subcommittee approved without recommendation today a bill that would reorganize bankrupt railroads in the Northeast and leave possibly scores of communities without rail service.

title: City Pupils' Reading Scores, in Shift, Show Gains
description: The proportion of pupils reading at or above the norm or standard for their grade increased during the last academic year in 334 of the city's 631 elementary schools, according to a new report compiled by the Board of Education.

title: 3 OIL GOVERNORS HINT RETALIATION
description: POINT CLEAR, Ala. Sept. 25 The governors of three major oil and gas producing states warned today that they might cut off shipments of energy supplies to other parts of the country if those areas did not relax Their environmentoriented restrictions on refining and ex ploration drilling.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended, Sept. 18.

title: JEWISH COMMUNITIES IN ARAB LANDS EBB
description: PARIS, Sept. 25  The once flourishing Jewish conimuni ties in several countries of the Arab Middle East are dwindling steadily, according to a report released today by the Ameri can Jewish Committee in Paris.

title: Theater: Poetry and Song of Self Love
description: The Canadian poet and entertainer Leonard Cohen seems to fancy himself rather a lot. It is an attitude that other people have the right to disassociate from.

title: The Trophy's in Lenox Hill Again.
description: Once, in discussing whether the National Football League should create new rules to protect the quarterback, Joe Namath shook his head.

title: America's Last Frontier
description: Alaska is the last great unspoiled area on the North American continent. It is the only state in which it still possible to save not only river valleys but also whole watersheds and integrated ecosystems. Alaska critically important for its vast forest and wildlife resources. It encompasses breathtaking wilderness and areas of extraordinary scenic beauty. The central section of the vast Brooks mountain range, for example, has been called the gates of the Arctic and would make a superb national park.

title: The Elusive Solution
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 25 The excruciating difficult task the nations of the nonCommu nist world set for themselves in Washington a year ago negotiating a new world mone tary systemstill seems far from a solution. The question now is whether the July 31, 1974, deadline set here for final agreement on the outline for the new system is not unrealistic as well, in the light of the serious differences the negotiating nations.Some observers here have even begun to wonder whether the whole process of negotia tion may not be headed for breakdown in the coming year unless political decisions > are taken at the highest level to reconcile opposing views on all the major issues.

title: Recently Published Books
description: FICTION

title: V.A. HEAD DEFENDS EDUCATIONAL AID
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  A Veterans Administration of ficial told a House subcommit tee today that the majority of Vietnam era veterans are better off today in terms of educational benefits than World War II or Korean vet erans.

title: HUGHES POUR BID ON NIXON CHARGED
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25 (UPI) Howard R. Hughes made cash contributions of $100,000 to President Nixon's campaigns be cause he wanted to own the President and choose his suc cessor, a former top assistant of Mr. Hughes alleged today.

title: JOHN HAMILTON, G.O.P. STRATEGIST
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., Sept. 25 (AP)John D. M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican Na tional Committee from 1936 to 1940, died yesterday in Morton S. Plant Hospital. He was 81 years old and had lived in Clearwater Beach since retiring in 1964 as senior partner in the Philadelphia law firm of Pepper, Hamilton & Scheetz.

title: People and Business
description: Quintin U. Ford, senior vice president of the Bankers Trust Company, proposed yesterday the adoption of tax incentives to draw small in vestors back into the stock market.

title: The Dazzling Pace of a Musical Genius
description: Today is the 75th anni versary of the birth of George Gershwin at 242 Snediker Avenue in Brooklyn. Three new books about him and new editions of two old books release today, among other activities, commemorate the occasion. Since he died at the age of 38not in Brook lyn, but in Holly wood  observ ance of his birth day becomes a memorial. There has always been a wistful feeling that he died before he had finished his work.

title: Triumph for Miss Price
description: Leontyne Price last sang the title role of Madams Butterfly at the Metropolitan Opera in 1961. Shortly there after, she sang it in Milan and Vienna and then dropped it from her repertory. For her the decision was probably wise: The music's unusually low range has been known to wreck sopranos' voices. But for the public this was a great loss.

title: LEFTISPS MOURN NERUDA AT RITES
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 25 The funeral service for the poet Pablo Neruda turned into a leftwing demonstration today, the first since the military junta overthrew President Sal vador Allende Gossens two weeks ago.

title: On Gershwin's Day, Rhapsody of Praise
description: George Gershwin, who would have been 75 today, was feted in absentia yester day at the oasis that will be forever 21.

title: Morse Decides Against Confiscation Of Braniff Jetliner in Smuggling Case
description: Robert A. Morse, the United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, said yes terday that he would not con fiscate a Braniff International DC8 jet on which narcotics had been smuggled into the United States from South Amer ica last spring.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N., Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Listed to speak in gen eral debate: West Germany, Denmark, Britain, the Neth erlands, Mongolia, New Zea land, Upper Volta, El Salva dor.

title: Doctor at C.I.A. Links Kissinger To Request for Ellsberg Profile
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 25The Senate Watergate committee made public today an affidavit, in which an official of the Cen tral Intelligence Agency linked Henry A. Kissinger, the new Secretary of State, to a 1971 request for a psychiatric profile of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg.

title: Women Gambling in Las Vegas Don't Hide in Corner Any More
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev.A fash ionable, darkhaired woman in sunglasses, who faintly re sembled Jacqueline Onassis, picked up the dice, blew on them and shook them in the air over her right ear.

title: Equity Financing
description: The Cerro Corporation said about 240,000 shares of its common stock had been tendered its offer, extended to expire on Oct. 15, to purchase up to 500,000 of its own shares at $15 a share. The company's stock closed at 15, up  on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Laws on Obscenity Opposed for Adults By Book Publishers
description: The Association of American Publishers, which represents 260 book publishing houses that produce 85 per cent of the nation's books, urged yesterday the outright repeal of all so called obscenity laws as they relate to consenting adults.

title: Angry judge Calls A Persico Mistrial
description: Angrily accusing The New York Times and The Daily News of prejudicing the jury, Federal Judge John R. Bartels yesterday declared a mistrial in the Govern ment's case against Carmine Persico.

title: Where Are Volunteers?
description: HONOLULUUnited States reliance upon a volunteer military establish ment does not seem to be working well, and if an improvement in the rate of enlistments doesn't material ize, the nation will either be forced to reduce overseas commitments more than its policymakers desire or find a new defense budgeting ap proach.

title: Excerpts From Hunt's Testimony Before Senate Panel Investigating Watergate
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of the testimony in Washington yesterday of E. Howard Hunt Jr. before the Senate Select Committee on Presidential Campaign Activities:

title: Sextuplets Off Respirators; Mother Allowed to Go Home
description: DENVER, Sept. 25 (UPI) Doctors tok the fifth of the Stanek sextuplets off a re. spirator today and allowed the infants mother to go home. All five surviving children will spend at least another month in the hospital under intensive care.

title: Big Board Selects a Chief For FeasibilityStudy Unit
description: The New York Stock Ex change has named Samuel A. Gay, a senior vice president, to head a team of Big Board staff members who will de velop feasibility studies on com bining the New York and Pa cific Stock Exchanges.

title: 3d Council Redistricting Plan Drafted
description: A special committee of the City Council yesterday pro duced a third version of its controversial plan to redistrict itself to increase representa tion of blacks and Puerto Ri cans.

title: DETROIT TEACHERS WILL DEFY COURT
description: DETROIT, Sept. 25 (AP) The Detroit Federation of Teachers voted today to defy a court order and continue the fourweek strike that has given some 270,000 students ex tended summer vacations.

title: 12 Firefighters Treated.
description: Twelve firemen reported to St. Luke's Hospital for treat ment of smoke poisoning yes terday after quelling a smoky onealarm fire at 16 West 134th Street. No one else was injured in the fire, which oc curred after 11 A.M, on the top floor of the fivestory brick building.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:The infinitesimal risk of cancer caused by nuclear power plants claimed in his Sept. 14 letter by Dr. L. D. Hamilton of the Brookhaven National Laboratory (an institution funded by the Atomic Energy. Commission) replete with glaring flaws in logic.

title: CAT BURGLAR GETS 30 WORKS OF ART
description: A cat burglar squirmed 25 feet up a drainpipe on a hand some town house on East 68th Street and, the police believe, was helped by accomplices to steal 30 pieces of art valued at almost $150,000.

title: SOYBEAN PRICES IN WIDE SWINGS
description: Soybean prices were on a roller coaster yesterday. Heavy buying on news of rain in growing areas pushed prices ahead, profit taking then ran them, down again, and finally they Moved up sharply to close up the daily limit or near it.

title: COMINCO INCREASES SOME PRICES OF ZINC
description: Corninco, Ltd., announced yesterday that it was raising its price for zinc sold in Can ada by 3 cents a pound to 28 cents. Later, Cominco said the price increase applied to North American zinc with prime Western zinc quoted at 28 cents a pound and special high grade zinc at 28 cents a pound.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Bloomingdale's has discovered that flattering its customers does it no harm. So it has dedicated its latest batch of model rooms to the Cogno scenti. Which cognoscenti? Oh, some writers, a composer, a cook.

title: Mets Win, 21, Lead by Game and Half As Phils' Carlton Thwarts Pirates, 21
description: In a riotously noisy eve ning before 53,603 fans in Shea Stadium, the New York Mets said goodby to Willie Mays last night and then gained their seventh straight victory by defeating the Montreal Expos, 21.

title: Threat by Bolivian Strikers
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 25. (AP)  Leaders of a strike paralyzing the Bolivian capi tal's financial institutions and factories today threatened ex treme measures unless the military Government freed 89 labor leaders accused of a Marxist plot against the Gov ernment.

title: Race Without Issues
description: State Senator John J. Mar chi's hard line on crime in the city has generated some life in his mayoral campaign and some heat in a mayoral race that threatens to be one of the dullest in memory. But, there is considerable questioning among politicians of how much light had been shed by the tough talk on law and or der or how much impact it will have on the voters. A major reason for the lack of ex citmentbeyond the lowkey personalities of three of the four major contenders and the fact that it's the second time around for three of themis the lack of a major issue to differentiate them.

title: Soviet Portrays Sakharov as Backer of Chile's Junta
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 25  They Soviet press today resumed personal attacks against An drei D. Sakharov after a two week interlude, seeking to pre sent the physicist and civil rights advocate as a supporter of the military junta in Chile.

title: Inquiry Told How Crime Victim Became Police Target
description: ALBANY, Sept. 25  A for mer detective testified today that after a State Assemblyman was mugged here and com plained about inadequate police protection, Albany detectives were sent to interview prosti tutes and bar owners in an ap parent attempt to discredit the legislator's story.

title: Mad Bomber Due For Court Hearing; It Could Free Him
description: George Metesky, the Mad Bomber who has been in state mental hospitals since he was judged incompetent to stand trial in 1957, will receive court hearing that could lead to his freedom.

title: POLICEMAN WOUNDS FUGITIVE BOY IN CAR
description: A policeman in Brooklyn yesterday shot and wounded a 15yearold fugitive from a youth house who tried to run down the officer with an auto mobile, the police said.

title: Lefkowitz Advises A Consumer Class On How to Save
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz moved his plead ings from the legal community to the classroom yesterday as he began the first of eight. lectures on Protecting the Consumer in New York at the New School for Social Re search.

title: Deeley Deplores Proposal by Caso For Mitchel Park
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 25 William J. Deeley Jr., Demo. cratic candidate for Nassau County Executive, today pro posed a development plan for Mitchel Field that he said would relieve one of the most press ing burdens on the residents of Nassau County, the realprop erty tax.

title: Sadat's Successes: New Moves Winning Arab Acclaim
description: CAIRO, Sept. 25Arab diplo mats here believe that Presi dent Anwar elSadat has gained substantial political strength at home and in the Arab world as a result of recent events.

title: Senate Votes Measures That Could Add Billions to Budgets for Defense Department
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 The Senate, which has sper the last week debating whet er to cut military spending approved today amendment potentially adding billions dollars to future defense budgets.

title: North Brunswick Presses For Transfer of Students
description: NORTH BRUNSWICK TOWN SHIP, Sept. 25  This mu nicipality's Citizens Action Group has organized a letter writing, telephone and tele graph campaign to persuade the state's Education Department to approve the transfer of North Brunswick's 10thgrade pupils from New Brunswick High School to a new high school here.

title: CALIFORNIA GETS COMMODITIES LAW
description: California has become the first state to put into effect a tough, comprehensive law regulating trading in commodi ties and commodity options.

title: F.D.A. Orders New Mushroom Check
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI)The Food and Drug Ad ministration ordered today a nationwide examination of all canned mushrooms still in warehouses after finding that half the mushroomcanning plants in the country had de fective equipment or proce dures.

title: City Aides and Tenant Groups Split on Merits of Housing Court
description: City housing officials said yesterday that the city's new housing court, scheduled to be gin functioning next Monday after various delays and con troversy, would play a far more effective role in combating housing decay and violations than the present court system did.

title: 20 PERSONS RESCUED AS 2 CHURCHES BURN
description: A threealarm fire destroyed a fourstory commercial  style building and damaged a neigh boring sixfamily tenement and a civic center last night on Manhattan's Lower East Side.

title: Net Up at Pan Am and Northwest and Off at Eastern
description: Earnings of Pan American World Airways and Northwest Airlines climbed in August, but those of Eastern Air Lines piunged from the similar month last year, according to the re sults reported yesterday by the three carriers.

title: Excerpt From MonetaryReform Draft
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 25 (Reuters)  Following is an excerpt from the text of the draft on monetary reform by the Committee of 20 deputies:

title: MUNICIPAL UNION ENDORSES BEAME
description: The biggest of the municipal employe unionsan organiza tion that, according to its ex ecutive director, puts its money where its mouth is put its money on the citywide Democratic ticket yesterday.

title: $250,000 Home Given for Disabled Children
description: MANTOLOKING, Sept. 26A twostory, 11room Dutch Col onial house and its furnishings, valued at $250,000, was pre sented to the state today as a home for physically and emo tionally handicapped preschool children.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester day was:

title: Sudan Postpones Hearings
description: CAIRO, Sept. 25 A Suda nese magistrate's court today postponed until November fur ther hearings on the case against eight Palestinian guer rillas who invaded the Saudi Arabian Embassy in Khartoum in March, took hostages and finally murdered three of them two American diplomats and a Belgian envoy.

title: ExHusband Kills Former Wife And Himself in Jersey Home
description: CALDWELL, N. J., Sept. 25 (UPI)  After holding his divorced wife hostage while 25 policemen surrounded his home and filled it with tear gas to day, a Caldwell man apparently shot her in the head and then committed suicide, the police reported.

title: House Votes Shift Of School Funds To Urban Areas
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP)The House voted 286 to 94 today to make a major change in the way school funds are distributed. It would take money away from most South eastern states and give it to urban areas.

title: Nebraska Jet Crash Kills 3
description: LINCOLN, Sept. 25 (UPI) Three men were killed today when their small jet crashed into a field north of the Lincoln Airport shortly after takeoff. Rolland Harr, director of the Lincoln Airport Authority, said that the pilot and one other man from the Lincoln area and a third man from Georgia had been killed. Their identities were being withheld pending notification of the families.

title: STRIKE IS BEGUN BY PHILHARMONIC
description: The 106member New York Philharmonic Orchestra went on strike last night and the orchestra management an nounced cancellation of all per formances until further notice. The next scheduled concert was to be given tomorrow night.

title: Kissinger Advises Arabs NOt to Expect U.S. to Bring Miracles
description: Secretary of State Kissinger told a group of Arab diplomats yesterday that the United States recognized their unhap piness with the Middle East stalemate and was ready to assist in finding a solution, but warned against expecting Wash ington to bring forth miracles.

title: Kitchen Closings Are Held Beyond Sussman's Power
description: TRENTON, Sept. 25The dramatic closings of dirty Jtit chens in restaurants, hospitals and state institutions by Dr. Oscar Sussman ended today.

title: Advertising: Latest Rallying Cry
description: There is a new rallying cry abroad in the land, still so faint that it is barely audible, but it goes like this:

title: HIGHSULPHUR OIL IS WORRYING CITY
description: Any use of highsulphur fuel oil here this winter will undo the city's work in lowering sulphur pollution of the air and start an upward swing, Fred C. Hart, Commissioner of Air Resources, warned yesterday.

title: 2 Homers, FiveHitter Beat Pittsburgh
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25 The lastplace Philadelphia Phillies proved anything but cousins tonight as they hand ed the Pittsburgh Pirates a 21 defeat and a blow to their Eastern Division title aspirations.

title: Orangetown Aide Indicted
description: ORANGETOWN, N. Y., Sept. 25 (UPI)Donald Brenner, the director of public works, has been indicted on corruption charges following a seven month Rockland County grand jury investigation. Mr. Brenner, pleaded not guilty yesterday.

title: STUDENT MARCHERS DISPERSED IN ATHENS
description: ATHENS, Sept. 25  Hun dreds of Greek students staged a march across downtown Athens today after Athens Uni versity's new senate banned unauthorized campus meetings.

title: A Tokyo Raider to Retire
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex. Sept. 25 (UPI)Col. James H. Ma cia Jr., the only member of Col. James H. Doo little's Tokyo Raiders still on active duty will retire from the Air Force next week.

title: Ranking of City Elementary Schools by Scores on Last Spring's Reading Tests
French Officers Publish A Moral Guide for Forces
description: PARIS, Sept. 25The prob lem of reconciling modern mili tary policy and Christian mo rality has provoked a debate in France.

title: CrimeMonitoring TV Goes On in Times Sq.
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday started the operation of a closedcircuit television sys tern that allows a policeman to keep watch on a stretch of the Great White Way and a number of its darker, side streets from a trailer at the middle of Times Square.

title: Music: New Ensemble
description: The failure rate for small orchestras in this city must be close to that for French restaurants, but no musician or chef worth discussing would be intimidated by mere statistics. In the case of chamber orchestras, the literature is so vast and so largely neglected that musi cal gourmets salivate at the appearance of a new ensem ble such as Nuits Musicales.

title: Mrs. McCabe, Osborn Elliott Plan to Marry
description: Mrs. Inger Abrahamsen McCabe and Osborn Elliott, editor, board chairman and chief executive officer of Newsweek magazine, plan to be married here Oct. 20 at the home of Dr. David Abra hamsen, psychiatrist, and Mrs. Abrahamsen, parents of the future bride. The Rev. Dr. Walter Donald Kring of All Souls Unitarian Church will perform the ceremony.

title: Bridge: Generous Opponent Rewards An Unsung Good Samaritan
description: Many devotees of the game work unobtrusively be hind the scenes in a variety of organizational capacities. Their efforts are important and valuable, but they re ceive little thanks and little recognition. One of these un sung heroes was Albert (Hap) Harter of New York, who died earlier this month.

title: Angry Judge Calls A Persico Mistrial
description: Angrily accusing The New York Times and The Daily News of prejudicing the jury, Federal Judge John R. Bartels yesterday declared a mistrial in the Govern ment's case against Carmine Persico, who is charged with harboring a murder suspect.

title: Poetry Dispute in School Awaits U.S. Court Ruling
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 25 (AP)  Some students from suburban Hilliard Junior High School objected when a book of poems they bought through the school for $1.25 had four pages missing.

title: BalanceofPayments Outlook Is Strong
description: The outlook for the balance of payments is exceptionally strong. The economy may be headed for a recession. Gov ernment policies probably will be ineffective in dealing with inflation.

title: Buffalo Inquiry Chief Named
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 25 (UPI) An Army captain with four years in military intelligence operations has been selected to head this city's. Absentee Control Unit, which has been investigating noshow city jobs. The captain, William C. Gwizdowski, 25 years old, is being discharged this week from the Army.

title: MacGregor Believes Tapes Support Nixon
description: WATERTOWN, Conn., Sept. 25 (AP)  Clark MacGregor, former chairman of the Com mittee for the Reelection of the President, said last night that he believed tape read ing of President Nixon's con versations would substantiate Mr. Nixon's story about the Watergate affair.

title: Whitehead Is Recipient Of Shubert Gold Medal
description: Robert Whitehead, the Broadway producer who is marking his 25th year it the theater, received the 197273 Sam S. Shubert Foundation award yesterday for out standing contribution to the American theater.

title: Prison Guard Is Slain
description: MARQUETTE, Mich., Sept. 25 (UPI)  A prison guard at Mar quette State Prison was stabbed to death early today by an in mate. The victim was Earl De marse, 55 years old.

title: City Pupils' Reading Scores, in Shift, Show Gains
description: The proportion of pupils reading at or above the norm or standard for their grade increased during the last academic year in 334 of the city's 631 elementary schools, according to a new report compiled by the Board of Education.

title: FRIEND OF NIXON WINS COURT POINT
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 25C. Arnholt Smith won a prelimi nary skirmish today with the Internal Revenue Service over the service's move to press criminal proceedings agains the 74yearold financier, longtime friend of President Nixon.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Plans to close the East Side Airline Terminal were assailed by 15 Councilmen and civic groups at a City Hall news conference. Councilman Carter Burden, Democrat Liberal, said that if necessary the city should help meet the present annual deficit of nearly $1million. The terminal, which serves La Guardia and Kennedy Airports with buses from First Avenue and 37th Street, is scheduled to close Oct. 31. Carey Transportation Company, which runs the buses, would like to pick up and discharge pas sengers on city streets. Mayor Lindsay said that he wanted the terminal kept open and that negotiations were under way to prevent the closing.

title: Notes on People
description: Patrick V. Murphy, former New York City Police Com missioner and now president of the Police Foundation, said yesterday that Americans should be more concerned about corruption of the po lice than about corruption of any other agency, includ ing the White House.

title: 41 Neighborhood Groups Get Beautification Prizes
description: Fouryearold Gerald Wil liams planted a white flower that, to the best of his recol lection, was a yesanthenan.

title: Salvador Allende: In Memoriam
description: PARISWithin him [Allende], will power vibrated stronger than ideas. Salvador was first of all a man of heart, for whom all that this expres sion holdscourage, faithfulness, emo tioncounted more than everything else. A man who spoke to you using the familiar to [an intimate form of address in Latin languages equivalent to the archaic thee in English], and you would have to make an effort to keep from answering him in the same fashion. One acknowledges the politi cal animal in him but that was his twinhis role, his fateful image which sometimes made him bitter. Be cause he had quite another image of himself, disarming and disarmed, which he kept secret, without speak ing about it.

title: STOCKS RISE AGAIN IN HEAVY TRADING
description: The stock market, displaying remarkable resilience, weath ered a midsession wave of prof it taking yesterday to post its fifth straight advance accom panied by heavy trading vol ume.

title: OTC LIST MIXED AS AMEX CLIMBS
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange climbed sharply again yesterday in steppedup trading with the result that the exchange's index scored its secondbest gain since its in ception on Sept. 4.

title: Philip Morris in Venture
description: Hugh Cullman, president of Philip Morris International, an nounced yesterday that the company had signed agree ments to manufacture Marl boro cigarettes under license in Japan and Poland. At the same time, the company said that it would form a joint yen ture with Spanish and Ecua doriaan investors to mnufac ture and market cigarettes in Ecuador.

title: Statement by Richardson
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25Following is the text of a statement today by Attorney General Elliot L. Rich ardson on the investigation of Vice President Agnew:

title: Off Course in Chile
description: Despite their tradition of noninvolvement in politics, Chile's armed forces are apparently following the dis mally familiar pattern of other military dictatorships since their violent overthrow of President Allende. They have even added a few distinctand distinctly unsavory trappings of their own. While the reports of large scale executions of alleged leftists may not be true, the junta's avowed aim to return Chile to peaceful, constitutional government sounds more hollow with every passing day.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A teenager was held in the shotgun death of 19 yearold Gregory Rinker, who was fatally wounded in front of about 20 people last night as he sat in a car in Northfield. The police said the accused youth, who was not identified because he was only 17, had been charged with murder and was scheduled to be arraigned.

title: Robert V. Breen Is Dead at 62; Byoir Executive Vice President
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Sept. 25 Robert V. Breen, executive vice president of Carl Byoir & Associates, Inc., international public relations counseling firm, died of cancer, yesterday in Stamford Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived here.
