title: Futures Trading Is Defended
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  The chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade, the nation's biggest commodities exchange, told Congressional investiga tors here today that traders an speculators in farm products for future delivery were being the whipping boys for soar ing food prices. He denied that the markets were being manip ulated by them.

title: State's Commerce Unit Will Reopen in Japan
description: ALBANY, Sept. 25The State Commerce Department trade office in Tokyo will be reopened about Oct. 1, it was announced today by Com merce Commissioner Neal L. Moylan.

title: Letter to the House
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25Following is the text Vice President Agnew's letter to the House:

title: CrimeMonitoring TV Goes On in Times Sq.
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday started the operation of closedcircuit television sys tem that allows a policeman to keep watch on a stretch of the Great White Way and a number of its darker, side streets from a trailer at the middle of Times Square.

title: City Center Seeks Angels To End $2.4Million Debt
description: The City Center of Music and Drama, saddled with an unprecedented $2.4million def icit as it moves into the fall season, will begin next week a series of special perform ances, galas, parties and other events designed both to cele brate its 30th anniversary and to wipe out the deficit.

title: Aaron 15 Feet Short In Bid for No. 713
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 25Henry Aaron missed his 713th home run by about 15 feet to night as the Los Angeles Dodgers scored a 51 victory over the Atlanta Braves be fore 10,211 customers.

title: The City's Crime Issue
description: As the mayoral campaign enters its final weeks, State Senator John J. Marchi, the Republican nominee, seems determined to vie with Representative Mario Biaggi, the Conservative candidate, in appealing to popular fears and prejudices on the crime problem. The situation in the streets of New York (and most other cities) is bad enough without the need for distorted, sensational charges of the kind Mr. Marchi has recently indulged in.

title: JOSEPH C. LOMBARDI
description: Joseph C. Lombardi, a vice president of the real estate firm of Brown Harris Stevens, Inc., died Sept. 12 while on vacation in Alicante, Spain. He was 71 years old and lived in Pur chase, N. Y.

title: European Football
description: WORLD CUP QUALIFYING

title: A.E.C. AIDE FINDS WASTE KEPT SAFE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 The United States does not need a crash program for dispos ing of highly radioactive wastes from nuclear power plants, a member of the Atomic Energy Commission told a Congres sional panel today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: L.I.R.R. Is Changing Schedules

title: PowerShortage Warning
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 26 (UPI)  State residents have been urged to economize on electri cal power to ease a possible power shortage this winter. The State Public Utilities Com mission said yesterday it was cautiously optimistic about the utility company's ability to supply the state's needs but added that it was concerned that nuclearpowerplant shut downs or fueloil shortages could reduce generating ca pacity.

title: Musicus Claims Con Ed Wastes 80% of the Heating Oil It Uses
description: Milton Musicus, the city's coordinator, for energy, charged yesterday that 80 per cent of the No. 2 heating oil used by the Consolidated Edison Com pany to generate electricity with gas turbines was being wasted.

title: A SPEEDY DECISION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  Carl Albert, Speaker of the House, refused today to act at this time on Vice President Agnew's request for an investi gation by the House of Repre sentatives into allegations that he received kickbacks from contractors in Maryland.

title: German Shipyard to Expand
description: Howaldtswerke  Deutsche Wed t announced yesterday that its board of directors had approved plans to expand the company's KielGaarden ship yard to allow construction of vessels up to 700,000 dead1 weight tons. The German com1 pany's present capacity is for 250,000ton tankers.

title: Opera
description: In any opera company, the standard favoritesparticu larly older productions of standard favoritestend to be slighted when it comes to preparing a season. Even so, the Metropolitan Opera's Rigoletto looked and sounded needlessly drab in the season's first perform ance on Tuesday night.

title: Business Briefs
description: Two Japanese airlines said yesterday they had signed contracts to buy 10 Americanbuilt jet airliners at a total cost of approximately $220million.

title: Bonn Suggests Currency Plan
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 26 A leading West German cen tral banker suggested today means by which the world would, in practice, return to stable currency exchange rates well in advance of formal in ternational monetary reform.

title: People and Business
description: Ann D. Love, wife of John A. Love, the director of the Administration's Energy Pol icy Office and former Gov ernor of Colorado was elect ed a director yesterday of the Great Western United Corpo ration. On Tuesday, she was named to the board of the United Bank of Denver.

title: U.S. HELD WILLING TO HELP PRE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  The Nixon Administration is willing to provide interim fi nancing to the Penn Central Railroad so that it could tem porarily maintain all of its existing freight and passenger services, according to Claude S. Brinegar, Secretary of Trans portation.

title: Detroit Teachers Defy Order to End Strike
description: DETROIT, Sept. 26 (AP) School officials abandoned an attempt to open the Detroit public schools today as striking teachers defied a court order to end their fourweek strike.

title: Radivoj Ristic, Economist And Editor at Fortune, Dies
description: Radivoj Ristic, an economist and editor on the staff of Fortune, died Tuesday. He was 56 years old and lived in Man hattan.

title: Scarlet Camellia' Arrives From Japan:The Cast
description: On the landscape of old Japan, Yoshitaro Nomura, the director, has sown the seeds of a 20th-century psychological murder story and reaped a harvest of teary melodrama in "The Scarlet Camellia," which opened yesterday at the Bijou.It's the kind of movie you don't see much around here any more, with footprints in the snow, convenient rains, autumn leaves swirling in a prison courtyard and a weepy girl  with consumption  as its focal point.Unfortunately, Oshino, played by Shima Iwashita exhausts patience and sympathy long before she graduates from the adolescent moralizing that has prompted her to incinerate her sluttish mother, skewer several of that woman's lovers with silver hair pins and condemn her true father to shame, madness and the suicide of his wife. All this is by way of making up to her step-father for the suffering he put up with at the hands of her mother.Visually, it is all very lovely, but at bottom it promises more than it can deliver.

title: Warrant for Indian Leader
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 26 (AP)  Joseph Trimbach, special agent in charge of the Min neapolis office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that a Federal fugitive warrant had been issued for Dennis Banks, a leader of the American Indian Movement. Mr. Trimbach said that the warrant was issued yesterday in Rapid City, S. D., on the as sumption that Mr. Banks had fled South Dakota to avoid prosecution on state charges stemming from a Feb. 6 dis turbance at the Custer, S. D. courthouse.

title: Stanek Babies Doing Fine
description: DENVER, Sept. 26 (UPI) Hospital officials said today that the five surviving Stanek sextuplets were doing splen didly, and their mother, Mrs. Edna Stanek, spent her first full day at home. The babies, born seven weeks early on Sept. 16, are expected to remain at the hospital for at least another month.

title: Gunman Kills Wife Of Grocery Owner In a Bronx Holdup
description: The 38yearold wife of a grocery store owner was shot to death last night by one of three holdup men in the Mor risania section of the Bronx, the police said.

title: United Merchants Net Up in Quarter
description: United Merchants & Manu facturers, Inc., a leading do mestic and foreign producer of textiles, which operates the Robert Hall apparel chain realized increases of 94 per cent in fourth fiscal quarter earnings and 31 per cent for the annual period ended June 30 on record sales volumes, the yearly statement disclosed yesterday.

title: Basketball Transactions
description: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION

title: SIHANOUK REQUESTS RECOGNITION BY U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26Prince Norodom Si hanouk has asked the United Nations to recognize his gov ernment in exile as the sole legal government of Cambodia and to expel the Lon Nol Gov ernment.

title: Chris Evert Gains In Georgia Tennis
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., Sept. 26 (AP)  Secondseeded Chris Evert had little trouble today in defeating Janet Haas of Miami Beach, 61, 60, and advancing to the second round of the $30,000 Colum bus women's pro tennis tour nament.

title: QUEBEC ELECTION PLANNED OCT. 29
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 26Pre mier Robert Bourassa of Quebec last night called an election that could determine the future of the separatist movement in his province.

title: The Dirtiest Trick
description: WASHINGTONLike a beached whale, the Senate Watergate commit tee is wheezing and blowing in its final throes, a hulk that has begun to pall as a tourist attraction and poses a problem in its disposal.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Those who hunt in New Hampshire this year should be aware of a new law that makes it illegal to carry a loaded firearm in any air craft, motor vehicle, power boat or offhighway recrea tional vehicle (O.H.R.V.).

title: U.S. Abandons Suit To Get Crime Data In Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, Sept. 26The Jus tice Department dropped yes terday a court action seeking to require Massachusetts to grant two Federal agencies ac cess to its criminal information records.

title: Union and a Railroad Agree to Cut Crew Sizes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26In an agreement with important] economic implications for the nation's railroads, the United, Transportation Union and the Chicago & North Western Transportation Company set tied today their longstanding dispute over the size of train crews.

title: Delay Over Stennis Jury
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) Jury selection in the trial of a youth charged with attempt ing to kill Senator John C. Stennis, Democrat of Missis sippi, bogged down today when 20 potential jurors disclosed ties to lawenforcement agencies.

title: Secrecy on Prison Rules Scored by Chief Judge
description: TRENTON, Sept. 26 (AP) Chief Justice Pierre P. Garven of the State Supreme Court sharply questioned today the need for secrecy of regula tions affecting prison in mates.

title: E.P.A. Would Allot $1.2Billion to State
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 New York State would re ceive $1.2billion in Federal funds this year for waterpol lution control projects under a directive published today by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: HIGHWAY PROJECT STIRS SOME DOUBT
description: Consultants to three West Side community boards have concluded that the West Side Highway plays only a rela tively small role in meeting the area's transportation needs and that an upgraded highway might simply attract trucks from New Jersey without great ly reducing truck traffic on local Manhattan streets.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Plea for the Criminally Insane

title: Bruins Tie Rangers in Exhibition, 22
description: When the Boston Bruins come to Madison Square Garden to play the Rangers, it is always a special event or lovai hockey fans. The rivalry is old and keen enough so that it attracted 17,500 fans last night for a National Hockey League exhibition game that wound up in a 22 tie.

title: RATE DOWNTREND IS GIVEN IMPETUS
description: The sensational recent de cline in interest rates lost more momentum yesterday, but re ports of optimistic lateafter noon comments on inflation by Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz gave fresh im petus to the downtrend.

title: Cornfeld Rebuffed On a Bid for Bail By a Swiss Court

title: Film: If in Doubt, Punt:Jim Brown Runs Same Old Play in 'Slams' The Cast
description: "I can always take care of myself," Jim Brown assures his mother just before starting a stretch in "The Slams" for heisting $1.5-million, which everyone, including "the syndicate," in that titular California prison wants.There's no need to worry, mama. Our black, tough hero has been successfully taking on all comers as a top fullback and in 15 muscular movies before this one smashed into the Cinerama and R.K.O. 86th Street yesterday. And the results are about as unusual as a television rerun of a hard-fought football game.The now all too familiar clashes involving black and white machismo are here, including explicit, colloquial dialogue, fights between cons, bloodshed and a prison break as Mr. Brown keeps the whereabouts of the loot secret from Frank de Kova (the incarcerated mob boss), Roland Harris (the black prison guard captain), the black and white inmates and even the warden.Mr. Brown is his normal stoic but rough self as he finally escapes to that Caribbean sanctuary with the loot and his girl, Judy Pace."While they're making it," he remarks smugly, "we're taking it." But "The Slams" doesn't give the viewer much more than gory, explosive action.

title: And Nowa Finnish Film Festival ':Change Is Sought Old-Fashioned Personality
description: Just try telling someone that you're off to a festival of Finnish films and the response is likely to be, "Did you say finished films?"Although film has become an international art, it's still hard to imagine that such countries as Brazil, Nigeria and, yes, Finland, have small film industries of their own. To let filmgoers here know that Finland is not just the country of saunas and Sibelius, the library at Lincoln Center and Cinema Dimensions, a distribution company, are presenting, through Saturday, 13 Finnish films in the library's museum.In recent years, the only Finnish director to emerge with any recognition was Jorn Donner, and most of his films have been Swedish productions. His bubbly sex comedy, "To Love," starring Harriet Andersson, was shown several years ago at the New York Film Festival and then had a modest run here. Donner's worldly film, influenced by Ingmar Bergman's light comedies, had a kicky champagne spirit.Change Is SoughtI remember "To Love" because it aroused my curiosity about Finlandand the Finnish movie industry. Donner is not included in the festival. The sponsors understandably wanted to introduce other directors. His presence was missed."There's a lot of talent in Finland," says Richard Anobile of Cinema Dimensions, "but the films are not considered commercial on foreign markets." He's right, but he hopes to change the situation with Finnish-American co-productions.The grand old man of Finnish theater and films is apparently Edvin Laine, whose three-hour epic of Finnish history, "Under the Northern Star," opened the festival and will be shown again this week. The color, widescreen film, based on a popular Finnish trilogy, might be described as Finland's "Gone With the Wind."With a big cast in interweaving stories covering two generations, "Star" shows the plucky nation's suffering and stumbling progressfrom a grand duchy of Russia to independence and civil war. Like a Cecil B. DeMille pageant, the canvas is almost too cumbersome, the characters are cardboard and yet, despite elements of operatic kitsch, the director knows how to build suspense and pathos while giving a thumbnail sketch of Finnish history.Old-Fashioned PersonalityHis plot devices are old-fashioned, but you have to admire the unabashed sentiment of his last shot: a bedraggled soldier returning home in the howling rain. Obviously there was a personality behind this work, which I did not feel at all in the two other "modern" movies I saw."Worker's Diary" by Risto Jarva deals with contemporary life in Finland, which rises like a glassy skyscraper on the edge of a primeval forest. It touches, but only blandly, the monotonyand isolationin the marriage of a clerical secretary and her husband, a factory foreman. It's almost as if the director were embarrassed by the bleakness of his material."Green Widow," by Jaakko Pakkasvirta, is a suburban housewife who finds relief from her philandering, boorish husband with a mini-affair of her own. The mad housewife, ably played by Eija Pokkinen, is the sort of striking Finn who usually runs to Parisone of the exotic Left Bank Lapps.But this "Green Widow" is strangely repressed. The social mores reflected in her life are related to yesterday, to the late nineteen-fifties. I refuse to believe that the ultimate Finnish decadence is a marijuana cigarette smoked in the late afternoon.My impression from these films is that the Finns have resources. What they really need is boldnessand cinematic vision.

title: Sisters' Goes Soft On Horror
description: Grace Collier (Jennifer Salt) has several problems. She writes for a Staten Island newspaper that isn't as interested in news as it is in civic promotion. She has a mother who wants her to get married. "The Cunningham girl," her mother says one day, "is engaged. He's a doctor. Well, he's really a veterinarian, but all the animals are owned by wealthy people." Grace's biggest problem is the Staten Island policeman who refuses to believe her when she says she saw a man murdered in an apartment across the way.This is pretty much the beginning of Brian De Palma's "Sisters," a good, substantial horror film with such a sense of humor that it never can quite achieve the solemnly repellent peaks of Roman Polanski's "Repulsion." Never, however, does it become the sort of Nancy Drew detective tale it otherwise resembles, at least in outline.At the center of the story is a lovely French-Canadian girl named Danielle Breton (Margot Kidder), one of a pair of separated Siamese twins. Danielle, like so many young women in horror stories of this sort, has a terrible guilt complex about sex, and it is in her apartment that Grace thinks she saw a man repeatedly stabbed, then write "help" on the window in his own blood.The screenplay, by Mr. De Palma and Louisa Rose, cuts back and forth between Grace's investigation of the murder, with the help of a persistent though none-too-bright private detective, and Danielle's story, quite stunningly presented through news film and drug fantasies that take the narrative place of flashbacks.Mr. De Palma, best known for his anarchic comedy ("Hi, Mom," "Get to Know Your Rabbit"), reveals himself here to be a first-rate director of more or less conventional material that has associations not only with "Repulsion" but also with Hitchcock's "Psycho." The "Psycho" associations are unfortunate, since they tip one important plot point sooner than is absolutely necessary.The performances are fine, especially Miss Kidder's as the loony twin whom we first meet when she's doing a walk-on on a popular television quiz show called "Peeping Toms," which, like so many of Mr. De Palma's comic fancies, is just terrible enough to become a reality.An intelligent horror film is very rare these days. "Sisters," which opened at three theaters yesterday, is just the thing to see on one of those nights when you want to go to the movies for the old-fashioned fun of it.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 About 9:30 this morning, Senator Mark O. Hatfield, the liberal Oregon Republi can, called Vice President Agnew to ask him to lunch.

title: Trade Gap Shrinks; Business Index Up
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP)The country's foreign trade slipped into deficit in August again after a onemonth surplus in July, but the trade picture was greatly improved from a year earlier, the Commerce Department reported today. The department also reported that its index of leading business indicators rose 1.2 per cent last month. The trade deficit totaled $16.6million in August, based on exports of $6,004,300,000 and imports of $6,020,400,000. Both figures were monthly records.

title: INA Corp. Agrees to Comply With Plea to Cut Dividend
description: The INA Corporation, which last month refused to comply with a Government plea to cut its dividend, decided yesterday to conform after all.

title: S.E.C. OPPOSING MERRILL DEFENSE
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, which last sum mer charged Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc., with fraud, yesterday chal lenged the big brokerage house's defense plans during an unusual closed hearing.

title: Bus Accident Kills 15
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 26 (UPI)At least 15 elderly per sons were killed and 23 seri ously injured today when a tourist bus plunged over the Tumut Ponds Dam in snow covered mountains about 300 miles southwest of Sydney, the police said. The accident oc curred as the bus, carrying old age pensioners on a sightsee ing trip, was climbing a steep pass above the dam wall, slipped and fell back into 200 feet of water.

description: PARIS, Sept. 26 (Reuters) The Concorde supersonic airliner today cut the transAt lantic flying time by about half an its first nonstop crossing from Washington to Paris. The plane covered the 3,636 miles in three hours, 33 minutes. The flying time by Boeing 707 is about seven hours.

It has taken the Whitney Museum, far from the largest of these institutions, to demonstrate that one of the best things to do with art is to spread it around a little bit, like cheer, or sunshine.

description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 26 (UPI)You are on Long Is land and you get ready to drive home to New Jersey, but your 1966 Cadillac won't go into forward gear. You leave it there, right?
