title: Podgorny Applauds Feat
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 26 (AP) President Nikolai V. Podgorny oof the Soviet Union has sent a congratulatory message to President Nixon on the safe splashdown of the three Skylab astronauts, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported today. Nikolai Podgorny asked the President to convey congratu lations and best wishes to the courageous astronauts Alan Bean, Owen Garriott and Jack Lousma, whose flight has been an outstanding step in man's exploration of outer space, Tass said.

title: Race for Governor in Virginia Pits an OldLine Conservative Against an Aggressive LiberalPopulist
description: RICHMOND, Sept. 23The 1973 Virginia governorship elec tion is shaping up as one that will give Old Dominion voters their best chance in years to clear up the mindboggling po litical confusion caused by abolition of the poll tax, the death of Harry F. Bryd Sr. and an ideological realignment of parties and allegiances.

title: Mets Bow to Expos, 8 to 5, Lead Is Cut to Half a Game
description: The magic deserted the Mets and Tom Seaver last night in their final home ap pearance of the season, when the Montreal Expos snapped their sevengame winning streak and shaved the Mets' lead to half a game in the hectic National League East.

title: INDIA DROPS CURBS ON ALIEN STUDENTS
description: NEWDELHI, Sept. 26The Indian Government, in a ma jorshift of policy, has over hauled restrictions on the in flux of foreign scholars after strong criticism here and in the United States.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Because of the Jewish holi day of Rosh haShanah, the drawing for the weekly win ning number in New York was held a day earlier than usual. Winning numbers drawn yesterday were:

title: Van Lier Fined $500
description: BEAVER, Pa., Sept. 26 (UPI)Norm Van Lier, a for ward with the Chicago Bulls of the National Basketball Association, was placed on a year's probation and fined $500 today for resisting ar rest last year at a police sta tion in his nearby home of Midland. Van Liar's cousins, Thomas Van Lier, 21 years old, and James Oliver Jr., 23, were fined $250 each and placed on a year's probation for assault and battery in connection with the same in cident.

title: Libel Suit by Police Group Names Imus and WNBC
description: A $10million libel suit has been brought by the Northport (L. I.) Police Benevolent Asso ciation against Don Imus and WNBC Radio for statements al legedly made by Mr. Imus on his earlymorning radio show on Aug. 25 accusing Northport policemen of being heavy into drugs and taking money under the table.

title: Impeach or Indict ...
description: In the search for personal vindication, Vice President Agnew has chosen a course of action that is constitu tionally obscure and most likely to expose the nation to uncertainty and potential risk.

title: Play With Tony Curtis Is Closed on the Road
description: The Broadway stage debut of Tony Curtis, the film star, in The OneNight Stand the comedy by Bruce Jay Friedman and Jacques Levy has been called off because of poor business on the road and unfavorable notices.

title: Senate Votes, Then Voids, 40% Cut in Troops Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 The Senate voted unexpectedly today for a 40 per cent re duction in United States mili tary forces abroad. But then it reversed itself after inten sive lobbying by the Nixon Administration.

title: DOCTORS ELATED AT SKYLAB 2 CRE
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 26Spa agency doctors are ?? lievably happy with the ?? cal condition of the three ?? lab astronauts, who return, from their record 59day ?? journey yesterday in apparer ly better physical shape ?? had been expected.

title: 400 ATTEND RITES FOR DIANA SANDS
description: Some 400 friends, relatives and associates from the theater world attended a funeral serv ice yesterday for Diana Sands, the actress, at the Roman Ca tholic Church of St. Catherine of Siena, 411 East 68th Street.

title: Judge Assails Rail Blackmail Hint by Port Body
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., Sept. 26 A lawyer far the Port Author ity of New York and New Jersey warned today that the invalidation of rules restricting Port Authority funds for rail passenger travel would un doubtedly jeopardize a $650 million expansion of mass transit in the metropolitan area.

title: DOROTHY BUDD
description: BRANENTON, Fla., Sept. 26 Dorothy Budd, who from 1930 to 1950 was administrator and supervisor of women's physical education in the public schools of Lynbrook, L.I., died on Friday. She was 75 year old.

title: A 5c Limit on PATH Rise Blocked by Jersey Aides
description: Governor Rockefeller's effort to hold any increase in the Port Authority TransHudson railroad to 5 cents was effec tively blocked yesterday by the New Jersey members of the Port Authority's governing body.

title: POLL FINDS PRICES TOP U.S. CONCERN
description: The public's concern about high prices and inflation is paramount over other problems in the country, according to the latest Gallup Poll, released yesterday.

title: JOHN H. DUYS
description: John H. Duys, long prominent in the leaftobacco trade here, died Monday of a heart attack on a Manhattan Street. He was 69 years old and lived at 1 East 66th Street.

title: Kissinger Denies Any Role In C.I.A. Study of Ellsberg
description: Secretary of State Kissinger denied yesterday that he had had anything to do with the 1971 request for a psychiatric profile of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg by the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Stanek Babies Doing Fine
description: DENVER, Sept. 26 (UPI) Hospital officials said today that the five surviving Stanek sextuplets were doing splen didly, and their mother, Mrs. Edna Stanek, spent her first full day at home. The babies, born seven weeks early on Sept. 16, are expected to remain at the hospital for at least another month.

title: European Football
description: WORLD CUP QUALIFYING

title: Man of Many Rules Lewis Deschler
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 Somewhere on the list of those consulted by House Speaker Carl Albert in arriv ing at his decision today against holding an inquiry on Vice President Agnew is the name of Lewis Deschlera name that, despite his 45 years' tenure in a highly in fluential post, means almost nothing to the world beyond Capitol Hill.

title: Michigan NoFault Trial Set
description: DETROIT, Sept, 26 (AP) Wayne County Circuit Court Judge Horace Gilmore declined today to stop Michigan's no fault auto insurance law from taking effect Oct. 1, He sched uled a trial to begin Nov. 19 on a suit filed against the law by the Michigan Trial Lawyers Association.

title: DR. JOHN N. SHELL, NASSAU SURGEON, 72
description: FREEPORT, L. I., Sept. 26 Dr. John N. Shell, director of surgery emeritus at the South Nassau Communities Hospital in Oceanside, died there today. He was 72 years old and lived here.

title: Argentines Strike to Honor Slain Labor Leader
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 26 In a city hushed by a general strike, the body of Jos Igna cio Rucci, the Argentine labor leader who was killed by urban guerrillas yesterday, was borne through the streets to a burial with presidential honors.

title: A SPEEDY DECISION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  Carl Albert, Speaker of the House, refused today to act at this time on Vice President Agnew's request for an investi gation by the House of Repre sentatives into allegations that he received kickbacks from contractors in Maryland.

title: Equity Financing
description: A secondary offering of 350,000 common shares of the Halliburton Company at 166% a share was made by underwriters headed by Lehman Brothers. The company's stock closed at 166, down  on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Pork, Chicken and Beef Prices Decline
description: New York City consumers could go out yesterday and get good buys in chicken at 39 to :49 cents a pound for fryers and broilers in supermarkets down from early August highs of 85 to 92 cents in most stores, some then even over $1.

title: 22 Jurors in Agnew Case: Mosaic of Maryland Life
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 26Last December, Federal District Judge C. Stanley Blair im paneled a special grand jury in Baltimore and directed it to seek out corruption in govern ment in the state of Maryland.

title: BankRobbery Suspect Is Seized in Village
description: An armed robbed seized seven bags of nightdeposit money yesterday from a tell er at the Chase Manhattan Bank branch at 2 Fifth Ave nue, near Eighth Street, and dropped four bags before he fled. A suspect was seized when his car was caught in traffic half a block from the bank after a police chase.

title: Figures in Senate Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26Following are the names of individuals who figured in today's hearings by the Senate committee on the Watergate case:

title: The Earthquake
description: BOSTON, Sept. 26It is as if we were living a chapter of history, with fresh revelations of a system's crisis at each turn of the page. The Agnew drama disposes of the claim that we were somehow past the crisis of American institutions. Even after these past months, it hits with the force of an earthquakeand one that will not shake Spiro Agnew alone.

title: State Plans Medical School Without Walls
description: GREEN BROOK TOWNSHIP, Sept. 25The state is planning a medical school without walls in South Jersey, Gover nor Cahill announced today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Queens Graft Laid To 17 Sergeants

title: After 2 Vetoes, President Signs A Vocational Rehabilitation Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 26 (UPI)President Nixon signed today a vocational rehabilita tion bill, scaled down from a version that he had vetoed twice before as too costly.

title: Turkish Martial Law Ends; Imposed in '71 in Disorder
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 26 (Reuters)Twentynine months of martial law came to an end today without fanfare, opening a new chapter in the history of the Turkish Republic.

title: The Senate Roll Calls On Troop Measures
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP)The Senate voted to day 49 to 46 to reduce the number of American land based troops abroad by 40 per cent. Later the Senate reversed itself and by a vote of 51 to 44 rejected the amendment to reduce the number of troops abroad. Following is the roll call on the first vote:

title: HighestLevel Bugging
description: WASHINGTONThroughout the re sponses of the White House to the charges of improper conduct in Water gate runs one attempt at legally justi fying the acts that took place. It is that the inherent power of the Presi dent to protect national security per mits burglary, wiretapping, surveil lance and other violations of the law. This pernicious theory, if accepted, would mean the demise of the Ameri can tradition of individual civil liber ties, no doubt our nation's most sig nificant contribution to Western civili zation.

title: Basketball Transactions
description: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION BOSTONReleased Martinez Denman, Iowa State; Byron Jones, University of San Francisco; Wayne Grabeic, Michigan; Sam McCamey, Oral Roberts, and Clarence Glover, Western Kentucky.

title: Wilt Jumps to Q's; To Get $1.8Million
description: Wilt Chamberlain an pounced yesterday that he had signed a threeyear con tract to be playercoach of the San Diego Conquistadors of the American Basketball Association, setting the stage for legal fireworks on sev eral fronts.

title: In Concert Man Gathers Stones for New Series
description: In the television syndica tion business, a lead time of at least six months is con sidered normal in finding buyers for a new series. In less than five weeks, one new syndicated series has, so far, signed up 113 stations with access to about 84 per cent of the national audience. That recordbreaking pace provides still another indica tion of both the new success of rock music on television and the continuing success of Don Kirshner in the music business.

title: Building Fund Chief Named
description: Sol A. Liebman, who has been general counsel to the New York City Educational Construction Fund for the last six years, has been appointed its executive director, effective Monday. The fund finances construction of public schools in combination with residential and commercial buildings.

title: BOYLE'S CONDITION IMPROVES SLIGHTLY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP). The condition of W. A. Boyle, the deposed mine union leader, improved slightly today, ac cording to hospital spokesmen.

title: Cahill Orders Inspections Of Food Places to Go On
description: TRENTON, Sept. 26Gover nor Cahill today directed Dr. James R. Cowan, the State Health Commissioner, to con tinue, without letup, a vigorous inspection program of food serving facilities at state insti talons, private healthcare fa cilities and retail food estab lishments.

title: Jersey to Get Money For the Construction Of Sports Complex
description: NEWARK, Sept. 26The New Jersey Sports and Expo sition Authority said today that it had arranged to raise the $280million needed to build a race track and stadium for the New York Football Giants in the Hackensack Meadows by way of a combined public and private bond sale.

title: U.S. Considers Abolition Of Crime Strike Forces
description: The Justice Department is considering restructuring, or possibly dissolving, the 18 spe cial Federal strike forces set up during the last seven years to combat organized crime, ac cording to department sources.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The daily New Jersey lot tery number will be found on the first page of this sec tion.

title: AMEX PRICES UP IN HEAVY TRADING
description: As trading continued heavy, prices rose again yesterday for the seventh consecutive sessior on the American Stock Ex change. Similar conditions pre vailed in the overthecounter market.

title: TOP U.S. OFFICERS WARY OF CUTBACKS
description: Senior American military officers say that a 40 per cent cut in United States ground and air forces overseas, if carried out, could drastically reduce American deterrent strength in West Germany and South Korea.

title: For Sale: Columbus Relics
description: Dust alleged to have come from the remains of Chris topher Columbus will be auc tioned Oct. 30 by Sotheby Parke Bernet. The auction house expects to get upwards of $20,000 for two lockets enclosing the dust.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: FREDERIC G. PITTS
description: WEST CHESTER, Pa., Sept. 26 (AP)Frederic G. Pitts, for mer editor of the Bulletin of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, died last evening in the Chester County Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Wilmington, Del.

title: Vice President's Battle to Stay Out of Court
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 The decision by Carl Albert, Speaker of the House, to take no action for now on Vice! President Agnew's request for a Congressional inquiry into his case is widely believed here, to have significantly worsened Mr. Agnew's chances of head ing off an investigation by a Federal grand jury. The grand jury is scheduled to begin tomorrow to re ceive evidence of his alleged role in a bribery and extortion scandal in Maryland.

title: DI NAPOLI FIGHTING NADJARI OVER WRIT
description: Joseph Di Napoli, who was arrested in Feburary, 1972, in a car that had $967,550 in a suitcase on the back seat, and who now is serving a three year term in Federal prison for extortion, is attempting to avoid testifying before a spe cial grand jury probing police corruption.

title: Union Commerce Leads Unit In Building Systems Loan
description: The Union Commerce Bank heads a syndicate of six banks that has loaned $19million to Building Systems, Inc., which yesterday filed a petition under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act.

title: SAIGON SAYS PLANES HIT TANKS AT BASE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 26  South Vietnamese, fighter planes have attacked NorthVietnamese tanks that overran an isolated South Vietnamese ranger outpost in the Central Highlands, accord ing to military sources.

title: I.B.M. Files for New Trial
description: The International Business Machines Corporation yester day filed a motion for a new trial of the antitrust suit won by the Telex Corporation on Sept. 17.

title: Auto Issues Pace Advance As Stock Climb Continues
description: Higher prices for automotive and other cyclical issues helped to send stock prices ahead yesterday for the sixth straight session of a dynamic rally.

title: Judge Assails Port Agency Rail Threat
description: HACKENSACK, Sept. 26A lawyer for the Port Authority of New York and New Jerse warned today that the invalida tion of rules restricting Port Authority funds for rail pas senger travel would undoubt edly jeopardize a $650million expansion of mass transit in the metropolitan area.

title: Caged by Saigon
description: WASHINGTONThere are more political prisoners in South Vietnam today than in any nation in the world. Amnesty International estimates that there are 100,000. This is three times its 31,000 estimate for the Soviet Union, Brazil, Turkey, Spain, Ceylon, Portugal, Angola, Mozambique, Czech oslovakia, East Germany and South Africa combined.

title: South Africa Selling Most of Her New Gold
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 26  The South African Finance Minister disclosed today that his country had sold nearly all of its gold production on the free market since March.

title: Mindszenty to Visit New Brunswick For Dedication of Hungarian Church
description: Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty, the Roman Catholic Primate of Hungary who is in exile, will visit the United States begin ning Friday to dedicate a re novated church in a Hungarian section of New Brunswick, N.J.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
ArmsTwisting
description: By chance the legislative and diplomatic calendars have coincided to set this week as the opening both of a new round of Strategic Arms Limitations Talks with the Russians, and of the longprepared Senate debate on defense spending. SALT is the Administration's forum on for negotiating mutual ceilings on superpower weaponry, while the Senate debate gives opportunity to the Admin istration's critics to curb the Pentagon's ambitions for more glittering and deadly hardware.

title: Chess: When the Going Gets Tough The Tough Get Going, Slowly
description: With one round to go, the pace of the United States Chess Championship has slowed to a crawl. While John Grefe, the young California master and the surprise of the tournament, was idled with a bye, Lubomir Kavalek, the pretourney favorite, drew against Larry Evans to achi eve tie for first place.

title: U. S. MAY ADMIT CUBANS IN SPAIN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 The State Department is con sidering a proposal to ease the entry into the United States of some 20,000 exiled Cubans who are living in Spain.

title: Japan's Premier Off for Talks in Europe and Soviet
description: TOKYO, Sept. 26Premier Kakuei Tanaka took off today on a twoweek tour of West ern Europe and the Soviet Un ion.

title: Guild Ends 13Day Strike At Providence Journal Co.
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I. Sept. 26 (AP)  The Providence Jour nal Company resumed publica tion of its two newspapers to day after Local 41 of The Newspaper Guild votcd over whelmingly to end its 13day strike.

title: Magazine Says a Brandt Aide Envisioned NATOLess Europe
description: BONN, Sept. 26The con servative weekly magazine Quick published today the text of what it said was a 1968 Government study by one of the closest and most influen tial advisers to Chancellor Willy Brandt, who was then the Foreign Minister, on pos sible courses of political and military developments in Eu rope.

title: School for Scoundrels and Hard Knocks:The Cast
description: Angela Mao, the Billie Jean King of Kung-fu films, came back to town again yesterday in another Wimbledon of mayhem.Distinguishable from its predecessors principally by means of its title, "Deadly China Doll" pairs Miss Mao once again with Carter Huang, in competition against opium smugglers and hijackers. The outcome is never in doubt.Suffice it to say that Miss Mao seems to have suffered no loss of skills since last seen here a couple of weeks back in "Lady Kung Fu." The stunning backhands, forehands, drop shots and overheads are all there, as well as that particular contribution of the martial arts films, the sternum crunch.The dialogue and most of the performances are as deadly as the principals. Miss Mao works very hard, and one only hopes that, like Miss King, she earns equal pay.

title: POPULAR ELECTION OF PRESIDENT URGED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI) Robert Strauss, chairman of the Democratic National Com mittee, and Senator Robert Dole the former Republican nation al chairman, called today for abolishing the Electoral College system and replacing it with a direct, popular election of the President.

title: Excerpts From Testimony of Buchanan Before the Senate Watergate Committee
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of the tes timony in Washington yes terday of Patrick J. Buchan an before the Senate Select Committee on Presidential Campaign Activities:

title: New Jersey Sports
description: Last year, Westfield High won its nine football games, reached a state record of 42 games without a loss (one tie) and got a congratulatory letter from President Nixon.

title: Tentam Pick in U.N. Turf Race Today
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 26  To the accompaniment of the parade of the flags of the United Nations, and to the strains of the regionally famous Bishop McDevitt High School Band, the United Nations Handicap will have its 21st running tomorrow. A field of 12 is named to com pete in the 13/16mile grass contest, with the recently syndicated Tentam the over night favorite.

title: The Stage: Aspects of Shakespeare
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts has devoted September to Shake speare. It has been using all of its three houses to cele brate Shakespeare in speech, dance, song, film and music.

title: BUCHANAN SOUGHT TO BLOCK MUSKIE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 Patrick J. Buchanan, a special consultant to President Nixon, acknowledged today that he had urged a White House strat egy to undercut Senator Ed mund S. Muskie and elevate Senator George McGovern in 1972 Democratic Presidential primaries.

title: Modern Museum Goes Into Critical Talks With Staff
description: The Museum of Modern Art and its union of professional and administrative workers ap pear to be heading for a critical phase in contract talks next week.

title: DR. SAMUEL GRAFF
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 26Dr. Samuel Graff, a biochemist and cancer researcher, died here yesterday while visiting his son, Dr. Charles Graff. He was 68 years old and lived at 2500 Johnson Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx, New York.

title: Chilean Officers Tell How They Began to Plan the TakeOver Last November
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 26 Middleranking officers of all three military services began plotting the coup against Presi dent Salvador Allende Gossens as far back as November, 1972, conversations with officers and civilians close to the situation have revealed.

title: URBAN STATES GAIN IN NEW SCHOOL PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) The House has approved a new schoolfunding formula that would bring more money to urban areas and reduce. Federal school aid to most Southeastern states.

title: PowerShortage Warning
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 26 (UPI) State residents have been urged to economize on electri cal power to ease a possible power shortage this winter. The State Public Utilities Com mission said yesterday it was cautiously optimistic about the utility company's ability to supply the state's needs but added that it was concerned that nuclearpowerplant shut downs or fueloil shortages could reduce generating ca pacity.

title: The Times Editorial Page Is Denounced by Marchi
description: Flinging a copy of The New York Times to the floor and shouting in apparent anger. State Senator John J. Marchi denounced the newspaper's edi torial page yesterday.

title: BROOKE FURTHERS BLACK CAUCUS TIE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  The private, accommodating relationship between the Sen ate's only black, Edward M. Brooke a Republican, and the 16 black members of the House, all Democrats, will go public for the first time Sat urday in an address by the Senator.

title: Tuesday's Fights
description: Kansas CityDuane Bobick, 209 pounds, St. Paul, knocked out Ron Draper, 193, Kansas City, 4 rounds.

title: LibbeyOwensFord Indicted for Exports Of Armored Glass
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI)  The LibbeyOwens Ford Company of Toledo, Ohio, was indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on charges of illegally exporting bulletproof windows to Portu gal and making false state ments to the United States Government.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest re port of changes in stock owner ship by major stockholders, directors and officers of its listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange did not issue list this week.

title: Kissinger Denies Any Role In C.I.A. Study of Ellsberg
description: Secretary of State Kissinger denied yesterday that he had had anything to do with the 1971 request for a psychiatric profile of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg by the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: GOVERNORS ELECT A BLACK IN SOUTH
description: POINT CLEAR, Ala., Sept. 26 The Southern Governors' Conference, without discussion and with the blessing of Gov. George C. Wallace, elected a black today as its chairman.

title: BUCHANAN SOUGHT TO BLOCK MUSKIE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 Patrick J. Buchanan, a special consultant to President Nixon, acknowledged today that he had urged a White House strat egy to undercut Senator Ed mund S. Muskie and elevate Senator George McGovern in 1972 Democratic Presidential primaries.

title: ITALIAN COMPANY BUYS 6% OF ITE
description: The ITE Imperial Corpora tion, a major manufacturer of electrical distribution, transmis sion and control products, dis closed yesterday that about per cent of its common stock had been acquired by an Italian company affiliated with the Agnelli group.

title: DRIVE FOR VOTERS IS DISAPPOINTING
description: TRENTON, Sept. 26 Although New Jersey will elect a new Governor on Nov. 6, many potential voters have shown tremendous apathy during the sevenweek voter registration drive that ends to morrow.

title: Okun, Johnson Economic Aide, Urges Easing of Credit to Bar a 1974 Slump
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  Arthur M. Okun, former chair man of the Council of Eco nomic Advisers, said today that the Federal Reserve should be gin promptly but gradually to ease credit, if a recession is to be avoided next year.

title: MUSICIANS PICKET AT FISHER HALL
description: Picket lines went up outside Avery Fisher Hall (formerly Philharmonic Hall) yesterday as mediation sessions began in an effort to end the strike by the 106 members of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra.

title: Tuesday's Fights
description: Kansas CityDuane Bobick, 209 pounds, St. Paul, knocked out Ron Draper, 193, Kansas City, 4 rounds.

title: Woodall's Not a Namath Nor the Woodall of Old
description: Who said the Jets can't get to the playoffs without Joe Namath? Not Al Woodall.

title: Disarmament Study Set
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 26 (AP)Harvard University said today that it would use a $1 million Ford Foundation grant to set up a program for science and international affairs to study disarmament.

title: Gregory Is Defensive About Giants' Pass Rush
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 26 Jack Gregory, who is being paid by the New York Giants to make life miserable for op posing quarterbacks, is find ing himself being harassed by skeptics these days.

title: 5c Limit on PATH Fare Rise Is Blocked by Jersey Officials
description: Governor Rockefeller's effort to hold any increase in the Port Authority TransHudson railroad to 5 cents was effec tively blocked yesterday by the New Jersey members of the Port Authority's governing body.

title: WORKING STUDENTS ON THE INCREASE
description: STONY BROOK, N.Y., Sept. 26 (AP)The number of young students combining college with work has increased faster than total enrollment in the last dec ade, a Labor Department official said yesterday.

title: Naples Declassifies Its Ancient Erotica
description: NAPLES, ItalyWhat has been described as the world's largest and best collection of ancient erotic art, hidden in a secret room of the Naples National Museum for nearly 200 years, will be put on public view for the first time this year. There are 250 ob jects in the group, which is reportedly rivaled only by the Vatican collection of erotic art.

title: Nixon Sought to Sway Press On Lindsay's Victory in 1969
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 President Nixon personally or dered his White House aides to attempt to persuade news men that Mayor Lindsay's re election in 1969 was based on local issues, and not the Mayor's opposition to the Viet nam war.

title: Van Lier Fined $500
description: BEAVER, Pa., Sept. 26 (UPI)Norm Van Lier, a for ward with the Chicago Bulls of the National Basketball Association, was placed on a year's probation and fined $500 today for resisting ar rest last year at a police sta tion in his nearby home of Midland. Van Lier's cousins, Thomas Van Lier, 21 years old, and James Oliver Jr., 23, were fined $250 each and placed on a year's probation for assault and battery in connection with the same in cident.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Mrs. Hicks Outranks 20 In Boston Council Primary
description: BOSTON, Sept. 26 (UPI)  Louise Day Hicks, a former Congresswoman, outpolled all candidates in a preliminary election for the Boston City Council last night.

title: JAILINQUIRY CASE ON L.I. DISMISSED; Have Charges Dropped ?? Is Unavailable
description: MINEOLA Sept. 26A State ?? Court justice dis ?? charges of bribery, as sault and drug trafficking against 10 Nassau County Jail guards and two alleged organ izedcrime figures today after the District Attorney's office said it could not produce its chief witness.

title: Excerpts From Secretary of State Kissinger's News Conference Here
description: Following are excerpts from Secretary of State Kissinger's news conference in New York yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Bridge: 7 Knockouts Coming for Those Who Like HeadtoHead Play
description: Most serious players con sider that headtohead team matches are the most satis fying form of competition. This accounts for the grow ing popularity of knockout and double knockout events played over a long period. As long as they survive, teams play a match every five or six weeks.

title: MRS. ADELBERT AMES 3D
description: CONCORD, Mass., Sept. 26 Mrs. Judith Quentin Derby Ames, a granddaughter of Pres ident Theodore Roosevelt and the wife of Dr. Adelbert Ames 3d, died today.

title: AGREEMENT BACKED IN ANTITRUST PACT
description: An agreement announced late last month for an outof court settlement of an antitrust suit against five producers of antibiotics has been confirmed by Judge Miles M. Lord of the United States District Court in Minneapolis. The suit was brought by veterinarians and animalfeed manufacturers and retailers.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 27, 1973

title: Rosh haShanah Sermons Emphasize Faith in U.S.
description: Rabbis, in Rosh haShanah sermons at sundown yesterday, urged worshipers to maintain tain their faith in the nation's democratic ideals and princi ples that have been undermned by the Watergate revelations.

title: Pirates Lose to Phillies in 13th, 3 to 2, And Drop a Full Game Behind Idle Mets
The Partners Are Three Nunsand 1,000 Maine Craftsmen
description: ORLAND, Me.  All I know of tomorrow is that Providence will rise before the sun.

title: SENATE VOTES CUT OF 110,000 TROOPS OVERSEAS BY 1976
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The Senate, in a foreign policy setback to the Administration, voted today, 48 to 36 to require a 110,000man reduction in overseas troops by the end of 1975.

title: Union Picks Scanlon
description: SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 27 (AP)William Scanlon became the new varsity bas ketball coach at Union Col lege today, succeeding Gary Walters, who returned to his alma mater, Princeton, to be come an assistant coach. Scanlon, 29 years old, was freshman basketball coach at Union for the past three years and compiled a 3910, wonlost record.

title: Brokerage House Profits May Predate Rise in Rates
description: Wall Street's stock brokerage firms, which earlier this month won approval of an estimated $300million rate increase from the Government, apparent ly were moving into a profit able stance even as the in crease was being granted, ac cording to industry officials.

title: MODEL CITIES AIDE GUILTY IN BRIBERY
description: John Sanders pleaded guilty yesterday to a conspiracy to obtain bribes in 1971 when he was acting director of the Har lem Model Cities Program.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: OUR TOWN It's not hard to find movies and plays that have New York as a backgroundKnicker bocker Holiday, Dead End, The French Connec tion, for instancebut now there's a show in which the city has the starring role.

title: Agnew Reaches Decision: Intends to Fight, Not Quit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 Vice President Agnew has made up his mind about the next phase of what he calls his nightmare. He does not intend to resign, even if he is indicted by the Baltimore grand jury, but to fight for exonera tion through the courts, and keep appealing to the House of Representatives for a full and open hearing, no matter how long it takes.

title: Ice Follies
description: ICE FOLLIES 1974. Director of chore ographer and staging, Bob Shipstad; costumes by Helen Colvig; production associate and director of music, Paul Walberg. Presented by Bob Shipstad. At Madison Square Garden. WITH: Janet Lynn, The Funsters, Atoy Wilson, Susan Berens, Richard Dwyer, Nancy and Leandre, Karen Kresge, Christie Ito, Hans Leiter and Mr. Frick, the Cook Family, Snoopy.

title: Economic Shortages Include Workers
description: In an economy marked by shortages, not the least these days is a shortage of personnel.

title: Pound's Papers Bought by Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 27 The archives of Ezra Pound, among the most controver sial literary figures of this century and a bulwark of modern AngloAmerican po etry, have been sold to Yale University for an undisclosed sum.

title: Empty Seats for the Aaron Drama
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 27Maybe the people here are too close to it to appreciate the significance. Maybe they just don't understand. Or maybe they don't want to understand. Whatever the reason, the panorama of Atlanta Stadium is dominated by empty blue seats as Henry Aaron ap proaches Babe Ruth's record of 714 home runs. In a modern ball park with 52,870 seats, there were 47,299 empty seats last night, 42,659 empty seats the night before. Of those who came, the majority were white. One reason is that the Atlanta Braves' ticket prices are too high Sports for many blacks. When the Braves end their season against the Houston Astros on Satur day day night and Sunday afternoon, bigger The Times crowds are anticipated. But until more peo ple appear, Atlanta is the disgrace of base ball. It prides itself as a historical city, but it's ignoring history. Atlanta doesn't deserve Henry Aaron's drama. He'd be better off on a barnstorming tour.

title: Rockefeller PATH Shift Nettles Cahill Spokesmen
description: Spokesmen for Governor Cahill of New Jersey accused Governor Rockefeller yester day of leading Jersey officials into an embarrassing political trap over fares on the PATH commuter line.

title: Pacific Sailors Improved
description: HONOLULU, Sept. 27 (AP) Two men rescued last week af ter drifting for 72 days in the Pacific Ocean were reported improving today at a hospital here. They are Robert Tinin enko, 34 years old, of Longview, Wash., and James Fisher, 26, of Moses Lake, Wash.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Detroit Tigers, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 7:30 P.M. (Radio WMCA, 7:30 P.M.)

title: GEORGE KARGER, 71, PHOTOGRAPHER, DIES
description: George Karger, a retired pho tographer whose fashion and theater pictures of ten appeared, in Vogue and Life magazines some years ago, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 252 East 61st Street.

title: CHAVEZ REACHES TENTATIVE ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The International Brotherhood of Teamsters and Cesar Chav ez's United Farm Workers reached a tentative settlement today of their bitter dispute over which union has the right ito repres??nt agricultural work ers in California, union sources reported today.

title: Commodity Price Index Fell 1.6 From WeekAgo Level
description: The comodity spot market price index of foodstuff and in dustrial materials fell to 194.0 from 195.6 last week.

title: Mets Fate Is Brewing In Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 27Yogi Berra flew into Chicago to night with a small head cold and several large headaches as the New York Mets ar rived at the site of their final four games in the battle for first place.

title: Samuel Flagg Bemis Dies
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 27Samuel Flagg Bemis, twice a Pulitzer Prize winner and leading authority on the diplo matic history of the United States, died here yesterday at the age of 81. He had lived here since his retirement in 1960 as Sterling Professor of Diplomatic History and Inter American Relations at Yale University.

title: F. GLADDEN SEARLE
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 27 F. Gladden Searle, a former vice president of sales and a director of the Continental Can Company, died today in Law rence Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 33 Northway, Bronxville.

title: Union Picks Scanlon
description: SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 27 (AP)William Scanlon became the new varsity bas ketball coach at Union Col lege today, succeeding Gary Walters, who returned to his alma mater, Princeton, to be come an assistant coach. Scanlon, 29 years old, was freshman basketball coach at Union for the past three years and compiled a 3910, wonlost record.

title: Watergate and Taxes
description: WEST HARTFORD, Conn.  The tax aspects of political campaign fi nancing are an important part of the Watergate scandal. They should re ceive more of the spotlight.

title: Cards Top Cubs, 20, On 1Hitter
description: ST LOUIS, Sept. 27 (AP)  Reggie Cleveland of the Cardinals faced only 27 bat ters tonightthe minimum number possible in a nine inning game  and shut out the Chicago Cubs, 20.

title: RALPH EARNHARDT
description: KANNAPOLIS, N. C., Sept. 27 (UPI)Ralph Earnhardt, stock car racer, died yesterday ap parently of a heart attack, at his home here. He was 45 years old.

title: Military in Chile Executes Two, Including a Former Governor
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 27 Two opponents of the military takeover in Chile were exe cuted today on the order of military tribunals.

title: Prison Inmate Killed
description: WALPOLE, Mass., Sept. 27 (AP)Michael J. Sullivan of Boston was found dead today, the victim of a stabbing at Walpole State Prison. He had been sentenced Jan. 16 to two concurrent 5year terms for armed robbery and possession of burglar tools.

title: Chile's Military Imposing Strict Standards on Nation
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 27 In the 16 days since it over threw the Marxist coalition Government, the military junta has emerged as a strongly au thoritarian antiMarxist regime bent on remodeling traditional Chilean institutions and remain ing in power for a long time.

title: FREDERICK JOHANNS JR.
description: Frederick L. Johanns Jr., president of Johanns and Keegan Company, Inc., a ma rine and industrialsupply com pany founded by his father, died of cancer yesterday in the New York Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived at Moun?? Grey, Setauket, L.I., where he was a former mayor of the village of Oldfield.

title: Kissinger Is Seeking Views of Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27  Henry A. Kissinger entered the State Department for the first time today as Secretary of State and immediately took steps intended to carry out his pledge to consult regularly with Congress.

title: Yanks Earn 20 Triumph For Dobson
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 27 (AP)  Pat Dobson scattered nine hits and the New York Yankees clinched a fourth place tie in the American League's Eastern Division by defeating the Milwaukee Brewers, 20, tonight.

title: Six Cliburn Finalists To Compete in Texas
description: FORT WORTH, Sept. 27 (AP)Six finalists were chosen yesterday to compete here in the Van Cliburn in ternational piano competi tion beginning tomorrow.

title: BACON CHOW, 63, BIOCHEMIST, DIES
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 27Bacon Field Chow, a professor of bio chemistry at the Johns Hopkins School of Hygiene and Public Health, who in 1936 was cred ited with helping to isolate for the first time in pure form one of the substances known as antibodies, died today at the Johns Hopkins Hospital. He was 63 years old.

title: U.S. JURY OPENS INQUIRY ON AGNEW; 4 GIVE TESTIMONY
description: BALTIMORE, Sept, 27The Federal grand jury investigat ing political corruption in Maryland began today to hear evidence against Vice President Agnew after weeks of legal maneuvering by the Justice De partment and Mr. Agnew's at torneys.

title: Department Store Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $1,009,000,000, up 15 per cent from the yearearlier $879million. Total retail store sales were about $9.73billion, up 11 per cent from last year's $8.80billion.

title: People in Sports: The Last Blow West Adds
description: Ernie Terrell, who won the World Boxing Association heavyweight championship in 1965, was retired from box ing in New York yesterday by a unanimous decision of the threeman State Athletic Commission.

title: U.N. ASSEMBLY HEARS NATIONAL OFFICIALS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 27  Ranking officials from a number of countries ad dressed the General Assembly today, generally expressing gratification at the improve ment in relations among the major powers of the East and the West.

title: Namath Shoulder: Good Progress
description: Joe Namath and New York Jets fans got some good news yesterday as Dr. James Nicholas, the team physician, confirmed that there was lit tle likelihood he would have to operate on the quarter back's separated right shoul der.

title: NETWORKS TO LIMIT WATERGATE'S TIME
description: The three major television network have not renewed their agreement to provide rotating coverage of the Senate Select Watergate Committee hearings and henceforth will carry them as news events warrant. The reason, according to a spokes man for the American Broad casting Company, is that the character of the hearings has changed and the story has run down.

title: Station (Landmark or Eyesore) Nears End
description: NEW LONDON, Sept. 27 A dingy railroad station that historians call a turning point in American architecture and that many residents here re gard as simply an eyesore is facing the wrecker's ball after 10 years of attempts to save it.

title: People and Business
description: Allison R. Maxwell Jr., with nearly four decades of service with the Wheeling Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, yesterday announced his re tirement as chairmanat age 59. Mr. Maxwell served as chief executive of the com pany for 17 years, the long est tenure of any steel lead er in modern times.

title: Ford Is Optimistic
description: DETROIT, Sept. 27, (Reuters) Henry Ford 2d, chairman of the Ford Motor Company, said today that he believed there would be a peaceful settlement between the company and the United Auto Workers along the lines of the union's contract with the Chrysler Corporation.

title: Grefe, a Newcomer, Ties With Kavalek For U.S. Chess Title
description: EL PASO, Sept. 27 (AP)  John Grefe, a newcomer, and Grandmaster Lubomir Kavalek tied at 9 points each today to share the title of 1973 United States Chess Champion.

title: 3 Card 64's And Share Shot Lead
description: BETTENDORF, Iowa, Sept. 27 (AP)Larry Wise, Dwight Nevil and Dave Stockton equaled the course record with 64's today and shared the firstround lead in the $100,000 Quad Cities golf tournament.

title: Agnew Reaches Decision: Intends to Fight, Not Quit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 Vice President Agnew has made up his mind about the next phase of what he calls his nightmare. He does not intend to resign, even if he is indicted by the Baltimore grand jury, but to fight for exonera tion through the courts, and keep appealing to the House of Representatives for a full and open hearing, no matter how long it takes.

title: YugoslavU.S. Air Pact
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 27 (Reuters)Yugoslavia and the United States signed an agreement today regulating charter flights between the two countries, the Yugoslav press agency reported.

title: Market Advances. 7th Day in Row Trading Heavy
description: The stock market staged its seventh straight advance yes terday on heavy trading vol ume.

title: Dollars for Defense
description: Vice President Agnew, in his travail, has let it be known that he will organize a defense fund to pay the legal costs he is facing. So will Mr. Egil Krogh, the former White House aide who has been indicted on charges of authorizing the burglary of a Los Angeles psychiatrist's office.

title: Cost of Home Insurance Down 2.2% in 8 Months
description: The cost of homeowners in surance in the state dropped 2.2 per cent during the first eight months of 1973, continu ing a downward trend that be gan in 1972, according to the state Insurance Department.

title: U.S. Team Scores Volleyball Upset
description: PRAGUE, Sept. 22 (AP) The United States upset Bul garia, 3 to 2, in volleyball's Friendship Cup competition today.

title: Wright 206 Leads 4Ball Golf by 5
description: GLENEAGLES, Scotland, Sept. 27 (AP)Jimmy Wright of Glen Cove, L.I., toured the St. Andrews course in a five under par today to take the thirdround lead in the inter national FourBall golf tour nament.

title: Skylab 3 Ready to Study Comet Returning to View
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 27  A comet that could outshine Halley's Comet of 1910 moved into telescopic view this week, following a predicted course that should give the Skylab 3 astronauts an unprecedented opportunity to gather data on such brilliant objects in the sky.

title: Guerrillas Declare Independence In a Part of Portuguese Guinea
description: DAKAR, Senegal, Sept. 27 (Reuters)  African nationalist guerrillas have proclaimed in dependence in a liberated area of neighboring Portu guese Guinea and said their prime aim was the expulsion of Portuguese forces from the rest of Africa.

title: PERCY B. MENAGH
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., Sept. 27  Percy B. Menagh, retired executive secretary of the Sav ings Banks Association of New Jersey, died yesterday in a nursing home in New Provi idence. He was 84 years old and lived here.

title: Mr. Hunt's Mission
description: E. Howard Hunt Jr. has testified before the Senate Watergate committee in great detail about his secret mission to the Denver hospital bedside of Dita D. Beard, the lobbyist for the International Telephone and Tele graph Corporation. According to his testimony, the White House plumber went on this extraordinary errand in a disguise furnished by the Central Intelligence Agency and with an aide memoire containing a specific line of interrogation, drawn up inside the White House. He not only was following instructions given by Special Presidential Counsel Charles W. Colson, but telephoned Mr. Colson during a break in the interrogation to report on the mission's progress.

title: Changing Exchanges
description: After nearly two centuries of sheltered operation, the traditional mechanism for trading shares of ownership in public corporations is coming up for major overhaul. If fully implemented, the recent decision by the Securities and Exchange Commission to abolish fixed brokerage commissions for stock exchange transactions should spark a profound revolution in the securities industry.

title: MOSCOW RATIFIES 2 U.N. COVENANTS ON HUMAN RIGHTS
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 27The So viet Union, in an apparent ef fort to influence voting in the United States Congress on So vietAmerican trade, has an nounced ratification of two in ternational covenants on human rights adopted by the United Nations General Assembly in 1966.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Precinct Honors 12th Slain Policeman

title: News Summary and Index FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 28, 1973
description: The Soviet Union announced that it had ratified two international covenants on hu man rights, including one affirming that everyone shall be free to leave any coun try, including his own. The announcement appeared to be an effort to influence the United States Congress, where approval of trade arrangements with the Soviet Union has been linked to the right of Soviet Jews to emigrate. [Page 1, Column 4.]

title: Chaotic Session Raises Doubts About Japan's Legislative Body
description: TOKYO, Sept. 27A long and tumultuous session of Ja pan's Parliament ended today when the speaker of the house stood up and intoned wearily: Here I adjourn the session.

title: Pompidou Gives Lively News Session
description: PARIS, Sept. 27 President Pompidou discoursed for almost two hours at his semiannual news conference in the Elyse Palace today, making no major pronouncements but proving that he can still give a lively oneman show.

title: To Peter Brook, Audience Is a Partner
description: A park in BedfordStuyve sant, a drug prevention cen ter in Sheepshead Bay, a street corner in Canarsie, a courtyard at the Brooklyn Museum, a lofty new space in the Brooklyn Academy of MusicPeter Brook is all over Brooklyn these days with his International Cen ter for Research, conducting workshops, performing plays, giving lectures and encoun tering new audiences.

title: Direct Elections Are Given Backing Of Administration
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UPI)  The Administration to day expressed support for abolishing the Electoral Col lege but said that a proposed emergency provision allowing Congress to decide the outcome of a national election would undercut the independence of the Presidency.

title: Sometimes When You Get Stuck It's O. K. if You Have Right Altitude
Drug Panel Head Resigns
description: Assemblyman Chester Hardt, an Erie Republican, has resigned as chairman of the temporary state commission to evaluate the drug laws. He will be suc ceeded by Assemblyman Emeel S. Betros a Republican from Poughkeepsie Mr, Hardt, chair man of the commission since it was formed three years ago, said he resigned because of an increasing workload in other legislative areas.

title: Dance: Talking Through
description: I'm not asking everyone to swallow this presentation hook, line and sinker, Ken neth King noted helpfully at his Inadmissleable Evident dance concert Wednesday night at Washington Square Free Church, 133 West Fourth Street.

title: Abplanalp Concern Drops Sullivan Airport Proposal
description: The Precision Valve Corpora tion of Robert H. Abplanalp an nounced yesterday that it was withdrawing a proposal to take over the operation of the dor mant Sullivan County Interna tional Airport.

title: Brandt Aide Calls Printing Of '68 Bonn Study a Plot
description: Rtidiger von Wechmar, the chief spokesman for the West German Government, says that it is absurd to charge the Brandt Government with neu tralist tendencies.

title: Iceland Bids Britain Withdraw Warships By Next Wednesday
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Sept. 27 (Reuters)Iceland notified Britain today that she would break off diplomatic relations if British warships were not withdrawn from the disputed 50mile fishing limit here with in a week.

title: COPPER FUTURES SHOW PRICE GAIN
description: chaotic trading, copper fu tures on the Commodity Ex change ranged widely in price yesterday.

title: CONGRESS WEIGHS PATIENTS' RIGHTS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 Despite Administration objec tions, Congress may be moving toward the creation of a na tional commission to protect the rights of human subjects of all federally supported medical research.

title: NIXON ASKS EASING OF BILL ON SOVIET
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 27 President Nixon urged Con gress today to modify the anti Soviet restrictions voted by the House Ways and Means Com mittee yesterday and permit the Soviet Union to enjoy im proved trade treatment in the United States without linking it to the emigration of Soviet Jews.

title: 6 of Alabama's Largest Lobbies Face Corrupt Practice Charge
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 27Six of Alabama's largest and most influential lobby groups have been indicted on charges of violating the state's Corrupt Practices Act by sec retly financing a front group in order to avoid disclosure of campaign financing.

title: Nixon Economic Nominee Urges 5% Instead of 4% Jobless Target
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 William Feltner, President Nixon's nominee for member ship on the Council of Economic Advisers, said today that the goal of reducing un employment to 4 per cent ought to be abandoned and a 5 per cent target substituted.

title: G.O.P. BLOC SEEKS ALBERT REVERSAL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 Republicans on the House Ju diciary Committee sought today to put pressure on Speaker Carl Albert to reverse his decision rejecting for the time being Vice President Agnew's request that the House investigate charges against him.

title: ROMNEY BARS RACE IN UTAH FOR SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP)  Former Gov. George Rom ney of Michigan said today that he would not run for the Sen ate from Utah next year.

title: LEBANON IS UPSET OVER ARMED UNITS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 27 An incident said to involve the kidnapping and torture of an Iranian Embassy official by Palestinian guerrillas has em barrassed the Lebanese Gov ernment and added to disquiet over armed groups.

title: Phnom Penh in a Festive Mood Despite the Enemy at the Door
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sept. 27  Cambodians cele brated their most important festival today in a demonstra tion of the continuity of life in this country amid war.

title: Problems for the President, Vice President and G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27  Vice Presidents count for little in the American scheme of things. They are likely to spend their careersif not like Alex ander Throttlebottom, taking tours through the White House  in relative obscurity. They affect the political equation only when they are chosen as candidates (is the ticket balanced?), when they say something contro versial (did the President author ize that?), when they do some thing reprehensible (can the President tolerate that?) and when they succeed to the Presidency.

title: Sabotage Is Ruled Out in Crash That Killed Mrs. Howard Hunt
description: WASHINGTON Sept. 27 (AP) The Chicago plane crash that killed a Congressman and the wife of E. Howard Hunt, the convicted Watergate defend ant, was caused by pilot error, not by sabotage, the Na tional Transportation Safety Board said today.

title: SOVIET'S AUTHORS FACING STIFF TAX Government Can Claim 75 of Foreign Royalties
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 27The So viet Union disclosed today a new system of high tax rates on authors income from for eign royalties, suggesting that the Government's need for for eign exchange had been a major consideration for its joining the Universal Copyright Conven tion earlier this year.

title: Suspect in Slaying Of 2 Officers Flees
description: A 24yearold member of the Black Liberation Army, who was being held for trial in the murder of two policemen in the East Village and who had twice before tried to break out of jail, escaped yesterday from a crowded clinic in a Brooklyn hospital.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Listed to speak are: Gabon, Turkey, Albania (ten tative), Morocco (tentative), Senegal, Oman, Tanzania, Spain, Sierra Leone, Cam bodia, and Saudi Arabia.

title: In This Ballroom, Dining Is a Breezy, Informal Experience
description: The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment or quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as ex cellent and four as superb.

title: Judge Orders City to Run Bilingual Elections Nov. 6
description: A Federal District Court judge here ordered the city's Board of Elections to run a bilingual election on Nov. 6, with all amendments, propositions and voting instructions printed in Spanish as well as English.

title: Withdrawal Symptoms
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27Though the Senate voted the other day to cut United States military forces overseas by 40 per cent, and then reversed itself under intense pressure from the White House, that challenge to the present balance or power in the world has sent a shudder through the Ad ministration and the Western alliance. And late yesterday, the Senate again voted for a large cut23 per cent, or 110,000 of 471,000 landbased troops.

title: Aide to Governor Expected to Head Investigation Unit
description: Howard Shapiro, chief as sistant counsel to Governor Rockefeller, is expected to be named chairman of the State Commission of Investigation, a post that has been vacant since Paul Curran became United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York last June.

title: Rain Halts Play With Coles Leading Scottish Golf
description: TURNBERRY, Scotland, Sept. 27One of the rough est days in British Isles golf history was finally halted to day after six hours of rain, wind and cold had numbed the 36 professional contest ants in the $145,000 John Player Classic.

title: National Farmer Group Under I.R.S. Inquiry on Tax Exemption
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The National Farmers Organi zation faces possible loss of its tax exemption, and several of its home office aides have been subjected to personal income tax review by the Internal Rev enue Service.

title: CHINA EXPLORING LINKS WITH I.M.F.
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 27 The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank have received from Peking a com munication regarding the mem bership of China, a spokesman disclosed today.

title: NEW TRACKS PLAN CHEAP ADMISSION
description: NEWARK, Sept. 27  The New Jersey Sports and Expo sition Authority, in a competi tive move apparently aimed at New York race tracks, has cut proposed admission prices at the thoroughbred and harness plant it plans to build in the Hackensack meadows. The prices planned are below those now prevailing elsewhere in the metropolitan area.

title: Interest Rates Retreat Across Broad Spectrum
description: Interest rates continued to slide along a broad front yes terday, spurred by an increas ingly widespread belief  now supported by Administration officials  that the highs for this business cycle were set six weeks ago.

title: Mr. Lippmann
description: WASHINGTON  For sixty years Walter Lippmann (who turned 84 last Sunday) has been a lodestone not only for American journalists but also for journalists around the world. It is an extraordinary career reaching into a past that must seem dim and remote. He has rarely if ever wavered in his pursuit of the truth in the nation and the world. It is safe to say that no other journalist, author or philosopher for he is that toohas in this cen tury been so often quoted and with such telling effect. Genius may be the word for it. But it is more than that. His scrupulous dedication to his craft, the unfailing care with which he has met how many thousands of deadlines, is a lesson which above all strikes home for us today.Marquis Childs.

title: Suspect in Slaying Of Evers Arrested With a Time Bomb
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 27 (AP)Byron De La Beckwith, who was tried twice but never convicted in the 1963 murder of Medgar Evers, the civil rights leader, was arrested today as he drove into New Orleans with a bomb and several rifles.

title: Giants Picked Over Browns
POLICE GET LEADS IN BRONX SLAYING
description: Detectives said last night they were working on some new leads in the slaying of Martha Smith, who was shot to death Wednesday night by three young gunmen.

title: Advertising: A Funeral Plan
description: Two years ago Halsted & Co., San Francisco, founded in 1883, retained its first ad vertising agency  the local office of DancerFitzgerald Sample, a big national com pany.

title: LOMENZO IS SEEN READY TO RESIGN
description: State government sources said yesterday that Secretary of State John P. Lomenzo would probably submit his resignation to Governor Rockefeller within the next few months.

title: Police Study Here Shows Few Gun Offenders Jailed
description: The chances that a person arrested for carrying a loaded pistol on the streets of New York City will escape convic tion and imprisonment have increased in the last two years, a Police Department study has found.

title: Tentam 1st In U.N. by 4 Lengths
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 27 Tentam took to the grass with gusto in the $125,000 United Nations Handicap to day. The star 4yearold, recently purchased for $2 million by a syndicate head ed by the Windfields Farm, closed fast in the stretch of the 1 316mile event to score by four lengths over Star En voy, who preceded the bet ting outsider, Return to Reality, by 1 lengths.

title: Equity Financing
description: A secondary offering of 194,900 shares of the American Can Company common at 31 was made by Jefferies & Co. and associates. The company's stock, traded on the New York Stock Exchange, closed unchanged at 31.

title: City Maps $2Billion Plan Based on State Bond Issue
description: The city has put together a $2billion package of highway construction projects that it plans to set in motion if the voters approve the state trans porationbond issue in Novem ber.

title: For Jews From Soviet, Fear and joyin Vienna
description: SCHONAU, Austria, Sept. 27For Josef Neiman, a 44yearold mechan ical engineer from Kiev, it was the best possible new yearmy first as a free man. After six months of uncertain waiting for permission to leave the Soviet Union, and an ex hausting fiveday train trip via Hun gary and Czechoslovakia, he and his wife and two children arrived at this ancient Habsburg castle outside Vienna in time for Rosh haShanah, the Jewish New Year.

title: 3 Card 64's And Share Shot Lead
description: BETTENDORF, Iowa, Sept. 27 (AP)Larry Wise, Dwight Nevi] and Dave Stockton equaled the course record with 64's today and shared the firstround lead in the $100,000 Quad Cities golf tournament.

title: Way of Life Shifting for Tuaregs
description: CAMP LAZARETH, Niger, Sept. 18Neatly placed among the tall, green stalks of ripen ing millet, just a few hundred yards from this jumble of ani mal skin and canvas tents, are the recent graves of scores of victims of the subSahara's five year drought and famine.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Tickets matching the num ber above win $50,000. Tick ets matching the last five numbers win $4,000. Tickets matching the last four num bers win $400 and those matching the last three, $40.

title: HENRY FRIEDRICKS
description: MIAMI, Sept. 27  Henry Friedricks, founder and presi dent of Henry Fredricks & Co., a coat and suit manufacturer in New York, died Tuesday at the Heart Institute here. He was 77 years old.

title: I.L.A. Dock Feud in Jersey Tied To Shooting and Disappearance
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 27  The shooting of one official of the International Longshore men's Association and the dis appearance of another have been linked by investigators to a battle for control of thou sands of jobs on the Hudson County waterfront.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 27 (AP)Bobby Tolan was sus pended by the Cincinnati Reds today for the rest of the regular season for what Bob Howsam, the club president, said was a continued refusal to take and participate in regular batting and fielding practice and for a lack of interest.

title: 50 Miners Die in Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 27 (Reuters)  At least 50 miners were killed and buried under tons of mud at a remote mineral mine in northern Thai land when the mine collapsed because of torrential rain, the Interior Miinstry reported to day.

title: Recently Published Books
description: Clone, by Richard Cowper (Double day, $5.95). Satirical science fiction story. Crash, by J. G. Ballard (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $6.95). A fan tast's adventures in a motorcar world.

title: Brokerage House Profits May Predate Rise in Rates
description: Wall Street's stock brokerage firms, which earlier this month won approval of an estimated $300million rate increase from the Government, apparent ly were moving into a profit able stance even as the in crease was being granted, ac cording to industry officials.

title: EXCADET CHARGES HAZING CONTINUES
description: A West Point cadet who re signed a few weeks ago, appar ently after being hazed into a state of acute dehydration, charged yesterday that upper classmen at the United States Military Academy were ignor ing new regulations intended to modify this form of harass ment.

title: BRIBECASE JURY ACQUITS GARRISON
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 27 (AP)  District Attorney Jim Garrison was acquitted by a Federal jury today of charges of taking bribes to protect gambling interests.

title: U.S. Names Finance Adviser for State
description: The Federal Government has appointed an overseer to pro vide technical assistance to the state in handling more than $2 billion a year in Federal health, education and welfare funds.

title: To Lakers' Problems
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27 (AP)Wilt Chamberlain is gone and Jerry West says he is almost certain to quit which would leave the Los Angeles Lakers with only twofifths of the starting team that made a shambles of the National Basketball Association two years ago.

title: Police Study Here Shows Few Gun Offenders Jailed
description: The chances that a person arrested for carrying a loaded pistol on the streets of New York City will escape convic tion and imprisonment have increased in the last two years, a Police Department study has found.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Winning numbers drawn on Sept. 27 were: NEW JERSEY 013669 Tickets matching the num ber above win $50,000. Tick ets matching the last five numbers win $4,000. Tickets matching the last four num bers win $400 and those matching the last three, $40.

title: Boyle Still Is Critical After Taking Barbiturates
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UPI)W. A. Boyle, former president of the United Mine Workers Union, regained con sciousness today for the first time since he swallowed bar biturates in an apparent suicide attempt.

title: Suspect in Slaying Of 2 Officers Flees
description: A 24yearold member of th? Black Liberation Army, who was being held for trial in the murder of two policemen in the East Village and who had twice before tried to break out of jail, escaped yesterday from crowded clinic in a Brooklyn hospital.

title: Monetary Deadlock
description: This year's annual meeting of the International Mone tary Fund in Nairobi was to have marked the end of the first stage in the creation of a new world monetary system. But instead of agreeing on basic principles, the conference has disclosed a fundamental deadlock between the United States, on one side, and the Europeans, Japa nese and most other nations, on the other.

title: John B. Peck, 55, Editor At Farrar, Straus & Giroux
description: John B. Peck, senior editor at Farrar, Straus & Giroux, Inc., the bookpublishing house, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hos pital. He was 55 years old and lived at 354 West 21st Street.

title: Pop Music: Hello, Camel
description: Sopwith Camel was one of the Big San Francisco Bay area bands back in the long distant summeroflove days'Then, after a hit (Hello, Hello), a round of touring and a couple of commercials for Levi's, the group drifted apart. It took another kind of commercial  Burger King wanting to use Hello, Hello as a jingleto inspire the performers reunion, and Wednesday night they opened at the Bitter End, 147 Bleecker Street, with four of the original five members on hand.

title: Nixons and Agnews Are Javial at Party
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP)For the first time since the inauguration in January, President and Mrs. Nixon danced in public tonight. At a dinner party for Prime Minister Norman Kirk of New eZaland, the Nixons and Vice President and Mrs. Agnew were in a jovial mood.

title: The Screen: Badly 'Mixed Up Files':The Cast
description: When Fielder Cook's "From the Mixed-Up Files of Mrs. Basil E. Frankweiler" opens, we see 12-year old Claudia Kincaid (Sally Prager) running through the New Jersey wood, finally coming to rest hugging a tree. Claudia is a restless romantic. She wants to be Lady Guinevere. Any movie that defines an adolescent's restless romanticism in terms of tree-hugging is, I have found, usually a fake.Little girls hug cats, sometimes fatally. They hug dogs, horses, gerbils and, if allowed, they would probably hug parakeets, opossums, lions, tigers and polar bears. Little girls will hug almost any kind of creature, as long as it breathes and is soft to the touch. Trees are an adult fancy.It's not an accident that Claudia hugs a tree. "From the Mixed-Up Files of Mrs. Basil E. Frankweiler" is one of those G-rated movies about children, not as they are but as they appear in television commercials for things like peanut butter and potato chips. They play out adult dreams in adult gestures.Claudia and her 10-year-old brother Jamie (Johnny Doran) run away from home and take up residence in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where Thomas Hoving's ever-alert guards somehow never come upon them, even though the children clatter through the halls and exhibition rooms at all hours of the day and night. They are horribly stanch youngsters. They bathe nightly in the pool in the cafeteria (with their underwear on) and regularly change their socks.Somewhere along the line, they come upon a movie plot of sorts: they will authenticate the origins of a statue that has been attributed to Michelangelo. These children are not only clean, they are also scholarly.Their investigation leads them eventually to the home of Mrs. Basil E. Frankweiler, described as a wealthy recluse, who is played in the film's last 25 minutes by Ingrid Bergman wearing a white wig and long black dress of the sort usually worn by the male lead in "Charley's Aunt."The screenplay by Blanche Hanalis is based on E. L. Konigsburg's novel, which, I am ??? may also be some interest in the fact that a large portion of the film was shot in the Metropolitan, with the museum's cooperation.I guess this gives the movie some quasi-educational status, which is the only status it deserves. It opened yesterday at the Radio City Music Hall.

title: COASTAL STATES GAS TO BE TRADED AGAIN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP)  The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today it has given the goahead for a re sumption of trading in stock and other securities of the Coastal States Gas Corporation of Houston.

title: SOVIET MEDIATES ON MACEDONIANS
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept, 27The Soviet Union is reported to be quietly trying to cairn discord between Yugo slavia and Bulgaria over the Macedonians, a Slavicspeaking people living in Yugoslavia, Bulgaria and Greece.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: John Wilson of Union County announced yesterday that he was dropping out of the race for the State Assembly.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 17.1 billion tonmiles, 8.4 per cent above the corresponding week last year. Carloadings in the same week totaled 561,568 cars, 2.8 per cent above last year.

title: SICKOUT ENDED BY PRISON GUARDS;Staff at Leesburg Reaches Accord on 4 Grievances
description: LEESBURG, Sept. 27Guards at the Leesburg State Prison tonight tentatively agreed to return to work at 6 A.M. to morrow, ending their twoday sickout in protest against prison security policy.

title: Internal Battle in Open at Eastern Air
description: A fierce internal struggle broke out at Eastern Air Lines yesterday as a result of news reports that its president was about to be dismissed in the wake of an alarming slump in the company's financial pros pects.

title: SENATE VOTES CUT OF 110,000 TROOPS OVERSEAS BY 1976
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The Senate, in a foreign policy setback to the Administration, voted today, 48 to 36, to re quire a 110,000man reduction in overseas troops by the end of 1975.

title: Brezhnev and Peking
description: Recent statements by Soviet party leader Brezhnev indicate the Kremlin's growing concern over Peking's rapidly changing status in the world community. Speak ing in Tashkent this week, Mr. Brezhnev openly chided those independent nations who are intent on seeking friendly relations with both Peking and Moscow. In view of the recent visit to China by French President Pompidou, there can be little doubt that France, which has long enjoyed friendly relations with Moscow, was on the Communist party chief's mind.

title: A Copter Hovers Over the Sandmans And Kicks Up Fuss
description: TRENTON, Sept. 27  The gubernatorial campaign got off the ground briefly today, thanks to a helicopter.

title: Trumpeter in a OneMan Band
description: GOODBYE, MR. CHRISTIAN. By Richard Dougherty. 263 pages. Doubleday & Co. $7.95.

title: Colson Is Said to Blame Haldeman for Fake Letter
description: Joseph Kraft, the columnist, reported yesterday that Charles W. Colson, former White House aide, contends it was H. R. Haldeman, not Mr. Colson, who sent a faked letter to the Dis trict of Columbia Republican chairman, Carl Shipley, ques tioning the patriotism of lead ing Democratic Senators in the 1970 elections.

title: A Rehearing Denied in Freeing of ExProsecutor
description: A new hearing has been denied on the dismissed con viction of former Assistant Dis trict Attorney Norman D. Arch er and two codefendants in a Queens bribery case.

title: Bridge: Schenken, Perhaps Best Ever In U.S., Marks 70th Birthday
description: Endless argument could be generated by an attempt to establish any one player as the best ever. The strongest American candidate for this title is probably Howard Schenken of New York, who celebrates his 70th birthday at his home here today.

title: Baker's 75 Leads N.J. Seniors Golf
description: DEAL, N. J., Sept. 27 William O. Baker of Glen Ridge shot a threeoverpar 75 to take the firstround lead in the older division of the 36hole New Jersey State Golf Association Seniors Preseniors tournament today at the Hollywood Golf Club.

title: Eduardo Zuleta Angel Is Dead; Leader of First U.N. Assembly
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 27 (UPI)Eduardo Zuleta Angel, former foreign minister of Co lombia and the diplomat who presided at the first United Nations Assembly in London, died yesterday in Miami, rela tives here reported today. He was 74 years old. Death was ascribed to a cerebral hemor rhage.

description: Remaining Games

title: C.A.B.Resignation Eases Way for Nixon Nominee
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP)  A Civil Aeronautics Board member, Robert Mur phy, resigned today effective Oct. 15.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, Sept. 27 (AP)Exxon Corporation said to day it was prepared to take action against unauthorized buyers of crude oil and other hydrocarbons from its Libyan concessions that were 51 per cent nationalized earlier this month. The company's position was contained in a state ment scheduled for publication as a paid announcement in newspapers in major nonCommunist countries. It is issued in the names of Esso Standard Libya, Inc., and Esso Sirte, Inc., two unites of Exxon with Libyan operations.

title: AMEX RETREATS ON LATE SELLING
description: Late selling pressure sent prices on the American Stock Exchange down yesterday af ter they had drifted higher dur ing much of the session with the net result that they closed mixed in slightly lower trad ing. However, prices rose in the overthecounter market.

title: Albania Protests to Italy
description: VIENNA, Sept. 27 (AP)Al bania protested to Italy today over possible contamination of coastal waters by cholerain fected shellfish dumped into the sea.

title: Treasury Secretary Confronts Developing Nations Head On
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 27 George P. Shultz, the United States Secretary of the Treas ury, confronted the whole bloc of lessdeveloped countries headon today by saying that what they most wanted out of world monetary reform was a printing press.

title: Dismissed Teachers Return
description: WALLINGFORD, Conn., Sept. 27 (UPI)  Eight elementary schoolteachers who were dis missed from the financially troubled Wallingford school system have been reinstated by the Wallingford Board of Edu cation. Mayor Joseph Carini said money was now available in the Schoolboard budget to allow the eight to return to work.

title: Brig Meets Hovercraft, a Rare Harbor Sight Here

title: RECEIVERSHIP ENDED AT BAKING COMPANY
description: The Horn and Hardart Bak ing Company announced yes terday it had been discharged from receivership under Chap ter I of the Federal Bankrupt cy Act after 23 months.

title: TALKS CALLED TODAY IN ORCHESTRA STRIKE
description: Vincent D. McDonnell, chair man of the State Mediation Board, said yesterday that he had called a meeting for this morning at 10 A.M. at his of fice at No. 2 World Trade Cen ter in an effort to end the New York Philharmonic strike.

title: Hartke Planning Negotiations Over Proposed Rail Legislation
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 27 Senator Vance Hartke, Demo crat of Indiana, chairman of the Senate Surface Transporta tion subcommittee, said today his staff would begin to nego tiate immediately with the staffs of the House subcom mittee and the Department of Transportation to resolve a dispute over proposed legisla tion designed to resolve the Northeast rail crisis.

title: Ivy Teams Open Season Tomorrow With Care
description: Ivy League teams will open their football seasons tomorrow, with each of the eight teams playing a non league opponent. But it does not appear to be the easy start the league used to have.

title: Franco Gives Plan for SelfRule In Sahara but He Sets No Date
description: MADRID, Sept. 27General issimo Francisco Franco made public today a program of par tial selfgovernment for the Spanish Sahara as a necessary prepartion for selfdetermi nation.

title: Kenyan Banker Gains Respect
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 26 Though Duncan Ndegwa of Kenya is a financial official of one of the less developed countries of Africa, he is a central banker to his finger tips.

title: Sen. Long Visits Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, met with President Nixon for 90 minutes at the White House today to push his workbonus plan for poor families.

title: Major Institutions Are Not Expected to Follow Now
description: A small St. Louis bank yes terday afternoon lowered its prime rate on corporate loans to 9 per cent.
