description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 27The Federal grand jury investigat ing political corruption in Maryland began today to hear evidence against Vice President Agnew after weeks of legal maneuvering by the Justice De partment and Mr. Agnew's at torneys.

title: Theater: The Revolution
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 Last night the Ford's Theater, here in Washington, tried to recreate the American Revo lution. It was called The American Revolution, Part I. It appears that Part II and Part III are waiting in the wings.

title: Rockefeller Shift on PATH Irks Jersey
description: Spokesmen for Governor Cahill of New Jersey accused Governor Rockefeller yester day of leading Jersey officials into an embarrassing political trap over fares on the PATH commuter line.

title: Soviet Puts Soyuz 12, With 2 Aboard, Into Earth Orbit
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 27  The Soviet Union, in its first manned space mission in more than two years, today launched an improved Soyuz spacecraft with two astronauts aboard, placing it in earth orbit.

title: NEW RIGHTS CHIEF IS EXPECTED SOON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 President Nixon is reportedly prepared to appoint a new chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights to replace the Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, who was forced off the commission last November.

title: General Tire Reports Reduction In Earnings for Third Quarter
description: The impact of rising costs with no corresponding price relief under Government con troll reduced net income of the General Tire and Rubber com pany in the third fiscal quarter, and nine months ended Aug. 31, it was reported yesterday. Sales, however, rose 18.5 per cent for the quarter and 28.6 per cent for the nine months.

title: TV Review
description: The National Broadcasting Company's Wednesday Mys tery Movie, which consists of several series presented in weekly rotation, introduced its new Faraday and Com pany this week. In the wholly familiar tradition of private investigators on TV, it is slickly produced, riddled with action sequences and skimpy on credibility.

title: Gasoline Retailers Predict Price Rise of 1 to 3 Cents a Gallon if U.S. Freeze on Auto Fuel Is Lifted
description: Gasoline retailers say they will raise prices one to three cents a gallon if the price freeze on motor fuel is lifted.

title: I. L. A. Dock Feud in Jersey Tied To Shooting and Disappearance
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 27 The shooting of one official of the International Longshore men's Association and the dis appearance of another have been linked by investigators to a battle for control of thou sands of jobs on the Hudson County waterfront.

title: NEW TRACKS PLAN CHEAP ADMISSION
description: NEWARK, Sept. 27  The New Jersey Sports and Ex position Authority, in a com petitive move apparently aimed at New York race tracks, has cut proposed admission prices at the thoroughbred and har ness plant it plans to build in the Hackensack meadows. The prices planned are below those now prevailing elsewhere in the metropolitan area.

title: Racial Fighting Closes A High School in Boston
description: BOSTON, Sept. 27 (AP)  A brawl today between black and white students forced the clos ing of Dorchester High School for two days. Officials attrib uted the violence to recipro cal fear.

title: Sir Harold Christie Dies at 77; Spurred Growth of Bahamas
description: LONDON, Sept. 27Sir Har old G. Christie, one of the largest landowners in the Ba hamas, died Tuesday during a business trip to Frankfurt, West Germany. He was 77 years old.

title: MOSCOW RATIFIES 2 U.N. COVENANTS ON HUMAN RIGHTS
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 27The So viet Union, in an apparent ef fort to influence voting in the United States Congress on So vietAmerican trade, has an nounced ratification of two in ternational covenants on human rights adopted by the United Nations General Assembly in 1966.

title: Unit of R. J. Reynolds Is Buying Containerships for $32Million
description: The Reynolds Leasing Cor poration, a subsidiary of R. J. Reynolds Industries, Inc., an nounced yesterday that it had agreed to purchase from Pacific Far East Lines, Inc., two con tainerships at a price of ap proximately $32million. The transaction is subject to the approval of the Maritime Administration. Reynolds Leasing said it would place the purchased ves sels as part of the fleet of SeaLand Service, Inc., another subsi diary of R. J. Reynolds In dustries.

title: BOWATER SEEKING A NEWSPRINT RISE
description: The Bowater Paper Corpora tion said in Montreal yester day that it intended to apply to the Cost of Living Council for permission to increase newsprint prices.

title: REVISIONS ASKED FOR PATENT LAWS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 President Nixon asked Congress today to enact major changes in the patent laws that would alter the basic procedures for granting patents and require publication of detailed informa tion about patent applications before the patents are actually, granted.

title: WILLIAM J. GODDARD
description: MASSAPEQUA, L. I., Sept. 27 William J. Goddard, assistant editor of The Long Island Cath olic, died Tuesday at Good Samaritan Hospital, West Islip. He was 49 years old and lived here.

title: U.S. Want Ad: Talented Wornen
description: Now is the time for all tal ented women to come to the aid of their country, accord ing to Nola Smith, President Nixon's recently appointed recruiter for women execu tives in government.

title: Conditions in Chile Protested By Writers and Publisher Here
description: The Authors League of Amer ica, representing 6,000 writers, and Grove Press, the publish ing house, sent separate cable grams to Chile yesterday decry ing what were described as acts by the ruling junta against writers in Chile and their works.

title: U.S. SIGNS PACT FOR IRANIAN GAS
description: A longterm contract was signed yesterday in Teheran, Iran, for the importation of large quantities of Iranian natu ral gas products to help allevi ate growing fuel shortages on the East Coast. This is be lieved to be the first such con tract signed with Iranian pro ducers.

title: Grosset Offers Rights For Paperback Marilyn
description: Grosset & Dunlap, the pub lishing house, has offered to sell the massmarket paper back rights to Marilyn, Norman Mailer's bestselling book about Marilyn Monroe, for a minimum guarantee of $500,000 against royalties, paperback publishing execu tives reported yesterday, but no paperback firms have met the terms.

description: Here is a detailed ilsting of the $1.8billion program, by calegory, planned by the city if the state transporta tion bond issue is passed in November.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 The Senate Watergate commit tee, its Democratic Senator embarrassed by the outcome of yesterday's interrogation of Patrick J. Buchanan, is plan ning to speed up its investiga tion of political dirty tricks.

title: White Liberal and Black Vie in Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 27Charles Longstreet Weltner hitched a leg over the arm of a chair in his law office the other day and couldn't help laughing as he savored the rich ironies that run through his campaign for Mayor of this Southern capital.

title: U.S. SIGNS PACT FOR IRANIAN GAS

title: Rainout Dampens Aaron's Pursuit of Homer Record
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 27After tonight's game with the Los Angeles Dodgers was can celed because of wet grounds, Henry Aaron of the Atlanta Braves acknowledged that his opportunity was that much slimmer to tie or sur pass Babe Ruth's record of 714 home runs this season.

title: DR. HARRY E. VOSS
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Sept. 27 Dr. Harry E. Voss, long a staff member at Lawrence Hos pital, Bronxville, and Director of Medicine there from 1958 to 1967, died yesterday at the hospital. He lived here and in Woodland Valley.

title: Splitting Up of A.E.C. Urged To Reassure Public on Safety
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27A member of the Atomic Energy Commission and a leading mem ber of the Congressional Joint Committee on Atomic Energy agreed at a public hearing to day that dividing the A.E.C. into a research and a regulatory agency, as President Nixon pro posed earlier this year, is ne cessary to bolster public con fidence in the safety of nuclear power.

title: When a Song Star And a Seagull Meet
description: Jonathan Livingston Sea gull, the film of the book, will have its premiere next month and in among all the bird doings is a soundtrack written by Neil Diamond, a singer and writer whose cred its wind back to the early nineteen  sixties, stretching from the Monkees to his own remarkably successful solo career.

title: WILLIAM H. LECK
description: ASHEVILLE, N. C., Sept. 27 (AP)William H. Leck, found er and chairman emeritus of Leck Industries Ltd., in Long Island City, Queens, New York, died yesterday at his home here. He was 80 years old.

title: Sihanouk Bars Interviews
description: PEKING, Sept. 27 (Reuters) The exiled Cambodian leader, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, said in a statement sent to resident correspondents in Peking today that tie would no longer grant them interviews and that cer tain Western newsmen had dangerously distorted his re marks and interpreted him falsely. But he added that cor respondents could still submit questions to which he would reply in writing.

title: Inflated Expectations
description: When Avery Fisher, the electronics manufacturer, gave several million dollars to Lincoln Center last week to help underwrite the operating and maintenance deficit of the New York Philharmonic, he could hardly have expected that the first fruit of his benefaction would be a strike by the orchestra. The Philharmonic has been telling its musicians for years that its ability to pay higher wages was limited by the oceans of red ink in its budget. Since that same refrain had been played in the current negotiations, the musicians understandably took the Fisher gift as an invitation to a Lucullan feast. Now it develops that the terms of the donation will make relatively little money immediately available for wages or any other purpose.

title: BUTTERFIELD TO QUIT F.A.A.,MAGAZINE SAYS
description: Alexander P. Butterfield, who first disclosed that President Nixon taperecorded all conver sations in his office, has lost support in the White House and is expected to resign as head of the Federal Aviation Ad ministration, Electronics maga zine reported yesterday.

title: Jules Podell, Showman, Dead; Owned Copacabana Since '40
description: Jules Podell, owner of the Copacabana, the last of the big New York nightclubs, died [yesterday afternoon at his home, 900 Fifth Avenue. He was 74 years old.

description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27 (AP)Wilt Chamberlain is gone and Jerry West says he is almost certain to quit which would leave the Los Angeles Lakers with only twofifths of the starting team that made a shambles of the National Basketball Association two years ago.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: An Essex County grand jury indicted a 26yearold window washer on charges he murdered a Montclair socialite and her daughter last May 14. Robert Del Petrarca of Newark has been charged with the hanging deaths of Mrs. Rene Cali and her pregnant 24yearold daughter, Mrs. Leslie Grant, in their 20room mansion on Upper Montclair Avenue in Montclair.

description: WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 28  Less than a minute after the 14th edition of the rich Roosevelt Futurity had been completed at Roosevelt Raceway tonight, Stanley Dancer, the noted trainer and driver, was on the phone inquiring about the outcome.

description: Weatherman went under ground in 1970, and most of the members of the militant leftwing organization have been hiding ever since to avoid prosecution on charges that include violation of Federal antiriot laws and destruction of property.

title: Goody Ahead by 4 Strokes
description: TURNBERRY, Scotland, Sept. 28  The 18th green was white with hailstones today as Toni Weiskopf sank his final putt for a 72 and a tie for second place at 216 after three rounds of the $140,000 John Player Classic.

title: SOVIET CUTS TERMS OF TWO DISSIDENTS
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 28  Two Soviet dissidents who were given mild sentences for having turned state's evidence in publicized trial a month ago had their terms reduced even further on appeal today.

title: Screen: 'Day for Night':Truffaut's Own World Viewed From Inside The Cast
description: Movie-making is a strange business, says Severine (Valentina Cortese), an actress who steadies her nerves by sipping champagne on the set of "Meet Pamela," a rather tacky melodrama being made within Franois Truffaut's exhilarating new comedy about movie-making, "Day for Night.""As soon as we grasp things," says Severine, "they're gone."In one way and another, almost all of Truffaut's films have been aware of this impermanence, which, instead of making life and love seem cheap, renders them especially precious.Worthy adventures are risky; they are headlong plunges into the unknown. Whether they end with a shotgun murder ("La Peau Douce"), middle-class boredom ("Bed and Board") or total isolation ("Jules and Jim") is not so important as the acceptance of the gamble itself. The quality of an experience cannot be measured by its duration or its end. Longevity is for redwood trees.The original French title of "Day for Night" is "La Nuit Americaine," which is what French movie makers call the method by which a scene shot in daylight is made to look like night through the use of filters. "Day for Night" is a hilarious, wise and moving chronicle about the members of a crew who come together for seven weeks at the Victorine Studios in Nice to manufacture a movie, an illusion that is, for the period of its production, more important than life itself.They include Ferrand (Truffaut), the director who observes at one point that making a movie is like a stagecoach trip through the old West ("At first you hope for a pleasant trip. Then you simply hope to reach your destination"); Julie (Jacqueline Bisset), the beautiful Hollywood star of the film within; Alphonse (Jean-Pierre Laud), a nice, nut-brained young actor preoccupied by movies and women, in that order; Alexandre (Jean-Pierre Aumont), the aging male lead of the film within, and Severine (Miss Cortese), Alexandre's co-star and former mistress, who is genuinely pleased for Alexandre when he reveals plans to settle down with his new young male lover."Day for Night" is Truffaut's fondest, most compassionate film, and although it is packed with references to films and film people (Welles, Vigo, Fellini, Buuel, among others) and although it is dedicated to Lillian and Dorothy Gish, it's not a particularly inside movie. That is, it has great fun showing us how movies are made, how rain and snow are manufactured, how animals are directed (or not), how acts of God can affect a script, but its major concerns are people working at a profession they love, sometimes to the exclusion of everything else.The movie people are different from you and me, Truffaut seems to say, but only in the intensity of their passions and in constantly having to differentiate between reality and its various reflections. Romantic alliances are always shifting. Infatuation is mistaken for love (and, for a moment, it may really be love). Severine becomes hysterical after fluffing half a dozen takes because the make-up girl is doubling as a maid in a brief scene. "In my day," she screams, "make-up was make-up, and an actress was an actress."The performances are superb. Miss Cortese and Miss Bisset are not only both hugely funny but also hugely affecting, in moments that creep up on you without warning. It's no accident, I suspect, that the only characters who come close to being either evil (the jealous wife of the film's production manager) or uninteresting (Julie's doctor husband) are nonmovie people. In "Day for Night," Truffaut is looking at the world from inside a glorious obsession: everyone outside looks a little gray and dim."Day for Night," which begins its commercial engagement Oct. 7 at the Festival Theater, was the opening attraction of the New York Film Festival last night at Lincoln Center. Never has the festival been so appropriately begun.

title: Nixon's Housing Policy
description: President Nixon, in his housIng message to Congress last week, was blunt and to the point: Nearly 40 years of Federal housing programs for the poor had failed, the President said in essence, and the time had come for a fundamental new approach.

title: Hearing on New Parks
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) The Senate Interior Committee announced today that it would hold a hearing Oct. 5 on measures to establish a Boston National Historical Park and a Tuskagee (Ala.) Institute National Park.

title: The Economy in the Long Run
description: WASHINGTONFor twenty years, and especially recently, policies to restrain inflation have failed, These policies, based upon the tradeoff idea, have tried to fight inflation by repressing real economic growth, lifting unemployment of manpower and plant, short changing our great domestic priorities, and moving contrary to improved income distribution and sociallustice. The remedies have been upsidedown. For the new inflation has not stemmed from too much real growth, employment, priorities, and justice, but from far too little.

title: GEORGE H. BOND JR., CORPORATE LAWYER
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 28 George Hopkins Bond Jr., senior partner in the law firm of Bond, Schoeneck & King, who was a prominent attorney for the milk industry, died last night at the Upstate Medical Center after undergoing heart surgery. He was 63 years old and lived in Cazenovia.

title: Salesman Robbed And Pushed Down An Elevator Shaft
description: A 61yearold furniture salesman was pushed down the shaft of a freight elevator yesterday in his downtown Brooklyn store by two robbers while a third attempted to crush him with the elevator car because they were dissatisfied with the $1,200 they had forced him to give them.

title: Stocks Retreat to Break 7 Advances in Succession
description: Stock prices retreated in orderly profit taking yesterday after seven straight sessions of advance on huge volume.

title: Musicians's Strike Goes On
description: Negotiators for the New York Philharmonic and striking orchestra members failed to make progress in resolving their dispute yesterday, but are scheduled to meet again Monday at the offices of the State Mediation Board, No. 2 World Trade Center.

title: Top Award Is Taken By Terrier
description: BLUE POINT, L. L, Sept. 28A: houndmarked wire fox terrier, flown to the United States the day after Cruft's last February, won his fourth bestinshow award in this country today. He led a field of 1,063 dogs at the Brookhaven Kennel Club's fixture on the Suffolk County Republican Club grounds.

title: Senate Bars Nixon Delay on Pay Rises
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI)The Senate blocked today President Nixon's attempt to delay raises far 3.3 million Federal whitecollar workers and military personnel. Mr. Nixon promptly but reluctantly announced a 4.77 per cent raise.

title: Raynaud, French Comic, Killed in Mountain Crash
description: PARIS, Sept. 28  A wellloved clown, Fernand Raynaud, died a violent death when his RollsRoyce crashed today in the mountains of the Massif Central whose upcountry humor he successfully plugged on variety stages.

title: KISSINGER GIVES AIDES A PEP TALK
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 Secretary of State Kissinger gave a pep talk to about 1,000 State Department employes this noon, telling them he wanted their work to be the best in town.

title: PAKISTANI P.O.W.'S ARE FREED BY INDIA
description: WAGAH, India, Sept. 28 The longdelayed release of Pakistani prisoners of war began today as India freed 842, mostly civilians, at this border post.

title: 8 Murders in Baghdad Bring Curfew and Security Dragnet
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 28 A curfew was imposed today in Baghdad, the capital of Iraq, while security forces searched for agents rand traitors who have been blamed by Iraq's leftwing Government for a recent series of brutal murders.

title: AGNEW BIDS COURT BAR INVESTIGATION BY FEDERAL JURY
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 28Attorneys for Vice President Agnew filed a suit in Federal District Court here today seeking to halt a grand jury investigation of Mr. Agnew's possible role in political corruption in Maryland.

title: PATH Fare Dispute
description: This week's flareup over fares on the PATH commuter line was another round in a longrunning dispute whose roots are at least 25 years old: How much of the profits if the rich Port Authority of New York and New Jersey should go to mass transit? Commissioners of the authority from New York and New Jersey split on the proposal to raise the fare from 30 cents to 50 cents not so much because they disagreed on how much the line was running in debtbut over the extent to which it shuld be subsidized by the Port Authority's bridges, tunnels, airports and other facilities.

title: 52 Chinese Restaurants Begin Mandatory Classes in Good Hygiene
description: Fiftytwo Chinese restaurant operators yesterday began the fourth mandatory foodprotection training class given by the City Department of Health.

title: AMEX PRICES OFF AS TRADING SLOWS
description: With a noon rally failing to wipe out morning losses, prices on the American Stock Exchange closed lower yesterday in moderate trading. Prices in the overthecounter market were mixed.

title: Today's Football at a Glance
description: Today's Football at a Glance

title: Connally Gets Mixed Response From G.O.P. Women's Group
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28John B. Connallytook his traveling political road show before the National Federation of Republican Women today and received a mixed response from this organization of grassroots party loyalists.

title: Delta Air Lines Sets $300.Million Borrowing
description: Delta Air Lines, Inc., announced yesterday that it arranged to borrow $300million under a new credit agreement with a group of 32 banks. The lending institutions, led by the Citizens and Southern National Bank, Atlanta, are in 20 cities on Delta's system.

title: Sadat Pardons Dissidents, Reflecting an Apparent New Confidence
description: CAIRO, Sept. 28President Anwar elSadat announced clemency measures today for more than 200 dissident journalists and students.

title: People in Sports: Schoendienst Rehired
description: Manager Red Schoendienst, whose St. Louis Cardinals are still in the running for the championship of the National League East Division with only two days left on the regular schedule, yesterday signed a contract to return for the 1974 season.

title: Television
description: 5:30 (4)Modem Farmer

title: Art: Blacks: USA: 1973 Is Eclectic
description: The exhibition called Blacks: USA: 19737 which opened this week at the New York Cultural Center, 2 Columbus Circle, is, according to a statement released by the museum, the first major comprehensive exhibition of black art chosen by an allblack selection committee. One is acutely aware, after seeing the exhibition, that the most important word in this statement is the word committee.

title: MELVILLE F. ROGERS
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 28 (AP)Melville F. Rogers, former national and international skating champion, died Wednesday in a hospital here. He was 73 years old.

title: Dining Out In New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Chavez Says Pact Means Teamsters Will Leave Fields
description: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., Sept. 28 (AP)  Cesar Chevez, president of the United Farm Workers, said today that an agreement had been worked out calling for the International Brotherhood of Teamsters to give up field worker contracts.

title: Coody Ahead by 4 Strokes
description: TURNBERRY, Scotland, Sept. 28  The 18th green was white with hailstones today as Toni Weiskopf sank his final putt for a 72 and a tie for second place at 216 after three rounds of the $140,000 John Player Classic.

title: GOVERNOR SPEAKS OF NATION'S NEEDES
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 28  The businessmen here wanted to know what Governor Rockefeller of New York thought of Phase 4. A mixedup answer in response to a question on the subject may have reflected the confusion that many citizens feel about the Nixon Administration's price and wage policies.

title: Two Die in Helicopter Crash
description: PARKER, Colo., Sept. 28 (UPI) Two soldiers died yesterday in the crash of a Fort Carson, Colo., helicopter. Killed were First Lieut. Richard W. Lally, 24 years old, of West Roxbury, Md., and Chief Warrant Officer Billy T. Heckler, 26, of Hattiesburg, Miss.

title: DR. FRANK KERN, 90, DEAN AT PENN STATE
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Sept. 28Dr. Frank D. Kern, first dean of the Graduate School of N;Ilennsylvania State University for whom its new building is named, died today at a nursing home here. His age was 90.

title: Research Finds Rich Sorghums To Bolster Diet of World's Poor
description: A scientific discovery that promises a powerful new weapon against starvation and malnutrition among millions of people in the poorest nations today the world was announced today by the State Department and Purdue University.

title: October Cotton Futures Trading Halted to Keep Prices Stable
description: Trading for liquidation only was ruled at the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday for transactions in the October delivery. The rule thus ends new speculative buying in the hope of price increases.

title: ExSenator Turner Gets Up to 5 Years; Will Remain in Race
description: TRENTON, Sept. 28  Former State Senator James M. Turner was sentenced to a maximum of five years in prison today for conspiring to frame a fellow legislator on drug charges, but he promptly announced that he still intended to run for reelection on Nov. 6.

title: 200Million Generator Unit
description: The Southwestern Electric Power Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Central and South West Corporation, said yesterday it would build a $200million electric generating plant about two and a half miles south of Siloam Springs Ark. It will have a 530,000kilowatt capacity and will be owned jointly by Southwestern Electric and the Arkansas Electric Cooperative Group.

title: Articles of U.N. Compact
description: Following are articles from the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights cited in a Soviet commentary yesterday:

title: ClosedEnd Funds
description: Following Is a weekly listing of the net asset value of a closedend Investment fund's shares as reported by the companies through The Association of ClosedEnd Investment Companies at the close of business Friday.

title: I. T. T. OFFICE HERE DAMAGED BY BOMB
description: A time bomb demolished four rooms in the LatinAmerican section of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation on Madison Avenue early yesterday morning, apparently in protest against the company's activities in Chile.

title: DualPurpose Funds
description: Following Is a weekly listing of the ??? audited net asset value applicable In the capital shares of dualpurpose investment companies at close of business Friday. Also shown are closing listed market prices of best overthecounter dollartodollar asked Prices for the capital shares of each company with the perecentage difference (discount of Premium) between the net asset value and the asked prices of the capital shares.

title: U.S. Consumer Unit Asks Easier Access to Courts
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 An Administrationsponsored study group called today for legislation opening Federal courts to a wide range of consumer classaction suits without the restrictions favored by President Nixon.

title: Edging Toward the Right
description: HONOLULU  The moon controls tidal flows on this planet but no one has yet calculated what governs cyclical changes in world politics. Nevertheless, just as the past decade saw global gains in various leftwardtending movements around the earth, the present one sees an edging toward the right.

title: Laurin's Decision Up in Air
description: When Secretariat and Riva Ridge ran one, two in the $250,000 Marlboro Cup at Belmont Park two weeks ago today, Lucien Laurin said he would never run these two horses in thesame race again. Laurin is the trainer for the Meadow Stable, which owns these exceptional thoroughbreds. The $100,000 added Woodward Stakes is listed for its 20th running today, at Belmont, and the names of Secretariat and Riva Ridge are among the seven named to the 11/2mile event. This circumstance, however, is not to be construed as an indictment of Laurin's veracity. The fact that he has named his two charges to the race is not definite indication they will run against each other. The situation depends on the weather.

title: Something Really New to Worry About
description: We live in mortal danger of being struck dead by watermelons inadvertently dropped from passing airplanes. Technology is obviously to blame for this hazard to life, because, if technologists had not developed airplanes, we would not have to worry about the danger of falling watermelons. However, when we examine the probability that a person will be struck by a falling watermelon, we must conclude that this environmental danger is not worth worrying about.

title: Idle Dockers Gripes Help Fill Their Day
description: HOBOKEN, N. J., Sept. 28 At 7 o'clock every weekday morning the doors of the German Seaman's Mission open and the longshoremen begin drifting into the hiring hall that is operated there by the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The stars have provided inspiration for some understated jewelry in the mood of today at Van Cleef & Arpels. Little ovals of 18karat gold bearing cut out signs of the zodiac are linked together to form delicate chain bracelets and necklaces. The nice thing is that the customer has some say in the finished product; each order is, in effect, a special order.

title: WINE TALK
description: LODI, N. J.Is it possible to be a martini drinker and a wine drinker at the same time? It is impossible not to be. Unless you are a fanatic whose martini is simply a slug of gin or vodka, you use vermouth and vermouth is wine. A bit doctored, perhaps, but wine nonetheless.

title: Robert A. Lester Sr. Dies; An Amateur Golf Medalist
description: NAPLES, Fla., Sept. 28 Robert A. Lester Sr., retired secretarytreasurer of Lester & Co. jewelry manufacturers of Springfield, N. J., and former amateur golf medalist, died Sunday of cancer at the Naples Community Hospital. His age was 64, and he lived here.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Peru Aide Denies A Cerro TakeOver
description: Miguel de la Flor, the Foreign Minister of Peru, said, in effect, last night that his Government had no intention of expropriating the mining or smelting operations of the Cerro Corporation.

title: Folk Dance: Krasnayarsk in Debut
description: Speed is of the essence for the Krasnayarsk Dance Company of Siberia, the Soviet folk group that made its sparkling and enthusiastically received United States debut last night at Carnegie Hall.

title: Boyle Off the Critical List; Condition Is Still Serious
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (Reuters)  W. A. Boyle, the former leader of the United Mine Workers, who faces murder charges, was taken off hospital critical list today. Three days ago he was said to have tried to commit suicide.

title: Troop Cuts: The Senate Guard Is Changing
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 Twentytwo years after the great debate over sending four divisions to Europe, the Senate has been going through a debate, potentially as significant, over bringing some troops home.

title: Dave Anderson
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 28Twice a day, the letters arrive for Henry Aaron in bundles. There were 75 today in the morning mail, 260 in the afternoon batch. His personal secretary in the Atlanta Braves offices, Carla Koplin, opens them all.

title: Major League Box Scores
description: Major League Box Scores

title: Guilty Plea Filed In Fatal Bombing At Midwest Campus
description: MADISON, Wis., Sept. 28 Karleton Armstrong pleaded guilty here today to reduced state charges of seconddegree murder and arson resulting from the Aug. 24, 1970, bombing of the University of Wisoonsin Army Mathematics Research Center, in which a physics researcher was killed.

title: Greek Deputy Premier Resigns Early From His Post in Dispute
description: ATHENS, Sept. 28 Deputy Premier Nikolaos Makarezos announced his resignation today.

title: MICHAEL HERSCOWITZ
description: Michael Herscowitz, an auditing supervisor in the City Controller's office until his retirement five years ago, died Thursday in Long Island College Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 140 Cadman Plaza West, Brooklyn.

title: Butterfield Is Staying, White House Declares
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI)The White House denied today reports that Alexander Butterfield, who disclosed the existence of President Nixons Watergate tapes, was being eased out of Ms job as head of the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: Swedish Ambassador Extends Shelter To Refugees of Chile's Political Storm
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 28 Virtually alone, Harald Edelstein saved the Cuban Embassy from, being stormed and provided protection to Chilean, Brazilian and other political refugees. He is a prime mover behind an international effort to win guarantees for security for opponents of Chile's new military rulers.

title: L T. T. OFFICE HERE DAMAGED BY BOMB
description: A time bomb demolished four rooms in the LatinAmerican section of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation on Madison Avenue early yesterday morning, apparently in protest against the company's activities in Chile.

title: GROMYKO IS GIVEN PLEDGE BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 President Nixon promised Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gro myko today that the Administration would make a diligent effort to overcome Congressional opposition and obtain an improved trade status for the Soviet Union in this country.

title: Expos Rally on 3 Unearned Runs to Erase Lead
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 28For the second straight night, the Pittsburgh Pirates lost a gameand valuable ground in the Eastern Division race because of a mistake. Tonight, an error on a potential doubleplay ball gave the Montreal Expos three unearned runs, enough to beat the fading Pirates, 32.

title: 2 JAILS VIOLATE CITY HEALTH CODE
description: The City Health Department has found serious cases of insect and rodent infestation in kitchens and other areas in the Manhattan and Brooklyn Houses of Detention. Walter J. Hinckley, deputy commissioner of health, acknowledged the agency's findings in response to a query and said that preliminary reports on five other jails in the city indicate similar problems.

title: SOIUZ IS SHIFTED TO UNUSUAL ORBIT
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 28  Two Soviet astronauts, in an unusual orbital change, today flew their modified Soyuz spacectaft higher above the earth than previous Russian manned missions.

title: Judge for Agnew Plea
description: NORFOLK, Va. Sept 28As the troubles besetting the Nixon Administration have come before the Federal courts, judges who were virtually unknown outside their own judicial districts have been propelled into national prominence. And on some of the thorniest judicialconstitutionalpolitical issues, there is a wideMan spread belief that, so far those in the judgeshave shone. News Here in Norfolk today, another judge, Walter E. (for Edward) Hoffman, a 66yearold Republican, began making the historic record in the matter of Agnew v. United States. The assignment came to him by default.

title: FARM PRICES FELL BY 87, FOR MONTH; BEEF PACED DROP
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 Farm prices dropped 8 per cent, in the month ended Sept. 15, the Department of Agriculture, said today, and a top official) at the Cost of Living Council predicted that sharp declines in meat animals would be reflected soon at retail counters.

title: Sifting the Ashes of Quang Tri
description: PUTNEY, Vt.This past summer E. W. Pfeiffer of the University, of Montana and I were invited to the Democratic Republic of (North] Vietnam on a mission for the Scientists' Institute for Public Information, in behalf of its new task force on scientific aid for Indochina. While there we were asked by the Provisional Revolutionary Government of the Republic of South Vietnam (the Vietcong) to make a preliminary assessment of the scientific needs of South Vietnam. We were the first Americans to have been invited into that portion of South Vietnam under P.R.G. control.

title: Club Can Win Title With Sweep and a Pirate Loss
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 28Rain fell on the New York Mets' dash to some sort of destiny today, postponing their game against the Chicago Cubs and forcing the battle for first place to be waged in consecutive doubleheaders tomorrow and Sunday.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on nomination of Henry A. Kissinger to be Secretary of State, which was confirmed, 78 to 7, Sept. 21.

title: SOVIET SETS LOAN OF GRAIN TO INDIA.
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 28 (AP) The Soviet Union, which made history's biggest purchase of food grains last year because of shortages, is lending two million tons of grain to India, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Government announced today.

title: 6 MICHIGAN BANKS CUT PRIME RATE
description: The six banks of the Michigan National Corporation, a $2.88billion holding company, reduced yesterday their prime interest rates on corporate loans to 9 per cent in a move that resulted from high rates pinching smaller and mediumsized companies.

title: Business Briefs
description: The heavy outflow of deposits from New York State savings banks has sharply reduced commitments to make mortgage loans, and expansion of actual mortgage loans has slowed down. According to data released this week by the Savings Banks Association of New York State, commitments declined by $361million  their largest monthly drop since 1969  and now total $4.2billion. In April, commitments by savings banks to make mortgage loans had reached a peak of almost $5billion.

title: Doctor in Sterilization Dispute Barred From Medicaid Births
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 28A South Carolina obstetrician was told today that he would not be permitted to deliver babies under the Medicaid program unless he stopped sterilization requirements for welfare mothers.

title: U.N. Took Years for Pacts on Rights
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept, 29The Soviet Union's use of the humanrights covenants to justify its restriction of immigration, free expression and other individual freedoms will be one of the great ironies of United Nations history, according to the men and women here who helped shape these documents.

title: Troop Compromise
description: After a bewildering display of indecision, the Senate finally hammered out a reasonable interim position this week between the contradictory pressures affecting the United States military presence overseas. It put on record an impressive show of support for cutting back a bloated military establishment, but wisely backed away from specific cuts in European troop strength which could have weakened American negotiators just as they began delicate talks with the Soviet Union.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NATURAL Venga y traiga a sus amigos y familia, the American Museum of Natural History says, so please do. Come with your friends and family to the museum and environs at Central Park West and 79th Street, which for today will become an allday festival of nationalities when its fourth annual West Side Day is held.

title: Tour Bus in Czech Acident
description: PRAGUE, Sept. 28 (AP)A San Francisco woman was killed and 25 other Americans were injured Wednesday when an Austrian tourist bus hit a tractor and overturned, the Embassy confirmed today.

title: Deaths
description: In Memoriam

title: Nastase, Okker in Semifinals
description: NILES, Ill., Sept 28 (AP) Topseeded Ilia Nastase advanced to the semifinals of the $50,000 Tim Tarn international open tennis tournament today, along with Tom Okker of the Netherlands and Marty Riessen.

title: Reid Shows Ambitious Figurative Art
description: The emergence of figurative painting as one of the going trends on the current art scene may not have acquired the urgency of a highpowered movement, but the fact of it is confirmed in one's round of the galleries nowadays. The first oneman exhibition of paintings by Charles Reid at the Roko Gallery, 90 East 10th Street, adds another name to the growing ranks.

title: Uproar Marks End Of Madrid Parley Of World Lawyers
description: MADRID, Sept. 28  The is sue of the independence of the Spanish bar threw some 700 lawyers from all over the work into an uproar here today at the closing session of the 25th con gress of the International Union of Lawyers.

title: British Football
description: British Football

title: Seating Room Only
description: The jury of a Queens Civil Court has found, in what may be a landmark verdict, that the Penn Central Railroad must refund a rider his fare of $1.80 and pay him $10 for discomfort for having failed to provide him with a seat on a ride from Grand Central to White Plains.

title: 72 Nixon Aides Disclose 60Million Election Fund
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22Responding to a Federal court order, President Nixon's 1972 campaign finance aides disclosed today that the President's fundraisers had collected a record $60.2million for his reelection, including nearly $1.5million in cash.

title: Italy's 100 Days
description: PALERMO, SicilyInflation is one thing; spaghetti, ice cream, good wine and the good life another. We Italians become poorer every day but spend as if we were richer. Italy and Italiansperhaps Europe and Europeansare living in the center of a troubled paradox. We have learned to be consumers in recent years but now we are admonished to be austere.

title: PATH Fare Dispute
description: This week's flareup over fares on the PATH commuter line was another round in a longrunning dispute whose roots are at least 25 years old: How much of the profits of the rich Port Authority of New York and New Jersey should go to mass transit? Commissioners of the authority from New York and New Jersey split on the proposal to raise the fare from 30 cents to 50 cents not so much because they disagreed on how much the line was running in debt but over the extent to which it should be subsidized by the Port Authority's bridges, tunnels, airports and other facilities.

title: People and Business
description: Two aerospaceindustry executivesHerman R. Staudt, 47, years old of the MartinMarietta Aerospace Corporation, and Frank A. Shrontz, 41, of the Boeing Company, have been chosen by President Nixon for highlevel Pentagon posts, a White House spokesman said yesterday.

title: TERM WON'T STOP EXJERSEY AIDE
description: TRENTON; Sept. 28  Former State Senator James M. Turner was sentenced to a maximum of five years in prison today for conspiring to frame a fellow legislator on drug charges, but he promptly announced that he still intended to run for reelection on Nov. 6.

title: EVIDENCE ON NIXON CITED BY LAWYERS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28Lawyers for the Senate Watergate committee argued today that there was sufficient evidence to establish a prima facie case that the President was engaged in criminal conduct. Thus, they contended, he has damaged his claim to executive privilege in withholding tape recordings of conversations made in his office.

title: Oklahoma to Test So. California
description: If Southern California loses to Oklahoma tonight, the Trojans will fall from the No. 1 ranking in the nation with little or no chance of regaining that perch this season. But an end to the Southern California 14game winning streak would not prevent John McKay's team from going on to the Rose Bowl since that trip is based solely on team's Pacific 8 Conference record.

title: British Football
description: By Reuters

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Police Department's towaway program, designed to remove illegally parked automobiles from the city's streets, will be expanded to the Bronx beginning Monday. A spokesman for the department, in announcing the expansion, said the police would first concentrate on removing double and tripleparked cars and those illegally parked at bus stops and fire hydrants along the Grand Concourse.

title: Chile Offers to Reopen Talks on Copper
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 28 Chile's new Foreign Minister, Vice Adm. Ismael Huerta, said today that the door is open for a resumption of negotiations on compensation for United States copper holdings nationalized by the former Marxist coalition Government.

title: MRS. CHESTER WILLIAMS
description: SARASOTA, Fla., Sept. 28Mrs. Elizabeth S. Williams, who retired in 1968 after 13 years as social services director of University Hospital, New York, died Wednesday at Sarasota Hospital of a heart ailment. Her age was 70. She was the wife of Chester Williams, who retired as publicaffairs director of the Community Council of Greater New York.

title: How to Live Almost Forever
description: So jogging may kill you. It was in the papers the other day. Joggers keeling over, medical journals voice concern; have heart examined first, savants warn; EKG's performed lying down not good enough, caution medicoscientific spokesmen.

title: The Pennant Race
DR. BRYAN GALLAGHER
description: Dr. Bryan J. Gallagher, a general practitioner for 37 years and a member of the staff of Mary Immaculate Hospital, Jamaica, Queens, died Thursday of a heart attack at Brooklyn Hospital. His age was 64. and he lived at 39 Briarfield Drive, Great Neck, L. I.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS DOWN ANSWER TO PREVIOUG PUZZLE

title: Guerrillas Seize 3 Soviet Jews on Train, Then Release Them in Austrian Deal
description: VIENNA, Saturday, Sept. 29 Two armed Arab guerrillas raided a MoscowtoVienna train yesterday, kidnapped three Soviet Jews and an Austrian customs official, and took them to the Vienna airport.

title: MORELAND, ACTOR IS DEAD AT 72
description: HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 28 (UPI) Mantan Moreland, the comedian who played the chauffeur Birmingham Brown in the Charlie Chan movies, died today at the age of 72.

title: Bache Is Sued by Customer On BondAccount Handling
description: Bache & Co., Inc. was charged Thursday in a damage suit in Federal District Court in Atlanta with having defrauded a customer in the handling of his margin account of $2.5million worth of Ginny May bonds.

title: Canada Development Offer
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 28 (Canadian Press)The Canada Development Corporation today routinely extended for another week its offer to buy 10 million shares of the Texasgulf Corporation stock, which would give the Crown corporation effective control of the big, United Statesbased natural resources company. Canadian Development continued its price offer of $29 per share, for a total of $290million, despite a recent Texasgulf announcement of new ore findings in its Canadian properties near Timmins, Ontario.

title: Hudson River Getting Cleaner In 8Year, $lBillion Program
description: The tide has turned in the battle to eliminate pollution in the Hudson River, with almost all fishermen, marine biologists, environmentalists and government officials agreeing that the river is cleaner now than it has been in recent years.

title: DR. SIDNEY SCHIFF
description: Dr. Sidney Schiff, who practiced veterinary medicine on West 145th Street for more than 50 years, died Thursday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 78 years old and had retired a year ago after suffering a stroke.

title: Antiques: Study in Silver
description: Can the uninitiate fully appreciate a museum's collection of, say, silverware, without a textbook in hand to explain styles and techniques?

title: Garage Attendant Is Shot to Death On East 74th St.
description: A garage attendant was shot and killed by two men who may have made their escape by taking one at of the automobiles parked in the East Side garage, the police reported yesterday.

title: Tutwiler Sets Pace In Crump Cup Golf
description: CLEMENTON, N.J., Sept. 28 Ed Tutwiler, a former Walker Cup player from Indianapolis, paced 16 golfers qualifying for the 49th George Arthur Crump Memorial Cup with a fouroverpar 36, 3874 today on the Pine Valley Golf Club course. The 1972 United States Amateur champion, Marvin (Vinnie) Giles 3d of Richmond, qualified in the second flight of 16 for the match play rounds tomorrow and Sunday with 42, 3981.

title: GROMYKO IS GIVEN PLEDGE BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 President Nixon promised Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko today that the Administration would make a diligent effort to overcome Congressional opposition and obtain an improved trade status for the Soviet Union in this country.

title: Correction Agency Was Told Suspect Might Try to Flee
description: The Police Department dis closed last night that it had warned the Department of Cor rection last week that Henry: Brown, the Black Liberation Army member who was being held in the murder of two policemen in the East Village, might try to escape from Kings. County Hospital.

title: Hudson River Getting Cleaner In 8Year, $1Billion Program
description: The tide has turned in the battle to eliminate pollution in the Hudson River, with almost all fishermen, marine biologists, environmentalists and government officials agreeing that the river is cleaner now than it has been in recent years.

title: $76Billion on Tax Rolls
description: TRENTON, Sept. 28 (UPI) The state division of Taxation said today the true value of all the taxable land and buildings in New Jersey is $76.3billion. The total assessed value was $58.7billion, but the assessed value is usually less, the division said.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Mayoral campaigns historically have a way of producing misstatements and exaggerations, even by able and responsible candidates who should know better. While campaign utterances, frequently are taken for what they are, experience has shown that they sometimes are accepted at face value with disastrous cons& quences.

title: Broader Indian Panel Balked
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) The Senate Interior Committee defeated an amendment today that would have added five Presidential appointees to a proposed 15man Indian Commission. Senator James Abourez11 Democrat of South Dakota, the bill's author, opposed the amendment, arguing that the commission is designed to produce a Congressional study.

title: Notes on People
description: John D. Rockefeller 3d said yesterday that he hoped the forthcoming bicentennial of American independence would provide the antidote to the demoralizing impact that the Watergate affair has had on the social and moral fabric of the nation.

title: ARLEN IS SEEKING CONTROL OF CHAIN
description: The Men Realty and Development Corporation announced yesterday it had filed an application with the Federal Trade Commission to reacquire control of Atlantic Department Stores, Inc., which operates 68 discount stores.

title: Blake Ritter Is Dead at 58; Actor on Broadway and TV
description: BRYN MAWR, Pa., Sept. 28 (AP)  Blake Ritter, singer, Broadway actor and broadcaster, died Friday at Bryn Mawr Hospital. He was 58 years old.

title: NORMA CRANE DEAD; PLAYED TEVYE'S WIFE

title: Foreigners Build Dam in the Swiss Alps

title: FlyingSaucerShaped, Home TV Antenna Is Devised

title: Film: A Chilean Duo:' Que Hacer' on Bill With 'Allende' The Cast
description: The recent events in Chile, culminating in the death of the Marxist President, Salvador Allende Gossens, and the imposition of military rule, lend a special poignancy to an unusual and engrossing new film called "Que Hacer" ("What's to Be Done").Mordant, self-aware, freighted with sensitivity toward Chile's problem, wary of caricature, disposed toward consciousness of human fallibility, it is a deft blend of fiction and documentary set in the tumultuous days leading up to the election of Dr. Allende in 1970.Although its bias is clearly pro-Allendeits villains are militant rightists, an American foundation representative who talks about "matrices" and, especially, a mysterious American engineer who is most certainly a C.I.A. manit leaves unresolved the question of precisely what it means to be a revolutionary.On the documentary level, "Que Hacer" makes its points about Chile and its problems through the faces and voices of its people, the flimsiness of their hovels and the hardship of their lives, in a landscape possessed of mineral and agricultural riches and studded with the billboards of American industry.On the fictional level, it delineates political argument through a revolutionary returned from Cuba, a Communist legislator living in luxury, his terrorist son, the American engineer, a revolutionary priest and a girl working for the Peace Corps.The performances by a cast of unfamiliar faces are restrained and appropriately despairing. The mordant commentary comes from occasional glimpses of the film crew itself and particularly from the presence and singing of Country Joe McDonald.The work of Saul Landau, who produced this film and served as one of its directors, also includes an earlier, well-received documentary on Fidel Castro. "Que Hacer" will remind some audiences of the Costa-Gavras films, "Z" and "State of Siege," although it is less blatantly emotional.It shares the bill with a 30-minute documentary interview with Dr. Allende, with Mr. Landau asking the questions. History will render its eventual judgment, but at least in this film, Dr. Allende emerges as a compassionate leader who "thought that man should have a different dimension."The films opened yesterday at the Bleecker Street Cinema.

title: JAPANESE PAYMENTS SHOW LARGE DEFICIT
description: TOKYO, Sept. 28 (AP)Japan's balance of payments recorded a deficit of $872million in August, compared with a $657million deficit in July and a $557million surplus a year earlier, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: Moscow Maneuvers
description: The Soviet Union has now ratified two international covenants on human rights adopted by the U.N. General Assembly in 1966. Since the United States has not ratified these covenants, the groundwork has now been laid for Moscow to claim it is even more virtuous on civil rights than the United States. Indeed, a Soviet newspaper has already, boasted that the Soviet Union has become the first great power to ratify the covenants.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Two Arab guerrillas raided a MoscowtoVienna train, seized three Soviet Jews and an Austrian customs official and took them to the Vienna airport, where they demanded a plane to take them and their hostages to an Arab country. The hostages were later freed and the guerrillas were allowed to leave aboard a small plane after the Government promised to suspend the largescale transit or Soviet Jews through Austria on their way to Israel, where the three hostages were bound. [Page 1, Columns 13.]

title: Notes: Keeping Track Of Serious Diseases

The average traveler, of course, couldn't care less, and yet the 12,000 copies of this blue folder serve as a vital safeguard for the health of international travelers, reporting the incidence of smallpox, cholera and plague throughout the world and dictating when innoculations are required to diminish the risk of contracting serious diseases while traveling.

title: A record of Kafka's love for a girl and hate for himself

He instructed that all his letters and unpublished manuscriptsincluding all three of his novelsbe burned unread. Yet he made the request to a friend who had vowed he could never obey it. The late Walter Benjamin commented that Kafka was prepared to pass his work on but unwilling to be responsible to posterity for it.

description: LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., Sept. 29Scott Coolidge, a tailback, raced for 209 yards on 33 carries to lead Lawrenceville School to a 3826 victory over Deerfield Acad emy here today.

title: Compensation Chief Named
description: ALBANY, Sept 29 (AP)Governor Rockefeller today named Albert D'Antoni of New City chairman of the State Workmen's Compensation Board. Mr. D'Antoni will be paid $39,825 a year.

title: 2,028 in Cast of 51st Show of Distinction
description: The 51st edition of what the Westbury Kennel Club calls the Show of Distinction takes place today on the grounds of C. W. Post College in Brookville, L. I. Sharing the spotlight is the Nassau Dog Training Club's 25th trial, held in conjunction with Westbury since 1948. This year, Westbury has new president, Mrs. Bernard Freeman of Manhasset, an active Rottweiler breeder for many years and five times Long Island golf champion.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: ONE month ago the economic headlines were dominated by the reports of soaring food prices and meat shortages, the gasoline pinch, the relentless rise of interest rates and the gloomy, lackadaisical stock market.

title: INDIANS ARE WARY AS P.O.W.'S GO FREE
description: ATARI, India, Sept. 29Ajir Singh, a 36yearold Sikh, sat at his bicyclerepair shop opposite the railroad station at this border village and watched the Pakistani prisoners of war with some disdain.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: Slaughterhouse on Wheels
description: RENO, Sept. 29 (UPI)Nevada cattle rustlers are operating a slaughterhouse on wheels to speed their livestock thefts, the State Farm Bureau reported this week. It said stolen cattle were butchered in a van immediately after their capture and their hide and entrails thrown out along the road. The carcass is ready for sale by the time the van reaches a town.

title: What's Doing in TOKYO
description: FESTIVALSTokyo is normally gray city but in the fall it can be a blaze of color, especially in the districts where the matsuri, or festivals, are being held. The Yasukuni Shrine, memorializing war dead, is the site of a small festival Oct. 1719, and then showing of chrysanthemums that runs until midNovember. The Meiji Shrine, dedicated to Emperor Meiji, who died in 1912, is the scene of a more elaborate weeklong event running from Oct. 31. Culture Day, on Nov. 3, is the big occasion there, with court music and dancing, demon strations of the martial arts, and yabusame (archery from horseback by marksmen in ancient costume). Sensoji, sometimes known as the Asakusa Kennon Temple, hosts a twoweek commemoration of its new pagoda in early November. The best day there also will be Nov. 3, with the dance of the white birds. Konpira Shrine, near the Toranomon Crossing, is dedicated to the God of the Sea and has a festival the tenth of each month, Oct. 10tenth day, tenth monthbeing the largest. Sengaku Temple, the burial place of the 47 Ronin Warriors in Takanawa, will hold a memorial parade on Dec. 14 in honor of the men who gave up family and fortune in the early 18th century to avenge the murder of their master. The 47, who then committed seppuku, or ritual suicide, are idealized by the Japanese for their loyalty.

title: Sunday Observer
description: The ghost of Stalin is walking again. You can tell when it is up and about. People start being put in mental hospitals for disagreeing with the Ministry of Thought. Strait jackets, electricity, needles here and there in the body, deep brain massage, cold baths. Who can say for sure, except those who have disagreed with the Ministry of Thought? And who would dare believe them? Who knows what might be done to a person caught believing people officially certified mad by the Ministry of Thought? One attempts not to think at all, not even to think of thinking. Thinking is safest left to the Ministry of Thought when old Stalin walks.

title: BRITISH EXPLODE MARKET'S MYTHS
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 28  The British have been in the Common Market for nearly a year now, and some old myths about the probable impact of their membership are being ex ploded.

title: Old Argument Enlivens Stamford Boat Show
description: The 50foot tomatored Phantom looked none the worse for wear after a sixday voyage from Fort Lauderdale to a quiet slip in Yacht Haven West at Stamford,. Conn.site of the secand annual North Atlantic Boat Show this weekend. The flashy custombuilt racing sailboat, and the small number of other racing sailboats at the show, stood out from the smaller pleasure craft.

title: The Cool Ride In the Sky
description: When a buzzard looks cool and pleased, you had better believe he's up to no good. That's the point Diane Wolkstein makes here: Be wary of any helpful offer from a buzzard for he's never thoughtful but predatory. The best thing about this tale and most folktales is that they are parables on human nature. (It's unimportant whether you can believe the ending in which the buzzard is said to have been shamed by the monkey into straightening up and flying right.)

title: Joep de Koning Will Marry Miss Catharine Dixie Miller
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 29  Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Stanley R. Miller of New Canaan and Lyford Cay, the Bahamas, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catharine Dixie Miller, to Joep M. J. de Koning, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. H. J. de Koning of Aerdenhout, the Netherlands, and Tarragona, Spain.

title: Summit Star Hurts Back After 88Yard Runback
description: BERKELEY HEIGHTS, Sept. 29Willie Wilson, star Summit running back, opened today's game against Berkeley Heights by racing 88 yards with the kickoff to a touchdown.

title: L.I. Fair To Stress Rural Life Of Past
description: OLD BETHPAGE, L. I.The traditional rural way of American life of bygone days will be among the attractions at the Long Island Fair at Nassau County's Old Bethpage Village restoration.

title: Verstehen Sie Zeichensprache (Sign Language)?
description: Directional symbols, being an international language, are a boon to the traveler. And yet, at first glance, some of these German and Austrian symbols seem to raise more questions than they answer. For example, is there any difference in meaning between the sign depicting a woman holding a little girl by the hand and another showing man holding a child by the hand? And what is meant by the symbol of a man and a woman on what appears to be the panels of a pair of swinging doors? For interpretations, see below.

title: YOTE BY SENATE STIRS NATO FEARS
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 29This week's vote by the United States Senate to reduce American troop commitments abroad has cast a shadow over delicate talks under way at the headquarters of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization here.

title: Education
description: Anxious teenagers, their minds honed by cramming, fold themselves into their seats. The ordeal lasts three hours, one rugged multiplechoice question after another. Then the anguish ceases and the students leave, frazzled, certain they have sealed the course of their lives.

title: The Secret of Traveling in Mexico Is Never to Hope to Arrive
description: MY morning begins in Puebla, a small town in central Mexico. It is a mathematical town, senor. The streets are laid out east and west, north and south, senor. You cannot lose your way. This is a logical town. Like France, senor. We defeated the troops of France here on the fifth of May, senior. And indeed, the Mexicans did just that. However, since the rest of their actions against the handful of foreign troops sent against them were patriotically unmemorable retreats, every Mexican town now has its Avenue Fifth of May among its main streets. A road by any other name would smell as treason.

title: Miss D'Andria Bride of Paul M. Rumely
description: Miss Antoinette D'Andria, laughter of Mrs. Giorgio D'Andria of New York and the late Mr. D'Andria, and Paul Meinrad Rumely, son of Mr.and Mrs. Aloysius Rumelv of LaPorte, Ind., were married here yesterday by the Rev. Patrick McNamara in St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Academies Face Suit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI)A Federal court here has been asked to order the Navy and Air Force academies to admit women as cadets. The Center for Women's Policy Studies filed a class action suit Wednesday.

title: Enforcing Equal Rights
description: The announcement by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission that it is investigating job discrimination charges against four of the country's biggest corporations and the unions they bargain with indicates a new determination to enforce vigorously the expanded authority Congress gave the commission last year.

title: Klein Vows Tax Cuts In Offering His Budget
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I.  Suffolk County Executive John V. N. Klein submitted his proposed county budget to the County legislature last week, calling for a drop in the tax rate without a loss in services.

title: Flaws Are Found in Credit Bureau Law to Protect Consumers
description: In response to widespread public fears about the danger that credit bureaus were gaining more and more untrammeled influence over the lives of Americans, a Federal law went into effect in 1971 that attempted to bring these bureaus under some kind of control.

title: Cost Overruns Reported On Roads, Apollo, Transit
description: Interstate highways accounted for $32billion of the cost overruns found by G.A.O. auditors in a study of 20 civilian projects requested by Representative William L. Dickinson, Republican of Alabama.

title: Olympic Congress Begins
description: VARNA, Bulgaria, Sept. 29 Representatives from about 120 nations are gathered here to determine policy and the future direction of the Olympic Games.

title: 10 Die in a Hoboken Fire
description: HOBOKEN, N. J., Sept. 29Ten persons were killed and six were injured after a fire spread quickly through four aging tenements here early this morning. Two persons are unaccounted for.

title: Gail Spring Fiancee To Larry S. Eisner
description: GREAT NECK, L.I., Sept. 29Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Spring have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gail Spring, to Larry Simpson Eisner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Eisner of Miami Beach.

title: Rapid transit
description: In a world championship match the play of most hands is free of error. With each step down the ladder of ability the average number of playing errors per deal increases. In a home game it is not uncommon for the declarer to make a poor play, unwittingly attempting to sabotage his own contract, only for a defender to return the compliment, putting him back on a winning track. And so it continues, giving a pendulum effect.

title: State Shifts 2,000 Billboards to Beautify Its Roadways
description: TRENTONIn a campaign designed to remove billboards from state property along highways, the New Jersey Transportation Department has shifted more than 2,000 advertising signs since June. In addition, the owners of 1,500 other signs have been directed to move their billboards. They have two weeks in which to comply.

title: Australian's Will Voided
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 29 (UPI)  A supreme court judge has ruled invalid a will of a man who left most of his $383,500 estate to the Israeli Air Force. The judge said the man, Zvi Harry Haber, a former company director, was probably suffering from a mental illness when he made the will. Mr. Haber's wife, Leah, ??? who was left nothing in the will, contested its validity.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Through much of MAN ON A LEASH by Charles Williams (Putnam's, $4.95) the ingredients are familiar. Hero Eric Romstead is a brute, with wolfish grin when he is aroused: our old friend, the man's man, who makes his own rules and gets away with it. He is in Nevada trying to find the killers of his fatherand his father was a man just like him, doubled in spades.

title: A Work of Love for a Bach
description: UPPER SADDLE RIVERTwo New Jersey housewives, Mrs. Rita Koors Myers and Mrs. Ingrid Dingfelder, have embarked on an ambitious project for the Musical Heritage Society, a mailprder record concern.

title: Probing the G.O.P.
description: New York Republicans could only wince at the headline: Vote Inquiry Set to Call Duryea.

title: Nonsmoker Is Winning Rightto Clean Indoor Air
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 29Politely, and sometimes not so politely, the nonsmokers of America are taking on the puffers and hackers with new zeal. Nonsmokers, once timid closet characters content to simply leave a smokefilled room, are now demanding, and getting, equal but unpolluted indoor air.

title: Chart of the Woodward
description: Chart of the Woodward

title: Judith Saab Married to. Guy Sunderlin
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 29Miss Judith Seaton Baab, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Andrew Baab, was married here this afternoon to Guy Alexander Sunderlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Sherwood Sunderlin of St. Croix, Virgin Islands.

title: Jacquelyn Shaw to Wed
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Sept. 29The engagement of Miss Jacquelyn Debre Lynn Shaw to Kevin Raymond Loughlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Gerard Loughlin of Manhasset, L. I., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. James Woodland Shaw. Both Miss Shaw and her fianc and thirdyear students at the New York Medical College.

title: The Region
description: The sight of gasoline stations shut down in protest against the Nixon Administration's economic policies has suddenly become a familiar one, and the station owners last week were promising that the protests would spread rapidly unless the retail price of gasoline, frozen under Phase 4, were allowed to go up in line with wholesale price increases.

title: Philip Warner Fiance Of Miss Susan Handal
description: Mr. and Mrs'. Abe S. Handal have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Handal, to Philip Ward Warner, son of Mrs. John M. Warner of Philadelphia and the late Mr. Warner. The wedding is planned for Nov. 17 at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer.

title: The Days Of Emperor And Clown
description: A good deal has been written about the ItaloEthiopian War, mostly by interested parties or eyewitnesses. Despite the lapse of nearly 40 years since the war was fought, this book is one of the first in which an attempt has been made to review the conflict and its background of intrigue, deception and misunderstanding from an objective standpoint.

title: SEWAGE TREATED TO GROW OYSTERS
description: WOODS HOLE, Mass., Sept. 29If experiments being carried out here with processed sewage from Otis Air Force Base are successful, oysters may become a common feature of the American diet instead of a luxury.

title: A Real Hawk on Inflation
description: Under the chairmanship of Herbert Stein, the President's Council of Economic Advisers has attracted increasing criticism for its involvement in what many see as partisan politics.

title: A Special Kitchen Helps Infirm Cooks Keep Skills
description: UNIONDALE, L. I.Dorothy Conyers has always prided herself on her cooking. And this did not change when she was confined to the county home for the aged and infirm.

title: John Strachey
description: The life of John Stracheyas set forth in this efficient biography written on the invitation of, and with the support of Strachey's widowcontains the makings of an exemplary political and moral tale: how to be left but right in the English Establishment.

title: Burdens of Housing Assessed
description: GUILFORD, Conn.  A costrevenue analysis of singlefamily home development here has indicated that the town would have saved money if it had bought the land outright and prohibited the housing construction.

title: Edgar W. McInnis, 74, Canclian Historian, Dies
description: TORONTO, Sept. 29 (Canadian Press)Edgar W. McInnis, a histcrian and former delegate to the United Nations, died Thursday in a hospital here.

title: SENATORS TO ASK PERJURY INQUIRY OVER GRAIN DEAL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29A request for a review of conflicting testimony during a Senate investigation of the Russian grain deal will be forwarded to the Justice Department within the next few days, Congressional sources say.

title: World News Briefs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 29 (UPI)  The Iraqi Government today lifted the curfew imposed yesterday on Baghdad and apparently ended a sweeping security crackdown. One Beirut newspaper reported thousands of arrests in a hunt for a hatchet murderer that brought on the crackdown.

title: Radio
description: Thursday Friday Saturday Thursday News Broadcasts Friday Monday Today: Leading Events Wednesday The Week's Concerts Tuesday Today

title: Sutton Accuses Lindsay of Forcing Lowery Out
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 Mayor Lindsay was accused today by Manhattan Borough President Percy Sutton of having forced Fire Commissioner Robert 0. Lowery out of office.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  Ottawa's latest energypolicy moves suggest that Canada is drawing away from the United States.

title: Susan N. Gray Is Bride in Greenwich
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 29  Miss Susan Nichols Gray and Donald L. Townsend 3d were married here this afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church by the Rev. Bradford Hastings. A reception was given at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William S. Gray Jr. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Townsend Jr. of Riverside.

title: SOVIET MIGRANTS TO VOTE IN ISRAEL
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 29 Thousands of recent immigrants from the Soviet Union appear to be leaning polltically to a new grouping of nationalist parties that will attempt to unseat the Governmen in the parliamentary election Oct. 30.

title: Leo's Roar Becomes a Whimper VINCENT
description: METRO  GOLDWYN MAYER, the company that gave us Shaft in Africa, Pat Garrett and Billy the Kid, Lolly Madonna XXX, Skyjacked and The Man Who Loved Cat Dancing, has ceased to exist, for all intents and purposes, as a producerdistributor of theatrical films. It was about time.

title: Nixon and Brandt Review Progress on Atlantic Ties
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 President Nixon and Chancellor Willy Brandt agreed today that the West European countries and the United States were progressing on the right path in attempting to negotiate a new definition of transAtlantic ties.

title: Innovation For Labor
description: WASHINGTON  Labor unions are now regarding with unabashed admiration the health insurance clause won by the United Auto Workers from the Chrysler Corporation. They see in it a new collective bargaining tool that has uses that go beyond the medical program issuesone that could rock collective bargaining tables for years to come.

title: Bicycles Head U.S. List Of Hazardous Products
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 The Consumer Product Safety Commission took the first big step today toward the issuance of mandatory safety standards for a, number of dangerous products:

title: AUSTRIAN DECISION ON JEWISH TRANSIT SETS OFF DISPUTE
description: VIENNA, Sept. 29The Government's decision to close transit facilities for Soviet Jews caused a storm of controversy throughout Austria today.

title: 65% IN POLL BACK U.S. CAMPAIGN AID
description: A substantial majority of the public favors a plan to prohibit all campaign contributions from private sources to Presidential candidates and the substitution of a system whereby the Federal Government provides a fixed sum of money for the campaigns, according to a Gallup poll.

title: Soviet Says the West Is Trying Blackmail at European Parley
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 29Pravda accused Western circles today of trying to blackmail Communist countries at the European security conference into permitting imperialist subversion as a price for holding the final stage of the conference.

title: PRESERVATION DRIVE SET FOR BETHLEHEM
description: A 43yearold Baptist minister will lead a 10day Christian pilgrimage to Israel beginning Nov. 27 to raise funds for the preservation of Bethlehem, the city where Jesus was born.

title: Letters: The Intrepid Mr. Buckley Replies
description: To the Editor: I have only just now seen Diane Ouding's article of Aug. 12, entitled Some of the Best People Are Afraid of Flying, and featuring a gallery of faces including what I hope is the most poltroonish photograph of me ever taken. The writer includes me in the roster of the fearful with the sentence, William F. Buckley (who says in his typical fashion that flying is committing an egregious effxrintery upon the laws of nature and recommends a little of the grape).

title: Trial Date Is Set In $500Million Suit On Coast Oil Spill
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Sept. 29  A Federal judge set a date this week for the trial in a $500million damage suit against four oil companies resulting from the 1969 oil spill in Santa Barbara Channel. Counsel for the plaintiffsthe city and county of Santa Barbara, the city of Carpinteria and the state of California hailed the action.

title: Rain Muddles Race in National League
description: Rain postponed a doubleheader between the Mets and the Cubs at Chicago yesterday and also threatened to send the bizarre race for the National League Eastern Division championship beyond the date for the end of the regular schedule. Five teams are still in contention.

title: Alma North, $7.20, Takes Bowie Dash
description: BOWIE, Md., Sept. 29 (AP) Alma North scored a 2length victory over Twixt today in the sevenfurlong $25,000added Mary Duvall Handicap at Bowie race course.

title: Davis Sparks Bayside in 50to6 Victory
description: Bayside crushed Flushing, 506, yesterday in a Queens' Public Schools Athletic League game at Memorial Field in Flushing. Bayside led by Pierre Davis and Wayne Griffin, running backs, have rolled up 81 points to 12 for opposition in two league starts. In the opener Bayside beat John Adams, 316.

title: SHOOTING SPREE LEAVES 5 INJURED
description: Five persons, including a detective, were wounded in a shooting melee at a Bronx bar shortly after midnight yesterday.

title: Major League Averages
description: American League National League Records Include Games Played Friday Night Major League TeamAgainstTeam Records

title: Television This Week
description: Television This Week

title: Selling the President, Architecturally
description: ARCHITECTURAL footnote on current political events: the Nixon Library is not dead, only dormant. It is on the hack burner, according to Leonard K. Firestone, head of the foundation that will build it. But he gave an important tidbit of design information. It will be in early California Mission style. That does not really represent any giant leap backward for the the Administration's building record, because there has never been any giant leap forward. Although there has been a good deal of impressive talk about architecture and the design necessity in this year's Administrationbacked First Design Assembly, it obviously hasn't filtered up.

title: The sad case of Yevgeny Yevtushenko
description: As the gloom of terrorized conformism settles on the Soviet intellectual world with only a few moral jabs by Solzhenitsyn and Sakharov, fighting a desperate Thermopylae, it may be suitable to recall the more typical and less edifying career of one who was till very recently still regarded by many in the West as a sign of more promising things.

title: Black life before black consciousness
