description: There is a kind of stubborn honesty in Ed Bullins's plays that also appears in his novel. He is leaving an absolutely faithful record of a segment of American life during the period in the fifties that nostalgic magazines like to call the good old days. We know of course that they were not all that great.

title: At 51, He's London's Official Enfant Terrible
description: MANY things about Richard Hamilton, the English Pop artist currently having a retrospective at the Guggenheim Museum, may be mysterious to an American viewer. The first is the magnitude of his reputation. Though never much regarded in this country, he is one of the most respected and influential contemporary artists in England. At the age of 51, he is evidently something like London's official enfant terrible. It is hard to square this information with a body of work that, while far from uninteresting, often seems at once labored and tame and sometimes even inept.

title: Mich. State Bows, 3421, To U.C.L.A.
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Sept. 29 (AP)Kermit Johnson ran for three touchdowns, two of them in the decisive second period, as the University of California, Los AngeleS, defeated Michigan State, 3421, today.

title: MICHIGAN URGED TO PROTECT SHORE
description: LANSING, Mich., Sept. 29Nearly 1,000 miles of Michigan's Great Lakes shorelands are environmentally significant and should be protected from development, the first ilcomprehensive study of the state's shorelands recommends.

title: Tests by Skylab Spiders Hint Man's Adaptability
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Sept. 29Anita and Arabella, the two space spiders who overcame weightlessness and spun their webs aboard the orbiting Skylab, have bolstered the scientific suggestion that human beings may be far more adaptable to unusual experiences than is generally believed.

title: Tennessee Sinks Auburn On Holloway Aerials,210
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 29 (AP)Ninthranked Tennessee used a swarming defense, the passing of Condredge Holloway and the running of Haskel Stanback in beating Auburn, 210, today in a Southeastern Conference football opener for both teams.

title: Georgian Jews Find Israel Is Too Worldly
description: ASCALON, Israel  The Jews of what is now Soviet Georgia managed to hold on to their religion under Persians, Arabs, czars and Communists. Whether they can continue to do so in the first modern Jewish state is an open question.

title: Rulings on Industry Job Bias Vary Among Agencies
description: The disclosure suggests significant differences among Federal agencies on the standards used to judge the adequacy of industry efforts to assure equal employment and economic opportunity to minority and women workers.

title: POLICE WOUND MAN IN QUEENS SHOOTOUT
description: A 35  year  old Flushing, Queens, man was shot and critically wounded in a shootout with two policemen late Friday night after they had tracked him down in the belief that he was going to commit suicide.

title: British Football
description: British Football

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
description: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles

title: Field Goal Wins For Newark State
description: TEANECK, N.J., Sept. 29Norbert Layterman kicked a 41yard field goal in the second quarter today to give Newark State its third consecutive triumph of the season, a 30 victory over Fairleigh Dickinson University.

title: The Nation
description: A few days after the assassination of President Kennedy in 1963, a very junior member of the Senate, Birch Bayh of Indiana, decided to try to do something about the long unsettled problems of Presidential succession and disability. On a plane trip he turned the possibilities over in his mind.

title: Snassky and Bryne To Meet in San figan For a Chess Match
description: LONDON, Sept. 29  The quarterfinal world championRobert Byrne, the United States grandmaster, and Boris Spassky, the former world champion, will take place in San Juan, P.R. on Jan. 14.

title: Scientists Term Vitamin E an Enigma Of LittleProved Therapeutic Benefit
description: is not currently available in this country, might benefit patients with circulatory defects in the hands and feet. These patients suffer pain, numbness or blue discoloration in their extremities when exposed to cold.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Human Resources Administrator Jule M, Sugarman has challenged State Welfare Inspector General George F. Berlinger, with whom he has been fighting a running battle over welfare administration for two years, to a golf match. But Mr. Berlinger declined, an H.R.A. spokesman said.

title: ANTITHEFT RULES DEFENDED BY A.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 The Atomic Energy Commission defended this week its strengthened regulations to prevent the theft by gangsters or terrorists of material from nuclear power plants that could be fabricated into nuclear explosives.

title: What They Are Saying
description: The 50foot tomatored Phantom looked none the worse for wear after a sixday voyage from Fort Laudrdale to a quiet slip in Yacht Haven West at Stamford,. Conn.site of the secand annual North Atlantic Boat Show this weekend. The flashy custombuilt racing sailboat, and the small number of other racing sailboats at the show, stood out from the smaller pleasure craft.

title: Gardens
description: YOU see the color, the vast panorama of yellow and orange and red and brown, of Maple and birch and dogwood and oak, on the hills and flowing down the valleys. You see, and you say, I've seen autumn. I've seen the color.

title: Body of Unidentified Woman Found in Queens Cemetery
description: The body of an unidentified woman about 17 to 19 years old was found yesterday lying between two graves in Calvary Cemetery near 52d Street and Queens Boulevard, in the Woodside section of Queens.

title: PRIMARIES SLATED FOR CONNECTICUT
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 29With the worst of the internal party disputes resolved in most other places in the state, Republicans in 18 of Connecticut's 169 towns will vote Monday to pick their candidates for the local elections in November.

title: Dance
description: IT is now nearly eight years since the Royal Danish Ballet last danced in New York. It was a very exciting company at that time. But it was also a company very much on the point of change. Today the Royal Danish Ballet is in many respects unrecognizable as the same company that gave a triumphant month's season at the New York State Theater in the fall of 1965.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE COMMITTEE OF 20, finance ministers who represent the 126 member nations of the International Monetary Fund, met at the I.M.F. conference in Nairobi, Kenya, and decided not to negotiate further at this time in its effort to develop an improved world monetary system. The committee set next July 31 as a deadline for agreement on the main issues Also in Nairobi, the World Bank announced a $22billion fiveyear lending program for poor countries.

title: N. Plainfield Struggles to Tie With Franklin Township, 66
description: Somerset County's two top teams, North Plainfield and Franklin Township, met yesterday in North Plainfield and played to a 66 tie.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Attorney General Eliott L. Richardson recently advised Senator John V. Tunney that he would not reopen the consent decrees in the International Telephone and Telegraph case. Mr. Richardson concluded that based on analysis by the antitrust division of the Justice Department, I do not believe that a reopening of the judgment  would give the Government any greater relief than it obtained under the settlement.

title: Mrs. Berning's 140 Leads by 3 Strokes
description: CAMERON PARK, Calif., Sept. 29 (UPI)  Mrs. Sue Berning, the women's United States Open champion, shot fourunderpar 69 today and took a threeshot lead at 140 in the $30,000 Cameron Park golf tournament.

title: DR. FURSTCHIAVACCI
description: Dr. Sidonia T. FurstChiavacci, a dermatologist and a physician to the Austrian Consulate here, died Friday in Doctors Hospital. She was 79 years old and lived at 27 West 86th Street.

title: A Rite of Fall
description: WASHINGTON  Every year about this time, Congress finds itself in the middle of a thicket  the military's annual budget.

title: AGNEW DECLARES HE WILL NOT QUIT; ATTACKS INQUIRY
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29Vice President Agnew declared today that he would not resign if indicted and denounced the Justice Department for what he called its unprofessional and malicious and outrageous handling of the current investigation into charges of kickbacks and bribery in his home state of Maryland.

title: For Reasons of State
description: These three collections of essays illuminate some of the ways in which the academic intellectual has defined his vocation while trying to make sense of the troubled political world of recent years. Each of the authors, in his own way, has been engaged with the ruling powers and dominations: Noam Chomsky and Christopher Lasch with the powers of the American political elite and the global domination exercised by American capitalism, Edward Shils with the more perennial relations between those who profess knowledge and those who possess power.

title: Chess: Pas de Deux in El Paso Ends In Tie for U.S. Championship
description: Strategy and counterstrategy balanced out to produce a dead heat for first place in the United States Chess Championship in El Paso between John Grefe of California and Lubomir Kavalek of Washington, D.C.

title: Mrs. Smoller Has Child
description: A daughter was born Sept. 14 to Dr. and Mrs. Bruce M. Smoller of New York at the LyingIn Hospital here. The child has been named Jamie Brooke, Mrs. Smoller, known professionally as Dr. Cosette Nieporent, is a resident in radiology at the New York Hospital.

title: Miss Susan Diantha Melinette Is Married to James H. Riding
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 29Miss Susan Diantha Melinette, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Northrop Melinette of Scarsdale, was married here this afternoon to James Harry Riding, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Henry Riding of Seattle.

title: I Am the Standby. The Frustration Is Gigantic
description: AS, nightly, the curtain rises on The Sunshine Boys, its usual clatterandcreak is augmented by another, more curious sound, like a soft moan, a subtle yet positive expulsion of air, as of someone sighing. As a matter of fact, it is someone sighing. Me. I am sighing for two reasons: One, the curtain has gone up and I am not on stage and, two, the curtain has gone up and I am not on stage. The first is a sigh of relief, the second, frustration. I am the Standby.

title: and One Buyer Finds a Pleasant Life
description: The author of the following article was the news makeup editor of The New York Times and its stamp columnist until his retirement last March.

title: Peter Meades Have Child
description: ALEXANDRA, Va., Sept. 29 A daughter was born Sept. 12 to Mr. and Mrs. Peter Anthony Meade at the Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. The child has been named Jennifer Mary.

title: Feminist Coalition Planning Workshops
description: A communications network and menwomen workshops are being planned by the Long Island Feminist Coalition, which recently brought together a variety of women's groups seeking to unify and coordinate activities.

title: Service in Morris Helps The Widowed Readjust
description: MORRISTOWN.  A personal service is seeking to help the bereaved and lonely make the transition to widowhood.

title: Miss Bonnie Jean Cruikshank Is Bride of William E. Hyde
description: Miss Bonnie Jeanne Cruikshank, a personnel administrator with Philip Morris International, was married here yesterday to William Edward Hyde, a certified public accountant with Arthur Andersen & Co. The Protestant ceremony was performed at the Church Center for the United Nations by the Rev. Frederick D. Hayes.

title: Vanderbilt Is Shut Out By Alabama
description: NASHVILLE, Sept. 29 (AP) A host of Alabama running backs, complemented by Wayne Wheeler's clutch catches led unbeaten Alabama to a 440 victory over Vanderbilt tonight in a Southeastern Conference game.

title: Weakened Giants Face Browns
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 29The New York Giants will not lean until game time tomorrow (1 P.M.) whether two of their big guns, Ron Johnson and Bob Tucker, will be available for a pivotal game against the Cleveland Browns.

title: New in Theater?
description: THE WALTZ OF THE TORE

title: Soviet Woman Sets Mark
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, Sept. 29 (AP)  Nadezhda Chizhova, an Olympic champion from the Soviet Union, set a world record today in the women's shotput with a toss of 70 feet 4 inches to better the previous mark by 10 inches. The Bulgarian press agency, B.T.A., said the record was established at the Yuri Gagarin Sports Stadium at Varna.

title: Pop
description: HARD rock, contemporary England's major musical export, tends to obscure softer expressive modes, thus rendering such an excellent singer as Cleo Laine as a kind of cultural casualty.

title: From Aid to ReColonialization
description: Of two monumental problems man has faced in the last half of the 20th century, one gets all the attention and the other gets virtually none. The first is that of finding a way to avoid destroying the world in the face of twohour nucleardelivery systems that can do the job nicely. Nuclear holocaust is an immediately threatening and easily understood threat. Spokesmen for the nuclear giants report great progress toward solving this one. They tell us that the world is closer to Richard Nixon's generation of peace than it has ever been.

title: W. H. Auden Dies in Vienna
description: W. H. Auden, the foremost poet of his generation, died in a Vienna hotel Friday night at the age of 66.

title: 25 Firemen Are Injured In Fighting Brooklyn Fire
description: Twentyfive firemen received minor injuries and 45 persons wrre made homeless yesterday ac a result of a twoalarm fire that damaged six threestory frame houses in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn;

title: and the golf addict
description: They have been playing golf for 800 years and nobody has satisfactorily said why.

title: Helen Joy Jones, Becomes Bride Of H. D. Marsh
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29 Miss Helen Joy Jones and Howard Denham Marsh were married here this afternoon in Our Mother of Consolation Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Richard Nahman.

title: BAO DAI BOOKET FLOATS IN SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 29Nguyen goes, according to the 19thcentury poet Trang Trinh, and Nguyen comes back again.

title: Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRESWhen former dictator Juan Domingo Peron emerged from Argentina's presidential elections last Sunday with 62 per cent of the vote, after campaigning as an elder statesman on a platform of national reconciliation and moderate reform, the Buenos Aires stock exchange rose, the peso strengthened on the black market and hundreds of thousands demonstrated joyfully in the streets.

title: Major League Box Scores
description: Major League Box Scores

title: Retirement Villages Are On the Increase
description: They have names like Leisure Village, Holiday City, The Gardens of Pleasant Plains or Strathmore Gate, names that promise tranquility, the rural simplicity of an English country village, a safe haven. To such places flock the old and notsoold, most of them with cash on hand and years of work and childrearing behind them.

title: The New York Times Book Review
description: A FAIRY TALE OF NEW YORK, by J.P. Donleavy. (Delacorte/Seymour Lawrence, $7.95.) A modern Christian's progress through the malign Niebelungen of our urban land; a novel of explosive comic imagination.

title: Here Is America's Innocence
description: IT has been the dream of my life to form a Heritage Theater of our native dances and songs, to do for America's dances what Moiseyev has done for Russia's: that is, to revitalize our great traditions creatively and dynamically. I have no thought to reproduce obsolete relics in an archival and Smithsonian styleI leave that to the Library of Congressbut to create out of the sources. All other countries have such theaters (the Moiseyev, the Bayanihan, the Folklorico of Mexico, the Feux Follets of Canada, Inbal of Israel). We alone do not.

title: Mrs. Cecilia Robinson Remarried
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 29  Mrs. Cecilia Halpern Robinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Halpern of New York and Greenwich, was married here this afternoon to Robert Edward Morgan also of Greenwich, son of Dr. and Mrs. Oliver M. Morgan of Largo, Fla.

title: Silent Witness Faces New Call Before Panel in Agnew Inquiry
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 29The Federal grand jury investigating Vice President Agnew has recalled a witness who said he reluctantly refused to testify Thursday on the ground of possible selfincrimination.

title: Jury Convicts Contractor In Migrant Worker Case
description: MIAMI, Sept. 29 (AP)A farm labor contractor has been convicted by a jury in United States District Court here on two of 16 counts of peonage and involuntary servitude.

title: Big Chains Get a Bigger Slice of the Retail Pie
description: By ISADORE BAILMASH

title: Trouble With Too Much Money
description: WASHINGTONThe planned third phase of the Senate Watergate Committee's inquiry, involving campaign finances, has yet to begin, but a sneak preview was provided by another source last week. In response to a Federal court order, President Nixon's campaign finance aides disclosed that Mr. Nixon's supporters had raised record $60.2million for the 1972 election. The figure was at least $8million more than the previous acknowledged total of $52million.

title: DeMille Theater Robbed
description: The manager of the DeMille Theater, at 47th Street and Seventh Avenue, and a guard who was collecting the theater's receipts were robbed yesterday of $6,000 shortly after midnight by four armed men. The guard's revolver also was taken by the holdup men.

title: C.P.A.'s Will Hold October Seminars
description: NEWARK  The New Jersey Society of Certified Public Accountants will conduct five professional development seminars throughout the state next month.

title: Chile
description: SANTIAGOWe never thought the military could push things back into place so quickly, said the new general manager of a plant that had been returned to private control after the violent overthrow of President Salvador Allende's Marxist Government by a military junta three weeks ago.

title: Poet of Civilization
description: An Appraisal

title: News of the Screen
description: While austerity is the general rule in hardpressed Hollywood these days, 20th CenturyFox has broken the rule. The company is paying William Goldman $500,000 for rights to his new novel, The Princess Bride, and his screen adaptation of the book.

title: Child to Mrs. J. C. Wood
description: A daughter was born Sept. 18 to the Rev, and Mrs. Jeffrey C. Wood of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, at the New York University Medical Center. Mrs. Wood, the former Miss Margaret Lloyd, has been principal of the Lower School at Ade1phi Academy. Her husband is associate coordinator for developing resources and services of the unit on evangelism of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. The child has been named Rebecca Marie.

title: Carroll J. Cavanagh, Lawyer, Weds Miss Valerie I. Mixter
description: NOROTON, Conn., Sept. 29 Miss Valerie Ives Mixter was married here this afternoon to Carroll J. Cavanagh. The Rev. Robert N. Back and the Rev. Garvan Cavanagh, a Roman Catholic priest and uncle of the bridegroom; performed the ceremony in St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

title: PATH Is Changing Link to Airport
description: NEWARKThe projected $240million extension of the PATH transit line from Newark will not directly enter Newarl International Airport, nor will it provide baggage  checking facilities for airline passengers using the trains.

title: MEDICAL RECORDS OF HOGAN STOLEN
description: Two medical records of the illness of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of Manhattan were stolen from St. Luke's Hospital files and have not been recovered, according to the hospital and the police. Deputy Chief James Meehan of the Manhattan detective Command said no clues had been uncovered. He said de tectives would seek inforniadon from The New York Post, which on Sept. 17 published what it said was a picture of the records.

title: Louise Salembier Is Bride in Suburb
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., Sept. 29Miss Louise Ramsdell Salembier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pierre H. Salembier, was married here this afternoon to Nicholas John Fitzgerald, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. J. Fitzgerald of Katonah. The Rev. Saturnino Diaz performed the ceremony in Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church.

title: Clifton Totals 325 Yards Routs Fair Lawn, 5624
description: Clifton, unbeaten a year ago, got its season off to a belated start yesterday, but it opened with a 5624 victory over Fair Lawn that projected the Passaic County team into the thick of the battle for statewide recognition.

title: The Fondness for Naps Persists in Maoist China
description: PEKING, Sept. 29  Airline pilots curl up around the nosewheel of their aircraft and do it. Pedicart drivers clamber atop the rear decks of their threewheeled contraptions and do it. Even Foreign Ministry officials do it, though not so publicly. In fact, just about everybody in China has his noontime hsiuhsi, or rest.

title: Deaths
description: In Memoriam Huveiling Card of Thanks

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market extended its strong rally in heavy volume last week and then ran into a spate of profittaking on Friday.

title: ProductRelated Injuries
description: ProductRelated Injuries

title: SIRICA ORDERS DELAY IN TAPE ARGUMENTS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI) United States District Court Judge John J. Sirica today ordered a delay from Monday until Thursday of arguments over the Senate Watergate committee's suit to obtain White House tape recordings.

title: Belknap College to Close; Cites Financial Troubles.
description: CENTER HARBOR, N. H., Sept, 29Belknap College, financially troubled throughout its 10year history, has announced that it is closing effective Dec, 14.

title: The City's New Housing Court to Open Tomorrow
description: After six months of delay and bickering and amid continuing controversy, the city and the state embark tomorrow on a major new approach to saving troubled housing here: a special Housing Court.

title: The street freak scene
description: In his essay The New Journalism, Tom Wolfe rather chidingly asks whatever became of the big counterculture novels that the sixties should have producedand the answer, even from the stanchest defender of the novel, must be that they simply haven't been written. It's not, God knows, for a lack of tryingpublishers have done their best to dredge up an incisive chronicler of the hippie experience, and most of the results have been nothing if not trying. Only a few have achieved anything near commercial successmost notably Don Mitchell's muchhyped and dreadful Thumb Tripping. The best  Elia Katz's Armed Love,, for one, an intelligent semifictional survey of communal lifehave gone by with hardly a ripple.

title: Movie Mailbag.
description: TO THE EDITOR: RROBERT F. MOSS is hard man to please. He objects to Blume in Love for not being Jewish enough, and to The Heartbreak Kid for being too Jewish.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Book Review has been hoaxed. Brooklyn Bridge historian David McCullough has bought the bridge, via his raving review of Hugh Eames's Winner Lose All, an apologiobiography of explorer Dr. Frederick Cook (18651940), this century's clumsiest conartist (so far).

title: Mailbox: Power Cliques of Nonathletes
description: To THE EDITOR: Robert Hersh's letter September 23 with criticisms of the Amateur Athletic Act of 1973 are untenable. The act was drafted by Senators Tunney, Pearson and Cook, and also contains important elements of a bill introduced earlier this year (S.1690) by Senators Gravel, Fannin, Goldwater, Gurney, Humphrey, Randolph, Scott and Thurmond. In addition to the United States Amateur Sports Board, the act provides fora review of our Olympic participation, development of safety and health measures to protect athletes and a National Sports Development Foundation to promote widespread national athletic participation.

title: Juliette Murphy Dies at 71; Dancer, Wife of ExSenator
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Sept. 29 (UPI)Juliette Murphy, the wife of former Senator George Murphy died last night at the couple's home here. She was 71 years old.

title: Ohio State Crushes T.C.U., 373
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 29 (AP)  Cornelius Greene scored twice, once on a 72yard run, and Archie Griffin dashed 68 yards for a touchdown today, leading. Ohio State to a 373 victory over Texas Christian.

title: MORATORIUM PUT ON RELIEF CASES
description: Concerted neighborhood pressure has brought changes to the administrative practices of the Department of Social Services's Fordham center in the Bronx.

title: Six New Horses in the Ratings Race
description: 9THE MAGICIANBill Bixby as a night club prestidigitator who lends others a helping sleightofhand. With Keene Curtis (NBC).

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: EPISCOPAL WOMEN AS PRIESTS URGED
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 29In an opening address that was a farewell speech as well, the retiring Presiding Bishop of the 3.4millionmember Episcopal Church, the Right Rev. John E. Hines, urged the denomination's triennial convention today to allow the ordination of women as priests and bishops.

title: American Stock Exchange
description: American Stock Exchange

title: Nation's Oldest Seminary to Install New Head
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  The nation's oldest theological seminary will install its newest president tomorrow night. The hourlong ceremony will take place at the old First Reformed Church at the corner of Neilson and Bayard Streets.

title: DR. BENJAMIN SEGAL
description: Dr. Benjamin Segal, former chief of the obstetrics and gynecology department at Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx, died Friday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 136 East 64th Street.

title: The Region
description: Everyone seems to be running for police commissioner instead of mayor, Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal, the Liberal candidate for mayor of New York City told a Patrolman's Benevolent Association meeting two weeks ago. It was meant to be a joke but it was right on target.

title: The Hotels That Changed India Tourism
description: >NEW DELHI  The occasion could have been a wedding. The banquet tables were piled with hors d'oeuvres and imported whiskey flowed freely. Everyone smiled as the handsome family of the late Maharaja of Jodphur gathered together to yield their most precious possession to the moonfaced elderly gentleman.

title: 102 NEW JERSEY
description: MILLBURN  To parents, it may be a classy cheese shop. But to their children, rom kindergarten through high school, Cheese N Spice is the pennycandy store of lung ago  and equally as popular.

title: News of the Stage
description: Kenneth Waiss.man and Maxine Fox, the producers of Grease, which spoofed the nineteensixties' rock n roll, will present another musical parody, Over Here, dealing with the forties, when the Dodgers were still in Brooklyn, when Aration stamps were issued for gasoline and when everybody was cultivating victory gardens.

title: Cornell Runs SinkColgate By 35 to 21
description: HAMILTON, N.Y. Sept. 29 (AP)A sophomore halfback, Don Fanelli, ran for three touchdowns and Mark Allen passed for one score, leading Cornell to a 3521 victory over Colgate today.

title: Emerson Upsets Ashe
description: ALAMO, Calif., Sept. 29 (AP)Roy Emerson of Australia upset secondseeded Arthur Ashe, 57, 62, 61, to gain the final of the $50,000 Fireman's Fund international tennis tournament today before 5,600 fans.

title: 161 Prove Out Wins
description: Once more the Hobeau Farm caused anguish and defeat for the Meadow Stable. In the $108,200 Woodward Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday a relatively unproved colt named Prove Out carried the Hobeau silks to a smashing victory over the Triple Crown winner, Secretariat of the Meadow Stable.

title: Israel Opposes Austrian Decision on Transit Facilities
description: TEL AVIV, Sunday, Sept. 30 Premier Golda Meir's Cabinet, in an extraordinary session this morning, opposed the Austrian Government's decision to close transit facilities for groups of Jews traveling from the Soviet Union to Israel.

title: How to cook cow's udder
description: In the first place, who is the snail? Giinter Grass? Apparently not, though he does say, I am the civilian snail, the snail made man. But when one of his children asks, What do you mean by snail? he answers, The snail is progress. What's progress? (Part way through the diary you suspect that a chorus of pliant offspring has been laid on to feed Papa cues.) Progress means being a little quicker than the snail, says Grass. Snail also incarnates the political rise of Willy Brandt. Let us just say here that this snail is too gorged with spleen and Schopenhauer to make a good meal, and that it is probably harmless to gardens. Besides, it would always slither around poisontraps; it is morosely keen on survival.

title: Westfield Raises Streak to 44
description: Westfield and its star running back, Glen Kehler, continued their spectacular play yesterday with a 357 victory over Union in Westfield.

title: Ens. Eliza Deans Is Wed to Michael Biehl
description: LITTLE SILVER, N. J., Sept. 29Ens. Eliza Deans of the Navy Nurse Corps was married here this afternoon to Medical Corpsman/3 Michael David Biehl of the Navy. Both are stationed in Camp Lejeune, N. C., where the bridegroom is attached to the Marine Corps. The Rev. Ronald Jayues per formed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: Nyack W ins A gain, 266; Clarkstown North Victor
description: The Nyack Indians got their second Public Schools Athletic League victory yesterday by derailing previously undefeated Pearl River, 266. Carl Oliver paced the Indians with touchdown runs of 1 and 5 yards. Nyack recorded its other scores on 15yard pass play from Kenny Gray to Rob Woods and 1yard plunge by Kevin Ma honey. Pearl River's only tally was on Paul Gugandzic's 8yard run in the third period.

title: HENRY A. BARON
description: Henry A. Baron, formerly assistant manager of the National Motor Boat Show and lassistant treasurer of the National Association of Engine and Boat Manufacturers, died Thursday in a nursing home in Huntington, L.I. He was 84 years old and lived at 26 Falmouth Street, Brooklyn.

title: M'NAMARA STARTS A DISEASE BATTLE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y.In a small medical clinic in Upper Volta a year ago, the visiting president of the World Bank, Robert S. McNamara, listened to a French doctor describe the devastating effects of onchoceriasis  a parasitic disease better known as river blindness.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Austrian Government's announced decision to close group transit facilities for Soviet Jews caused a storm of controversy throughout the country. But the arrival and departure of Jews emigrating to Israel from the Soviet Union continued quietly despite the decision to yield to the Arab guerrillas who demanded the closing of the facilities in exchange for the release of their four Jewish hostages. Though the Government made no moves to carry out the decision, officials said it would close such group facilities as Schonau Castle, which has been the key transfer point for more than 60,000 Israelbound Soviet Jews over the last two years. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: BROWN REPORTED KNOWN TO GUARDS
description: Correction Commissioner Benjamin J. Malcolm charged yesterday that the two correction officers who took a Black Liberation Army member to hospital in Brooklyn  from which he escapedwere aware of their prisoner's identity, despite their denial.

title: Planners Weighing Housing Complex
description: A huge, mostly vacomt section of land that streddles the BrooklynQueens border near Jamaica Bay may be developed into a residential, industrial and recreational complex, the City Planning Commission said last week.

title: Local Orchestras Thrive on Island
description: First, they were just groups of doctors, lawyers, engineers and housewives who got together simply for the joy of making music among themselves. Then they began to expand and wanted to share their enthusiasm and talent with friends and neighbors. Finally, they wanted to be noticed by their whole communities, if not their entire areas.

title: Syosset Downs Plainedge, 2512, and Farmingdale Rolls to 21st in Row, 280
description: Kevin Mannix, Nassau County's top scorer last season, was limited to one touchdown by Plainedge yesterday, but the bruising Syosset fullback gained 190 yards in 32 carries in a 2512, North Shore Division I victory.

title: Use of PersonalCharacterization Coding on Military Discharges Is Assailed
description: On one veteran's DD 214 form, the record of his Army discharge under honorable conditions, was the code SPN followed by a number. He wondered about it after a public utility here asked to see the form and then turned him down for a job.

title: House on Wrong Lot Funny Just at First
description: MIAMI, Sept. 29 (UPI)Carlos Gonzalez and Alvin Rose knew they were going to be neighbors. But they never expected to find themselves on the same lot.

title: The Shabbiness of It All
description: Mr. Nixon cannot serve as a valid test of ultimate Presidential prerogatives. In his heart, as in his peace and disarmament deals, he has long since abandoned the source of his prerogatives, which is the principle that the nation's safety is its highest law. He survives now only as a crippled captive of his old enemies.

title: Will he, won't he reach for the Presidency?
description: WASHINGTON. At his best moments in the Senate Watergate hearings Howard H. Baker has come on like a senatorial Dick Cavett with a Tennessee hillcountry drawl, an eager student of motives and character with a keen ear for theatrical dialogue. I want to know more of the why, he pressed one witness, a junior accomplice in the coverup. In his questioning of the inimitable Anthony Ulasewicz, the New York cop turned White House spyWho thought you up? Baker asked he was the first to see the possibilities for humor.

title: Rutgers Routs Princeton; Jennings Gets 5 Scores
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 29 Rutgers once went 69 years between victories over Princeton, but the alert Scarlet Knights made up for, those past indignities today at Palmer Stadium.in two lost fumbles and an intercepted pass  and all three miscues became Rutgers touchdowns.

title: Columbia, Bucknell Play 00 Tie
description: Columbia opened its 83d football season and celebrated the 50th anniversary of the opening of Baker Field yesterday by playing Bucknell to a 00 tie before a crowd of 4,837.

title: The Pros and Cons of Planting Roses in the Fall
description: THE best planting time for bareroot roses depends on where you live. In warm climates, it may be winter, December to March, and in very cold climates it may be in late spring, May or even early June. In the vicinity of New York City and in other moderate regions, gardeners have a choice between spring, late March and April, and autumn, November.

title: 121 City Tennis Courts Slated for Resurfacing
description: Mayor Lindsay and Parks Administrator Richard M. Clurman announced yesterday that the city would spend $1.24million to resurface 121 city tennis courts, to be completed or under way by the end of the current fiscal year.

title: Cards Beat Phils; Close In on Mets
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 29Bob Gibson pitched six strong innings today and received 17hit support as the St. Louis Cardinals battered Steve Carlton and the Philadelphia Phillies, 71. It was the Card's fourth straight victory.

title: PATH
description: Robert Juppe, a Manhattan executive who lives in Ridgewood, N. J., could easily commute directly to New York via the bus that stops not far from his home. But instead he pedals a bicycle to the ErieLackawanna railroad depot in Ridgewood, rides a train to Hoboken and then switches to silver airconditioned PATH train that rolls to Manhattan through a tube in the Hudson.

title: POLLUTION PERIL WORRIES GREEKS
description: ELEFSIS, Greece, Sept. 26A small but sustained economic boom has set Greeks worrying about filthy water in picturesque bays, industrial fumes gnawing at marble columns, smog darkening the celebrated sunlight of Attica and other threats to their unique scenery.

title: John Patrick Walsh, 68, Criminal Lawyer, Is Dead
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 29 (AP)John Patrick Walsh, wellknown criminal lawyer, died here Thursday at the age of 68. He had been living in Margate.

title: HAL MATHEWSON
description: Hal Mathewson, a New York Daily News photographer, died yesterday of a heart attack in the fifth inning while covering, the baseball game between the Detroit Tigers and the New York Yankees at Yankee Sta dium. He was 59 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Edwin H. Wilson, in his emotional reaction letter (Sept. 16) to Eugene McGovern's emotional reaction to Humanist Manifesto II, correctly observes that Mr. McGovern has drawn upon the traditional arsenal of Christian apologetics and has come forth with a language which is likely to convince only the already convinced, Anselm's dictum, Credo ut intelligam (I believe in order that I may understand), fits Mr. McGovern; however, it also fits Mr. Wilson, whose dogmatic unfaith (antifaith? faith?) is in the best absolutist tradition of homo religiosus. The truth is that few (none?) of us can live well without some more or less settled convictions about the fabric of reality.

title: For the mentally ill, a court of last resort
description: At 18, Julia stabbed an unknown girl who jostled her, arm in a movie theater. Months later, she nearly killed a nurse in a mental hospital in a fit of rage over a minor incident. By the time she was referred by a psychiatrist to Dr. Vernon Mark, head of neurosurgery at Boston City Hospital, Julia was 21a comely, musically inclined woman with a record of a dozen unprovoked assaults on acquaintances and strangers.

title: French Protest on Chile
description: LE HAVRE, France, Sept. 29 (Reuters)Dockers here have refused to load spare parts of the French Mirage IV jet fighters to be delivered to Chile. The dockers said yesterday that their action was taken as a protest against the military takeover in Chile.

title: Mary C. Ambler Wed to a Lawyer
description: Miss Mary Cary Ambler, daughter of Mrs. William G. H. Finch of Richmond and Newtown, Conn., was married here this evening to John Jordan Finley, son of Mrs. William Thompson Finley of Falls Church and the late Judge Finley of the Falls Church Municipal Court. The Rey. Walton $. Pettit performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: TodayEast Metropolitan Rae ing Association and New York Region, S.C.C.A., Vanderbilt Cup races at Bridgehampton (L.I.) Race Circuit, 1:30 P.M.

title: Jim Bouton Bangs the Drum, Loudly
description: I SAW Bang the Drum Slowly twice and both times there were a lot of sniffles in the audience. This is embarrassing. Right after the movie you have to walk out into broad daylight past a huge crowd waiting to get into the next showing. Hey, look, there goes Jim Bouton, he's crying. Actually I had something in my eye both times. The waiting crowd studies your face to see whether you liked it. I liked it. (Advertisers please note: Do not use, Jim Bouton says I liked it.  Reviewers always include a couple of lines that they know will appeal to advertising blurb writers. Here's mine: Deeply moving, superbly cast, or A simply marvelous cinematic experience, or combine both. Thank you.)

title: Charter Vote Is Stirring IssueConscious Montclair
description: MONTCLAIRShould the government of this Essex County town be changed? One doesn't hear or read much of anything else in Montclair these days. Should the Commission form of government, by which Montclair has been represented for 57 years, remain, or should it be rePlaced by a Council and a manpropfessional man ager ? This issue has tended to overshadow others in this issueconscious town. It has submerged a controversy over reorganization of the schools, overshadowed a recent vote by the Town Commission to bar rent controls and led people to forget, for the moment at least, about efforts to force the Erie Lackawanna Railroad to cease whiptleblowing night freight service.

title: The Capricorn Bracelet
description: Students of early British history are lucky to have so distinguished a writer as Rosemary Sutcliff hooked on her country's first millennium. In this, her 30th book, she returns to subject matter she treated 20 years ago in her first big novel, The Eagle of the Ninth.

title: QLI Bulletin Board
description: Cold Spring HarborSittlers All in the Family show, a grouping of paintings, drawings, watercolors and sculpture, through Saturday, weekdays 11 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. and Sundays 2 P.M. to 5:30 P.M., Vera Lazuk Gallery, Main Street.

title: Brick Township Escapes First Loss in 22 Games
description: Brick Township, which narrowly averted defeat in its opener, scored with a minute and a half to play yesterday to defeat Phillipsburg, 70, and increase Its unbeaten streak to 22 games.

title: Encounters With the Unfriendly Arabs
description: AMERICAN he says, contemptuously, jerking your passport out of your hands and ordering you out of the bus. Then he shouts in Arabic at the bus driver to shut up and get going.

title: Stamps
description: THE International Criminal Police Organization, known throughout the word as Interpol, this year marks a half century of its existence, and this milestone has occasioned a spate of commemoratives from many of the more than 100 nations in the organization.

title: Oil Shortage Spurs Demand for Stoves For Burning Wood
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 29With winter on the way and oil and gas shortages threatened, the woodburning stove is making a comeback.

title: People and Business
description: She did not plan it that way, and she does not take the stump for Women's Lib. But Mrs. Annette Petrick of Somerset now heads a femaledominated business that originally occupied part of the family garage and employed only a parttime secretary; today; seven years later, it has its own modern building, employs 13 persons (all but one of them a woman) and grosses about $250,000 annually.

title: Rumania Improving Dracula's Image
description: TIRGOVISTE, RumaniaCount Dracula, the Transylvanian vampire now stalking his victims mainly on latenight television, has emerged from the tomb again, this time as an offbeat attraction for foreign tourists.

title: Why Should Anyone Go to a Museum Any More?
description: ON the face of it, it is rather puzzling that, such a disparity in standing should exist throughout the country between art museums and universities. If it is not a qualitative disparity, it is certainly one of kind, even though both institutions, in part at least, are devoted to similar ends. No more eloquent manifestation of the difference would be possible than the continuous reporting of strife between museum directors and their boards of trustees, and the relative tranquility that appears to exist, so far as academic matters are concerned, between boards and the universities in their care.

title: U.S. Urban Coalition Elects Rothschild
description: Walter N. Rothschild Jr., a former president of Abraham & Straus who left the post a few years ago to devote more time to social issues, has been, named the new chairman of the National Urban Coalition, an alliance of business, labor and minority interests formed six years ago to attack urban problems.

title: Demolition Teams Take Yanks Place at Stadium
description: Without a twinge of regret, a baseball fan named Jay Schwall will drive to Yankee Stadium tomorrow and start tearing apart the House That Ruth Built.

title: Connecticut Scores Sound's Pilot Fee
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 29Among shipping companies and port authorities in Connecticut, opposition is gathering to the pilotage fees imposed by New York and Rhode Island on ships entering and leaving Long Island Sound.

title: Games
description: I wish I had grown up on the same block with Anne Rockwell. Maybe she'd have let me play some of the games described here with her and her crowd. I would like to have tried my luck at I Love My Love, Sardines, Have You Seen My Flute? or Pussy Wants a Corner. Alas, alack, it didn't work out that way; she was in Tennessee, New Mexico and Arizona, and I was in northern New York State. While she was obviously Dropping the Handkerchief, Forfeiting, Quack! Quacking or Pushing Piggy to Market in sunny spots I was playing KeepYourBloodCirculating  So  You  Don't Freeze  to  Death, Filching (something called Shoplifting) or Swat, played blindfolded with a stout wad of rolled up newspapers in a circle of boys bent on mayhem.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Sept. 29Just when it was beginning to appear that his University of California eleven was going to provide him with little comfort this season, along came his Golden Bears this afternoon to provide Coach Mike White with at least one bragging point for 1973.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Minischools Empty P. S. 208
description: Mrs. Nettie Fishman graduated from Public School 208 in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn, her daughter graduated from P.S. 208 and her 7yearold grandaughter, Renee, attended P.S. 208 until last June. But when the school year began earlier this month, Renee was enrolled in an East Flatbush minischool, a whole new educational system set up by parents who are boycotting P.S. 208 in a dispute over the selection of a principal.

title: Goody 77 for 289 Wins Player Golf by 3
description: TURNBERRY Scotland, Sept. 29I still don't like the wind, said Charlie Coody, who today became the first United States professional to win the John Player classic, Europe's richest golf tournament. As he blew on his hands to keep warm, he added: I want to thank the gallery for standing around the greens and keeping the wind from blowing me over.

title: Trade With Russia
description: WASHINGTON  Is expansion of trade relations with Moscow necessary for SovietAmerican dtente? Does dtente require the liberalization of the Soviet system of government? Can the Soviets deal with an American President who is being undercut by the Congress?

title: Musicians'Strike atlmpasse
description: Vincent D. McDonnell, state mediator, said yesterday that negotiators for striking musicians and the New York Philharmonic were further apart than before the strike, which entered its sixth day today. Negotiations are scheduled to resume tomorrow at 11 A.M. in the State Mediation Board of?ices, No. 2 World Trade Center.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 29The suspense in baseball's only pennant race deepened today when the New York Mets and Chicago Cubs were rained out again, forcing their twin doubleheaders in the battle for first place to be postponed to tomorrow, Monday and possibly beyond. The Mets needed one victory to clinch a tie for first.

title: Academies Face Suit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI)A Federal court here has been asked to order the Navy and Air Force academies to admit women as cadets. The Center for Women's Policy Studies filed a class action suit Wednesday.

title: CountryMusic Series Set
description: HIGHLAND PARKCountry music, which has been making vast inroads in the metropolitan area, will take another giant step toward local acceptance on Tuesday. That is when a series of biweekly lectureperformances on such music will begin at the Highland Park Public Library.

title: The tennis addict
description: First, some words to the unwary about the author of the following report on the competitive aspects of tennis. My credentials in this field are not striking, consisting mainly of the facts that I play tennis and have a competitive temperament (though this last point bristles with qualifications that will emerge as we go along). In any case, the larger reaches of the subject are closed to me: I have never played in a tennis tournament or belonged to a team, and I have no ranking whatsoever, not even on the ladder at the Central Park courts. My game isn't up to any of that. What you'll be getting, then, is a report from the lower depths of the tennis scene, where the paunchy, middleaged, middlerange players contend, banging away at their opponents and themselves, looking to win back a little of what they are losing to the caricaturing hand of time and the world's slow stain.

title: How to Guard Trade Secrets
description: It may have been a minor consolation, but the International Business Machines Corporation did win a point in the decision this month in the Telex case, and that concerned trade secrets.

title: Theater of the Observed
description: The cameras went up in Times Square last week, but this time they weren't there to photograph smiling starlets stepping out of limousines for a premiere.

title: Recordings
description: DECADE ago, it seemed as if Herbert von Karajan was everywhere at once, touring all over the world while holding posts in Berlin, Vienna, Salzburg, Milan and Paris the unofficial Generalmusikdirektor of Europe as he was dubbed then. Today, however, Karajan turns up relatively infrequently on the international circuit, and he prefers to concentrate his energies on the Berlin Philharmonic and the Salzburg Festival; both organizations are carefully molded reflections of his own unique personality. And he has been making recordshundreds of them it seems, for hardly a month passes without a major Karajan release.

title: HARD EUROPE LINE LAID TO KISSINGER
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29While Secretary of State Kissinger is talking optimistically in public about the current dialogue between the United States and Western Europe, topranking European diplo mats report that he is taking a much harder line in private discussions with the foreign ministers of the ninemember European Economic Community.

title: Miss Kimberlinwed to Thomas Forbes Jr.
description: Miss Elizabeth Anne Kimberlin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew L. Kimberlin of Lake Charles, La., was married here yesterday afternoon to Thomas Rogers Enrhes Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Forbes of Hamden, Conn.

title: A WalkUp In the Village Getting Help To Go Coop
description: For years the sixstory walkup at 211 West 10th Street, two doors from Bleecker Street in Greenwich Village, seemed headed on a familiar path. As lowrental apartment dwelling in prime residential area, it would be purchased by an investor and upgraded into small luxury apartments. And the tenants in residence would have to move.

title: Crackdown Begun By Sanitation Police On 1,400 Scofflaws
description: The city's sanitation policemen will begin serving arrest warrants Tuesday on building superintendents, landlords, and merchants who are multiple violators of the Health and Administrative Code.

title: Numismatics
description: ALL the gears seem to be meshing at last for the Carson City silver dollar sales program of the General Services Administration. The third sale begins tomorrow and will end Oct. 31, and the amazing thing is that few observers thought the program would survive the problemplagued first sale. It not only survived, it has apparently thrived.

title: Late Listings for Today's TV
description: Sunday: Guests are Representative Edward I. Koch, Democrat of Manhattan, Robert and Ethel Scull, Channel 4, 9:30 A.M.

title: Record of a legislative craftsman
description: In his conservative voting record over the last seven years, Baker has shown himself to be a Tennessean and a party man, content to let his occasional bursts of initiative lie largely out of public view in committee work. (He is the ranking Republican on the Public Works Committee and its environmental subcommittee as well as a member of the Commerce Committee and the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy.)

title: Mrs. Mary Elizabeth Parr Rewed
description: MAPLEWOOD, N. J., Sept. 29  Mrs. Mary Elizabeth Wright Parr, widow of Charles McKew Parr Jr., was married this afternoon to John H. Dieters, a widower. The couple live in Maplewood, where the Rev. Albert 0. Judd performed the ceremony in St. George's Episcopal Church.

title: Headliners
description: It was the kind Of message that hasn't been heard often since the more violent times when the Weathermen, an offshoot of Students for a Democratic Society, took credit for a series of bombings across the country. The young man's voice told the telephone operator at The New York Times at 2:19 Friday morning: I am the Weatherman underground. At the I.T.T. American building a bomb is going to go off in 15 minutes. This is in retaliation of the I.T.T. crimes they committed against Chile. As police rushed the skyscraper in midtown Manhattan, a crude bomb exploded in a ninthfloor closet. It shattered some walls and windows, but the building was almost deserted and no one was injured. As usual, there was no way of knowing if the caller really spoke for the Weathermen.

title: Monetary Notebook From Nairobi
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The plastic plaques attached to the room keys of the Nairobi hotels gave this first African conference of the International Monetary Fund its watchword. The plagues warned: Achten sie auf ihr geld. Faites attention a votre argent. Fate attrenzione at vostro denaro. Guard your money.

title: Music
description: WITH the musicians strike ended, the New York City Opera will, fortunately, be able to go ahead on Saturday with its new production of A Village Romeo and Juliet by Frederick Delius. At least it will be new to this city. The New York City Opera is using the production given last year (April 26, 28 and SO, 1972) by the Opera Society of Washington. Which means that New Yorkers now will be exposed to the new ideas of stagecraft represented by the work of Staging Techniques Inc.

title: GROUP TO ASSIST MENTAL PATIENTS
description: A meeting called last week out of concern over inadequate aftercare for the mentally ill ended with the formation of group that will press for housing and rehabilitation for patients discharged from mental institutions.

title: FEAR FOR ALIENS IN CHILE VOICED
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 29We were freed thanks to pressure from the United States Embassy, friends and parents and Congressmen at home, but we only hope that international pressure will be brought to get the Chileans out, who have no embassies to stick up for them, said David Hathaway, an American sociology student here today.

title: The Nairobi Talks
description: NAIROBI  When Jomo Kenyatta, the 83yearold president of Kenya, took the rostrum last Monday at the extraordinarily beautiful new conference center here to open the annual Meeting of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund, he spoke possibly the truest words uttered at the weeklong conference.

title: Sports Today
description: POLO TRACK AND FIELD HARNESS RACING FOOTBALL GAELIC FOOTBALL, HURLING BASEBALL

title: Harriet Said
description: Wordsworth, singer of the delights and liberties of childhood, had yet a thorough enough understanding to recall it as a time of obstinate questionings Of sense and outward things, Fallings from us, vanishings. In these novels of unusual childhoods, the three young protagonists stubbornly probe the givens and the losts of their worlds and come to radically different conclusions: one murders; one slips, just in time, into the saving realm of poetry and the imagination; the third goes mad.

title: September 30, 1973/Section6 Part
description: Richard and Noriko Moore live in a loft in the midst of Manhattan's warehouse district. It's a comfortable, lightfilled place full of fresh ideas.  Peter and Juliet GlynnSmith, their two children, new baby and overgrown dog live in what once was a derelict Victorian. Its big, oldfashioned rooms are a real family home again, complete with back porch, yard and garden. Howard Feldman lives in a new old Colonial that he built in an orchard in PennSylvania when he could not find an authentic one to restore.  Bil and Ellen Ehrlich live in a stunning environment dedicated to 20th century art and design; it's in an anonymous building where you would never expect it. What all this diversity proves is something we've been saying for a long time: People make their places. Experts go on philosophizing about how we all ought to live, with what furniture and in what kinds of houses. But the public is not buying it. Their rebellious attitude reflects a change of priorities in our lives. With rents climbing, some families turn to less fashionable districts and industrial areas and are making them fashionable again. Others prefer to splurge on a yearly trip rather than amass a houseful of possessions. Some weigh the merits of a boat against the responsibilities of a weekend house. It all goes to show that what works for one family may not work for another. And it doesn't have to. That may be the biggest news of all. The public has acquired selfconfidence. A realistic look at what people are doing proves that they want to think for themselves, recognize their options and are not involved in following the leader. You won't be gauche if you hate turquoise and it happens to be next season's hot color. Nor are you hopelessly backward if your living room isn't drowned in patchwork. For those who cannot bear to live without trends, here are predictions: a lessening of the need for clutter. The hardedged modern of the Bauhaus is being increasingly soft ened by warm textures and natural woods. Status houses are on the wane and some bright architects even proclaim that dumb houses (the kind we all live in) are more newsworthy than the classy ones. THE HOME, this year, covers both clashing viewpoints and clashing budgets. Some of the projects shown cost less than $10,000 while others soar up to $125,000. Money isn't the pivotal point of good design. The sense of pride and pleasure that a home gives could never be measured in dollars.

title: TV Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: FRED NASSIF's article, Who Says Women Never Win? (Sept. 16), correctly points out that women in TV commercials, in spite of being on their hands and knees scrubbing, appear as dominating monsters, whereas their male counterparts are seen as inept, clumsy and helpless.

title: News Summary and Index SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 30, 1973
description: The Austrian Government's announced decision to close group transit facilities for Soviet Jews caused a storm of controversy throughout the country. But the arrival and departure of Jews emigrating to Israel from the Soviet Union continued quietly despite the decision to yield to the Arab guerrillas who demanded the closing of the facilities in exchange for the release of their four Jewish hostages. Though the Government made no moves to carry out the decision, officials said it would close such group facilities as Schtinau Castle, which has been the key transfer point for more than 60,000 Israelbound Soviet Jews over the last two years. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Westbury K. A. allbreed and Nassau Dog Training obedience trial, C. W. Post College, Route 25A, Brookville, L. L; 2,028 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: Repairs to Cat Traffic On West Side Highway
description: Three months of repair work on the West Side Highway will begin tomorrow.

title: Middlebury Victor On Late Field Goal
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Sept. 29Middlebury College notched its 10th straight victory by downing Wesleyan University, 1714, today on 35yard field goal with no time remaining on the clock.

title: Dictionary of American Biography
description: The Dictionary of American Biography moves along in its magisterial way. The first volume of the D.A.B.immediately people called it thatwas published in faroff 1928; the basic 20 volumes, tor 1936, followed by supplements adding biographical sketches of men and women who died in subsequent, fiveyear periods. Now, five editors, 15,443 entries, 3,527 contributing authors, and several million dollars later, Supplement Three appears in the familiar russet of the D.A.B. s distinguished design.

title: The New Movies
description: GET TO KNOW YOUR RABBIT, directed by Brian De Palma from a screenplay by Jordan Crittenden and starring Tom Smothers, Katharine Ross, Orson Welles and John Astin, got 7 favorable reviews (Vincent Canby, Times; Jerry Oster, News; Richard Natale, Women's Wear; Joseph Gelmis, Newsday; Jeffrey Lyons, WPIXTV; Paul D. Zimmerman, Newsweek; Judith Crist, New York), 4 mixed (Archer Winsten, Post; William Wolf, Cue; Hollis Alpert, Saturday Review / World; Jay Cocks, Time) and 1 negative (Rex Reed, News).

title: Why Watch Birds? Ah, Just Because They Are Exquisite
description: A GREAT blue heron flaps out of stand of reeds and awkwardly sets down a short distance away. Shorebirds skitter and stalk across the mud flats. The bushes and stunted pines teem with sparrows and warblers. Far overhead a rare peregrine falcon vanishes as swiftly as appeared.

title: Son Born to Mrs. Fish
description: A son was born here on Sept. 12 to Dr. and Mrs. Irving Fish of Tenafly, N. J., at University Hospital. Mrs. Fish is the former Miss Ilene Rubin of Pittsfield, Mass. The child has been named Peter Nathaniel.

title: Monzon Retains Middleweight Crown
description: PARIS, Sept. 29  The Fronch make fun of JeanClaude Bouttier's nerves, but no one can question the boxer's courage.

title: N.C. State Bows, 3112, To Georgia
description: ATHENS, Ga., Sept., 29 (UPI)  Gene Washington, playing the hero's role for the second successive week, raced 86 yards with a kickoff for a touchdown today leading Georgia to a 3112 victory over North Carolina State.

title: What's New in the Camera World
description: FREE course in amateur motion picture production will be conducted by the Metropolitan Motion Picture Club of New York on the first Thursday of each month, starting this Thursday. To meet at the School of Art and Design, 57th Street and Second Avenue, at 8 P.M. the course will be taught by Sid Macy and will have prominent filmmakers as guest lecturers. For information phone Sarah Neumark at (212) CH 32459.

title: Time Out to Compose Three More Operas By RAYMOND ERICSON
description: COMPOSERS have to make a living, which they can rarely do by composing. They teach, they administer, they conductuntil work and the need to create clash. This is the point recently reached by Robert Ward, who has announced his resignation as chancellor of the North Carolina School of the Arts in WinstonSalem. (He comes in for much praise in Agnes deMille's article above.)

title: Commuting on the Dawn Patrol
description: TWIN RIVERS.Five days a week, 52 weeks a year, 170,000 commuters, the majority of them from New Jersey, pass through the Port Authority Bus Terminal in New York. It all adds up to an annual total of 8,800,000plus Jerseyans who move to and from their jobs and errands iri the five boroughs of the metropolis.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Butterflies
description: At Gay Head on Martha's Vineyard Island earlier this month, dozens of tourists waxed rhapsodic over the multicolored cliffs and the ocean far beneathits voice a distant moanbut few appeared to notice the hundreds of Monarch butterflies, some going to sea in dipping, fluttering, gliding flight and still others hovering over or feeding on lush blooms of goldenrod.

title: DR. STEINGESSER
description: Dr. Edward Steingesser, a physician for half a century on the Lower East Side, died yesterday Sn the New York Infirmary. He was 75 years old and lived at200 East 15th Street.

title: Pergolesi's Innarnorato Revived by Opera Buffa
description: Si'ce Pergolesi's Lo Frate Innamorato has remained in obscurity for most of the 241 years of its existence, it is unlikely that Igor Stravinsky saw it performed before he appropriated some of the score for inclusion in his own Pulcinella. But Stravinsky had the right idea about this opera in choosing to honor the music he liked, passing over the rest, and ignoring the words altogether.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 29Carrying a large A on their defensive report card from their last test, the Jets run into a couple of other initials tomorrow.

title: The Cat Who Wished to Be a Man
description: Once an author sets his own high standard it is difficult not to compare his succeeding work with it. And compared to the high fantasy of The High King or the picaresque romance of The Marvelous Misadventures of Sebastian, Lloyd Alexander's latest book seems like a packaged deal. It is a mock medieval adventure complete with a crotchety wizard, a naive and goodhearted hero, a spirited heroine, a trusty, phrasemaking friend, and a pair of unscrupulous villains. They are variations of characters the author has dealt with so often that he probably could have written the book in his sleep. Even in spite of all the lastminute, lastsentenceinthechapter surprises, it is filled with the kind of predictability that can result when a writer is too much in control of the developing action.

title: Maryland Conquers Villanova
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Sept. 29 (UPI)  Steve MikeMayer of Maryland kicked three field goals in the first three quarters, including a 54yarder for an Atlantic Coast Conference record, and the Terrapin offense exploded for 22 fourthperiod points today to trounce Villanova, 31 to 3.

Skoggard of Darien, Conn. The Rev. George B. Holmes performed the Episcopal ceremony in St. Mary's Chapel.

description: Controller Abraham D. Beame yesterday urged the adoption of a sevenpoint program aimed at strict supervision of hotels that drug addicts and prostitutes frequent. He also proposed measures to provide lowcost housing for welfare recipients who now occupy these hotels.

description: NEW HOPE, Pa., Sept. 29 (AP)Harry Rosin, a sculptor, died yesterday at his Bucks County home. He was 75 years old.

description: CHICAGOA throng of present and former New York area residents streamed to Wrigley yield here this weekend to loot for the Mets in their fight to finish on top in the ??? League's chaotic Eastern Division.

description: NEW YORK (4)Away Chicago, Sept. 30 (2), Oct. 1 (2),

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The graft and inefficiency of New York City housing agencies as implied in the article Harlem Project Leaves Bitterness [Aug. 19] are deplorable.

title: Soyuz 12 in Space
description: The Soviet Union's first manned space flight in more than two years has been successfully completed. There is no comparison, of course, between the 591/2 day trip of the three American Skylab 2 astronauts, and the two day voyage of Soyuz 12 with its two man crew; the near coincidence in timing was purely accidental. The purpose of the Soyuz 12 flight was not primarily set new records. Its main goal was to test the latest improved version of the Soyuz spacecraft. The improvements were required by the deficiencies of the earlier Soyuz vehicle, deficiencies that caused the tragedy June 1971 when the three Soyuz 11 astronauts died during reentry.

title: 5Million Given for Nixon in 2 Days Predating Law
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29New evidence that President Nixon's 1972 fund raisers worked to collect and spend millions of campaign dollars secretly before a new Federal disclosure law took effect emerged today in a Republican, finance document, forced into the open by a lawsuit.

title: R. C. Hodgkins to Marry Pamela Tosi
description: COHASSET, Mass., Sept. 29Miss Pamela Maria Tosi, curatorial assistant in the department of European decorative arts and sculpture at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, and Robert Clifton Hodgkins, a graduate student at the Boston Architectural Center, plan to be married.

title: The working class at play and work
description: A couple of years ago I did line work in a Bucks County, Pennsylvania, carton factory, a business with lots of labor troubles. Half of the workersusually those in their forties and fiftieswere reliable to what I can only describe as a fault. The rest had other faults. Many wore the colors of the Breed, a local bike club. They drank on the job, dropped uppers and downers, gangbanged in the parking lot, and generally did what they felt like doing. Every other month there would be mass walkouts, for reasons no trade union could arbitrateit was too sunny outside to stay shut up in the plant, it was raining and everyone was depressedand whole new crews would have to be hired on. Later, though, some of the old gang would trickle back. They came without their Breed jackets, carrying brown lunch bags, often with new wedding bands; it was understood that they were now prepared to act as responsible citizens.

title: St. John's Is Given Flavor Of China
description: A palatial structure straight out of the Forbidden City in Peking seems unlikely among the functional red brick buildings and gray masonry that dominates much of Queens. But that is exactly what is standing on a hill overlooking the camqpus of St. John's University.

title: New Jersey
description: Calendar of Events

title: Hospital Cuts Back Expansion
description: Faced with difficulties in procuring state funds and opposition from some segments of the community, Long Island College Hospital has sharply cut back plans for a $100million expansion of its facilities.

title: Drug Laws, Guns and Violence
description: In Prince Georges County, Md., last week, a 24yearold man who had been arrested in possession of 300 pounds of marijuana, valued by the police at $100,000, was sentenced to three years probation. In New York State, the same man would have received many years in prison for the same offense, due to harsh new laws setting mandatory minimum prison terms for most drug offenses, and life imprisonment for second drug offenses.

title: Miami Tops Fla. State's Team, 1410
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sept. 29 (AP)Woody Thompson led the University of Miami to an uphill 1410 football victory over Florida State today.

title: Aaron Signs A Lucrative Talent Pact
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 29Henry Aaron will earn between $1.5million and $2million during the next two years in nonbaseball income, it was predicted today by a William Morris Agency executive.

title: You had to be there, and he was
description: On May 28, 1951, three actors named Spike Milligan, Peter Sellers and Harry Secombe, employing variety of sometimes maniacal voices, launched The Goon Show in the hitherto staid precincts of B.B.C. radio. For Americans who never heard it (it has been broadcast on WBAI in New York) The Goon Show is difficult to describe. Call it pure radio and pure comedy with a good dollop of the Marx brothers veering off into the empyrean of pure surrealism. The program did have scripts, of course, written mostly by Spike Milligan, and there was a plot of sorts which was somewhere between a Chinese opera and World War II in comprehensibility. The stories bore such pregnant titles as The Dreaded Batter Pudding Hurler (of BexhillonSea), The Phantom HeadShaver (of Brighton) and Foiled by President Fred. Milligan, Sellers and Secombe impersonated a variety of characters including Ned Seagoon, Maj. Denis Bloodnok, the nefarious Moriarty, GryptypeThynne and Blue Bottle. Goonery was not so much a show, more a way of life, and if you have to ask what it was, we'll be here all day explaining the joke. The Goon Show expired, to eternal regrets in Britain; Jan. 28 1960.

title: NADER UNIT ASSAILS HEARINGAID SECTOR
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 29 (AP) A Ralph Nader study group released a report today that said the hearingaid industry, health professionals and regulatory agencies had failed to provide hardofhearing people with the help they need.

title: Is Television a Man's World? Yes, Ma'am
description: HOW can you write for children when you don't have any? A simple question, asked of me last week by a simple man as I was doing what I do to pay the rentworking as associate producer of a latenight ABC program about television, TV Times. I can't earn a living in New York doing what I'd rather dowrite for televisionand I'm not yet ready to give in and make the move West where all the work is  so, weekends I write and Monday through Friday it's TV Times.

description: Picture Credits

title: Surgery Patients Can Donate Own Blood
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L. I.If one plans in advance, the blood he receives in transfusion during surgery could very well be his own.

title: London Closing Tower
description: LONDON, Sept. 29 (Reuters)  Bloody Tower, one of the bestknown parts of the historic Tower of London, is to be closed to tourists next week for repairs expected to take two years.

title: Adams's 64 For 200 Leads by 2
description: BETTENDORF, Iowa, Sept. 29 (AP)Sam Adams carded his second straight 64 to forge a twostroke lead today in the $100,000 Quad Cities open golf Tournament with 54hole total of 200.

title: Yanks Beat Tigers, 30, On 5Hitter
description: Mike Hegan backed George Medich's fivehitter with two runsbattedin on a homer and a forceout, leading the New York Yankees to a 30 victory over the Detroit Tigers yesterday.

title: PET SHOPS IN CITY ASSAILED ON PUPS
description: Dog breeding concerns in the Middle West, more commonly referred to as puppy mills, are supplying pet shops here with animals that have calcium deficiencies, are loaded with worms and are often suffering from malnutrition, according to speakers at the First Humane Congress.

title: Variations on the apple By Jean Hewitt
description: Mom's apple pie may be the national dessert, but this meringuetopped apple tart may replace the twocrust version in the family's affections. Another delicious way to make the most of this season's apple crop a spicy apple cake studded with walnuts and raisins. Red Delicious and McIntosh apples, both of them plentiful, are used in the recipes below.

title: The Wrong Prayer
description: In 1971, the House rejected a proposed constitutional amendment to permit voluntary nondenominational prayer in the public schools by the narrow margin of votes. Now, spokesmen for a variety of religious and patriotic groups have renewed their efforts to push such an amendment through Congress. The Rev. Robert Howes, a Roman Catholic priest and national coordinator of the Citizens for Public Prayer, in testimony before the Senate Constitutional Amendments subcommittee, charged that the prayer ban constitutes a denial religious freedom in the public classroom.

title: Julia A. Wren Bride of Cornelius Reid 3d
description: HAWLEY, Pa., Sept. 29Miss Julia Ann Wren, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Robert Wren of Gastonia, N. C., was married here this afternoon to Cornelius J. Reid 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Reid Jr. of Mill Neck, L. I. The Rev. Emory Killburn performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Lutheran Church.

title: The Intellectual as Faust or Quixote
description: In some parts of the world, the relationship between politics and intellectuals is taken more seriously than most intellectuals would prefer; it can be terminal case.

title: Delaware Defeats Lehigh, 21 to 9
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Sept.29 Delaware extended the nation's longest football winning streak to 18 games to day with a 21.9 victory over Lehigh.

title: ST. ALBANS IS URGED FOR VETERANS USE
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday urged the Veterans Administration to acquire the St. Albans Naval Hospital in Queens for medical use by veterans. The Federal Government has proposed that the 607bed facility on Linden Boulevard be used as an animal quarantine station when it is phased out as a hospital next year.

title: Law Expert Advocates Divorce On Demand
description: TRENTONA prominent lawyer who helped draft New Jersey's current liberalized divorce law contends the measure didn't go nearly far enough.

title: Arthur Daley
description: It doesn't seem too many years ago that gag writers could provide surefire laughs whenever they ridiculed the New York Mets. One unfailing producer of yaks was the line: The Mets have as much chance of winning a pennant as man has of walking on the moon. Both then seemed manifest impossibilities. But in the historic year of 1969 man walked on the moon. And the Mets won a pennant. And the World Series. My Mets, which is slightly amazin', was a favorite expression of their inventor, Casey Stengel. For most of their existence they were amazingly bad. In succession they became amazingly good, amazingly soso andwith unexpected suddenness late this seasonamazingly good again.

title: Colorado Triumphs Over Baylor
description: BOULDER, Colo., Sept. 29 (AP)Clyde Crutchmer and David Williams, sophomore quarterbacks, each threw two touchdown passes today and Colorado routed Baylor, 5228. Bo Matthews added 140 yards rushing to the Buffaloes offense.

title: Brown Ties State Rival On Late Bid
description: PROVIDENCE, Sept. 29 (AP)  Pete Beatrice completed an 80yard pass play to Jeff Smith with four seconds left today to give Brown a 2020 tie wtih Rhode Island.

title: Memory Lane: Where Nobody Ever Moves Away
description: The writer of this article of reminiscences retires tomorrow after 15 years as sports editor of The New York Times and 45 years as a newspaperman specializing in sports. He has been appointed Public Information Director of the New York State Racing and Wagering Board.

M., and the late Mr. Woodard.

description: YONKERS, Sept. 29Senior Judge John E. Tobin of the City Court of Yonkers died today of a heart attack in Yonkers Professional Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 343 Hathorne Avenue.

description: MOSCOW, Sept. 29  Two Soviet astronauts completed today a twoday test flight of a modified Soyuz craft in the first successful manned Russian space mission in more than two years.

description: SEATTLE, Sept. 29 (AP)A defensive back, Steve Lipe, blocked a Syracuse punt and carried the ball in for a touchdown, and James Anderson ran 63 yards on a broken play as the Washington Huskies beat the Orangemen, 217, today.

title: Publication of a Secret Goebbels Diaty Is Considered.
description: Joseph Goebbels, Hitler's chief propagandist, privately abhorred Mozart, considered Herman Goring a vulgar buffoon and was relieved to learn that the Nazis had finally sunk the British aircraft carrier Ark, Royalafter he had already re ported it sunk three times.

title: Chronicles of Wasted Time
description: There is a strong theatrical streak in Malcolm Muggeridge, and I have no doubt that, had he chosen, he could have become a notable char acteractor. As a young man he wrote several plays, one of which was successfully produced, and more recently he figured in a striking TV production of Alice in Wonderland. No one who has heard him lecture or seen one of his numberless TV appearances  and who has not? will deny him the accolade of a great performer.
