title: An American Verdict
description: Here comes Michael J. Arlen. He went to Harvard, and he's a staff writer for The New Yorker. His novelist father knew Hemingway and F. Scott Fitzgerald. Arlen has already written two successful books: Living Room War and Exiles, a memoir of his father and mother. So now he conies to live in Chicago, and he's going to write a book and tell the rest of us what Chicago and the murder of Fred Hampton, the Black Panther, are all about.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29A rift that interrupted five years of dialogue among the executive heads of the United States Catholic Conference, the National Council of Churches and the Synagogue Council of America has been ended.

It was the second straight ManhattanBronx Public Schools Athletic League victory for the Governors and the second loss for Washington.

title: Television
description: THERE is nothing, but nothing, quite so scandalous as the state of children's programing on American commercial television. Public television, with Sesame Street, Electric Company, Mister Rogers Neighborhood and Zoom, has proved solidly that the category need not automatically exclude intelligence and quality.

title: Nets Down Bullets As Erving Scores 42
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 29Julius Erving scored 42 points as the New York Nets rallied from a 17point deficit in the third period to overtake the Capital Bullets, 127121, tonight in an exhibition game at the Westchester County Center.

title: Boston 8 years ago integrated schools intelligently
description: BOSTON. Three floors above Beacon Street a creaky spittoonage elevator opens through a grillwork cage into the Boston School Committee chamber, where a big electric fan labors in vain to churn the soggy August air. Several dozen spectators in shirtsleeves fidget in rows of movie seats planted in green linoleum. Before them, gathered around a dais, are the school committeemen. Elected independently of the rest of city government, they are the autocrats who preside over 97,000 students, 5,000 teachers, a patronageladen $95million budget and 202 schools that make up the oldest and, in some ways, the most troubled school system in the land.

title: JOHN H. CLAIBORNE JR.
description: CEDARHURST, L. I., Sept. 29 John H. Claiborne Jr., former fiscal agent of the Federal National Mortgage Association, died yesterday of cancer at his home, 86 Auerbach Lane. He was 71 years old.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Last winter, Larry Meyer, an independent home heating oil dealer in the Kansas City area, was forced to cut back deliveries to his commercial customers by more than 30 per cent. Asked the other day about the prospects for this year, he said: It will probably be worse.

description: Now that the stock.market showing signs of rigor, top money managers are in a position not linlike that of the shyest guy on campus who finds himself alone with the campus queen. He dares not dream of the pleasures that may be in store.

description: Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty, the 81yearold exiled Primate of Hungary, made an unscheduled, informal visit yesterday morning to St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Home for the Blind Is Expanding Its Horizons
description: When the Industrial Home for the Blind opened its doors for the first time 80 years ago in Brooklyn, it was intended to provide employment, a home and companionship for sightless men. Today, however, it has grown into an organization helping 9,000 men, women and children through 28 varied services and last week it was awarded a Federal grant of $5million to establish a new center in Sands Point.

title: U.S.C. Skein Cut By Okla., 77

title: E. Burd Grubb, 80, Headed Curb Exchange in 19381
description: HADUZME, Conn., Sept. 29 E. Burd Grubb, president of the New York Curb Exchange (now the American Stock Exchange) in 1938 and a former govergovernor of the New York Exchange, died yesterday at his home here.

title: Librarians Reflect on the Past
description: RIDGEWOODThe public libraries in Ridgewood and Maplewood, similar communities 25 miles apart, have had remarkably parallel histories in the halfcentury of their existence. Now they face another common problem: the pending retirement of their head librarians.

title: Braves Subdue Knicks, 118103
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 29 (AP)Bob McAdoo scored 31 points and snagged 11 rebounds to lead the Buffalo Braves to a 118103 exhibition victory over the New York Knicks tonight.

title: What sings doesn't always read
description: At the nowlegendary concert for Bangladesh two years ago, Bob Dylan made his last notable appearance. The Phantom of the Opry hadn't been seen in quite awhile. Now, suddenly, he materialized on the stage of Madison Square Garden. A small, wry figure, clad in Levi jacket and baggy brown pants and wearing an orthopedic harmonica holder around his neck, he stood angled into the bend of 20,000 people, looking up at those Ice Follies spotlights as if they were Mazdas in some country juke joint. Raising and lowering his hardedged, nasal voice with the weary sincerity of Woodie Guthrie come back among the living, he electrified his audience, then edified them with the steady, handonthetiller, eyeonthestar assurance of an authentic spiritual captain. When be stepped back into the shadows, every youth present felt confirmed in the faith, eager once again to get out on that dusty road and follow that shy, small figure who had proven so durable, so shrewd, so determined to survibe.

title: Williams Defeats Trinity, 15 to 10
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Sept. 29 (AP)Bill McMillan scored two touchdowns to lead Williams to a 1510 victory over Trinity today.

title: The Nation
description: HOUSTON  When Halley's Comet blazed through the heavens in 1910, was viewed with wonder and a certain dread. Was it, as many believed, a fiery harbinger of death and calamity? Would its gaseous tail poison the world? The great comet came and went, of course, with no apparent responsibility for all that has befallen mankind in the last 63 years, but a worthy successor is now approaching.

title: Trouble With the Witnesses
description: WASHINGTONThe Senate. Watergate inquiry which in its first phase piled startling revelation on revelation, opened its second phase last week with testimony from a onetime master spy for the Central Intelligence Agency and a senior speech writer for President Nixon. It seemed to produce little more than a fizz and a pratfall.

title: Jefferson Victor, 520; James Scores 3 Times
description: Jefferson continued to unleash its devastating running attack yesterday on Brooklyn Public Schools Athletic League Division II opponents by overwhelming Canarsie, 52.0, on the winner's field. It was the Jeff's second straight victory. They have now scored 86 points in two games and held both opponents scoreless.

title: Arabs Hail Transit Curb As Victory for Guerrillas

title: Modernization to Reward Gladstone Line's Loyal Riders
description: GLADSTONETo the more than 5,000 commuters who ride the Gladstone branch of the Erie Lackawanna Railroad, it may come as no surprise that the line is well over 100 years old. The rickety roadbed feels it. So do the hard canecovered seats.

title: Choate Pins 146 Setback On Exeter
description: WALLINGFORD, Conn., Sept, 29Tom Lauder, a 200pound tailback, scored on a 16yard touchdown and booted 2 extra points today as Choate defeated Exeter, 146. Lauder gained 100 yards in 16 carries.

title: Connecticut Stuns Yale, 2713
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 29The Connecticut team was ready and Yale's was not. The Huskies ripped the. Elis apart in the Yale Bowl today before a disappointing crowd of 16,714, winning the 25th game in this series, 2713.

title: Gasoline: One Dealer's Plight
description: LITTLE FALLSLast May, Fred Browning, who operates a gasoline station here under lease from the Mobil Oil Corporation, was selling five times as much fuel as he had been a year earlier. And Mobil, which at the time was declaring, in newspaper advertisements, that there was a shortage, of gasoline, was supplying Mr. Browning with as much fuel as he could sell.

title: October
description: It comes like spring running a high fever, like spring returning with an overflowing cargo of color. Spring went north sixteen miles a day, and now autumn comes south at about the same pace, half as fast as a leisurely man might walk.

title: A Game Plan for Women
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  Female faculty members and women students at Rutgers may be fighting a determined battle to integrate all phases of sports at the state university, but one allwomen's groupthe Football Fanees seem to be satisfied with things as they are.

title: An Entirely New Vision
description: THE functions of art vary from epoch to epoch, but within its culturebound objectives the esthetic impulse seems at all times to oscillate between two ambitions: on the one hand, the representation and celebration of the ideal, and, on the other, an insistent depiction of the actual. Those shifts between realism and abstraction that we are so conscious of in the history of modern art are, in fact, only the latest variations of a basic disposition. Techniques, together with the iconographies they serve, change from civilization to civilization, and from period to period within particular civilizations. But the creative impulse itself seems pretty constant in its tendency to alternate between these polarities of expression.

Elliot, the only one returning from last year's Irish team, was a Golden Glover himself this year, winning the middleweight championship. He is ex pected to remain in New York and turn professional.

title: Future of Fire Island Awash in Uncertainty

As summer residents boarded up their houses along the slim barrier beach that makes up Fire Island this week to protect against the uncertain hazard of winter winds and waves in the coming months, they prepared as well for another year of uncertainty about the longrange future of their vacation haven.

title: Future Social Events
description: Sills in Tudor Windows Oct. 3  Were Beverly Sills one of the three Tudor queens she portrays in Dohizetti's opera trilogy, British history might have to be rewritten. Donizetti cast them all as coloraturas, and Miss Sills brings to the royal protagonists, Anne Boleyn, Elizabeth and Mary, Queen of Scots, a resemblance otherwise oddisclosed. Anna Bolena at the State Theater, the last premiere of the three by the New York City Opera Company, is sponsored by the City Opera Guild and aids the Opera Production Fund. Patrons, 2,711 of them, who will pay $2 to $150 a ticket, will also celebrate the occasion at a champagne reception In the promenade and the second, third and fourth ring levels. The honorary chairmen of the evening are Mr. and Mrs. Ralph J. Corbett of Cincinnati. The party's cochairmen are Mrs. E. Allan Flog and Mrs. Stephenson Oresman.

title: Excerpts From Agnew Talk to Republican Women
description: LOS ANGELES, Calif., Sept. 29 (UPI)Following are excerpts from the text of a speech given by Vice President Agnew to the National Federation of Republican Women today:

title: 85% of Interstate Roads in State. Complete at a Cost of $2.5Billion
description: ALBANY, Sept. 29About 85 per cent of the roads in the interstate highway system in New York State have been completed at a cost of $2.5billion, according to reports this week from the State Department of Transportation. But it will cost about the same, $2.4billion, to build the remaining 15 per cent.

title: The Joker in Campaign Funding
description: WASHINGTONAgainst the backdrop of a major study showing that incumbents raised more than twice as much money as their challengers in last year's Congressional elections, incumbents in the House will start considering this week just how far, and how fast, the campaign spending laws should be reformed.

title: Firstfruits
description: How to judge the crop of Firstfruits? This anthology is not only a culling of modern Israeli fiction, but something more, and it is this additional ingredient which makes consideration of this volume important.

title: WOMEN COLLECT IN SEX BIAS CASE
description: They are also to get special training and, perhaps, transfers to put them in more comparable position with male contemporaries for further promotions.

title: New & Novel
description: The results of building not only big but monstrous are whipped into a cautionary thriller that could give pause to anyone who has ever ridden in a highspeed elevator. Skyscrapers are built to withstand lightning, earthquakes, even exotic disasters unforeseen like the collision of the Empire State building with a fourengine Army bomber. But some of the newer monoliths seem to be outreaching safety techniques.

title: Montclair Stops Irvington by 290
description: Earl Vaughan came up with his second twotouchdown performance of the season yesterday to lead highly regarded Montclair to a 290 victory over Inrington in Montclair.

title: Sweaters that double as jackets
description: Thick. Long. Textured like handknits made on giant needles. That is the year's big sweater message. And the sweaters are really big. These bulkies double as jackets (some are almost coat length) and are right with pants and this season's kneelength skirts. They're warm. They're right for the active life. And they're in the stores.

title: MONTREAL RUN TOPS AMTRAK ESTIMATES
description: Amtrak's Washington  New YorkMontreal train service was one year old yesterday and the two trainsone in each directionhave averaged 1,000 passengers a day.

title: the travolar WOrld
description: IN Europe, Africa, Asia and South America, waiters and hotel cashiers function with precision and nonchalance when American tourists offer United States currency or traveler's checks, or other nonnative travelers lay their own money on the dish with l'addition, if conto or In cuenta. But in all 50 of the United States, a foreign traveler has a hard time finding hotel or restaurant that will take his legal foreign currency in payment.

title: Photography
description: AUGUST SANDER (18761964) and Alfred Eisenstaedt (born 1898) are so different from one another that it is almost immoral to review their new books in the same column. Eisenstaedt was a Life photographer from the magazine's birth in 1936 till its death in 1972, and his entire career has been in photojournalism. Sander, nearly a generation older, was an oldfashioned portrait and pictorial photographer who, like Atget and Steiglitz, undertook a vast project on his own.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: So Short A Time
description: Among the daydreams that nourish the heart and soul of radical youth, no illusion dies harder than the glorious image of walking arm in arm with one's comradelover into the revolutionary dawn. With a clear eye, Barbara Gelb has given us Camelot painted red, the reallife love story of journalists John Reed and Louise Bryant, whose brief and shining moment flickered across the political horizon from Greenwich Village to Moscow.

title: William Stuhr, Lawyer, Is Dead; Leader in New Jersey Industry
description: William S. Stuhr, a prominent lawyer and industrialist in New Jersey, died on Monday evening in Christ Hospital, Jersey City. He apparently suffered a heart attack on his way to meeting of the Weehawken Parking Authority, of which he was chairman.

title: From the Heights to A Precipice
description: WASHINGTONSome of the nominee's advisers wanted John V. Lindsay; others suggested Ronald Reagan or Robert H. Finch or John A. Volpe. But the choice was up to the new Presidential nominee, and on that August morning in 1968, Richard M. Nixon chose Spiro T. Agnew as his running mate. Chose him because he came from a Border state, because he was an ethnic American, because he was a moderate who had also taken a hard line on law and order (a few months earlier, he had inveighed against caterwauling riotinciting, burnAmericadown leaders) but mostly because he wouldn't hurt the ticket.

title: Council Lists Sessions That Are Open to Public
description: Following are meetings of City Council committees at City Hall that are open to the public this week:

title: COUNTY'S TOP RACE GOES UNNOTICED
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 29Westchester will elect a new County Executive this year, no matter who wins the threesided race for the county's most powerful post. After 16 years, the Republican incumbent, Edwin G. Michaelian, is retiring.

title: W. W. Campbell Jr. Weds Miss Barra
description: Miss Mariolina Barra, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Armando Barra of New. York, was married here yesterday afternoon to Woodrow W. Campbell Jr., son of Mr. Campbell and Mrs. Ronald. C. Whittaker of Salt Lake City. The ceremony was performed in St. Thomas More's Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. John Calhoun.

title: A Triumph of Terror Over Compassion
description: VIENNAFor the four hostages three emigrating Soviet Jews and an Austrian customs officerit was 16 hours of terror. For the two Arab guerrillas, it was bloodless triumph for their movement. For the Austrian Government, it was an Ignoble capitulation taken, in the words of Chancellor Bruno Kreisky, with heavy heart. And for the Soviet Jews who have used Austria as a way station to freedom, it was a tragedy.

title: Hunt on the C. L A.
description: E. Howard Hunt Jr., of recent Watergate notoriety, has written a fascinating, highly personal and, at times, rather eloquent defense of himself and of the Central Intelligence Agency during the resounding bungle of the Bay of Pigs in April, 1961. It goes without saying that Hunt continues to justify the attempted overthrow of Fidel Castro's Government by the Kennedy Administration with an invading Cuban refugee brigade. Hunt's contempt is reserved, instead, for those who have always cringed from American exercise of power in our national selfinterest. In the wake of the far more monumental American fiasco in Vietnam, Hunt's basic assumptions will no longer win wide support.
